title: Union That Endorsed Edwards Will Back Obama
description: The Transport Workers Union, which represents 140,000 active workers, is expected to announce Friday that it will become the first union that had backed John Edwards to switch its endorsement to Barack Obama, one union adviser said Thursday night. The union, which endorsed Mr. Edwards, last September represents transit workers in New York City, flight attendants at Southwest Airlines and ground crew for American Airlines.

title: Bushs Empty Words on Two Troubled Nations
description: Words are cheap. And never cheaper than when humanitarian tragedies are invoked in speeches for dramatic effect or out of a perfunctory sense of obligation with no effective followup.

title: Sergey Brins iPhone Adventure in Davos
description: For a company that is busy building its own cellphone operating system, Google shared a lot of love for the iPhone on its earnings-related conference call today. The most heartwarming story came from Sergey Brin, the companys co-president, who said that he uses an iPhone himself. He described the value of the My Location feature of Google Maps on the iPhone, which can figure out (more or less) where you are even though the iPhone cant receive G.P.S. navigational signals.

title: Pre-Debate Show in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Its almost a wrap.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Over Her Dead Body'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Over Her Dead Body," directed by Jeff Lowell.

title: Harrison Guarantees Better Defense Against Giants
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The Giants scored the most points against New England this season in a 38-35 loss, but Patriots safety Rodney Harrison isnt worried about whether his teams defensive mistakes in that game have been corrected.

title: Hulk Hogan Has Obamas Back
description: Should Barack Obama make it to the general election, hes got his own pseudo-superhero in his corner: Hollywood Hulk Hogan.

title: Live Blogging the L.A. Debate
description: 10:30 p.m. | Wrapup: Everyone is all smiles, especially Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton, and its clear why. This, the 17th debate for the Democrats, was by far the most substantive and engrossing and cordial of this long season.

title: Another Cup
description: That just about says it all, doesnt it?

title: Conversation With Los Angeles Mayor
description: The mayor and campaign co-chairman for Hillary Clinton talked to John Harwood about the nomination race and the California economy.

title: Burress Held Out of Practice for Second Straight Day
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Giants wide receiver Plaxico Burress missed his second consecutive practice Thursday, this time because of swelling and soreness in his left knee, according to the designated pool reporter at the session.

title: Seeking Independence
description: Nicaragua and Colombia both claim San Andrs in a bitter territorial dispute. Now, a nonviolent separatist movement is growing increasingly vocal.

title: CNN Puts Ohio Debates On Schedule
description: LOS ANGELES  See you next time Senator, a CNN producer remarked to Senator Barack Obama as he walked off the Kodak Theatre stage.

title: Chinas Inflation Hits American Price Tags
description: SHANGHAI  Chinas latest export is inflation. After falling for years, prices of Chinese goods sold in the United States have risen for the last eight months.

title: Carrying a Weight, but Standing Firm
description: When Brian Cashman tells the story of how he became the Yankees general manager, he makes his voice squeaky, like a teenagers, as he tries to sound confident before the principal owner George Steinbrenner.

title: Monumental Gesture at Renovated Museum
description: A dramatic photograph on the cover of the Oct. 13, 1967, issue of Time magazine shows the sculptor Tony Smith looking purposely diminutive as he is posed gazing up at his most monumental sculpture, Smoke, that enveloped the atrium of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. The sculpture he created that year is 22 feet high, 45 feet long and 33 feet wide.

title: China Accuses Online Activist of Subversion
description: BEIJING  A prominent Chinese human rights advocate who has been in custody since late December was issued a formal arrest warrant this week on charges of subversion despite calls from prominent Chinese intellectuals and lawyers for his release.

title: When the Conceptual Was Political
description: In December 1983 the Argentine Conceptual artist Marta Minujin and a group of helpers spent 17 days building a full-scale model of the Parthenon in a public park in Buenos Aires. Except for a metal scaffolding, it was made almost entirely of books wrapped in plastic. All the books had been banned by one of the most oppressive juntas in the countrys history, which was just being dismantled after Argentinas first democratic election in a decade. The Parthenon of Books/Homage to Democracy, as Ms. Minujins work was titled, stood for about three weeks. Then the public was allowed to disassemble the piece and keep the books.

title: Yankees Add Ensberg to the Mix at First Base
description: Morgan Ensberg has played only one game at first base in seven major league seasons, so he does not know how hard it will be to learn that position for the Yankees this spring. But he has a theory.

title: Small Law Firms Big Role in Bundling Mortgages
description: In recent years, as subprime lending proliferated, a small law firm played a big role on Wall Street.

title: More Than Workout Space
description: GETTING away to a second home usually means leaving routine behind, but when that routine is a workout regimen, many second-home owners like to take it with them.

title: Artistic Muscle, Flexed for Medicis
description: Michelangelo was a terrible kvetch. His back forever ached; popes were slow with the paychecks; the local food was always an insult, a disgrace. No one worked half as hard as he did, and slacker artists made him nuts. Draw, Antonio; draw, Antonio; draw and dont waste time, he scrawled on a sketch he gave to a lackadaisical young pupil and studio assistant, Antonio Mini, in 1524.

title: Troubled Bond Insurer Puts on Its Defense
description: On Thursday, MBIA fought back. Under attack from critics who describe the company as effectively insolvent, MBIA, a big and troubled bond insurer, presented a spirited defense in a four-hour conference call with investors and analysts. Its executives did not allow the participants to ask questions directly, accepting only questions submitted in advance.

title: A Plea for More Federal Dollars to Build America
description: To the Editor:

title: Solaris and Apes Hill Club
description: Solaris

title: Florida: F.B.I. Backs Students on Explosives
description: Two Egyptian college students arrested near a Navy weapons station in South Carolina last year were carrying low-grade fireworks, as they claimed, not explosives as charged by federal prosecutors, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has determined. The men, Ahmed Abdellatif Sherif Mohamed, 26, and Youssef Samir Megahed, 21, engineering students at the University of South Florida, were indicted by a Tampa grand jury on charges of transporting explosives. The F.B.I. report was submitted to the court Wednesday by Mr. Megaheds lawyer as part of a motion seeking bail. It said the items in the car  PVC pipe containing a mixture of sugar, potassium nitrate and cat litter  were ingredients for a pyrotechnic mixture that burned but did not explode. Mr. Megahed is a permanent resident of the United States; Mr. Mohamed was on a student visa.

title: The Verdict: Its Broken
description: The case of the mismanaged American Indian trust funds is Dickensian both in length  now 11 years before the courts  and inequity. On Wednesday, Judge James Robertson of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia ruled that the Interior Department had unreasonably delayed its accounting for billions of dollars owed to American Indian landholders and that the agency cannot remedy the breach.

title: Senator Wants N.F.L. Spying Case Explained
description: The ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee wants N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell to explain why the league destroyed evidence related to spying by the New England Patriots.

title: For His Super Bowl Wager, One Mayor Keeps It Real
description: Its not so much the NY logo on the Giants helmets that gets to James L. Cassella. He can handle that. I happen to like New York City, said Mr. Cassella, who is the mayor of East Rutherford, N.J. Thats the small borough where the Giants have played football since well before Eli Manning first drew breath.

title: Indonesian Chickens, and People, Hard Hit by Bird Flu
description: KONCANG, Indonesia  The rooster started to crow at 3 a.m., and Partoparmin, a farmer in this small hillside village, went into his yard to look. All around him, chickens were lying on the ground, twitching and shaking.

title: TV Stations Seek Shows to Put Online
description: LAS VEGAS

title: St. Peters A.D. Will Retire
description: Bill Stein, the athletic director for St. Peters College in Jersey City, will retire in July after 26 years, the college announced.

title: Pakistani P.R.
description: You have to hand it to Pervez Musharraf. With all the problems the Pakistani president faces at home, he still found time to spend eight days in Europe last week, assuring world leaders everything is fine in his nuclear-armed state. But everything is not fine, and the cracks in his sunny public-relations facade were not hard to see.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: An Obsessive Love of Prayer
description: Shot over three years in a close-knit Jewish Reconstructionist community in Philadelphia, Praying With Lior documents the extraordinary life of Lior Liebling, a rabbis son with Down syndrome and an obsessive love of prayer.

title: Bush Presses Democrats to Pass Stimulus Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush said on Friday that the economy remains basically sound, but that the disappointing report on jobs shows the need for Congress to approve a stimulus package without delay.

title: Lost Boosts ABC
description: The return of Lost, albeit a two-hour repeat of last seasons finale, buoyed ABCs ratings on Wednesday during a night otherwise dominated by Foxs American Idol and The Moment of Truth. According to Nielsens estimates, the two Fox programs delivered the nights largest audiences by far, 25.3 million viewers at 8 for American Idol, followed by 17.9 million for The Moment of Truth at 9. ABC ranked a distant second for the night among adults 18 to 49, with Wife Swap at 8 (5.8 million), followed by the Lost rerun at 9 (8.5 million), which the network enhanced with on-screen pop-ups to fill in the back story. In total viewers, however, ABC finished third behind Fox and NBC, which benefited from Deal or No Deal at 8 (9.8 million) and Law & Order at 10 (11.1 million). CBS finished fourth over all with repeats.

title: Motorola Weighs a Shift in Cellphones
description: Motorola, which in recent years has been unable to capitalize on the success of its popular Razr phone, said Thursday that it was exploring the possibility of selling or spinning off its cellular phone business as a way to make the company more profitable.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,934 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

title: OBrien Allowed to Coach Again
description: Jim OBrien won an appeal Thursday and can return to the college sidelines after he had been fired by Ohio State as its mens basketball coach and essentially barred from coaching by the N.C.A.A. for paying a recruit.A year after the initial 2006 ruling found seven rules violations, the N.C.A.A. threw out three of them and part of a fourth because the associations enforcement staff missed a deadline for filing charges. Any further restrictions on future employment were lifted by Thursdays ruling by an N.C.A.A. appeals committee.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $6,999,342

title: Regulators Warn France Against Protecting Bank
description: PARIS  As numerous European banks considered whether to make a bid for Socit Gnrale, reeling from a $7.1 billion trading loss, regulators in Brussels warned the French government Thursday against trying to protect the bank from foreign suitors.

title: Feminists Find Unity Is Elusive
description: Jessica Valenti, a 29-year-old blogger from Astoria (by way of Williamsburg), and Marcia Pappas, a 57-year-old life coach who owned and ran a hair salon in Albany for most of her career, might be surprised to find how much they had in common if they ran into each other at a party. (Admittedly, its hard to imagine what that party would look like).

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the Democratic primary in Florida referred incorrectly to a pledge by the candidates that they would not campaign in the state. They made that pledge to Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina, the four states that had permission to hold early primaries; they did not make that deal with the Democratic National Committee. (Go to Article)

title: A Home for Your Gear, and a Place to Play With It
description: MICHAEL HUNT was tired of keeping his fishing boat and Mercedes convertible under tarps next to his house in Post Falls, Idaho. His prized recreational vehicle was slowly falling apart after spending a few winters outside. With no room left in his garage, he wasnt sure what to do.

title: Robert M. Ball Is Dead at 93; Led Social Security
description: Robert M. Ball, the commissioner of Social Security in the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon administrations, an architect of Medicare and an influential opponent of privatizing Social Security, died Wednesday at his home in Bowie, Md. He was 93.

title: To Giants, Desert Solitude Is Nothing but a Mirage
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  The man had climbed over a fence, apparently, and made his way quietly along the railroad tracks that border the east side of the practice fields where the Giants are preparing for the Super Bowl.

title: Stockholm Plans Bergman Street
description: The Stockholm City Council is expected to name a street and adjoining square in honor of Ingmar Bergman, the Swedish master filmmaker who died in July, Agence France-Presse reported. I would be very surprised if the decision doesnt go through, said Mikael Soederlund, a city councilor who backs the proposal. The street and square are near the Royal Dramatic Theater, of which Bergman was the director and where he staged plays by Strindberg, Ibsen, Anouilh, Tennessee Williams and others.

title: Only G.M. Posts a Gain in January Sales in U.S.
description: DETROIT  General Motors was the only one of the six biggest automakers whose sales in the United States increased last month, according to figures released Friday.

title: Patriots Get Ready for the Giants and History
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  With the excitement continuing to build for Sundays Super Bowl XLII, New England quarterback Tom Brady only heightened the hyperbole Thursday.

title: Gearing Up for the Big Countdown
description: A DEFINITE contender for the title of Most Precocious Republican in New York City, Marcus Cederqvist, at 37 the baby-faced new executive director of the Board of Elections, is gearing up for his debut as the citys chief vote counter for Tuesdays New York presidential primary.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Jan. 21 about two music stores in Harlem that are victims of gentrification misstated their relative location. The Harlem Record Shack, on West 125th Street, is southeast  not northwest  of Bobbys Happy House, which is on Frederick Douglass Boulevard, and is a few hundred feet  not a few hundred yards  away.

title: China and Alcoa Buy Stake in Rio Tinto
description: BEIJING  The state-owned Aluminum Corporation of China joined Alcoa on Friday in taking a 12 percent stake in Rio Tinto. The Chinese company also said it might buy more shares to derail a hostile takeover attempt by BHP Billiton, a merger that China fears could drive up prices for raw materials even further.

title: Times Reporter Subpoenaed Over Source for Book
description: WASHINGTON  A federal grand jury has issued a subpoena to a reporter of The New York Times, apparently to try to force him to reveal his confidential sources for a 2006 book on the Central Intelligence Agency, one of the reporters lawyers said Thursday.

title: U.S. Economy Unexpectedly Sheds 17,000 Jobs
description: The economy lost 17,000 jobs in January, the Labor Department reported on Friday, the first monthly decline in four years and the most striking evidence yet that the United States may be slipping into a recession.

title: Travels With Hemingway: Thats Not All She Wrote
description: It is one of the myths of the profession that inside every journalist there is a great novel struggling to get out. For Ernest Hemingway, the myth became a reality. For Martha Gellhorn, Hemingways third wife, the struggle was her life story. In The Maddening Truth, a new play being staged by the Keen Company at the Clurman Theater, David Hay makes a case that Gellhorn ultimately won the battle.

title: Plenty of Porcelain in West Palm Beach
description: Floridians have always had a healthy appetite for fine porcelain, which explains its appearance at the 10-day, 90-dealer art and antiques fair that opens on Friday in West Palm Beach.

title: Kurds Power Wanes as Arab Anger Rises
description: BAGHDAD  As a minority group in Iraq, the Kurds have enjoyed disproportionate influence in the countrys politics since the ouster of Saddam Hussein in 2003. But now their leverage appears to be declining as tensions rise with Iraqi Arabs, raising the specter of another fissure alongside the sectarian divide between Sunnis and Shiites.

title: In the List of Top-Selling Games, Clear Evidence of a Sea Change
description: Ever since video games decamped from arcades and set up shop in the nations living rooms in the 1980s, they have been thought of as a pastime enjoyed mostly alone. The image of the antisocial, sunlight-deprived game geek is enshrined in the popular consciousness as deeply as any stereotype of recent decades.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 1 about the parole of Sara Jane Moore, who tried to assassinate President Gerald R. Ford in 1975, referred incorrectly to her ties to radical leftist groups. She was not involved with the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: Former President Shows Calmer Face in Campaign
description: The red-faced, finger-wagging Bill Clinton has left the campaign trail.

title: Microsoft Bids $44.6 Billion for Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft said Friday that it has made an offer to buy Yahoo for about $44.6 billion, or $31 a share, in a mix of cash and stock.

title: Lawmaker on Long Island Wants Worker Status Verified
description: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y.  In the latest move on eastern Long Island to crack down on illegal immigrants, a freshman Suffolk County legislator proposed a bill on Thursday that would require the estimated 15,000 licensed contractors there to verify their workers legal status.

title: A Small-Town Oasis in the High Desert
description: SOUTH of Tucson on Interstate 19, just over the Santa Cruz County line, two rugged mountain ranges vie for your attention: the soaring Santa Rita Mountains to the east, and the smaller, but no less compelling, Tumacacori Mountains to the west.

title: The No. 6 Train From Pelham Bay Park to Brooklyn Bridge-City Hall
description: This is the last commute in the Next Stop series. Billie Cohen took a different commute around the New York region every week day in January.

title: New York Candidates Awash in Real Estate Cash
description: The real estate industry, racing to beat strict new limits on campaign contributions, has been flooding New York City candidates with donations for the 2009 campaign at a rate three and four times that in previous election cycles.

title: Mehdi and Sarah and Adrien and Manu, Coupling Under a Cloud
description: The French director Andr Tchin is a master at evoking personality quirks, the unpredictability of relationships and the haphazard way love affairs, friendships and social groups form and dissolve. Many of his films, like Changing Times and Wild Reeds, portray a multicultural environment in which French and North African characters mingle, sometimes uneasily.

title: Two Are Sentenced for 1992 Mob Killings
description: Two Ukrainian immigrants convicted in a pair of organized-crime murders in Brooklyn that went unsolved for 14 years were sentenced on Thursday to 25 years to life in prison, prosecutors said.

title: Voters Dark Mood
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Help Valiquette Claim First N.H.L. Shutout
description: PHILADELPHIA  The first goal the Rangers scored against the Flyers on Thursday night seemed like it was drawn from their wish list. They had been playing defense relentlessly, trying to stop their season from sliding out of control, when forward Nigel Dawes skated into the offensive zone with no teammates to help him and no indication that he would alter the course of the game.

title: Democrats: And Then There Were Two
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Lawmaker Is Killed as Kenyas Riots Intensify
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A second Kenyan opposition lawmaker was shot dead on Thursday, and riots immediately exploded in opposition strongholds, putting the country increasingly on edge.

title: 8 Banks in Talks to Rescue Bond Insurer
description: Eight major banks are in talks to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, as part of an industrywide rescue being orchestrated by state regulators, people briefed on the negotiations said Friday.

title: Australia Wont Punish Lawyer for Leak
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The lawyer for an Australian resident who had been a suspect in connection with the bungled bombings in London and Glasgow last June will not be subject to any disciplinary action for leaking the transcript of the police interview with his client, a state agency reviewing the matter said on Friday.

title: A Stadium Goes Up, but It Is Missing a Cornerstone
description: The Minnesota Twins are building a ballpark that is expected to open in 2010.

title: Favor Between Friends Led 2 Officers Into Corruption Case, Court Papers Show
description: Luis M. Batista and Henry Conde: old friends, and New York City police officers. Mr. Batista joined the force in 1997, his friend in 1994.

title: Doing Their Part to Help Save the Planet, in High Style
description: Jessica Stam, the leonine fashion model with honey-colored hair and outstanding high arches, tried on a very short ivory dress by the label Rodarte. It was described as being made of hemp silk and a Pia cobweb, which sounded as if it might be a drink order for Elvira.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the Democratic primary in Florida referred incorrectly to a pledge by the candidates that they would not campaign in the state. They made that pledge to Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina, the four states that had permission to hold early primaries; they did not make that deal with the Democratic National Committee.

title: Nets and New Drug Make Inroads Against Malaria
description: Widespread distribution of mosquito nets and a new medicine sharply reduced malaria deaths in several African countries, World Health Organization researchers reported Thursday.

title: Bellwether State Fervently Seeks Choice Who Can Win in the Fall
description: ST. LOUIS  They are used to picking the president around here, and more than ever, it seems, they want to extend their winning streak to the primaries.

title: Public and Private: The Gap in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Release of 1950s U.S. Grand Jury Transcripts Is Sought in Rosenberg Atomic Spy Case
description: After half a century of scholarly work, one might have thought that little of the famous spy story of the Rosenbergs could still be left untold. On Thursday, however, a group of historians, led by a government watchdog group, began the process of prying loose the last trove of secret documents remaining in the case.

title: Suicide Attack in Mosque Kills an Afghan Deputy Governor
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The deputy governor of Helmand Province and five other people were killed by a suicide bomber during afternoon prayers in a mosque in the provincial capital, Afghan officials said. The Taliban claimed responsibility through a spokesman.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about a new production of Porgy and Bess by the Zachary Scott Theater Center in Austin, Tex., misspelled the surname of one of the singers whose recording of the work inspired the theaters producing artistic director, Dave Steakley. She is Cleo Laine, not Lane.

title: Estrada and Nationals Have Deal
description: Johnny Estrada and the Washington Nationals agreed to a one-year, $1.25 million contract, giving the Nationals an experienced catcher to back up Paul Lo Duca.

title: Mexican Farmers Protest End of Corn-Import Taxes
description: MEXICO CITY  Tens of thousands of farmers clogged the streets of the capital on Thursday to protest the end of tariffs on corn from the United States, warning that the elimination of trade barriers could drive them out of business and lead more Mexicans to migrate north.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about the downhill skier Daron Rahlves and his hopes for the skiercross event at the Winter X Games misstated, in some editions, his place in the history of the prestigious Hahnenkamm downhill in Austria. In 2003, he became the second American to win that race, not the first. (Bud Werner was the first, in 1959.)

title: OPEC Is Expected to Keep Oil Production Unchanged
description: Ignoring calls from the United States and other consuming countries to pump more oil into the global economy, the OPEC oil cartel is expected to keep its output unchanged when the groups ministers meet in Vienna on Friday.

title: Burger King Profit Jumps 29 Percent
description: MIAMI (AP)  Burger King Holdings said Thursday that its second-quarter profit jumped 29 percent, helped by strong sales of its Whopper and new Homestyle Melt sandwiches, along with promotions with TV tie-ins.

title: Buying Low: Minor Leaguer Takes Stock of Himself
description: While the pending trade of Johan Santana to the Mets has shaken up Major League Baseball, a relatively unknown, submarine-throwing farmhand who might never reach the big leagues has also spent the week rattling his sports economics.

title: Skis of a Different Breed
description: To the Editor: As Natural as Sneezing, But So Much More Fun (Rituals, Jan. 25) is a fine story on the joys of downhill skiing, but based upon the accompanying photograph I fully expected this to be on the joys of cross-country skiing. Any skier will know that that photo is of cross-country skis and poles, not the far more complicated downhill gear.

title: For Retired N.F.L. Greats, Checks Are Out of Balance
description: Phoenix

title: A Good Plan for Traffic Relief
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg rightly touts congestion pricing as a solution for New Yorks traffic gridlock, a boon to the environment and a way to finance improvements to the citys mass transit system. A commission, appointed by top state and city officials, has now proposed a sensible pricing plan. Important details still must be worked out, and city and state lawmakers must approve a plan before the end of March to qualify for a $354 million federal grant. They must not miss that deadline or this opportunity.

title: Giants Make Statements of Fashion and Confidence
description: Most of the Giants wore their white jerseys with big, red numerals Thursday morning when they met with the news media for the final time before Super Bowl XLII.

title: Cradle for Serious Grooving
description: ITS 7:30 on a weekday evening, and the Josie Robertson Plaza at the heart of Lincoln Center is crowded. Slender teenagers from Juilliards ballet program, hair still up in tight bunhead knots, dart like gazelles toward the New York State Theater, where City Ballet is about to perform. They cut through the older operagoers flowing toward the Metropolitan Opera House. Film fans stroll diagonally across the plaza, heading to the Walter Reade Theater.

title: Maybe Never? Loves Old Bittersweet Song
description: Maybe Forever, which explores a failed relationship, might have made a good show for Co-Dependents Anonymous, one audience member observed wryly when the piece opened at Dance Theater Workshop on Wednesday. The 85-minute work is occasionally as tedious as the real thing and the memories that linger. But Meg Stuart, who created the piece with Philipp Gehmacher, has long specialized in teetering productively on the edge of tedium. And while Maybe Forever is less ambitious than some of her other work, it suggests why Ms. Stuart, who left New York for Europe in the early 1990s, has a reputation for unfailingly imaginative, provocative avant-garde theater dance.

title: Amazon to Buy Audiobook Seller for $300 Million
description: Amazon.com, which has been rapidly adding digital downloads to its vast Web store, said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy Audible, the largest online seller of audiobooks.

title: Wesley Snipes Is Acquitted of Tax Felonies
description: OCALA, Fla.  The actor Wesley Snipes was acquitted of the most serious charges against him on Friday in the most prominent tax prosecution since Leona Helmsley, the billionaire hotelier, was convicted of tax fraud in 1989.

title: A Green Energy Industry Takes Root in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The sun is starting to grow jobs.

title: Bank Chief May Face Questions
description: PARIS  A senior prosecutor examining the trading scandal at Socit Gnrale recommended Friday that the embattled chief executive, Daniel Bouton, be questioned by judges in connection with accusations he has made about a rogue traders role in the banks loss of billions of euros.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Well column in Science Times on Tuesday, about statins, misidentified the location of the university where Dr. Beatrice Golomb, who questioned whether they help most users live longer, is an associate professor of medicine. It is the University of California, San Diego  not San Francisco.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: One on One in Debate, Democrats Set Aim at G.O.P.
description: LOS ANGELES  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama met for debate here Thursday, sitting side by side and sharing a night of smiles, friendly eye-catching and gentle banter. Cordial as the encounter was, the candidates did not mask their own divisions, even as they previewed the attacks one of them will ultimately make against a Republican rival.

title: Coins in the New Realm
description: HOLLYWOOD  Xavier Buck planned to spend $100,000 to bid for domain names, those parcels of virtual Internet real estate, at a live auction here last week.

title: Senate Democrats Stimulus Plan Hits Roadblock
description: WASHINGTON  Backed solidly by the Bush administration, Senate Republicans said on Thursday that they would block a $157 billion economic stimulus package championed by Senate Democrats, who said they would have no choice but to quickly adopt a cheaper, more streamlined plan approved this week by the House.

title: Home Depot Will Lay Off 500 Workers
description: Home Depot, battered by a downturn in the housing market, is laying off 500 workers at its headquarters in Atlanta, or about 10 percent of its work force there, the company said Thursday.

title: A Long Illness Compounds Dubious Financial Decisions
description: Agnes and Francisco Santiago are homeowners.

title: The Rev. Marcial Maciel, 87, Conservative Catholic Leader, Dies
description: ROME  The Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado, founder of the influential Roman Catholic group the Legionaries of Christ and the most prominent priest disciplined after accusations of sexual abuse, died Wednesday, the group announced Thursday. He was 87.

title: Aid to Indebted Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Britney	Spears Woes Inspire Meltdown
description: The Rambert Dance Company, one of Britains leading modern-dance troupes, will perform Meltdown, a choreographic interpretation of the travails of Britney Spears, in an appearance on Friday as part of its new season at the Southbank Center in London, Agence France-Presse reported. Hubert Essakow, who created the work, set to music by Richard Thomas (Jerry Springer: The Opera), said he became interested in Ms. Spearss problems about a year ago. I thought this was a really modern-day tragedy, this reversal of fortune, he told BBC Television. I saw somebody who had such great hope and was adored by millions of people, then goes down the wrong route. In an excerpt from Meltdown that accompanied the BBC report, the Spears character is seen dancing in an abbreviated pink top, black vinyl hot pants and a pink Stetson while being harried by photographers costumed in menacing black. Eventually she is carried away by dancers dressed as white-coated doctors.

title: Georgia: Life Sentence in Hikers Death
description: A man was sentenced to life in prison, with possibility of parole in 30 years, after pleading guilty to murder in the beating-death of a young woman hiking in the north Georgia mountains. District Attorney Lee Darragh of Dawson County said the murder resulted from a plan by the man, Gary M. Hilton, 61, above, to abduct the woman, Meredith Emerson, 24, in order to steal money using her A.T.M. cards. But Ms. Emerson, whose body was found Jan. 7 near Dawsonville, misled Mr. Hilton, giving him false numbers with the hope that the authorities would be alerted to efforts to gain access to her account, Mr. Darragh said. Mr. Hilton was indicted on one murder count.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: From the Housing Market to the Maternity Ward
description: For the first time in 35 years, Americas total fertility rate  the estimated number of children a woman will have in her lifetime  reached 2.1, the theoretical level required to maintain the countrys population, according to recent data from the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Deal Over Randalls Island Sports Fields Is Voided
description: A Manhattan judge voided an agreement between the Bloomberg administration and 20 private schools on Thursday, ruling that the city had improperly given the schools priority in using athletic fields on Randalls Island in exchange for $45 million.

title: An Alienated Bunch Not Dealing With Loss
description: Why do we like sad plays? Is it because they allow us to confront painful emotions or escape from them? Deathbed, a coolly thoughtful and taut meditation by the stylish playwright Mark Schultz, engages this question with an eyebrow raised.

title: California: Early Report on Plane Crash
description: The pilots of two small planes did not move to avoid each other before colliding last week near Los Angeles, killing five people, investigators said. A preliminary report by the National Transportation Safety Board said a witness saw the planes cruising toward each other for at least five seconds without taking an evasive maneuver. The collision occurred about a mile south of Corona Municipal Airport, which does not have a manned control tower. The report said that a Cessna 150 was headed east on approach to the airport and that a Cessna 172 was traveling north. It did not blame either pilot. The collision on Jan. 20 killed two people in each plane and a person on the ground. A final report is expected by the end of the year.

title: Bored Stepbrothers, Intrepid Platypus
description: Imagine Family Guy with an espionage subplot and a big dose of magical realism, and you have Phineas and Ferb, a new animated childrens series whose debut episode will be shown on the Disney Channel on Friday night.

title: Talk of Independence in a Place Claimed by 2 Nations
description: SAN ANDRS, Colombia  Down the road from a neighborhood here called the Hill, where reggae blares out of weathered houses and parishioners sing hymns in English at the First Baptist Church, President lvaro Uribe recently inaugurated a hospital with a decidedly Colombian name: Amor de Patria.

title: Electronic Arts Posts Loss, Citing a Revamp
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Electronic Arts, the video game maker, swung to a quarterly loss because of reorganization charges and deferred revenue. But the company largely met Wall Streets forecasts as it posted solid revenue gains in what was a strong holiday season for the game industry.

title: Arthur B. Kramer, Playwrights Brother, Dies at 81
description: Arthur B. Kramer, who built a small New York law firm into an international one and whose tense relationship with his brother Larry Kramer, the playwright and gay rights advocate, helped inspire a benchmark play of the 1980s, died on Saturday. He was 81 and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Britain: People-Smuggling Arrests in Raids
description: After dawn raids on 12 locations in London and one in the British Midlands that resulted in 13 arrests, Scotland Yard officials said they had broken up two Turkish-led gangs engaged in large-scale human smuggling into Britain. Police commanders said the gangs charged Chinese migrants up to $42,000 each for journeys that could take up to 18 months, with stopovers at safe houses in Belgium and France, where additional arrests were made. The police said the raids demonstrated a resolve by European governments to curb criminal gangs that run an underground railroad for illegal immigrants along with other rackets that include heroin smuggling and money laundering.

title: Spreading Joy With a Mobile Disco
description: I want to see these hills shine and sparkle like disco floors. So says Vincent (Magnus Aronson), the kooky dreamer hero of the short feature Build a Ship, Sail to Sadness.

title: Digging for Truth in a Life Thats Built Upon a Lie
description: Fundamental issues of ethnic and religious identity and the agony of exile are at the heart of Live and Become, an intermittently compelling swatch of recent Israeli history filtered through the experience of an African immigrant.

title: Winter. Cross-Country Racing. And Not a Ski on the Course.
description: ON a clear, 13-degree December morning at 8,000 feet above sea level, hundreds of snowshoers are assembled around a white plastic tent, preparing to race one another up and down the side of a snow-covered mountain. They are limbering up, sprinting for short distances across the hard-packed snow, turning on G.P.S. watches, cueing up MP3 play lists. They are growing familiar with the apparatus strapped to their feet, which will allow them to climb up icy hills in this part of Beaver Creek, Colo.; bound through aspen-rich trails; and fly down steep mountain pitches coated in thigh-high powder.

title: Ad Growth Still Strong, Google Says
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said it has seen no effect from a slowing economy on its advertising business, as it reported a 17 percent jump in profit and a 51 percent growth in revenue in the fourth quarter.

title: Blizzards and Coal Shortages Strain Chinas Rail Network
description: BEIJING  After blizzards disrupted coal deliveries, acute electricity shortages across a swath of central and southern China have exposed the fragility of transportation networks in the worlds fastest-growing major economy.

title: Giuliani Will Return Diminished, but Not Finished, Associates Say
description: WASHINGTON  He left as Americas Mayor. But Rudolph W. Giuliani will return to New Yorks business and political arenas as a mere mortal, some of his friends and business associates acknowledge.

title: Petty Already Rocking Long Before Halftime
description: PHOENIX  The Giants and the New England Patriots will be busy fine-tuning their game plans Sunday when the halftime entertainment, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, takes the stage for a 12-minute set.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: A Musical Sermon Steeped in Darkness
description: Maybe the directors of the new-music ensemble Sequitur were feeling mystical rather than merely dour when they assembled the groups Wednesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall. Four of the five scores were vocal works, and death figured prominently in each text. The fifth, as an instrumental work, might reasonably have been taken as abstract  it is basically a chaconne  except that the composer, Arthur Levering, named it Furies, after the mythological goddesses of vengeance.

title: Jay-Z to Headline Glastonbury?
description: A New York rapper will be one of the headliners at the Glastonbury Festival in England this summer, but Michael Eavis, 72, the dairy farmer who has been organizing the event on his land since 1970, refused to confirm on Thursday that he was referring to Jay-Z, Agence France-Presse reported. Were trying to get youngsters to the festival this year, he said, expressing hope that half of the 137,500 ticket holders would be under 25. Hopefully the headliner will appeal to them. Traditionally weve had a very white lineup, and Im moving away from that. The Saturday slot is a wonderful hip-hop artist from New York and a bit of a legend, in my view. We need more young people here. Im trying to address the balance. Otherwise, the festival will die out with the older people. Nevertheless, a golden-oldie star usually is the Sunday headliner, and Mr. Eavis confirmed that the honor this year would fall to Neil Diamond. This years festival on the 800-acre farm runs June 27 through 29.

title: Microsoft Bids $44.6 Billion for Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a bold move to counter Googles online pre-eminence, Microsoft said Friday that it had made an unsolicited offer to buy Yahoo for about $44.6 billion in a mix of cash and stock.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about genital pain in women, misspelled the name of a muscle relaxant said to bring relief in some cases. It is Flexeril, not Flexoril.

title: Oregon: Deadline for Fish-Run Plan Is Delayed
description: A federal judge in Portland has postponed for a second time a deadline for a plan that meets his standards for balancing operations of Columbia River Basin dams with threatened or endangered fish runs. At a December hearing the judge, James A. Redden of Federal District Court, moved the deadline for a third biological opinion to March 18 from March 1 but threatened unspecified consequences if he rejected it. On Tuesday he extended it to May 5, said Brian Gorman, spokesman for the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration Fisheries in Seattle. Judge Redden has thrown out two opinions as inadequate and wrote in December that a draft of a third effort looked little better.

title: Are You Up Yet?
description: It is hardly a revelation that teenagers like to sleep late. But more and more research is showing that this is not just a preference  or even the result of late-night studying or instant messaging  but is rooted in their biological rhythms. All of this would be little more than an interesting observation except that most high schools start so early, and so many teenagers are having a hard time staying awake.

title: Online Schooling Grows, Setting Off a Debate
description: MILWAUKEE  Weekday mornings, three of Tracie Weldies children eat breakfast, make beds and trudge off to public school  in their case, downstairs to their basement in a suburb here, where their mother leads them through math and other lessons outlined by an Internet-based charter school.

title: Exxon Mobil Profit Sets Record Again
description: By any measure, Exxon Mobils performance last year was a blowout.

title: Star of the Silver Screen and a Political Entourage
description: Among political types, Rudolph W. Giulianis failed campaign in Florida will be the subject of endless post-mortems, second-guessing, what-ifs. They will rehash the strategic miscalculations, the exit poll numbers, the single-minded focus on Florida.

title: Smiles All Around in an Evening of Dueling Niceties
description: They did not ostentatiously shake hands. They let their eyes make nice.

title: Money for Transit Systems to Increase
description: The public transit systems in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey will be getting a large increase in federal financing to help them better prevent or respond to a terrorist attack, according to government officials.

title: Across the Universe, Literally
description: NASA will send the Beatles song Across the Universe across the universe on Monday, the agency said. At precisely 7 p.m., E.S.T. the song will be beamed by the agencys Deep Space Network of antennas at the North Star, Polaris, which is 431 light years away. The transmission is to mark the 40th anniversary of the recording of the song, as well as the 50th anniversary of both NASA and its first satellite, Explorer I, and the 45th anniversary of the Deep Space Network, which carries out communications between NASA and its far-flung fleet of spacecraft. In a message to the space agency, Paul McCartney, one of the two remaining Beatles, said, Send my love to the aliens. All the best, Paul.

title: Lottery Numbers
Fireworks Explosion in Istanbul Kills 22
description: ISTANBUL  An unlicensed fireworks factory here exploded accidentally, leaving at least 22 people dead and at least 100 injured, Turkish officials said Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about the confirmation of Ed Schafer as secretary of agriculture misspelled the surname of his predecessor. He is Mike Johanns, not Johans.

title: Sony Reports 25% Rise in Profit, but Lowers Its Forecast
description: TOKYO  Sony said Thursday that its profit rose more than 25 percent in the final three months of 2007, helped by robust sales of televisions and computer games. But it said strong yen and subprime problems would weigh on demand this year.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: A Guy, His Psychic and a Jealous Ghost
description: For what it is  a romantic comedy about the rivalry between a jealous ghost and a flaky psychic for the love of a veterinarian  Over Her Dead Body is not bad. Eva Longoria Parker, as Kate, the ghost, represents the control-freak/ice-queen end of the female comedic spectrum pretty well, while Lake Bell as Ashley, the psychic, is perfectly lovely on the sweet, scatterbrained end. In the middle is Henry the vet, played by the winningly smirky Paul Rudd, and there are sidekicks drawn from the usual storeroom: the kooky sister (Lindsay Sloane) and the gay male best friend (Jason Biggs).

title: Britain: Lawmaker Suspended Over Sons Pay
description: The longstanding practice of politicians putting family members on the public payroll came under scrutiny with the censure and 10-day suspension by Parliament of a Conservative member, Derek Conway, left, after he was found to have paid his 22-year-old son nearly $100,000 in public money for work as a parliamentary researcher during three years when he was a full-time college student in Newcastle, 300 miles from London. A House of Commons panel found no record of any work by the son. Mr. Conway apologized and said he would not seek re-election. More than 40 other Commons members employ spouses and other family members. Sir Christopher Kelly, chairman of the Committee on Standards in Public Life, urged that Britain consider following the example of the United States Congress in barring lawmakers from employing family members.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Senior Qaeda Commander Is Killed by U.S. Missile
description: WASHINGTON  An American missile strike in Pakistans northwestern tribal areas killed a senior commander of Al Qaeda who had been involved in planning attacks on United States and NATO troops in Afghanistan, American officials said Thursday.

title: Times Co. Swings to Profit
description: The New York Times Company reported a fourth-quarter profit of $53 million on Thursday as revenue dropped, but it continued to fare better than most of its peers across the troubled newspaper industry.

title: Russia Creates a $32 Billion Sovereign Wealth Fund
description: MOSCOW  Russia has split its oil proceeds into two funds and cleared the way for one to invest in foreign stocks and bonds, officials said Thursday. But actual investments are not expected to begin until fall at the earliest.

title: State Commission Approves a Plan for Congestion Pricing
description: A state traffic commission voted on Thursday to recommend that New York City charge drivers an $8 daily fee to bring their cars into Manhattan below 60th Street.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Exploring the Neighborhood, on Screen and Off
description: READING

title: Lone Star Executive Sentenced
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A court here on Friday found Lone Star, the United States private equity fund, and one of its executives guilty of manipulating stock prices, dealing a blow to Lone Star in its intensely monitored legal battle with South Korean prosecutors.

title: Awakening, Nightly, at 50
description: EARLY in the first act of Spring Awakening, the hit Duncan Sheik musical about teenage lust in 19th-century Germany, Kate Burton throws open her blouse, revealing a lacy, low-cut corset, and does a bouncy, hoochie-coochie dance into the face of her young co-star, Gerard Canonico. She looks as if shes having a lot of fun. (So does he.) But not as much fun as in the last scene, when Ms. Burton  a Serious Thespian herself and the daughter of another, Richard Burton  sings and dances in a buoyant group number.

title: Women Weigh Use of Clout in Primary
description: In the garden-level kitchen of a Harlem brownstone last Sunday, five women sat around a long wooden table, overshadowed by a large leafy plant in the window, sipping hazelnut coffee and excitedly finishing one anothers sentences as they talked about the presidential candidates as if they were on intimate terms, calling them Hillary and Barack.

title: McCain Wins Schwarzenegger Endorsement, and Romney Delivers Barb
description: LOS ANGELES  John McCain and Mitt Romney battled across the daunting political landscape of California on Thursday as Mr. McCain basked in the potent endorsement of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Mr. Romney poured at least $1 million into a statewide television advertising campaign and likened Mr. McCains tactics to those of the Nixon era.

title: Jackson Hole Mountain Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Tenor Cancels Appearances
description: The star tenor Juan Diego Flrez, who has a throat infection caused by a fish bone he swallowed, has been forced to cancel his performances in the Lyric Opera of Chicago production of Rossinis Barbiere di Siviglia. The company said on Thursday that doctors in Parma, Italy, have advised Mr. Flrez, 35, not to perform at least through mid-March. For the 12 scheduled Lyric Opera performances through March 22, he will be replaced in the role of Count Almaviva by John Osborn. Mr. Flrez, left, is next scheduled to sing in his native Peru on March 31 as the Duke in Verdis Rigoletto. Beginning on April 21, he is to portray Tonio in the Metropolitan Operas new production of Donizettis Fille du Rgiment. ... A knee injury suffered by the tenor Michael Schade has forced the cancellation of his Lincoln Center Great Performers duo recital with the baritone Russell Braun, scheduled for Feb. 10 at the Rose Theater in Frederick P. Rose Hall. It will not be rescheduled.

title: Eurozone Inflation Rising at Record Pace
description: PARIS  Inflation in the euro zone rose in January at the fastest pace on record, official data showed Thursday, highlighting the difficult task facing the European Central Bank as it seeks to enforce price stability in the face of slowing economic growth.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Comrades Speak of Fallen Marine and Ties That Bind
description: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq  As a cold wind swept across much of the Middle East on Thursday, bringing snow to northern Iraq and subfreezing temperatures to Baghdad, about 100 soldiers and marines gathered for a ceremony to rename a small helicopter landing zone on this huge American base in honor of a fallen comrade.

title: Bond of Brothers in a California Wilderness
description: ONE recent winter night, having just scrubbed out after an emergency C-section, Jonathan Bourne, an anesthesiologist at Mammoth Hospital in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., threw his pack and skis into his brothers secondhand Suburban and slid into the passenger seat. The plan was to make a routine trek east across one of the largest, darkest volcanoes in North America, the Long Valley Caldera, to the familys private ski retreat on the eastern edge of California.

title: Support for Israeli Premier Amid Calls to Resign
description: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, received crucial support from senior ministers of his own Kadima Party on Thursday, and leaders of a public campaign to oust him said they were not immediately planning mass demonstrations. Those developments improved Mr. Olmerts chances of surviving a formal inquiry that found grave failings in the handling of the 2006 war against Hezbollah in Lebanon.

title: F.D.A. Finds Increase in Suicide Symptoms for Patients Using Seizure Medications
description: Drugs for epilepsy, bipolar illness and mood problems double the risks of suicidal thoughts and behavior, and patients taking them should be watched for sudden behavioral changes, drug regulators have said.

title: Federal Agents Crackdown on  Super Bowl Fakes
description: MESA, Ariz.  It seemed like a good deal.

title: Whos Your Daddy?
description: To the Slate editor in chief, Jacob Weisberg, the presidency of George W. Bush is a plane crash, and he says there is a black box that can help explain just what brought this White House down in flames: a black box filled with a series of relationships  familial, personal, religious and historical, most notably the father-son relationship, which lies at the very core of the second Bush presidency and its spectacular, avoidable flame-out.

title: A Haircut, With an Affair and Highlights of Support
description: The Beirut beauty salon where most of Caramel takes place is likely to be a familiar type of establishment, even to viewers who have never been to the Lebanese capital. What the shop lacks in sleekness and chic it makes up for in the kind of friendly, sisterly warmth that could be found, for instance, in Beauty Shop, the distaff installation in the Barbershop franchise.

title: Defense Says Police Violated Brooklyn Stepfathers Rights
description: The day that Cesar Rodriguez was charged in the beating death of his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, he was questioned by a series of police officers and prosecutors.

title: Extreme Cultural Realignment for Randolph and Frye
description: TUALATIN, Ore.  How, exactly, should a person judge a blockbuster trade after a half-season of results?

title: Pop in 3-D
description: Every generation throws a hero up the pop charts, Paul Simon once sang, and in 2008 theres Miley Cyrus (excuse me, Miley Ray Cyrus)  on television, on the iTunes Top 10 and in theaters with this 3-D artifact of her just concluded tour. Bygone decades had Donny Osmond, Menudo and New Kids on the Block. Today Walt Disney  which also spawned Britney Spears, Justin Timberlake and Christina Aguilera  feeds tweens their pop idols. But dont call it packaged teenage rebellion. In this movie there are few teenagers and no rebellion, only bouncy inspirational ditties. I Miss You, a wholesome ode to Ms. Cyruss dead grandfather, is as doleful as it gets.

title: Sweden Accuses 4 of Copyright Offenses
description: LONDON  Prosecutors in Sweden on Thursday charged four men who are associated with a popular file-sharing Web site called Pirate Bay with facilitating copyright infringement.

title: Slide, Jump, Fly in Connecticut
description: PEOPLE have been skiing for about 6,000 years, but its safe to say that when someone first donned a pair of skis, it wasnt long before that person had another entertaining thought: I wonder how far I can jump on these things?

title: South Africa: Zimbabweans Shelter Raided
description: The police raided the Central Methodist Mission in central Johannesburg, where hundreds of Zimbabweans had taken refuge, hauling people in pajamas to a police station. Bishop Paul Verryn sheltered about 1,200 people at the church, which has become a haven for Zimbabweans fleeing their country. Police officers could be heard asking people taken from the church for their residency permits. The authorities have been struggling with the influx of migrants. South Africa is believed to have one of the largest communities of Zimbabwean refugees, estimated at three million.

title: Canada, but Think of Warmth and Wine
description: They come seeking heat and wine, not igloos, said Jim Henry, managing broker at MacDonald Real Estate, referring to buyers who choose Osoyoos for a second home. This may be Canada, but were at the northernmost tip of the Sonoran Desert. By May, temperatures are in the mid-80s, and through the summer months, its in the 90s almost every day.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Gambling Money Is in the Minutiae
description: The best anyone can remember, proposition bets, or the props, as they are known, began with Super Bowl XX in 1986 when the Chicago Bears faced the New England Patriots and the burning question was whether William Perry might score.

title: Enlisting New Donors, Obama Reaped $32 Million in January
description: As he was winning contests in Iowa and South Carolina, Senator Barack Obama raised $32 million in January for his presidential bid, tapping 170,000 new contributors to rake in nearly double the highest previous one-month total for any candidate in this election cycle.

title: Winter Storms Hit Northern U.S.
description: Snow, sleet and freezing rain pelted the northern Midwest and northeastern states Friday, closing the Buffalo airport and causing travel delays around the region. Hundreds of flights were canceled Thursday at Chicagos OHare airport, and Friday started with arrival delays averaging two and a half hours, according to federal aviation officials.

title: Suit Seeks to Block Oil Search Off Alaska
description: A coalition of environmental organizations and Inupiaq native groups filed suit in federal court in Anchorage on Thursday to force the Interior Department to do a new analysis of the environmental consequences of oil and gas exploration in the Chukchi Sea, off northwestern Alaska.

title: Consumers Slow Spending Pace
description: Consumer spending slowed in December and inflation continued to rise, the government said Thursday, leaving the Federal Reserve less maneuvering room as it ponders policy decisions in the months ahead.

title: Mets Are Optimistic About Signing Santana
description: A second round of talks with the representatives for Johan Santana left the Mets feeling optimistic about their chances of signing him to a lucrative extension before their 72-hour negotiating window expires at 5 p.m. on Friday.

title: Sanctioned Killings, and the Very Many That Arent
description: Under Pain of Death, a show at the Austrian Cultural Forum about capital punishment, approaches its theme with such timidity and indirectness you might conclude that contemporary art is just not equipped to deal with the topic. Buried within it, however, are glimmers of what a more daring show could entail. (For the record, Austria has banned capital punishment.)

title: China Tries to Reassure U.S. About Its Investing Plans
description: WASHINGTON  The head of Chinas $200 billion government investment fund, seeking to reassure Americans nervous about the possibility of foreign takeovers, said Thursday that China would invest mostly in portfolios rather than individual companies  except when a big fat rabbit like the investment banker Morgan Stanley came along.

title: Correction
description: The American Journeys column last Friday, about Cuban culture in Miami, gave incomplete lyrics for a song performed in Spanish by the Cuban singer Albita at a club in Little Havana. The correct lyrics include the preposition de three times: Que culpa tengo yo de estas caderas? Que culpa tengo yo de este sabor? Que culpa tengo yo de haber nacido en Cuba?

title: Vermonts Highways of Snow
description: STEVE RUSHFORD had been riding his snowmobile all morning, and by 11 a.m. both his vehicle and stomach were in need of fuel. But first there was a more pressing issue.

title: Art in Review
description: HARUN FAROCKI

title: Berkeley Finds a New Way to Make War Politics Local
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  While the City Council here has little  read, no  sway over foreign policy and distant wars, local parking is a different matter. And so it was that a parking space directly in front of the recruiting station here for the Marine Corps was awarded on Tuesday night to an antiwar group in the hope of running the Marines out of town.

title: Determined to Beat a Ticket, but Finding Bigger Trouble
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A motorist who received a ticket for driving through a stop sign and then tried to outsmart the system did not count on the traffic commissioner outsmarting him, officials said Thursday.

title: Britney Spears Is Hospitalized
description: Britney Spears, with a police escort of nearly a dozen motorcycles, two cruisers and two helicopters, was removed by ambulance from her home and taken to U.C.L.A. Medical Center, early on Thursday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Spears, 26, whose erratic behavior has made her a public spectacle and cost her the custody of her two young sons, was hospitalized to get help, said a Los Angeles police officer who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the matter. Allan Parachini, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Superior Court, said: The way it works is a law enforcement agency or mental health professional can conclude that someone is a danger to self or others and undertake an involuntary commitment. To extend that for another 14 days there has to be a court hearing. On Jan. 3, when Ms. Spears refused to return her children to her ex-husband, Kevin Federline, who has custody, the police had paramedics take her from her home to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where she was released after a day and a half.

title: In Court Ruling on Floods, More Pain for New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  There is disappointment but little surprise here at a federal judges grudgingly absolving the Army Corps of Engineers of liability in the flooding of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina.

title: Stocks Rally in Defiance of Bad News
description: Thursday had all the ingredients for a bearish day on Wall Street.

title: In Report, Officers Call for Major Overhaul of NATO
description: BERLIN  With NATO facing the risk of failure in trying to defeat Taliban insurgents in Afghanistan, a group of former senior officers has called for a major overhaul of the alliance, which they say is paralyzed by cumbersome decision-making rules, inequitable financing arrangements and an inability to sustain long-term missions.

title: The Edwards Effect
description: So John Edwards has dropped out of the race for the presidency. By normal political standards, his campaign fell short.

title: Like Home-Builder Shares? Look Again
description: The worse the news got, the better the stocks performed.

title: Footnote
description: Richard Chamberlain and Jan Maxwell will play George and Martha when the Berkshire Theater Festival revives Edward Albees Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? for its 80th-anniversary season, from May 22 through Dec. 30 in Stockbridge, Mass. The schedule also includes works by Beckett, Shaw and Harold Pinter, as well as two new plays.

title: Washington: Wireless Tracking System for Miners
description: Federal mine-safety regulators said they approved the first wireless tracking system to locate miners trapped underground. The Mine Safety and Health Administration said the technology was developed by Venture Design Services Inc., based in Liberty Lake, Wash., a subsidiary of the Venture Corporation of Singapore. After deadly mine explosions in 2006, Congress passed legislation that year requiring that mine operators adopt wireless communications and electronic tracking systems by June 2009. A January 2006 explosion in West Virginia killed 12 men. In May of that year, five men died in an explosion in a Kentucky mine. In August, nine people died in two cave-ins in Utah.

title: Ohio: Jeb Magruder Pleads Guilty in Crashes
description: Jeb Stuart Magruder, a Watergate conspirator, pleaded guilty to a traffic charge stemming from two crashes last summer in Columbus that happened as he had a stroke while at the wheel. Mr. Magruder had been charged with failing to maintain proper distance and leaving the scene of an accident, but pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of reckless operation. He was fined $300, placed on a years probation and lost his license for a year. He says he has no recollection of the crashes. Mr. Magruder was President Richard M. Nixons deputy campaign director, an aide to H. R. Haldeman and deputy communications director at the White House. He spent seven months in prison for his role in covering up the 1972 Watergate break-in.

title: Views of the City, His and Hers, With Lens and Brush
description: When I arrived in New York in 1935, the photographer Rudy Burckhardt recalled near the end of his life, I was amazed at the difference in scale between the people and the buildings. Over the course of his career he figured out a way to make the citys architecture fit the human scale he favored. Faced with the same choice, Burckhardts wife of 40 years, the painter Yvonne Jacquette, opted to focus on the citys skyscrapers.

title: Tentative Deal to Salvage Real Estate Empire
description: Harry and William Macklowe, the father-and-son team of real estate developers who doubled the size of their holdings in a $7 billion deal last year, have reached a tentative agreement to give their lender control of all seven Manhattan skyscrapers purchased in the deal, according to real estate executives.

title: Rights Group Says U.S. Is Too Eager to Endorse Suspect Elections
description: WASHINGTON  The advocacy group Human Rights Watch on Thursday said that the Bush administration was giving lip service to the promotion of democracy around the world by endorsing suspect elections while allowing human rights violations in those countries to go unchecked.

title: Roar of Crowd Is Music to Ears of PGA Tour
description: PHOENIX  The brass at PGA Tour headquarters has long dreamed of the day when its traveling golf show would approach the N.F.L. for size of fan base, television ratings and sheer fan excitement. Although a comparably sized fan base and TV ratings are still a distant dream, golf is  for at least one week, in one sports-crazed Southwestern city  going head-to-head with the N.F.L.s showcase event and holding its own.

title: Finding a Tangle of Knots, Untying Them Smoothly
description: The American composer Elliott Carter turns 100 in December, and the sheer wealth of his music being played in celebratory concerts could easily overwhelm admirers who have otherwise waited months and even years for opportunities to hear these pieces. Notably absent from most of these celebratory events are Mr. Carters five string quartets.

title: McCains Critics on Right Look Again
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain has long aroused almost unanimous opposition from the leaders of the right. Accusing him of crimes against conservative orthodoxy like voting against a big tax cut and opposing a federal ban on same-sex marriage, conservative activists have agitated for months to thwart his Republican presidential primary campaign.

title: From Berio, the Dark Fraying Ends of the 1960s
description: Luciano Berios Sinfonia may not be as well known as Pet Sounds, Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band or the Simon and Garfunkel songs for The Graduate. But in its way this seminal work from the modernist wing of 20th-century contemporary music is equally emblematic of the 1960s.

title: Budget Cuts Raise Wrath of Principals
description: Principals across New York City turned on their computers Thursday morning to discover that because of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs new budget proposal, their budgets had been slashed overnight by sums ranging from $9,000 to $447,587. And they reacted with unvarnished fury, while frantically scouring for places to cut spending.

title: Agent Tied to McNamee Is Interviewed
description: WASHINGTON  Jim Murray, a sports agent linked to conversations with the personal trainer Brian McNamee about Roger Clemens and performance-enhancing drugs, spoke Thursday to lawyers for the House oversight committee at a closed-door interview that lasted more than three hours.

title: Drawn and Quartered
description: Washington

title: The McCain Transition
description: John McCain is exhausted. He hasnt had a full-nights sleep in forever. It took him 10 hours to get to California because of flight trouble. He underperformed in the debate Wednesday night, as his staff understands. He took some shots at Mitt Romney that were gratuitous considering the circumstances, as he privately acknowledges.

title: Times Co. Posts Profit, but Revenue Declines
description: The New York Times Company reported a fourth-quarter profit of $53 million on Thursday as revenue dropped, but it continued to fare better than most of its peers across the troubled newspaper industry.

title: McCain and Giuliani Sit on Lenos Couch
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani teamed up with Senator John McCain in a chummy joint appearance on Jay Lenos Tonight Show on Thursday and quickly deflected questions about whether he would ever consider accepting an offer for the vice presidential spot on the Republican ticket.

title: HDTV Shoppers' Survival Guide
description: David Pogue cuts through some of the confusion over HDTV.

title: The Bush Tragedy
description: The Bushes and the Walkers

title: Premium Tornado Package
description: From the Associated Press:

title: Microsoft Makes $44.6 Billion Bid for Yahoo
description: Microsoft said Friday that it would offer $44.6 billion for Yahoo, the ailing search giant. The surprise offer of $31 a share represents a 62 percent premium to Thursdays closing share price. Yahoo shareholders could elect to receive either cash or stock.

title: Fridays Links: Workplace Envy and How to Cure It
description: Every time I read a best places to work story, I start wondering if working for myself is all that I thought it would be. (Before you start scratching your heads, remember that even though you see me here each day at Shifting Careers and often in the pages of the print edition of The Times, I remain a freelancer.)

title: Modern Stone-Age Ads
description: Here are some commercials from the early 1960s (found here) that are so politically incorrect by todays standards you can only laugh. Fred Flintstone and Barney Rubble hawking smokes

title: Too Soon for Gores Current Media?
description: After scoring a Nobel Peace Prize, Al Gore is looking for accolades on Wall Street  namely, that old brass ring known as an initial public offering, TheStreet.coms Kevin Kelleher writes.

title: Russia Creates a $32 Billion Sovereign Wealth Fund
description: Russia has split its oil proceeds into two funds and cleared the way for one to invest in foreign stocks and bonds, officials said Thursday. But actual investments are not expected to begin until fall at the earliest.

title: Microsofts Letter to Yahoo
description: Below, the text of Microsofts letter to the board of directors at Yahoo, proposing to buy the Internet company for $44.6 billion, or about $31 per share in cash and stock.

title: Small Law Firms Big Role in Bundling Mortgages
description: In recent years, as subprime lending proliferated, a small law firm played a big role on Wall Street.

title: The New Online Stock: Web Site Names
description: The notion that names of Web sites can be valuable, cash-generating assets just like stocks, bonds or property  appears to be gaining a broader acceptance that veteran domainers, as they call themselves, are not accustomed to and may not be totally comfortable with.

title: Branson Takes to GreenRoad
description: Clean-tech investors Benchmark Capital and Sir Richard Bransons Virgin Green Fund are wagering that rating a drivers performance can offer a profitable path to improved fuel economy and reduced accidents and carbon dioxide emissions.

title: Calpine Emerges from Bankruptcy
description: Calpine, the giant power producer, emerged from bankruptcy late Thursday after more than two years.

title: Chinalco Teams With Alcoa to Take Stake in Rio Tinto
description: China has muscled in on miner BHP Billitons attempts to buy rival Rio Tinto, with its biggest aluminum producer teaming up with U.S. group Alcoa to buy a 12 percent stake in Rio.

title: SRM Opposes Countrywide Deal
description: SRM Global, the British hedge fund that unsuccessfully sought to block a takeover of troubled British lender Northern Rock, is now taking the fight to Countrywide Financial, signaling its intention to fight the $4 billion takeover by Bank of America.

title: Motorola May Spin Off Cellphone Unit
description: Motorola, it seems, is finally picking up Carl C. Icahns messages.

title: Lone Star Found Guilty by South Korean Court
description: A South Korean court ruled Friday that U.S. private equity group Lone Star Funds and the head of its South Korean unit were guilty of stock price manipulation.

title: Investors Bet on Bidding War for Spains Iberdrola
description: Shares of Iberdrola jumped 6.5 percent Thursday, as rumors of potential offers led to at least one concrete signal of interest in the Spains No. 3 utility, which has a market cap of 49.7 billion euros ($73.6 billion).

title: Merrill to Repay Springfield for C.D.O. Losses
description: Merrill Lynch late yesterday agreed to reimburse Springfield, Mass. for nearly $14 million in losses on risky investments its brokers sold to the struggling city in the southwestern corner of the state.

title: Private Equity Returns Slow in 3rd Quarter
description: Returns on private equity investments across all strategies declined in the third quarter of last year, when the burgeoning credit meltdown began to slow the pace of buyout deals.

title: Glam Said to Raise More Funding
description: Glam, the fashion-themed Web portal and advertising network run by Samir Arora, is raising between $50 million and $100 million in cash, and is expected to finalize the amount soon, VentureBeat reported.

title: More SharePoint-Inspired Deals for Microsoft?
description: Microsoft is staking a meaningful chunk of its future on its applications platform known as SharePoint, as shown by its recent offer to pay $1.2 billion for a Norwegian search firm. What might be next? Analyst firm The 451 Group takes a look at other potential acquisitions in this area.

title: Bain Closes $20 Billon Buyout Fund
description: Buyout shop Bain Capital is putting the finishing touches to its $20 billion global buyout fund in an indication that dealmaking volumes may be set for a comeback after a lean spell.

title: As Suitors Circle, E.U. Warns Against Protecting SocGen
description: As numerous European banks considered whether to make a bid for Socit Gnrale, reeling from a $7.1 billion trading loss, regulators in Brussels warned the French government Thursday against trying to protect the bank from foreign suitors.

title: A Tentative Deal to Salvage Real Estate Empire
description: Harry and William Macklowe, the father-and-son team of real estate developers who doubled the size of their holdings in a $7 billion deal last year, have reached a tentative agreement to give their lender control of all seven Manhattan skyscrapers purchased in the deal, according to The New York Times.

title: Troubled Bond Insurer Puts on Its Defense
description: On Thursday, MBIA fought back.

title: Reader Responses to Dynasty
description: In his request for comments about his Thursday column about political dynasties, Nick asked for examples of nominally democratic governments that had been in the hands of one family. Michael Evenson:

title: Will Yahoo Bid Put AOL in Play?
description: With its potential to redraw the battle lines in the struggle for Internet domination, Microsofts $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo may end up putting other companies in play. High on the list of potential targets is AOL, which is the middle of a turnaround effort by its parent company, Time Warner.

title: Ghouls Gold
description: David Poland, watching as the crows come off the wire to peck at the body of Heath Ledger, wishes them no end of ill.

title: Shameful solitary vices
description: Recently I learned from some veteran Times reporters that they, too, engage in a shameful solitary vice: checking the position of their articles on the most-emailed list. Its a terrible way to judge your work  and you always have to remember that the most-emailed article ever was the one about using animal-training techniques on your husband. But the temptation is irresistible.

title: The Early Word: Roaring Into the Weekend
description: Whew! This has been, undeniably, a busy week. Weve seen the Florida primary, several marquee drop-outs and endorsements, the Reagan Library debate and the first Hillary Rodham Clinton-Barack Obama face-off. Now, could it be  a weekend without a primary?

title: B+ in Beauty Pageants
description: Can it be true? Can the lot of this years cinematic achievers rate no more than a B + in user ratings? Sasha Stone did some forensics on Yahoo Movies user ratings and found out that There Will Be Blood arouses significant feeling for and against, while Juno gets the most love, although even that lovable high-schooler isnt an A student.

title: Very Long Odds
description: Andrew Sarris at the New York Observer is putting his nickels down already. He thinks Ellen Page will sink Julie Christie. And he doubled down, riding with Juno for best pic as well. Then again, Mr. Sarris says The Diving Bell and the Butterfly is the odds-on favorite to win in the foreign-language category. Theres a thought. Except, um, its not nominated.

title: RSVP or RIP?
description: If the Oscars are sacred, the holy of holies, why then cant the people who run them just sit back and wait for the smoke to clear? Thats the question on the mind of Tom ONeil of Gold Derby.

title: Lost
description: Like a lot of folks, the Bagger set aside some quality time last night for the premiere of Lost.
