title: Lenders Who Sold and Left
description: THE Federal Bureau of Investigation said last week that it had opened criminal investigations into 14 companies that played a part in the mortgage boom and bust. While it did not identify the companies on its dance card, the F.B.I. said they included mortgage brokers, lenders, and the Wall Street banks that packaged and sold the securities. Investigators are looking for accounting fraud and possible insider trading at the companies, an F.B.I. spokesman said.

title: Last Exit
description: Brooklyn isnt Greenwich Village, but many writers  established and ascendant  are concentrated in a handful of low-rise neighborhoods there. In Brooklyn Was Mine, a collection of essays edited by Chris Knutsen and Valerie Steiker, some of the boroughs writers ruminate on arrival and domestic survival in this emerging haute bohemia. The jealous ownership implied by the word mine suggests that ( la Walt Whitman) to live in Brooklyn is both to claim possession of a milieu and to be possessed by it. The contributors make the place more sought after and, by a handy symbiosis, the place makes them cool.

title: Letters: The Education of Ben Bernanke
description: Roger Lowensteins article (Jan. 20) was extremely informative about the evolution of Ben Bernankes philosophical and scientific approach to Fed policy. Lowenstein says that when Bernanke took over as Fed chairman, he knew more about central banking than any economist alive. A troubling contradiction arises, however, when Lowenstein asserts that, although Bernanke knew the experience of the 1930s in his sleep, he was, in truth, unfamiliar with the exotic mortgage instruments that were failing now.

The brother, Ariel, had just graduated from college and had been hired by a prestigious financial firm in Midtown. So it was especially chilling last week to hear the agencys former chief counsel, Peter Barton Hutt, tell a Congressional panel that the F.D.A. was barely hanging on by its fingertips.

description: DAKAR, Senegal  A rebel army swarmed the capital of Chad on Saturday, and gun battles erupted around the presidential palace, according to Chadian and Western officials, in an attack that raised the specter of deeper chaos in one the most war-scarred and fragile regions of the world.

title: Correction: Number of Rooms Cant Meet Surging Demand
description: An article on Jan. 20 about rising hotel rates around the world misstated the number of rooms in New York City in a comparison with those in India. The city has about 74,000 hotel rooms  not 100,000, which is the estimated total for India.

title: Leaving Las Vegas
description: Charles Bock, the son of Las Vegas pawnbrokers, spent much of his childhood behind the counter of his parents shop, staring out at desperate adults as they hocked their most precious possessions in hopes of restoring their luck. From the back of the store, he recalls on his Web site, Id watch as the customers exploded and called my parents dirty Jews and cursed at them and threatened them at the top of their lungs. Its impossible in situations like that not to feel for everybody involved  to be horrified, sure, but more than that, to be saddened by the spectacle, to want so much more than that out of life for everyone.

title: Beneath the Bay, a Mystery and Maybe Worse
description: A HALF-CENTURY ago, an ammunition barge broke loose from the U.S.S. Bennington, an aircraft carrier anchored a mile offshore in Gravesend Bay. The barge drifted over to Rockaway Point, but somewhere along the way it overturned, scattering 15,000 live antiaircraft shells, each as long as a mans leg, onto the sea floor.

title: Patriots and Giants Hope to Cap Their Quests With a Win
description: PHOENIX  The New England Patriots path to perfection, it turns out, began at their most imperfect moment.

title: A Reporter Finds Drama in Iraqis Heartbreak
description: ONE of the more poignant moments in Betrayed, George Packers play about a group of Iraqi translators that opens Wednesday at the Culture Project in SoHo, is presented by Intisar, an idealistic young woman employed by the American Embassy in Baghdad.

title: Solar and Relatively Affordable?
description: The In the Region article in Long Island and Manhattan copies last Sunday, about energy-efficient modular homes, misstated the height restrictions on trucks, which deliver the modules to building sites. While these limits vary according to state, none are lower than 13 feet 6 inches. The maximum is not 13 feet.

title: 3 Cheers for the Home Team! (But, Uh, Which One Is It?)
description: Milford

title: My Wired Youth
description: Last month, a PBS documentary called Growing Up Online revealed that kids today create false Internet identities, contend with cyberbullies and visit Web sites that promote anorexia. To my surprise, I felt defensive: the scare phrase growing up online recalled nothing so much as my own shady adolescence 25 years ago, when, because of a quirk of early communications technology, a small group of New Hampshire girls, including me, came of age on a primitive computer network  the Internet before the Internet.

title: Home Is Where Harmony Is
description: DURING her apartment hunt, Catherine Brophy carried with her the essential tool of her trade  a loupan, the traditional feng shui compass.

title: Presidential Race Dividing Some Top State Democrats
description: TRENTON

title: Still a Warehouse Wonderland
description: WHEN Julia Warr, Martin Brierley and their three children moved to Brooklyn from London two and a half years ago, they settled in Cobble Hill, largely because of the local elementary school, Public School 29. So it was with some chagrin that they found out not long ago, on a visit to a friends place, that they were smitten with the friends neighborhood on the south side of Williamsburg.

In a breathtaking spree that lasted little more than a week, the Patriots signed linebacker Adalius Thomas, tight end Kyle Brady and running back Sammy Morris, and traded for receiver Wes Welker. Later, they added receiver Donte Stallworth and, on draft weekend, stunned the league by trading for Randy Moss, who took a pay cut because he wanted to join the Patriots. The team insisted that was not unusual.

title: Bang the Drums Softly
description: MODELS do not as a rule make a lot of noise, being paid to suggest secret realms of sensuality without making a sound. As for making a joyful (or other) sound unto the heavens, well, isnt that what all those rock-star husbands are for?

title: Breadless Baking
description: When you pass through the Prussian-blue door of the Blue Bakery, the first aroma youll notice is likely to be coffee, not bread. Thats because the Blue Bakery brews plenty of joe, as well as half a dozen types of latte, but doesnt bake any bread.

title: The Civic Poet
description: Robert Pinsky has been writing outstanding poems for more than 30 years  Gulf Music is his seventh collection  but youre more likely to know him for his poetry advocacy than for his own examples of the art. Given Pinskys public profile, this is more than understandable; he has served as a highly visible poet laureate of the United States for an unprecedented three terms, founded the acclaimed Favorite Poem Project (and edited or co-edited several resulting anthologies, including Americans Favorite Poems and An Invitation to Poetry), fashioned an eloquent translation of Dantes Inferno, written a regular Poets Choice column for The Washington Post, moderated a Meta-Free-Phor-All on The Colbert Report and read one of his poems during a cameo appearance on The Simpsons. (No token haiku, either! A real live longish poem!) No other living American poet  no other living American, probably  has done so much to put poetry before the public eye.

title: Playing It Safe in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Where the Twain Meet
description: Sunset Park is home to two distinct culinary districts. Eighth Avenue is known as the Chinatown of Brooklyn, while Fifth Avenue has a trove of Mexican restaurants. Whether youre celebrating the Chinese New Year, which starts Thursday, or craving a taco, this neighborhood is worth exploring.

title: Discs Filled With Discoveries
description: COPLAND: PIANO VARIATIONS, PIANO SONATA, PIANO FANTASY

title: Datebook
description: BAGUIO, THE PHILIPPINES

title: Evangelicals a Liberal Can Love
description: At a New York or Los Angeles cocktail party, few would dare make a pejorative comment about Barack Obamas race or Hillary Clintons sex. Yet it would be easy to get away with deriding Mike Huckabees religious faith.

title: A Store Where Profit Comes Not in Dollars
description: AT a small high-end childrens clothing and toy store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, shirts for infants go for as much as $40 and sweaters for toddlers to first graders cost $40 to $70. But many parents in the area are well off and accustomed to paying those prices, according to the stores operator, Marjorie Stern.

title: Will 6 Be a Lucky Number for Halston?
description: NEVER have so many people gone to a mountain. Tomorrow, at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea, Marco Zanini will present his first collection for Halston. Mr. Zanini, 35, is the sixth designer to put his name behind Halston, which has had at least eight owners in the 35 years since Roy Halston Frowick sold his own name to Norton Simon. Thats a lot of believers.

title: Childhood, Interrupted
description: When poets or novelists write the story of their youth, the plot turns in a circle: they tell the story of the making of the mind of the writer who wrote the book. But this means that, while the writers memoir involves remembrance and return, it also involves development and departure. The story is about getting away from the past as well as going back to it.

title: Correction: Hip-Hops Newest Faces: Indie, Fierce and Female
description: An article last Sunday about female rappers misidentified the member of the hip-hop duo Yo Majesty who married and then divorced a male Christian missionary. She is LaShunda Flowers  not Jewel Baynham, the other rapper.

title: Letters: Kilimanjaro Memories
description: To the Editor: I was dismayed to learn from your article on Kilimanjaro, "On Africas Roof, Still Crowned With Snow" (Jan. 20), that a veritable ants-trail of tourists climb my mountain each year. When I climbed it in 1961, my group met only three other parties in five days, and our guide refused to take us beyond Leopard Point on the rim of the crater around to the actual summit, then still called Kaiser-Wilhelm-Spitze, because the snow was too deep and dangerous!

title: Ex-Prosecutors Question Handling of Spying Case
description: PHOENIX  When the N.F.L. investigated spying charges against the New England Patriots, it asked for evidence gathered by the New England Patriots.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Notice Nagging Problems? Here Are Solutions
description: CLUTCH problems on 2007 Nissan 350Zs and moaning Acuras are among this months roundup of technical service bulletins.

title: Antonia Phillips and Peter Hommeyer
description: Antonia McGowan Phillips and Peter Bertram Hoagland Hommeyer were married on Saturday evening at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: In Summer, Hitting the Books, Not Just the Beach
description: WHEN Jeremy Grant of Roslyn, N.Y., was 16, he decided not to return for another summer of sleep-away camp, opting instead for a precollege program at U.C.L.A. In the mornings he took courses in SAT prep and public speaking; in the afternoons he hopped on a van to the beach, a museum, or a TV game show.

title: Still Readable
description: To the Editor:

title: Prediction: Burresss Projection Wont Hurt
description: Phoenix

title: Robber Kills 5 Women at Store in Chicago Suburb
description: TINLEY PARK, Ill.  The authorities in this suburb southwest of Chicago were engaged in a huge search on Saturday evening for a man they say shot and killed five women in a clothing store during a robbery attempt gone wrong.

title: Lucy Demerjian, Joseph Flynn
description: Dr. Lucy Elizabeth Demerjian and Joseph Daniel Flynn were married on Saturday at St. Margaret of Antioch Church in Pearl River, N.Y. Msgr. John J. OKeefe, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: As Corzine Lines Up Allies for Toll Plan, Republicans Push Back
description: TRENTON  Schering-Plough, Verizon and the Atlantic City casinos.

title: Correction: For Strikers, the Agony of Spare Time
description: An article and picture caption last week about the ways that striking writers are filling their time misidentified the location in California of a Bobs Big Boy where an anonymous celebrity benefactor has offered to pick up the tab for any card-carrying writer. The restaurant is in Burbank, Calif., not Toluca Lake.
The season opener, a 38-14 victory over the Jets, made it clear that Robert K. Kraft need not have waited. Tom Brady completed 22 of 28 passes, 9 of them for 183 yards to Moss.

title: Beaten Down, and Not Only by Nature
description: The Living In article last Sunday, about Far Rockaway, Queens, referred incorrectly to the affordability of Ocean Park Apartments. The complex is now part of the federal low-income housing tax credit program, so its apartments will stay affordable for 40 more years. It has not lost its affordable units.

title: A Director With a Bent for the Visceral
description: Columbus, Ohio

title: 16 Ways of Looking at a Female Voter
description: 1. The Female Thing

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 38 of The Times Magazine this weekend about voting patterns among women refers incorrectly to the questions in a Norman Lear Center/Zogby International poll used to help discern those patterns. Respondents were asked to indicate their degree of agreement with certain statements; the questions were not true-or-false or open-ended. (Go to Article)

title: Offering New Roles to Wounded Marines
description: SAN DIEGO  Two marines enter the Iraqi village and take aim.

title: Obama Seldom Asks His Pollster to Play the Role of an Oracle
description: AS a key pollster for Senator Barack Obamas presidential campaign, Joel Benenson has a job that would typically make him one of the most sought-after voices in the candidates inner circle. But that status depends on who the candidate is.

title: How Democracy Produced a Monster
description: Sheffield, England

title: As Knicks Fall Again on Road, Robinson Loses in Hometown
description: SEATTLE  It took Nate Robinson two years to make it back to his hometown, to play in front of his friends and relatives and to strut through the arena the way he once did here in high school and college.

title: Working to Resettle Iraqi Allies at Risk
description: Three groups trying to help Iraqi employees and contractors are Human Rights First (humanrightsfirst.org), which does legal work for Iraqi refugees; Refugees International (refugeesinternational.org), the main advocacy group on the issue; and the List Project (thelistproject.org), a nonprofit group that has collected the names of more than 1,000 Iraqis who worked for American agencies in Iraq and are now trying to move to the United States.

title: Eureka! It Really Takes Years of Hard Work
description: WEVE all heard the tales of the apple falling on Newtons head and Archimedes leaping naked from his bath shrieking Eureka! Many of us have even heard that eBay was created by a guy who realized that he could help his fiance sell Pez dispensers online.

title: Here Come the Babies. There Go the Jackhammers.
description: JACOB GOLDSTEIN, the longtime chairman of Community Board 9 and the unofficial mayor of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was driving his little red Ford Contour through the neighborhood the other day, honking at acquaintances. Several times on every block, he braked and gestured at a newly risen, salmon-colored apartment building, or a plywood fence protecting a construction site.

title: Correction: When Icons Die Young
description: An article last Sunday about the ways in which successive generations have mourned the deaths of young celebrities referred imprecisely to those saddened by the death of the actor James Dean in 1955. Those who mourned, in general, were young people whose generation had not been given a name; they were not baby boomers. (A generally accepted definition of the baby boom generation dates its start to 1946, meaning many baby boomers were not yet born at the time of his death or would have been too young to appreciate its significance.)

title: The Party Animal Either Plays Well or Fights Well
description: SOMETIMES the simplest of arguments can reveal the deepest of divisions. Take the dispute between Senator Barack Obama and the Clintons over the legacy of Ronald Reagan. The episode began in Reno, Nev., you will recall, when Mr. Obama told an editorial board that Mr. Reagan was a president of ideas who had moved the countrys politics. His ideas werent necessarily good ideas, as Mr. Obama framed it, but they were transformative.

title: Letters: A Breckenridge Problem
description: To the Editor: Your 36 Hours column on Breckenridge, Colo. (Jan. 20), reminded me of my stay there a few years ago.

title: Dibs on a Junker
description: Dibs on a Junker

title: A Fine Romance, My Friend, This Is
description: IT might be Kate Hudson, or maybe Mandy Moore, or possibly Rachel Weisz, Lindsay Lohan or a Jennifer. (Lopez? Aniston? Garner?) But if its February, you can be pretty sure that some pretty, plucky actress will be traipsing around some glamorous and photogenic American city (or its Canadian double) in search of the dimple-chinned fellow who embodies her one true love.

title: Boomtown Builds Its Future on the Business of Sports
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Jeff Feagles, the punter for the Giants, grew up in the Phoenix area and remembers the suburb of Glendale as out in the boonies, a farming town northwest of the city that was really, really far away and filled with cotton fields.

title: Perfect Would Not Mean Most Dominant
description: If the New England Patriots complete an unprecedented 19-0 sweep of the regular schedule and the Super Bowl XLII playoffs Sunday night, they will deserve to be hailed as the best one-season team in N.F.L. history. But as a dynasty, the House of Belichick will still trail the Vince Lombardi Packers of the 60s and the Chuck Noll Steelers of the 70s.

title: Beyond the Point Spread: Super Bowl Science
description: FARMINGDALE

title: Where Money Doesnt Talk
description: ON the corner of Fulton Street and Bedford Avenue stands the red-brick building that houses Rent-a-Center, a national chain store that tempts low-income, credit-challenged customers with a range of slightly worn couch sets, scuffed refrigerators and consumer electronics, among which television sets were a prime attraction last week.

title: For Jewish Voters in New York, Almost an Embarrassment of Riches
description: The notion that New Yorks Jewish electorate can be easily characterized has long been debated. But the looming primary election on Tuesday is raising new speculation about how strongly Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama will appeal to Jewish Democrats.

title: Santana Deal Took Intense Negotiating
description: It was nearing 5 p.m. on Friday, when the Mets 72-hour window to sign the star left-hander Johan Santana was to expire, and they had improved what had been their take-it-or-leave-it proposal. But that was not good enough for Santana, and he said so  in person. At the Mets request, he had flown to New York from his home in Florida, and he was sitting in a room with his agent, Peter Greenberg, and the Mets senior executive vice president, Jeff Wilpon, when he rejected it.

title: The Fixer
description: AS a child growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Robert Holt Jr. thought that the mysterious gray machines rolled into his school for Election Day looked like coffins. Now, as one of 21 repairmen in the place where Brooklyns voting machines are fixed, he has developed a certain amount of affection for the hulking contraptions.

title: Patriots Deny Another Accusation of Taping
description: PHOENIX  The N.F.L. investigated rumors last year that the New England Patriots had videotaped the final walk-through by the St. Louis Rams before the 2002 Super Bowl and found no evidence that the taping had occurred, the league said Saturday. The Patriots told the N.F.L. that the rumor was not true and on Saturday denied a report in The Boston Herald that quoted an unnamed source saying the taping had occurred.

title: Delta Gets Help in Bolstering Its Wine List
description: Delta is getting serious about wine. The airline recently brought on board the wine educator and author Andrea Robinson, one of 15 women in the world who have been awarded a master sommelier diploma by the Court of Master Sommeliers, to reconfigure its wine list for its BusinessElite international service starting this month. Later this year, Ms. Robinson will also make wine selections for its international coach and domestic first and coach classes.

title: Patricia Whitby and David Irwin
description: Patricia Dawn Whitby and David Horandt Irwin were married Saturday at their home in Deephaven, Minn. The Rev. Timothy Johnson, a Lutheran minister, officiated. On Feb. 14, a second ceremony is to be performed by the Rev. Charles Vere Nicoll at St. Bartholomews Anglican Church in Gustavia, St. Barts.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Rock Around the Block
description: ROCK musics past and its present live side by side in New York, though the line that splits the two is porous. When it closed in 2006, CBGB, on the Bowery  to many the birthplace of punk  seeped into the past. And when the 80s rock group Duran Duran played the Hammerstein Ballroom last June, you might say they seeped back into the present, however briefly.

title: Other Peoples Money
description: Eight years ago, American liberalism split sharply in two over the Clinton economic record. The larger, more moderate faction deemed the departing administration to have done an exemplary job  or at least a credible effort with a weak political hand  shepherding economic growth and social justice. But a smaller, more populist faction recoiled at policies that sat comfortably with corporate America and allowed the very rich to pull farther away from the middle class. Ultimately, that populist critique became the basis of Ralph Naders 2000 presidential campaign, which polled in the mid- to high single digits before settling at a lower, but still decisive, 2.74 percent of the vote.

title: To Pull a Thorn From the Side of the Planet
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.

title: For Many Jets Fans, Super Sunday in Name Only
description: Not since Joe Namath made good on his guarantee to beat the Baltimore Colts in 1969 have the Jets been back to the Super Bowl. The players continually change, so the wait may be harder on longtime Jets fans who have endured two victories in three Super Bowl appearances by the rival Giants.

title: Letters: Consumer Man
description: I could relate to Paul Mecurios Lives column (Jan. 13). I was consumer woman before my daughter changed my life.

title: Perfection Is Afterthought, Perfect Examples Say
description: PHOENIX  The 18-0 New England Patriots take the field Sunday for Super Bowl XLII seeking perfection and a place in sports history. But those who have already tread the path to a flawless sports achievement say that finding perfection and fame will be the farthest thing from the Patriots minds.

title: Candidates Scrambling in States About to Vote
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The presidential campaign played to new audiences on Saturday as the leading Democratic and Republican candidates fanned out across the nation, drawing distinctions with their rivals and making urgent appeals to voters in delegate-rich or politically symbolic states.

title: In Praise of the Decisive C.E.O.
description: DURING this season of economic alarm and political choice, Judgment (Portfolio, $26.95), by Noel M. Tichy and Warren G. Bennis, could not be more timely. Americans live in a democracy, cherish checks and balances, and remain skeptical of concentrated power. But many also seem to hope for a savior-leader  whether in the form of a United States president, a Fed chairman or a corporate titan.

title: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
description: FORGET the issues.

title: A Bold Step to Capture an Elusive Gas Falters
description: CAPTURING heat-trapping emissions from coal-fired power plants is on nearly every climate experts menu for a planet whose inhabitants all want a plugged-in lifestyle.

title: Voting Will Reflect Republican Retirements
description: CHICAGO  Voters in Illinois on Tuesday will begin the process of filling three Republican seats in the House of Representatives that are up for grabs, just one states slice of a broader pattern of Republican retirements across the nation.

title: Amo, Amas, Amuse
description: Not only does Latin train the mind; it also polishes the manners. So you might think from the tone of rueful apology that Harry Mount sometimes adopts in Carpe Diem, his chatty Latin primer: The annoying thing is that theres no real way round needing to know adjectives, he writes, before hitting the reader with some pretty relentless tables of declensions. Its hard to imagine anyone ambivalent about adjectives tackling a book on Latin, but if one does, hell be reassured.

title: Partisans and Progressives
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction:  No Room at the Lot and Late at the Gate
description: Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on Jan. 20 about airport parking misstated the number of airports served by AirportParkingReservations.com, which allows travelers to reserve parking spots through the Web site. It is more than 65, not 200. (The service does offer reservations at more than 200 lots at those airports.)

title: Candidates Feel the Lure of Celebrity Cash
description: They make their fortunes engineering the worlds biggest deals or making hearts swoon in movie houses and concert halls. But inside their storied prewar East Side town houses and palatial downtown lofts, members of the citys power elite are grappling with the same question as the rest of the nation: Who should next occupy the White House?
The Patriots returned to form in the playoffs, routinely dispatching the Jaguars and the Chargers.

title: Trim and Ready to Rumble
description: TESTED 2008 Lamborghini Gallardo Superleggera.

title: Feisty Flyers Get Better and Meaner
description: Last season, the Philadelphia Flyers finished last in the N.H.L. with the worst record in their 40-year history. But this season, they have been first among the turnaround teams.

title: Asian Horror Films: Whos Inspiring Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Passengers on Amtrak Are Stranded in Mountains
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)  Dozens of passengers were stranded on a train in the Sierra Nevada on Saturday after a large snowplow fell through the tracks and blocked the railroad, officials said.

title: Yahoo Sale Could Be Bad for Minnows
description: SAN FRANCISCO  FOR decades, Silicon Valley has been the land of eternal optimism and high anxiety, traits that pitch into overdrive anytime a seismic business event washes across the corporate and entrepreneurial landscape here  like, for example, Microsofts blockbuster $45 billion bid for Yahoo on Friday.

title: What Money Can Buy: Help With Achieving a Self-Sufficient Life
description: Every day, Neediest Cases articles offer glimpses into the lives of New Yorks poor. Often, the subjects have recently survived a crisis  or are still in one  and their futures seem uncertain at best. Revisiting three cases from the 2005-6 campaign shows how timely assistance, and the continuing support of the seven agencies that are the beneficiaries of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, have turned lives around.

title: Up Front
description: Like Susan Sontag, Katie Roiphe is no stranger to polemic. Her first book, The Morning After: Sex, Fear, and Feminism on Campus, a critique of the gender wars, was published in 1993, when she was in her early 20s. It drew both intense criticism and comparisons to Mary McCarthy. Roiphe  her mother is the novelist Anne Roiphe  most recently wrote Uncommon Arrangements, about literary marriages in early-20th-century London.

title: All Eyes Are Focused on Beijing Olympics
description: This is only February, and six months remain before the Beijing Olympics, but many elite track and field athletes are already establishing their Olympic credentials or trying and not succeeding.

title: A Track in the Snow
description: A couple of weeks ago, when the snow was at its deepest, I walked up the hill in the middle pasture after chores. By that time in the afternoon, I am often trudging through my thoughts, barely noticing anything around me. Part of the pleasure of chores is that they happen in the same light every day, though the hour changes as the days lengthen and contract. No matter what Im doing, I am propelled outside by the falling light, which means that Im often doing chores mid-paragraph. I imagine that the animals are mid-paragraph too, for we are all just going about our business together.

title: Betting on Cuisine to Marginalize Crime
description: Usually, it is the harsh yellow of the crime scene tape that catches the eye, its cold, crisp snap in the wind a universally understood sign of recent unpleasantness.

title: Great Literature? Depends Whodunit
description: IN a British court recently, an author said, in effect, that glue-sniffing had made her write a thriller. The author, Joan Brady, is a 68-year-old American who has lived in England for the last several decades and in 1993 became the first woman to win the Whitbread book prize. She received a 115,000 out-of-court settlement after arguing that fumes from the glue and solvents used in the Conker shoe factory next door to her home in Totnes had poisoned the air and made her sick. She suffered nerve damage, she said, and a loss of concentration that caused her to abandon the literary novel she was working on, Cool Wind From the Future, and instead crank out a potboiler called Bleedout.

title: 1972 Dolphins: Undefeated on Field, Undeterred Off It
description: MIAMI  Dick Anderson made $38,000 as a Pro Bowl strong safety for the Dolphins in 1972, but that was only part of his income. He started an insurance agency five years earlier and would sometimes return calls to clients before or after practices.

title: The Headlock That Won for the Giants
description: MOM crushed indoor horseplay. If my brother Rory and I started in, Mom yelled once. If we continued wrestling, shed throw things. If we kept it up, shed hurl us into the hallway outside our apartment in Yorkville and not let us back in till she felt like it. How much time we spent there depended on her mood and the neighbors complaints.

title: My Birthday Wish: Not Burdening Our Children
description: ITS official. As of today, at 6 a.m., I am a half-century old. Special thanks go to my mom for bringing me into the world back in 1958 and for looking after me all these years. But she doesnt need to worry about me anymore. My welfare now falls within the mission statement of AARP.

title: Francos Monuments: Healing War Wounds
description: To the Editor:

title: J. B. Smoove: True to Character
description: To the Editor:

title: A Foundation in the Classics
description: IN the contemporary landscape of architecture, someone like Richard Sammons doesnt get lionized by the fledgling and impressionable (and constantly blogging) designerati. That might be because his firm, Fairfax & Sammons, which he owns with his wife, Anne Fairfax, specializes in traditional architecture.

title: Sunnis Say Law Opening Jobs to Ex-Baathists Would Do More Harm Than Good
description: BAGHDAD  Top Sunni politicians say they are trying to stop final approval of legislation that they now believe would hurt Sunnis chances of holding government jobs, rather than helping them get more posts in the Shiite-led government.

title: Yes, a Giant Can Sprint
description: FOR investors, the idea that a German industrial giant could also be a nimble stock market star might seem far-fetched, if not outright delusional. Indeed, the very concept of anything nimble and industrial might seem an oxymoron, whether Teutonic or American.

title: Editors Choice
description: THIS REPUBLIC OF SUFFERING: Death and the American Civil War, by Drew Gilpin Faust. (Knopf, $27.95.) The lasting but little-understood impact of the wars immense loss of life is the subject of this extraordinary account by Faust, who is president of Harvard.

title: Soap Opera
description: Just as one Ring Cycle may be enough for some operagoers, one book recounting the Wagner family saga probably suffices for many readers. Certainly, by now, the most distasteful aspects of the story  the familys association with German nationalism, anti-Semitism and, eventually, the Fhrer himself  are well known. Yet, with some archives still under lock and key, more dark secrets can be expected to emerge.

title: A Statesman Without Borders
description: Bernard Kouchner, the foreign minister of France, has urged his countrys ambassadors to engage in diplomacy in motion. Kouchner, who established the organization Mdecins Sans Frontires 37 years ago; has had four or five careers since then; has often polled as the most popular politician in France; has written a dozen or so books; and once contemplated running for president of France, is himself the chief practitioner of this aerobic statecraft. So it was that at 6 a.m. on New Years Day, he and a few staff members gathered in the courtyard of the Quai dOrsay, the headquarters of the foreign ministry, to drive to the airport for an overnight trip to Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan. The goal, Kouchner explained, was to bear witness to the solidarity of the French people with the family of the former prime minister Benazir Bhutto, murdered the week before, and with democratic forces in Pakistan.

title: A Clearer Picture on Voter ID
description: THIS is a major election year. Unfortunately, our two major political parties  Democratic and Republican  continue to disagree on some of the rules that apply to the administration of our elections. This divide is perhaps most contentious when the issue becomes one of whether voters should present photo identification to vote.

title: On the Trail of an Urban Nomad
description: THATS not the phone book that Keira Naughton has to recite at the beginning of Hunting and Gathering, but its pretty close.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 4: Alison

title: Who Pays the Most Taxes?
description: A TAX collectors tour of Manhattan might rightfully begin in front of the neo-Georgian town house on East 63rd Street with stately stone pillars and a bowed brick front, a large flagpole protruding from a fourth-floor terrace. Once a private club and later a Catholic school, it is now the home of Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire who made his fortune buying up troubled companies.

title: Waiting for It
description: For writers, few steps in the publishing process are as strange as the state of suspended animation between submitting a manuscript and seeing the book appear in stores. The sudden change in cabin pressure from writing to waiting can be jarring  and can last a very long time. It comes as a huge shock when it happens the first time, said the Irish writer Colm Toibin, whose first novel, The South, appeared in 1990, a year and a half after he turned it in. It was all slow and strange.

title: Beyond the Point Spread: Super Bowl Science
description: TELL me, why do they use Roman numerals to count the Super Bowls  like, Super Bowl X-L-I-I instead of just saying 42  why is that? said John Sanford, 61, sitting Tuesday afternoon at the J Two Lounge, a bar in a strip mall in Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Running Through the Cholesterol Maze
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate Investing, Made Easier Online
description: IT wasnt long ago that finding commercial property, especially for the neophyte investor, meant traveling by car or plane to various sites  with measuring tools, notepads and camera in tow  then pounding the pavement to inspect comparable places, vet tenants or peruse town hall documents. Newspapers and trade publications were also routinely scoured.

title: Clean Look
description: Tide

Philadelphia showed the Patriots unexpected defenses and provided a blueprint for beating them: pressure Tom Brady and run the ball. Although the Eagles lost, they were the first of two opponents to give the Patriots a scare.

title: An Open and Shut Marriage
description: AT an upscale pub in our small Northwestern town, one of the mothers seated around our table made an indissoluble confession: she told us she had been having a very serious crush on a man who was not her husband. She said the crush bothered her. Besides making her feel guilty, it also made her unsure of the status of her marriage. As she spoke, red blotches formed around her neck.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday in the Evening Hours column misspelled the surname of a guest at the Quadrille Ball of the Germanistic Society of America on Jan. 19. She is Julia Yale, not Gale.

title: A Budget Package for Seeing Iceland
description: If youve been wanting to see the fjords, waterfalls and hot springs of Iceland, but have been daunted by the cost  even more expensive than Britain  then check out a self-driven itinerary called Iceland on a Budget. The nine-day trip, which was put together by the travel company Iceland Experience (www.iceland-experience.com; click on Independent Tours), includes a rental car, lodging in guesthouses with shared baths and daily breakfasts.

title: Sean Yseult and Chris Lee
description: IF there is one law of social physics in New Orleans, it is that after first meeting someone, you will cross paths again within weeks. It was this certainty that gave hope to the rock musicians Sean Yseult and Chris Lee.

title: He Got His Workshop, She Got Her Privacy
description: WHEN Alan and Helene Ferris decided 16 years ago to move from their longtime home in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., they had some strict requirements.

title: In Miami, the Beach Party Moves Indoors
description: THE art and cocktail bacchanal known as Art Basel Miami Beach was still three months away, but that didnt stop a hundred artists and their hangers-on from cramming into a raw and unoccupied restaurant in Miamis Design District last fall. Glasses of Red Bull and vodka flowed freely. A noise band, armed with electric guitars and homemade synthesizers, jammed so loudly that it seemed to disturb the entire neighborhood. A gang of fresh-faced artists in tight T-shirts and worn-out jeans suspended a six-foot-long digital timer from the ceiling that counted down the milliseconds left in the party.

title: Rebecca Adamus and Kaustuv Basu
description: Rebecca Paige Adamus and Kaustuv Basu are to be married Sunday at the Crowne Plaza resort in Melbourne, Fla. The Rev. Francis X. Metzbower, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate at a nondenominational ceremony.

title: A Tale of the Velvet Rope
description: IN early February every winter, Bryant Park becomes a tangle of pulsing white tents and the buzzing apparatus that provides them with heat and light so that the glories of Fashion Week, which this year began on Friday, can go on display.

title: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
description: FORGET the issues.

title: Detox for the Camera. Doctors Order!
description: ON the first episode of the VH1 reality series Celebrity Rehab With Dr. Drew, Jeff Conaway arrives for in-patient treatment at the Pasadena Recovery Center in California slumped over in the passenger seat of a car, caressing an open bottle of Dom Prignon. The actor, who starred in the television show Taxi and the movie Grease, describes himself as loaded, for which he blames people who, the night before, accused him of being an addict.

title: Trying to Clear Fog From Pension Plans
description: NEW pension rules being phased in this year may make some employees curious about the financial health of their pension plans  but its still hard to get enough information to make an intelligent judgment.

title: True Believers Rally Campaign Troops
description: MOST likely, youve never heard of them.

title: Preconceptions Defied
description: NO one in my family had gone to college. My mom finished high school. My father was a pipe fitter who completed 10th grade. He injured his back and shoulders on the job and retired on disability. They had saved a small amount for my college education. I thought I would go to a state university or junior college to stretch out the money.

title: Coaches Will Have Extra Time on Their Hands
description: PHOENIX  At halftime of a regular-season game, teams have 12 minutes to get to the locker room, use the restroom, get a drink or a bite to eat, get an injury checked, make game-plan adjustments, collect thoughts, hear a quick motivational speech and run back to the field.

title: Under Wintry Skies, a City Revealed
description: CALL it the travel equivalent of contrarian investing: Prague, a famously beautiful city in spring, summer and fall, can yield big dividends for travelers in the winter off-season. Teeming crowds? Gone. Prices? Much lower. Overbooked hotels? Not for now. Picturesque spires and cobblestone lanes? With a gentle dusting of snow, perhaps even more so.

title: A Water Park With a View
description: Last Friday, a water park with 362,080 gallons worth of rapids, waves and pools had its official opening on the grounds of El Conquistador Resort and Golden Door Spa in Puerto Rico (www.elconresort.com).

title: Long Islands Political Leaders Regroup as Landscape Shifts
description: UNTIL last Wednesday, Long Islands political leaders had declared this to be Hillary and Rudy country. But with Rudolph W. Giulianis departure from the campaign last week and now a one-on-one contest between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama, the political landscape is shifting as voters head to the polls on Tuesday.

title: Google Assails Microsofts Bid for Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said Sunday that Microsofts proposed $44.6 billion takeover of Yahoo could pose a number of potential threats to competition that need to be examined by policymakers around the world.

title: Argentina Rises, Minus Its Swagger
description: RIO DE JANEIRO

title: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
description: FAIRFIELD

title: The Magic of the Alimar, Airlifting Paris to New York
description: Q I am intrigued with the apartment building on the northwest corner of 105th Street and West End Avenue. It looks as if it should be in Paris. Any enlightenment would be appreciated. ... Robert Trenta, Manhattan

title: Kill the Cats, but Keep the Career
description: FOR sketch comedy fans the 90s were nothing short of a renaissance, thanks in no small part to the pioneering efforts of Michael Showalter. While troupes like Kids in the Hall, from Toronto, and Upright Citizens Brigade, from Chicago, hit pay dirt with their own acclaimed television shows, amassing legions of fans along the way, The State on MTV, adapted from the New York University improv group of the same name, was probably the periods most groundbreaking.

title: A Frail Economy Raises Pressure on Irans Rulers
description: TEHRAN  In one of the coldest winters Iranians have experienced in recent memory, the government is failing to provide natural gas to tens of thousands of people across the country, leaving some for days or even weeks with no heat at all. Here in the capital, rolling blackouts every night for a month have left people without electricity, and heat, for hours at a time.

title: How Are the Bees of Winter? Doing Fine, Sticking Together
description: An article last Sunday about bees in winter misstated the position held by Howland Blackiston. He is a former president of the Back Yard Beekeepers Association and a member of its advisory board. (David Blocher of Redding is the groups current president.)

title: In the Ruins of Ice Dams, Splendor
description: IT is at the edges of a house that damage often creeps in  the rotted sills, the cracked stone steps, the crumbled bricks of the chimney. In winter, though, you are most likely to find it at the edge of the roof. That was where we found it last winter, coming in as ruin so often does, quietly, without announcing itself, escaping our notice until the wreckage was nearly complete. In this case, we noticed not a torrent of water but streaks on the wall, the more subtle stains and drips that proved once again that Abstract Expressionism is winters given art form.

title: The Changing Room
description: THE FIRST TIME I walked into an N.F.L. locker room  the locker room of the New York Giants, as it happens  I was shocked by how little effort went into making me feel as if I didnt belong. Id grown used to baseball locker rooms, where the players edginess made outsiders feel instantly unwelcome and rendered useful human interaction all but impossible. In their private sanctums, baseball players behave as if someone might walk in at any moment and ask them to leave; theyre a bit like starving dogs who have just stumbled upon a slab of raw meat. Not all of them, of course  the effect is atmospheric, produced by the sum of the personalities. Give 25 professional baseball players a place to call their own and they give it a forbidding name: clubhouse. If you arent a member, you dont belong.

title: Robin Rosenthal and Richard Rothfeld
description: Robin Marci Rosenthal, the daughter of Sandra Rosenthal and the stepdaughter of Charles Rosenthal of Woodbury, N.Y., was married in the Bahamas on Saturday to Richard Z. Rothfeld, the son of Harriet Rothfeld and Eric A. Rothfeld of New York. Melvin Grant, a justice of the peace and marriage officer for the Bahamas, officiated at the One & Only Ocean Club on Paradise Island, at a ceremony led by Rabbi Yaakov Nerenberg.

title: A Head Start on Head Start
description: BRENTWOOD, N.Y.

title: A Lengthy Journey, Nowhere Near Over
description: THOUGH the chemistry of any happy relationship is hard to define, there are tangible elements behind the success of the diminutive Chinese conductor Xian Zhang at the New York Philharmonic and elsewhere. Her incisive gestures elicit vivid performances from musicians who have seen it all, and her passionate musicality reflects the boundless energy that has propelled her improbable journey from a small town in China to the Philharmonic, where, as associate conductor, she is a rising star.

title: Seller Beware
description: Seller Beware

title: A Wild Ramble, Near the Golden Gate
description: MARIN COUNTY, just north of San Francisco, cradles wealthy bedroom communities in picturesque bays. But nearly half of the countys 520 square miles is protected open space  bucolic and wild, its tiny towns separated by forested mountains.

title: A Miracle Indeed
description: If William Gibsons 1959 play The Miracle Worker were a made-for-television after-school special, it would probably end with a postscript, suitably accompanied by swelling strings, informing viewers just why Helen Keller became such a household name during the first half of the 20th century.

title: Belmondo, Bond and Now Kerviel
description: France has always had a soft spot for the lawbreaker, from Jean Valjean in Les Misrables to Jean-Paul Belmondo in Breathless. Now Jrme Kerviel, the trader who cost Socit Gnrale more than $7 billion, has attracted a fan club of his own.

title: Radio Days
description: COLER-GOLDWATER, a public long-term care hospital on Roosevelt Island, is a world unto itself. There are chapels for the faithful, a Subway fast-food restaurant, smoking lounges and a small gift store that sells items like soda, chips and stuffed animals.

title: Home Prices Start to Dip, Recalling 90s Slump
description: For homeowners in the metropolitan area, all of the talk in the past year about a real estate collapse may have sounded as foreign as a Bollywood musical.

title: For Ruby Dee at 83, Acclaim and Performances
description: A MONTH of awards ceremonies began triumphantly last Sunday for Ruby Dee, who won the Screen Actors Guilds Award for best supporting actress for her role in the Denzel Washington film American Gangster.

title: Chug-a-Lug Contest: A High Profile Comes at a High Price
description: Long Beach, Calif.

title: Where Soldiers Slept, a Cultural Enclave Rises
description: BY 9 p.m.  early according to the neighborhoods standards  a lively crowd had already gathered in the courtyard of Metelkova City, a compound of former military barracks in the heart of Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia. Variously attired as neo-Goths and punk rockers, many in the crowd were nursing cigarettes and drinks as they stood amid the sculptures and murals, waiting for the evenings activities to begin.

title: In Football and Politics, Connecticut Is Betwixt and Between
description: WOODBURY, Conn.

title: Coming to America
description: It is hard to imagine where American culture would be today without the contributions of Hitler and Stalin  that is, without the thousands of creatively gifted refugees who fled these murderers. A good many cultural historians and writers have explored this meaty subject from different angles since Anthony Heilbuts 1983 landmark, Exiled in Paradise (still the best book on the topic). And now, in Artists in Exile, Joseph Horowitz has taken a crack at it.

title: An Older Woman Bursts Into a Bedroom ...
description: Elizabeth Ashley can do almost no wrong. Michael Wilson, Hartford Stages artistic director, has directed her before, and things have gone well. So I am going to have to blame the material for the disappointment that is their latest collaboration. That is Zerlines Tale, the stolid one-act drama in which Ms. Ashley is currently starring.

title: The House That Whimsy Built
description: AT Seventh Avenue and Second Street, on a prime corner in the heart of Park Slope, stands an abandoned brownstone whose state of disrepair has been a source of local speculation for years.

title: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
description: NEVER mind that the race for the presidential nomination in both parties was still as rich and compelling  not to mention wide open  as it has been in memory. Never mind that the field of candidates was deep and diverse and that voters interviewed here in Union County would be called upon to cast their lot for one of them earlier in the race than ever before.

title: Nuclear Leaks and Response Tested Obama in Senate
description: When residents in Illinois voiced outrage two years ago upon learning that the Exelon Corporation had not disclosed radioactive leaks at one of its nuclear plants, the states freshman senator, Barack Obama, took up their cause.

The first half of the season seemed part showcase for the Patriots new offensive threats and part puzzle: why would this team bother to cheat? The Patriots pulverized their opponents, winning games by pinball margins: 38-7, 34-13, 48-27  against the Cowboys, the best the National Football Conference had to offer then  52-7, 56-10. Only the Colts, their most talented opponent, gave the Patriots a game before falling, 24-20.

title: Hamas and Egypt to Work on Sealing Gaza Border
description: JERUSALEM  Hamas said Saturday that it would cooperate with Egypt to close the breached border between Egypt and the Gaza Strip on Sunday.

title: New Jersey Guidelines Allow Unaffiliated Voters to Participate in Primaries
description: Even though the majority of New Jerseys registered voters are not affiliated with any political party, state election guidelines allow them to participate in the presidential primaries on Tuesday.

title: A Tenant Wants a Lease for More Than One Year
description: Q I have had a rent-stabilized lease since 1989. It is now up for renewal, and the landlord is offering to extend it for only a year. I would prefer to have a two-year or even a three-year lease. Isnt the landlord required to offer a multiyear lease?

title: Congresswoman Collapses at a Clinton Rally
description: United States Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester, collapsed on Saturday afternoon during a campaign rally for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in White Plains. Ms. Lowey, who was conscious and joked that she had gotten too excited, was taken away on a stretcher to a hospital.

title: Placing Family First Hasnt Held Childrens Author Back
description: TRUMBULL

title: The F.D.A. in Crisis: Another Danger Made in China
description: The F.D.A.  and American consumers  got another warning last week about the need for vigilant monitoring of imported drugs from the developing world, especially from China. The contamination of a drug used to treat Chinese leukemia patients should also raise alarms at multinational pharmaceutical companies that plan to outsource manufacturing to China.

title: Number of Homes Using Wood-Fired Boilers and Wood Stoves Rises
description: FOR three decades, Robin Norton of Bethany, Conn., heated her 2,000-square-foot home the way many people do: by burning oil. In 2004, though, fed up with the $1,200 annual bill, Ms. Norton, an emergency medical technician, switched to a wood-fired boiler.

title: A Strong Week for Stocks After Fed Cuts
description: Buoyed by another Federal Reserve interest-rate cut and by Microsofts $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo, the broad stock market rose last week and the Nasdaq composite index had a weekly gain for the first time in 2008.

title: This Year, Full Dance Cards for Local Politicians
description: EVERY four years, Connecticut residents swallow their pride and acknowledge a political truism: in the presidential primary season, their state plays a wallflower. While the suitors flirt with the popular kids from Iowa and New Hampshire, those from the Nutmeg State must content themselves with an occasional nod, a few sporadic phone calls, maybe a fund-raiser or two.

title: A 17-Year-Olds Breakthrough Victory
description: We may be ready for a changing of the guard.

title: The Many Benefits of a Childrens Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Trying to Bring Their Fallen Heroes Home
description: The military telegram arrived in Peekskill, N.Y., on a springlike day in February 1945. The parents put it down unopened, falling to their knees to pray. Three of their five sons were pilots fighting overseas, and they were afraid to learn which of their boys was dead.

title: From Irrelevance to Influence
description: With the wash comes the election.

title: Thrust Into Leading Role, Crawford Is Showing Strain
description: SEATTLE  On his best nights, Jamal Crawford is the one who takes the biggest shots, makes deficits disappear and makes the Knicks (if ever so briefly) believe anything is possible. Pressure hardly affects him, and neither do the occasional shooting jags.

title: My Bloody Valentine
description: The premise of Eli Gottliebs second novel, Now You See Him, is irresistible to anyone even slightly acquainted with the frustrations of writers block. A celebrated short story writer up against the limitations of his gift, becomes slowly unhinged, gets a gun and shoots his ex-girlfriend (also a writer, now quite successful) between her green eyes. He then kills himself, leaving behind a fatal valentine of literary ravings.

title: Special Delivery for Golfers on the Go
description: Attention golfers: now theres a new alternative to lugging your clubs through the airport: www.golfclubsaway.com is a new online rental service that delivers top brand clubs, like Callaway and Nike, directly to your hotel. The company charges $35 or $45 a day, depending on the brand, to deliver a bag of clubs, which includes a sleeve of golf balls and golf tees. Renters may also pay a fee of $10 to customize their bag by mixing and matching clubs.

title: Copenhagen: Danhostel Copenhagen City
description: THE BASICS

title: A New Year of Apricots
description: Pacific Rim sweet riesling is a fine match for Szechuan cuisine on the Chinese New Year, which starts Thursday.

title: Erin Conroy, Thomas Welling Jr.
description: Erin Elizabeth Conroy, a daughter of Mary Conroy and James Conroy of Newtown, Pa., was married on Saturday to Thomas John Welling Jr., a son of Helen Welling and Mr. Welling Sr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Carleton P. Jones, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Letters: Art in the Age of Franchising
description: Virginia Heffernans column (The Medium, Jan. 20) suggests that the critically acclaimed Friday Night Lights receives poor ratings because the series doesnt lend itself to franchising, but shes confusing cause and effect. Great ratings lead to spinoff properties, they dont follow them; if the show were a hit, NBC would certainly look for ways to capitalize on that.

title: A Farce of Many Parts (and Darting Otello Look-Alikes)
description: Jim Poulos and Catia Ojeda make such a cute young couple in Ken Ludwigs farce Lend Me a Tenor that you really want things to work out for them. As the mild-mannered Max, an unappreciated opera underling, and the super-pretty Maggie, his reluctant girlfriend (she thinks she loves him, but she doesnt hear bells), they give real heart to the John W. Engeman Theater production, which is itself as cute as a button.

title: A.I.G. Chief Cant Stop Looking Over His Shoulder
description: WHEN Martin J. Sullivan, now 53, took over the worlds largest insurer, the American International Group, three years ago, the company was the target of multiple criminal and civil investigations and its books were in such disarray that its auditors refused to endorse them. During Mr. Sullivans first 18 months on the job, A.I.G.s bottom line was successively pounded by three huge hurricanes and a South Asian earthquake. Then came an equally costly disaster, though one of human origin: the subprime credit market meltdown.

title: 36 Hours in Cairo
description: CAIRO is third world and first world, Islamic world and pharaonic world, a teeming city that jars all the senses, all at once. There are thousands of years of history in this city of 18 million people, and that history can be seen in the people themselves: the modern-day ful seller peddling his stewed beans from a decorated cart, the felucca captain guiding his sailboat through the murky Nile, the young man riding a bicycle through traffic with a ladder-sized tray of bread balanced on his head. Come prepared: a scarf for women to enter mosques; packets of tissues for bathroom stops; small bills for tips; and if you like to drink, a bottle or two of wine from the duty-free airport shop. Cairo has a lot to offer, but a good bottle of wine is not included.

title: Pentagon Seeks Record Level in 2009 Budget
description: WASHINGTON  As Congress and the public focus on more than $600 billion already approved in supplemental budgets to pay for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and for counterterrorism operations, the Bush administration has with little notice reached a landmark in military spending.

title: From the World of Brew Pubs, Earthly Beers With Heavenly Tastes
description: FARMINGDALE

title: Events in Westchester County
description: Film

title: In-Verse Thinking
description: As the poet laureate of the United States, what are you doing to increase the publics interest in poetry at a time when cultural alarmists insist that reading is on its way out? Poetry doesnt need much promotion. It is doing quite well in this country. I gave a reading the other night in Concord, N.H., with two former poet laureates  Donald Hall and Maxine Kumin and 740 people came. Thats a lot of people!

title: The Bishops Report
description: Can a novel that features cannibalism, amputations, burning at the stake and the devouring of children by wolves be a comedy? Tackling the gruesome and the grotesque with gleeful abandon, The Voyage of the Short Serpent is an eccentric, slightly maddened and often brutally funny tale of a colony of Roman Catholics marooned in medieval Greenland by the encroachment of a new ice age. Much has been made in France of the fact that its author, Bernard du Boucheron, was 76 years old when Voyage, his first novel, was published, and theres something oddly triumphal about the way the narrative takes direct aim at death  which, despite its omnipresence (the bodies pile up rapidly) is never entirely conceded to.

title: Giving the People What They Want
description: An article on Jan. 20 about Jack W. Batman, executive producer of the White Plains Performing Arts Center, referred incorrectly to the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck and the Westchester Broadway Theater in Elmsford. They are not the only other professional theaters in Westchester. (Others include the Hudson Stage Company in Briarcliff Manor, the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls, Blueberry Pond Theater Ensemble in Ossining, Axial Theater in Yorktown Heights and the Mighty Theater in Peekskill.)

title: Tostadas to a Salsa Beat
description: ON a cold and wet evening, Ingrid Hoffmann, the Colombian-born star of Simply Delicioso, a Latin-themed cooking show on the Food Network, bounded into La Esquina, a Mexican restaurant in NoLIta.

title: Correction
description: A review on Jan. 13 about They Knew They Were Right: The Rise of the Neocons repeated the books erroneous date for a view about World War II once expressed by Irving Kristol, who later became a founder of neoconservatism. It was in 1943, when Kristol was 23, that he published an article referring to a near hysterical insistence upon the pressing military danger posed by the Axis powers; it was not as late as 1944, when he was 24.

title: Listening to the Jobs Report
description: The most pressing data in the latest jobs report is this: The number of people who were unemployed for six months or more as of January was 1.38 million.

title: Candidates Go to Final Round in Battle for Super Tuesday
description: With two days to go before Super Tuesdays multistate nominating contests, candidates for both parties campaigned furiously on Sunday, trying to seize voters support in the hours before the countrys attention shifted to the Super Bowl.

title: Toughest Moves in Dance: The Last Ones
description: THE British choreographer Antony Tudor once asked Martha Graham if she wanted to be remembered as a dancer or as a choreographer. When Graham chose dancer, he responded, I pity you.

title: Cmon. Would You Cross This Director?
description: WHEN a recording at the Laura Pels Theater recently had Kathleen Turner asking audience members to turn off their cellphones, her mix of sex, gravel and good breeding actually made people turn off their phones. Ms. Turner is making her New York directing debut with a revival of Beth Henleys Pulitzer Prize-winning play, Crimes of the Heart. The Off Broadway production, which opens on Feb. 14, ran last year at the Williamstown Theater Festival, with Ms. Turner directing and with much the same cast.

title: Thai Dishes to Contrast and Savor
description: IT was my second meal at the Terrace, a small, neat-looking Thai restaurant in Hamden that had come highly recommended. Word had it that the chef, Amy Wongwiwat, a young Thai woman, had studied French cooking in Lyons.

title: Mormons Say Farewell to President
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Most of the time, this city succeeds in projecting the secular, cosmopolitan image that its leaders and residents have polished over the years: the ski capital, the economic engine, the desert metropolis of wide streets and mountain vistas.

title: Correction: Built for the Earth and the Pocketbook
description: A Square Feet article last Sunday about energy-efficient modular homes misstated the height restrictions on trucks, which deliver the modules to building sites. While these limits vary according to state, none are lower than 13 feet 6 inches. The maximum is not 13 feet.

title: Giants Hope a Moral Victory Can Lead to a Real One
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The term moral victory is not exclusive to sports. It has been used to describe everything from Al Gores disputed defeat in the presidential election of 2000 to the battle at the Alamo in 1836.

title: Must a Landlords Fee Apply to All Tenants?
description: Q My wife and I live in a rental building. In the summer, we are charged an extra fee for each air-conditioning unit. We recently discovered that this fee was introduced a few years ago and that tenants who had lived here before then are not charged. Is it legal for the landlord to charge some tenants but not others?

title: Seeking a Path in Democracys Dead End
description: KIEV, Ukraine

title: Elsewheres Children
description: As someone whose subway rides tend to resemble scenes from an Evil Dead movie, in which I am Bruce Campbell dodging zombies who have had all traces of their humanity sucked out of them by a sinister book  not the Necronomicon, but Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows  I sometimes wonder how any self-respecting author of speculative fiction can find fulfillment in writing novels for young readers. I suppose J. K. Rowling could give me 1.12 billion reasons in favor of it: get your formula just right and you can enjoy worldwide sales, film and television options, vibrating-toy-broom licensing fees, Chinese-language bootlegs of your work, a kind of limited immortality (L. Frank Baum who?) and  finally  genuine grown-up readers. But wheres the artistic satisfaction? Wheres the dignity?

title: French Leader and Ex-Model Wed in Quiet Ceremony
description: PARIS  She has called herself a tamer of men and described monogamy as boring.

title: Innocent as Charged
description: To the Editor:

title: Yahoo Deal Is Big, but Is It the Next Big Thing?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In moving to buy Yahoo, Microsoft may be firing the final shot of yesterdays war.

title: Its Even Worse Over There
description: IF stock prices are supposed to reflect the underlying health of the economy, its easy to see why the market is off to such a tough start this year. Wall Street is worried that the economy is headed for its first recession in six years, so its only natural that investors are a little spooked.

title: Albert Landa Dies at 80; Helped the New School Develop
description: Albert W. Landa, a public relations executive who went far beyond that role in helping to develop the New School in Manhattan into a full-scale university, died on Jan. 26 in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: The Gray Areas of Jasper Johns
description: St. Martin

title: Along a Road of Antiquity
description: SOUTH of the tourist-crushed Trevi Fountain, past the scooter-clogged streets of Centro Storico and just outside the citys 1,700-year-old walls is a miles-long stretch of ancient landmarks, quaint restaurants and serenity known as Appia Antica.

title: The Tax Bills of New Yorks Rich
description: A TAX collectors tour of Manhattan might rightfully begin in front of the neo-Georgian town house on East 63rd Street with stately stone pillars and a bowed brick front, a large flagpole protruding from a fourth-floor terrace. Once a private club and later a Catholic school, it is now the home of Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire who made his fortune buying up troubled companies.

title: Azinger Aims for a Ryder Cup Victory
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Clad in a black leather jacket over a collarless shirt, oozing a relaxed casual chic, the United States Ryder Cup captain Paul Azinger again shook up the status quo for Septembers Ryder Cup by sending a clear message to the European team earlier this week.

title: Much About History
description: Im a history professor  my period is 1500-1800  with an M.A. student who wants to pursue a doctorate. While she is smart and capable, she is very religious, subscribing to the young earth theory that the world is only 6,000 years old. I am to work with her for a year and then recommend her to Ph.D. programs. Must I do so if I find her views incongruent with those of historians?  NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

title: Hairdressers and Clients, and the Roles They Play
description: It would be all too easy to simply dismiss And Her Hair Went With Her, Zina Camblins new play at the New Jersey Repertory Company, as the flawed, if mildly diverting, trifle that it ultimately proves to be. Doing so, however, would mean failing to recognize the extraordinary promise of Ms. Camblin, who clearly embodies what Nina Simone and Weldon Irvine were celebrating when they wrote the song To Be Young, Gifted and Black nearly 40 years ago.

title: High Cost of Superfund
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: A VIEW OF THE OCEAN, by Jan de Hartog. (Pantheon, $17.95.) In this slim memoir, Hartog, a noted novelist and playwright who died in 2002, sketches his mother: shes the girl beneath the flowering cherry, the piously forbearing housewife and the white-haired mischievous saint, attested doer of good works in Japanese prison camp and Dutch retirement home alike. But at its heart, A View of the Ocean is an unsparing account of her death. De Hartog was a sort of northern European Hemingway: a best-selling novelist and legitimate hero of the Dutch resistance before he turned 30. But for all his physical and moral courage, he couldnt bear nursing his mother in the last weeks of her life. He breaks down in the attempt  and the simple rhythm of his prose turns to a howl. In particular, hes undone by the stench of her cancerous breath: It defeated everything in me that wanted to help, to love, to succor. This is painful to read, but that pain is necessary to understand why de Hartog  though a lifelong skeptic  turns to prayer, and to believe in the religious revelation that follows. The ending suggests he will convert to Quakerism. In fact, he did, adamantly, and went on to write several well-regarded novels about that faith.

title: Designing Woman
description: It can be hard, 25 years after it was first published, to appreciate the impact of the psychologist Carol Gilligans book In a Different Voice. Its argument that women and men make moral decisions differently  women emphasize relationships, while men focus on justice  now sounds familiar, even if its implications are still controversial. Although some scholars criticized (and continue to criticize) its findings, politicians, parents and teachers began to re-evaluate how they treated young boys and girls. Gilligan was named to the first professorship in gender studies at Harvard. Jane Fonda credits the book with changing her life. Many other women would agree.

title: Events on Long Island
description: FILM

title: Letters: Airport Parking
description: To the Editor: I read, with interest, your Practical Traveler column "No Room at the Lot and Late at the Gate" (Jan. 20), about the lack of parking at airports around the nation. One suggestion: Airports should consider offering valet parking at airports. This would be a help to those who miscalculate and are in a rush to park their cars but cant find spots, and to travelers who are not taking advantage of other long-term parking options. Valet parking could ease anxiety among travelers and generate some additional revenue for airport operations.

title: Letters: A Cutting Tradition
description: The seven images that accompany Sara Corbetts article (Jan. 20) depict a culturally sanctioned practice in Indonesia of female genital mutilation. Aside from the single photo of the child in severe pain, the pictures show female attendants preparing to deform young girls in an environment of care and concern, mothers trying to soothe their fearful daughters and, finally, the face of a serene-looking child, who has apparently recovered from her acute pain and is accepting of her mutilation.

title: Mourning the Medicine Man
description: LOWENS PHARMACY, at the corner of Bay Ridge Avenue and Third Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, since 1953, was open for business last week, with a Valentines Day display in the window next to an old newspaper article, blown up to poster size, hailing the store as a beacon of service. With the text was a picture of John Rossi, the stores gray-haired owner, wearing glasses and a serious look, and filling a prescription.

title: Ruling Allows Legal Status for Partners of Same Sex
description: PORTLAND, Ore. (AP)  A state law allowing same-sex couples to register as domestic partners took effect Friday after a federal judge ruled the states process of disqualifying petition signatures was consistent enough to be valid.

title: The Archaeology of Hunger
description: In late November 2006, a San Francisco couple with two young children made a wrong turn and found themselves snowbound in their car in the Oregon wilderness, where they stayed for more than a week. The parents lived on berries, the babies on breast milk. (The father, James Kim, died of hypothermia while trying to get help.) A year later, Frederick Dominguez, of Paradise, Calif., and his three adolescent children went into the woods looking for a Christmas tree and lost track of their car; they slept in a culvert and made a HELP sign from sticks. After three days, they were rescued, more or less unharmed. These grim situations attracted relentless media attention: family plus snow plus stranded equals human-interest story nonpareil.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE VIEW FROM CASTLE ROCK: Stories, by Alice Munro. (Vintage International, $14.95.) Munro (right) based her 12th collection of stories on family records extending back to their origin in the Scottish lowlands. They were not memoirs but they were closer to my own life than the other stories I had written, she explains in a foreword. You could say that such stories pay more attention to the truth of a life than fiction usually does. But not enough to swear on. In the books second half, Munro moves toward the present and her typical themes: class, domesticity, sexual desire and the tensions between ambition and loyalty, duty and dreaming. Our reviewer, A. O. Scott, said Munro is incapable of writing a sentence that is sloppy, dishonest, unnecessary or dull. Another story collection  his first  comes from Colm Toibin, the author of five novels, including The Master. All nine of the tales in MOTHERS AND SONS: Stories (Scribner, $14) contain a mother and son, but rarely are they together. Instead, Toibin is interested in people in hiding from themselves and their feelings, and in the relationship between the watcher and the watched. Writing in the Book Review, Pico Iyer found that Toibins craft is immaculate, and that the stories are beautiful and echoing, but warned that despite its title, this is not ... a collection to share with your loved ones on the second Sunday in May.

title: Ask Not What J.F.K. Can Do for Obama
description: BEFORE John F. Kennedy was a president, a legend, a myth and a poltergeist stalking Americas 2008 campaign, he was an upstart contender seen as a risky bet for the Democratic nomination in 1960.

title: Meet the Neocons
description: To the Editor:

title: Wal-Mart: The New Washington
description: OBAMA, Clinton, McCain, Romney ... Wal-Mart?

title: Huskies Stay Hot With Win Over Pittsburgh
description: HARTFORD  Last season, the Connecticut Huskies won only six games against opponents in the Big East Conference. For the first time in two decades, they were deemed too lackluster to earn a postseason berth.

title: Without Metaphor
description: One cant say Susan Sontag died a particularly private death. She once declared she wouldnt tell her readers what it is really like to emigrate to the kingdom of the ill and live there, but it seems other people were determined to do it for her. The latest glimpse we have of her sickbed is Swimming in a Sea of Death, David Rieffs intelligent, disordered account of his mothers final illness.

title: Mellow and Groovy and Fighting Crime
description: YOUTHFUL-LOOKING, telegenic cops head undercover, infiltrating schools and their peers hangouts to bust the bad guys. Mention that plot, and the first response will be 21 Jump Street, the 80s drama that gave the world Johnny Depp. But the founding father of that premise was The Mod Squad, the ABC series from the late 60s and early 70s in which three young counterculture delinquents sought to redeem themselves by joining the police force.

title: Hello, Neighbor
description: Anyone who caught Hugo Chvezs act at the United Nations in September 2006  in which Chvez, the president of Venezuela, compared George W. Bush to Satan  might infer that relations between Latin America and the United States have gone to hell. But Chvezs extreme theatrics mask the real problem. Our mostly Spanish-speaking neighbors have reason to suspect that except for occasional military and economic interventions, American leaders dont pay them much mind, let alone give them the respect theyve earned.

title: Morality Studies
description: Imagine that you are standing next to a railway track and you see a runaway trolley, with nobody on board, heading toward a group of five people down the track. The only way to save these people is to throw a switch that will divert the train to another track. This will save the five, but unfortunately will kill another person standing on the second track. Now imagine the same runaway trolley and the same five people, but this time you are standing on a bridge above the track, next to a very large stranger. The only way to stop the trolley is to shove the man off the bridge and into the trolleys path, killing him but saving the five. (It wont help to jump yourself; youre too small to stop the trolley.) What is interesting is that both situations present the option of saving five by killing one, but most people respond to them differently. Most believe that you would be right to throw the switch, yet wrong to push the man. But why do we think this? And are we right to do so?

title: Lovin Spoonfuls
description: If you have ever tried passing through customs at Newark with a partly wrapped Burgundian salami in your luggage or have found yourself stuck in traffic outside a 72,000-person stadium while the biggest football game of the year is about to start, then you know that five minutes can seem like an eternity. Making pudding, on the other hand, is a different kind of exercise in stretching time  a pleasant one. The five minutes spent in front of a stove, dragging a wooden spatula across the pan to ward off scorched spots and looking for that subtle thickening that seizes the custard just before all-out lumps break out, are elastic, meditative, (ideally) unbothered  a reminder that sometimes the comfort of a comfort food has less to do with eating than it does with cooking.

title: Swiss Sausage Fans Fret Over How to Save Their Skin
description: BERN, Switzerland  Amid the news of global warming and huge losses at UBS, the countrys largest bank, the Swiss were confronted this winter with an even more dire report: the possible extinction of cervelas, the national sausage.

title: A Roommates Rights
