description: In Chinas latest move to secure iron ore supplies, the countrys $200 billion sovereign wealth fund, the China Investment Corporation, and a coal mining company, the China Shenhua Group are reportedly in talks to take a sizable stake in Fortescue Metals, a major Australian iron ore producer.

title: Yahoo Sale Could Be Bad for Minnows
description: For decades, Silicon Valley has been the land of eternal optimism and high anxiety, traits that pitch into overdrive anytime a seismic business event washes across the corporate and entrepreneurial landscape here  like, for example, Microsofts blockbuster $45 billion bid for Yahoo on Friday.

title: BHP May Need to Match Chinalco Bid for Rio
description: BHP Billiton, the worlds largest mining company, must raise its $127 billion bid for the Rio Tinto Group to at least match the price Aluminum Corporation of China paid for its stake, Bloomberg News reported citing investors and analysts.

title: Icahn Is Said to Buy Stake in Penney
description: The investor Carl C. Icahn has gone shopping again, this time acquiring shares in the retailer J.C. Penney, according to press reports. While the exact size of his stake in the retailer is unknown, The Wall Street Journal said that Penney is now among Mr. Icahns five largest holdings, which could place it in the hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Bids Due for Northern Rock
description: Investors in the troubled British lender Northern Rock are expecting bids Monday from Richard Bransons Virgin Group and an investment firm, Olivant Advisers. But, according to The Times of London and others, they shouldnt be expecting a higher offer from Mr. Branson, despite warnings from two hedge fund shareholders that the current proposed offer is unsatisfactory.

title: How Google Could Keep Yahoo From Microsoft
description: Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, is offering Yahoo  and, it seems, anyone else  whatever help he can to make sure Yahoo isnt swallowed by Microsoft.

title: Massachusetts Accuses Merrill of Fraud
description: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts accused Merrill Lynch on Friday of defrauding the city of Springfield with subprime-linked investments, casting light on how Wall Street banks sold complex mortgage securities that are now plummeting in value as the housing slump deepens.

title: Rough Economic Conditions May Fuel Visa I.P.O.
description: MasterCard once again reported blowout earnings last week, bolstering predictions of a smooth ride for the much-anticipated $10 billion initial public offering for its rival Visa.

title: Goldman to Invest in China Buyout Fund, Report Says
description: Two senior Goldman Sachs bankers are teaming up to run a new $2 billion private-equity fund aimed at landing big deals in China, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Wall St. Stays Charitable in an Off Year
description: Several analysts from Goldman Sachs and Citigroup delivered an envelope full of cash, checks and change last week to the offices of The New York Times Company Foundation.

title: Are Tech Deals Getting More Hostile?
description: Microsofts $44.6 billion unsolicited bid for Yahoo on Friday may be proof that hostile takeovers are coming of age in high tech, The San Jose Mercury News says.

title: Delta Says It Also Has a Strong Stand-Alone Plan
description: Delta Air Lines executives are painting a picture of the airline as a suitor that can afford to be picky.

title: As Some Predict M&A Wave, Bankers Look Set to Profit
description: Following Microsofts unsolicited offer for Yahoo, some industry observers are predicting that the $44.6 billion move may usher in a wave of other strategic mergers this year as other top companies with pristine balance sheets go hunting for beaten down competitors.

title: January Worst Month for Hedge Funds Since 1998
description: Last month was the worst for hedge funds since the August 1998 crisis that presaged the collapse of Long Term Capital Management, according to data from Chicago-based Hedge Fund Research.

title: Private Equity Unlikely to Bail Out Bond Insurers, Report Says
description: Leading private equity firms are unlikely to participate in any recapitalization of the bond insurers Ambac and MBIA, according to The Financial Times, increasing the pressure on banks to come up with a rescue package.

title: States Seek Hearings on BofAs Countrywide Deal
description: Consumer groups in four states are asking congressional banking committees to conduct hearings on Bank of Americas proposed $4.1 billion buyout of the struggling mortgage lender Countrywide Financial.

title: China Railways Said to Postpone $4 Billion I.P.O.
description: The Chinese securities regulator has asked China Railway Construction to postpone its Shanghai and Hong Kong dual stock listing, worth as much as $4 billion, because of poor market conditions, Reuters reported.

title: France Said to Suggest New Controls for Its Banks
description: A French government report to be released Monday calls for tighter risk-control measures at Socit Gnrale and a broad review of the rules at other French banks in response to huge losses from a trading scandal, according to The New York Times.

title: Happiness at Work: Does it Matter?
description: Todays guest post is written by Gretchen Rubin, who writes the popular blog, The Happiness Project. Ms. Rubin is also working on a book of the same title, which will be a memoir of the year she spent testing every principle, tip, theory and scientific study about happiness she could find, whether from Aristotle, St. Therese, Martin Seligman or Oprah. Prior to her foray into the world of happiness, Ms. Rubin had an impressive career as a lawyer, including clerking for a Supreme Court justice, Sandra Day OConnor. She is also the author of three books, Power Money Fame Sex: A Users Guide, Forty Ways to Look at JFK and Forty Ways to Look at Winston Churchill.

title: Malone and Diller: 2 Deal-Makers, 2 Different Styles
description: Like Hollywood stars stuck in a rut, Barry Diller and John C. Malone are always cast in the same contrasting roles. Mr. Diller, 65, lives a razzle-dazzle life of extravagance and celebrity. If he isnt flying off to Capri with his wife, the socialite and fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg, he is running his company, IAC/InterActiveCorp, from a sculptured $133 million tower designed by Frank Gehry on the Hudson River.

title: Another Difficulty for a MSFT-YHOO Marriage: Recruiting
description: With competition for engineering talent in Silicon Valley as fierce as it has been since the late 1990s, if not fiercer, one crucial question about Microsofts $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo is whether a combined company could more easily attract software engineers  an increasingly precious commodity. Both companies are already fighting the perception that their most innovative days are behind them.

title: Quien es Mas Macho?
description: Who is the baddest one of all: Daniel Plainview or Anton Chigurh? Perhaps Sweeney Todd, the avenging barber? Little Gold Men does the math.

title: Is M&A Dead?
description: If so, did private equity kill it?

title: What Would Jesus Watch?
description: Beliefnet, a place for spiritual matters on the web, is running a little movie contest of its own, looking for Best Spiritual Film, Best Spiritual Performance and Best Spiritual Documentary.

title: Poll Finds Obama Closing In on Clinton in New York and New Jersey
description: Senator Barack Obama has made rapid gains in New York and New Jersey among likely Democratic voters and has nearly closed in on Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons once-dominant lead in New Jersey, according to poll results released by Quinnipiac University this morning. On the Republican side, the polls showed Senator John McCain with a commanding lead over former Gov. Mitt Romney among likely voters.

title: Grosses as Big as Montana
description: The Bagger was one of those loser parents that could not get his kid tickets to the Best of Both Worlds concert that featured a duet of Miley Cyrus and Hannah Montana. And just in case his loser credentials werent firmly established with Shorty Bagger, he could not even get her into a movie of the concert, which was sold out as well.

title: Boy Meets Girl and Falls Asleep
description: A.O. Scott gets a jump on Valentines Day by pointing out that romantic comedy, once a genre known for sophisticated plots, characters and dialogue, has become a modern rodeo of clichs and hacks. Mr. Scott, who has always struck the Bagger as a red-blooded romantic in cinematic matters, calls the current crop of who-cares-if-he-gets-the-girl movies a scandal.

title: And the Nominees are  Absent
description: The Academy is holding their nominees lunch today, typically a star-studded affair where people try to be present without preening. But Tom ONeil reports that many on the A-List have commitments elsewhere, including Cate Blanchett, Daniel Day Lewis, Johnny Depp and Tommy Lee Jones. Hey, maybe Sean Young is available.

title: In Search of the Elusive Oscar Angle
description: Lemme see, the Giants win a historic Super Bowl victory over the smug overdogs from New England and the Bagger remembers that the movie Giant was nominated for 10 Academy Awards in 1956, with a win for director George Stevens. Not much of a hook? Who cares? He just wants to celebrate in some fashion and is planning on being miles away from the victory parade in Manhattan on Super Tuesday.

title: Health care thoughts
description: Just a note to explain where Im coming from on all this.

title: The Golden Rule
description: Risky Biz, which has been running some analytics on historical Oscar winners and vectoring with them with box office receipts, has reached the conclusion that in the last ten years, with one exception, the best picture win has gone to one of the two top grossing films.

title: Dial-a-Conspiracy
description: The Los Angeles Timess Andrew Malcolm thinks someone on Hillary Clintons side is is playing dirty pool in California, setting up a malicious political virus that is designed not to elicit answers but to spread positive information about one candidate and negative information about all others under the guise of an honest poll. Is it a dreaded push poll? Well, not everyone thinks so.

title: The Early Word: Clinton, Obama in Nationwide Tie
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton called her hometown New York Giants surprise Super Bowl victory a real omen for her Super Tuesday chances.

title: Who Would Want AOL Now?
description: AOL is looking pretty lonely these days.

title: Now Thats a Super Duper Bowl, New York
description: The New York papers, not surprisingly, provide heavy coverage of the Giants improbable 17-14 victory in the Super Bowl, which denied the New England Patriots (and their quarterback with the supermodel girlfriend, Tom Brady) a chance at historic perfection and gave the New York team its first Super Bowl championship since 1991. The New York Post praises them as Supermen! while The Daily News blares Champs on their front covers. Giants quarterback Eli Manning, arguably played more like Brady than Brady himself, and was awarded the most valuable player award only a year after his older brother, Peyton Manning, won it while leading the Indianapolis Colts to the championship.The newspapers dissect the heart-stopping game (the lead switched three times during the final quarter). The Patriots defense crumbled in the fourth quarter, which proved telling given that the Giants aggressive defense shut down what was perhaps the best offense in the history of football. While the Giants were universally deemed the underdog, Plaxico Burress, who caught the game-winning touchdown, exhibited prescience in his pre-game prediction of a low-scoring game with a small margin of victory in favor of the Giants (off by the winning margin, off by the exact score, but close enough that everyone is praising him). The Giants had walked away with a sense of confidence and strategy after their 38-35 loss to the Patriots in December, feeling perhaps they knew how to beat the undefeated Patriots.

title: New York Fashion Week | Preen
description: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment.

title: Antidepressants Dont Ease Back Pain
description: Nearly one in four primary care doctors prescribes antidepressants as a treatment for low back pain. But a new report shows theres no evidence the drugs offer any relief.

title: The Super Bowl Ad Derby
description: An interview with Stuart Elliott and Donny Deutsch about Super Bowl ads. (Courtesy CharlieRose.com)

title: The House Stays Out to Vote
description: Nothing captures the attention of politicians like an election  even if they are not running.

title: McCain Plans Two Days of Campaigning Here
description: Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who has a strong lead in national polls for his partys presidential nomination, plans to campaign in Midtown Manhattan this afternoon and again on Tuesday, his campaign has announced. Mr. McCain, who is scheduled to lead a rally at his New Jersey campaign headquarters in Hamilton, N.J., at noon today, will hold a 3 p.m. news conference at Grand Central Terminal. Then at 7 a.m. Tuesday, Mr. McCain is scheduled to appear with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for a rally at Rockefeller Center Plaza. The candidates for the Democratic nomination are also in the New York region today.

title: Electability
description: One thing Im being told quite often is that what really matters isnt candidates policy proposals, but their electability.

title: The Game Comes to the Rescue, and Oh, What a Game It Was
description: Will Leitch is the editor of Deadspin.com and a frequent contributor to Play: The New York Times Sports Magazine. His latest book is God Save the Fan.

title: Super Bowl Outbursts From Unlikely Sources
description: New York is understandably ecstatic over the Giants stunning victory over the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLII. But sports fans arent the only ones who rushed to the Web afterward to share their thoughts on the big game. Heres a selection of interesting snippets from unlikely sources outside the wide world of sports:

title: Another Potential Deal for Yahoos Chairman
description: Roy J. Bostock is a busy man these days. Appointed as Yahoos chairman only on Thursday night, his first order of business was to huddle with his fellow directors and Jerry Yang, the companys co-founder and chief executive, about Microsofts hostile approach.

title: Regions Surprised Voters Are Suddenly Relevant
description: As voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut prepare to vote in the presidential primaries on Tuesday, voters of both political parties in the suburbs of New York City appeared during recent interviews to be more focused on the character and personal histories of the candidates, even if the views of those candidates were sharply at odds with their own.

title: A Sort of Homecoming
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton had a teary-eyed moment on the campaign trail today during a nostalgic visit to Yale, where she graduated from law school nearly 35 years ago.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Post-Strike, Writers May Confront a Hostile Hollywood
description: Over the weekend, Hollywood was swept by hope that the walkout by writers may soon end, Michael Cieply reports in todays New York Times.

title: The End of Something
description: Theres been talk here about what The Moviegoer generated. But I think its also worth considering how it represents the end of something. As weve seen, Aunt Emily  standing in for William Alexander Percy  stands for the end of the Southern Way, for a certain noblesse oblige that had already been swept aside by history by the time the book was written, and which Percy can only salute in passing. And Binx himself represents a certain kind of self-conscious Southern protagonist who isnt quite an anti-hero but is self-conscious, well aware of his limitations and foibles  if he doesnt in fact revel in them. Hes wounded and he knows it and he loves himself for it  hes a noble Confederate junior officer ill-equipped for life in the squalid Union, and proud of it. He too has been swept away by the tides of progress  and Percys later fiction, from the perfectly-titled The Last Gentleman on, bears witness to his noble, doomed trajectory.

title: Inside The Debate Control Room
description: Thursdays showdown between Senator Hillary Clinton and Senator Barack Obama was promoted by CNN and other media outlets as fight night because of the nasty shots each candidate had taken at the previous debate. Instead, the debate centered on policy, leaving the producers exasperated and at times seemingly bored by their own broadcast, todays New York Times reports.

title: By Invitation Only
description: A look at Hyde Lounge, a invitation-only nightclub for athletes, celebrities and other V.I.P.s.

title: Hanging Chad
description: With the election campaign in full-swing, the spread of Darfurs cancer into Chad hasnt received much attention. But for the last couple of days, there has been full-scale warfare in the Chadian capital, Ndjamena, and its a reflection of the international communitys passivity toward Darfur.

title: Ghana Riding High After Downing Super Eagles
description: There were two Super Bowls happening in the world on Sunday  the one in America with the Giants of gridiron football, and the one in Africa with the two giants of African football: Ghana vs. Nigeria. Both games were amazing.

title: Schwarzman Says He Doesnt Feel Rich
description: I dont feel like a wealthy person.

title: Purple States: Immigration Inquiry
description: In California, citizen reporters Alex and Bert take a close look at the immigration debate.

title: F1 and the French municipal elections
description: Le Figaro, the French national daily newspaper, today had a page two story about the role of Formula One in the municipal election campaign in Versailles. With the headline, Formula 1 in pole position in the campaign, the article outlines how the battle to stage the French Grand Prix in Versailles is being used by politicians to promote their candidacy.

title: Obama Volunteers Brave Snow Flurries and Harried Commuters
description: JERSEY CITY  A handful of volunteers for Senator Barack Obamas campaign braved snow flurries and an onslaught of commuters at PATH commuter rail stations on Monday morning to wave signs, hand out fliers and remind voters to get out to the polls on Tuesday. The unusually early primary day here in New Jersey has appeared to whip up exceptionally high interest in local residents, some of whom say they feel a sense of empowerment.

title: Racism Hits Formula One in Spain
description: A sad thing happened at Formula One testing last weekend outside of Barcelona. Fans attending the test spewed racist taunts at Lewis Hamilton, who last year became the first black driver in series history. A photograph from the Times of London showed four spectators in black face. They wore T-shirts that said Hamiltons Family.

title: African American Lives 2
description: An excerpt from African American Lives 2, the series on PBS.  Produced by Thirteen/WNET New York, Kunhardt Productions and Inkwell Films.

title: Lending Pullback Delays Bankruptcy Exits
description: The icy touch of the credit crunch has all but frozen the buyout boom in its tracks and forced the cancellation of more than a few private equity deals. It has hit another part of the market as well, Aleksandrs Rozens of Investment Dealers Digest reports in the current issues cover story. Companies seeking credit as they enter or exit bankruptcy are also feeling the pinch, he writes.

title: New York Fashion Week | Peter Som

title: Third world America
description: Carmen Reinhart and Ken Rogoff have an alarming paper on parallels between the United States and countries that have experienced financial crises in the past. The bottom line of the paper, which has already gotten a lot of attention, is that we look an awful lot like those other countries  and that if their experience is any guide, things could get really, really bad.

description: A simulated tour of Masdar City, Abu Dhabi. The car-free city will use solar energy for its residents. (Promo Video by Foster & Partners)

But what makes it a real winner is the combination of those flavors with lemon and green olives, both of which have a mouth-puckering quality that, combined with the spice mix, is enchanting.

description: Recent presidential elections have included sometimes emotional discussions about issues like same-sex marriage and gay military service. But as Andrew Jacobs reported last week, for many gay voters those issues are taking a back seat this year to more general concerns about the candidates themselves, the economy and the Iraq war. During the last week, City Room spoke to several gay men in New York about the Democratic primary, as part of a continuing look at different groups of voters.

And Real is the largest player left in that market with its Rhapsody service.

title: Parents Worried by Strangers in School on Primary Day

In an e-mail message to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, Rochelle Hestnas and Anthony Vasapolli, parents of a third grader at Public School 9 on the Upper West Side, wrote that they would keep their child home from school rather than subject him to eating lunch in his classroom while voting takes place in the school cafeteria.

Daniel Kenealy at Awards Daily spends some time staring at the English tea leaves and says advises that we look for mischief in the interplay of the top two categories  best film and best director in spite of Atonements commanding presence in both of them.

title: Future Shock
description: The tenor of the negotiations in the writers strike seems to have changed, but Michael Cieply reports that even if the writers do well in getting a deal, they will likely confront an altered landscape, one in which studios have gotten used to employing workarounds to marginalize the value of original content from writers.

title: Open Caucus: Primed for Tomorrow
description: As much as wed like to be, The Caucus cant be everywhere, all the time. Luckily, we have our Open Caucus contributors to fill in the gaps and divulge the nitty gritty details on what the political climate is like across the country. Today, we hear what the scene is like in Super Tuesday states Arizona and Oklahoma  as well as how things are shaping up in Ohio, which holds its primaries March 4. As always, we invite you to take part in the conversation in the comments section below.

title: Xs and Os
description: Yeah, theres still probably going to be some complicated campaigning left to do for Hillary and Barack after tomorrow, but Variety notes that the current Oscar campaign has its share of ins and outs, too.

title: Obama Enjoys Actors Nod and Spirit of Upset
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Despite the brutal schedule of the pre-Super Tuesday endgame, Senator Barack Obama seemed crisp and inspired this afternoon throughout his 35-minute address at the Meadowlands here. The audience of more than 3,000 did not fill the 20,000-seat stadium and was smaller than crowds of 12,000 to 20,000 that he has drawn in other states. (Later in the day, in Hartford, where new Connecticut voters were still registering in large numbers, an estimated 17,000 turned out to hear Mr. Obama speak.)

title: A Love Poem to New Orleans
description: I hate to turn every discussion of The Moviegoer into a discussion about New Orleans. It minimizes Walker Percy to perceive him as purely a Southern writer, or someone who just happened to write the greatest book about the city. But I cant resist pointing out in this final posting just how much of a love poem this book is to New Orleans, which could use one just about right now. The streetlights make golden spaces inside the wet leaves of the live oaks, he writes, describing a parade night Uptown. A south wind carries the smell of coffee from the Tchoupitoulas docks. Heres Percy on nightfall in Gentilly: The sky is a deep bright ocean full of light and life. A mares tail of cirrus cloud stands in high from the Gulf. High above the Lake a broken vee of ibises points for the marshes; they go suddenly white as they fly into the tilting salient of sunlight.

title: Troubles in Ireland
description: The bubble has officially burst in Ireland. After years of rapid growth, housing prices fell 7.3 percent in 2007, according to the annual housing index compiled by ESRI and Permanent TSB. The same study showed an 11.8 percent increase in 2006.

description: Three months into the writers strike, newsmagazines are still relatively rare on prime time schedules, despite pre-strike predictions that news would fill some of the scripted programming holes. Dateline is only being shown once this month, and 48 Hours is often being shown on Saturdays, the least lively night of the week on TV.

The Arizona senator stood in Vanderbilt Hall, in one of the nations busiest transit hubs, in the heart of Midtown Manhattan. The evening rush had not yet started, but startled commuters stopped to see what all the commotion was about.

This is pretty grim.

That means he will sit out Tuesdays game against Los Angeles at Madison Square Garden.

title: What About Bill?
description: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes, As long as the audience is Democrats, the Clinton camp firmly sees Mr. Clinton as more of a help than a hindrance. But if Mrs. Clinton goes on to win the Democratic nomination, you may see her campaign rethink how it uses Mr. Clinton as it appeals to a broader audience. Depending on what happens, Mrs. Clinton may even find herself considering a Bill speech, not unlike Mitt Romneys Mormon speech or J.F.K.s Catholic speech.

description: Well, as much as Bill Clinton enjoys the limelight, he might be glad to have one of the other candidates spouses in hot water for a change. title: Clinton Leading Among the Unpledged
description: Updated | Feb. 4 Heading into Tuesdays nominating contests, many of the unpledged delegates to the Democratic National Convention are still undecided, but more who have made up their minds are expressing support for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton than for Senator Barack Obama, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: When Super Tuesday Wasnt Decisive: 1988
description: If the contest between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination stretches past Super Tuesday, with a state-by-state battle for delegates that lasts well into the spring, election historians and political analysts might do well to look back at 1988, when a large field of contenders sought the Democratic presidential nomination, leading to a protracted battle for delegates that lasted for months.

title: Why Conservatives Dont Like McCain
description: In my job as associate editor at The Weekly Standard, I must get half a dozen e-mails a day from conservative readers who say they will never vote for John McCain for president. Conservative talk radio hosts and bloggers raise the idea that they will not support Senator McCain if he is the Republican nominee in the fall  even if that means a Clinton Restoration. When Senator McCain speaks at this years Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in a couple of weeks, its likely hell be booed in person, just as he was booed in absentia last year. Loudly.

title: The Worst Super Bowl Ad

description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J.  Looking as youthful as the Monmouth University college students to whom he spoke, Craig Romney, son of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney was unfailingly polite as he vouched for his fathers character Monday afternoon.

title: House Enjoys The Post-Bowl Time Slot

description: Nearly everyone has witnessed the toddler meltdown  that moment in a store, restaurant or airplane when a once-happy child loses it. He screams, cries and flails as his embarrassed parents desperately try to calm him.

title: For the Moment | Hana Soukupova
description: This weeks guest blogger is the 22-year-old supermodel Hana Soukupova, who has been treading catwalks since she was 13. Soukupova is the face of Gucci Envy, she appears in the current Gap campaign, and she has closed shows for such designers as Valentino, John Galliano, Dior, Celine, Gucci, Michael Kors, Roberto Cavalli, Alexander McQueen, Calvin Klein, Donna Karen and Zac Posen. But at The Moment, we love her for her sharp eye, which is why we slipped a digital camera into her handbag and asked her to cover Fashion Week through the lens of a model.

title: New York Central
description: Whenever I go to some black-tie affair at the Waldorf, I leave thinking of my father, Eugene Horyn, an ex-newspaperman. I cant help it. He loved all that big-city stuff, and I dont take any of it for granted even when my shoes feel too small. I went to the Waldorf tonight because Bill Cunningham was being honored, among others, by the Citizens Committee for New York, and the Times took two tables.

title: Creating Those Hallmark Moments
description: SAN FRANCISCO - Never mind the Kennedy dynasty. The Clinton family offered Hallmark moments to millions of voters across the nation Monday night during a 90-minute town hall meeting simultaneously streamed over the Web and on cable TV.

description: As news of the retirement of Texas Tech Coach Bobby Knight spread throughout college basketball, there has been an outpouring of reaction. Heres a sampling of what people around the game think about Knight and his legacy.

title: Zombies and Scrabble Knock-Offs to Invade MySpace
description: MySpace is about to join Facebook, Bebo, Meebo and so many other stars in the Web 2.0 firmament in opening up its platform and giving developers a set of tools with which to build applications that can run, and make money, on its site.

title: Dickensian Happenings for a Child of the 60s
description: Peter Careys novels  from the Booker Prize winners Oscar and Lucinda and True History of the Kelly Gang through recent ones like My Life as a Fake and Theft  tend to feature improbable undertakings, sudden reversals of fortune and elaborately manufactured or forged identities. Most of his characters inhabit a boldly colored limbo land somewhere on the great fiction map between Dickenss world of improbable coincidences and the old-fashioned world of the picaresque, where odd happenings and even odder people are strung together willy-nilly into rollicking, improvisatory tales.

title: Footnotes
description: Sylvester Stallone, below, who has achieved new popularity in Rambo, has signed an agreement to direct and star in two more action films for the same producers, Reuters reported. Last year Rocky Balboa, the sixth of Mr. Stallones Rocky films, grossed $70 million and cost an estimated $24 million. ... The seventh annual Tribeca Film Festival will take place from April 23 to May 4. Tickets will be priced at $15 for evening and weekend screenings and $8 for daytime weekday and late night screenings. Some screenings, with panel discussions, will be priced at $25; and ticket packages, will also be available. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.

title: Anna Netrebko Is Expecting
description: The soprano Anna Netrebko,  pregnant and engaged, has withdrawn from this summers Salzburg Festival, Agence France-Presse reported. She was scheduled to sing at the festival opposite the tenor Rolando Villazn in Gounods Romeo and Juliet. Ms. Netrebko, 36, a Russian-born Austrian citizen (right, with her finac, the Uruguayan-born baritone Erwin Schrott, 35), is in Vienna, filming Puccinis Bohme with Mr. Villazn as her leading man. She also was to sing in Massenets Manon, opening on April 4 at the Vienna State Opera, The Associated Press reported. Her manager, Jeffrey Vanderveen, said she will keep her engagements as long as her doctors permit it. Helga Rabl-Stadler, president of the Salzburg Festival, said: The nicest reason for a cancellation is a child. Anna will receive the most beautiful bouquet of flowers from us. The Metropolitan Opera said Ms. Netrebko has withdrawn from 10 performances of its revival of Lucia di Lammermoor, beginning Oct. 3, but said her seven performances in Massenets Manon in December and January remained undecided.

title: Will the Capital of Change Choose Change or Experience?
description: San Francisco
