title: A Mutant Obsession
description: This week Im introducing the first article in what will be an occasional series about mutation. And yes, I admit it: Im obsessed with mutation (which is why Ive already alluded to it in a couple of earlier articles). The reason is that mutations to DNA form the raw material for evolution. Its wondrous to think that mutations, accumulated over billions of years through the action of natural selection and the other forces of evolution, have produced such diverse life forms as vampire squid, coconut palms, death cap mushrooms, giant Gippsland earthworms, Etruscan pygmy shrews, E. coli  and us.

title: Super Tuesday: With a British Accent
description: Looking for an alternative to the incessant cable news coverage of tonights national primary? The BBC is putting a British accent on Super Tuesday with five hours of programming from the networks studios in Washington.

description: Charlie Rose interviews Pete Peterson, co-founder of the Blackstone Group, in 2004 on entitlements and the need to end preferential tax breaks for the wealthy.

title: Live Blogging the Democratic Contests
description: OK, night owls. Were calling this a wrap. At least for the night. But given these results, well be seeing you in Wisconsin and Texas and Ohio and Pennsylvania (as Howard Dean might say).

title: Super Tuesday: The Projections
description: The networks showed no apparent reluctance to project winners, despite some surprises from the polls in earlier races like New Hampshire. Many states were called just minutes after their polls closed when one candidate had rolled up sizeable early margins. Senator Clintons win in New York was called by every network almost immediately at 9 p.m., just as the polls closed.

description: John McCain is scoring big in the northeast, and Mike Huckabee in the deep south, and its not surprising that the conservative blogosphere is gloomy. Heres Mary Katherine Ham at Townhall:

We want to congratulate all of this years nominees and we look forward to hosting our 15th Oscar party next year.

description: I had the honor of meeting Diana Munson on Tuesday at the awards dinner named for her late husband, Thurman, the Yankees catcher and captain in the 1970s. It was the 28th annual Munson dinner, and all these years after Thurmans death, she still seems surprised and touched at the outpouring of affection for him.

title: Lenders Reinstated to Program
description: The Education Department has allowed seven student loan companies to resume submitting bills for payments under a government subsidy program that was created to promote access to higher education. The departments inspector general found that some lenders had improperly received tens of millions of dollars in payments on loans that were ineligible; the seven lenders went through an audit to confirm the eligibility of their loans.

title: Recipe: Tournedos of Beef With Pot-au-Feu Vegetables
description: Time: 50 minutes

title: Challenger to Mugabe in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  A senior member of Zimbabwes ruling party, Simba Makoni, announced Tuesday that he would run for president against Robert G. Mugabe, the man who has kept a mighty hold on power for nearly 30 years and presided over one of the worlds most horrific economic free falls.

title: BP Misses Estimates and Plans More Job Cuts
description: LONDON  BP, the British oil giant, announced on Tuesday that it would cut an additional 5,000 jobs by the middle of next year, part of a plan by the chief executive, Anthony B. Hayward, to slim management and make the company more efficient.

title: Catching Up, Finally, With a Worthy Trend
description: THERES nothing worse than a convert, and I have become one, so look out.

title: One Pot
description: WHEN he was growing up in Vienna, Va., David Chang refused to eat the oxtail soup that his Korean mother made for the family throughout the winter. Somehow he resisted the big bowl she set on the table  the oxtails long-braised and accompanied by tender pieces of daikon radish.

title: Sudan: Progress for Darfur Peace Force
description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said that Bangladesh and Ethiopia had offered to lend helicopters to the new African Union-United Nations force for Darfur and that President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan had dropped objections to Thai and Nepalese troops. Just 9,000 of the projected 26,000 troops are in Darfur because of the Sudanese governments reluctance to approve non-African soldiers and the unwillingness of military powers to meet repeated requests from Mr. Ban for the 6 attack and 18 transport helicopters the force will need. John Sawers, Britains ambassador to the United Nations, said the developments were welcome but added, Anyone who dealt with Sudan over the last several years will be wary of announcements of progress.

title: No Voting Decision Can Close This Wound
description: Late in the afternoon, the door swung open at 602 West 180th Street, and out came a husky man in a baseball cap and jeans, standing on the steps of his building, a captain of the sidewalk. For a long moment, he just stared into the distance of the familiar. Barbershop next door. Income tax place across the street. Neighbors, waving hello. His name is Julio Cesar Lora, and he was waiting to be asked about the one subject few people mentioned.

title: California Panel to Weigh New Road in Beach Park
description: SAN DIEGO  In a battle pitting two California passions  cars and beaches  against each other, a state panel will consider Wednesday whether a highway can be built through a popular oceanfront state park.

title: Otherworldly Phenomena: Explainable? You Decide
description: The world is a better place because of UFO Hunters, a new series on Wednesday nights on the History Channel.

title: Jeter Is Said to Have Settled Tax Inquiry
description: ALBANY  State tax officials have settled their case against Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter, who they said owed three years worth of resident income taxes, a state official who has been briefed on the case said on Tuesday.

title: A Shameful Record
description: The United States leads the world in a shameful category: the number of people it has locked up for life without parole for crimes committed by juveniles. Juvenile crime should not be taken lightly, but young people should not be completely written off.

title: Indias School Shortage Means Glut of Parental Stress
description: NEW DELHI  They offer prayers. They set aside bribe money. Their nights are restless.

title: McCain Surges; Huckabee Strong in the South
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona won the most states and the most delegates on Tuesday, with impressive primary victories in the delegate-rich states of California, New York and Illinois. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, revived his candidacy with victories across the South.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Saturday about a ruling giving absentee voters in New Jersey the right to cast another ballot if their candidate quit the presidential race misidentified, in some copies, the political affiliation of two candidates who dropped out. Representative Dennis Kucinich of Ohio and Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico are Democrats, not Republicans.

title: Child Welfare Chief Praised as He Leaves New Jersey Post
description: NEWARK  When Kevin M. Ryan took over the child welfare system he had critiqued so persistently as New Jerseys child advocate, he was seen as the white-hat reformer who just might be able to turn around a flawed system that faced a federal takeover. The big question at the time, said Richard Wexler, executive director of the National Coalition for Child Protection Reform, was: Will he be allowed the time to do the job?

title: Death Toll in Kenya Exceeds 1,000, but Talks Reach Crucial Phase
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The death toll in the aftermath of Kenyas flawed elections surpassed 1,000 people on Tuesday as negotiations entered a critical stage in the effort to end the countrys violent political crisis.

title: Overcoming the Emptiness Left by a Mothers Death
description: Three women sit carefully spaced on a white sofa that is sealed in a protective plastic slipcover.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,938 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

title: Two Days After the Game, Patriots Belichick Is Still Being Belichick
description: The voice on the other end of the telephone line sounded dour, as usual. His tone was clipped, his answers reserved. Victories  18 of them  have not altered New England Coach Bill Belichicks live-in-the-present style. Neither has a defeat, even one as crushing as the Patriots 17-14 loss to the Giants in Super Bowl XLII on Sunday that foiled their bid for a perfect season.

title: American Soldiers Kill 3 Iraqis in Raid
description: BAGHDAD  American forces killed at least two men and a woman and wounded a child in a raid late on Monday near Tikrit in northern Iraq, the American military said Tuesday. Iraqi officials said a fourth person, a young girl, was killed in the attack.

title: Next Years War Costs Estimated at $170 Billion or More
description: WASHINGTON  The military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan could cost $170 billion in the next fiscal year over and above the $515.4 billion regular Pentagon budget that President Bush has proposed, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Wednesday.

title: What Profits an Off Broadway Show?
description: For three years Altar Boyz, the little musical about a Christian boy band, playing at New World Stages, has been a classic example of commercial Off Broadways struggles.

title: He Says Its Greek. Will Mother Agree?
description: WAR and famine, war and famine, Michael Psilakis said as he walked through Titan Foods, a Greek supermarket in Astoria, Queens, the aisles stacked to the ceiling with cheese, yogurt, apricots, olive oil and branches of dried herbs from the mountains of Thrace.

title: Vanity Fair Cancels Its Oscars Party
description: Imagine a wedding reception without food, music or Champagne, and you get an inkling of how a lot of Hollywood would view the Oscars without the Vanity Fair party. But Hollywood will no longer have to imagine it  the party is off.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,320,514

title: In Hungary, Roma Get Art Show, Not a Hug
description: BUDAPEST  A show of contemporary Romany art just closed on Sunday here at the National Gallery, Hungarys grandest museum. The exhibition was the latest nod to Europes most despised, and this countrys largest, minority. It came and went uneventfully, which itself was an event, considering the rise this autumn of the Hungarian Guard, a right-wing extremist group, which has made much news dressing up in paramilitary outfits recalling the Nazi era, ranting about safeguarding national culture and traditions and marching on a village against what it said was Romany crime there. Nobody is quite sure how extensive the group is or whether it is just good at grabbing headlines.

title: From Amsterdam Players, 3 Concerts of Classical Musics Greatest Hits
description: The Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam is at Carnegie Hall this week, showing off its chief conductor as of 2004, Mariss Jansons, and offering three concerts of classical musics greatest hits. A number of messages are in the air, and Ill try to field a few of them.

title: Two Parties, Two Distinct Paths to the Nomination
description: The Republican and Democratic presidential contests began diverging Tuesday, leaving the Democrats facing a long and potentially divisive nomination battle and the Republicans closer to an opportunity to put aside deep internal divisions and rally around a nominee.

title: Manchester Remembers Disastrous Day
description: Everything changed for Manchester United on a winter afternoon in Munich 50 years ago Wednesday.

title: Public Broadcasters Prepare to Fight Federal Budget Cuts
description: Its a familiar dance: for eight straight years, the Bush administration has proposed deep cuts in federal funds for public broadcasting, and seven times so far, Congress has restored them. But the magnitude of the proposed cuts put forth this week  Patricia Harrison, president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, called them draconian  still sent public broadcasters scrambling.

title: Recipe: Crispy Cod With Skordalia and Sweet-Sour Beets
description: Adapted from Michael Psilakis

title: Gasol Shows Benefits in First Game as Laker
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Pau Gasol, the big man who improved the Los Angeles Lakers championship hopes simply by showing up, arrived Tuesday for his first game with his new team with a shaggy beard still hugging his long jaw line.

title: Papers Show Wachovia Knew of Thefts
description: Last spring, Wachovia bank was accused in a lawsuit of allowing fraudulent telemarketers to use the banks accounts to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims. When asked about the suit, bank executives said they had been unaware of the thefts.

title: In Defense of Decadence
description: IN the first clipped sentences of his current best seller, Michael Pollan, distinguished author and designated repository for the nations food conscience, writes: Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants.

title: Key Interest Rate Is Raised to Slow Economy
description: Australias central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter- point to an 11-year high, saying a significant slowing in demand is needed to cool the fastest inflation since 1991. The bank increased the target for the overnight cash rate to 7 percent and the banks governor, Glenn Stevens, said annual inflation, which has overshot the banks target, might accelerate further before moderating in 2009. Core inflation in Australia has breached the central banks 2 percent to 3 percent target for two consecutive quarters, forcing the Australian bank to raise rates for the third time in six months.

title: Energy Dept. Funding Institutes with Iranian Ties
description: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department is subsidizing two Russian nuclear institutes that are building key parts of Irans Bushehr reactor even though the United States has spent years trying to shut it down, according to a House committee.

title: Senate Democrats to Push Expanded Stimulus Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The majority leader, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that Democrats were prepared to force a showdown with Republicans over a $204 billion economic stimulus package and would not bow to pressure to simply make modest changes to a less expensive plan that was approved by the House last week.

title: McCain Gains Wide Support; Huckabee Wins in States in South
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona won the most states and appeared poised to win the most delegates on Tuesday with impressive primary victories in the delegate-rich states of California, New York and Illinois. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, revived his candidacy with victories across the South.

title: Mexico: Bush Praises Anti-Drug Effort
description: President Bush called the Mexican president, Felipe Caldern, to talk about bilateral relations and give him a pat on the back for his efforts to stamp out drug cartels, aides to Mr. Caldern said. The call came five days before Mr. Caldern is to make his first visit to the United States since his election in 2006, with stops scheduled for New York, Boston, Sacramento and Los Angeles. He will not be meeting with Mr. Bush then. Instead Mr. Caldern will meet with local political leaders and associations of Mexican immigrants. Mr. Bush and Mr. Caldern will meet in New Orleans in April and be joined by Canadas prime minister, Stephen Harper.

title: Rio Tinto Rejects Latest Offer
description: LONDON  Rio Tintos board rejected on Wednesday an improved takeover offer by BHP Billiton of about $147 billion, saying it still undervalues the company significantly. The rejection puts pressure on BHP to raise the price further.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a French government report on risk controls at banks gave incorrect dates for the sale of the holdings built up at Socit Gnrale by a rogue trader, Jrme Kerviel. The bulk of the holdings were sold off on Jan. 21-22, not Jan. 20-21.

title: In London, the Hunt for a Town House
description: LONDON

title: A Year of Good Intentions for Monarchs Recruits
description: NORFOLK, Va.  Old Dominions football coach, Bobby Wilder, has recruited players for a team that does not yet exist.

title: Criticized Tennis Star Wont Play in India
description: NEW DELHI  Sania Mirza, the most successful tennis star in India, has announced that she has no desire to play in her country any more after a string of controversies that have exposed her to months of negative publicity.

title: As Romney Falters in Republican Race, Huckabees Drive Gathers Momentum
description: BOSTON  Even before the results were clear on Tuesday, Mitt Romneys advisers conceded that they faced a steep climb to the nomination because of simple delegate math.

title: Doctor to Determine Spears Competency
description: Commissioner Reva Goetz of Los Angeles County Superior Court appointed a physician on Monday to determine if Britney Spears, 26, is competent to make decisions, The Associated Press reported. While Ms. Spears continues to be held in a psychiatric ward, the judge also barred that troubled singer from contact with her friend and sometime manager Sam Lutfi, and extended until Feb. 14 the conservatorship over her personal and financial affairs granted last week to her father, James Spears, and her lawyer Andrew Wallet.

title: Tale of the Ticker Tape Will Live On and On
description: The Giants were back home in New York, at least for a few hours. The only question was if Mara Weather still existed.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about African-American Lives 2, a PBS series that explores the genealogy of prominent African-Americans, included an incomplete address for the genealogy Web site co-founded by the host of the series, Henry Louis Gates Jr. It is www.AfricanDNA.com, not AfricanDNA.com. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly at one point to the actor whose white great-great-grandfather sold land to his biracial sons. He is Morgan Freeman, not Mr. Morgan.

title: Armory Official Indicted on Charges of Taking Bribes
description: A state employee has been indicted on charges of taking more than $30,000 in bribes from the fashion designer Marc Jacobs and other vendors over the past seven years in exchange for favors in using the Armory at 26th Street and Lexington Avenue, State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced Wednesday.

title: Atlantis Set for Liftoff After Fixes
description: WASHINGTON  The twice-delayed flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, carrying a major addition to the International Space Station, is set for liftoff Thursday following the resolution of several technical issues, NASA managers said on Tuesday.

title: One Writers Brooklyn: Chronicles of Crime, Boombox Abuse and Divorce
description: An Italian woman tends her garden in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, and worries about her neighbor, an increasingly sullen black teenager, all the while arguing with her bigoted mother.

title: Youre 16, Youre Beautiful and Youre a Voter
description: THE 2008 presidential campaign has made history in many ways, not least being the arrival of a new generation at the polls. Voters under 29 were the first to anoint Barack Obama as their candidate. Reversing a general decline that began in 1972, youth turnout leapt in 2004, and in the early contests in this primary season it was up sharply.

title: Serbia Votes for the Future
description: Serbias voters wisely chose future hopes over past resentments in handing a narrow but important re-election victory to President Boris Tadic.

title: French Trader Says He Wont Be Made a Scapegoat
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel, the employee that the French bank Socit Gnrale has accused of trading losses that cost it more than $7 billion, emerged in public Tuesday to say that he would not be made the banks scapegoat.

title: Chads Capital Eerily Quiet as Rebellion Falters
description: NDJAMENA, Chad  A rebellion aimed at toppling Chads president appeared to falter Tuesday as France declared that it would intervene to protect the Chadian government if called upon, and a Darfur rebel group with close ties to the Chadian government said it had sent troops to help bolster the president, Idriss Dby.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Jan. 26 about the growing endowments of college preparatory schools referred incorrectly to the rankings by age of prep schools in the United States, and a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the founding date of one of those schools. Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., is the sixth-oldest boarding school, not the third-oldest school over all, including day schools. And Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., was founded in 1778, not 1781. An accompanying article about prep schools hiring of professionals to invest endowments and run capital campaigns misstated the given name and the surname of a New York consultant who helped the Childrens School in Stamford, Conn., raise $7 million. He is Timothy L. Hogen, not Tom Hogan.

title: China Frees a Journalist It Accused of Spying
description: BEIJING  China has freed a Hong Kong journalist jailed on charges of spying for Taiwan, the Hong Kong city government said Tuesday, after an international campaign calling for his release.

title: Darkness and Light
description: LOS ANGELES

title: For Democrats, Slower Road Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  Where to now?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Barry Morse, the actor who played the relentless detective in the 1960s television hit The Fugitive, misstated the name of the Canadian network he joined after moving to Canada in the early 1950s. It is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not Company.

title: Texas: Board Rejects Bids for Preserve
description: A state board unanimously rejected two private bids to buy about 9,200 acres of rugged state land in West Texas. The decision, by the School Land Board, was seen as a move toward a proposal from the National Park Service to acquire the land, the Christmas Mountains Ranch, and add it to Big Bend National Park. The state land commissioner, Jerry Patterson, had proposed the sale, but it was opposed by environmentalists.

title: Disney Is Upbeat Despite Economys Troubles
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company, reporting fiscal first-quarter results, sought to reassure investors that the weakening economy was not affecting television advertising sales or its robust theme park business.

title: Isn't America Great?
description: Days after becoming a United States citizen, Craig Ferguson will get a chance to zing President Bush. Mr. Ferguson, host of the Late Late Show on CBS, said he had been booked as the entertainer at the annual White House correspondents dinner in Washington on April 26. Mr. Ferguson, born in Glasgow, was sworn in as an American citizen on Friday. Customarily attended by the president, the dinner, described by Mr. Ferguson as like the Oscars for politicians, is a gathering not without pitfalls for comics. Barbed political jokes led to criticism of Don Imus and Stephen Colbert.

title: Luck and Defiance Rescued Limping McCain Campaign
description: On a Friday morning last July, Senator John McCain packed a carry-on bag, boarded a cheap flight out of Baltimore and traveled alone to New Hampshire.

title: Support Divided, Democrats Trade Victories
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama carved up the nation in the 22-state nominating contest on Tuesday, leaving the Democratic presidential nomination more elusive than ever. Mrs. Clinton won California, Massachusetts, New Jersey and her home state, New York, while Mr. Obama took Connecticut, Georgia, Minnesota and his base in Illinois.

title: Cisco Profit Up, but Shares Fall on Cautious Outlook
description: SAN FRANCISCO _  Cisco Systems, the largest network equipment maker, surpassed Wall Streets sales targets slightly as it announced quarterly earnings on Wednesday, but it forecast a slowdown in orders for the current quarter in the face of tightening corporate budgets.

title: Manufacturer in $2 Million Accord With U.S. on Deficient Kevlar in Military Helmets
description: A North Dakota manufacturer has agreed to pay $2 million to settle a suit saying it had repeatedly shortchanged the armor in up to 2.2 million helmets for the military, including those for the first troops sent to Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bottom Line for (Red)
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  A year ago, staff members at the Treatment and Research AIDS Center could barely cope. Patients, unable to find care elsewhere, flowed in from every corner of the country. And if one of them was fortunate enough to find a bed here, she often had to share it.

title: Text: Rells State of State Address
description: Following is the text of State of the State address by Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut as prepared for delivery on Wednesday:

title: Rios and Blue Jays Agree
description: Outfielder Alex Rios avoided salary arbitration by agreeing to a one-year, $4.8 million contract with the Toronto Blue Jays. Rios has career highs with 24 home runs and 85 runs batted in last season while batting .297. Rios had asked for $5.65 million and the Blue Jays countered at $4.5 million. Rios, 26, made $2,535,000 last year.

title: Support Divided, Top Democrats Trade Victories
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama carved up the nation in the 22-state nominating contest on Tuesday, leaving the Democratic presidential nomination more elusive than ever. Mrs. Clinton won California, Massachusetts, New Jersey and her home state, New York, while Mr. Obama took Connecticut, Georgia, Minnesota and his base in Illinois.

title: A Sizzle Among the Young (at Least Some)
description: In the hours before his first presidential caucus, Zach Hernandez, 24, sat at his office computer Tuesday in St. Paul, continually refreshing his profile on the Facebook networking site, watching the count of his fellow Obama supporters tick upward.

title: Whos the 800-Pound Gorilla?
description: In matters of business philosophy and practice, there are a lot of reasons to suspect Microsofts latest foray into the online world. It has a troubling history of bullying  and even worse  to undercut all challengers. Its relentless efforts to lock users into its software are particularly ill fitted to the Internets open spirit.

title: Give the Banks Some Credit
description: THE $145 billion economic stimulus package that President Bush is encouraging Congress to pass, with its tax refunds for individuals and tax cuts for business investments, may help relieve some of the symptoms of the countrys current financial trouble, but it does not address the most important economic problem we face. The health of the American  and indeed the global  economy depends on having a financial system that is able to extend credit to businesses and consumers.

title: Connecticut Governor Proposes Three-Strikes Law
description: HARTFORD, Conn.  Kicking off a new session of Connecticuts Legislature, Gov. M. Jodi Rell pledged today to push for a three-strikes law that would assure that three-time violent offenders received life sentences.

title: Champions Defend Title
description: The defending champions won again in the 31st annual Empire State Building Run-Up. Thomas Dolt, 23, of Germany won the mens elite race for the third consecutive year, covering the 1,576 steps from the lobby to the 86th floor observation deck in 10 minutes 8 seconds. Rickey Gates of Boulder, Colo., was second. Suzy Walsham, 34, of Australia repeated as the womens champion in 12:44.

title: A Protest in Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: Kayaker to Miss Games
description: Birgit Fischer, a kayaker who won eight Olympic gold medals, will skip the Beijing Games because she has not trained enough. Fischer, a 45-year-old German, has competed at six Olympics. She also has four silver medals from the Olympics and 27 world championship titles.

title: LaVaughn Robinson, Tap Virtuoso and Teacher, Dies at 80
description: LaVaughn Robinson, a tap-dance virtuoso on the big-band circuit in the 1940s and 50s who became a master teacher and a major force in taps revival, died on Jan. 22. He was 80.

title: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid
description: More than a decade ago, Andrew S. Grove, then the chief executive of Intel, aptly described the hypercompetitive mentality of Silicon Valley in his book title Only the Paranoid Survive.

title: Rangers Reap Benefits of Deal for Avery
description: A quirk in the Rangers schedule had the Los Angeles Kings playing at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, the one-year anniversary of their trading forward Sean Avery to the Rangers.

title: A Plan to Open a 1980 Gehry Mall Design to the Air
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Frank Gehry won acclaim as an innovative architect when he redesigned his home in this beachside city. But another local Gehry design, the enclosed 1980 mall known as Santa Monica Place, has long been regarded as obsolete  a suburban-style shopping center that turns its back on a thriving urban corridor.

title: When Histrionics Undermine the Music and the Pianist
description: Wandering from one television channel to the next the other day, I came across young people playing the piano. One man, bearded and a little hefty, rippled through a Beethoven sonata, sharing with the camera complicit smiles, exultant grimaces, gazes to the right and left, and a gentle swaying from side to side.

title: Monsanto Seed Approved by 3 Countries
description: The Monsanto Company said Japan, the Philippines and Taiwan had approved imports of its first new genetically modified soybeans in more than a decade. The seeds, Roundup Ready 2 Yield, increase yields by 7 percent to 11 percent compared with the first-generation Roundup Ready soybean seeds that have been sold since 1996, Monsanto said. The new plants, which resist Roundup weed killer, won regulatory approval in the United States and Canada in July, the company said. The product remains under review in the European Union, China and other export markets, Monsanto said.

title: Obama Takes Connecticut, Helped by Lamont Voters
description: Ned Lamont was not on the ballot, but his presence was nonetheless felt in Connecticuts Democratic presidential primary.

title: A Glimpse of Chinese Culture That Some Find Hard to Watch
description: Each of the first few numbers was more elaborate than the last, teeming with acrobatic dancers, awash in jewel-toned silks, swelling to the anthemic strains of the orchestra. It was the opening night of Chinese New Year Splendor, a music and dance production that began at Radio City Music Hall last week.

title: Alcohol and Drugs Abound in Pop? Who Knew?
description: Lyrics about drugs, alcohol and tobacco pervade popular music in the United States, according to a study published in the journal Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine, Reuters reported. The report of a team led by Dr. Brian Primack of the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine and released on Monday calculated that Americans from ages 15 to 18 listening to 2.4 hours of music a day hear 84 references to substances daily and more than 30,000 annually. About two-thirds of the references put drugs, alcohol and tobacco in a positive light by associating them with sex, partying and humor, the study said. Some genres, like rap and country in comparison with pop, have more references than others. The team used Billboard charts to identify the most popular songs of 2005, based on sales and airplay. They selected the 279 most popular from country, pop, R&B, rap and rock to examine for references to drugs, alcohol and tobacco. One third had explicit references; 42 percent had some kind of substance abuse reference. Jonathan Lamy, a spokesman for the Recording Industry Association of America, said, While we have not had the opportunity to thoroughly assess the study, its important to note that music is generally a reflection of society. He noted that albums carry parental advisory logos.

title: Paul Newman, Stage Director
description: Paul Newman will make his debut as a theater director when he stages a production based on John Steinbecks novella Of Mice and Men at the Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut from Oct. 7 to 25 and from Oct. 30 to Nov. 1. The Playhouse, where Mr. Newmans wife, Joanne Woodward, and Anne Keefe are artistic directors, will open its 78th season on Feb. 28.

title: Seattle Takes Steps to Recognize Minorities Role in Shaping Region
description: SEATTLE  Gray and green may be the colors most associated with this forward-focused city, but it has a history in other tones, too. Chinese immigrants helped build railroads, only to be driven out later. Japanese residents were forced into internment camps during World War II. Blacks surged into the city after the war for work. Hispanics are the fastest-growing group.

title: Area Voters Savor Rare Feeling: A Suspenseful Primary
description: It was a day when, beyond all else, New York and its suburbs finally seemed to matter.

title: Rift Over Closer Ties to Europe Ignites Serbian Political Crisis
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Prime Minister Vojislav Kostunica of Serbia on Tuesday attacked plans by his coalition partners to sign an agreement on closer ties with the European Union, plunging the government into crisis and calling its future into doubt.

title: Parking Rules for Ash Wednesday
description: Because of Ash Wednesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Letters
description: Boys Gone Wild

title: Ernesto Illy, Chairman of Coffee Company, Is Dead at 82
description: Ernesto Illy, who as chairman of Illycaff, maker of an expensive brand of coffee, was renowned as a scientific perfectionist of coffee and especially as an evangelist of espresso, died Sunday in Trieste, Italy. He was 82.

title: Nations Top Prospect Is Majoring in Drama
description: On college football national signing day, there is enough drama to fill a John Grisham novel. And as the Internet has transformed the day into a sports holiday in the past decade, virtually no recruitment has held the intrigue as that of quarterback Terrelle Pryor.

title: Football Upstages Munson Awards
description: It was a day for politics and football in New York on Tuesday, leaving Alex Rodriguez a bystander. Rodriguez, the Yankees third baseman, donated to Rudolph W. Giulianis presidential campaign, and his favorite football team is the hapless Miami Dolphins.

title: Correction: Recipe: Roasted Arctic Char With Ancho-Shallot Butter
description: A recipe with the Feed Me column last Wednesday, for Arctic char with ancho-shallot butter, misstated the stick equivalent for the 8 ounces of butter called for. It is two sticks, not one. A corrected recipe is at nytimes.com/dining.

title: Decisive California Wins for Clinton and McCain
description: LOS ANGELES  Hillary Clinton and John McCain scored decisive victories in California late Tuesday night after heated skirmishes for the states opulent troves of delegates to each partys national convention.

title: Recipe: Oxtail Soup
description: Adapted from David Chang, Momofuku Noodle Bar

title: The Story Behind a Late-Night Brawl
description: Forgive those television viewers who might have drifted off for a few minutes at the end of The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC on Monday, only to awaken confused to this scene: Conan OBrien, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert brawling backstage at Mr. OBriens Late Night, variously armed with a baseball bat, a fire extinguisher and, of course, an oversize recycling bin.

title: Asia Stocks Follow Dows Decline; Europe Is Steady
description: TOKYO  Asian markets slumped Wednesday amid fears that shrinking consumption in the United States could harm exporters, and possibly affect broader Asian economic factors. But European markets closed higher.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about the Democratic presidential campaign misstated the given name of the president of CNN, who was in the control booth for Thursdays Democratic debate. As the article noted, he is Jonathan Klein, not Joe. The article, in likening the lack of intensity in the debate to a brown bag lunch at a certain Washington policy research organization, misstated part of the organizations name. It is the Brookings Institution, not Institute.

title: A Warhol Surfaces and Is Headed for Court
description: Last September, a man who has admittedly lived a hard-knock life walked into Christies auction house with an Andy Warhol painting of a dollar sign and asked to have it put up for sale.

title: Questions Abound About the Recruit Who Wasnt Recruited
description: Before an assembly of his high school classmates last week, with all the fervor and high dudgeon only a pep rally can conjure, a football player from Nevada announced his commitment to play for the University of California. Then the university announced it had made no such offer.

title: Intelligence Chief Cites Qaeda Threat to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Al Qaeda is gaining in strength from its refuge in Pakistan and is steadily improving its ability to recruit, train and position operatives capable of carrying out attacks inside the United States, the director of national intelligence told a Senate panel on Tuesday.

title: Huckabee Revived With Strong Showing in South
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona won the most states and appeared poised to win the most delegates on Tuesday with impressive primary victories in the delegate-rich states of California, New York and Illinois. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, revived his candidacy with victories across the South.

title: Recipe: Foamy Avgolemono Soup
description: Adapted from Michael Psilakis

title: France: Romantic, Glamorous, Litigious
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy and his wife, Carla Bruni, won a lawsuit against Ryanair, the European low-cost airline, for the unauthorized use of their photograph in an ad. A judge in Paris ordered the airline to pay Mr. Sarkozy one euro in damages, the sum he had asked for. Ms. Bruni, a former model, was awarded 60,000 euros, about $88,000. She had sought 500,000 euros, or $732,000, what she said she would expect to earn for appearing in an ad. The couple filed the suit against the airline after the ad appeared in the newspaper Le Parisien last week, just days before they married on Saturday. A cartoon bubble above Ms. Bruni read: With Ryanair, my whole family can come to my wedding.

title: Recipe: Broiled Feta With Roasted Peppers and Olive Salad
description: Adapted from Michael Psilakis

title: Asian Markets Follow Dows Decline
description: Stocks plummeted on Wall Street on Tuesday after a business survey provided another strong signal that the United States might be in the early stages of a recession. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 370 points as the market experienced its worst day in nearly a year.

title: A Love Letter to Putin (but Its Not Addressed to Him)
description: MOSCOW  They meet in Leningrad, where President Vladimir V. Putins career took off in the early post-Soviet years: he is a dashing official, and she is a flight attendant. They move to Germany, where Mr. Putin was once a K.G.B. agent. They are deeply in love.

title: For Candidates, Lighter Schedules Ahead After a Frenzied Day of Voting
description: WASHINGTON  Where to now?

title: Playing Dress-Up With Better Resources
description: Four looks into the Proenza Schouler show on Monday night, each involving a short dress made of intricately folded layers of silk twill, you realized that Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez had moved into serious design territory. Maybe too serious for many of the young women who are their most ardent fans.

title: U.N. Warns of Huge Crop of Afghan Opium Poppies
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Afghanistan will produce another enormous opium poppy crop this year, close to last years record harvest, and Europe and other regions should brace themselves for the expected influx of heroin, the United Nations warned in its annual winter survey of poppy planting patterns.

title: After 3 Road Victories, Rangers Falter at Home
description: This was a Rangers letdown that Coach Tom Renney could see coming from a distance: a date against the worst team in the Western Conference, just as his team returned home after winning three road games that injected new life into its puzzling season.

title: Deal for Casey and Red Sox
description: The free-agent first baseman Sean Casey completed an $800,000 contract with the Boston Red Sox to be their backup first baseman. Casey hit .296 with 4 homers and 54 R.B.I. in 143 games for Detroit last season.

title: BHP Billiton Launches Hostile Bid for Rio Tinto
description: LONDON  The battle over Rio Tinto intensified early Wednesday when BHP Billiton, the worlds biggest mining company, increased its takeover offer to about $147 billion after a Chinese rival bought a stake last week.

title: Clemens Is Questioned by Congressional Staff
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens emerged from nearly five hours of questioning by congressional investigators Tuesday repeating his denials that he never used steroids or human growth hormone and thanking them for the chance to say so under oath.

title: Petrova Ousted
description: The defending champion Nadia Petrova was upset by Kateryna Bondarenko, 7-6 (4), 3-6, 6-4, in the first round of the Open Gaz de France in France. Amlie Mauresmo, a two-time winner, cruised past the American qualifier Julie Ditty, 6-1, 6-2.

title: Obama and Clinton Settle In for the Long Run
description: With no breakout winner in Tuesdays Democratic primaries, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama began fortifying for a drawn-out and expensive campaign on Wednesday, with Mrs. Clinton disclosing that she had lent her campaign $5 million and Mr. Obama rejecting calls for several more debates.

title: Arkansas Petitions N.C.A.A.
description: Arkansas will ask the N.C.A.A. to allow the transfer quarterback Ryan Mallett to play immediately for the Razorbacks without sitting out a year. Mallett transferred from Michigan after Rich Rodriguez replaced the retiring coach Lloyd Carr. Mallett has three years of eligibility remaining.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: DNA Indicates Lice Reached Americas Before Columbus
description: When two pre-Columbian individuals died 1,000 years ago, arid conditions in the region of what is now Peru naturally mummified their bodies, down to the head lice in their long, braided hair.

title: Burned by Bad Polls, Networks Try Restraint
description: Remember the Maine! was the rallying cry of the 1898 midterm elections (and the Spanish-American War). Super Tuesday 2008 came with a warning label: Dont forget New Hampshire.

title: Recipe: Garlic Confit
description: Adapted from Michael Psilakis

title: Loud Cheers and Jumps for Joy for Giants
description: The weather forecast said showers in New York on Tuesday, but the Giants got deluged by paper, cheers and virtual hugs instead.

title: Connecticut City Plans to Team Its Police With Federal Immigration Agents
description: DANBURY, Conn.  When baseball season begins, Mayor Mark D. Boughton will probably throw out the first pitch again for this citys Dominican baseball team. On Sundays, he sometimes can be found on the sidelines at the soccer games organized by many of the ethnic communities here. And he makes it a point to be at the annual Hajj festival held by the sizable Muslim population.

title: Young Voters Flock to Polls
description: In the hours before his first presidential caucus, Zach Hernandez, 24, sat at his office computer Tuesday in St. Paul, Minn., continually refreshing his page on the Facebook networking site, watching the count of his fellow Obama supporters tick upward. Zach Hernandez is excited for Minnesota to vote for Obama! he declared on his personal page.

title: Vis--Vis Visas
description: The rapper Snoop Dogg, below, who was denied a visa to enter Britain last year, said the ban had been lifted, the BBC reported. Speaking on Larry King Live on CNN last week, Snoop Dogg, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, said a judge found me innocent, and now Im able to go back there. The Home Office said it was unable to comment on individual cases. The entertainer was arrested in 2006 in a disturbance at Heathrow Airport. ... The British singer Amy Winehouse left a rehab clinic in London on Monday to meet with officials at the United States Embassy about obtaining a visa to enter the United States to perform at the Grammy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles on Sunday, the BBC reported. Her spokesman said no decision had been made about her application. Ms. Winehouse, 24, has been nominated for six Grammy Awards.

title: Voter ID: The Solution, or the Problem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Ordered to Pay French First Couple Over Ad
description: PARIS  A French court on Tuesday ordered the low-cost airline Ryanair to pay damages to French President Nicolas Sarkozy and his new wife, the super-model-turned-pop-singer Carla Bruni, for using a photograph of them in an advertisement without their consent.

title: Danger in Kenya
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Take Manhattan, and It Takes to Them
description: The Giants surprised even their most ardent fans with their Super Bowl victory. On Tuesday, the new N.F.L. champions were the ones left awestruck.

title: One More Nook for Japans Noodles
description: BACK in 2004, when Ryuichi Munekata opened Yakitori Totto, many things about it seemed novel and different: chicken sashimi, waitresses with PalmPilots, comfy nooks for small groups, pitch-perfect yakitori prepared over bamboo charcoal.

title: The President Who Would Be King
description: Canberra, Australia

title: Bordeauxs a Bargain, and Heres Why
description: ITS been said that the distinctions between Bordeaux and California are rapidly diminishing, and that the singular finesse, elegance and longevity that have long characterized good Bordeaux wines have given way to a New World emphasis on powerful fruit flavors and easy accessibility.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the business of buying and selling Internet domain names described incorrectly the investments of one private equity firm that has backed companies in the field. The firm, Oak Hill Capital Partners, invested in one such company, Oversee.net, but it did not invest in another, Demand Media. (A similarly named company, Oak Investment Partners, invested in Demand Media.)

title: Popes Rewrite of Latin Prayer Draws Criticism From 2 Sides
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI on Tuesday issued a replacement for a contentious Good Friday prayer in Latin, removing language that many Jewish groups found offensive but still calling for the Jews conversion.

title: Toyotas Profit Rises on Shift in Strategy
description: TOKYO  Toyota reported Tuesday that its profit rose 7.5 percent in the October-to-December quarter as its strategy of shifting its focus to emerging markets from the United States appears to be paying off.

title: From Prince Andrew, Critical Words for U.S. on Iraq
description: While Prince Andrew declares himself a fan of the United States  and his cellphone ring tone comes from the American TV drama 24  the man who is fourth in line to the British throne has some critical words for Americas Iraq policy and thinks that Washington should have listened to advice from London.

title: Pairings: Tournedos of Beef With Pot-au-Feu Vegetables
description: For guests at a chateau in the Mdoc, lunch or dinner is often a rather classic dish of lamb, beef or veal. With the regions often elegant wines, which show complexity from fruit tamed by acid and soft tannins, roasted meats are a safe choice and they match the wines breeding.

title: An Ad With Talking Pandas, Maybe, but Not With Chinese Accents
description: THE sponsor of two commercials during Super Bowl XLII for Salesgenie.com, which drew complaints from viewers because of the characters ethnic accents, says he is sorry and promises to stop running one of them.

title: Wine Calendar
description: Champagne With a View

title: Plans for Domino Sugar Refinery Elicit Criticism
description: Plans for revisions and additions to the landmark Domino Sugar refinery on the Brooklyn waterfront, including five stories of glass apartments on top, drew criticism from preservationists at a hearing before the citys Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday.

title: Recipe: Chicken Liver Challah Crostini With Sage
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: In CBS Test, Mobile Ads Find Users
description: Pssst, hey you! Theres a cheap latte waiting at the coffee shop on the corner!

title: Voting Goes Smoothly in Most Places
description: Despite long lines, confusion among poll workers and scattered computer malfunctions, there were no reports of widespread problems Tuesday as voters showed up in record numbers to cast ballots for their preferred presidential candidates.

title: Judge Rules to Dismiss Cases of 17-Year-Olds Seen as Adults
description: A Rhode Island judge ruled Tuesday that felony cases brought while state law briefly treated 17-year-olds as adults would be dismissed or transferred to Family Court.

title: Northeast Delivers 2 Big Prizes for Clinton
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton scored twin victories in the Democratic primaries in her home state of New York and in New Jersey on Tuesday. But her rival for the nomination, Senator Barack Obama, won by a narrow margin in Connecticut, a state she once expected to win easily.

title: Texas: Immigrant Limits Challenged
description: A lawsuit was filed over a Dallas suburbs latest effort to keep out illegal immigrants by barring home rentals to people who cannot prove they are in the country legally. The suit, filed on behalf of a real estate broker, accuses the City Council of the suburb, Farmers Branch, of having violated the Texas Open Meetings Act when it drafted and approved the rule last month.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Jan. 26 about the growing endowments of college preparatory schools referred incorrectly to the rankings by age of prep schools in the United States, and a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the founding date of one of those schools. Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., is the sixth-oldest boarding school, not the third-oldest school over all, including day schools. And Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., was founded in 1778, not 1781. An accompanying article about prep schools hiring of professionals to invest endowments and run capital campaigns misstated the given name and the surname of a New York consultant who helped the Childrens School in Stamford, Conn., raise $7 million. He is Timothy L. Hogen, not Tom Hogan. (Go to Article)

title: Rutgers Women Hand UConn Its First Loss
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Epiphanny Prince picked a good night to have the best game of her Rutgers career, scoring a career-high 33 points, including 27 in the decisive second half, to lead the Scarlet Knights to a 73-71 victory Tuesday over top-ranked and previously unbeaten Connecticut.

title: Army Names Vice Chief of Staff
description: The No. 2 commander in Iraq, Lt. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno has been chosen to be the next Army vice chief of staff, replacing Gen. Richard Cody, the Army said. General Odierno, currently commander of the Third Corps, has been the top day-to-day commander in Iraq under Gen. David H. Petraeus for the past 15 months. In another shift, Lt. Gen. Martin E. Dempsey has been nominated for promotion to four-star general and assignment as the commander of U.S. Army Europe.

title: Its Awesome, Baby! Vitale Has His Voice Back
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Dick Vitale wept over the deterioration of his voice, his moneymaker.

title: Rival Democrats Clutch Their State Prizes, and Look to Collect a Few More
description: A coast-to-coast series of primaries and caucuses Tuesday ended with one definitive conclusion for Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama: The show will go on.

title: Footnotes
description: The Canadian singer Feist has won the Seventh Annual Shortlist Music Prize for her album The Reminder (Cherry Tree/ Interscope). The prize was established in 2001 to honor innovative and underground performers who had not yet achieved mainstream commercial success. ... Claudia Bonn, executive director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center since 2003, is leaving after 15 years with the organization to become executive director of Wave Hill, the 28-acre public garden and cultural center in Riverdale, the Bronx. She will succeed Kate French, who announced in June she would leave in the spring.

title: Defense in Girls Beating Death Focuses on Mothers Role
description: Three times now, the photographs of Nixzmary Browns body have brought jurors to tears.

title: Germany: Truck Makers Profit Rises 33%
description: The German truck maker MAN said its profit increased by 33 percent in the fourth quarter, powered by strong demand for its commercial vehicles, and forecast that earnings would continue to rise this year. MAN, which is based in Munich, said it earned 331 million euros ($490 million) in the October-December quarter, up from 248 million euros a year earlier. Total group sales rose 35 percent, to 5.23 billion euros ($7.7 billion) from 3.88 billion euros a year earlier. Sales of commercial vehicles rose 42 percent, to 3.6 billion euros ($5.3 billion). MAN said its fourth-quarter operating profit was up 78 percent, to 631 million euros ($935 million) from 354 million euros a year earlier.

title: Georgia Loses Federal Case in a Dispute About Water
description: ATLANTA  Georgia lost a major court fight in the Southern battle over water rights on Tuesday when a federal appellate-court panel said the state could not withdraw as much water as it had planned from an Atlanta-area reservoir.

title: What You Get for ...$350,000
description: Provincetown, Mass.

title: Pirates Sign Sanchez
description: Second baseman Freddy Sanchez, a two-time All-Star, signed a two-year, $11 million contract Tuesday with the Pittsburgh Pirates that included a 2010 option that could make the deal worth $18.4 million. Sanchez, 30, made $2.75 million last year and was seeking $4.9 million. The team offered $4.1 million.

title: Michigan: Documents Ruled Public
description: Documents related to a whistle-blower lawsuit that led to a text-messaging sex scandal involving the mayor of Detroit must be released to the public, a judge ruled. The city said it would appeal the ruling by Friday, the deadline set by the judge, Robert J. Colombo Jr. of Wayne County Circuit Court. Two newspapers are suing the city to determine if there was a secret settlement in the suit, in which a jury ruled against the city. The case eventually cost the city more than $8.5 million.

title: Rockies Sign Podsednik
description: Scott Podsednik, the catalyst of the White Sox world championship run in 2005, agreed to a minor league contract with the Colorado Rockies. Since leading Chicago to the championship, Podsednik has been slowed by injuries. He batted .243 with 12 steals and 30 runs in 62 games last season. In 2005, he batted .290 with 59 stolen bases, and hit 2 home runs in the playoffs.

title: When Anxiety Is at the Table
description: FOR some of us the trouble starts before we even step into a restaurant.

title: That Gypsy Girl: She Is and Always Will Be Trouble
description: Tension is the central characteristic of any production of Bizets Carmen, because it is the central characteristic of the work itself. On the one hand, Bizets miraculous score offers a parade of seemingly effortless, showstopping arias and ensembles. On the other, its main characters are at an increasing simmer that breaks into a full boil by the end.

title: Divided They Run
description: Americans have made it clear that they are fed up with partisan division. But there has been no healing in the 2008 campaign, despite many candidates promises. The primary season has created stark intramural divisions that pose risks for both Democrats and Republicans. And the real interparty race hasnt even begun.

title: Hamas Claims Responsibility for Blast
description: JERUSALEM  Israel appeared to face a heightened threat from Palestinian suicide bombings on Tuesday after the military wing of Hamas officially claimed responsibility for a lethal blast the day before at a shopping center in the southern town of Dimona.

title: Spain: Industrial Production Declines Sharply
description: Industrial production in Spain posted the biggest contraction in more than five years in December as slower European growth curbed demand for Spanish goods. Production at factories, farms and mines fell 2.4 percent from a year earlier after adjusting for the number of days worked, following a 1 percent drop in November, the National Statistics Institute said.

title: Storms Across 5 States Leave at Least 50 Dead
description: About 50 people were killed and at least 100 were injured after a wide swath of thunderstorms packing tornadoes, high winds and hail swept through the South on Tuesday night and Wednesday morning.

title: The Best of Two Old Worlds
description: ALTHOUGH Russ & Daughters and Babbo are not much more than a dozen blocks apart, the distance between them might as well be a universe when it comes to chicken livers.

title: Halston Reappears as the Scene Changes
description: Liza Minnelli, sitting at the Halston show next to Harvey Weinstein, one of the labels new owners, let out a sharp Yes! at the sight of the first outfit, a gray cashmere cape over a matching dress with suede boots, and spanked her hands together. Ms. Minnelli was a friend of Halston, one 1970s icon indelibly linked to another, but the challenge for the company is to find a new customer and to avoid being an American sentimentalist for once.

title: The Next Step to Safety
description: American consumers endured a nerve-racking 2007. Companies recalled millions of toys containing lead paint or tiny magnets. Regulators were forced to order the recall of one million cribs after three babies strangled because of defective side rails.

title: Metallica and Pearl Jam and Kanye West and
description: Pearl Jam, Metallica, Kanye West, B. B. King, Jack Johnson and Alison Krauss  and Robert Plant (both below) will be among the more than 100 acts at the seventh annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts festival this year, the organizers announced. Taking place from June 12 to 15 at its regular spot, a 700-acre farm in Manchester, Tenn., south of Nashville, the festival will also include Willie Nelson, Phil Lesh, the Mars Volta, Sigur Ros, Jack Whites Raconteurs, My Morning Jacket, Death Cab for Cutie, Levon Helm and the list goes on. Bonnaroo was one of the first rock festivals to specialize in broad, eclectic programming, but along with Coachella in California, it has faced stiffer competition as similar events have sprung up around the country.

title: Artists Rally for Spiral Jetty in Utah
description: An oil companys plan to begin exploratory drilling near the remote site of Robert Smithsons Spiral Jetty along the Great Salt Lake in Utah has stirred an impassioned response from artists and others who fear that the project could endanger that massive artwork. The jetty, a 1,500-foot-long curlicue of salt crystals, rocks and mud jutting into the lake, was completed by Smithson in 1970, three years before he died in a plane crash. The State of Utah, which must approve any plan for drilling in the area, decided recently to extend a period for public comment on the proposal until Feb. 13. John Harja, who runs the states public land policy coordinating office, said on Tuesday that the office had received 900 letters, e-mail messages and calls about the issue in the last several days. Richard Moe, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, issued a statement calling the jetty a significant cultural site and saying that the trust was deeply concerned about the potential harm that energy development could bring to it.

title: A Fee That Developers Would Like to See Rise
description: It may seem befuddling that an industry group would favor having to pay higher fees to the government for more intense regulation, but that seems to be the case with developers of condominiums and co-ops in New York.

title: A 2nd Case on Detainees Complicates Deliberations
description: WASHINGTON  Two months after the Supreme Court heard arguments in a case on the rights of the Guantnamo detainees, an unanticipated development has suddenly scrambled the outlook for a straightforward resolution. Cases that have been proceeding on completely separate judicial tracks may be about to converge.

title: 2 Die in Harlem and Bronx Fires
description: Two people were killed in separate fires in Manhattan and the Bronx on Tuesday morning, fire and police officials said.

title: Ukraine Joins the W.T.O.
description: MOSCOW  Ukraine joined the World Trade Organization on Tuesday after 14 years of negotiations, a milestone for the former Soviet republic that helps clear the way for a valuable free trade agreement with the European Union.

title: Faith, Politics and the Good Deed Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review in Sports on Monday about Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, who performed at halftime of the Super Bowl, and Alicia Keys, who performed before the game, referred incorrectly to Ms. Keyss current album, As I Am. It fell to No. 2 on last weeks Billboard chart; the soundtrack for the movie Juno was No. 1.

title: Calendar
description: Salmon on the Syllabus

title: Germany: Turkey Joining Inquiry Into Fire
description: The Turkish government added to the pressure on German officials to determine whether a deadly blaze in an apartment building in the southwestern German city of Ludwigshafen could have been a premeditated hate crime. The Turkish Foreign Ministry called for an extensive investigation into the disaster on Sunday, in which nine people, five of them children, were killed, and a baby was tossed from a third floor window to save its life. All were Turks. The German Interior Minister, Wolfgang Schuble, accepted the Turkish governments offer to send its own fire experts to take part in the investigation. A police spokesman said investigators had not been able to enter the building because it was so badly damaged that it was in danger of collapsing. Arson has not been ruled out. Investigators were interviewing two girls who said they saw a man start the fire. The police said the building was the target of an attack with Molotov cocktails in August 2006.

title: G.O.P. Senators Block Democrats Stimulus Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans managed Wednesday evening to block a relatively expansive and expensive economic stimulus package championed by Senate Democrats, who could not muster the 60 votes needed to advance their plan to a final vote.

title: At Least 15 Die in South in Rare Midwinter Storms
description: ATKINS, Ark. (AP)  Tornadoes across four Southern states tore through homes, ripped the roof off a shopping mall and blew apart warehouses in a rare spasm of violent winter weather that killed at least 22 people and injured dozens more.

title: Military Retirees Demand Musharrafs Resignation
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  Several hundred retired generals, admirals and servicemen gathered Tuesday for the third time in two weeks in this military town and demanded the resignation of President Pervez Musharraf.

title: S.E.C. Fines 4 for Trades Involving Dow Jones
description: A former Dow Jones & Company director and three associates will pay more than $24 million to settle charges that the associates traded illegally on inside knowledge of the News Corporations takeover of Dow Jones, federal regulators announced on Tuesday.

title: A Long-Term Tenant Takes Top Billing
description: It was business as usual on Monday night at the Village Vanguard, and nobody was complaining. The 16-piece Vanguard Jazz Orchestra was playing arrangements from its celebrated book, including a few that made their debuts some 40 years ago. The sound of the band filled the room, and the players exuded a kind of crisp and spirited poise.

title: Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, Spiritual Leader, Dies
description: Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, who introduced transcendental meditation to the West and gained fame in the 1960s as the spiritual guru to the Beatles, died Tuesday at his home and headquarters in Vlodrop, the Netherlands. He is believed to have been in his 90s. Steven Yellin, a spokesman for the organization, confirmed the Maharishis death but did not give a cause.

title: Colorblind Conclusions on Racism
description: A black man stands on a street corner in Manhattan and waves for a taxi, and the driver speeds by. Is this racism? The actor Danny Glover thought so, and he took his case to the public and city regulators, resulting in a citywide crackdown on wary cabbies in the late 1990s. But what if he got it wrong?

title: Dow Plunges on Survey of Business
description: Stocks plummeted on Wall Street on Tuesday after a business survey provided another strong signal that the United States might be in the early stages of a recession. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 370 points as the market experienced its worst day in nearly a year.

title: Some Trustees Challenge Polytechnic-N.Y.U. Merger
description: New York Universitys ambitious plan to merge with Polytechnic University in Brooklyn and acquire an engineering school is suddenly facing a rebellion from Polytechnic alumni and trustees on the eve of a final board vote.

title: Drugs Killed Pimp C
description: The death of the influential Southern rapper Pimp C, below, has been ruled an accident attributable to an overdose of drugs celebrated by Three 6 Mafia and the Pimp C group Underground Kingz in the 2000 single Sippin on Some Syrup, The Associated Press reported. The Los Angeles County coroners office identified the drugs as codeine and promethazine, essential ingredients of syrup. The coroners office said Pimp C, whose real name was Chad Butler, had sleep apnea, an ailment that can cause breathing during sleep to stop for as long as 30 seconds. Capt. Ed Winter of the coroners office said that sleep apnea, combined with large amounts of prescription-strength cough syrup, killed Pimp C on Dec. 4 in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 33.

title: A Mournful Womans Magic Calls Forth Slavery Times
description: In Conjur Woman, a folk opera for a single performer, the venerable actress Sheila Dabney, working with three proficient musicians onstage at the La MaMa Annex, creates a potent spell seasoned with the power of myth.

title: Macquarie Chief to Retire; Successor Is Named
description: The Macquarie Group, the securities firm, said that its chief executive, Allan Moss, would retire and be succeeded by Nicholas Moore. Mr. Moore is currently head of Macquarie Capital. The firm also forecast a 23 percent gain in full-year profit to 1.8 billion Australian dollars ($1.62 billion) on higher trading volumes. Mr. Moore, 49, who runs the division that generates more than 50 percent of profit, takes the top job May 24, the company said in a statement.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Shortcuts column in Business Day on Saturday, about elaborate marriage proposals, misspelled the residence of Elaine Pursey, a British woman whose husband proposed on the Wollman Rink in Central Park in Manhattan. She is from Berkshire, England  not Barkshire (though it is pronounced BARK-shire in England).

title: Super Tuesday: Night Of The Touch-Screens
description: Television news has come a long way since the NBC anchor Tim Russert infamously scribbled his 2000 election calculations on a plain white board.

title: Hillary Clinton Speaks in New York
description: Hillary Clinton celebrated wins in several key states on Super Tuesday, including New York and New Jersey. (Video: NBC News)

title: Battles Decided, Not Wars
description: The late-night results have been worth waiting for, although the waiting may go on for quite a while after the Opinionator dons (or drinks) a nightcap.

title: A Night at the Primaries
description: Torn from my notepad while watching the election returns:

title: A Night at the Primaries
description: Torn from my notepad while watching the election returns:

title: Barack Obama in Chicago
description: Barack Obama recalled his time as a community organizer as he exhorted his supporters to fight on for the Democratic nomination. (Video: NBC News)

title: Super Tuesday: Networks Try Restraint
description: Alessandra Stanley on the Super Tuesday TV Watch:

title: John McCain in Arizona
description: John McCain struck a conciliatory tone toward his Republican nomination rivals as he celebrated Super Tuesday victories. (Video: NBC News)

title: Tornadoes Sweep Southern States
description: Tornadoes churned through Arkansas, Mississippi, Tennessee and Kentucky on Tuesday.

title: Assessing the Results
description: There was no knockout blow for either Democratic contender on Super Tuesday, while John McCain gained in the G.O.P. race.

title: Live Blogging the Republican Contests
description: 11:22 p.m. Pacific| Wrapup  On the Republican side, dare we say the F-word? We mean front-runner, of course.

title: Super Tuesday: Charles Gibson, Enjoying Every Minute
description: ABC was the only broadcast network to replace all three hours of its prime time programming with primary coverage on Tuesday. The broadcast, titled Super Tuesday Showdown: Coast to Coast, seemed most interesting as late night turned into early morning.

title: Super Tuesday: Calling California, Monitoring Missouri, Counting Delegates
description: California is a magical place for politicians, Jeff Greenfield, the chief political correspondent on CBS, said, minutes before the polls closed in the most populous state up for grabs on Super Tuesday.

title: A Super Tuesday in the NHL
description: So many games are important now, with about a third of the regular season remaining and so many teams figuring that if the Giants can win the Super Bowl then anythings possible.

title: Wednesday: New York Fashion Week
description: Selections from the Wednesday runway shows during New York Fashion Week.

title: Ritchie Capital to Pay $40 Million to Settle Late-Trading Case
description: The hedge fund Ritchie Capital will pay $40 million to settle investigations into its trading practices from 2001 to 2003, regulators and the company said on Tuesday.

title: Fashion Diary: Skinny Male Models
description: In the Paris and Milan shows, the male model appeared to have been downsized, now the trend has followed the fashion pack back to New York.

title: Papers Show Wachovia Knew of Thefts
description: Last spring, Wachovia bank was accused in a lawsuit of allowing fraudulent telemarketers to use the banks accounts to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims. When asked about the suit, bank executives said they had been unaware of the thefts.

title: S.E.C. Sets New Office to Distribute Penalties to Investors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Tuesday it has created a new office in the agency to quickly distribute financial penalties to wronged investors.

title: Recession Fears Send Bank Shares Down
description: Shares of Citigroup and other financial companies suffered broad declines for a second day on Tuesday, as evidence mounted that borrowers are falling behind on more payments, the nations economy might be in recession, and losses on complex debt securities might worsen.

title: Food Stuff
description: For a New Restaurant, Homage to History

title: AOL Snaps Up Buy.at
description: Time Warners AOL unit said Tuesday that it has acquired buy.at, a leading affiliate marketing network backed by the venture capital firm DFJ Esprit.

title: S.&P. Warns on Banks Exposure to Bond Insurers
description: Commercial and investment banks could see their credit ratings cut if the bond insurers that hedge some of their assets were themselves downgraded, Standard & Poors said on Tuesday, as billionaire investor Wilbur Ross mulled whether to invest $1 billion or more in the sector.

title: D.O.J. Calls for Rule Changes for Futures Exchanges
description: The Justice Department has called for change in financial futures exchanges, saying they should not own the trade clearing business because their ownership inhibits competition.

title: Diageo Abandons Absolut Plans in Favor of Ketel One Deal
description: Diageo abandoned its interest in buying Swedens Absolut vodka Wednesday after forming a joint-venture with the owners of the Ketel One vodka brand at a cost of $900 million.

title: AXA Buys Out Turkish Partner
description: AXA, Europes second-biggest insurer, has agreed to buy local partner Oyak out of its Turkish insurance joint venture for $525 million, Oyak said on Wednesday, the latest deal in the fast-growing Turkish sector.

title: Coca-Cola Brews $40 Million Deal for Stake in Honest Tea
description: Coca-Cola spent millions to showcase its flagship Coke Classic brand in Super Bowl ads on Sunday, but the $40 million it invested Tuesday in a trendy tea company might be a better indicator of its sales growth plans.

title: Gap Fall 2008 Collection
description: Patrick Robinson's fall mens and womens collections for Gap call to mind the 1990s grunge moment.

title: Canadian Hedge Funds Start Incubator Fund
description: A pair of Canadian firms have started a hedge fund incubator fund, calling it the first of its kind in the country.

title: Germanys Debitel Eyes I.P.O.
description: Debitel, Germanys biggest mobile-phone services reseller, is planning a return to the stock market through an initial public offering within a year, the companys chief executive, Oliver Steil, told The Financial Times Deutschland.

title: Spanish Energy Upstart Plans $1 Billion I.P.O.
description: Eolia Renovables de Inversiones, an independent wind and solar power company that is taking on Spains national utility giants, is scheduled to go public on the Madrid exchange this year with a $1 billion valuation.

title: Will $147 Billion Be Sweet Enough For Rio Tinto?
description: BHP Billiton is hoping its increased $147 billion takeover offer for Rio Tinto is enough to bring the board to the table.

title: CIT Names Head of Capital Markets
description: The CIT Group, the commercial financing company, said Tuesday that it had named William J. Koslo Jr. to run its capital markets division.

title: EBuddy Makes Friends With V.C.s
description: eBuddy wants to be the lingua franca of Web- and mobile-based instant messaging. A start-up, eBuddy offers a Web-based instant messenger that allows people to chat on any of the AOL, Google Talk, MSN, MySpace, and Yahoo Messenger clients.

title: Benchmark Answers Numobiqs Call
description: Numobiq, a company that develops software that turns low-end mobile phones into smartphones, has raised $4.5 million from Benchmark Capital.

title: Advanced Technology Closes New $303 Million Fund
description: Advanced Technology Ventures announced on Tuesday that it had closed its eighth fund at $303 million.

title: Blank Check Raises $879 Million in Europe
description: Liberty International Acquisition, the latest blank-check company formed by investor Nicolas Berggruen, raised 600 million euro ($879 million), somewhat less than the expected $1 billion, when its initial public offering priced late Tuesday in Europe. But the deal did succeed in pricing, a feat in itself given Tuesdays swan dive in global stock markets.

title: Massachusetts Pension Fund Fires Goldman Sachs
description: The Massachusetts state pension fund has fired a money manager for the fifth time in five months, terminating a $1.2 billion contract with Goldman Sachs because of alleged substandard performance and discomfort with personnel changes at the bank.

title: The Race Card
description: In November 1987, a deputy sheriff was dispatched to an apartment building in Dutchess County, upstate New York. There a resident of the building led him to a large plastic garbage bag that contained a seemingly unconscious Tawana Brawley. Brawleys body was smeared with feces, her clothes were torn, the crotch burned away from her jeans, and she was not wearing a bra or underwear. An ambulance was dispatched, and Brawley was taken to the hospital. When her clothes were removed, the markings were stark and unambiguous: the words nigger, bitch, and KKK were scrawled on Brawleys torso in black charcoal.

title: Merrill Gets In on Another Big Mining Deal
description: Merrill Lynch, dropped as an adviser and financier to the Brazilian mining company Vale, has re-emerged in the mining sector as a lender to BHP Billiton, which raised its bid for a rival, Rio Tinto.

title: Buyout Bosses in Europe Form Committee
description: A whos who list of Londons top private equity bosses has come together in a new committee aimed at developing a common hymn sheet for the controversial industry, The Times of London reported.

title: Morgan Stanleys Vietnam Venture Is Derailed
description: Morgan Stanley has failed in its attempt to form a landmark securities joint venture in Vietnam after the government bowed to pressure from rival banks angered by the proposed deal.

title: S.E.C. Fines 4 for Trades Involving Dow Jones
description: A former Dow Jones & Company director and three associates will pay more than $24 million to settle charges that the associates traded illegally on inside knowledge of the News Corporations takeover of Dow Jones, federal regulators announced on Tuesday.

title: French Trader Says He Wont Be Made a Scapegoat
description: Jrme Kerviel, the employee the French bank Socit Gnrale has accused of trading losses that cost it more than $7 billion, emerged in public Tuesday to say that he would not be made the banks scapegoat.

title: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid
description: More than a decade ago, Andrew S. Grove, then the chief executive of Intel, aptly described the hypercompetitive mentality of Silicon Valley in his book title Only the Paranoid Survive.

title: Sympathy for Blackstone?
description: Round one of the Alliance Data Systems/Blackstone Group litigation is under way. On Monday, Blackstone filed a motion to dismiss ADSs suit. Later that day ADS fired back with its own letter in opposition.

title: Canaan Closes $650 Million Fund
