description: Canaan Partners, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif., said Wednesday it closed its eighth investment fund with $650 million, which it will use to back start-ups in the technology and healthcare industries.

title: Ministry of Silly Walks, or Ministry of Peace?
description: From The Times of London:

title: Sniffing Crazily at Her Ankles
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: The issues primary
description: From the California exit polls:

title: The Early Word: How Super Was It?
description: Months ago, the pundits and media saw the distant Feb. 5 and its more than two dozen nominating contests as the Day When We Would Have Our Nominees.

title: 2009 Underdogs
description: The Giants can play the underdog card straight through the off-season. The Patriots have been installed as the favorites to win the 2009 Super Bowl, at odds of 5-2, at many sports books in Las Vegas. The Giants? Theyre a 12-1 choice.

title: Bill Gross puts me in the same basket as Keynes, I think
description: I dont deserve it, but Ill take it.

title: The Morning After
description: The Opinionator is looking foward to spending the day feasting on the carcasses of last nights primary races, and is going to start close to home with an interesting tidbit from the Politicos resident Dem-watcher, Ben Smith:

title: Clinton Prevails on Home Turf, but Obama Pulls Connecticut Surprise
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton easily won in New York and New Jersey, but lost in Connecticut  a state she once expected to win easily  by a narrow margin to Senator Barack Obama. (Senator John McCain swept the Republican races in all three states.) Michael Powell of The Times credits Clintons coalition of women voters, Latinos and Democrats who say experience is the most important factor, but he notes surprising weaknesses in parts of that base. For example, Mr. Obama came within less than 2 percentage points of winning Brooklyn, one of the biggest Democratic counties in the nation.

title: Conan, Stewart,  Colbert  The Brawl
description: It began with a faux feud over which comic has bragging rights to the success of Mike Huckabee in the Republican presidential campaign. And given that TV writers are on strike, the dispute easily escalated to some cheap slapstick Monday night on Conan OBriens show (some salty fightin words):

title: The Return of Vitale
description: Dick Vitale is back, baby!

title: Democratic Race: What's Next?
description: John Harwood discusses the states that are important for both Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama to win in the coming contests.

title: Tuesday and Beyond
description: How many times in American history has a candidate won the black vote in a state, roughly split the white vote, and still lost the state by a whopping 10 percentage points? Thats what happened to Barack Obama in California. He did well among whites, thanks to his support from white men. He won African-Americans. But he lost Asians and he lost by two-to-one margins among Latinos, who make up nearly a third of the Democratic vote.

title: The Nuclear Option for Europe?
description: One of the nuclear industrys main selling points these days is that nuclear reactors generate nearly nothing in terms of planet-warming carbon dioxide gases. Another selling point, underlined in a report issued Wednesday by the London-based World Energy Council, is that fission atomic reactors already supply the largest amount of low-carbon energy in Western Europe.

title: Yang to Yahoos: Dont Lose Focus
description: The prospect of working for Steven Ballmer and the leviathan that is Microsoft cant help but be a bit distracting to the many employees of Yahoo. That could be why Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive of Yahoo, decided to circulate a memo to his workers Wednesday in which he thanked them for staying focused on executing our priorities and asked them to sit tight while Yahoo considers how to respond to Microsofts $44.6 billion takeover offer.

title: Bubble-Wrapped Reviews
description: For the next 30 working days, the Bagger will spend two-and-a-half hours a day inside a hyperbaric oxygen chamber. No paper is allowed in the chamber, which is a tube with a capacity for two people. Once inside and brought to pressure, the Bagger  he is not making this up  has to place a bag/helmet over his head and sit there.

title: Party Favor
description: As some of you may know, Vanity Fair is pulling the plug on its post-Oscar party. As Graydon Carter, the magazines editor, told the Baggers colleague, Richard Perez-Pena: There will be something sort of liberating about ordering Chinese food and watching the Oscars in bed.

title: A Metal Concert for Putins Heir Apparent
description: Gifts for exiting colleagues can be so difficult: What do you give the guy who has everything? Or more to the point: What do you give the guy who is all but guaranteed to assume the presidency of the worlds largest country?

title: Global-Warming Jujitsu
description: Suppose that the pessimistic forecasts of global warming are accurate. Suppose that the planets temperature rises according to the high-end scenario of the U.N.s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, and that we experience the economic and social impacts (like hunger, malaria and coastal flooding) projected by the much-publicized Stern Review sponsored by the British government.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Meghan Daum
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: Heath Ledgers Death Is Ruled an Accident
description: Updated, 12:43 p.m. | The New York City chief medical examiners office has ruled that the actor Heath Ledger, whose body was found in a SoHo apartment on Jan. 22, died of an accidental overdose of prescription medications that included painkillers, sleeping pills and anti-anxiety drugs.

title: College Signing Day: The Paper Trail
description: I just arrived in Pittsburgh and am headed down to Jeannette, Pa., for the singing day festivities surrounding the nations No. 1 college football recruit, Terrelle Pryor.

title: The Endless Pursuit of Unnecessary Things
description: Amid the flow of Super Tuesdays, Superbowl surprises, news about faltering energy projects and rising solar cities, Ive been collecting threads that relate to a central theme of Dot Earth: the implications of humanitys growing numbers and resource thirst.

title: What Would It Be Like to ? (Part 2)
Edgar Bronfmans Fifth Avenue Flip
description: Private equity bosses are constantly fighting off criticism that they are flippers, buying companies and quickly selling them for a profit without adding much real value.

title: Why Hate Bordeaux?
description: Two weeks ago the wine panel took a look at what $50 could get you among 2004 Napa Valley cabernet sauvignons. In my column today, we follow up with what $50 buys among 2004 Mdocs. The comparison in terms of value is not even close, as $50 buys you a lot more in Bordeaux than in Napa, at least among the 2004s.

title: Live From Jeannette
description: Over a decade covering college sports, Ive never seen anything quite like this: at Jeannette High School on the outskirts of Pittsburgh, there are nine television trucks, five with satellites affixed to the top, waiting for the college announcement of star prep quarterback Terrelle Pryor. Two television stations  ESPNU and CSTV  are setting up to go live.

title: Obsessed With Restaurants
description: One of the most fascinating things about eating in restaurants is how subjective the experience is. You can be having the meal of a lifetime while the couple at the next table sulks and glowers at each other, their food untouched.

title: A Show of Support
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Rio Tinto Rejects BHP a Second Time
description: Its BHP Billitons move again.

title: Send In Your Storm Photographs and Video
description: We are inviting readers to submit digital photos and videos of the severe storms that swept through the South for publication on NYTimes.com.

title: Obama Girl Didnt Vote
description: So, did the Obama Girl actually vote for Barack Obama on Tuesday?

title: Rogue Trader on Getting a Bit Carried Away
description: As our article today reports, Jrme Kerviel, the trader accused of causing billions in losses at Socit Gnrale, emerged on Tuesday with a vow that he would not be made a scapegoat in what he claimed was a much wider case of fraud at the bank.

title: A Truly Super Tuesday
description: Sure, Hillary Clinton had a better night than Barack Obama. But the biggest headline of the night was not her successes, it was a trifecta of good news for the Democrats.1.Turnout, Turnout, Turnout. Its almost become cliche in this primary season to note that Democratic turnout in primary states is topping G.O.P. turnout, but the difference on Tuesday was unbelievable, and especially noteworthy in some key battleground states for the fall. The Democratic vote exceeded the Republican vote by more than 200,000 in Missouri, by almost 100,000 in Georgia and by more than 50,000 in Tennessee  all states that went Republican in the 2004 presidential election. And in what were once known as competitive states in American politics  California, New Jersey and Illinois  fuggetaboutit.

title: Parody of Tom Cruise's Video
description: Jerry O'Connell parodies Tom Cruise's video, where he talks about Scientology.

title: Reaction Abroad to Feb. 5 Results
description: The IHT's managing editor, Alison Smale, discusses the results of the presidential nominating contests in 24 U.S. states.

title: ABC Profits Soars 30 Percent
description: Revenue for The Walt Disney Company rose 9 percent, to $10.45 billion, led by gains in advertising revenue at ABC and ESPN, Brooks Barnes reports in todays Times. In its fiscal first quarter:

title: Cable TV Drives Time Warner Profit
description: The Associated Press reports on Time Warners earnings:

title: Josh Brolin
description: "No Country for Old Men"

title: Marion Cotillard
description: "La Vie en Rose"

title: Lens:  'The 39 Steps'
description: Photographs by Sara Krulwich taken behind the scenes at the Broadway play.

title: Paul Dano
description: "There Will Be Blood"

title: Amy Ryan
description: "Gone Baby Gone"

title: Pathetic Losers, Callous Brutes
description: I saw Jerry Springer: The Opera when it was playing in Londons West End. It was one of the most exhilarating evenings of theater Ive experienced in recent years. So I was delighted when Ben Brantley raved about a New York production that had a limited run of two performances last week. Remarkable, Brantley said, spectacularly inventive, celestial. At the end of his review, Brantley pleaded for some producer to open Springer on Broadway so that more people would be able to see it. Im not sure thats going to happen.

title: James McAvoy
description: "Atonement"

title: Jim Sturgess
description: "Across the Universe"

title: Ellen Page
description: "Juno"

title: Casey Affleck
description: "The Assassination of Jesse James"

title: Breakthroughs
description: The subjects of the 2008 Oscars portfolio talk about the actors who inspired them.

title: You Can Hardly Call It a Friendly
description: The United States mens national team will play Mexico tonight at Reliant Stadium in Houston. Jack Bell reports that more than 55,000 fans are expected to attend. If youre not one of them, you can watch on ESPN2 (and Univision) starting at 9 p.m. Eastern time. Or, you can log on for extensive coverage online today courtesy of U.S. Soccer.

title: Fashion Week Catch-Up | Suzy Menkes

title: Leader of the Pack
description: Switching to the Republicans, the liberal Washington Post columnist Harold Meyerson is oddly giddy about John McCains strong showing. A more direct affront to the Republican strategy devised by Karl Rove  to build support within the partys right-wing base and then try to win over just enough moderates to carry elections  cannot be imagined, he insists. McCains whole campaign is anti-Rovian. His core supporters are Republican moderates and Republican-inclined independents, and then he picks off enough conservatives to prevail. Even if he didnt have a history of rocky relations with various right-wing leaders, the very trajectory of his campaign would pose a threat to the conservative movement, notwithstanding that McCain is philosophically an heir to Barry Goldwater.

title: Win or Lose, It Was Party Time
description: It wasnt a full-fledged victory party, but Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons supporters cheered each and every victory on Tuesday night from the packed ballroom of the Manhattan Center Studios on West 34th Street. Sitting on bleachers or mingling on the carpeted ballroom floor, with Bruce Springsteen and Tom Petty blaring from the speakers, hundreds of people watched returns from a large television screen tuned to CNN. Some clutched beer or wine, though many people may have been scared away from the prices at the cash bar ($8 for a Corona, for instance).Terry McAuliffe, the campaign chairman, hustled through the room wearing a tight smile and trailed by nervous-looking aides. Mrs. Clintons spokesman, Jay Carson, chatted with reporters and tried to play down expectations, suggesting that Senator Barack Obama was poised to win New Jersey.

title: Bruno on Race and the Primary
description: New Yorks top Republican, the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, suggested this morning that race could play a critical role in the continuing battle for the Democratic presidential nomination. And that is good news, he predicted, for the candidate he wants to get the Republican nomination, Senator John McCain.

title: What I Ate Last Night Department
description: This is a keeper. On the way home yesterday, I scored some lovely sea bass fillets, Savoy cabbage, and one of my favorite winter vegetables, sunchokes. I cooked the sunchokes as I often do: thin-sliced, in olive oil, thyme, garlic, and parsley (in the picture, the sliver of orange is a piece of habanero, which I was too timid to mince, but it contributed something). The cabbage I cut poached in meat stock, steamed the fish on top of that, and seasoned it with nothing but salt and pepper. Could not have been better.

title: Debating a Science Debate
description: There has long been a tendency for science either to be ignored or cherry picked in the rough and tumble arena of politics and lawmaking. Many scientists have said that things got markedly worse through two terms under President Bush, as strings of incidents showed how political appointees were involved in shaping government reports on everything from climate to condoms.

title: France: Mobile Phones Buoy Telecom Concern
description: France Telecom said 2007 net profit rose 52 percent on better margins and lower taxes, with its mobile phone businesses fueling sales. Net profit increased to 6.3 billion euros ($9.28 billion) from 4.14 billion euros a year earlier. The 2006 figure was reduced by a write-down of 2.8 billion euros for good will, but the rise in profit was attributed also to lower taxes and financial charges and improving margins. Revenue rose to 52.96 billion euros ($77.99 billion) from 51.7 billion euros in 2006, helped by growth in France Telecoms mobile phone operations across Europe, Africa and the Middle East.

title: Hundreds of Expatriates Flee Violence in Chad
description: PARIS  About 300 expatriates evacuated from Chad arrived safely on Wednesday on a flight chartered by the French government after being trapped in the middle of fighting between rebel and government forces in the capital, Ndjamena.

title: Europe Spars With Serbia Over Union and Kosovo
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  The European Union criticized Serbias nationalist prime minister, Vojislav Kostunica, on Wednesday for blocking plans to sign a political and economic agreement with Europe. Mr. Kostunica had called the pact a deception aimed at tricking Serbia into conceding the independence of Kosovo.

title: Star's Swimsuit to Be Sold to Buy Cows
description: Question: Whats the connection between an abandoned bathing suit and three cows? Answer: Nicole Kidman. The story goes this way: a bathing suit left by Ms. Kidman at a pool in Sweden is to be auctioned on Saturday to raise money to buy cows for poor families in India, Agence France-Presse reported. The suit, now owned by Zlatko Nedanovski and on display in a second-hand store in Eslov, a town in southern Sweden, will go to the highest bidder when the sale finishes on Saturday. Mr. Nedanovski, 32, bought the swimsuit for $778 after the staff at the pool turned it over to a local radio station. Ms. Kidman, an avid swimmer, forgot the suit at a pool she had reserved for her use in the town of Vanersborg in 2002 while in Sweden to film Lars von Triers Dogville. Mr. Nedanovski said he hoped to raise $1,400 to buy five cows through the Swedish aid organization Erikshjaelpen. Today, he said, referring to an early bid, we have enough for three cows.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Gates Foundation Head to Leave Longtime Post
description: SEATTLE  Patty Stonesifer, who helped start the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation in an office over a pizza parlor seven years ago and has overseen its growth it into the worlds largest philanthropic institution, said in an interview on Wednesday that she would step down by the end of the year.

title: Iran: Russia Says New Rocket Raises Nuclear Suspicions
description: Russian news agencies quoted the deputy foreign minister, Aleksandr Losyukov, as saying that Irans test of a rocket this week had raised suspicions about its nuclear program. Iran fired the rocket Monday from its new space center in the deserts of Semnan Province and said it wanted to launch domestically built satellites for research and telecommunications. The United States said the launch was a troubling show of a technology that could be used to fire long-range ballistic missiles. It adds to general suspicions of Iran regarding its potential desire to build nuclear weapons, said Mr. Losyukov, who is also the top Russian negotiator in the six-nation talks over North Koreas nuclear weapons program. Long-range missiles are one of the components of such weapons. That causes concern. Iran gave no details about the rocket, but the official Russian news agency RIA Novosti said some experts believed it could be an advanced version of the Shahab-3 ballistic missile, which has a range of 1,200 miles.

title: With Flawed System Unchanged, Italy Sets Elections for April
description: ROME  President Giorgio Napolitano dissolved Italys Parliament on Wednesday, and the cabinet scheduled national elections for April 13.

title: Olivier Award Nominees Chosen
description: With a record-breaking 11 nominations, the musical Hairspray leads the competition for the Laurence Olivier Awards in London. Hairspray was followed by three other musicals: Parade, with seven nominations, and The Drowsy Chaperone and Lord of the Rings, each with five. All four shows will compete in the best new musical category. The contenders for best new play are A Disappearing Number by Simon McBurney; The Reporter by Nicholas Wright; Vernon God Little by DBC Pierre, adapted by Tanya Ronder; and War Horse, adapted by Nick Stafford from the novel by Michael Morpurgo. War Horse captured a total of six nominations. The 32nd annual Olivier Awards, created to recognize excellence on the London stage, will be announced on March 9 in London.

title: Toll of Deadly Tornadoes in South Climbs Past 50
description: ATKINS, Ark.  Residents in five Southern states rose Wednesday to widespread clusters of destruction caused by an unusually ferocious winter tornado system. At least 55 people were killed, and scores more were injured.

title: Schiano Extends Reach of Rutgerss Recruiting
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Greg Schiano said Wednesday that he did not get every high school player he wanted from the so-called State of Rutgers, the expanding region that now includes New Jersey, New York City, Staten Island and Long Island.

title: ONeal Dealt to Suns for Marion
description: The Phoenix Suns acquired Shaquille ONeal on Wednesday in a stunning trade that could propel the franchise to its first championship or wreck the N.B.A.s most entertaining team. Either way, the Western Conference race just became a little more compelling.

title: Triptych by Francis Bacon Is Sold for $46.1 Million
description: LONDON  A mysterious three-part painting that is viewed as a Francis Bacon masterpiece sold for $46.1 million Wednesday night at a Christies auction here, countering expectations of a record price for his work.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about a film industry apprenticeship program for wounded marines referred incorrectly in some editions to a man shown working at a computer in a film editing class. Like all of the people in the group photograph, he was an unidentified student; the man was not Nick Popaditch, a marine quoted in the article.

title: Britain: Diageo Drops Bid for Absolut Vodka
description: Diageo said it had abandoned a potential bid for the Swedish brand Absolut Vodka and formed a joint venture with the owners of a rival Dutch vodka, Ketel One. Diageo said that it would pay $900 million (611 million euros) in a deal with the Nolet family for perpetual exclusive global rights to sell, market and distribute Ketel One vodka. The Nolet family, distillers since 1691, will continue to own the brand rights for Ketel One and the Nolet distillery in Schiedam in the Netherlands. That leaves three rivals  Pernod Ricard, Bacardi and Fortune Brands, the United States distributor of Absolut  in the auction, for Absoluts owner, Vin & Sprit, which is being sold by the Swedish government. Analysts have estimated the sales price at $6.3 billion.

title: The Beta Males Charms
description: EVERYWHERE theres someone better than you, said Steven Tsapelas, 26, over a cheeseburger deluxe at Mikes Diner in Astoria. Everywhere you go, if youre talking to a girl theres five other guys right in their immediate vicinity blowing you away.

title: Ruth Stafford Peale, 101, Dies; Helped Ministry Flourish
description: Ruth Stafford Peale, the daughter of a minister who vowed never to marry a minister, then married the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale and worked with him to build one of the 20th centurys most influential ministries, died on Wednesday at her home in Pawling, N.Y. She was 101.

title: The Allure of Precision Just Around the Curve

title: Democrats in New York: Enthusiastic and Divided

But more than a third of the states enrolled Democrats voted Tuesday, the highest percentage in a New York presidential primary in 20 years and more than twice the proportion that cast ballots in 2004.

title: Rio Tinto Rejects Latest Offer
description: LONDON  The board of Rio Tinto, the mining company, rejected on Wednesday an improved takeover offer by a rival BHP Billiton of about $147 billion, saying it still undervalues the company significantly. The rejection puts pressure on BHP to raise the price further.

title: A Hopeful Year for Unions
description: By virtually every indicator, 2007 was a dismal year for American workers. Job growth slowed, unemployment jumped and wages lost what little ground they had gained against inflation since 2003. There is one sliver of good news: the percentage of American workers who belong to a union rose for the first time in three decades.

Stimulus Plan 
Clears Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Congress overwhelmingly approved a $168 billion economic stimulus program on Thursday, sending it to President Bush for his signature so that millions of Americans can look forward to government checks in the mail.

title: Pet Food Indictments for 3 Firms
description: Two Chinese companies and an American importer were indicted Wednesday on charges of intentionally defrauding and misleading American manufacturers about poisonous ingredients used in pet food last year.

title: Editors Note
description: A front-page article on Tuesday described the problems of the tribunals at the American military base in Guantnamo, as seen through the failure to resolve the case of Abdul Razzaq Hekmati, an Afghan war hero who died there Dec. 30 after a five-year-long detention. The article quoted several Afghan officials who said they were prepared to offer evidence that he was falsely accused, but were never given a chance to do so.

title: A Pint-Size Peacemaker With a Lot to Teach
description: Theyre both assertive young heroines with dark eyes and dark hair, brightly colored animal friends, theme songs that feature much chanting of their names and a habit of slipping non-English words into their conversations. Oh, and they both work for the same division of Viacom.

title: A Digital Still Camera Able to Shoot Video Thats Ready for YouTube
description: YouTube is turning up everywhere  even on digital still cameras. Casios new 8.1-megapixel Exilim Zoom EX-Z80, like a few other recent cameras, features a YouTube capture mode that shoots movie clips in the sites recommended format and resolution, and comes with software to upload the videos easily to the Web.

title: California Voters Reject Proposal for Peace on the Rock
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Alcatraz escaped.

title: Abraham Brumberg, Writer on Eastern Europe, Is Dead at 81
description: Abraham Brumberg, a well-known writer on Eastern Europe, died on Jan. 26 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 81.

title: Kid Stuff for Jack Black
description: The Academy Awards telecast may have Jon Stewart as its host, but the Kids Choice Awards, in which the favorite performers of teenagers and tweens are honored (and then doused onstage with green slime), will have Jack Black, above. Nickelodeon, which will broadcast the 21st annual edition of its so-called Kiddie Oscars from Los Angeles on March 29, is expected to announce its selection of Mr. Black formally on Thursday.

title:
Romney Exits, 
Saying He Has 
to Stand Aside 
for Our Party
description: Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who sought to position himself as the true conservative choice for the Republican presidential nomination, announced Thursday afternoon that he had ended his campaign.

title: From a 9-Year-Old Teacher, a Lesson in How to Squeeze
description: There have been several teenage grandmasters in chess. It takes longer to reach that level of expertise in bridge. An exception who proves the rule is Shivam Shah from London. He is now 15, but he has been playing since he was 4.

title: Knicks Know What It Takes to Win, Not How
description: There was a lot of championship talk at Madison Square Garden again Wednesday night.

title: More Fun Than Root Canals? Its the Dental Vacation
description: JENNIFER GATES, 40, a hairstylist and makeup artist from Northern California, hadnt seen a dentist in a decade when she got the call last spring. Her father, Jerry Halley, 64, phoned to say he desperately needed crowns for a few back teeth and other work. Without insurance, Mr. Halley, who owns a landscaping business in Oregon, would have to pay the estimated $8,000 bill.

title: Characters Adrift on the Fast Track to Nowhere
description: Among the lost souls drifting through Charles Bocks avidly seedy Las Vegas novel, Beautiful Children, there is a loner named Kenny. There are three things about Kenny that the reader needs to know.

title: Northwest and Delta Talk Merger
description: In events that could reshape the airline industry, merger talks have picked up pace between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines, a combination that could force other carriers to seek partners, people with knowledge of the talks said Wednesday.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,323,124

title: The Secret Lives of Pollsters
description: Washington

title: Army Pilot Charged With Selling Stolen Egyptian Artifacts
description: A United States Army helicopter pilot who was briefly based in Cairo has been charged with selling more than 80 stolen Egyptian artifacts to an art dealer in Texas, federal authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Shutting Down Zanan
description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran and his hard-line allies rail against the United States and other external enemies, but who they really fear are their own citizens.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,941 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday and Wednesday:

title: Fire Takes All They Have, Except a Sense of Family
description: It was about 8:30 on the evening of Oct. 12. Nilda Cedeo and her son Luis Perez were walking home from the grocery store, just three blocks from their apartment in the South Bronx.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Damascus Journal article on Monday, about the political implications of a performance by a well-known Lebanese singer in Syria, misstated the title of Hassan Abbas, who was briefly involved in planning the cultural festival at which the singer performed. He is a researcher at the French Near East Institute in Damascus, not its director.

title: For Political Analysts, Ground Keeps Shifting
description: Fund-raising success and poll standings have long been the election-year equivalent of the EKG, used to measure presidential candidates supposed vitality by journalists, other political analysts and campaign strategists until the real results  called votes  are in hand.

title: Before the Ante, the Mets Have a Pair of Aces
description: The other night, after the Johan Santana deal was in place, Willie Randolph was chatting with Pedro Martnez about the immensity of acquiring a pitcher with a 93-44 career record. Why, Santana just might win the Cy Young award, the manager said.

title: Italy Defeats Portugal
description: Fabio Quagliarella headed in a goal less than 30 seconds after he took the field, helping Italy beat Portugal, 3-1, in Zurich.Luca Toni put Italy ahead in the 45th minute. Italy, the defending World Cup champion, scored again in the 51st when Milan midfielder Andrea Pirlo scored to the lower-right corner.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the On Baseball column on Sunday comparing the Super Bowl appearances of the brothers Eli and Peyton Manning with the World Series pitching performances of the half brothers Livn and Orlando Hernndez misstated the number of consecutive World Series in which the Hernndezes were starters. It was six, not five. (A picture caption repeated the error in some editions.)

title: Betting a Farm Would Work in Queens
description: One can only imagine how the judges reacted when the architects walked in lugging the kind of hulking concrete-pouring cardboard tubes used at construction sites filled with flowering heads of cabbage.

title: A Top American Gymnast Is Back to His Routine
description: LAS VEGAS (AP)  After several months of training and tracking progress by his standards, Paul Hamm finally gets to compete in front of a crowd and a scoreboard.

title: Copter Crash Kills 7 Pakistani Army Officers
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Seven Pakistani Army officers were killed Wednesday when their helicopter crashed in the restive South Waziristan tribal region straddling the border with Afghanistan, military officials said.

title: Keeping Your Stuff Yours, With a Do-It-Yourself Home Security System
description: Security means keeping other people out of your stuff. Just as a $50 piece of software can guard your computer, there are do-it-yourself options for keeping your house safe from intruders.

title: Seduced and Abandoned by Promises of Freedom
description: It is strange to think of becoming Swedish, says the man named Adnan, whose intense brown eyes and olive skin seem about as far from the stereotype of the Scandinavian as you could get.

title: For Travelers, a Hand-Held Device Performs Basic Printing
description: Printing on the road has long been filled with problems. The Printstik PS950 by Planon lets you skip the quest for a printer by bringing one with you. It weighs 1.5 pounds and is completely self-contained.

title: More Than Sleep Deprived
description: To the Editor:

title: Condoleezza Rice Visits Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With criticism of the war in Afghanistan increasing on both sides of the Atlantic, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Wednesday that European governments needed to convince their people that sending troops to Afghanistan  and keeping them there  should remain a priority for NATO.

title: Who Is More Electable?
description: Its increasingly likely that the Republican presidential nominee will be John McCain, who is also the Republican most likely to win the November election.

title: A Fine Mess
description: EVERY four years, Washington moans about the way the national political parties select their presidential nominees. But the grumbling about the 2008 contest has struck an unusual note. Instead of complaining about a process that is too short, some now mutter that the process is too drawn out. Instead of being too predictable, the campaign is too confusing and uncertain: no one has any idea what will happen next. Is this any way to pick a president?

title: Huckabee Leads in Keeping His Cost Per Delegate Low
description: If political victory was measured in the wise use of scant financial resources, Mike Huckabee would be the front-runner in the presidential race.

title: 6 City Schools Designated by the State as Failing
description: Six New York City public schools, five of them middle schools, were newly placed on the states list of schools performing so poorly that they are at risk of being shut down. Four other city schools, state officials said, would have been added to the list, released on Wednesday, had the city not already decided to close them.

title: England Wins for Capello
description: Shaun Wright-Phillips scored a tie-breaking goal in the 62nd minute of a 2-1 exhibition victory over Switzerland in London on Wednesday, and Fabio Capello got off to a winning start as Englands new coach.Jermaine Jenas also scored for England, which played without the former captain David Beckham. Beckham, the Los Angeles Galaxy star, was denied the chance to become the fifth player to make his 100th appearance for England when Capello left him off the roster.Eren Derdiyok scored the equalizer in the 58th minute for Switzerland.I must say that we were quite nervous at the start, worried, Capello said. We probably have still at the back of our minds our failure to qualify for Euro 2008, and Wembley always generates pressure on the players and they couldnt play as they wished to at first.

title: Tocchet Returns to the Coyotes After Serving a 2-Year Suspension
description: Rick Tocchet spent nearly 3,000 minutes in the penalty box during a 17-year career as a hard-nosed N.H.L. forward. On Thursday, he will return from the toughest penalty of his career  a two-year suspension imposed by the league for his involvement in a New Jersey betting ring.

title: Corrections: Beauty Blogs Come of Age: Swag, Please!
description: An article last Thursday about the growing influence of beauty bloggers referred incorrectly to efforts by Lancme in 2006 to promote a limited-edition lipstick. The company sent press releases to several bloggers, but only one received a sample of the lipstick; Lancme did not send samples to dozens of bloggers.

title: Mourning a Teams Loss, in a Much Different Era
description: LONDON  Just about everyone in Britain old enough to remember events of 50 years ago can recall the moment on Feb. 6, 1958, when the baleful news came through.

title: Red Cross Fined $4.6. Million Over Donation Screenings
description: The American Red Cross, the biggest operator of American blood banks, was fined $4.6 million after regulators found it failed to properly screen blood donations. The Food and Drug Administration sent a letter to the Red Cross describing the agencys findings, said an agency spokeswoman, Peper Long, in an interview. The penalty followed a agency review of blood that was recalled by the Red Cross, she said. Regulators have now fined the Red Cross more than $20 million since the agency and Red Cross entered into a legal agreement in 2003 allowing penalties for failing to follow federal standards to ensure blood is not contaminated, Ms. Long said.

title: Santana Easily Navigates Bumper-to-Bumper Coverage
description: Johan Santana entered the Diamond Club at Shea Stadium to a song played by the Mexican rock band Man, one of his favorite groups, and then waited in the front row as one famous Santana was used to introduce another.

title: Tata Gines, 77, Cuban Master of the Congas, Is Dead
description: Tata Gines, one of the most important percussionists on the tumbadora, or conga drum, in the first generation of Afro-Cuban jazz and son montuno, died on Monday in Havana, where he lived. He was 77.

title: In Big Mob Sweep, Gambino Leaders Are Indicted
description: In the largest sweep in recent memory, federal and New York State authorities on Thursday rounded up scores of accused organized crime figures who were indicted on charges including murder, racketeering, construction extortions and the looting of union benefit funds.

title: Competition Doesnt Wait for New Device
description: Dr. Robert Jarviks newest device, the Jarvik 2000, operates on a so-called continuous-flow basis  a design intended to have a lower failure rate than implantable heart-assist devices currently approved, which pulsate and are larger.

title: Nearly Neighbors, but Split Over Clinton and Obama
description: In a Democratic primary season that has come to resemble a cousins war, New Jersey and Connecticut offered up an intriguing question mark Tuesday night: Why did such similar northeastern states, ranked first and second nationally in income and each with a suburban locus of power, come down on opposite sides of the divide between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton?

title: A Cordless Phone With a Direct Google Connection
description: Google, in the role of Ernestine the Operator, plays center stage in a new cordless phone kit from General Electric. The Premiere DECT 6.0 28821FJ3 has a GOOG-411 button on the keypad, which lets a caller request phone numbers and addresses from Googles extensive database without having to speak to a person.

title: James J. Fuld, Collector of Rare Music Scores, Dies at 91
description: James J. Fuld, a New York lawyer whose love of music inspired him to assemble one of the worlds finest collections of first editions of musical scores, died at his home in Manhattan on Jan. 29. He was 91.

title: Medical Examiner Rules Ledgers Death Accidental
description: The actor Heath Ledger died accidentally from the abuse of prescription medications  specifically, six kinds of painkillers, sleeping pills and anti-anxiety drugs  a spokeswoman for the New York City medical examiner said on Wednesday.

title: Speakers at Academy Said to Make False Claims
description: The Air Force Academy was criticized by Muslim and religious freedom organizations for playing host on Wednesday to three speakers who critics say are evangelical Christians falsely claiming to be former Muslim terrorists.

title: Obama Made Some Inroads, but Fervor Fell Short at End
description: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois made some headway in building a coalition of support among Democrats in Tuesdays cross-country sprint of primaries.

title: Morocco: Man Held in Alleged Royal Identity Theft
description: The authorities arrested a 26-year-old engineer they said stole the identity of Prince Moulay Rachid, left, the 37-year-old brother of King Mohammed VI and the second in line to the throne, on Facebook, the popular social networking Web site. The state news agency MAP said the engineer, Fouad Mourtada, was detained in Casablanca and accused of villainous practices linked to the alleged theft of the identity. The report did not elaborate, but went on to say that members of the royal family had no Web sites or blogs and that the only official way to obtain information about them was through MAP.

title: Will She Fold em or Hold em?
description: WEST SHOKAN, N.Y.

title: Japan: Officials Suggest Poisoning Was Deliberate
description: As Japanese officials disclosed more evidence that may point to deliberate poisoning of the China-made dumplings that sickened at least 10 people here. In Beijing, Wei Chuanzhong, vice minister of the General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine, said the contamination may have been sabotage by extremists opposed to any friendlier relations between Japan and China.

title: An Industry Imperiled by Falling Profits and Shrinking Ads
description: In just the last few weeks, The San Diego Union-Tribune eliminated more than 100 jobs, one-tenth of its work force. The Chicago Sun-Times began a major round of newsroom layoffs, then put itself up for sale, and publishers in Minneapolis and Philadelphia warned that tough economics could force cuts there.

title: Getty Museum Acquires Penn Photographs
description: The subjects of the velvety black-and-white pictures are not exactly Irving Penns elegantly dressed, or undressed, regulars: a plump charwoman with her bucket and brush; a bespectacled seamstress draped with her measuring tape; a deep-sea diver disappearing into his monstrous helmet and suit.

title: Governor Vows to Push Again for Three Strikes Law in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD  Opening the new session of the Connecticut legislature on Wednesday, Gov. M. Jodi Rell proposed several modest economic goals and pledged to push again for passage of a three strikes law imposing life sentences for repeat violent offenders.

title: The Cult of Secrecy at the White House
description: Theres no end to President Bushs slyness in subverting new Congressional law and clinging to the secrecy that has been the administrations executive cloak. When a vital measure to strengthen the tattered freedom-of-information law won unanimous approval by both houses of Congress, the president was forced to soften his stand and quietly sign it into law on New Years Eve.

title: Scientists Say Mummies Lice Show Pre-Columbian Origins
description: When two pre-Columbian individuals died 1,000 years ago, arid conditions in the region of what is now Peru naturally mummified their bodies, as well as the lice in their long, braided hair.

title: Lottery Numbers
Huckabee Claims Identity as Candidate of the South
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Mike Huckabee fashioned a new campaign identity after his victories in five Southern primaries on Tuesday, proclaiming himself the candidate of the Republicans true base, the South.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Jan. 17 about a study on a new DNA test that can help predict the risk of prostate cancer, whose findings were published online by The New England Journal of Medicine, misstated the scheduled date of publication in the journals print edition. It is Feb. 28; it was not published last Thursday.

title: Cone Back With Yanks as an Analyst for YES
description: David Cone, who has lived a private life since his short comeback with the Mets in 2003, returned Wednesday to a more public role as a booth and studio analyst for a combined 50 to 75 games on the YES Network. He signed a two-year contract.

title: Cheney Defends Use of Harsh Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Dick Cheney on Thursday vigorously defended the use of harsh interrogation techniques on a few suspected terrorists, saying that the methods made up a tougher program, for tougher customers and might have averted another attack on the United States.

title: Slide Show Mounted in a Frame
description: The other day at a trade show, a reader accosted me. I cant believe you gave speech-recognition software a good review, he scolded. I had an awful experience with it! I wound up sticking it in a drawer.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on Jan. 25 about Electric Fountain, an artwork that will go on display in the plaza at Rockefeller Center on Feb. 27, misstated the history of public artworks by its creators, Tim Noble and Sue Webster. They have made such works before; Electric Fountain will not be their first.

title: A Tonier Image Is Sought for Eighth Avenue in Midtown
description: Eighth Avenue is no longer Manhattans answer to the Tenderloin district of San Francisco. But now that almost all of its peep shows and pornographic video stores have been eradicated, the open question is, what will this once-seedy part of Midtown become in its next life?

title: France: Vuitton Profit Is Up, but Outlook Is Clouded
description: LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the worlds largest luxury-goods maker, posted a 12 percent increase in second-half profit but said the economic outlook was worrisome. Profit in the half was 1.19 billion euros ($1.75 billion), up from 1.06 billion euros a year earlier, LVMH said. Second-half sales rose 9.3 percent, to 9.07 billion euros. The chairman, Bernard Arnault, left, said the company, which is based in Paris, faced a likely recession in the United States, where it was raising prices to counter a weak dollar.

title: Competition Gaining on Running Gear Stores
description: Some of the stores are seemingly no bigger than a closet and their wares fairly limited. But for a generation, specialty running stores have managed to survive  even thrive  around the country despite competition from the big chains and online and mail order outlets.

title: At Buddhist Temple, Cleansing Rituals to Ring in the New Year
description: Ha Tran was applying the final swipes on Saturday to a 20-foot Buddhist statue inside a Chinatown temple. It took two days, but Mrs. Tran, a 62-year-old Vietnamese immigrant, lovingly washed every one of the deitys thousand arms and did the same for its 10 heads. Balanced on scaffolding, she painstakingly removed 12 months of accumulated dust and incense in time for the Chinese New Year on Thursday, her yearly rite for 22 years.

title: Shoe-Savvy Friends Against the City
description: Blahnik fatigue syndrome. Its the disease that sets in when too many television series rely on glamorous women in expensive shoes to pick up where Sex and the City left off  and even that HBO series is coming back to life in movie form this spring.

title: A Prize Recruits Thinking Cap
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  In a nearly empty ESPN Zone restaurant here Wednesday morning, Darrell Scott, who is considered the nations top high school running back, ended the recruiting drama that had gathered for months around his college choice.

title: Casino Developer Now Wants to Revive the Concord Hotel
description: The company whose longstanding proposal to build a Las Vegas-style casino in the Catskills was derailed by the federal government last month is expected to announce this week that it is working with the owners of the dormant Concord Hotel to build a luxury resort and conference center on the 1,600-acre property.

title: Orchestras Daring Mix: Bit of Bach and a Jolt of Jazz
description: The Riverside Symphony, a hardy ensemble founded in 1981 by the conductor George Rothman and the composer Anthony Korf, has thrived on a steady diet of innovation and exploration. Displaced from its usual home at Alice Tully Hall by renovations, the orchestra and its audience took over Zankel Hall on Tuesday night for a characteristically inventive program of Baroque and jazz-oriented works.

title: Ryan Returns to Rangers
description: Nolan Ryan was hired as president of the Texas Rangers, reuniting him with the struggling team he pitched for at the end of his career.The Rangers introduced Ryan, a 61-year-old Texas native, with the fanfare of a major free-agent signing, taking him into a packed stadium hall that cheered after a highlight video trumpeted the return of the Ryan Express.Ive known since I was a player that Id like to be involved in the shaping of an organization, said Ryan, the major leagues career strikeout leader. This gives me that opportunity.Ryan threw seven no-hitters and won 324 games in a record 27 major league seasons. The last five of those were with the Rangers and included his final two no-hitters and 5,000th career strikeout.Ryan replaces Jeff Cogen, who was moved by the owner Tom Hicks to the Dallas Stars during a shake-up of his N.H.L. hockey team in November.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the Giants relationship with New York City, misidentified the franchises founder. It was Tim Mara, not his son Jack.

title: Tip of the Week: Saving Web Pages
description: If you find Web pages you absolutely want to save for fun, posterity or research, the ScrapBook extension for Firefox will snag those pages for you and organize them like bookmarks, right from the Firefox menu bar. You can save whole Web pages on your computer, search through the text and even edit the collected Web pages. ScrapBook can be downloaded at https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/427.

title: With a Little Help From the Sun
description: THANKS to size-reducing advances over the last four years in rechargeable batteries and solar panels, consumers who want to keep a soundtrack at ears length when outlets are miles away now have more viable, earth-friendly options for keeping players juiced.

title: Lineman Made Up Recruiting Story
description: RENO, Nev. (AP)  A Fernley High School football player who claimed he was duped into believing he was recruited to play at a Pacific-10 university admitted Wednesday that he had made up the story.

title: Taking a Chance on a Candidate, and Winning Big (or Not)
description: Behind the voting results in the region lurk less obvious winners and losers. Some put themselves on the line for the candidate who prevailed; others found that their favorite came up short.

title: Its Sensuous. Its Lyrical. Its Also Fragmented.
description: The dance theater of Trisha Brown consists of happy paradoxes, and so does my reaction to it, not least to her current program at the Joyce Theater, which opened Tuesday night. She exemplifies the Against Interpretation spirit once encapsulated by Susan Sontag, and yet she always reveals the natural expressiveness of the human body in motion while  incidentally, or so it seems  demonstrating her own views on energy, manners, gender and other issues.

title: European Banks Confront Economic Slowdown
description: FRANKFURT  Europes top two central banks highlighted rising hazards to economic growth on Thursday, with the Bank of England cutting interest rates and the European Central Bank, in a reversal, signaling that it might follow suit.

title: Man Charged in 2 Rapes
description: A Brooklyn man has been charged with raping two women after DNA evidence linked him to an attack in June and a victims description of his 400-pound physique implicated him in a second rape that occurred on Friday, the police said.

title: Craving the High That Risky Trading Can Bring
description: It is easy to dismiss Jrme Kerviel, the rogue trader at Socit Gnrale, as a fluke.

title: McNamees Evidence Would Be Hard to Date
description: The syringes, vials and gauze pads that Brian McNamee has turned over to federal investigators to back up his contention that he injected Roger Clemens with steroids and human growth hormone will be the subject of a strenuous attack if they enter the courtroom, according to medical and legal experts.

title: Reigning Trowel in a Kingdom of Orchids
description: Homestead, Fla.

title: Pressure on McCain to Reconcile With Conservatives
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona might have expected his appearance on Thursday at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington to be a gracious makeup session with his former critics on the right. He hoped to arrive as the presumptive Republican presidential nominee.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about President Bushs 2009 budget misstated the cost of a scholarship program named for Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. It is $40 million, not $40 billion.

title: Polytechnic Universitys Vote on Merger With New York University Is Likely to Be Delayed
description: The board of trustees of Polytechnic University appears likely to postpone a vote, which had been scheduled for Thursday morning, on a merger with New York University.

title: C.I.A. Destroyed Tapes as Judge Sought Interrogation Data
description: WASHINGTON  At the time that the Central Intelligence Agency destroyed videotapes of the interrogations of operatives of Al Qaeda, a federal judge was still seeking information from Bush administration lawyers about the interrogation of one of those operatives, Abu Zubaydah, according to court documents made public on Wednesday.

title: PBS Will Broadcast Concert From North Korea
description: The New York Philharmonics concert in North Korea on Feb. 26 will be broadcast that evening on WNET, Channel 13, and distributed two days later on PBS, broadcast officials said Wednesday.

title: Viewers Choose American Idol
description: Tuesday might have been an important night for the presidential primary process, but Fox came away the big winner in the television ratings race, easily outpacing its rivals election coverage. As usual, American Idol led over all, drawing 27.8 million viewers at 8, according to Nielsens estimates. At 9, Foxs House earned a similarly dominant 23.2 million viewers. Meanwhile, ABC, the only network to broadcast three full hours of election returns, ranked fourth over all with an average of 5.3 million viewers during prime time. CBS, which broadcast presidential primary results from 9 to 11, finished third (4.7 million). NBCs election coverage won the 10 oclock time slot (5.6 million), possibly benefiting from higher ratings leading into the hour. NBCs Biggest Loser averaged eight million viewers in second place from 8 to 10, behind Fox. NBC also led Monday nights ratings, thanks to American Gladiators (nine million) followed by Deal or No Deal at 9:30 (13.2 million). Also on Monday, at 10 p.m., ABCs 20/20 special on the death of Natalee Holloway drew 12.7 million viewers, the largest audience for 20/20 in more than a year.

title: Corrections: Tattooed for a Day, Wild for a Night
description: An article on Jan. 24 about temporary tattoos referred incorrectly to Gwen Stefani. She has no permanent tattoos.

title: Obama and Clinton Brace for a Long-Distance Run
description: With no breakout winner in Tuesdays Democratic primaries, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama on Wednesday began fortifying for a drawn-out nomination fight, with Mrs. Clinton disclosing that she had lent her campaign $5 million while Mr. Obama raised $3 million online in a single day and rejected calls for more debates.

title: Clemens and McNamee Take Their Stories to Capitol Hill
description: Brian McNamee has given federal investigators bloody gauze pads, vials and syringes he said he used to inject Roger Clemens with steroids and human growth hormone in 2000 and 2001, a lawyer with knowledge of the case said Wednesday.

title: Ted Kennedy and the Gap
description: Great job, voters. Huge turnout, good vibes and everythings still up in the air. We could be working on these presidential nominations for months. Maybe all the way to the conventions! At last, an opportunity to have really serious discussions about the makeup of the credentials committee.

title: Keys Back at No. 1
description: Having a No. 1 album just isnt what it used to be. This week Alicia Keys is back atop the Billboard chart with As I Am (J), but the 61,000 copies it has sold is barely above the historic low for a No. 1 album, Nielsen SoundScan reported. The Juno soundtrack, on Rhino, fell to No. 2, with 55,000 sold. New releases dot the chart this week. The Mars Volta, which revels in head-spinningly complex progressive rock, opened in the third spot with 54,000 sales of The Bedlam in Goliath (Universal); the Welsh heavy metal band Bullet for My Valentine reached fourth place with Scream Aim Fire (Jive), selling 53,000; and the 2008 Grammy Nominees compilation (Hip-O/Universal) moved 50,000, opening at No. 5. The remix album Hannah Montana 2: Non-Stop Dance Party (Disney) bowed at No. 7, and Vampire Weekend, the acclaimed New York indie band, reached No. 17 with its self-titled debut on the XL label.

title: In Seized Video, Boys Train to Fight in Iraq, U.S. Says
description: BAGHDAD  The children in black  T-shirts, trousers and face masks  hoist AK-47s and pistols and rush toward an apparently unarmed man on a bicycle. In an instant they have surrounded him, shouting in the high voices of boys who are not yet men, Put your hands behind your back.

title: Losses Aside, Romney Puts Convention on Calendar
description: Mitt Romney is committed to staying in the Republican presidential race despite his losses on Tuesday, and has an eye on the long-shot possibility of a brokered convention fight, his advisers said Wednesday.

title: Parking Rules for the Asian Lunar New Year
description: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Fighting in Chads Capital Ebbs, but Problems Loom
description: NDJAMENA, Chad  The body brigade had its work cut out for it.

title: Top Football Prospect Puts Off College Choice
description: JEANNETTE, Pa.  Nine television trucks idled outside Jeannette High School on Wednesday, a harbinger of what was expected to be big news emerging from this sleepy town of about 11,000 on the outskirts of Pittsburgh.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Lighting Design

title: Reconstruction at Museum of the Moving Image
description: The Museum of the Moving Image, right, in Astoria, Queens, will close on March 23 for a $65 million reconstruction that will double its size. The back wall of the building has to be demolished, and in order to do that, theres a huge amount of vibration and noise, Rochelle Slovin, the director of the museum, told Reuters. It would not be a good idea to have the public in the building at that time. When the work is completed, the first floor of the museum will be transformed, and the structure will have a new three-story addition. The building will house a 262-seat theater, a 71-seat screening room, an education center, expanded gallery space and a courtyard. Groundbreaking for construction is scheduled for Feb. 27, with reopening expected in late 2009. In the meantime no full-time employees are to be laid off, Ms. Slovin said, and museum members will continue to have access to screenings and programs in all five boroughs.

title: Winehouse Questioned About Drugs
description: Amy Winehouse, right, has been questioned by the British police about a video that appeared to show her smoking crack cocaine, The Associated Press reported. The police said that no charges had been filed, but that the investigation was continuing. The Metropolitan Police in London said that detectives had interviewed a 24-year-old woman on Tuesday about allegations of drug possession. Although it is police policy not to name suspects who have not been charged, an officer read out a statement about the matter in response to a question about Ms. Winehouse. Last month The Sun published still images from a video that showed her inhaling from a small pipe. The video was said to have been made during a party at her home in London. Ms. Winehouse has since been admitted to a rehabilitation clinic in London but has said she is hoping to attend the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday. She has been nominated in six categories.

title: Using the Old to Open the New
description: Q. I sometimes get Microsoft Word documents with a .docx file extension. What is this format, and is there a way to open them with Word 2003?

title: Niedermayers Together Again to Pursue the Cup
description: It was a made-for-Hallmark moment, the championship trophy passing from one brother to another as if it were a family heirloom. This was not Eli Manning winning the Super Bowl the year after his older brother Peyton did. It was Scott Niedermayer passing the Stanley Cup to his younger brother, Rob, on the ice last June after the Ducks closed out the Ottawa Senators in the fifth game of the finals.

title: A Gap Guy, Head to Toe
description: HAD you seen the gold-embroidered shearling vest or the patent tortoiseshell belts shown this week at Oscar de la Renta, or the Proenza Schouler silk gazar blouse so stiff it could stand on its own, or the thick fur cummerbund at Carolina Herrera, you would probably conclude that designers are not entirely concerned about the likelihood that the country is entering a recession.

title: A Garbage Hauler Tidies Up Its Image
description: EVERYONE is all for waste management, the concept. Who could be against getting a handle on the worsening garbage stream?

title: State Aide at Fashion Show Site Is Accused of Shaking Down a Designer
description: It has become the most anticipated show of the high-stakes merry-go-round that is Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs at the 26th Street Armory. This week, Mr. Jacobss show, known as much for its celebrity-filled front rows and long delays as its provocative collection, will act as a capstone to the season when the worlds fickle arbiters of style descend on New York to say yea or nay, determining the fortunes of multibillion-dollar businesses.

title: White House Moves to Ease Guest Worker Program
description: The Bush administration announced plans on Wednesday to overhaul the notoriously inefficient federal guest worker program for agriculture, seeking to provide more legal workers to American farmers who now rely primarily on illegal immigrants.

title: St. Johns Tops Rutgers, and It Wasnt Pretty
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  The game matching the two worst offensive teams in the Big East had no problems living down to its low expectations. St. Johns scored only 52 points and shot 36.2 percent, but that was enough to defeat Rutgers, 52-45, Wednesday night.

title: Lawyers Say McNamee Has Evidence
description: Brian McNamee has given federal investigators bloody gauze pads and syringes he said he used to inject Roger Clemens with steroids and human-growth hormone in 2000 and 2001, a lawyer familiar with the matter said Wednesday.

title: Drop Down and Give Me More Than Shes Doing
description: JOE DUFFY, a cross-country skier who skis marathons, considers himself fit and motivated. About three years ago he decided to focus on strength, balance and endurance. He knew his workouts would be more interesting if he had people to compete against. So instead of visiting the gym on his own, Mr. Duffy and his wife, a former marathoner, exercise twice a week with a group of seven to nine people and a personal trainer at 501Fit in Minneapolis.

title: In Many Communities, Its Not Easy Going Green
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  This urban suburb of Washington seems well-prepared for a leading role in the green revolution embraced by hundreds of the nations cities, counties and towns.

title: Drug Ads Raise Questions for Heart Pioneer
description: Dr. Robert Jarvik is best known for the artificial heart he pioneered more than a quarter-century ago. Since then he had toiled in relative obscurity  until he began appearing in television ads two years ago for the Pfizer cholesterol drug Lipitor.

title: Mixed Results for New Jersey Students on Statewide Tests
description: New Jersey public school students performed better on last years statewide math tests than they did the previous year at elementary and middle schools, but slightly worse at high schools, according to results released Wednesday by the states Education Department.

title: Pre-Chewed Baby Food Said to Transmit H.I.V.
description: BOSTON  Researchers have identified another way that babies can be infected with H.I.V.  through food pre-chewed by an infected parent or caretaker.

title: Space Shuttle Atlantis Blasts Off
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  The space shuttle Atlantis, dodging an approaching weather front, rumbled into space on Thursday afternoon, carrying the European scientific laboratory Columbus to the International Space Station.

title: Uranium Exploration Near Grand Canyon
description: With minimal public notice and no formal environmental review, the Forest Service has approved a permit allowing a British mining company to explore for uranium just outside Grand Canyon National Park, less than three miles from a popular lookout over the canyons southern rim.

title: Turning a Pier Into a Park
description: The narrow pathway along Manhattans western shore has become one of the real treasures in New York Citys park system. The Hudson River Park draws bikers, skaters, walkers, readers, dog-lovers  thousands each year who want to stand out on a pier and breathe the freshest air around.

title: The Vanishing Point
description: CREDIT Hedi Slimane or blame him. The type of men Mr. Slimane promoted when he first came aboard at Dior Homme some years back (he has since left) were thin to the point of resembling stick figures; the clothes he designed were correspondingly lean. The effects of his designs on the mens wear industry were radical and surprisingly persuasive. Within a couple of seasons, the sleekness of Dior Homme suits made everyone elses designs look boxy and pass, and so designers everywhere started reducing their silhouettes.

title: Robinho Sparks Brazil
description: Brazil defeated Ireland, 1-0, in an exhibition in Dublin.Robinho scored the deciding goal in the 66th minute when he sidefooted a ball through the legs of Lee Carsley and past Irelands diving goalkeeper, Shay Given.Ireland had a chance to tie the game in the 88th minute, but after a series of quick passes inside the box and a deft flick by Kevin Kilbane, Robbie Keane could not get a touch before Julio Csar smothered the ball.

title: Danbury Council Vote on Policing Immigrant Community Draws Thousands to Protest
description: DANBURY, Conn.  On Wednesday night, Jose Contreras gazed toward City Hall here, his face wrinkled with pain as he wondered aloud about what the future might hold for his restaurant  not to mention for his neighbors. Thousands of them were standing nearby in the crisp darkness, waving signs, whistling and chanting in Spanish and English at a volume that could be heard blocks away.

title: On the Island, Facing the Challenge of New Suburbia
description: To the Editor:

title: Diabetes Study Partially Halted After Deaths
description: For decades, researchers believed that if people with diabetes lowered their blood sugar to normal levels, they would no longer be at high risk of dying from heart disease. But a major federal study of more than 10,000 middle-aged and older people with Type 2 diabetes has found that lowering blood sugar actually increased their risk of death, researchers reported Wednesday.

title: Duke Ends 3-Game Skid Against Tar Heels
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  As if there were not enough vitriol between Duke and North Carolina, fans now have The Foul to add to the lore of perhaps the most intense rivalry in college sports.

title: Time Warner Plans to Split Off AOLs Dial-Up Service
description: Time Warner, seeking to cut costs and streamline operations, plans to split off AOLs Internet access business from its Web site and online advertising business and cut 100 jobs at its corporate unit, the companys new chief executive, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, said Wednesday.

title: The Night of the Split Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Rise in Profit, Cisco Eases Its Forecast
description: Cisco Systems, the largest maker of network equipment, edged past Wall Streets second-quarter sales targets but forecast a slowdown in orders for the third quarter as European and American customers pull back on technology spending.

title: Floyd M. Boring, Agent Who Guarded 5 Presidents, Is Dead at 92
description: Floyd M. Boring, a Secret Service agent who guarded five presidents and took part in the gunfight that foiled an attempt by Puerto Rican nationalists to assassinate President Harry S. Truman, died Friday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 92.

title: Store on TiVo, Save to DVD
description: Q. Is there a way to record programs stored on my TiVo recorder in the living room onto a DVD so I can save them or watch them elsewhere?

title: The Reconquest of America by a Swedish Pop Royal
description: I think its almost on the day, 10 years ago, that I was here with my first album, said Robyn, and there was a cheer. But this is the first time that I have ever played live in the United States of America. And then came an ovation so loud and so long that she seemed faintly embarrassed by it.

title: Broadway Encounters Jazz Not Far From the Actors Studio
description: Abbey Lincolns great jazz ballad Throw It Away is the kind of philosophical reflection that invites Method interpretations by singers willing to connect their personal associations with its advice to divest oneself of unnecessary personal baggage. You can never lose a thing if it belongs to you, concludes the song, whose final image evokes the singer standing alone and unencumbered on a beach, with arms outstretched.

title: Turnabout for Bennett and Cougars
description: The big game was on TV last month in the Wisconsin home of Tony Bennetts parents, but his father, Dick, was too wound up to watch. Retreating to an adjacent room, he found a radio playing polka music and turned up the volume so that it drowned out his wife, Anne, who could be heard through the wall chiding the officials and cheering the players.

title: Wal-Mart Will Expand In-Store Medical Clinics
description: Moving to upgrade its walk-in medical clinic business, Wal-Mart is set to announce on Thursday plans for several hundred new clinics at its stores, using a standardized format and jointly branded with hospitals and medical groups.

title: Razor-Thin Margins in Missouri Reflect Nationwide Split
description: In all but one presidential general election in the past century, Missourians have chosen the candidate who won the presidency. But the states value as a compass of the nations political mood extends beyond general elections because its populations makeup (rich and poor, urban and rural, agricultural and industrial) tends to look like a microcosm of the country.

title: Just Browsing, Ogling, Prattling, Giggling
description: UNTIL recently, the fashion-savvy sissy-boy has had to endure the taunts of ill-informed, poorly dressed bullies. For Jeffrey, the 9-year-old fashion emporium in the meatpacking district, this came in the form of a recurring skit on Saturday Night Live.

title: Respond to Todays Column: Ted Kennedy and the Gap
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Feb. 7 column.

description: Inside the NFL ends its 31-year run on HBO this week. The last program was taped yesterday.

description: It seems the Redskins coaching job could come down to the Giants defensive coordinator, Steve Spagnuolo, and the former Giants coach Jim Fassel. Spagnuolo had another day of interviews with the Redskins yesterday.

description: Vera Wang presented her fall 2008 collection at the Tent in Bryant Park.

description: As expected, the Calgary Flames opened the vault to keep their franchise defenseman, 22-year-old Dion Phaneuf, from leaving as a restricted free agent at seasons end. Phaneuf, the next generation Scott Stevens, signed a six-year extension worth $39 million.

description: The following is a transcript of Senator John McCain's speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington, D.C., as provided by Federal News Service.

description: The International Center of Photographys survey is confusingly fragmentary and does not provide full justice to Barbara Blooms mercurial talent.

title: Your Comments on Electability
description: My Thursday column argues that the Republicans seem to be choosing their strongest general election candidate, John McCain, as their nominee, and explores electability on the Democratic side. With lots of qualifications, I argue that theres some evidence that Obama has the edge there.

title: Dizzywood Finds V.C.s Young at Heart
description: Another start-up in the ever-popular niche of online virtual world for young people has scored venture capital funding. Dizzywood, a virtual world for kids aged 8-10, has taken $1 million Series A in a round led by Shelby Bonnie with Charles River Ventures, with other individual investors also participating, TechCrunch reported.

title: Indias Bharti Gets $250 Million Infusion from Kohlberg Kravis
description: Indias top mobile operator, Bharti Airtel, said it has tapped Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for a $250 million investment in one of its subsidiaries  its second major infusion from a foreign private investor in two months.

title: 3i Takes Another Shot a Pharma With A.P.I. Deal
description: The 3i Group, a London buyout shop, gave itself a shot in the arm Wednesday with an agreement to buy Alpharmas injectable antibiotics supplier, Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients, in a deal valuing the business at $395 million.

title: Deutsche Bank Avoids Pitfalls of Subprime Collaspse
description: Deutsche Bank, Germanys biggest bank, posted a smaller than expected decline in fourth-quarter profit after avoiding the collapse of the subprime mortgage market in the United States that left competitors with record losses.

title: Brewer Deal Rumors Prompt Talk of a Brawl
description: InBev, the worlds second-largest beer producer by volume, and Anheuser-Busch are in talks that could lead to a merger of the two, a Belgian business magazine, Trends, reported.

title: Apex Snaps Up Dynogen
description: Apex Bioventures Acquisitionagreed Tuesday to buy venture capital-backed Dynogen Pharmaceuticals, a biopharma company focused on gastrointestinal and genitourinary disorders.

title: Diller Says Weak IAC Results Justify His Spinoff Proposal
description: Its not every day that an embattled chief executive uses lackluster results as a defense against a disgruntled shareholder.

description: Does money predict victory in a primary or caucus?

title: SRM Global Said to Be Down 30%
description: SRM Global, the British hedge fund headed by a former star trader atUBS, Jon Wood, may have ratcheted up its profile by opposing deals for the troubled British lender Northern Rock and a United States counterpart, Countrywide Financial, but the investments havent done its balance sheet any favors.

title: SAC Calls $2.9 Billion Pharmion Bid Too Low
description: Steven A. Cohen is apparently not thrilled with Celgenes $2.9 billion deal to buy the drug maker Pharmion.

description: Reuters reports on some interesting comments Wednesday from Warren Buffett, the legendary value investor, about the troubles facing many of the biggest financial firms:

title: Chatter of an HSBC Bid for SocGen Resurfaces
description: Speculation that HSBC, the British bank, might bid for Socit Gnrale of France resurfaced on Wednesday as an impending $8 billion capital increase by Socit Gnrale loomed in the background.

title: No Delay for Prada I.P.O., Banker Says
description: The recent choppy markets will not delay the initial public offering of Prada, the Italian fashion house, which is expected this year, an executive at a bank managing the offering said Thursday.

title: Changes Ahead at Time Warner, and Maybe Deals
description: The main event at Jeffery L. Bewkes first analyst conference call taking the chief executives post at Time Warner was his plan to split off AOLs Internet access business from its Web site and online advertising business.

title: Rebel Monkey Nabs $1 Million in First Round
description: Rebel Monkey, a year-old startup that develops casual multi-player games, briefly emerged from stealth mode Wednesday to snatch $1 million in first-round financing from Redpoint Ventures.

title: Another One Bites the Dust: Transoma Pulls I.P.O.
description: A medical technology company, Transoma Medical said Wednesday it is postponing its initial public offering because of unfavorable market conditions.

title: BBC Said to Mull Private Equity Partnerhsip
description: The BBCs commercial arm, BBC Worldwide, is looking to go into partnership with private equity firms in a bid to expand its acquisition muscle beyond its 350 million pounds ($681 million) borrowing limit, according to The Guardian.

title: Quitting the Energy Business to Evangelize for the Climate
description: It used to be that idealistic people seeking more meaning from their lives would quit good jobs, and join aid agencies to feed people suffering famines or to teach kids in inner cities. Now, it seems, some are evangelizing on behalf of the climate.

title: Panel to Consider Risks of Sovereign Funds
description: The national security implications of investment funds controlled by foreign governments, known as sovereign wealth funds, will be the subject of a full-day hearing Thursday before the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission, a bipartisan congressional panel.

title: Todays Economic Report
Under Microsoft, Will Yahoo Become Another AOL?
description: If Microsoft gets its way with its unsolicited bid $44.7 billion bid, will Yahoo end up like AOL, Time Warners now-disgraced merger partner?

title: Northwest and Delta Talk Merger
description: In events that could reshape the airline industry, merger talks have picked up pace between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines, a combination that could force other carriers to seek partners, according to The New York Times.

description: Interesting New York magazine piece on the last big slump to hit New York. Tagline:
