description: It is easy to dismiss Jrme Kerviel, the rogue trader at Socit Gnrale, as a fluke.

title: Should IAC Merge With AOL?
description: Barry Diller was, not surprisingly, trying to put a positive spin on a bad situation while talking to investors yesterday.

title: Where Do Pirates Come From?
description: There has long been a theory that the release of Oscar screeners is a source of copyrighted entertainment for pirates, but the Gold Rush blog has a spreadsheet that demonstrates that movies often go viral long before the screeners hit the mailbox.

title: A Sun-Powered Hydrogen Car (Sort of)
description: I have mixed feelings about a post on a new toy, given my focus yesterday on Adam Smiths warning about the endless pursuit of unnecessary things. Do we really need another radio-controlled gadget?

title: The Vulture Circles, But Does Not Land
description: Harvey Weinstein apparently bought himself six months of immunity, along with the film rights to Wolf Boy.

title: Sultan of smooth
description: Via Mark Thoma, Michael Mandel has Robert Gordons latest estimate of trend productivity. Its not good.

title: The Half-Life of Julian Schnabel
description: Pajamas and Sean Young aside, Julian Schnabels anti-campaign is beginning to wear thin on some, including Little Gold Men.

title: Early Brokering for Democrats?
description: Well, as Democratic National Committee chairman Howard Dean moves to avoid a messy floor-fight at the convention, one potential headache seems to have been avoided.

title: A Right to Bear Cellphones?
description: Most of the judges on a state appellate court panel on Wednesday seemed sympathetic to parents arguments against a New York City ban on the phones in school.

title: Or You Could Always Just Eat a Few Cheeseburgers
description: Anne Thompson dug up an email in which anorexia-addled stars are given tips in how to hide their emaciation while maintaining size-zero perfection. Its the kind of memo that could give even a robust eater like the Bagger a bit of bulimia.

title: Ford Trucks Get New Gadget to Track Tools
description: When Ford asked owners of its trucks and utility vans which work-related problems drove them nuts, forgetting to bring crucial tools to a job was high on the list. On Wednesday at the Chicago Auto Show, Ford demonstrated radio frequency identification technology that should allow its 2009 F-150 trucks and E Series vans to instantly advise owners if they have every tool on their checklist with them when they set out or, for that matter, before heading home.

title: Bubble-Wrapped Review: Michael Clayton
description: As some of you may have read, the Bagger is trapped in a bubble not of his own making and is celebrating his imprisonment by watching and musing about all five best pic nominees. The Bagger has seen all the movies on the big screen and is now watching them on a wide-screen television. The sound is intermittent, so the emphasis is on what these movies look like. If you want to read a real review of Michael Clayton, a smashing one in fact, click here. The Baggers take is more about oxygen-enhanced atmospherics.

title:
Advice and More Advice,
Especially with Cupid on the Way
description: On one recent day it was my older brother, wanting to know where, with just a week to go, he could likely get a reservation for six businessmen, including him, who were after three-star food, in a setting just quiet enough for chatting, and were indeed willing to pay three-star prices for it.

title: All Eyes on FEMA in Tornados Aftermath
description: The story of the storm that killed more than 50 people across five states is still being told to the nation and the world. But local and state emergency workers have been firmly in the aftermath stage since Wednesday morning, setting up shelters, treating the wounded and sifting through the rubble for survivors.

title: Philip K. Dicks YA Novel
description: In my Book Review column last weekend, I looked at some issues that arise when genre authors best known for their adult fiction try their hand at writing for younger readers. Of course, science-fiction, fantasy and horror writers have been publishing YA fiction for decades: everyone from Robert A. Heinlein to Ursula K. Le Guin has done it; even Clive Barker has his own YA franchise; and there are those who argue that Orson Scott Card shouldnt be writing it.

description: From Brian Frazer, in Los Angeles magazine, on the film version of Love in the Time of Cholera:

title: The Early Word: Money Matters
description: Yes, policies are important and character is key, but another gauge of a campaigns health is the amount of money coming in from supporters. And Wednesdays news cycle was all about the Benjamins.

title: Who is the Obama of Law Firms?
description: The New York Observer has answered a burning political question that never occurred to us, at least until now: If the major presidential candidates were top New York law firms, which ones would they be?

title: Fashion Nation
description: Last nights fundraiser at the U.N. for Unicef and Malawi was a wild end to an eventful day. At one point yesterday I was in a caf on 10th Avenue, having a lonely bowl of minestrone and listening on the phone to a designer rant (didnt like the review: O.K.), and the next I was squeezing into the throng at the United Nations behind Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes. This was a little surreal. I mean, Ive seen Cruise and Holmes at other parties. I remember seeing Cruise at a Vanity Fair Oscar party when he was married to Nicole Kidman. But it was funny seeing him last night, because Demi Moore swept up with Ashton Kushner and gave Cruise a big bear hug. I stepped around them, and saw Gwyneth Paltrow. People had that deer-in-the-headlights look: Its Gwyneth. I thought she looked beautiful. I saw Narciso Rodriguez and Diane von Furstenberg, who was with her husband Barry Diller. The place was packed. The dinner crowd moved into a tent set up on the U.N. lawn, and, as Madonna reminded everyone, when she made her speech, we werent technically in the United States anymore.

title: From Rome to Sicily: Plane or Train?
description: We are headed to Rome the last week in February and are then planning a trip to Sicily. What are your recommendations for traveling to Sicily? Is the train ride worth doing?

title: Ratings: Kids (Well, Young Adults) Love Politics, Giving CNN A Super Tuesday Win
description: CNN was the most popular cable news source for Super Tuesday coverage, averaging 3.16 million viewers between 8 p.m. Tuesday and 2 a.m. Wednesday. Fox News Channel averaged 2.54 million viewers and MSNBC averaged 1.75 million.

title: Live From North Korea, Its the New York Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonics concert in North Korea on Feb. 26 will be broadcast that evening on WNET, Channel 13, and distributed two days later on PBS, Daniel J. Wakin reports.

title: Of Sovereign Funds and Shooting Rabbits
description: After being the talk of the World Economic Forum in Switzerland last month, the subject of sovereign wealth funds was the buzz of Capitol Hill on Thursday. A bipartisan commission heard testimony from four Democratic lawmakers who warned, some more intensely than others, about the potential risks of government-run funds in China and other foreign countries making big investments in American businesses.

title: Designing Whats Right for Consumers

title: The End of eBays Egalitarianism
description: For years, Meg Whitman boasted that eBay treated the newbie selling junk out of her attic the same as I.B.M. unloading a warehouse full of computers. Among the many changes that John Donahoe is making as he takes over as chief executive is a new structure that resembles most of the rest of the business world: bigger customers will get a better deal.

description: Will the Phoenix Suns stunning trade for Shaquille ONeal propel the franchise to its first championship or wreck the N.B.A.s most entertaining team?

description: Aired Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Hey, I was watching the primaries last night, and on the Republican side, the delegates are in. John McCain is up to 660. Im not sure if thats his delegates or age, but its a lot.

title: A Dozen Walnuts in His Mouth
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: In a recent speech, California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger said that if Republicans want to win, they have to become more like him. I think they are taking his advice, because today, Mitt Romney gave a speech with a dozen walnuts in his mouth.

title: Why I Never Buy Vinaigrette
description: Naturally fresh? I dont think so. In fact, just by looking at the list of more than fourteen (I stopped counting at that point  my eyes arent that good) ingredients on the one-ounce container of vinaigrette dressing I was given on an airplane recently, I could tell there was little fresh or natural about the stuff.

title: Climate Roundup: Tornadoes, Coral, Drought
description: Heres a quick roundup of notable developments related to perceived or projected links between dramatic events and global warming. While the greenhouse basics remain clear (more CO2 = warmer world), the connection between the trend and dramatic events on short time scales  the kind that catch our attention  remains murky, at best. None of this means global warming is unimportant to address. All of this, though, does illustrate the challenge facing those trying to jog the public to respond now to limit a long-term risk. There is no single smoking gun. It remains more a Seurat-style pointillist canvas of evidence. And pointillism does not have the potent punch of, say, The Scream.Tornadoes: There was a spate of Instanet attacks on Senator John Kerry yesterday for discussing projections of stronger storms in a warming world in the context of the catastrophic tornado strikes. His comment was nuanced, but by even bringing climate policy into a conversation on severe weather, he was probably destined to get roughed up. The reason? The science remains utterly equivocal on how global warming might boost the longstanding peril from tornadoes in the storm belt.

title: Buying a Used Car? Details Hold Key, in Any Language

I want my money now! he said, perhaps with the hope that a representative of an unscrupulous used car dealership might be in the audience in Lower Manhattan on Thursday. Mr. Coral, of East Elmhurst, had taken the day off work to testify about being cheated last March, when he bought a 2004 Nissan Quest for an agreed price of $14,000, only to discover an additional $6,245 in service contracts and a $884 dealer preparation fee in the final contract.

In a warning letter released today, the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board took the position that city employees may only do so if they keep careful track of such activity and reimburse the city for it. The ruling could affect a sizable number of the citys 281,000 full-time employees who increasingly use BlackBerry devices.

title: A Party Divided?
description: The modern nomination system was designed to prevent us from getting to exactly where we are right now; the point of moving up the first few contests every four years, soon followed with a Super Tuesday payoff, was to try to head off the kind of protracted fights to the convention that had doomed the Republicans in 1976 and the Democrats in 1980. And for the last few decades, at least, it worked. But here, once again, come the chaotic winds of democracy to derail the efficient engine of party politics. The Democratic race, in particular, could go all the way to Denver, and it could end uglyperhaps with super delegates hijacking the convention, or with lawyers arguing about whether Florida and Michigan should be seated.The accepted wisdom about such drawn-out, titanic clashesand the reason that insiders have worked so hard to preclude themis that they are ruinous for a party. The failures of sitting presidents like Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter (as well as challengers like Hubert Humphrey and Walter Mondale) are said to have proven that parties riven by internal disputes in the summer are incapable of reuniting in the fall; a nominee needs time before the convention to soothe feelings, raise money and recast himself for the general election. This year, though, the accepted wisdom is at least half wrong. That is, it probably still holds true for Republicans, but it could be a mistake to assume the same about Democrats.

title: Scent Notes | Polo Black by Ralph Lauren
description: Perhaps one should not be astounded that Doreen Bollhofer*, the creative director of Ralph Laurens perfumes, has produced a nice, not-half-bad masculine scent. The surprise is partly a function of the fact that around 90 percent of the scents marketed as masculines range from intentional scent banalities to olfactory amphibious assault vehicles. Its also relevant that Laurens 1978 Polo Green (as the brand now calls it), a masculine previously referred to as Polo, was as ubiquitous among young American males as Rive Gauche was across the Atlantic among young French females ten years earlier.

Now, with the Nebraska caucuses coming up on Saturday, he has a chance to add the actual blessing into the mix, with a new spot running in the state.

title: How McCain Benefits From a Longer Primary Race
description: Mitt Romneys decision to quit the Republican race is terrific news for John McCain. It removes the challenger with both the money and the message to hurt John McCain politically, even if he couldnt win the Republican nomination for himself. An expensive broadcast attack on Mr. McCains conservative credentials is the last thing the Arizona senator needs right now.

title: The Un-Greening of Biofuels
description: Two new studies published online by the prestigious journal Science on Thursday raise serious questions about the green credentials of biofuels. The studies conclude that all or almost all biofuels in use today cause a net increase in greenhouse gas emissions, when scientists add in the environmental costs of their production.

title: Islanders Said to Snub LaFontaine
description: Anaheim Ducks General Manager Brian Burke said he asked the Islanders for a credential for Pat LaFontaine, a former Islander and Hall of Famer, so he could sit with him on Tuesday night when the Ducks played at Nassau Coliseum. But the Islanders would not grant him one. Burke said he reiterated his request as a personal favor and was again refused.

title: Patterns of Distinction
description: In terms of the numbers, Super Tuesday was as much a national election as it was the sum of individual contests in 24 states. While significant variations emerged in voting patterns from state to state, similarities outweighed differences. In both political parties, distinct patterns shaped the outcomes from coast to coast, and they provide some indication of the course ahead  particularly in the closely contested Democratic race.

title: Arms at Rest
description: I am a migraineur. I use the noun with care, because after a lifetime of headaches, I have come to think of migraines as a part of me, not as some force or plague that infects my body. Chronic headaches are my fate, and I have adopted a position of philosophical resignation. I am aware that such a view is resoundingly un-American. Our culture does not encourage anyone to accept adversity. On the contrary, we habitually declare war on the things that afflict us, whether its drugs, terrorism, or cancer. Our media fetishizes the heart-warming stories of those who, against all odds, never lose hope and fight their way to triumph over poverty, addiction, disease. The person who lies back and says, This is my lot. So be it, is a quitter, a passive, pessimistic, spineless loser who deserves only our contempt. And yet, the very moment I stopped thinking of my condition as the enemy, I made a turn and began to get better. I wasnt cured, wasnt forever well, but I was better. Metaphors matter.

title: How Difficult Is It?
description: To design a good Bill Blass collection you have to get into the psyche of Bill and not his archiveand Bill let very few people get that close to him. He constantly pushed people away, men and women. At the same time, he was constantly sketching people (at least in his prime). He noticed things about womens style, things he liked, and then he adapted them. He had a pretty good judgment about what was too much, whether in a house or in a design. Yet he liked the big gutsy gesturewhy else did he shop at Axel Vervoordt, the Antwerp decorator and antiques dealer? No one in New York made a better little black dress.

Soukupova is the face of Gucci Envy, she appears in the current Gap campaign, and she has closed shows for such designers as Valentino, John Galliano, Dior, Celine, Gucci, Michael Kors, Roberto Cavalli, Alexander McQueen, Calvin Klein, Donna Karen and Zac Posen. But at The Moment, we love her for her sharp eye, which is why we slipped a digital camera into her handbag and asked her to cover Fashion Week through the lens of a model. You can find her blog posts from earlier in the week right here.

description: Promising to re-define urban family living in the U.K. for the 21st century, a mixed-use residential project covering 38 hectares (95 acres) is moving forward in east Manchester.

title: Theater Listings
description: THE SLUG BEARERS OF KAYROL ISLAND (OR, THE FRIENDS OF DR. RUSHOWER) The cartoonist Ben Katchor, best known for his urban tales The Jew of New York and Julius Knipl, Real Estate Photographer, once dropped a princess telephone to the floor. In the wreckage he found a small lead weight, a slug, and wondered where it had come from. The thought prompted a short comic strip that he later expanded into a story about an ethical question of what happens when you make things in the world, he said. He teamed up with the composer and performer Mark Mulcahy, and eventually the tiny slug and the random query that it inspired led to a genre-defying musical thats unconventional in several ways.

title: Mont Tremblant Ski Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Family Legends
description: The third feature by the Tunisian filmmaker and poet Nacer Khemir is a structurally audacious fairy tale that imparts moral lessons and shows how narratives reflect and shape life.

title: Apology for BET Protest
description: One of the biggest critics of Black Entertainment Television says she will make a public apology Friday to Debra L. Lee, the networks chairwoman and chief executive, for supporting a protest outside Ms. Lees home in Washington. The cyberspace mea culpa comes from Gina McCauley, a lawyer whose site WhatAboutOurDaughters.blogspot.com has admonished BET for misogynistic and racially insensitive programming. But Ms. McCauley said on Thursday that the five months of protests led by a group calling itself Enough Is Enough now lacked specificity and impact. I thought this was more like the Montgomery bus boycott, but going into the sixth month, this looks more like the Salem witch trials or The Scarlet Letter, Ms. McCauley said in an e-mail message. The protests are led by Baptist ministers who say that BET broadcasts music videos that degrade women and black and Latino men. After focusing on Ms. Lee, the protest rallies spread to the Upper East Side home of Philippe Dauman, the president and chief executive of Viacom, which owns BET. The Rev. Delman L. Coates, pastor of the Mount Ennon Baptist Church in Clinton, Md., and the protest organizer, said on Thursday that the rallies brought attention and were one weapon in their battle.

title: Bullet Grazes an Infant in Brooklyn
description: An 18-month-old boy was grazed by a bullet that was accidentally discharged from the service gun of a New York City police officer in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, on Thursday afternoon, the police said.

title: Spagnuolos Decision to Stay With Giants Is Rewarded
description: Steve Spagnuolo, who helped shut down the highest-scoring offense in N.F.L. history in the Super Bowl, will remain with the Giants as defensive coordinator after spending days being interviewed by the Washington Redskins for their head-coaching position.

title: House Passes Bill Aimed at College Costs
description: Despite strong criticism from the Bush administration, the House overwhelmingly approved legislation on Thursday that would establish a federal list of the nations most expensive colleges and crack down on the way student loan companies try to curry favor with college officials and gain access to their students.

title: Lagging in New Mexico

title: C.I.A. Chief Doubts Tactic to Interrogate Is Still Legal
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, told a Congressional committee on Thursday that waterboarding may be illegal under current law, despite assertions this week from the director of national intelligence and the White House that the harsh interrogation method may be used in the future.

title: Australia Shows Graphic Images of Japanese Whaling
description: Australias government stepped up its campaign against Japanese whaling by releasing grisly surveillance pictures of the carcasses of a minke whale and a calf being hauled aboard a harpoon ship. The images were taken by a Customs ship that has been tracking the Japanese fleet in the Antarctic to gather evidence for a diplomatic and legal battle against whaling. It was not immediately clear when the whale and the calf, less than 12 months old, were photographed.

title: What You See, What You Get
description: One would think that after increasingly embarrassing forays into reality television, the Internet and the penitentiary, Paris Hilton might have taken a moment to reflect on her choices. Or perhaps not: with The Hottie & the Nottie Ms. Hilton proves yet again that introspection  not to mention shame  is as alien to her as a life without paparazzi.

title: Amid Storm Debris, a Need for Miracles Small or Large

title: Congress Votes for a Stimulus of $168 Billion
description: WASHINGTON  Moving with uncommon speed, Congress gave final approval on Thursday to a $168 billion economic rescue package, including rebates for taxpayers and tax breaks for businesses, that lawmakers and President Bush hope will set off a rush of springtime spending and spark the slowing economy.

For many regulars who attend the fashion shows at Bryant Park, hes the man they know by his trademark straw boater, a hat he wears regardless of the season, although the ribbon wrapped around its brim changes regularly.

The move, coming the same day the Bank of England decided to cut rates, highlighted rising fears of an economic slowdown.

title: Holt President Moves On
description: John Sterling, the president and publisher of Henry Holt & Company, is stepping down and will become executive vice president and editor-at-large at Macmillan, the parent company of imprints that include Holt; Farrar, Straus & Giroux; and St. Martins Press. Mr. Sterling, 55, has been publisher at Holt for nine years, shepherding authors like Richard North Patterson, Naomi Klein and Rick Atkinson. He said the company had achieved a record-breaking year in 2007 in sales, profits and number of best sellers, and he decided he wanted to go back to his first love, editing, and to pursue digital and pod-casting projects. I just want to try new things, and I cant do as much as I want to do if I stay in this chair." John Sargent, chief executive of Macmillan, said in a statement that Dan Farley, formerly president and chief executive of Harcourt Trade Publishers, will assume the role of interim president and publisher of Holt.

title: Poiret Designs at a Paris Sale
description: Last year a popular exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art renewed interest in the French couturier Paul Poiret, interest that is likely to continue on Feb. 14 with a sale of his original clothing designs in Paris.

title: Slain Dentists Wife Is Charged With Murder and Conspiracy
description: A doctor from Queens was arrested on Thursday night in the killing of her estranged husband, a dentist who was gunned down in October at a playground in front of their 4-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: Two Arrested in Bhutto Assassination
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani government on Thursday announced the arrests of two suspects in the assassination of Benazir Bhutto, the opposition leader and former prime minister. Meanwhile, thousands of her supporters thronged her hometown in southern Pakistan, marking the end of a 40-day mourning period.

James Blake and Stefan Koubek will play in the second match of the best-of-five series. In Saturdays doubles, top-ranked Bob and Mike Bryan will play Melzer and Julian Knowle.
