description: EDUCATION, as the saying goes, may be wasted on the young. But who says the same has to hold true for college towns?

title: Congressional Debate Club
description: One of the main knocks on Congress in recent years has been that members of the two parties simply talk past each other. Hunkered down in their partisan fox holes, Republicans and Democrats dont really debate, they trade barbed talking points.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Worker Is Electrocuted at Con Edison Plant
description: A contract worker installing electrical cable at a Consolidated Edison power substation in Queens was electrocuted Thursday when he touched a highly charged cable, the authorities said.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Southern Discomfort for a Hollywood Talk-Show Host
description: Late in Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins, a comedy about a talk-show host (Martin Lawrence) revisiting his relatives down South, theres a scene in which characters sit in the family patriarchs living room playing video games. The scene is already funny because the competitors are playing on a bulky 1977 television while the heros recent gift to his father, a flat-screen plasma set, sits unopened in a box nearby. But the crowning touch is a throwaway detail: The TVs knob is missing its button, and in its place is a pair of pliers clamped over the metal stem.

title: Canada: Quarterly Turnaround at Airline
description: Air Canada reported fourth-quarter profit of 35 million Canadian dollars ($34.8 million), reversing a year-earlier loss, helped by a stronger Canadian dollar and higher domestic demand. Net income was 35 cents a share, the airline said. A year earlier, Air Canada had a net loss of 144 million Canadian dollars. Revenue increased 3.7 percent, to 2.51 billion Canadian dollars ($2.5 billion). Air Canada, which generates a fifth of its revenue from flights to the United States, had been shifting capacity to domestic routes to avoid a slowdown in the United States. Air Canadas stock rose 18 percent after the results were released.

title: Court Bars Sale of Billions in Oil Assets by Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The oil giant Exxon Mobil has won court orders freezing as much as $12 billion in petroleum assets controlled by Venezuelas government in an escalation of a dispute over efforts by President Hugo Chvez to assert greater control over the countrys oil industry.

title: E. Leroy Tolles, Law Firm Founder, Is Dead at 85
description: E. Leroy Tolles, a co-founder of the Los Angeles law firm of Munger, Tolles & Olson, which grew from seven lawyers into a nationally prominent firm with about 200 lawyers, died on Jan. 28 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 85 and lived in San Marino, Calif., and Montecito, Calif.

title: With 14 More Shots, Rangers Lose to Ducks
description: For a split second in the third period Thursday night, Rangers center Chris Drury watched one of his shots skim along the Anaheim goal line behind goalie Jean-Sbastien Gigure. Drury was close enough to watch its tantalizing slide, but he could do nothing to change its course because he was being held down by Ducks defenseman Sean ODonnell.

title: Not Highfalutin, but Highly Satisfying Indulgences
description: With a look ahead to Valentines Day and a nod to Rodney Dangerfield, the classical music critics of The New York Times find themselves in a confessional mood and have decided to reveal some of their secret musical passions: works and performances they listen to for sheer pleasure  but perhaps not loudly when neighbors are around to hear.

title: Park Toll Road Plan Rejected in California
description: DEL MAR, Calif.  After a marathon public hearing in which hundreds of people spoke, the California Coastal Commission voted late Wednesday to deny approval for a toll road through a popular beach state park.

title: Sweet Sounds, Shamelessly Easy Listening
description: These are the recordings mentioned in the article:

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Mob Figure Is Arrested in Officers 1976 Killing
description: For more than three decades, the shooting death of Albert Gelb remained a mystery. On March 11, 1976, Mr. Gelb  at that time, the citys most-decorated uniformed court officer  was found behind the wheel of his car with four bullets shot into his chest and face. It was 1:35 in the morning, and the car was parked only a few hundreds yards from his house.

title: Bush Urges Conservatives to Rally Behind 2008 Nominee
description: WASHINGTON  Although he did not explicitly mention Senator John McCain, President Bush on Friday sought to unify the Republican Party behind its eventual nominee, describing the election of his successor as president as a stark ideological choice.

title: New Leader Named for Greek Orthodox Church
description: ATHENS  Greeces top Orthodox clerics on Thursday elected Metropolitan Ieronymos of Thebes, a seasoned cleric who has avoided conflict, to be the new leader of the Greek Orthodox Church. He succeeds Archbishop Christodoulos, a charismatic leader whose strong views sometimes brought criticism and who died last month at age 69.

title: Is It Too Late for Yahoo?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One of the first questions that Jerry Yang and his top lieutenants pondered after he became chief executive of Yahoo last summer was whether the company could remain independent. They quickly answered yes.

title: Gates Says Anger Over Iraq Hurts Afghan Effort
description: MUNICH  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Friday that many Europeans are confused about NATOs security mission in Afghanistan, and that they do not support the alliance effort because they opposed the American-led invasion of Iraq.

title: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
description: Previously recorded: $7,331,944

title: Martin to Drive No. 8 Car
description: The veteran Nascar driver Mark Martin will share the No. 8 Chevrolet with the rookie Aric Almirola in the 2008 Sprint Cup season. Martin and Almirola take over for Dale Earnhardt Jr., who left Dale Earnhardt Inc. after last season to join Hendrick Motorsports.

title: Top Anglican Seeks a Role for Islamic Law in Britain
description: LONDON  The archbishop of Canterbury called Thursday for Britain to adopt aspects of Islamic Shariah law alongside the existing legal system. His speech set off a storm of opposition among politicians, lawyers and others, including some Muslims.

title: Clemens and McNamee Take Stories to the Hill
description: WASHINGTON  The photograph of Brian McNamees evidence shows a crushed can of Miller Lite, some gauze and cotton pads and a single hypodermic needle.

title: Take Me Out to the Real Ballgame
description: People of America, can we stop talking about football now? It's been four days since the Super Bowl and I'm still seeing Tom Coughlin on SportsCenter. Don't get me wrong. I'm thrilled for New York -- I live there -- but as someone only moderately interested in the result in the first place I have already moved on. To baseball.

title: A Tour of Candyland in Wisconsin, Timeless and Sweet
description: OAKS Candy Corner in Oshkosh is a chocolate mirage.

title: Too High a Price for Building
description: The cost of New York Citys failure to adequately regulate the construction industry was made tragically clear again last month when a worker pouring concrete fell 42 stories to his death during work on a Trump hotel in SoHo. The city is now starting to take some overdue steps to force contractors to operate more safely. For the sake of the workers, and pedestrians below, we hope that these reforms are adopted right away.

title: Bond Raters in Effort to Repair Credibility
description: Under fire for their role in the mortgage crisis, Standard & Poors and the Moodys Corporation are scrambling to restore confidence in their credit ratings.

title: Iraqi Parliament Debates Split of Power and Money
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament again deferred a vote on the budget on Thursday as political blocs argued about how to divide financing among the provinces, but legislators did make headway toward approving a law that would outline provincial powers.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about a high school football players commitment to a university that had not actually offered him a scholarship described national signing day incorrectly. It is the first day recruits can sign letters of intent committing to college programs; it is not the deadline for doing so.

title: A New Venture for Jay-Z, on Madison Avenue
description: JAY-Z is a Grammy-winning rapper, a club owner, a clothier, a fledgling hotelier, the part-owner of a basketball team and the former president of a record label. Now, he gets to add adman to his rsum.

title: A Sweaty Hand in the Face: On the Ice, Its Perfectly Fair
description: Devils center Travis Zajac grappled with Philadelphia Flyers defenseman Derian Hatcher after the whistle during a testy game last month. Zajac is 3 inches shorter and 35 pounds lighter than the 6-foot-5, 235-pound Hatcher, but the great equalizer in the scrum was apparently Zajacs slimy, smelly pair of hockey gloves.

title: Keeping Track From Afar
description: WHEN youre not at your second home, there are basically three things you want to be able to do from the comfort of your primary residence: maintain security, monitor crucial systems like heating and air-conditioning and turn on and off various lights and locks.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Washington Post Names Publisher
description: Katharine Weymouth will become publisher of The Washington Post, its parent company announced on Thursday. The move passes that title to the fourth generation of the family that has controlled the paper for 75 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about financial problems in the newspaper industry misstated the circulation declines for The San Francisco Chronicle, The Los Angeles Times and The Boston Globe, which is owned by The New York Times Company. They have lost 20 to 30 percent of their circulation since 2003  not 30 to 40 percent. (Some of the loss came from eliminating sponsored copies that were distributed in bulk.)

title: In Their Own Words
description: Remarks to the Conservative Political Action Conference on Thursday in Washington.

title: Spotlight On: Bob Knight
description: Bob Knight's surprise retirement on Monday from Texas Tech produced the obligatory mentions of his achievements -- three national titles and a record 902 wins -- as well as highlights of his epic outbursts. It also caused Joan Mellen, Knight's friend for more than 20 years, to call his wife on Tuesday, concerned that a health problem prompted the decision. She was assured that was not the case. "I have this secret hope that he'll coach again," she said by phone yesterday.

title: Winehouse Drama Shadows Grammys
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Dcor Is Crimson, and the Ceiling Isnt Glass
description: PAUL NIKAC, the convivial daytime bartender at the Harvard Club of New York City, spots the clubs newest, youngest, and first-ever female president, Nicole M. Parent, a managing director at Credit Suisse and gung-ho global sector head of its capital goods equity research division, and does not genuflect.

title: Chad Capital Under Curfew Days After Coup Effort Failed
description: NDJAMENA, Chad  The government imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew across much of Chad on Thursday even as life in the capital returned to something resembling normal and fears of a new rebel attack faded several days after a coup attempt nearly toppled the president.

title: At Times, It Can Take Courage to Dress Up
description: Charline Mitchell, a freshman at St. Johns University, was the first in her family to go to a private four-year college. Her path there was hardly assured.

title: Home Standoff in Los Angeles Leaves 5 Dead
description: LOS ANGELES  A lengthy hostage standoff inside a home here ended Thursday morning with the deaths of three hostages, the man who had taken them captive and the first Los Angeles Police Department SWAT team officer ever killed in the line of duty.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 28 about The Washington Post Companys plans to start an online magazine aimed at blacks referred imprecisely to the formative years of Henry Louis Gates Jr., a Harvard professor who will be its editor in chief. Mr. Gates grew up in Piedmont, W.Va., not a small town in western Maryland. (As a child, he spent considerable time with his fathers family in nearby Cumberland, Md., and it was that town he was referring to when he spoke of reading newspapers in black barbershops.)

title: Six Dead in Georgia Refinery Blast
description: Four bodies were recovered in the ruins of a sugar refinery near Savannah, Ga., that was rocked by an explosion Thursday evening and burned all night.

title: MBIA Sells Stock to Aid Rating and Raises $1 Billion
description: The bond insurer MBIA raised $1 billion on Thursday by selling shares at $12.15 each in an effort to protect its AAA insurance rating.

title: Biofuels Deemed a Greenhouse Threat
description: Almost all biofuels used today cause more greenhouse gas emissions than conventional fuels if the full emissions costs of producing these green fuels are taken into account, two studies being published Thursday have concluded.

title: Seattle Taps Its Inner Silicon Valley
description: Seattle

title: Buffett Wont Be Witness in Fraud Trial
description: HARTFORD (Bloomberg News)  Defense lawyers rested their case at the fraud trial of General Reinsurance executives accused of helping the American International Group mislead investors, without jurors hearing from the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.

title: Satirical Songs of Noncommitted Lovers and Nonhuman Voices
description: Automated voices that fail to reassure as you wait impatiently to be connected to customer-service representatives; the hyperbolic argot of sportscasters; graying male movie stars romantically teamed with babes less than half their age: all these and more are twitted in the amusing, fast-paced lyrics of Lorraine Feather.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Corporate Auditors Focusing on Cash and Securities
description: What happens when cash really is trash?

title: A Determined Rice, in Taliban Country, Exhorts NATO to Do More to Press the War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice ventured to Kandahar on Thursday, deep in the belly of the Taliban insurgency, in a surprise trip to southern Afghanistan to send a message that the United States and NATO will press the war here despite the increase in Taliban attacks.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about deadly tornadoes in the South omitted reporting credits in some editions. Cynthia Howle reported from Jackson, Tenn.; J. Michael Kennedy from Macon County, Tenn.; Jim Noles from Birmingham, Ala.; and Andrew C. Revkin from New York. The article, datelined Atkins, Ark., was written by Shaila Dewan in Atlanta and Brenda Goodman in Atkins.

title: Fox Pairing Undoes Rivals
description: Foxs combination of American Idol and The Moment of Truth lifted it far ahead of its rivals in the Wednesday night ratings. According to Nielsens estimates American Idol at 8 p.m. drew the largest audience of the night, 26 million viewers, while 16.9 million tuned in at 9 for The Moment of Truth. CBS ranked second with comedy repeats followed by a Criminal Minds rerun at 9 (10.4 million) and a new episode of CSI: NY at 10 (10.7 million), which led its time slot ahead of NBCs Law & Order (10.1 million). NBC shared third place with ABC. NBC fared better in total viewers, while ABC edged past NBC among adults 18 to 49 thanks to Wife Swap at 8 (6.6 million) and Supernanny at 9 (7.6 million). ABCs Cashmere Mafia continued to struggle at 10 (5.1 million). On primary election night, CNN drew slightly more viewers during prime time (3.6 million) than its cable news competitor Fox News (3.5 million). MSNBC finished third (2.1 million). Among adults 25 to 54, however, MSNBC (1.03 million) nearly tied Fox News (1.09 million). Both trailed CNN (1.5 million) by a wide margin in that demographic.

title: Figure in Mitchell Report to Learn Fate
description: Thousands of miles from the halls of Congress, Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee, a former drug distributor named Kirk Radomski will appear in a federal courtroom in San Francisco on Friday to be sentenced for his illegal activities.

title: Celebrating Jack Currans 50 Years at Archbishop Molloy
description: On a summer day in 1958, Jack Curran sat in a Massachusetts diner sipping coffee and flipping through the pages of a newspaper.

title: Britain: Radical Imam Ordered to U.S.
description: Home Secretary Jacqui Smith signed an order for the extradition of the radical Islamic cleric Abu Hamza al-Masri to the United States to face terrorism charges. He has been serving a seven-year prison term in Britain for incitement to murder and other charges during the years when he ran the Finsbury Park mosque in North London. He is wanted in the United States on charges of involvement in a global conspiracy to wage a holy war and in connection with establishing a terrorist training camp in Bly, Ore., in 1999. He has 14 days to appeal.

title: Bush Seeks Senate Support
description: President Bush asked the Senate to swiftly approve an agreement ratified by more than 70 nations to fight the use of steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs in sports. In a statement, the White House said the agreements principles were already reflected in United States law and policy.

title: Having No Order on the Court With No True Point Guard
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Three weeks ago in a fleeting moment of bliss, Isiah Thomas handed the Knicks offense to Jamal Crawford and effectively proclaimed the start of a new era.

title: A Personal Workout, but With Others
description: Though it sounds like an oxymoron -- personal training in a group? -- it is a growing trend at large health clubs and small gyms alike, The Times reports today. Besides the significant cost savings -- depending on the size of the group, it can cost as little as $20 a session, compared with as much as $100 for individual training -- the group dynamic can help foster camaraderie and lure more people into the club.

title: A Long Story
description: The economic news has been fairly dire this week. The credit crunch is getting worse, and a widely watched indicator of trends in the service sector  which is most of the economy  has fallen off a cliff. Its still not a certainty that were headed into recession, but the odds are growing greater.

title: W.H.O. and Bloomberg Open Global Antismoking Project
description: Tobacco could kill up to a billion people during the 21st century, as cigarette sales soar in poor and middle-income countries even as they drop in wealthier ones, says a report issued Thursday by the World Health Organization.

title: Spain: Bank Hurt by U.S. Subprime Fallout
description: Banco Santander said fourth-quarter profit fell 6 percent as the bank took a $1.08 billion write-down in its main United States investment, Sovereign Bancorp. Santander said quarterly net profit fell to 2.49 billion euros ($3.64 billion) from 2.65 billion euros ($3.87 billion) in the fourth quarter of 2006. With Sovereign shares down 50 percent over the past year, Santander is realizing a big paper loss on its 25 percent stake in the bank. Sovereign this year reported a $1.3 billion (890 million euro) net loss for all of 2007, partly as a result of fallout from the subprime lending crisis.

title: In Northwest Colorado, the Workingmans Spa Town
description: FOR many Coloradans driving west from Denver, Glenwood Springs is little more than an exit ramp, its landmark hot-springs pool signaling the turnoff for Aspen, 40 miles to the south. But G-wood, as young hip locals call the town, is worth more than a pit stop.

title: European Group Cancels Mission to Observe Russian Election, Citing Restrictions
description: MOSCOW  The principal election-observation organization in Europe said Thursday that it would not send observers to monitor Russias presidential campaign and election on March 2, citing severe restrictions imposed on its work by the Russian government.

title: Split of Division Iii Weighed
description: The N.C.A.A. is asking the presidents and chancellors of Division III universities, already the associations largest membership group, about the feasibility of splitting the division or creating a new Division IV. Surveys were mailed Thursday to the 440 Division III members.Division III already is projected to grow to 480 members in the next 12 years. The N.C.A.A. last year formed a working group on membership issues, and the Division III group recommended the creation of a fourth division for the associations smallest institutions.

title: Ethics Inquiry Postpones N.Y.U. Merger With Polytechnic
description: New York Universitys plan to re-enter the engineering field by taking over a Brooklyn engineering school suffered a setback on Thursday, after a state senator said he would investigate the merger.

title: Gunman Kills 5 People at City Council Meeting
description: Five people were fatally shot and two others wounded on Thursday evening by a man who opened fire as a City Council meeting began in Kirkwood, Mo., a generally placid suburb of St. Louis, the authorities there said. The gunman was shot to death by police.

title: Hit by Rockets, Israel Attacks, Killing 7
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces killed six Palestinian militants and a civilian in Gaza early Thursday after militant groups in Gaza stepped up their rocket fire against Israel.

title: Head Injury Killed Bhutto, Report Said to Find
description: WASHINGTON  Investigators from Scotland Yard have concluded that Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistani opposition leader, died after hitting her head as she was tossed by the force of a suicide blast, not from an assassins bullet, officials who have been briefed on the inquiry said Thursday.

title: Tropical Pursuit of Love, Coins and No Tan Lines
description: In Fools Gold Kate Hudson and Matthew McConaughey, as golden as a pair of rotisserie chickens, squabble and cavort in a tropical paradise. How nice for them, and for those in the audience who want nothing more from a midwinter trip to the movies than to gaze upon the tawny limbs and perfect bellybuttons of the stars.

title: Inspections on Bridges Are Falsified
description: ATLANTA  A veteran bridge inspection team for the Georgia Department of Transportation falsified checks of dozens of bridges in the metropolitan area, including 11 previously rated as needing repair or replacement, department officials said Thursday.

title: Languid Hawaii Looks to Be an Energy Leader
description: To the long list of natural blessings to resent Hawaii for, you can add a dizzying abundance of clean, renewable energy sources. The state announced in late January that it had formed a partnership with the federal Energy Department to plunge into green technologies and to outpace the nation in moving beyond fossil fuels. Two highly plausible reactions to the news were: 1) of course, and 2) what took it so long?

title: France: Lawmakers Say Yes to New European Treaty
description: Both houses of Parliament, mending wounds left by a national referendum that helped bury the proposed European Union constitution in 2005, voted to ratify a slimmed-down treaty that would give the 27-nation union a long-term president and streamline its decision making. All of Europe is waiting for this signal from France, Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner said before the vote. The approval made France the fifth country and the largest so far to ratify the treaty. President Nicolas Sarkozy is expected to sign the ratification soon.

title: Hamm Leads in Return
description: Paul Hamm was in first place after the opening session of the Winter Cup Challenge on Thursday in Las Vegas, the first United States mens meet this year on the road to Beijing, and his first full meet since he won the all-around gold medal at the Athens Olympics four years ago. Hamm, who took a two-and-a-half-year break from the sport after Athens, had 92.8 points, 3.8 better than second-place Raj Bhavsar. Hamm also outscored the last two national champions: Sasha Artemev (88.9) and David Durante (88.7). The finals are Saturday.

title: German Bank Gets $7.2 Billion Bailout
description: FRANKFURT  WestLB, a German state-owned bank, said Friday that it would reduce its work force by 25 percent and receive 5 billion euros or $7.2 billion from its owners to cover losses tied to bad trades and the subprime mortgage market.

title: Reporter Sans Portfolio Is a de Facto East Village News Bureau
description: Anyone who has paid attention over the years to goings-on in the East Village is likely to recollect the story of a short-order cook named Daniel Rakowitz, who killed and dismembered his former girlfriend in their East Ninth Street apartment in 1989.

title: U.S. Intensifies Efforts to End Deadly Conflict in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The American government is playing an increasingly active role in trying to restore peace in Kenya, holding hearings in Washington on Thursday and threatening to prohibit some Kenyan politicians from entering the United States.

title: After Hard-Won Lessons, Army Doctrine Revised
description: WASHINGTON  The Army has drafted a new operations manual that elevates the mission of stabilizing war-torn nations, making it equal in importance to defeating adversaries on the battlefield.

title: Mukasey Warns of Drug Case Releases
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey warned Congress on Thursday that unless it enacted legislation quickly, hundreds of people in jail for cocaine offenses, many of them violent gang members, will be eligible for immediate release into the community nationwide.

title: Politics in Washington State Are Lively Though Puzzling
description: SEATTLE  Loggers, bloggers, farmers and philanthropists. Political relevance does not come around often for the distinctive mix of constituencies that keeps things lively here in the other Washington. So this Saturday, when presidential caucuses will be held statewide, people plan to make the most of it.

title: Mary Allen Engle, Pediatric Cardiologist, Dies at 86
description: Mary Allen Engle, a leading pediatric cardiologist who began an international philanthropic exchange that brought needy children to Manhattan for heart treatments in the 1970s, died on Jan. 27 at her home in Easton, Md. She was 86.

title: Side Trips in St. Louis: A Holiday for Eccentrics
description: GAY RHODES paused on a catwalk on the side of the 10-story former shoe factory in St. Louis that is the City Museum, arched her neck and gazed skyward.

title: Everyones Here, Pass the Oscars
description: This is the best place in the house to be, Angie Harmon said on Wednesday night as she made it through a boldface mob gathered in a tent outside the United Nations, edging her way toward the Champagne bar.

title: A Portrait of the Artist, in Bits and Pieces
description: Back in 1989, when SoHo was still a booming contemporary-art center, Barbara Bloom produced a memorably trenchant installation called The Reign of Narcissism at Jay Gorney Modern Art on Greene Street. It was in the form of a neo-Classical period room in an imaginary museum dedicated to one Barbara Bloom. There were faux-antique marble busts portraying Ms. Bloom; fine teacups watermarked with her image; a 38-volume set of The Complete Works of Barbara Bloom; a tombstone with a carved epitaph that said, She traveled the world to seek beauty and many more artifacts testifying to the transcendent qualities of a great artist.

title: Revelstoke Mountain Resort and the Residences at Red Mountain
description: Revelstoke Mountain Resort

title: Stolen Laughs
description: Buried in the impenetrable clutter of How to Rob a Bank is a Saturday Night Live-worthy spoof of heist movies in which the bank robbers have code names connected to Duran Duran and poor cellphone reception  and call waiting  turn communication between them and the police into a comedy of errors.

title: You Cant Buy the Naming Rights, but Call It the Billion-Dollar Ballpark
description: The old Yankee Stadium cost Jacob Ruppert and Tillinghast Huston $2.5 million to build and $100 million (or so) for the city to rebuild. The cost to replace it is now about $1.2 billion  not $930 million ($830 million and financing) as originally estimated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about financial problems in the newspaper industry misstated the circulation declines for The San Francisco Chronicle, The Los Angeles Times and The Boston Globe, which is owned by The New York Times Company. They have lost 20 to 30 percent of their circulation since 2003  not 30 to 40 percent. (Some of the loss came from eliminating sponsored copies that were distributed in bulk.) (Go to Article)

title: Scorsese Salutes the Stones
description: Martin Scorsese credited the Rolling Stones with inspiring his filmmaking when he appeared on Thursday for the world premiere of his Stones concert movie, Shine a Light, the opening attraction of the 11-day Berlin Film Festival, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Scorsese said that the bands music was part of his life beginning in the 1960s, and that its feel became the basis for most of the work Ive done in music from Mean Streets through Raging Bull all the way up to The Departed. The premiere of Shine a Light, built around two Stones concerts in 2006 at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan, was attended by  Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Ronnie Wood and Charlie Watts.

title: No Yarmulke, Please, Were Assimilated
description: For proof that American playwrights have not quite cornered the market on angsty dramas about domestic strife, check out Two Thousand Years, a comedy by Mike Leigh in which a middle-class Jewish clan in London kvetches about the future of Israel and the sore spots in the family past. The unexpected arrival of a long-estranged sister sets off a conflagration that escalates vertiginously from surly sniping to bitter recriminations, and ends in shouted avowals of hate and desperate gulps from a bottle of Scotch.

title: Very Rich, and Very Different From You and Me
description: Bernard and Doris, a new HBO film directed by Bob Balaban, is like the most delectable kind of Vanity Fair article, one that doesnt leave you feeling guilty or venal or vaguely nuts for reveling in the particulars of great wealth even as you are made fully aware of all the isolating negatives.

title: Egypt and Cameroon in Final
description: Egypt, the defending champion, and Cameroon advanced Thursday to the final of the African Cup of Nations in Ghana. Amr Zaki scored two second-half goals as Egypt defeated Ivory Coast, 4-1. Earlier in the day, Cameroon beat host Ghana, 1-0, on a 71st-minute goal by Alain Nkong. The final will be Sunday in Accra.

title: Together Again, With More Sugar Than Tabasco
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Girl Power was the slogan when the Spice Girls reunion tour came here to Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum on Wednesday night, the first of six sold-out shows in and around New York City. After a decade apart, the power of a brand name was just as strong. Then and now, the Spice Girls promise an upbeat, cheerful, well-dressed good time, with songs about love and friendship. Its the kind of show thats safe for the young girls who filled the arena  not exactly the overwhelming number of 6- to 10-year-olds that the Spice Girls drew in the 1990s, but plenty of junior high students who squealed nearly as loud.

title: Mexican Robin Hood Figure Gains a Kind of Notoriety in U.S.
description: HOUSTON  Jess Malverde has been revered for almost a century in northwestern Mexico. According to folklore, he was a Mexican Robin Hood who took from the rich and gave to the poor until he was killed by the police in 1909.

title: Billy Joel at Shea Stadium
description: Billy Joel will become the last entertainer to perform at Shea Stadium when he appears on July 16 in his concert The Last Play at Shea, From the Beatles to Billy, Billboard reported. The concert will take place the day after Yankee Stadium, like Shea in its final season on its present site, plays host to the Major League Baseball All-Star Game. Both stadiums are to be replaced by new ones next year. Tickets for the Billy Joel show go on sale Feb. 16. ... Jay-Z and Mary J. Blige will tour together in the spring, beginning with a performance on March 22 at the American Airlines Arena in Miami, Billboard reported. Although all the dates for their Heart of the City concerts have not been arranged, they will appear at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y., on March 27 and at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on March 28. Tickets go on sale Feb. 15.

title: Rescuers Script a Possible Ending for a Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  With Hollywood writers on the brink of ending a three-month strike, they can thank this citys time-honored way of getting things done: connections.

title: Injury Hurts Schillings Outlook
description: Curt Schilling could have retired after the Boston Red Sox won the World Series last fall, but he quickly agreed to an $8 million contract for one last season. Now, a shoulder injury could ruin the final flourish to a decorated career.

title: Restraint That No One Will Find Stifling
description: Come fall, if professional women are taking their fashion cues from Lipstick Jungle, they will be wearing gauzy princess dresses that emphasize their breasts. If they are watching the runways, however, they will be dressing like Hillary Clinton.

title: Newarks Recent Drop in Crime Highlights Mayors Annual Speech
description: NEWARK  Thursday nights State of the City speech was the annual occasion for Mayor Cory A. Booker to highlight his accomplishments and broadcast his grand plans, but for many here  including, to a significant extent, Mr. Booker himself  the actual state of the city can be summed up in a single digit: 2.

title: New York Fan No. 1
description: "Did you see Tom Brady?" Spike Lee asked yesterday over the phone. "He hasn't ever gone up against a pass rush like that before. He thought he'd have the time to get the snap, read The New York Times, read The Wall Street Journal, chill a while and then make a decision. But our guys weren't having any of that" he said. "Tom Brady got a beat-down, Brooklyn style."

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Thursday about the weekly Billboard album chart misidentified the album by the Mars Volta that ranked No. 3. It is the groups new recording, The Bedlam in Goliath  not Frances the Mute, which was released in 2005.

title: Rate of Growth in Consumer Debt Slowed in December
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Consumers increased their borrowing in December at the slowest pace in eight months, additional evidence that economic activity slowed significantly at the end of last year. For all of 2007, consumer credit rose at the fastest clip in three years.

title: Former Trader at French Bank Is Ordered Jailed
description: PARIS  A Paris court on Friday ordered that Jrme Kerviel, the former trader who Socit Gnrale says cost it more than $7 billion last month, be jailed during the course of the continuing investigation and any eventual trial.

title: Put Another Nickel in for Bleary Jukebox Soul
description: To set up her first encore at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night, Cat Power relied on a simple but effective bit of stagecraft. She and her four-piece backing group, the Dirty Delta Blues Band, had just been lumbering engagingly through a tune called Willie, and they didnt wait for it to finish before peeling off into the wings. Eventually the only person left onstage was Jim White, the drummer. He kept his beat going long enough for Cat Power to reappear with an armload of roses and enact a ritual of handing or tossing them, stem by stem, to her grateful fans.

title: Mourning in Missouri as Shooters Motives Emerge
description: The man who police say went on a shooting rampage in a St. Louis suburb Thursday night had a history of conflict at the City Council chamber where he made his last stand.

title: They Dont Throw Paper Like They Used To
description: Football fans probably dont see it this way, but by one measure the Giants Super Bowl victory on Sunday had less than one-hundredth of the significance of V-J Day, which marked Japans surrender and the end of World War II in 1945.

title: Norman Evokes the Past, but the Present Catches Up
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Even with the usual drop-dead vistas from ancient cliffs, waves crashing on the rocks and whales fluking in Carmel Bay, other sightings at the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am induced double takes Thursday.

title: The Tenant Who Wrote Macbeth
description: To posterity the balding man in the courtroom was the greatest writer in the English language. To the maidservant formerly employed at his lodgings, he was one Mr Shakespeare that laye in the house. To the Court of Requests, taking depositions in a lawsuit in 1612, he was simply a witness who gave his statement, signed a hurried Wm Shakspe and then took his leave.

title: In Their Own Words
description: "I know I have a responsibility if I am, as I hope to be, the Republican nominee for president, to unite the party and prepare for the great contest in November, and I am acutely aware that I cannot succeed in that endeavor ...without the support of dedicated conservatives ... Many of you have disagreed strongly with some positions I have taken in recent years. I understand that. I might not agree with it, but I respect it for the principled position it is. And it is my sincere hope that even if you believe I have occasionally erred in my reasoning as a fellow conservative, you will still allow that I have, in many ways important to all of us, maintained the record of a conservative. ... All I ask of any American  conservative, moderate, independent, or enlightened Democrat  is to judge my record as a whole, and accept that I am not in the habit of making promises to my country that I do not intend to keep.

title: Suit Tangles Issue of James Browns Estate
description: He called himself the hardest-working man in show business, and now, even in death, there is little peace for James Brown.

title: Elegant Bungalows
description: WHO Robin Nelson, 55, interior designer  WHAT 1-bedroom house WHERE Dillon Beach, Calif.

title: Hit Men on Holiday Get All Medieval
description: Not long after the start of In Bruges, an amusing trifle from the potty-mouthed playwright Martin McDonagh, two hit men pause before a painting, awe and puzzlement and perhaps something else shading their faces. The painting  a 15th-century Netherlandish diptych  shows a prisoner wearing a loincloth and a strangely calm expression given that hes being flayed alive. A small gathering of men (an audience, you might say) stands around the condemned, whose left calf is being peeled like a blood orange.

title: Gates Defends NATO Mission in Afghanistan
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, continuing his self-described effort to nag allies for more troops in Afghanistan without alienating them, said Thursday that NATO was not in crisis and that the Afghan mission was not failing.

title: Jasper Johns Shows His True Color
description: The art of Jasper Johns has been a cultural fact for about as long as most people can remember. A half century ago his deadpan paintings of flags and targets helped derail second- and third-generation Abstract Expressionism and changed the way we think about art. Since then he has been praised far and wide, his every artistic move doggedly studied and parsed. Meanwhile, he has done little but work, restlessly pushing forward and then circling back, still and ever driven by whatever brought him here in the first place.

title: Congo: 3rd Ex-Warlord Sent to U.N. Court
description: Congo has arrested an army colonel and former militia leader, Mathieu Ngudjolo, and handed him over to the International Criminal Court in The Hague. He faces numerous war crimes charges, including murder, sexual slavery and the forced conscription of children in the eastern region of Ituri in 2003. He is the third militia leader Congo has sent to the court and the first arrested while an active military officer.

title: Deutsche Bank Escapes Subprime Losses
description: FRANKFURT  To the short list of global banks that avoided being badly burned by the subprime bonfire, a roster led by Goldman Sachs, add Deutsche Bank.

title: Alliance Data Drops Merger Suit
description: Alliance Data Systems dropped a lawsuit on Friday that had sought to compel the Blackstone Group to complete a $6.4 billion takeover, putting a swift end to the latest legal battle to emerge over a failed private equity deal.

title: Accused Gambino Leaders Indicted in Sweep
description: One crime stretched back to the 1976 killing of a court officer ambushed outside his home in the early morning hours to prevent him from testifying against a member of the mob.

title: Shadow Journey to the East on Rawhide Wings
description: Long before the invention of film the Chinese developed a remarkable art form of moving images. Shadow puppets, made of pierced and embossed rawhide and manipulated with sticks behind an illuminated screen of transparent cloth, entertained both emperors and rural peasants. Accompanied by music, shadow theater brought good luck at weddings and offered welcome distraction at funerals.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Alcatel Posts Loss and Halts Dividend
description: PARIS  Alcatel-Lucent, the telecommunications giant, predicted a loss in the current quarter on Friday after posting a big fourth-quarter loss and suspending its stock dividend.

title: Romney Is Out; McCain Emerges as G.O.P. Choice
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain all but captured the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday after Mitt Romney withdrew from the race, saying the war in Iraq and the terrorist threat made it imperative that the party unite.

title: Sigh of Relief From the Nervous London Auctions
description: LONDON  Reassurance. Thats what motivated so many dealers and collectors from around the world to flock here this week for the big February art auctions. Reassurance that, despite the shaky state of world financial markets, there are still plenty of people willing to spend millions of dollars to put Impressionist, Modern or contemporary art on their walls.

title: Obama Outshines Clinton at Raising Funds
description: Concerned that it could lose several primaries and caucuses through the rest of February, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign sought to create an alternate storyline of success on Thursday by announcing that Mrs. Clinton had raised $7.5 million online so far this month.

title: An Orchestra Sounding Like Itself Again
description: A common lament among classical music fans is that jet travel and modern recording techniques have destroyed the qualities that make an orchestra sound different from all others. Its generally true: national and local variations in tone color, to say nothing of interpretive approaches, have largely disappeared. But every now and then an ensemble like the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam turns up at Carnegie Hall and reminds listeners that character and distinctiveness have not been obliterated entirely.

title: Davis Cup Resumes Without Some of the Games Most Important Players
description: For some of this years Davis Cup teams, like Israels and South Koreas, the wait to rejoin the World Group has often seemed interminable. But Patrick McEnroe and the Americans cannot quite believe they are being asked to play again so soon.

title: Questions for Dr. Retail
description: QUESTION: Dr. Retail, now that the Democratic presidential race has entered its long, bloody slog phase, I figured it was time to get a fresh perspective. Can you explain to me what its all about?

title: Judge to Decide if French Trader Remains Free
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel, the Socit Gnrale trader accused of losing $7.1 billion in illegal trades, faces a pivotal hearing Friday that will determine whether he remains free pending a trial.

title: Gazprom Threatens to Halt Fuel for Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the worlds largest natural gas company, threatened to halt fuel supplies to Ukraine unless that country settled a $1.5 billion debt by Monday or offered assurances that it would pay.

title: Hamlet and Hair in the Park
description: Who needs groundhogs to file conflicting forecasts of spring when the Public Theater is around to set the stage for summer in Central Park? Hamlet and a full-scale production of the musical Hair are promised for the Shakespeare in the Park season. Hamlet, directed by the Publics artistic director, Oskar Eustis, and starring Michael Stuhlbarg, right, in the title role and Richard Easton as Polonius, will open in previews on May 27 and run through June 29 at the Delacorte Theater. The tragedy has not been staged there since 1975, when Sam Waterston played Hamlet. Hair, starring Jonathan Groff and Will Swenson and directed by Diane Paulus, who staged the 40th-anniversary concert version in the park last September, will run from July 22 through Aug. 17. Bank of America is the lead sponsor of the Shakespeare in the Park performances, which are free of charge. ... The run of the Roundabout Theater Companys production of Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps at the American Airlines Theater has been extended for a week, through March 29.

title: New Suspect Is Arrested in 2 Mississippi Killings
description: ATLANTA  In a possible conclusion to a case that has drawn national attention, a man was arrested this week at his parents home in Mississippi after confessing to raping and killing two young girls in separate attacks in that state in the early 1990s, lawyers involved in the case said. Two other men had been sent to prison in Mississippi for the crimes.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,946 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Healing Cultural Wounds
description: Mary Olive Smith and Amy Buchers documentary A Walk to Beautiful, about the mistreatment of mothers suffering from childbirth injuries in Ethiopia, starts out quietly furious, detailing how its female subjects were ostracized by their villages, husbands, siblings, even parents.

title: Bhutto Report Backs Pakistan Claim
description: WASHINGTON  Investigators from Scotland Yard have concluded that Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistani opposition leader, died after hitting her head as she was tossed by the force of a suicide blast, not from an assassins bullet, according to an executive summary of their report.

title: Conservative Success? Define Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in The Arts on Dec. 27 with the continuation of an article about the photographer Dan Eldon, using information provided by his mother, carried an erroneous credit, and a correction in this space on Jan. 1, also using information provided by Mr. Eldons mother, misspelled the surname of the photographer. The picture, of Mr. Eldon in Somalia, where he was killed in 1993, was by Yannis Behrakis, not Bechrakis. (Mr. Eldons mother, Kathy Eldon, pointed out the misspelling in an e-mail message on Sunday.)

title: Iran Is Reported to Test New Centrifuges to Make Atomic Fuel
description: WASHINGTON  Iran has reportedly begun to deploy a new generation of machinery to produce nuclear fuel, a development bound to intensify a debate in Washington about whether a recent National Intelligence Estimate accurately portrayed Tehrans progress toward the ability to build a nuclear weapon.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline on Wednesday with an article about a proposal to build a toll road through a state park near San Diego misstated the path the road would take. It would cut through the park, known as San Onofre State Beach; the plan is not to build a new road across a beach.

title: In a Red Hood and Running From the Wolves of London
description: With its riffraff and swells, its jerky camerawork and gritty texture, the British film London to Brighton tries awfully hard to pass itself off as a slab of rancid naturalism. Then theres that title, of course, which invokes Graham Greenes pitiless 1938 novel, Brighton Rock, with its slums, its fear and the razor-wielding boy of whom Greene writes, Heaven was a word: hell was something he could trust.

title: Veiled Democracy?
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Committee Investigates Ad Tactics for Lipitor
description: A Congressional committee investigating the Lipitor advertising campaign featuring Dr. Robert Jarvik wants information about payments to people who might have served as stunt doubles for the doctor in televised ads.

title: Four Man Fast Break?
description: Will the Phoenix Suns stunning trade for Shaquille ONeal propel the franchise to its first championship or wreck the N.B.A.s most entertaining team?

title: Face-Lift at the Garden Taps Corporate Money
description: The Devils have moved into their new arena in Newark, and the Mets, the Yankees, the Giants, the Jets and the Nets are building or designing new homes  all of them with more luxury seating and more space for advertising.

title: For Barber and Giants, a Parting, Then an Embrace
description: For the past few days, the million dollar question in New York  outside of whether Roger Clemens did it or didnt do it  is how Tiki Barber feels about the Giants rousing Super Bowl victory.

title: Lottery Numbers
Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Oh, Let Those Musicians Groove to the Beat!
description: To the Editor:

title: ...On the Wall, Making Something of It All
description: Stand before a mirror. What do you see? Yourself? Another room? A portal to an alternate world? A domestic accouterment? A symbol of vanity? A sheet of glass with a metallic coating applied to its back side?

title: An Intolerable Fraud
description: An envelope arrived in our office the other day. It had the bulky, tawdry look of junk mail: pink and lavender Easter eggs, a plastic address window and a photo of a young man in fatigue shorts using crutches to stand on his only leg. Thousands of severely wounded troops are suffering, it read. Will you help them this Easter?

title: Miscalculations Dogged Romney From the Start
description: With Mitt Romneys campaign for president nearly in tatters, he huddled with his senior advisers on Wednesday morning, jotting notes with pen and paper, to go over his options.

title: Diabetes Health Goes Beyond Blood Sugar
description: The startling findings of a major federal study on the effects of lowering blood sugar are unlikely to change the way most people with Type 2 diabetes manage their illness, doctors said Thursday.

title: English Study Global Games
description: The 20 teams in the English Premier League agreed to examine proposals to expand the regular season and play 10 games overseas starting in 2010-11. The matches would be played at five sites around the world over a single weekend in January 2011. Each city would play host to one game on Saturday and one on Sunday. The international round would be in addition to the traditional 38 home and away matches each of the clubs currently play.

title: Crossing the Border From Light to Human
description: A human being becomes one with manufactured light in Chunky Moves Glow, seen on Wednesday night at The Kitchen. This ingenious 30-minute solo, created by this Australian modern-dance companys director, Gideon Obarzanek, is not its first experiment with mixed media, but it must certainly be the troupes most advanced. Ringed on four sides by the audience members, Kristy Ayre creates a world of light around her as she moves.

title: Nebraska Supreme Court Outlaws Electric Chair
description: The electric chair is cruel and unusual punishment, the Nebraska Supreme Court ruled Friday, effectively suspending executions in the only state that made sole use of the practice, once the dominant form of execution in the United States.

title: Abused Girl Was Dead for Seven Hours Before 911 Call, Doctor Testifies
description: Seven-year-old Nixzmary Brown slipped into unconsciousness more than 13 hours before her stepfather and mother sought medical help for her, a medical examiner testified Thursday at her stepfathers murder trial.

title: Taking People Power to a New Level
description: Some people exercise by power walking. But what if walking could actually provide electrical power? Researchers have developed an electrical generator mounted on the knee that turns walks into watts.

title: Trouble in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Final Spin on the Budget
description: As a political document, President Bushs new budget could not be timelier for Republican candidates  those aspiring to City Hall, the Capitol or all the way to the White House  who wax xenophobic about immigration and the Mexican border.

title: Britney Spears Is Released
description: Britney Spears, removed from her home to a psychiatric ward on Jan. 31 after repeated bizarre behavior, was released on Wednesday, prompting her parents to complain that her life is presently at risk, The Associated Press reported. People magazine, citing an unidentified source, reported that her release was attributable to a court representative who overrode the wishes of her parents and the doctor overseeing her care at U.C.L.A. Medical Center.

title: Checking In for the Long Haul
description: EVERY year, right about this time, Deena Fishmans baffled friends start in with the telephone calls and the questions. They all want to know why Mrs. Fishman and her husband, David, residents of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., dont follow their particular  sensible  example and buy a condominium in Florida.

title: Mayor Accuses Realty Firms of Seeking Undue Influence
description: In a rare public scolding of an industry that is friendly with his administration, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg criticized real estate companies on Thursday, saying it appears they are trying to buy influence in the 2009 mayoral campaign.

title: In Mexico: A Bus of Womens' Own
description: Mexico City has created "Women Only" buses in response to complaints of sexual harassment on public transportation.

title: From Sympathy to Outrage
description: According to philanthropic watchdogs like the American Institute of Philanthropy, nonprofit groups that raise money for veterans causes are among the worst in the charity world for wastefulness and mismanagement. Todays editorial about the issue is here.

title: Romney's Campaign Comes to an End
description: Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, said he ended his campaign to help unify the Republican Party.

title: The Right Call, the Right Referee
description: What if . the ref had gotten it wrong?

title: Naming the Catch
description: As the City Room blog noted, several blogs have been asking readers to name David Tyrees catch in the Super Bowl.

title: Friday: New York Fashion Week
description: Selections from the Friday runway shows during New York Fashion Week.

title: The Lodger Shakespeare
description: The Deposition

title: The List of Winners
description: Overall Game of the Year: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare, Activision

title: Soccer Leads to New Hope
A Man Needs a Parade
description: A blog reader and longtime Giants fan sent us this dispatch from Tuesdays parade:By Dan Bruskewicz

title: Discover Will Sell a Card Unit in Britain at a Big Loss
description: Discover Financial Services said Thursday that it had agreed to sell its Goldfish credit card unit in Britain to the British bank Barclays for $70 million, abandoning a money-losing business it acquired two years ago for $1.68 billion.

title: Buffett Wont Be Witness in Fraud Trial
description: Defense lawyers rested their case at the fraud trial of General Reinsurance executives accused of helping the American International Group mislead investors, without jurors hearing from the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.

title: Three Natural Gas Traders Convicted in Texas
description: Three former El Paso Corporation natural gas traders were convicted on Thursday of reporting false deals to manipulate gas prices from 2000 to 2002.

title: Court Bars Sale of Billions in Oil Assets by Venezuela
description: The oil giant Exxon Mobil has won court orders freezing as much as $12 billion in petroleum assets controlled by Venezuelas government in an escalation of a dispute over efforts by President Hugo Chvez to assert greater control over the countrys oil industry.

title: Real Goods Solar to Brave Stormy I.P.O. Market
description: Real Goods Solar, which installs solar panels on homeowners rooftops, filed paperwork on Thursday to go public with the goal of raising up to $57.5 million.

title: Bronfman Said to Face Insider Charges Over Vivendi Dealings
description: Warner Music Groups chairman and chief executive, Edgar Bronfman Jr., faces preliminary charges of insider trading as part of a French investigation of alleged wrongdoing at the French media and telecom group Vivendi Universal, The Associated Press reported.

title: Transmeta Hires Piper Jaffray to Advise on Buyout
description: A chip designer, Transmeta said Thursday it had lined up Piper Jaffray to help it weigh an unsolicited buyout offer from an investor, Riley Investment Management.

title: Brazil State Bank Wont Oppose Vale Bid for Xstrata
description: Brazils state development bank BNDES sees no reason to oppose an attempt by a local mining company, Companhia Vale do Rio Doce to buy a Swiss-based rival, Xstrata, the banks president said Thursday, signaling that the bid is unlikely to be blocked by the government.

title: V.C.s Sweeten SugarCRMs Pot
description: SugarCRM a maker of open-source customer relationship management software, has landed a $20 million venture investment round designed to boost its international expansion, the company said Thursday.

title: Creators of Credit Crisis Revel in Las Vegas
description: Before the current credit squeeze, this weeks conference of the American Securitization Forum in Las Vegas might have been called the Predators Ball of this era. This year, though, the gathering felt more like group therapy, The New York Times reports.

title: Seattle Taps Its Inner Silicon Valley
description: Many communities dream of becoming the next Silicon Valley. But, says The New York Times, the Fremont District in Seattle is actually doing it.

title: New Executive Post Heightens I.P.O. Chatter at Citadel
description: As chatter that the Citadel Investment Group, the powerful hedge fund run by Kenneth C. Griffin, may be planning an initial public offering grows, the latest inside move has added to the speculation.

title: MBF Healthcare Swallows Critical Homecare
description: MBF Healthcare Acquisition, a special-purpose acquisition company backed by MBF Healthcare Partners, said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Critical Homecare Solutions Holdings from the private equity firm Kohlberg & Company for $420 million.

title: Biffa Accepts $2.3 Billion Buyout Bid
description: Biffa, a British waste management group, said Friday it had agreed to a 1.2 billion pound ($2.34 billion) takeover from a private equity consortium. Its shares rose above the offer price, suggesting investors hoped for a counterbid.

title: Play-Dohs Dialogues
description: You thought E*Trades baby was wise beyond his years in those Super Bowl ads. Heres what London schoolkids are into, the Daily Mail reports:

title: GSO Capital Said to Hire From Rival Firm
description: GSO Capital Partners, the $10 billion hedge fund that recently agreed to sell itself to the Blackstone Group, has recruited the head of asset-backed securities at Brevan Howard, a British rival, Financial News reported. Najib Canaan, who has worked at Brevan Howard since last May, is also a former colleague of GSOs co-founders, the publication said.

title: Bond Raters in Effort to Repair Credibility
description: Under fire for their role in the mortgage crisis, Standard & Poors and the Moodys Corporation are scrambling to restore confidence in their credit ratings. But proposals released by the companies this week have met with skepticism from some of their toughest critics.

title: National Health Crisis in a Nutshell
description: From Overheard Everywhere:

title: Smell the Glove
description: From Fridays sports section, on the legal hockey tactic of face-washing, often to provoke an opposing player into an infraction:

title: Antitrust Concerns Hover Over UnitedHealth Deal
description: Investors concerns about the $2.4 billion merger of Sierra Health Services and the UnitedHealth Group appear to be growing, judging from the widening spread in the companies share prices. The reason? Continued political opposition in Nevada and the risk that a further delay in the federal antitrust review could trigger new proceedings at the state level, The Deal reports.

title: The Parked-in-My-Driveway-Until-Further-Notice Express
description: More of your late night comedy (sent via the comment link below):

title: How Would You Like to Be Those Five Guys?
description: Aired Thursday night on CBS: Did you hear that Mitt Romney has dropped out of the race? But do not worry about Mitt, because hes going to go back to playing Stuart Chandler on All My Children.

title: A Fence Around Our Parking Lot Security Guard
description: Aired Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Mitt Romney dropped out of the race for president, and they say Romney spent $37 million of his own money on the campaign. Thats amazing. I was able to not win the presidency for free.

title: Fridays Links: The Readers Weigh In
description: Usually, I wind up the week by linking to good stuff Im reading on and offline. But lately, the comments on this blog have been so rich that I wanted to shine the light back on them.

title: Sanford and Pun
description: The 1970s junk-dealer sitcom Sanford and Son was based on a BBC series (Steptoe and Son), but no word if this London storefront was any inspiration. From Shop Horror: The Best of the Worst in British Shop Names (Fourth Estate). More on the book here.

title: Flowers Said to Be Near $4 Billion China Deal
description: The China Investment Corporation, the Chinese sovereign wealth fund, is close to an agreement with the private equity firm J.C. Flowers to put about $4 billion into a new fund to invest in ailing financial institutions, The Financial Times reported.

title: Bebo Said to Be Raising Fresh Capital
description: Contrary to some reports, Google and News Corporation are not about to buy Bebo, a social networking site, for $1 billion to $1.5 billion, according to All Things Digital.

title: Judge to Decide if French Trader Remains Free
description: Jrme Kerviel, the Socit Gnrale trader accused of losing $7.1 billion in illegal trades, faces a pivotal hearing Friday that will determine whether he remains free pending a trial.

title: MBIA Sells Stock to Aid Rating and Raises $1 Billion
description: The bond insurer MBIA raised $1 billion on Thursday by selling shares at $12.15 each in an effort to protect its AAA insurance rating.

title: Deutsche Banks Ackermann Is Feeling Good
description: To the short list of global banks that avoided being badly burned by the subprime bonfire, a roster led by Goldman Sachs, add Deutsche Bank.

title: Softbank in Talks With Yahoo Over Microsoft Bid
description: Could Softbank, the Japanese telecom and Internet company that owns a stake in Yahoo, add a new wrinkle to Microsofts $44.6 billion attempt to take over the Web giant?

title: This Week Moves To Newseum In April
description: The Newseum, a Pennsylvania Avenue museum dedicated to journalism, will open its doors on April 11, the Freedom Forum announced on Thursday.

title: Is It Too Late for Yahoo?
description: One of the first questions that Jerry Yang and his top lieutenants pondered after he became chief executive of Yahoo last summer was whether the company could remain independent. They quickly answered yes.

title: Smell the Glove
description: Our own Dave Caldwell gives the lowdown on that time-honored hockey tradition, the face wash, in Fridays Times. As Chico Resch says, its a tactic thats been around since hands were invented.

title: The Early Word: Democrats Still in the Weeds
description: If it wasnt clear before, John McCain emerged the presumptive nominee in the Republican race on Thursday after Mitt Romney suspended his campaign.

title: Bubble-Wrapped Review: Juno
description: Those of you who have been keeping score know that the Bagger is spending a couple of hours a day stuck in an oxygen-enhanced cell. To pass the time  no paper or electronic devices are allowed inside the chamber  the Bagger is spending some lo-fi time with the Best Picture nominees.

title: The Not-So-Hottie
description: SpoutBlog takes note of the fact that Slant Magazine watched The Hottie And The Nottie so the rest of us didnt have to. Ed Gonzalez stares into the space between Paris Hiltons ears and comes away with a newfound respect for Ugly Betty. He writes that the Nottie is enough to make me rethink Ugly Betty, almost respecting the ABC show for keeping America Ferrara looking ugly and still doable.

title: An Unlikely Principal Revives a South Bronx School
description: The man behind the improvement of one of the citys most dangerous junior high schools seemed, at first, a cultural mismatch for a predominantly minority school: a Hasidic Jew with a beard, a black hat and a velvet yarmulke.

title: The Worst Idea Ever
description: Vulture points to two game sites that are suggesting that Juno is about to get retrofitted with a joystick. Juno the game brings to mind a few scenarios and Vulture takes a whack at one: Will it be the worlds easiest Guitar Hero knockoff, in which players try to hit only off-key notes in Moldy Peaches songs?

title: There Will be Milkshakes. And Frocks
description: Anne Thompson points at Funny or Die, highlighting a set piece of David Spade as Daniel Day-Lewis as Daniel Plainview, giving a Socratic discourse on why there must be an Oscar ceremony this year. Its a reminder that just a small touch of funny would not hurt the ceremonies one bit this year. Funny is hard, but Spade makes it look pretty easy.

title: Banned for Life
description: Randy Quaid, last seen in Oscarville during the Brokeback campaign, is being tagged out by his union. The Actors Equity Association has pulled his card and fined him $81,000 for his behavior during the Seattle production of Lone Star Love, which was supposed to come to Broadway, but was allegedly derailed by his bullying.

title: Tough Crowd
description: The American Conservative Unions annual C.P.A.C. meeting in Washington was always going to be a Scylla and Charybdis moment for John McCain  if he was going to try and play to the crowd and burnish his right-wing credentials, would he risk losing his moderate Republican and independent support? Well, he caught an early break with Mitt Romneys departure from the race. So what did he make of his moment of emergence as the de facto nominee?

title: Hearing on Microsoft-Yahoo Deal Postponed
description: Just as Capitol Hill was about to start debating the potential effects of a MicrosoftYahoo merger, some lawmakers seem to have called a time out.

title: Recipe of the Day: The Ultimate Minimalist Macaroon
description: For most traditionalists, almond macaroons are the standard. But to me, killer macaroons are made from coconut. What could be better than the simple and sublime combination of unsweetened coconut, egg whites, sugar, salt, and vanilla?

title: Alliance Data Drops Lawsuit Against Blackstone
description: Alliance Data Systems on Friday dropped its lawsuit against its would-be buyer, the Blackstone Group, leaving open a path to settlement talks. Alliance Data, a credit card services provider, filed a motion to dismiss its case in Delawares Court of Chancery.

title: Wall Street May Be Cutting Back
description: Wall Streets woe  falling stock prices and a shaky economy  may be affecting campaign fund-raising. The Center for Responsive Politics reports a big drop in campaign contributions from Wall Street in the fourth quarter, just as the markets began to tumble. In the first quarter of 2007, Wall Street gave a total of $10 million to all presidential candidates. That fell to $4.5 million by the last three months of the year.

title: Stray Questions for: Ilan Stavans
description: Ilan Stavanss books include On Borrowed Words: A Memoir of Language and The Disappearance: A Novella and Stories.

title: Poetry Corner
description: Just uncovered some 1967-68 Buffalo Bisons programs from my youth and was happy to find a fantastic poem I read in them way back then and never forgot: Ill Take Hockey Any Time! by John Kieran. Believe it or not, the poem does not exist anywhere on the Web, so this is its electronic debut. Quiet please, the reading is about to begin.

title: At 60, a French Classic Stays of Age
description: PARIS  The Citron 2CV, whose role in France was like that of Fords Model T in America, started celebrating its 60th birthday on Friday at the 10-day Rtromobile show in Paris. Inside exhibition hall no. 4, the 2CV display may be surrounded by prettier cars, but none more lovable.Rtromobile, held annually at the Porte de Versailles, celebrates any car that deserves preservation by collectors, and around 320 exhibitors are on hand this year. Some have books, spare parts and key chains. But at the heart of the show are the classic cars displayed by clubs, dealers, and auctioneers: Bugattis, Hispano-Suizas, Amilcars, and Panhards share floor space with Hondas, Mercedes-Benzes, BMWs, Peugeots, Renaults and Citrons.

title: Pleasantness Is Fleeting in a Changing Neighborhood
description: Standing near First Avenue and looking down East 117th Street toward the East River, a shiny new glass-and-metal condo building can be seen, and in the distance, there are the beginnings of the East River Plaza shopping center, future home of a Home Depot store. Two of the buildings that can also be seen in East Harlem make up Pleasant East, a set of four apartment buildings with a troubled history of neglect and violence and resident discontent. The New York branch of the Acorn Housing Corporation, which now owns the buildings, held a ceremony last week to mark the end of more than two years of renovations there. Meeting with some residents for the Dispatches feature in The City section this week about the state of the buildings, I saw a neighborhood in transition  the kind of transition that can make people with low incomes, struggling to find a place to live with affordable rent, nervous.

title: Romney Reaganesque Withdrawal

Mr. Romney then took the stage and picked up on the same analogy, putting himself in the role of Reagan. There is an important difference between now and 1976, he said. Today we are a nation at war. And for that reason, he said, he had to withdraw now so that the party could unify against the Democratic threat to withdraw prematurely from Iraq.

title: Budapest Festival Orchestra:Model Orchestra and Orchestra Models
description: Take 50 to 100 highly trained musicians, put instruments in their hands, place em on stage and charge admission. Its called an orchestra. But how do you organize them? Pay them? Make use of their time? Keep them happy? Keep audiences happy?All sorts of models exist. I had a chat with Ivan Fischer, who leads the Budapest Festival Orchestra, at a Lincoln Center bakery/eatery on Friday, and he told the story of his group. It sounded pretty special. Now since I have not looked closely at exactly how the orchestra works, it is hard to gauge the reality. But at the least, Mr. Fischers description sounded like a fine ideal.The Budapest Festival Orchestra has been around since 1983, when Mr. Fischer, a budding freelance conductor at the time, decided to settle down and helped establish it. But it has not achieved the notice in this country of other top European bands. It has concert dates Friday night and Sunday afternoon as part of Lincoln Centers Great Performers series.Mr. Fischers orchestra, he said, has three cardinal virtues, established at its creation: an emphasis on the players individual creativity; few rules, for maximum flexibility; and unusual programming.Thus, on Point 1, the orchestra has internal concerto competitions, so not just principals get to play solos. Players are encouraged to come up with their own chamber music programs. Seating rotates. More active musicians make a better team, said Mr. Fischer, who speaks slowly with a Hungarian accent. The no-rules rule means no long-term contracts, no overtime and auditions that end up with five or six finalists who play with the orchestra.Innovative programs mean daylong festivals devoted to a composer; surprise concerts, in which the program is unknown until the players come on stage; and sight-reading concerts, in which a slip of paper is drawn out of a tuba bell with a seat number. The person in that seat then picks the piece. A truck with the orchestra library is waiting outside, so the parts can be delivered. Next season, the orchestra comes to Carnegie Hall with Gypsy musicians.Often readers of material like the above will write in and say, Gee, thats all very well, but my orchestra has been doing those things for ages; you failed to mention X, Y and Z. So consider this an open invitation to comment on ArtsBeat about orchestra models, model orchestras and interesting features of both.

title: A Rat in the Kitchen
description: BEFORE I begin, a wish to all for good fortune in this Lunar New Year, annum 4706, a Year of the Rat in the cyclical Chinese zodiac. It is a custom each year to look into the character and traits of the creature that governs ones birth year, and to ask if they might mirror ones own propensities. The rat, for example, is notable for his guile and clever talk and for being an occasional toady, yet as the year goes on he has the capacity to become an upstanding fellow. So, happiness and growth to all rats, most of whom will begin celebrating their year, as will we, dining festively.

Their faces were smeared with black coal dust as a dingy white truck carried them down an underground road to the floor of the mine.

title: Resistance to Flu Drug
description: Almost 5 percent of the flu samples tested in the United States this season were resistant to the antiflu drug Tamiflu, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. Tamiflu resistance has been previously almost unknown in the United States. It is more common in Japan, where the drug, also known as oseltamivir, is heavily prescribed. The reason for the increase in resistance is still under investigation, said Dr. Joseph Bresee, chief of prevention in the agencys flu division. All strains tested were susceptible to a related drug, Relenza, or zanamivir. After a slow start to the flu season, the illness is now being reported in all 50 states, Dr. Bresee said. Doctors visits and deaths attributable to flu are slightly above normal and increasing, but not atypical compared with some of the last 25 years, he said.

title: Austria: 11 Dead in Retirement Home Fire
description: At least 11 residents of a retirement home were killed when a fire engulfed the building in the western town of Egg, a regional government spokesman said. Twenty-three residents and two supervisors were in the building when the fire started. The cause is under investigation.

title: G.I. Tells of Ordering Unarmed Iraqis Death

title: In Venezuela, Faith in Chvez Starts to Wane
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  These should be the best of times for Venezuela, blessed with the largest conventional oil reserves outside the Middle East and oil prices near record highs. But this countrys economic and social problems have become so acute lately that President Hugo Chvez is facing an unusual onslaught of criticism, even from his own supporters, about his management of the country.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Friday about the investigation of pitcher Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, for suspected doping misidentified the lawyer who defended Mr. McNamees decision to keep medical supplies from the case. It was Richard Emery  not Earl Ward, another lawyer for Mr. McNamee. (Both men spoke at a news conference.)

title: Teams Turn to W.N.B.A. for Coaches
description: Before entering her 34th season as the Tennessee womens basketball coach, Pat Summitt had already won seven national championships, amassed an N.C.A.A.-record 947 victories and produced dozens of all-Americans and Olympians. Her name had long been synonymous with the sport.

title: Book Fairs Plans to Honor Israel Lead to Protests
description: ROME  The selection of Israel as guest of honor at this springs International Book Fair in Turin has set off a furious debate among Italian, Israeli and Arab authors and intellectuals, including calls to boycott the event, Italys largest annual gathering of the publishing world.

title: Israel Reduces Gazas Electricity as Rocket Attacks Continue
description: JERUSALEM  Israel has begun reducing the amount of electricity it sells to Gaza as part of sanctions against continued rocket fire, Israeli officials said Friday.

title: Appellate Panel Rejects E.P.A. Emission Limits
description: A three-judge federal appeals panel in Washington struck down on Friday the Environmental Protection Agency limits on mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants.

title: In Missouri, City Asks What Made Killer Snap
description: KIRKWOOD, Mo.  The day after a gunman opened fire at City Hall, killing five people before the police fatally shot him, residents of this affluent suburb southwest of St. Louis struggled to come to terms with what they called the unthinkable.

title: Yahoo Board to Reject Takeover Bid From Microsoft
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoos board of directors plans to reject Microsofts $44.6 billion hostile bid with a letter Monday saying the offer undervalues Yahoo, a person familiar with the matter said Saturday.

title: Usually the Plays the Thing, but Give the Bidding Its Due
description: A newspaper column contains a deal diagram, a bidding sequence and a description of the play. If it is a constructed deal to illustrate a particular play technique, the contract might be unusual, and giving a credible auction can be difficult. The writer does his best, but he will concentrate primarily on the play.

title: Bhuttos Party Disputes Scotland Yard Report on Her Death
