description: KARACHI, Pakistan  The party of Benazir Bhutto insisted Friday that she was killed by gunfire, despite a report by British investigators that supported the governments view that she was killed when the force of a suicide blast caused her to strike her head.

title: Unforeseen Change of Course for Ailing Sailor
description: Last week, a drained Nick Scandone sat at the Coral Reef Yacht Club bar in Miami after dominating an international sailing fleet and winning the Rolex Miami Olympic Classes Regatta with seven firsts out of 11 races. For Scandone, a member of the United States sailing team, this was one of many training regattas on his schedule leading up to the race of a lifetime in China at the end of the summer.

title: Atlantic 10s Resurgence Starts With Scheduling
description: With four of their teams in the top 25 in simulations of college basketballs ratings percentage index and a host of impressive victories, Atlantic 10 athletic directors and coaches do not have to fight so hard for respect this season.

title: Mexican Leader to Visit U.S., Outside the Beltway
description: MEXICO CITY  President Felipe Caldern of Mexico will tour the United States next week, but he will avoid the White House, Capitol Hill and the presidential candidates, sticking instead to meetings with Mexican immigrants in major cities like New York as well as with a few local officials.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 19 about a major natural gas deal that Russia signed with Bulgaria misstated the quantity of Russian natural gas that is to be transported each year in a pipeline across Bulgarian territory. It will be one trillion cubic feet, not one billion cubic feet.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about modest signs of progress for the new African Union-United Nations force for Darfur misstated the composition of the helicopter fleet the United Nations says is needed. It is 18 transport helicopters and 6 attack helicopters, not the other way around.

title: Lives and a Georgia Communitys Anchor Are Lost
description: PORT WENTWORTH, Ga.  A day after an explosive fireball cratered the sprawling Dixie Crystal sugar refinery, the anchor of this small community for decades, families of missing workers waited in a Catholic church across the street on Friday as rescue workers tried to determine the human toll.

title: Surviving, Just
description: The 16th edition of the CBS series Survivor made its debut on Thursday with the lowest ratings for a premiere in the shows eight-year history. Nielsen estimated that the show, set in Micronesia, drew 13.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., short of the 15.4 million who tuned in for the start of Survivor: China in September (which matched the previous all-time low, set by the seriess first episode in 2000). Still, Survivor easily won its time slot, helping CBS deliver the most viewers on average for the night. The runner-up, ABC, led the night among adults 18 to 49, with Lost at 9 (15.1 million) taking first in that demographic. ABCs Eli Stone (9.4 million) also managed to lead the 10 p.m. time in that group, although CBSs Without a Trace rerun in that hour had more viewers (10.2 million). Also at 10, the premiere of NBCs Lipstick Jungle drew a disappointing 7.6 million viewers; in January, ABCs similarly themed Cashmere Mafia attracted 10.6 million viewers. NBC ranked fourth for the night but tied Fox for third among the 18-to-49 set.

title: Alliance Data Drops Suit to Force Deal
description: Alliance Data Systems, the credit card processor, dropped its lawsuit against its would-be buyer, the Blackstone Group private equity firm, on Friday, putting a swift end to the latest legal battle to emerge over a troubled private equity deal.

title: The Insider Host Seeks Alcoholism Treatment
description: Pat OBrien, a host of The Insider, has entered a rehabilitation center for treatment of alcohol abuse, his shows syndicator, CBS Television Distribution, announced on Friday. Mr. OBrien acknowledged his alcoholism in an interview on CBS in 2005. The Insider correspondent Thomas Roberts is expected to be co-host with Lara Spencer in Mr. OBriens absence.

title: From Japans Slump in 1990s, Lessons for U.S.
description: In broad strokes, the parallels are alarming. After a long boom, the Japanese economy in the 1990s, as Americas today, was jolted by a sharp plunge in the real estate market.

title: Call It Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: On the G.O.P. Side, a Clearer Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: After Raid, New Leaders May Emerge in Mob Family
description: With its structured chain of command, its varied revenue streams and its emphasis on maximizing earnings, the Mafia has always styled itself as a criminal version of Big Business. There is even an argument to be made that Cosa Nostra, as purists often call it, is one of Americas most enduring industries, having been around for at least as long, if not longer, than Fortune 500 companies like General Motors or I.B.M.

title: The Greener Side of Recession
description: TONGUE planted firmly in cheek  or maybe not, its a bit hard to tell  Fion MacCloud of the British site Finance Markets recently offered 10 Ways the Recession Can Help the Environment. A recession, he noted, means less waste dumped into landfills, fewer S.U.V.s sold and fewer people taking vacations, in that way using less fuel.

title: Serbia: Kosovo Set to Declare Independence, Serbia Says
description: The Serbian minister for Kosovo, Slobodan Samardzic, said his government had received relevant information that the provinces Albanian leadership would declare independence on Feb. 17, a Sunday. He did not specify the source. Western diplomats speaking on condition of anonymity because of the delicacy of the matter said the move would be made on Feb. 18, as the European Unions foreign ministers met in Brussels, and that the Kosovo Parliament would convene at 4 a.m. Eastern time, making it all but impossible for Russia to call an immediate session of the United Nations Security Council to try to block it. Kosovos prime minister, Hashim Thaci, did not confirm or deny the date cited by Mr. Samardzic but said Kosovos split from Serbia was a done deal. He added that 100 countries were ready to recognize Kosovos independence as soon as it was declared.

title: McCain Seeks to Unify Support, but Huckabee Is Steadfast
description: WASHINGTON  In an effort to unify the Republican Party around his candidacy, Senator John McCain was spending Saturday making telephone calls thanking his supporters, and trying to line up more endorsements.

title: South Africa: Mbeki Addresses Power Crisis
description: President Thabo Mbeki apologized in his annual State of the Nation address for the electricity shortage that has caused widespread, crippling blackouts over the last month. He called on households and businesses to conserve energy and said the government would carry out a campaign for solar water heating and efficient lighting.

title: NBC Makes News on Clintons, and Reports on It, Too
description: NBC made its share of Clinton-related political news on Friday, suspending a reporter for what it said were inappropriate comments about Chelsea Clinton and also featuring scenes of Bill Clinton saying that he had learned he should not be defending his wife but promoting her.

title: For a Spiritual Cleansing, Try Movement
description: Deganit Shemy has the mind of an engineer with a strong background in psychology and gender studies, to judge by Iodine, her new work seen on Thursday night at Performance Space 122. Six women dressed in what look like schoolgirls clothes wind their way through meticulously plotted encounters for 50 minutes with little sense of repetition. They cry out, fiddle with their clothes, bat one another about and crumple to the floor with the jagged angularity of broken bones. Each eruption is precisely timed, a quick spike on an unending graph of life force.

title: Five Years of Probation for Radomski
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Kirk Radomski, a former clubhouse attendant for the Mets who spent nearly a decade peddling performance-enhancing drugs to major league baseball players, was given five years of probation Friday.

title: Morgenstern Wins Again
description: Thomas Morgenstern of Austria won a World Cup ski jumping meet in Liberec, Czech Republic, his third consecutive victory and his 10th of the season. He jumped 132.0 and 128.5 meters for a total of 272.4 points. Morgenstern improved his lead in the overall World Cup standings to 1,555 points. Gregor Schlierenzauer of Austria was second with jumps of 130.5 and 129 meters. Andreas Kuettel of Switzerland was third.

title: The Race to Read Genomes on a Shoestring, Relatively Speaking
Video Game Industry Picks a War Game as Its Best
description: LAS VEGAS  Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare, the high-octane antiterrorism thriller developed by Infinity Ward and published by Activision, took top honors on Thursday night at the 11th annual Interactive Achievement Awards, the video game industrys equivalent of the Oscars.

title: Media and Candidate Methods of Counting Delegates Vary and So Do Totals
description: Turn on MSNBC and you will learn that Senator Barack Obama has more delegates (861) than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton (855) in the Democratic presidential contest.

title: Facing Free Software, Microsoft Looks to Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Nearly a quarter-century ago, the mantra information wants to be free heralded an era in which news, entertainment and personal communications would flow at no charge over the Internet.

title: On Investigating a Republican
description: The federal investigation involving Joseph Bruno, the New York Senate majority leader, reportedly broadened this week. The wider investigation raises new questions about Mr. Brunos own conduct, of course. But, the sluggish pace also makes us ask whether White House politics could be dragging out an investigation of considerable importance to New Yorkers and to Washington.

title: Student Kills 2 and Herself at a Louisiana College
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  A nursing student opened fire Friday morning in a classroom filled with students at a technical colleges campus here, killing two young women before fatally wounding herself, the police said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Thursday with an article about Wal-Marts plans to install several hundred new medical clinics misspelled the surname of the senior director of health business development for the retailer. She is Alicia Ledlie, not Ledie.

title: Gates Says Anger Over Iraq Hurts Afghan Effort
description: MUNICH  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Friday that many Europeans were confused about NATOs security mission in Afghanistan, and that they did not support the alliance effort because they opposed the American-led invasion of Iraq.

title: 2nd Trader Emerges in Inquiry in France
description: PARIS  French investigators said Friday that they were questioning a second trader in connection with Socit Gnrales 5 billion euro ($7.1 billion) loss, the worst in history caused by a rogue trader.

title: Toward Drug Case Justice
description: Attorney General Michael Mukasey tried to scare the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday into blocking a responsible plan by the United States Sentencing Commission to address the gross disparity in penalties for possession or sale of crack cocaine and those for powder cocaine offenses. His alarm is unwarranted.

title: A Tight Grip Can Choke Creativity
description: On Friday, a lawyer named Anthony Falzone filed his sides first big brief in the case of Warner Bros. Entertainment and J. K. Rowling v. RDR Books. Mr. Falzone is employed by Stanford Law School, where he heads up the Fair Use Project, which was founded several years ago by Lawrence Lessig, perhaps the law schools best-known professor. Mr. Falzone and the other lawyers at the Fair Use Project are siding with the defendant, RDR Books, a small book publisher based in Muskegon, Mich. As you can see from the titans who have brought the suit, RDR Books needs all the legal firepower it can muster.

title: No Damage to Shuttle Atlantis
description: The space shuttle Atlantis appears to have made its fiery trip to orbit without any obvious signs of damage to its delicate heat shield, NASA officials said. The first look at the ascent video showed that the few small chunks of foam that fell from the rockets external fuel tank after liftoff did not appear to pose any risk to the shuttle or crew, said John Shannon, the head of the mission management team. The shuttle, which is carrying a new laboratory module to the International Space Station on this 11-day mission, will dock on Saturday.

title: Panel Gains Right to See C.I.A. Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional investigators have been given permission to review interrogation tapes of a terrorism suspect as part of an inquiry into the destruction of other tapes by the Central Intelligence Agency, according to a letter sent Thursday to the House Intelligence Committee.

title: Following Two Paths to the Same Destination: Environmental Doom
description: Two lavish, cautionary nature documentaries go head to head on Sunday in a fight for the worried viewer. Their messages of ecological doom are similar, but their methods couldnt be more different.

title: Growing Pains of Universal Coverage
description: It has not been a good few weeks for state efforts to provide universal health insurance. A pioneering program in Massachusetts to cover hundreds of thousands of uninsured has cost a lot more in its opening phases than originally projected, raising fears about its sustainability. An even more ambitious proposal to cover millions of uninsured in California collapsed in the State Senate over fears that it would prove unaffordable.

title: Allowed In, Winehouse Chooses to Stay Home
description: Amy Winehouse, right, the British soul singer, will perform via satellite for the 50th annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday despite an unexpected reversal of the State Departments rejection of her visa, her spokesman said Friday. Officials at the Department of Homeland Security issued a waiver that in effect overturned a decision by the United States Embassy in London to deny her visa request, according to an administration official. But the shift came too late for Ms. Winehouse, who recently entered a rehabilitation clinic after a video purporting to show her using drugs surfaced online, to prepare for a live performance in Los Angeles. Her spokesman, Chris Goodman, said, Unfortunately, due to the logistics involved and timing complications, Amy will not be traveling to the U.S. to perform at the Grammys in person. Ms. Winehouse, who is nominated in six categories, including album of the year for Back to Black, will join a long list of performers on the broadcast, which grew longer on Friday with the announcement that Kanye West, whose eight nominations are the most for anyone, will take the stage at the ceremony. John Mayer and Bebe Winans will also perform on the live CBS broadcast. Organizers previously announced a lineup including Beyonc, Rihanna, Kid Rock and the Foo Fighters.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Inside Art column in Weekend on Friday, about the February art auctions in London, misidentified the nationality of the artist Rudolf Stingel, whose three paintings offered at a Christie's auction went unsold. He was born in Italy and holds Italian citizenship, and recently became an American citizen. He is not German.

title: Karl Ehrhardt, 83, Sign Man and Shea Stadium Fixture, Is Dead
description: Karl Ehrhardt, who through championship seasons and woeful ones and grand slams and botched plays let the Mets know what he thought of them by raising block-lettered signs from his box seat behind third base at Shea Stadium, died Tuesday at his home in Glen Oaks, Queens. He was 83.

title: Wary U.S. Olympians Will Bring Food to China
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  When a caterer working for the United States Olympic Committee went to a supermarket in China last year, he encountered a piece of chicken  half of a breast  that measured 14 inches. Enough to feed a family of eight, said Frank Puleo, a caterer from Staten Island who has traveled to China to handle food-related issues.

title: Mounting Struggles Endanger Roots of Racing
description: BARBERVILLE, Fla.  Only the uninitiated sit in the first few rows of the grandstand once the racing begins here on the dirt track of Volusia Speedway Park. Drivers jam the throttle upon entering a turn, which spins their cars sideways, lifts the front left tires off the track and sprays clumps of dirt everywhere.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart on Thursday about senators who have sought the presidency omitted one such candidate and erroneously included another. Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon sought the 1960 Democratic nomination, but eventually withdrew. And although Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, explored presidential runs in 1988 and 1992, he never formally entered the races. A picture with the chart was also published in error. The photograph was of William J. Martini, a former congressman from New Jersey, who never sought the presidency; it was not of Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, who did seek the Republican nomination in 1996.

title: Abstruse Sounds Governed by Balance and Contrast
description: The young guitarist Mary Halvorson orients herself around jazz, yet stands about two steps removed from it. With her hollow-body electric guitar, broadcasting its natural tone through an amp at low levels, she seems all set to play standards; no doubt she can and does. But in her own tossing, prickly trio she seems more like a folk musician who has spent months in isolation, building strange chord clusters and then soldering them together.

title: Alcatel-Lucent Posts Loss, but Revenue Climbs 18%
description: PARIS  Alcatel-Lucent, the telecommunications giant, said Friday that its fourth-quarter revenue increased 18 percent over the same period a year ago, at 5.23 billion euros ($7.6 billion), despite earlier warnings of a rough period.

title: Chris Anderson, 81, Influential Jazz Pianist, Is Dead
description: Chris Anderson, a jazz pianist whose sophisticated and personal approach to harmony made him a pronounced influence on many other players, notably Herbie Hancock, died in Manhattan on Monday. He was 81.

title: Conservative Rabbis to Vote on Resolution Criticizing Popes Revision of Prayer
description: The revision of a contentious Good Friday prayer approved this week by Pope Benedict XVI could set back Jewish-Catholic relations, Conservative Judaisms international assembly of rabbis says in a resolution to be voted on next week.

title: Safety Lapse Is Suggested in Fatal Blast at Test Site
description: The employees who were killed in a blast last year at a California spaceship company were watching a propulsion system test though a chain-link fence when the explosion occurred, according to a report from a California workplace-safety agency.

title: Working by Eavesdropping on DNA Doing Its Work
description: To understand Pacific Biosciences approach to sequencing  or reading  genomes, think of the windowed door of a microwave oven.

title: MTV President Is Stepping Down
description: The president of MTV, Christina Norman, is stepping down after almost three years of trying to revitalize the cable channel and adding music and reality-based programming.

title: Bush Presses for G.O.P. Unity; Party Set to Focus on Security
description: WASHINGTON  Offering a preview of the general election campaign, President Bush sought on Friday to unify the Republican Party behind its presumptive nominee and said the contest would present the country with a stark ideological choice at a time of war.

title: Church Collection Basket Goes Online
description: CINCINNATI  For generations of Roman Catholics in the United States, the ritual of attending Mass on Sundays has been intertwined with slipping a numbered envelope into the collection basket.

title: Possible Third Fatal Meningitis Case in State
description: An 8-year-old Long Island boy died this week of what was believed to be a fast-moving form of bacterial meningitis, health officials said on Friday.

title: Obama Defeats Clinton in 3-State Sweep
description: Senator Barack Obama won powerful victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Washington, Louisiana and Nebraska, giving him a Saturday sweep going into a month when the Democratic nominating contests were expected to favor him.

title: France: Le Pen Guilty in Defending Nazis
description: The far-right National Front leader Jean-Marie Le Pen, a perennial presidential candidate, was given a three-month suspended prison sentence for saying that the Nazi occupation of France was not particularly inhuman and that excesses were inevitable. The Paris court ruled that he had denied a crime against humanity and that he was complicit in justifying war crimes, and fined him $14,500. The charges stemmed from comments he made in 2005 in a right-wing weekly.

title: Job Growth Where Bush Didnt Want It
description: IT is not exactly a distinction that he had in mind, but seven years into his presidency, George W. Bush is in line to be the first president since World War II to preside over an economy in which federal government employment rose more rapidly than employment in the private sector.

title: Moving in the Round With the Master of High Silliness
description: One of the dumber things people say about dance is that its a universal language. One of the finer things about watching a Deborah Hay dance is that the experience quickly proves this truism to be hokey claptrap. It is perilous to say that any given Hay piece is about something in particular, but one of her works underpinnings is the impossibility of fully grasping what is happening to and in your body at any given time, let alone to strangers. It doesnt get less universal than this, and thank goodness.

title: Washington Is the Contest du Jour
description: TACOMA, Wash.  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama crisscrossed Washington State on Friday, drawing standing-room-only crowds as they campaigned only miles apart on the eve of Saturdays Democratic caucuses.

title: Suing the Smoker Next Door
description: Offices and restaurants have become no-smoking zones in New York City. But Galila Huff, a chain-smoking restaurateur from the Upper West Side, always thought that when it came to smoking, her apartment was her sanctuary.

title: Few From Obamas Youth Remember His Drug Use
description: Nearly three decades ago, Barack Obama stood out on the small campus of Occidental College in Los Angeles for his eloquence, intellect and activism against apartheid in South Africa. But Mr. Obama, then known as Barry, also joined in the party scene.

title: Big Lead Dissolves, Surprising No One
description: Shaquille ONeal just rumbled back into the Western Conference, and Pau Gasol just relocated to Los Angeles, to take geometry lessons from Kobe Bryant. Clearly, the San Antonio Spurs should have greater concerns now than how to beat the collection of misfits that calls Madison Square Garden home.

title: Mayor Quiet on Bid. Senator Not So Much.
description: There are still outstanding questions about the fast-fading presidential dreams of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. Here are a few answers:

title: Yahoos Directors Discuss How to Face Microsoft Bid
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A week after Yahoo learned that it would be the target of a $44.6 billion hostile bid by Microsoft, the companys board met on Friday to consider its options, a person briefed on the meeting said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Inside Art column in Weekend on Friday, about the February art auctions in London, misidentified the nationality of the artist Rudolf Stingel, whose three paintings offered at a Christies auction went unsold. He was born in Italy and holds Italian citizenship, and recently became an American citizen. He is not German.

title: Lottery Numbers
Wheres the Big Idea?
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Mexico: Huge Weapons and Marijuana Seizure
description: Soldiers searching a house near Miguel Alemn, near the Texas border, on Thursday night discovered a huge cache of arms and nine tons of marijuana. In addition to the mountain of marijuana, they seized 89 assault rifles, a battlefield machine gun, grenades, plastic explosives, military uniforms and more than 80,000 rounds of ammunition. Five men guarding the house were arrested.

title: Last Dance: A Studio Tears Up Its Floors
description: The places where cultural history was made in New York City have largely disappeared, and on Friday another institution was lost. Fazils Times Square Studio closed after 73 years as a ramshackle, homey rehearsal center that served as a mecca for everyone from movie stars to struggling tap, flamenco and Middle Eastern dancers.

title: Sarkozy Vows to Aid Frances Immigrant Suburbs
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy promised Friday to tackle the problems of the nations immigrant suburbs, vowing to send in 4,000 more police officers and aid for neighborhoods that have struggled with despair, violence and riots.

title: A Program in Four Parts, With One a Farewell
description: In leaving the job of resident choreographer of New York City Ballet, Christopher Wheeldon seems to be taking up another as traveling choreographer to the world. Rococo Variations, his City Ballet farewell, had its premiere on Thursday; his next premiere, for the Royal Ballet in London, opens on Feb. 28; his first work for the Royal Danish Ballet opens in Copenhagen on May 8; and a second season of his own company, Morphoses, presumably with further premieres, is to occur on both sides of the Atlantic, from July to October.

title: Wheres Our Disgust?
description: To the Editor:

title: Documents Disclosure Adds to Scandal Over Detroit Mayor
description: DETROIT  During negotiations over lawsuits by three former police officers who said they had been unfairly fired, Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick reached a confidentiality agreement with them in which they agreed never to reveal text messages that suggested he had conducted an extramarital affair with an aide.

title: Phyllis A. Whitney, Author, Dies at 104
description: Phyllis A. Whitney, a prolific best-selling author of romantic mysteries, young-adult novels and childrens mysteries for more than a half-century, died on Friday in Faber, Va. She was 104 and lived in Faber.

title: Under a Scarf, a Turkish Lawyer Fighting to Wear It
description: ISTANBUL

title: Replacing Commercial Bail
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Who Stood Against Hitler
description: To the Editor:

title: German Bank Gets $7.2 Billion Bailout
description: FRANKFURT  WestLB, a state-owned German bank, said Friday that it would reduce its work force by 25 percent and receive 5 billion euros ($7.2 billion) from its owners to cover losses tied to bad trades and the subprime mortgage market.

title: Change the World? Well, Maybe Not
description: Neil Young said on Friday that he had lost all hope that music can change the world, as he presented a documentary about 2006 antiwar concert tour by Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young at the Berlin film festival, Agence France-Presse reported. I know that the time when music could change the world is past, Mr. Young said. I really doubt that a single song can make a difference. It is a reality. Mr. Young made no distinction between the Vietnam War, during which Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young earned a reputation for political activism, and the war in Iraq, which their tour condemned with songs like Lets Impeach the President. It is all the same war, and it hurts everybody, he said. Its a wrong way to solve a problem, he said, adding that Americans were deluded if they thought they were liberating Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Feb. 1 about the concerns of some former N.F.L. players over their pensions despite the prosperity of the modern game misstated the monthly payment for Carl Eller, a retiree who has criticized the system. Based on information from the N.F.L. Player Benefits Office, Mr. Ellers pension is $6,292 a month, not $1,600. (Mr. Ellers pension was originally calculated for the lower amount, but it increased because he did not begin accepting payments until age 62.)

title: An Indomitable Diva Played by, Well, an ...
description: Having the flu in February is the stuff that circles in hell are made of, and I wouldnt wish it on anyone. Still, those who attended the Thursday night opening of the Encores! concert production of Applause, the less-than-classic backstage musical from 1970 based on the classic backstage movie All About Eve (1950), had reason to be grateful that its star, the remarkable Christine Ebersole, was seriously flu-ridden. If she hadnt been, the evening would have forfeited its only excitement.

title: Vocal  Contest Gives McDonalds Employees Something to Sing About
description: DUNMORE, Pa. Might as well call it Corporate Idol.

title: Its Tough for Women, and Heres the Grim Proof
description: Sometimes with nontraditional theater pieces, the most illuminating moment comes at the end, in that eye-blink after action has ceased, and before the cast returns for bows.

title: Man Accused of Killing Dentist Exchanged 91 Calls With Dentists Wife
description: In the weeks before a Queens orthodontist was slain near a playground, his estranged wife exchanged more than 90 phone calls with the man accused of pulling the trigger, the authorities said.

title: Informant in Mob Case Had Power, and a Wire
description: The informant at the center of the sweeping organized crime case unveiled this week was such a powerful force in the New York trucking industry that two Gambino family factions vied to feed off his business, investigators said Friday.

title: Nielsen Tells TV Clients It Is Working on Ending Delays in Ratings
description: With many of its television clients, including the broadcast networks, expressing increasing frustration with delays in reporting ratings for programs, the Nielsen Company sent a letter on Friday to its customers expressing disappointment with its performance and promising to do better  though not for a while.

title: The Music of Tango and Improvisation
description: Through much of his concert at Joes Pub on Wednesday night, the pianist Fernando Otero used his instrument as an engine of rhythm. Repeatedly he pounded syncopations around the pianos lower register; sometimes he created a bristling overlap of arpeggios. When he opted for a gently flowing cadence, his tenderness felt fraught with anticipation, like the quiet before a gathering storm.

title: Sillinger Feels at Home With Islanders
description: After playing for 12 N.H.L. teams since his debut in the league in October 1990, center Mike Sillinger says he hopes he will still be a member of the Islanders when the leagues trade deadline passes at 3 p.m. Feb. 26.

title: Tolls Plan Is Dead Unless Revised, Corzine Is Notified by Opponents
description: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzines plan to sharply raise tolls is all but dead, according to influential Democrats and every Republican state legislator, who have warned that he has to modify his plan substantially if he expects to win their support.

title: Canada Talks of Extending Afghan Role, With a Catch
description: OTTAWA  The Conservative government introduced a motion in Parliament on Friday to extend Canadas combat mission in Afghanistan, contingent on other NATO countries sending 1,000 more troops to southern Afghanistan.

title: The Revenge of Seamus
description: Oh, Mitt, Mitt, Mitt.

title: A Plastic Bag Tax?
description: To the Editor:

title: Electrocution Is Banned in Last State to Rely on It
description: The electric chair is cruel and unusual punishment, the Nebraska Supreme Court ruled Friday. The decision effectively suspended executions there, as Nebraska is the only state that still relies solely on electrocution, which was once the dominant form of execution in the United States.

title: Turkeys Parliament Votes to Lift Head Scarf Ban
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys parliament took a major step toward lifting a ban against womens head scarves in universities on Saturday, setting the stage for a final showdown with the countrys secular elite over where Islam fits in the building of an open society.

title: Sending an S O S for a PC Exorcist
description: AT high noon on a recent Monday, I leaped up from my desk vowing to commit the most sensational attack of revenge in the history of the personal computer industry. Just 72 hours earlier, I had taken delivery on a Dell Inspiron 1720 laptop loaded with Microsoft Windows Vista. It was already on the blink. I couldnt open a Word document. I couldnt run a Google search. I couldnt even send e-mail. I vowed to shave Michael Dell and Bill Gates with a broken beer bottle.

title: CW Pins Smackdown
description: The CW network will stop broadcasting the long-running World Wrestling Entertainment show Friday Night Smackdown at the end of this broadcast season, the two companies said. Neither company gave any reasons for ending the partnership, though WWE said it was in negotiations to find a new home for the show. Smackdown, which had its premiere on UPN in 1999, moved to CW in 2006 when UPN merged with WB. The show has averaged 4.9 million viewers this season, second to Americas Next Top Model, CWs most popular program. But among the 18-to-34 viewer group, the show is only seventh. Last month WWE extended its contract with the USA channel for another show, Raw, through 2010.

title: U.N. Officials Tell of Impasse in Darfur Peacekeeping Task
description: UNITED NATIONS  Two senior United Nations officials on Friday gave the Security Council a grim account of the situation complicating international efforts to protect civilians in Darfur, the Sudanese region where 200,000 have died and 2.5 million have been chased from their homes.

title: Radomski Sentenced to Probation in Steroid Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Kirk Radomski, the former Mets clubhouse attendant and drug distributor, was sentenced on Friday to five years of probation in connection with his guilty plea to steroid distribution and money laundering. Radomski was also ordered to pay a fine of $18,575.

title: Kerrys Policy Proposals
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching for Title, Suns Take a Chance
description: It wasnt Jerry Colangelos money, any more than it was his call.

title: Playing the Female Lead in a Strange Love Story
description: Romeo and Juliet. Tristan and Isolde. Bernard and Doris. Which of these couples is not like the others?

title: L.S.U.'s Holliday Remains Elusive After Bowls
description: At 5 feet 6 inches and 160 pounds, Trindon Holliday does not look like a frightening football player. But as a speedy kickoff returner, slot receiver, end-around threat and even inside runner, averaging 6.9 yards a carry last season for Louisiana States national champions, he has frightened opponents.

title: An Inside Look at Violence in Camden
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  With cocaine for the citys addicts and bullets for his rivals, a young drug lord named Raymond Morales rose to power here in the 1990s, terrorizing the city as he wrung it for profit.

title: The Case of the Poisoned Pet Food
description: The Bush administration has moved with welcome vigor to prosecute two Chinese companies and an American importer involved in the sale of contaminated pet food ingredients that killed or sickened thousands of dogs and cats. After last years flood of tainted imports, American regulators have been struggling with limited success to strengthen their inspection capabilities. Those efforts must be buttressed with criminal prosecutions of anyone who knowingly sold harmful or untested products.

title: Music in Review
description: NEW YORK COLLEGIUM

title: Overseas Funds Resist Calls for a Code of Conduct
Resettling Iraqi Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Concedes Race, Sort Of
description: In a message to supporters sent just before 11 p.m. Friday night, Representative Ron Paul, a long-shot G.O.P. candidate from Texas, basically conceded that hes not going to win the partys nomination.

title: Behind 'The Masque'
description: A look at an interactive production of "Masque of the Red Death" in London.

title: Great Race 2008: Window to the Future?
description: This week we celebrate the centennial of the 22,000-mile New York to Paris race of 1908. It was a test of man, machine and where to find gasoline. It was tough enough to locate a gas station in the rural United States back then; imagine how much more difficult it was in Japan  where they had never seen an automobile  or the uninhabited expanses of Siberia.

title: Holding On to Hope
description: Do you have a comment about this article or have a similar story to share? We invite you to post your thoughts. Read the Article

title: Respond to Todays Column: The Revenge of Seamus
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Feb. 9 column.

title: 2008 Grammy Award Winners and Nominees
description: A selected look at the winners and nominees for the 50th annual Grammy Awards.  denotes the winning nominee in each category.

title: One for the Bucket Postscript
description: One of our readers, Michael OGrady, had written about his and his daughters bolt-out-of-the-blue decision to attend the N.F.C. title game at Lambeau Field. This week, he sent in a postcript: (The original story is below)

title: Whom Will Independents Choose?
description: A Time magazine poll shows Senator Barack Obama doing better than Senator Hillary Clinton in a hypothetical match-up against Senator John McCain.

title: Huckabee Wont Quit Race
description: Updated Speculation about why former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee remains in the race for the Republican presidential nomination, though his chances are slim, has settled recently on the notion that he wants to be Arizona Senator John McCains vice presidential running mate.

title: Wholl Get Brian Campbell, All-Star Defenceman and TV Pitchman?
description: Buffalos All-Star defenceman, Brian Campbell, seems headed elsewhere by the Feb. 26 trade deadline or, failing that, for free agency after the season ends. If so, he will be yet another in a long line of top players  Daniel Brire, Chris Drury, J.P. Dumont, Jay McKee, et al  the Sabres have let get away.

title: Jozy Altidore: An Unbelievable Experience
description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore, who contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog, is back with the club after making his first start for the United States senior national team, against Mexico last Wednesday, when he also scored his first international goal. New York is currently in preseason training in California..

title: The Insider Host Seeks Alcoholism Treatment
description: Pat OBrien, a host of the entertainment newsmagazine The Insider, has entered a rehabilitation center for treatment of alcohol abuse, his shows syndicator, CBS Television Distribution, announced on Friday.

title: MTV President Steps Down
description: The president of MTV, Christina Norman, is stepping down after almost three years of trying to revitalize the cable channel and adding music and reality-based programming.

title: The Early Word: Long Slog Contests Start Today
description: In the first round of contests since the Feb. 5 wave, voters in Louisiana and Washington, as well as Republicans in Kansas and Democrats in Nebraska and the Virgin Islands, will be choosing a nominee today. Maine Democrats caucus Sunday.

title: Does Egypts Success Lead to Failure?
description: ACCRA, Ghana  After the Black Stars of Ghana lost to Cameroon, 1-0, in the semifinals of the Africa Cup of Nations on Thursday, and everyones second-favorite team, the Ivory Coast, were thrashed by Egypt in the other semifinal, most of the locals lost interest in the whole thing.

title: The Grand Prix: What Happened to Asia and the Americas?
description: For those who do not get dizzy on roller coasters, here is another trip down the rabbit hole that is the world championship process as we now know it.

title: Big 5 crises
description: Barry Ritholtz does what I should have done, except that I was too busy: post a link to and charts from the truly scary Reinhart-Rogoff paper on parallels between the United States and earlier crisis countries.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: In Vino Veritas
description: Why are videos of drunken people so compelling?

title: Writers Guild Members Meet Today
description: East Coast members of the Writers Guild of America will meet in New York at 2 p.m. Saturday to discuss the tentative contract language released early Saturday morning. West Coast guild members will meet at 7 p.m. in Los Angeles.

title: Writers Say They Have Tentative Deal; Guild Leaders Call Strike A Success
description: The union representing Hollywoods striking writers said it reached a tentative deal with studios and will meet members later on Saturday to discuss ending a three-month walkout that has crippled television production and overshadowed the awards season, Reuters reports.

title: In New Contract, Writers Guild Would Cover Made-For-New-Media Programs
description: The tentative agreement between the writers guild and the Hollywood studios also attempts to define how made-for-new-media programming would be handled. The guild would be identified as the exclusive bargaining representative for Internet and mobile phone programming.

title: Contract Language Describes Fees For New Media Re-Use
description: The fees for re-use of scripted programming on new media platforms were widely believed to be a key sticking point between the Writers Guild of America and the Hollywood studios during the three-month-old strike. The tentative contract language released by the guild includes several compromises between the two sides.

title: George the unlucky (and poor Ben, too)
description: You know, if it wasnt for the bit about lying us into war, lying about just about everything else, fearmongering for political gain, making America synonymous with torture, busting the budget to cut taxes for the rich, and so on, Id almost feel sorry for George W. Bush.

title: Recession Would Work in Democrats Favor
description: In his Web column today, Tom Redburn writes that even if the economy skirts a formal recession and only undergoes a more modest slowdown before rebounding later this year, voters are likely to blame the weak economy mostly on the Republicans, who are all but certain to be led in November by Senator John McCain. It doesnt make much difference that President Bush will not be on the ballot. Go to column

title: Product Integration, Recap Clips Also Included In Contract Language
description: The tentative contract language between the Writers Guild of America and Hollywood studios also includes several provisions that are new in this round of contract talks, reflecting a changing media landscape.

title: Huckabee Brings His Stand-Up Act to Maryland
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Higher education is important, Mike Huckabee told a crowd of predominantly college students. It doesnt matter if you graduate summa cum laude, magna cum laude, cum laude or just thank you, laude.

title: Huckabee Takes Kansas
description: Mike Huckabee is the winner of the first state to report results today: Kansas.

title: Strike News: Optimism and Questions Inside the New York Writers Meeting
description: The mood was upbeat as the meeting began, according to writer who attended but spoke on condition of anonymity to avoid conflict with guild leaders. But several questioners said they didnt fully understand the contract terms, and some asked why they were being asked to lift the strike so quickly. One questioner said: I feel like were being forced to quickly ratify something when we dont fully understand it.

title: Clinton Blasts NBC Over Chelsea Comment
description: Senator Hillary Clinton sent a blistering letter today to the head of NBC, which suspended one of its reporters Friday for comments he made about Chelsea Clinton.

title: New York Fashion Week
description: Two designers illustrate the difference between what is commercial and high concept in contemporary fashion.

title: Ask Charles E. Thorpe a Question
description: Charles E. Thorpe, the dean of Carnegie Mellon in Qatar, is fielding questions on overseas branch campuses of American universities.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Feb. 10
description: You can tell that Feb. 5 is behind us by the lack of presidential candidates on Sundays talk shows. Mike Huckabee is the only one making the rounds tomorrow, with appearances on NBCs Meet the Press and CBSs Face the Nation.

title: New York Fashion Week
description: Two designers illustrate the difference between what is commercial and high concept in contemporary fashion.

title: Bradley (the Junior) Does It Again
description: Michael Bradley is an American on fire.

title: Clinton, Obama Court Maine Voters
description: BANGOR, Me.  Both Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama campaigned in Maine today in advance of the states Democratic caucuses on Sunday.

title: Wellington Mara Is Smiling
description: Would anyone have enjoyed the Super Bowl more than Wellington Mara?

title: Strike No Joke, but Web Got Last Laugh
description: So the three-month writers strike is tentatively settled. Over its duration, as Dave Itzkoff writes in Sunday Arts, the walkout both hobbled traditional entertainment and injected Web-based comedy videos with new vitality. Take Liz Cackowski, who wrote for Saturday Night Live and now stars in The Jeannie Tate Show online. She plays a soccer mom with a talk show from her minivan

title: Hyde Park on Horseback
description: Like New York, London is a bustling metropolis with a surprisingly large green area right in the middle, thanks to the adjoining St. Jamess Park, Green Park, Kensington Gardens and Hyde Park.

title: In the Desert, Theyre Talking Playoffs
description: Slap Shots Lew Serviss reports from Arizona that Wayne Gretzkys rebuild of the Coyotes is showing immediate results. Going into a game with Nashville on Sunday, Phoenix is just a howl from a playoff spot in the Western Conference.

title: Not a Fan Favorite
description: The Indiana freshman Eric Gordon must have known he was going to face an icy reception when the Hoosiers traveled to play Illinois on Thursday night.

title: Your Comments on my Women Leaders Column
description: My Sunday column focuses on the challenges that women leaders face in a democracy. There is the basic difficulty (as demonstrated in psychology experiments) that women, though not men, face a trade-off between competence and likability. If shes perceived as competent, then shes also perceived as unpleasant. Likewise, self-promotion by men leaves people with the perception that hes a smart guy; self-promotion by women leaves people thinking that shes full of herself.

title: Obama Wins Nebraska
description: The Times is officially calling Nebraska for Senator Barack Obama. As of this posting, he received 69 percent of the vote in the states Democratic caucuses, with 73 percent of precincts reporting.

title: Obama Wins Washington
description: Senator Barack Obamas second win of the evening is the days biggest prize: the Washington caucuses. The Times is calling for the Illinois Democrat with percent of 42 precincts reporting; he has so far received 67 percent of the vote.

title: Fassel Passed Over Again
description: In something of a surprise (but consider the owner), the Redskins have hired Jim Zorn as their coach.

title: Writers Guild Awards
description: The Writers Guild of America East left the screenplay awards for the end of the program Saturday night, at a stripped-down event at the Hudson Theater hosted by Seth Meyers of Saturday Night Live. The awards went to the favorites in both categories.

title: FIDE Unveils New Titles to Mixed Reactions
description: Last week, the World Chess Federation (also known by the acronym FIDE, which stands for Fdration Internationale des Echecs) began collecting fees for its newest titles: FIDE trainers. What are FIDE trainers? They are essentially people certified by the federation to teach and train chess players.

title: Four-Wheeled Fashion,  la Franaise
description: PARIS  From February 7  10, the Festival Automobile International is exhibiting 18 recent concept cars at the historic Htel des Invalides here in my new hometown.

title: Obama Takes Louisiana Primary
description: The Times projects that Senator Barack Obama will win the Louisiana Democratic primary, the only true primary of the day (the other contests are caucuses). As of this posting, with 40 percent of precincts were reporting, Mr. Obama had 53 percent of the vote.

title: At Writers Meeting, Cautious Optimism
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Hard at Work, the Model Whisperer
description: DURING Fashion Week, any given table at any trendy restaurant might yield characters worthy of a novel about the ephemeral value of youth and beauty. It would be airplane reading, quickly adapted for cable television. Ill Never Be Alone, it might be called.

title: Donna Karan Speaks Softly, and Not as Precisely as Some
description: At the New York fall collections last week, it was surprising how many designers showed heavy woolens or double-faced cashmere, and a number of fashionistas asked, Arent we supposed to be having global warming?  as if wearing a boiled wool coat were worse than ozone depletion.

title: Israelis Urge Tougher Action in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli cabinet ministers on Sunday urged sharper military action in Gaza after a rocket attack by Palestinian militants the night before seriously wounded two brothers, ages 8 and 19, in the Israeli border town of Sderot.

title: Missionaries Spread the News, but Dont Read It
description: For most Mormons, the last few weeks have been a time of shocks. Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, as the faith is formally known, died Jan. 27 at the age of 97.

title: When Audiences Get In on the Act
description: I RECENTLY made my New York acting debut, but I doubt you heard about it. It took place at a coffee shop in the East Village in a production called Etiquette. Presented as part of the Under the Radar festival, Etiquette required patrons to perform the play themselves, two at a time. Dialogue and stage directions were fed through headphones.

title: The War He Knew
description: Covering a war is not a calling for every journalist, but many do it, some at the cost of their lives. In the Iraq war alone, 126 journalists  two American, but most of them Iraqis supporting international media  have died. Mourning their loss does not diminish the deaths of tens of thousands of other Iraqi civilians, nor the loss of nearly 4,000 Americans in the military. When a journalist dies in a war zone, the rest of the world risks becoming a bit more removed from the horror.

title: Upstate, Drop in Catholics Leads to Drop in Churches
description: JAMESVILLE, N.Y.  Armed sheriffs deputies removed the last man from the Catholic church here 10 days ago, pasting No Trespassing signs on the doors as they left and surrounding the perimeter of the grounds with crime-scene tape reading: Do Not Cross.

title: Superdelegates, Back Off
description: Washington

title: Politics Makes Good Home Buyers
description: IN the hurly-burly leading up to Tuesdays primaries, one political consultant had his nose buried deep in paperwork  not results from the polls in New York, but an escrow statement on the closing of a sprawling West End Avenue apartment.

title: Paul Newman to Direct Of Mice and Men
description: PAUL NEWMAN is returning to the Westport Country Playhouse, this time as a director.

title: The Professional
description: One afternoon in late November, Defense Secretary Robert Gates was flying back to Washington from the Army base at Fort Hood, Tex., where he had spoken with soldiers and spouses about the future of Iraq. Sitting across from him at his desk in the back of the Pentagons jet, I asked him about the possibility of another military conflict: U.S. air strikes on Iran. The last thing the Middle East needs now is another war, he said quietly. We have to keep all options on the table, he went on, reciting the standard caveat. But if Iraq has shown us anything, its the unpredictability of war. Once a conflict starts, the statesmen lose control.

title: Gelato With a Common Touch
description: There are those who might say that discovering gelato at a strip mall is like discovering Beethoven through a ring tone. Then there is Jimmy Tai, proprietor of Ice Milan, a pristine gelateria in Whippany.

title: Baseballs Devil May Not Be in the Details
description: WHEN the House Oversight Committee convened recently to discuss baseball and steroids  another hearing is scheduled for Wednesday  Representative Mark Souder, an Indiana Republican, injected a specific proposal.

title: Its Party Time in the Galleries
description: IN the movies, being in a museum after dark is not such a great idea: youre likely to be killed by an albino monk, say, or attacked by miniature cowboys.

title: Writers Reach Tentative Deal With Producers
description: LOS ANGELES  An end to Hollywoods long and bitter writers strike appeared close on Saturday, as union leaders representing 12,000 movie and television writers said they had reached a tentative three-year deal with production companies.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: Describing the Elephant
description: As George W. Bush enters his final year as president, the struggle to succeed him has revealed deep disagreements about the definition of post-Bush conservatism. Two new books by former members of the Bush administration contribute to this debate.

title: This Year, Commodities Are on a Rockier Road
description: STOKED by rising demand, a falling dollar and rosy economic predictions, commodities like oil, corn and precious metals soared in price over the last few years.

title: Great Race, 2008 Edition
description: TO commemorate the 1908 New York to Paris race, a group of adventurers will leave New York City on May 30, heading west toward a planned arrival in Paris on Aug. 2.

title: Love Among the Lamb Chops
description: I FINGERED the yellowed Post-it tabs that have come loose with time and that Ive secured with double-sided Scotch tape. Each tab has a year written on it, starting with 1980 and continuing until 2000, marking the intricate recipes that my husband, Irv, used to prepare for our Valentines Day dinners.

title: Love Me, Love My Apartment
description: REAL ESTATE in New York City has a way of looming large in matters of the heart.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: When Self-Interest Isnt Everything
description: TRADITIONAL economic models assume that people are self-interested in the narrow sense. If homo economicus  the stereotypical rational actor in these models  finds a wallet on the sidewalk, he keeps the cash inside. He doesnt leave tips after dining in restaurants that he will never visit again. And he would never vote in a presidential election, much less make an anonymous donation of money or time to a presidential campaign.

title: Letters: Old-School Economics
description: Thank you for Christopher Caldwells article (Jan. 27) and the fascinating statistics that accompany it. Who knew that in America today more people make their living by shuffling and dealing cards in casinos than by operating lathes? Who knew that there are almost three times as many security guards as machinists?

title: Jennifer Garzia, Michael Schidlow
description: Dr. Jennifer Marie Garzia and Michael Samuel Schidlow were married on Friday at the Miami Beach District Court. Harvey Ruvin, the clerk for Miami-Dade Circuit and County Courts, officiated.

title: Union Boards Back Deal to End Writers Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  An end to Hollywoods long and bitter writers strike appears all but assured, as the governing boards of the unions representing 12,000 movie and television writers on Sunday unanimously approved a tentative three-year deal with production companies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Recruit Has Wrong Focus

title: Lending Library? More Like a Giving Library
description: Rowayton

title: Views Clash Over Old Buildings in Yonkers
description: YONKERS

title: Clotheshorse Confidential
The Beautiful Duckling Gets the Presidents and the Poets
description: WE can be certain that when Dorothy Parker wrote, Men seldom make passes at girls who wear glasses, she didnt have in mind women like Carla Bruni, cruising the Pyramids in her Dolce & Gabbana sunglasses on the arm of her beau, who moonlights as the president of France.

title: Correction: The Party Animal Either Plays Well or Fights Well
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions last Sunday about orthodoxy and consensus in presidential politics misidentified the Republican politician who The Hill newspaper said once considered changing parties. The report concerned John McCain, not Mitt Romney.

title: Marc Jacobs Play It Safe? Come On, Now
description: How cute. Marc Jacobs, wearing his Sunday best and still with blue hair, came out onto a concert stage in the 26th Street Armory not 10 minutes after his show was scheduled to start, waving his arms and calling out babyishly to the arriving guests, who included fashion plates like Victoria Beckham and Kevin Federline.

title: Hepburn and Tracy 2.0
description: To the Editor:

title: Disputes Swirl Over Hiring Site Case
description: Southampton Village

title: Mets Lore Lands in New Jersey Basement
description: Charlie Sobel received a rather unusual bar mitzvah gift in 1971.

title: Out of Whiz-Kid Caldron, Intel Finalist
description: East Setauket

title: Lovers Lost
description: Since Valentines Day is on Thursday and you just edited an anthology of lovelorn essays by 32 guys  Things Ive Learned From Women Whove Dumped Me  I thought it might be interesting to ask you about the current state of romance in America. O.K., well theres your first mistake.

title: In Alaska, Emergency Help May Be Slow to Arrive
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP)  Across the remote, frozen reaches of Alaska, scores of native villages have no full-fledged police officers at all. And help in an emergency can be a long way off.

title: Neck and Neck, Democrats Woo Superdelegates
description: WASHINGTON  Seeing a good possibility that the Democratic presidential nomination will not be settled in the primaries and caucuses, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama are lavishing attention on a group that might hold the balance of power: elected officials and party leaders who could decide the outcome at the convention in August.

title: Prosecutor to Review Official Handling of C.I.A. Tapes
description: The prosecutor investigating the Central Intelligence Agencys destruction of interrogation videotapes is reviewing whether government officials violated any of 17 court orders requiring the preservation of evidence or broke the law by concealing the tapes existence or approving their destruction, according to court papers filed late Friday night.

title: In Communities Losing Hospitals, Rising Voices
description: NEWARK

title: Robin Weiswasser and Andrew Markus
description: Robin Joy Weiswasser and Andrew Samuel Markus were married last evening at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan. Rabbi Chava Koster officiated.

title: Enthusiasm Cools for Hockeys Foray Into the South
description: Almost 20 years ago, the N.H.L. embarked on a master plan to expand into the Sun Belt. The idea was to add teams in nontraditional hockey markets and, in the jargon of the day, increase the N.H.L.s television footprint and make it popular across the United States.

title: Brazil Is Site of New Resort by Beckham
description: David Beckham has recently expanded his soccer empire to include Brazil. Cabo So Roque, a new luxury resort to be located 20 miles north of Natal, the capital of Rio Grande do Norte, will feature David Beckham World of Sport, a professional training center with eight soccer fields  six grass and two AstroTurf  accommodations for both individuals and entire teams, and a multipurpose stadium that will seat up to 10,000 people (Brazil will be host of the World Cup in 2014).

title: Sidelined by the Strike, Comedy Goes Online
description: HISTORY will judge whether Jerry OConnell will be best remembered as the cornfed football prospect in Jerry Maguire, the awkward chubby kid in Stand by Me, or as the husband of Rebecca Romijn. But for a few glorious days last month, Mr. OConnell, 33, was seared into the minds of thousands of Internet surfers as a cocky, cackling replica of Tom Cruise, in a parody of a Scientology recruitment video.

title: Pyro Wins Louisiana Prep
description: Pyro showed he is one of the top 3-year-old colts with a powerful victory in the Grade III $300,000 Risen Star Stakes at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans, the final prep for the Louisiana Derby. Pyro, who has been working out in the mornings with the horse of the year, Curlin, for the trainer Steve Asmussen, is a top Kentucky Derby contender. Last at the top of the stretch, Pyro angled out for running room under Shaun Bridgemohan and came roaring down the center of the track in the final furlong to win by two lengths over his stablemate Z Fortune.

title: Parents Feel Betrayed by Millionaire Role Models
description: They will attend the Congressional hearings Wednesday, the husband and wife with the sad eyes. They have become part of the steroid circuit, honored with reserved seats near the front, silent witnesses to the plague of the last generation.

title: Correction:  Instant Nostalgia? Lets Go to the Videotape
description: An article on Jan. 27 about the depiction of videotape on film misidentified the type of cassette that bore deranging nightmares in the movie Videodrome. It was a Betamax tape, not a VHS tape.

title: Editors Choice
description: BEAUTIFUL CHILDREN, by Charles Bock. (Random House, $25.) This bravura first novel, set against a corruptly compelling Las Vegas landscape, revolves around the disappearance of a surly 12-year-old boy.

title: Miller Fails to Finish
description: Reinfried Herbst of Austria put together the fastest times in each run to win a World Cup slalom in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany. The overall leader, Bode Miller, failed to finish.Herbst had a combined time of 1:42, and Manfred Moelgg of Italy followed in 1:42.65. Miller straddled a gate halfway down the slope and did not finish the first run. His closest challenger, Benjamin Raich of Austria, finished 11th to gain ground in the overall standings.Although Herbst led by nearly a half-second after the first run, he did not hold back in the second heat in earning his second World Cup victory.

title: Airfare Web Site Goes International
description: With the continued weakness of the dollar abroad, budget travelers are pinching pennies now more than ever. Farecast.com recently announced that it would help travelers find the best deals on international flights.

title: The Candidate
description: I want the citizenry to elect Hillary Clinton as president of the United States next November  if only so that we might all get a respite from seeing her offhand, controversial 1992 comment that she could have stayed home and baked cookies and had teas (rather than pursuing an outside profession) parsed and squeezed and hung out to dry again and again like the moldy old dishrag that it is. Dull economic policy briefs? Droning States of the Union with senators clapping cheerlessly in the aisles? Forced marches down the stairs of Air Force One, striding in the hot sun across the Rose Garden to the familiar strains of Hail to the Chief? Bring em on, baby  bring em on.

title: Spotlight on Cuba
description: Back in 1992, when I visited Cuba to attend the Havana Biennale, I knew it was only a matter of time before the world took notice of the countrys artists. The following year New Yorks Museum of Modern Art staged Latin American Artists of the 20th Century, a landmark event for the exposure of Cuban artists. Among them was Jos Bedia, who is also in the compelling show Cuba: Artists Experience Their Country, now at the Hunterdon Museum of Art.

title: The Tightrope of Promising a Genuine Transformation
description: NEWARK

title: Bette Keltner and Joseph Jacobs
description: THROUGH his work, Dr. Joseph Jacobs had spent decades trying to recapture his Indian heritage. He had worked at clinics on reservations and been an administrator at the federal Indian Health Service.

title: Gleaning the Tax Burden When You Own the Shop
description: YOURE thinking of starting your own business. Maybe youve lost your job, maybe youve just lost interest in it and have decided to move on, or maybe youre just moonlighting.

title: For Her Art: Fonts, Musings and a Bit of Daring
description: Ronkonkoma

title: A 9-Year-Old Who Wont Stop Singing? Send Him to the Met
description: Scarsdale

title: Making Sense of the Great Suicide Debate
description: AN expression of true love or raw hatred, of purest faith or mortal sin, of courageous loyalty or selfish cowardice: The act of suicide has meant many things to many people through history, from the fifth-century Christian martyrs to the Samurais hara-kiri to more recent literary divas, Hemingway, Plath, Sexton.

title: Jannett De Agustini, Jonathan Rudnick
description: Jannett De Agustini and Dr. Jonathan Adam Rudnick were married Monday aboard the Enchantment of the Seas, a Royal Caribbean cruise ship that was docked at Port Everglades in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Christine J. Field, a Florida notary public, officiated.

title: Kurds and the New Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: After Evacuation, Artists Begin an Effort to Save Their Haven
description: The tale of the warehouse-turned-loft building by the banks of the East River in Brooklyn seemed a familiar one, at first.

title: Fearlessly Foul, and on the Verge of Respectability
description: ON a recent trip to the Canyon Ranch spa in Tucson the comedian Lisa Lampanelli was asked by a companion if she had ever won an award. Dude, they dont give awards to me, she replied, suggesting that her routines were laden with too many ribald jokes, four-letter words and sexually explicit stories to qualify.

title: Preserving Profits in a Falling Market
description: IT is still early, but the way things are going, its quite possible that 2008 will turn out to be just the 15th year of declining stock prices since 1945, as gauged by the Standard & Poors 500-stock index.

title: Wales and France Victorious in Six Nations Championship
description: PARIS  The teams taking part in the Six Nations rugby championship start each season dreaming of more than simply winning the tournament. They dream of perfection and it is a dream that quickly evaporates for most of them.

title: Girls Will Be Girls
description: Hillary Clinton isnt the only woman struggling to find an ideal mix of feminism and femininity, one that allows a woman to behave both like and unlike a man without being penalized either way. Mothers of daughters, even if they dont support the former first lady, feel, if not her pain, at least her conflict. You need only look at the staggering success, in a publishing industry gone soft, of two advice manuals for young women, The Daring Book for Girls and The Girls Book: How to Be the Best at Everything.

title: Yonkers Mayor Wants Action on Rebuilding
description: WITH the first phase of a $3.1 billion proposal for rebuilding Yonkerss downtown languishing before the City Council, and critics in recent months challenging another plan for high-density housing along a blighted strip of riverfront, Mayor Philip A. Amicone is growing increasingly impatient  and worried.

title: Hey, Massachusetts, New Jersey Is Passing on the Left
description: NEW JERSEYS political hue is not just blue these days. Its cobalt.

title: Venerable Poets Words to a Pop Music Beat
description: WOODBRIDGE

title: Love Me, Love My Apartment
description: REAL ESTATE in New York City has a way of looming large in matters of the heart.

title: Underground Man
description: History may be written by the winners  the winners of tenure anyway  but the best fiction tends to be composed by and about losers. Consider: A gloomy retired seaman imagines a shipwrecked sailor bobbing about the Pacific in a coffin. Or a tubercular insurance agent, spooked by marriage, scared of his father, dreams up a man-turned-bug. What hagiographies can compare with such portraits of loss by such intimates of failure? As the Buddhists like to point out, life is suffering, and it is to fellow sufferers that readers in their innermost selves relate. Add to this the contemporary novelists lot as cultural wallflower, lacking even the evanescent glamour of an also-ran on American Idol, and it is easy to see why a fiction writers sympathies are likely to affix themselves to outliers, losers and superfluous men.

title: Hawaiian Pleasures
description: To the Editor: The article "Hawaii on a Dime" (Jan. 27), on how to enjoy the islands of Hawaii and Kauai cheaply, missed a few important points in regard the north shore of Kauai. We have been visitors to Kauai for the past 30-plus years, always staying in the stretch of paradise between Hanalei and Kee Beach, at the end of the road. Im surprised there was no mention of Kilauea Point National Wildlife Refuge with boobies, shearwaters and other birds, plus spectacular coastal views.

title: The Bible as Graphic Novel, With a Samurai Stranger Called Christ
description: Ajinbayo Akinsiku wants the world to know Jesus Christ, just not the gentle, blue-eyed Christ of old Hollywood movies and illustrated Bibles.

title: Older Apartments Often Lack Fire Sprinklers
description: HOBOKEN

title: Letters: Questions for Sheryl Crow
description: Im sure Sheryl Crows song Gasoline is highly topical, and it certainly touches on an unusual subject for pop music, but she and Deborah Solomon (Jan. 27) are mistaken in their assumption that it is the first song to deal with the issue of high fuel costs. In 1979, the Kinks humorously addressed high gas prices and the oil shortage in their song A Gallon of Gas. Sample lyrics: Ive been waiting for years to buy a brand new Cadillac/But now that Ive got one I want to send it right back/I cant afford the gas to fill my luxury limousine/But even if I had the dough no ones got no gasoline.

title: Obama Wins Maine, Giving Him 4 Victories in Weekend
description: Senator Barack Obama defeated Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Maine caucuses on Sunday, giving him his fourth victory this weekend as he headed into three more state contests on Tuesday.

title: Correction: Dining Thats Not Set to Strauss Waltzes
description: The Choice Tables column on Jan. 27, about casual restaurants in Vienna, and a picture caption misspelled part of the name of a cafe in the citys Stadtpark. It is Steirereck Meierei, not Meirerei.

title: Ghana Finishes Third
description: Ghana claimed third place at the African Cup of Nations in Kumasi, Ghana, rallying past Ivory Coast, 4-2, with two late goals Saturday. Cameroon will play Egypt in the African Cup final Sunday. Cameroon failed to qualify for the 2006 World Cup when it was held to a 1-1 tie at home by Egypt in its final qualifier.

title: New York to Paris the Hard Way
description: THE telephone call that would change George Schusters life and, perhaps, the course of the automobile industry didnt give him much time to prepare. He had barely 12 hours to catch an overnight train from New England so he would be in New York City the next morning, Feb. 12, 1908, for the start of the longest auto race in history: around the world, from New York to Paris.

title: Racings Sharp Elbows Informed Potential Olympian
description: For many people who did not follow track and field closely, there was a puzzling question about the American team at last years world outdoor championship in Osaka, Japan.

title: Hemingway, Your Letter Has Arrived
description: THOUGH no one talks about them much, Ernest Hemingway wrote two plays. The first, finished in 1926, was Today Is Friday, a forgettable one-acter set on the evening of the original Good Friday, when three Roman centurions get together at a tavern to discuss memorable crucifixions theyve seen, including the one that afternoon. Not surprisingly, they sound a lot like Hemingways Nick Adams. He looked pretty good to me in there today, one of them says admiring Jesus stoicism.

title: Corrections: Evening Hours
description: A picture caption last Sunday in the Evening Hours column reversed the identities of two guests at a dinner on Jan. 26 after the Fort Worth Symphony Orchestras debut at Carnegie Hall. The cellist Alban Gerhardt was second from right; the violinist Augustin Hadelich was at the far right.

title: Knowing Marital Bliss When You Get to It
description: ON the Valentines Day when Shirley got engaged, Lois called Myrna, Myrna called Sharon and Sharon called me. There was shrieking from house to house, and spirited conjecture about the size and shape of the engagement ring.

title: In the Land of Fischer, Dismay and Awe
description: ON Saturdays, a dozen habitus of the Brooklyn Chess Club sit under fluorescent lights in a synagogue in Canarsie, moving plastic pawns and bishops across rubbery chess mats.

title: An Ice Hockey Rivalry Runs Deep
description: Bridgeport

title: Mindy Jaffe, Per Chilstrom
description: Mindy Leigh Jaffe, a daughter of Bonnie Sue Jaffe of South Orange, N.J., and the late Joel Jaffe, was married last evening to Per Benjamin Chilstrom, the son of Buena Hamlin Chilstrom and Robert Meade Chilstrom of Maplewood, N.J. Rabbi Daniel M. Cohen officiated at Cipriani 23rd Street, an event space in New York.

title: Cybercourting
description: O.K., I told my best friend, theres this guy online I think I have to go out with. It wasnt said with the enthusiasm of one who finds love at first sight over the Internet. It was with a sigh, more than a modicum of dread and the appropriate amount of resignation that I admitted this to her, my happily married friend who found it all too easy to urge me to get out there and date.

title: Which Worksheet Is for the Away Games?
description: DEREK JETER, the Yankee shortstop, has resolved his problems with New York State tax collectors, state officials said last week. Details of the settlement are not known, but the dispute revolved around a tax issue that is central for athletes and other itinerant workers: the official location of their permanent residence.

title: Home, Semisweet Home
description: AT times over the years, the name Pleasant East apartments, on four buildings on 117th and 119th Streets in East Harlem, has seemed like a cruel joke. There were years of rot and neglect under a previous owner, and a move by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which had seized the properties in 2000, to tear them down.

title: Tangy White for Shellfish
description: In Italy, rustic grillo often accompanies shellfish and grilled sardines. Grillo, a minor white grape, is familiar to fans of Marsala, a sherrylike Sicilian wine that has lost favor over the years.

title: Correction: A Campus Serves as a Needed Oasis in a Crowded City
description: The Heads Up column on Jan. 27, about the Ciudad Universitaria in Mexico City, with its sites of interest for tourists, misspelled part of the name of the university with which it is affiliated. It is the Universidad Nacional Autnoma (not Autnomo) de Mxico. The article also misspelled the name of one of the artists whose sculptures can be seen on the grounds. He is Mathias Goeritz, not Matas Goertiz.

title: A Brunch Standard That Can Stay Up Late
description: SOME years ago, in New Orleans, I witnessed the following: Man walked into a bar. Middle-aged guy, wearing pleated khakis and a plaid shirt; had the look of a Midwestern conventioneer. Lets call him Bob.

title: Gulp! Burger King Is on the Rebound
description: BURGER KING may offer a menu full of gut-busters and may nickel and dime farm laborers. But theres one thing you have to give it credit for: it knows its demographic.

title: Astronauts Health Problem Delays Spacewalk Mission
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  Astronauts will delay by one day attaching a European science laboratory to the International Space Station because of an undisclosed health problem with one member of the space shuttle Atlantis seven-man crew, NASA officials said Saturday.

title: Corrections: Will 6 Be a Lucky Number for Halston?
description: An article last Sunday, about the Halston labels new owners, misstated the number of years it has been since Roy Halston Frowick sold his fashion business to Norton Simon. It was 35 years ago, in 1973, not 25 years ago.

title: Lessons From the Founding Fireplaces
description: CHESTER

title: The Hockey Life, and After
description: PLAYING hockey, I learned an important lesson about business and life: the puck either goes in the net or it doesnt. Sometimes it doesnt go in regardless of what you do. Im not really interested in the reasons why it didnt.

title: Trading Places
description: With the N.B.A.s trading deadline quickly approaching, players from around the league are reacting to the trades. What follows are players comments to various news media outlets in the past week:

title: From Factory Ruins, Windows on the Hudson
description: EXCITING changes are taking place on the Hudson River waterfront. New restaurants have risen phoenixlike from the dust and detritus of old commerce and industry, tasteful metamorphoses that respect an original structure while fitting it out to serve a new contemporary function.

title: Ohio Officials at Odds Over Paper Ballot
description: CINCINNATI  Ohios effort to clean up its voting system before the presidential primary on March 4 has pitted state election leaders against local officials over an order to provide a paper ballot to any voter who requests one.

title: Broken-Language Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: Return Trip on the Shamrock Express
description: IN the north Bronx neighborhood of Woodlawn, where it seems every storefront is adorned with a shamrock, there has been talk lately that the Irish may be coming back.

title: Remembering a City They Hoped Would Be Theirs
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: The Moral Instinct
description: Steven Pinkers thoughtful and fascinating article ( Jan. 13) misses the mark on one point. Bill Gates and Norman Borlaug may have contributed far more to human welfare than Mother Teresa, but she is revered for more than her aura of sanctity.

title: Stores Unmoored in a Sea of Banks
description: RIDGEFIELD

title: This Time, Knicks Arent the Ones Who Come Up Short
