description: MILWAUKEE  The only man standing between the Knicks and another night of intense psychic pain Saturday was Michael Ruffin, a well-traveled and not particularly skilled reserve forward for the Milwaukee Bucks. For the first time in two weeks, fate was kind to Coach Isiah Thomass bedraggled crew.

title: Do Boomers Want a Web Home of Their Own?
description: THE 78 million baby boomers born between 1946 and 1964 are the largest, wealthiest, most tantalizing target ever defined by American marketers. No one seems certain of the boomers annual disposable income, but figures loosely bandied about range from $1 trillion to $2 trillion.

title: To Have and Give Not
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Letters
description: The Skinny Man

title: Romantic Comedies: Todays Standouts
description: To the Editor:

title: At Church Built by Farmers in 1930s, Blessings Are Shared
description: ASHFORD

title: Rest and Rendition
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Chocolate as You Like It  Hand-Dipped and Handmade
description: THIS may be one of the biggest chocolate weeks of the year, but a shortage of bonbons isnt likely in these parts. There are at least 15 chocolate producers in the state, from tiny artisanal boutiques to companies that started small and grew over several generations.

title: The Other Iran
description: MADRASA kojast? Where is the school?

title: Biker Shrine: Harley-Davidson to Open Museum
description: Diehard motorcyclists: Milwaukee could be your destination of choice this year. The Harley-Davidson Museum (www.h-dmuseum.com) scheduled to open this summer in downtown Milwaukee (the companys home for over 100 years), will have 130,000 square feet of exhibition space, a restaurant, a shop, meeting space and the Harley-Davidson archives.

title: A Valley of Misery Between Peaks of Joy
description: AS editor of this column, I was trying to make sense of the preceding Year in Love (as revealed by the manuscripts that cross my desk every day), bewildered that Paul McCartneys divorce had led to a lot of essays welcoming him back on the dating market (Paul and Let It Be Me!), when my eyes drifted to a news headline: Middle-Aged Misery Spans Globe.

title: True Grit? Not So Much, Anymore
description: THERE is disagreement whether stemming from geographic rivalries or plain old confusion  on how best to draw a line around this boisterous, night-lively neighborhood.

title: Report Backing Clemens Chooses Its Facts Carefully
description: Last week, Roger Clemens made the rounds on Capitol Hill to rebut charges by Brian McNamee, his former trainer, that he used steroids and human growth hormone late in his career. In addition, Clemenss agents from Hendricks Sports Management have provided a report loaded with numbers  45 pages, 18,000 words and 38 charts  to support his position. You can find the report at the Web site www.rogerclemensreport.com.

title: Letters
description: How to Pay Tomorrows Bills

title: Negative Campaign
description: Bushs Last Day memorabilia

title: The Big Blind
description: A few years ago, an American lady showed up late at an exclusive Parisian store and was turned away. The outraged shopper was Oprah Winfrey, who charged racial bias; a companion said it was one of the most humiliating moments of her life. Oprah may have been denied a prerogative of elite status in our new gilded age  being waited on in luxury stores after hours  but had she been the victim of racism?

title: Ready for a Giant Leap Back Home
description: AT New York City Ballet, Nikolaj Hbbe is a poet. He knows how to make his Apollo shimmer, how to cast a spell in the pensive, spiritual solo of Square Dance and how to invoke the fury of a gang leader in West Side Story Suite.

title: Cutting to the Quick
description: WITH the Federal Reserve busy cutting interest rates, investors in financial services companies are surely hoping that their beleaguered stocks will rebound. That has been the outcome after previous Fed rescue efforts, of course, and for good reason. When the capital costs of large commercial banks decline significantly, it is far easier for them to generate profits: for example, they lend at much higher rates than their cost or invest in higher-yielding securities.

title: The Perfect Gown? Its Adventurous and Travels Light
description: AT her wedding last fall on Johns Island, S.C., Mimi van Wyck engaged in some fanciful role playing. Sheathed in spiraling layers of silk tulle, she looked every inch the languid 19th-century heroine.

title: 39 Steps, 2 Actors, Countless Roles
description: IN the second act of Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps, the comic stage adaptation of the classic film, two mackintoshed villains interrogate the McGarrigles, a Scottish innkeeper and his wife. Its a suspenseful scene: Will the thugs harm the old couple? Will the McGarrigles reveal the whereabouts of our hero and heroine? And how on earth will all four roles be played by just two actors?

title: New Life for Works Hitler Tried to Kill
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Is Sound Tunnel D.O.A. or Just Decades Away?
description: Oyster Bay

title: Conflicts Deepen Between Local Iraqi Governments and U.S.-Backed Sunni Groups
description: BAGHDAD  Conflicts between provincial governments and local Sunni Arab forces allied with the United States intensified this weekend in two provinces. The conflicts raise the prospect that the creation of the forces, known as Awakening Councils or Concerned Local Citizens, formed to fight extremists and bring calm to the country, might instead add to the unrest in Diyala and Anbar provinces.

title: Correction: The Ski Town That Aspen Used to Be Like
description: A picture caption with the Next Stop column on Jan. 27 about Ellicottville, a ski town in western New York, misstated the name of a ski resort there. As the article noted, it is Holiday Valley, not Holiday Mountain.

title: Identity Politics
description: For Americans of African descent, one of the difficulties in writing about identity is that the discussion, intentionally or not, is simultaneously intensely personal and profoundly public. Our unique experience and the racial identification manifested in melanin binds us inextricably to both our individual, subjective, personal experiences and to the collective experience of the group. Efforts to be seen as an individual necessitate that we differentiate ourselves from some supposedly monolithic black identity and authenticity. Like it or not, our individuality is dependent on first identifying and, depending on where we are coming from and where we are going, either embracing or distancing ourselves from the group.

title: New York Legislators Pushing to Raise Their Pay
description: ALBANY  New York legislators are looking for a raise of as much as 22 percent, saying the $79,500 base salaries they earn are not enough.

title: State Pursues Case Against Luxury Car Dealer
description: WHEN Michael Torsone decided to sell his 1967 Jaguar convertible more than a year ago, he turned to Evolution Motor Sports in Lime Rock, an antique, sports and luxury car dealership and garage.

title: R, North Carolina
description: Appearing on Larry King Live in 1995, Jesse Helms, then the senior senator from North Carolina, fielded a call from an unusual admirer. Helms deserved the Nobel Peace Prize, the caller gushed, for everything youve done to help keep down the niggers. Given the rank ugliness of the sentiment  the guest host, Robert Novak, called it, with considerable understatement, politically incorrect  Helms could only pause before responding. But the hesitation couldnt suppress his gut instincts. Whoops, well, thank you, I think, he said. With prodding from Novak, he added that hed been spanked as a child for using the N-word and noted (with a delicious hint of uncertainty), I dont think Ive used it since. As for the callers main point  the virtue of keeping down blacks  it passed without comment.

title: St. Johns Wins Third in a Row, but the Doubts Persist
description: For a day, at least, jubilation replaced consternation at Carnesecca Arena as St. Johns beat Providence, 64-62, on Saturday. The Red Storm has won three consecutive games, all in the Big East. That had not happened in more than two years.

title: Have You Seen This Dog? Only With Telepathy
description: Vivi the whippet, the prize-winning show dog who vanished two years ago at Kennedy International Airport, is alive and well and living in Brooklyn. At least thats what the animal psychics say. These are the professionals who claim to tune into an animals thoughts through telepathy the way another person might find a radio station.

title: Accorsi Never Stopped Believing in Manning
description: The story that ended last Sunday with Eli Manning and the Giants winning the Super Bowl started nearly 40 years earlier on a small-college football field in Golden, Colo.

title: Can a Condo Board Change the Bylaws?
description: Q The board of managers of our condominium issued a ruling that any owner who is delinquent in paying the monthly common charge cannot vote at the annual meeting. Our bylaws state that each unit owner is entitled to one vote. Doesnt this ruling require a change in the bylaws? And doesnt a change in the bylaws require a two-thirds vote of unit owners?

title: Genres to Bend, Words to Finesse, Rhymes to Unravel
description: Cascada

title: Hearing of Special Interest to an I.R.S. Special Agent
description: When Barry Bonds stood up in federal court in San Francisco in November to plead not guilty to charges of perjury and obstruction of justice, Jeff Novitzky was sitting in the front row.

title: Curves in the Road to Redeeming Miles
description: DAVID BORAK, an environmental policy analyst from Washington, has 300,000 frequent-flier miles with United, but for five months now, he hasnt been able to use them for a family vacation in Rome next summer. While his dates are flexible, he said there were no seats available for the so-called Saver price of 50,000 miles.

title: German Students Confront the Holocaust
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: La Dolce Vita, Both Day and Night
description: Top reader suggestions on Rome, compiled from user comments posted on the Travel section's Web site, travel.nytimes.com.

title: In Stimulus Plan, Democrats See Gain
description: WASHINGTON  As President Bush, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and Republican leaders in Congress urged the Senate to approve swiftly an economic rescue plan adopted by the House, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, suddenly seemed the odd man out, beating his partisan drum as the rest of Washington joined in a chorus of cooperation.

title: Fragile Matters of the Heart
description: DEPENDING on your mood, you could interpret the giant red hearts being hung on the walls of the place you spend most of your days as evidence of a happy development.

title: El Barrio Reinvented
description: East Harlem became famous as El Barrio, the center of Puerto Rican culture on the mainland. But in the past three decades, the neighborhood has undergone profound changes, with the Upper East Side inching northward, immigrants moving in, and good Latin restaurants being complemented by a variety of other types of cuisine.

title: Letters: Waving Goodbye to Hegemony
description: Parag Khanna (Jan. 27) may be right in general outline and in some specifics with his argument for an emerging new world order led by China, the European Union and the United States. But he poses not a single meaningful obstacle for either China or Europe along their paths to such emergence. Under his scenario, the two move only from strength to strength  sewing up oil and gas contracts, filling power vacuums and winning not so much hearts and minds as some share of transient loyalty from unfailingly canny second world states. This while the U.S. apparently stands by helpless.

title: For Spring Training Locations, Florida Wanes as the Desert Blooms
description: After a 60-year residency, the Los Angeles Dodgers will leave Vero Beach, Fla., in five weeks. After a nearly 90-year stay interrupted only by a three-year break during World War II, the Cincinnati Reds are negotiating to leave Florida. After a 16-year hiatus in Florida, the Cleveland Indians are planning to return whence they came.

title: Global Finance Leaders Warn of Risk From U.S. Housing Woe
description: TOKYO  Finance leaders from the worlds wealthiest nations warned Saturday that global economic woes could get worse from the slump in the American housing market, but offered few specific remedies.

title: A Little Off the Top
description: To the Editor:

title: The Unending Allure of the Free Lunch
description: With usura hath no man a house of good stone

title: A Fairer System: Tax the Annoying
description: ITS tax season and an election year, so again our thoughts have turned to change.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE BEAUTIFUL THINGS THAT HEAVEN BEARS, by Dinaw Mengestu. (Riverhead, $14.) This first novel of hope and loss concerns an Ethiopian immigrant who owns a failing grocery store in a gentrifying neighborhood. He lives in two cities  the Washington where he struggles to survive and the Addis Ababa of memory. His pain is offset by the friendship of fellow immigrants and that of a white woman who moves with her young daughter into the house next door. Our reviewer, Rob Nixon, praised Mengestus watchful honesty and egalitarian tenderness and added, This is a great African novel, a great Washington novel and a great American novel.

title: Warning: Fast Driving May Lead to More Trading
Alicia Svenson and Matthew Friese
description: Alicia Lindall Svenson and Matthew Bach Friese were married Saturday evening at the Explorers Club in New York. Justice Richard F. Braun of the State Supreme Court in New York officiated.

title: Bhuttos Widower Rallies Party
description: THATTA, Pakistan  Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, opened her partys election campaign on Saturday with a huge rally in her home province, Sindh, in a bid to sweep the party into power on her legacy and her martyrdom.

title: Tell the T.S.A. (and Dont Hold Back)
description: Ever since you started X-raying our shoes, Ive been forced to carry all my plastic explosives in my pants, which I find most inconvenient.

title: Arts Developers, Now Hear This
description: IT seems a talent peculiar to artists: the ability to locate real estate ripe for transformation, imbue it with a little panache, and price oneself out.

title: Whos in Charge Here? Need You Ask?
description: ALTHOUGH I know better  I really do  when I have the impulse to adopt a new pet, I picture only love and fulfillment. I forget the work; I play down the mess. Think of those cat food commercials where a woman is curled up reading in the company of a sleek, purring, contented creature, and youll see straight into my fantasy life.

title: Pebble Beachs 18th Hole Is a Perfect Intersection of Golf and Nature
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Every year at this time, the familiar coastline comes into view. Beamed into millions of living rooms and dens are the scenic assortment of aerials, ground-level looks from worm cams, slo-mo and super-slo-mo beauty shots of players and celebrities great and small strolling the golf course on the cliffs at Pebble Beach. To see it all unfold each February is a ritual as familiar as opening the family photo album.

title: Recalling the Maharishi and Carvilles Killer Ad
description: WITH his high-pitched giggle and his gentle ways, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi is not someone you would expect to be used as a blunt-force weapon in a political campaign.

title: Turkeys Parliament Lifts Scarf Ban
description: ISTANBUL  Parliament took a major step on Saturday toward lifting a ban against womens head scarves at universities, setting the stage for a final showdown with Turkeys secular elite over where Islam fits in the building of an open society.

title: Inside the List
description: KINGS KINDLING: Stephen King is, famously, no admirer of the cellphone. But when it comes to other fripperies, like electronic books, hes long been an early adapter. His novella Riding the Bullet (2000) was first published in e-book form. That same year he also self-published The Plant  an ultimately uncompleted serial novel  online, and even adopted an honor system payment plan, predating Radioheads stab at this by seven years. The lastest gleam in Kings eye is Kindle, Amazons fledgling e-book reader. Ive argued all my life that the story means more than the delivery systems involved (and that includes the writer), King wrote recently in Entertainment Weekly, praising the device. Among other things, he likes that Kindle allows him to increase a books type size. His conclusion: My definition of Kindle: a gadget with stories hiding inside it. Whats wrong with that? Kings new novel, Duma Key, enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 1. As it happens, Duma Key is also  as this issue goes to press  No. 1 on Kindles own most-downloaded list.

title: The Job Interview, Starring Your Avatar
description: AS far as job interviews go, my recent meeting with Sandy Gould was anything but ordinary.

title: Insurance Appraisals: High-Tech Protection
description: GONE are the days when buying homeowners insurance meant telling your local insurance broker how much you paid for your house and then tacking on a buffer for inflation.

title: Willies World
description: If the agents at Guantnamo Bay ever run out of interrogation techniques, they might consider forcing their prisoners to spend hours reading aloud to one another from the memoirs of American politicians. Its a dreadful genre, mainly because any politician who is still alive and coherent  and this would include at least two-thirds of the United States Congress  is too concerned about his own place in history to be a very reliable chronicler of it.

title: A View of Pueblo Life From the Inside
description: AT about 8:30 at night, an artillery-like barrage of fireworks shattered the silence, followed by the oompah of a tuba and the beating of drums. My curiosity aroused, I left the simple wooden cabin in which I was staying and went into the darkness to investigate. I found a slow-moving parade of perhaps 200 people shuffling down the streets of the Mexican village of Santa Ana del Valle, some 20 miles east of the city of Oaxaca. Indigenous Zapotec faces, from the newborn to the elderly, glowed in the flickering light of the candles many carried, along with bouquets of poinsettias, roses, or gladiolus.

title: Letters: A Cutting Tradition
description: Female circumcision is neither mandated nor recommended in Islam (Sara Corbett, Jan. 20). Your photo gallery shows a particular practice in a particular ethnic group. Culture, not religion, dictates much of what Muslim and non-Muslim people do worldwide. The distinction is essential to make in these times when Islam and Muslims are under the microscope.

title: Child of the Revolution
description: When circumstances throw a child into the company of a stranger, do you wish for that stranger to be male or female? What would the child prefer? In Harry Mulischs novel The Assault, a young Dutch boy is separated from his parents at the end of World War II, after members of the underground assassinate a collaborator outside the family home. Alone and afraid, he is taken to a police station and pushed into a dark cell. All about him he could feel the presence of the man who must be in there somewhere. When a voice in the blackness says, Why are you here? relief washes over him. Why? Because it is the gentle voice of a woman. Suddenly it was as if a great danger had been averted. As the woman pulls him close to console him, the boy smells sweat and something strangely sweet  perfume, he thinks. But its blood. The woman who comforts him is one of the assassins, a terrorist in the words of the soldiers who imprisoned her. Her actions led to the death of the boys parents, but he doesnt know that, nor does she. Still, as she holds him, he hears her heart pound, really much too hard for someone who was just comforting someone else. Years later, he sobs when he learns she has died: She was resurrected together with all she had meant to him, hidden there in the darkness.

title: Other School Districts Offered State Intervention
description: THE state bailed out the financially and academically troubled Roosevelt school district, with $14 million. But Long Islands representative on the State Board of Regents said that Roosevelt was not the only district on the Island where the state should intervene.

title: Good News: Bad News Arrives Quickly
description: IT has not been a great year so far for Enfield High School. Beyond the two snow days the school district has racked up, students at the high school, in northwestern Connecticut, received an unexpected extension on their holiday break when a pipe burst on Jan. 1, letting water pour in for hours before the break was discovered. The school was closed for three days, reopened, then shut down again the next week, when the main electrical box caught fire, possibly as a result of the flooding.

title: John Myers, 96, World War II Test Pilot, Is Dead
description: John W. Myers, a leading civilian test pilot in World War II, who helped develop the first American fighter plane designed specifically for night combat, died on Jan. 31 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 96.

title: Clean Power or Dirty Coal?
description: Opposition to new coal-fired power plants built without new technology  that is, without the capacity to capture greenhouse gas emissions  is rising on both Wall Street and Main Street. Citizen opposition has led companies to cancel some high-profile projects, including a proposed plant near the Florida Everglades. Pressure from environmental organizations has persuaded major banks to begin weighing the risks of global warming when deciding whether to finance new plants.

title: Learning From Britneys Troubles
description: THE involuntary hospitalization of Britney Spears last week brought back memories. Ten years ago, when I was 15, I was a high school dropout and heroin addict, living in the back of a dealers van. My mom first noticed red flags at 14: rapid weight loss, self-mutilation, coming home high, irregularly showering. The therapist she had me see, as well as my school counselor, believed that, cutting aside, my actions were typical teenage behavior. The first time I ran away, though, my mother formed her own conclusions, and got a 5150 issued  California code for the involuntary 72-hour psychiatric hold that Ms. Spears was under, before she left the hospital on Wednesday.

title: A Peruvian Place That Aims High
description: UPSCALE Peruvian?

title: Now, Feed the Data to the Subprimeoscope
description: AS a nation, the central question we face just now  even more than, Can I still exchange this dreck for something I might actually wear?  is whether our economy is entering a recession (recession, of course, being technically defined as two consecutive quarters in which office managers keep warning everyone to stop using FedEx for personal mail).

title: Going Global With Concerns on Health Costs
description: The United States has long been an unusual study in medical care, with employers assuming much of the cost. Now, though, as the employers say enough, calls are deepening for the government to take on more of that role through nationalized health care.

title: When Women Rule
description: While no woman has been president of the United States  yet  the world does have several thousand years worth of experience with female leaders. And I have to acknowledge it: Their historical record puts mens to shame.

title: Whose Responsibility Is a Terrace Door?
description: Q At a recent shareholders meeting of my co-op, the board said that a terrace is the co-ops responsibility but that the door leading to it is the responsibility of the shareholder. Is this true?

title: Two of Yesterdays Stars Face Off With Gusto
description: In chess, as in life, the elders deserve a little respect. The games legends may not regularly face the rigors of tournament play, but they can still put on a good show.

title: A Little Jewel Box of a Shoe Store
description: THE shoe designer Israel Miller built an unusual series of stores in the 1920s and 1930s, none more remarkable than his arresting little gem, rebuilt in 1926 at the northeast corner of Broadway and 46th Street.

title: In Reversal, Courts Uphold Local Immigration Laws
description: After groups challenging state and local laws cracking down on illegal immigration won a series of high-profile legal victories last year, the tide has shifted as federal judges recently handed down several equally significant decisions upholding those laws.

title: Wedding-Bell Grille
description: Wedding-Bell Grille

title: Next Up for the Democrats: Civil War
description: WHAT if a presidential candidate held what she billed as the largest, most interactive town hall in political history on national television, and no one noticed?

title: Bollywood Princess, Hollywood Hopeful
description: Mumbai

title: Endless Task: Keeping Unions Clean
description: For more than a decade, federal officials and court-appointed monitors have strained to clean up two New York-area unions, representing cement truck drivers and construction laborers, that prosecutors say were long under Mafia control.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 5: Sweet Guys

title: Up Front
description: This weeks issue of the Book Review ranges over American politics but not, we hope, in a familiar way. While some of the books reviewed relate, directly or obliquely, to the presidential election and address many of its most divisive issues  race, gender, religion and war  others touch realms where politics meets the imagination and the present confronts the past.

title: Correction
description: An entry on the fiction best-seller list last Sunday for Plum Lucky, by Janet Evanovich, misidentified the character who finds a bag of cash. She is Stephanies grandmother, not her mother

title: Girardi Is Leaving a Lot Behind
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  Joe Girardi had tears in his eyes, tears that have been building for months, even years, and tears that were close to covering his face. But Girardi, the manager of the Yankees, stared upward, plowed through his thoughts and kept the tears from escaping. He held them back, for now, anyway.

title: In Tavel, Paying Homage to the Ros of Kings
description: TAVEL, a town of 1,600 perched at the edge of the Languedoc, on the brink of Provence, is the veritable cradle of French ros. A staple of the ancient papal court in nearby Avignon and a favorite of Louis XIV and Philippe le Bel (earning it the dual sobriquets Ros of Kings and King of Ross), Tavel was the first ros to be designated AOC (Appellation dOrigine Contrle). The appellation has stayed true to its roots; to be called a Tavel, it must be a ros.

title: Suzanne Kopp, Michael Moskow
description: Suzanne M. Kopp and Michael H. Moskow were married on Saturday at the Kohl Childrens Museum in Glenview, Ill. Rabbi Samuel N. Gordon officiated.

title: In Vino Veritas
description: Why are videos of drunken people so compelling?

title: Pathfinders
description: The South, as its great historian C. Vann Woodward once noted, developed into the United States most distinctive region. Among its distinctions  bound up with but outlasting its peculiar institution of chattel slavery  were white Southerners preoccupations with human limitations, guilt and evil. Not for them the optimistic creed or dream of perfection associated with their Northern brethren. In that sense, Woodward argued, the Souths outlook was a thoroughly un-American one.

title: Because They Said So
description: Even by the dismal standards of what passes for a national debate on intelligence and civil liberties, last week was a really bad week.

title: The Time of Their Lives
description: Campaigning against a president who refused to respond to the growing opposition to a cruel, dishonest war, the charismatic young candidate insisted: What we need in the United States is not division. What we need in the United States is not hatred. What we need in the United States is ... love and wisdom and compassion toward one another. That wasnt last week  it was April 1968, and two months later Robert Kennedy was dead. Opposition to the war continued and broadened after the election of Richard Nixon that fall, but one of the engines of the antiwar movement, Students for a Democratic Society, largely disbanded after a split in 1969; the next year its leaders, gripped by revolutionary fantasies, went underground.

title: Nods to the Old Country in a Modern Space
description: IN 2004, Ermenegildo Zegna, the mens luxury clothing and accessories brand, opened a new United States flagship store at 663 Fifth Avenue, between 52nd and 53rd Streets. The Zegna family, the sole owner of the company, would eventually decide that it needed something that better told the story of the business, now 98 years old, and went back to the drawing board.

title: Taking the Bite Out of a New Mexico Winter
description: TAOS is at its moodiest and most beautiful in winter. Its the time of the silver gray mesa, of ominous clouds, of crackling cedar logs in kiva fireplaces, of snow clouds billowing in across the plain, of the smoke of house fires leaning in lines from the pueblo rooftops. The adobe architecture seems so well suited to winter, both physically and spiritually. It offers the kind of haven from the cold no other building material can.

title: Legos for the Grown-Ups
description: THE social event of the season in Locust Point, a quiet enclave of tidy family homes along the East Bronx waterfront, took place just over a week ago when a crane lifted two 18-ton halves of a prefabricated house off flatbed trailers and stacked them like Legos on an empty lot.

title: Rumor Has It ...
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: From One Cuckoos Nest to Another
description: ITS funny to realize, but in my relatively short life I have lived through six or seven different social and cultural systems, the filmmaker Milos Forman said. First the Democratic Republic of Czechoslovakia, then the limited democracy before World War II, then the Nazi regime. After the Nazi regime there was a kind of democracy again for three years, then came the Stalinist regime, then the reformed Communist regime, and now I am living in a free country.

title: Letters: How Its Couched
description: Daphne Merkins interesting essay (Jan. 27) suggests that nowadays the tweaking of serotonin and dopamine levels is considered more effective than examining the wrong turns of the psyche and that psychotherapy... has always required a degree of blind faith. Popular notions, these, but clinicians familiar with the research of the past 30 years believe otherwise. Well-controlled studies of cognitive-behavioral and other types of psychotherapy have shown them to be as effective as medication for certain kinds of psychological problems, like panic attacks. Indeed, for some disorders, cognitive-behavioral therapy may have longer-lasting effects than medication. Experienced psychiatrists know that both psychotherapy and medication have their proper place and often work best when combined.

title: Breaking Through
description: In 2005, at the Sundance Film Festival, a star was born, but almost no one noticed. Well, actually, a few studio executives who saw Hard Candy raved about the performance of the unknown Ellen Page  she played an avenging, psychopathic 14-year-old who entices and then violently tortures a would-be pedophile. But the movie was so relentlessly disturbing (at one point, Pages character ties her enemy down and slowly begins to castrate him) that when Hard Candy was released the following year, no one went to see it. What the audience missed then is what they later found in Juno  the birth of a different sort of actress. Unlike her glamour-girl peers who double as tabloid superstars, Page, who is now 20, is a tomboy  her on-screen persona is sharp, clear-eyed, determined and self-consciously original. In Hard Candy, she managed to be adorable and persuasive while wielding a large knife; in 2007, that same spirit and charm animated Juno, a kind of fairy tale about a pregnant 16-year-old who decides to have the baby and give it to the couple (in the end, half the couple) she chooses. In Juno, the lack of realism  no one questions Junos decision  and the lack of politics are trumped by the overwhelming appeal of Pages acting. She is so alive on screen  so unique, so ingratiating  that she makes the character, and the entire film, believable.

title: The Vanishing Establishment
description: A LITTLE more than 40 years ago, the journalist Richard H. Rovere set off in search of that indistinct tangle of power and influence known as the American Establishment. After months of investigation, Mr. Rovere, in an essay published in 1961, unmasked the establishments members  the directors of the Council on Foreign Relations, the chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, the head of the Ford Foundation, and so on  and offered a working definition: A more or less closed and self-sustaining institution that holds a preponderance of power in our more or less open society.

title: When Pink Pigeons Soared in the Sky
description: AT the Rosebank Deli on Tompkins Avenue, in an unhurried Staten Island neighborhood near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the colors on the awning are the red, white and green of the Italian flag, and on the window, there is the green of a poster advertising homemade meatballs. On Tuesday afternoon, four gray-haired men sat as they often do at a wooden table drinking their coffee out of foam cups.

title: Man Bites Insect
description: David Gracer eats bugs. Not any old crushed, oozy, sidewalk kind of bug, but insects selected just like any other food  for sustenance and taste. He eats them sauted, filleted and roasted. And he thinks you should eat them, too.

title: Who Killed the Courtesan?
description: Henry II, the Plantagenet king who occupies the English throne in Ariana Franklins captivating medieval mysteries, proved himself a wise and just (if headstrong) monarch in Mistress of the Art of Death, so intellectually enlightened and free of religious superstition that he entrusted a sensitive murder case to Adelia Aguilar, a woman brought up as a free-thinker and schooled in Italy to perform autopsies. In THE SERPENTS TALE (Putnam, $25.95), which continues this exciting series, the focus is on Henrys contentious queen, Eleanor of Aquitaine, whose agile mind, strong will and vibrant personality make her a formidable adversary for her royal spouse.

title: Holiday Show Thats Rockin Round the Clock
description: An article on Dec. 16 about Jon Solomon, who is the host of a 24-hour holiday radio show for WPRB-FM at Princeton University, referred incorrectly to Mr. Solomons coverage of mens basketball at the university. He reports for a Web site, princetonbasketball.com, not the radio station.

title: Terror Threat From Pakistan Said to Expand
description: This article was reported by Elaine Sciolino, Victoria Burnett and Eric Schmitt and written by Ms. Sciolino.

title: Little Children
description: Thirty-five years after Roe v. Wade, the pro-life movement faces a new challenge: biotechnology. The first human biotech issue, embryonic stem-cell research, looks like an easy call. Stem cells could save millions of lives. And the entity we currently sacrifice to get them  a sacrifice that may soon be unnecessary  is a tiny, undeveloped ball of cells. The question, like the embryo, seems a no-brainer.

title: The Republican Reformation
description: Washington

title: Pushing Paper Out the Door
description: CHRIS UHLIKS children can be found in their home computer lab almost every morning. Nicole is writing a story about her two lizards. Tony is playing an interactive spelling game, while Andy is learning multiplication tables. Even 5-year-old Joceline is clicking away at a storybook game.

title: Backing for a Behemoth
description: The Posting article last Sunday about Sky View Parc, a new mixed-use development in Flushing, Queens, misstated the area to be used for retail space. It will be 800,000 square feet, not 80,000.

title: Marrakesh, Morocco: Les Borjs de la Kasbah
description: THE BASICS

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A Calendar listing last Sunday about an exhibition of drawings and prints at the Fairfield Public Library misspelled the surname of the artist. He is James Reed, not Reid.

title: Republicans Weighing the Benefits of Bushs Embrace
description: WASHINGTON  With President Bushs job approval ratings hovering around 30 percent and four-fifths of Americans believing the country is on the wrong track, some Republicans say the best thing he could do this election season would be to simply stay out of the way.

title: Chinese Hockey Players Make Islanders Ice Theirs, for a Period
description: UNIONDALE

title: Queens Lives Up to Its Billing
description: FOR Patrick Haggerty, Queens was absolutely the place to be. He was convinced of it.

title: Fresh From Broadway, Souls (and Sex) for Sale
description: There are four hustlers onstage at TheaterWorks in Hartford, but only one of them is in the business of peddling sex. The other three characters in Douglas Carter Beanes satirical comedy about Hollywood, The Little Dog Laughed, cheerfully sell their souls instead.

title: Left Wing and a Prayer
description: The leadership of the Democratic Party, to its misfortune, has tended to confuse the religious right with religion, period. As a result, they can now look back at a long campaign of successful efforts to alienate white Christians, who make up two-thirds of the American electorate.

title: Were Friends, Right?
description: IN classic buddy movies like Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, a mismatched pair of friends learn to transcend their differences and forge a lasting, loyal friendship.

title: Redskins Hire Zorn as Coach
description: The Washington Redskins hired Jim Zorn as their coach Saturday night, a surprise ending to a monthlong search for a replacement for Joe Gibbs.Ive always dreamed of being a head coach with a franchise rich in tradition like the Redskins, Zorn said in a team news release. As a player who had to fight Redskins teams at R.F.K. as well as at our home field, I know about the history of this franchise as well as the passion of its fans. I wont let you down.The Redskins said Zorn, 54, agreed to a five-year contract.Zorn, a former Seattle quarterback, has been the Seahawks quarterbacks coach for the last seven years. The Redskins hired him to be their offensive coordinator Jan. 26 while continuing their search for a head coach. Zorn replaces Gibbs, who resigned Jan. 8.

title: Joint Chiefs Chairman and Musharraf Discuss Terror Threat
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, speaking after meeting top military officials here on Saturday, said Pakistan faced an escalating terrorist threat that could affect the United States, but he also underscored the limitations of what Washington could do about it.

title: U.S. Universities Rush to Set Up Outposts Abroad
description: When John Sexton, the president of New York University, first met Omar Saif Ghobash, an investor trying to entice him to open a branch campus in the United Arab Emirates, Mr. Sexton was not sure what to make of the proposal  so he asked for a $50 million gift.

title: Brothers in Arms
description: Mahammed Farooqi, a 49-year-old Pakistani news addict, was snoring through the story of his generation.

title: Will Disney Keep Us Amused?
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  VISIT Disneys California Adventure  a 55-acre theme park next door to the fabled progenitor of the modern amusement Mecca, Disneyland  and you will find a noisy reminder of what happens when a company loses its focus and cuts corners.

title: 36 Hours in Napa Valley
description: STRIKING waves of mustard flower. Rolling fields of budding vines. No traffic. You might need to pack an umbrella and an extra sweater, but winter is a surprisingly beautiful time to visit the Napa Valley of California. A misty and painterly moodiness sweeps over the 30-mile-long region this time of year, scattering the crowds, sharpening the colors and infusing the oak-scented tasting rooms with coziness. Daytime temperatures hover as high as the 50s, and though the season brings rain, it encourages an air of reflection perfectly suited to those big California reds.

title: How Long Is a Tenant Entitled to Insider Price?
description: Q I live in a three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment on the Upper West Side that was once rented by my mother. In the early 80s, when the building went co-op, she was offered an insiders price of $165,000 to buy it. She declined. Do I have any right to buy at a lower price?

title: Lawsuit May Force Ex-U.S.C. Star to Talk
description: New Orleans Saints running back Reggie Bush has faced continual accusations since April 2006 that he and his family took as much as $300,000 in cash and goods while he attended the University of Southern California.

title: From Bush, Foe of Earmarks, Similar Items
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush often denounces the propensity of Congress to earmark money for pet projects. But in his new budget, Mr. Bush has requested money for thousands of similar projects.

title: Beyond Bush
description: An author who has published a book extolling George W. Bush as a leader of heroic proportions faces a challenge in deciding what to write next. Given the current state of popular opinion, he might understandably wish to choose a different subject altogether. Or he might simply dig in and argue that Bush will one day be recognized as a great statesman unappreciated in his time. Or, more interestingly, he might decide to pull back from his earlier posture of admiration, take a serious look at what has gone wrong over the past seven years of Republican stewardship, and offer suggestions for how the party and the American conservative movement in general might attempt to recover.

title: Missing From World War II, but Not Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Give to Colleges in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: In a House, You Can Make All the Noise You Want
description: FOR the West Village sippy-cup set, it marked the passing of an era when Hali Lee and Peter von Ziegesar moved from that neighborhood across the river to Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: No Tool Left Behind
description: WHEN Ford asked owners of its trucks and vans which work-related problems drove them nuts, forgetting to bring crucial tools to a job was high on the list. At the Chicago Auto Show, Ford demonstrated a radio frequency identification system designed to let owners of its 2009 F-150 and E-Series trucks know if they had every tool on their checklist when they set out.

title: Cowboys Hire Herring
description: The Dallas Cowboys have hired Reggie Herring as linebackers coach. The hiring comes a little more than a month after Herring, the former Arkansas interim coach, was named the defensive coordinator at Texas A&M. Herring filled the last of the positions that opened in Dallas after Tony Sparano became the Dolphins new coach and hired three Cowboys assistants for his staff.

title: Father and Sons
description: My aging father needs a kidney transplant. A brother and I are willing donors, but I am a perfect blood match while he is only an acceptable match. The hospital says either will do for the next round of testing, but it prefers the perfect blood match. We could flip a coin, a fair way to choose between us, but our dad could get the second-best kidney. Whose needs take precedence?  NAME WITHHELD

title: Letters: What Happened in Vegas Stayed in His Novel
description: In his otherwise excellent profile (Jan. 27), Charles McGrath observes that Charles Bock is a little old to be a first novelist at age 38. Good thing Henry Miller, Anas Nin, Joseph Conrad, George Eliot, Stephen Carter, Julia Glass and the nonagenarian writer Millard Kaufman, to name a few, didnt think they were all washed up when they turned 38.

title: Letter: Galpagos Islands
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Can Darwins Lab Survive Success?" (Jan. 27): You could not have picked a more appropriate setting to begin the Green Traveler series on travel and the environment than my native Ecuadors Galpagos Islands. These truly enchanted islands, which were the inspiration and the basis for Darwins theories, are one of the ultimate destinations for nature lovers and eco-tourists and one of the most treasured, fragile and endangered ecosystems on our planet.

title: Look Out, Soccer Moms: Shes Got You Nailed
description: MONTCLAIR

title: Lasting Devotion, in the Shape of a Heart
description: Teaneck

title: Citing 15-Year Delay, Suit Seeks Action on Rebuilt Wrecks
description: WHEN President Bush signed a bill that would keep millions of vehicles seriously damaged in crashes  and potentially dangerous  from being repaired and sold to unsuspecting buyers, consumer advocates were thrilled.

title: Yahoo Expected to Reject Microsofts Takeover Bid
description: Yahoos board plans to reject Microsofts $44.6 billion hostile bid in a letter on Monday, saying the offer undervalues Yahoo, people involved in the discussions said Saturday.

title: Recession Hint Sends Stocks Down Sharply
description: Buffeted by concerns about a weakening economy, the stock market fell last week after two weeks of gains.

title: Its Not Just Cruel; Its Unusual, Too
description: THE unthinkable has happened. Someone is staging The Cenci.

title: Horror Auteur Is Unfinished With the Undead
description: TORONTO

title: Super Bowl Touches and Inspires Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: This Just In, From Inwood
description: INWOOD, at Manhattans northernmost tip, has a 212 area code, but in many ways thats almost all it has in common with the rest of the borough.

title: Indulge, Charitably
description: If pastries are part of your Valentines Day plans this year, you might consider buying ones that not only taste good, but do good: All the proceeds from Connies Bakery and General Store in Mount Kisco go to local charities.

title: Commuters Fear Ferry Will Shut Down
description: HIGHLANDS

title: Matchmaker, You Have Until Thursday
description: JON BRANSDON left his date on Wednesday night with a glass of scotch in one hand and a scorecard in the other.

title: Berlin: Weinerei
description: With artists and other creative types slowly being priced out of the adjacent Berlin neighborhoods of Prenzlauer Berg and Mitte, places like the weinerein (wine bars) owned by Jrgen Stumpf are welcome holdouts. These wine bars  all based on an honor system  have a charming, if maybe a bit nave, faith in mankinds honesty. For the price of 1 euro (about $1.50), you rent yourself a glass and get to sample as many of the wines as you want. At the end of the night you throw some bills or coins into a big jar, the amount based on what you think is fair.

title: New Rules Ease the Sting of Mortgages
description: REACTING to the troubles in the nations housing and mortgage markets, Congress enacted measures late last year that will give tax breaks to some beleaguered home buyers.

title: Its Time to Reform the F.D.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: A Strange Career Takes an Odd Turn
description: IT had to be one of the least surprising statements ever uttered by a comedian.

title: For Your Pet, a Policy All Its Own
description: SERIOUS illness can take a financial toll on families without health insurance  even when the patient is the family pet.

title: In an Era of Glitz, a Witness With Panache
description: THE ABOLAFIA FILES, as Oscar Abolafia describes his celebrity photographs, are kept in file cabinets in a narrow, dim hallway in his small prewar apartment on West 98th Street.

title: Fitzgerald vs. Hollywood
description: Most writers, the writer F. Scott Fitzgerald once wrote, look like writers whether they want to or not. It is hard to say why.

title: Holding On to Hope
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.

title: Family Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Price for Being International
description: SOME of the most expensive and historic mansions on the Upper East Side pay no taxes at all, and the number is growing. These are, of course, the properties picked up over the years by foreign governments, at a time when prices were far lower than they are today.

title: Mashups Are Breaking the Mold at Microsoft
description: REDMOND, Wash.  TUCKED away in a building on this forested corporate campus, John Montgomery and his team of 17 programmers might be more at home in Silicon Valley than at Microsoft.

title: On the Night Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Fuzzy Election Math, Before and After
description: THE polls leading into this years presidential primaries and the delegate counts coming out of them are giving the news media and the public fits.

title: Dont Let the Green Grass Fool You
description: AS a suburban environmentalist, Mike Tidwell, 45, of Takoma Park, Md., always felt like a walking contradiction.

title: Iraq Onstage: We Need a Fix, Not Drama
description: To the Editor:

title: Datebook
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: For a Book About Peace, a Dose of Trouble
description: KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, the 7-foot-2 basketball legend, seemed a fitting subject for a childrens coloring book about tolerance in the age of the war on terror. Mr. Abdul-Jabbar is a Muslim, and he has a distinctly Arabic name. With his status as a celebrity athlete, he seemed a perfect illustration of the principle that people defy stereotypes.

title: Dan H. Laurence, 87, Bibliographer and George Bernard Shaw Scholar, Is Dead
description: Dan H. Laurence, a noted scholar, editor and bibliographer who devoted nearly every waking moment of his professional life to compiling the voluminous works of George Bernard Shaw, died on Tuesday at his home in San Antonio. He was 87.

title: Proposal in Texas for a Public-Private Toll Road System Raises an Outcry
description: ROBSTOWN, Tex.  Leon Littles farm here near Corpus Christi would not be seized for Texass proposed $184-billion-plus superhighway project for 5 or 10 years, if ever.

title: Correction: Seeking a Path in Democracys Dead End
description: A map last Sunday with an article about the decline of democracy in Central Asia and the Caucasus misidentified a lake in eastern Kazakhstan. It is Lake Balkhash  not Lake Baykal, which is in Siberia.

title: When Horizontal Meets Vertical
description: ISLANDIA

title: Death March
description: No matter how serious a disease may be, devising a cure or treatment or ways of prevention is only half the battle. The other half can be more mysterious. Throughout the world, people who should know better eat, drink or have sex in needlessly risky ways, or ignore medical danger signs until it is too late. These, the willful ignorers, are what interest the South African journalist Jonny Steinberg about the gravest medical crisis his country has experienced: AIDS. More than one out of every eight South Africans is H.I.V. positive, Steinberg reports; every day roughly 800 South Africans die of AIDS and more than 1,000 additional people are infected. A recent survey found that in the previous month, the average South African was more than twice as likely to have been to a funeral as to a wedding.

title: Selling on eBay? Keep Eye on Gains
description: EBAY and other Web sites have transformed the neighborhood garage sale into a never-ending global auction, vastly expanding the number of potential buyers. The market for a Mickey Mantle rookie baseball card is no longer limited to the kids on the block  nor is the price determined by what those kids are able to pay.

title: Indian Discontent Fuels Malaysias Rising Tensions
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysian Indian Casket, a shop on the outskirts of this modern and cosmopolitan city, sells coffins in all sizes: standard coffins clutter the entrance, child-size boxes are stacked high on the shelves and extra-large models, those for the tallest of the deceased, are stored in the back.

title: Alexandra Certilman, David Kay
description: Alexandra Beth Certilman was married on Saturday evening to David Victor Kay. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: That Other East End Artists Colony
description: STONY BROOK

title: Atop Vietnamese Noodle Shop, Wars Course Shifted
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  The pho bo, Vietnams traditional beef noodle soup, is tasty at the Pho Binh restaurant, but in truth no better than at other places here. The broth is hearty, the noodles are chewy, the small slices of beef tender even if the accompanying pieces of lime and chili pepper looked a bit tired. The price is right: 22,000 dong, or about $1.30.

title: Long Before Legos, Wood Was Nice and Did Suffice
description: SOMETIMES one great idea is all you get. Take Friedrich Froebel, who, back in the 1830s, convinced that childrens education started too late, founded a play school for younger children (in Blankenburg, Prussia). He named it kindergarten.

title: Sacred Chow
description: One morning, we heard a shriek from the kitchen. Our cook, Saratbhai, came racing to get my mother to view the evidence: my sisters handprint in the curd dish and a line of white plops all the way to the bedroom we shared.

title: Two Cities, Two Besieged Hospitals, Two Startlingly Different Results
description: PATERSON

title: Messages Show Details of French Traders Actions
description: PARIS  A transcript of conversations between Jrme Kerviel, the trader whom Socit Gnrale says cost it nearly $7.2 billion, and a broker at one of the banks subsidiaries suggests that Mr. Kerviel was well aware of the gravity of his actions.

title: Close Indian Point? It Could Be Costly
description: CLOSING the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan could have dire consequences for the countys economy, according to a new report by the Westchester Business Alliance, a coalition of regional groups.

title: Christina Hanson, Nicholas Slimack
description: Christina Elizabeth Hanson and Dr. Nicholas Patrick Slimack were married Saturday at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Karl R. Rodig, a priest of the Ecumenical Catholic Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Correction: The Week Ahead: Feb. 3-9
description: A picture caption with a television entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday omitted the credit. The photograph, of Grand Central Terminal, was taken by Boris Klapwald.

title: Shared Song, Communal Memory
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.

title: You Are What You Spend
description: Dallas

title: The Bag of Tricks Is Almost Empty
description: WASHINGTON

title: Singh Shares Lead, and Mickelson Misses Cut After an 11
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Even as Vijay Singh roared into a tie for the lead with Dudley Hart at nine under par, restoring some sense of order in the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am on Saturday, Phil Mickelson went the other way by missing the cut here for the first time in six years.

title: Meet David Wright, the Real Mr. Met
description: When Brian Schneider was traded to the Mets from the Washington Nationals in November, his first phone call came from the Nationals general manager, Jim Bowden. Then he heard from Omar Minaya, the Mets general manager. Almost immediately after he hung up with Minaya, his cellphone buzzed again. It was a text message from one of his new teammates. Its D-Wright, the message began.

title: Dont Like Taxes? Consider the Alternative
description: EVERY year at tax time, someone is sure to remind us of Benjamin Franklins maxim that nothing is certain but death and taxes. The statement happens to be true, but associating taxes with death adds only to the gloom of the moment. My goal here is to remove some of that gloom.

title: When Pigs Fly
description: TESTED Jeep Grand Cherokee SRT8.

title: Is Sound Tunnel D.O.A. Or Just Decades Away?
description: Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Tasty Morsels on a Limited Menu
description: WITH no real rivals in its path, a hot-orange Dodge muscle car smoked the field at the 2008 Chicago Auto Show.

title: Myanmar Junta Calls for Vote
description: BANGKOK  Myanmars military government on Saturday announced a timetable for what it calls its roadmap to democracy, scheduling a referendum on a proposed constitution for May and elections for 2010.

title: Postpartisan
description: G.O.P. Doubts, Fears Post-Partisan Obama went a Washington Post headline as this election year began. A week before, the Times columnist David Brooks told ABCs George Stephanopoulos about the post partisan independence of John McCain. A week later, Times reporters noted how Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York has spent months laying out his vision for a post-partisan approach to politics that would take the best from left and right.

title: In Dentists Death, Clues Line Up After a Big Break
description: A homemade silencer found lying in some leaves. Bingo.

title: Obama Scores Convincing Wins in Three States
description: Senator Barack Obama won decisive victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Washington, Louisiana and Nebraska on Saturday, giving him an impressive sweep going into a month when the Democratic nominating contests are expected to favor him.

title: The First Ache
description: Twenty-five years ago, when Kanwaljeet Anand was a medical resident in a neonatal intensive care unit, his tiny patients, many of them preterm infants, were often wheeled out of the ward and into an operating room. He soon learned what to expect on their return. The babies came back in terrible shape: their skin was gray, their breathing shallow, their pulses weak. Anand spent hours stabilizing their vital signs, increasing their oxygen supply and administering insulin to balance their blood sugar.

title: Europeans Are From Venus
description: At the time of the World Cup the summer before last, there was a nice cartoon in the papers by Oliphant, with two panels. One showed Soccer as seen by Americans, a group of dainty chaps prancing lightly across the grass with purses dangling from their limp wrists, and the other, American football as seen by Europeans, a heap of brutally moronic humanoids using severed limbs to batter each others brains out.

title: Cape Town Townships
description: To the Editor: Ive been to Cape Town twice, and the highlight of each trip was two days spent touring the townships. They were the most memorable of all of Cape Towns extraordinary sights and experiences but were omitted from your 36 Hours (Jan. 27) itinerary.

title: A League of Their Own
description: AVERAGE apartment sale prices in Manhattan soared last month to the highest levels ever, showing the tenacity and power of the luxury market.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Letters: Minorities for Money?
description: I disagree with the Ethicists advice (Jan. 27) regarding financial incentives for hiring minority candidates. While he is correct that presenting a diversity of backgrounds and viewpoints is an important part of any universitys mission, the financial incentives as described are unethical and possibly illegal. The universitys acceptance of a job application is an implied promise that the candidate will be assessed based on her qualifications for the position, not the interviewers potential financial gains.

title: A Walk on the Wild Side, and Then Some
description: Among the many outrageous works in Person of the Crowd: The Contemporary Art of Flnerie, at the Neuberger Museum of Art, is a photograph of Marina Abramovic, the grandmother of performance art. It is one of a series documenting a performance in which she traded places for four hours with a Dutch prostitute to mark the opening of her 1975 show at a gallery in Amsterdam. The work is called Role Exchange, and in many ways typifies the loopy experimentation of the era, when artists knew no boundaries.

title: Some Killings Dont Get Solved
description: LONDON

title: High End and Front Rank
description: Bedell Cellars first vintage of Muse (Museum) and second of Gallery symbolize its commitment to art, both on walls and in bottles.

title: Coyotes Are Yowling Confidence
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  It has been easy for the Phoenix Coyotes to exceed expectations because they were expected by most of the hockey world to finish last in the N.H.L. this season.

title: Rustic, Cozy and Casual
description: WILD HARVEST, a new restaurant that opened in Glen Cove in mid-December, has a name that makes clear the connection with its four-year-old sibling, Wild Honey in Oyster Bay; both are owned by Tina and Rob OBrien and Zane Smith, who is also the chef.

title: Idol to Be a Theme on Cruises
description: If you think youll need an American Idol fix while the show is on hiatus next fall, heres an idea: take a cruise. Royal Caribbean International has announced that it will offer five cruises with an American Idol theme Nov. 19 through Dec. 21 aboard its newest ship, the Independence of the Seas.

title: A More Intimate Grand Bazaar
description: FORGET the Grand Bazaar. If you want to return from Istanbul with truly memorable souvenirs, head over to the winding streets of Cukurcuma, the citys funky antiques district, where you can get anything from camel saddles to decorative brass faucets from defunct Turkish baths.

title: Look Whos Getting Rolled Out of the Bar
description: THESE days little children are brought along to places that would have been considered inappropriate a generation ago: four-star restaurants, cocktail parties, rock concerts. But for all the sniping from adults who resent this territorial invasion, the onslaught shows no sign of letting up. In fact, one of its latest flash points is the local bar.

title: NATOs Leader Says the Alliance Remains Unified on Troops for Afghan Mission
description: MUNICH  NATO is not devolving into a two-tier alliance of those who fight and those who will not, the alliances secretary general said Saturday at an international security conference.

title: Why Did They Trust Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vonn Ties American Mark
description: Lindsey Vonn won her ninth career World Cup downhill Saturday in Sestriere, Italy, matching the American record set by Picabo Street and Daron Rahlves.The victory propelled Vonn back to the top of the overall World Cup standings, 3 points ahead of Nicole Hosp of Austria. Its awesome, Vonn said. I was superpsyched about that, and I still have more this season, so hopefully I can get another one under my belt.Vonn used a much straighter line than the other skiers to cover the 1.84-mile Kandahar Banchetta course in 1 minute 38.86 seconds. It is the same downhill course the men used at the 2006 Turin Olympics.

title: Andrea Linett and Michael Waring
description: Andrea Lee Linett and Michael Simon Waring were married on Saturday at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in Manhattan. Judge Joseph E. Gubbay of Brooklyn Criminal Court officiated.

title: Washingtonians
description: Former Senator Bob Dole once said the most dangerous place in Washington is between Chuck Schumer and a television camera, as Dana Milbank reminds us in his new book. Today, things are worse. Now there is also the retired diplomat Joe Wilson (Milbank quotes The New Republic: Do not let yourself get between him and a camera, a lectern or a buffet, or you will likely be trampled), the pundit Larry Sabato (a former governor of Virginia, Milbank writes, postulated that the shortest distance between two points is Larry Sabato and a TV camera ) and many others. They belong to the Gang of 500, as Mark Halperin, formerly of ABC News, describes (in Milbanks words) the lawmakers, strategists, journalists and officials who, collectively, define the social order of Potomac Land. And they are the focus of Homo Politicus.

title: In Mexico: A Bus of Women's Own
description: Mexico City has created "Women Only" buses in response to complaints of sexual harassment on public transportation.

title: Brothers in Arms
description: In Queens, two Pakistani newspaper editors are divided by politics and  business. Still, they share a wall - and a friendship.

description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke at the Jefferson-Jackson Dinner in Virginia. (MSNBC Video)

description: Film

title: Spezza Smites the Habs
description: The year was 1999 and I was in Mississauga, Ontario, to see this Jason Spezza everyone was touting as the next Gretzky. He has the vision, theyd say, the sixth sense of the ice. He knows where the plays going.

title: The Battle for Connecticut
description: Our colleague Dave Caldwell takes a look at the intense rivalry in the Nutmeg State: The Hartford Wolfpack vs. the Bridgeport Sound Tigers. Its AHL training for Rangers-Islanders.

title: Introducing Op-Classic
description: This week, the Opinion section introduces Op-Classic, a series presenting commentary from The Times's archive. Every week, we will feature essays by an Op-Ed columnist or contributor that we hope sheds some light on the current news or provides a window on the past.

description: Six cars competed in the first around-the-world race from New York to Paris. Only three made it all the way.

The Party Unfaithful
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Its amazing how quickly things change in politics. I was talking about it this morning with my driver, Mitt Romney.

description: Aired Friday night on NBC: The White House has announced that during President Bushs last year in office, hes going to visit more countries than in any other year of his Presidency. Yeah. Yeah, Bush says hes going to accomplish all of this in one weekend, by going to Epcot Center.

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: His Illegal Self
description: There were no photographs of the boy's father in the house upstate. He had been persona non grata since Christmas 1964, six months before the boy was born. There were plenty of pictures of his mom. There she was with short blond hair, her eyes so white against her tan. And that was her also, with black hair, not even a sister to the blonde girl, although maybe they shared a kind of bright attention.

description: Who Is "Black"?

description: GEORGE W. BUSH: What Went Wrong?

title: Correction
description: A Style article on Jan. 27 about Emi Fontana, a Los Angeles curator and gallerist, misidentified the typeface used in collages by one of the artists, Barbara Kruger, featured in Fontanas new production. It was Futura Bold Italic, not Helvetica.

title: Heroic Conservatism
description: Sometimes in government the most dramatic and noble events come disguised as endless meetings, what might be called the banality of goodness.

title: Comes Apart at the Seams
description: Aired Friday night on CBS: Its Fashion Week in New York City. And everybody in New York gets into Fashion Week. As a matter of fact, Hillary Clinton today was wearing her strapless pantsuit.

title: Avoiding the Deep End
description: TAX season is never pleasant, but this one could have been much worse for many taxpayers. An estimated 20 million Americans were spared additional tax burdens by the Tax Increase Prevention Act of 2007, known less formally as "the A.M.T. patch," signed by President Bush on Dec. 26. The change means that they will escape the alternative minimum tax, though it is still expected to snare more than 4 million other taxpayers.

title: Can We Uninvent Suburbia?
description: Theres a fine story in our Sunday Styles section today by Alex Williams examining the environmental costs of suburban life, which evolved around the highway system, cheap oil, and the automobile and now typically consumes several times more energy per person (and thus fossil fuels) than urban living. Theres all that driving. There are the chugging mowers and fertilizers and pesticides used to keep all those lawns lovely. Lighting, heating and cooling those ballooning homes consumes vast amounts of energy compared to a city apartment  or a house half a century ago.

title: Income and consumption inequality
description: So Cox and Alm have a piece in todays Times arguing that consumption inequality is much less than income inequality, so nothing to worry about.

title: Obama at Jefferson-Jackson Dinner
description: Senator Barack Obama spoke at the Jefferson-Jackson Dinner in Virginia. (MSNBC Video)

title: The Mortgage Fallout Spreads
description: Borrowers with good credit are now facing financial  difficulties as fallout from the mortgage crisis spreads.

title: The Wire, 30 Rock Win WGA Awards
description: The Carpetbagger was at the Writers Guild awards on Saturday night, where the East Coast guild handed out awards for both film and television writing.

title: Egypt 1, Cameroon 0: Egypt, Champions of Africa
description: Look back on commentary of the African Cup final between Egypt and Cameroon by Jeff Z. Klein who described the action in Accra as he watched from African Kine restaurant at W. 116th St. in Harlem.

title: Rangers Turn to Valiquette Again
description: Fresh off two shutout victories at Philadelphia, Rangers backup goalie Steve Valiquette will start for the second straight day as the Rangers play at Washington Sunday afternoon. It gives a rare weekend off to starter Henrik Lundqvist, who has played a bit lately like he needs it.

title: Seatwave Pulls in $25 Million
description: Seatwave, a startup that creates a secondary market for theater, sports and music event tickets in Britain and Europe, is expected to announce on Monday that it has raised $25 million in a series C round of fundraising.

title: Champ Car and IRL to merge?  So what?
description: With all the recent talk about a merger between Champ Car and IRL finally coming about, maybe even for 2008  I ask myself, so what?

title: Early Tea?
description: Ninny that you are, are you waiting breathlessly for the results from the BAFTAs? Tom ONeil did some browsing and found out that even though the event hasnt started, the results, or what look to be the results, are already online.

title: Writers Could Be Back To Work On Wed.
description: On Sunday, the two guilds governing bodies will meet to formally recommend the deal, Michael Cieply reports.

title: Parenting | Mothers and Sons
description: Two mothers keep constant watch over the care of their injured soldier sons.

title: The Guilds Disappointment: Giving Up Animation and Reality
description: While the tentative agreement between the Writers Guild of America and the Hollywood studios is being praised by the unions leaders, it also includes some disappointments for them.

title: Writers May Be Doin It For Themselves
description: If the legacy of the 1988 writers strike was unscripted shows like Cops, the legacy of the 2008 writers strike will be online projects that bypass the Hollywood studios, according to Patric Verrone, the president of the West Coast writers guild.

title: Clinton Campaign Manager Is Out
description: WASHINGTON  Patti Solis Doyle has stepped down as Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign manager, the campaign announced on Sunday.

title: Postmodern recessions
description: Calculated Risk says much of what Id say about housing and the prospects for quick economic recovery. But Id like to offer a bit more analysis.

title: A Photographer's Files
description: Oscar Abolafia worked for Time, People and Life as a celebrity photographer in the 1960s. Here are some of his images.

title: Obama Edges Out a Clinton  For a Grammy
description: Barack Obama, not known for his singing prowess, nevertheless picked up a Grammy Award Sunday for the spoken-word recording of his most recent book, The Audacity of Hope.

title: Down the Rabbit Hole With Chronic Daily Headache
description: When he plunged Alice down the rabbit hole, the author Lewis Carroll was armed with a powerful tool from his own inner life to make his heroines journey all the weirder: migraines. He certainly took advantage of the vision distortions that accompanied his particular spells to make Alice feel as clumsy and disoriented as possible in her far-from-wonderful wonderland.

title: Ask Dana Hadan a Question
description: Dana Hadan, a business student enrolled at the Carnegie Mellon campus in Qatar, is fielding questions on what its like being a student at an overseas branch of an American university.

title: A Shocked Crowd in Buffalo
description: A gruesome accident sent Richard Zednik off the ice bleeding profusely at the Florida-at-Buffalo game Sunday. People sat in stunned silence at the sold-out HSBC Center. Zednik had been cut on the neck by the skate of Florida teammate Olli Jokinen.

title: Spain Horror Story Redux
description: Another expat couple is facing heavy fines and the possible demolition of their home in Spain, after the local government declared it illegal.

title: On to Virginia
description: Sixty-three Republican delegates and 83 Democratic delegates are up for grabs at the Virginia primary on Tuesday. Recent polling shows Senator John McCain with a two-to-one advantage over former Gov. Mike Huckabee, and Senator Barack Obama with a strong lead over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. The poll was conducted Thursday and Friday by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research and included 400 likely Democratic primary voters and 400 likely Republican primary voters.

title: A Calumny a Day To Keep Hillary Away
description: The responses to my column on Hillary Clinton-hating have been both voluminous (the largest number in the brief history of Think Again) and fascinating. The majority of posters agreed with the characterization of the attacks on Senator Clinton as vicious and irrational, but in not a few posts the repudiation of Hillary-hatred is followed by more of the same. Lisa (No. 17) nicely exemplifies the pattern. She begins by saying I agree that there is a rabid nature in the manner in which numerous conservative groups attack Hillary Clinton,, but in the very next sentence she declares that most of Hillarys reputation is well earned and then she spends nine paragraphs being rabid. A significant minority of posters skipped the ritual disavowal of hatred and went straight to the task of adding to it.

title: As Voting Pattern Emerges, So Does Need to Break It
description: Senator Barack Obama scored impressive weekend victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in several Democratic presidential nomination contests. He is well positioned for this weeks voting in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. But neither candidate has achieved what is most important for deciding their battle. That is breaking the pattern of voter preferences that has structured their competition so far.

title: Bill Clinton Takes to the Churches
description: SILVER SPRING, Md.  After losing two caucuses and a primary to Senator Barack Obama Saturday, Senator Hillary Clintons campaign seemed like it might need a prayer. Or two. And so Bill Clinton started off his day of Potomac Primary campaigning with a stop at the Temple of Praise, an African-American church in Washington, DC.

title: Conflict Hurts Kenya's Middle Class
description: Torn between their work identity and their ethnic backgrounds, members of Kenya's vibrant middle class anxiously try to stay in business.

title: Beyond Buckingham Palace: Hip London Style Tours
description: London is a sprawling city, and can be difficult to navigate. The many tour buses that visit all the main sites of interest such as the Tower of London, Buckingham Palace and Houses of Parliament are great for first time visitors.

title: World Club Top 10: Birth of the K.H.L.
description: Most European leagues have been on international break for the last week or thereabouts, so not much change in the Top 10.

title: Tyree Talks About His Rise From Rock Bottom to Super Bowl Stardom
description: The Giants David Tyree spent about 90 minutes with The Times on Saturday morning for an article in Mondays newspaper, and graciously recounted his arrest, his drunken blackouts, his finding faith and his moms death in December. He had just arrived home after taking a red-eye flight from Los Angeles, where he was making the talk-show rounds after making his memorable catch in the Super Bowl. He sat at his kitchen table, surrounded by family preparing for an afternoon baby shower. What follows are some excerpts from the conversation.

title: In Mexico: A Bus of Women's Own
description: Mexico City has created "Women Only" buses in response to complaints of sexual harassment on public transportation.

title: HarperCollins Will Post Free Books on the Web
description: In an attempt to increase book sales, HarperCollins Publishers will begin offering free electronic editions of some of its books on its Web site, including a novel by Paulo Coelho and a cookbook by the Food Network star Robert Irvine.

title: This Weeks Major Business Events
description: COMPANY EARNINGS Some big names will post earnings this week, including Hasbro and Loews (Monday); Credit Suisse, General Motors, Marsh & McLennan, Molson Coors, Omnicom, Qwest Communications, Sanofi-Aventis and Schering-Plough (Tuesday); Belo, Coca-Cola, Deere and Jones Apparel (Wednesday); Clear Channel, Comcast, Daimler, Goodyear Tire & Rubber and UBS (Thursday); and Campbell Soup and Hormel Foods (Friday).

title: John Alvin, Designer of Memorable Film Posters, Is Dead at 59
description: John Alvin, who created memorable images for movie posters, billboards and advertisements, including the two fingers touching above the Earths surface for E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial, died on Wednesday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 59.

title: Nafta Is a Sweet Deal, So Why Are They So Sour?
description: Fourteen years after Nafta came into effect, the last remaining barriers to agricultural trade in North America were dismantled last month. Mexican corn farmers and American Big Sugar hate this unreservedly.

title: Lowery Wins in Playoff After Collapse by Singh
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Steve Lowery came in from the golf wilderness Sunday. Lowery, who was ranked 305th in the world and had not had a PGA Tour victory in the past seven years, rediscovered what it takes to win, birdieing the first hole of sudden death to defeat Vijay Singh in the Pebble Beach National Pro Am.

title: Roy Scheider, Actor in Jaws, Dies at 75
description: Roy Scheider, a stage actor with a background in the classics who became one of the leading figures in the American film renaissance of the 1970s, died on Sunday afternoon in Little Rock, Ark. He was 75 and lived in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Chvez Threatens to End Oil Exports to U.S. in Exxon Feud
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez threatened Sunday to halt oil exports to the United States if the oil giant Exxon Mobil succeeds in freezing billions of dollars of foreign petroleum assets controlled by Venezuela.

title: Army Buried Study Faulting Iraq Planning
description: WASHINGTON  The Army is accustomed to protecting classified information. But when it comes to the planning for the Iraq war, even an unclassified assessment can acquire the status of a state secret.
