title: Train Strikes and Kills a Veteran N.J. Transit Welder
description: A longtime New Jersey Transit track welder was killed when he was hit by a train on Sunday morning near the Ridgewood station, a spokesman for the railroad said.

title: As Toll Dodgers Get Creative, Eyes of E-ZPass Are Watching
description: Cameras photographing cars from just about every imaginable angle. High-speed radio frequency readers instantly scanning E-ZPass tags. Two dozen image review clerks hunched over computers in their cubicles examining thousands of photographs each day, waiting to pounce.

title: U.S. Wonders if Stock Deal Is Tax Abuse
description: A strategy that corporate executives routinely use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Moderator and a Panelist Ousted at Fox News Watch
description: Fox News Watch, one of two weekly television shows that assess the conduct of the national news media, has fired its longtime moderator and let go one of its more liberal panelists.

title: As Voting Pattern Emerges, So Does Need to Break It
description: Senator Barack Obama scored impressive weekend victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in several Democratic presidential nomination contests. He is well positioned for this weeks voting in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. But neither candidate has achieved what is most important for deciding their battle. That is breaking the pattern of voter preferences that has structured their competition so far.

title: Carter Sticks It Out, and So Do Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Vince Carter squinted hard as he dropped back on defense, seemingly not sure he was guarding the right player. He had taken a hard elbow to his jaw, and he did not appear to have regained all five senses.

title: Kenyas Middle Class Feeling Sting of Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  George G. Mbugua is a 42-year-old executive with two cars, a closet full of suits and a good job as the chief financial officer of a growing company.

title: TMZ Catches Tech Whiz in Benign Act
description: Britney, Lindsay, Paris, and ... Mark?

title: Campaign Needed for Minority Candidates for Football Coach
description: Like most of you, Ive been riveted by the presidential race and actually struck by the fact  as I recently told my 90-year-old father  that in our respective lifetimes, an African-American or a woman may be elected president of the United States.

title: Rolling Stones Comment on Drug Use by Others
description: Having been there and done that, a couple of Rolling Stones had a few words of counsel for todays drug-prone young musicians, Reuters reported. In an appearance at the Berlin Film Festival, the guitarist Keith Richards, right, referring to Amy Winehouse, said, She should get her act together. The Stones frontman, Mick Jagger, in speaking about Ms. Winehouse and Pete Doherty, said times were different. Mr. Jagger said: When we were experimenting with drugs, little was known about the effects. In our time there were no rehab centers like today. Anyway, I did not know about them. Now 64, a grandfather and a fitness fanatic, Mr. Jagger said he couldnt understand how the younger generation, knowing the dangers of drugs, could still be users.

title: Would Voting at 16 Be Even Sweeter?
description: To the Editor:

title: President of East Timor Wounded in Rebel Attack
description: President Jos Ramos-Horta of East Timor was shot and seriously wounded Monday, and gunmen attacked a convoy carrying Prime Minister Xanana Gusmo, threatening to further destabilize the struggling young nation.

title: As the Tides Turned: Hollywood in 1967 Through the Lens of Five Films
description: In the same year and even on the same planet, five crazily diverse films became nominees for the Academy Award for best picture in 1967. At its April 1968 ceremony the academy chose among an instant-classic vision of the brand new Generation Gap (The Graduate), a painfully dated Hollywood dinosaur (Guess Whos Coming to Dinner), a fierily innovative, mythic outlaw tale (Bonnie and Clyde), a walking lecture on racial prejudice (In the Heat of the Night) and a budget-busting musical full of animals (Dr. Dolittle). The last of these, stinker that it was, appropriately had to be filmed on sets with drains patrolled by workers wielding brooms.

title: Consumer Product Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: West Gets a Workout in the Deductive Arts
description: Everyone makes mistakes at the bridge table, even experts. Twice I have seen top pairs fail to defeat three no-trump when in the suit led at Trick 1 declarer had a singleton on the board and three to the jack in his hand. Once the defenders blocked the suit; the other time the opening leader shifted at Trick 3.

title: Bush, Breaking Campaign Silence, Offers a Nod to McCain (and Huckabee)
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush broke his silence on the 2008 presidential race on Sunday, giving his imprimatur to Senator John McCain of Arizona as a true conservative, who nonetheless has got some convincing to do to persuade fellow Republicans of his bona fides with the right.

title: How Many More Warnings?
description: Even with families victimized in the Virginia Tech massacre looking on, lawmakers in Virginia lined up like clay pigeons for the gun lobby last month to block legislation that would have closed the states notorious gun-show loophole. That means that anyone  ex-felons and deranged citizens included  can continue to buy firearms at laissez-faire sportsmen shows.

title: Lottery Numbers
Maine to Obama; Clinton Replaces Campaign Leader
description: VIRGINIA BEACH  Senator Barack Obama racked up his fourth decisive victory this weekend, winning the Maine caucuses on Sunday, as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton replaced her campaign manager and longtime aide in the biggest shakeup of her campaign to date.

title: Drawn to the Screen, Big and Small
description: There are times when a heavy diet of one medium means less of another. For example, teenagers who play the video game Halo 3 are most likely to do so just before prime time, meaning they watch less television than the average teenager. One might imagine, similarly, that teenage moviegoers would see less television than their more movie-averse peers.

title: And the Grammy Award for Best Polka Record Goes To...
description: Record of the Year: Rehab, Amy Winehouse

title: In Britain, a Campaign Against Obesity Is Snarled in Controversy
description: LONDON  The campaign against AIDS has its red ribbons. The movement against poverty has its white wristbands. And if the advertising industry has its way, the effort to curb obesity may soon get its own instantly recognizable symbol.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: David Barrington joined the North American operations of MPG, New York, part of Havas, in a new post, executive vice president and managing director for video investments. He had most recently been the senior vice president and general sales manager at My Network TV, part of the News Corporation.

title: Committee Chairman Criticizes Clemenss Lawyer Over Remarks
description: The chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform criticized one of Roger Clemenss lawyers Sunday for remarks he had made about a federal agents plan to attend a committee hearing Wednesday.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Microsoft Signals Fight for Yahoo Isnt Over
description: Yahoo officially rejected Microsofts $44.6 billion takeover offer on Monday, calling the bid too low, but Microsoft appeared to signal that it was gearing up for a long acquisition fight.

title: Threat to Campus Reactors Cited
description: WASHINGTON  The risk of a terrorist attack on a nuclear research reactor on a college campus, and the potential consequences, have been underestimated by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, according to Congressional auditors.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: HSBC Is Expected to Sell 400 Banks
description: LONDON  HSBC Holdings, the biggest bank in Europe, plans to put about half of its 800 French consumer branches up for sale as it focuses on expanding in Asia and other emerging markets, a person with direct knowledge of the plan confirmed on Sunday.

title: Tug of War Over Undecided Virginia Democrats
description: LEXINGTON, Va.  With less than 24 hours to decide, Priscilla Baker remained torn between voting for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama in the Democratic presidential primary here on Tuesday.

title: L.I. Hospital Scrutinized After Deaths of Patients
description: Last spring, doctors at Mercy Medical Center on Long Island gave a patient the news she had feared: Cancer had been detected in her left breast.

title: Restoring Luster to Two 20th-Century Dance Legends
description: This year brings the centenaries of the births of two choreographers who loomed large in New York in the middle of the last century: Jos Limn, who died in 1972, and Antony Tudor, who died in 1987. Theirs are once-big names whose legacies seem to be shrinking. Plenty of todays dancegoers have never seen a single work by either. Special thanks, then, to the enterprising New York Theater Ballet last weekend for giving New York what I believe are the years first staged revivals of either mans work.

title: Houstons Hip-Hop Scene Picks Up the Pieces After Yet Another Death
description: HOUSTON  On Friday night here at Warehouse Live, 48 hours and 1,500 miles from the Grammy Awards, more than a thousand fans gathered for a different sort of musical celebration.

title: Hope Later
description: The Bush administration was too slow to wake up to the foreclosure crisis. Now its asking Congress for more time to show results through Hope Now, a mortgage industry alliance created at the urging of the Treasury Department. Given the administrations poor record on the issue, lawmakers should not wait to pass their own foreclosure prevention plans. Most important is amending bankruptcy law to allow defaulting borrowers to modify the terms of their mortgages under court protection.

title: Star-Crossed Lovers Caught in an Unenlightened Era
description: Oroonoko, which opened Sunday night at the Duke on 42nd Street, is a disappointment onstage, maybe in part because it sounded so intriguing on paper.

title: Between States, Hard Feelings Over a Rocks Place
description: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio

title: Good Days Have Arrived, but Bad Times Have a Say
description: Better late than never: for reasons alluded to in Before the Money Came (The Battle of Bettye LaVette), her career-summarizing personal anthem of bad luck, hard times and ultimate triumph, the 62-year-old Detroit soul singer Bettye LaVette is only now receiving the kind of recognition she should have enjoyed 40 years ago.

title: Bush Calls McCain a True Conservative
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush broke his silence on the 2008 presidential race on Sunday, giving his imprimatur to Senator John McCain of Arizona as a true conservative, who nonetheless has got some convincing to do to persuade fellow Republicans of his right-wing bona fides.

title: Unworthy Nominees
description: President Bush staged an event in the East Room last week for his unconfirmed appointees and repeated a story line so tired that its hard to imagine even he believes it. His nominations  of judges, top Justice Department officials and others  are stalled, he said, because of undue Senate delay. The real problem, of course, is that 15 months after American voters put the Democrats in control of the Senate, Mr. Bush is still trying to muscle far-right ideologues with troubling records into important positions.

title: On Single-Sex Buses, Relief From Unwanted Contact
description: MEXICO CITY  Body-to-body contact is inescapable on Mexico Citys crowded public transportation system. Get on a train or a bus during rush hour and a man in a business suit may have his arm resting against your shoulder, a woman toting a bulky shopping bag may have her back pressed against your flank, and a teenager listening to an iPod may tap his sneaker all over your newly shined left shoe.

title: No Manchurian Candidate
description: I believe Barack Obama is a strong but not uncritical supporter of Israel. That is what the Middle East needs from an American leader: the balance implicit in a two-state solution.

title: The Do-Not-Call List
description: To the Editor:

title: Trading Pinstripes for Politics
description: Youve been dating the same person for years. Shes not flashy, but she is steady and, to your mind, glorious. And then you begin to notice changes. A slimmer profile, a suddenly increased concern with appearances. You keep your suspicions to yourself, but it soon becomes obvious that everything is changing. And you finally just blurt it out.

title: Feisty Birds of a Feather, No Chickens in Sight
description: Every workplace has someone like Rachel, an employee who beams with false confidence, broadcasts her talents and puts her own advancement ahead of teamwork. The Rachels of the world give themselves pep talks like this one: You have to be able to look in the mirror and say, Im worth a thousand for half an hour, Im worth $10,000 for a half an hour, Im worth whatever.

title: Keeping a Faun, a Scamp and a Firebird in Line
description: Marin Alsops motley program with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening told several colorful tales, evoking the ill-fated scamp of Strausss Till Eulenspiegel and the exotic protagonists of Debussys Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun and Stravinskys Firebird Suite. But it only hinted at the tale that some listeners were most curious about: how Ms. Alsops relationship with the orchestra is faring.

title: Proportion of Immigrants in U.S. Rises
description: If present trends continue, within two decades the proportion of immigrants in the United States will surpass the peak reached more than a century ago, a new analysis concludes.

title: Rebels With Instruments: Dashing Tradition, Sort Of
description: Hey, Johnny, what are you rebelling against? The question was posed to a leather-jacketed biker tough played by Marlon Brando in the 1953 film The Wild One. His response is now legend: Whaddya got? The lines effectively defined an American type: the rough-hewn iconoclast with no use for the rules of polite (read: uptight) society.

title: For McCain, Losses Signal Challenges
description: Just as Senator John McCain appeared poised to become the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, he was reminded over the weekend that many Republican voters still have not climbed aboard his bandwagon.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A caption on Thursday with a photograph of a home in Israel hit by a Palestinian rocket described the events surrounding the attack imprecisely. While the rocket attack followed an Israeli airstrike in southern Gaza, it was not known whether it was in fact in retaliation for the airstrike.

title: In This Election, Its Running Cats and Dogs
Energy Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Astronauts Attach Science Module to Space Station
description: WASHINGTON  Two astronauts and a robot arm on Monday guided Europes new Columbus science module out of the space shuttle Atlantis to become a permanent part of the International Space Station.

title: Car Bombing Outside Market in Iraq Kills 23
description: BAGHDAD  At least 23 people were killed Sunday after a car bomb exploded north of Baghdad at a checkpoint run by the police and citizen patrols of Iraqis who have turned against the insurgency, Iraqi officials said.

title: G.I. Gets 10-Year Sentence in Killing of Unarmed Iraqi
description: CAMP LIBERTY, Iraq  A military panel on Sunday sentenced an Army soldier to 10 years in prison for killing an unarmed Iraqi detainee and planting a machine gun near his body to mislead investigators.

title: A CBS Newsmans Serenade: Give My Regards to Mr. Redstone
description: Two singers who owe their success, in part, to the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone paid tribute to him at a gala given in his honor last week in New York by the Paley Center for Media. One, Tony Bennett, the 81-year-old singer, sang Fly Me to the Moon and thanked Mr. Redstone for changing the path of his career.

title: Tiny Cellphone Chip Aims to Improve Sound Quality
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A Silicon Valley start-up company that has modeled the function of the human ear plans on Monday to introduce an integrated circuit intended to improve the sound quality of cellphones.

title: High Lead Levels Are Found in Vinyl Plastic Baby Products
description: High levels of lead were found in a handful of well-known baby products made of vinyl plastic by an environmental group based in California that spread the word about lead on vinyl baby bibs and lunchboxes.

title: That Book About the Patriots Perfect Season Ended With a Giant Asterisk
description: Talk about premature congratulation: The Boston Globe had planned to run a supplement marking a big Super Bowl win for the New England Patriots in its Feb. 4 issue. Instead the paper carried the forlorn front-page headline History Derailed.

title: An Absence of Scoring Leaves Jagr Cringing
description: The grimace has become so common now, the total disgust that consumes Jaromir Jagrs face when another shot lands harmlessly in a goaltenders pads. It is a look of pain and frustration that grows more acute as the Rangers season sputters along, with Jagr, their captain, wearing its effects for all to see.

title: Highlights Showed a Hard Worker
description: David Tyrees road to the N.F.L. was nearly as improbable as his remarkable catch in the Super Bowl. Coming out of Syracuse in 2003, his numbers  6 feet 1 inch, 197 pounds, 4.5 speed in the 40 and only 36 catches his senior season  did not appear to be N.F.L. material.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,947 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

title: Film Prize Winners
description: The Juno script by Diablo Cody, below, won the prize for original screenplay when the Writers Guild of America announced its awards on Saturday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. The accolade for adapted screenplay went to the brothers Ethan and Joel Coen for No Country for Old Men. ... Ratatouille won best feature production and received nine other Annie Awards, honoring achievements in feature film and television animation, at an International Animated Film Society ceremony in Los Angeles on Friday, The Associated Press reported. ... The London Film Critics Circle named No Country for Old Men film of the year, the BBC reported. Honors for best actor went to Daniel Day-Lewis for There Will Be Blood and for best actress to Marion Cotillard for La Vie en Rose.

title: Ex-Washington Post Reporter to Lead a Rival
description: WASHINGTON  For more than 25 years, The Washington Times has positioned itself against its more liberal cross-town rival, The Washington Post.

title: After Strike, TV Shows Hurry Up and Wait
description: The switch that controls the television business is expected to be flicked on all the way early this week, initiating a flurry of activity that may begin to restore the regularly scheduled programming interrupted when the writers strike shut down major parts of the television season.

title: NBC News in Orbit
description: Network newscasts have been known to go to great lengths to find new viewers, but the NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams has taken that search to a place where few, if any, anchors, have gone before: outer space. In an interview from the International Space Station on Friday via satellite, an American astronaut, Daniel M. Tani, right, said he and his crew members actually watch the NBC Nightly News. Mr. Tani was responding to a question from an NBC correspondent, Tom Costello, about how the space station crew stays current on world events. The network said that Mr. Costello had been unaware that NASA regularly transmits podcasts of Nightly News (minus commercials) to the space station. The astronauts also receive news updates from The Houston Chronicle, one of NASAs hometown newspapers. Brett Holey, director of Nightly News, said NBC began making the program available to the space station in early 2006. It did so, he said, after a psychological support scientist for NASA suggested the transmission as a way to ease isolation.

title: How Sticky Is Membership on Facebook? Just Try Breaking Free
description: Are you a member of Facebook.com? You may have a lifetime contract.

title: Wide BlackBerry Outage Reported
description: OTTAWA  For the second time in less than a year, a technical failure idled the thumbs of many BlackBerry users on Monday by severing their wireless link to e-mail and the Web.

title: Top Dogs Live On, and On, in Progeny
description: Mick is a retired elite athlete whose libidinous talents were once so coveted that well-bred ovulating females flew to his crib near Sacramento in the fervent hope that their assignations would make them pregnant.

title: Rangers Have the Chances, but Not the Result
description: WASHINGTON  For one stomach-dropping moment, Rangers goaltender Steve Valiquette watched Sundays game turn right in front of him. Washington defenseman Mike Green wound up for a slap shot on a power play in overtime, a shot that Valiquette saw but was left helpless to stop as it ricocheted off one of his teammates, defenseman Marc Staal, and sailed past him.

title: Israeli Officials Seek Tougher Military Action in Gaza After Rockets Wound 2 in Sderot
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli cabinet ministers on Sunday urged sharper military action in Gaza after a rocket attack by Palestinian militants the night before seriously wounded two brothers, ages 8 and 19, in the town of Sderot on the Israeli border.

title: Egyptian Court Allows Return to Christianity
description: CAIRO  Cairos highest civil court on Saturday ruled that 12 Christians who had converted to Islam could return to their original church, ending a bitter yearlong battle over identity and minority rights.

title: Families Adopting in Vietnam Say They Are Caught in Diplomatic Jam
description: WASHINGTON  Eyes like black pearls, the softest skin and little tufts of hair made it totally easy to fall in love at first sight. And that is what Julie Carroll  and Jewel McRoberts and Tommi-Lynn Sawyer  did when they saw the three tiny girls at a Vietnamese orphanage. They adopted the babies after months of waiting and then had to leave them behind because they could not obtain entry visas to bring them back to the United States.

title: Hedge Fund Group Increases Stake in Times Co.
description: The coalition of hedge funds that wants to place directors on the board of The New York Times Company has more than doubled its stake in the company, to at least 9.96 percent of the regular shares, according to federal records filed Monday.

title: Two Picasso Oils Stolen in Switzerland
description: Two Picasso oils valued at $4.5 million were stolen last week from a Swiss museum in Pfaeffikon, Agence France-Presse reported. The paintings, the 1962 Tte de Cheval (Horses Head) and the 1944 Verre et Pichet (Glass and Pitcher), were on loan from the Sprengel Museum in Hanover, Germany. The police theorized that the thieves, who touched off an alarm when leaving at 7 p.m., may have remained in the museum after it closed.

title: U.S. Ties Europes Safety to Afghanistan
description: MUNICH  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates issued a stark warning on Sunday to Europeans, saying that their safety from terrorist attack by Islamic extremists was directly linked to NATOs success in stabilizing Afghanistan.

title: Israels Secret Success
description: Jerusalem

title: Court Rebuffs Fisk University
description: Fisk University in Nashville suffered a setback in its efforts to ease its financial problems when a judge rejected on Friday its proposal to raise $30 million by sharing its Alfred Stieglitz Collection of modern art with the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, founded in Bentonville, Ark., by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice L. Walton, The Associated Press reported. Davidson County Chancellor Ellen Hobbs Lyle ruled that such an arrangement would not reflect the wishes of the artist Georgia OKeeffe, who donated the 101-piece collection to Fisk, a historically black university, in 1949. A trial scheduled for Feb. 19 will determine if Fisk should forfeit the collection to the Georgia OKeeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Footnotes
description: A Nicole Kidman swimsuit, abandoned at a Swedish pool, sold in Sweden at an auction for charity on Saturday for $2,500, enough to buy nine cows for poor families in India, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Two books are to be named winners of the 2008 Lincoln Prize for American history on Monday. The winners were The Radical and the Republican: Frederick Douglass, Abraham Lincoln, and the Triumph of Antislavery Politics (W. W. Norton) by James Oakes, a professor at City University of New York, and Reading the Man: A Portrait of Robert E. Lee Through His Private Letters (Viking) by the diplomat and historian Elizabeth Brown Pryor. Each author is to receive a $20,000 cash award and a bronze cast of an Augustus Saint-Gaudens sculpture of Lincoln.

title: The Auction of Getty Images Appears to Be Stalled
description: The auction of Getty Images, the distributor of pictures and video, appears to be in jeopardy, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

title: Inspired by America, Then Brought Onto the Stage
description: The New York City Ballets American Songs and Dances is an odd collection of dances. The program, seen on Saturday night at the New York State Theater, should have been much more fun and thought-provoking.

title: Many Obstacles to Digital TV Reception, Study Says
description: Nearly six million people with digital receivers may still lose TV signals when digital-only broadcasts begin next February, a new study says.

title: Theory Gains That Trader Had a Helper
description: PARIS  The police investigating the trading scandal at Socit Gnrale were moving on Sunday toward a theory that its rogue trader, whom the bank blames for losing it nearly $7.2 billion, might not have acted alone, as he and the bank have claimed.

title: Ivy Leaguer Is Intense Enough for Two Sports
description: The Columbia senior John Baumann was already known as Hard Hat and Mr. Saturday Night before Navy Coach Billy Lange added another name to the list. Lange was watching a tape of the Lions basketball team, admiring Baumanns intensity, and could not resist calling Columbia Coach Joe Jones multiple times. With each call, Lange grew more excited.

title: This Years Awards: Yesterday, Once More
description: The Grammy Awards hit 50, and looked older, on Sundays broadcast. Always distrustful of the noisy youth music that has sustained the business, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences went out of its way to let the air out of this years show.

title: Putting Candidates Under the Videoscope
description: One late night last November, Mitt Romney, campaigning in Greenville, S.C., was approached by three young women in bright matching outfits looking for a hug. Mr. Romney, thinking they were cheerleaders from nearby Clemson University, obliged.

title: After the Writers Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  It is not quite peace that has broken out here in Hollywood. But emotions are finally settling down in the entertainment industrys bubbling cauldron of labor disputes. This calm holds the promise of three years without strike threats, picket lines and the loss of Americans favorite television shows.

title: Scientists Find New Receptor for H.I.V.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Government scientists have discovered a new way that H.I.V. attacks human cells, an advance that could provide fresh avenues for the development of additional therapies to stop AIDS, they reported on Sunday.

title: Yahoo Bidder Wants a More Aggressive Microsoft
description: When Yahoo sends its letter rejecting Microsofts $44.6 billion on Monday, it will end up in the inbox of a largely unknown executive on Microsofts sprawling campus, Christopher P. Liddell.

title: Hate Springs Eternal
description: In 1956 Adlai Stevenson, running against Dwight Eisenhower, tried to make the political style of his opponents vice president, a man by the name of Richard Nixon, an issue. The nation, he warned, was in danger of becoming a land of slander and scare; the land of sly innuendo, the poison pen, the anonymous phone call and hustling, pushing, shoving; the land of smash and grab and anything to win. This is Nixonland.

title: Amy Winehouse Wins Big at Grammy Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  Amy Winehouse, the troubled British soul singer with the darkly self-referential hit Rehab, failed to attend Sundays 50th annual Grammy Awards in person, but she proved a dominating figure nonetheless, picking up five trophies as voters kept her in a tight competition with the rap star Kanye West.

title: Obamas Path to Victory
description: Last summer, George W. Bush told The Washington Examiners Bill Sammon that Hillary Clinton would probably be the 2008 Democratic nominee. Shes got a national presence and this is becoming a national primary, he said. And therefore the person with the national presence who has got the ability to raise enough money to sustain an effort in a multiplicity of sites has got a good chance to be nominated.

title: Hillary Clinton as the Fashion Police: My Polka-Dot Dress Should Be Arrested
description: In almost two decades on and off the campaign trail, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has weathered criticisms of her hair, her clothes and even a hint of cleavage. Last week, she decided to join the ranks of her own fashion police.

title: Soccer as an Escape to Hope for Afghan Teenager
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J.  In world religion class, Shamila Kohestani is neither the adolescent who defied the Taliban in Afghanistan nor the symbol of liberation that shared the stage with stars from Hollywood and sports at the 2006 ESPY Awards. She is a teenager whose lips move as she takes notes, and whose list of words to look up grows exponentially each minute, each hour and each day.

title: Isle-Hopping and Other Musical Jaunts
description: Foreign instruments, timbres and rhythms have long provided inspiration for classical musicians. The Silk Road Ensemble and composers including Osvaldo Golijov regularly demonstrate the fascinating results of adventurous border hopping. Other multicultural musical experiments serve as a reminder that cross-cultural relationships can be tense.

title: A Parallel Musical Universe, Forged in South America
description: When the historical progression from Haydn to Mahler began to run out of options at the end of the 19th century, composers could either follow new trains of thought issuing from old ideas, or else declare bankruptcy and start all over again. For better or worse Schoenberg, Elliott Carter and the like have led classical music along a rational path into a smaller, perhaps finer world. A separation of the classes has been ensured: a knowing listening elite kept at a distance from an all-inclusive, less discriminating populace at large.

title: New Shuttle Team Ready for Walk After Days Delay
description: WASHINGTON  Astronauts aboard the International Space Station spent Sunday moving supplies from the shuttle Atlantis and preparing for a spacewalk delayed by the illness of a German astronaut.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about the results of the Democratic primaries in New Jersey and Connecticut referred incorrectly to Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate and a supporter of Senator Barack Obama. He is not chairman of Mr. Obamas campaign in New Jersey. (That post is shared by two mayors, Cory Booker of Newark and Jerramiah T. Healy of Jersey City.) Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the position held by Lowell P. Weicker, the Connecticut Republican, in 1992, the year that Connecticut voters chose Jerry Brown, the long-shot candidate from California, in the Democratic primary. At the time, Mr. Weicker was governor of Connecticut, not its senator.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A caption on Thursday with a photograph of a home in Israel hit by a Palestinian rocket described the events surrounding the attack imprecisely. While the rocket attack followed an Israeli airstrike in southern Gaza, it was not known whether it was in fact in retaliation for the airstrike.

title: Attacks Pushing Darfur Refugees Into Chad
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Thousands of refugees fleeing attacks by Arab militias and Sudanese Army bombs in the ravaged western region of Darfur have flooded into neighboring Chad, the United Nations said Sunday, and many more may be on their way as Sudan strikes back at a rebel offensive in the area.

title: Corzine Drops Route 440 From Toll Plan
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Gov. Jon S. Corzine said Sunday that he would drop his proposal to turn a portion of Route 440 in Middlesex County into a toll road as part of his multibillion dollar package to restructure the states wobbly finances.

title: 2 Celebrity Magazines Buck Circulation Trend
description: Sales of US Weekly and a new competitor, OK! Weekly, climbed sharply in the second half of 2007, even as a round of price increases contributed to an unusual drop in overall sales of celebrity magazines, according to a report released Monday.

title: Coveted Quarterback Looks to Thrive on Next Level
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Autographed photographs of Matt Leinart and Colt Brennan hang on the wall in Bruce Rollinsons office at Mater Dei High School.

title: In Oil-Rich Mideast, Shades of the Ivy League
description: DOHA, Qatar  On a hot October evening, hundreds of families flocked to the sumptuous Ritz Carlton here in this Persian Gulf capital for an unusual college fair, the Education City roadshow.

title: U.S. Seeking Execution for 6 in Sept. 11 Case
description: Military prosecutors have decided to seek the death penalty for six Guantnamo detainees who are to be charged with central roles in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, government officials who have been briefed on the charges said Sunday.

title: Speechless Actors Roam London Stage
description: In a play new to the National Theater in London, 27 actors perform for 90 minutes without uttering a word. The attraction is The Hour We Knew Nothing of Each Other, a 1992 work by the Austrian playwright Peter Handke. The script has 60 pages of stage directions and no dialogue, although there are bangs, crashes, screams and laughter, The Independent of London reported. Mr. Handke said that the idea came to him in the 1980s when he found dramatic meaning in the comings and goings in a town square near Trieste, Italy. Is there much to discover in it? he said of his play. I dont know.

title: A Caribbean Corner of Brooklyn, Fighting to Survive
description: Inside the red brick shoe box that is the Moore Street Retail Market lies a tiny patch of Latin America. The stalls of this Brooklyn public market on the edge of Williamsburg explode with Caribbean colors and sounds, as local shoppers buy everything from yams and peppers to maracas and mystic potions.

title: New CDs
description: LAURA MARLING Alas, I Cannot Swim (Virgin UK)

title: Discovering Second Acts in Sustained Working Lives
description: Marc Freedman has become the voice of aging baby boomers who are eschewing retirement for what he calls encore careers, long periods of meaningful and sustaining work later in life. Mr. Freedman, who was one of the founders of Experience Corps, now runs Civic Ventures, an incubator of programs and ideas to redefine the second half of life. One of those programs, the Purpose Prize, gives monetary awards to entrepreneurial innovators over the age of 60 who have contributed to the social good.

title: For an Era of Twins, the End May Be Near
description: Walk around the Upper West Side with a double stroller, as I do from time to time, and its amazing how long it can take to make it to Fairway. An older gentleman wants to know whether there were twins in the family. A middle-aged woman needs to stop and list every pair of twins shes come to know in a five-block radius. There are many, many, many young twins in that five-block radius. The listing of them takes a long time. There are twins on 72nd Street and two sets in her building alone and girl twins on the corner and boy twins she always sees at the Starbucks ... Is it something in the water?

title: Campaign Focus Shifts to Chesapeake Bay Region
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain were decidedly upbeat in separate appearances on Monday, as both parties prepared for Tuesdays primary contests in the Chesapeake Bay region.

title: Winter Storms Squeeze Supplies of Road Salt
description: Local governments in New England and in the Midwest are running critically low on road salt, the result of a stream of winter weather that has hit the regions in recent months.

title: U.S. Charges 6 With Key Roles in 9/11 Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  Six Guantnamo detainees who are accused of central roles in the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, will be shown all the evidence against them and will be afforded the same rights as American soldiers accused of crimes, the Pentagon said Monday as it announced the charges against them.

title: As Latest Skid Ends, Knicks Find Hope
description: As their latest serial nightmare faded late Saturday night, the Knicks stood, bounced and cheered. The bench, so often filled with sleepy stares and bowed heads, was empty.

title: Spitzer Quickly Reduces Revenue Projections, Citing the Gloomy Economy
description: Only three weeks after presenting its budget, Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration is lowering projections for tax revenue by $384 million, because of increasingly ominous reports of distress on Wall Street and in the nations economy.

title: A Return to Thrift
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Remains Optimistic on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The White House predicted on Monday that the economy would escape a recession and that unemployment would remain low this year, though it acknowledged that growth had already slowed sharply.

title: Brunos Activities Give Pause to Ethics School
description: ALBANY  The federal investigation of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, is weighing on a Connecticut school dedicated to teaching ethics.

title: The Bush Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: The Super Bowl Spotlight Shines on a Changed Man
description: WAYNE, N.J.  The walls of the jail cell were built from stone, providing the perfect place for David Tyree to hit rock bottom. Arrested for drug possession after the police found half a pound of marijuana in his car, caged between stone walls and steel bars, Tyree covered his face with his hands.

title: Fools Gold Earns Real Money
description: Fools Gold (Warner Brothers), the action-romance-comedy starring Kate Hudson and Matthew McConaughey, right, captured the No. 1 weekend ranking at North American box offices by grossing an estimated $22 million in its debut, the tracking company Media by Numbers reported. Another new film, Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins (Universal), a comedy starring Martin Lawrence as a talk-show host visiting his relatives down South, took second place by drawing $17.1 million. Last weeks No. 1 film, Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (Disney) dropped to third place with a take of $10.5 million while averaging $15,295 per screen, more than twice as much as Fools Gold. Last weeks second-place film, The Eye (Lionsgate and Paramount Vantage), slid to fourth, pulling in $6.6 million. Continuing to climb, Juno (Fox Searchlight) moved up a notch, taking fifth place with $5.7 million for a total of $117.6 million in 10 weeks. The Paris Hilton vehicle The Hottie & the Nottie (Regent Releasing) amassed $25,500 in tickets sales at 111 locations. The site calculated that based on an $8 average ticket price, 29 paying customers showed up at each location over the three weekend days.

title: You Cant Keep That Carrot in Your Ear, Mr. Stubborn
description: Roger Hargreaves is the one of the best-selling authors in Britain. The son of a Yorkshire laundryman, Mr. Hargreaves aspired to be a cartoonist but did not find his way there until 1971, when his young son, Adam, asked him what a tickle looked like. Mr. Hargreaves responded by drawing an orange blob with friendly features and extremely long arms. Mr. Tickle, the hero of a colorful book for preschoolers and early readers, was born.

title: 2008 Grammy Awards
description: Photos of winners and presenters at this year's awards.

title: A Diaspora Through Dance
description: The choreographer Ronald K. Brown and his dance troupe examine the African Diaspora through movement.

title: They Were All in San Diego
description: More of your late night comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: Der Mann in Schwarz
description: I Walk the Line in German:

title: It Takes a Pantsuit
description: US Weekly has Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons own picks of her all-time worst outfits, Mondays Times reports:

title: Moderator and a Panelist Ousted at Fox News Watch
description: Fox News Watch, one of two weekly television shows that assess the conduct of the national news media, has fired its longtime moderator and let go one of its more liberal panelists.

title: Resolution Makes Actors Strike Less Likely
description: It is not quite peace that has broken out here in Hollywood. But emotions are finally settling down in the entertainment industrys bubbling cauldron of labor disputes, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report.

title: Yahoo Said to Be Restarting Talks With AOL
description: Yahoo is seeking to restart merger talks with AOL as a means of defending itself against Microsofts unsolicited $44.6 billion bid, according to the Times of London.

title: U.S. Wonders if Stock Deal Is Tax Abuse
description: A strategy that corporate executives routinely use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Credit Suisse Expected to Dodge Subprime Woes
description: The Credit Suisse Group is earning more than UBS for the first time in almost a decade after it avoided the write-downs that forced UBS to report the biggest-ever quarterly loss by a bank, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Harbinger Injects $100 Million into TerreStar
description: A hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, is teaming up with EchoStar and other investors to inject $300 million into TerreStar to help develop a land and satellite mobile broadband communications network.

title: Tamping Down SocGen Chatter, HSBC Is Expected to Sell 400 Banks
description: HSBC, the biggest bank in Europe, plans to put about half of its 800 French consumer branches up for sale as it focuses on expanding in Asia and other emerging markets, according to press reports.

title: V.C.s Cut $12 Million Check fo Cellfire
description: A mobile phone coupon company Cellfire has raised $12 million in a third round of funding. The round includes a new investor, Silver Creek Ventures, and existing ones, including Menlo Ventures and Storm Ventures.

title: V.C.s Shower Suniva With Cash
description: A solar cell maker, Suniva, has raised $50 million in its second round of funding to be used for a new manufacturing facility near Atlanta. The financing was led by New Enterprise Associates and Advanced Equities.

title: Hedge Funds Reverse Position
description: If hedge funds are, as is often claimed, the investment vanguard, their latest moves appear to be telling financial markets it is time to take a break from the trading patterns that have dominated since mid-2007.

title: Sale of Retailer Hits Legal Snag
description: The co-founder of Active Endeavors, an upscale clothing retailer, and two other investors who are owed $936,200 apparently have blocked, at least temporarily, the sale of the company.

title: As Yahoo Balks, Microsoft Plots Next Move
description: When Yahoo sends its letter rejecting Microsofts $44.6 billion on Monday, it will end up in the inbox of a largely unknown executive on Microsofts sprawling campus, Christopher P. Liddell.

title: Overseas Funds Resist Calls for a Code of Conduct
description: Last year, as governments in Asia and the Middle East started to buy stakes in financial institutions in the West, the Bush administration called for an international code of conduct by sovereign wealth funds. The purpose was to get the funds to disclose more of their activities and not play politics with their investments.

title: At Macquarie, a Dealmaker Takes the Helm
description: Smart, tough and above all a dealmaker, the Macquarie Groups new chief executive, Nicholas Moore, draws plaudits befitting the head of a global investment bank.

title: Upstart Exchange Said to Eye Archipelago Founder for Top Post
description: Building up its arsenal before facing off against the CME Group, an upstart and still unnamed electronic futures exchange backed by a dozen financial players is considering Archipelago founder Jerry Putnam for its chief executive, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Should the Giants Trade Shockey?
description: Ernie Accorsi and then Jerry Reese made enough wise decisions to give the Giants a chance to win the Super Bowl. Now Reese must continue to make sound choices for an opportunity to repeat. One of those decisions has a name: Jeremy Shockey.

title: German Bank Gets $7.2 Billion Bailout
description: WestLB, a state-owned German bank, said Friday that it would reduce its work force by 25 percent and receive 5 billion euros ($7.2 billion) from its owners to cover losses tied to bad trades and the subprime mortgage market.

title: Nucor Goes to Scrap Heap for $1.4 Billion Deal
description: A steel producer, the Nucor Corporation, is buying one of the biggest scrap metal companies in the United States for $1.44 billion.

title: Milberg Case Alters Class Action Landscape
description: As the famed class-action lawyer William S. Lerach steps before a federal judge in Los Angeles on Monday to learn his sentence in a wide-ranging fraud and conspiracy probe, his misdeeds and those of his former colleagues might be helping to alter the way securities law is practiced, according to The Los Angeles Times.

title: IAC Streamlines M&A Division
description: As the courts sort out a struggle for control of IAC/InterActiveCorp and its planned five-piece breakup, the company has reshuffled its in-house dealmakers.

title: Dogged by the Media
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Getty Images Auction Appears to Be Stalled
description: The auction of Getty Images, the distributor of pictures and video, appears to be in jeopardy, The New York Times reported Monday.

title: TheStreet Sets Up Shop on MainStreet.com
description: After getting a $55 million injection from Technology Crossover Ventures last November, TheStreet.com is using some of that cash to roll out mainstreet.com today in a bid to expand beyond its pure-play financial focus and add celebrity news with a personal finance angle.

title: Air Canada Attracts Buyout Interest
description: Air Canadas depressed share price might put it in play for privatization or partnership with a carrier in the United States, the airlines parent company, ACE Aviation Holdings, said Friday.

title: SocGen Launches Rights Issue At Deep Discount
description: Socit Gnrale, the French bank reeling from a rogue trading scandal, started a rights issue at a steep discount on Monday, intending to raise 5.5 billion euros ($7.97 billion) to bolster its balance sheet.

title: Theory Gains That Trader Had a Helper
description: The police investigating the trading scandal at Socit Gnrale were moving on Sunday toward a theory that its rogue trader, whom the bank blames for losing it nearly $7.2 billion, might not have acted alone, as he and the bank have claimed, The New York Times reported.

title: Atonement Gets a Turn in Jolly Old England
description: At last nights Orange British Academy Film Awards, otherwise known as the BAFTAs, Atonement won best picture, the Coens won best director(s), Javier Bardem and Daniel Day-Lewis assumed their usual positions. But there were a few curves in the womens category, with best lead going to Marion Cotillard for inhabiting the character of Edith Piaf in La Vie en Rose and best supporting going to British actress Tilda Swinton for her riveting portrayal of an American businesswoman with a taste for lethal solutions in Michael Clayton. Diablo Cody picked up another chit for conceiving Juno, while the adapted category went to Ronald Harwood for The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.

title: The Men Behind Clark Kent: A Tribute to Jewish Cartoonists
description: By Robert P. Walzer

title: Can These Girls Talk, or What?
description: The Bagger is not a huge podcast fan  theyre not searchable, for one thing, and its pretty obvious, listening to them, why most of the writers being recorded type for a living. But he made an exception for the gab session between Tom ONeil, he of the Gold Derby, and Sasha Stone, empress of Awards Daily. Among other juicy bits, they fire back at some of the mainstream journalists who are in such a snit about the rise of the blogocrats. And they do a fine job of explaining how No Country, a film with lots of rough edges, ended up leading the Oscar pack.

title: Still More Questions in Tobiass Death
description: The life and mysterious death of Seth Tobias, the hedge fund manager found floating lifelessly in his pool last September, has fascinated the press for months. How could it not? The rogues gallery includes Mr. Tobiass wife; a former assistant to Mr. Tobias (and reputed former pimp) named Bill Ash; a male go-go dancer named Tiger; and a mysterious Internet psychic who goes by the name Mama.

title: Almost Famous
description: Lynn Hirschberg of the New York Times magazine muses on where fame comes from and anoints a new crop of the soon-to-be- famous in a remarkable portfolio of photos. The nascent pantheon includes a few folks who have been seen around Oscar-town this season.

title: Grammy Awards Red Carpet
description: A look at the fashions at the 2008 Grammy Awards.

title: Goldman Said to Buy 20% Stake in Capula Fund
description: A private equity fund run by Goldman Sachs has acquired about 20 percent of Capula Investment Management, a $3 billion hedge fund, The Financial Times reported citing unnamed sources. The stake could be worth as much as $100 million but carries no voting rights, the newspaper said.

title: Terrorist Surveillance Bill at Issue in Congress
description: The continuing clash between Democrats and Republicans over national security will play out in Congress this week through a terrorist surveillance bill.

title: CCMP Hires Advisers for Consumer, Healthcare Investments
description: CCMP Capital Advisors said that it had hired two executive advisers to help the private equity firm find investments in the consumer and healthcare sectors.

title: The Early Word: Chasing Votes Near the Chesapeake
description: After another busy weekend on the campaign trail, both parties candidates will be canvassing the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia today ahead of Tuesdays primary there.

title: Will Write for Food
description: On Saturday night, the Bagger came in for the Writers Guild Awards at the Hudson Theater in Manhattan. He showed partly because there was news of a possible strike settlement, and partly because he has a soft spot for the event, which has little of the sizzle and none of the gloss of the other awards dealibops.

title: What About the Bucket List?
description: Anne Thompson offers a clear view of the collective Id of the Oscars.

title: Just remember, the financial problems are contained
description: To Planet Earth, that is  though I wouldnt be surprised if all this eventually affects the International Space Station, too.

title: State Revenue Projections Worsen
description: Only three weeks after presenting its budget, Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration is lowering projections for tax revenue by $384 million, because of increasingly ominous reports of distress on Wall Street and in the nations economy, Danny Hakim reports. To keep the budget in balance, the governor is proposing several new spending cuts, including further paring back increases in Medicaid reimbursements and dipping into the states environmental protection fund. While the changes represent a fraction of New Yorks $124 billion budget, they are a sign of how rapidly shifting economic forecasts are causing havoc with the states fiscal planning. It is rare for a governor to second-guess his own budget, especially so soon after releasing it.

title: A Victory That Actually Means Something
description: The Bagger has a small admission to make. While the writers strike has been storming along, its been a little difficult to get excited about the micro and macro aspects of the Oscars. As long as people were out of work and both the outcome and the future were in doubt, the correct answer to the question of whether another film could sneak through for best picture if No Country and There Will Be Blood split the voters, was, Who cares?

title: On race cards and all that
description: Im starting to get emails from angry people who tell me that Im ignoring all the terrible race-baiting the Clintons have done. I think Ill just outsource my response to Clive Crook  who is, by the way, an Obama supporter.

title: Microsofts Other Takeover Deal: Danger Inc.
description: Not everyone is so reluctant to be bought by Microsoft these days.

title: Its Official: Yahoo Rejects Microsoft Bid
description: Over to you, Microsoft.

title: Clinton Stops in D.C.
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has not spent much time courting voters in the District of Columbia, where Senator Barack Obama is heavily favored in the upcoming Democratic primary on Tuesday.

title: Maybe Hes Cool and Smart
description: Matthew Yglesias doesnt understand where the oft-heard notion that Barack Obamas presidential campaign is vague on matters of policy comes from. Yglesias writes at his blog for The Atlantic:

title: Another Security Threat: It Was All a Dream
description: The evacuation on Sunday of an oil platform off the northeastern coast of Britain was very real and very urgent at first, as one of many initial news agency reports indicated:

title: New York Fashion Week | LWren Scott
description: (Don Ashby)New York Fashion Week is over but The Fashion Telex continues as the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file dispatches from last weeks shows.

title: Egypt Ready to Take on the World
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Now the pressure is really on. Egypt defeated Cameroon, 1-0, in the final of the Africa Cup of Nations Sunday, the Pharaohs sixth cup victory. They are now the undisputed heavyweights of African soccer. Un-dis-puted.

title: Answers From Charles E. Thorpe
description: Charles E. Thorpe, the dean of Carnegie Mellon in Qatar, answered questions on overseas branch campuses of American universities.

title: Watching NBC Nightly News In Orbit
description: Why did the NBC Nightly News anchor Brian Williams offer a special hello to the International Space Station on Fridays evening newscast?

title: Moscows Unusual Prize Distribution
description: The 2008 Moscow Open imbued the Swiss system with a unique Russian flavor.

title: Yahoo Shareholders Believe Company Is Bluffing Microsoft
description: So far, investors are showing modest support for Yahoos board of directors, which formally rejected Microsofts $31-per-share buyout offer this morning.

title: Science Debate Is Set; Now, Will Candidates Come?
description: The organizers of a proposed science and technology debate among the presidential candidates have set a date, April 18, and place, the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. This would be four days before the Pennsylvania primary.

title: Talk to the Newsroom: Sports Editor Tom Jolly
description: Tom Jolly, sports editor at The Times, is answering reader questions Feb. 11-15, 2008. (He previously answered questions in August 2006.) Questions may be sent to askthetimes@nytimes.com. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

title: Shows Prepare To Resume Production
description: The switch that controls the television business is expected to be flicked on all the way early this week, initiating a flurry of activity that may begin to restore the regularly scheduled programming interrupted when the writers strike shut down major parts of the television season, Bill Carter reports.

title: Bloomberg Urges U.N. to Act on Climate Change
description: Updated, 12:37 p.m. | Addressing the United Nations General Assembly this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reiterated his call for a carbon tax in the United States, suggested that congestion pricing could be a model for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in other world cities and announced a plan to reduce the citys use of tropical hardwoods, calling tropical deforestation an ecological calamity. And of course, he managed to throw in a boast about the citys 311 line.

title: Speaking Out: Show-Runners Talk About the Guild Deal
description: As the tentative writers deal is reviewed and the ratification vote is held, the opinions of the show-runners  people who work as both writers and producers, bearing both creative and professional control over shows  will be critically important. They serve as informal ring-leaders of the television community.

title: D.E. Shaws (Very) Good Timing
description: When Alliance Data Systems announced Friday that it was dropping its lawsuit against the Blackstone Group, many shareholders surely leaped for joy as the companys stock jumped 6.9 percent. But perhaps chief among the beneficiaries of the news was D.E. Shaw, which made an extremely timely investment, PE Hubs Dan Primack points out.

title: Has Oil Peaked?
description: The people who run the Dow Jones industrial average are messing with it again, and in that, there could be a warning that oil prices have peaked.

title: For the Red Wings, Disturbing Signs of Imperfection
description: On Sunday Detroit lost at home to the defending Cup champion Anaheim Ducks, 3-2. It was a close game, and Nicklas Lidstroms apparent tying goal with less than a minute to go was waved off by referee Dan OHalloran for goalie interference, as you can see here

title: Recipe of the Day: Pasta With Garlic, Anchovies and Tomatoes
description: For this recipe, steer clear of anchovies that come in two-ounce tins, usually packed in vegetable or other non-olive oil. The right ones are packed in jars, in olive oil from Spain or Italy, or packed in salt. The ones packed in salt require rinsing, de-boning and, preferably, a bit of marinating in olive oil before use. Theyre really good but obviously far more work.

title: In Britain, Attacks on a Surprising Group: Firefighters
description: British firefighters spent Saturday extinguishing a huge blaze in Camden Market, a trendy district in London, but they evidently spend most days under siege, according to a report from their union:

title: Trading Retirement for Something Else
description: The encore career is the brainchild of social entrepreneur, Mr. Freedman, whom I interviewed for todays Shifting Careers column. Through his nonprofit organization, Civic Ventures, and the book, Encore, Mr. Freedman has been working furiously to create a blueprint and tools for a generation of aging baby boomers who want to spend their later years productively.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: Racing season is back and so is Monday Morning Motorsports.

title: Spike and Biscuit, Spot 1
description: A campaign for the Charleston Animal Shelter in Charleston, S.C., capitalizes on the intense interest in politics this year.

title: Spike and Biscuit, Spot 3
description: A campaign for the Charleston Animal Shelter in Charleston, S.C., capitalizes on the intense interest in politics this year.

title: Spike and Biscuit, Spot 2
description: A campaign for the Charleston Animal Shelter in Charleston, S.C., capitalizes on the intense interest in politics this year.

title: McCain Plays Nice With Huckabee
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Senator John McCain continued his campaign of congeniality with former Gov. Mike Huckabee today when he said that it was fine with him if Mr. Huckabee challenged the results of Saturdays Washington State caucuses. Party officials have declared Mr. McCain the winner by several hundred votes, but the Huckabee campaign says that 1,500 votes went uncounted.

title: New York Fashion Week | Tony Melillo
description: (Jimi Celeste)

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: New York: Random Thoughts
description: A deep winter freeze has settled on my part of the world. Last night, as the roast chicken and scalloped potatoes were coming out of the oven, the power went off. The lanterns were brought out and dinner resumed for the hour or so it took the electric company to patch things back together. The New York shows were that fast-receding train; suddenly, on Saturday morning, they were no more.

title: Yahoo and the Art of the Rejection
description: Microsoft has already shown its skill in crafting a bear hug letter. Now Yahoo has tried its hand at the bid-rejection letter, and the result is remarkably, well, nice  especially when compared with the much harsher rejections that some other companies have issued in recent years.

title:
The Answer Man:
You Can Take It With You
description: A reader writes: When I (infrequently, because of budget) eat out locally, it often happens that there is food left over and I ask (I dont ask, I tell the waiter), Id like to take this home. Does that happen at, say, Le Cirque? Do you always eat everything served or is it permitted in NY restaurants (of whatever quality) to walk out with a Styrofoam box of leftovers?

title: New York Fashion Week | Marc Jacobs
description: (Evan Sung for The New York Times)New York Fashion Week is over, but The Fashion Telex continues as the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file dispatches from last weeks shows.

title: The Skinny on Skinny Bitch
description: The diet book called Skinny Bitch has been flying off bookstore shelves, buoyed by the modeling pedigree of its authors and a frank stop eating crap message that distinguishes it from traditional diet books.

title: David Tyree, a Hard Worker
description: David Tyree's college highlight tape is filled with textbook blocks, busted wedges and smothering punt coverage.

title: Hey, You Gotta Learn How To Let Go
description: Video

title: A Video on McCains 100 Years
description: Heres the latest from YouTube:

title: Borrow and Spend
description: Yesterdays Times included an op-ed piece by W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, arguing You Are What You Spend. They compare 1975 statistics to 2006 figures and conclude the bottom 20 percent of Americans in terms of income are doing better than you might expect in terms of consumption.

title: Girl Power!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Feb. 11:

title: A Memo to Yahoos Board
description: To: The Yahoo Board of Directors

title: More Good News: Krod Mandoon Will Start Shooting Soon
description: MRC, one of the studios that reached an interim agreement with the Writers Guild of America before the broader strike was settled, has just announced its first slate of television projects with broadcast and cable companies.

title: Reason No. 4,782 Why Its Good to Be David Wright
description: On the drive down to Port St. Lucie, Fla., from his home in southeastern Virginia, David Wright stopped to play 18 holes at the famed TPC at Sawgrass course in Ponte Vedra Beach, outside Jacksonville. The golf nuts among us will know it as the home to the Players Championship, but even the casual followers have probably seen its most recognizable hole, the par-3, 132-yard 17th that is known as the Island Green. Getting a chance to play that hole was, Wright said, his whole reason for stopping.

title: Aftermath of the Strike: What to Expect on Cable
description: Cable networks have not felt the pinch of the writers strike to the extent the broadcast networks have. After all, they rely more extensively on repeats, reality shows and movies. Also, many of their series premiere during the summer months, against the grain of the September-to-May broadcast season.

title: London Fashion Week | Topshop, Biba, Emilio de la Morena, Poltock & Walsh
description: Fall clothes at the Topshop show. (AP)

title: London Fashion Week | Topshop, Biba, Emilio de la Morena, Poltock & Walsh
description: Fall clothes at the Topshop show. (AP)

title: Flying New York-Hong Kong with kids?
description: Carey from New York asks about travel to Hong Kong with a 4- and 7-year-old. Are some airlines better than others in terms of space and services for children?

title: The New Stimulus Package: A Big Disappointment
description: Better than nothing is the best thing that can be said about the economic stimulus bill passed by Congress last week and soon to be signed by President Bush. Yet congressional leaders are full of self-congratulation over the bill, because they passed it swiftly with bipartisan support.

title: How Bad Is It? AIG Cant Tell
description: If someone wants to buy insurance against a risk, perhaps the insurance company should assume the risk is real.

title: Day One in Port St. Lucie
description: Its been a full 10 months since I last set foot here, and its calming to see that not much has changed  a few more stoplights on Peacock Boulevard, a new shopping center (PETCO! Panera!) under construction. Im a creature of habit, and as long as the weather is good, the iced tea at Camilles is cold and the storylines are intriguing, Im a happy camper. Spring training is all about routines, and Im sure those players working out on the minor-league side this morning would certainly agree with that.

title: Hedge Fund Group Raises Stake in Times Co.
description: The coalition of hedge funds that wants to place directors on The New York Times Companys board has more than doubled its stake in the company, to at least 10 percent of the regular shares, according to federal records filed Monday.

title: Can You Sell Chinese Dumplings in Japan?
description: The race for the White House isnt the only news story that is enriched (or perhaps not-so-enriched) by polls. Over the weekend, a poll conducted in Japan showed how seriously consumers are taking a recent food scare.

title: Eat Your Brownies, er, Veggies
description: I sincerely hope that the moronic idea of hiding food that kids dont like in foods they do  see The Sneaky Chef and Deceptively Delicious  is a passing phase. (The funniest thing about these two books is that the public uproar wasnt over their approach to cooking but over which author had the idea first.) This does a real disservice to kids and  not that this is my bailiwick  is evidence that todays parents will do anything to avoid a confrontation.

title: Strike Fallout: A Complete Guide to How Your Favorite Shows Are Affected
description: Updated throughout on Tuesday afternoon.

title: The Animated Life: Tulips
description: Variations on the kiss, animated in honor of Valentine's Day.

title: Subprime Crisis Festers in New York
description: New York Citys 18,000 foreclosure filings last year accounted for more than half of state foreclosure filings in 2007. Now one out of every 40 homes with a mortgage in New York City had a filing as of the end of September 2007, more than twice the rate for the rest of New York State.

title: Cheaper Wi-Fi Access at Starbucks and Beyond
description: The idea of city-sponsored Wi-Fi seems to be floundering. And the fancy wireless service that may come of the government spectrum auction will be many years away. But that doesnt mean that theres nothing new for road warriors who want a connection.

title: Most Breast Cancer Sites Get It Right
description: The Internet is filled with unreliable health information and bogus claims. But sites dedicated to breast cancer information appear to have a high level of accuracy, a new study shows.

title: Ask not to whom the Tolls sell
description: They sell to each other  unless they walk away from the contract.

title: The Hillary Index
description: Ever since a sharp-eyed co-worker spotted an index entry years ago (in a book by McGeorge Bundy) that said, Khrushchev, Nikita S.  salami-slicing technique of, Ive studied indexes closely, looking for anything that might brighten a dreary workday.

title: Obama-Edwards Meeting Is Scratched, for Now
description: Updated Senator Barack Obamas campaign has confirmed that he has canceled a meeting scheduled for today with former Senator John Edwards in North Carolina. The two have been talking on the phone and will meet soon, people close to both men say, but for now the media attention has become too intense and is out of control, with stake-outs at Mr. Edwardss home.

title: Lerach Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
description: William Lerach, a former partner at a prestigious New York law firm, was sentenced Monday to two years in federal prison for his role in a lucrative kickback scheme involving class-action lawsuits against some of the nations biggest corporations.

title: Sunday Ratings: Makeover Draws 16 Million
description: The Grammy Awards helped CBS finish No. 1 for the night over all, leading the 7 p.m. hour prior to the Grammys with 60 Minutes (13 million viewers). ABC ranked second for the night thanks to a two-hour Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 p.m. (15.8 million) followed by Brothers & Sisters at 10 p.m. (8.6 million).

title: Viewership Down For Grammy Awards
description: CBSs broadcast of the 50th Annual Grammy Awards was the highest-rated program on Sunday night, both among overall viewers and within the choice demographic of adults 18 to 49. But the good news for the program pretty much ends there.

title: I. M. Peis Silver Towers Could Become a Landmark
description: Updated, 10:56 p.m. | The Landmarks Preservation Commission is expected on Tuesday to schedule a hearing on whether to designate Silver Towers/University Village, a concrete complex designed by I. M. Pei that was part of Robert Mosess vast urban renewal program, as a historic landmark. Preservationists have urged such a move, arguing that New York Universitys proposed campus expansion could some day threaten the towers, which sit at the edge of the universitys campus in Greenwich Village.

title: For the Heart, a Risky Emotional Duo
description: Emotional and personality traits have long been associated with heart disease. Now researchers have shown that the combination of two traits  hostility and depression  may exact a particularly risky toll on the heart.

title: The Curious Incident of the Kellwood Tender Offers
description: The Kellwood deal took a slight turn this weekend. On Friday, Sun Capital amended its tender offer to include a new condition that, upon the closing of the tender offer, Sun Capital representatives on the Kellwood Board of Directors will constitute a majority of the directors and be proportionate in number to Sun Capitals percentage shareholding in the Company.

title: Love, Istanbul style?
For Jeter, the Manager Will Be Joe or Girardi
description: Derek Jeters rookie season in 1996 coincided with Joe Torres first year as the Yankees manager and ended with a World Series title. Jeter had a strong relationship for 12 seasons with the man he called Mr. Torre or Mr. T.

title: Kaffee und Kuchen in Frankfurt
description: Yes, I know the image of sitting down to coffee and cakes in the afternoon, a German and Austrian tradition especially, has the feel of something your grandparents do. You totter over to the table in your Sunday best and linger for lack of anything better to do in retirement. But soft! Doesnt a ritual built around good coffee and delicious pastries deserve more respect than that? As a matter of fact, it does.

title: Westminster Dog Show
description: The Westminster Kennel Club's 132nd annual dog show got underway in New York on Monday.

title: Clinton Better Suited to Take On McCain, Her Campaign Says
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Anticipating grim results in primary contests throughout February, the Clinton campaign tried on Monday afternoon to change the subject - to the general election.

title: Agenda at the Mobile World Congress
description: CNBC reports from Barcelona on the latest developments and breakthroughs in the mobile phone industry.

title: Microsoft Teams With Sony Ericsson
description: CNBC talks with Pieter Knook, Microsoft SVP for mobile communications, on the company's new partnership with Sony Ericsson.

title: Obama Joins the Clintons, for a Sitting
description: Ever dreamed of a hands-on experience with Barack Obama?

title: Pakistani Divisions in Queens
description: Video

title: Breaking Hearts With Chocolate Price-Gouging?
description: Mere days/hours/seconds (how excited are you?) before Valentines Day, BBC News brought most unwelcome news: Regulators raid chocolate firms.

title: Romane-Conti Comes to Town
description: I dont go to very many industry tastings. These are large, invitation-only events where an importer or distributor generally will show its roster of wines, often with winemakers themselves pouring samples. You can taste dozens if not hundreds of wines at these events, if you spit and work efficiently. Mostly, theyre useful to retail and restaurant buyers who have to stock their stores and wine lists. Theyre rarely useful to somebody like me, unless I can target specific wines that I want to taste for one reason or another, or find specific people whom I want to speak with. I dont learn much about wines in that kind of context.

title: The Senators Load Up
description: The Ottawa Senators and Carolina Hurricanes have broken the ice, swinging the first major deal of the trading season, with two weeks to go to the Feb. 26 trade deadline.

title: Yellow Rat and Workers Reach a Settlement
description: This is not the kind of buzz typically sought by Yellow Rat Bastard, the trendy SoHo clothing retailer: It has agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a lawsuit over unpaid wages and overtime, according to the state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo. The apparel and shoe chain, which takes its name from Frank Millers Sin City crime comics and cultivates an edgy notoriety with its pierced staff and graffiti decor, is no stranger to controversy.

title: Rent Anything  From the Family Down the Street
description: You can rent a car online. But how about a power drill? Or a disco globe? Or your neighbors pool-cleaning equipment?

title: Less is More
description: Greetings from Anna Maria Island, where the sun is shining, a gentle breeze is blowing and the temperature is hovering in the high 70s. (To those Northeastern readers in the deep freeze, sorry to rub it in!)

title: For the Moment | Stefan Sagmeister
description: (Philip Greenberg forThe New York Times)

title: Posada: Dodging Bats and Chasing Boston
description: Jorge Posada swung, his bat shattered and, for a millisecond, everyone around the batting cage gasped. After Posadas bat broke, a large chunk of it ricocheted off the backstop netting, the same side of the backstop where Derek Jeter was standing, and hit Posada in the right leg.

title: The Smallest of Price Hikes
description: Prices hikes dont get much smaller than this: The United States Post Office has decided to raise the price of stamps from 41 cents to 42. The new price will take effect in May, a year after a two cent increase. Other post office services will cost slightly more as well, but not more than the rate of inflation over the past 12 months. More details at the official site. MN

title: ABCs Fall Lineup Takes Shape
description: ABC announced pick-ups for nine series on Monday, including five returning hits and four new programs.

title: Peltz Seeks Control of Wendys Board
description: Nelson Peltz, the billionaire investor, is turning up the heat on Wendys International, which he wants to add to his fast-food holdings.

title: Lucy, Lost and Found
description: Maybe, just maybe, Lucys story offers hope after all for Vivi  the prize-winning whippet who went missing two years ago at Kennedy International Airport after the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show this week.

title: And the Winner Is
description: The theme of this campaign season is that everyone has been wrong all the time, so now that everyone thinks the Democratic primary campaign will extend into March and possibly April and beyond, could everyone be wrong again? Is the race for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination already over?

title: Microsoft Reserves the Right to Pursue All Necessary Steps
description: Thats the take-away from Microsofts response to Yahoos spurning of its $44.6 billion bid on Monday, in what was the next expected step in the biggest-ever tech takeover drama.

title: Clinton, Obama Set Debate Dates
description: Barack Obama has accepted an invitation to debate Hillary Rodham Clinton in Austin, Tex., his campaign announced.

title: Things That Are Depressing for 100, Alex
description: A Grammy Award Season Quiz:

title: Exploring the Manhattan Grit Chamber
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Soft Serve | Posh Skin, Petrus Police, Guccis No-No
description: Ding, ding  Soft Serve is served.  New York Fashion Week ends, London Fashion Week begins. Fashion editors should be careful when exercising their expense accounts. A very wealthy restaurant patron in London suspects he was served a fake bottle of 1961 Chateau Ptrus (cost: about $35,000). To crack the case, the restaurant has called the Bloodhound Gang of the wine world, the Ptrus Police.  Talk about rip offs, a van Gogh, Monet, Degas and Czanne were reported stolen a private collection (cost: about $100 million)  Usually Gucci is getting knocked off, not the other way around. The heat is on the luxury brand for its new campaign, an unauthorized homage to Milton Glasers I heart NY Also in legal hot water is Croc, the un-chic shoe manufacturer.
