The family of a girl whose Croc got chewed up by an escalator is suing for $7 million. Croc has acknowledged, a long-existing issue that we think is very important  escalator safety.  For less serious scrapes and cuts, look forward to Band-Aids 2.0, with build-in microchips  Speaking of painful, this week New York Magazines Best Bets goes rummaging for 40-year-old junk.  Count us in, maybe, for a round of retail therapy at Damien Hirsts London Art Shop. We cant afford the $100 million diamond skull, but a second mortgage might afford us a $50,000 painted cranium.  We guess Londoners like to blow their cash on tighty whities. After the hunky David Beckham billboards were erected, Emporio Armani saw a 150 percent sales increase. Must be the packaging  Closer to home, Posh got a similarly jubilant reception last night from the gay crowd at Hiro nightclub. One solitary dissenter, the porn actor and activist Michael Lucas, poo-pooed Posh on dermatological grounds, saying, I think I would commit suicide if I had her skin her skin is yellow with big pores. Major meanie!  Soft Serve will spice up your life tomorrow, when we return.

title: Bloomberg Denies Talking With Hagel About White House Bid
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg denied today that he had spoken with Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, about mounting an independent presidential run, as reported in an article in The Times on Saturday.

title: Twin Bombings in Baghdad
description: Ian Fisher reports on two deadly blasts in the neighborhood of Karada.

title: Spitzers Budget Is Under Fire by Hospitals and Environmental Groups
description: Another day in Albany, another skirmish in the budget wars. Over the weekend, Gov. Eliot Spitzer began floating some changes to his proposed budget for the coming fiscal year, including a projected $384 million in state revenue because of the worsening economy climate.

title: The Mexican Presidents Whirlwind Visit
description: One very rushed president, 50 community leaders, dozens of concerns and fewer than 30 minutes of face time: that, in a nutshell, is what characterized the meeting this afternoon between President Felipe Caldern of Mexico and a group of Mexican activists from across the New York region, held behind closed doors at the New York Marriott Downtown Hotel in Lower Manhattan.

title: Tennessee Goes Pink
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  It is a spectacular and moving sight inside Thompson-Boling Arena on the Tennessee campus. They may have found the one sport and the one color that can finally trump football and the Big Orange: basketball and pink.

title: A Fight About What?
description: The close and impassioned battle for the Democratic nomination is about many things  an insider versus an outsider, the boomer generation versus the millennial generation, a choice between two different firsts  but oddly enough, there is one thing that it is NOT about: policy.

title: Tulips
description: Cinema has been fascinated with kissing since Thomas Edison filmed May Irwin and John Rice in 1896 in The Kiss.

title: McCain's Apostasies
description:
Bloggers Bill Scher and Conn Carroll debate whether John McCain is a true conservative.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Some eBay Sellers Will Get a Price Break, but Hated Feedback System Stays
description: EBay is giving a little to disgruntled sellers, but it is holding firm on the changes it has made recently that many of them like least.

title: Two CBS Journalists Missing In Iraq
description: Two CBS journalists are missing in the southern Iraqi city of Basra, the network said in a brief statement on Monday, James Glanz reports.

title: Reader Responses to When Women Rule
description: Heres a sampling of the comments in response to Nicks Sunday column. Richard Attanasio:

title: Obamas Success in the Caribbean
description: Senator Barack Obama had a victory over the weekend that didnt get much attention: he took the Democratic presidential caucuses in the Virgin Islands, riding a wave of black support on Saturday to add three delegates to his tally.

title: Parker Plays Through the Pain
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  With less than a minute left in warmups before the Tennessee-Rutgers game, the Volunteers Candace Parker was still wearing her long orange warmup pants. Parker, the reigning national player of the year, injured her left knee Feb. 7 in a victory over Mississippi State and was carried off the floor.

title: Speaking of Face Plants
description: The Bagger wrote about the Writers Guild awards ceremony at the Hudson Theater last Saturday night and suggested that the head writer for The Daily Show had a rugged time during his tour at the mic. While the would-be funny guy in question does work for The Daily Show, he is not the head writer. That guys name is Steve Bodow and he was at home taking care of his newborn daughter. He was nowhere near the mic or the Hudson Theater. The Bagger and David Carr both apologize for the error.

title: Bristol Cars: Exclusive Anonymity
description: LONDON  Toby Silverton, chairman of Bristol Cars, is terribly disappointed. Sitting with him in Bristols only showroom in the world, on Kensington High Street, Ive explained that 50 percent of my friends and car-loving colleagues had no idea who or what Bristol was when I mentioned my plan to visit the company  horrible news for any other car manufacturer.

title: Stock-Car Science Quiz
description: Never mind being smarter than a fifth grader. Are you smarter than a Nascar driver?

title: The Powell Factor
description: One contest, it seems, has been left off the official calendar of the 2008 presidential race: the Colin L. Powell primary.

title: Pearl in Pink
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  Bruce Pearl, the effervescent Tennessees mens basketball coach, promised to be dressed in pink from head to toe for tonights Think Pink intiative to raise breast cancer awareness at No. 1 Tennessees game with No. 5 Rutgers.

title: Is Interest in Bulgaria Waning?
description: The Financial Times is reporting that British home buyers have disappeared from Bulgaria hot spots. The article provides details of a sharp reduction in the sales of moderately priced holiday properties and notes that developers have started to offer steep discounts.

title: Twin Bombings in Baghdad
description: Ian Fisher reports on two deadly blasts in the neighborhood of Karada.

title: How Deep Is Your Love?
description: For most couples, passion and romance eventually fade over time, and a more calm, contented love takes over as the years go by.

title: Removing the N from Neglected Tropical Diseases
Now: A Casualty on the CW
description: CW Now  the painfully low-rated product placement platform dressed in newsmagazine clothing  is off the networks schedule at the end of February.

title: Times Co. Nominates 2 to Board
description: The New York Times Company, which is under pressure from a group of hedge funds that want to gain representation on its board, said Tuesday that it had nominated two candidates of its own.

title: Agencies See a Window to Alter the Business of Television
description: Madison Avenue, assessing the aftermath of the writers strike, is optimistic that there can be long-term benefits from the disruptions suffered during the 2007-8* broadcast TV season.

title: At Harvard, a Proposal to Publish Free on Web
description: Publish or perish has long been the burden of every aspiring university professor. But the question the Harvard faculty will decide on Tuesday is whether to publish  on the Web, at least  free.

title: Recovering the Complex Legacy of the Photographer Jacob Riis
description: If you have seen any of Jacob Riiss photographs, you have probably never forgotten them. Riis was the Danish-born police reporter who in the late 1880s brought magnesium-flash photography into some of the darkest and most troubled spots in New York City  the tenements near Mulberry Bend, where Columbus Park now stands. New immigrants were crushed together there in some of the worst squalor and highest population densities ever recorded on this planet.

title: Taliban Commander Is Captured
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A senior Taliban commander was wounded and arrested by Pakistani forces as he tried to slip across the Afghan border into Pakistan with a small band of men, Pakistani military authorities said Monday.

title: US Weeklys Circulation Rises 10% in Soft Year
description: Sales of US Weekly and a new competitor, OK! Weekly, climbed sharply in the second half of 2007, even as a round of price increases contributed to an unusual drop in overall sales of celebrity magazines, according to a report released Monday.

title: Suit Against New Campaign Finance Law Claims Racial Bias
description: The real estate industry and lobbyists, who together provide millions in campaign cash for city candidates, are trying to overturn a new law that would vastly reduce how much they can donate.

title: Two Old Partners, Playing Sonatas in Yin and Yang
description: The violinist Joan Kwuon, who grew up in Los Angeles, became a fan of Andr Previns after hearing him conduct the Los Angeles Philharmonic in the late 1980s, when he was its music director. She later met Mr. Previn (who is also a pianist) at Tanglewood, where he was so impressed with her talent that he invited her to perform in professional concerts under his baton.

title: Israeli Casts Doubt on Pact This Year
description: JERUSALEM  A senior Israeli minister said Monday that his country hoped to reach agreement with the Palestinians on a declaration of principles for peace by the end of the year, but not on a detailed peace treaty.

title: Dozens of Companies Underpay or Misreport Workers, State Says
description: A new crackdown on employers in New York State that are paying workers off the books has snared dozens of companies and uncovered millions of dollars in violations, state officials said on Monday.

title: No End in Sight
description: February cant end soon enough for Senator Hillary Clinton.

title: Despite Empty Seats at Home, Hornets are Thriving
description: NEW ORLEANS  The N.B.A. All-Star Game arrives Sunday to shine a spotlight on this recovering city, but also to embrace a local franchise that continues to lag in the stands even as it has become a contender in the standings.

title: Who Won the Writers Strike?
description: When the Writers Guild of America held its annual awards ceremony Saturday night in Manhattan, it felt more like a victory celebration. So after a long and bitter strike, the writers won, right?

title: Fire Damages Big Market in the Bronx
description: Fire damaged the buildings of several wholesale meat suppliers in the Hunts Point Cooperative Market in the South Bronx on Monday night, causing tens of millions of dollars in damage, fire officials and business owners said.

title: Rules Eased to Expedite Green Card Applications
description: Searching for ways to reduce a huge backlog of visa applications, immigration authorities have eased requirements for background checks by the F.B.I. of immigrants seeking to become permanent United States residents, federal officials said Monday.

title: Russia Forgives Iraq Billions in Debt
description: MOSCOW  Iraqs foreign minister won a long-sought agreement on Monday to write off most of Iraqs $12.9 billion in debt to Russia, much of it dating to before the first gulf war when Saddam Hussein government purchased Soviet weapons.

title: 5200 B.C. Is New Date for Farms in Egypt
description: Long before the rule of pharaohs, Egyptians grew wheat and barley and raised pigs, goats, sheep and cattle. Spotty evidence had suggested that agriculture was practiced there more than 7,000 years ago, two millenniums earlier than the first royal dynasties.

title: Martian Umbrellas
description: Q. If solar flares and cosmic rays are known to be dangerous to life, how can scientists speculate about life forms on Mars?

title: Seeking Unity, Obama Feels Pull of Racial Divide
description: WASHINGTON  It was November 2006 when Senator Barack Obama first gathered friends and advisers at a Washington law firm to brainstorm about what it would take for him to win the presidency.

title: The Trip to Bronx Science: A Long Ride to a Choice School
description: Three bridges connect Queens to the Bronx. But if you are a high school student dependent on public transportation, the 10- to 15-mile trip can easily translate into hours on the subway.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline on Monday with an article about pressure on the Israeli government to respond more forcefully to rocket attacks on Israel from Gaza misstated the condition of two brothers, ages 8 and 19, after an attack on their town, Sderot. They were seriously wounded; they are not dead. (Go to Article)

title: Nascars Screech and Slam? Its All Aerodynamics
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  When Junior Johnson entered the Daytona 500 in 1960, hed already achieved fame in two careers  first as a moonshiner who kept outrunning federal agents, then by applying those skills to win stock-car races.

title: A Look at Two Rival Ideas About How to Compose
description: The Manhattan Sinfonietta, a flexible new-music ensemble led by Jeffrey Milarsky , took over Merkin Concert Hall last weekend for two concerts that explored competing notions of contemporary musical language.

title: You Remind Me of Me
description: Artful persuasion depends on eye contact, but not just any kind. If one person prefers brief glances and the other is busy staring deeply, then it may not matter how good the jokes are or how much they both loved Juno. Rhythm counts.

title: Kenyas War of Words
description: Nairobi, Kenya

title: British Film Awards
description: Atonement, adapted from the Ian McEwan novel and starring Keira Knightley and James McAvoy as suffering lovers, was named best film at the British Academy of Film and Television Awards (popularly known as the Baftas) on Sunday night in London, The Associated Press reported. Daniel Day-Lewis, above, came away with best actor honors for his performance as the oilman in There Will Be Blood, and Marion Cotillard was named best actress for her portrayal of dith Piaf in La Vie en Rose. Joel and Ethan Coen won the award for directing for No Country for Old Men, and the prize for best original screenplay went to Diablo Cody for Juno.

title: $89 Million Needed in Southern Floods
description: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs appealed for $89 million to aid 449,000 people in Mozambique, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe hit by flooding. Halfway through the rainy season, thousands have seen their crops ruined and homes destroyed.

title: The News? No Bad News for 4 Weeks in Newark, if Murders Are Your Guide
description: NEWARK  The last time this city went a month without a murder, a Clinton was president, Life Is Beautiful was in movie theaters, and a 29-year-old councilman named Cory A. Booker was just starting to make a name for himself.

title: A Medical Robot Makes Headway
description: YOU would never know a recession might be under way from looking at Intuitive Surgical, the leader in medical robot technology.

title: $1.2 Billion Write-Down at Credit Suisse
description: LONDON  Switzerlands two largest banks may have their Zurich headquarters within walking distance of each other but when it comes to weathering the credit crisis they are miles apart.

title: Experts to Discuss U.S. Space Plan
description: Back to the Moon? Push on to Mars? Visit an asteroid?

title: A Deal We Can Live With
description: Nairobi, Kenya

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review in Weekend on Friday about the Spice Girls, at Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, misidentified a song performed by Melanie Chisholm, who is known as Sporty Spice. It was I Turn to You by Ms. Chisholm, not the song of the same title recorded by Christina Aguilera and written by Diane Warren.

title: The Battle for the Democratic Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: Chads Leader Survives, but Dissidents Peril Grows
description: NDJAMENA, Chad  Franoise Djiuihen responded with a start to each rap at the door, each passing car that lingered too long beyond the front gate of the safe house.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Charges Will Be Filed in Fund Managers Death
description: The state attorneys office in Palm Beach County, Fla., said Monday that no charges would be filed in the drowning of Seth Tobias, 44, a hedge fund manager and regular commentator on CNBC.

title: Start-Up Brings Free Calls to Mobile Phones
description: PARIS  In a few years time, well look back and say how strange it was that we didnt always use Facebook on our mobile phones, predicts Avi Shechter, an Israeli technology entrepreneur.

title: Finding May Solve Riddle of Fatigue in Muscles
description: One of the great unanswered questions in physiology is why muscles get tired. The experience is universal, common to creatures that have muscles, but the answer has been elusive until now.

title: New DVDs
description: LUBITSCH MUSICALS

title: Lottery Numbers
Obamas Drug Use: A Mountain Out of a Molehill?
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Bares Transit Woes in New Jersey
description: Though California is famous for its gridlocked freeways, no state beats New Jersey when it comes to congested highways. Commuters in New Jersey also have the third-longest travel time to work  exceeding Californias  even though the state also has the second-highest percentage of mass transportation use.

title: Schools Revived by Special Aid in New Jersey Brace for New Formula
description: PERTH AMBOY, N.J.  The Perth Amboy schools were once so impoverished that the teachers used yellowing textbooks, class sizes crept up to 35 students, and makeshift gyms were fashioned out of hallways and basements.

title: Proposal for Catskill Resort Turns Old Rivals Into Partners, and Vice Versa
description: Donald J. Trump, who was once fined for waging a secret lobbying campaign against a proposed Indian casino at Monticello Raceway, said on Monday that he may join his former opponent and another developer in developing a $700 million resort with thousands of electronic slot machines at the old Concord Hotel, just a few miles from the track.

title: Gates Endorses Pause in Iraq Troop Withdrawals
description: BAGHDAD  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said for the first time Monday that he supported a pause in American troop reductions in Iraq. It was the most authoritative indication to date that the United States will maintain a large force here through 2008 and into the next presidential term.

title: Tolkien Heirs Sue New Line Over Millions From Rings
description: Following in the footsteps of Peter Jackson, the director of the Oscar-winning Lord of the Rings trilogy, heirs to J. R. R. Tolkien, the author of the books on which the films are based, are suing New Line Cinema for failing to pay them at least $150 million, which they say they are owed as part of the movies gross receipts.

title: Banks and the Subprime Crisis: No Deficit of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Footnotes
description: Dolly Parton, below, citing a back injury, has postponed a United States tour that was to have begun on Feb. 28 in Minneapolis. An announcement said the concerts, promoting her Backwoods Barbie album, to be released on Feb. 26 on Dolly Records, would be rescheduled for late April and May. ... A show arrives: Shrek the Musical, so far starring Sutton Foster, Christopher Sieber and Kecia Lewis-Evans, is to begin previews on Nov. 8 at the Broadway Theater with an opening on Dec. 14. The title ogre and Donkey have yet to be cast. ... And a show leaves: The Farnsworth Invention, which opened on Dec. 3, will end its run on March 2. It will have played 34 previews and 104 regular performances. ... Julia McKenzie, 67, will be the new Miss Marple, succeeding Geraldine McEwan, who said last month that she was leaving Marple, the British crime series. Ms. McKenzie will be the seventh actress to portray this character, created by Agatha Christie, the BBC reported.

title: HarperCollins to Offer Free Books Online
description: Seems like a lot of people want Neil Gaiman, the fantasy novelist, short-story and comics writer, to give away his books. On Saturday Mr. Gaiman invited readers of his blog to select the book they would give to a friend who has never read his work before. More than 16,500 votes have been cast for one of eight titles highlighted at neilgaiman.com. Mr. Gaiman will select a winner next week, and a free electronic copy of that book will be posted on the Web site of HarperCollins Publishers, harpercollins.com, later this month. The book will be one of six, including a novel by Paulo Coelho and a cookbook by the Food Network star Robert Irvine, that HarperCollins is making available free online for a month each. Readers will not be able to download or print the books. In Mr. Coelhos case the publisher will upload a different title each month until the end of the year.

title: Opera, They Wrote
description: Ian Rankin may be best known for his Inspector Rebus mysteries. Alexander McCall Smith, right, may be best known for chronicling the exploits of the No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency. So what have they been up to lately? Writing 15-minute operas. They are participants in Five:15, a Scottish Opera initiative intended to attract young audiences by joining authors and composers like Craig Armstrong (Love Actually) to create 15-minute operas. The results range from Mr. Rankins Gesualdo, about the murderous 16th-century composer Carlo Gesualdo, to Queens of Govan, about a 15-year-old girl who works in a kebab shop in a gritty Glasgow neighborhood, The Independent of London reported. Mr. McCall Smiths work is based on Dream Angus, his collection of Celtic myths. The five operas will be presented in March in Glasgow and Edinburgh. The performances are sold out.

title: At Zurich Museum, a Theft of 4 Masterworks
description: ZURICH  Three men wearing ski masks walked into a private museum here in daylight, grabbed four 19th-century masterpieces, tossed them into a van and sped off, pulling off one of the largest and most audacious art robberies of all time. It was the second multimillion-dollar art heist in Switzerland in less than a week.

title: Ahead of 3 Primaries, a Dash About Chesapeake
description: BALTIMORE  Hopscotching around the region on the eve of the so-called Chesapeake primaries, the two contenders for the Democratic Partys presidential nomination traded boasts and challenges on Monday about who was better equipped to take on the likely Republican nominee, Senator John McCain.

title: Price Limit on Text Messages Is Sought
description: The European Unions telecommunications commissioner said she would seek limits on the price Europeans pay to send short text messages when traveling outside their home countries, unless operators lower the charges by July. The commissioner, Viviane Reding, said the rates are four to five times domestic messaging rates. If prices were not reduced by July, Ms. Reding, left, said she would ask the European Parliament and Council of Ministers to enact price limits, which could take effect by the summer of 2009. Operators reacted coolly to her threat. Craig Ehrlich, the chairman of the GSM Association, which represents 700 mobile operators, said competitive pressure among operators was already bringing down prices, and further regulation was not needed.

title: Bad Bets and Accounting Flaws Bring Staggering Losses
description: Mark S. Fishman was a modern prince of the markets  a pedigreed money manager who raised billions of dollars at the height of the hedge fund boom.

title: Building Organs Even the Prudish Can Handle
description: The human breast comes in wondrous varieties. Good luck learning that in medical school. There, students practicing on training dummies mostly encounter the same set of perky 36Bs. Many students become doctors never having learned the nuances of checking for cancerous lumps in larger, smaller, flatter, fuller or droopier breasts.

title: For Clinton, Bid Hinges on Texas and Ohio
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her advisers increasingly believe that, after a series of losses, she has been boxed into a must-win position in the Ohio and Texas primaries on March 4, and she has begun reassuring anxious donors and superdelegates that the nomination is not slipping away from her, aides said on Monday.

title: A Godlike Dancers Company Farewell Keeps Adventures Rolling to the End
description: After more than 15 years with New York City Ballet, Nikolaj Hbbe danced his farewell performance on Sunday afternoon not as if he were delivering the last word on his roles, but as if they were brave new worlds he was still exploring. Especially in the title role of Balanchines Apollo, the opening ballet of this special program, he was utterly in the moment, apparently discovering or even testing the steps and gestures as they arrived. To see this kind of fresh energy in a dancer who looks entirely Apollonian is heady stuff.

title: Battle Against Counterfeit Drugs Has New Weapon: Pollen
description: After the Chinese company Guilin Pharmaceutical began getting complaints about its antimalarial medicine, artesunate, the company decided in 2006 to test some field samples. They turned out to be fake.

title: Robert Jastrow, Who Made Space Understandable, Dies at 82
description: Robert Jastrow, who led a major space science institution and helped to bring space down to earth for millions of Americans, died Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 82.

title: A Victory for Jazz, or Just Grammy Being Grammy?
description: When something newsworthy or popular or positive happens to a jazz musician  a big award, say  many in the jazz world feel astonished for about four seconds, then quickly act very smug. You know: Weve been sitting here patiently, full of our aesthetic virtue, so used to being ignored, and the world has finally come around to our point of view. Are we happy about it? More to the point, what took you so long?

title: Sunni Leader Seems to Be Target in Baghdad Bombings
description: BAGHDAD  Two car bombs exploded here in the capital on Monday, killing at least 11 people in what appeared to be a coordinated attack on a leader of the citizens groups that have turned against Sunni insurgents, Iraqi officials said.

title: Birds Who Ride Winter Gravy Train See Benefits in Spring
description: If you feed birds in the winter, should you continue feeding them in the spring? Conventional wisdom suggests that you should let the birds fend for themselves when there is plenty of food around, that continuing to feed them might be disruptive in some way.

title: Hurdles Seen as Capital Charges Are Filed in 9/11 Case
description: WASHINGTON  Military prosecutors filed capital charges against a former senior leader of Al Qaeda and five other Guantnamo detainees on Monday for their roles in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, but the possible obstacles facing a death penalty case in the Bush administrations military commission system were immediately apparent.

title: City Hospitals Reinvent Role of Emergency
description: The New York City emergency room  overcrowded, exhausting, sometimes terrifying  has long been a legendary circle of medical hell.

title: Virginias Diversity Offers a Challenge to Democrats
description: LEXINGTON, Va.  With just a day left in which to decide, Priscilla Baker remained torn between voting for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama in the Democratic presidential primary here on Tuesday.

title: Peru: Kimberly-Clark to Build Two Plants
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the maker of Huggies diapers and Scott paper towels, plans to build two plants in Peru as part of a plan to make the country its South American hub. The company, based in Dallas, will double its personnel in Peru to 1,200 workers and invest about $60 million in a paper mill and a diaper factory in Lima, according to Kimberly-Clarks country manager, Blanca Quino, who at a news conference at the presidential palace in Lima said the move will be the companys largest investment so far in Latin America.

title: Justice Dept. Announces Arrests in 2 Chinese Espionage Cases
description: WASHINGTON  Federal officials arrested a Defense Department official in Virginia on Monday and charged him with passing to agents of China classified defense documents about Taiwans arms purchases.

title: How Self-Serving Can They Get?
description: If there ever was a time for New York legislators to get a pay raise, this isnt it. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has just warned that the states economic forecast is bleaker than he thought only weeks ago, and he is proposing an array of cuts in the states $124 billion budget. Like mayors and governors all over the country, Mr. Spitzer is readying the state for an economic storm.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review on Monday about the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, referred incompletely to a work that was performed. It was Stravinskys 1919 version of his Firebird suite; not the full ballet score.

title: European Union to Tighten Border Entry Rules
description: BRUSSELS  Non-Europeans would need to submit biometric data before crossing Europes frontiers under sweeping European Union proposals to combat illegal migration, terrorism and organized crime that are to be outlined this week.

title: The Physics of Coltranes Technique: How Pros Hit the High Notes
description: The saxophone, invented by Adolphe Sax, the Belgian instrument maker, and patented in 1846, is a curved tube of brass with holes. Its vibrations can reach high-pitched wailing notes, particularly when played by jazz musicians like John Coltrane.

title: Beagle Is Top Hound at Westminster Dog Show
description: Of the many breeds that have never won best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show is the beagle. Through 131 previous editions, no beagle has celebrated what terriers have more than 40 times.

title: Economists Tea Leaves Point to Recession
description: According to Wall Streets forecasters, the recession of 2008 is now unavoidable.

title: Pigs and a Puzzling Illness (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a resolution by Conservative rabbis critical of a prayer on Good Friday referred incorrectly to that prayer. It is part of a service on Good Friday, but not part of a Mass. (No Mass is said on Good Friday.)

title: Again, BlackBerrys Are Disrupted by a Technical Snag
description: OTTAWA  For the second time in less than a year, a technical failure on Monday idled the thumbs of many BlackBerry users by severing their wireless link to e-mail and the Web.

title: Exercise: Parkinsons Patients Benefit From Tango
description: When the band strikes up a tango, people with Parkinsons disease may want to head for the dance floor.

title: Sudanese Army Officer Is Held in American Officials Murder
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  One of two men arrested Saturday in connection with the killing of the American diplomat in Sudan last month is a Sudanese Army officer, a senior Sudanese law enforcement official said Monday.

title: Whats in a Beethoven Quartet? A Full Curriculum
description: PHILADELPHIA  It is Distillate of Beethoven: 21 minutes of sharply compressed music that shows him in all his violent, tragic, angry, plaintive, contemplative guises. For four months it has haunted the halls of the Curtis Institute of Music, the elite conservatory here.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 3 about three people helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during the 2005-2006 campaign misidentified the employer of one of them, Walter Morris, a refugee from Hurricane Katrina and a former drug abuser. It was the FEGS Health and Human Services System, a social services agency, not the UJA-Federation of New York, one of the beneficiary agencies of the Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Writers Vote to End Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods writers made it official on Tuesday night, ending their bitterly fought strike at the 100-day mark by an overwhelming margin. Of 3,775 writers who cast ballots, 92.5 percent voted in favor of ending the strike. Officials of the Writers Guild of America West and the Writers Guild of America East disclosed results of the tally an hour after voting had closed at 6 p.m. here.

title: Putting the Play Above the Politics in Europe
description: More than 20 years after he stepped off the soccer field for the final time as a player, Michel Platini has had a greater impact on the game than when he wore the black-and-white striped shirt of Juventus or the brilliant blue of France.

title: CBS Reports 2 Journalists Missing in Iraq
description: Two CBS journalists are missing in the southern Iraqi city of Basra, the network said in a brief statement on Monday.

title: Battling to Get a Connection for a Flight or a Laptop
description: I AVOID using the term road warrior, but now Im ready to reconsider.

title: When Grizzlies Ruin Eden, Moose Take to the Road
description: Joel Berger, 56, is a specialist in ungulates, hoofed mammals that, in general, walk on the tips of their toes to sustain their body weight. His investigations into the behavior and habits of rhinoceros, bison, pronghorn sheep and moose have been used to find ways to preserve them and their environments.

title: White House Does Not See a Recession
description: WASHINGTON  The White House predicted on Monday that the economy would escape a recession and that unemployment would remain low this year, though it acknowledged that growth had already slowed.

title: For Trophy Wives, Tarnish Is an Occupational Hazard
description: The first question Alex Witchels new novel, The Spare Wife, poses is one of genre: is it a silver fork novel? The silver fork novel is a subgenre that has been around almost as long as novels themselves, affording the reader the double pleasures of following the lives of the aristocracy and scorning its mindless snobbery, triviality and malice.

title: Trade-In: Open Wheel for Stock Cars
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Dario Franchitti and Kyle Petty chatted briefly as the two racecar drivers sat together before a news conference last month, Franchittis Scottish brogue mixing amiably with Pettys more traditional Nascar dialect.

title: A Life Worth Living? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Frget Txt Msgs: Real E-Mail Comes to More Phones
description: MILAN  Mobile e-mail, until recently the exclusive terrain of business executives, is breaking out of its niche market even as cellphone operators remain ambivalent about a service that will cut into their lucrative text messaging market.

title: I.R.S. Said to Flout Orders to Yield Data About Audits
description: WASHINGTON  A tax research group went to court Monday, arguing that the Internal Revenue Service was not complying with federal court orders to release data on its audit practices.

title: Tom Lantos, 80, Is Dead; Longtime Congressman
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Tom Lantos of California, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the only Holocaust survivor ever to serve in Congress, died on Monday. He was 80.

title: A Hard-Times Road Show on New Jersey Finances
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J.  The first snide outburst came, as usual, a few minutes into the program when Gov. Jon S. Corzine, relying on a PowerPoint slide show several font sizes too small, spoke about New Jerseys fiscal woes. Stop lying! someone blurted.

title: Top Anglicans Rally to Besieged Archbishop
description: CAMBRIDGE, England  The archbishop of Canterbury received a strong show of support from the Church of Englands top clerics and laymen on Monday in response to demands for his resignation over his call for Britain to accept some aspects of Shariah, the legal code of Islam based on the Koran.

title: Where Marines Are Called Intruders and Recruiting Office Is Unwelcome
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  On Tuesday night, the nine members of the Berkeley City Council are expected to do something they, or the Marines, for that matter, very rarely do: retreat in the face of fierce opposition.

title: Vision: Antioxidants May Cut Cataracts
description: The antioxidants vitamin E and lutein, from both food and supplements, may reduce womens risk for cataracts, researchers report.

title: $300 Million to Burn, With a Catch
description: Heres an odd predicament: You have to spend $300 million in the next 14 days or it all goes poof.

title: Focus of Detainee Trial Is Likely to Suit Bush
description: WASHINGTON  Harsh interrogations and Guantnamo Bay, secret prisons and warrantless eavesdropping, the war against Al Qaeda and the one in Iraq. On issue after issue, President Bush has showed little indication that he will shrink from the most controversial decisions of his tenure.

title: Gates, Truth and Afghanistan
description: By the Bush administrations standards, Defense Secretary Robert Gates was remarkably candid last week: acknowledging that popular opposition in Europe to the Iraq war was making it harder to persuade European governments to send more troops or take more risks to salvage Afghanistan.

title: N.J. Transit Investigates After Death on Tracks
description: New Jersey Transit suspended all scheduled repair work on Monday, one day after a track welder was struck and killed by a train in the first fatal accident involving an employee at the agency since 2001.

title: Williamstowns Season
description: Nicholas Martin, who recently took over as artistic director of the Williamstown Theater Festival after the departure of Roger Rees, has announced the festivals new season, beginning in June. The mainstage season will begin with the 1963 Joe Masteroff-Sheldon Harnick-Jerry Bock musical She Loves Me, followed by a production of Chekhovs Three Sisters, to be directed by Michael Greif. Next John Rando (Urinetown) will direct David Ivess adaptation of Georges Feydeaus Flea in Her Ear. A production of David Storeys 1970 play, Home, with a cast that includes Richard Easton and Dana Ivey, above, will finish the mainstage season. On the midsize Nikos stage, Campbell Scott will perform in The Atheist, Ronan Noones solo play about an ethically-challenged journalist, followed by a production of Harriet Jacobs by Lydia Diamond, and a new Theresa Rebeck play, The Understudy, about the backstage goings-on of a long-lost Kafka play that becomes a Broadway hit. Scott Ellis will direct; the Rebeck veteran and Tony Award-winner Julie White will star.

title: Managing the Present in Order to Protect the Future
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain tossed a baseball over and over on a sunny Monday at the Yankees minor league complex here. His valuable right arm was not wrapped in gauze. He did not have a pitching coach inquiring how he felt after each casual throw. Chamberlain tried to act like every other pitcher. Of course, he is not.

title: At Seton Hall, a Brief Lockdown
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.  The Seton Hall University campus was briefly locked down Monday night after a man shot himself, the university said.

title: The Claim: If Possible, Avoid Hospitals on Weekends
description: THE FACTS

title: When Reality Bites
description: Theres a big difference between the Republican and Democratic campaigns: The Republicans have split on policy grounds; the Democrats havent. Theres been a Republican divide between center and right, yet no Democratic divide between center and left.

title: Reinventing Date Night for Long-Married Couples
description: From our archives.

title: Settlement Gives Past Wages to Clothing Retailers Workers
description: Yellow Rat Bastard, a trendy apparel retailer based in SoHo, has agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a lawsuit over unpaid wages and overtime, the state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, announced on Monday.

title: The Physics of Coltranes Technique: How Pros Hit the High Notes
description: The saxophone, invented by Adolphe Sax, the Belgian instrument maker, and patented in 1846, is a curved tube of brass with holes. Its vibrations can reach high-pitched wailing notes, particularly when played by jazz musicians like John Coltrane.

title: Toy Magnet Swallowed? No Problem. Two? Call 911.
description: Swallowing a magnet the size of a watch battery is unlikely to cause health problems, but swallowing two can be fatal.

title: An Islands Fire Truck, Idle for Years, Goes Quickly on the Web
description: The red fire engine with the 100-foot-long extendable arm was called Super Truck. Left behind by the Coast Guard a decade ago, it sat on Governors Island in New York Harbor, unwanted by the firefighters stationed there and unavailable to others who coveted it from afar.

title: Long in the Tooth, but Short in Wingspan (for a Pterosaur)
description: Its the cutest little 120-million-year-old flying reptile you could ever hope to see.

title: You Want to Be a What? For the Son, Its a Calling, for the Mother, a Disgrace
description: Christopher Hitchens, Richard Dawkins and the many others railing from the best-seller lists about the global plague that is religious belief have a staunch ally in the title character of Grace, a play by Mick Gordon and A C Grayling that opened on Monday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: Making Rich Tales of Diaspora Take Flight
description: For Ronald K. Brown, the choreographer and dancer who formed Evidence Dance Company in 1985 at 19, evidence is a twin concept. Part of it is spiritual faith, evidence of things unseen, and part is physical movement used in telling stories from the African diaspora, evidence of endurance, suffering and triumph.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a Scotland Yard investigation into the assassination of Pakistan opposition leader Benazir Bhutto misidentified the location of the school attended by her 19-year-old son, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari. He attends Oxford University in Oxford, England, about 60 miles northwest of London. He is not a student in London.

title: Weeks Notables
description: PLAYER In Germany, the 22-year-old Brazilian midfielder Diego scored a goal in Werder Bremens 1-1 tie with Bayern Munich on Sunday. Diego denied reports last week that he was contemplating a summer move to Juventus of Italy.

title: Pettitte Will Not Testify at Public Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee will face off at a hearing of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform on Wednesday, without any testimony from two other ballplayers or a steroids distributor who had also been scheduled to testify, the committee announced Monday night.

title: Arizona Seeing Signs of Flight by Immigrants
description: PHOENIX  The signs of flight among Latino immigrants here are multiple: Families moving out of apartment complexes, schools reporting enrollment drops, business owners complaining about fewer clients.

title: Socit Gnrale Seeks to Raise $8 Billion
description: PARIS  The French bank Socit Gnrale offered millions of new shares to investors at a fire-sale price Monday, seeking to replace the more than $7 billion it had lost in a trading scandal.

title: A Father, a Son and a Political Imbroglio in France
description: PARIS  He is a lieutenant so loyal that President Nicolas Sarkozy personally rewarded him with the partys nomination for mayor of the affluent Paris suburb that Mr. Sarkozy himself long governed.

title: The Business Trip (X-Rated)
description: Two European business executives who travel to the worlds most glamorous cities like to get the most out of the endless launch parties, art fairs and exhibitions they attend. But when the fun is over, the two men agree not to speak about their exploits again: not with each other, nor with anyone else.

title: Taming the Toddler
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Foresees the Fall of an Immigration Record That Has Lasted a Century
description: If present trends continue, within two decades the nations foreign-born population will surpass the historic 19th-century peak of nearly 15 percent of all residents, according to projections released Monday.

title: A Woozy Thrill Ride on a Volcanos Edge
description: The songwriter David Yazbek is a daredevil juggler catching spiked pins in the traveling carnival of his imagination. The nihilism in his deceptively rollicking songs is sometimes so pungent that you wonder how much of his own bile he can stomach before he shrugs and allows those pins to bop him on the head.

title: Layoffs Across Yahoo  Finally
description: These are trying days for everyone at Yahoo  not just for Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive. As Mr. Yang and his board try to keep Microsoft from buying Yahoo  or try to get it to raise its offer before they agree to sell  the ax came down Tuesday on some 1,000 employees.

title: Fashion Test Drive
description: When Net-a-Porter announced it planned to sell two styles from the Halston runway the day after the show, I thought it would be interesting to test drive the concept. After all, this was the first time, to my knowledge, that a look from a designer runway would be immediately available to consumers. The plan was for Net-a-Porter to have two shirt dress styles, in chocolate brown or teal blue, and a draped silk jersey shift with a low back. The Halston show was last Monday, and Net-a-Porter planned to go live with its sale within 24 hours of the show. I felt like Betty Crocker, testing a new concept.

title: It's Show Time
description: The scene at the second day of the Westminster Dog Show in New York City.

title: Clinton Deputy Campaign Manager Quits
description: Mike Henry, a deputy campaign manager for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, has resigned from the Clinton team, writing in his farewell letter to the staff that he was stepping aside out of respect for the new leadership team led by Maggie Williams, who was installed as campaign manager on Sunday.

title: Live Blogging the Potomac Primaries
description: 10:57 p.m. | Wrapup:  Heres all you have to know about tonight, beyond Mr. Obamas landslide wins that washed out Mrs. Clinton in Virginia, Maryland, and the District: Mr. Obama beat Mrs. Clinton among women in both Virginia and Maryland. (There were no exit polls in the District.) And Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton were running about even among white voters. Hes also pulled ahead a bit in the race for delegates by the Associated Presss count.  Its serious retrenchment time in the Clinton camp. And its time to see if Mr. Obama can turn this series of wins since Super Tuesday into the Big Mo.

title: Mile-High Magic
description: When Paul Stastny went down Jan. 17 with an appendicitis in the middle of a brilliant sophomore season, the prognosis was grim for the Colorado Avalanche.

title: A Tyrannical Romance
description: If Charles Darwin were alive today, hed be turning 199: like Abraham Lincoln, he was born on Feb. 12 1809.

title: Oscar Crew Back in Session for Plan A
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Braised Short Ribs
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, puts an exotic twist on an old-fashioned dish.

title: Tina Fey To Host First Post-Strike Episode of SNL
description: As noted earlier today, Saturday Night Live, the only late-night television show that stayed off the air during the entirety of the writers strike, is expected to return on Feb. 23.

title: The 100-Day Writers Strike: A Timeline
description: The Writers Guild of America strike ended at the 100-day mark after a vote by guild members. Here is how the strike commenced and concluded:

title: Writers Vote Overwhelmingly To End Strike
description: Hollywoods writers made it official on Tuesday night, ending their bitterly fought strike at the 100-day mark by an overwhelming margin, Michael Cieply reports. Of 3,775 writers who cast ballots, 92.5 percent voted in favor of ending the strike. Officials of the Writers Guild of America West and the Writers Guild of America East disclosed results of the tally an hour after voting had closed at 6 p.m. here.

title: Audio Slide Show: Steroids and Congress, Past and Present
description: The New York Timess Jay Schreiber looks back at the last time Congress held a public hearing concerning steroids and baseball, and previews Wednesdays hearing featuring Roger Clemens and his former trainer, Brian McNamee, regarding accusations contained in the Mitchell report.

title: Usually on Attack, U.S. Attorney in Newark Finds Himself on the Defensive
description: In the six years that he has been the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie has investigated freeholders and governors, party hacks and United States senators, winning indictments against Republicans and Democrats alike and obtaining convictions or guilty pleas against more than 125 public officials without losing a case.

title: Warding Off Evil Spirits, but Not Toll of Affluence
description: MIYAKO ISLAND, Japan  With less than an hour of daylight left, the residents of Nobaru Village here gathered on a recent Saturday to drive evil spirits from their community.

title: Dorm Rooms Are Revoked Over Grades
description: OLD WESTBURY, N.Y.  The day before she was to return to the State University of New York campus here for her second semester, Denisha Dennis opened a letter from the administration to learn she had been kicked out of the dormitory because her grade point average had fallen below 2.0.

title: Campaign Correspondence Suggests Giulianis Committee Is in a Financial Hole
description: WASHINGTON  Winding down a presidential campaign that sputters  like cleaning up after one of those great Hollywood epics that remain unfinished  can be a complicated, joyless task. After the dream dies, there are lots of bills to pay and loose ends to tie up.

title: Dominicans Say Cockfighting Is in Their Blood
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  It is Sunday morning at the Club Gallistico de San Martn, and merengue pulses from two loudspeakers by the outdoor bar. But over by the plexiglass cages, the din of 106 roosters overpowers any other sound.

title: France: Sarkozys Son Not a Candidate
description: President Nicolas Sarkozys 21-year-old son, Jean, will not be a candidate for local office next month in Neuilly, the wealthy Paris suburb that his father ran as mayor from 1983 to 2003, according to news reports. Speculation that he might run came after he turned against the presidents handpicked but unpopular candidate for mayor, David Martinon, after a poll suggested Mr. Martinon would lose the race, and he withdrew.

title: Sex Discrimination Suit Reinstated
description: An appeals court in Seattle has reinstated a lawsuit against the University of Washington by a woman who said she was raped by a football player. The university is accused of sex discrimination.The woman is a former equipment manager who says she was assaulted by Roc Alexander in 2001, after they ended a relationship. Alexander denies the rape accusation. He now plays for the Houston Texans.A lawyer for the university, Andrew Cooley, said that the woman never told the university that she had been raped and that he considered the matter closed after mediation.Rebecca Roe, a lawyer for the woman, said that using mediation was inappropriate because it suggested shared responsibility.

title: Making a Case for a Pause in Troop Cutbacks in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  There is an overarching reason American commanders in Iraq want a pause in American troop reductions this summer: The United States has learned through painful experience that security can rapidly deteriorate if it overestimates the ability of Iraqs forces to keep the peace.

title: Hydrogen Leak in Connecticut Forces Dozens From Homes
description: MIDDLEBURY, Conn.  Dozens of homes were evacuated here early Tuesday after a tractor-trailer ran off the shoulder on Interstate 84, tumbled down an embankment and began leaking highly volatile hydrogen gas.

title: Reliving an Encounter With Rock n Roll Royalty, in Her Own Write
description: It seems almost inconceivable that a sense of innocence could be restored to the activity of stargazing. I am not referring to the contemplation of things twinkling in the night sky, of course, but to the adoration of celebrities gleaming from the front pages of glossy magazines.

title: Young, in Love, Ill at Ease and Mad at Their Parents
description: Here I am, young and pretty/Still Im sweeping up the floor again, sings the Oregon hipster Bean (Julie Fitzpatrick) in the opening of the short musical Co-Op. Its a bad start. What painfully shy girl suffering from low self-esteem calls herself pretty? But dont lose faith so soon.

title: Busch and Stewart on Probation
description: Nascar placed the drivers Kurt Busch and Tony Stewart on probation for six races Tuesday, beginning with the Daytona 500. The punishment resulted from a confrontation between the two after a wreck in practice last week.Nascar officials came into this season saying that drivers would be given more latitude to show emotion this year, and the relatively light nature of Tuesdays punishments would seem to support that.No one would confirm that Stewart punched Busch at a meeting with officials, but Robin Pemberton, Nascars vice president for competition, said that how they conducted themselves after the accident, from there through the rest of the evening, is why the penalties were equal.But the Nascar spokesman Ramsey Poston noted, If you are on probation for an altercation with another driver, and you have a second incident during that probation period, we are going to take action.

title: Power Couples Take Command With Quiet Romance
description: The annual ballet gala produced by Solomon Tencer tends to be long on fun and interesting dancers, partly because it plays down the usual tacky glamour of such events. But a little more razzle-dazzle would have been welcome on Monday night at the New York State Theater, when Stars of the 21st Century rolled out an evening of 13 pas de deux and solos. Live music might also have helped.

title: A Vicious Count, His Family and Their Acts of Cruelty
description: Those who cant do, teach, the old insult goes. Which brings us to Antonin Artaud, the French poet and essayist. He taught, in the sense that his theories on theater have been given some credence. But he sure couldnt do, as the new production of his play The Cenci at the Ohio Theater reminds us.

title: Frank J. Dixon Dies at 87; Led Way in Immunology
description: Dr. Frank J. Dixon, whose penetrating studies of how misdirected responses by the immune system can cause diseases that damage the kidneys and other organs won him an Albert Lasker Award in 1975, died on Feb. 8 at his home in San Diego. He was 87.

title: Buffett Offers Aid on Bonds, but at a Price
description: Warren E. Buffett volunteered on Tuesday to rescue Wall Street from its latest looming crisis.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about young journalists who follow presidential candidates for television networks to blog and file frequent video clips misspelled the given name of one such journalist, hired by ABC and assigned to John McCain. He is Bret Hovell, not Brett.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Feb. 1 with an art review of Picturing New York: The Art of Yvonne Jacquette and Rudy Burckhardt, at the Museum of the City of New York, included a title provided by the museum that misidentifies the Manhattan site shown in a Rudy Burckhardt photograph. While the title is 34th Street, the photograph shows the intersection of Seventh Avenue and 50th Street, not 34th Street. (According to the museum the photograph, in which a store with the sign A&K Deli Market can be seen in the background, had an alternate title, Deli Market.)

title: Report Faults Mental Care for Iraq Veterans at Upstate Base
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y.  The four tours in Iraq served by the Second Brigade at Fort Drum here have created an unusual level of stress, especially after the standard Iraq tour was increased to 15 months from 12. Yet according to a new report on the shortcomings of mental health care at the base, a soldiers wait to be seen for psychological help can take more than a month.

title: U.N. Weighs a Ban on Weapons in Space, but U.S. Still Objects
description: GENEVA  The Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, on Tuesday presented a Russian-Chinese draft treaty banning weapons in space to the United Nations Conference on Disarmament, an idea that was quickly rejected by the United States.

title: Bush, at Commemoration, Says Nooses Are Symbol of Gross Injustice
description: WASHINGTON  Making some of his most pointed remarks on race relations, President Bush on Tuesday denounced racially charged incidents involving nooses and called the era of lynchings from the 19th to the 20th centuries a shameful chapter in American history.

title: Garbage Truck Kills 2 Pedestrians
description: Two people were killed and two others were injured on Tuesday night when a garbage truck jumped the curb on West 35th Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, in Manhattan about 10:30 p.m., the police said. Investigators were looking into whether the driver may have had a medical problem.

title: The War on Drugs Starts Here
description: If we have learned one thing in the protracted war on drugs, it is that reining in illicit drug trafficking will require more than fighting cartels south of the border. Nothing can be achieved unless this country curbs its own demand for illegal narcotics.

title: Senate Passes Interrogation Ban
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted 51 to 45 on Wednesday afternoon to ban waterboarding and other harsh interrogation methods used by the Central Intelligence Agency against high-level terrorism suspects.

title: You Think Its Easy to Schlep Those Cases in Four-Inch Heels?
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Minutes before showtime on the set of Deal or No Deal, Wendi San George, the programs chief stylist, is trying to head off a crisis.

title: City Moves to Overturn 1974 Ruling on Race
description: New York City went to court on Tuesday seeking to undo a 1974 desegregation order for a middle school in southwest Brooklyn, arguing that the ruling was outdated and no longer reflected the racial mix of the neighborhood.

title: Where Choreography Becomes a Mere Point of Embarkation
description: In November the Performa 07 biennial showed previously unseen film of Group I and Group II, two important Deborah Hay works from 1968, a time when she was using untrained dancers to enact strict, minimalist patterns. This week Dance Theater Workshop presented Solo Adaptations, four interpretations of Ms. Hays dance Room over two nights by highly trained performers.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: Internet Sex Video Case Stirs Free-Speech Issues in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  A series of arrests here for posting sexually explicit images of what appear to be some of Asias best-known pop stars has led to a division among Internet users over free speech, and questions of selective police enforcement of obscenity laws.

title: Americans Spend More to Treat Spine Woes
description: Americans are spending more money than ever to treat spine problems, but their backs are not getting any better.

title: A Chicago Hotels New Life in a Rising Area
description: CHICAGO  The restoration of the Blackstone, a fabled but long vacant hotel on South Michigan Avenue here, is evidence of a reviving lodging market in one of the countrys largest convention cities. It also reflects the newfound vitality of the South Loop neighborhood in the wake of the development of nearby Millennium Park in the early 2000s.

title: Yahoo Is Said to Be in Talks With News Corp.
description: Yahoo has begun discussions with News Corporation to explore alternatives to Microsofts buyout offer, people familiar with the talks said on Wednesday.

title: Damaging Information Said to Await Clemens
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens will be confronted with a new and damaging affidavit from Andy Pettitte when he appears before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform on Wednesday to testify about allegations that he used performance-enhancing drugs, two lawyers familiar with the matter said late Tuesday.

title: Bolshois Director Wont Join City Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet and Alexei Ratmansky have ended their pas de deux. After inviting Mr. Ratmansky to become its resident choreographer, City Ballet said Tuesday that he would not be taking the job because he was too busy.

title: A Reversal on School Vouchers, Then a Tempest
description: Sol Stern is at it again.

title: A Diabetes Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Kirk Browning, 86, Dies; Put the Arts on TV
description: Kirk Browning, whose unusual career path took him from chicken farmer to television director of Live From Lincoln Center, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Plan to Aid Borrowers Is Greeted by Criticism
description: A Bush administration plan to delay foreclosures for some troubled homeowners met a cool reaction on Tuesday from politicians and investors who questioned its ability to stave off what could be a long and painful string of mortgage defaults.

title: In Price and Supply, Wheat Is the Unstable Staple
description: CHICAGO  For decades, wheat was a commodity no American needed to think much about, except the farmers who grew it. The grain was usually plentiful and prices were low.

title: Quitting Facebook Gets Easier
description: Aiming to address the privacy concerns of disenchanted users, Facebook.com said on Tuesday that it was trying to make it easier for people to delete their accounts permanently from the social networking site.

title: Snow Is Great. But That Road Plan to Get to It?
description: DENVER  The deepest snows in nearly 30 years have fallen this winter in some corners of the West, reinvigorating a thorny, prolonged debate for many of the 2.4 million people in the Denver metropolitan region  how to get to where the snow is.

title: Lake Mead Could Be Within a Few Years of Going Dry, Study Finds
description: Lake Mead, the vast reservoir for the Colorado River water that sustains the fast-growing cities of Phoenix and Las Vegas, could lose water faster than previously thought and run dry within 13 years, according to a new study by scientists at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Monday about the actor Roy Scheider erroneously included the daughter from his first marriage among his survivors. The daughter, Maximillia Connelly Lord, died in 2006. The obituary also misspelled the surname of Mr. Scheiders wife. She is Brenda Siemer, not Seimer.

title: Writers Vote to End Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods writers made it official on Tuesday night, voting to end their bitterly fought strike at the 100-day mark by an overwhelming margin.

title: Strawberry Owes I.R.S.
description: Darryl Strawberry, a former Mets and Yankees slugger, must pay the Internal Revenue Service more than $430,000 in back taxes, penalties and interest, according to a judgment signed Tuesday by a United States District Court judge in West Palm Beach, Fla.Strawberry was convicted of tax evasion in 1995 over income from autographs and memorabilia. He is agreeing to pay the I.R.S. for tax years 1989 and 1990.

title: Three Cheers for the Also-Rans
description: THE quest for greatness is the stuff of myth and romance. Americans revere the star-bound strivers, whether Lincoln or Edison, Babe Ruth or Muhammad Ali, Bill Gates or Warren Buffett, those who aimed to be the toppermost of the poppermost, as the Beatles used to say, and made it. Few remember the good, the competent, the runner-up.

title: There Will Be Scandal: An Oil Stain on the Jazz Age
description: Scandals in Washington come and go, but Teapot Dome remains one of the real humdingers. In a scheme of breathtaking audacity a handful of oil tycoons and corrupt government officials nearly managed to make away with a hefty percentage of the nations petroleum reserves. It was, in the words of Thomas J. Walsh, the senator whose committee hearings blew the lid off the teapot, the most stupendous piece of thievery known to our annals, or perhaps to those of any other country.

title: A Flawed Feminist Test
description: WASHINGTON

title: No Pause Button: TV Studios and Writers Play Catch-Up After Strike
description: With writers expected to return to their posts on the television-production assembly line first thing on Wednesday morning, the enormous machinery that generates episodes of series will get a huge restart, and it is expected to go full tilt for months.

title: Goodell and Specter Ready to Meet
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell will travel to Washington on Wednesday to meet with Senator Arlen Specter for a discussion about the leagues investigation into the Patriots spying on other teams.

title: Senate Votes to Expand Spy Powers
description: WASHINGTON  After more than a year of wrangling, the Senate handed the White House a major victory on Tuesday by voting to broaden the governments spy powers and to give legal protection to phone companies that cooperated in President Bushs program of eavesdropping without warrants.

title: A Country Pantheon
description: Emmylou Harris, right, Tom T. Hall, the Statler Brothers and Ernest Stoneman, who died in 1968, are bound for glory in the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. Their selection was announced on Tuesday; formal induction takes place later.

title: Religion Joins Custody Cases, to Judges Unease
description: MADISON, Ala.  On a January night nine years ago, Laura Snider was saved.

title: British Sprinter to Run at Worlds
description: The sprinter Dwain Chambers will run for Britain at the world indoor track and field championships next month in Spain after winning a legal fight to be placed on the team.The British selection committee said Tuesday that it reluctantly agreed to put Chambers on the team. He earned a spot on the team by winning the 60-meter race at Sundays qualifier.He served a two-year suspension, from 2003 to 2005, after testing positive for the steroid THG, and returned to the sport only six weeks ago.Britains governing body for track and field had said he could not run until he had spent a year proving he was drug-free, but Chambers challenged that ruling. One of his lawyers, Nick Collins, said UK Athletics had no legal case to bar him.

title: Totally Spent
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Speaker Seeks Hiatus on Sales Tax for a Week
description: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, striking a campaign-style tone, proposed a mix of modest cost-saving initiatives, spending plans and tax-cutting proposals on Tuesday, saying the measures would help to ignite economic activity in the city.

title: All Spiffed Up in Paris
description: The Arc de Triomphe in Paris reintroduced its museum, right, with a new permanent exhibition highlighting the history of the site. More than $1.45 million was spent to clean and refurbish the museum in the first major makeover since it opened, in 1929, Jean-Paul Ciret, director of cultural development for Frances national monuments, said in a telephone interview. The arc is the most symbolic monument of France, like the Eiffel Tower is a symbol of Paris, he said. The exhibition, officially inaugurated by culture officials on Monday, includes video images showing famous arches throughout Europe and details of the monuments frieze. The arch, which opened in 1836, was visited by 1.3 million people last year, more than 80 percent of them foreigners.

title: Clemens Autograph Seekers May Have Broken Federal Law
description: WASHINGTON  Any members of the House oversight committee or their staff who asked Roger Clemens for an autograph during his tour of the Capitol over the past week might have violated a federal law against soliciting things of value from people with interests before the committee, several lawyers with expertise in Congressional ethics laws said.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: At Trial, Lawyer Says Buffett Gave Approval
description: HARTFORD  The lawyer defending the former chief executive of General Reinsurance against fraud charges pointed the finger Tuesday at the investor Warren E. Buffett.

title: Obama and McCain Sweep 3 Primaries
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama rolled to victory by large margins in Virginia, Maryland and the District of Columbia on Tuesday, extending his winning streak over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to eight Democratic nominating contests.

title: From Paris, With Hustle
description: WHEN I was young and studying in Paris I had a friend, Stphanie, who helped demystify some of the more intimate aspects of French culture. A chic gamine, she taught me the delights of forthright flirting, the art of knotting a silk scarf just so and perhaps most important, how to make a sublime dinner-party dessert in five minutes flat.

title: New Pakistan Army Chief Orders Military Out of Civilian Government Agencies, Reversing Musharraf Policy
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The new army chief of Pakistan has ordered the withdrawal of military officers from the governments civil departments, officials said Tuesday, an action that reverses an important policy of his predecessor, President Pervez Musharraf.

title: Limbo for U.S. Women Reporting Iraq Assaults
description: WASHINGTON  Mary Beth Kineston, an Ohio resident who went to Iraq to drive trucks, thought she had endured the worst when her supply convoy was ambushed in April 2004. After car bombs exploded and insurgents began firing on the road between Baghdad and Balad, she and other military contractors were saved only when Army Black Hawk helicopters arrived.

title: Australia Says Sorry to Aborigines for Mistreatment
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Kevin Rudd opened a new chapter in Australias tortured relations with its indigenous peoples on Wednesday with a comprehensive and moving apology for past wrongs and a call for bipartisan action to improve the lives of Australias Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.

title: Australia Sends Troops to East Timor
description: DILI, East Timor  Australia rushed troop reinforcements into East Timor on Tuesday to help enforce a security clampdown a day after two assassination attempts prompted fears of unrest.

title: Tale of Dead Texas Dog Bites Mayor Who Told It
description: ALICE, Tex.  Rustling has been frowned upon in this South Texas cow and cotton town since long before it was named for the youngest daughter of the founder of the nearby King Ranch.

title: New Chairman at Drug Maker
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, a drug maker, named its chief executive, James M. Cornelius, as board chairman, succeeding James D. Robinson III, who resigned as nonexecutive chairman.

title: Instead of Men Behaving Badly, MSNBC Strains for a Polite Primary Night
description: At its best, which is usually on election nights or after a debate, MSNBC makes viewers feel that they are in a neighborhood bar with political insiders, listening in on the banter and smart assessments. At its worst, the cable news channel makes viewers feel they are in a neighborhood bar waiting on political insiders, the butt of their banter and smart-aleck assessments.

title: Calendar
description: Just Say Cheese

title: Economists Tea Leaves Point to Recession
description: According to Wall Streets forecasters, the recession of 2008 is now unavoidable. That is, if you read between the lines of their predictions.

title: Ear Infections Too Often Misdiagnosed, Then Overtreated
description: As many parents know all too well, ear infections are the scourge of early childhood, causing apparent agony for children and many sleepless nights for families. Attempts to provide quick relief may be why ear infections have traditionally been overdiagnosed and overtreated. Doctors continue to write millions of antibiotic prescriptions for acute otitis media, as the condition is medically known, despite what the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality has called a woeful lack of evidence for their use. In many cases the drugs may do more harm than good, leading to side effects, antibiotic resistance and a cycle of hard-to-treat and recurring infections.

title: Clemens Says Pettitte Was Wrong About H.G.H. Remark
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens, in heated and sometimes indignant testimony, told a House oversight committee on Wednesday that his former teammate Andy Pettitte misremembers two conversations they had about human growth hormone, and that he was shocked to learn later that Mr. Pettitte had used the substance himself.

title: Plot Would Thicken, if the Writers Remembered It
description: LOS ANGELES  As 10 writers for the hit CBS drama NCIS returned to work Wednesday following a 100-day strike, Shane Brennan, the shows writer-producer, asked a question that drew blank stares. Can anyone remember what we were working on three months ago?

title: Selected Studies: Ear Infections
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information: ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: My Saudi Valentine
description: TOMORROW will be my second Valentines Day in the United States. As Ive discovered, the celebration here bears little resemblance to the one I know from growing up in Saudi Arabia.

title: With Stimulus Package, the Big Winner Could Be Small Business
description: Businesses, large and small, will be directly helped by the new economic stimulus legislation passed by Congress last week. But small businesses, in particular, may get the biggest lift indirectly  from consumers spending their tax rebates.

title: Lawyer Who Handled Witnesses Becomes One
description: The only thing separating Roger Clemens and his accuser Brian McNamee on Wednesday will be the lawyer who did much of the heavy lifting behind the scenes on the Mitchell report.

title: Putin Strengthens His Legacy
description: There has been a lot of talk about Vladimir Putins legacy. On Friday, he gave a 45-minute speech that, as Pravda put it, was meant to remind everyone of the terrible situation in Russia before Putin. But Mr. Putins real legacy needs no speech or spin from Pravda.

title: California: Pet Sterilization Is Ordered
description: Trying to reduce the number of animals the citys shelters kill each year, the Los Angeles City Council voted to require sterilization of cats and dogs at age 4 months or older. The ordinance, which passed 14 to 1, is also meant to curb illegal breeding and dog fighting, said Councilman Richard Alarcon, the sponsor. One of the ordinances biggest supporters was the retired game show host Bob Barker, who for 25 years concluded the Price Is Right by urging viewers to spay or neuter their pets. He has put about $35 million of his own money toward programs that subsidize those operations. Mr. Barker, who will be named by Mr. Alarcon to an outreach committee, said the statute would not be a burden on poor residents because the city offered about 11,000 vouchers for free operations a year and 20,000 for discounts. The bill has seven categories of exemptions, including licensed breeders and show, guide and law enforcement dogs.

title: Space Station Laboratory Powered Up
description: American and European astronauts inaugurated the Columbus science laboratory, the newest addition to the International Space Station and Europes largest contribution. The 14-ton module, which cost about $2 billion, was delivered last weekend and installed Monday during a spacewalk. It will expand the range of zero-gravity experiments aboard the station. NASA also said a section of thermal blanket that pulled free during the shuttles climb to orbit last week did not need repair and would adequately protect the shuttle during re-entry next week.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jailhouse Notes
description: The rapper the Game was sentenced on Monday to 60 days in jail after pleading no contest to felony possession of a firearm in a school zone, The Associated Press reported. Under a plea agreement, two other counts against him were dropped, but his sentence also includes 150 hours of community service and three years of probation. The Game, 28, above, whose real name is Jayceon Terrell Taylor, was accused of pulling a gun on an opposing player during a pickup basketball game at a south Los Angeles school nearly a year ago. ... A three-judge court in Los Angeles has denied an appeal by the R&B singer Ronald Isley of his 37-month federal sentence for tax evasion. Mr. Isley, 66, a member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and one of the Isley Brothers, whose hits included Twist and Shout, argued that his sentence was unreasonable because of his age and poor health. The appellate court said the trial judge correctly balanced the need to sanction Mr. Isleys pathological tax evasion against the need to accommodate Mr. Isleys poor health. Mr. Isley is in the Federal Correctional Institution in Terre Haute, Ind. His projected release date is April 2010.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Saturday about a concert production of Applause at City Center, starring Christine Ebersole, misstated the year Ms. Ebersole won a Tony for her performance in Grey Gardens. It was 2007, not this year.

title: Dark May Be King, but Milk Chocolate Makes a Move
description: CHOCOLATES dark mood is lightening at last.

title: Iraqis Search for 2 Kidnapped Journalists
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi security forces in the southern city of Basra searched Tuesday for two CBS television journalists who were captured there over the weekend, while in Baghdad Parliament remained stalemated on the budget and other major legislation.

title: Quit Kibitzing and Pass the Gribenes
description: IN time, wed get to the pastrami sandwich, and wed quibble over its height and quarrel about condiments. Condiments are personal.

title: Venom? Cult? Its Campaign Fever
description: To the Editor:

title: Beagle, a Breed Long Unsung, Wins Best in Show
description: When Dr. J. Donald Jones, the judge for the best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show Tuesday night, looked at the seven competitors for the title, he saw four breeds that had been denied the crown and three that had worn it.

title: New Home for Mets: On Time, On Budget
description: Standing in the numbing cold amid fluttering snowflakes, Jeff Wilpon expressed few warm, fuzzy feelings for Shea Stadium on Tuesday as he led a guided tour of Citi Field, the adjacent future home of the Mets.

title: McCain Signs Up a Bush Fund-Raising Organizer
