description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain began tapping into President Bushs prized political donor base on Tuesday as his campaign announced that Mercer Reynolds, who helped Mr. Bush raise a record $273 million for the 2004 re-election campaign, would be the national finance co-chairman for Mr. McCain.

title: Aid for Business in Stimulus Package
description: The economic stimulus legislation approved by Congress on Thursday includes two provisions that would benefit businesses. The first raises  to $250,000 in 2008, from $128,000  the dollar amount of limits on expensing. The second allows for a one-year depreciation deduction of 50 percent of the cost of the property, in addition to regular depreciation on the remaining cost. Barbara Weltman, a lawyer and author of J. K. Lassers Small Business Taxes, 2008, provides examples of how both would work.

title: A New Look at How Mary Lost Her Head, Way Back When
description: Poor Elizabeth Tudor. Although she was an avid theater lover and presided over one of the greatest periods the English stage has known, playwrights revile her for beheading her cousin and rival, Mary Stuart, a k a Mary, Queen of Scots. The latest to take up Marys cause is Glyn Maxwell in The Lifeblood, staged by the Phoenix Theater Ensemble at the Connelly Theater.

title: Brazil: Approval for Gene-Altered Corn
description: The Monsanto Company and Bayer received final government approval in Brazil to start selling genetically modified corn seeds that resist insects and herbicides. The National Biotechnology Council gave final approval for Monsantos insect-resistant YieldGard Corn Borer and Bayers herbicide-resistant Liberty Link corn, a council spokesman, Rafael Godoi, said.

title: Two Literary Laurels
description: Lucette Lagnado, a senior special writer and investigative reporter for The Wall Street Journal, has won the $100,000 Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature for her memoir, The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit: My Familys Exodus From Old Cairo to the New World (HarperCollins/Ecco). Ms. Lagnado was chosen by the Jewish Book Council for her demonstration of a fresh vision and evidence of future potential to further contribute to the Jewish literary community. ... Tom Sleigh of Brooklyn, a teacher in the creative writing program at Hunter College, has won the $100,000 Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award for his collection Space Walk (Houghton Mifflin). The annual award, established in 1992 in honor of the poet Kingsley Tufts and administered by Claremont Graduate University in Claremont, Calif., recognizes a poet who is past the very beginning but has not yet reached the acknowledged pinnacle of his or her career.

title: G.M. Offers Buyouts to 74,000
description: DETROIT  A surprisingly tough fourth quarter and a gloomy outlook for the United States market prompted General Motors to offer buyouts Tuesday to its entire unionized work force.

title: I Love You, but You Love Meat
description: SOME relationships run aground on the perilous shoals of money, sex or religion. When Shauna Jamess new romance hit the rocks, the culprit was wheat.

title: In France, a Creative Country House
description: MENTON, France

title: Boston Scientific Loses Patent Trial
description: A jury in Texas has ruled that Boston Scientifics drug-coated stents infringe a 1997 patent issued to a radiologist in Princeton, N.J., and has awarded the inventor $431 million in damages, Boston Scientific said Tuesday. The suit by the patent holder, Dr. Bruce N. Saffran, did not seek to halt sales of the stents.

title: Fire at Hunts Point Meat Market Is Mostly Confined to One Building
description: Every day, thousands of trucks come and go from Hunts Point, a bulge of land on the Bronx waterfront that serves as a supermarket for the New York region.

title: Retail Sales Report Lifts Stocks
description: Stocks rallied on Wednesday for the third day in a row as investors embraced the first positive economic news in weeks: an unexpected climb in retail sales in January. But economists said the report was far from an all-clear on the recession front.

title: Wooing Hispanics, With Spanish
description: Three weeks from the Texas primary on March 4, the Democratic candidates have already started a fierce tug-of-war over the states Hispanic voters.

title: Coaxing Exotic Flavor From Familiar Elements
description: THERE is hardly a combination of flavors that does not work with short ribs, as long as you braise them. The old French combination of aromatic vegetables and herbs  onions, celery, carrot, garlic, thyme and bay leaf  and the standard Korean kalbi jim  soy, sugar, sesame seeds, oil, garlic and ginger  have little in common except the cooking technique and the meat, yet theyre both stunning classics.

title: New York Investigates Medical Rate Setting
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Wednesday that he was investigating whether the nations health insurance companies had systematically forced patients to pay more than they should when using doctors or hospitals outside of their insurers networks.

title: Deal Reported on Running Thoroughbred Race Tracks
description: State officials have agreed on the broad outlines of a deal over the future of New Yorks troubled thoroughbred horse-racing franchise, an individual familiar with the negotiations said on Tuesday.

title: Warmth for Americans in Once Hostile Tehran
description: TEHRAN  When the shah ruled Iran, the Westernized elite enjoyed Hollywood movies at a small theater in the center of the city. Today, that theater is an Islamic cultural center and a meeting place for fundamentalists.

title: A Fair Trade Approach to Licensed College Gear
description: One day seven or eight years ago in Bangkok, Joe Falcone began to feel an uncomfortable sensation of futility. The grandson of garment workers, he had been working in Asias clothing factories for nearly a decade, making certain they complied with labor and environmental laws. The idea was to assure American consumers their apparel and shoes were not made in sweatshops.

title: Japan: Wholesale Prices Driving Inflation
description: Wholesale prices rose at the fastest pace in a quarter-century, led by higher oil and wheat costs that are causing inflation. Producer prices climbed 3 percent in January from a year earlier, after a 2.6 percent gain in December, the Bank of Japan said. Consumer prices rose the most in almost a decade in December, which, combined with falling wages, drove household sentiment to a four-year low. The current-account surplus narrowed for the first time in a year in December as oil pushed the nations import bill to a record, a separate report showed. The gap shrank 4.7 percent to 1.69 trillion yen ($15.7 billion) from a year earlier, the finance ministry said.

title: Innocence Lost, on a Battlefield Somewhere in Africa
description: The title character of Ezra, Newton I. Aduakas scorching portrait of an African child who is kidnapped and turned into a soldier for a rebel militia, is first seen as an innocent little boy crossing a bridge on his way to school. Inside, a teacher scrawls the date, July 13, 1992, on the blackboard and assigns the pupils an essay, Why I Love My Country.

title: Yahoo Acquires Ad Technology Company
description: Even as Yahoo tries to stay out of Microsofts grip, the company is busy closing acquisitions of its own.

title: Trying for a Fourth Olympics
description: Blaine Wilson, a five-time national champion, earned a spot on the United States mens team Tuesday, and will receive funding for three months. He is attempting a comeback at 33, trying to make his fourth Olympics.

title: What You Get for ...$900,000
description: Pinehurst, N.C.

title: Human Error, Not Clock, May Have Cost Rutgers
description: The creator of the timing system used in the controversial Tennessee-Rutgers womens game Monday night said he suspected that human error led to the clocks stopping and then suddenly restarting in the final seconds.

title: Presidents Resolve Ukraine Gas Dispute
description: MOSCOW  The presidents of Russia and Ukraine averted a threatened cutoff of natural gas supplies to Ukraine on Tuesday, at the same time that Russias president said his country might aim nuclear missiles at Ukraine if it followed through on its intention to join NATO.

title: A Rare Jewish Bid for the Classically Sacred Concert
description: The sacred side of the classical repertory does not offer a great deal that speaks directly to Jewish listeners. Several of Handels oratorios fit the bill, given his predilection for the books of the Hebrew Bible, and Brahmss German Requiem is appealingly ecumenical. Its even possible to take an archaeological approach to the Mass, teasing out traces of the Hebrew Kedushah prayer, which begins with the word Holy repeated thrice, in the Sanctus, which does the same.

title: Flawed Software Upgrade Caused BlackBerry Malfunction
description: OTTAWA  As was the case with last years BlackBerry service failure, Research In Motion blamed a flawed software upgrade for shutting down wireless e-mail messages to millions of its North American subscribers for about three hours on Monday.

title: Unnecessary Harm
description: The Bush administrations decision to put six detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, on trial before military tribunals and to seek the death penalty is both a betrayal of American ideals and simply bad strategy. Instead of being what they could and should be  a model of justice dispensed impartially, surely and dispassionately  the trials will proceed under deeply flawed procedures that violate this countrys basic fairness. The intense negative attention they will receive will do enormous damage to what is left of Americas standing in world opinion.

title: Big Deal for NBC
description: A 90-minute edition of Deal or No Deal lifted NBC to another No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsens estimates, 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the game show from 9:30 to 11 p.m., making it the nights top-rated broadcast. NBC also fared well earlier in the night as American Gladiators won its 8 to 9:30 time slot among adults 18 to 49, while attracting a modest 8.8 million viewers. ABCs Dance War delivered slightly more viewers during the time period (9.2 million), but it lagged far behind in the 18-to-49 set, falling to its lowest ratings to date in that demographic. ABC finished a distant fourth over all as both Notes From the Underbelly at 9:30 (4.3 million) and October Road at 10 (4 million) continued to struggle. Fox was second in the 18-t0-49 set with Prison Break at 8 (7.9 million total viewers) and Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles at 9 (8.3 million). CBS fared slightly better in total viewers with its comedy lineup, which included strong ratings for a Two and a Half Men repeat at 9 (11.9 million).

title: Times Co. Nominates Two for Election as Directors
description: The New York Times Company, which is under pressure from a group of hedge funds that want to gain representation on its board, said Tuesday that it had nominated two candidates to fill director vacancies.

title: Teachers Union President to Step Down; New Yorker Is Seen as Successor
description: Edward J. McElroy, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, announced Tuesday that he would step down in the summer, a move widely expected to put Randi Weingarten, the president of the teachers union in New York City, in line to succeed him.

title: An Uneven Year Over, a Met Seeks the Grind
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Joe Smith wants to set the record straight. Although he is not about to beg the team elders  Billy Wagner, for instance  to dress him up in womens clothing (leather miniskirt?) or an outlandish costume (Scooby-Doo, anyone?), he would not necessarily mind, either.

title: Recipe: Pomegranate-Rose Cream Meringues
description: Time: 2 hours, plus 2 hours cooling

title: House Vote on Contempt Is Expected Soon
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic House leaders plan to force a vote as early as Thursday on holding Joshua B. Bolten, White House chief of staff, and Harriet E. Miers, former White House counsel, in contempt of Congress.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in The Caucus column on Thursday about record voter turnouts in the Feb. 5 nominating contests referred imprecisely to the turnouts in Utah and New York, and the Jan. 8 primaries in New Hampshire. In each case, the turnout figures represented the percentage of all eligible citizens who voted in each primary, not the percentage of registered Democratic or Republican voters who did so. Turnouts in the three states were: 28.5 percent in the New Hampshire Democratic primary and 23.3 percent in the states Republican primary; 7.8 percent in the Utah Democratic primary and 18 percent in its Republican primary; and 13.6 percent in the New York Democratic primary. (The turnout figure for New Yorks Republican primary was 4.8 percent.) (Go to Article)

title: In Second Trial, Avastin Is Found Effective in Treating Breast Cancer
description: Genentech said Tuesday that a new clinical trial had shown that its best-selling drug Avastin was effective in treating breast cancer, a finding that could increase the chances that the product will be approved for that use.

title: Verdian Victims of the Plague of Doubt
description: The title role of Verdis Otello is probably the most intimidating challenge for tenors in the entire Italian repertory. It demands visceral dramatic intensity, great vocal stamina and abundant power. Yet an Otello must also be able to shape Verdis phrases with lyrical elegance. Its always an event when a tenor takes on Otello for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Mexico: Axa Buys Ing Insurance Unit
description: Axa, Europes second-largest insurer, agreed to buy part of the ING Groeps insurance business in Mexico for 1 billion euros ($1.5 billion), the Dutch-based financial services group said in a statement. ING, based in Amsterdam, said it was selling the business, Seguros ING, and its subsidiaries.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the future of the Gambino crime family, whose entire leadership was arrested in federal raids last week, misidentified the boss of the Luchese family who was indicted in 1985 after a secret recording device placed in his Jaguar picked up incriminating conversations. It was Anthony Corallo, not Anthony Salerno. (Mr. Salerno, who was also indicted that year, was a leader of the Genovese family.) The error also appeared in a caption with a picture of Mr. Salerno.

title: Star Wars: The Toons
description: New chapters in the everlasting George Lucas Star Wars saga will turn up on Turner Broadcastings Cartoon Network in the fall. The network broadcasts of the new computer-generated animated series, Star Wars: The Clone Wars, will be followed by broadcasts on TNT. Lucasfilm Animation has produced more than 30 half-hour episodes about the battle of Jedi Knights against villains seeking control of the galaxy. The series will follow the premiere of a film of the same title on Aug. 15.

title: Venom? Cult? Its Campaign Fever
description: To the Editor:

title: A Changing View of Ear Infections
description: Dr. Stephen Berman, a pediatrician at the University of Colorado School of Medicine, has written extensively about ear infections. My view on the management of ear infections has changed over the past decade, because of the rise of resistant bacteria and the importance of excessive antibiotic use in contributing to this rise, Dr. Berman said. Here are five things he feels that every parent should know about ear infections.

title: Zimbabwe: Party Formally Expels Mugabe Challenger
description: The ruling party, ZANU-PF, formally expelled Simba Makoni, a former finance minister who announced last week that he would challenge Robert G. Mugabe for the presidency. Nathan Shamuyarira, a party spokesman, said any party officials who supported the renegade candidacy would be similarly expelled. The Makoni candidacy might prove formidable, especially if he can unite opposition against Mr. Mugabe. But Morgan Tsvangirai, the candidate of the Movement for Democratic Change, has dismissed any notion of stepping aside for Mr. Makoni, calling him old wine in a new bottle.

title: Looking for Sure Political Bets at Online Prediction Market
description: There is a professional poker player in Queens named Serge Ravitch who is convinced that he can make money off this years presidential election. But to explain what hes up to, I want to start with a story about last weeks Democratic primary in California.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about efforts by Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama to outdo each other in campaign fund-raising misstated the month that the totals for February will be made public by the Federal Election Commission. It is March, not April.

title: U.S. Acts to Avert Tactic Expected in Qaeda Trial
description: WASHINGTON  Bush administration officials said Tuesday that they were confident that charges against six suspected members of Al Qaeda would survive expected defense contentions that the cases are based on unreliable statements obtained using harsh interrogation methods.

title: 2 Boys, 2 Sides, 2 Beds in an Israeli Hospital Ward
description: TEL HASHOMER, Israel  Two small boys lay sedated in a hospital ward in this Tel Aviv suburb on Tuesday, unaware of each other or of the growing commotion around them.

title: U.S. Program to Verify Worker Status Is Growing
description: LOS ANGELES  The number of businesses taking part in a voluntary program that allows them to verify electronically their newly hired employees legal authorization to work in the United States is soaring, the federal government said Tuesday.

title: Nachbar Puts Aside Jump Shot for Dunks
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Bostjan Nachbar makes a living with a jump shot, often coolly launching it from long range. But he was on the Nets bench for the entire first half Tuesday and had stored up enough energy to try something much bolder.

title: Twins Sign Livn Hernndez
description: The right-hander Livn Hernndez agreed to a one-year, $5 million contract with the Minnesota Twins on Tuesday. The deal could earn him an additional $2 million in performance bonuses.Hernndez, who has never pitched in the American League, made $7 million last season with Arizona, going 11-11 with a 4.93 earned run average in 33 starts. He has played for Florida, San Francisco, Montreal, Washington and Arizona since his major league debut in September 1996.

title: What to Ask About Ear Infections
description: Here are some questions you may not think to ask, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: A $1.2 Billion Write-Down at Credit Suisse
description: The Zurich headquarters of Switzerlands two largest banks may be within walking distance of each other, but when it comes to weathering the credit crisis they are miles apart.

title: Ex-Firefighter, 101, Fixture in Atlantic City Department, Dies in Home Fire
description: After starting as a police officer in the raucous Prohibition era, and serving another 47 years as a firefighter during Atlantic Citys rise and decline before the advent of casinos, Edward Jordan was a legendary local character.

title: Swimsuit for the Olympics Is a New Skin for the Big Dip
description: Ryan Lochte, an Olympic swimmer, said he felt like a superhero. Michael Phelps, who is expected to win multiple gold medals at the Beijing Games, said it was as if he were wearing a spacesuit. And this was after Phelps, promoting a slinky black unitard swimsuit, stood on a podium with his arms and legs splayed like Leonardo da Vincis Vitruvian Man.

title: Crew Powers Up Laboratory at International Space Station
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  American and European astronauts on Tuesday inaugurated the Columbus science laboratory, the newest addition to the International Space Station and Europes largest contribution.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about a production of Peter Handkes play The Hour We Knew Nothing of Each Other, at the National Theater in London, referred incorrectly to the play. While it is new to the National Theater, it was written in 1992. It is not a new play.

title: Lifeline for Whom?
description: When pressed by government officials, the mortgage industry has repeatedly pledged to modify the loans of at-risk borrowers.

title: Nokia Dominates, but Rivals Insist That Could Change
description: BARCELONA, Spain  At a glance, the mobile phone, a steel-blue clamshell model able to display streaming video at broadband Internet speeds, could be mistaken for one of the more than 100 models made by Nokia, the worlds leading cellphone maker.

title: Russia: Campbell Soup in Broth Venture
description: The Campbell Soup Company said it planned to team up with a Russian meat supplier, Joosten Products, to make broths at a factory outside Moscow. The company plans to start selling the locally made broth in Russia by the end of the year. The opening of local production goes in line with Campbells strategic plans for the Russian market: to provide maximum accessibility of high-quality products in one of the worlds most promising markets, Campbell said. The company, based in Camden, N.J., began selling imported broths in Russia in October.

title: Smart Land Deals as a Cornerstone of Free Tuition
description: Most colleges sometimes get involved in the thorny world of real estate, but for the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, owning property in Manhattan and managing it wisely are an integral part of its success as a college.

title: Man Is Sought in New York Psychologists Stabbing
description: Armed with a suitcase full of knives, an unidentified middle-aged man unleashed a rampage of violence inside the offices of an Upper East Side psychiatry practice on Tuesday night, fatally stabbing and slashing a well-known psychologist before wounding her colleague when he tried to come to her aid, officials said on Wednesday.

title: Letters
description: Anxiety and Me

title: Bush Presses House on Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush strongly urged the House of Representatives on Wednesday to quickly approve a surveillance bill passed by the Senate Tuesday evening, saying he would not agree to a further extension of the current eavesdropping law.

title: Man Is Sought in New York Psychologists Stabbing
description: Armed with a suitcase full of knives, an unidentified middle-aged man unleashed a rampage of violence inside the offices of an Upper East Side psychiatry practice on Tuesday night, fatally stabbing and slashing a well-known psychologist before wounding her colleague when he tried to come to her aid, officials said on Wednesday.

title: The Worlds of Flesh and of Ink Blur in an Animated Landscape
description: Flat feels surprisingly full in The Slug Bearers of Kayrol Island (Or, the Friends of Dr. Rushower), the droll and hypnotizing musical that opened on Tuesday night at the Vineyard Theater. This deadpan fable of colliding cultures from the urban-lore cartoonist Ben Katchor blurs the line between two and three dimensions to the point that it creates its own spatial universe, delicately wedged in between.

title: Spielberg Drops Out as Adviser to Beijing Olympics in Dispute Over Darfur Conflict
description: WASHINGTON  Steven Spielberg said Tuesday that he was withdrawing as an artistic adviser to the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, after almost a year of trying unsuccessfully to prod President Hu Jintao of China to do more to try to end Sudans attacks in the Darfur region.

title: Beagle, a Breed Long Unsung, Wins Best in Show
description: When Dr. J. Donald Jones, the judge for the best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show, looked at the seven competitors for the title Tuesday night, he saw four breeds that had been denied the crown and three that had captured it.

title: With Surge in Momentum, Obama Makes His Case
description: WASHINGTON  The lopsided nature of Senator Barack Obamas parade of victories on Tuesday gives him an opening to make the case that Democratic voters have broken in his favor and that the party should coalesce around his candidacy.

title: Helicopter School Closes, Leaving Students in Lurch
description: LAS VEGAS  A helicopter flight training school run by a prominent Republican fund-raiser in Nevada has declared bankruptcy, leaving students in 18 states responsible for hundreds of thousands of dollars in uninsured student loans.

title: Super, Sure. But Who Asked Them?
description: In late November, the Democratic superdelegates from New York met in Virginia, at a gathering of the partys national committee. All but three or four people in the room wore buttons that said Hillary.

title: Are Ear Tubes in Your Childs Future?
description: Dr. Jack Paradise is professor emeritus of pediatrics at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine.

title: From Russia With Verve: Its Ovechkin
description: When Bruce Boudreau first met his players as the Washington Capitals coach, he had no idea what to expect. His career, spent largely bouncing around minor leagues, had not taken him in front of the kind of players now judging his every move.

title: Creative Juices Flow for Pro Bono Effort to Aid Global Water Projects
description: LIKE the ripples from a drop of rain when it falls on a pond, a charitable campaign created last year by a New York boutique agency is arriving next month in more than a dozen other cities, and there are plans to expand it globally in 2009.

title: Australia Says NATO Needs New Strategy in Afghanistan
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia wants a major reconsideration of Western strategy in Afghanistan and will not increase its troop levels in the country until underperforming NATO countries shoulder their fair share of the burden, the Australian defense minister said Tuesday.

title: More Students Passing A.P. Exams
description: A higher percentage of students in public high schools are taking and passing Advanced Placement exams, according to a report issued Wednesday by the College Board. The gap between the performance of black and white students, however, remains large.

title: Tasting Notes
description: OVER several weeks, through steady nibbling and one large blind tasting, members of the Dining sections staff tasted more than 30 milk chocolates ranging from 30 percent to 50 percent cacao. These dark milk bars revealed a broad spectrum of color, creaminess, sweetness, spice and fruit.

title: Girardi Urges Pettitte to Focus on the Future
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Long before Andy Pettitte fields his first questions from reporters this week about his turbulent off-season, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi has already plotted a strategy to assist him. Girardis comments indicate that he wants Pettitte to look forward, not backward, and feel normal, not abnormal.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page Inside summary on Feb. 5 for a sports article about Coach Bob Knights resignation at Texas Tech referred imprecisely to his place in major college basketball history. As the article noted, Mr. Knight won more games than any mens coach, not more than any coach  a distinction that belongs to Pat Summitt, the womens coach at Tennessee.

title: McCain and Obama Turn Fire on Each Other
description: A day after his overwhelming victories in three eastern primaries, Senator Barack Obama hammered his economic message in Wisconsin on Wednesday, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sidestepped the next round of Democratic primaries to concentrate on the delegate-rich Texas race.

title: 3 Arrested in Plot to Kill Cartoonist
description: BRUSSELS  Two Tunisians and a Dane were arrested in Denmark on Tuesday to prevent what the Danish police said would have been a terror-related assassination of one of 12 cartoonists behind caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad published in 2005 that provoked fury across the Muslim world.

title: Southwest. Way Southwest.
description: DALLAS  Southwest Airlines, with a raucous corporate culture that is the exception in the grim airline industry, stands to look even wilder as some of its big competitors contemplate mergers that would only further muddy their corporate identities.

title: Going Out to Eat, but Staying Green
description: AT the Oko frozen yogurt shop in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the counter and walls are made from sunflower seeds and its awnings have solar panels.

title: Japan Focuses Anger on U.S. In Rape Arrest of a Marine
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda of Japan voiced anger on Tuesday over accusations that a United States marine had raped a 14-year-old girl in Okinawa, calling the episode unforgivable.

title: City Landmarks Named
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to give landmark designation to Congregation Tifereth Israel (1911), believed to be the oldest structure in Queens built as a synagogue. Este Lauder attended services there as a young woman, and in 1979 and 1980 Madonna lived nearby in a building that used to be a yeshiva affiliated with the congregation. The two-story, wood-frame synagogue, right, designed by Crescent L. Varrone, at 109-18 54th Avenue in Corona, combines Gothic and Moorish design elements with Judaic ornaments: pointed-arched windows, a roundel with a Star of David in colored glass, and a gabled parapet. The original wooden stoop and railing have been replaced with a brick porch with an iron railing, and the wood clapboard siding has been covered with stucco. The design was modeled after synagogues on the Lower East Side, where the founders of the congregation, established in 1907, had originally lived. In 2002 the building was placed on the National Register of Historic Places. Also on Tuesday, the commission voted for a third time to designate the Jamaica Savings Bank building, an 1898 Hough & Duell Beaux-Arts structure at 161-02 Jamaica Avenue, in Jamaica, as a landmark. Twice previously, the commissions landmark designation for that building has been overturned: by the Board of Estimate in 1975, and by the City Council in 1992. The buildings owner has agreed to support the current designation, which is expected to meet with Council approval.

title: Sources of Heat and Light to Challenge an Icy Season
description: On a miserably cold winter evening, musical comfort food like Schumanns vibrant Piano Quintet provides warming nourishment. It was given a vigorous performance on Monday at Weill Recital Hall by the Modigliani String Quartet and the pianist Jean-Frdric Neuburger.

title: India: More Than Half of Tigers Lost in 5 Years, Census Finds
description: A much-anticipated tiger census report found that their numbers had dwindled to 1,411 from 3,642 in 2002, the last census year. The report confirmed the fears of conservationists that Indias tigers are fast declining because of poaching and the loss of their natural homes.

title: Richard Ford Leaves His Longtime Publisher
description: In a surprise move, Richard Ford, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Independence Day and The Lay of the Land, has switched publishers for his next three books.

title: Clinton in El Paso
description: Hillary Clinton addressed supporters in Texas after losses to Barack Obama in Maryland, Virginia and Washington, D.C. (Video: NBC News)

title: John McCain in Alexandria, Va.
description: John McCain spoke to supporters after winning contests in the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia. (Video: NBC News)

title: Barack Obama in Madison, Wis.
description: Barack Obama celebrated wins in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. (Video: NBC News)

title: Start Getting Your Brackets Ready
description: Just as Tom Lemming, Allen Wallace and other football recruitnics are being put into hibernation for a long winters nap (at least until Terrelle Pryor announces where hell play his college ball), the bracketologists are waking up. Well, theyve actually been awake for a while. But now we can start paying legitimate attention to them. Theres just over a month remaining until Selection Sunday, which means that the bracket is coming into clearer focus.

title: The Season in Quotes
description: We commend to you profootballoutsiders.com and their compilation of the seasons top quotations:

title: Food Stuff
description: A Family Bakery, Still Going Strong

title: Dell to Buy E-Mail Service
description: Dell, the computer maker, said on Tuesday that it would buy the business e-mail services provider MessageOne, which was co-founded by Michael S. Dells brother, in an effort to compete with similar services provided by Microsoft and Google.

title: At Trial, Lawyer Says Buffett Gave Approval
description: The lawyer defending the former chief executive of General Reinsurance against fraud charges pointed the finger Tuesday at the investor Warren E. Buffett.

title: Delphi Financing Hits Speed Bump
description: The $6.1 billion plan to bring auto-parts supplier Delphi out of bankruptcy protection may be in jeopardy as bank lenders face trouble syndicating loans to other lenders, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: MySpace to Launch Incubator, Report Says
description: MySpace plans to announce as soon as Wednesday 13 that it has formed a business incubator called SlingShot Labs to spawn Internet start-ups for News Corporations growing empire of Web properties, which now includes The Wall Street Journals WSJ.com as well as the video game site IGN, according to BusinessWeek.

title: Citi Sets Aside $3.5 Billion to Shore Up SIVs
description: Citigroup said on Tuesday it plans to provide a $3.5 billion facility to support six of the seven structured investment vehicles it took onto its balance sheet last year to shore up their debt ratings and protect creditors.

title: SocGen Rights Issue May Not Deter Bidders
description: A deeply discounted $8 billion rights issue from Socit Gnrale, seen in part as a bid by the scandal-hit French bank to remain independent, has not convinced analysts that it will deter predators.

title: DBS Appoints Citigroup China Head to C.E.O. Post
description: The DBS Group, Southeast Asias biggest bank, said Wednesday that it had hired Richard Stanley, the chief executive of Citigroup China, as chief executive to revive its China business and expand outside Singapore.

title: E.U. Antitrust Regulators Raid Intel Offices
description: The European Commission conducted antitrust raids Tuesday at the Munich offices of Intel, the worlds largest chip maker, and of retailers selling products made by the company, the commission and the chip maker said.

title: Quebec Pension Fund Backs Exchange Merger
description: Caisse de dpt et placement du Qubec, the powerful Canadian pension fund, is supporting the TSX Groups proposed 1.3 billion Canadian dollar takeover of the Montreal Exchange, provided that some operations stay in Montreal and its governance concerns are met.

title: Alpha Mom Sells Stake to Fahrenheit 212
description: Alpha Mom, the popular parenting blog, has sold a minority stake to Fahrenheit 212, a consultancy, in exchange for its help in developing products and services to expand the brand nationally, The New York Post reported.

title: Duquesne Capital Washes Its Hands of InterOil
description: InterOil, which is seeking to develop a liquefied natural gas project in Papua New Guinea, appears to have lost a believer, as a hedge fund run by one of the richest men in the United States has sold all of its shares in the company.

title: The Point Gets a Bunch of Money from New Enterprise
description: New Enterprise Associates rallied around The Point with $4.8 million in funding for the company, a social networking site that was started late last year.

title: Hedge Fund Investors Favor Emerging Markets
description: Inflows to hedge funds investing in emerging markets has increased more than 40 percent in two years to $9 billion, fueled by volatility in commodities and foreign exchanges.

title: Canadian Private Equity Sector Shows Resiliency
description: Canadas private equity deal makers showed resiliency in the face of the deepening credit crunch in the fourth quarter of 2007, but the quarter exposed the beginnings of a slower era facing the sector in 2008.

title: Liz Claiborne Close to Selling Ellen Tracy, Reports Says
description: Liz Claiborne, the fashion apparel company, is close to selling its Ellen Tracy brand to a private investment consortium for $50 million, The New York Post reported Wednesday.

title: Wellspring Said to Prepare Dave & Busters Sale
description: Wellspring Capital Management has decided to take a Dallas-based restaurant chain Dave & Busters to market months after an initial attempt to sell the company was pulled, The Deal.com reported.

title: Britain Said to Request Improved Northern Rock Bids
description: Two suitors competing to rescue the British bank Northern Rock have been told to improve their offers to beat the alternative of nationalization, according to press reports.

title: Speculation in the Valley: Oracles Next Big Deal?
description: Analysts and industry observers appeared split on whether a rumor that Salesforce.com has approached Oracle about an $8.9 billion deal to sell itself to Larry Ellisons firm may become a reality.

title: Yahoo Turmoil Stokes a Recruiting Frenzy
description: Microsofts unsolicited  and recently rejected  bid for Yahoo is apparently creating a feeding frenzy of sorts for Silicon Valley headhunters.

description: Delta Air Lines chief executive, Richard Anderson, has told the airlines board he will waive compensation in the event of a merger.

description: Whos the hottest young female lawyer at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom? Last week that question sent the New York firm into a bit of a tizzy.

title: American Capital Agency Seeks $400 Million I.P.O.
description: The American Capital Agency has filed with regulators for an initial public offering in hopes of raising as much as $400 million on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Goldman Tops Tech Deal-Maker List
description: Goldman Sachs claimed the top spot as the busiest adviser in technology mergers during 2007, according to data compiled by The 451 Group. It was Goldmans third year in a row at No. 1, as measured by the volume of tech deals on which it served as adviser. But its lead has narrowed from previous years.

title: Buffetts Rescue Seen as Shrewd Move
description: Warren E. Buffett volunteered on Tuesday to rescue Wall Street from its latest looming crisis.

title: UBS Names Head of Investment Banking
description: UBS on Wednesday named Jerker Johansson as head of its investment bank, ending a protracted search that followed the write-downs of billions of dollars from the subprime crisis.

title: Honest to Blog
description: Kris Tapley at Red Carpet District has a few items of ninny interest, including pointing us to a great story in Variety that deconstructs how the Academys music branch hit a few sour notes this year. He also hosts a Juno Jargon Jenerator that lets readers listen to their hearts content to neologisms like fo shizz.

description: Gold Rush says that the reigning funny man of our time is short, hairy, and prone to antic body movements. And no, it aint Robin Williams.

description: Listen to contributors Siri Hustvedt and Paula Kamen interviewed on N.P.R.s Talk of the Nation, here.

title: Defamed
description: Over the past few years, the Bagger has found himself admiring, linking to and occasionally coveting the voice of Defamer, which always seems to have a ready supply of bemused lan on hand regardless of topic. Now comes word that Mark Lisanti, the sites editor, who can turn any random starlet or studio monster into red mist with a flick of the mouse, is leaving to spend more time with his family.

title: Who is Your Queen?
description: The FilmExperience blog has a bit of bake-off underway for Diva of the Year.  Where else could you seen Marjane of Persepolis and Cate Blanchetts Elizabeth thowdown over the right to wear the crown? Marjanes turn-ons include Bruce Lee and bad 80s rock, but she still counts Abba among her turn-offs. Elizabeth, meanwhile, loves the art of human manipulation but cannot abide Spain.

title: Paying the Full Price of Your Car
description: The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, is once again ahead of the climate change game. On Tuesday he announced that drivers of vehicles producing very high levels of emissions would have to pay a very high price to enter central London: 25 a day, starting in October.

title: In Denmark, Encore for Muhammad Cartoon
description: So many things to report, so little space. Thats chief reason newspapers arent usually in the business of reprinting things. Heres another: To avoid worldwide fury.

title: A Reversal of Position on School Vouchers
description: From his perch at the Manhattan Institute, the right-leaning research group, Sol Stern, 72, has reveled as the citys cantankerous provocateur against liberal education policies, criticizing reading curriculums that de-emphasize phonics as well as public schools that focus on social justice, Jennifer Medina writes. Like many of his intellectual allies, he had ardently supported school vouchers as a way to give poor and minority children better educational choices and to create competition that would help improve public schools. Although colleagues long thought they had him pegged, he made an abrupt about-face on vouchers in the most recent issue of City Journal, the institutes magazine, saying there was little evidence they had done much to improve public education across the country. In the circles Mr. Stern inhabits, such a sentiment is a kind of heresy, and his essay has set off a firestorm. But he is relishing the attention.

title: The Early Word: On, Wisconsin
description: Barack Obama swept the Crab Cake Primaries in D.C., Maryland and Virginia on Tuesday, defeating his opponent Hillary Rodham Clinton by large margins. It was telling, perhaps, that Mr. Obama made his victory remarks at an arena in Madison, the capital of Wisconsin  the next primary battleground and a place where so far he holds a slight lead in the polls  while Mrs. Clinton watched Tuesdays results from El Paso, Texas, where she was working to get a jump in that big, delegate-rich state, whose nominating contest is set for March 4.

Living With Music:

description: Lisa Dierbeck is the author of the novel One Pill Makes You Smaller.

title: Be Like Mike?
description: How bad have things gotten for Hillary Clintons presidential campaign? If you look at the Clinton and Huckabee votes in Virginia, they mirror each other. They both do well where its poor and white, writes Matt Cooper, the Washington editor of Portfolio (whose wife, Mandy Grunwald, works for Hillary Clinton), at his Portfolio blog. He later adds:

title: PETA vs. the Dog Show
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals never shies away from publicity-seeking provocation (and media, including this blog, often cover it). This week, the group is starting an advertising campaign in New York and other cities that advocates dog population control, including one commercial that likens dog breeders to the Ku Klux Klan. In New York, like many other places, about half the dogs and cats taken into animal shelters are euthanized.One of the commercials shows a hooded Ku Klux Klan member walking into a meeting of the purebreds-only American Kennel Club, where the members eye him suspiciously. He gets the group to concede that they both believe in the sanctity of pure bloodlines and a master race. He sits down, saying, Ill fit right in here. Then the message All dogs are created equal flashes on the screen.

title: Mustard and Memories
description: As todays review of the Second Avenue Deli notes, New Yorkers have very strong  and divergent  opinions about deli food.

description: Is it possible that Barack Obama has become the favorite in Texas, a state long considered to be a firewall for Hillary Clinton?

description: Just before the first spring vegetables begin to appear, and almost at the last possible time to exploit last falls harvest, my friend Ed Schneider  who will be making his first guest appearance on this blog soon enough  dropped this gift in my lap: a recipe for a dessert soup of winter squash poached in coconut milk.

title: Satisfying Cravings
description: There are two addictions I find treated in especially perverse fashion in the contemporary food world: caffeine and alcohol. In most of the world, most of the time, both of these drugs are treated as such, and the delivery systems are rarely discussed. They may be better-tasting (espresso and Burgundy), or worse (coffee that sits on a hot plate for a few hours, or rotgut).

title: Vietnam Enters a New Era
description: Thanks to its spectacular coastline and rich culture, tourism to Vietnam is soaringand so are the countrys property prices. But its still a difficult market for international property investors, according to James Gonzalez, market analyst for Obelisk, the property firm.

description: Today is the day that the writers return to work, and  perhaps not coincidentally  CBS has announced the anticipated return dates for its popular shows that were sidelined by the work stoppage.

title: Nostalgia Draped in Orange: Remembering The Gates
description: If you can have nostalgia for something that only happened three years ago, then the screening of The Gates, an HBO documentary about the 2005 Central Park art installation by Christo and Jeanne-Claude, inspired waves of it (and a lot of orange) at Gracie Mansion on Tuesday night.Jeanne-Claudes hair was orange, the passionfruit and vodka drinks on the silver trays were orange, the ranuculus blossoms in scattered glass vases were orange, the chandelier was decked out in orange. Even Katherine Oliver, the city commissioner who oversees film and theater, had orange highlights in her suit.

title: For Bear Fund Manager, the Split Was Mutual
description: When Ralph Cioffi left Bear Stearns, he did it quietly. Asked about the departure by Bloomberg News in December, a Bear Stearns spokeswoman wouldnt discuss why he packed up his things. Mr. Cioffi, who had presided over two Bear Stearns hedge funds that filed for bankruptcy protection, wouldnt comment to Bloomberg at all.

title: Open Caucus: Obamas Winning Streak
description: Our Open Caucus participants reacted to Barack Obamas recent victories in D.C., Maryland and Virginia  not to mention last weekends contests in Louisiana, Nebraska and Washington. Is this momentum going to lead Mr. Obama to the Democratic nomination, or will Hillary Rodham Clinton stop Mr. Obama in Ohio? As always, feel free to join the discussion in the comments section below.

title: Picking the Lock on Best Actor
description: The Bagger is still waiting for a copy of There Will Be Blood so he can check the view from the bubble. He knows that Daniel Day-Lewis is a lock for best actor, but had a naughty thought he should probably keep to himself, but thats not in his nature. If the Bagger were a member of the Academy, he would not be marching in lock-step with his peers to put the crown atop Mr. Lewiss head. He would instead pause, consider who did what in the context of the film, and mark the spot marked Clooney.

title: Why Brooding Shoppers Overpay
description: When youre depressed, you tend to devalue things around you. But then why are you more inclined to hit the mall and buy stuff at higher prices than you would at other times? A new paper to be published in Psychological Science provides an answer to that question  and support for a theory of the self proposed by William James more than a century ago.

title: Clinton Goes Negative in Wisconsin Ad
description: Updated  The gloves are off. Hillary Rodham Clinton just released her first TV ad specifically attacking Barack Obama.

title: A Good Kaning
description: Just had a look online at Christopher Kanes collection, and what remarkable work it is. Completely engaging, and an extension in a way of his spring 2007 show, in Holland Park, with the decoration. Except now the clothes, and the thinking behind it, seems far more sophisticated and new. I was struck by exits #7, 12, 14 and 18, particularly the silver-black dress with lines that suggest suspension cables, like a Calatrava bridge.

title: In Wisconsin, Obama Turns to Economy
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.  Emboldened by a fresh round of victories, Senator Barack Obama delivered a blistering critique of his Democratic and Republican rivals on Wednesday, blaming Washington for the economic crisis that has gripped the nation.

title: Do bad wars hurt economic confidence?
description: One favorite claim of Bush supporters, trying to explain why people are so negative on what they insist is a terrific economy, is that people are upset about Iraq and project their bad feelings onto the economy, too. That  along with the evergreen claim that the liberal media refuse to report how great things are  is what seems to be going on in this example of whining.

title: Bear Hugs From Abroad
description: In the midst of this weekends Yahoo hullabaloo, two other bear-hug letters  in addition to the one from Microsoft that we previously wrote about  were delivered to United States-based companies.

title: Street Photography in an Image-Filled Age
description: In our media-saturated culture, everyone is a picture-taker and image-maker, adding a new wrinkle to the work of those who practice the time-honored tradition of street photography.Its harder and harder to take a picture without somebody in the picture whos also taking a picture, the Brooklyn-based photographer Gus Powell said on Tuesday evening, explaining that the mere act of taking a photo hardly makes him stand out in a crowd. We all take pictures  thats what we do. Its more that your camera doesnt look like a phone  thats the bigger issue.

title: Heads, Hearts and David Frum
description: Academics build entire careers trying to figure out why we vote the way we do, whether we make our decisions with our heads or our hearts. Right now, its the hearts that are getting most of their attention, and two scholars who stress the role of emotions in political behavior, George Lakoff and Drew Westen, have become darlings of the Democratic party. People think with their guts, Westen says. Well, none of us really likes to believe that (is Westen thinking with his gut when he votes?), but whats a poor rationalist to do? Politics is hard. Consider health care.

title: Storybook Debut for Milan Teenager
description: Not bad  18 years old and a goal-scorer 18 seconds into a debut on his first touch of the ball.

title: Writers Return to Late-Night Shows

title: A Size 48 Neck Is Completely Normal
description: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Cold here in New York City today. Were you folks cold outside? Heres a tip. Heres what savvy New Yorkers do on a cold day like this, I did it earlier today myself. Try it out, let me know what you think. You go over to Grand Central Station  you know where that is, the big train place? Theres the Oyster Bar up there. And on a really cold day like this, go up there and fill your pants full of steamed clams.

title: Fashion Show | Londons Spring Projects Gallery
description: (Slve Sundsb)Just in time for London Fashion week, the well-known London photo studio Spring Studios has opened a new, experimental gallery space called Spring Projects. Directed by Andre Cooke and with an opening solo show from the fashion photographer Slve Sundsb (his first), the gallery hopes to represent artists who bridge the gap between art, fashion and product design. T Magazines market editor of design, Andreas Kokkino, spoke with Cooke and Sundsb about the launch of this new venue and about the relationship between art and fashion.

description: From the Daily Mail of London:

title: Interpreter Freed, but CBS Journalist Still Held
description: An Iraqi interpreter kidnapped in the southern city of Basra was freed Wednesday, but the CBS journalist seized with him this week was still being held, Ian Fisher reports.

title: No Malapropisms, Please. Were British.
description: Video

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, Feb. 13:

title: Bubble? Bubble!
description: A strange post by Alex Tabarrok, who seems to think that because housing prices havent yet given up much of their gains, there wasnt a bubble.

title: Go Ahead, Ignore the Economy
description: LONDON  We devotees of American politics from across the pond have been so gripped by the battle between Barack Obama and the Clintons that we risk missing a very striking point about this election campaign. Had you asked European (and probably Asian) pundits on Jan. 1 what was their greatest fear in Americas election year, Id bet that many of them would have said protectionism (or, for those that dont care about economics, isolationism).

title: Candidates Fine-Tune Their Fund-Raising Prowess
description: After the frenzied politics of the New York primary, it might be easy to forget that there are a number of New Yorkers who are preparing for what promises to be highly competitive contests in next years primary races within New York City.

title: More Ecstatic Mode of Living
description: Fan videos for Hillary Clinton. Lets take a look. (Anyone recognize the title of this post?)

title: Idol Delivers Again
description: Hollywood Week on American Idol got off to a promising start on Tuesday as a two-hour edition of Foxs talent competition trounced its competitors in the ratings, drawing 29.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. Although Tuesdays Idol audience grew by 2 million compared with a week ago, the first installment of Hollywood Week last year attracted 31.2 million viewers.

title: Day 3 Highlights From Port St. Lucie
description: The news you have all been waiting for. OK, maybe thats too strong. But Johan Santana made a surprise appearance Wednesday afternoon and threw on flat ground for 15 minutes with the pitching coach Rick Peterson and the bullpen coach Guy Conti watching.

title: Iranian Official Singles Out Persepolis
description: Film critics in the United States may have intensely disliked the movie 300, but Iranians downright hated it from the top levels of its government to the man on the street.

title: From Picket Lines to Desk Jobs
description: Weary writers didnt seem to expect such a precipitous end to the three-month-old strike.

title: Answers About Urban Parenting
description: Following is a first set of answers from Erin Sheehan, the community editor for UrbanBaby, who took questions from readers during the week of Feb. 11 about parenting in New York City and other urban areas.

title: I Naturally Select You to Be My Valentine
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: President Signs Stimulus Bill
description: CNBC coverage of President Bush signing the economic stimulus bill into law.

title: Homeless? Low-Paying Job? Her Mortgage Was Approved
description: How did a homeless woman end up buying a house in Queens with no down payment and a mortgage bill that was multiples of what she earned each month?

title: 10 Things We Love About our House
description: Yesterday, we spent the morning lingering over breakfast outside at the Rod and Reel restaurant on Anna Maria.

title: Up In Smoke: President Bushs Big Environmental Broken Promise
description: We noted with regret in a recent editorial the passing of a much-touted Bush Administration project known as FutureGen.

title: N.Y.C. Condoms in Translation
description: Get some or Put it on? Both messages  one in English, the other in Spanish  are part of the new ad campaign for New York Citys redesigned official condom wrapper.On Valentines Day last year, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene unveiled the citys first official condom. The letters NYC CONDOM were printed in white or black letters against colorful circles, evoking the letter symbols the Metropolitan Transportation Authority uses to represent subway lines. This years redesign  by Yves Behar, a noted product and industrial designer  features the letters NYC on black letters against three interlocking circles, with the word CONDOM underneath, each of the six letters in a different color.

title: New York Probes Health Payment Rates
description: CNBC reports on New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo's investigation into health insurers allegedly forcing patients to pay more than they should.

title: Carrin to Name Campaign Chairmen
description: Adolfo Carrin Jr., the Bronx borough president and candidate for city comptroller, is expected to name two co-chairmen for his campaign: former State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Leo J. Hindery Jr., a longtime media executive, according to advisers to Mr. Carrin.

title: Cuttlefish Camouflage
description: Carl Zimmer visits Dr. Roger Hanlon in his lab at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: A 25-Year Deal on Horse Racing
description: State officials have announced a final deal  really  to extend New Yorks state horse racing franchise another 25 years. Most of the details remain unchanged from what was in the works on Monday night.The New York Racing Association, which has run the tracks at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga Springs since 1955, will continue to run them for the next quarter-century, with an overhauled board of trustees and under the supervision of a new, five-member oversight board dominated by appointees of Gov. Eliot Spitzer. That board will review the associations performance every five years against a predetermined set of benchmarks, including attendance and financial measures.

title: Hezbollah Chief Killed in Bombing
description: Reporter John Kifner examines the death of Hezbollah commander Imad Mugniyah.

title: Is the Mayors Housing Plan on Track?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has proposed a 10-year, $7.5 billion New Housing Marketplace plan to create or preserve 165,000 units of affordable housing. So, is the plan on track to be completed by 2013? A panel of experts, including the citys commissioner of housing preservation and development, tackled that question this afternoon in a panel discussion at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: The Candidate as Database
description: Yes, someone out there still loves Mike Huckabee. There is one small but influential group of G.O.P. political insiders who are praying for Mike Huckabee to continue his increasingly Quixotic campaign for the Republican nomination: voter mail and list consultants, writes Richelieu, the pseudonymous Republican strategist who blogs for The Weekly Standard. Heres why:

title: A Guide to Yahoos Unlikely Alternatives to Microsoft
description: In the course of a terminal illness, a person will often start to cast about for alternative therapies: herbs, acupuncture, fasting on a Tibetan mountain. This exploration is simply part of the process of coming to terms with the painful truth.

title: Clinton Drops MSNBC Debate Boycott
description: When you run an attack ad against your opponent for refusing to compete in a debate, you cant very well bow out of one yourself. So today, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign said that she would participate in a debate sponsored by MSNBC in Cleveland, Ohio.

title: Soft Serve | Purified Pepsi, Bachelorette Butlers, Cooking With Coolio
description: Whats worst than eating soft serve on a daily basis? The gym rats over at Mens Health made a list of the Worst Food in America. The first place finisher is Outbacks Aussie Cheese Fries Why not cook yourself something healthy like a caprese salad? Coolio, the host of an internet cooking show, has a recipe for a caprese that will get them panties right off  Londons May Fair hotel has another way to get a relationship to the next level. Its new proposal butler will help women pop the question to their man. Our favorite option on the proposal menu is one that involves you and your loved one getting lost and (hopefully) finding each other at the center of the Hampton Court Labyrinth. Of course. Because wandering around alone is so romantic While in London, chug some Pepsi Raw, an all-natural soda targeted, ironically, at the nightclub set If your love life needs a boost that all-natural soda cant provide, CNNs list of surprising reasons youre not having sex may have some advice for you Keeping the kids in their bed and out of yours has never been easier. For $2600, send your little ones into orbit with a Space Ship bunk  Speaking of orbit, NASA needs your help to name a satellite Dreaming of Hollywood stardom? Snatch up the 138 acres  right next to the Hollywood signs letter H  formerly owned by Howard Hughes. On second thought, at $22 million, youd better be a star already Come back tomorrow for more of the Soft Serve star treatment.

title: Saving Afghanistan From the Sidelines
description: There are many ways to describe Paddy Ashdown: British politician. The Michael Jackson of postconflict reconstruction. The man asked by the United Nations secretary general to be the UNs special envoy in Afghanistan but was rejected by Mr Karzai.

title: Hezbollah Chief Killed in Bombing
description: Reporter John Kifner examines the death of Hezbollah commander Imad Mugniyah.

title: Analysis: The Clemens and McNamee Hearing
description: The New York Timess Alan Schwarz was on Capitol Hill for the House Oversight committee hearing and provided question-by-question analysis of Roger Clemenss and Brian McNamees testimony. Read Schwarzs account and watch video of the witnesses and listen to audio clips from the hearing below.

title: Chelsea Clinton Speaks
description: On the campaign trail with the past (and possibly future) first daughter.

title: Surveillance Video
description: The entry and exit of the alleged assailant in the death of an Upper East Side psychologist was captured on video tape.

title: Back to Work
description: Playwright and television writer Diana Son goes back to work after the  Writers Guild of America ended its three-month-long strike.

title: YouTubes Advertising Coming-Out Party
description: It used to be only television networks that could get senior advertising executives to drop their plans for an afternoon or evening to party, but now gatherings hosted by the likes of Google and Facebook are the place to be seen.

title: Commercial Ocean Fertilization Project Halted
description: Planktos, the California company trying to turn a profit by fertilizing the ocean with iron dust, pulled the plug on planned field tests on Wednesday, citing a lack of funds. At the companys Web site, planktos.com, a simple notice blamed the shutdown on a highly effective disinformation campaign waged by anti-offset crusaders.

title: Bloggingheads: Who's the Hawk?
description:
Bloggers Heather Hurlburt of Democracy Arsenal, left, and Daniel Drezner of Danieldrezner.com debate whether Hillary Clinton is more hawkish than Barack Obama.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Sun Hasnt Set
description: Tuesday at lunch in the food court across the street from the New York Times San Francisco bureau, I couldnt help listening to the conversation at the next table, where one data center manager was telling his colleague about how he would like to toss Solaris, Sun Microsystems recently open-sourced operating system, out of his shop.

title: Strike Didnt Change Late-Night Habits
description: While loyal viewers undoubtedly noticed the absence of striking writers at the late-night comedy shows, it made little difference in their viewing habits, ratings show, the Associated Press reports.

title: Patterns
description: I have had migraines for most of my life; the first attack I remember occurred when I was 3 or 4 years old. I was playing in the garden when a brilliant, shimmering light appeared to my left  dazzlingly bright, almost as bright as the sun. It expanded, becoming an enormous shimmering semicircle stretching from the ground to the sky, with sharp zigzagging borders and brilliant blue and orange colors. Then, behind the brightness, came a blindness, an emptiness in my field of vision, and soon I could see almost nothing on my left side. I was terrified  what was happening? My sight returned to normal in a few minutes, but these were the longest minutes I had ever experienced.

title: Writers Are Really, Really, Really, Really Happy To Be Back
description: Returning to work on Wednesday, chatter among writers centered on how relieved everyone was that the strike was finally finished, Brooks Barnes reports:

title: Meanwhile, Back on Wisteria Lane
description: The writers and producers of Desperate Housewives had mapped out a season-long story arc for the hit ABC drama last summer. On Wednesday, back at work for the first time in more than three months, they began figuring out how to condense thirteen episodes of plot into seven hours of television.

title: A Celebrated and Controversial Pastime
description: In the Dominican Republic, cockfighting is celebrated as a symbol of the country's warrior spirit.

title: Your Comments on my Guantanamo Column
description: My Thursday column is about Sami al-Hajj and the prisoners in Guantanamo. I see our policies in Guantanamo as shameful but also foolish and counter-productive. Id welcome your comments below.

title: Clemens-McNamee: Not Must-See TV for Yankees
description: As Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee verbally sparred at Congressional hearings in Washington, D.C., the Yankees held a seven-hour organizational meeting in Tampa, Fla. Manager Joe Girardi said that he and Yankees officials took a 10-minute break for lunch, but they never flipped on the television to monitor Clemens, the former Yankee, and McNamee, a former Yankee employee.

title: Whether to Stay a Spectator or Take the Bidding Plunge
description: There are days when you feel that you should have stayed in bed. Things did not go well. But if you remained indoors all the time, life would be boring. You have to get out there and live.

title: In Tribal Pakistan, Religious Parties Are Foundering
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Senator Asfandyar Wali, the leader of an opposition party, the Awami National Party, is campaigning for the elections next week from the safety of his bed, under a quilt and propped up on bolsters for his bad back at his country home outside Peshawar.

title: The Sweet Smell of ... Nothing
description: PERFUME has long been an aphrodisiac decanted sparingly from an iconic glass bottle. But for Leslie Ware, a fashion editor at a quarterly magazine in Huntsville, Ala., fragrance has worked its magic in the opposite direction, as a romantic deal breaker.

title: Vicious Killing Where Troubled Seek a Listener
description: It was just after 8 p.m. in a suite of mental health offices at East 79th Street and York Avenue. One doctor was seeing patients; another was working in her study.

title: Seeing the Light
description: Goggles might not help you ski faster, but they can help you see icy spots and protect your eyes against the elements, making them a crucial component of any downhill adventure. Because most major manufacturers make goggles with interchangeable lenses, picking a frame is the easy part. Glen Traylor tells customers at Cole Sport, a retailer in Park City, Utah, that's frequented by both novices and members of the U.S. Ski Team: "If you like the way it looks, and if it fits well, then you've found your goggles."

title: China Vetoes Film
description: China has blocked production of Shanghai, a Hollywood film about an American who investigates a friends death in Japanese-occupied Shanghai, The Associated Press reported. Luan Guozhi, the director of international cooperation at the Chinese Film Bureau, declined to reveal the governments concerns, but said the filmmakers could alter the script and resubmit their application. The Japanese invasion of China during World War II remains a sensitive topic, and other filmmakers have had difficulty winning approval from China for projects set in the same era. Variety has reported that the cast includes John Cusack, Gong Li, right, and Ken Watanabe. Hundreds of thousands of dollars have already been spent on production, and the director, Mikael Hafstrom, has been in China since September preparing to film. Variety reported that he planned to move the production to Hong Kong.

title: An All-in-One Printer, Without All the Messy Wires
description: Epsons first printer with Wi-Fi, the Stylus CX9475Fax, also happens to be a scanner  and as the name suggests, a fax machine. Although it can hook up directly to a computer with a U.S.B. cable, it is really more at home on a wireless network, where it can be used by multiple computers in a household, a small business or a loft shared by starving artists.

title: Before bin Laden, One of Worlds Most Feared Men
description: WASHINGTON  Long before Osama bin Laden founded Al Qaeda and initiated the Sept. 11 attacks against the United States, Imad Mugniyah was perhaps the worlds most feared terrorist.

title: A Clivia, Withholding
description: Q. A decade ago, I was given a baby offshoot from a friends clivia. It is kept in a cool greenhouse with medium light and has grown into a large, healthy plant. But all it does is make leaves. How do I get it to bloom?

title: East Timor, Shaken by Attack on Leaders, Weighs Causes
description: DILI, East Timor  In the wake of Mondays twinned attacks on the president and prime minister here, the United Nations, the international military force and the East Timorese government are all facing questions about how the countrys two top leaders were exposed to attack, why a renowned rebel leader and his gang were left largely free to roam the countryside for months and what exact motive the attackers had.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a new study on muscle fatigue and what could prevent it misidentified the exercise scientist at Appalachian State University who collaborated with the principal investigator, Dr. Andrew Marks. He is David Nieman  not Dr. Stephan Lehnart, who works in Dr. Markss laboratory. The article also misstated the name of the North Carolina town where Appalachian State is located. It is Boone, not Boonetown.

title: Strike Disrupts Greece as Workers Seek to Protect Their Pensions
description: ATHENS  A 24-hour nationwide strike on Wednesday grounded air travel and shut down public services, state banks and hospitals in the latest show of swelling labor protests against government plans to make changes in Greeces deficit-plagued pension system.

title: At Home in the World
description: As soon as Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electrics chairman, became chief executive in 2001, his foreign-based managers began pressing him to move some major operations overseas.

title: Police Identify Gunman in Illinois Killing
description: The authorities say a 17-year-old who was already detained on related charges was the gunman in the November 2007 shooting death of a University of Chicago graduate student from Senegal. The suspect, Demetrius Warren, is one of three teenagers and a 21-year old who have been charged in a series of crimes that culminated in the killing of the student, Amadou Cisse, 29, outside his apartment just off campus. Before killing Mr. Cisse, the authorities say, the group drove around looking for people to rob, mugging university students and shooting at an employee.

title: S.E.C. Asks Money Managers to Post Full Details on Web
description: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)  Money managers in the United States would have to provide online brochures describing their services, fees, investment performance and potential conflicts of interest under a proposal approved Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Here Comes Kosovo
description: Europe will get a new state, Kosovo, on Sunday and the long, bloody unraveling of Yugoslavia will be concluded 17 years after the first war of its dissolution broke out in Slovenia. That is cause for celebration.

title: Gunman Kills 5 on Illinois Campus
description: A gunman killed five students and wounded 16 others in a Northern Illinois University lecture hall on Thursday afternoon in DeKalb before killing himself, according to university and police officials.

title: As Mores Evolve, Indias Divorced Seek Second Chance
description: NEW DELHI  Above a working mans diner in the middle of a hurly-burly city market, Yuvraj Raina abets what until recently would have been seen as a radical challenge to the social order.

title: Senate Ethics Committee Admonishes Larry Craig
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Larry E. Craig was admonished by his colleagues on Wednesday for conduct that reflected poorly on the Senate as the result of his arrest and guilty plea last summer in an undercover sex sting in a mens bathroom at the Minneapolis airport.

title: What Was at Hand and Where He Found It
description: DESIGN, William Harvey-style, means working with whats at hand, and what you find in his living room often ends up in a furniture line.

title: Eavesdropping Law Is Likely to Lapse
description: WASHINGTON  Broad spying powers temporarily approved by Congress in August appear likely to lapse this week after a daylong game of chicken on Wednesday between the White House and House Democrats produced no clear resolution.

title: And What About the Straws?
description: IF ever Nina Valenti had fielded a clients request that sounded less like a challenge from Project Runway, she did not know what it was. Ms. Valenti, a Brooklyn designer, was at work on an ensemble for the concert pianist Soyeon Lee, who had asked for a dress made entirely of used juice pouches.

title: Abscess Becomes a Key Point in the McNamee-Clemens Confrontation
description: WASHINGTON  Throughout the confrontation between Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee, much of the back and forth has been based on recollections of events as far as 10 years ago.

title: The Mysterious Common Cramp
description: Cramps are common among endurance athletes, who get taken by surprise when they hit and the muscle contracts violently, as if prodded with a jolt of electricity. But as Gina Kolata writes in The Times today, cramps remain a medical mystery despite their ubiquity. Medical textbooks skirt the topic, and few scientists have studied them. That hasn't slowed the advice circulating on how to avoid them.

title: Man Stabs 3 to Death in New Jersey, Police Say, Then Calmly Confesses
description: IRVINGTON, N.J.  Shortly after noon on Wednesday, the authorities said, a young man walked into the Fifth Precinct station house in Newark, approached the front desk and calmly made a startling announcement: I just killed three people.

title: Small Companies Are Finding a Home on the Web
description: The Web site for Sophia Brodskys day spa in Philadelphia, the Body Klinic, was pretty rudimentary until a college student walked into the spa a little more than two years ago with an irresistible offer.

title: Plaintiff Stops Bush Deposition
description: The plaintiff in a civil lawsuit against Reggie Bush walked out of a deposition Tuesday after the lawyer for Bush arrived with a plainclothes security guard who carried a concealed handgun.

title: Bomb in Syria Kills Militant Sought as Terrorist
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A top Hezbollah commander long sought by the United States for his role in terrorist attacks that killed hundreds of Americans in the 1980s, died Tuesday night in Damascus, Syria, when a bomb detonated under the vehicle he was in, Syrian officials said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline on Tuesday about presidential campaigning leading up to three primaries that day referred incorrectly to the contests. They were held in two states and the District of Columbia, not in three states.

title: Women in Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Officials Say Broken Satellite Will Be Shot Down
description: WASHINGTON  The military will attempt to shoot down a crippled spy satellite some time in the next two weeks, senior officials said on Thursday, laying out a high-tech plan to intercept the large spacecraft over the Pacific Ocean just before it tumbles uncontrollably back to earth with toxic fuel aboard.

title: New Settlement in 2003 Nightclub Fire
description: BOSTON  Clear Channel Broadcasting has reached a tentative $22 million settlement with survivors and families of those killed in a 2003 nightclub fire in West Warwick, R.I., according to court documents filed Wednesday.

title: For Sale: Parcel Near Big Sign. Views Are Nifty.
description: LOS ANGELES  If Howard Hughes had had his way in 1940, the famous Hollywood sign would be sitting in the shadow of the sprawling mansion he planned to build for the woman he loved at the time, the actress and dancer Ginger Rogers.

title: Yahoo Chief Explains Rejection of Microsoft Bid
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, explained his companys rejection of Microsofts buyout offer in a letter to shareholders late Wednesday outlining why he believed the bid, initially valued at $44.6 billion, was too low.

title: Los Angeles Times Names New Top Editor
description: The Los Angeles Times named a new top editor on Thursday, Russ Stanton, three weeks after the previous editor, James E. OShea, was forced out for resisting another in a series of staff cuts.

title: At Cellphone Trade Show, the Spotlight Chases Google
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Toru Arakawa, chief executive of Access, the biggest cellphone software company in Japan, took a diplomats view of Googles foray into telecommunications.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Senator John McCains decision to hire Mercer Reynolds, one of President Bushs major fund-raisers, misstated the position of Senator Barack Obama on using public financing for the general election. Although the Obama campaign has been raising private contributions for that election, Mr. Obama is still open to returning those contributions and abiding by the limits of the public financing system if the Republican nominee agrees to do the same. Mr. Obama has not definitively ruled out using public financing. (Go to Article)

title: Tour Organizers Exclude 2007 Winner and His Team
description: For the second year in a row, the defending champion of the Tour de France is unlikely to be at the starting line in July.

title: In a Time of Trouble, a Transcendent Valentine Bond
description: The first time Andrea Nieto Hernandez saw the ocean, she cried.

title: Surprising Retail Sales Lift the Gloom, for a Day
description: Stocks rallied on Wednesday, sending the Dow Jones industrials up nearly 180 points, after the Commerce Department released some unexpected positive economic news: a climb in retail sales for January.

title: McCain and Obama Take Their Senatorial Rivalry Into the Presidential Race
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  Their tempest began well before their bids for a presidential nomination.

title: Lottery Numbers
When We Torture
description: The most famous journalist you may never have heard of is Sami al-Hajj, an Al Jazeera cameraman who is on a hunger strike to protest abuse during more than six years in a Kafkaesque prison system.

title: Residential Sales
