description: Manhattan

title: German Bank Receives Its Third Bailout
description: FRANKFURT  The German government said on Wednesday that it would participate in a third bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the lender whose near-collapse in July heralded the arrival in Europe of the crisis stemming from the faltering subprime mortgage market in the United States.

title: Ambacs Chief Risk Officer Leaves
description: The Ambac Financial Group, a bond insurer, said Wednesday that its chief risk officer had resigned.

title: Places to Find Jelena and Little Suzie
description: SOME of the best witch hazels for the Northeast may be ordered from Fairweather Gardens, in Greenwich, N.J. (fairweathergardens.com; 856-451-6261), which offers 25 witch hazels, including Barmstedt Gold, Orange Peel and Wisley Supreme.

title: There, Amid the Music, a Mind Is on the Edge
description: As befits what is surely New Yorks first mainstream musical about manic depression, Next to Normal, which opened Wednesday night at the Second Stage Theater, is apt to produce bipolar reactions in anyone who sees it. How could it be otherwise with a show that suggests a hybrid of fractured-family soapers like Ordinary People and The Whos Tommy, the 1969 rock opera of illness and noncomformity?

title: Trying to Capture That iPhone Flair
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The Mobile World Congress brought the cellphone industry together this week to show off the latest and greatest phones.

title: Nuclear Application Delayed
description: WASHINGTON  Hearings on the first application in 30 years for an operating license for a nuclear reactor have been delayed indefinitely, because the applicant is not ready, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Wednesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 6 about the addition of Ukraine to the World Trade Organization referred incompletely to the reasons that Georgia, another former Soviet republic and W.T.O. member, opposes Russias quest for membership. While Georgian officials have objected to Russian membership in part because Moscow has banned imports of Georgian wine, the republic is also insisting on the removal of Russian customs checkpoints in the separatist territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

title: For Off Broadway Shows, an Encores!-Like Series
description: The Encores! series at City Center is devoted to Great American Musicals, which, in a cavernous, 2,750-seat theater, has pretty much meant Great American Musicals that appeared on Broadway. Thus theres been no luck, so far at least, for Little Mary Sunshine, Dames at Sea or, sadly, Bat Boy.

title: What the Next President Will Inherit
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands of New Prisoners Overwhelm Iraqi System
description: BAGHDAD  The increase in American troops in Iraq over the past year has been accompanied by waves of new Iraqi detainees, inundating the countrys already overburdened prisons and courts, American officials said Wednesday.

title: Italy: Rome Mayor Resigns to Take on Berlusconi
description: Walter Veltroni resigned as mayor of Rome to focus on his campaign to become Italys prime minister in the April national election. Mr. Veltroni, 52, representing the center-left, is running against Silvio Berlusconi, 71, a former prime minister and the countrys richest man, who is representing the conservatives. Recent opinion polls show Mr. Veltroni trails by almost 10 percentage points.

title: Knocked Off Balance, Clinton Campaign Tries to Regain Its Stride
description: SAN ANTONIO  The Texas and Ohio presidential primaries, on March 4, have become must-win contests for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, her advisers say. So why is she just opening campaign field offices across those states?

title: Amputee Sprinter Appeals
description: Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee sprinter who was barred from able-bodied competition in January, is making his final bid to be eligible to qualify for the Olympic Games.

title: Celebrity and Showmanship on a Soul Food Menu
description: ATLANTA  There is no limit, it seems, to this citys claim on the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Suddenly, Everyone Hanging Out at the Water Cooler Is a Political Expert
description: WHITE PLAINS  They sound like seasoned political pundits, dissecting delegate counts, comparing speaking styles, conjuring dream tickets and eagerly anticipating the conventions.

title: Clinton and McCain Jab at Obama, Who Offers Details of His Jobs Program
description: WASHINGTON  As Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton accused Senator Barack Obama of using rhetoric that lacks specifics or fails to yield results, Mr. Obama countered on Wednesday by offering a detailed plan to spend $210 billion to create jobs in construction and environmentally friendly fields.

title: For Clemens, No Joy Found in Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee kept a tight grip on their contradictory accounts of illegal drug use in a dramatic showdown Wednesday before a Congressional panel whose 40 Democrats and Republicans seemed to line up and take sides on a partisan basis.

title: Poetry and Song to Plumb the Russian Souls Depths
description: The day the persecuted Russian poet Joseph Brodsky went into exile, a recording of Mozarts Divertimento in D (K. 136) was on his record player, according to the program book for the concert by the Chamber Orchestra Kremlin at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening.

title: The Kidd-to-Mavericks Trade Falls Apart
description: A blockbuster trade that would have sent Jason Kidd to the Dallas Mavericks, further escalating a virtual arms race in the Western Conference, fell apart late Wednesday, leaving confusion all around.

title: Steve Gerber, Creator of Howard the Duck, Dies at 60
description: Steve Gerber, who created Howard the Duck, the dour, dyspeptic, utterly disagreeable and therefore wildly popular comic-book hero of the 1970s, died on Sunday in Las Vegas. He was 60 and lived in Las Vegas.

title: The Top Steroids Investigator Is a Silent Presence
description: WASHINGTON  Less than 10 yards away from Roger Clemens on Wednesday was the I.R.S. agent who literally dug through trash to start the governments investigation into performance-enhancing drugs four and a half years ago and will most likely soon consider what to do about Clemens.

title: Astronauts Replace Spent Station Tank
description: WASHINGTON  Two spacewalkers, including a German astronaut who was too ill to venture outside the International Space Station earlier this week, replaced a large nitrogen tank on the station on Wednesday.

title: Fed Chief Leaves Room for More Rate Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said on Thursday that the economic outlook had worsened, and he left room for the central bank to reduce interest rates yet again.

title: Give a Spreadsheet More Room to Spread Out
description: Fans of devices running Windows Mobile just got a new sidekick. The Redfly from Celio, which looks like a mini-laptop, works with almost any Windows smartphone and provides a better look at data.

title: Hewlett-Packard Settles Spying Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hewlett-Packard has agreed to a financial settlement with The New York Times and three BusinessWeek magazine journalists in connection with the companys spying scandal that stemmed from surreptitiously obtaining private phone records.

title: Dumb and Dumber: Are Americans Hostile to Knowledge?
description: A popular video on YouTube shows Kellie Pickler, the adorable platinum blonde from American Idol, appearing on the Fox game show Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? during celebrity week. Selected from a third-grade geography curriculum, the $25,000 question asked: Budapest is the capital of what European country?

title: A Point-and-Shoot Camera Wrapped in a Suit of Armor
description: Neither rain nor sleet nor controlled drops from a height of 6.6 feet shall deter the Olympus 1030 SW from taking snapshots. This 10-megapixel point-and-shoot camera is waterproof, freezeproof and, interestingly enough, crushproof.

title: A Long-Running Mystery, the Common Cramp
description: IT can happen for no reason, it seems, taking you completely by surprise. And it can be excruciating. Suddenly, a muscle contracts violently, as if it had been prodded with a jolt of electricity. And it remains balled in a tight knot as painful second after painful second drags on.

title: Back as a Lad in Arcady, Safe or Sad
description: The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there. The British novelist L .P. Hartley was referring to childhood or, more exactly, to the memory of childhood. Its the foundation of any explored adult consciousness, of course, and particularly that of the poet and often the novelist. It is most particularly true of British writers, who have made a virtual genre of traveling back to that foreign country and treating it as Arcadia.

title: Bill Curbing Terror Interrogators Is Sent to Bush, Who Has Vowed to Veto It
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted Wednesday to ban waterboarding and other harsh interrogation methods that have been used by the Central Intelligence Agency against high-level terrorism suspects. The vote, following House passage of the measure in December, set up a confrontation with President Bush, who has threatened to veto it.

title: German Executive Faces Tax Inquiry
description: BERLIN  German prosecutors accused one of the countrys most prominent business executives with tax evasion on Thursday after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.

title: Tip of the Week: Googles Keyboard Shortcuts.
description: If you spend too much time pointing and clicking just to read your Gmail on the Web, check out Googles set of keyboard shortcuts. Log into your Gmail account, click the Settings link and go to the General tab to enable keyboard shortcuts. Click the Learn More link to see a list of what you can do on the keyboard  or just click Save Changes and then type a question mark to see a list pop up on screen. Once you learn them, keyboard shortcuts can save time and mouse work  for example, just type an exclamation mark to tag an open message as spam and remove it from your In box.

title: Upholding the Standards of Smooth Jazz Purists
description: Have you seen the Wikipedia entry on smooth jazz lately? Probably not, but its a mess. The administrators have tagged almost every section with provisos: Its neutrality is disputed; needs additional citations for verification; reads like an advertisement; may contain unverified claims.

title: Time to Vote Contempt
description: Alberto Gonzales may be out, but the country is still waiting for a full accounting of how he and his White House patrons cynically politicized the Justice Department. Congress is rightly asking questions about the actions of yet another United States attorney: New Jerseys Christopher J. Christie. The House also needs to stop procrastinating and vote to hold witnesses in contempt for refusing to testify in the wider scandal.

title: Whats the Best Plan for the Hudson River Park?
description: To the Editor:

title: Politicians Turn Steroid Hearing Into a Partisan Squabble
description: Washington

title: Malaysia Leader Ends Parliament, Setting Stage for Bitter Contest
description: BANGKOK  Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi of Malaysia dissolved Parliament on Wednesday, paving the way for what is likely to be a rancorous election campaign amid ethnic tensions, scandals in the countrys judiciary and concerns over corruption and rising food prices.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture credit in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about Joel Berger, an expert on moose and other hooved animals, misidentified the newspaper that supplied a photograph of a moose crossing a road. It was The Peninsula Clarion, of Kenai, Alaska  not The Pennsylvania Clarion.

title: Michelle Obama Thrives in Campaign Trenches
description: CHICAGO  There is no confusing Michelle Obama for her husband on the campaign trail.

title: Scavenger King of Williamsburg
description: AMONG Williamsburgs layered streetscapes, where tenements now wear vinyl clapboards in candy colors and the old brick warehouses have been converted to live-work studios for post-post-grunge hipsters or condo lofts for baby investment bankers, its hard to miss William Harveys handmade house, which fits into none of these categories.

title: Little Room for Yahoo to Maneuver
description: Can Yahoo avoid being gobbled up by Microsoft?

title: Venture to Use Sea to Fight Warming Runs Out of Cash
description: Planktos, a California company that is trying to turn a profit by fertilizing the ocean with iron dust, canceled planned field tests on Wednesday, citing a lack of funds. At the companys Web site, planktos.com, a notice blamed a highly effective disinformation campaign for the cancellation.

title: Exiled Georgian Opposition Politician Dies Near London at 52
description: MOSCOW  An exiled Georgian tycoon and opposition politician, who had accused the pro-Western Georgian government of tilting toward autocracy and corruption, died unexpectedly Tuesday night at his home outside London, the authorities said.

title: Obamas Lead in Delegates Shifts Focus of Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama emerged from Tuesdays primaries leading Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton by more than 100 delegates, a small but significant advantage that Democrats said would be difficult for Mrs. Clinton to make up in the remaining contests in the presidential nomination battle.

title: Notes From a Caucus
description: Once again, we are discovering that our election process works great as long as it doesnt actually have to decide anything.

title: Zimbabwe Opponent Criticizes Mbeki
description: JOHANNESBURG  The leader of Zimbabwes main opposition party said Wednesday that President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa had failed as a mediator in laying the groundwork for fair elections in Zimbabwe and urged him to show a little courage and stop his quiet support for the dictatorship of President Robert G. Mugabe.

title: Oops!
description: The virtuoso instrumentalist and sometime model known as the David Beckham of the classical violin couldnt have done more damage if he had kicked his violin past a goalkeeper. The musician, David Garrett, was leaving the Barbican Center in London after a concert at Christmastime when he fell down a flight of stairs and landed on his violin case. Inside was his 236-year-old Giovanni Battista Guadagnini instrument, known as the San Lorenzo. Mr. Garrett, 26, who was 14 when he became the youngest artist ever signed by Deutsche Grammophon, opened the case. Inside, he told The Independent, the London newspaper: The violin was in pieces. I couldnt speak, and I couldnt get up. I didnt even know if I was hurt  I didnt care. Ive had that violin for eight years. It was like losing a friend. Repairs will take eight months and cost close to $120,000, and the violin may never sound the same. Mr. Garrett is scheduled to perform a Bruch violin concerto on Thursday night at the Barbican on a borrowed Stradivarius. A three-member security team will be helping him watch his step.

title: Making (Some) Progress in Iraq
description: Good news is rare in Iraq. But after months of bitter feuding, Iraqs Parliament has finally approved a budget, outlined the scope of provincial powers, set an Oct. 1 date for provincial elections and voted a general amnesty for detainees.

title: So, What Were We Writing About Again?
description: LOS ANGELES  Facing his writing staff on Wednesday for the first time since the end of a 100-day strike, Shane Brennan, the co-executive producer of the CBS drama NCIS, asked a question that drew blank stares. Can anyone remember what we were working on three months ago?

title: Gionta Revels in Some Open Ice as Devils Finally Solve Senators
description: NEWARK  Yet another tight game dragged into overtime Wednesday, but that turned out to be a good thing for Brian Gionta, the Devils energetic right wing. Gionta finally had room to move  and to try a maneuver that would result in a victory.

title: The Fun Starts Here
description: LIGHTEN up, people. When times are tough, take a cue from Mary Poppins and eat some sugar, or go fly a kite. If that doesnt put a smile on your face, you might delve a little further into the Disney songbook for inspiration. Think a little more Zip-a-Dee-Doo-Dah and less Oh, Bother.

title: Jack Johnson Breaks a Curse
description: After painfully slow sales last month, the music industry finally has a hit: Sleep Through the Static (Brushfire), by Jack Johnson, above, sold 375,000 copies last week  more than six times the sales of the top album the week before  to reach No. 1 on the Billboard chart. It set a record for the most digital sales in a single week, with 139,000 copies, or 37 percent of its total, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week busy with high-profile releases, Sheryl Crows Detours (A&M) opened at No. 2 with 92,000 sales; Lenny Kravitz moved 73,000 copies of It Is Time for a Love Revolution (Virgin) to bow at No. 4; and K. D. Lang is No. 8 with her new Watershed (Nonesuch), selling 41,000. Last weeks No. 1, Alicia Keyss As I Am (J), dropped two spots with 80,000. Any sales bumps after last Sundays Grammy Awards would be reflected in next weeks chart.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Senator John McCains decision to hire Mercer Reynolds, one of President Bushs major fund-raisers, misstated the position of Senator Barack Obama on using public financing for the general election. Although the Obama campaign has been raising private contributions for that election, Mr. Obama is still open to returning those contributions and abiding by the limits of the public financing system if the Republican nominee agrees to do the same. Mr. Obama has not definitively ruled out using public financing.

title: Tension and Horror at the End of a Dark Hall
description: While I have tried, I find it impossible to play video games 24 hours a day, and must often stop because I am hungry, or tired, or my hands hurt or my head aches.

title: Working in Mental Health, the Prospect of Violence Is a Part of the Job
description: Therapists  psychiatrists, psychotherapists, psychiatric social workers and other mental health professionals  are as much part of the New York landscape as hot dog vendors. And they have discovered, sometimes the hard way, that delving deeply into peoples feelings can be dangerous.

title: Kon Ichikawa, Japanese Film Director, Dies at 92
description: Kon Ichikawa, the Japanese film director whose versatility ranged beyond his well-known antiwar dramas like The Burmese Harp and Fires on the Plain to comedies, documentaries and literary adaptations, died on Wednesday in Tokyo. He was 92.

title: Do As I Do?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Light Show in a Bulb
description: Adding mood lighting to a space-age bachelor pad is easy with this five-watt L.E.D. bulb from ThinkGeek (www.thinkgeek.com) that comes with its own remote control.

title: Mortals Amid the Immortals, Savoring the Romance of Art
description: On a recent cold and rainy Friday night, the Metropolitan Museum of Arts lobby was warm and inviting. Blossoms from quince branches arranged in giant urns with pussy willows shed their pale pink petals as couples, some on blind dates, arrived to meet.

title: Scientists Find Solar System Like Ours
description: Astronomers say they have found a miniature version of our own solar system 5,000 light years across the galaxy  the first planetary system that really looks like our own, with outer giant planets and room for smaller inner planets.

title: A Band That Cradles Its Rock, Even Under All Those Layers of Expectations
description: Yannis Philippakis, lead singer of the emerging British band Foals, spent most of Tuesday night with both his hands on his chest. He wasnt being shy; he was playing the guitar. Like the bass player and the other guitarist, he wore a short strap, so the instrument was almost under his chin. And like them, he worked high on the fretboard, peeling off nimble riffs without ever uncrooking his arm.

title: 2 Sue to Void Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
description: DENVER  A lesbian couple from nearby Englewood are seeking to overturn Colorados constitutional ban on same-sex marriage, in what is thought to be the first challenge to the 2006 ballot initiative that established it.

title: Beautiful Models, Hairy Legs and All
description: NOW that Uno, the 15-inch beagle, has captured the crown, becoming the first of his breed to win best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show, and now that more than 2,600 other canine competitors have been leashed and crated and hauled home to familiar kennels and sofas, it seems fitting to consider an overlooked aspect of this crowd-pleasing sport: the strange collision of fashion and dog shows.

title: Viewing Old Photographs and Picturing the Stories
description: The choreographer Ronald K. Brown is something of an archaeologist. In his dances  poetic structures of great subtlety and force  there is the sense of a singular artist digging for a forgotten treasure. The qualities he holds dear are those that current society tends to ignore: legacy, tradition, heritage, gratitude and obligation. Yet Mr. Brown obstinately marches along his own path and, in doing so, conjures portraits of modern folklore.

title: Exports Help Narrow Trade Gap
description: The United States trade deficit shrank in 2007 for the first time in five years, buoyed by a surge in exports that has helped domestic businesses stay afloat as the domestic economy flags.

title: Parent Shock: Children Are Not Dcor
description: WHEN Jacqueline Brown and her husband, Gavin Friedman, were in their early 30s, they lived in a condominium in Santa Monica, Calif., with a black leather Ikea couch Mr. Friedman had bought for law school, a few modest pieces from Pier 1 Imports and assorted hand-me-down furnishings. Within a few years, though, having acquired professional and financial stability  both were litigation associates at prominent law firms  they bought a house in Cheviot Hills, an affluent neighborhood in West Los Angeles, and began remodeling and decorating.

title: Deal to Sell Clear Channel for $19 Billion Is Approved
description: The $19.5 billion sale of Clear Channel Communications to two private-equity firms cleared its final regulatory hurdle Wednesday with approval by the Justice Departments antitrust division.

title: Road Distractions
description: To the Editor:

title: Footnotes
description: Michael S. Harper, a professor of English at Brown University and the first poet laureate of Rhode Island, has been named the recipient of the 2008 Frost Medal of the Poetry Society of America. The honor, recognizing distinguished lifetime service to American poetry, will be bestowed on April 21 at the societys 98th annual awards ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York. ... The rapper Lil Wayne, right, has been indicted on felony drug and weapons charges by a grand jury in Yuma, Ariz., The Associated Press reported. Lil Wayne, 25, whose real name is Dwayne Michael Carter Jr., pleaded not guilty when arraigned on Friday. His lawyer, James Tilson, said on Tuesday that Lil Waynes tour would continue as scheduled. He is next due in court on March 7.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: On Design

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,952 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: A House Divided by Old Magic and New Residents
description: Every devoted reader of childrens literature knows that magic is difficult  for the young wizards who practice it, of course, but even more so for their would-be creators, who must compete in an ever more crowded field. Bookstore shelves are full of spells and sorcery, and so, these days, are multiplexes, as filmmakers take advantage of special-effects technology to bring literary enchantments to life.

title: A Festival With Plenty of This, That and the Other
description: Boundaries of geography, genre and taste are tested and occasionally trampled in the ninth edition of Film Comment Selects, the annual cinema roundup from the editors of Film Comment magazine, which runs through Feb. 28 at the Walter Reade Theater. Such border crossings are common inside the pages of Film Comment, a citadel of intellectually committed, aesthetically adventurous, sometimes prickly, sometimes maddening, sometimes baffling, if invariably lively and passionate cinephilia that is published bimonthly by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. You may want to throw the magazine against the wall on occasion, but it remains essential reading.

title: Agency Sued Over Death of Firefighter at Tower
description: The sister of one of the two firefighters killed in August fighting a fire at the former Deutsche Bank building sued the government agency that owns the building and several contractors on Wednesday, charging they knowingly created dangerous conditions that led to her brothers death.

title: The Sensation of Flight, on Terra Firma
description: Flight simulation programs can feel a little earthbound when played at a desk, but a new gaming chassis gets the whole body into the experience.

title: Time-Space Continuum? No Big Deal. And the Swag...
description: Its impossible for outsiders to know who deserves most of the blame for this dud  its director, Doug Liman, its three screenwriters, its multiple producers or the various studio executives who might have done far too much meddling or not nearly enough. Whatever the case, Jumper  a barely coherent genre mishmash about a guy who transports himself across the globe at will  is of interest only because it revisits a theme that Mr. Liman has explored in films like The Bourne Identity and, if reports about his troubled productions are true, speaks to his own reputation as an escape artist: the character who wiggles out of trouble.

title: Daily News to Have Color for All Pages
description: The Daily News said Wednesday that it would become the first major newspaper in the country capable of printing full color on every page, a move to attract readers and advertisers in the fierce competition among New Yorks tabloids.

title: Thomas Gets a Head Start on the All-Star Break
description: BOSTON  Isiah Thomas was ejected for reasons he could not surmise from a defeat that he could not explain, and the Knicks trudged into the All-Star break as dizzy and disoriented as they have ever been.

title: Social Equality Comes With a Beat, Again
description: Step Up 2 the Streets is an earnest sequel to the 2006 cornball musical drama Step Up, mixing new characters into the originals setting, the neighborhoods surrounding the Maryland School of the Arts in Baltimore.

title: Police Talk to Man About Therapists Killing
description: A law enforcement official said that detectives from New York City interviewed a man in Bethlehem, Pa., in connection with the killing of a psychologist in Manhattan on Tuesday.

title: Ending Impasse, Iraq Parliament Backs Measures
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs parliamentary leaders on Wednesday pushed through three far-reaching measures that had been delayed for weeks by bitter political maneuvering that became so acrimonious that some lawmakers threatened to try to dissolve the legislative body.

title: Preventing Plump: Start Young
description: Want your teenager to be trim as an adult? Give in to the whining and buy that skateboard he craves. That's the message of a major longitudinal study of adolescence and weight gain published last month in the journal Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine. In the study, led by researchers at Johns Hopkins University, 3,345 adolescents were asked about their daily physical activities, both in physical education classes and on their own. The kids reported their weights, which were used to calculate theirbody mass indexes. Most -- 72 percent -- were average weight or below.

title: Witness in Absentia Appears in Words
description: Well before the Congressional hearing Wednesday, Andy Pettitte was viewed as being the most critical witness because he had acknowledged that the Mitchell report was correct about him, that Brian McNamee had injected him with human growth hormone in 2002.

title: Protest Group Assails Eli Broad Art
description: The Guerrilla Girls, a group that protests what it calls sexism and racism in politics, the art world, film and the culture at large, sent an open letter to the philanthropist Eli Broad saying that female and minority artists are inadequately represented in the exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Mr. Broads private foundation. In a posting on the groups Web site, guerrillagirls.com, the organization claims that of the 30 artists in the inaugural exhibition at the Broad Museum, 97 percent are white and 87 percent are male. Similarly, the group says that of the 194 artists in the collection of the Broad Foundation, the nonprofit organization that acts as a lending library for Mr. Broads art holdings, 96 percent are white and 83 percent are male. That, the group said, is an insignificant number of women and artists of color. Contacted about the statement, a spokeswoman for Mr. Broad and his art foundation, Karen Denne, said by e-mail: Women are prominently featured in the opening installation at BCAM, which was curated by Lacma. In fact, 33 percent of the works in the exhibit are by women. One of the largest galleries at BCAM is devoted to Cindy Sherman, whose works the Broads have collected since 1981.' Ms. Denne added, Artwork with a strong social and political perspective has always been important to the Broads and to their collecting. She said that 33 percent of the 43 artists added to the foundations collection since 1995 were women .

title: A Strong Field in Boston
description: Lidiya Grigoryeva of Russia, who won the Boston Marathon womens race last year, and Rita Jeptoo of Kenya, who won the year before, will compete April 21 in the 112th running of the event. Marathon officials also announced that Jelena Prokopcuka of Latvia, the runner-up the last two years, would be back. The womens field will include three young Ethiopians: Askale Tafa Magarsa, 23, who won in Paris and Dubai last year; Dire Tune, 22, the Houston winner last year and this year; and Robe Tola Guta, 21, who won in Hamburg, Germany, two years ago. Other entries include Tetyana Kuzina-Hladyr of Ukraine, Magdaline Chemjor of Kenya, Alevtina Biktimirova of Russia and Bruna Genovese of Italy.The best American women will race on a different course the day before in the United States Olympic trials.

title: Relying on New Jersey Roads, and Fearing Higher Tolls
description: DAYTON, N.J.  Up and down the New Jersey Turnpike, warehouse managers like Ray OBrien are bracing for the worst.

title: House Cites 2 Bush Aides for Contempt
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted Thursday to issue contempt citations against the White House chief of staff and a former White House counsel for refusing to cooperate in an investigation into the mass firings of federal prosecutors.

title: Cone Denies Telling McNamee Owners Opposed Testing
description: TAMPA, Fla.  David Cone was casually monitoring the Congressional hearings featuring Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee from his home in Stamford, Conn. After he left the room for a few minutes, he said he was surprised when he heard his name mentioned on television.

title: Clean Power Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprise Twist Ends Old Homicide Case: Cocaine, Not Mother, Killed Girl
description: BUFFALO  Since 1993, prosecutors and defense lawyers have argued over who killed Crystallynn Girard, a 13-year-old girl who was found dead in her bedroom here exactly 15 years ago.

title: Where Lincoln Sought Refuge in His Dark Hours
description: WASHINGTON  If you look out the windows of President Lincolns Cottage at the Soldiers Home  the idiosyncratic and intriguing museum that is opening to the public on Tuesday after a ceremonial event on Monday  you have to imagine what Abraham Lincoln might have seen during those summer evenings when he stood here. The cottage is on a hilltop, the third highest in the area. And when Lincoln first came here, seeking a respite from the summer heat, the swampy air and the incessant bustle of the White House, he could have looked out over the expanding city below him, with the unfinished Washington Monument and incomplete Capitol dome rising in the distance.

title: City Council Approves a Bill Requiring Residents to Recycle Electronics
description: New York City is a step closer to adopting one of the toughest electronics recycling laws in the nation, despite strong objections from manufacturers and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: So Is That Like an A?
description: Time was that a fifth graders greatest concern about gym was whether he or she would be picked last for the kickball team. Now, in schools in Hartford, that 10-year-old would-be athlete is being graded on how he or she establishes and maintains a healthy lifestyle by avoiding risk-taking behavior. In music class, students are being graded on how they make connections between music and other disciplines through evaluation and analysis of compositions and performances. That is pretty far from just trying to sing Yankee Doodle on key.

title: New York Times Plans to Cut 100 Newsroom Jobs
description: After years of resisting the newsroom cuts that have hit most of the industry, The New York Times will bow to growing financial strain and eliminate about 100 newsroom jobs this year, the executive editor said Thursday.

title: How I Met Your Mother: A History Lesson in Love
description: Definitely, Maybe, a nimble and winning little romance written and directed by Adam Brooks, begins with one of those awkward Important Talks that parents are sometimes required to have with their children. In this case Maya Hayes (Abigail Breslin) needs some debriefing after a sex education class at her Manhattan elementary school. Shes acquired some technical vocabulary but not a lot of context, and so it falls to her dad, Will (Ryan Reynolds), to do the necessary explaining.

title: The Power to Say No
description: In recent weeks, the federal Forest Service awarded a British company the right to explore for uranium on 39 separate sites on national forest land just outside Grand Canyon National Park, less than three miles from a popular lookout over the canyons southern rim.

title: U-Turn or Bump in the Road?
description: Do you think Roger Clemens's testimony at Wednesday's Congressional hearing will alter his path to the Hall of Fame? Should it?

title: Hollywood Produces for Idol
description: Hollywood Week on American Idol had a promising start on Tuesday as a two-hour edition of that Fox talent competition trounced its competitors in the ratings, drawing 29.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. Although Tuesdays Idol audience grew by 2 million compared with last weeks, the first installment of Hollywood Week last year attracted 31.2 million viewers. Trailing far behind Fox in the nights ratings, CBS drew the second most viewers, earning a solid 11.7 million at 8 p.m. for a rerun of NCIS. Later in the night, however, a more modest 7.3 million viewers tuned in at 9 for the premiere of Big Brother: Til Death Do You Part, the first winter edition of that CBS summer mainstay. At 10 the second season debut of Jericho attracted 7.2 million viewers, tying ABCs Boston Legal, but trailing a repeat of NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (8.3 million). NBC finished third for the night while edging past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49 thanks to The Biggest Loser, from 8 to 10 (7.5 million). ABC was a distant fourth overall.

title: Resolution on Prayer Is Approved
description: Conservative Judaisms international assembly of rabbis voted Tuesday to approve a resolution criticizing Pope Benedict XVIs revision of a Latin Good Friday prayer. The prayer calls for God to enlighten the hearts of Jews so that they may acknowledge Jesus Christ, the savior of all men. The resolution adopted by the rabbis said the prayer could set back Jewish-Catholic relations. Most Catholics worship in the vernacular, and their prayers will not be affected.

title: If You Cant Let Go, Twitter
description: SOMETIMES, you just have to trust your relatives. You have to be willing to let them leave the house unchallenged. Suspend disbelief and let them take the car.

title: Lessons From the Intersection of Children and High Design
description: PARENTS Tracy McArdle Brady, 39, and Nathaniel Brady, 40, Carlisle, Mass.

title: Dog Running: Easier Does It
description: FOR those who run with their dogs, trying to stay fleet of foot with a dog on a leash can be an exercise in futility. While the two-legged jogger aims for an even pace, the four-legged set sniffs, pulls, doubles back and dashes forward, yanking the shoulder socket. Regular leashes can also cause gait problems for serious runners, said Kelly Liljeblad, a dog owner and marathoner from Boulder, Colo. If you run with the leash in the left hand, youll naturally bend to the left, she explained.

title: Moving Outlook: Mail to a Mac
description: Q. I am thinking of buying a MacBook to replace my Windows laptop. Is there a way to move the Microsoft Outlook file (e-mails, contacts and calendars) between a PC and a Mac?

title: Chug-a-Lugging Aphrodisiacs
description: GRAVITY shifted the items in my dish rack the other day, making the blade of one of my better knives suddenly slide its entire length along the stem of a wet wineglass. It gave me goose bumps, it was such an unexpectedly erotic sound; the kind of foley youd hear if Liliana Cavani (The Night Porter) directed a Batman movie: Zing!

title: A Little Piece of Microsoft Aids Small Business
description: So Microsoft is making a hostile bid for Yahoo.

title: This Is as Good as It Gets, Paws Down
description: When a dog trots around a show ring, what is he thinking?

title: Inquiry Set on Health Care Billing
description: It is a common medical puzzler. The benefits statement arrives from the insurance company, saying that although the doctor has charged, say, $200 for that recent office visit, only $80 is covered  and the consumer is obliged to pick up the balance.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. Where can I find lightweight draperies that will block out the light?

title: Primitive Bats Took to the Wing, but They Didnt Have That Ping
description: The most primitive bat ever discovered could fly but not navigate by sound, scientists reported Thursday.

title: Panama Releases Report on 06 Poisoning
description: Panamanian investigators have concluded that at least 174 people were poisoned, 115 of them fatally, by counterfeit cold medicine linked to an unlicensed Chinese chemical plant.

title: Barber, Bernstein and Other Heroes of U.S. History
description: Isnt it odd how Lincoln Centers constituent musical organizations present programs that should be the norm for 21st-century ensembles, but try to make them seem special or unusual by giving them names or calling them festivals? The New York Philharmonic has long done this with its Composer Focus programs, which rarely amount to more than a few of a contemporary composers works spread through a season. Behold the triumph of marketing as a substitute for creative programming.

title: Defense Lawyer Casts Doubt on Timeline in Brokers Killing
description: The Fifth Avenue real estate broker Linda Stein might have been alive and well for at least 45 minutes after the personal assistant who is accused of killing her left her apartment, the assistants lawyer contends in court papers that were filed on Wednesday.

title: Chinese Factory Linked to Drug Under Inquiry in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  A Chinese factory that has not been inspected by the Food and Drug Administration is the source for the active ingredient of a critical blood-thinning drug whose production was suspended this week after 350 patients reported ill effects from it.

title: UBS Posts Loss on Big Write-Down
description: PARIS  UBS offered no hope for a near-term turnaround in its business after it posted a huge fourth-quarter loss on Thursday and warned that 2008 would be a difficult year.

title: Quite a Show, Offering Something New
description: Roger Clemens has starred in three major TV performances this year: a 60 Minutes interview with Mike Wallace; a news conference in which he stormed out; and his testimony to the House oversight committee on Wednesday in which he continued to deny using human growth hormone or steroids, as alleged by his former personal trainer Brian McNamee.

title: Why, Beethoven, Youve Gone Mahlerian
description: Gustav Mahlers orchestral transcription of Beethovens Opus 95 String Quartet suggests that inside every thin man is a fat one trying to get out. Such urges for physical change are usually practical ones; artistic advantage tends to be accidental.

title: Correction: Reigning Trowel in a Kingdom of Orchids
description: An article last Thursday about Robert Fuchs, an orchid grower in Florida, gave an incorrect name for his nursery. It is R.F. Orchids, not R.H. Orchids.

title: The Frosty Reality of Spring Training
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Garbage Truck Driver Charged in Crash That Killed Two Tourists
description: A New Jersey garbage truck driver was charged with manslaughter on Wednesday after a truck he was driving in Manhattan on Tuesday veered out of control, jumped a curb and killed two tourists from England, the police said.

title: Yes, Its Valentines Day, and Yes, Frances First Lady Is in Love
description: PARIS  In her first interview since she married President Nicolas Sarkozy, the model-turned-singer Carla Bruni said that they had fallen in love immediately and that only death would part them.

title: Testy Moments Are Fueled by Nanny
description: WASHINGTON  Amid testimony regarding Roger Clemens, his former trainer, syringes and steroids, some of the most dramatic and heated moments in Wednesdays House Oversight Committee hearing centered on a nanny, a barbecue, and suggestions of witness tampering.

title: Larger Share of Students Succeed on A.P. Tests
description: A higher percentage of students in public high schools are taking and passing Advanced Placement exams, according to a report issued Wednesday by the College Board. The gap between the performance of black and white students, however, remains large.

title: Limiting Power on a Shared PC
description: Q. Whats the difference between sharing a PC on an Administrator user account and a Limited user account? Is there any advantage to using one over the other?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the theft of four masterwork paintings valued at $163 million from a Zurich gallery misspelled the name of the French village in the title of one painting, an 1879 Monet. It is Poppies Near Vtheuil, not Vertheuil.

title: Lawmakers Put Out New Call for Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON  The window for Congressional earmarks is open once again. Lawmakers from both parties are inviting constituents and lobbyists to recommend pet projects that could be financed by the federal government as the 2008 earmark season gets under way.

title: Big Selling Point for G.M. Tower: Naming Rights
description: Whats in a name? Tens of millions of dollars, the owner of the General Motors Building hopes.

title: Mexico Human Rights Agency Called Ineffective
description: MEXICO CITY  There is a common saying in Mexico about police investigations and government inquiries that goes no pasa nada, or nothing happens.

title: Oscar Night Starting to Seem Like Another Super Bowl
description: SPONSORS of the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards on Feb. 24 are deciding that the show is no country for old ads.

title: Flowing and Intricate, With a Toe in Many Styles
description: The pianist Edward Simon reconciles a few different agendas in his music, borrowing judiciously from classical impressionism, post-bop modality and the folk music of his native Venezuela. Hes careful with his calibration of these and other influences, but the effort doesnt feel belabored. In his first set on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, his debut there as a leader, he projected flowing ease along with a canny sense of drama.

title: Ruling on Fortunoff Sale
description: Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware won court approval on Wednesday to sell its business for $80 million in cash to the private equity firm NRDC Equity Partners, barring higher offers at auction.

title: Harvard Research to Be Free Online
description: Harvard University will soon begin posting research and articles produced by its faculty on the Internet free of charge. On Tuesday the arts and sciences faculty voted overwhelmingly in favor of a resolution that would commit Harvard to open access  the movement to speed the exchange of knowledge by freely distributing research on the Web. The chorus of yeas was thunderous, Robert Darnton, the director of the University Library, wrote in an e-mail message. I hope this marks a turning point in the way communications operate in the world of scholarship. The library will oversee an Office of Scholarly Communication, which is being created to handle the project. Professor Darnton said a Web site instructing the faculty on how to transmit articles is already up and running, and the technical work should be completed by April 1. Meanwhile open access took another step forward on Wednesday when Fastcase inaugurated the Public Library of Law (www.plol.org), a free online legal research site.

title: Winters Cheerleader, Yelling for Spring
description: SUNNY, warm days in midwinter always send me in search of fragrant witch hazels, those graceful shrubs that unfurl their crinkled, confetti-like flowers from January to March.

title: A Deep Injection of Righteous Hysteria
description: Last week, a famous pitcher likely bound for the Hall of Fame was reportedly injected with a steroid in an effort to prolong his career. This news, however, was not greeted with any widespread clutching of pearls. There were no calls for Congressional meddling and no inquiries about any palpable growths on his hindquarters. There was no talk, either, of the sanctity of the record books, and no earnest invocations of The Children, those poor souls sent down a wayward path because Nook Logan might've dabbled with growth hormone. In fact, it was all perfectly legal. The pitcher's injection, according to the Boston Globe, was part of a "conservative treatment plan" laid out by his team's medical staff. The headline: "Schilling receives shot of cortisone."

title: A Struggle to Steal a Fur or Two
description: MILLBURN, N.J.  Perhaps the four thieves were not aware of the valet service available at The Mall at Short Hills.

title: Interpreter Freed, but CBS Journalist Still Held
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi interpreter kidnapped in the southern city of Basra was freed Wednesday, but the CBS journalist seized with him this week was still being held.

title: Back to Work
description: Playwright and television writer Diana Son goes back to work after the  Writers Guild of America ended its three-month-long strike.

title: Respond to Todays Column: Notes From a Caucus
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Feb. 14 column.

title: After the Big Dig
description: With the $15 billion construction project officially over, the promised transformation of downtown Boston finally seems within reach.

title: We Cant Wait for the Video
description: This comes from Craig Custance of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution at Thrashers Blog via the ubiquitous Kuklas Korner.

title: Chinese Retailer Said to Bring HSBC and UBS on Board for I.P.O.
description: A Chinese department store operator, Maoye International Holdings, has hired two more investment banks to underwrite its postponed Hong Kong initial public offering, according to Dow Jones.

title: S.E.C. to Ease Rules for Foreign-Share Registrations
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission may free some foreign companies from the agencys oversight as long as they make financial disclosures widely available to investors over the Internet.

title: S.E.C. Asks Money Managers to Post Full Details on Web
description: Money managers in the United States would have to provide online brochures describing their services, fees, investment performance and potential conflicts of interest under a proposal approved Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: German Bank Receives Its Third Bailout
description: The German government said on Wednesday that it would participate in a third bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the lender whose near-collapse in July heralded the arrival in Europe of the crisis stemming from the faltering subprime mortgage market in the United States.

title: Commerzbank Takes $1.2 Billion Hit from Subprime
description: Commerzbanks bill from the subprime crisis crept up towards 800 million euros ($1.2 billion) in 2007 but the bank still managed a record profit for the year as bad debt provisions fell.

title: AstraZeneca Spins Off Gastrointestinal Unit
description: AstraZeneca said Thursday it is spinning off its Swedish gastrointestinal research operations into a new company called Albireo, backed by a consortium of investment firms led by Nomura Phase4 Ventures.

title: Air France to Buy Stake in Merged Delta-Northwest, Report Says
description: The Air France-KLM Group, Europes biggest airline, plans to invest in a combined Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines carrier, according to news reports.

title: Intel Takes Up Bragsters Dare
description: Bragster, a London-based site for dares and social bets, announced Wednesday that it had secured $3.5 million in Series A venture cash. The funding round was led by none other than Intel Capital, Intels investment branch.

title: Investors Take Ellen Tracy Off Liz Claibornes Rack
description: A group of investors have agreed to try on Ellen Tracy for size.

title: Judge Approves $80 Million Auction of Fortunoff
description: Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware won court approval on Wednesday to sell its business for $80 million to the private equity firm NRDC Equity Partners, barring higher offers at auction.

title: Ambacs Chief Risk Officer Leaves
description: The Ambac Financial Group, a bond insurer, said Wednesday that its chief risk officer had resigned. The executive, William T. McKinnon, left on Feb. 8, the company said in a regulatory filing.

title: As Profits Rise, Rio Again Rebuffs BHP
description: Rio Tinto again rebuffed a hostile takeover bid by its larger rival, BHP Billiton, saying that there was clear water between BHPs sweetened $147 billion bid and its fair value.

title: Madison Dearborn: When Nice Doesnt Finish Last
description: It could be argued that the maxim nice guys finish last was created with private equity titans in mind. The industry is littered with tales of cutthroat buyout competitions. The rivalry between Blackstones chief, Stephen A. Schwarzman, and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, chieftain, Henry R. Kravis, alone has been been the subject of oceans of spilled ink.

title: Hewlett-Packard Settles Spying Case
description: Hewlett-Packard has agreed to a financial settlement with The New York Times and three BusinessWeek magazine journalists in connection with the companys spying scandal that stemmed from surreptitiously obtaining private phone records.

title: NBCs Silverman Sells Production Company to Shine
description: NBC Entertainments co-chairman, Ben Silverman, on Wednesday sold his television production company, Reveille, to London-based Shine, owned by the media baron Rupert Murdochs daughter Elisabeth, for $125 million.

title: Banks Seek Government Help for Mortgages, Report Says
description: The banking industry is proposing to members of Congress and the White House that some of the risk of troubled mortgages should be shifted to the federal government, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Plankton-Seeding Venture Runs Out of Funds
description: Planktos, a California company that is trying to turn a profit by fertilizing the ocean with iron dust, canceled planned field tests on Wednesday, citing a lack of funds, The New York Times reported. At the companys Web site, planktos.com, a notice blamed a highly effective disinformation campaign for the cancellation.

title: Restricted Stock May Flood Market When Rules Take Effect
description: On Friday, billions of dollars in restricted stock will become eligible for trading on the open market as new Securities and Exchange Commission rules take effect.

title: Harbinger Capital Raises Calpine Stake
description: Could a sale be in the future for the California power company Calpine?

title: No Bad News for British Bankers Bonuses
description: Bonuses for 2007 rose or were unchanged for 80 percent of Londons financial-services employees as a second-half market slump failed to bite until this year, Bloomberg News reported, citing British recruitment company Morgan McKinsley.

title: Give Each Other the Mitten
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Justice Dept. Approves Clear Channel Deal
description: The $19.5 billion sale of Clear Channel Communications to two private-equity firms cleared its final regulatory hurdle Wednesday with approval by the Justice Departments antitrust division.

title: MBIA to Call on Congress to Rein in Ackman
description: MBIA, the worlds biggest bond insurer, is planning to hit back at the hedge fund heavy William A. Ackman, who has long been betting against the insurers shares.

title: Freescale Names a New Chief Executive
description: Freescale Semiconductor, the chipmaker that was acquired by a group of private equity firms in 2006, named Rich Beyer as its new chief executive on Wednesday. Mr. Beyer was most recently the chairman and chief executive of Intersil, another semiconductor company.

title: Little Room for Yahoo to Maneuver
description: Can Yahoo avoid being gobbled up by Microsoft? Many analysts say it is increasingly unlikely.

title: Solutia Seeks to Depose Citis Pandit in Financing Suit
description: Solutia, a bankrupt chemical company, wont be sending any Valentine Days goodies to Citigroups chief executive, Vikram Pandit, but it will head to a Manhattan court on Thursday to try to persuade a judge to allow it to depose him.

title: Say It! Say It! Or Well Leave Again
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Big news for us, the writers strike is finally over and I just want to say personally its great to have them back. In fact, they wrote that. That was the first thing they wrote. Say it! Say it! Or well leave again.

title: Football Isnt Held to the Same Standard (It Is What It Is)
description: Why does football get a pass?

description: Coming soon to a theater near you

title: And Speaking of Not Wearing Pants
description: Todays obituary page notes the passing of Steve Gerber, who created Howard the Duck, the dour, dyspeptic, utterly disagreeable and therefore wildly popular comic-book hero of the 1970s (too bad the movie was a bomb). But folks at Disney were not among Howards fans, as the obit notes:

title: For Your Next PowerPoint Presentation
description: Found at Mental Floss, which notes that:

title: Looking for Passion, at Work
description: Whenever I write about finding passion in our careers, the naysayers show up to say that passion really doesnt belong at work. So in honor of Valentines Day, I ask why was this advertisement one of the most popular videos on YouTube a week after it aired on the Super Bowl? Is it just a case of clever ad copy and animation? Or is it that people really do want something resembling passion in their careers? Either way, enjoy it if you havent yet seen it.

title: I should count myself lucky
description: I get some pretty harsh comments. But theyre nothing like what I used to get when criticizing Dear Leader, back when he had an 80% approval rating, and  this is new to me  nothing like the comments people leave on financial blogs when they say a good word about short-sellers.

title: Cocktail Art
description: The Bagger visited the preview Oscar luncheon in New York at the Carlyle Hotel where the chef came up with a plate to mirror each movie. There will be video of this momentous event, but in the meantime, Grub Street conjured a list of drinkables to match the nominees, including:

title: UBS Expects Another Difficult Year
description: Shares of UBS, the Swiss bank, fell in Europe on Thursday after it confirmed its previous warning of a big fourth-quarter loss and said it expects 2008 to be another difficult year. The bank also revealed $26.6 billion in exposure to risky United States mortgages distinct from the now-infamous subprime loans, increasing its vulnerability to the global credit crisis.

title: Clayton May Have One More Twist
description: The Spidey sense of Scott Feinberg, who follows the race closer than most, is tingling. He says that Michael Clayton is surging across the board, perhaps even threatening Day-Lewis and Bardem. Tilda Swinton is on a roll as well, according to Pete Hammond.

title: Some Ripples in the Pool
description: Some of you have already started filling in your ballots for the Oscar pool, beginning with the easy ones, like Diablo Cody for original screenplay. Sasha Stones takes a hard look and smells a rat than might sneak up on her.

title: Cheesy Theme Post
description: This being Valentines Day, the Bagger has to have a Hallmark moment and salute some of the great romances in the years movies.

title: Wonky Enough
description: The New Republics Jonathan Chait tries to arbitrate the campaign dispute over whether Barack Obama has a firm enough grasp on policy matters to be president. Well, its certainly true that Obama cant match Hillary Clintons grasp of policy detail, Chait writes at The Plank, his magazines staff blog. Clinton is a true policy wonk. He continues:

title: Renewals on NBC: Heroes, Chuck, Life
description: The NBC dramas Heroes, Chuck, and Life will return for the next television season, the network said Wednesday.

title: How Goodman Globals Deal Got Done
description: Did you hear that sound Wednesday? It was a big sigh of relief among the arbitrage community as the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman completed its acquisition of Goodman Global.

title: Waterboarding Not Legal Now, Justice Dept. Lawyer Says
description: Updated

title: The Early Word: The Count
description: No matter which way you calculate the delegate count, that score is dictating the shape of the Democratic race these days.

title: A self-reinforcing cycle of anxiety
description: Things are proceeding more slowly that I sort-of-but-didnt-really predicted. But current events  in which every week or two some important market you never heard of seems to collapse  bear at least a family resemblance to the scenario I laid out a year ago.

title: A Manhunt for Killer of Psychologist
description: The top story of the day is the police search for a man who fatally stabbed a psychologist, Kathryn Faughey, then attacked a psychiatrist, Kent D. Shinbach, in a medical office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The man  described as middle-aged, with a black cap and sneakers  came in from the freezing rain, toting two pieces of black luggage and saying he was there to see Dr. Shinbach. But Dr. Shinbach had another patient, a woman, waiting for him, so the man sat on a couch and made small talk. Then he disappeared into the office of the other doctor, Kathryn Faughey, and stabbed her in the head, face and chest. Hearing her screams, Dr. Shinbach rushed in and saw her lying still and bleeding on the tan carpet by her desk.

title: Buen Dia, Dakar Rally
description: So the Dakar Rally is moving to South America. Whether it will continue to be called the Dakar Rally is still up in the air, in part because the events organizers are holding out hope that the 30-year-old cross-continent rally might someday return to its Lisbon-Dakar route.

title: Hooking Up on Valentines Day
description: Its that time of the year when velvet boxes get opened  perhaps with some candlelight and a fancy dinner, just to seal the deal  and the question gets popped. In recent days, some were expecting that even Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines might feel the romance and choose Valentines Day to announce a merger agreement. Frank Boroch, an analyst at Bear Stearns, suggested last week that a Feb. 14 merger announcement would play up the friendly aspects of any proposal, as opposed to the ugly situation with Deltas previous suitor, an unabashedly hostile (and ultimately unsuccessful) US Airways.

title: U-Turn or Bump in the Road?
description: Do you think Roger Clemenss testimony at Wednesdays Congressional hearing will alter his path to the Hall of Fame? Should it?

title: CSX Rebuffs TCIs Demands for Special Meetings
description: Theres no love lost between CSX, the railroad operator, and The Childrens Investment Fund, the hedge fund battling for seats at the company.

title: Sell Stocks, Buy Flowers
description: Howard Silverblatt of Standard & Poors reports that St. Valentines Day tends to be a poor day in the stock market, with the S.&P. 500 rising only 39 percent of the time, and fallling 57 percent of the time.

title: Creator of 24 Calls It Quits
description: Joel Surnow, the creator of 24, is clocking out.

title: A Soul Man
description: Shaila Dewan has a great piece today about the Soul Food Museum, which had an official opening of sorts in Atlanta yesterday. The museum is the creation of Kenneth Willhoite, whose expansive vision of soul food can accommodate both Smokey Robinsons seafood gumbo mix (The Soul is in the Bowl) and Lucille Balls Predic-a-mints.

title: Galaxies
description: The eventful life of galaxies in low density environments performed by Ruth Gruetzbauch and Jess Varela.

title: Refitting Repasts
description: A spatial exploration of food processing, sharing, cooking and disposal at the Dunefield Midden campsite in South Africa performed by Brian Stewart and Giulia Saltini-Semerari.

title: The Ultimate Valentine Card: Full-Frontal Gorilla Love
description: Imagine you are a gorilla who has just made a momentous discovery: having sex while facing your partner. What is going through your mind? What do you say to your partner? (Hint: Think Barry White, not Dan Hill.)

title: Diane Keaton Flips Legendary Los Angeles House
description: Anyone with a penchant for preserving historical Los Angeles real estate should probably bow down and kiss the Oscar winning toes of actress Diane Keaton, writes the author of Real Estalker, who goes by Your Mama.

description: (Raymond Meier)

description: Dogs and their owners sports some all kinds of looks at the Westminster Kennel Club show.

title: News of Ledgers Passion Emerges After His Death
description: Chess players eagerly keep track of celebrities devoted to the game, with Will Smith, Howard Stern and Madonna prominent on the list. But in clubs, at tournaments and on Internet forums, I never heard any players talk about Heath Ledger. The Australian actor, who died Jan 22 at age 28, apparently enjoyed the game as much as anyone in Hollywood. But the depth of his passion has only come out post-mortem.

title: Separate Rallies in Lebanon
description: Supporters of an anti-Syrian coalition marked the third anniversary of the assasination of Rafik Hariri on the same day of the funeral of Hezbollah leader Imad Mugniyah.

title: Party Valentines
description: Nothing says Valentines Day like long-stemmed roses, dark chocolate and a sweet love note from Hillary Rodham Clinton:

title: Will You Be My Anti-Valentine?
description: One persons Valentines Day is anothers Singles Awareness Day (yes, the acronym spells SAD, and yes, someone has already thought to trademark it).

title: Recipe of the Day: Quick Whole Wheat and Molasses Bread
description: The quintessential American quick bread is corn bread, and this points us in the direction of wholesome, fast, savory breads that can anchor a hearty vegetarian dinner or serve as a side dish at a more conventional meal. This one, made predominantly with whole wheat flour, does it all  and with almost no work.

title: A Kosher Quibble
description: In response to my review of the Second Avenue Deli, a writer who contributes frequently to the Times e-mailed me with an interesting assertion to which some of you may have equally interesting reactions. So I throw it out there for discussion.

title: Symptoms of a Tip-Off in UnitedHealth Trades?
description: In the highly volatile world of options trading, minutes count. And it was one particular minute on Wednesday morning  one second, actually  that caught the eye of Jon Najarian, the co-founder of OptionMonster.com.

title: Practicing C.P.R. on City Government
description: At a news conference in the Bronx this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is announcing Citywide Performance Reporting, a new online tool intended to allow the public to track and monitor more than 500 indicators of municipal performance.

title: Soccers Most Lamentable Knee(s)
description: There is only one way to describe Ronaldos brief appearance for AC Milan Wednesday against Livorno: disaster!

title: Are Books Romantic?
description: Theres a whole genre that says they are, of course, but in my experience the most intimate literary moments dont necessarily come from love stories.

title: Making the Case for a Countertop Printer
description: After I reviewed digital picture frames in last weeks column, I just could not believe the number of readers who wrote to say, Why buy an expensive frame just to show pictures? My computer has a screensaver that does the same thing! Why not just buy a cheap old Dell and dedicate it to showing your pictures?

title: Valentines Day | I Love You [This Much]
description: Say it with chocolate this Valentines Day. How much you say is up to you.

title: Shelley Duncan: Yankees Spokesman for a Day
description: Shelley Duncan, who has played 34 games in his career with the Yankees, was left to be a spokesman for the team on Wednesday. Since Derek Jeter and Jorge Posada had the day off, Duncan was the only Yankee who stopped to talk to the news media. Duncan fielded questions about Roger Clemens and the Congressional hearings in Washington, D.C.

title: A Basic Tart Crust
description: There have been some requests for a basic tart crust recipe since my column on making walnut tart, so here you go. Its obviously very buttery, but its even richer than that because it contains an egg, too. This makes it almost like shortbread; you might think of it as a large cookie.

description: Happy V-Day!

title: On the Trail of a Therapists Killer [Updated]
description: Updated, Feb. 17 | A 39-year-old man who blamed a Manhattan psychiatrist for having him institutionalized 17 years ago was charged on Saturday with killing a female therapist in a furious knife attack and then slashing the psychiatrist when he tried to come to the womans aid, law enforcement officials said.

description: CNBC coverage of Senate testimony by Ben S. Bernanke, Federal Reserve Chairman, on the state of the economy.

My computer has a screensaver that does the same thing! Why not just buy a cheap old Dell and dedicate it to showing your pictures?

title: Yahoo Makes Its Case to Shareholders
description: In what may be a sign that its investor base is growing restless, Yahoo sent a letter from its chief executive, Jerry Yang, to shareholders Wednesday explaining the Web companys decision to turn down a takeover offer from Microsoft and laying out its turnaround strategy.

title: Putin Charmingly Denies Amassing Billions in Office
description: During his final annual press conference as President of Russia today in Moscow, Vladimir V. Putin offered a tantalizing sound bite, especially for his critics:

title: Where Art Thou, Smart Car?
description: Last month I posted about my new Smart car  or, rather, the Smart car I hope to buy. I put my $99 down to reserve one last March, when the reservations first opened up. And I waited.

title: Chafee Endorses Obama
description: MILWAUKEE  Lincoln Chafee, a former Republican Senator from Rhode Island, said today that he is changing party registration  at least on primary day next month  and endorsing Senator Barack Obamas presidential candidacy.

title: For the Moment | Stefan Sagmeister
Campaign Conversations
description: John Harwood talks to New York Senator Chuck Schumer about the close race between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.

title: Paulson Senate Testimony
description: CNBC coverage of Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., who spoke on factors that are hampering the economy.

title: Choking Game Deaths on the Rise
description: At least 82 children have died in recent years as a result of playing the choking game, a bizarre but increasingly common practice, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: The Back Story | Wacky Crazy Cake
description: (Lars Klove for The New York Times)

title: Beautiful Mount Airy Lie
description: New Yorkers who have been here since the 1980s cannot forget an old television jingle celebrating the beautiful Mount Airy Lodge in the Poconos in Pennsylvania. That hotel featured such things as floor-to-ceiling mirrors and heart-shaped bathtubs, but it had declined to a sad state by the time it closed in 2001.

title: 30 Seconds Cost a Lot, but the Memories May Be Priceless
description: Thirty seconds of advertising time on the Academy Awards will cost an estimated $1.6 million. To ensure that no dollar goes to waste, marketers like J.C. Penney, Unilever and MasterCard are planning to run spots previously unseen by consumers, Stuart Elliott reports in todays New York Times.

title: Fox Shows Its (Mainly Unscripted) Cards
description: While some networks have announced when their programs will return from a strike-induced hiatus, Fox has made a longer-term scheduling announcement, naming a line-up for the spring and summer that is dominated by unscripted shows.

title: A New Feature: Interactive Chess Puzzles
description: Feel up to testing your wits? These are interactive problems based on positions from recent tournament games. In each case, click on the chess board and wait for the viewer to load, then make a move on the chess board by clicking and dragging a piece and wait for the computer to respond. If you get the whole sequence of moves right (if more than one move is needed to solve the problem), the computer will let you know that you succeeded. Hints are available. The problems range in difficulty from easy to fairly hard. This feature will appear periodically.

title: UrbanEye: Macbeth at BAM
description: Patrick Stewart treads the Brooklyn boards as Macbeth in a new production imported from the United Kingdom. Melena Ryzik reports.

title: Writing to Sami al-Hajj
description: After reading todays column about Guantanamo and Sami al-Hajj, plenty of people have been asking what they can do. I dont have any great suggestions, although calls to the White House couldnt hurt. Another option is to write Sami directly. He speaks and reads English, so thats not a problem. The Pentagon claims that he gets mail, but his lawyers say he hasnt received a single letter for the last three or four months, even though his wife writes him constantly. So Im not sure hell get a letter, but someone will read it.and its just possible that some day a box of letters will be delivered to him. Heres his address:

title: Chelsea Clinton is Off to Hawaii
description: My mom ran for president and all I got was this stupid trip to Hawaii.

title: First Step to One-Name Status
description: Time stopped here a little before 10:40 a.m. when Johan Santana made his way from a back field toward the six-pack  the six pitching rubbers outside the Mets clubhouse  to pitch off a mound. Standing in the shade, Brian Schneider and David Wright stopped their conversation to watch. John Maine, Mike Pelfrey and Joe Smith leaned against a fence and stared. A crowd of minor-league catchers hurried over, too.

title: Simon Returns . . . But Where?
description: Islanders left wing Chris Simon, finishing up his record 30-game suspension for stomping on the leg of Pittsburghs Jarkko Ruutu, joined the Islanders for practice Wednesday at their training facility in Syosset.

title: Purple States: Ron Paul Considered
description: Throughout the primary season, the Purple States team returned repeatedly to the topic of Ron Paul's unconventional candidacy.

title: Trending Obama
description: After Super Tuesday, I was surprised to find that a friend of mine, a lifelong Democrat who had been pledging his allegiance to Barack Obama all year, had stepped into the voting booth and suddenly changed is mind. He voted, instead, for Hillary Clinton, and heres why: hed watched that video online you know, the one starring celebrities like will.i.am, Scarlett Johansson and Herbie Hancockand he thought it made Obama look Hollywood smug, as if supporting him were this years version of wearing an AIDS ribbon on your lapel. My friend didnt want anything to do with the latest chic cause, and he just couldnt bring himself to pull the lever for the guy who now symbolized the things he liked least about Democratic politics, starting with all those stars who think they know more about America than the people who live in it.

title: Scent Notes | Teint de Neige by Lorenzo Villoresi
description: In 1981, a Florentine doctoral student studying ancient philosophy took a trip to the Middle East and visited a local market. There he discovered highly-scented spices and perfume essences, which he brought home with him. He began mixing them to create fragrances. Then he began studying perfumery. In 1990, he began his namesake perfume house.

title: Clinton Appeals to Texan Soldiers
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, looking ahead to the March 4 Texas primary, has a new ad up in the Lone Star State that zeros in on its large active and retired military population.

title: CNN Producer Says He Was Fired for Blogging
description: Should journalists be permitted to maintain personal  and highly opinionated  blogs on their own time? Chez Pazienza, a senior producer for CNNs American Morning, says the network fired him on Tuesday on the grounds that he violated its standards for journalists through his blog, Deus Ex Malcontent.

title: Video: Schumer on the 2008 Race
description: Video

title: No-Boarding in B.C.
description: A new sport that's like skateboarding on snow is taking root in the back country of British Columbia, Canada.

This news, however, was not greeted with any widespread clutching of pearls. There were no calls for Congressional meddling and no inquiries about any palpable growths on his hindquarters. There was no talk, either, of the sanctity of the record books, and no earnest invocations of The Children, those poor souls sent down a wayward path because Nook Logan mightve dabbled with growth hormone. In fact, it was all perfectly legal. The pitchers injection, according to the Boston Globe, was part of a conservative treatment plan laid out by his teams medical staff. The headline: Schilling receives shot of cortisone,  Tommy Craggs writes in this weeks newsletter.

title: No Bailout Needed, MBIA Tells Congress
description: A major bond insurer told Congress on Thursday that it has adequate capital to survive industrywide distress and that neither a bailout nor tighter federal regulation is needed.

title: Must a Stopover in Venice Break Your Budget?
description: We are flying to Venice to catch a cruise and are looking for an inexpensive (is there such a thing in Venice?) hotel close to the cruise ship terminal for a night.

title: Next Stop, Grand Cayman
description: After days on the snow-swept prairies of Wisconsin, who wouldnt long for a stretch of sandy beach in, say, the Cayman Islands?

title: An Ivy Road To the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: ITHACA, N.Y. - Its just after noon here on Thursday, and the Cornell basketball team is going through a light workout at Newman Arena before embarking on a two-game road trip.

title: MTV To Preview Quarterlife
description: Television networks NBC and MTV unveiled an unusual plan on Thursday to promote a new TV show, quarterlife, that will premiere on MTV, but air weekly on competitor NBC, Reuters reports:

title: McCain Campaigns in Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  Fully ensconced as the Republican front-runner, Senator John McCain made quick stops Thursday in Vermont and Rhode Island, both of which hold their primaries on March 4th.

title: Fox Sweeps Wednesday Night
description: With an average of 24.6 million viewers, Foxs American Idol dominated Wednesday nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates, as the singing competition narrowed its field of contestants to 24 semifinalists. Fox easily led the night over all, winning the 9 p.m. time slot after American Idol with its new game show The Moment of Truth (14.5 million).

title: Dancing Dissertations
description: Video

title: Maybe One Day a Schnauzer?
description: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: I dont know about the rest of the country, but here in New York City, rainy couple of days. A lot of rain, soggy  am I right? A lot of soaking rain here. So rainy  listen to this  Amy Winehouses hair jumped up and shook itself dry.

title: London Fashion Week | Gareth Pugh, Luella, Giles, Gina Couture
description: A zipper-adorned look at Gareth Pugh. (Getty Images for IMG)

title: Valentines Day on the Trail With Clinton
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  Its sugar and spice with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Valentines Day in Ohio, as she delivered some tough new attack lines against Senator Barack Obama and then served chocolates to her traveling press corps to mark the day.

title: The Year of the Rat
description: As I was trying to keep up with the Roger Clemens hearing yesterday it occurred to me that 2008 was indeed the Year of the Rat. A Chinese dinner was in order, even if the official new years celebration was the week before.

title: I Do. Break Up With You.
description: For Valentines Day, from SuperDeluxe:

title: Theyre Called Corduroy Pants
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Welcome to The Tonight Show, ladies and gentlemen. And look for the union label!

title: Talking Fashion With Paris Hilton
description: Bruce Pask, T Magazines mens fashion director, sent this report from a fashion trade show in Las Vegas.

title: Racing Around George M. Steinbrenner Field
description: When I got to the newly named George M. Steinbrenner Field for the Yankees reporting day for pitchers and catchers at about 8:15 a.m. Thursday, I counted 22 workers sprucing up the place.
