They were completing the addition of two elevators, doing brick work and adding landscaping. There is a huge banner touting the 2008 All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium covering the building.

title: Spitzer Testifies on Bond Insurance
description: CNBC coverage of Elliot Spitzer, Governor of New York, as he testified before a House subcommittee and called for additional help for bond insurers.

title: MoveOn to Superdelegates: Wait!
description: MoveOn.org is once again throwing its well-established heft into an internal Democratic Party debate  and the effort dovetails with the organizations endorsement of Senator Barack Obama, as well.

title: Road Trip: Tommy Boy and Sour Patch Kids
description: SOMEWHERE ON 88 EAST IN UPSTATE N.Y.  If there are two fundamental elements to any college sports team road trip, they are food and movies. They are the two things that dominate conversations, drive itineraries and basically make the road trip go round. Aside from, of course, the games.

title: U.F.C.W. Backs Obama; S.E.I.U May Endorse Tonight
description: Updated | 5:44 p.m. The Service Employees International Union, widely seen as the nations most politically potent union, is likely to endorse Senate Barack Obama on Thursday evening, a top union official said.

title: Offshore Outsourcings Next Wave: How High?
description: The first wave of offshore outsourcing was in computer programming, sending software development and maintenance abroad, mainly to India. The next wave, well underway, is shipping back-office business tasks overseas, like finance, payroll, claims processing, procurement and the like. Thats business process outsourcing, or BPO, in nerd talk.

title: What I Ate Last Night Department
description: Theres a nice challenge in staring into a less than sufficiently stocked refrigerator. Last night we were down to not much more than carrots.

title: Romney Endorses McCain
description: Updated It was quite a truce. The bitterest, feuding-est duo of the 2008 Republican nomination battle were all peace, love and mutual respect Thursday afternoon when Mitt Romney threw his support behind his former adversary, Senator John McCain.

title: Mr. Cheney, the Noted Gunslinger, Goes to Court
description: The political power of the gun lobby was formidably displayed this month when a majority of the nations lawmakers  55 Senators and 250 House members  signed on to a legal brief urging the Supreme Court to strike down the District of Columbias ban on handguns.

title: Hoosiers at the Crossroads
description: With allegations of wrongdoing swirling Indiana Coach Kelvin Sampson, the Hoosiers find themselves in a place they are not used to being: in the crosshairs of the N.C.A.A.

title: Local Home Prices Head Higher, Lower
description: CNBC reports on a National Association of Realtors survey that shows strong shifts in home prices that hinge on region and metro area.

title: At Long Last: The House Stands Firm
description: Three cheers for the House of Representatives  and for the Democratic leadership.

title: Google Tests Video Ads on Search Results Pages
description: Google has always had a love-hate relationship with advertising. Its power and wealth come from the $16 billion a year of advertising that it sells. Yet on its most important pages, the results from its Web search engine, it has limited ads to nothing more garish than a dozen words of text.

title: Vibrating Food
description: So Im on the radio, ostensibly being interviewed about an article I did on the environmental costs of eating a lot of meat but a) Im being congratulated for the journey Im on, as if my final resting place is being a vegetarian, and b) the host asks me what I think about alkalarians, which I have to google (good line: is it about being from Alkalar?) and turns out to be a benign diet with a weird name and a concern about positive and negative charges, and c) a caller begins to talk about the vibrations in food.

title: Cupids Arrow Lands in Spam Filter
description: The Onion: E-dating helps women get their hopes crushed more efficiently:

title: Obama Ad Responds to Clinton Debate Attack
description: Updated Barack Obama dismissed an ad put out by Hillary Rodham Clinton that criticizes him for not agreeing to debate in Wisconsin. He says Mrs. Clinton is engaging in the same old politics of phony charges and false attacks.

title: A Face-Off Over Horse-Drawn Carriages
description: Even Cupid couldnt bring these two together.

title: Yellowstones Departed: Bison Calves Head to Slaughter, a Long-Lost Hare
description: So-called wildlife is ever less wild these days, it seems, and ever more managed, something like props on a stage. Heres a brief update on the comings and goings of some mammals in Yellowstone National Park, where a new study finds there was a mysterious vanishing long ago of the white-tailed jack rabbit, not only from the sprawling park but the greater Yellowstone ecosystem all around. Some biologists seek its reintroduction. In the meantime, the parks expanding herd of bison is finding itself in harms way once again.

title: Bible Belt N.Y.C.?
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Soft Serve |  Luggage GPS, Scarletts Album, White Castle Romance
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Clinton Wins New Mexico
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has been declared the winner of the New Mexico caucuses, nine days after the event. Mrs. Clinton edged out Barack Obama by 1,709 votes, party officials announced.

title: CNN Producer Says He Was Fired for Blogging
description: Our sister blog City Room reports:

title: Sayonara, Girlfriends
description: The long-running sitcom Girlfriends is ending its run after eight seasons on UPN and the CW.

title: The Birds, the Bees and Hardcore Business
description: Steven Hirsch, the co-chairman of Vivid Video, the pornography film studio, plans on Saturday to take Google and Yahoo to task for being purveyors of smut to minors.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Cabinets of Wonder
description: My friend was recovering from surgery. The tumor was entirely benign. The doctor says its just a dermoid cyst, she said. A what? We paused, as realization dawned. We had it: our search term. As any hypochondriac knows, a fresh new word from a doctor can set off a daylong orgy of medical Googling.

title: No-Boarding in British Columbia
description: A new sport that is like skateboarding on snow is taking root in the back country of British Columbia, Canada.

title: To Shoot Down a Satellite: Less Risk or More?
description: Last month, experts counted the reasons why a satellite plunging to Earth was nothing for people to fear, even though no one could predict where it might land.

title: Two Gatherings in Beirut
description: Robert F. Worth discusses the funeral of the Hezbollah leader Imad Mugniyah and the anniversary of the killing of  Rafik Hariri.

title: The Segregation of Kenya
description: Hundreds of thousands of Kenyans are being forced to resettle in ethnically homogeneous zones, redrawing the country's map.

title: Betting on Lundqvists Better Side
description: Goalie Henrik Lundqvist and the Rangers finalized a six-year contract extension on Thursday that will keep Lundqvist in New York and pay him $41.25 million. There were no surprises in this because both sides had committed to the principle when Lundqvist signed a one-year deal last summer, but the signing just happened to fall during the worst stretch of Lundqvists three-season career here.

title: Overselling Overmedication
description: On the bookshelf behind me at work, I have two new books on the way the pharmaceutical industry is turning us into a nation of hypochondriacal pill-popping zombies: Shyness: How Normal Behavior Became a Sickness and Our Daily Meds. On the floor, windowsill and shelves of my office at home, I have quite a few more: Generation Rx  The Last Normal Child  Toxic Psychiatry  Let Them Eat Prozac  The latest volume, front and center now on my desk, is Charles Barbers Comfortably Numb: How Psychiatry Is Medicating a Nation.

title: Clinton Strategist Tied to Nuclear Power Company
description: Earlier this month, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons chief campaign strategist, Mark Penn, circulated a memo calling attention to a New York Times article about Senator Barack Obamas dealings with Exelon Corporation, a nuclear power company.

title: Two Gatherings in Beirut
description: Robert F. Worth discusses the funeral of the Hezbollah leader Imad Mugniyah and the anniversary of the killing of  Rafik Hariri.

title: Poussin and Nature:  Arcadian Visions
description: Images from the exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: A Farewell Note From a Departing Yahoo
description: In the 18 months or so that Ive been covering Yahoo and its competitors here, Ive run into a good number of dejected, demoralized Yahoo employees. Ive also run into many who have mixed feelings  they love Yahoo, but think it was mismanaged  and many others who cant say enough good things about the place. That includes many people who chose to leave  not because of ill will toward Yahoo but because their careers took them elsewhere.

title: Road Trip: Fun N Games
description: SOMEWHERE ON I-90 OUTSIDE CHICOPEE, Mass.,  The intrepid Cornell sports information director Jeremy Hartigan came to the Big Red after working with teams at Cincinnati during the Bob Huggins era.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Definitely, Maybe'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Definitely, Maybe," a romantic comedy about a divorced man telling his daughter how he met her mother.

title: Silicon Valley Executive Sticks Up for His Hillary Video
description: Gene Wang, a Silicon Valley success story and amateur musician, wanted to make some noise for Hillary Clinton. Now hes getting an earful from the blogosphere.

title: Reader Responses to Guantanamo
description: Heres a roundup of the comments from the Thursday column. Most commentators agreed with the content of the column, but several took issue. Ray Moseley was among many who questioned Nick about his approach to the Bush administrations actions:

title: Silicon Valley Executive Sticks Up for His Hillary Video
description: Gene Wang, a Silicon Valley success story and amateur musician, wanted to make some noise for Hillary Clinton. Now hes getting an earful from the blogosphere.

title: Wooing With Charm and PACs
description: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been putting on a charm offensive of phone calls and personal visits to woo the undecideds among superdelegates, the 796 elected Democrats and party leaders whose votes may eventually determine the partys nominee.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Parents'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "The Year My Parents Went On Vacation," a film about a boy who's parents flee Brazil in the 1970s.

title: Fridays Links: Health Insurance for the Self-Employed
description: Im often asked about where independent workers and other self-employed people can get health insurance. I would like to hear from you, readers, about how you get your insurance. What kinds of policies are you choosing, and why? Where do you get it? What does it cost? If you have a resource to share, do it in the comments. If you want to write a longer note about your personal experience, e-mail me at heymarci@nytimes.com using the words health insurance in the header. I wont be able to reply directly to everyone, but I will read them all and promise to share what I learn in the column or blog.

title: A Fund-Raiser a Day to Keep Nomination in Play
description: CINCINNATI  While the campaign trail is keeping Hillary and Bill Clinton quite busy, they are also about to undertake a hectic fund-raising schedule, advisers disclosed in interviews Thursday.

title: Breaking the News to Paul ONeill About No.21
description: Paul ONeill did not sound perturbed about the Yankees taking his No. 21 out of storage and giving it to Morgan Ensberg this spring, but he did sound perplexed. The Yankees had not issued No. 21 to a player since ONeill retired in 2001.

title: Will Microsofts Executive Shuffle Scare Yahoo?
description: If there was apprehension at Yahoo already about the prospect of a takeover by Microsoft, the fear will no doubt increase as those in Sunnyvale study the details of Microsofts reorganization announced Thursday.

title: Hot Spot in Costa Rica
description: Guanacaste, the jungle-covered coastline of northwest Costa Rica, is attracting some heavy hitters. AOL founder Steve Case is developing a resort in the province, and there are projects in the works anchored by Ritz Carlton and JW Marriott hotels.

title: Silverman Sells Reveille To Shine
description: Ben Silverman, the co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, announced Thursday the sale of his independent production company Reveille to a British firm, the Shine Group, for $125 million.

title: No More Fear of Flying: The Reform of Aeroflot
description: Fly Aeroflot? Are you kidding? At least that used to be my reaction. The very name was enough to induce fear of flying. It wasnt so much for safety concerns  although that was a factor in the 1990s after a pilot allowed his children to take a spin at the controls, prompting his Airbus to crash in Siberia. Historically, the general chaos and surliness of the carrier and its staff were unsurpassed.

title: House Votes to Issue Contempt Citations
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted Thursday to issue contempt citations against the White House chief of staff and a former White House counsel for refusing to cooperate in an investigation into the mass firings of federal prosecutors.

title: Friend Is Questioned for Eight Hours in Killing of Therapist
description: Detectives investigating the killing of an Upper East Side therapist dug through her e-mail messages, telephone records and paper files, officials said Thursday, as they followed several potential paths to finding her killer. A Pennsylvania man who knew the victim  and exchanged recent e-mail messages and telephone calls with her  was interviewed by detectives for up to eight hours, officials said.

title: Westminster Pulls in Viewers
description: Uno the beagles best-in-show victory at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday night attracted an average of 3.4 million viewers on the USA channel, up 23 percent from last years broadcast. USAs Web site had a record day, with 5.5 million page views, up 63 percent from the same day last year.

title: Rangers Hope Long-Term Deal Helps Lundqvist Return to Form
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  With the signing of his new $41.25 million contract imminent Thursday morning, Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist had to endure barbs from his teammates about his usual reluctance to pick up dinner tabs and other light-spending ways.

title: House Leaves Surveillance Law to Expire
description: WASHINGTON  The House broke for a weeks recess Thursday without renewing terrorist surveillance authority demanded by President Bush, leading him to warn of risky intelligence gaps while Democrats accused him of reckless fear mongering.

title: The Red Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: As Kenyan Rivals Haggle, a Mother Mourns at 2 Graves
description: KATITO, Kenya  It did not take many people to carry the coffins of Wycliffe and Cynthia Awino.

title: Fresh Start Conservatism
description: In the 19th century, industrialization swept the world. Many European nations expanded their welfare states but kept their education systems exclusive. The U.S. tried the opposite approach. American leaders expanded education and created the highest quality work force on the planet.

title: A Crisis of Faith
description: A decade ago, during the last global financial crisis, the word on everyones lips was contagion. Troubles that began in a far-away country of which most people knew nothing (Thailand) eventually spread to much bigger countries with no obvious connection to Southeast Asia, like Russia and Brazil.

title: Biofuels and Emissions
description: To the Editor:

title: China Denies Justice Departments Accusations of Espionage
description: BEIJING  China denied Thursday that it was conducting espionage operations in the United States, rebutting accusations by the Justice Department this week that four people had passed military secrets to the Chinese government.

title: Closings for Washingtons Birthday
description: Washingtons Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: David Groh of Rhoda Dies at 68
description: David Groh, who in the 1970s sitcom Rhoda played Joe, the groom whose wedding to the title character became one of the highest-rated events of its time, died Tuesday in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 68.

title: China Rejects Darfur Criticism
description: BEIJING  China has dismissed Steven Spielbergs move to link the Olympic Games with Chinese policies in Sudan, saying Thursday that sports and politics should be kept separate.

title: Delegates of Steel
description: Washington

title: U.N. to Help Organize Iraqi Elections Set for October
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs Parliament, faced with a stalemate in appointing election commissions in the most populous provinces and accusations of overt politicization of the election process, announced Thursday that it would welcome the United Nations to play a large role in organizing the vote.

title: Ford Introduces One Small Car for a World of Markets
description: DETROIT  This time, the Ford Motor Company is keeping it simple  one car with one name for every market in the world.

title: Sometimes Those Magicians of Song Need to Show Whats Up Their Sleeves
description: Magicians are generally ill advised to reveal their tricks, but when the conductor Kent Tritle let the audience in on a few crafty secrets during a concert by the Choir of St. Ignatius Loyola on Wednesday night, the tactic paid off. The major work on the program, presented at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola as part of its Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series, was the Concerto for Choir by Alfred Schnittke. Mr. Tritle and his choir performed the piece here in 2005; this time it was being recorded for a CD.

title: Choi Takes Advantage of Early Tee Time to Aim at Flags
description: LOS ANGELES  This is a place of many languages and cultures and, during Thursdays first round of the Northern Trust Open, so was Riviera Country Club.

title: And Speaking of Broad
description: Eli Broad and the Broad Art Foundation have responded to the Guerrilla Girls, a protest group that accused them of inadequately representing female and minority artists in the inaugural exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Mr. Broads private foundation. (Reviews of the building and collection are on Page 31.) A statement issued by the foundation spokeswoman, Karen Denne, said work by women was prominently featured in the exhibition. In fact, 33 percent of the works in the exhibit are by women, the statement said. (The nearly 180 works include 49 photographs by Cindy Sherman.) The Guerrilla Girls had said that of the 30 artists in the Broad Museum show, 97 percent were white and 87 percent male. The Broad statement went on to say, Since 1995, of the 43 new artists added to the Broad Art Foundations collection 14 (33 percent) are women, and nine of those are collected in depth.

title: Wintertime, and Fishing Is Easy
description: AS the lakes of the Midwest, Northeast and Canada freeze, clusters of fishing shacks appear, forming villages above the best wintertime fishing spots  despite the cracking, moaning and eerie warbling of the thickening but unstable skin of ice.

title: Architects Plans Scrapped
description: Plans for a London building designed by the Pritzker Prize-winning, Baghdad-born architect Zaha Hadid have been dropped as a result of the credit crunch that began with the subprime mortgage collapse. The building was to have been the first permanent one in Britain by Ms. Hadid, who is known for bold, unconventional forms and was chosen last month to design the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University in East Lansing. The $10 million London structure, scheduled for completion in July 2009, was to have served as headquarters for the Architecture Foundation. The Evening Standard in London reported that senior members of the foundation said they were unable to guarantee sufficient money from donors to cover the costs because of economic nervousness and a stock market slump. Ms. Hadid called the decision disappointing.

title: High School High Jinks and the Depths of Dread
description: Choreography by committee seldom works, and it did not in The Other Side, an American premiere presented by Jonathan Hollanders Battery Dance Company on Wednesday afternoon at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. The three choreographers  Mr. Hollander, Thaddeus Davis and Daniel Cardoso  merged their work rather than adopting the more usual tactic of creating separate sections. The results were a mess.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the sentencing of Army Sgt. Evan Vela to 10 years in prison for killing an unarmed Iraqi detainee described his relationship to the Army Rangers imprecisely. While he graduated from Ranger school and earned the qualifications to serve with the Rangers, he was not assigned to a Ranger battalion at the time of the incident or sentencing and therefore was not considered an Army Ranger.

title: Scientists Call for Space Exploration
description: The next president of the United States should give NASA an additional $3 billion each year, both to get to Mars and to focus attention on science issues in space and on Earth, a group of scientists, industry figures and former astronauts said on Thursday.

title: Pettitte Is Now Working on His Damage Control
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte had one pinstriped uniform, several blue shirts, a few Yankees caps and a toiletry bag in his locker here Thursday. Everything seemed to be in place for him to report with the Yankees other pitchers and catchers and be ready for the opening workout Friday. But Pettittes chair remained empty.

title: Gunman Was Once Revered on Campus
description: A day after a lecture hall was attacked at Northern Illinois University, the gunman emerged in two portraits not easily reconciled.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Justice Will Be Served Only if Clemens Isnt Given a Pass
description: I listened to every second of Wednesdays four-hour hearing, looking for hints to bolster my suspicion that the American people were being set up for an intentional walk for Roger Clemens. There were code phrases, like Were not here to convict or Lets move on and, of course, Lets get back to baseball.

title: FEMAs Formaldehyde Foul-Up
description: Just when you thought the federal government could not possibly outdo its incredible record of ineptitude in the handling of the victims of Hurricane Katrina, it contrives, against all odds, to make yet another colossal mistake. The latest blunder involves the torpid response to the threat of formaldehyde contamination in trailers supplied to hundreds of thousands of New Orleans residents made homeless by the storm.

title: A Couple of Country Singers Stop to Strut a City Stage
description: The tour is called Love, Pain & the Whole Crazy Carnival Ride, which doesnt sound promising. Somehow, the organizers have turned two infelicitous album titles  Keith Urbans Love, Pain & the Whole Crazy Thing and Carrie Underwoods Carnival Ride  into one singularly unpleasant phrase, which is odd, especially when they could have called this tour Keith & Carrie! Live! Seriously! What else do you need to know?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend last Friday about Jasper Johns: Gray, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, referred incorrectly to the orange, green and purple in the painting Cline. They are secondary colors (made by mixing primary colors), not tertiaries (made by mixing secondary colors).

title: F.D.A. Broke Its Rules by Not Inspecting Chinese Plant With Problem Drug
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The Food and Drug Administration violated its own policies when it approved for sale a crucial blood-thinning drug without first inspecting a Chinese plant which, along with a plant in Wisconsin, made the drugs active pharmaceutical ingredient.

title: Tale of the Tapes Continues With New Evidence
description: A day after meeting with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell to discuss the videotaping controversy that has entangled the league, Senator Arlen Specter said that he was more determined to continue probing.

title: Deutsche Post Chief Under Tax Inquiry
description: BERLIN  German prosecutors accused one of the countrys most prominent business executives of tax evasion on Thursday after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.

title: British Ruling for Former 9/11 Suspect
description: LONDON  A British appeals court said Thursday that a pilot the American authorities had suspected of training some of the hijackers in the 9/11 terrorist attacks had been completely exonerated. The pilot, who had been held by the British for nearly five months, can seek compensation from the British government for wrongful arrest and detention, the court said.

title: Some Cities Are Spared the Slide in Housing
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The real estate market these days is a tale of two Americas, and one of them is not doing too badly.

title: Gunman Slays 6 at N. Illinois University
description: DeKALB, Ill.  With minutes left in a class in ocean sciences at Northern Illinois University on Thursday afternoon, a tall skinny man dressed all in black stepped out from behind a curtain on the stage of the lecture hall, said nothing, and opened fire with a shotgun, the authorities and witnesses said.

title: Microsoft Reassigns Several Top Executives
description: Microsoft announced a sweeping shake-up of its executive ranks Thursday, placing new executives over operations facing fierce new competition from Google, Apple and cellphone makers.

title: A Leap Forward, but Hurdles Remain in Narcolepsy
description: Scientists have begun to pull back the veil of mystery that has surrounded narcolepsy since it was first described more than 125 years ago. In 2000, investigators reported that a lack of a neurochemical called hypocretin is a prime culprit in the sleep disorder. Patients with classic narcolepsy  a combination of irresistible sleepiness and sudden collapses from muscle weakness  are missing most of the brain cells that make the wakefulness-promoting protein.

title: Court Rules Waiters Are Entitled to Fees Disguised as Tips
description: In a major victory for the states restaurant employees, New Yorks highest court ruled on Thursday that restaurants must pay their wait staff any mandatory service fees that customers are led to believe are substitutes for tips.

title: New Therapies Aim at Lung Tumors, Case by Case
description: The numbers are terrifying: lung cancer kills more people in the United States and across the world than any other cancer. Fewer than half of newly diagnosed lung cancer patients live beyond a year. And only 16 percent survive for five years, only a few percentage points higher than when President Richard Nixon declared a war on cancer back in 1971.

title: Earthquake Shakes Southern Greece
description: ATHENS  A powerful earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale shook southern Greece on Thursday, sending panic-stricken residents into the streets but causing no major damage or casualties.

title: Torre Is Looking Good in a New Shade of Blue
description: Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about cellphone trends misstated the title of Daniel Moloney of Motorola, who commented on competition in the industry. He is president of the companys home and networks mobility business, not its cellphone business.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the sentencing of Army Sgt. Evan Vela to 10 years in prison for killing an unarmed Iraqi detainee described his relationship to the Army Rangers imprecisely. While he graduated from Ranger school and earned the qualifications to serve with the Rangers, he was not assigned to a Ranger battalion at the time of the incident or sentencing and therefore was not considered an Army Ranger. (Go to Article)

title: President Putin Talks of the Future as Premier
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin, in the final weeks of an eight-year administration that secured his place as the countrys most popular politician, said Thursday that he intended to wield substantial and long-running power in the Kremlin after leaving office next month and becoming Russias prime minister.

title: Selected Studies: Lung Cancer
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information about these and other trials: ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Hezbollah Threatens Attacks on Israeli Targets
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Accusing Israel of killing one of his top commanders, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, threatened Thursday to intensify his groups conflict with Israel and to retaliate against Israeli targets anywhere in the world.

title: Israel Heightens Its Security After a Threat of Revenge
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli militarys chief of staff ordered land, air and naval forces on alert to ensure the defense of the northern border and of other Israeli interests, an army statement said Thursday, after the Hezbollah leader threatened to avenge the death of a senior military commander, Imad Mugniyah.

title: Mistaken Iraq Battle Kills 6 Fighters Allied With U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  Six members of an Awakening Council, groups composed mostly of Sunni Muslims who have turned against the insurgency, were killed early Thursday after they mistakenly fired on American soldiers in the north, the Iraqi police said.

title: Earnhardt Sets the Tone in a Qualifier
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Dale Earnhardt Jr.s victory Thursday in the first Gatorade 150 qualifying race at Daytona International Speedway established him as the leading contender going into Nascars biggest event of the year, the Daytona 500.

title: A Co-op for $14,000? Its No Fiction
description: Like so many other single New Yorkers who stubbornly persist in pursuing fulfilling but decidedly nonlucrative careers, Matthew Thomas, a 32-year-old aspiring novelist, endured a housing history defined by transience and tests of endurance.

title: 2 Ports of Stability in Floridas Market
description: Its not Yahoo, but it is G.E., said Mike McMurray, an agent with VIP Realty in Sanibel, about the investment potential for property on Sanibel and Captiva Islands in Southwest Florida. Even with general downturns in real estate, this market tends to be relatively stable, he said.

title: Rounding Up the Usual Suspects
description: LOS ANGELES  The inaugural exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Arts spanking new Broad Contemporary Art Museum has no title, because it isnt really an exhibition.

title: Attacks on the Homeless Rise, With Youths Mostly to Blame
description: CROSS CITY, Fla.  Warren Messner was 15 when he and some friends attacked a homeless man and left him for dead. Mr. Messner jumped on a log laid across the mans ribs. He does not know why. He was high, does not remember much and wants to forget the rest.

title: Hezbollah Leader Issues Threat to Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollahs leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, told 10,000 mourners on Thursday at the funeral of a senior commander killed in Syria that Hezbollah was ready to retaliate anywhere against Israel, which it blames for the death.

title: Giants in Training for Life A.B.: After Bonds
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Matt Cain is a main cog in the San Francisco Giants starting rotation, but last year he was merely another setup man for the season-long spectacle that was the Barry Bonds Show.

title: Missing Basquiat Painting Found
description: An $8 million Jean-Michel Basquiat painting whose last known owner was a bankrupt Brazilian banker has been found in a Manhattan warehouse, The Associated Press reported. Federal prosecutors filed papers seeking to seize the 1982 work, Hannibal, which was valued at $100 on a customs declaration form when it arrived by courier from London at Kennedy Airport after apparently being smuggled out of Brazil. Prosecutors are seeking to help Brazilian authorities claim the painting, whose last known owner was Edemar Cid Ferreira, former owner of Banco Santos and one of Brazils foremost art collectors. The bank went bankrupt in 2005, leaving debts of more than $1 billion. Mr. Ferreira was convicted of money laundering and bank fraud, and sentenced to 21 years in prison; a Brazilian court ordered seizure of $20 million to $30 million worth of his art, saying it was bought with proceeds of illegal schemes, but Hannibal was missing.

title: Islam Critic Seeks European Union Protection
description: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, the former Dutch lawmaker who began receiving death threats in 2004, when she criticized political Islam, and later left for the United States, asked the European Union to pay for her round-the-clock protection while in the United States, saying that Europe had a responsibility to defend freedom of expression. Last year, the Dutch government said it would no longer pay for bodyguards while she is abroad.

title: Hundreds Mourn at Burial of East Timor Rebel
description: DILI, East Timor  The body of the slain army mutineer who led attacks on the president and prime minister of East Timor was buried in the garden of his home here Thursday in a peaceful ceremony witnessed by hundreds of mourners.

title: Zimbabwe: Inflation Surges to Official 66,000%
description: In November, the official rate of inflation, far and away the worlds highest, was 26,740.8 percent, so bad that a decent days pay was nearly worthless by the time a worker arrived home in the evening. But the December rate, announced Thursday by the Central Statistics Office, made that seem like the good old days. That rate was 66,212.3 percent.

title: McCain and Obama Skirmish on Financing
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCains presidential campaign said Thursday that it stood by a year-old pledge made with Senator Barack Obama that each would accept public financing for the general election if the nominee of the opposing party did the same. But Mr. Obamas campaign refused to reaffirm its earlier commitment.

title: Idol Marches On
description: Drawing an average of 24.6 million viewers, American Idol on Fox dominated Wednesday nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates, as Idol narrowed its remaining contestants to 24 semifinalists. Fox easily led the night over all, winning the 9 p.m. time slot after Idol with its new game show The Moment of Truth (14.5 million). NBC ranked a distant second, faring best at 8 with Deal or No Deal (11 million) and at 10 with Law & Order (10.2 million). ABC finished third among adults 18 to 49, thanks to a strong showing for that demographic from Supernanny at 9 (8.8 million). CBS, in fourth place among the 18-to-49 set, edged past ABC in total viewers with repeats. At 8, however, Big Brother on CBS attracted a disappointing 5.8 million viewers.

title: Classical Visions, Romantic Eye
description: If a painter can be judged by the love he inspires, Nicolas Poussin (1594-1665) was one of art historys favorite valentines. Corot, Delacroix, Constable and Czanne all adored him. So did Picasso and Matisse. Nor were artists his only fans. The 19th-century English critic William Hazlitt surpassed himself in his praise of Poussin and may well have introduced his work to an already deeply Poussinian John Keats.

title: Bush Appeals to Justices on Detainees Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to review an appeals court decision that it said had created a serious threat to national security by requiring the government to supply extensive evidence supporting the classification of more than 180 Guantnamo detainees as enemy combatants.

title: Something Wicked This Way Comes
description: His thoughts stalk him like snipers in the shadows, and when they attack, its with a violence that leaves him shorn of defenses. Bloodthirsty enemies on the battlefield, double-dealing politicians of the court and would-be assassins at home: the Macbeth embodied with such fearsome insight and theatrical fire by Patrick Stewart has the wiles and the nerve to conquer such adversaries. What he doesnt stand a chance against is his own mercurial mind.

title: Federal Housing Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: FEMA Vows New Effort on Trailers Posing Risk
description: The federal government pledged Thursday to intensify its efforts to move Gulf Coast hurricane victims out of trailers and into apartments or hotels after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention finally confirmed that many trailers were contaminated with high levels of formaldehyde.

title: New Top Editor for Los Angeles Times, the 4th in 3 Years
description: The Los Angeles Times named a new top editor on Thursday, Russ Stanton, three weeks after the previous editor, James E. OShea, was forced out for resisting another in a series of staff cuts.

title: Black Leader, a Clinton Ally, Tilts to Obama
description: MILWAUKEE  Representative John Lewis, an elder statesman from the civil rights era and one of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons most prominent black supporters, said Thursday night that he planned to cast his vote as a superdelegate for Senator Barack Obama in hopes of preventing a fight at the Democratic convention.

title: Tax Break Helps a Crusader for Deficit Discipline
description: Where is it ordained that private equity pays only a 15 percent tax?

title: 4 News Companies Ally to Sell Ads on the Internet
description: Four large newspaper companies are joining forces to sell advertisements on the Internet, hoping that the combined heft of their Web sites will encourage large advertisers to spend more money.

title: Philippines on Alert After Plot
description: MANILA  The Philippine authorities went on high alert Thursday after the discovery of what officials said was a plot to assassinate President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

title: Were Spending Too Much to Make a Little Money
description: Not a chance, my neighborhood news dealer said. Hes a friendly fellow. But no way was he about to count the 75 pennies put forth as payment for two newspapers. The woman at the bakery was absolute about not accepting 215 pennies for a danish.

title: Sisterhood Is Complicated
description: Beth Henleys comedy Crimes of the Heart has proved to be a durable showcase for actresses in the two decades and more since it won the Pulitzer Prize. A little bit Chekhov and a little bit Eudora Welty, it tells a twangy story of three Southern sisters loving, feuding and fussing through a very bad day.

title: For No-Boarders in British Columbia, Its No Bindings, No Problem
description: THREE miles into the Kootenay Range backcountry by snowmobile, I stood alongside 50 other riders, gathered at the bottom of a wide and untracked sub-alpine run. The mid-January snowpack was so deep in the Interior Mountains of British Columbia that the effects of logging were buried beneath 180 inches of powder  the downed trees, stumps and rocks all transformed by the bounty of snow into a snowboarders paradise.

title: Theater Listings
description: GAUGUIN/SAVAGE LIGHT Occasionally a musical will find new life through replacement casting. George Fischoff has taken things a step further with his pocket musical Gauguin/Savage Light: he has eliminated the cast entirely.

title: A. D. Lewis, Administrator Behind Conrail, Is Dead at 89
description: Arthur D. Lewis, a transportation executive whose long career spanned airplanes, buses, and, most significantly, the formation of Conrail, which consolidated many of the countrys surviving freight lines, died on Jan. 12. He was 89.

title: Romney Backs McCains Candidacy, Ending a Heated Campaign Feud
description: One of the bitterest feuds of the 2008 presidential race ended Thursday when Mitt Romney threw his support  and vowed to try to throw his delegates  behind his former archrival for the Republican nomination, Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Striking When the Spirit Was Hot
description: WACK!: Art and the Feminist Revolution is a big, messy, fascinating scrapbook of a show. It doesnt instruct or admonish us about gender and politics; rather, it haphazardly tells a story about freedom and possibility. The quality is uneven, but the overall effect is exciting. It takes you back to a heady time when female artists were throwing out old, patriarchal rules and reinventing art in all kinds of idiosyncratic and sometimes dangerously extreme terms.

title: Lung Cancer, an Equal Opportunity Killer
description: Dr. Joan Schiller is deputy director of the Harold C. Simmons Comprehensive Cancer Center at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center. She is president of the National Lung Cancer Partnership, a nonprofit educational and advocacy group that focuses on women.

title: What to Ask About Lung Cancer
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: All Nothing, All the Time
description: IF youre wearing a cast right now, this advice comes too late, but file it away for next winter: Theres nothing wrong with doing nothing. And theres a bed-and-breakfast out there, framed in snow but with plush rooms and welcoming fires inside, that is made for helping you remember how.

title: Top Officials See Bleaker Outlook for the Economy
description: WASHINGTON  With the credit markets once again deteriorating, the nations two top economic policy makers acknowledged Thursday that the outlook for the economy had worsened, as both came under criticism for being overtaken by events and failing to act boldly enough.

title: Pressing Beijing on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Expects 15,000 to 20,000 G.M. Workers to Take Buyouts
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  The head of the United Automobile Workers union said on Thursday that he expected 15,000 to 20,000 workers to leave General Motors during a new round of buyouts, and that G.M. would replace nearly all of them with lower-paid employees.

title: New Works That Employ or Disregard Electronics
description: Bang on a Cans Peoples Commissioning Fund is a lovely idea. Concertgoers contribute whatever they can afford, and Bang on a Can, the new-music organization, commissions a few new works, usually from young composers. The scores are played by the Bang on a Can All-Stars at an annual concert and recorded for broadcast on WNYC-FM.

title: William D. Modell, Seller of Sporting Goods, Is Dead at 86
description: William D. Modell, who as chairman of the Modells Sporting Goods chain oversaw its expansion throughout much of the Northeast, died Thursday in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Hewlett Harbor, N.Y.

title: Judge Says Use of MySpace May Violate a Court Order
description: In one of the first rulings of its kind, a Staten Island judge has said that a teenage girl could be charged with violating a restraining order by using MySpace.com to reach out to people she was told not to contact.

title: Star Pitcher Says Mets Have Room for Another
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The doors swung open and out sauntered Pedro Martnez. His entourage  trainers, coaches, club officials, photographers, video cameramen  filed in stage left as he shook hands, waved, hugged and shimmied toward his red carpet, the lush green grass of Field No. 4.

title: Where the Real Action Is
description: Not so long ago, the documentary feature category was among the snooziest at the Oscars, the target of jokes that said you couldnt lose by making a film about the Holocaust. That backward-looking pattern began to morph when Michael Moore won the 2002 award with Bowling for Columbine, and exploded with last years win for Al Gores one-man show, An Inconvenient Truth. Odd though it sounds, Michael Moore and Al Gore have made the image of documentaries  O.K., maybe not sexy, but hot.

title: Profiles of the Victims
description: The following six died as a result of the shooting at Northern Illinois University, as identified by the DeKalb County Coroner and the university:

title: What to Ask About Narcolepsy
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Millionaires Are a Dime a Dozen
description: In the planned community of Ladera Ranch, Calif., there are signs asking dog owners to clean up after their pets. It also provides mutt mitts for this purpose. And in case civic duty doesnt do the trick, Ladera contracts with a company called EntreManure just to come in and pick up the poop. According to the authors of a woefully ill-timed book about runaway American prosperity, delegating this type of job is a triumph of middle-class millionaire spirit.

title: Love, Sex, Belly Dancing and Religious Differences
description: The star-crossed romance David & Layla tells of a beautiful young Iraqi Kurd named Layla (Shiva Rose) who is threatened with deportation from her adopted home, Brooklyn, and pins her hopes of staying on a suitor named David (David Moscow), an American-born agnostic Jew who has a public-access cable show about sex and is trapped in an unsatisfying relationship with a snooty fiance (Callie Thorne of the television series Rescue Me).

title: Heliport Owner Would Move Landing Pads Into Hudson
description: The operator of the heliport in Hudson River Park, spurred by a lawsuit brought by park advocates, has proposed moving its operation out of the park and about 100 feet into the river.

title: In Guilty Plea, Actresss Killer Changes Story to Robbery
description: His original confession had the ring of truth: He was an illegal immigrant working on a renovation job in a Greenwich Village building when the imperious woman upstairs confronted him over construction noise.

title: Waxman Regrets Hearing Was Held
description: WASHINGTON  A day after a dramatic, nationally televised hearing that pitted Roger Clemens against his former personal trainer and Democrats against Republicans, the chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform said Thursday that he regretted holding the hearing in the first place.

title: A Little Bit of Country, a Little Bit of Dark Despair
description: What can a Broadway country gospel singer bring to the lyrics of Billy Strayhorn, Stephen Sondheim and Lorenz Hart? Those are three of the super-urbane songwriters covered by Lari White in her new show, Love Letters, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: Georgia Exile Autopsied
description: LONDON  Initial inquiries and an autopsy gave no indication of foul play in the unexpected death of the exiled Georgian tycoon and opposition politician Badri Patarkatsishvili, the Surrey police said Thursday.

title: Major Immigrant Smuggling Ring Is Broken in Phoenix, Police Say
description: PHOENIX  In a case highlighting this citys prominent role in the smuggling of illegal immigrants across the border, the authorities conducted a series of raids on Thursday, arresting what they said were the leaders of a ring that helped transport hundreds of people to way stations in Phoenix.

title: Turmoil in Africa Alters Focus of Bushs 5-Nation Tour
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a planned trip to Africa, President Bush thrust himself into the role of peacemaker on Thursday, as his plans to promote American efforts against poverty and disease gave way to a more pressing imperative: addressing the violence and turmoil on the continent.

title: Signs in Kenya of a Land Redrawn by Ethnicity
description: OTHAYA, Kenya  Sarah Wangoi has spent her entire life  all 70 years of it  in the Rift Valley. But last month, she was chased off her farm by a mob that called her a foreigner. She now sleeps on the cold floor of a strangers house, seeking refuge in an area of Kenya where her ethnic group, the Kikuyu, is strong. It is, supposedly, her homeland.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Feb. 6 about Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, who introduced transcendental meditation to the West and gained fame as the spiritual guru to the Beatles, described incorrectly those who may bear the title of Maharishi, Hindi for great seer, and misstated his own eligibility for it. The title may be bestowed on people of any caste, not only Brahmins. He was not ineligible because he was from a lower caste.

title: In Utah, the Fast Way to Town
description: J. T. ROBINSON parked his Subaru station wagon on 27th Street in Ogden, Utah, a residential road that dead-ends before a wall of mountains to the east. He shouldered his skis and pointed to a peak above town. That used to be my route home, he said, hand stretched toward a craggy pyramid that cut the sky.

title: The Ritz-Carlton, Dove Mountain and Nizuc Resort & Residences
description: The Ritz-Carlton, Dove Mountain

title: Show Us the Money
description: As the presidential campaign narrows and its costs skyrocket, detailed disclosure of financial resources becomes ever more important. Of the leading contenders, so far, only Senator Barack Obama has released his full income-tax returns  a level of disclosure once routine for candidates after the political corruption of Watergate.

title: U.S. to Produce Data on Irans Nuclear Program
description: The Bush administration has agreed to turn over to international inspectors intelligence data it has collected that it says proves Iran worked on developing a nuclear weapon until a little more than four years ago, according to American and foreign diplomats.

title: Ex-State Senator Is Charged With Extortion
description: NEWARK  A former New Jersey legislator was indicted on extortion charges in federal court Thursday, accused of using his position on the State Senate Budget Committee to steer millions of tax dollars to a hospital in exchange for more than $100,000 in consulting fees, prosecutors said.

title: Lawyer Says McNamee Lied in a Recording
description: The day before the Mitchell report was released, Brian McNamee lied to investigators for Roger Clemens when he told them that federal authorities had additional evidence about Clemenss use of performance-enhancing drugs. McNamees lawyer said Thursday that McNamee made up the story in order to explain his own discussions with the authorities.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: A Brazilian Boy, Alone in the Tumult of 1970
description: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation takes place in Brazil in 1970, when the country was ruled by a military dictatorship and its national soccer team, led by Pel, was making its way toward the finals of the World Cup. Accordingly, sports and politics both play parts in this film, directed by Cao Hamburger, which filters the tumult and trauma of Brazilian history through the perceptions of a 12-year-old boy named Mauro.

title: The Times to Cut 100 News Jobs
description: After years of resisting the newsroom cuts that have hit most of the industry, The New York Times will bow to growing financial strain and eliminate about 100 newsroom jobs this year, the executive editor said Thursday.

title: Give This Man a Pencil
description: THE identity of the littlest conference room inside the headquarters of the Writers Guild of America East is situation-dependent: sometimes it functions as a law library, sometimes as the caucus room for mini-negotiations deemed too private to conduct in full conference mode. Writers are secretive: Think soap opera scribes.

title: Warring on McCain, Limbaugh Sees No Reconciliation
description: Rush Limbaugh took his show on the road this week, forsaking his main broadcast studio in Palm Beach, Fla., for one in Midtown Manhattan. But the change of scenery did nothing to dampen the Republican-on-Republican smackdown he has been waging from afar against Senator John McCain, the partys likely presidential nominee, whom Mr. Limbaugh considers too moderate.

title: Entertainers Rally for Singer Opposed to Venezuelas President
description: More than 80 entertainers, including Shakira, Jennifer Lopez, Marc Anthony, Ricky Martin and Penelope Cruz have signed a statement supporting the Grammy Award-winning Spanish singer Alejandro Sanz, below, after two of his concerts in Caracas were canceled because he criticized the president of Venezuela, Hugo Chvez, The Associated Press reported. The signatories said they believe in a Latin America where we are all free to express our views. Last week Venezuelan organizers announced that Mr. Sanzs sold-out Feb. 14 concert would be canceled because it lacked the appropriate conditions. Another concert was canceled when officials withdrew permission to use a government auditorium. Mr. Sanzs criticisms of Mr. Chvez have prompted Venezuelan officials to declare that he is not welcome in the country. On Sunday Mr. Sanz ended a concert in the Dominican Republic by dedicating a song to his Venezuelan fans, a bunch of people in a country where I cannot go.

title: UBS Posts Huge Loss and Warns About 2008
description: PARIS  UBS offered no hope Thursday for a near-term turnaround as it posted an $11.3 billion fourth-quarter loss and warned that 2008 would be a difficult year.

title: Municipalities Feel Pinch as Another Debt Market Falters
description: The credit crisis paining Wall Street is reaching out across the nation, afflicting municipalities, hospitals and cultural touchstones like the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: A Mountain Town Where Mineral Waters Flow
description: WHEN Zoe Burger first started spending weekends in Berkeley Springs, she was curious about the legendary healing powers of the warm mineral waters the region is named for. So she headed to Berkeley Springs State Park in the center of town, where public bathhouses offer a good soak for $20.

title: Angels in the Infield at Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  On Sunday, the Rev. Ronnie Barton found himself comparing the trials of the Christian life to the challenges confronting Nascar race teams.

title: Footnotes
description: The Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford has a new director. She is Susan Lubowsky Talbott, the director of Smithsonian Arts at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. She will assume her new post on April 15. She succeeds Willard Holmes, who announced in February 2007 that he was stepping down. ...Patrick Stewart, currently starring in Macbeth at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is to receive this years Gielgud Award for Excellence in the Dramatic Arts. He will be honored on March 10, when the Shakespeare Guild joins the English-Speaking Union of New York and the National Arts Club in a gala at the club, 15 Gramercy Park South. ... Paramount Pictures is delaying the release of Star Trek to May 8, 2009, from Dec. 25, 2008, Variety reported. The studio said the films potential is greater as a summer season attraction. ...Tovah Feldshuh, who starred on Broadway in Goldas Balcony, will make her debut at Feinsteins at Loews Regency from March 4 to 15 with Tovah in a Nutshell! singing songs from Gershwin to Judy Collins and inhabiting a variety of characters.

title: Arroyo Plot Reported
description: MANILA  The Philippine authorities went on high alert on Thursday after the discovery of what officials said was a plot to assassinate President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

title: The Wake-Up Flight of a Wayward B-52
description: A B-52 bomber took off from an Air Force base in North Dakota in August and  in a startling mistake attributed to post-cold war operational complacency  carried six nuclear-tipped cruise missiles on a 1,400-mile flight to a base in Louisiana. The missile tips should have been dummies, but somehow actual nuclear warheads were loaded for the cross-country trip. No one knew where they were, or even missed them, for over 36 hours, said Senator Carl Levin in a hearing this week into preventing such a dangerous mix-up from ever happening again.

title: Off the Set, Into the Desert
description: This is the story of a couple who moved to California from the East Coast and then, one day, built a home in the desert, said Tracy Tynan. Her voice slipped playfully into the earnest, dulcet tones of a museum docent, as if Jacqueline Kennedys tour of the White House were being played as screwball comedy.

title: The Knicks Foundation Is Really a Pile of Sand
description: In the Knicks renaissance that took shape in Isiah Thomass head, Eddy Curry and Zach Randolph were twin bulldozers, brutishly blazing a path to better days. Overmatched opponents trembled. Rival coaches wailed. Thomas beamed with pride. It was a nice fantasy.

title: Lowry Extends Tenure at MoMA
description: LOWRY EXTENDS

title: Smaller Version of the Solar System Is Discovered
description: Astronomers said Wednesday that they had found a miniature version of our own solar system 5,000 light-years across the galaxy  the first planetary system that really looks like our own, with outer giant planets and room for smaller inner planets.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about a lawsuit filed against New Line Cinema by heirs of the author of the Lord of the Rings trilogy misspelled the authors surname in some editions. He was J. R. R. Tolkien, not Tolkein.

title: British Judge Questions Halt to Arms Fraud Inquiry
description: LONDON  A British High Court judge raised new questions Thursday about why the government ordered the Serious Fraud Office to stop investigating claims of corruption related to a 1990s arms deal with Saudi Arabia that was brokered by BAE Systems, the biggest British weapons maker.

title: Large Union Backs Obama; Another Is Likely to Do Same
description: Giving Senator Barack Obama new momentum, one of the nations largest labor unions, the United Food and Commercial Workers, endorsed him on Thursday. Another giant, the Service Employees International Union, was on the brink of backing him.

title: Remembering a Woman of Very Original Tastes
description: Remembering a Woman

title: Marketers Are Putting Nascar on Different Kinds of Circuits
description: GENTLEMEN, start your modems.

title: Profit at Daimler After Chrysler Sale
description: Daimler, the German maker of luxury vehicles, reported a fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, helped by the sale of its Chrysler division in the United States and job cuts at Mercedes-Benz Cars.

title: Spitzer Utilities Nominee Started Job While Still an Industry Lobbyist, Report Finds
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers nomination early last year of a top energy industry lobbyist as chairwoman of the Public Service Commission created a number of ethical problems, the state inspector general, Kristine Hamann, said in a long-awaited report on Thursday.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: In Remote Valley, a Grim Redefinition of Fishing
description: RIO GRANDE VALLEY, Jamaica  Catching freshwater shrimp in the legendary Rio Grande here in the forested hills of eastern Jamaica used to be done at night with a homemade bamboo torch in one hand and a sharp spear in the other.

title: When Strains on Military Families Turn Deadly
description: A few months after Sgt. William Edwards and his wife, Sgt. Erin Edwards, returned to a Texas Army base from separate missions in Iraq, he assaulted her mercilessly. He struck her, choked her, dragged her over a fence and slammed her into the sidewalk.

title: State to Preserve Heart of Adirondacks
description: State environmental officials agreed on Thursday to preserve a vast swath of wild acreage in the northern part of Adirondack Park, using a combination of outright purchase and conservation easements meant to protect both wilderness and jobs.

title: Man Fatally Stabbed With Corkscrew
description: The body of a Brooklyn man who had been stabbed in the side of the head with a corkscrew was discovered by relatives in his Prospect Heights apartment on Wednesday, the police said on Thursday.

title: Art Museum Mixes Pomp and Hint of Pop
description: LOS ANGELES  This city is growing up, and I count myself among those who see that as a mixed blessing. Over the last decade or so it has embarked on its most ambitious cultural building boom in a generation, adding a new dimension to a city whose notable civic monuments have famously been its freeways. But with exceptions like Frank Gehrys Walt Disney Concert Hall, these projects have often failed to live up to Los Angeless great tradition of architectural experimentation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A film column on Thursday about the Film Comment Selects series, at the Walter Reade Theater, misstated the given name of the director whose films 10 Rillington Place and Mandingo will be shown. He was Richard Fleischer, not Robert.

title: An Unfamiliar Take on Familiar Literary Figures
description: Dont think of The Jazz Age as yet another go-round with sloshy Scott, zany Zelda and earthy Ernie, three of the last centurys most overexposed literary figures. Think of it as a chance to see three skilled actors demonstrate that even the familiar can be made very watchable.

title: Company Behind Many TV Hits Is Sold
description: Ben Silverman, the co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, announced Thursday the sale of his independent production company Reveille to a British firm, the Shine Group, for $125 million.

title: Deer Hunt Goes Ahead After Years of Protest
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  The hunters gathered on Thursday at the glow of dawn on the icy slopes of South Mountain Reservation in Essex County. By sunrise, the thermometer had risen to 27 degrees and they were 30 feet up in tree stands, camouflaged and waiting.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about voters in Virginia in the lead-up to the Democratic primary that day misstated the distance between Lexington and Roanoke, two cities in the state where Senator Barack Obama was receiving strong support from young people. They are about 45 miles apart, not 100.

title: Ex-Congressman Agrees a Road Should Not Bear His Name
description: TRENTON  When Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a bill last month that officially changed the name Route 23 to the Robert A. Roe Memorial Highway, in honor of a former congressman who had represented North Jersey for more than two decades, it was the legislative equivalent of getting a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

title: Imprisoned Rappers Father Elected in Belize
description: Jamal (Shyne) Barrow, the young rapper and Sean Combs protg serving a 10-year sentence in New York State for a 1999 nightclub shooting that injured three people, has a friend in high places, highbridnation.com reported. Last weekend the Central American country Belize elected its first black prime minister. He is Dean Barrow, the father of Jamal, who could be released this year.

title: Trade Deficit Shrank by 6.2% Last Year
description: The United States trade deficit shrank in 2007 for the first time in five years, the government said on Thursday. But while the numbers reflected strength in exports, they also indicated that American consumers had cut back on their spending as the economy flagged.

title: Art in Review
description: ARS FENNICA

title: Filmmakers Who Become Their Own Zombie Movie
description: In George A. Romeros Diary of the Dead, the loosest, goosiest chapter in the filmmakers continuing zombieland epic, we meet the enemy and he is us, with video cameras. Set in Mr. Romeros usual Pennsylvania stomping and chomping grounds (a k a Canada), the story pivots on a clutch of University of Pittsburgh students who, in the process of fleeing legions of the undead  despite their obvious handicap, zombies always find fresh meat  have taken up cameras, thus becoming the producers of their own snuff biopic.

title: Lottery Numbers
Exploring Influences and Finding Inspirations
description: When the violinist Midori and the pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin performed Ravels Sonata for Violin and Piano on Wednesday evening at the Rose Theater, notes and phrases were as carefully placed as stones in a Japanese garden. But the details blended into a seamlessly organic whole, flowing from a languid, delicate Allegretto into Midoris sultry, smoky rhapsodizing in the jazz-influenced second movement, then into the frenzy of the concluding Perpetuum mobile.

title: A Window Into China
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Woman Runs for President
description: To the Editor:

title: Bleak New Batch of Data on Economy
description: A fresh batch of data on Friday presented a bleak picture of the economy, with rising prices of imported goods, struggling manufacturing and an erosion in consumer confidence.

title: Frank Piasecki, a Pioneer in Helicopters, Is Dead at 88
description: Frank Piasecki, an inventor of one of the first helicopters and the first to develop a tandem-rotor helicopter  the so-called Flying Banana  capable of carrying large cargo loads or troops into combat, died Monday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 88.

title: Clemens on the Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Service With a Caveat
description: WHATS the worst that can happen with a cleaning person or some other service at your second home? They dont show up? They dont do good work? Theft?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about efforts by the operators of E-ZPass in New York to track down highway toll evaders referred incorrectly at several points to the technology used to identify and match E-ZPass tags as a car passes through a lane. The tags are identified via radio frequencies, not optical scans.

title: A Crime-Fighting Opportunity
description: In October, California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a smart new law that will help police apprehend violent criminals and deter the gun traffickers who supply them. The measure requires that all new semiautomatic pistols sold in the state starting in 2010 be equipped with technology known as microstamping, which will allow police to quickly match empty bullet casings to the weapon that fired them.

title: Boeing-Boeing Is Inbound
description: After a few months of circling Broadway, Boeing-Boeing, a revival of the 1960s farce by Mark Camoletti about an architect frantically trying to maintain relationships with three stewardesses, will touch down at the Longacre Theater. Christine Baranski, Mark Rylance and Bradley Whitford are to star in the play, currently a hit in London. Matthew Warchus (Art) will direct. Previews begin on April 19, with an opening set for May 4. The stewardesses have not yet been cast.

title: When the Borders Between Sleep and Wakefulness Blur
description: Dr. Emmanuel Mignot is director of the Stanford Center for Narcolepsy. Trained in psychiatry and pharmacology, he has studied narcolepsy for more than 20 years and treats patients one day a month in the clinic.

title: A Cuban-Americans Wish to Find Her Ancestral Home
description: At an anti-Castro protest in Miami, the playwright Carmen Pelezs alter ego, Camila, visits her grandmother and hears again about the familys flight from Havana decades before. You are not free, because youre Cuban and youre not home, her grandmother tells the American-born Camila.

title: Make Big Profits Illegally (and Maybe Keep Them, Too)
description: There is not much doubt that Oleksandr Dorozhko used inside information when he made a killing trading stock options last fall. Nor is there a dispute that he gained the information illegally. His lawyer, arguing before an appeals court this week, spoke of a high-tech lock pick.

title: U.S. to Attempt to Shoot Down Faulty Satellite
description: WASHINGTON  The military will try to shoot down a crippled spy satellite in the next two weeks, senior officials said Thursday. The officials laid out a high-tech plan to intercept the satellite over the Pacific just before it tumbles uncontrollably to Earth carrying toxic fuel.

title: No Mickey Mouse Stuff
description: It would be a mistake to assume that the 10 movies nominated this year for best live-action and animated short film in the Oscar sweepstakes are the kind of cinematic amuse-bouches often shown before the main feature at film festivals. Most are not trifles, and some range from 30 to 40 minutes long.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about government assistance for a struggling German bank, IKB Deutsche Industriebank, misstated part of the name of a political party that has criticized the rescue effort. It is the Christian Democratic Union, not the Christian Democratic Party.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about cockfighting in the Dominican Republic referred imprecisely to the legal status of the practice in the United States. Although all 50 states have voted to ban cockfighting, it is not yet illegal in all of them. (Cockfights can continue in Louisiana until the states prohibition takes effect in August.)

title: French Traders Bets Said to Assure an Alarm
description: PARIS  Someone well acquainted with the trading controls at Socit Gnrale said it was inconceivable that Jrme Kerviels immediate supervisors were not alerted after his trades set off alarm bells at Eurex, the derivatives exchange based in Frankfurt.

title: Oscar Organizers Express Relief at Shows Resumption
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Both a little grayer then they were a few weeks ago, Sidney Ganis, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, and Gilbert Cates, producer of the Oscar telecast, said they were going full steam ahead with Show A.

title: Even-Paced Movements, Ranging From Hip-Hop to Ballet
description: Kota Yamazaki is one of the mysteries of dance in New York City. He has skittered across the aesthetic map in the 11 years that he has been presenting dance here, never quite settling convincingly into one style but being consistently chosen to perform in major theaters.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about efforts to find the source of fake ingredients in Chinese antimalarial medicine misstated the official name of the geographic area of southern China where Guilin Pharmaceutical, a company that discovered the fakes in 2006, is based. It is the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous region; there is no Guangxi Province.

title: McCain Calls for Obama to Use Public Financing
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  Hammering Senator Barack Obama for a fourth straight day, Senator John McCain said here on Friday that he expects Senator Obama to abide by his pledge use public financing for his general election if Mr. McCain does so as well.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Selected Studies: Narcolepsy
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information about these and other trials: ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Meditating on History, Art, Paris and Berlin
description: The Blue Flower, a production by the Prospect Theater Company at the West End Theater, bites off a compelling chunk of the 20th century and presents it in a way that too often resembles a disjointed historical pageant: See Paris in the teens! The battlefields of World War I! Weimar Berlin!

title: New Trouble in Auction-Rate Securities
description: SOME well-heeled investors got a big jolt from Goldman Sachs this week: Goldman, the most celebrated bank on Wall Street, refused to let them withdraw money from investments that they had considered as safe as cash.

title: European Union Seeks Longer Music Copyrights
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union said Thursday that it would seek to extend copyright protection for singers and musicians to 95 years  rather than the current 50  in a move intended to let performers receive royalty payments later in life.

title: A String of Campus Gun Rampages
description: If the news from DeKalb, Ill.  a gunman bursting into a college lecture hall, killing 5 students and wounding 16 more people in a fusillade of gunfire, then killing himself  gives you a sickening feeling of familiarity, youve been paying attention. The Northern Illinois University shooting rampage joins a string of similar incidents to hit the headlines in recent years  one of them less than a week ago.

title: Adler Planetarium and Astronomy Museum
description: The Adler Planetarium's collection of remarkable globes, star charts and moon maps suggest that the modern planetarium is just another reflection of ancient cosmological impulses.

title: Game of the Week: North Dakota-Denver
description: The W.C.H.A. is college hockeys version of the SEC. Its stacked. With seven teams in the top 20 nationally, every conference game from here on in will have an impact on postseason seeding. Among many high-profile matchups in the West this weekend, North Dakota playing host to Denver University for the first time since October 2005 is easily the biggest. With the teams separated by the slimmest of margins in the Pairwise rankings, this weekends big winner will inch that much closer to a No. 1 seeding in the N.C.A.A. mens tournament.

title: Devean George Enters Maelstrom as He Rejects Trade
description: Devean George had a television camera trained on him as he entered U.S. Airways on Thursday night for the Dallas Mavericks' game against the Phoenix Suns. It was a surreal scene for George, who is used to blending into the background, on and off the court.

title: Lampert Begins Breaking Up With Citi
description: For Edward S. Lampert, it appears the bloom is off the rose at Citigroup.

title: Plan to Rescue Bond Insurers Is Outlined
description: The recapitalization of bond insurers hit by the subprime crisis may occur soon, but if it fails, insurers can be forced to separate riskier activities from their municipal bonds business, New York State officials said Thursday.

title: Like a Party at Elton Johns House
description: Aired Thursday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Valentines Day started out as an ancient Roman fertility festival. What would happen is a young nobleman would charge through the street naked, striking people with a leather thong for good luck. It is like a party at Elton Johns house.

title: Deutsche Post Chief Under Tax Inquiry
description: German prosecutors accused one of the countrys most prominent business executives of tax evasion on Thursday after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.

title: Microsoft Reassigns Several Top Executives
description: As it continues to push for its $44.6 billion unsolicited bid for Yahoo, Microsoft announced a sweeping shake-up of its executive ranks Thursday, placing new executives over operations facing fierce new competition from Google, Apple and cellphone makers.

title: Investors Remain Wary of $19.5 Billion Clear Channel Buyout
description: Now that the $19.5 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications by Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners has cleared all the necessary regulator hurdles, attention is turning to the sale of debt necessary to finance the deal.

title: Buffett Becomes Krafts Biggest Shareholder
description: Warren E. Buffett seems to like Nelson Peltzs work.

title: NYSE Euronext Takes Stake in Indian Exchange
description: NYSE Euronext, which owns the New York Stock Exchange and four European bourses, is picking up a 5 percent stake in the Multi Commodity Exchange of India for $55 million.

title: I Guess Things Didnt Go Very Well
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Its Valentines Day. So if youre watching this show right now  I guess things didnt go very well.

title: Bear Stearns Investigation Said to Center on Managers
description: A criminal investigation into the collapse of two Bear Stearns hedge funds could hinge on whether managers misled investors about the funds difficulties on a conference call last April, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Yes, Another Success Story for eHarmony.Com
description: Aired Thursday night on CBS: You folks having a good Valentines Day? Then why are you here?

title: ArcSight I.P.O. Fails to Thrill
description: Silicon Valleys first initial public offering of the year landed with a thud Thursday.

title: IDS Group Seeks to Raise $86 Million in I.P.O.
description: IDS Group, which provides software for financial institutions and equipment manufacturers, is planning an initial public stock offering that could raise $86.25 million.

title: The Carpetbagger
description: David Carr (a.k.a. the Carpetbagger) takes a sneak peek at the menu for a party scheduled to take place at the Carlyle Hotel on Oscar night.

title: New Trouble in Auction-Rate Securities
description: Some well-heeled investors got a big jolt from Goldman Sachs this week: Goldman, the most celebrated bank on Wall Street, refused to let them withdraw money from investments that they had considered as safe as cash.

title: Inspector Specter
description: After the embarrassing episode on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, when many members of Congress seemed to take sides on the Clemens-McNamee affair based on party affiliation instead of on the merits of the case, N.F.L. fans are fortunate that they have an impartial arbiter looking into the N.F.L. spying scandal.

title: French Traders Bets Said to Assure an Alarm
description: Someone well acquainted with the trading controls at Socit Gnrale told The New York Times that it was inconceivable that Jrme Kerviels immediate supervisors were not alerted after his trades set off alarm bells at Eurex, the derivatives exchange based in Frankfurt.

title: Transcript: Q & A With Ben Shpigel
description: The Mets pitchers and catchers reported to spring training Thursday in Port St. Lucie, Florida. Ben Shpigel, The New York Timess Mets beat writer has been there for a few days, updating fans here on the Bats blog and in The Timess baseball coverage.

title: Greenhills SPAC Prices at $10 Per Share
