description: As scads of firms are pulling their initial public offerings due to volatile market conditions, yet another special purpose acquisition vehicle continued merrily on its way to market. The I.P.O. of GHL Acquisition Corporation, backed by the boutique merger advisory firm Greenhill & Company, priced late Thursday at $10 per unit, raising about $400 million before commissions and discounts.

title: In Second Installment, Hollywood Producer Wins the Lightning
description: In what amounts to a rerun of sorts, Hollywood producer Oren Koules is again on the verge of purchasing pro hockeys Tampa Bay Lightning four months after the original deal he was a part of fell through.

title: Cerberus Sees Potential Difficulty at GMAC
description: Cerberus Capital Managements Stephen Feinberg said in a letter to his funds investors that GMAC, the auto and mortgage lender that it controls, may run into substantial difficulty if credit markets dont improve, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Thoma Cressy Takes Macrovisions Software Unit
description: As Macrovision seeks to shore up support for its $2.8 billion Gemstar-TV Guide acquisition, the company announced on Thursday that it is selling its software business to a unit of private equity firm Thoma Cressey Bravo.

title: Hoo You Gonna Call It?
description: Where is it written that new-media leviathans shall have benign-sounding if not silly names? Theres Microsoft, Yahoo, Google and now, with the prospective combining of the first two, quite possibly Microhoo  yes, if the media have their way. Brings to mind the giant Stay Puft Marshmallow Man ravaging New York at the end of Ghostbusters, doesnt it? Some recent indicators:

title: Carlyle Unveils Wave of Promotions
description: The Carlyle Group has promoted 30 executives to senior positions in the company, eight to managing director  the most senior role below those of senior adviser, founder and chairman  and 22 to director.

title: Avedro Scores $8 Million in First Round
description: Medical device maker Avedro has raised an $8 million round of venture capital funding, according to a federal filing.

title: United, Continental Said to Hold Advanced Merger Talks
description: United Airlines is in advanced negotiations to combine with Houston-based Continental Airlines and is poised to quickly seal a deal if Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines merge, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Go Chelsea Football! A Soccer Stadium Tour
description: Last week I received an e-mail from a fellow Chelsea football (soccer) supporter, who now lives in France, inviting me to join him on a tour of Chelsea Football Clubs stadium. I jumped at the opportunity  particularly since I can no longer afford to go to matches; the cheapest tickets of this much loved team are around 50 pounds.

title: UBS Stock Falls After Bearish Citi Report
description: Shares in UBS fell again on Friday as fears of more massive losses mounted after equity analysts at Citigroup said UBS could need up to $18 billion in additional write-downs in 2008, Reuters reported.

title: Citi Said to Lock Down 2 Funds Amid Losses
description: Citigroup has barred investors in one of its hedge funds from withdrawing their money, and a new leveraged fund lost 52 percent in its first three months, The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.

title: Bear and Citic Said to Renegotiate Deal
description: Bear Stearns and Citic Securities, Chinas largest investment bank, are discussing a reciprocal adjustment of the stake-swap deal they negotiated in October, when Bears stock was much higher, The Financial Times reported Friday, citing a person familiar with the matter. Under the new terms, Citics stake in Bear is likely to reach 9.9 percent, up from 6 percent under the October agreement.

title: Love and Despair on the Battlefield
description: Prolific and famous in his own country, the Swedish playwright Lars Noren is hardly known here. The American premiere of his 2003 work War, at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, may not explain that difference, but it offers clues, beginning with a title that is both overreaching and basic to the point of blandness.

title: The Early Word: Center Stage Wisconsin
description: Three of the top four presidential candidates will campaign across Wisconsin today, all hitting Milwaukee at some point, ahead of the states Tuesday primary.

title: A Cast That Jumps Through Hoops
description: Is there anything they cant do?

title: An Epic of Blood and Oil
description: Watching There Will Be Blood in his bubble, unable to hear every word of dialogue or note of Johnny Greenwoods much-lauded contemporary soundtrack, was a bit of a revelation to the Bagger. The experience helped explain why he was never knocked down by this movie like other, more learned colleagues.

title: A Grainy Reality
description: There are some stunning, hallucinatory moments in Sand, Trista Baldwins three-actor play about American soldiers in an unnamed, Iraq-like war zone. Pedro Pascal as Armando, a sergeant and the senior of the three, at times smoothly shifts into the role of Ahmed, a Middle Eastern man  he may be real or imaginary  who wanders into the barren desert where the soldiers are guarding a gas pump. In these graceful dramatic turns the play suggests how the line between enemies, and even identity itself, shifts as easily as the sands for anyone in the surreal state of combat.

title: Clues, but No Arrests Yet, in Killing of Psychologist
description: E-mail messages and phone records led detectives to a Pennsylvania man who was questioned for eight hours and then released as part of the investigation of the killing of an Upper East Side psychologist, Kathryn Faughey. The man, William Kunsman, had met Dr. Faughey and her husband at a guitar camp six years ago and had recent contact with her via e-mail, according to Al Baker. While newspapers observed that Mr. Kunsman had little resemblance to the man in the videotape (Mr. Kunsman appeared to have a full head of hair, while the killer had a bald spot), he had been identified in a picture lineup by Dr. Faugheys colleague, Kent D. Shinbach, a psychiatrist who was in the office during the murder and was critically injured. A patient who was in the office and tried to stop the assailant as he was leaving did not identify Mr. Kunsman.

title: Pushing on a string
description: Ben Bernanke has cut interest rates a lot since last summer. But can he make a difference? Or is he just, as the old line has it, pushing on a string?

title: Gingrichs Call for a Re-vote
description: Partisan Democrats may suspect his motives, but Newt Gingrich sounds sincere when he calls, on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal, for a do-over in the Democratic primaries in Florida and Michigan.

title: T Online | Our Oscar Picks
description: Lynn Hirschberg, T Magazines editor at large, has a remarkable nose for Oscar nods. She plays a featured role in selecting the actors and actresses who will be photographed for the covers of Ts fashion issues, then interviews them for the magazine and for Ts Screentest films. One of her criteria: Is their work in the coming season Oscar worthy? As the 10 covers shown on the new home page of our mothersite, nytimes.com/tmagazine, show, shes frequently right. Among the T talent hoping for gold at the Hollywood ceremony on Sunday Feb. 24 are Marion Cotillard and Tilda Swinton. Good luck, ladies.

title: Recipe of the Day: Chili Garlic Paste
description: It has a reputation for being one of the mysteries of international cuisine, but chili paste is really about as easy to make as applesauce. Take dried chilies, soak them until they are soft, combine them with a spice or two (or not) and pure.

title: Two Americas
description: Says the Times:

title: A Condiment Clarification
description: Some of the e-mails I get from readers  e-mails that come through channels different from this blog  are too delicious not to share, and the following one fits that bill.

title: Blackstones Peterson Puts Riches Toward a Cause
description: Peter G. Peterson has conspired with Henry Kissinger in the Nixon White House, led Lehman Brothers away from the brink of bankruptcy and been a co-founder of the worlds most recognized private equity firm, The New York Times wrote Friday.

title: Dinallo Confirms FGIC Move to Split
description: CNBC interviews Eric Dinallo, New York State Insurance Superintendant, on what he plans to do to overhaul the bond insurance industry.

title: The Pyrotechnic Imagination
description: The artist Cai Guo-Qiang creates a gunpowder drawing.

title: Stray Questions for: Clive James
description: Clive Jamess most recent book is Cultural Amnesia.

title: Good Climate Policy, Bad Politics
description: A new report from the Congressional Budget Office confirms one of the most depressing facts about climate change: The best policy is the one thats going nowhere in Washington.

title: Sparkle to the Finish?
description: The Bagger has to admit that there seems to be a bit of an energy crisis around Oscar town. At this time in the previous seasons, there would be missiles flying back and forth from various camps and people would be genuinely frantic about who was going to win what.

title: The AOL Peoples Choice Award
description: Awards Daily  points us to AOL, where people are voting their little hearts out. It turns out that No Country, the presumptive favorite so far this year, has pulled ahead of Juno in the battle for best picture.

title: Women More Likely to Postpone New Knees
description: Women appear to delay knee replacement surgery longer than men, and often show up far more disabled by the time they undergo the procedure.

title: Kid A
description: The men behind the curtain met with the press yesterday and it appears that Oz is under rapid construction. Michael Cieply reports that Sid Ganis, president of the Academy, and Gil Cates, the producer of this years show, are wiping the flop sweat out of their eyes after months of wondering whether they were going to have to come up with a work-around and are now full steam ahead with Plan A. And there will be no shortage of A-Listers.

title: Februarys Poli-Book Best Seller List
description: This month is bookended by the big presidential primary season. Well have to wait to see whether any of the already published authors among the Republican and Democratic candidates who recently quit the race offer up new titles in the coming months.

title: Renewals: CBS Shoots Schedule Full Of Bullets
description: The murderers row of CBS dramas  CSI and its spin-offs, Criminal Minds, NCIS and their ilk  will return next season, the network confirmed on Thursday.

title: Ahead of Dexters Broadcast Debut, Critics Slam CBS for Celebrating Murder
description: Dexter, the celebrated Showtime series about a sympathetic-seeming serial killer, went under the knife ahead of its broadcast debut Sunday night on CBS. The curse words were replaced and the most visible moments of gore were truncated.

title: Will Toshiba Suspend Its HD DVD Campaign?
description: UPDATE: This race is over. Wal-Mart has switched its vote to Blu-ray. See below.

title: New York Fashion Week | Richard Chai
description: (Don Ashby)New York Fashion Week is over, but The Fashion Telex continues as the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file dispatches from last weeks shows. Read all Fashion Telexes from New York Fashion Week.

title: For the Moment | Defragmentation of Machine and Man
Nine Months of Rehab for Il Fenomeno
description: For the third time, AC Milan striker Ronaldo underwent knee surgery to repair a ruptured tendon. This time, doctors operated on his left knee (in 1999 and 2000, it was the right). The surgery went well, according to renowned French surgeon Dr. Gerard Saillant, who operated on Ronaldo eight years ago and oversaw the procedure performed by Dr. Eric Rolland on Thursday night in Paris.

title: No Rest for the Weary
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In Ozone Park, the Mob Ties That Bind
description: Standing in front of the old site of the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club in Ozone Park, Queens, you can see a few immediate differences between its appearance now and its appearance when it was home base for the John J. Gotti and his associates in the Gambino crime family. First, the space, at 98-04 101st Avenue, has been divided into two businesses, a medical supply store and a pet groomer, and it looks a lot more welcoming now than it used to. Second, there was some faded graffiti on the front of the building. That is the kind of thing, people in the neighborhood said this week, that would not have flown when Mr. Gotti, who died in prison in 2002, was still around.

title: Can a Toyota Win the Daytona 500?
description: Believe it or not, Toyota will have two cars in the top five positions at the start of the Daytona 500 on Sunday (and three in the top six).

title: Imagine Everyone Was Equal, in Emissions
description: In a three-day summit at the United Nations on global warming this week, a parade of representatives from developing countries expressed growing discontent with the lack of action by rich ones to start curbing emissions of greenhouse gases that, in the long run, are likely to exact the most harm in the worlds poorest places.

title: Road Trip: Killing Time
description: NEWTON, Mass.  Good morning from the team hotel, the lovely Newton Marriott on the outskirts of Boston. Welcome to one of the most delicate parts of any college road trip  killing time until tipoff.

title: Fancy New Digs for Bears Chairman
description: Lloyd Blankfein and Sanford Weill are among the current and former Wall Street heavyweights who have recently bought into 15 Central Park West, New Yorks uber-luxurious new condominium complex.

title: Bloomberg on Illegal Guns and Rampages
description: Updated, 1:38 p.m. | The morning after the shootings at Northern Illinois University, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rattled off a grim list of gun rampages across the country that have left at least 18 people dead in February alone, not counting the gunmen who in some cases killed themselves or were killed by police. Mr. Bloombergs comments on his weekly radio call-in were part of his crusade to get illegal guns off the streets.This month John, so far, has just been wretched, the mayor told John Gambling, his host on WABC-AM (770). He said he had asked his press secretary, Stu Loeser to get me a list of things that occurred just this month alone. Yesterday, Northern Illinois University, six people, another one died this morning, six people killed. Last Friday in Baton Rouge, a college student shot and killed two people then took his own life. Last Thursday, a gunman shot and killed five people in Kirkwood, Mo., in the City Hall, killed two City Council members and two police officers, and the mayor was very seriously wounded, and hes hanging in there. And Feb. 2, just a week ago, in the Lane Bryant store in Illinois, a gunmen shot and killed five customers and employees, all in their 20s and 30s. (The Lede blog has a list of recent campus rampages.)

title: Shaq Promotes Shoes in China
description: CNBC interviews Shaquille O'Neal, who recently moved to the Phoenix Suns, about his plans to sell his line of basketball shoes in China.

title: Bush 41 to Endorse McCain
description: Updated | 2:22 p.m. OSHKOSH, Wis.  Well, he didnt use the word endorsement or confirm that it was on its way, but a visibly pleased Senator John McCain did allow that he will travel to Houston Monday morning to meet with former President George H.W. Bush.

title: The Week in Comments: They Seem Overwrought
description: Monday, Feb. 11

title: Borough Superdelegates Stick By Clinton
description: Despite Senator Barack Obamas strong showing in several congressional districts in New York City, the members of Congress from those districts who are superdelegates to the Democratic National Convention say they remain firm in their decision to support Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Good News/Bad News
description: The good news: Something smart is happening in the school system to help fight the growing problem of childhood obesity: cooking lessons will be required for all kids aged 11 to 14, beginning in 2011.

title: Inside the Mind of the Boy Dating Your Daughter
description: The stereotype of the 16-year-old boy is that he has sex on the brain. But a fascinating new report suggests that boys are motivated more by love and a desire to form real relationships with the girls they date.

title: Road Trip: Shootaround
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The Cornell team bus pulled into Harvard just before noon for a shootaround on the scenic campus. Its a beautiful day here in Boston. The sun is resplendent. Its warm for this time of year, with the temperature about 40 degrees.

title: A (Red) Auction at Sothebys, to Raise the Stakes
description: Christy Turlington dropped $170,500 on a watercolor painting. Takashi Murakami nodded off briefly after his painting sold for $1.65 million. Bono rallied the Sothebys crowd for a sing-along to the Beatles All You Need Is Love. And a greater-than-projected $42 million was raised for the Global Fund to fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria through the sale of 82 works of art at the Product Red Sothebys auction on Thursday night. (The original somewhat conservative estimate was that the items would sell for a collective $21 million to $29 million.)

title: What I Ate Last Night Department
description: Were it not for my Italian guru, Andrea Graziosi, I would be making this dish in an inferior fashion and enjoying it less. Thanks to him, its one of my favorite dishes. So upon wandering into My New Favorite Fish Store with Dining editor Pete Wells yesterday and seeing piles of tiny vongole, dinner was determined.

title: FGIC Confirms It Seeks to Split Its Businesses
description: The Financial Guaranty Insurance Corporation, a bond insurer that has lost its top credit ratings, has told New York regulators it wants to split into two companies, a spokesman for the state insurance regulator said on Friday.

title: Married to Rhoda
description: David Groh, who in the 1970s sitcom Rhoda played Joe, the groom whose wedding to the title character became one of the highest-rated events of its time, has died at 68. Interestingly, he wasnt a dominant character in that episode

title: Amazons S3 Cloud Has a Dark Lining for Start-Ups
description: UPDATE: see updated Amazon statement below.

title: A Worse Day Than Usual to Promote Guns in National Parks
description: The Interior Department was expected to announce today that it would begin re-evaluating regulations that currently prohibit visitors from carrying loaded weapons in Americas national parks.

title: Digital Traces of the N.I.U. Shooting
description: Updated 4:00 p.m. Eastern

title: Paine Acquires Germanys Stabilus
description: Paine and Partners, a middle-market American buyout firm, agreed on Thursday to acquire German gas-springs maker Stabilus from Montagu Private Equity, a European buyout firm, for an undisclosed amount. Financial News reported Friday that Paine will pay between 550 million euros and 580 million euros ($806 million to $850 million).

title: Video Games and Valuations
description: Earlier this week, we covered Yahoos brief, polite rejection of Microsofts bear-hug letter. In making the determination that Microsofts bid substantially undervalues its assets, Yahoo had the benefit of advice from three investment banks.

title: Service Workers Union Backs Obama
description: The Service Employees International Union gave Barack Obama its highly prized endorsement on Friday afternoon.

title: The Next Big Thing?
description: Upstart companies can make big money in the non-alcoholic beverage industry. The hard part is breaking into the fickle New York City market.

title: Violence Segregates Kenya
description: Violence brought by the aftermath of a contested presidential election is redrawing the ethnic map of Kenya.

title: Now Screeening | London Fashion Videos
description: As London Fashion Week wraps up, the IHT has posted two new videos. In the first video, Suzy Menkes dives into the aesthetics of green fashion with Orsola de Castro, a designer and co-curator of the Esthetica showcase for sustainable fashion. In the second video, Jessica Michault interviews Justin Smith, a new hat designer whose work references turn of the century hat making.

title: Ratings: CBSs Formula? Survive, Repeat, Rinse
description: Survivor: Micronesia buoyed CBSs otherwise repeat heavy line-up on Thursday, as the network earned the most viewers even as ABC fared better among adults 18 to 49. ABC got a boost from the nights top rated show, Lost, which led the 9 p.m. hour with 13.6 million viewers according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Strike News: CW Announces Gossip Return

Bloomberg invoked a rarely used power today not to enforce a law he deems illegal, saying he would ignore an electronic recycling bill passed by the City Council this week if his planned veto is overridden.The mayor, on his weekly radio program on WABC-AM (770), said the bill as currently written is totally illegal.

The chart below shows the University of Michigan index; consumer confidence is now lower than it ever was during the 2001 recession and aftermath, and close to its worst levels during the early 90s, when the unemployment rate went well above 7 percent.

As a player for the French national team and Juventus of Italy, Platini cut an elegant figure on the soccer field. In the corridors of power, Platini has moved to defuse tensions between Europes biggest clubs, the now disbanded G14, while pushing to expand participation in the European Champions League.

title: Head Sets to the Highest Bidder (Paranoia Not Included)

Well, this is probably as close as youre going to get.This week, the N.F.L. put up for auction the head sets worn by Giants Coach Tom Coughlin and Patriots Coach Bill Belichick at the Super Bowl. The bidding ends Wednesday. Play cards with which to cover ones face, while showing off ones head set, are not included.

title: The Army Recruiter Is Not In

But if their aim was to disrupt recruiting, they did not. The office had already been closed for the day, with a metal gate drawn down over the plate glass windows.

description: The Daytona 500 gets a green flag this weekend without a Chevrolet Monte Carlo in the field for the first time in many years. The Monte Carlo was discontinued last year, after accumulating more victories than any car in racing history, according to Chevrolet. I can attest to the Monte Carlos performance capabilities. Years ago, I drove one in a Monte Carlo rally.

title: Vows: Rachel and Michael
description: San Francisco natives Rachel and Michael married in the same New York City church as his grandparents did 70 years ago.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass  Cornell Coach Steve Donahue asked his team a question in a heated halftime talk during his teams game with Harvard on Friday night: Did you not expect a hard game?

title: Your Comments on my McCain Column
description: Im putting this up early because Im en route to Kenya and beyond, but my Sunday column will be about John McCain. Id welcome your comments on it, so just post below. Ill put up a separate spot to post your predictions for my election contest, so post here for the McCain column only.

title: The Election Predictions Contest
description: I invite you to enter my little contest here to see who can best predict the outcome of the November election.

title: Missile Defense Future May Turn on Success of Mission to Destroy Satellite
description: WASHINGTON  The order by President Bush for the Navy to launch an antimissile interceptor to destroy a disabled satellite before it falls from orbit carries opportunity, but also potential embarrassment, for the administration and advocates of its missile defense program.

title: Prosecutors in Germany Expand Tax Evasion Inquiry
description: FRANKFURT  German prosecutors said on Friday that they were investigating several hundred people on suspicion of tax evasion in a case that quickly claimed the job of Klaus Zumwinkel, the chief executive of Deutsche Post.

title: On the Stump, Pakistani Candidates Avoid Musharraf
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  A veteran politician, Sheik Rashid Ahmed is a close friend of President Pervez Musharraf and served as a minister in his cabinet for the last five years. Yet on the campaign trail in this, his hometown, before Mondays parliamentary elections, he never mentions the president once.

title: Well, Doctor, I Have This Recycling Problem
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: Hardball With Warren and Eliot
description: States and localities  including New York State and New York City  took a hit from the credit crunch this week. And in separate yet complementary ways, the investor Warren Buffett and New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer struck back.

title: Gaps Likely to Persist in Campus Security
description: As a parent, Jay Spradling feels the same fear that campus shootings stir up in parents everywhere.

title: Anxious About Earths Troubles? Theres Treatment
description: For people who feel an acute unease about the future of the planet, a small but growing number of psychotherapists now offer a treatment designed to reduce worries as well as carbon footprints: ecopsychology.

title: The Sound of Howl
description: The earliest known recording of Allen Ginsberg reading from his epic poem Howl has been found at Reed College in Portland, Ore., the British newspaper The Guardian reported. It had been thought that Ginsberg, right, first recorded the work in Berkeley, Calif., in March 1956. But according to The Oregonian, the recently discovered recording was made several weeks earlier. Ginsberg, having hitchhiked to Portland with his fellow Beat poet Gary Snyder in the winter of 1956, gave a reading at a student hostel, the Anna Mann Cottage, that was recorded on a reel-to-reel machine on Feb. 14. The tape was found by John Suiter, a biographer of Mr. Snyder, in a box in the college archives labeled Snyder Ginsberg 1956. It contained a 35-minute tape of Ginsberg reading the first section of Howl and other poems. The recordings can be heard at reed.edu.

title: Running From Despair
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  On a cold Saturday morning last month, 16-year-old Chantel Hunt ran across a highway onto a gravel road where the snow under her shoes packed into washboard ripples. She ran around a towering red rock butte, past two old mattresses dumped on the roadside, and into the shadow of a mesa she sometimes runs on top of.

title: Russia Warns It May Back Breakaway Republics in Georgia
description: MOSCOW  Russia held a high-level meeting with the leaders of two breakaway republics in Georgia on Friday, and vowed to increase its support for the separatists if Kosovo declared its independence and was recognized by the West.

title: Vast Legal-Aid Fraud Laid to Two Brothers
description: DENVER  For years, people who dialed information asking for legal aid, in the hope of getting a lawyer who could help them at little or no charge, were frequently given phone numbers of two half brothers. The brothers, named Brown and White, claimed to provide authentic legal services but did not, and ran a nonprofit that was anything but, the Colorado attorney general says.

title: The Mittification of McCain
description: As Mitt Romney said this week when he endorsed John McCain, the campaign might have been rough but we always had good laughs together. As examples of this hitherto-unnoticed good fellowship, Mitt pointed cheerily to the fact that he and McCain had shaken hands before the debates and said hi to each others wives.

title: A Split-Up of Insurers of Bonds Is Considered
description: Regulators and bankers racing to bolster troubled bond insurance companies are considering splitting the firms into two parts: one for safe municipal debt and the other for riskier mortgage-related securities.

title: Famous Fund Open Again. Is It a Buy?
description: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS is welcoming new shareholders into its venerable Magellan fund after shutting them out for a decade. With the funds asset base shrinking, it is a sensible move for Fidelity, but should you accept the invitation?

title: Solo Flight on Feathered Wings and Bare Back
description: First came a cloud of dark, ratty tulle, just visible at a back corner in the dim light. Then a few patches of glowing skin were visible. By the time the apparition reached the other end of the stage, shedding bits of tulle like molting fur, a woman was emerging.

title: In State Senate, Aging Fingers Cling to Power
description: ALBANY  Last year was a tough one for State Senator Caesar Trunzo.

title: Surviving in Style
description: Survivor: Micronesia helped CBS draw the most viewers on Thursday night, though ABC fared better with adults 18 to 49. ABC also had the top-rated show, Lost, which led at 9 with 13.6 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. Survivor won the 8 oclock time slot with 13.1 million viewers; NBCs Deal or No Deal had 12 million. Trailing Lost at 9 were CBSs CSI repeat (11 million) and NBCs Celebrity Apprentice (9.1 million). NBC tied CBS for second among the 18-to-49 set and tied ABC for second in total viewers. Fox finished fourth over all.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Thursday about a British musician who fell down a flight of stairs and damaged his violin, using information from the London newspaper The Independent, misidentified the maker of the violin. He was Giovanni Battista Guadagnini, not Antonio Stradivari. The report also misstated the age of the violin. It is 236 years old, not 290.

title: If Clemens Is Pursued, a Grand Jury Is Probable
description: WASHINGTON  If the Justice Department moves ahead with an investigation into Roger Clemenss statements under oath to Congress over the last several weeks, federal authorities will probably convene a grand jury to delve deeper into Clemenss possible links to performance-enhancing drugs and to question him more directly.

title: Showtimes Serial Killer Moves to CBS, to a Not Entirely Warm Welcome
description: Dexter, the Showtime series about a sympathetic-seeming serial killer, went under the knife ahead of its scheduled broadcast debut Sunday night on CBS. The curse words were replaced, and the most visible moments of gore were truncated.

title: Suit Could Shed Light on Actions of Patriots
description: A former St. Louis Rams player and three fans filed a lawsuit against the Patriots and Coach Bill Belichick on Friday, saying that the Patriots fraudulently gained an unfair advantage by taping a Rams walk-through practice the day before the teams played in the Super Bowl in 2002.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some copies of the Arts & Leisure section this weekend about the state of public broadcasting misspells the surname of a host whose show is distributed by Public Radio International. He is Kurt Andersen, not Anderson.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Meredith Monk, at Symphony Space, misstated the date of the second concert, at which two members of her group will present works of their own. As noted elsewhere in the entry, the concerts were scheduled for Friday night and next Thursday night  not Friday and today.

title: Veterans Charities
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to a Justice Department examination of a contract that he awarded to former Attorney General John Ashcroft, who had been his boss. It was reviewed by the departments criminal division, not the office of inspector general. (No wrongdoing was found.)

title: Worries on the Vine
description: IN the coming decades, might oenophiles be debating the subtle aromas and delicate flavors of all the great new wines coming out of Saskatchewan?

title: Germany: German-Pakistani Accused of Supporting Al Qaeda
description: The police in the western state of Rhineland-Palatinate have arrested a German citizen of Pakistani origin on suspicion of acting as a courier of money, night-vision equipment and radios to Al Qaeda in the Afghan-Pakistani border area. The authorities said the suspect, Aleem Nasir, left, had taken four trips to the region from April 2005 to June 2007, carrying at least the equivalent of $5,800 in euros each time, and equipment on three occasions. According to the prosecutors statement, he also received explosives training and successfully recruited another German resident for the terrorist group in 2006. In an interview in September, Mr. Nasir denied any Qaeda ties and said he had confessed while being beaten by Pakistani agents. German officials warned last week that Qaeda commanders had ordered terrorist attacks against the country and were increasingly seeking to recruit German-speaking terrorists over the Internet.

title: Suicide Blast at Campaign Rally in Pakistan Kills 37
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed a car into a campaign rally in the tribal areas on Saturday, killing 37 people and injuring 90 others, the Interior Ministry said.

title: In San Jose, Disputes and Anger After Vote on Street Name
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Story Road, at first glance, is unremarkable. Often congested, it runs beneath a freeway, over railroad tracks and through acres of parking lots.

title: More Than a Feeling
description: Tom Scholz, the chief songwriter and founder of the band Boston, has written to Mike Huckabee, complaining of his use of the groups 1976 song More Than a Feeling in his presidential campaign without permission, The Associated Press reported. A former band member, Barry Goudreau, has played the song with Mr. Huckabee at campaign events. Mr. Scholz, who supports Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, for president, objects to the implication that the band has endorsed the candidacy of Mr. Huckabee, a Republican. You have taken something of mine and used it to promote ideas to which I am opposed, Mr. Scholz wrote. In other words, I think Ive been ripped off, dude! In response, Fred Bramante, who was chairman of Mr. Huckabees New Hampshire primary campaign, said: Governor Huckabee plays Sweet Home Alabama. Does that mean Lynyrd Skynyrd is endorsing him?

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions on Feb. 6 about possible nominees for vice president referred imprecisely to the work that one of them does now. Tom Daschle, a former senator who has been a mentor to Senator Barack Obama, is a consultant on public policy in the Washington office of a law firm; he is not a lobbyist. (Go to Graphic)

title: Chinas Trade Surplus Jumps, but Imports Are Rising
description: BEIJING (AP)  Chinas trade surplus grew by 22.7 percent in January over the same month last year as foreign demand for exports stayed strong despite worries about slowing global growth, according to data reported Friday.

title: Loves Labors Tossed and Turned in a Survey of the Hearts Hard Edges
description: Anyone with a romantic streak will have room in his heart for various kinds of unhappy ending. The love that cannot succeed in this world, at which ballet can excel, is part of what romanticism is all about. In what kind of grim but not for me temper, though, did New York City Ballet assemble Matters of the Heart on Valentines Day?

title: Kenya Peace Talks Stall on Power-Sharing Issues
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Despite soothing words from Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general who is trying to mediate a solution to Kenyas political crisis, one thing seemed clear on Friday: Kenya is stuck.

title: The Workplace as Clubhouse
description: BOEING is known around the world for building jetliners, but in Washington State, it also has a reputation for turning out top winemakers.

title: Just Click the Mouse. Follow the Cursor. You Are Calm. You Feel Good.
description: GREENVILLE, N.C.  The Psychophysiology and Biofeedback Laboratory at East Carolina University here is in the subterranean bowels of a former gymnasium, just down the hall from an old locker room that still smells faintly of feet.

title: Lottery Numbers
Is Satire in a Slump? Yes and No
description: For 36 hours, Marco Ceglie was holed up this week in a borrowed apartment off the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, his eyeballs pinned to a computer screen. He was editing videotape at a full-out sprint. There was not a minute to waste. A group of celebrities organized by the musician Will.i.am of the Black Eyed Peas had already turned a Barack Obama speech into a spoken-word music video, Yes We Can. It instantly became a digital hymn watched by zillions.

title: Political Heir Is Less Rosy Than Putin on the State of Russia
description: MOSCOW  The presumptive successor to President Vladimir V. Putin presented his platform for seeking Russias highest office on Friday, giving a speech before business leaders in Siberia in which he vowed to continue Russias economic revival, but also struck markedly liberal notes.

title: Fire Department Frees Boy Stuck in Jettys Rocks
description: A 14-year-old boy whose foot had gotten stuck in the rocks of a jetty about 100 yards from the northern end of Orchard Beach in the Bronx on Friday was rescued by Fire Department divers, the authorities said.

title: Gates Foundations Influence Criticized
description: The chief of malaria for the World Health Organization has complained that the growing dominance of malaria research by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation risks stifling a diversity of views among scientists and wiping out the world health agencys policy-making function.

title: Training for Alaska, in New Jersey
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J. (AP)  A state known for the turnpike and an abundance of oil refineries is not the easiest place to pursue sled dog racing.

title: The Caucus and I: Democracy and Doughnuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Confidentiality Hinders Police in a Therapists Killing
description: As part of an expansive effort to catch a knife-wielding attacker, police officials confronted a thorny legal hurdle on Friday as they sought the medical records of an Upper East Side therapist who was slain and those of a colleague who was wounded rushing to her aid.

title: Cruel and Gratuitous
description: It happened last spring.

title: Uranium Mining Isnt Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: In Pakistan, Islam Needs Democracy
description: Islamabad, Pakistan

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column in Weekend on Friday about the response by the Broad Art Foundation to criticism that female and minority artists were inadequately represented in an exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Eli Broads private foundation reversed the given name and surname of the foundations spokeswoman. She is Karen Denne.

title: By Making Holocaust Personal to Pupils, Sarkozy Stirs Anger
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy dropped an intellectual bombshell this week, surprising the nation and touching off waves of protest with his revision of the school curriculum: beginning next fall, he said, every fifth grader will have to learn the life story of one of the 11,000 French children killed by the Nazis in the Holocaust.

title: Looking at the Stars From Angles Old and New
description: CHICAGO  There is something very simple, almost elemental, at stake as I sit in a wooden cart, and the machinery begins to grind. I am slowly lifted up a ramp until I reach the center of a hollow, darkened 15-foot sphere. When the noise from the gears below stops, another rumbling begins that is difficult to place. I am stationary but feel as if I am rotating, levitating in strange directions. When I look up at the 692 pinpoints of light in the metallic ceiling, I see they are revolving in a painted nighttime sky, lines joining them in simple constellations.

title: To Retire Better Off, Wait a Bit
description: COULD the secret to having enough money in retirement be as simple as working a bit longer? Writing in AARP magazine, Jonathan D. Pond, a financial planner, argues yes.

title: Indian Point: Safety Must Come First
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidd Deal Not Dead, but Maybe on Life Support
description: NEW ORLEANS  Jason Kidd sliced through a mob of cameras, microphones and bodies, settled into a padded chair and tried to dispel the chaos with a simple three-word introduction: Im a Net.

title: Two Immortal Lovers Have a Rematch in Paris
description: PARIS  The German choreographer Pina Bausch is celebrated (and occasionally denounced) for her epic tragicomic productions, in which her performers speak as much as they dance, offering vignettes of human life and behavior that are absurd, uncomfortable and moving amid strange and powerful stage landscapes.

title: In the Case of the Model vs. the Boxer, a Court Showdown That Wasnt
description: This one you couldnt miss. The press release was just too good.

title: The Rings Prompts a Long Legal Mire
description: LOS ANGELES  According to the legend, one ring ruled the rest, with cruelty, malice and a will to dominate all life. It has also provoked an awful lot of litigation.

title: McCain and Obama Tussle Over Future Financing
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  Senators Barack Obama and John McCain tussled directly Friday over how they will pay for their campaigns, with Mr. McCain challenging Mr. Obama to abide by his earlier pledge to use public financing for his general election if Mr. McCain does so as well.

title: Bomb Kills Man on Street in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  One man died and two people were wounded when a bomb exploded on a sidewalk just 300 yards from this capitals police headquarters on Friday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: At Berra Museum, the Display of Clemenss Jersey Is Over
description: The Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center last week removed a Roger Clemens jersey from an exhibit about the Yankee renaissance that started in the mid-1990s.

title: U.S. Struggles to Tutor Iraqis in Rule of Law
description: BAGHDAD  A mob had gathered by the time the F.B.I. agents arrived at the house where an assassins bomb killed nine people last year, narrowly missing a deputy prime minister. Fearing their own lives might be at risk, the agents gave themselves no more than 30 minutes to collect evidence.

title: All-in-One Telecom Packages: The Savings Dont Come Simple
description: This month, my husband and I decided to make a major move in our lives.

title: Buy Less but Pay Lots More, and Get a Misleading Rise in Sales
description: FACED with tightening credit and a slowing economy, Americas consumers are being forced to scale back their purchases, but high prices of necessities are keeping their overall purchases rising at a reasonably strong rate.

title: Super Bowl and Olympics: This Marketers Dream Year
description: THE ADIDAS GROUP of Germany, which owns the formerly independent Reebok, is using major athletic events like the Super Bowl and the Summer Olympics in its battle to catch up with and surpass Nike, says Herbert Hainer, chief executive of Adidas. Adidas, based in Bavaria, makes only 5 percent of its sales in Germany and uses English as its official language. Mr. Hainer was interviewed in New York. Here are excerpts from the conversation:

title: Athlete Hit by Javelin Is Healthy, but Angry
description: On Friday the 13th in July, Tero Pitkamaki of Finland, one of the worlds best at what he does, rumbled forward and released his javelin during a Golden League meet in Rome. It sailed far off target to the left, and nearly 80 meters away it landed in the back of an unsuspecting long jumper, Salim Sdiri of France.

title: Exploring Folk and Soft Rock and Discovering Pop Standards
description: Unfailingly demure, stalwartly upbeat and blessed with a vocal technique second to none, Maureen McGovern might be described as the Julie Andrews of the Love Generation. Because she has devoted most of the last 25 years to a pop-jazz, Broadway and light classical repertory, I hadnt thought of her quite that way until her captivating new show, A Long and Winding Road, at the Metropolitan Room.

title: Developer Holds Off Creditors, for Now
description: Harry Macklowe, the embattled billionaire developer who is struggling to hold on to his real estate empire, persuaded his two largest lenders not to foreclose on billions of dollars in property debts on Friday, even as prospective buyers submitted bids for his most treasured asset: the General Motors Building.

title: Phoenix Police to Check Arrestees Immigrant Status
description: PHOENIX  The police in this city at the center of the immigration debate will soon ask all people arrested whether they are in the United States legally and will in certain cases report the information to the federal authorities, Mayor Phil Gordon announced on Friday.

title: Bush and the Earmarks
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about Representative John Lewiss possible shift of support from Hillary Rodham Clinton to Barack Obama misstated, in some editions, the day that the photograph of Mrs. Clinton holding boxing gloves was taken. It was Thursday, not Wednesday.

title: Judges Asked to Widen Inquiry at French Bank
description: PARIS  A lawyer representing Socit Gnrale shareholders asked judges on Friday to interview an immediate supervisor of Jrme Kerviel, the trader the bank blames for billions of euros in losses from unauthorized trades, to try to determine when his superiors were first alerted to his actions.

title: Gnarls Is Back
description: Gnarls Barkley, the duo consisting of Danger Mouse and Cee-Lo, has set April 8 as the release date for The Odd Couple (Atlantic), the follow-up to its platinum-selling, Grammy-winning 2006 debut album, St. Elsewhere, Billboard reported. The two plan to support the album with a summer tour.

title: Nebraskas Electric Chair
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Officers Charged After a Brawl in Yonkers
description: WHITE PLAINS  Four New York City police officers were charged Friday over their roles in a late-night brawl in Yonkers in September in which a man suffered a cracked skull outside a strip of Irish pubs.

title: Brooklyn Scholars
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday announced the creation of the Samuel H. Scripps BAM Scholarship Fund, for students who pursue a higher education in arts administration, dance or theater. Awards will range from $4,500 to $20,000 and are open to any student who has taken part in the academys education program between kindergarten and the 12th grade. Roughly $45,000 will be disbursed yearly. Application details are at bam.org.

title: Chelsea Clinton Talks Policy in Obama Territory
description: The question was one she had heard before, but this time it was asked in downright hostile terms.

title: Universal Royalty Suit
description: The estates of some of American musics biggest names, including Count Basie, Benny Goodman and Sarah Vaughan, have sued Universal Music Group for more than $6 million, claiming the company cheated them out of royalties, The Associated Press reported. The lawsuit, which was also filed on behalf of some living artists, asserts that the company withheld record royalties, engaged in self-serving schemes with record clubs and suppressed payments from Apples iTunes and other digital distributors. The court papers accuse Universal of breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment. The 14 plaintiffs are Patti Page, Tony Martin, Dick Hyman, Richard Hayman, Kitty Kallen and the estates of Basie, Goodman, Vaughan, Woody Herman, Les Brown, the Mills Brothers, Jerry Murad, Frankie Laine and the gospel singer Sister Rosetta Tharpe. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, says Universal has been using questionable accounting practices since at least 1998. We believe that these claims are baseless, and we are confident that we will prevail in court, said Peter Lofrumento, a spokesman for the Universal Music Group.

title: China Didnt Check Drug Supplier, Files Show
description: A Chinese factory that supplies much of the active ingredient for a brand of a blood thinner that has been linked to four deaths in the United States is not certified by Chinas drug regulators to make pharmaceutical products, according to records and interviews.

title: Parks Worker Is Charged With Trying to Kill Birds
description: Around 3 p.m. on Friday, several people walking in Battery Park called 911 to report curious goings-on: a man driving a Parks Department golf cart was tearing erratically through a city park at 1 Whitehall Street.

title: Reading the Discards Helps Israel to Another Victory in Japan
description: The 13th NEC Cup Bridge Festival ended on Sunday in Yokohama, Japan. For the fourth time in five years, Israel won, its team being Migry Zur Campanile, Michael Barel and Doron and Israel Yadlin, who are brothers.

title: Bush Proposes Linking the Medicare Drug Premium to Beneficiaries Income
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush proposed legislation on Friday to increase prescription drug premiums for higher-income Medicare beneficiaries.

title: Yankees Come and Go, but One Thing Remains
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When the Yankees pitchers and catchers gathered in right field to begin their first spring training workout, so much was new. The Yankees have a new manager in Joe Girardi and several new coaches; it was the start of a new season; and, in an office four floors above the field, they have a new leading voice in Hank Steinbrenner.

title: Steve Fossett, Missing Adventurer, Is Declared Dead at 63
description: Steve Fossett, the wealthy, record-setting adventurer who for years blithely sailed, soared and drove through all manner of danger before disappearing in September during what was meant to be a routine short flight, was declared dead Friday by a Chicago court. He was 63, and had homes in Chicago; Beaver Creek, Colo.; and Carmel, Calif.

title: For EcoMoms, Saving Earth Begins at Home
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.  The women gathered in the airy living room, wine poured and pleasantries exchanged. In no time, the conversation turned lively  not about the literary merits of Geraldine Brooks or Cormac McCarthy but the pitfalls of antibacterial hand sanitizers and how to retool the laundry using only cold water and biodegradable detergent during non-prime-time energy hours (after 7 p.m.).

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A Public Lives profile in some editions on Friday about Michael Winship, the president of the Writers Guild of America East, misstated the purpose of a union vote on Tuesday night. The vote was to decide whether to end the strike; it was not to ratify a contract.

title: Prosecutor, Under Fire, Steps Down in Houston
description: HOUSTON  Besieged by an e-mail scandal and perjury accusations, Texass most powerful prosecutor resigned on Friday, saying that a combination of prescription drugs had caused some impairment in my judgment.

title: River of Danger, River of Peace
description: MANAUS, Brazil  For several miles flying northwest in a small plane out of this city in the northern part of Brazil, where the Rio Negro and the Rio Salimoes meet to form the Amazon River, there was evidence of humans: the cutting of forests, clearings with crops, buildings and roads. But then, suddenly, as if we had left a coastal city for the ocean, the development ceased.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on Thursday about a new soul food museum in Atlanta referred incorrectly to Smokey Robinsons Seafood Gumbo, a product on display at the museum. It is frozen gumbo, not a gumbo mix.

title: A Fighting Chance?
description: There seems to be no end to the Big Three automakers woes. This week, General Motors offered a new buyout plan to its 74,000 unionized workers in the United States  those who didnt take the 2006 buyout offer. The Ford Motor Company and Chrysler also have plans to buy out thousands of employees. Still, there is a glimmer of hope: the companies plan to hire new workers to replace at least some, and perhaps a substantial share, of those they let go.

title: A Single-Payer Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: After Slow January, Best Buy Lowers Forecast
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)  Best Buy said on Friday that its annual profit would be smaller than expected, hurt by a slowing economy as shoppers held back on purchasing TVs, digital music players and cameras.

title: Favorite in 08? Look to 07 and 06
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  On the way to winning consecutive championships in the Nascar Cup series, Jimmie Johnson has made a place for himself in stock car racings record book. In 2006, he became the only driver to win the Daytona 500, the Allstate 400 at the Brickyard, the All-Star race and the Cup championship in the same year.

title: Defense Opens Its Case in Beating Death of Girl
description: Cesar Rodriguez has admitted brutalizing his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown  beating her with his hands and a belt, plunging her head into cold water, lashing her to a wooden chair to discipline her, and finally leaving her, naked and starving, on a cold floor.

title: F.D.A. Seeks to Broaden Range of Use for Drugs
description: WASHINGTON  When federal drug regulators approve a medicine for sale, they limit how drug makers sell it. A drug approved to treat only breast cancer cannot be marketed for lung cancer even if some studies suggest that the medicine may save lung patients.

title: Whither the Corsets of Yesteryear?
description: The BBCs historical costume and wigs department has been forced to shut down after a deal to sell the department to a rival props company collapsed, The Times of London reported. The failure of the sale, part of a cost-saving drive, has created a crisis for period-drama productions. The BBCs costume vault houses about one million outfits and 12,000 hairpieces. But BBC Resources, as the operation is called, has announced that it is shutting down. The costumes and wigs will be moved from London to Oxford and held in storage until their future becomes clear. The shutdown comes after the BBC announced a series of period pieces, including productions of Tess of the DUrbervilles and Little Dorrit. A permanent closing would also hit film production. Sofia Coppolas 2006 film Marie Antoinette, which won the Oscar for costume design, used 400 items rented from the department.

title: Taps for HD DVD as Wal-Mart Backs Blu-ray
description: SAN FRANCISCO  HD DVD, the beloved format of Toshiba and three Hollywood studios, died Friday after a brief illness. The cause of death was determined to be the decision by Wal-Mart to stock only high-definition DVDs and players using the Blu-ray format.

title: 17,000 Child Care Providers Joining Union
description: About 17,000 home-based child care providers will join the Civil Service Employees Association as a result of a lopsided pro-union vote, state officials said Friday.

title: An Iranian Revolutionary, Dismayed but Unbowed
description: TEHRAN

title: Blast at House in Gaza Kills Militant and 5 Others
description: JERUSALEM  A senior military commander of the radical Islamic Jihad movement was killed Friday night along with at least five others as a powerful explosion destroyed his house in Gaza, but the Israeli military denied having anything to do with the blast.

title: Randolph Confident Mets Can Kick Funk
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  His funk, as Willie Randolph called it, set in immediately after the Mets meltdown in September. It lingered as his job security dangled for 24 hours, then as the leaves changed colors, as he cut the Thanksgiving turkey and as he opened presents on Christmas. It continued as he rang in 2008 and even into the last few weeks, when the acquisition of an ace, Johan Santana, temporarily brightened his mood.

title: Bush, in Africa, Emphasizes Successes
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  Opening a six-day tour of Africa, President Bush on Saturday defended his decision not to visit violence-stricken nations like Kenya and Sudan, saying he wanted to focus on his programs to fight AIDS and malaria instead.

title: Sharp Exchanges Over Surveillance Law
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush and House Democrats on Friday traded another round of angry words over whether to grant immunity to telecommunications companies that aided the Bush administrations terrorist surveillance program by providing private data without warrants after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Religious Right May Be Fading, but Not the Culture Wars
description: On every side, one can read obituaries for the religious right.

title: Data Shows Struggling Manufacturers, Costly Imports and Gloomier Consumers
description: A fresh batch of data released on Friday revealed an economy in distress, as manufacturers struggled, import prices rose, and consumer confidence continued to erode.

title: Zimbabwe: Opposition Faction Backs Mugabe Challenger
description: Arthur Mutambara, the leader of a breakaway faction of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, announced that he would support Simba Makoni, a former finance minister, in the March 29 presidential election. Mr. Makoni is himself a breakaway candidate, having defied the ruling ZANU-PF party and the countrys longtime president, Robert G. Mugabe, in order to run. Makoni has shown great courage in standing up to Mugabe, Mr. Mutambara told reporters. His backing makes it a three-man race among Mr. Mugabe, seeking a sixth term, Mr. Makoni, and Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the dominant faction of the M.D.C.

title: Gunman Showed Few Hints of Trouble
description: DeKALB, Ill.  Steve Kazmierczak, the man who walked silently into a classroom here on Thursday and opened fire, was not seen as struggling in college. He was not an outcast. And until recently, at least, he was not brooding.

title: Queens Man Arrested in Killing of Therapist
description: The police arrested a Queens man Saturday afternoon in connection with the murder of a psychologist on the Upper East Side, commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said in a news conference at police headquarters.

title: Abortion Law Is Suddenly a Pivotal Issue in Italys Elections
description: ROME  With voting less than two months away, a bitter debate over abortion has unexpectedly flared up, putting the issue at the center of the Italian electoral campaign.

title: Wheres the Beef? PETA Has Sent Treats
description: Roger Clemens has been called a steroid user, a hothead and a liar over the last two months, and he has denied them all.

title: As Kosovo Rebuilds, U.N. Hurries to Return Property
description: GJILAN, Kosovo  The 9-year-old ethnic Albanian boy screamed until he was red in the face, pounding his fists on the door of a small concrete house that only minutes before he had called home.

title: Democrats Look for Way to Avoid Convention Rift
description: Former Vice President Al Gore and a number of other senior Democrats plan to remain neutral for now in the presidential race in part to keep open the option to broker a peaceful resolution to what they fear could be a bitterly divided convention, party officials and aides said Friday.

title: Reyes Happy the Mets Didnt Give Up on Him
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Its one of the tried-and-true realities of life in the Mets clubhouse. Looking for Jos Reyes? Just find the loudest shirt, and there he is.

title: Eritrea: U.N. Protests Thwarting of Peacekeepers
description: In a rare rebuke of an individual nation, the United Nations Security Council strongly condemned Eritrea for obstructing the peacekeeping mission on its disputed border with Ethiopia, and Secretary General Ban Ki-moon demanded an immediate end to what he described as Eritreas threats, seizures of equipment and denial of food and fuel to the 1,200 peacekeepers there. We are in a situation where it is getting harder to stay and harder to leave, and thats untenable, said Jean-Marie Guhenno, the under secretary general for peacekeeping.

title: For a Better E.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: Wars Past and Present, Rockers Evergreen
description: BERLIN  In 1970 the Berlin International Film Festival ground to a halt over a movie about American wartime atrocities. O. K., a film by the German director Michael Verhoeven, dramatized an actual event that had made headlines a few years earlier: the rape and murder of a Vietnamese girl by a group of American soldiers. (The incident later inspired Brian De Palmas Casualties of War.) After the movies premiere, some members of the jury, led by the American director George Stevens, called it incendiary and demanded that it be pulled from the competition. The ensuing uproar  a flurry of protests, resignations and canceled screenings  was enough to shut down the festival.

title: Joyously Leaping From Earthy to Spiritual
description: Ronald K. Browns repertory program, presented at the Joyce Theater on Thursday as an alternative to his evening-length One Shot, is something of a primer to his magnificently textured style, which shifts from earthy, raw-powered movement to jumps that send dancers sailing into the air like spirits. Its the sort of metamorphosis that occurs within a single phrase.

title: Conflict on the Menu
description: New York Citys new rules for menu labels at chain restaurants have set off a food fight among the nations obesity experts.

title: Read Their Lips
description: A year ago, before Barack Obamas prodigious fund-raising powers were clocked in at $1 million a day, the senator made a great show out of raising a good idea: He would take the narrower road of public financing in the general election if he secured the nomination and his opponent did the same. Senator John McCain, then a long shot, agreed. Mr. Obama even secured a ruling from the Federal Election Commission that he could return unused private donations and then accept public financing.

title: Present Perfect
description: Chicago

title: Imprisoned, Rabbi Sues Over Space for Prayer
description: A Hasidic rabbi serving time at a federal penitentiary is suing the Bureau of Prisons to change its policy on where inmates can pray.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about a decision by the owner of the General Motors building in Manhattan to license naming rights for the tower misstated the name of the building where Bloomberg LP has its headquarters. Its official name is 731 Lexington Avenue; it is not named after the company.

title: Presidential Politics and Support for Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday about Russian politics misstated the reason that President Vladimir Putin closed the European University of St. Petersburg. Mr. Putin accused the university of being an agent of foreign meddling. The university did not criticize Mr. Putin.

title: In Calmer Newark, the Unease Persists
description: NEWARK  The police say the streets here are quieter, with less shooting, fewer assaults and no killings since Jan. 13. But J. D. Crowder, whose son was murdered by robbers two years ago, still has trouble believing that anything has changed.

title: A Muslim and a Hindu. Lets Dance.
description: They may not make em like they used to in Hollywood, but sometimes in India they still do. Jodhaa Akbar, a historical romance directed by Ashutosh Gowariker, is filmmaking on the grand scale of Cecil B. DeMille, with romance, stirring battles, a cast of thousands and enough elephants and gold to sink the Titanic.

title: An Auction for Love and for Money
description: A Valentines Day charity auction at Sothebys in New York raised more than $42.5 million to benefit H.I.V./AIDS relief programs in Africa, far above the presale estimate of about $29 million, The Associated Press reported. Organized by Sothebys, Bono, Damien Hirst (whose Where Theres a Will Theres a Way, above, was among the works sold) and the Gagosian Gallery, the event set sale records for 17 artists, including Howard Hodgkin, Marc Quinn and Keith Tyson, and included pieces by Jasper Johns, Jeff Koons and Ed Ruscha. Proceeds will go the United Nations Foundation and will support programs run by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.

title: Wang to Earn $4 Million After Arbitration Loss
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Chien-Ming Wang experienced his first loss since a forgettable postseason Friday when he lost his arbitration case to the Yankees. Wang, who had been seeking $4.6 million this season, will earn $4 million, the amount the Yankees offered him.

title: Unofficial Tallies in City Understated Obama Vote
description: Black voters are heavily represented in the 94th Election District in Harlems 70th Assembly District. Yet according to the unofficial results from the New York Democratic primary last week, not a single vote in the district was cast for Senator Barack Obama.

title: Reforming the Mining Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture in some editions last Saturday with a sports article about Trindon Holliday, a world-class sprinter who plays football at Louisiana State University, was published in error. The photograph, supplied by Getty Images, was of Early Doucet, another player  not Mr. Holliday.

title: Taking Aim at a Disabled Satellite
description: The United States has given a plausible reason for wanting to shoot down an errant spy satellite before it can tumble to Earth and release potentially harmful gas near the impact point. But that hasnt calmed suspicions that what the Bush administration really wants to do is test its capacity for waging anti-satellite warfare.

title: Headlong Rush for All Occasions
description: Joshua Bell, the young violinist, is one of American classical musics continuing success stories. He is everywhere, doing everything, and people want to come and hear him play. Carnegie Halls 2,800 seats looked pretty much filled on Thursday night when he and his regular partner, Jeremy Denk, played a violin and piano recital. There were no surprises on this program of Tartini, Prokofiev, Dvorak and Grieg, but no one seemed to miss having them.

title: Spears's Father in Control
description: A court has ruled that Jamie Spears, the father of Britney Spears, will retain control over her affairs for about three more weeks, Reuters reported. Mr. Spears was granted temporary conservatorship over his daughters affairs two weeks ago when she was in a Los Angeles hospital for psychiatric evaluation. Los Angeles Court Commissioner Reva Goetz has extended that conservatorship, giving Mr. Spears control over her business, finances and some personal affairs until March 10.

title: Congress and Consumer Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Soon to Say Israel Has Won
description: To the Editor:

title: Unanswered Questions Make a Goodbye More Painful
description: Mourners at Kathryn Faugheys wake on Friday afternoon were by turns angry, apprehensive and generally bewildered by the gruesome circumstances of her killing and the fact that it remained unsolved nearly three days after it occurred.

title: Grief and Questions After Deadly Shootings
description: DeKALB, Ill.  The day after five students were gunned down in an afternoon science class on the campus of Northern Illinois University here, survivors struggled to manage their grief as the authorities released more details about the shooting and the gunman.

title: Respond to Todays Column: The Mittification of McCain
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Feb. 16 column.

title: Correction
description: Earlier editions of this article failed to disclose that the author serves as an informal adviser to the Obama campaign.

title: Mister Wonderful
description: I. Mister Wonderful: Conclusion (pdf format) By DANIEL CLOWES  Chapter 1  Chapter 2  Chapter 3  Chapter 4  Chapter 5  Chapter 6  Chapter 7  Chapter 8  Chapter 9  Chapter 10  Chapter 11  Chapter 12  Chapter 13  Chapter 14  Chapter 15  Chapter 16  Chapter 17  Chapter 18  Chapter 18   Interactive Feature: The Visual Language of Graphic Novels  Past Graphic Novels from the Magazine   Watergate Sue    George Sprott (1894-1975)

title: Jozy Altidore: Some Welcome Time Off
description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore, who contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog, is back home in South Florida as the New York Red Bulls wrap up their two-week training session at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. Altidore is resting and preparing for his next trip  to Austria with the club the last week in February.

title: Theme Songs and Others
description: Correction Appended

title: The Early Word: Superdelegate Dilemma
description: There are superdelegates, and then there are super-duper delegates. Well, among the Democrats, theres one. His name is Al Gore. And party leaders wringing their hands over the nomination process are ringing the partys most prominent neutral figure. Don Van Natta Jr. and Jo Becker report:

title: Defining the macroeconomic problem
description: As we debate interest rates, fiscal stimulus and all that, I thought it might be worth backing up to think about what our macroeconomic problem is right now.

title: In Berlin
description: Images from the films and from the red carpet of the Berlin International Film Festival.

title: Why Ovechkin, Lecavalier and Kovalchuk Cant Win
description: Ever wonder why some of those Southeast Division teams are so bad? Why the Capitals, with the great Alex Ovechkin, are sub-.500? Or why Tampa, with the incandescent Vincent Lecavalier and Martin St. Louis, lose more often than they win? And how about Atlanta, with the magical Ilya Kovalchuk? With such great scoring stars, why do these teams have so much trouble winning?

title: The good sense of GP2 in Asia
description: The first few times I heard about the GP2 Asia series, my eyes glazed over. Wasnt one GP2 series enough? (Or maybe even too much?!) Slowly, though, it has begun to break into my conciousness, and I have suddenly seen how interesting and important this series is, maybe even more so than the original GP2 series.

title: Rangers Return From Hiatus, With Shanahan
description: The Rangers strange schedule quirk comes to a close Saturday with a home game against Buffalo after five idle days of watching teams in the Eastern Conference catch up to them and knock them back to ninth place.

title: Round 2 in Wisconsin: Obama Smacks Back
description: Updated How many rounds can the Democratic rivals go before Tuesdays primary in Wisconsin?

title: The Final Word?
description: In what might amount to a final comment on the partisan nature of Wednesdays Congressional hearing, Representative Darrell Issa, a Republican from California, fired back Friday at Henry A. Waxman, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

title: The Station Survivors, 5 Years Later
description: Offers of help to the victims of a fire that killed 100 have all but disappeared.

title: Finding a New Big Name for M.L.S.
description: When the Major League Soccer season begins March 29, there will be four players earning more than the leagues maximum salary of $400,000 and carrying the designated player tag reserved for mostly foreign superstars.

title: Mercury in Fish: Two Views
description: Philippe Grandjean is adjunct professor of environmental health at Harvard Universitys School of Public Health and chairman of the department of environmental medicine at the University of Southern Denmark. Dariush Mozaffarian is assistant professor of epidemiology at the Harvard School of Public Health.

title: Road Trip: Surreal Night
description: FAIRLEE, Vt.  The whole thing played out in fast forward, yet it seemed like slow motion. Down 5 points with less than 30 seconds remaining, Cornell stunned Harvard by rattling off three consecutive baskets to win, 72-71. The surreal finish, however, soon met a harsh reality.

title: Elegy for a Vanishing Pastime
description: When Charles McGrath writes about pond hockey, we listen.

title: How Would Darwin Read?
description: Popular books applying Darwinian logic to everything from religion to dating to dealmaking may fly off the shelves, but attempts to apply evolutionary theory to literary analysis tend to make novelists, English professors and other humanist types break out in hives.

title: Road Trip: Grand Larceny
description: FAIRLEE, Vt. - There are certain moments in sports, indelible times from improbable games that resonate for years. For Cornell, its 72-71 victory at Harvard on Friday night was the type of game that the Big Red players and coaches will talk about long after graduation.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Feb. 16:

title: Girardi Nets Rangers Latest Contract Extension
description: The Rangers announced during the Rangers game against Buffalo that defenseman Dan Girardi had signed a two-year contract extension, prompting the question of when exactly Girardi signed the extension. Between shifts, perhaps?

title: Prologue
description: Welcome back to the Reading Room! So far, weve discussed three works that would be strong contenders for any Great Books survey (you can revisit the conversations by clicking the links at right). This time around, were trying an instant classic.

title: They Leap to Embrace the Unknown
description: The Majlis continues the conversation started by The Timess series Generation Faithful, which began today with Dreams Stifled, Egypts Young Turn to Islamic Fervor. Commenting on the article is Osama Anwar Okasha, a leading Egyptian television script writer responsible for among the most popular Arabic language miniseries. His shows are known for examining a variety of complex social issues in Egypt and across the Arab world. He spoke in Arabic to Mona el-Naggar, a researcher-reporter in The Timess Cairo bureau.

title: What the Generation in Question Thinks
description: The Majlis refers to a group of people sitting down together to talk, informally or formally, or where they meet. These Lede posts continue the conversation about points raised in Generation Faithful, a Times series about Middle Eastern youth. The first article focuses on the Stalled Lives of Egypts young, and the initial Majlis entries are from the staff of The Times Cairo bureau.

title: Dont Worry About Mitt
description: Aired Friday night on CBS: President Bush says if John McCain is the Republican nominee, he will campaign for him. Well, you cant do better than that. Top 10 List.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, Feb. 17
description: Surrogates dominate this Sundays breakfast menu.

title: Close Friends Since the Civil War
description: Aired Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Former President George H.W. Bush will endorse Senator John McCain for president. They have been close friends since the Civil War and the former president says that John McCainis the only candidate who has the strength, the leadership and the vision to dig America out of this giant hole his son has put us in.

title: Same Reason Al Gore Didnt Run for President
description: More of your late night comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: Pinhead or Partiot? Why Cant You Be Both?
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Yesterday appearing on stage together in Boston, Mitt Romney endorsed John McCain. You see that picture? You see him standing there? Looked like the head of Leisure World giving out an award to the senior shuffleboard champion. You know something? I dont think theres been a more uncomfortable embrace between two politicians since the last time Bill hugged Hillary.

title: Literary Evolution
description: There was a time  in distant history to you and me, but to those who lived through that time very much a modern one  when, with nothing more than quill, parchment, gaslight and inkwell, Victorians, as they were called then, who thought themselves clever enough to take up the mighty yoke of language, crafted marvelous, dignified, soaring, melodic sentences that danced about the periphery of comprehension, through the very soul of the English language, down so many twists and turns and inlets and eddies that a reader, inundated by an onslaught of language as such, would be forced to compose himself and begin the tedious, but ultimately rewarding, process of returning to the start of such a sentence and piecing its meaning together word by word, clause by clause, until said reader felt satisfied and knowledgeable of the material written therein.

title: A Sabres Audition That Flops
description: There were roughly a dozen N.H.L. scouts at the Rangers-Sabres game at Madison Square Garden Saturday afternoon and presumably some of them came to watch Sabres defenseman Brian Campbell as the trade deadline approaches.

title: Road Trip: Midnight Run
description: HANOVER, N.H. - The most important person in the Cornell traveling party isnt Coach Steve Donahue, star guard Louis Dale or even the trainer Marc Chamberlain.

title: Road Trip: The Tension Mounts
description: HANOVER, N.H.  Cornell Coach Steve Donahue gathered his team at halfcourt at their afternoon shootaround. His message typified the focused and straightforward demeanor hes held on this weekend road trip.

title: Kitchen Ambition
description: After immigrating to New York at 14, Domingo Torres washed dishes in the East Village. He is now a chef at two of the city's popular Mexican restaurants.

title: Hello Bobby?
description: Kelvin Sampsons troubles at Indiana have been a boon for conspiracy theorists.

title: Road Trip: A Telling Message
description: HANOVER, N.H.  We got to see both sides of Cornell Coach Steve Donahue in the first half, as the Big Red leads by 36-35 at halftime. Donahue left the floor steaming mad after a turnover in the waning seconds allowed Dartmouths DeVon Mosley to bank in a 23-foot 3-pointer at the buzzer to cut the lead to a point.

title: 10 Shots for the Thrashers  in the Entire Game
description: We dont mean to harp endlessly on how bad the Southeast Division is, but tonight the Atlanta Thrashers lost on Long Island, 4-1, giving up 49 shots on goal while managing only 10 shots of their own in the entire game.

title: Huckabees Island Getaway
description: GRAND CAYMAN, Cayman Islands  Mike Huckabee said he was having such a good time here in this sun-splashed tourist resort that it may take a S.W.A.T. team to get him out of his hotel room at the Ritz Carlton and head back to the snowy campaign trail in Wisconsin.

title: Road Trip: On The Road Again
description: HANOVER, N.H.  Theres a strict rule on Cornell road trips: No movies on the team bus after a loss.

title: More Fallout From Scotts Recruitment
