description: The Colorado recruit Darrell Scott and his mother are optimistic that St. Bonaventure High Schools firing of the recruiting coordinator Roger Sonsini will serve as a warning to other high school coaches.

title: How the Guaranteed Point Is Ruining the N.H.L.
description: The NHLs system of awarding points in the standings is weird enough, but now players and coaches are saying its making them take it easy in the third period of close games. Our own Dave Caldwell has the story here.

title: Audiotape in Murder Is Reported as Missing
description: A New York police officer who was translating wiretapped conversations in a case against a Queens doctor charged in the killing of her estranged husband, a dentist, is under investigation because one of the tapes is missing, officials said on Saturday.

title: Correction: Cutting to the Quick
description: The Fair Game column last Sunday, about loan losses at Citibank during the 1990 recession, misstated the history of stock prices for the banks parent, then called Citicorp. The stock traded as low as $11.125 in October 1990, not $1.39. After the Federal Reserve started cutting interest rates, the price rose to $15.625, not $2.50, by March 6, 1991; it climbed to $67.25, not $10, by the end of 1995. (The lower prices were for Travelers, a company that later merged with Citicorp.)

title: A Delicate Market
description: KIRK HENCKELS, the bow-tie-wearing broker serving the rich and would-be rich on the Upper East Side, offered a sobering thought in his latest report on the luxury Manhattan market.

title: Honey-Lacquered | New Places in a Genteel Quarter
description: If youre looking for a hot new restaurant, the East 60s may not spring to mind, but these recently opened places fit this quiet, upscale neighborhood like a satin glove.

title: In the Eye of the Beholder: When a Boom Begins
description: AS Bill Clinton was the first baby boomer president, Barack Obama could be the first Generation X president.

title: Slavery as Seen From the Other Side
description: BIYI BANDELE comes bearing human cargo.

title: I Married a Republican: There, I Said It
description: IT was happening again. I was at a cocktail party where the hosts were people I had just met, people I wanted to become friends with, and was sipping chardonnay and nibbling papadum chips when a woman said, Oh, the people next door! Theyre ..., she paused and lowered her voice,  ... Republican.

title: Stern Says Relocation of Sonics Is an Inevitability
description: NEW ORLEANS  A prolonged legal and political battle to keep the SuperSonics in Seattle is all but over, and the result almost assured: the Sonics will be leaving, and only the timing of their move is in question.

title: Hail, and Welcome
description: The nods towards suburbanization  the kids menu, the addition of gooey brownies and espresso that invite you to linger  are here. But theyre not what you notice right away about Hale and Heartys first foray into the land of strip malls and superstores. And theyre definitely not the first things youre going to appreciate about the Manhattan-based chains Livingston location, which opened Feb. 4 and shares sidewalk space, somewhat unappealingly, with a Mens Wearhouse off Route 10.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 6: All Hands

title: Jitters for First-Time Homebuyers
description: IF there is a bright spot in New York Citys uncertain real estate market, it is that over the last several months, some first-time buyers have found it easier to buy apartments.

title: Anna Kohanski, Jordan Klein
description: Anna Leah Kohanski, the daughter of Cheryl Spielman Bari of Englewood, N.J., and Ronald Kohanski of Columbia, Md., is to be married on Sunday to Jordan Scott Klein, a son of Carol Klein and Dr. Howard Klein, both of Louisville, Ky. Rabbi Irving Spielman, the brides maternal grandfather, will officiate at the Pierre in New York.

title: Urban Gumbo
description: In August 1769, a fleet of 12 Spanish ships carrying 2,000 troops sailed into the port of New Orleans. Alejandro OReilly, a Dublin-born officer of the Spanish military, was sent there to punish the rebellious leaders of a French town that had recently become a property of Spain. Since its founding in 1718, tiny New Orleans had scraped by on tobacco and indigo crops, a profitless outback of the French Empire. In contrast, the island of St. Domingue, with 400,000 slaves, had booming profits in sugar. Louis XV, reeling from wartime losses to Britain, gave Louisianas city to Spain.

title: When Mrs. Robinson Met Dr. Dolittle
description: On July 4, 1965, Jane Fonda and her husband-to-be, Roger Vadim, had a party in their oceanfront home in Malibu and brought together, probably for the first time, old Hollywood and what would come to be known as the new Hollywood. Henry Fonda roasted a pig on one side of the house while the Byrds, hired by his son, Peter, played on the other. The guest list ran from William Wyler and Sam Spiegel to the then barely employed Jack Nicholson and Dennis Hopper. Lucky attendees might have glimpsed Sidney Poitier and Gene Kelly instructing Vadims little girl in tap-dancing, or Darryl Zanuck and George Cukor staring dumbstruck at a barefoot hippie nursing her baby.

title: Letters: Much About History
description: I must take issue with the Ethicists response (Feb. 3) to the professor writing about a doctoral candidate in history who subscribes to the so-called young earth theory.

title: Mexico City Bombers Motive Unclear, Police Say
description: MEXICO CITY  A bomb that exploded Friday near the Mexico City police headquarters was carried by an unidentified man wearing two layers of clothing, the police said Saturday. They said that the man died in the blast and that no evidence had yet been found linking him to a guerrilla group or a drug cartel.

title: Hispanics Fight At-Large Voting System
description: Port Chester

title: The Pyrotechnic Imagination
description: Cai Guo-Qiang says his favorite artistic moment is the pregnant pause between the lighting of the fuse and the detonation of the gunpowder. There is a pressure in it to be preserved, and then it explodes, he says. This moment belongs just to the artist and the work. On a breezy afternoon last September, in a large A-frame shed at the Grucci fireworks plant on Long Island, he was setting the stage. With the help of his wife, Hong Hong Wu, he cut a long green fuse into segments, then laid the pieces carefully on eight contiguous panels of handmade Japanese rice paper.

title: Howard, the Next Big Thing, Still Has Room to Improve
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Eight hours before tipoff last Monday, the coach was calmly detailing how he pushes and prods his budding star, a coltish player with infinite potential, toward becoming the standard by which contemporary N.B.A. big men are measured.

title: Paperback Row
description: CALL ME BY YOUR NAME, by Andr Aciman. (Picador, $14.) In this first novel of adolescent sexual awakening, the precocious 17-year-old son of a wealthy academic falls for an older male graduate student who has come to his fathers well-appointed home on the Italian Riviera. The student is there to revise a manuscript, which, since this is a novel about time and love, is on Heraclitus. Stacey DErasmo, our reviewer, called it an exceptionally beautiful book ... as much a story of paradise found as it is of paradise lost.

title: The Last Man Exits
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Alaska Avalanche Kills 2 Snowmobilers
description: ANCHORAGE (AP)  Two snowmobile drivers were killed Friday when they set off an avalanche in the backcountry near Turnagain Pass, about 70 miles south of here, Alaska state troopers said.

title: The Girl in the Bubble
description: IN the spring of 2004, when my daughter, Hannah, was just shy of 2 years old, she and I walked into a childrens clothing store in Westchester. As we made our way to the back, we came upon two little girls seated in miniature rocking chairs in front of a TV. When we walked up behind them, one of them looked over her shoulder at Hannah and broke into a smile, then exclaimed to her companion: Look! Look! A little girl!

title: Painted Whimsies
description: Though they have sold well and delighted many, the childrens books written and illustrated by Maira Kalman and produced by her husband, the influential designer Tibor Kalman, who died in 1999, have been criticized over the years. Irked reviewers and baffled kids have found them too hip and worldly-wise for humans too young to grasp a reference to, say, Swifty Lazar. In her new book, The Principles of Uncertainty, based on her illustrated blog for The New York Times, Kalman has explicitly concocted what her critics have always accused her of secretly wanting to create: a childrens book for adults.

title: Learning From a Native Speaker, Without Leaving Home
description: THE best way to learn a foreign language may be to surround yourself with native speakers. But if you cant manage a trip abroad the Internet and a broadband computer connection may do the job, too, bringing native speakers within electronic reach for hours of practice.

title: Battlegrounds
description: A million years ago  or before the Iowa caucuses  the Op-Ed page asked several writers to file occasional dispatches describing how the presidential campaign was playing out in their part of the country. Here are their latest reports.

title: The Rising Popularity of Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle Against Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: For Israel, Gaza Offers a Range of Risky Choices
description: JERUSALEM  Israel hoped that by pulling its settlers and troops from Gaza in 2005, it would also leave behind responsibility for the Gazans. With help from the West and some Arab nations, Israelis thought, the Palestinian Authority could begin to create a prosperous state, as if the continuing Israeli occupation of the West Bank were somehow irrelevant.

title: Whats Your Poison?
description: To the Editor:

title: At War With the Train Whistle
description: WHEN Robert and Kristin Schmid finally found a house they could afford after a long and frustrating search, they were ecstatic. For $474,000, they bought what they believed was their dream house, complete with a backyard and plenty of room for a family someday.

title: Correction: Hey, Massachusetts, New Jersey Is Passing on the Left
description: An article last Sunday about the trend in New Jersey toward more liberal policies referred imprecisely to measures passed in the states capital, Trenton, and in Maryland that address the allocation of electoral votes in the presidential election. The measures would deliver the states entire allocation to the winner of the national popular vote if enough states  those with a majority of votes in the Electoral College  agreed to do the same. The measures do not take effect unilaterally.

title: Drivers to Watch
description: Jimmie Johnson

title: Master Builders of Ballets Future
description: BY the end of the last century ballet was looking more like a museum art than it had in more than 400 years. With the deaths of George Balanchine, Antony Tudor, Frederick Ashton, Kenneth MacMillan and Jerome Robbins, the ranks of world-class choreographers specializing in ballet looked thin or just empty. The three biggest names creating new ballets were Twyla Tharp, William Forsythe and Mark Morris: each, by ballet standards, in some way controversial and offbeat.

title: Bookshelf
description: WHO WAS FIRST? DISCOVERING THE AMERICAS By Russell Freedman. Illustrated. Clarion. $19. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: Perks: Upping the Ante Onboard
description: As cruise lines look to outdo one another when it comes to onboard amenities, the cruise experience is increasingly one that rivals a vacation back on land, with everything from water parks to elaborate spas becoming almost standard features. Here are some of the newest offerings by major cruise lines.

title: Correction: Pulse
description: An entry on the Pulse page last Sunday about Stella McCartney lingerie omitted the first sentence in a description of the bra and panties. It should have read: The Stella McCartney woman tends to let her flirty, feminine side peek out from under sharp-shouldered jackets.

title: Doctor Is Charged in a Killing, and Her People Bear the Shame
description: Dr. Daniel Malakovs name is still on the placard that hangs outside his office in Rego Park, Queens, even though he was killed three and a half months ago, and even though another orthodontist now works there in his stead.

title: Whom Do You Believe, G.P.S. or Your Own Eyes?
description: BEDFORD HILLS

title: In France, the Heads No Longer Roll
description: PARIS  OF all the clubs in the world, the Club of 100 in France may be the most exclusive. Its ranks include leaders in business, politics and law, but its the admission policy that really makes the Club des Cent, as it is known here, truly remarkable: only when an existing member dies is space made for a new one.

title: When Stock Meant Stock
description: WHEN the field takes the green flag for the start of the Daytona 500 on Sunday, Nascars departure from its stock car roots (not to mention its name) will be complete.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies of Arts & Leisure this weekend about the state of public broadcasting misspells the surname of a host whose show is distributed by Public Radio International. He is Kurt Andersen, not Anderson. (Go to Article)

title: A Wedge Turns Dull
description: Kansas City, Mo.

title: Helene Yan and Brian Yee
description: Helene Yilin Yan and Maj. Brian Kendall Yee are to be married on Sunday on Smathers Beach in Key West, Fla. Sharon Estenoz, a Florida notary public, is to officiate.

title: McCain Draws Criticism on Torture Bill
description: Senator John McCains vote last week against a bill to curtail the Central Intelligence Agencys use of harsh interrogation tactics disappointed human rights advocates who consider him an ally and led Democrats to charge that he was trying to please Republicans as he seeks to rally them around his presidential bid.

title: Correction: New Rules Ease the Sting of Mortgages
description: An article last Sunday in the special Your Taxes report about tips for preparing a tax return referred incompletely to the limit on claims for refundable alternative minimum tax credits resulting from the exercise of incentive stock options. While it is $5,000 under one calculation method, some taxpayers may claim more than that under a second method if their income is not too high.

title: Show Me the Delegate Rules and Ill Show You the Party
description: WASHINGTON

title: Taste Schmaste! This Is for a Diva
description: IT has been four years since Bette Midler last had her way with a stage in the United States. On Wednesday, when she opens at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas with The Showgirl Must Go On, the stage will reflect this pop divas reputation for extravagance. Over a year in the making, the set has components that were constructed in Los Angeles, New Jersey and New York before being shipped to Las Vegas, including three 45-foot-tall trees and curtains created out of hundreds of thousands of individually painted gold coins.

title: General Motors Raids the Pantry and Bakes a Prize
description: IT seems unreal to be considering the Chevrolet Malibu as an alternative to such world-class cars as the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry, but it has happened. General Motors has finally delivered the first-class midsize sedan it promised for years if not decades.

title: The Green Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Pack Light or Pay Up: 2 Airlines Add Charges
description: Heavy packers might want to reconsider what theyre bringing if theyre flying on United (www.united.com). Earlier this month, United announced that free bag check-in will be limited to one per person. Starting May 5, it will charge passengers with domestic nonrefundable economy tickets $25 to check a second bag. Exempt from the fee are those with Premier status or higher in Uniteds Mileage Plus program or those with Silver status or higher within the Star Alliance. The new charge will be applied to tickets purchased on or after Feb. 4.

title: For Students Problems, Some Legal Advice
description: BRIDGEPORT

title: 8 People Are Killed at Site of an Illegal Road Race
description: ACCOKEEK, Md.  A car crashed into a group of people watching an illegal street race staged here in the early morning hours on a dark highway Saturday, killing eight people and leaving five hospitalized.

title: That Newfangled Light Bulb
description: Across the world, consumers are being urged to stop buying outdated incandescent light bulbs and switch to new spiral fluorescent bulbs, which use about 25 percent of the energy and last 10 times longer. In Britain, there is a Ban the Bulb movement. China is encouraging the change. And the United States Congress has set new energy efficiency standards that will make Edisons magical invention obsolete by the year 2014.

title: Datebook
description: FLORENCE

title: When There Is No We in Marriage
description: AT many weddings, the officiant talks about how a husband and wife should be like two pillars on a porch: separate but together. In their marriage, Jennifer Belle, a novelist, and Andrew Krents, an entertainment lawyer, take the separation part to the extreme. It is almost as if they are afraid of spending too much time together.

title: Correction: The Greenback Is Losing Global Appeal
description: Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on Feb. 3, about the weakened dollar, misstated the value of the Indian rupee. There are 39 rupees to the dollar, not 29.74.

title: Someone to Speak for Borrowers in Trouble
description: NEWARK

title: Santanas Here, and Mets Are Team to Beat
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The most amazing thing happened Saturday morning. Sitting on a stool in front of his locker, Johan Santana stuck his right leg into his baseball pants, then his left, and pulled them up. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, it is true: Santana does, in fact, put his pants on one leg at a time. Here is more bad news: Santana practiced looking runners back to second base. It is, alas, possible that someone gets that far against him this season.

title: Potential Buyers Serenaded
description: YOU never know what a broker is going to find when showing a Manhattan apartment.

title: For Patients, More Comfort and a Bigger Dose of Respect
description: Mount Kisco

title: Where You Going With That Monet?
description: THE plots of art heist movies are about as multifarious as the canvases of the paintings pilfered by their main characters  the postmodern heroin-cool of Nick Nolte in The Good Thief; the playboy-billionaire boredom of Pierce Brosnan in The Thomas Crown Affair. But one thing art theft movies tend to have in common is that they dwell on the heist and not on the aftermath, for reasons that are probably more than cinematic: art is an exceedingly dumb thing to steal.

title: The Doctors Are In. The Jury Is Out.
description: THREE articles in The Times last month raised an intriguing question: When does fairness demand that a newspaper walk down the middle in a scientific dispute, and when does responsibility demand that it take sides?

title: Despite the Wig, a Bronx Boy at Heart
description: I GREW up in the rough-and-tumble Morrisania section of the East Bronx. Im not sure when Morrisanias gangs began, but they were already there during the Revolutionary War.

title: Daniella Giraldi, Kevin Prussia
description: Daniella Yetta Gioconda Giraldi, a daughter of Dr. Ernest Giraldi Jr. of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Gloria Isaacs Giraldi, is to be married on Sunday to Kevin Scott Prussia, the son of Valerie Mair and Bevin Prussia, both of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Ian Adler is to include Jewish and Methodist elements in a ceremony at La Valencia Hotel in La Jolla.

title: Paradise of Lies
description: My mother ran away to Montreal shortly after my birth and left me behind in Jamaica. And the wealthy Chinese man from Montego Bay  whose name she gave me  denied he ever had any relations with her. I grew up with relatives, knowing I wasnt like everybody else.

title: A Greek Temple Dedicated to Art and Learning
description: THE giant blocky temple at 30th Street and Lexington Avenue is silent and cold now, over a year after Touro College sold it to an investor. Built in 1908 as the New York School of Applied Design for Women, this striking super-Classical building, an early work of Harvey Wiley Corbett, a visionary skyscraper architect, stands as an unusual counterpoint to his soaring towers.

title: Out of Office, Will He Be Out of Sorts?
description: He would immediately find himself in the upper echelons of private philanthropy, with the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and the J. Paul Getty Trust.

title: Greek Favorites, on a Simple Scale
description: HUNKERED down along Route 9 South, My Little Fat Greek Restaurant in Freehold occupies a building that brings to mind manufactured housing. The interior could have easily felt the same, but the tables are clothed in white, and the ceiling is festooned with strands of holiday lights that create a soft, sweet glow. A small waterfall divides the dining room and functions as a wind block as well, which is handy since theres no vestibule between diners and the wintry blast that accompanies every opening of the door.

title: Hawaii Budget Choices
description: To the Editor: In "Hawaii on a Dime" (Jan. 27), the couple missed a big chance to economize by not looking for places to stay, and go, on the eastern side of each island, which are generally more budget-friendly than the western sides.

title: Wash, Spin, Dry, Gone
description: ALBERT BENNETT has lived for 52 years on the same block of Morton Street between Hudson and Bedford Streets, and like a lot of residents of Greenwich Village, he has a clear mental map of the area, both as it is and as it used to be.

title: As Nuclear Waste Languishes, Expense to U.S. Rises
description: WASHINGTON  Forgotten but not gone, the waste from more than 100 nuclear reactors that the federal government was supposed to start accepting for burial 10 years ago is still at the reactor sites, at least 20 years behind schedule. But it is making itself felt in the federal budget.

title: With Nuevo Comfort Food, Who Needs Pricey Cuisine?
description: NORWALK

title: Obama Adding Detail to His Oratory
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis.  If he does say so himself, Senator Barack Obama delivers a fine political speech.

title: There Will Be Memories
description: THE Academy Awards may have been around for 80 years now, but, as Suzanne Stone Maretto (Nicole Kidman) in To Die For (1995) might have told you, if it wasnt on television, it didnt really happen. So an equally important anniversary is that of the Oscar broadcast. The ceremony was first shown on television in March 1953. (Above, Bob Hope was the host for that ceremony.) And it should go on (thank you, Writers Guild of America) for the 56th time next Sunday broadcast on ABC from the Kodak Theater in Hollywood with Jon Stewart as host.

title: Syracuse Holds On to Early Lead and Beats Georgetown
description: SYRACUSE  With eight minutes left and Syracuse comfortably ahead of Georgetown, the manager of the Carrier Dome came tapping on the shoulders of the reporters seated by the court.

title: Correction: Lenders Who Sold and Left
description: The Fair Game column on Feb. 3, about problems at mortgage lenders, misstated the circumstances surrounding a bankruptcy filing related to the home mortgage lending unit of NovaStar Financial. An involuntary petition to force the unit into bankruptcy was filed with the court on Jan. 24 by a creditor who won a $49 million judgment against the unit; the unit did not file for bankruptcy. (On Feb. 7, the judge overseeing the case ruled against the petition.)

title: Deborah LaCoy, Jeffrey Dine
description: Deborah LaCoy and Jeffrey Malcolm Dine are to be married on Sunday at the Lotos Club in New York. Rabbi Jack Bemporad is to officiate.

title: Speech on the Mideast Brings Opinions to a Boil
description: Greenwich, Conn.

title: Dream Logic
description: We poets in our youth begin in gladness, wrote Wordsworth, who might have felt otherwise had he spent his own youth as an adjunct assistant professor of creative writing. If hed done so, as many younger writers do nowadays, hed probably have thought twice about pairing gladness with a job that often involves $50,000 in student loans and no health insurance. To be fair, its never been easy to be a young poet, and teaching creative writing is certainly safer than working as a roofer. Yet because most are neither wealthy (like the young James Merrill) nor constantly in jeopardy (like Villon), writers in their early careers today face a peculiar and sometimes unenviable set of circumstances. On the one hand, the proliferation of M.F.A. programs gives a poet the chance to make a sort-of living from his art; on the other hand, the insularity of that world can tax both an artists social skills and his resistance to fashion. Given these difficulties, its tempting to replace Wordsworths salute to youthful vitality with the 29-year-old Bon Scotts less optimistic observation: If you wanna be a star of stage and screen / Look out, its rough and mean.

title: Playing With Fire
description: Our small community of perhaps 60 homes lacks adequate fire protection. Equipment could arrive within 45 minutes, so some feel we should purchase our own. Only 15 homeowners have agreed to this. Should the need arise, must we provide this equipment to those who did not share in its purchase?  NAME WITHHELD, BAHAMAS

title: Democratic Candidates Emphasize Need for Unity
description: MILWAUKEE  After days of battling each other in tit-for-tat television advertisements ahead of the Wisconsin primary, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama on Saturday night cooled their rhetoric and reminded Democrats of their fight ahead.

title: A Cure for the Winter Doldrums
description: ON a recent gray day at the Long Island Childrens Museum in Garden City, 4-year-old Justin Lee of Plainview was standing in front of a waist-high microphone, tapping on his stomach. With an amplified thump, he played along with a video of the Blue Man Groups Belly Drum Song on the monitor in front of him.

title: Breathing Room Gone, Mickelson Maintains Lead
description: LOS ANGELES  Phil Mickelson holed a critical 7-foot putt for par on the final hole Saturday to cling to a one-stroke lead over Jeff Quinney at the Northern Trust Open at Riviera Country Club, moving a step closer to winning the West Coast tournament that has eluded him.

title: Sometimes, the Real Stars Are Off the Court
description: Kathy and David Henry spent Valentines Day with the love of their lives  basketball.

title: Questions, Not Just on Iraq
description: How the next president plans to handle the disastrous Iraq war is the most important foreign policy question of this years campaign. But it is not the only foreign policy question that voters need answered.

title: Thats Not Old Stuff. Thats My Past.
description: AS a child, I dreamed of living in a one-room cottage deep in a fairy-tale forest. There I would have one bed, one chair and one table, one broom to sweep with and a wardrobe of two simple dresses. Obviously, I was already trying to conquer clutter and dodge the storage solution.

title: Baba Amte, 93, Dies; Advocate for Lepers
description: Baba Amte, a follower of Gandhi whose dedication to helping the lepers of India brought him the Templeton Prize and many other international awards, died on Feb. 9 at his shelter for leprosy patients in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. He was 93.

title: Excerpts of an Interview With Sheila Frazier
description: Sheila Frazier is a star of the 1972 film Super Fly. Her marriage to John Atchison is featured in Vows this week. She discussed how her acting career came about with the columns author, Devan Sipher.

title: Musical Marriages, Made by Design
description: JAY ANTHONY GACH, a 52-year-old composer who lives in Long Beach, admits he was a little on edge last month when he first met Soo Bae, a young cellist for whom he had just recently finished writing a piece.

title: Religion and Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracy Spitzberg, Marc Shedroff
description: Tracy Anne Spitzberg, the daughter of Alicia D. Leff of San Antonio and Larry A. Spitzberg of Houston, is to be married Sunday to Marc Daniel Shedroff, a son of Elissa S. Shedroff and Steven H. Shedroff of Allentown, Pa. Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl will officiate at the Westin Riverwalk Hotel in San Antonio.

title: Letters
description: A Farewell to Paper?

title: The Paranoiac and The Paris Review
description: When he died at 66 in 1992, Harold L. Humes had spent decades talking to himself, and to anyone else who would listen. Since the early 70s, Humes  a bearded, generally benevolent figure, his mind ravaged yet not entirely destroyed by mental illness  had been a fixture around Harvard and Columbia, a self-appointed freelance professor entrancing acolytes with his theories on vast government conspiracies, the benefits of cannabis, the shape of clouds.

title: An Iranian Magazine, Silenced
description: To the Editor:

title: Midwest Mex
description: Biggest home-chef mistakes: They dont cook over high enough heat, and they dont salt enough.

title: Keep It Simple, Says Yales Top Investor
description: IT has been a time to worry even the savviest investors. The credit markets have been in a crisis, the domestic stock market has been shaky and overseas markets havent been much better.

title: At Duke, Mentor Is the Message
description: DURHAM, N.C. (AP)  Johnny Dawkins did everything Mike Krzyzewski asked as an all-American player at Duke. But after years of taking direction, Dawkins felt odd speaking his mind as a new assistant when asked by his mentor for advice.

title: Letters: A Statesman Without Borders
description: In his excellent article on Bernard Kouchner, James Traub (Feb. 3) attributes the aphorism pessimism of the intelligence, optimism of the will to Antonio Gramsci. This beautiful phrase actually comes from Romain Rolland, the French Nobel Prize-winning novelist, playwright and intellectual. Gramsci borrowed the line as the motto of his newspaper, LOrdine Nuovo, appreciating its condensation of the revolutionary socialist process and the role of the radical intellectual. Kouchner is more Rollandist than Gramscian, especially given his critique of authoritarianism and blindness of the left.

title: When God and the Law Dont Square
description: A PRETTY good way to generate an outcry, as the archbishop of Canterbury learned in Britain recently, is to say that a Western legal system should make room for Shariah, or Islamic law. When the archbishop, spiritual leader of the worlds 80 million Anglicans, commented in a radio interview that such an accommodation was unavoidable, critics conjured images of stonings and maimings, overwhelming his more modest point.

title: F.B.I. Gained Unauthorized Access to E-Mail
description: WASHINGTON  A technical glitch gave the F.B.I. access to the e-mail messages from an entire computer network  perhaps hundreds of accounts or more  instead of simply the lone e-mail address that was approved by a secret intelligence court as part of a national security investigation, according to an internal report of the 2006 episode.

title: Up All Night
description: I was never an easy sleeper. On restless childhood nights, I played a game: first I imagined a birds-eye view of the bed where I lay awake, then let the lens pull back to reveal the rooftop of my familys house, then our town from above, then the silhouette of New Jersey, then America, and finally the whole world.

title: For Disabled Hunters, Sport Goes On
description: RINGOES, N.J.

title: Saving the V-8 by Turning It Inside Out
description: LAST December, after President Bush signed a 35-mile-a-gallon-fuel economy standard into law, General Motors quickly shelved a new V-8 it was designing to replace Cadillacs long-serving Northstar engine. The timing of these developments prompted a flurry of obituaries for V-8 engines, a breed with a reputation for speed, power  and lately, environmental insolence.

title: Katharine Kolb, Thomas Brennan
description: Katharine Yvonnet Kolb and Thomas Mark Brennan were married on Saturday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Newburyport, Mass. The Rev. Marc Pich, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: An Imaginary Friend
description: Ever since Sherman McCoys boating moccasins touched down on Park Avenue 20 years ago, readers have been offered plenty of fictional opportunities to eavesdrop on the residents of the Upper East Side of Manhattan  via their lovers, their kids teachers, their oppressed editorial assistants. Inevitably, the critics complain that this new ZIP code 10021 genre cant stand up to the past work of Edith Wharton, Truman Capote and Louis Auchincloss, or to Tom Wolfes Bonfire of the Vanities. Wharton herself frowned on employing her own tribe as protagonists, noting in her autobiography, A Backward Glance, that the group in which I grew up was like an empty vessel into which no new wine would ever again be poured.

title: Correction: A Statesman Without Borders
description: An article on Feb. 3 about Bernard Kouchner, the foreign minister of France, referred incorrectly to the Charles De Gaulle, a ship that Kouchner mentioned while speaking about Frances relations with Russia. It is an aircraft carrier, not a battleship.

title: Correction: 16 Ways of Looking at a Female Voter
description: An article on Feb. 3 about womens voting patterns misidentified the legislative body of which James W. Wadsworth Jr., whom the New York League of Women Voters tried to unseat in 1920, was a member. It was the United States Senate, not the New York State Senate.

title: Syracuse Holds On to Early Lead and Beats Georgetown
description: SYRACUSE  With eight minutes remaining in Saturdays mens basketball game between Syracuse and Georgetown, the manager of the Carrier Dome came tapping on the shoulders of all the reporters on press row.

title: Two Paths for the Aspiring Alpha Female
description: IN the 1964 film My Fair Lady, Prof. Henry Higgins, played by Rex Harrison, famously asked, Why cant a woman be more like a man? The subtexts of two new books that aim to guide women through the worlds of commerce and finance pose a strikingly similar question  Why cant a businesswoman be more like a businessman?  and come up with strikingly different answers.

title: From Dancehall Rapper to Nursery Rhymer
description: IF youve never heard of Father Goose, just ask a kid. As part of the eclectic family music ensemble Dan Zanes & Friends, Father Goose, a k a Wayne Rhoden, is the boisterous, big-bellied Jamaican guy who routinely steals the show with his gruff renditions of Georgie Porgie and the Hokey Pokey.

title: Seeing the Sights, Ditching the Shipmates
description: AFTER standing in line for the buffet, staking out a lounge chair on the sun deck and squeezing into the hot tub with total strangers, you might be forgiven for dreading the cruise excursion, which typically involves hundreds of passengers piling into little boats to go ashore, queuing up for a bus to take you to the standard tourist sites and straining to hear the guide rattle off some rote facts.

title: Citizenship Blues
description: Three bits of news from the first two months of 2008 highlight the galling inconsistency and inadequacy of the federal governments system for turning immigrants into citizens.

title: Shes Got Grand Plans for the Future of the Islip Airport
description: Ronkonkoma

title: Puerto Ricos Second City Steps Out
description: RENO has Las Vegas. Thessaloniki has Athens. And Ponce has San Juan.

title: A Fiesta Thats Fit for 20
description: The only thing missing from the enthusiastic South of the Border dcor at Burrito Loco in Commack is a piata.

title: 007 Might Drink Here
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Alicia Hirsch, Seth Resnick
description: Alicia Michelle Hirsch and Seth Alexander Resnick were married on Saturday evening at Capitale, an events space in New York. Rabbi Daniel Alder officiated.

title: Miracle Workers?
description: Even today, in our high-tech, accountability-obsessed and, supposedly at least, patient-empowered times, the oldest of all relations between patient and physician  that of supplicant to shaman  continues to exert its authority. This may not seem sensible if the only valid criterion for judging the doctor-patient relationship is the use that is made of scientific data and clinical findings. But good doctors want to treat their patients, not just their patients diseases, and certainly most patients want to be treated as human beings, not cases. Viewed from that perspective, the elevated expectations patients bring to the consulting room may be for the best.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Music and Dance

title: A Wonderful Town, but Hes Moving On
description: Jonathan M. Tisch, co-owner of the New York Giants and chairman and C.E.O. of Loews Hotels, is giving up one of his many extracurricular activities: his post as chairman of NYC & Company, New Yorks tourism marketing organization.

title: Old Clinton Ties and Voters Sway Tug at Delegates
description: WASHINGTON  The dwindling group of elected officials and party leaders publicly undecided in the Democratic presidential contest  about 300 out of the 795 so-called superdelegates who may determine the partys nominee  includes at least 30 who have a long and often personal history with the Clinton family.

title: Therapist Remembered as One Who Refreshed the Broken
description: Much of the later part of Kathryn Faugheys life was contained on this block of East 79th Street between First and York Avenues. It was where she shared a top-floor apartment with her husband, bought flowers on the corner on special occasions and listened to her patients as they shared their troubles. And it was where her funeral Mass was held on Saturday  at a church steps away from where she was killed on Tuesday.

title: Interactive Theater: The Acting Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Christine Pelosi, Peter Kaufman
description: Christine Pelosi, a daughter of Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Paul F. Pelosi of San Francisco and Washington, was married in San Francisco on Saturday evening to Peter Kaufman, the son of Rose Kaufman and the film director Philip Kaufman of San Francisco. Representative Anna G. Eshoo, Democrat of California, officiated at the St. Francis Hotel.

title: Nikolaj Hbbe: He Seems Underwhelmed
description: To the Editor:

title: Kazin and the Mind Behind Each Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Ink Before You Vote
description: Chillicothe, Ohio

title: Cabinets of Wonder
description: My friend was recovering from surgery. The tumor was entirely benign. The doctor says its just a dermoid cyst, she said. A what? We paused, as realization dawned. We had it: our search term. As any hypochondriac knows, a fresh new word from a doctor can set off a daylong orgy of medical Googling.

title: The Executioner Waits
description: Imre Kertesz, who in 2002 was the first Hungarian to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, once said, When I am thinking about a novel, I always think of Auschwitz. One is also always thinking about Auschwitz when reading his novels, as the best-known of them form a loose tetralogy that give a fictionalized account of Kerteszs own experience of the war. His unnerving 1975 debut, Fatelessness, recounts the story of a child deported to Auschwitz  and later Buchenwald and Zeitz. The subsequent volumes (Fiasco, Kaddish for an Unborn Child and Liquidation) portray him as an adult trying to make sense of his wartime experience through literature.

title: Is PBS Still Necessary?
description: FOR the eighth straight year the Bush administration has ritually proposed taking a hefty whack out of the federal subsidy for public broadcasting. The cuts would in effect slice in half the money that public television and public radio get from the government. If we follow the usual script, this means its time for upset listeners and viewers to rally to the cause, as they have in the past, and browbeat Congress into restoring the budget.

title: Letters: Back-Room Choices
description: As an example of how fluid the nominating process has become, Matt Bai (Feb. 3) cites the failure of the Culinary Workers Union to deliver its members to Barack Obama in Nevada. Even union workers, Bai writes, once considered a monolithic bloc, no longer blindly follow their leaders dictates.

title: Ah, the Pothole Senator. Wait! The Flags Wrong!
description: CENTRAL ISLIP

title: Editors Choice
description: A BOUND MAN: Why We Are Excited About Obama and Why He Cant Win, by Shelby Steele. (Free Press, $22.) Personal motivation seems to lie behind this account, in which Steele comes across as far more fascinating than what he has to say about the candidate.

title: Clemens Pays Price for Reputation That Is Soiled
description: What did Roger Clemens know, and when did he know it? To hear Clemens at last weeks hearing before the House oversight committee, he never knew anything. No one told him he was facing allegations that he had used performance-enhancing substances, not his long-time agent and lawyer, not the players association, not the commissioner, not George J. Mitchell.

title: They Lost It at the Movies
description: CHARLTON HESTON, dressed for disaster in a tight-fitting lemon sweater in Airport 1975, may have been making a fashion statement 33 years ago as he rescued a 747 that had been rendered pilotless. But the actors appearance drew a very different interpretation from the Thursday night crowd at Clearview Chelsea Cinemas.

title: Events on Long Island
description: FILM

title: Correction: Review of The Cure Within
description: A review on Jan. 27 about The Cure Within, by Anne Harrington, misstated the publishing status of a follow-up study on some 1989 breast-cancer research by the psychiatrist David Spiegel. The follow-up results have in fact been released, last year in the medical journal Cancer.

title: Correction: A More Intimate Grand Bazaar
description: The Day Out column on Feb. 10, about the Cukurcuma antiques district in Istanbul, included an incorrect street number for a textiles shop, Leyla Seyhanli. It is at Altipatlar Sokak 6, not No. 19.

title: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.: St. Regis Resort
description: THE BASICS

title: Dress-Up for Dollars
description: Stardoll

title: Notes on Camp
description: It is 1936, and we are in the Adirondacks, at a party at a luxurious camp on a vast private reserve. (Camp is a local upper-caste understatement, comparable to the use of cottage in Newport, R.I.) As the sun begins to dip behind the mountain range that dominates the horizon, a beautiful young woman detaches herself from her elders and walks barefoot to the shore of the lake. Suddenly a seaplane appears in the air and all look on, stunned, as it lands on the surface of the water. Such a thing has never before occurred, and furthermore is taboo under the largely unspoken laws of the reserve. A dashing aviator  we will discover that he is a famous artist, a radical, a free spirit  steps out of the plane and locks eyes with the glamorous yet troubled young woman.

title: Old-Timers Get Their Due
description: MANUFACTURERS of die-cast models of stock cars tend to move as fast as the real cars that will hurtle around the Daytona International Speedway on Sunday. In pit-stop time, a die-cast model usually goes on sale right after a Nascar driver unveils a new sponsor or paint job.

title: A Different Recollection
description: To the Editor:

title: Art and Life, Steeping in a Teapot
description: FRITZ HAEG is not the best-known artist in the Whitney Biennial, opening next month. He has not had a breakout solo show at the Zach Feuer Gallery. He is not being wooed by Larry Gagosian. His prices at auction are nonexistent.

title: In Hotel Design, Hes Mr. Prolific
description: IN his SoHo office, the architect Gene Kaufman is presenting drawings of his latest buildings.

title: Slow Food
description: Its no longer safe to assume that the winter will be cold, but February Sundays still have a cozy dreariness that carbon emissions have yet to thaw. What nicer day to spend the afternoon simmering a meaty rag that will taste even better the following week? It will also freeze beautifully for that freak blizzard in April.

title: Silicon Valley Starts to Turn Its Face to the Sun
description: CAN Silicon Valley become a world leader in cheap and ubiquitous solar panels for the masses?

title: The Worlds Worst Panderer
description: Even for those of us who shudder at many of John McCains positions, there is something refreshing about a man who wins so many votes despite a major political shortcoming: he is abysmal at pandering.

title: Neighbor vs. Neighbor
description: IMAGINE a letter slipped under an apartment door, and then a warning of a lawsuit in the offing: As you may not be aware, we are both lawyers and both litigators, for whom the usual barriers to litigation are minimal.

title: Arcane Market Is Next to Face Big Credit Test
description: Few Americans have heard of credit default swaps, arcane financial instruments invented by Wall Street about a decade ago. But if the economy keeps slowing, credit default swaps, like subprime mortgages, may become a household term.

title: Bush, in Africa, Emphasizes Successes Over Conflicts
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  As violence in Africa threatened to overshadow his six-day tour of the continent, President Bush on Saturday defended his decision not to visit strife-torn nations like Kenya and Sudan, saying he wanted to focus instead on successes like his programs to fight AIDS and malaria.

title: In New Rochelle, a Waterfront Plan Starts to Unfold
description: THOUGH at least several years and a host of bureaucratic hurdles from fruition, a plan to transform New Rochelles deteriorated Echo Bay waterfront into a vibrant neighborhood has been proposed, and the mayor calls it one of the most significant prospects in the citys history.

title: Correction: Which Worksheet Is for the Away Games?
description: An article last Sunday in the special Your Taxes report, about income taxes that must be paid by athletes who travel out of state, misstated the estimated New York tax liability of a hypothetical Boston Red Sox player making $20 million a year who appeared in nine games at Yankee Stadium. It would be about $60,000, not $100,000. (While such a player would be liable for New York State taxes, there would be no New York City tax due.)

title: Bright Lights in the Wee Hours
description: IT is 2 a.m., and Eighth Avenue, the main drag of Sunset Park, Brooklyn, is eerily silent and deserted. The fishmongers and mushroom sellers have long since packed up their wares. All that is left from the days bustle are crushed produce boxes, pungent with the remains of unsold fruits and vegetables, stacked neatly along the curb.

title: Historic Area, Great Shopping
description: LIKE a perfectly formed tic-tac-toe board, the quaint streets that straddle three of Amsterdams grandest canals form the citys most quirky neighborhood: the Nine Streets, or Negen Straatjes (www.theninestreets.com). In the heart of the western canal belt, only a few minutes walk from the Royal Palace in Dam Square, the Nine Streets  easily Amsterdams best shopping hub  is a charming mixture of designer boutiques, art galleries, vintage clothing stores, hair salons, gift shops and places to eat and drink.

title: No D.I.Y. Rent Laws, Court of Appeals Rules
description: A RULING by the New York Court of Appeals, the states highest court, underscores in no uncertain terms that tenants and landlords cannot write their own version of the rent-stabilization laws.

title: Elegy for a Vanishing Pastime
description: IN the New England of my youth, back when we still had winter, ice  the kind you skate on  was as reliable as the calendar. It usually turned up overnight, smooth and glistening, the week after Thanksgiving, and it lasted, with perhaps a minor thaw or two, until Washingtons Birthday at least. What you did every day back then was skate  which is to say, play hockey. After school, your mom dropped you off at the pond, the lake, the frozen river, the flooded playground, and she picked you up when it was dark. On Saturdays she made you a baloney sandwich to take along, but by the time you remembered to eat it, it was frozen hard as a puck.

title: Minority Rules
description: Walking through the Sur district of Diyarbakir with Abdullah Demirbas was like taking an old-fashioned mayoral stroll. As the day got under way in one of the largest cities in southeastern Turkey, Demirbas passed through the narrow stone alleys, and one by one, shopkeepers stepped outside and waved. In return, Demirbas patted his chest and called out loud greetings. He stopped to compliment a cafe owners new door frames, asked a trio of women if they were satisfied with the trash collection and teased some kids about getting to school on time. Demirbas addressed most of the locals in Kurdish, his native language, but every now and then he switched to Turkish. When I asked him why, he said he has known all his constituents long enough to remember which language each speaks.

title: With Big Finish, Charity Drive Tops Last Years
description: On Friday, Feb. 8, the last day of the 96th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign, contributions had totaled $7,635,259. That was nearly $4,000 lower than the amount raised the previous year.

title: The Short Sale Gains in Allure
description: EARLIER this month, Asaf German, a real estate lawyer, closed a deal in Oceanside in which a homeowner who had paid $700,000 for a house two years ago now agreed to sell it for $465,000. Yet somehow, as Mr. German put it, it was a win-win; the deal helped everyone involved.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washingtons Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: Amanda Bell, David Alfred
description: Amanda Robin Bell, a daughter of Alice Bell and Eugene Bell of Syosset, N.Y., was married last evening to David Alfred, a son of Lawrence Alfred of Albany and the late Risa Alfred. Rabbi Scott L. Shpeen officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.

title: In a Sultanate Known as Solo, One Too Many Kings
description: SOLO, Indonesia  Pop quiz: How many kings are there now in the ancient sultanate of Surakarta?

title: Working to Dissipate a Cloud Over Cycling
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Professional cycling is beginning its new season about where it finished the last one, with the consequences of the use of performance-enhancing drugs casting a broad shadow over the sport.

title: Wanting the Ball One Hearing Too Many
description: VERO BEACH, Fla.

title: Forget Caps and Gowns, Try White Dresses and Bouquets
description: Bronxville

title: Playing It Safe for a Bonus Point in the N.H.L.
description: The N.H.L. does not hand out points like frequent-flier miles. The winner of a regular-season game gets only 2 points, no matter how lopsided the final score or how many rounds of a shootout it takes.

title: Jennifer Abrams, David Stier
description: Jennifer Melinda Abrams, a daughter of Judith I. Abrams and Stephen N. Abrams of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday to David Aaron Stier, a son of Francine H. Stier and Dr. Steven A. Stier of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Jim Rosen officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Washington.

title: Someone to Speak for Borrowers in Trouble
description: AS she leafed through her clients mortgage papers, the housing loan counselor just shook her head.

title: Up Front
description: The novelist and short-story writer Jim Shepard, who reviews Mark Harriss Pictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood this week, moves back and forth between fiction and film.

title: When Will Earnings Recover?
description: FOR months, Wall Street economists and market strategists have argued that the economy is either in recession or is dangerously close to slipping into one later this year. Now, another constituency is coming around to this view.

title: Verrazano Light Show
description: Verrazano Light Show

title: Its an Election, Not a Revolution
description: IT has become common wisdom that the battle for the presidency is all about the economy. Voters are being told that the countrys economic health depends on pulling the right lever in the polling booth.

title: The Liberator
description: In Tree Shaker, Bill Keller writes about a presidential campaign based on hope, change and racial healing. He explores the tension between inspiring, idealistic leadership and the art of political compromise. This is not the United States election of 2008. It is the story of Nelson Mandela and the transformation of South Africa.

title: Determined to Find a New Beginning
description: MICHAEL BOSKET and Roland Rouse had plenty of time to think about how to turn their lives around.

title: Triumph Is Pick of Online Voters
description: GAVIN RHODES was surprised that his black 1959 Triumph TR3A won the Collectible Car of the Year contest on nytimes.com.

title: Sarah Gleit, James Wiener
description: Sarah Beth Gleit and James Stephen Wiener were married on Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton New York, Battery Park. Rabbi Gerald I. Wolpe officiated.

title: Presumed Guilty
description: Years ago, I asked a class I was teaching to read the first chapters of Balzacs Eugenie Grandet and A Flag for Sunrise, by Robert Stone. The Balzac begins with a leisurely tour of a provincial town, while, near the start of the Stone, a hippie backpackers corpse shows up in the freezer of an army lieutenant in a restive Central American country. I suggested to my students that the comparison might reflect one difference between 19th- and 20th-century fiction. Perhaps these contrasting openings had something to do with the way our attention spans have been altered  for better or worse  by the bright gratifications of movies and the rhythm of television, which has schooled us to expect the hook before the first commercial. Reading A Person of Interest, it occurred to me that if were lucky, Susan Chois new book may turn out to be a prototypical 21st-century novel, combining the unhurried pleasures of certain classics with the jittery tensions of more recent fiction.

title: So Who Wins the Big Prize? Its the Host
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Correction: Up Front
description: The Up Front column on Jan. 27 incorrectly included one script for a documentary among the television work of Geoffrey C. Ward, a featured reviewer. (Though not identified in the column, it was the Ken Burns film The Shakers.) While Ward was a consultant for the project, the script was written by Amy Stechler.

title: Resorts Springing Up on Costa Rican Shore
description: The Pacific Coast of Costa Rica  known as Guanacaste  is being snapped up by hoteliers and developers. Last summer, both Stephen M. Case, the co-founder of AOL, and the hotel chain Mandarin Oriental announced plans to build properties there. The Four Seasons Resort Costa Rica at Peninsula Papagayo and Hilton Papagayo Resort Costa Rica are open. And in January, Recreo (www.recreocostarica.com), above, a collection of 25 luxury villas on over 70 coastal acres, opened.

title: Sarah Akhtar, Jeffrey Cooper
description: Sarah Elizabeth Akhtar was married Saturday evening to Dr. Jeffrey Thomas Cooper at the Seattle Art Museum. The Rev. Patrick H. Callahan, a minister of the Federation of Christian Ministries, officiated.

title: The Contented Traveler
description: I GREW up in Napoleon, Ohio, in a great family that still gets along. I got my business skills from my father, who owned a hardware store, and people skills from my mother, who was a nurse.

title: The Internationalist
description: On Aug. 19, 2003, a Kamash truck pulled into the alley behind the Canal Hotel in Baghdad and a bomb detonated, crumpling a corner of the United Nations mission in Iraq. Inside the building was Sergio Vieira de Mello, a Brazilian-born United Nations official who had previously served in Vietnam, Lebanon, Cyprus, Cambodia, Bosnia, Rwanda, Kosovo and East Timor. More than anyone else at the United Nations, he embodied the organizations idealism, as well as its limitations. Vieira de Mello was pinned under the rubble and hung on for several hours before dying. The ineffectual efforts of American forces to save him were a harbinger of the larger American failure in Iraq.

title: Letters to the Editor
Island Hopping Without Leaving the City
description: ISLAND hopping in the Caribbean is fine, if you have the time, money and sunscreen, but there is an alternative in New York: a trip to islands known (at least for the next 900 words) as the Five Borough Antilles. It takes just a weekend, and youll pay less than $20 for transportation on a trip that departs from New York, N.Y., hits ports of call in New York, N.Y., and returns to New York, N.Y.

title: Its Lonely at the Plaza Hotel ...
description: KATHY RULAND decorated her familys new two-bedroom condo at the Plaza Hotel with care. The windows, overlooking Central Park, are draped with gold silk, and the living room showcases her beloved Indonesian painting of the Hindu goddess Sita, which was bought at a gallery near her main residence in Laguna Beach, Calif. When she wakes up to front-row views of Central Park, she says she feels like a princess.

title: Hilary Hotchkiss, Maurice Salth
description: Dr. Hilary Meg Hotchkiss and Rabbi Maurice Alan Salth are to be married on Sunday evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Scott Weiner is to officiate.

title: The Sound and the Fury
description: DOZENS of times a day in winter and more frequently in summer, a double-decker tour bus lumbers off Seventh Avenue South to head eastbound on Bleecker Street. The buses are a fact of life on this strip: fat, 13-foot-high behemoths, each with a tour guide lecturing through a powerful loudspeaker on local landmarks like Murrays Cheese and the Bitter End.

title: Harlem Pas de Deux
description: THE boy pressed his face to the window of the mens salon, his breath fogging the glass. He stood there, on a wintry day, staring at the sharply dressed men swathed in hot towels.

title: Decoding Lebanese Paranoia
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon

title: For Citys Schoolteachers, Retirement May Be Closer
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is poised to approve a deal that would sweeten retirement incentives for New York City teachers, a move that their union and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg support but that budget watchdog groups say is financially risky.

title: Cold Water Cruises
description: Lounging on the sun deck of a cruise ship as it navigates the warm waters of the Caribbean or Mediterranean, perhaps with a cooling cocktail in hand, is how many travelers envision spending a cruise. But others seem increasingly drawn to a vacation where the ice isnt just in their drinks, but in the very waters that surround them.

title: Life Is Sweet
description: Delicious: The Life and Art of Wayne Thiebaud, is the story of a happy man known for his happy paintings of cakes and pies. It turns out he also has many happy things to say about painting. For example: I love art history and I was a spoiled child. I had a great life, so about the only thing I can do is to paint happy pictures.

title: At the Maine Caucuses, a Tough Nut to Crack
description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: Footprint
description: The word footprint has taken on meaning, writes Michel Berger of Oakland, Calif., responding to a recent query in this space, beyond that of simple circumstantial evidence that someone has walked by, as in Daniel Defoes 1719 novel Robinson Crusoe. Where are those footprints headed?

title: Contemporary American, and Seasonal, Too
description: IT was dismaying to discover recently that La Colline Verte in Fairfield, one of Connecticuts few French restaurants, and a very fine one, had closed.

title: Sarah Chu and Neal Blangiardo
description: Sarah Chu and Neal J. Blangiardo were married on Saturday evening in Lenox, Mass. Betsy Holtzinger, a justice of the peace, officiated at Blantyre, an inn.

title: Where Church Pews Replaced the Bar Stools
description: Bayonne

title: Political Baseball on Capitol Hill
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Spoonful of Immunity?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Losing to Idaho
description: San Francisco

title: Trust and Estate Donors
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund invests contributions from trusts and estates of $100,000 or more in an endowment. The income, recently more than $1 million a year, goes into the next years campaign. This is a list of trusts and estates that donated to the fund during this years campaign.

title: Heartbreaking Work
description: Caregiver is a deceptively professional-sounding term for a role in which most of us are complete amateurs, and for one that is apt to descend upon us like a blow from fate, stunning and unforeseen. We have a great need to live with the illusion that we and those we love are immune to mortality, but inevitably, somewhere along the line, even if we ourselves are spared from illness, something cracks open  a father or a friend gets cancer, a mother succumbs to Alzheimers, a husband has a terrible accident, a child dies  and what Virginia Woolf once called extreme reality floods in. Like the 19 excruciatingly honest contributors to An Uncertain Inheritance, we may find ourselves tested to the limits of our endurance.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,954 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Renting Beats Buying (or Not)
description: TO buy or not to buy, that is the question  especially in a market where property values have been deflating, and may deflate still further.

title: Mediocrity Killed the Cat
description: WHAT WAS IT? 1988-94 Jaguar XJ6

title: Prague in Winter
description: To the Editor: Having returned from a 2007 post-Christmas, pre-New Year trip to Prague, I had to comment on "Under Wintry Skies, a City Revealed" (Feb. 3), about the joys of Prague in winter.

title: A First Foray Into New York
description: OPTIMISTIC about getting settled in his new home and starting work, Zeyd Rahman began his apartment hunt the moment he arrived in New York last month.

title: Players on a Bus Ride to Sad Reality
description: New Orleans

title: Who Is Responsible for Ceiling Damage?
description: Q I moved into a co-op a few years ago, and immediately after that, the residents in the apartment below said that a slow leak in our apartment had, over the years, damaged their ceiling.

title: Meticulous Jazzman of the World
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.

title: Cycling Commuters Have More Fun
description: To the Editor:

title: Settling In North of Main
description: HUNTINGTON is a happening restaurant town these days, with three new places opening in December alone. Noma, which took over the former Indigo, was one of them.

title: The Power of Whimsy
description: SANDRA BOYNTONS studio, in a converted barn next to her Connecticut home, bears the milestones of her singular career: a long rack of greeting cards featuring quirkily drawn animals; a room full of small, sturdy childrens books, with names like Snuggle Puppy! and Barnyard Dance!; and, upstairs, where she does much of her work, old-time radios and jukeboxes representing her more recent foray into music CDs for children.

title: Serious Steaks, at Breathtaking Prices
description: WITH the recent rise of glass-clad towers and high-end botes, the once-modest city of White Plains seems to be doing its best to impersonate Las Vegas, the land that not a single celebrity chef forgot. Developers and restaurateurs, including Rick Laakkonen at Antipasti and Anthony Goncalves at 42, are betting that suburbanites in search of fine dining will snub Manhattan and sink into a banquette closer to home. At the red-hot center of this big push is BLT Steak, a brand from Laurent Tourondel, sleekly ensconced on the ground floor of the new Ritz-Carlton on Renaissance Place.

title: Computers Are Ever Mightier, But They Still Have Their Flaws
description: If a computer played perfectly, could any human hope to achieve a draw? Chess engines are still far from perfection, but their advances have been staggering.

title: Bizarre Turn at Hearing for Suspect in Stabbing
description: The arraignment of a Queens man in the killing of an Upper East Side therapist quickly took a bizarre turn on Sunday morning when the man interrupted the proceedings with demands for food and complaints about his court-appointed lawyer.

title: Thai Antiquities, Resting Uneasily
description: IT just might rank as one of the biggest accidental discoveries in archaeology. In the summer of 1966 a Harvard student named Steve Young was living in a village in the northeast reaches of Thailand, going door to door canvassing political opinion for his senior thesis, when he tripped over the root of a kapok tree. As he hit the ground he found himself face to face with some buried pots, their rims exposed by recent monsoons. Intrigued by the look and feel of the unglazed shards, he knew enough to bring them back to government officials in Bangkok.

title: Letters: Old-School Economics
description: Christopher Caldwell (Jan. 27) argues that because America now possesses a new economy, with more security guards than machinists, presidential candidates who express concern over our ailing manufacturing sector are engaged in folkloric pandering. The true folklore, however, is the perception that our new economy represents progress. Middle-class Americans borrow to maintain their standard of living, as well-paid manufacturing jobs, like machinists, are replaced by lower-paid new economy jobs, like security guards. Masters of the new economy on Wall Street make millions on financial alchemy that ultimately weakens our economy further. One hopes that our next president will recognize that choreographers, blackjack dealers and security guards can never form the backbone of a strong economy and take steps to revive Americas industrial base.

title: Wisconsin Finally Gets Badgered
description: Shorewood, Wis.

title: Aye, Robots
description: SEEING Robby the Robot at the entrance to the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., is like running into an old friend. That is, if youre a fan of Forbidden Planet, the 1956 science fiction classic loosely based on Shakespeares The Tempest.

title: Free Lunch
description: To the Editor:

title: Kitchen Ambition
description: DOMINGO TORRES, a former dishwasher and line cook, manages the kitchens of La Palapa, a popular Mexican restaurant in the East Village, and its second location, La Palapa Rockola, across town.

title: Not So Fast
description: Not So Fast

title: 36 Hours in St. Barts
description: GETTING to St. Barts isnt easy, not even with your own Gulfstream. On the final leg, trade your million-dollar jet for a tiny puddle jumper, before threading between two jagged peaks and touching down on a teensy runway that, islanders like to joke, is as short as an aircraft carriers. That might explain the islands exclusivity. Although Jay-Z, Beyonc and a rotating cast of celebrities have kept St. Barts in the tabloids, this tiny French island still exudes a chic, laid-back vibe unspoiled by gawkers and day-trippers. And despite a new wave of wine bars, chichi boutiques and designer restaurants, the islands main attraction remains its luscious white sand beaches, fringed by the pool-blue waters of the Caribbean.

title: Who Knew There Was Water There?
description: Hiking the mountains of Bhutan. Exploring the temples of India. Wandering the ancient grounds of Angkor Wat. These are some of the unlikely trips you can take when signing up for a cruise vacation these days.

title: Schools Out. Its Cold. What to Do?
description: If it didnt arrive with a day off and a lot of department-store sales attached, Presidents Day might have all the excitement of Flag Day.

title: Gatsbys Green Light Beckons a New Set of Strivers
description: BOSTON  Jinzhao Wang, 14, who immigrated two years ago from China, has never seen anything like the huge mansions that loomed over Long Island Sound in glamorous 1920s New York. But F. Scott Fitzgeralds 1925 novel, The Great Gatsby, with its themes of possibility and aspiration, speaks to her.

title: They Cooked, They Cooed
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis Blame U.S. for Deaths of 8 Backing American Effort
description: BAGHDAD  Leaders in two Iraqi villages denounced American troops on Saturday for what they described as the killings of an Iraqi family and three other people who were working with the Americans against the insurgents.

title: Seeking Space for Cars at Grand Canyon
description: PHOENIX (AP)  The National Park Service wants to add hundreds of parking spots in developed areas at Grand Canyon National Park, hoping to ease traffic at the parks popular South Rim, officials said Friday.

title: The Love Boat for Policy Wonks
description: IM dancing on the top deck with a 71-year-old feminist and psychotherapist whom Ive come to think of as the Twirler. Weve spent two days attending seminars on The Nation magazines Alaska cruise; weve talked about the Bush presidency and prison reform and single-payer health care. Now, at almost midnight, my fiercely intelligent and opinionated new friend Charlotte is putting all the heady political talk behind her by bodily twirling.

title: Scientologys Star
description: The celebrity biographer Andrew Morton never met a grudge he couldnt get behind. He has aired the grievances of Diana, Princess of Wales, against the British royal family, and of Monica Lewinsky against Kenneth Starr. Now he champions the indignation of mostly anonymous former Scientologists in this brutal biography of the controversial religions most famous advocate, Tom Cruise.

title: Letters: Clean Look
description: Rob Walkers article (Consumed, Feb. 3) on Tides iconic design gives a brief but revealing look at the culture of overthinking that inundates the marketing community. Consultants with fancy titles and advanced degrees are ready to offer complex answers to even the simplest questions. For example, Walker quotes a Ph.D. in art history who describes Tides logo as almost a baroque composition full of great dynamic tension.

title: Inside the List
description: FLICKERS OF VANITY: Some of the writers who appear regularly on this page work hard  in their advertisements, anyway  to appear to be more or less ageless. Rita Mae Brown is not among these writers. Brown is best known, to some readers, as the author of the groundbreaking lesbian novel Rubyfruit Jungle, published in 1973. But in recent years shes spent her time churning out two successful mystery series, one about a fox-hunting club in Virginia, the other about a sleuthing cat named Mrs. Murphy. (The new Mrs. Murphy novel, The Purrfect Murder, enters the fiction list this week at No. 16.) On her Web site, Brown, who is 63 and lives on a farm in Virginia, stares at herself in the mirror and writes: I suppose I should say something about being older than dirt. Well, Im working on it. I love it. As long as youre healthy and have a job, life is really good. Yes, I look like my grandmother. My body hasnt aged yet, the face has gone, but ... I was never going to make the cover of Vogue. And in those moments when a flicker of vanity hits me and I think, Damn, I need a facelift, I remind myself that theres a starving hound someone has abandoned and I must catch it, feed it and restore its confidence in the hound-human bond. So what if I look like hell? My heart is full, and I wish the same for you.

title: Turning Minuses Into Pluses
description: DURING a nine-month renovation, Aaron Kirsten worked to make his duplex apartment safe and nurturing and fun for his son and daughter.

title: Sarah Lefton and William Selig
description: Sarah Gabrielle Lefton and William O. Selig are to be married on Sunday at the Swedish American Hall in San Francisco. Rabbi Andrew Shapiro Katz is to officiate.

title: The Race to Be the Biggest Ship of the Seas
description: There are no more coveted bragging rights in the cruise industry than the title of worlds largest ship. Indeed, as lines have jockeyed to best one another with luxury amenities and exotic itineraries, the size prize has remained the holy grail.

title: Rachel Ivey and Michael McCoy
description: Rachel Vanessa Ivey was married on Monday to Michael Thomas McCoy. The Rev. Raymond Nobiletti performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: A.T.M. Fees: Always Rising, Often Avoidable
description: Convenience usually comes at a price  and that price has been climbing for people who go outside their banking networks when they use an A.T.M.

title: Correction: The Perfect Gown? Its Adventurous and Travels Light
description: The Field Notes column last Sunday, about the influence that destination weddings are having on bridal gown design, misspelled the name of the country in which Katherine Farkas plans to marry in July. It is Colombia, not Columbia.

title: A Run for Governor, Rough Edges Included
description: HARTFORD

title: China Wineries Become a Stop for Tours
description: China is the new frontier of the international wine scene, says Paolo Wakham, a sommelier and guide for China Wine Tours. The company (www.chinawinetours.com) offers trips that combine visits to some of Chinas 500 wine producers with stops at more traditional destinations like the Great Wall, the Forbidden City and the Chang Family Mansion. The Shanxi Grace Vineyard in Taigu and the China Silk Winery in Urumqi are on the tour. Both produce cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay, riesling and merlot wines

title: Putting Top Chefs at the Helm
description: FOR many travelers, cruises have long been an excuse to eat. Now theyre increasingly becoming an excuse to eat well.

title: The Insiders Are Selling, but Why?
description: TROUBLES in the subprime mortgage arena are seeping into other markets, like credit cards, auto loans and college debt issued to people with risky profiles. So it isnt surprising that stocks of for-profit education companies  which are heavily reliant on students access to easy money  have fallen in recent months.

title: Brass-Colored, Good as Gold
description: Any white wine from Hugel, an Alsatian house founded in 1639, is a low-risk purchase.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Captive to Historys Caprice
description: WASHINGTON

title: Boys Will Be Boys, Girls Will Be Hounded by the Media
description: A VIDEO of Heath Ledger hanging out at a drug-fueled party two years before his death would seem to constitute must-see material for a tabloid entertainment show.

title: After Shootings, Illinois Campus Prepares to Mourn Victims
description: CHICAGO  Two days after a gunman opened fire at Northern Illinois University, killing five students and himself, academic officials announced that classes would resume in just over a week, to give the faculty and students time to deal with serious wounds of body and spirit.

title: In a Corrupt World Where the Violent Bear It Away
description: HE has 60 titles to his credit, ranging from one-reel shorts to international epics, with an Academy Award-wining documentary along the way (the 1947 feature Design for Death). But Richard Fleischer remains among the least known and least honored of major American filmmakers, in part because of the sheer volume of his output. Even the most conscientious critic has a hard time picking through the many impersonal projects  films like Doctor Dolittle with Rex Harrison (1967), or the 1980 remake of The Jazz Singer with Neil Diamond  to uncover the core of his achievement.

title: Modernizing an Old Elevator
description: Q I am an owner in a small co-op in New York City. The building was built in the early 1900s. We need to modernize the elevator, which rides on wood rails. Some elevator companies say we need to replace them with steel rails, an expensive proposition. Others say we dont have to. Who is right?

title: In the N.F.L., Its Not Cheating Until You Start Videotaping
description: An N.F.L. team could place an army of lip readers on the sideline to try to steal messages from the opposing side. It could fill a row of seats behind the other teams bench with espionage experts to decipher all the sideline cues. It could have scouts in the press box aiming binoculars at every opposing coach, scribbling notes to match with game tape to glean what all the signals mean.

title: A Condos Bylaws Say Nothing About Proxies
description: Q Our condo just elected a new board at a meeting that began at 6:30 p.m.   Many of the owners were not able to attend, but when we asked about proxies to cast our votes, the managing agent told us that if we did not care enough to attend the meeting, we would not be allowed to vote.

title: Stifled, Egypts Young Turn to Islamic Fervor
description: CAIRO  The concrete steps leading from Ahmed Muhammad Sayyids first-floor apartment sag in the middle, worn down over time, like Mr. Sayyid himself. Once, Mr. Sayyid had a decent job and a chance to marry. But his fiances family canceled the engagement because after two years, he could not raise enough money to buy an apartment and furniture.

title: Another Viewpoint on Readers Digest Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: A Certain Uncertain Je Ne Sais Quoi
description: PARIS

title: 5 Years After a Nightclub Fire, Survivors Struggle to Remake Their Lives
description: WEST WARWICK, R.I.  Savagely burned in the fire that incinerated the Station nightclub here five years ago next Wednesday, Linda Fisher has endured a dozen surgeries to salvage her arms, her hands, her face.

title: The Price for Being International
description: A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about the recent sale of a town house on East 75th Street whose ornate living room has been used for scenes in a television series misstated the name of the series. It is Gossip Girl, not Gossip Girls.

title: Deferred Dreams That Resonate Across Decades
description: IN the shabby living room of a Chicago apartment a frustrated young chauffeur dreams of owning a business and buying pearls for his wife. His fiery sister, a college student, dreams of becoming a doctor. His weary mother dreams of a nice home for them all, and his pregnant wife dreams of just holding on until their poverty eases.

title: Of Crime and the River
description: In his unparalleled Encounters With the Archdruid, John McPhee describes the conservationists version of hell on earth as a series of concentric circles. At the outermost ring of the devils world is a moat filled mainly with DDT (this was 1971, remember). Next comes a moat of burning gasoline, then there are bulldozers and chain saws, until one reaches the absolute epicenter ... where stands a dam. Why? Because rivers are the ultimate metaphors of existence, and dams destroy rivers. Its that simple.
