title: Long Cruises: Too Much of a Good Thing?
description: Cruises are like road races. Some are short and to the point, like 10Ks, and some are mileage-heavy, requiring a marathonlike time commitment. The trend for marathon cruises (longer than 30 days) is definitely strong, according to Mimi Weisband, a spokeswoman for Crystal Cruises, who attributes it to a growing distaste for flying and an already established pattern of passengers taking shorter back-to-back cruises to create longer travel experiences.

title: Anna-Liisa Corsi, Daniel Gonda
description: Anna-Liisa Corsi, a daughter of Irmeli and Louis Corsi of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Daniel Francis Gonda, a son of Patricia and Frank Gonda of Fairfield, Conn., are to be married on Sunday evening at Tribeca Rooftop, an events space in New York. The Rev. Bruce C. Page, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate.

title: Backers and Critics Spar Over a Rail Plan
description: WHILE some towns in central New Jersey are eagerly anticipating a New Jersey Transit plan to build a rail line intended to ease traffic congestion, others are refusing to climb on board.

title: Some Offbeat and on Beat Frequencies
description: Troupe Majidi

title: Old-School Spies
description: Englands enduring class system can be aptly summed up in two words: public school. Those who attend English public schools  in reality expensive private schools  inherit a kind of right to rule. They learn how to survive in a world no less riven by competition and cruelty than society itself. After graduating, they can forever recognize one another. Even those who rebel are shaped by the experience. To be an English public schoolboy  yes, most are still boys  is to belong to a caste.

title: More Power? Add Pressure
description: IN simplest terms, an engine produces power by burning fuel; to make more power, it must burn more fuel.

title: Officials Monitor G.P.S., and Car Batteries
description: THE global positioning system units installed in government vehicles around Long Island last year were intended to keep costs down and the staff in line, but they have kept some employees from going anywhere at all.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: A General in Army of Volunteers, Wade Is Honored
description: LOS ANGELES  Like nearly everything else in this ever-changing city, the professional golf tournament hereabouts has undergone more official name and address changes than Liz Taylor. At last count, what is now the Northern Trust Open has been known by eight different names and has been played on 11 different golf courses since its birth in 1926.

title: A Collection Devoted to Space Saving
description: LITCHFIELD

title: Forget Caps and Gowns, Try White Dresses and Bouquets
description: ON a recent Tuesday afternoon, dozens of girls descended on Botticelli Bridal Boutique in Bronxville, N.Y., and were quickly mired in layers of taffeta and satin. The girls were not preparing for a wedding, but for graduation ceremonies at their public high schools.

title: Rediscovering Operas: What About Botstein?
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Goal Gives Rangers a Shot of Momentum
description: It had barely registered to the Madison Square Garden crowd, not to mention the Buffalo Sabres, that Saturday afternoons game had started, when Rangers center Brandon Dubinsky grabbed control of the puck and barreled toward the Buffalo net.

title: As ONeals Shadow Fades, Who Will Cast the Next One?
description: NEW ORLEANS  Shaquille ONeal was everywhere, dominating the French Quarter the way he once dominated the fourth quarter. That was his DunkTruck parked in front of the local aquarium, drawing curious onlookers and dunking contestants Friday morning. That was his party, with the N.F.L. star Reggie Bush as co-host, drawing the brightest stars Friday night.

title: Nascar Returns to Basics in Hope Fans Will Return to Nascar
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  No one has acknowledged seeing The Punch, but it has already gone down in Nascar lore alongside the great fights in stock-car history. Tony Stewart versus Kurt Busch in 2008 may not top Cale Yarborough taking on Donnie and Bobby Allison after a wreck on the last lap of the 1979 Daytona 500.

title: Unforgivable Behavior, Inadmissible Evidence
description: Washington

title: Whos That Kid Staging Sondheim?
description: WHEN people think of Broadway special effects, the first things that probably come to mind are big, lumbering spectacles like the chandelier in Phantom of the Opera. Such elements are designed to drop jaws, stop shows and above all draw attention. But they dont always draw good reviews.

title: When It Rains, Its Porous
description: DAN RAIA thinks that the Pelham Gardens section of the northeast Bronx is sinking, and as proof he points to the hole in the concrete driveway at his boxy brick house.

title: Being Poor in a Charge It Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Strange Magic
description: Your powerhouse of a musical, Passing Strange, is about to open on Broadway, which might seem like an unexpected turn of events for a 46-year-old songwriter who has spent most of his career rocking with underground bands in small clubs. Have you always loved musical theater? No. Ive seen very few musicals, and my producers get scared when I give my opinion of them. Apparently, its not the thing to do when youre on Broadway, to dis other shows. Lets just say I loved Chicago.

title: Queens Man Is Arrested in Killing of Therapist
description: A 39-year-old man who blamed a Manhattan psychiatrist for having him institutionalized 17 years ago was charged on Saturday with killing a female therapist in a furious knife attack and then slashing the psychiatrist when he tried to come to the womans aid, law enforcement officials said.

title: Doubts on Security as Pakistani Vote Nears
description: GUJRAT, Pakistan  The winners of what may be the most anticipated election this country has held will be settled the usual way on Monday, by the number of ballots and fierce arguments over how they are counted. That, and perhaps the number of guns.

title: Father Accused of Killing Daughter
description: A building superintendent in the Bronx with a history of mental illness strangled his 14-year-old daughter and tried to burn her body in the buildings incinerator, the police said on Saturday.

title: New Site Tells All About New Yorks Ports
description: Theres something reassuring about knowing you can hop on a ship and cruise to warmer climes when youre living in the New York area in February. CruisingFromNewYork.com, a new Web site that was started last month, aims to expedite this fantasy. The site breaks down New Yorks three ports Manhattan (55th Street and 12th Avenue); Brooklyn (Pier 12 in Red Hook), above; and Cape Liberty (Bayonne, N.J.)  including directions, port history, nearby restaurants and parking. It also gives itineraries, along with a calendar of departures for 2008 and 2009.

title: The Grand Old White Party Confronts Obama
description: THE curse continues. Regardless of party, its hara-kiri for a politician to step into the shadow of even a mediocre speech by Barack Obama.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 37 at Pakistan Rally
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed a car into a campaign rally in the tribal areas on Saturday, killing 37 people and wounding at least 90 others.

title: Correction: Inside the List
description: A brief report in the Inside the List column on Feb. 3 about the annual Edgar Awards, given by the Mystery Writers of America, misstated the date of this years presentation banquet. It will be May 1.

title: Hemingways Letter: Better Left Unread
description: To the Editor:

title: Married, in a Way, to the Mob
description: EVERY once in a while at the Dog n Cat House, a pet grooming business in Ozone Park, Queens, the doorbell will ring when no one seems to be outside. The women who work there, attending to poodles and fluffy lap dogs, do not flinch, a receptionist named Beatrice said the other day. We just say, Hi, John, she added with a laugh.

title: Settling Into a Defensive Crouch
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Jorge Posada, who is 36 years old and has a bit of gray in his black hair, is still catching and still excelling for the Yankees. At an age when most catchers have retired to the couch, switched positions or stopped being productive, Posada is still a formidable threat.

title: Division of Champions Is Now an Also-Ran
description: The years have not been kind to the N.H.L.s Southeast Division. The Tampa Bay Lightning, winner of the Stanley Cup in 2004, has languished at the bottom of the standings. The Carolina Hurricanes, who won the Cup in 2006, the season after the lockout, have struggled to find consistency.

title: The Charisma Mandate
description: TAKING office in 1933, Franklin D. Roosevelt confronted a country in crisis. Four in 10 working-age Americans were jobless. Banks were collapsing. There were long lines outside tellers windows as people rushed to withdraw their savings.

title: A Future So Bright It Can Handle Dark
description: DURING the Metropolitan Operas 2004-5 season, when the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe sang Eduige in a new production of Handels Rodelinda, I was not the only opera fan who thought that here, at last, was the true successor to Marilyn Horne in the Baroque and bel canto repertory.

title: Restrained, With a Raucous Claim to Fame
description: THOUGH he hobnobbed with royalty, and might even have known a mermaid or two, the circus impresario P. T. Barnum retained a soft spot for Bethel, his hometown, 69 miles from Midtown Manhattan in northern Fairfield County.

title: Head Scarves in Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Marymount Being Sold; Village to Gain Taxes
description: FORDHAM UNIVERSITY has agreed to sell the historic Marymount College campus in Tarrytown for $27 million to EF Education, a private language school with 10 campuses in the country and 35 throughout the world.

title: Everybody Hurts
description: If you believe you are by now immune to gory novels, heres one with enough malevolence to give even the most hardened readers nightmares. The Seven Days of Peter Crumb, a chronicle of the final week in a psychopaths life by the British actor and writer Jonny Glynn, is gruesome, obscene and utterly disturbing. It is also absorbing and well written. Reading it, I fought the urge to throw up. Needless to say, I was transfixed.

title: Hitting the Books
description: To the Editor: In "In Summer, Hitting the Books, Not Just the Beach" (Feb. 3), I was exhausted just reading about summer programs where high school students can take college courses or SAT prep courses or perform community service to meet their schools service requirements or to enhance their college applications. What ever happened to the good old days when summer vacations were for fun?

title: California Still Counting Heavy Feb. 5 Vote
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It has been nearly two weeks since primary day in California, and Stephen Weir is still ironing ballots.

title: A Smiling, Fidgeting McCain, Learning to Rein Himself In
description: WASHINGTON  So this is what it looks like when the maverick becomes The Man.

title: Transition Continues for Igawa and Yanks
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Even the wealthy Yankees are wary of wasting $46 million on one player, so they are not about to give up on Kei Igawa, the left-handed pitcher from Japan who was a disappointment in 2007, his first season in the United States.

title: Liaisons Dangereuses
description: IT was a slow weeknight at the Comfort Zone, a meeting place for men that is in a drab office building amid the Broadway musicals on West 49th Street. Although snow and sleet fell in the streets, several men endured the frigid weather to make their way to the clubs spacious second-floor suite, eager to indulge the yearnings that had driven them out into the stormy night.

title: Sheila Frazier and John Atchison
description: IN 1979, the shag was all the rage  the haircut that is  and John Atchison, a New York celebrity hair stylist, worked his magic on Sheila Frazier, a Los Angeles actress who was catapulted to sex symbol status after her performance in the 1972 film Super Fly.

title: Taking Play Seriously
description: On a drizzly Tuesday night in late January, 200 people came out to hear a psychiatrist talk rhapsodically about play  not just the intense, joyous play of children, but play for all people, at all ages, at all times. (All species too; the lecture featured touching photos of a polar bear and a husky engaging playfully at a snowy outpost in northern Canada.) Stuart Brown, president of the National Institute for Play, was speaking at the New York Public Librarys main branch on 42nd Street. He created the institute in 1996, after more than 20 years of psychiatric practice and research persuaded him of the dangerous long-term consequences of play deprivation. In a sold-out talk at the library, he and Krista Tippett, host of the public-radio program Speaking of Faith, discussed the biological and spiritual underpinnings of play. Brown called play part of the developmental sequencing of becoming a human primate. If you look at what produces learning and memory and well-being, play is as fundamental as any other aspect of life, including sleep and dreams.

title: Most Popular Cruises
description: Perhaps its no surprise that the Caribbean, long a traditional cruise destination, remains the most popular spot for vacationers, with 42.8 percent of respondents to an industry survey saying they were headed there in 2008. But Europe seems to be gaining in popularity (up by 42 percent over 2006)  perhaps because of the cruise industrys efforts to convince customers that booking a cruise is a way to lock in costs, even if the dollar continues to decline in value.

title: Britain to Nationalize Troubled Mortgage Lender
description: LONDON  The British government announced Sunday that it would bring Northern Rock, the struggling mortgage lender, under its control. It was the first nationalization of a bank in more than a decade and a huge blow for the government of Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

title: Early Rally Offsets Economic Worries
description: Despite a decline on Thursday and Friday over worries about the economy, the stock market gained ground last week.

title: That Boring Job Should Sound an Alarm
description: Q. When you get up in the morning, you never want to go to work. Your job is repetitive, uninteresting and offers no challenges. When you are there, the clock barely moves, and you cant wait to leave.

title: Banker Leaves Hong Kong Post
description: David Li, the Hong Kong banker and lawmaker who is paying $8.1 million to settle a United States inquiry into his possible role in an insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones & Company, resigned from the city governments executive council late Saturday.

title: Alice Marshall and Arthur Pesch III
description: Alice Spencer Marshall, a daughter of Lisa and Michael Marshall of Crozet, Va., was married on Saturday evening to Arthur Jacob Pesch III, a son of Patricia Harder of Free Union, Va., and Mr. Pesch of Champaign, Ill. The Rev. Dominic M. Langevin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the University of Virginia Chapel in Charlottesville, Va.

title: The Forensic Humanitarian
description: International human rights work attracts activists and lawyers, diplomats and retired politicians. One of the most admired figures in the field, however, is a ponytailed statistics guru from Silicon Valley named Patrick Ball, who has spent nearly two decades fashioning a career for himself at the intersection of mathematics and murder. You could call him a forensic humanitarian.

title: Correction: Rock Around the Block
description: The Weekend in New York column on Feb. 3, about rock n roll sites, misstated the name of a club run by Andy Warhol. It was Dom  not the Electric Circus, its name under new management.

title: Turning Minuses Into Pluses
The Hunt
description: An eager ex-Londoner found that just having money and browsing Craigslist wouldnt get him an apartment.

title: Famous Art Heists
description: The biggest art theft in American history occurred at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on March 18, 1990.

title: Drivers to Watch
description: Nascar wants the drivers in its premier Sprint Cup series to show more emotion this season as a way to lure back fans who may have soured on the sport.

title: Another Broken Deal Ends Up in Court
description: Clear Channel Communications, the largest radio broadcaster in the United States, said Sunday that it had sued a unit of the private equity firm Providence Equity Partners to force a completion of a $1.2 billion purchase of 56 television stations.

title: The Last Flight of the Scarlet Macaw
description: If you feel a need to escape the law, elude creditors, hide assets, or shed the skin of your humdrum life, you could do worse than run away to Belize. Belize is a tiny nation tucked between Guatemala, Mexico, and the Caribbean Sea. It's firmly attached to Central America but considers itself a Caribbean island, like a chicken that thinks it's a duck. For more than a hundred years Belize was known as British Honduras, one of the most remote outposts of the British Empire, which explains why it's the only Latin American nation to embrace English as its official language.

title: Detective Story
description: The manuscript that I am hereby making public was entrusted to my care by my client, Antonio R. Martens. As to who he is, you will learn that from him in due course. All that I shall say in advance is that, given his scholastic attainments, he evinced a surprising flair for writing, as indeed does anyone, in my experience, who for once in his life steels himself to face up to his fate.

title: The Spare Wife
description: Jacqueline Posner stood at the edge of her dining room and aimed a blow-dryer at the center of a pale peach rose. It just refused to open the way it should, and she was running so late she hadn't even checked the place cards Ponce had set out that afternoon.

title: Tree Shaker
description: Mandela had started life as a child of royalty, had become the country's most notorious outlaw, and was now an emblem of moral courage around the globe.

title: Battle for the Pacific
description: Major League Soccer teams are entitled to feel jealous.

title: The Week Ahead: Feb. 17-24
description: Film

title: I Missed My Chance
description: The Majlis refers to a group of people sitting down together to talk, informally or formally, or where they meet. These Lede posts continue the conversation about points raised in Generation Faithful, a Times series about Middle Eastern youth. The first article focuses on the Stalled Lives of Egypts young, and the initial Majlis entries are from the staff of The Times Cairo bureau.

title: Hippo birdie two ewes
description: Congratulations to my most successful Yale classmate, who gets a big spread in the NYT.

title: Gore and the Internet
description: In badly worded earlier post I said something some people have interpreted as buying into the myth Al Gore said he invented the Internet. I was actually  if you read it closely  describing the claim that Al Gore said that as an example of a pervasive myth spread by some people in the news media.

title: 'Delicious,' by Susan Goldman Rubin
description: An illustrated biography of the artist Wayne Thiebaud.

title: Op-Classic: They Misled the Voters on Jackson
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times' archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: Today on the Rangers Dotted Line: Tyutin
description: Another day, another Rangers contract extension. Todays winner is defenseman Fedor Tyutin, who follows deals given goalie Henrik Lundqvist ($41.25 million over six years) and defenseman Dan Girardi ($3.1 million over two).

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, Feb. 17:

title: Living in Bethel, Conn.
description: P. T. Barnum retained a soft spot for his hometown, where 18th-century Colonials and 1960s ranches house a tradition-minded community.

title: When Stock Meant Stock
description: Cars like the Plymouth Superbird were once sold to the public just to make them eligible for the racetrack.

title: News Roundup: No Savior in Spain; Shake-Up in China; Picassos Home Sold
description: Stories from the world of property:

title: A Myth Debunked: The Guaranteed Point and Tight Playoff Races
description: Gary Bettman, Brian Burke and the rest of the NHL establishment have said repeatedly that the guaranteed point teams get for being tied after 60 minutes has made playoff races tighter. Never mind that the system has everyone playing it safe and easy in the third period so they can get their 1 point, and never mind that last years playoff races would actually have been tighter under a 3-2-1-0 points system.

title: Sundays Sampler
description: Things were fairly subdued on the mornings news shows. And the weather in Wisconsin is certainly curtailing some events.

title: Obama and Edwards Meet
description: CHICAGO  Senator Barack Obama and his former Democratic presidential rival, John Edwards, held a private meeting today in North Carolina, aides confirmed.

title: Understanding the rules
description: Ive written about Clinton Rules, under which anything a Clinton (or a Gore) says, no matter how innocuous it would seem if someone else said it, becomes proof of evil intentions.

title: A Vanishing Pastime
description: Warmer winters are beginning to render the winter pond into the stuff of memory.

title: Rangers Welcome Latest Shot of Youthful Energy
description: The Rangers were thrilled to get a dominant game out of rookie center Brandon Dubinsky on Saturday and just as happy to see forward Ryan Callahan dump in two goals against San Jose on Sunday. The injection of youth comes just in time, as the Rangers try to mount a serious run toward a good playoff berth in April.

title: Road Trip: Home Again
description: Ive got a confession to make. After spending three days with the Cornell basketball team as it traveled to Harvard and Dartmouth for a weekend road trip, I bailed before the most grueling part. That would be the six-hour bus ride back to Ithaca after the Big Reds victory at Dartmouth on Saturday. (My official excuse is that I had to get home to write a story, which will appear in Mondays New York Times.)

title: Modigliani Does Madrid
description: Considering hes so popular, there havent been as many shows dedicated to Italian painter and sculptor Amedeo Modigliani (1884-1920) as you might expect. If you are a fan, its worth braving the crowd to see Modigliani and His Time, the new show hosted by the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum and the Caja Madrid Foundation.

title: The Octopus Tank
description: August is about an unwelcome reunion of the Weston family. For those of you who havent read or seen the play, heres the setup: After the patriarch, Beverly, disappears, his far-flung and largely out-of-touch clan gathers together around Violet, the mother, at the family home in Pawhuska, Okla. As the grown Weston daughters arrive, its one confrontation and crisis after another. Ivy, the dutiful one who still lives close to home, is having a secret affair with her cousin Little Charles. Barbara and her husband, Bill, are trying to keep their impending divorce under wraps. Karen flies in from Miami with her lowlife fianc, Steve  and he immediately devotes himself to seducing Jean, Barbaras teenage daughter.

title: British Bungle Bank Bailout
description: Is this a case of throwing good money after bad?

title: Lifting, Lights, and Little People
description: Not every migraine has a prologue or aura, and not every aura is followed by a headache. Nevertheless, these overtures to pain or isolated events are the most peculiar aspect of the illness and may offer insights into the nature of perception itself. As a child I had what I called lifting feelings. Every once in a while, I had a powerful internal sensation of being pulled upward, as if my head were rising, even though I knew my feet hadnt left the ground. This lift was accompanied by what can only be called awe  a feeling of transcendence.

title: When Identity Politics Is Rational
description: If theres anything everyone is against in these election times, its identity politics, a phrase that covers a multitude of sins. Let me start with a definition. (It may not be yours, but it will at least allow the discussion to be framed.) Youre practicing identity politics when you vote for or against someone because of his or her skin color, ethnicity, religion, gender, sexual orientation, or any other marker that leads you to say yes or no independently of a candidates ideas or policies. In essence identity politics is an affirmation of the tribe against the claims of ideology, and by ideology I do not mean something bad (a mistake frequently made), but any agenda informed by a vision of what the world should be like.

title: Ferris State Shocks Miami
description: Another weekend, another shakeup in college hockey. It seems like every week one team either makes a big jump or a steep plunge in its NCAA Tournament standing, and this week was no different. The weekends biggest surprise was Miami (Ohio) being swept by Ferris State. Riding a four-game winless streak, the RedHawks reward looks like a first-round showdown with Wisconsin at the Midwest regional in Madison. Some gift.

title: Belichick Opens Up (Or, Whos Matt Walsh?)
description: The Boston Globe has the first comments from Patriots Coach Bill Belichick on the spying scandal that he no doubt wishes would go away. Among other things, Belichick said he couldnt pick Matt Walsh out of a lineup, a reference to the former Patriots staff member who has hinted that he may have a lot to say about the Patriots video library.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The TV Watch column on Wednesday, about coverage of the presidential primaries on Tuesday night, misidentified the channel that calls its stars the best political team on television. It is CNN, not MSNBC.

title: No Windows, No Heat, No Staff, No Rent. This Is a Gallery?
description: The real estate listing would read something like this: Approximately 800 square feet, ground floor, no windows, no heat, no drain pipe under the sink (slop bucket required), constant traffic noise, fine coating of black gunk on everything.

title: Lottery Numbers
Tax Scandal in Germany Fans Complaints of Inequity
description: FRANKFURT  For wealthy Germans, many of whom have long hidden their money outside the country to avoid its high taxes, this has been a weekend of high anxiety. For their fellow citizens, it has been a riveting spectacle, dominating the public discussion for days.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes an auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Weather and Other Primaries Thwart Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE  After all the attention showered upon Iowa, New Hampshire and a coast-to-coast string of states with elections this month, the voters of Wisconsin were anticipating having the presidential race to themselves for a week.

title: Mickelson Ends Long Wait With a Win at Riviera
description: LOS ANGELES  Phil Mickelson completed a quest Sunday at Riviera Country Club, reaching a goal that was personal and professional. His unrequited love affair with Riviera began when he first stepped inside the ropes here 20 years ago as a skinny 17-year-old high school golfer. Not until late Sunday afternoon, when he held aloft the silver trophy after his two-stroke victory in the Northern Trust Open, was it consummated.

title: No Lull in Mortgage Pitches
description: The mortgage market may be in a historic upheaval, but mortgage companies continue to pump out upbeat advertisements.

title: Newman Foils Stewart and Wins Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A pack of cars rounded Turn 2 on the final lap of the Daytona 500 on Sunday night, with Tony Stewart in the lead and close enough to imagine he might actually win this race after 10 years of futility and frustration. But out of the blue came a streak of blue.

title: Sense of Freedom Follows a Career Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  His official portrait sits in a closet at the Connecticut Democratic Party headquarters in Hartford. Party elders have stripped him of his superdelegate cape.

title: Iran Hangs 2 on Murder and Rape Charges
description: TEHRAN  Iran on Sunday executed two men  one accused of murder and the other of raping children  in a prison in the northeastern province of Khorasan, the ISNA news agency reported.

title: New CDs
description: CHRIS CAGLE My Lifes Been a Country Song (Capitol Nashville)

title: Directors Reward: A Second First Chance
description: HOLLYWOOD  The movie industry loves a comeback, if youve achieved stardom once already. But what if that first big break slipped by unexploited?

title: London Underground Vetoes Poster of Nude
description: She was born in 1532, but the golden-haired, milky-skinned woman cocking her hips behind a transparent veil in Venus, below, a painting by the German artist Lucas Cranach the Elder, is a bit too much for Transport for London, operator of the London subway system, The Associated Press reported. The painting is one of 70 works scheduled for exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London beginning March 8, and the academy wanted to advertise the show in the Underground system using a poster. But Transport for London said no, unless the bottom half was cropped, according to the academy. I think it is because shes totally nude as opposed to, say, shes topless, said Jennifer Francis, an academy spokeswoman. Were shocked. We wouldnt have put a poster design forward if we thought it was offensive. Transport for London said in a statement, We have to take account of the full range of travelers and endeavor not to cause offense in the advertising we display.

title: Today, Class, Were Playing Carnegie Hall
description: The Manhattan School of Music created a prototypical halfway house  a graduate program in orchestral performance  intended to help gifted students make their way from school to professional life. Its curriculum has been heavy on the practical: from learning symphonic as opposed to solo repertory to understanding the psychopathology of orchestra life and even to tips on travel.

title: Huckabee Takes a Break and Heads to the Islands
description: GRAND CAYMAN, Cayman Islands  Mike Huckabee left voters behind in the snow in Wisconsin over the weekend and headed to this getaway resort island.

title: Grosses Give Jumper Cause to Celebrate
description: Newcomers led by Jumper captured four of the top five positions when the North American three-day weekend film box-office grosses were tallied by the tracking company Media by Numbers. Jumper (Fox), starring Hayden Christensen as a man with a talent for teleportation, pulled in an estimated $27.2 million. The sequel Step Up 2 the Streets (Buena Vista), about a teenage girl (Briana Evigan) with a talent for dance, took No. 2 with $19.6 million. Third place, with $19 million, went to The Spiderwick Chronicles (Paramount and Nickelodeon), about a family in a spooky old house. The only holdover in the Top 5 was Fools Gold (Warner Brothers). That action-romance-comedy, last weeks top-ranking film, slid to fourth place on a gross of $13 million. The romance Definitely, Maybe (Universal), with Ryan Reynolds and Abigail Breslin, finished fifth with $9.7 million.

title: A Plan to Offer 50 Sites on Politics in 50 States
description: In the middle of a media-saturated political season, Jared Kushner, publisher of The New York Observer, has been quietly nurturing an ambitious political journalism venture.

title: After Stumbling, Facebook Finds a Working Eraser
description: Facebook.com, stung last week by the wrath of members who want to sever their relationships, tripped again when it tried to let them do so.

title: Moving the Grange, and Twisting It Around, Too
description: The idea is to restore Alexander Hamiltons country home, the Grange, to a state that Hamilton himself would recognize.

title: A Referral Service That Ensures Someone Actually Makes a Sale
description: ONLINE shoppers who cant decide whether to pull the trigger on their next purchase may be surprised at a new alternative: an offer to get it free.

title: Cant We All Just Agree to Agree?
description: A paper in The Journal of Consumer Research explores the false consensus effect, the degree to which people assume, often incorrectly, that others share their opinion. The authors found that the effect is greater among people who hold positive opinions than among those who hold negative ones.

title: Carpenters Fans Seek to Spare Home
description: Fans of the 1970s pop duo the Carpenters regard a modest home in the Los Angeles suburb of Downey, Calif., as their version of Graceland, but the owners want to tear it down to build a larger house, The Associated Press reported. Featured on the cover of the 1973 hit album Now & Then, the five-bedroom tract house, where the siblings Karen and Richard Carpenter lived, is also where they wrote some of their greatest hits and where Karen, an anorexic, collapsed in 1983 before dying. Manuel and Blanca Melendez Parra, owners of the house, apparently have grown weary of the visits of homage-paying Carpenters fans. They have torn down an annex used as an office, rehearsal studio and recreation room, and they want to replace the main residence. Officials in Downey said that they had received plans for a new residence, but had not issued a demolition permit. The musician Jon Konjoyan, above at the site with the album, is leading the campaign to save the home. He said he wanted it rehabilitated, or at least moved.

title: Rangers Show They Can Win Against West
description: In their first nine games against the Western Conference this season, the Rangers ran up against a group of big, immovable teams, for whom a snarling defensive style has become the price of admission to any conference game.

title: The New Bosss Salty Language Raises Eyebrows at His Papers
description: Samuel Zell, the new head of the Tribune Company, is known for colorful language  the sort that cannot be printed in his newspapers.

title: Commuting to School: Riders Tell Their Tales
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lights and Darks of Life, Punctuated by Stillness and Guitars
description: In the silent pools of the night, Eva Yerbabuena writes in the program notes for her new flamenco show, we learn how life is illuminated by light, but intensified by darkness. Fittingly, Ms. Yerbabuena begins Signs and Wonders standing on a darkened stage illuminated only by an overhead light. In the first section, she emerges from the blackness  her long ruffled dress and bolero jacket adding texture to the intensity of the night scene  and grandly circles a stool, first lunging in front of it and then sitting with her hands on her knees, her eyes cast downward.

title: Bracing for Revenge
description: Tel Aviv

title: In Washington State Vote, Relevance Is an Issue
description: SEATTLE  As many as 1.5 million votes are projected to be cast in Washington States presidential primary on Tuesday. The question is whether they will count.

title: Tanzania Welcomes Bush, but Obama Is Topic No. 1 on the Streets
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  President Bush has been smothered with affection here, never more so than on Sunday, when he sat at a wooden desk under a sweltering sun with President Jakaya Kikwete by his side and signed a $698 million grant of foreign aid to Tanzania.

title: Study Finds Cancer Diagnosis Linked to Insurance
description: ATLANTA  A nationwide study has found that the uninsured and those covered by Medicaid are more likely than those with private insurance to receive a diagnosis of cancer in late stages, often diminishing their chances of survival.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Saturday misstated the 2007 compensation of John J. Mack, chief executive of Morgan Stanley. Mr. Mack, who did not receive a bonus in 2007, received compensation valued at $1.5 million, not $41.7 million. (The companys Securities and Exchange Commission filing listed $40.2 million in stock awards for Mr. Mack in December 2006, which was in the companys fiscal 2007 year, but those awards applied to fiscal 2006.) (Go to Article)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 29 about the filing of charges against an employee of the New York State Archives accused of illegally selling rare books and documents from the states collections included an erroneous spelling from an eBay listing for the surname of the addressee on an 1823 letter from John C. Calhoun, the 19th-century vice president. The addressee was Col. Charles Haines  personal secretary to DeWitt Clinton, the 19th-century governor of New York  not Haine.

title: Kosovo Declares Its Independence From Serbia
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  The province of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia on Sunday, sending tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians streaming through the streets to celebrate what they hoped was the end of a long and bloody struggle for national self-determination.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Steve Riley and the Mamou Playboys, at Connollys on West 45th Street in Manhattan, misstated the date of the performance. It was on Sunday; the band will not perform on Thursday.

title: Rebukes Are Swift for the Chief of Deutsche Post
description: BERLIN  The German political elite has wasted no time in dissociating itself from Klaus Zumwinkel, the chief executive of Deutsche Post, who is suspected of using a foundation in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

title: Vote Is Expected to Further Weaken Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistanis began voting Monday morning in parliamentary elections that are expected to diminish President Pervez Musharraf further and present Washington with a challenging new political lineup here as it pursues its fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda in the region.

title: President-Elect of South Korea Is Questioned in Stock Scam
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President-elect Lee Myung-bak of South Korea was questioned Sunday by special prosecutors investigating accusations that he had engaged in financial fraud.

title: Clinton and Obama Emphasize Economic Themes
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama intensified their populist economic appeals on Monday in an effort to attract support from economically struggling voters in Ohio and Texas, which are taking shape as potentially decisive contests in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: John Brunious, 67, Louisiana Trumpeter, Is Dead
description: John Brunious, a jazz trumpeter who devoted his career to the music of his native New Orleans, leading the Preservation Hall Jazz Band for more than a dozen years, died on Tuesday in Casselberry, Fla. He was 67 and had lived in Casselberry, outside Orlando, since being displaced by Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

title: Former President Bush Backs McCain
description: HOUSTON  Senator John McCain got a Presidents Day endorsement Monday from former President George Bush, who called him the best candidate to lead the country and dismissed conservative criticism of his candidacy as absurd.

title: A Rip-Off by Health Insurers?
description: Have health insurers been systematically cheating patients and doctors of fair reimbursement for medical services? That is the disturbing possibility raised by an investigation of the industrys arcane procedures for calculating reasonable and customary rates.

title: Kennedy Assassination Trove Opened
description: DALLAS  After more than 40 years under lock and key, a large collection of documents and items related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy was released by the Dallas County district attorney on Monday.

title: Set Your Tasers on Slo-Mo Wipeout
description: The Japanese have always excelled at taking apart American products, making them better and then selling them back to us. Cars. Stereos. Cartoons. Outfielders.

title: Chvez Backs Off Threats to Halt Oil Exports to U.S.
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez said on Sunday that Venezuela was not planning to halt oil exports to the United States. The statement may ease fears in energy markets over fallout from Venezuelas legal battle with Exxon Mobil over compensation for the nationalization of a large oil project.

title: The Changed Seasons of Todays Salt and Pepa
description: If you know nothing at all about the women who made up the former hip-hop duo Salt-n-Pepa, what you will learn from randomly watching a few minutes of the VH1 reality series about them is that they named themselves more aptly than most performers. There was no confusion in the birthing room, no mistake in the paperwork. They have fulfilled their titular destinies. Salt (Cheryl Wray) has become a woman of quiet and comfortable tastes, and Pepa (Sandra Denton) lives by the rules of spice and bite.

title: Brazilian Film Wins Top Honors in Berlin
description: Films about police violence and prisoner abuse in Iraq captured the top prizes at the Berlin International Film Festival on Saturday. The Golden Bear for best film went to Tropa de Elite (Elite Squad), a Brazilian drama by Jos Padilha, right, about the black-uniformed paramilitary police who strike fear into residents of Rio de Janeiro shantytowns, The Associated Press reported. The Silver Bear jury grand prize went to Standard Operating Procedure, about the treatment of prisoners at the American-run Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq. That film, directed by Errol Morris, was the first documentary ever shown in competition at the festival, where 21 films vied for honors this year. The Silver Bear for best director went to Paul Thomas Anderson for There Will Be Blood, starring Daniel Day-Lewis as an obsessed man in the oil industry.

title: In a Hotel Deal, Showtime Fights HBOs Dominance
description: The battle among pay TV channels may be entering a new arena: hotel rooms.

title: Technology Can Be a Blessing for Bored Workers
description: OF all the repetitive, mind-numbing jobs in the late 19th century, cigar-rolling was special.

title: Hendrick Dominant, Just Not in 500
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Of the 18 Nascar Sprint Cup teams that showed up at Daytona International Speedway at the start of Speedweeks, only two managed to generate the headlines and carry all of the expectations heading into Sundays Daytona 500.

title: Antidoping Teams Lead California Event
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  If professional cycling hopes to turn the page this year in its fight against doping, it hardly could choose a better way to start than with the group of racers who stood on the podium after the opening day of the Tour of California.

title: 48 Hours on the Big Red Bus
description: HANOVER, N.H.  After victories at Harvard and at Dartmouth pushed his teams record to 8-0 in the Ivy League, the Cornell mens basketball coach, Steve Donahue, decided to indulge himself and his team.

title: Team Takes Leave of Another Town
description: VERO BEACH, Fla.

title: Veteran Judge in Bell Shooting Trial Has Seen It All Before
description: The first time Justice Arthur J. Cooperman of the State Supreme Court faced police officers charged in a high-profile case was in 1986, six years after becoming a judge. The case was tried in Queens, with the officers accused of torturing a teenage drug suspect with a stun gun.

title: A Big-Time Injury Striking Little Players Knees
description: Last year, when Collin Link was 11 years old, he was tackled as he went in for a touchdown in pee-wee football.

title: A Ring Doesnt Ensure a Stars Happiness
description: New Orleans

title: Women of Flamenco Expand the Edges of Passionate Tradition
description: Flamenco is an art of fiery passion, as everyone knows. Its dancing feet are soul-shattering, its singing voices gut-wrenching. To renew or refashion flamenco, a little Latin influence is added here or an involved narrative there. But the four women who starred in Mujeres (Women), a gala program presented by World Music Institutes New York Flamenco Festival 2008 on Friday at City Center, offered stunning proof that the old art lives on most vitally in committed new interpreters.

title: Protecting a Monumental Sculpture
description: In the northeastern United States, with all the woods and hills, it is usually pretty hard to see five miles at a stretch. In a place like Utahs Great Salt Lake  vast in its openness and flatness  five miles is a mere arms length away. That is why a Canadian companys plan to begin oil-drilling from a pair of barges near Rozel Point, on the edge of the lake, has caused so much concern.

title: Bad Apples and Blue Eyes: Shaking Loose Secrets From the Family Tree
description: There is a lake in the town of Templeton, where Lauren Groffs debut novel is set. In that lake there is a dead 50-foot-long prehistoric monster. This may sound like a sufficiently major plot point on which to hang a story, but for Ms. Groff its just a teaser. To the extent that anything so casual is possible, Ms. Groffs gigantic dead beast is a throwaway. And an opening salvo. The creature surfaces not at some dramatic climax, but in this books very first sentence.

title: At Least 80 Are Killed in Afghan Suicide Bombing
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber blew himself up in a large crowd gathered at a dogfighting event just outside this city in southern Afghanistan, killing about 80 people and wounding more than 90 others in the countrys worst single bombing since 2001.

title: A Days Work in Albany, a Days Pay, and $154 More
description: ALBANY  Assemblywoman Earlene Hooper and Senator Efrain Gonzlez Jr. recorded more travel expenditures last year than any other lawmakers in their respective houses, according to records obtained from the state comptrollers office.

title: Balanchine, Steeped in Romance and Russia
description: New York City Ballets Russian Treasures program of works choreographed by George Balanchine to music by Tchaikovsky embodies important City Ballet history. All three ballets offer the usual chances for veteran dancers to just do it, an early central tenet of Balanchines work, as well as for dancers to prove their mettle in new roles, as three did on Saturday night in the first Treasures of the season, at the New York State Theater.

title: After China Ships Out iPhones, Smugglers Make It a Return Trip
description: SHANGHAI  Factories here churn out iPhones that are exported to the United States and Europe. Then thousands of them are smuggled right back into China.

title: A Quirky Night for Quirky Romance
description: At first blush the stage at the Allen Room on Friday night appeared to be set for seduction. Soft lighting? (Check.) Simmering groove? (Check.) Slow drift of headlights in the background, along Central Park South? (O.K., sure.) And finally Kurt Elling in a double-breasted suit, microphone in hand. Love is the only thing to balance fearing, he sang, with suave self-assurance. Loving the deepest depths appearing. (Whats that again?)

title: Scripts Reappear on Daily Show
description: The teleprompter was working again on Wednesday at The Daily Show, as Jon Stewart performed his news satire on Comedy Central with the support of writers for the first time in more than three months.

title: Government to Control Struggling British Bank
description: LONDON  The British government announced on Sunday that it would bring Northern Rock, the struggling mortgage lender, under its control. It was the first nationalization of a bank in more than a decade and a huge blow for the administration of Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Before Murder, Troubled Quest to Find Mother
description: In the eight and a half months before his arrest in the fatal stabbing of a Manhattan therapist, a Queens man became so obsessed with his institutionalized mother that his father kept moving her from nursing home to nursing home, a law enforcement official said on Sunday.

title: Back in Arizona, Johnson Is Staring Down 300-Win Milestone
description: TUCSON  As Randy Johnson approached the mound Sunday, Arizona Diamondbacks Manager Bob Melvin gave him a wide berth, as if trying to avoid being singed. Johnsons burning competitiveness once again had turned him into the worlds tallest sparkler.

title: Tally Ho! A Determined Crew Hunts for Fox Hunters
description: LUXBOROUGH, England  Graham Floyd, an operative from the League Against Cruel Sports, had been on the hill for about an hour when he thought he heard something. Everybody in! he barked, conveying his hefty, camouflage-clothed person with surprising agility into a nearby thicket of brambles.

title: Suicide Bomber Is Spotted and Shot, but Kills 3 in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  It was Sunday, a busy day for shop owners in the bustling central Baghdad district of Karada, and Abbas Ali was tending to his morning routine when screams from people outside stopped him.

title: Wisconsin Weighs on 2 Candidates
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has vowed to make her stand in the Ohio and Texas primaries on March 4. John McCain has been embraced by Republican leaders as the nominee-apparent. But each has a big stake in the Wisconsin primary on Tuesday  and its not just about winning or losing.

title: Our Founding Lame Duck
description: HISTORIANS have often noted that George Washington not only began but also did much to define the American presidency. He imprinted on the office a sense of competence and integrity that can make later presidents, even successful ones, seem to fall short. Then to top it off, he left the job voluntarily. No law required him to step down, and running against him would have been impossible. Retiring after two terms, Washington enabled the transfer of executive power by electoral process.

title: Celebrating the Semicolon in a Most Unlikely Location
description: It was nearly hidden on a New York City Transit public service placard exhorting subway riders not to leave their newspaper behind when they get off the train.

title: In Harlem, Baby Talk and the Art of Diplomacy
description: Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, successor to Dr. Spock and a precursor to the hordes of child care experts whose books now crowd stores shelves, entered a small classroom at an elementary school in Harlem one Saturday not long ago and smiled broadly. The parents in the room, mostly mothers, did not return the favor. They were seeking child care advice because theyd had it, and they were evidently tired, in no mood to charm.

title: Primal Call and Response at a Bands Rumbling Bash
description: Sad-eyed Matt Korvette, lanky and a little slobby, stood on a chair, put his hands up by his clavicle and ripped off his white T-shirt from the collar down. Gathering concentration, he looked straight ahead as he made this strong and pathetic gesture.

title: Gardner Lindzey, Former President of the American Psychological Association, Is Dead at 87
description: Gardner Lindzey, a psychologist, editor and former president of the American Psychological Association who helped build a national framework to encourage scholarly exchanges and collaborations in the social sciences, died on Feb. 4 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 87.

title: College Paper Vows to Fight a Takeover by Gannett
description: J. David McSwane, the student editor of The Rocky Mountain Collegian, was looking forward to a quiet spring semester at the Colorado State University after drawing global attention last fall for a four-word editorial criticizing President Bush.

title: Angst in a Living Room Near You
description: Open house. The words are celestial music to the ears of certain real-estate-obsessed New Yorkers. What better way to spend a sleepy Sunday afternoon than by poking around condos and co-ops for sale, clucking with satisfaction at the lack of closet space or envying the eat-in kitchen?

title: Back Today, Pettitte Discusses H.G.H. Use
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte will not be under oath Monday, but he will be in the spotlight when he meets with the news media for the first time to discuss his admitted use of human growth hormone.

title: Judicial Rebukes on Clean Air
description: The federal courts have been a bulwark against the Bush administrations relentless efforts to weaken 40 years worth of environmental law, including statutes protecting the nations forests, wetlands and endangered species. The courts have been especially important in resisting the administrations assault on the 1970 Clean Air Act, which began with Vice President Dick Cheneys 2001 energy report and continues to this day.

title: In Images, the Lower East Side of Starker Days
description: Few parts of New York City have undergone a more rapid and drastic physical transformation over the past 20 or 30 years than the area below East 14th Street known broadly as the Lower East Side. In the 1970s and 80s the neighborhood was a gritty and often dangerous district where the population was dwindling and businesses were gradually being shuttered.

title: Deal for Kidd Has a Chance to Resurface
description: NEW ORLEANS  On a neutral court, in a meaningless game, Jason Kidd pulled on a blue jersey that read East across the chest and started bouncing clever passes to grateful teammates. He was neither a Net nor a Maverick in Sundays All-Star Game, his identity appropriately ambiguous for the evening.

title: Democrats Should Read Kipling
description: Browsing through a used-book store Friday  in the Milwaukee airport, of all places  I came across a 1981 paperback collection of George Orwells essays. Thats how I happened to reread his 1942 essay on Rudyard Kipling. Given Orwells perpetual ability to elucidate, one shouldnt be surprised that its argument would shed light or so it seems to me  on contemporary American politics.

title: Footnotes
description: Zoe Caldwell and Sam Waterston will read from the personal papers of Katharine Hepburn at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at 6 p.m. Tuesday. The event begins a series of four free public readings, Remembering Kate, celebrating the donation and opening for public view of the papers. Tickets, one to a person, will be distributed beginning two hours before each program. Participants in readings scheduled for March 31, April 12 and April 28 include Anthony Harvey, Katharine Houghton, Charlotte Moore, Dick Cavett and Marian Seldes. ... Eddie Vedder, the Pearl Jam frontman, will begin his first solo tour in the spring to promote his soundtrack album for the film Into the Wild, Reuters reported. The tour will open in Vancouver on April 2 and play five dates in California. Pearl Jam will headline the Bonnaroo Music and Arts festival in Manchester, Tenn., in June.

title: 3 Internet Providers in Deal for Tailored Ads
description: LONDON  For years, Internet service providers have watched with envy as the likes of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft sliced up the online advertising pie. Selling Internet access has been a good business, but selling Web advertising has been an even more lucrative one.

title: With a Timely Trump Lead, Thwarting Declarers Plans
description: The 13th NEC Cup Bridge Festival ended in Yokohama, Japan, eight days ago, and the diagramed deal featured probably the best defense during the five days of play. It was Board 13 of the quarterfinals.

title: Dutch Protest 104-Year-Old Singer
description: A 104-year-old Dutch-born singer, Johannes Heesters  who once performed for Hitler  touched off a protest when he took the stage in the Netherlands on Saturday for the first time in four decades, The Associated Press reported. Speaking for about 50 demonstrators outside the De Flint theater in Amersfoort, where Mr. Heesters, above, performed, Piet Schouten said: He kept singing for the Nazi regime, for the Wehrmacht, and he earned millions. Those are facts, and we have a problem with that on behalf of all the victims. Mr. Heesters was never accused of being a propagandist, and the Allies allowed him to continue his career after World War II. But in the Netherlands he is viewed by some as unforgivable, though he wrote in his postwar autobiography, I was ashamed of myself, and I still havent stopped feeling this way. In 1964 he was booed off the stage in Amsterdam when he appeared as the Nazi-hating Captain von Trapp in The Sound of Music. No disturbances were reported during the concert in Amersfoort, where Mr. Heesters, who lives in Germany, was born. But a handful of neo-Nazis turned up, uninvited, to support him, and some were detained by the police after they hurled eggs at demonstrators.

title: Demystifying Messiaen, With a Little Help From the Birds
description: As the climate for classical music in America adjusts to challenges (like the decline of arts education in public schools) and opportunities (the instantaneous availability of music on the Web), the role of the music director of a major orchestra is changing as well. Its no longer enough to be a comprehensive musician, a strong conductor and a good schmoozer of potential patrons. The music directors who are making differences in their communities and winning new listeners are also good teachers, proselytizers and speakers, in person and, increasingly, in videos.

title: Largest Recall of Ground Beef Is Ordered
description: A California meat company on Sunday issued the largest beef recall in history, 143 million pounds, some of which was used in school lunch programs, Department of Agriculture officials announced.

title: Peter Newton, Napa Vintner, Dies at 81
description: Peter Newton, a noted California vintner whose two wineries, Sterling Vineyards and Newton Vineyard, produced some of Napa Valleys most highly regarded wines, died Feb. 4 at his home in St. Helena, Calif. He was 81.

title: Proven Winner Finally Finishes First at Daytona
description: Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Here Come the Superdelegates
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Violence Film Has Release Date
description: Delayed after the deadly shootings last year at Virginia Tech, a movie about campus violence starring Meryl Streep will be released in the spring, the distributor said on Friday, a day after the killings at Northern Illinois University. The Associated Press reported that the film, Dark Matter, also starring Liu Ye as a disgruntled Chinese graduate student in science, will open in New York on April 11 and then in other American cities, said Gary Rubin, president of First Independent Pictures. Dark Matter, directed by Chen Shi-Zheng, won the Alfred P. Sloan Prize for films about science at the Sundance Film Festival last year.

title: Clashes With Israeli Troops Kill 4 Militants in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Four Palestinian militants were killed in clashes with the Israeli Army in southern Gaza early Sunday, and an Israeli soldier was seriously wounded in an exchange of fire.

title: One Friend Facebook Hasnt Made Yet: Privacy Rights
description: A co-worker apologized to me recently for being slow on a task. Its probably just your insomnia from last night, I said. She was confused about how I knew, but I reminded her we were Facebook friends, and that she had posted a status update about her sleeplessness.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Saturday misstated the 2007 compensation of John J. Mack, chief executive of Morgan Stanley. Mr. Mack, who did not receive a bonus in 2007, received compensation valued at $1.5 million, not $41.7 million. (The companys Securities and Exchange Commission filing listed $40.2 million in stock awards for Mr. Mack in December 2006, which was in the companys fiscal 2007 year, but those awards applied to fiscal 2006.)

title: Guantnamo, Evil and Zany in Pop Culture
description: This spring, the stoner screwball movie of 2004, Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle, will get a sequel. This time, because of some unfortunate confusion on an airplane between a bong and a bomb, our slacker antiheroes are shipped off to the moviemakers idea of the worst prison imaginable.

title: Mets Turn to Schneider to Take Charge Behind Home Plate
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On his lifes to-do list, Brian Schneider has already crossed off a great many things. Travel at the speed of sound? Yup. Catch ceremonial first pitches from the president and the vice president? Check. Fly with the Blue Angels  and keep his breakfast down? Done that, too.

title: Dumb or Just Fun? Animation Illustrates a CBS News Item
description: Critics who regularly bemoan the dumbing down of television news would most likely have been enraged by the sight, on a recent weekday, of animated characters on an evening newscast explaining the political power wielded by superdelegates.

title: McCain Facing Delicate Choice: A Role for Bush
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCains campaign advisers will ask the White House to deploy President Bush for major Republican fund-raising, but they do not want the president to appear too often at his side, top aides to Mr. McCain said Sunday.

title: A $1 Million Donation to a College, and $250,000 to Explain It
description: It did not cause quite the stir as when she claimed to have unmasked Jack the Ripper, but the crime novelist Patricia Cornwell still felt the need to explain herself in a very public way.

title: Ivy Back-to-Backs: Basketball and Bonding, Checking Schoolwork and Scores
description: For players, any trip is a lesson in unintended consequences. Ivy League trips, with back-to-back games scheduled on Friday and Saturday so players dont miss as much class, are even more so. I experienced this many times as a forward for Penn.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Thursday about a garbage truck driver who was charged with manslaughter after he had a seizure, veered out of control and killed two pedestrians, misstated the frequency with which commercial truckers who cross state lines must under federal law renew a certificate indicating that they do not have a debilitating medical condition. It is every two years, not every year.

title: Not Everyone Wants a Coaching Change at Indiana
description: Any Indiana fan who watched the Hoosiers take apart Michigan State on Saturday night had to take heart. Clearly distracted by news media speculation that the coach may be relieved of his duties before the week is over, Indiana climbed out of an enormous hole to defeat the Spartans, 80-61.

title: Washingtons Birthday
description: The holiday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: N.B.A.s Recovery Work Draws Malone Back Home
description: NEW ORLEANS  A severe knee injury pushed Karl Malone out of the N.B.A. four years ago. An injury to his home state helped bring him back.

title: After Rape, Calls to Limit Where Sex Offenders Go
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass.  After an arrest in the rape of a 6-year-old boy at the city library here late last month, the mayor drafted an ordinance to bar high-risk sex offenders from entering or coming within a certain distance of numerous public places.

title: Poverty Is Poison
description: Poverty in early childhood poisons the brain. That was the opening of an article in Saturdays Financial Times, summarizing research presented last week at the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: Of All the Hurdles to a Merger, View on Technology Is the Highest
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If Microsoft succeeds in its conquest of Yahoo, what then?

title: News Isnt Wasted on the Young
description: Last Tuesday, Barack Obama stood in front of 15,000 shouting supporters in Madison, Wis., basking in wins in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. In addition to issuing a classic call to arms for the rest of the campaign, Mr. Obama took time out to welcome any Republicans to his bandwagon.

title: A Start-Up Says It Can Predict Others Fate
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Is your start-up worthy of investment? Ask the venture investor in a box.

title: An Obama Refrain Bears Echoes of a Governors Speeches
description: CHICAGO  Senator Barack Obama adapted one of his signature arguments  that his oratory amounts to more than inspiring words  from speeches given by Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts during his 2006 campaign.

title: First on the Scene, Again, Is the College Newspaper
description: When news breaks on college campuses  as it did when a gunman killed five students at Northern Illinois University last week  reporters from the college paper are often the first journalists on the scene. For reporters at The Northern Star, the student newspaper, the incident became far more personal when they learned that one of their own staff members was among those killed.

title: Broadcaster Sues to Force Buyout Deal
description: Clear Channel Communications, the largest radio broadcaster in the United States, said Sunday that it had sued a unit of the private equity firm Providence Equity Partners to force a completion of a $1.2 billion purchase of 56 television stations.

title: Language, the Muse That Provokes Stoppard and Albee
description: Do you know what its like to be deeply, unbearably in love, all the while aware that you can never completely trust the object of your affection? I would wager that Edward Albee and Tom Stoppard do, almost to the point of delirium.

title: Global Heating, Atmosphere Cancer, Pollution Death. Whats in a Name?
description: [UPDATE, 5/2: John Broder has written a piece examining a new call for new terminology to describe the climate and energy problems confronting the country. What words, if any, do you think would be most apt to grab attention and propel change?]

title: But Keep This in Mind About Egypt
description: Alaa El Aswany is the author of The Yacoubian Building, a best-selling Arabic novel that depicts contemporary Egyptian society through the lives of the different inhabitants of a Cairo apartment building. He spoke in on the telephone in Arabic about Generation Faithful: Stalled Lives with Mona el Naggar of the Timess Cairo bureau.

title: Elections in Pakistan
description: Pakistanis began voting Monday morning in parliamentary elections. The vote will test the standing of President Pervez Musharraf, who has grown deeply unpopular.

description: If you doubt that the derelict shantytowns of Tijuana could work as a template for redevelopment in a quaint, upscale town in the Hudson River Valley, youre probably underestimating Teddy Cruz.

description: Wonder what John McCains campaign slogan will be? Im guessing a variation on something like: Hey, you punks, get off my lawn.

title: Abe Lincoln, Standup Comic
description: It was getting near closing time on open mike night at my favorite local comedy club  Laugh or Else  and I seemed to be the last comic-watcher standing or sitting. I handed a five to the waitress for one more virgin scotch-and-soda with a twist as the final wannabe comedian walked onstage. He was tall, thin and bearded, wearing a stovepipe hat and looking at notes scribbled on the back of an envelope. I grabbed the five back from the irritated waitress, checked the picture and rubbed my eyes in disbelief  I was about to witness the first performance of Abe Lincoln, Standup Comic:

description: NEW YORK  Leon Wieseltier of The New Republic wrote a simple sentence recently that cut to the quick of this U.S. election: What you think of a presidential candidate is in large measure determined by what you think of the world.

title: Superdelegate Poll: Unsettled Ground
description: Despite Senator Barack Obamas strong showing in recent primaries, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to hold onto more support from superdelegates, the Democratic Party elites, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.The current count is 189.5 superdelegate votes for Mrs. Clinton and 142.5 for Mr. Obama. But in a similar survey conducted last month, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Obama by 204 to 99. About 8 percent of the total 795 superdelegates changed their minds over the last few weeks, as many states held their primaries and caucuses. Few delegates switched allegiance from one candidate to the other; the main changes were among the undecided delegates. Among the previously undecided delegates who now are endorsing a candidate, Mr. Obama got more of their support. Some of Mrs. Clintons previous supporters are now undecided.

title: Even on Break, Congress Fights Over Wiretapping Bill
description: Congress is out of town for the week on a Presidents Day break, but the fight over whether lawmakers should be in Washington trying to reach a deal on terror surveillance legislation rages on.

title: E-Mail at Work: Some Basics
description: Two friends recently asked me for career advice using their companies e-mail accounts, something I thought we all knew was a no-no by this point in the electronic age. The first friend wanted to know if I thought she was revealing too many details about her employer on her blog. (She was.) The second asked me to review her rsum, which was attached. Shortly after these two incidents, I heard about a senior manager losing his job for revealing proprietary information about his firm, something he had done through the firms e-mail.

title: Justify Your Existence
description: The Bagger was asked to explain his fascination with the Oscars the other day and he felt as if he had been outed as a fan of show tunes or heirloom Fiesta table settings. The really embarrassing thing is that he not only enjoys the Oscars, he cares about them  more, probably, than he should.

title: Recipe of the Day: Pasta With Bones
description: We all know basic tomato sauce, and were aware that the variations are nearly infinite. But one of my favorites, which requires considerably more time but almost no extra effort, adds the wonderful depth of flavor, silken texture and satisfying chewiness of slow-cooked meat, bone and marrow. Southern Italian in origin, it begins with bony meat (or meaty bones) and requires lengthy simmering.

title: Milan: Please Dont Come
description: Although I am holding an invitation to Giorgio Armanis show today, at noon, I know I am not expected. Yesterday, shortly after I pulled the covers over my head for a little nap, I received an email from Robert Triefus, who is Armanis head of communications. It was marked urgent and inquired if I had received a letter from Armani. I had not, but it didnt take a genius to know what the letter was about. Armani had decided not to invite me to his show and, of course, that was the intent of the letter, once I had read it. He didnt like the tone of my comments about his January couture show in Paris; specifically, he thought I was belittling of his family and friends. I had described their appearance and manner in the moments before the show. It was pretty innocuous stuff. Armani, though, didnt think so. I asked Triefus why Armani had waited until just before todays show to say something; the couture reviews had come out two or three weeks ago. Triefus said Armani had become preoccupied with his ready-to-wear showwere up to fall 2008and hadnt had time to return to the matter until now. Thats our fault, Triefus said.

title: A Case for August
description: In the years since I worked as a drama critic  a period that ended in late 1993, just after the premiere of the second half of Tony Kushners Angels in America  Ive seen few new plays as invigorating as August: Osage County, let alone on Broadway. Though its hard to separate the text from the extraordinary production and cast sent to New York by Chicagos Steppenwolf Theatre Company, the virtues of Tracy Lettss drama should be apparent to readers as well as theatergoers. (Which is not to say you shouldnt rush to catch one of the remaining performances, if at all possible. Letts had most of these actors in mind when writing the play for the company, and when they disband after their limited run, now scheduled to end in mid-April, thats it.)

title: Frozen Potatoes for the Masses?
description: Well heres an interesting one: In the Times of England, Delia Smith, probably Britains best-known and best-selling cookbook author, says celebrity chefs should stay away from politics (which I take to mean everything except cooking) and that the obsession with organic produce is counterproductive. (Thanks to thefoodtimes for the tip. )

title: Q&A on Pakistans Election
description: In the wake of Mondays parliamentary election in Pakistan, Jane Perlez and Carlotta Gall, correspondents covering the vote for The Times, have been answering questions from readers this week. Today we conclude with a final batch of replies from Jane Perlez below. The forum is now closed for questions. Wed like to thank everyone for taking part in the discussion.

title: Herbs, Hypnosis May Ease Common Bowel Pain
description: An estimated one in five Americans suffers from irritable bowel syndrome, a disorder that can cause disabling cramping, constipation and diarrhea. But even though I.B.S., as its often called, is incredibly common, sufferers often are frustrated by the lack of good treatment options.

description: Simply providing a surgeons e-mail address nearly triples the likelihood that a patient will contact the doctor about the surgery, a new report shows.

title: What I Ate Last Night Department
description: I dont claim to invent much (thats because I dont, in fact, invent much), but I dont know too many cases where you brown something on one side then, in an attempt to preserve the crisp skin you achieved, turn it and effectively steam it over liquid or vegetables. (I guess what Im saying is, thanks to whoever taught me this!) This is one such example, and its a good one. This will work with any firm white fish fillet, and any bed of vegetables. You almost cant go wrong.

Jil Sander: Counterpoint
description: Ive just come from the Jil Sander show, at the end of a long, drab, shifty day. This may be the Milan season in which great significance is put on a pleat. The shift or sack dress seems a dominant trend (at Burberry, Alberta Ferretti, Ferre), at least on the first full day of the Milan shows. Dresses and full skirts have inverted or tacked-down pleats, all carefully placed but oh-so tediousand not helped by the doll-like vague models lurching on high shiny heels.

title: This Land: Dodgertown
description: After this year, the Los Angeles Dodgers are planning to hold spring training in Arizona, leaving their longtime home of Vero Beach, Fla.

description: The breakaway province of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia, a moment celebrated by tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians.

title: Hype and glory
description: One thing I worry about a lot if Obama is the Dem nominee  and hes surely the frontrunner now  is that there will be a backlash against Obamamania. Actually, its already starting  probably too late to have much effect on the nomination fight, but in plenty of time to affect the general election.

title: Off to Jury Duty
description: For months, I have known that I would be starting jury duty on February 19th. And for months I have been approaching this date with a mixture of anticipation and anxiety. The part of me looking forward to it hopes that I get selected for a jury. The part of me that is anxious has been hustling to get ahead on work and dodging meeting requests so that I am free in case I am out of commission for a week or longer. (I know that I can defer the jury duty to a more convenient time, but I have already deferred once and, in truth, there arent more convenient times.)

title: La Perla Acquired by French Firm
description: Two major players in international high-end residential development are merging.

title: Scientists Would Turn Greenhouse Gas Into Gasoline
description: If two scientists at Los Alamos National Laboratory are correct, people will still be driving gasoline-powered cars 50 years from now, churning out heat-trapping carbon dioxide into the atmosphere  and yet that carbon dioxide will not contribute to global warming.

title: When Things Go Wrong
description: One afternoon last week, I noticed that one of our mares  a quarter horse named Ida  was stepping slowly as she came into the corral. A horses mobility is everything, and I began wondering about a hoof abscess or a muscle strain. But when I walked over to Ida, I saw a gaping wound on her neck. I could look through the muscle wall and into an anatomical cavern. There was blood, but not the disastrous stream there would have been if the wound had been a couple of inches lower. I could barely watch Ida while we waited for the veterinarian. I was afraid I would see her slide to the ground.

title: Rice, in Nairobi, Offers Incentives to End Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice held pointed talks with the leaders of Kenyas rival political factions on Monday, and said afterward that while their differences were not unbridgeable, the two sides must move much faster to accept a power-sharing deal that would lead to a coalition government.

title: Delta Air Lines Said to Be Near a Northwest Deal
description: Delta Air Lines moved closer on Monday to a deal to buy Northwest Airlines, according to people involved in the talks.

title: Paleontologists Reconstruct a Monster Frog
description: When David Krause first discovered fossil bones from a frog that lived in Madagascar in the time of dinosaurs, he could not tell much except that it was big. He and his co-workers called it the frog from hell.

title: Hewlett-Packard Reports 13% Rise in Revenue
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hewlett-Packard reported first-quarter results on Tuesday that beat analysts expectations and forecast steady growth for the current quarter and the year.

title: Bringing Along Baby Food? Not Too Much, Rules Say
description: SAY you are traveling with your baby on a 2 -hour flight. The Transportation Security Administrations rule says you may carry on baby food and liquids in reasonable quantities for the duration of your itinerary.

title: Long Nights, 90 Below. What More Could Astronomers Want?
description: Its been called the whitest place on Earth, and at 90 degrees below zero, it could be the coolest place on the planet for astronomy.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Sunday about Shaquille ONeals absence from the N.B.A. All-Star Game misstated the year that Damon Jones was his teammate in Miami. It was 2005, not 2006.

title: Britain: Siv Nears Default
description: A $7.15 billion structured investment vehicle managed and sponsored by the British banking company Standard Chartered may default this week after failing to repay maturing debt, Standard & Poors said. The investment vehicle, Whistlejacket Capital, was put into receivership last week.
