It failed to pay notes due last Friday, S.& P. said, and will be in default if it fails to make a payment by Thursday, when a three-day grace period ends. Whistlejacket, based in the British Channel Islands, appointed receivers after a decline in the value of its holdings set into motion rules forcing it to wind down and prompted Standard Chartered to abandon a bailout it had proposed. Standard Chartered is pursuing a reorganization of Whistlejacket, S.& P. said, citing information from Deloitte & Touche, the companys receiver.

title: Britain: Life Sentence in Beheading Plot
description: Parviz Khan, the Birmingham man who pleaded guilty last month to plotting to kidnap and behead a British Muslim soldier, was sentenced to life in prison. Described by witnesses as a keen cricketer and pubgoer until contacts with Islamic militants radicalized him on a trip to Pakistan, he was ordered to serve at least 14 years for the plot, and for supplying militants in Afghanistan with money and equipment. The plot was uncovered by Britains security services. In secret recordings played in court, Mr. Khan was heard teaching his 5-year-old son to carry out a beheading. How do you cut them with a knife? he said to the boy. Show me. Like this. At another point, he asked the boy, Who do you love? The boy replied, I love Sheik Osama bin Laden. Mr. Khan then asked, Who do you kill? The boys reply: America kill. Bush I kill, and Blair kill.

title: Brazil: Retail Sales Increase 9%
description: Brazilian retail sales climbed 9 percent in December from December 2006, capping their best year since at least 2001 as record low borrowing costs stimulated consumer spending. Retail, supermarket and grocery store sales rose 9.6 percent last year, the biggest gain since the national statistics agency started the current series in 2001. The sales that gained the most were those that depend on credit, said Alex Agostini, chief economist at Austin Rating Servios Financeiros in So Paulo. Sales of home appliances and furniture rose 15.4 percent in 2007, the national statistics agency said. Computer and office material sales increased 29.4 percent and vehicle sales jumped 22.6 percent.

title: Behavior: An Absence of Free Will, a Tendency to Cheat
description: If there is no such thing as free will, do you really have to put that money into the office coffee kitty when no one is looking?

title: Gentlemen, 5 Easy Steps to Living Long and Well
description: Living past 90, and living well, may be more than a matter of good genes and good luck. Five behaviors in elderly men are associated not only with living into extreme old age, a new study has found, but also with good health and independent functioning.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a Russian-Chinese draft treaty to ban weapons in space referred incorrectly to five signers of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty that were asked to meet to discuss nuclear disarmament. They are the five nuclear powers that are parties to the treaty; they are not the only signers. (Go to Article)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Saturday about mothers who promote environmentally friendly behavior misstated the Web address of an environmental news site. It is grist.org, not grist.com.

title: An Oldie Vies for Nutrient of the Decade
description: The so-called sunshine vitamin is poised to become the nutrient of the decade, if a host of recent findings are to be believed. Vitamin D, an essential nutrient found in a limited number of foods, has long been renowned for its role in creating strong bones, which is why it is added to milk.

title: Suicide Attack Kills 36 in Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  In the second serious attack in southern Afghanistan in two days, a suicide bomber set off an explosion on Monday as he drove his car near a convoy of Canadian troops on a crowded border town street, killing 36 civilians and wounding 38.

title: Rambo Banned in Myanmar
description: DVD copies of the movie Rambo, starring and directed by Sylvester Stallone, below, are much in demand in Myanmar but very had to find, Agence France-Presse reported. That is because the police there have banned the film, in which Mr. Stallone portrays a Vietnam War veteran battling soldiers of the military junta that rules the country. Police have warned me I could go to jail for up to seven years if I sell the latest Rambo film, said a DVD vendor who declined to be identified. Another seller said that at least 20 customers asked for it every day. One democracy advocate, who declined to say how he obtained a copy, said, I watched the movie at home with my family and gave it to my friends because I wanted them to see it.

title: Barred From Mens-Only Event, Woman Sues Public Golf Club
description: Elaine Joyce, a champion amateur golfer, and her father were looking forward to a weekend tournament last May at the respected public course on Cape Cod where they hold full memberships. But their names were not listed when officials posted the tee times for the event at the Dennis Pines course.

title: Putting His Faith in Telling the Truth
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Three Actors Replace Heath Ledger
description: Jude Law, Colin Farrell and Johnny Depp, from left above, will replace Heath Ledger, above right, in the film he was starring in when he died last month, Aint It Cool News reported. The future of the $30 million film, The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus, a morality tale directed by Terry Gilliam, was thrown in doubt halfway through shooting when Mr. Ledger died of an accidental drug overdose. In the film  which a synopsis says is about a traveling theater troupe that tempts its audiences with the chance to transcend mundane reality by passing through a magical mirror into a fantastic universe of limitless imagination  Mr. Ledger was playing a character who is transported into three separate dimensions. These will now be inhabited, instead, by Mr. Depp, Mr. Law and Mr. Farrell.

title: Do Not Rank
description: MEXICO CITY  Fidel Castro stepped down Tuesday morning as the president of Cuba after a long illness, ending one of the longest tenures as an all-powerful, communist head of state in the world, according to Granma, the official publication of the Cuban Communist Party.

title: No Polo Pony, but Penneys New Label Is Pure Ralph Lauren Americana
description: WHAT do you get when the J. C. Penney Company and the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation team up to sell an extensive new line of clothing and home furnishings? A branding mash-up that some might call Polo Penney.

title: Feared Sweeps for Illegal Workers Found Just One
description: To great fanfare in October 2006, Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, signed a new law requiring 6,000 contractors working for the county to affirm that their employees were not illegal immigrants, prompting fear of impromptu inspections and roundups of Hispanic men.

title: Jamie Davies Is Dead at 73; Made Sparkling Wine
description: Jamie Davies, who with her husband, Jack, founded Schramsberg Vineyards and pioneered the production of fine sparkling wine in California, died Feb. 12 at her home in Calistoga, Calif. She was 73.

title: Verifying a Diagnosis (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hispanic Classics Flavor a New York Debut
description: The first New York appearance by the State Symphony Orchestra of Mexico had all the makings of an occasion. Enrique Btiz, an estimable maestro and the orchestras founder, conducted on Sunday afternoon at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx. The program featured a promising mix of European, Mexican and American classics, and a noteworthy soloist, the Mexican guitarist Alfonso Moreno.

title: In a Divided Kosovo City, a Resounding Vow to Remain Part of Serbia
description: MITROVICA, Kosovo  A day after Kosovos ethnic Albanian leadership declared independence from Serbia, 7,000 Serbs took to the streets of this divided city, waving Serbian flags, chanting Kosovo is Serbia! and burning an American flag covered with the words The Fourth Reich.

title: Plea for Aid as Winter Grips Tajikistan
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  United Nations officials issued an urgent plea on Monday for some $25 million in emergency aid to Tajikistan, the Central Asian country hardest hit by the regions harshest winter in three decades.

title: NASA Insists It Can Fix Flaw in Rocket Design
description: Preliminary calculations by NASA last summer suggested that the rocket it had on the drawing board to replace the space shuttle possessed a design flaw: vibrations in the booster might shake the top of the rocket so violently that any astronauts riding aboard would suffer severe, perhaps fatal, injuries.

title: Candidate Wins Support in the East. No, Farther East.
description: OBAMA, Japan  Just before the results of the big Feb. 5 round of primaries and caucuses reached this snow-covered fishing town hard by the Sea of Japan, a few of its most enterprising residents realized that a man who shared their towns name could be Americas next president.

title: With Oil Prices Rising, Wood Makes a Comeback
description: NEWPORT, Vt.  As a child, Brian Cook remembers hurling wood into the big orange boiler his father bought during the oil crisis of the late 1970s, helping feed the fire that provided heat and hot water to his family.

title: Oil Closes Above $100 for First Time
description: HOUSTON  Crude oil closed above $100 a barrel for the first time on Tuesday afternoon, vaulting through a longstanding psychological barrier amid persistent concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.

title: Tension About Religion and Class in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  When two women in Islamic head scarves were spotted in an Italian restaurant in this citys new shopping mall this month, Gulbin Simitcioglu did a double take.

title: Kosovo Is Recognized but Rebuked by Others
description: BERLIN  Kosovo won the recognition of the United States and its biggest Western European allies on Monday, while earning rebukes and rejections from Serbia, Russia and a disparate mix of states the world over who face their own separatist movements at home.

title: As the Wheels of the Economy Turn
description: To the Editor:

title: The Claim: Honey Can Soothe a Burn
description: THE FACTS

title: The Global Tobacco Threat
description: Three years ago, an international treaty took effect that was designed to help developing countries resist aggressive marketing by big tobacco companies. The idea was that if a large number of countries committed themselves to the same tobacco control policies  including bans on all advertising and promotion  they would be better able to resist pressure from multinational tobacco companies and their own domestic tobacco sellers.

title: Judge to Settle McCartney-Mills Divorce
description: Paul McCartney and Heather Mills had their chance, and now it is up to a judge to determine a divorce agreement and financial settlement for them, The Associated Press reported. As legal teams left the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Monday after no deal was reached between the parties, Mr. McCartneys lawyer, Nicholas Mostyn, said that Justice Hugh Bennett had reserved his ruling and would spend several weeks working out a settlement. Ms. Mills smiled as she departed. Mr. McCartney did not attend. The terms of a settlement will not become public unless it is challenged in the Court of Appeal or if one of the parties elects to disclose its contents. The couple, who separated in 2006 after four years of marriage, went to court to decide how much of Mr. McCartneys fortune, estimated to be as high as $1.6 billion, Ms. Mills would receive.

title: A Company Looks to Its Creative Side to Regain What It Had Lost
description: The great purveyors of modern mass entertainment  Walt Disney, Sumner Redstone, Ahmet Ertegun, Rupert Murdoch  have all known about the push-me, pull-you relationship between art and commerce. Give artists too free a rein, and they will come up with critically acclaimed statements that no one outside the Upper West Side or Laurel Canyon will buy. Hand over creative control to the bean counters and you end up with tepid, overly focus-tested disasters like Waterworld.

title: A Face Travelers Will Find on Every Southwest Flight
description: I TRAVEL the world assisting golf courses on soil and grass issues, as well as making sure that a courses turf meets players exacting standards. Essentially, someone pays me to visit some of the greatest golf courses on the planet. Its a tough job, but somebody has to do it.

title: Qatar Buying Credit Suisse Shares on Open Market
description: DOHA, Qatar  Qatar is buying shares in Credit Suisse and plans to spend as much as $15 billion on European and American bank stocks over the next year, according to its prime minister.

title: Decoding Human Rapport (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Obstacles Remain in  Kidd Trade
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jason Kidd was a no-show at Nets practice Monday, but he was still officially a member of the team.

title: A Cure for the Airport Blues
description: Airport hotels are enjoying a renaissance of sorts as business travelers, frustrated by mounting delays and canceled flights, are leaving the terminal in search of the wider array of amenities available nearby.

title: Fear Keeps East Timor Tent Camps Full
description: DILI, East Timor  When the rain-laden clouds open up, as they frequently do this time of year, the tarpaulin over Alicia Pintos bed leaks and the pathway outside her tent home becomes a quagmire.

title: Have You Ever Been in Psychotherapy, Doctor?
description: A curious thing happened to one of my psychiatric residents not long ago. One of his patients caught him off guard with a challenging question: Have you ever been in psychotherapy yourself?

title: The Color of Victory? Rethinking the Power of a Blue Judo Uniform
description: Its been said that Yankee pinstripes add a certain something to a ballplayers game, an aura of intimidation that will help him succeed. Red Sox fans and others may dispute that idea, but it raises an interesting question: Can an athletes uniform affect success?

title: Brown Defends Takeover of Ailing British Lender
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain on Monday defended his decision to nationalize the ailing mortgage lender Northern Rock, facing down angry shareholders and even the banks own management.

title: The Wrong Target
description: A New York City police detective and his girlfriend have been accused of kidnapping and forcing a 13-year-old girl into prostitution.

title: Magnetic Personalities
description: Q. Why wont a magnet stick to stainless steel?

title: Yanks Say Mitchell Report Didnt Affect Pettitte Deal
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Ever since Andy Pettittes use of human growth hormone was made public in the Mitchell report on Dec. 13, a day after his $16 million contract was announced by the Yankees, speculation has percolated about whether Pettitte and his agents had withheld important information from the club during negotiations.

title: Prognosis: Large Social Networks May Help Surgical Patients
description: Having a large network of friends and family, a new study suggests, may help surgical patients experience less anxiety and pain before their operations and a quicker recovery afterward.

title: Keeping Tabs on the Superdelegates
description: The last time the superdelegates really mattered in a Democratic primary was in 1984. One of the big differences between then and now is the Internet. This has allowed the emergence of a whole new political force that did not exist two decades ago. And it means everyone can watch the political alliances shift and, in a sense, everyone can play.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Jan. 21 about a fire that killed three day laborers in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, misstated the year in which Bensonhurst was annexed into Brooklyn. It was 1894, not 1890. The article also referred incompletely to the area that became Brooklyns 30th ward. It was New Utrecht that was annexed  not just Bensonhurst, which was part of New Utrecht.

title: Regimens: Diet Supplement Seen as Risky for Some Users
description: Probiotics, the potentially beneficial bacteria and yeasts available as diet supplements and in some foods, may not be as helpful as widely believed. A new study suggests that under certain circumstances, they can be deadly.

title: Assessing the Moneyball Payoff
description: Not that they want to see any prospect fail, but old-line major league scouts everywhere stood up and cheered last week. Jeremy Brown, the Oakland Athletics announced, had retired.

title: Consumers Urged to Be Fruitful, but Can Sales Multiply?
description: Editors Note: This issue of In Advertising is coming to you today because of the Presidents Day holiday yesterday. Look for the newsletter next week on its regular day, Monday.

title: In Change, Busch Puts Teammate First
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The boos have rained down on Kurt Busch since 2003, when he instigated a fight with Jimmy Spencer at Michigan International Speedway. Spencer punched Busch in the nose, and Nascar suspended Spencer. Many fans have never forgiven Busch.

title: Black Watch Returns
description: The National Theater of Scotlands production of Black Watch, Gregory Burkes play about a Scottish Army regiment in Iraq, was on just about everyones Top 10 list last year but was scheduled for only 23 performances, all of which sold out, at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn. Good news: Its coming back this fall for another limited engagement at St. Anns, from Oct. 9 to Nov. 30. ... Kate Moira Ryan and Linda S. Chapmans play The Beebo Brinker Chronicles, which opened at the Fourth Street Theater last fall, is also coming back. Lily Tomlin and Jane Wagner are on board as producers, and are bringing Beebo to the 37 Arts Theater. Previews begin on Tuesday. Opening is set for March 5.

title: David Oats, Park Advocate, Dies at 58
description: David Oats, who for 40 years bent the ears of New York City and state politicians in his efforts to protect and improve the 1,255 acres in Queens that he considered his backyard  Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, the site of two worlds fairs  died in Queens on Feb. 5. He was 58.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Neal Bangerter and Chris Betts joined Reactrix Systems, Redwood City, Calif., in new posts. Mr. Bangerter becomes vice president for product management; he had most recently been a business development manager and product planner in the entertainment and devices division at the Microsoft Corporation. Mr. Betts becomes vice president for corporate development; he joins from Hidden River L.L.C., San Francisco.

title: Dorothy Podber, 75, Artist and Trickster, Is Dead
description: Dorothy Podber, a wild child of the New York art scene in the 1950s and 60s who is probably best known for brandishing a pistol and putting a bullet through the forehead of Marilyn Monroes likenesses on a stack of Andy Warhols paintings, died at her apartment in the East Village on Feb. 9. She was 75.

title: Democrats Make Populist Appeals Before Contests
description: WAUSAU, Wis.  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama intensified their populist appeals on Monday, responding to widespread economic anxiety and pushing the Democratic Party further from the business-friendly posture once championed by Bill Clinton.

title: From Tokyo, a Raymonda Hints of the Romance of the Middle Ages
description: WASHINGTON  Romanticism was so called because artists seemed to be harking back to the pre-Renaissance spirit of romance, to the original era of chivalry, of Arthurian ideals and of legends in which knights encountered the supernatural. In that neo-medievalist era of Ivanhoe, La Belle Dame Sans Merci and Lohengrin, ballet came into its own  nowhere more evidently than in Raymonda, choreographed in 1898 by Marius Petipa toward the end of his long and prodigious career (he was 80) to a commissioned score by Alexander Glazunov. Its setting is medieval Provence, its hero a Crusader.

title: Visitor Takes a Countrys Fate in Her Hands
description: Catherine Fillouxs Killing the Boss is not, as its title might suggest, a dark comedy to warm the hearts of oppressed workers everywhere. But this beautifully performed, touching one-act play is not quite the personalized cry against genocide that the playwright intends it to be, either.

title: Protecting Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Defender in the Case of a Slain 7-Year-Old Girl Has His Admirers: Other Lawyers
description: Returning to his law office the other day after yet another Sisyphean court session, Jeffrey T. Schwartz found a letter that, impressively, contained neither threats nor insults.

title: Supreme Court Takes Case on Evidence
description: WASHINGTON  A string of utterly mundane events in southeastern Alabama one July day in 2004 gave rise to an important case that the Supreme Court accepted on Tuesday, turning on the question of when evidence gathered by the police in a wrongful arrest must be thrown out.

title: Footnote
description: Dedication ceremonies are to be held on Wednesday for the Sheila C. Johnson Design Center for Parsons the New School of Design. The 32,800-square foot campus center, designed by Lyn Rice Architects and made possible in part by a $7 million gift from Sheila C. Johnson, a New School trustee and Parsons governor, combines learning and public program spaces with exhibition galleries at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 13th Street in Greenwich Village.

title: Germany Breaks With Its Clubby Business Past
description: FRANKFURT  It has become a familiar tableau in Germany during this season of scandal, even if the names of the disgraced and the details of their misdeeds change from one case to the next.

title: What You Dont Know Can Hurt
Fighting Bedsores With a Team Approach
description: To understand why some doctors and nurses take bedsores so seriously, it helps to call them by their clinical name: pressure ulcers.

title: A Violent Act Takes Shape When Seen Through Time
description: What is it that makes Rules of Engagement, Tuesday nights Frontline offering on PBS, one of the more riveting recent installments of the program?

title: Learning From Tijuana: Hudson, N.Y., Considers Different Housing Model
description: If you doubt that the derelict shantytowns of Tijuana could work as a template for redevelopment in a quaint, upscale town in the Hudson River Valley, youre probably underestimating Teddy Cruz.

title: As Lending Tightens, Education Could Suffer
description: Major commercial education companies are scrambling to ensure a steady stream of college-level students despite the credit squeeze, with some preparing to offer student loans themselves.

title: New Yorker in the White House? Seems Like a Long Shot Now
description: For a while, it looked as if every day might become Presidents Day in New York.

title: After Decades of Dormancy, Drake Shows Its Teeth Again
description: DES MOINES  As the most visible link to the greatest era of Drake University basketball, the radio analyst Dolph Pulliam wears his Bulldogs heart on his sleeves, his back and everywhere else.

title: Obama Extends Streak With Ninth Victory Over Clinton
description: Senator Barack Obama won a decisive victory over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Wisconsin primary on Tuesday night, cutting into Mrs. Clintons long-held support among women, union members and middle-aged voters.

title: Mistake Led to Inspection Failure
description: Confusion over two Chinese factories with similar names led to regulators failure to inspect a plant that makes an ingredient linked to life-threatening side effects with the blood-thinning drug heparin, the Food and Drug Administration said. The regulators mistakenly referred to inspection records for a plant from a different company and cleared the heparin facility without necessary inspections and evaluations, said Joseph Famulare, deputy director at the agencys Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. The agency will begin inspecting the plant this week. On Feb. 11, the F.D.A. said use of heparin in multidose vials made by Baxter International Inc., of Deerfield, Ill., had been tied to dangerously low blood pressure, vomiting and difficulty breathing. Four patients died, the agency said.

title: Absolute Artifice: A Movie Star of the Old School
description: More than 30 years after her death, Joan Crawford continues to exert a fascination that has little or nothing to do with her gifts as an actress, a fact that is one working definition of the term movie star.

title: Revealed: Secrets of the Camouflage Masters
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.  The cuttlefish in Roger Hanlons laboratory were in fine form. Their skin was taking on new colors and patterns faster than the digital signs in Times Square.

title: The Early Lure of Tobacco (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Opinions Abound on English Plan
description: The English Premier Leagues plan for its 20 teams to play an extra league game outside England, a scheme that could be dubbed Plan 39 from Outer Space, gained a grain of support Monday.

title: Man Dies After Fistfight
description: A man died Monday afternoon after a fight with another man at a Dunkin Donuts in eastern Queens, the police said.

title: Patterns: A Video Game, an M.R.I. and What Mens Brains Do
description: Why does it often seem that men enjoy playing video games more than women? Perhaps because they do.

title: Strangers in a Very Dark New York Night
description: The lives of lonely New Yorkers come together and fall apart in Unconditional, a bluesy, moody, ultimately draggy new drama by Brett C. Leonard that opened Monday night at the Public Theater.

title: Diana Inquest Hears Fayeds Accusations
description: LONDON  Mohamed al-Fayed waited more than 10 years for the day in open court when he could lay out his theory of high-level conspiracy in the deaths of Princess Diana and his son Dodi, her lover when both died in a Paris car crash in August 1997.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a Russian-Chinese draft treaty to ban weapons in space referred incorrectly to five signers of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty that were asked to meet to discuss nuclear disarmament. They are the five nuclear powers that are parties to the treaty; they are not the only signers.

title: Slain Editor Heads List of Polk Award Winners
description: A California editor slain as he investigated a business now linked to his murder, and reporters who exposed brutalities in Myanmar and Iraq, an environmental disaster in China and corruption in America were among winners of 14 George Polk Awards for 2007 announced Monday by Long Island University.

title: French Police Round Up Suspects in November Unrest
description: PARIS  The French police on Monday carried out a series of high-profile raids in poor suburbs close to the capital, arresting dozens of people suspected of shooting at the police and setting fires during three days of unrest last November.

title: Reports of Gunmans Use of Antidepressant Renew Debate Over Side Effects
description: Steven P. Kazmierczak stopped taking Prozac before he shot to death five Northern Illinois University students and himself, his girlfriend said Sunday in a remark likely to fuel the debate over the risks and benefits of drug treatment for emotional problems.

title: In Southern California, a Cotton Industry Fades
description: BRAWLEY, Calif.  When a cotton gin is running, it smells like hay, twigs and freshly washed sheets, said Wally Leimgruber, a former cotton farmer. But as is often the case, the gin at the Planters Ginning Company here was silent as Mr. Leimgruber walked the dusty floor one recent afternoon.

title: What People Owe Fish: A Lot
description: Being a resolute hydrophobe who has no more desire to go for a swim than might a kitten in a bag or Luca Brasi in The Godfather, I admit I never thought of myself as a large, scaleless fish out of water.

title: Unshakable Optimist of the House of Bhutto
description: Benazir Bhutto called her 1989 autobiography Daughter of Destiny, and when she was assassinated in December at 54, she became the fourth member of her immediate family to die violently against the backdrop of Pakistani intrigue and politics: her father, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was hanged in 1979 on charges of having ordered the murder of a minor political opponent; her younger brother, Shahnawaz, mysteriously died of poisoning in 1985; and her other brother, Murtaza, was gunned down outside his home in 1996.

title: No Admission of Guilt From Gagn
description: PHOENIX  The stakeout started last Thursday and continued through the weekend. By Monday the news media contingent camped at the Milwaukee Brewers spring training site to talk to a pitcher implicated in the Mitchell report was wearing down like a starter in the late innings.

title: Credit Suisse Writes Down $2.8 Billion
description: PARIS  Credit Suisse on Tuesday announced a new write-down of $2.8 billion that cut $1 billion from its profit and said it had suspended traders for errors that contributed to the loss.

title: Image Awards for Great Debaters
description: The Great Debaters was a big winner at the 39th N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards ceremonies, Variety reported. The film, about the ascent of a debate team from a small all-black college in the 1930s, captured honors for best film, actor (Denzel Washington, who was also its director), actress (Jurnee Smollett) and supporting actor (Denzel Whitaker). Janet Jackson was named outstanding supporting actress for her performance in Tyler Perrys Why Did I Get Married? In the ceremonies at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, Talk to Me, a tale of the symbiotic relationship of two men, was honored for its script, by Michael Genet and Rick Famuyiwa, and its direction, by Kasi Lemmons.

title: Satellite Shooting Is Next as Shuttle Heads Home
description: WASHINGTON  The shuttle Atlantis left the International Space Station on Monday and headed home for a planned Wednesday landing, clearing the way for a Defense Department effort to shoot down a failed spy satellite.

title: Makeshift Office at Heart of Obama Fund-Raising
description: CHICAGO  A cluster of cramped cubicles, tucked away in a rear corner of Senator Barack Obamas campaign headquarters here, comprises the heart of a fund-raising machine that has reshaped the calculus of the 2008 election.

title: Opponents Organize Against States Plan to Scrap Javits Center Expansion
description: The Spitzer administrations decision to scrap a long-promised expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and sell some of its property to plug gaps in the state budget has prompted opposition from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials, state legislators, trade show producers and tourism executives.

title: Many Women Stay Away From the Polls in an Uneasy Pakistani City
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  They arrived in small groups over the course of the day, defying religious militants who say Pakistani women should not be allowed to vote.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about cities in which real estate values are holding up misidentified the state of one city cited as an example. The city is Salem, Ore., not Salem, Mass.

title: 5 Iraqis Killed as Rockets Hit U.S. Base in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Five Iraqi civilians were killed when a barrage of rockets struck the large American military base near Baghdad International Airport and a nearby neighborhood late Monday afternoon, according to American and Iraqi officials.

title: Exploring Different Sides of One of Handels Styles
description: Professional training workshops have been part of the programming fabric at Carnegie Hall since 1990, when they were introduced as part of the halls centennial celebration. The subjects of these concentrated coaching sessions change: chamber music, piano concertos, art song interpretation and conducting have been prominent in recent years. But Carnegies choral workshops have long held a special place in this constellation: the very first of the professional training workshops were those the great choral conductor Robert Shaw directed with his distinctive blend of experience, wisdom and inspiration.

title: A Savior for Chrysler? Read On
description: We despise all the public attention we are getting, Stephen Feinberg, the secretive founder of Cerberus Capital Management, wrote to his investors last month. We do our best to avoid the spotlight, but, unfortunately, when you do some large deals, such as Chrysler and GMAC, it is hard to avoid.

title: House Committee Questions Contract for Former Bush Appointee
description: WASHINGTON  The House Small Business Committee has asked for an investigation into how a newly retired Bush administration appointee with no experience in helping small businesses compete for government contracts received money from the Small Business Administration to do exactly that.

title: The Manchurian Conservative
description: I HAVE a framed New Yorker cartoon depicting two proper gentlemen in suits, eyeglasses and hats presenting themselves to the guard booth in front of the White House. The caption reads: Were from the Far Right. Were here to be mollified.

title: Readers Responses
description: The following are excerpts of reader responses to Alina Tugends Feb. 16 Shortcuts column on whether to buy cable television, high-speed Internet and telephone service in a package from one company:

title: For Perhaps $490 a Month, a Home on the Hudson River
description: Leslie Day flirted, dated, married, raised a family and found her lifes work in Manhattan  or rather, just off its shore.

title: Princeton Plans for an Early Year Abroad
description: Seizing on students desire for a year off before college, Princeton University is working to create a program to send a tenth or more of its newly admitted students to a year of social service work in a foreign country before they set foot on campus as freshmen.

title: Judge Orders Wikileaks Web Site Shut
description: In a move that legal experts said could present a major test of First Amendment rights in the Internet era, a federal judge in San Francisco on Friday ordered the disabling of a Web site devoted to disclosing confidential information.

title: Thomas T. Roberts Dies at 84; Ruled That Baseball Owners Engaged in Collusion
description: Thomas T. Roberts, a prominent arbitrator best known for his mid-1980s ruling that major league baseball club owners had improperly colluded to prevent free-agent players from obtaining richer contracts, died in his sleep Wednesday at his home in Palos Verdes Peninsula, Calif. He was 84.

title: Pettitte Apologizes to Yankees and His Fans
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In a one-hour news conference Monday that neither he nor the Yankees could have ever wished on themselves, a composed Andy Pettitte apologized for using human growth hormone in 2002 and 2004, said there was no other drug use he was concealing and revealed an awkward breakdown in his communications with Roger Clemens, his friend and former teammate.

title: Russias Claim Under Polar Ice Irks American
description: Last August, a team of Russian scientists and legislators trekked to the North Pole and plunged through the ice pack into the abyss, descending more than two miles through inky darkness to the bottom of the ocean.

title: MBIA Replaces Chief and Considers Split
description: The troubled bond insurer MBIA replaced its chief executive on Tuesday with its retired chairman, who said he would consider splitting up the companys insurance business to restore confidence.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the effect the arrest of a doctor accused of playing a role in the killing of her estranged husband is having on their Bukharan Jewish community in Queens misspelled the given name of the victims brother. (The error also appeared on Nov. 9 in an article in some editions.) He is Gavriel Malakov, not Gavril.

title: Showcase for Talents in Progress, and Mentor
description: The premise behind Sugar Salon is serious business: to address the shortage of financing and performance opportunities for women by nurturing and commissioning work by female choreographers. But for a project with such lofty ambitions, isnt the name a little demeaning? The word daddy seems to be lurking around the corner.

title: Inspired by Buddha, Admired as Art
description: The stars of the show arrived in wooden crates at Kennedy Airport on New Years Eve. They had already enjoyed a hugely popular run in Japan and were now embarking on a world tour.

title: Concert in North Korea to Be Broadcast Live
description: The North Korean government has agreed to a live national broadcast of the New York Philharmonics concert in Pyongyang next week, the orchestra said on Monday  an unheard-of event in that isolated country.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Sunday about Israels quandary in deciding what to do about the control of Gaza by the militant Islamic group Hamas misidentified the location where an Israeli soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, was captured in June 2006. It was in Israel, not Gaza. (He was later taken to Gaza.)

title: Fines Sought on Tower Demolition
description: Federal regulators said today that they have cited the general contractor taking down the former Deutsche Bank tower and its former subcontractor for dozens of safety violations at the building where two firefighters died, proposing nearly half a million dollars in fines against them.

title: When the Magic Fades
description: At first it seemed like a few random cases of lassitude among Mary Chapin Carpenter devotees in Berkeley, Cambridge and Chapel Hill. But then psychotherapists began to realize patients across the country were complaining of the same distress. They were experiencing the first hints of whats bound to be a national phenomenon: Obama Comedown Syndrome.

title: Villanova Runner Solves Sleeping Troubles
description: Two years ago, Marcus OSullivan, the former miler and now the Villanova mens track coach, feared for Bobby Curtiss future.Hed fall asleep in the middle of a meet, OSullivan once said. I wasnt sure if he would be awake for a race. I would enter two names for his relay leg. I thought his career might be over.The problem was circadian rhythm disorder, which prevented him from sleeping or staying awake. Now Curtis, a senior from Louisville, Ky., is fine, and two weekends ago he ran 3,000 meters in 7 minutes 50.17 seconds, the fastest time indoors by a collegian this winter. He will run the 3,000 and the distance medley in the Big East indoor championships Saturday and Sunday at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.I dont have trouble with sleep now, Curtis told the New York Track Writers Association by telephone Monday. At the time, it was a very bad thing. For a while, I was going to bed at 2 a.m. and waking up at 7. I had no energy. It closed down everything. The problem was unbearable. It took four months, but I learned better sleeping habits. Now I sleep from 1 to 9 a.m. I feel good now.

title: Delgado Uses Off-Season to Rebuild His Swing
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The statistics compiled by Carlos Delgado during 14 years in the major leagues  particularly his 434 home runs  offer ample evidence that he knows how to hit a baseball. Contrary to popular belief, he did not forget how last season, the worst of his career. But he returned home to Puerto Rico feeling he had to do something radical nevertheless.

title: BBC Ends English Shortwave Service in Europe
description: PARIS  The BBC World Service, which started its scratchy shortwave transmissions to listeners cut off by desert, snow and sea 75 years ago, ended its last English-language shortwave services in Europe on Monday.

title: Forging a Singular Vision From a Many-Sided Talent
description: Meredith Monks career work has long been described, though hardly defined, in terms of its protean nature. Ms. Monk, 65, is a composer and a singer, true. But she is also a dancer and a choreographer, a director, a filmmaker and a conceptualist. She has performed most of her pieces herself, with an ensemble of versatile, sympathetic performers.

title: Of Couples and Romance (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Honors Eastwood
description: The Clint Eastwood film Letters From Iwo Jima, about the lives and deaths of Japanese soldiers in the battle for Iwo Jima in World War II, was named best foreign film at the 31st Japan Academy Awards ceremony on Friday in Tokyo, Variety reported. Joji Matsuokas Tokyo Tower: Mom and Me, and Sometimes Dad, about a mother-son relationship, took the prizes for best film, best director, best actress (Kiki Kirin as the dying mother), best supporting actor (Kaoru Kobayashi as the absent father) and best screenplay (Masuo Suzuki). Hidetaka Yoshioka, who won the best actor prize in 2006 for his performance as a struggling novelist in Always, won again for reprising the role in the nostalgic drama Always 2.

title: In Search of a Real Urban Policy
description: By now, many Americans have heard the presidential candidates talk about issues close to the heart of rural America. They fell all over themselves to praise ethanol in Iowa and condemn nuclear storage in Nevada. But as important as rural problems are, theyre not nearly as big as the task of helping the nations struggling cities  where most Americans live or work. The cities have been the hardest hit as federal policies have failed or gone missing in education, housing, health care, jobs, transportation and environment, to name a few. Yet urban issues have gotten scant attention in this campaign.

title: In Asian Reaction to Kosovo Declaration, Fears of Secession
description: HONG KONG  China, Indonesia and Sri Lanka on Monday criticized Kosovos declaration of independence from Serbia while Taiwan and Australia welcomed it, as Kosovos move appeared a litmus test of attitudes in Asia toward secession.

title: Clinton Camp Says Obama Plagiarized in Speech
description: NILES, Ohio  With the next round of voters set to weigh in on the Democratic presidential race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign on Monday accused Senator Barack Obama of committing plagiarism in a weekend speech. Mr. Obama dismissed the charge as absurd and desperate.

title: In Books for Young, Two Views on Product Placement
description: Specifying a characters brand of lipstick, shoes or handbag is a commonly accepted way to add an aura of reality or consumer aspiration to books aimed at young readers: just think of The Gossip Girl, with that seriess abundant references to Prada and Burberry. But what if writers and publishers enlisted companies to sponsor those branded mentions, as is the widespread practice in Hollywood?

title: Pakistanis Deal Severe Defeat to Musharraf in Election
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistanis dealt a crushing defeat to President Pervez Musharraf in parliamentary elections on Monday, in what government and opposition politicians said was a firm rejection of his policies since 2001 and those of his close ally, the United States.

title: John L. Phillips Jr., 83, Civil Court Judge Is Dead
description: John L. Phillips Jr., a retired Civil Court judge who owned theaters in Brooklyn that were a prominent platform for black activists in the 1980s, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. He was 83.

title: For Publisher in Los Angeles, Cuts and Worse
description: The Hollywood Walk of Fame consists of more than 2,000 terrazzo-and-brass stars embedded in the sidewalk, bearing names from eminent to obscure (Strongheart the dog, anyone?). The walk attracts tourists, but most locals step over  make that drive past  without noticing.

title: Proxy Fight Looms for Yahoo
description: In an escalation of its fight for Yahoo, Microsoft will authorize a proxy fight at the Internet company this week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

title: Lowering Odds of Multiple Births
description: In the complex, expensive and emotionally charged world of fertility treatment, doctors are sounding a call to arms to reverse the soaring rate of multiple births.

title: A Young Politician Becomes a House Painter
description: On a late January morning, Jason West was under the weather and late for work. Sniffling and weary from nights of sleeping on a friends floor in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, the former mayor of the Village of New Paltz showed up at a building on West 60th Street, where he was on a job, in paint-splattered jeans and a work shirt.

title: Welcomed in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Silicon Valley Losing Middle-Wage Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley is in danger of creating its own digital divide.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A photograph on Friday with an article about domestic violence among military personnel carried an incomplete credit. The photograph of Sgt. Jose Aguilar, who was deployed to Iraq despite a pending charge of child abuse, was provided by The Daily News/FENC, Jacksonville, N.C.  not just The Daily News, a Freedom Eastern North Carolina newspaper.

title: China Expresses Concern Over U.S. Plan to Shoot Down a Faulty Spy Satellite
description: BEIJING  In response to a United States plan to shoot down a malfunctioning spy satellite, China has warned against threats to security in outer space, without mentioning its own successful anti-satellite missile test last year.

title: Impressions of Terrorism, Drawn From Court Files
description: Jeffrey Breinholt, who is on leave from a counterterrorism post at the Justice Department, has been studying what he calls an undervalued source of strategic intelligence about the threats we face from radical Islam within the U.S. He has been looking at court decisions.

title: Getting the Most Out of the Human Asset
description: Our inventory goes down the elevator every night, said Fairfax M. Cone, one of the pre-eminent advertising men of the last century. He was describing his companys most important asset: its people.

title: Support for a Theory as to Why Land Sinks Along the Gulf Coast
description: Climate change may be causing sea levels to rise, but in some coastal areas the problem is worsened because the land is sinking as well. Thats the case in Louisiana, where subsidence has caused erosion and loss of wetlands. Without wetlands to act as buffers, the devastation of storms like Katrina is even greater.

title: Wall St. Banks Confront a String of Write-Downs
description: Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.

title: Is There a Bass in the House?
description: In the middle of the first act of a packed English National Opera performance of Donizettis Lucia di Lammermoor on Saturday, a chest infection claimed the voice of the bass Clive Bayley, who was singing the leading role of Raimondo, Lucias tutor. Could the show be saved? Yes indeed, Reuters reported. Out from the audience came Paul Whelan, 38, who just happened to have been studying the role and was scheduled to take over from Mr. Bayley in a few weeks, through he had had no chance to rehearse. As the performance continued, Mr. Whelan sang from the wings and Mr. Bayley mimed the action. At the conclusion Mr. Whelan, wearing suit and tie, joined the cast for a bow onstage, above. The performers received a standing ovation. Im just so glad I was wearing my Armani tie, he said.

title: Promoting a Film, and Other Products
description: The American Basketball Association brought us the red, white and blue basketball, the 3-point shot, the slam dunk contest and huge Afros atop very tall athletes.

title: In U.S., Cuban Exiles Unmoved
description: Cuban exiles in the United States reacted coolly on Tuesday to the overnight news that Fidel Castro was stepping down as president of Cuba, an island he has ruled with an iron fist for almost 50 years.

title: Castro, the First Communist Retiree?
description: Fidel Castro's official announcement that he was stepping down as president of Cuba was long expected: he had temporarily given up power a year and a half ago when his health crisis first began. But Communist leaders are not known to give up power willingly, so Mr. Castro's exit might be a historical first. Or not.

title: Out of Adventurous, Reactionary Vienna
description: Do not look for the Viennese soul in the waltzes of Johann Strauss. Try instead the dark places of Anton Weberns Six Pieces for Orchestra or Alban Bergs Three Orchestra Pieces, both played by James Levine and his Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: Retired Police Officer Shot Dead at Home
description: A retired New York police sergeant was shot to death by his wife Monday morning during a domestic dispute at their home in Howard Beach, Queens, the police said.

title: Scientists Finding Ways to Perfect a Cup of Joe, Without the Attitude
description: Television viewers of a certain age may remember El Exigente, the Colombian coffee buyer with strict standards in commercials for Savarin coffee in the 1960s and 70s. Surrounded by local coffee growers, the white-suited Demanding One would take a sip of some of their fresh-brewed java. A smile of approval would be the cause for much rejoicing.

title: Health Plans Put Onus on Insured
description: Let the patient beware. Going outside your insurers network of preferred doctors or hospitals could be even more hazardous to your financial health than you suspected.

title: Lottery Numbers
New Trove Opened in Kennedy Killing
description: DALLAS  The Kennedy assassination  a defining moment in American history and a never-ending topic of debate among conspiracy theorists  re-entered the spotlight for a moment Monday, after the Dallas district attorney unveiled the contents of a safe that had been secret for more than 40 years.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column in some editions on Sunday about the runner Kenenisa Bekeles world record for two miles at the Norwich Union Grand Prix in England misidentified the nationality of the former record holder, Haile Gebrselassie. He is an Ethiopian, not a Kenyan.

title: Midlife Suicide Rises, Puzzling Researchers
description: Shannon Neal can instantly tell you the best night of her life: Tuesday, Dec. 23, 2003, the Hinsdale Academy debutante ball. Her father, Steven Neal, a 54-year-old political columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, was in his tux, white gloves and tie. My dad walked me down and took a little bow, she said, and then the two of them goofed it up on the dance floor as they laughed and laughed.

title: Chinas Inflation Rose to 7.1% in January
description: HONG KONG  Consumer prices rose 7.1 percent in China last month, the largest increase in more than a decade.

title: A Strong Endorsement for McCain From a Former President
description: HOUSTON  When former President George Bush stood beside Senator John McCain here on Monday and gave him a Presidents Day endorsement, it was just the latest chapter in the sometimes-tangled saga of the Bush and the McCain dynasties.

title: Weeks Notables
description: PLAYER Angelica Figueroa, a 17-year-old senior at Linden High School in California, is hoping to land a spot on Mexicos womens national team when it plays qualifying matches for the Beijing Olympics at a regional tournament April 2-13 in Juarez, Mexico. Two of the six teams in the tournament will advance to the Summer Games in August. Figueroa was born in the United States, but her parents are from Mexico. She is expected to be with the Mexican team Friday when it plays Southern California, the N.C.A.A. champion, in Los Angeles.

title: Domestic Passenger Traffic Rose in 2007
description: CARRIER CUTS MILEAGE BENEFITS Starting in May, US Airways says, frequent-flier miles in its Dividend Miles program will be awarded based on the actual number of miles flown. The change affects passengers who fly short-haul trips of less than 500 miles, including those who use the US Air shuttle between New York and Boston and Washington. Under the previous policy, passengers were awarded a minimum credit of 500 miles a flight, which is standard practice in major airlines frequent-flier programs. US Airways also said that passengers who redeem miles for award travel within 14 days of departure would be changed a quick-ticketing fee of $50 a ticket. US Airways cited record fuel prices and rising airline-related expenses for the changes.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Monday about a New York City Transit employees deft use of the semicolon in a public service placard was less deft in its punctuation of the title of a book by Lynne Truss, who called the placard a lovely example of proper punctuation. The title of the book is Eats, Shoots & Leaves  not Eats Shoots & Leaves. (The subtitle of Ms. Trusss book is The Zero Tolerance Approach to Punctuation.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Thursday about medical testimony in the confrontation between pitcher Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, misspelled the surname of a radiology expert interviewed by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform about an infection that Clemens developed in his left buttocks. He is Dr. Mark Murphey, not Murphy.

title: Little Panic on the Prairie: The Odd World of Jericho
description: The postapocalyptic fantasy Jericho has returned for a second season more pungent and more pointed than its first. (As a matter of procedure we properly ought to start by thanking the fanatics who borrowed from the shows spirit of communitarianism, sending CBS executives 20 tons of peanuts to rescue the series from cancellation.)

title: Higher Education Gap May Slow Economic Mobility
description: The widening gap in higher education between rich and poor, and between whites and minorities, may lead to a downturn in economic mobility, making it harder for todays poor to move up the income ladder, according to the authors of a major research report issued Wednesday.

title: Scientist at Work
description: Carl Zimmer visits Dr. Roger Hanlon in his lab at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Israel Museum
description: The Israel Museum in Jerusalem has opened an exhibition of important art looted by the Nazis from France and then returned after the war.

title: How Much More Damage Can Brian Burke Do?
description: One-minute penalties! Bigger goal nets! Fixing the shootout  by adding more shooters! Yes, its that time of year again: the NHL general managers are meeting to concoct a whole new grab bag of innovations that read less like a summit of hockey executives and more like a Mad Magazine parody of a professional sport.

title: $3.5 Million Homes
description: Properties on the market in Florida, California and Wyoming.

title: Fidel Castro Resigns as President
description: The Cuban leader said that he will not return to lead the country.

title: Credit Suisses $2.85 Billion Surprise
description: Credit Suisse on Tuesday announced new write-downs of $2.8 billion that cut $1 billion from its profit, in a stunning reminder of the difficulty banks face in valuing complicated financial instruments under current market conditions.

title: College Paper Vows to Fight a Takeover by Gannett
description: J. David McSwane, the student editor of The Rocky Mountain Collegian who drew global attention last fall for a four-word editorial criticizing President Bush, is facing another storm.

title: A Start-Up Says It Can Predict Others Fate
description: Is your start-up worthy of investment? Ask the venture investor in a box.

title: Rebukes Are Swift for the Chief of Deutsche Post
description: The German political elite has wasted no time in dissociating itself from Klaus Zumwinkel, the chief executive of Deutsche Post, who is suspected of using a foundation in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

title: Tax Scandal in Germany Fans Complaints of Inequity
description: For wealthy Germans, many of whom have long hidden their money outside the country to avoid its high taxes, this has been a weekend of high anxiety. For their fellow citizens, it has been a riveting spectacle, dominating the public discussion for days.

title: Silicon Valley Starts to Turn Its Face to the Sun
description: Can Silicon Valley become a world leader in cheap and ubiquitous solar panels for the masses?

title: Ericsson Sells Business Exchange to Canadas Aastra
description: A Swedish wireless equipment maker, LM Ericsson, said Monday it would sell its enterprise PBX solutions business to Aastra Technologies of Canada for 650 million kronor ($103 million).

title: Disney Seeks Controlling Stake in Indias UTV
description: The Walt Disney Company may acquire a controlling stake in Indias UTV Software Communications, maker of last years box-office hit The Namesake, after it offered to buy additional shares.

title: Sweden Said to Choose 4 to Advance in Vin & Sprit Auction
description: Swedens center-right government has chosen four bidders in its auction of Vin & Sprit, the maker of Absolut vodka, that will be allowed to perform due diligence of the company, the business daily Dagens Industri reported.

title: 3i Focuses on Ultralase
description: A buyout shop, the 3i Group of London, agreed on Friday to buy a laser eye surgery provider, Ultralase, from Spanish cosmetic surgery group Corporacin Dermoesttica for 174.5 million pounds ($343.2 million).

title: Fortune Super Equity Captures Scorpion
description: Scorpion Offshore, a money-losing oil rig startup, agreed on Friday to a takeover offer from Abu Dhabi-based Fortune Super Equity Management .

title: Season Awards for Giants
description: (This weeks guest blogger has been bleeding Giant blue since the late 1960s with Fran Tarkenton, Spider Lockhart and Ron Johnson. From 4th-and-17 to the Tyree-play-to-be-named-later, all things Giants football can be found on his blog at  ultimatenyg.blogspot.com)

title: IKB Plans $2 Billion Share Sale as Part of Rescue
description: IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the German bank wracked by losses from the United States subprime mortgage crisis, has announced plans to sell 1.5 billion euros ($2.19 billion) in shares as part of a government-sponsored bailout, provided its shareholders agree to the move.

title: NuConomy Raises $3 Million
description: A Web analytics company NuConomy has raised $3 million in its first round of venture funding led by a large advertising conglomerate WPP.

title: Rural Electrification I.P.O., a Test for Investors in India
description: An initial public offering of 156 million shares of Indias state-run lender, the Rural Electrification Corporation, was fully subscribed within the first hour of the opening.

title: Ex-Dow Jones Director Leaves Hong Kong Post
description: David Li, the Hong Kong banker and lawmaker who is paying $8.1 million to settle a United States inquiry into his possible role in an insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones & Company, resigned from the city governments executive council late Saturday.

title: In Turkey, Is Tension About Religion? Class Rivalry? Or Both?
description: ISTANBUL  When two women in Islamic head scarves were spotted in an Italian restaurant in this city's posh new shopping mall this month, Gulbin Simitcioglu did a double take.

title: Abramovichs Evraz Enters Asia With Delong Stake
description: Delong Holdings, a Chinese metals maker, gained 16 percent in Singapore after the Evraz Group, a steelmaker part-owned by the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, said it might buy the company in its first Asian takeover.

title: Reliance Mulls Offering Bonus Shares After Debut Plunge
description: Indias Reliance Power, owned by the billionaire Anil Ambani, could issue bonus shares to investors in a move to compensate them for a sharp decline in its stock price, the company said on Monday.

title: Qatar Petroleum Plans I.P.O. for Gulf Unit
description: Qatar Petroleum,a state-owned oil company, said on Sunday it would sell a 65.8 percent stake in a new holding firm in an initial public offering starting on Feb. 28.

title: Private Equity Firm Said to Rev Up Deal for Ducati
description: A major shareholder in the Italian motorcycle maker Ducati plans to bid for the entire company and delist it, Italys financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore reported, according to Reuters.

title: Deutsche Post Appoints Temporary Chief Amid Tax Scandal
description: The supervisory board of Deutsche Post on Monday picked Frank Appel to lead the mail and global logistics company after his predecessor resigned last week amid a growing tax evasion investigation that has gripped Germany.

title: Final Push for Delta-Northwest Deal
description: CNBC interviews Ron Allen, former chief executive of Delta Airlines and Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times, on the two carriers' push to create to world's largest airline.

title: Subprime Bloodbath to Cut ANZ Profits
description: The Australia & New Zealand Banking Group fell to a 2-1/2-year low in Sydney trading after the chief executive, Michael Smith, said the bloodbath in debt markets would erase profit growth this year.

title: JPMorgan to Funnel $750 Million into Asia Private Equity Fund
description: JPMorgan Chase announced a major push on Monday into private-equity investing in Asia, saying it had earmarked at least $750 million of its own capital to take minority stakes in businesses in a region where buyouts are notoriously difficult.

title: V.W. Denies Chairman Wants to Oust Porsche Chief
description: Volkswagen denied on Sunday that the chairman of its supervisory board, Ferdinand Piech, wanted to oust Wendelin Wiedeking as chief executive of the sports car maker Porsche, V.W.s biggest shareholder.

title: Hedge Fund Investor Raises $263 Million
description: Dexion Absolute, the largest listed closed-end fund investing in a pool of hedge funds, said it raised a further $263 million Monday as demand for those kinds of investments showed no signs of waning despite volatile returns in recent months.

title: Refcos Ex-Chief Pleads Guilty to Fraud and Conspiracy
description: The former chief executive of Refco, one of the worlds biggest commodities brokerage firms, pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy and fraud charges that carry a possible prison term of more than 300 years.

title: Silicon Valley Losing Middle-Wage Jobs
description: Silicon Valley is in danger of creating its own digital divide.

title: Citigroup Sells Japan Headquarters to Morgan Stanley
description: Citigroup, which has been raising funds since taking a huge hit from the United States subprime mortgage meltdown, has sold its Japan headquarters to a rival, Morgan Stanley, in a deal reportedly worth $445 million.

title: Citigroup Rescue Package Finds Admirer
description: In a six-month period from mid-summer to mid-January, government-allied, offshore institutional investors poured more than $40 billion into blue-chip American and European financial institutions, including Barclays, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and UBS.

title: Hedge Funds Hit by Northern Rock Decision
description: RAB Capital and SRM Global, two of Europes best known hedge funds, are likely to be the biggest losers following the British governments decision to nationalize the troubled lender Northern Rock.

title: Brown Defends Takeover of Ailing British Lender
description: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain on Monday defended his decision to nationalize the ailing mortgage lender Northern Rock, facing down angry shareholders and even the banks own management.

title: More Blood Expected on The Street
description: Forget the big bonus, access to the corporate jet and oceans of pricey champagne at dinner. For many bond and equity traders, The New York Post suggests, the new status symbol on Wall Street may a steady job.

title: In Microsoft-Yahoo Deal, Technologies Could Clash
description: If Microsoft succeeds in its conquest of Yahoo, what then?

title: V.C.s Hot on Pythagoras Solar
description: Solar energy startup Pythagoras Solar has completed a $10 million first round of funding led by Israel Cleantech Ventures, according to a report by Clean Edge.

title: Reviewing Disneys Pixar Gamble
description: In 2006, when a newly installed Robert Iger annexed Pixar Animation to Walt Disney, the company he had recently been appointed to run, the deal was met with skepticism.

title: Singapore Said to Sell Part of Merrill Stake
description: It appears that Merrill Lynch is about to get another foreign investor, albeit one with a very small stake. South Koreas Hana Bank has agreed to buy 1 million shares of Merrill Lynch from Temasek Holdings, Singapores state-owned investment company, for $50 million, according to Dow Jones.

title: His Hair Is Still Leaning Toward Hillary
description: Aired Monday night on CBS: Ladies and gentlemen, I know you heard about this: the big tainted meat recall. This is a huge story. Out in California, they found out that something was haywire with the beef. They recalled - listen to this - 143 million pounds of tainted beef, 143 million, yes. Thats one triple stack burger at Wendys.

title: Microsoft to Authorize Proxy Fight at Yahoo
description: In an escalation of its fight for Yahoo, Microsoft will authorize a proxy fight at the Internet company this week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Unless Yahoo quickly reverses course and enters into talks, Microsoft would then seek to nominate a slate of directors to Yahoos board by March 13, the final deadline for nominations, and pursue a lengthy campaign to oust the board.

title: Qatar Buys Up Credit Suisse Shares
description: Qatar is buying shares in Credit Suisse in the open market and plans to spend as much as $15 billion on European and American bank stocks over the next year, according to its prime minister.

title: The Applicant
description: How to make a big impression at your next job interview, from the New York comedy troupe Olde English:

title: The New England Patriot Act
description: Aired Monday night on NBC: Happy Presidents Day, or as Mitt Romney calls it, Monday, I guess.

title: Prada and Ferragamo Still Aim for Listings
description: Prada, the Italian fashion house, is getting ready to send its latest styles down the runways in Milan this week.

title: Bowls of Hot Mystery Meat
description: More of your late night comedy (send via the comment link below):

title: If Youre a Muslim, Why Not Be Religious?
description: The Majlis refers to a group of people sitting down together to talk, informally or formally, or where they meet. These Lede posts continue the conversation about points raised in Generation Faithful, a Times series about Middle Eastern youth. The first article focuses on the Stalled Lives of Egypts young, and the initial Majlis entries are from the staff of The Times Cairo bureau.

title: Slowdown to Test Market for Credit Default Swaps
description: Few Americans have heard of credit default swaps, arcane financial instruments invented by Wall Street about a decade ago. But if the economy keeps slowing, credit default swaps, like subprime mortgages, may become a household term, The New York Times says.

title: Barclays Reports $3.1 Billion Write-Down for 2007
description: Barclays, Britains third-biggest bank, raised its 2007 write-down on the value of risky assets to 1.6 billion pounds ($3.1 billion) but reported profits broadly in line with analysts expectations.

title: Wall St. Banks Confront a String of Write-Downs
description: Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.

title: Cuttlefish Camouflage
description: Carl Zimmer visits Dr. Roger Hanlon in his lab at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA.

title: MBIA Reinstates Ex-C.E.O.
description: MBIA, the beleaguered bond insurer, said Tuesday that Joseph Brown had returned as chairman and chief executive, replacing Gary Dunton, who resigned. Mr. Brown, 59, served as chairman and chief executive until May 2004 and served as executive chairman until May 2007 before retiring.

title: Delta Air Lines Said to Be Near a Northwest Deal
description: Delta Air Lines moved closer on Monday to a deal to buy Northwest Airlines, according to The New York Times.

title: The Early Word: Another Primary Day
description: Its no Super Tuesday, but Hawaiian Democrats and Wisconsinites will head to the voting booths today. Washington State Republicans will allot 19 more delegates in their primary (18 were doled out during the states caucus on Feb. 9). Early voting begins in Texas, as well.

title: A Savior for Chrysler? Read On
description: In a letter to investors about the state of Cerberus Capital Managements investments in Chrysler and GMAC, the firms founder, Stephen Feinberg, came off sounding at turns cavalier and ruthless, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his latest DealBook column.

title: Making Fuel From Air  Some Details
description: Kenneth Chang has written a piece in this weeks Science Times exploring the Los Alamos National Laboratories concept for nuclear-powered fuel refineries that could turn atmospheric carbon dioxide and water into gasoline, jet fuel or methanol. I wrote an initial post on this last week. [UPDATED below]

title: Milan Fashion Week
description: Selections from the runway shows during Milan Fashion Week.

title: You Wanna Make Something of It?
description: T. L. Stanley is about up to here with all of the chatter in the best actress race.

title: Buh Bye
description: Take a look at the video tribute to Mark Lisanti at Defamer, who is leaving so he has enough time to screw up his life enough so that he can go into rehab. The weird thing about the video? Everybody seems so darn sincere.

title: Lets All Meet at the In-N-Out Burger After
description: Surely something will rush in to fill the post-Oscar vacuum created by the cancellation of this years Vanity Fair party? Surely not, says Anne Thompson. She suggests all of the action will be on the run-up, after which the air will just start leaking out of the balloon. She also says that the Elton John bash, which is billed as a viewing party, will stay that way.

title: Little Havanas Less Than Impressed at Castro Resignation
description: What a difference a few hours makes.

title: Funeral of Fidel
description: Cubas dictator has resigned, so resign yourself to more like this:

title: Juno How to Stir Up the Homestretch?
description: Even in the homestretch  Oscar ballots are due today  some people are having trouble generating enthusiasm about this years race. Scott Feinberg is not one of them. As the overlord of the And the Winner Is  blog he has covered every wiggle and wobble in the race, some real and some imagined, and spends a great deal of time reporting, which is breathtakingly uncommon in the blog world.

title: Abandonment of Javits Expansion Stirs Opposition
description: The Spitzer administrations decision to scrap a long-promised expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and sell some of its property to plug gaps in the state budget has prompted opposition from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials, state legislators, trade show producers and tourism executives, Charles V. Bagli reports. It has also revealed deep fault lines within the coalition that in 2006 hailed a since-defunct $1.8 billion proposed expansion as critical to the citys tourism industry and the creation of 20,000 jobs and tens of millions of dollars a year in economic benefits for New York.

title: Following the Twists in the Clear Channel Suit
description: Last week we discussed how Goodman Globals deal got done. One of the points made there was that in these troubled times limiting complexity was a means to ensure greater certainty of deal completion in private equity deals.

title: Does Cuba After Castro Start Now?
description: Fidel Castros decision to opt for the gold watch after half a century has given bloggers something other than the presidential campaign to argue about, and Bobby Cramer, Shakespeares Sisters man in Miami, reports from the heat of the reaction:

title: John McCains Feb. 19 Speech
description: The following is the text as prepared for delivery of Senator John McCains speech to supporters after the Feb. 19 Wisconsin primary, as provided his presidential campaign.

title: For the Moment | High-Pitched Hope
description: (Matt Ross)

title: Hillary Clintons Feb. 19 Speech
description: The following is a transcript of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons speech to supporters after the Feb. 19 primary in Wisconsin, as provided by CQ Transcriptions via The Associated Press.

title: Paintings Street Sojourn: From Museum to Sedans Backseat
description: Update, 11:59 a.m. Police confirm two paintings were recovered. ***

title: European Union Approves Reuters-Thomson Deal
description: The Canadian electronic publisher Thomson won conditional permission from the European Commission on Tuesday to buy Reuters, a deal that will create the worlds leading provider of news and data for professional markets.

title: Bush is right about something
description: Hate to say this, but hes right when he says

title: Barack Obamas Feb. 19 Speech
description: The following is a transcript of Senator Barack Obamas speech to supporters after the Feb. 19 primary in Wisconsin, as provided by CQ Transcriptions via The Associated Press.

title: Recipe of the Day: Escarole and Beans
description: Escarole, a relative of radicchio, has never achieved its cousins status, but to me its a better vegetable, if anything. (Its certainly cheaper.) Like radicchio, its good raw, but escarole really cooks up much better.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: A Proxy Fight for Yahoo
description: CNBC interviews Jeffrey Sonnenfeld of the Yale School of Management and Andrew Ross Sorkin of The Times on Microsoft's new aggressive stance on its bid to buy Yahoo.

title: MBIA's New C.E.O.
description: CNBC's David Faber shares highlights of his discussion with MBIA's returning chief executive as the bond insurer tries to regain its footing.

title: Consumer Conundrum
description: CNBC interviews Floyd Norris, chief financial correspondent, on the misleading rise in retail sales from consumers buying less but paying more.

title: Fernandomania on a Busy Morning
description: Were almost there, everyone. One more day until the first full-squad workout. One more week until an exhibition game against the University of Michigan. Then the roster competition, such as it will be, can finally begin.

title: Listening for a Peep From Sunnyvale
description: Now its Yahoos turn again.

title: The Catalog of Obsolete Technical Skills
description: Another item from the Pogue mailbag:

title: Possible Proxy Fight Puts Yahoo Board in Focus
description: Ronald W. Burkle may want to watch his back.

title: Daytona 500: Behind the Numbers
description: Looking at the top 20 finishers of the Daytona 500, theres quite a bit to digest:

title: Moelis & Co. Said to be Planning a London Office

title: Grand Dreams for Engineers
description: Its not exactly light reading, but theres plenty of good news in a report from the National Academy of Engineering. Its a list of the Grand Challenges in engineering this century compiled by an array of experts like the genetics researcher J. Craig Ventner and Googles Larry Page. Whats encouraging isnt so much the list itself (which has predictably virtuous endeavors like improving the urban infrastructure) but the big picture if offers by comparing past achievements with the challenges of today.

title: Blogs Without the Links
description: By their very nature, the worlds 80 million blogs  give or take a few million  seem to defy easy categorization and evaluation. Sites like Technorati and Bloglines claim to track the most popular blogs, but popularity is just one way to find blogs worth reading. A new book, Ultimate Blogs: Masterworks from the Wild Web, takes a different tack. Edited by Sarah Boxer, it aspires to be a sort of Norton Anthology of Blogging, with excerpts from 27 blogs, 9 of them by people living in New York City.

In fessing up to a $2.85 billion mispricing of securities  a problem that senior management says it had no idea existed a week ago, when it reported fourth quarter profits  the bank says it is not sure whether the mispricing of assets will damage annual earnings for last year, but hopes that it will not.

He and his partner, Steve Clifton, who with his wife, Chrystal, have their own side project, Palmina, are two of the more thoughtful winemakers Ive met from California, dedicated to their own vision regardless of the critical consequences.

title: Congressman Serrano Praises Castro
description: The news of Fidel Castros decision to step down as president of Cuba has generated an outpouring of reaction from American politicians. Most, like President Bush, have expressed hope that Mr. Castros departure from the helm of power will signal a democratic transition in Cuba. But one politician  Representative Jos E. Serrano, a Bronx Democrat  went out of his way to actually praise the Cuban leader today.

title: Game Shows on NBC Led the Ratings on Monday
description: The combination of Deal or No Deal and the new game show My Dad is Better Than Your Dad lifted NBC to a solid No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsens estimates, the new show  which pits father-child teams against each other  attracted 9.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., a respectable showing but far less than the 16.9 million who tuned in for Deal or No Deal at 8 p.m.

title: Keeping Tabs on the Superdelegates
description: In her column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes, The last time the superdelegates really mattered in a Democratic primary was in 1984. One of the big differences between then and now is the Internet. This has allowed the emergence of a whole new political force that did not exist two decades ago. And it means everyone can watch the political alliances shift and, in a sense, everyone can play. Go to Column

description: The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are taking a huge toll on the American military. Who says so? The nations military officers, who are in as good a position as anyone to know.

description: The arrest of David M. Tarloff, a man with a long history of mental illness, in the fatal stabbing of a psychologist in Manhattan has revived discussion on the thorny issue of how people with severe mental illnesses can be helped, even when they resist that assistance.
