description: The Bugatti Type 41 Royale is widely considered the most expensive car in the world. Only six were ever built (between 1927 and 1933). And each is estimated to be worth around $10 million.

title: The Meat Industrys Real Malady
description: Two interesting links for those following the largest beef recall in our nations history. One  by the AP   in yesterdays Times includes a link to the video that shows workers at Westland/Hallmark Meat Co. of Chino, Calif., using fork lifts to ram still-living but sick cattle. The other, in the Wall Street Journal, quotes Westland/Hallmark president Steve Mendell as shocked and horrified by the video.

title: Your Conscience or Your Constituency?
description: How should the nearly 800 unpledged party leader and elected official delegates  the so-called superdelegates  vote when the Democratic convention is held in August? These delegates may well hold the balance of power in this years nomination contest, and unlike regular delegates, they will not arrive at the convention with a binding pledge to vote for either Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama. How they will exercise their power is crucial, and is already the subject of some high-level angst among the Democratic Partys most important leaders.

title: Soft Serve | A Dolce & Gabbana Gym, Luxury License Plates and Kool-Aid Sneakers
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Smarties in Dumbo
description: Its well established that Manhattan is for the rich, the rent-controlled and the prescient who bought years ago. And its old news that most up-and-coming New York writers and editors live in Brooklyn. But whoda thunk that Dumbo  the gritty-chic Brooklyn neighborhood whose acronym means down under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass, home of million-dollar condos, the York Street Projects, artists studios and high-end boutiques  would become a bastion of indie publishing? Lured by the subsidized rent offered by the developer David Walentas, in recent months, Verso, the leftie British press, and Melville House, the literary publisher, have moved to Dumbo, and the upstart literary quarterly N+1 is on its way. The London-based New Left Review has some space in Versos office, and the London Review of Books is also said to have scouted out space there.

title: This Place Is Thai
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Prouder Than  Thou
description: Michelle Obamas statement on the campaign trail that for the first time in my adult lifetime I am really proud of my country set off the expected, if not undeserved, handwringing across the blogosphere.

title: 10-Ton Fish Tanks Will Greet Staten Island Ferry
description: Staten Islanders understandably have a special relationship with the ferry terminals that greet them each day on their commutes to and from work. How else can one explain the grand announcement today that New York City will spend $750,000 in capital funds to erect two eight-foot-tall saltwater tanks  each weighing more than 10 tons  to house 400 colorful fish at the St. George terminal?

title: Getting Ready for The Endless Season
description: After months of speculation, NBC confirmed on Tuesday that it would sidestep the annual star-studded upfront presentation for advertisers and hold a series of client meetings with media buyers instead.

title: New York Democrats Fear Long Nomination Fight
description: New York Democrats are feeling the pressure building within their ranks and within the bigger Democratic machine, as Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama continue to battle it out on the campaign trail with no end soon in sight. Some of the more influential New York Democrats are even calling for one or the other to step down sooner or later to maintain accord in the party. I think Hillary and Barack, if theres not 2,025, have to get together and figure out a mechanism that they both abide by, Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Clinton supporter, said after a speech at the annual Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian caucus for state lawmakers in Albany over the weekend.

title: Moscows Immigrants Face Wave of Skinhead Violence
description: In response to a wave of recent skinhead attacks on non-Slavs in Moscow, city government officials sat down with representatives of ethnic diasporas on Monday for a tense meeting during which leaders from the Azeri, Kygyz and other communities accused law enforcement bodies of harboring sympathy for violent nationalists and for failing to adequately investigate and prosecute hate crimes.

description: Peak oil, that is  a dismal theory that keeps getting more plausible. Real oil prices in Feb. 2008 dollars:

description: A photographic look at a chiselmaker's transition and what may lie ahead.

title: Civic Group Calls for Voting Investigation
description: On Saturday, Sam Roberts reported that in about 80 of the citys 6,106 election districts, unofficial results showed Senator Barack Obama without a single vote, including several districts where he ran a respectable race in a nearby area. City election officials said their formal review of the results, which will not be completed for weeks, had confirmed discrepancies between the vote totals reported publicly  and unofficially  on primary night and the actual tally on hundreds of voting machines across the city.

title: Will Rubber Ducky Ever Be Enshrined?
description: Tucked down Aisle 900 of Toy Fair (just Toy Fair, mind you, not the Toy Fair) at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center  amid the newest whirring, glowing, hovering, shrinking playthings clamoring to be the hit product this year  is a space reserved for the elite of the elite, the toys that dont have to prove themselves anymore to anybody. They are the inductees to the National Toy Hall of Fame.The honored toys include the sophisticated but obsolete (Atari 2600, inducted in 2007) and the humble (cardboard box, 2005), the trademarked (Scrabble, 2004) and the generic (kite, 2007), the domestic (Easy Bake Oven, 2006) and the militaristic (G. I. Joe, 2004).

title: When They Were Young
description: A friend found this picture in an archive and I love all that it conveys about Italian fashion. Im not sure of the identities of the two women on the left (perhaps someone on the blog can help), but, from left to right, thats Giorgio Armani, Valentino, a former Italian president, Mariuccia Mandelli, Gianfranco Ferre and Gianni Versace. Hovering in the background, behind Valentino, is Giancarlo Giammetti. Swell picture, isnt it?

title: The Biggest Airline Deals to Take Flight
description: As the boards of both Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines gather Tuesday to discuss a potential merger  one that could shake up an industry that has clamored for consolidation  its worth putting any deal that is reached in perspective. Dealogic helped DealBook out by listing some of the biggest airline transactions to get off the ground.

title: The Party of the Elite
description: Just as Republicans base our party platform on the principle of individual freedom and opportunity, the ideological foundation for the Democratic Party is all about standing up for the little guy. Democrats want to give a voice to the voiceless and power to the powerless. Except when it comes to nominating their partys candidate for president.

title: Lukewarm
description: In 2005, meal assembly shops were the hottest trend in small business. But not anymore.

title: Are the Westons So Different?
description: I dont see many plays. In fact, being a mother of four small kids, I dont see much of anything lately except for the interior windshield of my minivan. What goes down inside that minivan, however  and I mean along the lines of family conflict and sibling relations and, for that matter, angry mothers (me?!) lashing out at their children  what goes on inside that minivan as we tear away to drop the eldest off at first grade, or try to get our act together in the parking lot of a grocery store as a three year old is in shambles  well, let me tell you, it is high drama. Im not kidding. Babies, toddlers, and small children are people who might as well be in the throes of Tracy Lettss play. They are all raw and barely patient, attached to their siblings unwittingly, vicious and angry, and then, by turns, hysterically funny and apt.

Or the way it tends to disrupt intimate relationships, empty all financial reserves, and sabotage the best-laid career plans. Its not even the endless barrage of (albeit well-meaning) suggestions for cures from everyone you meet, most of which youve already tried anyway (except for the colon cleansing and the Jews for Jesus conversion).

title: Hello Wisconsin!
description: Wrapup | 11:40 p.m.:  Wrapup: Mrs. Clinton heads back to New York tonight and there probably arent too many people who want to be on that plane ride, unless they are the Houdinis of politics. Her presidential bid is handcuffed, in a locked treasure chest, under the ice. Will Ohio and Texas let Mrs. Clinton come up for air?

title: The Miracle Dirt
description: Pilgrims flock to Sanctuario de Chimayo in Chimayo, N.M., known as the Lourdes of America.

title: Morton J. Savada, 85, Seller of 78-R.P.M. Records, Dies
description: Morton J. Savada, who lined the narrow aisles of his store in Midtown Manhattan with nearly a quarter of a million 78-r.p.m. records, offering devotees of King Oliver, Ma Rainey, Artie Shaw and Benny Goodman the chance to hear the original sound of nondigital discography, died at his home in Harrison, N.Y., on Feb. 11. He was 85.

description: Time: 1 1/2 hours

title: Research Centers on Finding New Drugs
description: After years of futile attempts at replacing the defective gene that causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy, researchers are now more intent on overriding the gene.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Friday about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens over the use of performance-enhancing drugs misidentified the investigators to whom Mr. McNamee revealed that he had injected Mr. Clemenss wife with human growth hormone. They were Congressional investigators, not Mr. Clemenss investigators.

title: Birds Sing, Glasses Wail, Storms Rage, Seas Toss
description: Among the great pleasures of regularly attending concerts is the occasional encounter with a performance that far surpasses expectations. The concert by the Juilliard Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night did just that. I cant think of another recent orchestral program that left me more exhilarated.

title: Credit Suisse Says Traders Pricing Errors Will Cause $2.85 Billion in Write-Downs
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse shook the markets on Tuesday when it announced that pricing errors by traders on asset-backed securities would result in write-downs of $2.85 billion.

title: Tape Inquiry: Ex-Spymaster in the Middle
description: WASHINGTON  It would become known inside the Central Intelligence Agency as the Italian job, a snide movie reference to the bungling performance of an agency team that snatched a radical Muslim cleric from the streets of Milan in 2003 and flew him to Egypt  a case that led to criminal charges in Italy against 26 Americans.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Christie  as a United States attorney  awarded a contract to monitor the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. And a correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the awarding of that contract. Although Mr. Christie and Mr. Inglesino served on the Morris County freehold board, they never served together. (Mr. Christie served from 1995 to 1997 and Mr. Inglesino from 2001 to 2007.) And Mr. Christies former law firm was not involved in awarding the contract. (Go to Article)

title: After a Judgment, Music Label Files Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
description: TVT Records, long ranked as one of the top independent labels in the recording industry, filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday as part of an overhaul that involved staff cutbacks and the closing of certain international offices, the company said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the Food and Drug Administration breaking its own rules by not inspecting a plant in China that made the active ingredient of a blood-thinning drug misspelled part of the name of the company that founded American Capital Strategies Ltd., the majority owner of Scientific Protein Laboratories, which owns the plant. It is Oscar Mayer, not Meyer.

title: A Long Journey to a Kinder Chisel
description: IN the 1960s, when Downie McCarty was a teenager and his head was filled with the futuristic wonders of space age technology, he asked his father about his own future. I used to say, Dad, how am I going to make a living making these old kinds of tools?

description: Economic mobility, the chance that children of the poor or middle class will climb up the income ladder, has not changed significantly over the last three decades, a study being released on Wednesday says.

title: A Home Remedy for Juvenile Offenders
description: When Jacob Rivera, 15, was resentenced in May on an assault conviction, he felt he had received a blessing.

title: Making Economics Relevant Again
description: It was only a decade ago that economics seemed to be an old and tired discipline. The field no longer had intellectual giants like John Maynard Keynes or Milton Friedman who were shaping public policy by the sheer force of their ideas. Instead, it was devolving into a technical discipline that was even less comprehensible than it was relevant.

title: Bank of Montreal Takes Write-Down and Bolsters SIVs
description: OTTAWA  The Bank of Montreal said on Tuesday that it would take a first-quarter charge of 490 million Canadian dollars, related to problems in the credit market.

title: Corzine Is Said to Weigh Cutting 3,000 Jobs and One Department
description: TRENTON  Faced with a worsening economy, Gov. Jon S. Corzine is considering reducing the states work force by 3,000 employees and closing at least one department in the administration as part of his plan to slash up to $2.5 billion from next years budget, people who have been briefed on his plans said on Tuesday.

title: Match-Play Event Brings Risks for Top 4 in Ranking
description: MARANA, Ariz.,  For one week each year, the normally staid golf governing bodies comprising the International Federation of PGA Tours step outside the lines and throw down some fairly risky behavior. This is that week, a week when the format is match play and the stakes are higher than only the $8 million purse at the Accenture Match Play Championship at The Gallery at Dove Mountain.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Monday of ****** Jeans at the Silent Barn in Queens misidentified the bassist. He is Randy Huth  not Dave Rosenstrauss, who left the band.

title: Slowdown Hits Towns at Outskirts of Texas Boom
description: LAVON, Tex.  Once little more than a speed trap 25 miles northeast of Dallas, this town started to boom about a year ago, as turreted stone castlettes and modest brick bungalows began springing up in what had been wheat fields.

title: Wisconsin? Texas and Ohio Are Where All the Action Has Gone
description: PARMA, Ohio  Before the polls even opened in Wisconsin on Tuesday, the two Democratic contenders had moved on to campaign in Texas and Ohio, the two next big prizes on the primary calendar.

title: To Lure Adults From Their Living Rooms, More Cinemas Try a Full-Frills Model
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Theres more than popcorn and soda on the menu at Robert Redfords new movie theater here. Try roasted game hen (priced at $17), braised oxtail ($21) or crab cakes ($12). Cocktails, craft beers and local wines round out the list.

title: Commission Report Cites Flaws in New Jersey Civil Union Law
description: New Jerseys civil union law creates a second-class status for same-sex couples and is particularly vexing for people in the military, transgender people, the poor and minorities, according to a report issued on Tuesday by a commission set up to review the law.

title: Work on Site at Trade Center Is Completed 48 Days Late
description: After incurring $14.4 million in late fees, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey completed its excavation of the site for two office towers at the World Trade Center complex on Sunday, and turned it over to Silverstein Properties, the developer.

title: Rice, Across Its Full Spectrum
description: ANYONE who has tried black rice or a good brown basmati knows that whole-grain rice has a bad rap, largely because it takes so long to cook.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the higher risks involved in multiple births misstated the meaning of the term vanishing twin. It is a miscarriage of one twin, not a fetus eliminated in a medical procedure called a reduction.

title: Kidnapping a Theater Critic, or Every Playwrights Dream
description: How funny is the first act of Gray Area at the Barrow Group Theater? So funny that at the intermission youll be saying to yourself, They cant possibly keep this up. And youll be right.

title: New $2.8 Billion Write-Down Jolts Credit Suisse
description: PARIS  Credit Suisse on Tuesday announced new write-downs of $2.8 billion that cut $1 billion from its profit, in a stunning reminder of the difficulty banks face in valuing complicated financial instruments under current market conditions.

title: Separating the Mythology From the Raw Politics of a Senate Campaign
description: One hundred and fifty years on, the Lincoln-Douglas debates enjoy the dubious status of myth. The specific circumstances and local passions that shaped them have long been forgotten, and subsequent events  the rise of Lincoln as a towering national figure and the Civil War  make it almost mandatory to read the debates as an ominous prologue or an intellectual dress rehearsal for national tragedy.

title: Dog Comes Home
description: For the outcast A&E bounty hunter Duane Chapman, the foreseeable future is ending. Mr. Chapman, below, familiarly known as Dog, is going back on the air in his reality show Dog the Bounty Hunter, the gossip Web site TMZ.com reported on Tuesday. The site said that preparations were in progress to restart production as soon as possible, although a premiere date had not been set. The series, the most successful on A&E in recent years, was suspended last fall after Mr. Chapman made racially charged comments in a private telephone conversation that was made public by The National Enquirer, which paid Mr. Chapmans son for it. At the time, A&E announced it was stopping production for the foreseeable future.

title: Bush Welcomes Castros Resignation
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  President Bush said Tuesday that the resignation of Fidel Castro ought to be a period of democratic transition for Cuba, and that the country must hold free and fair elections to pick a successor after half a century of Communist rule.

title: Pakistan Victors Want Dialogue With Militants
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The winners of Pakistans parliamentary elections said Tuesday that they would take a new approach to fighting Islamic militants by pursuing more dialogue than military confrontation, and that they would undo the crackdown on the media and restore independence to the judiciary.

title: Abbas and Olmert Struggle to Move Talks Forward
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli and Palestinian leaders met here on Tuesday amid growing dissonance over the content of their talks and the kind of agreement they are trying to achieve.

title: Document Says Traders Rogue Bets Began in Summer
description: PARIS  New details about the actions of a former trader accused of making billions of dollars of unauthorized bets at the French bank Socit Gnrale showed that he exposed the bank to a significant trading loss in July, six months earlier than the bank has acknowledged.

title: Castro Quits One Role, but May Not Be Done Yet
description: HAVANA  Fidel Castro, bedridden for 19 months, on Tuesday gave up the almost unlimited power he has wielded in Cuba for nearly 50 years, but whether the surprise announcement represented a historic change or a symbolic political maneuver remained unclear.

title: China Notes Pollution at Three Gorges Dam
description: HONG KONG  Chinas State Environmental Protection Administration said on Tuesday that water quality is barely improving in the main body of water behind the Three Gorges Dam and in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, although the water does meet Chinese national standards for drinking, fisheries and swimming.

title: Father Tells of Slaying Suspects Long Ordeal
description: On Saturday, shortly after the police arrested David Tarloff, he was permitted to talk on the phone with his father.

title: Chinese Envoy to Revisit Darfur
description: HONG KONG  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China told Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain on Tuesday that Chinas special envoy for the Darfur region, Liu Guijin, would make his fourth visit to Sudan on Sunday, Chinas Foreign Ministry said.

title: Defense Says Fetus in a Jar Shows the Fall of a Mother
description: Among the many gruesome discoveries detectives made after they entered the Brooklyn apartment where 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown was found dead more than two years ago was a jar containing a fetus on a dresser in the bedroom of the girls parents.

title: With These Nutrition Bars, Every Order Is Special
description: Los Angeles

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about grief on campus after the shootings at Northern Illinois University misstated the course of study in graduate school of the gunman, Steve P. Kazmierczak. He had been a graduate student in social work at the University of Illinois  not sociology, his undergraduate major at N.I.U.

title: Minutemen Fight Change in Highway Cleanup Site
description: SAN DIEGO  When California awarded the San Diego Minutemen, a group well known for its border monitoring in search of illegal immigrants, a permit last Nov. 21 to clean a stretch of highway including the Border Patrol checkpoint at San Onofre, complaints from immigrant advocacy groups and Hispanic lawmakers were swift and strong.

title: More on the Jameel Poverty Action Lab
description: Click on the links below for more information on the Jameel Poverty Action Lab and studies mentioned in David Leonhardt's Economic Scene column:

title: Kidd Really Is Traded to Dallas This Time
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jason Kidd era officially came to an end for the Nets on Tuesday, when they completed a trade that sent Kidd to the Dallas Mavericks for a package that included the talented point guard Devin Harris.

title: Abandoning Ship Is the Way Out for Captain Kidd
description: Nets fans should wish Jason Kidd well as he sets out on yet another expedition in search of that elusive holy grail: an N.B.A. championship.

title: Judge Shuts Down Web Site Specializing in Leaks
description: In a move that legal experts said could present a major test of First Amendment rights in the Internet era, a federal judge in San Francisco on Friday ordered the disabling of a Web site devoted to disclosing confidential information.

title: In Milan, a Four-Year Hunt for the Perfect Home
description: MILAN

title: Twilight of the Dictators: A Chance for Pakistan  and the U.S.
description: After years of American enabling and billions in American aid, Pakistans Pervez Musharraf, was  to put it delicately  trounced in Mondays parliamentary elections. The results are much better than the United States could hope for, and more than President Bush deserved after overinvesting in the former general and his anti-democratic excesses.

title: In Mamets Political World, the One With Ideals Is Odd Woman Out
description: David Mamets blog promoting his Broadway comedy November (at novembertheplay.com) is an intriguing if half-hearted experiment. Written in the voice of the main character, a bumbling president who tries to blackmail and buy his way to re-election, the blog occasionally echoes Mr. Mamets 2005 Off Broadway play, Romance, a too-late attack on political correctness. But more often it exploits the sitcom rhythms of November itself. The president mistily recalls phrases his father used at the dinner table, and writes on the blog: Stuffing the ballot box, I, of course, associated with Thanksgiving, and voting the dead, with Halloween.

title: Raw Broccoli by Another Name
description: HOW about sexy, spicy broccoli, a friend suggested.

title: Obama Extends Streak to 10, Makes Inroads Among Women
description: Senator Barack Obama decisively beat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Wisconsin primary and the Hawaii caucuses on Tuesday night, accelerating his momentum ahead of crucial primaries in Ohio and Texas and cutting into Mrs. Clintons support among women and union members.

title: Justices Will Hear Case on Evidence Suppression
description: WASHINGTON  In theory, a criminal-law doctrine known as the exclusionary rule forbids prosecutors from using evidence obtained by the police as the result of an improper search. In practice, the rule has significant exceptions, like for evidence obtained in good faith through reliance on an invalid search warrant or as the result of erroneous information from a court official.

title: A Pastor Begs to Differ With Flock on Miracles
description: CHIMAYO, N.M.  Its not the dirt that makes the miracles! the Rev. Casimiro Roca said with exasperation.

title: Comments Bring Wives Into Fray in Wisconsin
description: BROOKFIELD, Wis.  In the last week, Senator John McCain has increasingly been taking on Senator Barack Obama at campaign events. And now their wives seem to be entering the fray, with Cindy McCain seeming to get in a dig at Mr. Obamas wife, Michelle.

title: With Earnings Up 38%, H.P. Raises Its Forecast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  While some technology companies have warned of softening in the global economy, Hewlett-Packard is not seeing slowing demand in its own international business, company executives said Tuesday.

title: Its on to Plan B as a Hot Trend Cools Off
description: IN 2005, meal assembly shops were the hottest trend in small business, a concept taken on with gusto by mom-and-pop entrepreneurs. In storefront and shopping-center kitchens nationwide, they sold millions of uncooked entrees in freezer-ready Ziplocs and to-go tins, with stick-on instructions for boiling, simmering, baking or stir-frying the contents into quick dinners at home.

title: Spitzer Aide Uses $30,000 From Funds
description: ALBANY  Declaring that his administration would adhere to high ethical standards, Gov. Eliot Spitzer moved in early 2007 to ban his appointees from campaigning for political office, including fund-raising and spending to promote a candidacy.

title: Newest Restaurants Still Reflect Flush Times
description: SOMEBODY forgot to clue Daniel Boulud in to all of this recession talk. John Fraser and Ed Brown didnt get the memo, either.

title: One Mans Jury Duty Is Another Mans Inspiration to Make Choreography
description: Dancers and choreographers tend to walk through the world wondering what each empty space they see would look like filled with dance. Arthur Mitchell, the artistic director of the Dance Theater of Harlem, is not immune. Called to jury duty three years ago at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Mitchell gazed at the elegant rotunda of the courthouse at 60 Centre Street and saw his dancers performing there.

title: So Much Data, and So Many Ways to Guard It
description: PROTECTING the electronic re- cords of your business has gotten easier and more affordable, thanks to services that can make backups of computer files across the Internet.

title: In Her Own Words
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, speaking on Wednesday at Hunter College in New York City, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Japan: Destroyer Hits Fishing Boat
description: A Japanese naval destroyer collided with a two-man fishing boat in waters near Tokyo, apparently slicing the smaller craft in two, Japans military said. No survivors from the fishing boat have been found. The authorities are investigating why the ultra-modern warships crew and sophisticated Aegis radar systems had not seen the fishing boat.

title: Where to Find Some of the Good Stuff
description: AFTER tasting artisanal dairy products for the last six months, it was apparent that descriptors like artisanal, small batch, farmstead, local and grass-fed are no guarantee of great flavor. Here are some favorites:

title: Packing Heat in the Parks
description: A sound and bipartisan public lands bill is being held up in the Senate in behalf of the gun lobbys attempt to overturn decades-old safety regulations barring people from carrying loaded guns in national parks.

title: Bond Insurer in Turmoil Turns to Familiar Leader
description: Joseph W. Brown Jr. got an inkling three weeks ago that retirement would have to wait. Former colleagues began calling to lament the tough times facing MBIA, the bond insurance company he used to run.

title: Driving to the Gold Rush
description: MAGUARICHIC, Mexico  In these mountains, where conquistadors once gouged gold from open veins in the mountainside, the hardened gold miner of film lore is giving way to a new breed of prospector: geologists and engineers, armed with sophisticated equipment and millions of investor dollars.

title: Inflation Continues to Edge Up
description: Consumer prices rose more than expected last month, the government reported on Wednesday, reinforcing concerns at the Federal Reserve that inflation still poses a threat to the American economy.

title: Justices Make It Tougher to Sue Medical Device Makers
description: WASHINGTON  In a case with huge implications for the health care-technology industry, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that the manufacturer of a federally approved medical device cannot be sued under state law if the device causes an injury.

title: Eat 300 and Say Spherification
description: A BARTENDERS arsenal has looked roughly the same for a century or so. Just about any drink in the book can be whipped up with a sturdy bottle opener, a corkscrew, a long-handled bar spoon, a sharp knife and an all-purpose cocktail shaker.

title: Chianti Steps Out of Its Straw Skirt
description: THE Chianti region in the hills of Tuscany is the spiritual home of the sangiovese grape. With its black cherry and violet aromas, its earthy mineral flavors, its lively acidity and its sometimes dusty tannins, sangiovese speaks directly from the Italian soul.

title: Ex-Refco Chief Faces Civil Fraud Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges on Tuesday against Phillip R. Bennett, former chief executive of the commodities broker Refco Inc., days after he pleaded guilty to criminal charges in a scheme to mask the companys financial health.

title: They're Working on Their Own, Just Side by Side
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Bank Tower Contractors Accused of 44 Violations
description: Federal safety regulators have accused the contractors who were taking down the former Deutsche Bank tower in the summer of indifference or intentional disregard for dangerous conditions that led to a fatal fire there, and of a host of other serious safety violations, officials said on Tuesday.

title: Warehouses Nibble on Edge of Giant California Ranch
description: LEBEC, Calif.  Anyone who has traveled between Los Angeles and San Francisco along Interstate 5 has driven along the western flank of Tejon Ranch, a vast expanse of luminous oak-studded hills that divides the southern and central portions of the state.

title: Trial of 2 Ex-Officials in Iraq Is Delayed as Witnesses Fail to Show
description: BAGHDAD  The trial of two former government officials widely seen as a test of the impartiality of Iraqs judicial system got off to an inauspicious start on Tuesday when it was delayed because crucial witnesses failed to appear.

title: No. 5 Rutgers Struggles Early, but Finishes Strong
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  The Rutgers womens basketball team is hardly a free-flowing group to begin with, but Notre Dame made it even harder for the fifth-ranked Scarlet Knights to find their way to the basket Tuesday night, forcing them to think hard about every pass.

title: U.S. Ponders Next Steps in Pakistan After Election Results
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration was scrambling Tuesday to pick up the pieces of its shattered Pakistan policy after the trouncing that the party of President Bushs ally, President Pervez Musharraf, received in parliamentary elections.

title: Stolen Art on Display in a Search for Owners
description: JERUSALEM  In a remarkable feat of cooperation between France and Israel, requiring intensive negotiations and the passage of a law by the Israeli Parliament, the Israel Museum here has opened an exhibition of important art looted by the Nazis from France and then returned after the war. Some of it was never reclaimed, presumably because the owners were killed in the Holocaust.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a dance entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstated the date of Fluid hug-hugs final performance at the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival. The troupes final performance was Sunday; it is not this Sunday.

title: Inspiration Strikes Only a Desk Away
description: ONE of the most frequently cited advantages of coworking is the cross pollination that takes place. People share ideas rather than actually drum up business.

title: Celebrity Chef Sells His TV Shows and Products to Martha Stewart
description: Is there room in the well-appointed house of Martha for another larger-than-life name brand?

title: Hospitals Accounting Is Under Fire by a Union
description: A union is trying to force nonprofit groups like hospitals to comply with standards of governing similar to those that federal law requires of private companies.

title: Tax Inquiry? Principality Is Offended
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein  Its not exactly the mouse that roared, though maybe the mouse that resisted.

title: Fed Sharply Reduces Forecast for Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, for all its power, faces tough new limits on its ability to keep the economy out of a recession this year.

title: A Window Into Druse Cooking
description: IN the day you may spy Gazala Halabi in the window of her four-month-old restaurant, making Druse pita on a sagg, a griddle that looks like an overturned wok. By dinnertime the pita is made and Mrs. Halabi is at work in the open kitchen at the back of the 18-seat space, meticulously composing appetizer platters and tending to baskets of falafel in the deep fryer.

title: Actions Considered Insane Often Dont Meet the Standards of New Yorks Legal System
description: A diagnosis of schizophrenia and repeated commitments to mental institutions might seem like obvious qualifications for an insanity defense  or maybe not.

title: In His Own Words
description: Senator Barack Obama, speaking on Wednesday afternoon at a rally in the Reunion Arena in Dallas, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Task of Shooting Down Satellite Begins
description: WASHINGTON  The many moving parts of a mission to shoot down a dying spy satellite with an anti-missile interceptor lined up Wednesday after the space shuttle Atlantis returned to Earth, officials said.

title: OTB Unanimously Approves Plan for a Shutdown in June
description: With Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sitting beside them, the board members of the nations largest legal off-track betting operation voted Tuesday to shut down by mid-June, a plan that would close more than 60 neighborhood betting parlors and idle nearly 1,500 workers.

title: Microsoft Said to Plan Proxy Fight for Yahoo
description: Microsoft has begun to make preparations to proceed with a proxy fight against Yahoo as it seeks to gain control of the Internet company, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Ex-Patriots Employee Key Factor in Spy Case
description: Despite Coach Bill Belichick and the Patriots re-entering the public-relations quagmire of the spy saga, deciphering the depth and breadth of their electronic taping habits still largely rests with a former video assistant being prodded to talk from several angles.

title: Jon Stewart, Hands Long Tied by Strike, Pedals Fast for Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  In the bowels of the Kodak Theater, one floor below the auditorium where the elaborate set for the Academy Awards telecast on Sunday was already in place, Jon Stewart, unshaved and wearing Army boots, was sitting in his modest dressing room, just back from the latest planning session with his writing team.

title: Guess How Tooth Fairy Gets Her Cash
description: Imagine youre a playwright given the assignment of writing about the lives of sex workers. Should you titillate? Enlighten? Put corrupt society under a microscope?

title: Small Online Contributions Add Up to Huge Fund-Raising Edge for Obama
description: CHICAGO  A cluster of cramped cubicles, tucked away in a rear corner of Senator Barack Obamas campaign headquarters here, serves as the heart of a fund-raising machine that has reshaped the calculus of the 2008 election.

title: Sears Case Cited by Critics of Safety Panel
description: WASHINGTON  In an effort to pressure lawmakers to toughen legislation on consumer product safety, consumer groups this week began publicizing the recent settlement of a major lawsuit against Sears for installing millions of kitchen ranges that were vulnerable to tipping over.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart on Sunday listing Democratic superdelegates who are supporting a candidate other than the one who won their state or Congressional district erroneously included Representative Bill Pascrell Jr. of New Jersey, a superdelegate who supports Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Mr. Pascrells district was won by Mrs. Clinton, not by Senator Barack Obama.

title: Attack Iran, With Words
description: Prague

title: ONeal Brings Hope and Disquiet to the Valley of the Sun
description: PHOENIX  The Phoenix Suns plumped up their middle by adding center Shaquille ONeal, to the mortification of many denizens of this city who pride themselves on not being superficial. This Botoxing of the Suns starting lineup has launched a thousand scowls, the general sentiment being that it is foolish to risk losing the expressiveness of the Suns offense simply to keep up appearances in the bulked-up Western Conference.

title: Positive Government: A Republican About-Face?
description: To the Editor:

title: Toshiba Concedes Defeat in the DVD Battle
description: TOKYO  The biggest consumer electronic format war in a generation is officially over.

title: Girardi Hopes Hes Seen as Prepared and Caring
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For most of his 12-year stint as manager of the Yankees, Joe Torre made an opening speech to his players that became reasonably predictable: play hard, show up on time. Other maxims in the Torre Rule Book were little more than an index card.

title: Not the Price of Doing Business
description: Most contributors to political campaigns are probably unaware that their money, under federal and state laws, can be used for all sorts of purposes. It can be channeled to other candidates, stored away for a future campaign or spent on unrelated expenses. A prominent New Jersey politician recently tried to use campaign funds to pay his defense lawyers. The states election officials were right to turn him down.

title: Pairings: Lentils With Merguez
description: YEARS ago, when the dollar was stronger and the choices in wine shops fewer, Chianti Classico was the all-purpose wine, served with everything from spaghetti to steak. Even today, an unpretentious bottle of Chianti Classico, with its plummy fruit, good acidity and depth of flavor reminiscent of dried tomato, can stake a claim to an array of dishes.

title: Angry Serbs Burn Border Posts in Kosovo
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Serbs set fire to two United Nations border posts in the north of Kosovo on Tuesday, forcing NATO troops to intervene and fanning fears that the Serbian-dominated north could boil over into violence and lead to the partition of the newborn country.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about President Bushs role in Senator John McCains presidential campaign referred incorrectly to the campaign position of Mercer Reynolds, a Cincinnati businessman. As a national finance co-chairman, Mr. Reynolds is one of several people raising money for Mr. McCain; he is not leading the fund-raising effort. (That position is held by former Representative Tom Loeffler of Texas, the national finance chairman.)

title: Wealth Gap Growing Bigger Among American Colleges
description: Stanford University had an exceptional year for fund-raising in 2007, collecting $832 million in private donations. Harvard, too, reaped a bounty, with $614 million in gifts.

title: On Havanas Streets, Few Expect Much Change
description: Despite looming large over the Cuban people for half a century, engineering their lives down to the city block and barraging them with his innermost thoughts in speeches and essays that went on ad infinitum, Fidel Castro elicited a rather muted reaction on the streets of Havana on Tuesday with his decision to finally stand down as president.

title: Gunman Hid His Tracks, Officials Say
description: CHICAGO  The man who killed five students at Northern Illinois University in DeKalb and himself on Thursday took steps to hide his tracks and conceal his motive, the police said Tuesday.

title: Go on, Leave Your Job
description: FOR those who have started their own business or are thinking of doing so, theres inspiration, comfort, camaraderie  as well as nitty-gritty advice  online. Dozens of blogs offer small-business owners and entrepreneurs free start-up tips and business advice  much of it drawn from their creators experiences.

title: What Does Simplicity Mean? Its Complicated
description: Milan

title: Salem Girls Gone Wild, Townsfolk Gone Irrational
description: The thought of facing The Crucible, especially on a raw February night, can be fatiguing. All those righteous and base emotions, those Salem girls gone wild, those chilling New England interiors  its not easy, as an artist or an audience member, to go head to head with Arthur Millers cruelly magnificent play.

title: Shuttle Lands Safely in Florida
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  The space shuttle Atlantis, after successfully delivering a major new section to the International Space Station, glided home for a landing at the Kennedy Space Center on Wednesday, announcing its arrival moments before with twin sonic booms.

title: New Directors Festival Picks Opening Film
description: Frozen River, which won the grand jury prize at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival, will open the 37th New Directors/New Films series, from March 26 through April 9 in New York at the Walter Reade Theater and the Museum of Modern Art. Starring Melissa Leo, far right, and Misty Upham, near right, Frozen River, directed by Courtney Hunt, is the story of two women in upstate New York  one recently left with two sons to rear, the other a widow on a Mohawk reservation  who become partners in smuggling illegal immigrants from Canada into the United States.

title: Auctions Yield Chaos for Bonds
description: As municipal bond auctions continue to fail  and to produce very odd interest rates when they succeed  it is becoming clear that the auction-rate market is in crisis and chaos, and many securities may never have a successful auction again.

title: An Author Looks Beyond Age Limits
description: Three years ago James Patterson, the creator of the blockbuster best-selling Alex Cross and Womens Murder Club series, began Maximum Ride, a series for young adults about a group of genetically mutated kids who are part human, part bird. The idea, he said, was to get children to love reading  or at least to love reading his kind of books.

title: Ex-Official in Russia Is Convicted of Aid Theft
description: MOSCOW  Russias former nuclear energy minister, who has been charged in the United States with stealing $9 million in American aid intended to improve Russias nuclear security, was found guilty in a Moscow court on Tuesday of embezzlement and abuse of office.

title: Japanese Destroyer Strikes Fishing Boat
description: TOKYO  A Japanese Aegis destroyer ran into a two-man fishing boat on Tuesday in waters near Tokyo, apparently slicing the smaller craft in two, Japans Self-Defense Forces said.

title: Justices Say 401(k) Participants Can Sue
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday unanimously upheld the right of participants in 401(k) retirement plans to sue in an attempt to recover losses if they think their accounts have been mishandled.

title: Court Rejects Suit on Faulty Medical Device
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Supreme Court on Wednesday made it harder for consumers to sue manufacturers of federally approved medical devices.

title: Reporter Held in Contempt in Anthrax Case
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge found a former reporter for USA Today in contempt of court on Tuesday for refusing to name her confidential sources who had discussed a former Army scientists possible role in the 2001 anthrax attacks.

title: Ethan Coen to Have a Return Engagement
description: Sold out in January before its first preview at the Atlantic Theater Companys Stage 2, Ethan Coens Almost an Evening, which recently closed, is headed for a second life at the Bleecker Street Theater. Its three short works, which constituted Mr. Coens debut as a playwright, is to open in previews on March 20 for a run through June 1 at the theater, at 45 Bleecker Street, between Lafayette and Mott Streets, Greenwich Village.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Christie  as a United States attorney  awarded a contract to monitor the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. And a correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the awarding of that contract. Although Mr. Christie and Mr. Inglesino served on the Morris County freehold board, they never served together. (Mr. Christie served from 1995 to 1997 and Mr. Inglesino from 2001 to 2007.) And Mr. Christies former law firm was not involved in awarding the contract.

title: After Wins, Obama Is Focus of McCain and Clinton
description: The Democratic contenders on Wednesday both focused their campaigns on Texas, which has emerged as a critical race for the campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Toshiba Concedes Defeat in the DVD Battle
description: TOKYO  The biggest consumer electronic format war in a generation is officially over.

title: Games Pay Off for NBC
description: The combination of Deal or No Deal and the new game show My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad lifted NBC to a solid No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. Nielsen estimated that the new series, which pits father-child teams against one another, attracted 9.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., a respectable showing, but far less than the 16.9 million who tuned in for Deal or No Deal at 8 p.m. Opposite the game shows, however, the finale of ABCs Dance War averaged 9.1 million viewers while earning the shows lowest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC ranked fourth over all, trailing with October Road (4.4 million) at 10 p.m. behind NBCs Medium (8.5 million) and CBSs CSI: Miami repeat (9.6 million). CBS finished second for the night behind NBC, but third among adults 18 to 49, behind NBC and Fox, which got a boost in that demographic from the finale of Prison Break at 8 (7.4 million) and Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles at 9 (8.1 million). On Sunday NBCs Knight Rider (12.7 million) drew the highest ratings in the 18-to-49 age group for a made-for-television movie on any network in almost three years.

title: Lacking Cure, a New Tack on a Muscle Disease
description: For more than four decades, on telethons featuring celebrity performers and children in wheelchairs, Jerry Lewis has been raising money each Labor Day for the Muscular Dystrophy Association and the disease that helped make poster child part of the American idiom.

title: Supply Fears Push Oil to Triple Digits
description: HOUSTON  Crude oil closed above $100 a barrel for the first time Tuesday, vaulting through a longstanding psychological barrier amid persistent concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.

title: Reread Gatsby: The Dream Was Hollow
description: To the Editor:

title: In Pakistan, Musharrafs Party Accepts Defeat
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Pakistan appeared on Tuesday to be heading for a transition to an elected civilian government after President Pervez Musharraf told visiting United States senators that he accepted the resounding defeat of his party in elections and would work with a new Parliament.

title: Church Choir Director Hired a Pedophile, Prosecutors Say
description: NEW HAVEN (AP)  A former music director at a prominent Greenwich church who was convicted of possessing child pornography hired a pedophile and failed to tell the authorities when that man sexually assaulted a choirboy, prosecutors disclosed on Tuesday.

title: In Newark, Children Reclaim a Playgrounds Meaning
description: NEWARK  To cover the littered lake of cracked asphalt, the students suggested gardens. For the darkest corners of the schoolyard, they asked for new playgrounds, safe and bathed in light.

title: Some Tweaks Bring Success
description: AS the mother of three small children, Missy Carr loved the meal assembly concept. Go to a store, use its recipes and raw ingredients to prepare meals and cart home a bunch of dinners that could be cooked with a toddler hanging on your leg. In May 2006, Ms. Carr, a trained chef who once owned a catering business, opened Thyme Out in Gaithersburg, Md., on her own.

title: To Catch a Thief
description: WASHINGTON

title: Making the Breakup Much Easier
description: MICHAEL AYOUB was an experienced chef and restaurateur when a Brooklyn business owner enlisted his help in 1988 to turn around a struggling catering company. In exchange for his sweat equity, Mr. Ayoub would acquire a one-third interest and be an equal partner with the founder and his daughter.

title: Politics Through an Orwellian Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Natalia Bessmertnova, Ballerina of Innate Lyricism, Dies at 66
description: Natalia Bessmertnova, a ballerina with the Bolshoi Ballet known for her lightness, delicacy and Romantic style, died on Tuesday in Moscow. She was 66.

title: Angler Who Can Make His Line Dance, Too
description: ANDERSON, S.C.  The bass fisherman Skeet Reese rolls into the marina parking lot pulling a boat while bumping to hip-hop on his iPod. His truck is an eccentric size that holds 214 gallons of fuel and requires a climb to the door handle.

title: Telecommuters Cry Ouch to the Tax Gods
description: TENS of thousands of telecommuters are receiving tax bills from states where they do not live, do not vote and do not use local services like schools.

title: Twilight of the Dictators: And a Chance for Cuba  and the U.S.
description: It was age and illness, not the free voice of the Cuban people, that finally led Fidel Castro to announce Tuesday that he is stepping down as Cubas president  after a mere 49 years of absolute power. Mr. Castros immediate successor is likely to be his 76-year-old younger brother Ral. Still, the post-Fidel era is clearly at hand, and the Bush administration has done almost nothing to prepare for it.

title: Recipe: Panthay Noodles
description: Adapted from Irene Khin Wong, Saffron 59

title: 2 More Indictments in Tax Shelter Case
description: Federal prosecutors have widened their criminal case involving questionable tax shelters at the accounting firm Ernst & Young, adding two outside defendants.

title: A New Role for Bollywood's Bardot
description: Mallika Sherawat, above, the actress known in some circles as Bollywoods Bardot, has been cast as an ascetic who befriends Jesus of Nazareth in The Aquarian Gospel, a Hollywood film based on the legend that Jesus visited India, Reuters reported. The $15 million film, directed by Drew Heriot, deals with the life of Jesus between the ages of 13 and 30, a period not documented in the Gospels, when some believe he journeyed through India, Tibet and Persia. In a statement released by her press agent, Ms. Sherawat, whose 17 kissing scenes in her Bollywood debut, Khwahish, created a stir, said: I find that in most mythological and spiritual film stories, women seem to be lacking any true wisdom or a sense of humor. I look forward to bringing both of those qualities to this character.

title: A Warm Welcome Helps Pettitte Get Back to Work
description: TAMPA, Fla.  On Andy Pettittes first official day of spring training Tuesday, his teammates hugged him, the fans cheered him and reporters gradually changed the subject from his use of human growth hormone to his hopes for the 2008 season.

title: China: Water Quality Worsens Near Three Gorges Dam
description: The Environmental Protection Administration said water quality was barely improving in the main body of water behind the Three Gorges Dam and in the upper reaches of the Yangtze, although the water does meet national standards for drinking, fisheries and swimming. Water quality is worsening in several branches of the Yangtze that drain into the main reservoir, the agency said in a water management plan, echoing previous government documents. The dam has slowed the flow of the Yangtze, and that reduces the ability of the river and its tributaries to flush out polluted areas.

title: On the Bike: Heading for the Hills Ahead of the Field
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  After two days of sprint finishes by a largely intact peloton, the Tour of California will receive a sharp jolt Wednesday, when the route includes two significant climbs in what will probably be the toughest day of riding in the Tours three-year history.

title: In Rwanda, Bush Mourns 2 Conflicts
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  Skeletons are still being discovered and buried in mass graves on a terraced hillside in this lush, verdant city, the legacy of the gruesome genocide in which 800,000 Rwandans, many of them children, were slaughtered over 100 days in 1994.

The announcement was made in a letter to the nation written by Mr. Castro and published early Tuesday morning on the Web site of Granma, the official publication of the Cuban Communist Party.

title: For Cubans in U.S., Views Have Evolved
description: MIAMI  There was a time when the resignation of Fidel Castro as president of Cuba might have been hailed here by a Cuban-American community speaking in a single full-throated roar of anti-Castro invective.

description: Senator Barack Obama decisively beat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Wisconsin primary and the Hawaii caucuses on Tuesday night, accelerating his momentum ahead of crucial primaries in Ohio and Texas and cutting into Mrs. Clintons support among women and union members.

title: First Film Festival in Saudi Arabia
description: Saudi Arabia, where movie theaters are banned, has something new to look forward to, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the English-language newspaper Arab News: its first official film festival. On May 20 a five-day competition underwritten by the government will feature films from Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf and Arab states. Planned as an annual event and including the participation of film critics from the region for the first time, the festival will take place in the eastern city of Damman under the auspices of the Damman Literary Club and the Saudi Society of Arts and Culture. Films were exhibited in private clubs in Saudi Arabia until all public screenings were banned in the early 1980s on the ground that they contravened Islamic law. Nevertheless, cafes in main cities show films, sports and video clips on large-screen televisions.

Ms. Saxelby, who owns Saxelby Cheesemongers in Manhattan, said that for all the butter she had eaten in her life, I had really never had butter before  this is butter.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about Qatars plans to invest in Credit Suisse and other European and American banks misstated Credit Suisses fourth-quarter earnings report and its write-down of assets because of soured American investments in debt and leveraged loans. It has written down $1.2 billion, not $13.7 billion, and it earned 1.33 billion Swiss francs in the fourth quarter  it did not lose 12.5 billion Swiss francs. The article also misstated the date of the earnings report. It was Feb. 12, not Thursday. (The figures cited were for another large Swiss Bank, UBS.)

title: Supreme Court in Japan Upholds Mapplethorpe
description: The Supreme Court of Japan on Tuesday overruled a 2003 Tokyo High Court decision and decided that Mapplethorpe, a book of erotic photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe (1946-89), shown at right in a self-portrait, did not violate obscenity laws, The Associated Press reported. The decision should pave the way for sale of the book in Japan for the first time in eight years. Although it decided that the book was not indecent, the Supreme Court rejected a demand by the publisher, Uplink, for government compensation of $20,370, according to Takashi Ando, a spokesman for the court. Takashi Asai of Uplink had been contesting the confiscation of the book in 1999 and his voluntary suspension of its sales in 2000 in response to police warnings. In the Supreme Court decision, by a majority of the five-judge bench, Justice Kohei Nasu wrote that the 384-page volume of black-and-white portraits, including 20 close-ups of male genitalia, compiles work from the artistic point of view, and is not obscene as a whole. Mr. Asai sold about 900 copies of the Japanese version of Mapplethorpe, originally published in Japan by Random House in 1994 without objection from the authorities. But airport customs officials, declaring the book obscene, confiscated Mr. Asais copy when he returned from a trip to the United States in 1999. He called the Supreme Court decision groundbreaking and said it could change the obscenity standard used for banning foreign films that depict nudity and for censoring photographs in books.

title: World Club Top 10: Strength  Draining  Away
description: Its been a bad fortnight for the two clubs that have dominated world hockey this season, Detroit Red Wings and Salavat Yulaev Ufa. The Wings went 0-0-1-5 from Feb. 7 through Feb. 17  good for a winning percentage of only .056. And when they did finally win on Monday night, they lost Nicklas Lidstrom, their biggest, most durable star, to a knee injury.

title: Father and Brother of Suspect Describe Long Ordeal With Mental Illness

The family had dealt with a mental health system that, in general, prohibits patients from being hospitalized against their will unless they have been proven to be dangerous to themselves or to others. Eric Konigsberg and Ann Farmer describe an ordeal that began with Mr. Tarloffs diagnosis of schizophrenia 17 years ago. The psychiatrist who made the diagnosis, Kent D. Shinbach, was critically injured when Mr. Tarloff went to his office last week and fatally stabbed his colleague, Kathryn Faughey, a psychologist.

title: Video Intensifies Abortion Debate in Albany

Republicans will try to hold on to their thin margin in the Senate, their last bastion of power in Albany, but strong turnout for the presidential election could aid Democratic efforts to take control of the entire Legislature for the first time in decades.

title: Easy Baba Au Rhum
description: A word of introduction from Mark Bittman:

title: Ratings: CBSs Brother and Jericho Tumble
description: One week after earning relatively mediocre ratings in their debuts, CBSs Big Brother and the second season of Jericho saw their audiences shrink more than a million additional viewers on Tuesday.

title: A Clinton Strategy?
description: If you listened in on a nearly hour-long conference call with Senator Hillary Clintons campaign officials this morning, you could see at least an eight-point strategy for trying to bounce back after 10 straight losses to Senator Barack Obama:

title: Sweet Chaos at the Hawaii Caucuses
description: Democracy is more fun when everybody gets involved. A prime example was yesterdays Democratic caucuses in Hawaii.

title: Dating Ayn Rand
description: In response to my Valentines Day post about books and romance, a reader named Sharon wrote that she was drawn to the passion and devotion of the twisted love between Dominique and Howard in The Fountainhead.

title: Hillary Clinton in Youngstown, Ohio
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton speaks to supporters after the Feb. 19 primary in Wisconsin.

title: Auction Puts Break-Up Fees in Focus
description: Ah, the joys of bankruptcy M&A.

title: Malkin Takes the Scoring Lead
description: You could say Evgeni Malkin has been holding the fort in Pittsburgh. Since Sidney Crosby went out with a high ankle sprain Jan. 18 against Tampa Bay, Malkin has stepped it up as if he were in a reduced-gravity atmosphere. In the 14 games A.S. (After Sidney), Malkin has 11 goals, 16 assists and 27 points. Thats Martn Strakas point total in 45 games.

title: Teamsters Set to Back Obama
description: In a surprising boost for Senator Barack Obama, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will announce this afternoon that it is endorsing him, a top union leader said.

title: Clinton Takes Aim at Hedge Funds
description: Hillary Clinton has drawn a lot of support from Wall Street moguls, including the heads of Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs. Her daughter, Chelsea, even works for a hedge fund, the Avenue Capital Group. (Heres a list of other hedge fund managers who have donated to her campaign.)

title: Mets Take the Field Together
description: The first full-squad workout of the spring began Wednesday in grand style as the players, fresh off the morning address from Willie Randolph, ran out onto the field to stretch.

title: Clintons Stock Dwindles
description: Hillary Clinton may be insisting that its time to get real in the Democratic campaign, but the market-minded seem to think that times long past.

title: Bronx Landlord Is Jailed for Code Violations
description: A Bronx landlord, Hamid Khan, was sentenced to nine days in jail and fined $155,000 for failing to repair hundreds of housing code violations in the 94-unit, six-story building he owns, the citys Department of Housing Preservation and Development announced today.

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: In his weekly show on NY1, Sam Roberts guests include New York Times Metro reporter William Neuman.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Marni
description: (AP)

title: Congrats to Jim Poterba
description: Hes the new president of the National Bureau of Economic Research. Everyone, and I mean everyone, thinks hes a great choice.

title: Ryan Giggss European Century
description: Only eight players have reached the century mark in Europes top club competition. And Manchester Uniteds dynamic Welshman Ryan Giggs is now one of them. He started the teams European Champions League match Wednesday against Lyon, notching his 100th appearance in UEFAs top club competition.

title: Men in Chadors
description: Fareed Zakarias forthcoming book, The Post-American World, tackles big issues  globalization, the rise of China and India, the decline of American hegemony  sometimes by looking at small facts. In a couple of pages, Zakaria discusses the relationship between modernity and clothing, particularly womens clothing. Not surprisingly, he writes, the Muslim world has the biggest problems with its women wearing Western-style clothes. It is also the region where women remain the farthest behind by any objective yardstick. Zakaria has less to say about mens styles, but the connections he draws between politics and clothes made me think of a photograph of one of the Republican presidential debates that appeared in The New York Times last December.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Gucci
description: (AP)

title: McCains Campaign Cash Totals
description: By the end of January, Senator John McCain, who had struggled all of last year in raising money, brought in $11.7 million in contributions, close to the most he had ever raised in a three-month span previously, as Republican donors jumped on his bandwagon, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Daytime TV Judge Loses High Court Case
description: Reuters reports:

title: Rio Tinto Chief on BHP Buyout Bid
description: CNBC interviews Tom Albanese, chief executive of Rio Tinto, on his company's rejection of BHP Billiton's offer to buy it.

title: Obama Responds to Rivals
description: DALLAS  With 10 straight victories behind him, Senator Barack Obama turned his attention squarely on Texas  and, from a distance, Ohio  as he denounced the criticism from his Democratic rival and the presumptive Republican nominee.

title: Professor in Noose Case Is Cited for Plagiarism
description: Updated, 5:18 p.m. | A Columbia University professor who was the apparent target of a hate crime last October, when a noose was left on her office door, has been sanctioned for plagiarism, university officials confirmed today. The plagiarism investigation of the professor, Madonna G. Constantine of Teachers College, was reported today by The Columbia Spectator. This afternoon, she called the investigation biased and flawed and accused the university of a witch hunt.

title: Fox on 52-Week Season: Hey, What About Us?
description: Preston Beckman, the chief scheduler for Fox Broadcasting, was amused by NBCs announcement yesterday of a 52-week programming schedule and a client-centric upfront process.

title: Gabelli Takes CSK Stake
description: Despite one unsolicited merger offer dominating headlines, there are other hostile takeover bids percolating. But one investor appears to think that a conclusion to the drama over CSK Auto may be near.

title: Up on the Roof, at Last
description: Our house is exactly 3,002 square feet under air. (Meaning enclosed and air-conditioned.)

title: After Illinois Shooting Rampage, a Cold Digital Trail
description: The hunt for digital clues in the latest school shooting got off to a promising start last Friday. Hours before the police or news organizations identified the gunman, Loren Coleman of the Copycat Effect took tidbits plotted by a Chicago Tribune article and quickly connected them using the Web.

title: How the West Was Lost?
description: For Democrats, 2008 was supposed to be the year of the Mountain West, when three years of relentless Republican attacks on undocumented immigrants would fuel a backlash among Hispanics that would change the playing field in Arizona, Colorado, Nevada and New Mexico, and perhaps alter the landscape of presidential politics for a generation, reports The Washington Posts Jonathan Weisman. But the emergence of Sen. John McCain (Ariz.) as the likely standard-bearer for the G.O.P. may have scrambled the equation, cooling a potential political revolt among Hispanics and sending Democrats in search of a new playbook.

title: The Discouraging End of the Larry Craig Case
description: After months of lurid clamor, Senator Larry Craig has been formally rebuked by the Senate ethics committee for his run-in with the vice squad last summer in an airport mens room.

title: In Mortgage Crisis, Church Offers Financial Counseling
description: With Brooklyn and Queens accounting for 40 percent of New York States home foreclosures last year, pastors in Catholic churches in the two boroughs started seeing a sharp rise in parishioners with mortgage problems last fall.As a result, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has put together the largest coordinated financial counseling effort since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, focusing on the most vulnerable neighborhoods, in eastern Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Blu-ray Won the Battle. Now Comes the War
description: There is a concept rattling around the blogosphere that Sonys victory over Toshiba in the war to define the high-definition video disc format is moot because soon people will be downloading high-definition videos rather than buying them on discs.

title: The Carpetbagger
description: David Carr visits the Oscars on display in Times Square, and prepares for his L.A. voyage by winning one of his own.

title: Two New Jersey Superdelegates Now Back Obama
description: Senator Barack Obamas resounding victory in Wisconsin on Tuesday echoed in New Jersey today, where he won the backing of two additional superdelegates, including one who had previously declared for his opponent, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.One of the superdelegates, State Senator Dana Redd, who had backed Mrs. Clinton, said she switched because Mr. Obamas growing support had convinced her that he was the best choice to win the general election and lead effectively as president.

title: Maybe They Dont Want to Change
description: With Michelle Obamas remarks about finally being really proud of America having set off a mini-firestorm, a speech she gave at U.C.L.A. in early February is coming under renewed scrutiny. The conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt has audio here, and the passage that has him and others riled up comes at the 8:40 mark: Barack Obama will require you to work. He is going to demand that you shed your cynicism. That you put down your divisions. That you come out of your isolation, that you move out of your comfort zones. That you push yourselves to be better. And that you engage. Barack will never allow you to go back to your lives as usual, uninvolved, uninformed.

title: 3Com: A Failure to Communicate
description: The pending 3Com acquisition on Wednesday joined the Alliance Data Services transaction in regulatory limbo. 3Com announced that it and its agreed buyers, Bain Capital and Huawei Technologies, had withdrawn their application for clearance of the acquisition under Congress Exon-Florio provision.

title: Soft Serve |  Bespoke Hello Kitty, Perriers Fashion Cans, A Whale of An Aquarium
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: The Over/Under is $100 Million
description: Jon Stewart is landing, finally, with both boots on the Oscars and spends some time chatting with Bill Carter. His take about whipping up a show on very short notice now that the writers strike is settled? Make like Nike:

title: A Smarter City Car in Paris?
description: PARIS  A group of spiky-haired teenagers and a small crowd of tourists cracked up as I drove past them in the center of Paris. They had a good reason; I was behind the wheel of an Aixam Scouty R, a two-seater city car built in France.

title: The Head That Wears the Crown
description: The model Agyness Deyn is the inspiration for the boy-short, peroxide-blond heads of hair are appearing all over fashionable London.

title: The Democratic Take: From Top to Bottom
description: The Democratic race is turning out to be a battle of Hillary Rodham Clintons top-down style of politics and Barack Obamas bottom-up, grassroots approach.

title: More from Michelle Obama on Pride
description: Michelle Obama sought today to clarify her pride in her country after two days of criticism, most notably from her potential Republican counterpart.

title: Are You a Log Lady?
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Dress Codes | Don't Step on My Steel-Toed Shoes
description: Work clothes for the stylish idle.

title: Lawsuit Over Police Press Passes
description: The Police Department has faced some recent complaints over how it decides to issue press credentials for journalists. Now it is facing a lawsuit from the New York Civil Liberties Union, which is seeking information about the departments press pass policy.Last year, Rafael Martnez Alequin, a City Hall gadfly who writes about city government for his personal Web site, said he had been denied a press pass because of the often critical questions he poses to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Jury Duty: It Came. It Went. I Served.
description: After all my anticipation and anxiety, jury duty came and went in a flash. Day 1 was interesting. And short. I arrived at 60 Centre Street at 8:45 a.m. along with throngs of fellow citizens and took my seat. The clerks who run the jury process  two women so polished they could play their roles in Jury Duty, the Movie  began orientation with a list of rules. They sprinkled their instructions with more than a few well-placed one-liners. Do not remove any articles of clothing below the waist. Never put your face to the water-fountain fixture. We have cups. Never abandon your possessions; we have had thefts. My neighbor leaned in and whispered to me, If they say it, its happened. We bonded. She agreed to be the trusted buddy whom Clerk #1 advised us to find, available to watch my possessions should I need to use the restroom. I offered the same back.

title: For Advertisers, The Countdown To The 2009 Super Bowl Has Begun
description: Super Bowl XLIII may still be almost XII (er, 12) months away, but at least one advertiser from this years game is already thinking about next year.

title: Profile In Style: Chloe Sevigny
description: Her outfits can be as controversial as her film choices, but Chloe couldn't care less.

title: Bloggingheads: Can Barack Attack?
description:
Jon Fine of BusinessWeek and Ana Marie Cox of Time.com discuss whether Barack Obama can get into the gutter with John McCain if necessary.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: The Indian in the Attic
description: Several readers have pointed out the importance of Johnna, the Cheyenne woman whom Beverly hires to keep house at the beginning of the play  and in whose arms Violet takes comfort at its very end. Since we get to know the Westons through their pathologies and their acid tongues, its easy to ignore the other woman in the house: shes kind to everyone, stays in the background and is all but mute in most of her scenes. But, as Paul Gambaccini points out in a comment, she is essential to the symmetry of the play. In the prologue, Beverly quotes T.S. Eliots poem The Hollow Men to her: Life is very long. And in that final scene, when Violet has finally driven the last of her daughters away, Johnna sings to her from the last lines of the same poem: This is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends. (Eliots punchline, not spoken in the play but entirely relevant: Not with a bang but a whimper.)

title: Betting Parlors Set to Close
description: New Yorkers weigh in on the possibility that Off-Track Betting is approaching extinction in New York City.

Barack Obama in Houston
description: Barack Obama speaks to supporters after the Feb. 19 primary in Wisconsin.

description: (Getty)
