description: In his weekly show on NY1, Sam Roberts interviews New York Times Op-Ed columnist Paul Krugman.

title: Spring Theater: Fantasy Revivals
description: In a season rich with high-profile revivals, the time is right to ask the question: If you could choose any show to revive, what would it be, and which living actors would you cast? Hugh Jackman in Camelot? Reba McEntire in The Unsinkable Molly Brown? Jane Fonda in Applause?

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: In his weekly program on NY1, Sam Roberts talks to the cheif judge of New York State, Judith S. Kaye.

title: Burger Armageddon in South Beach
description: We interrupt our regularly scheduled talmudic inquiries into the laws of kashrut to bring you this special report from Miami.

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: The guests on Sam Roberts's weekly NY1 program this week include the actor and writer Steve Martin.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Touring Shanghai
description: The New York Philharmonic has been burrowing its way deeper into the Chinese world on its Asian tour, which started in Taiwan on Feb. 11, moved to Hong Kong last weekend and is now in Shanghai.

title: International Investors Eye Fernie
description: Add Fernie, Canada, to the list of international snow bird retreats.

title: Kuala Lumpur: A City and its Keychains
description: Theres one big reason to travel to Kuala Lumpur. Well, actually, two:

title: Bidding War
description: BOSTON - So this is what its come to for the Colonial Athletic Association. Two seasons after George Masons magical run to the Final Four and one year after Virginia Commonwealth beat Duke in the N.C.A.A. tournament, one of the most formidable mid-major leagues looks like it could receive only one bid for the tournament field.

title: Book Lust
description: Every now and then, someone who is brilliant says something stupid  often the result of spending too much time riding a jet stream of high praise. Steve Jobs, the co-founder and chief executive of Apple Inc., did such a thing last month when he all but declared the death of reading.

title: Bush Confronts Hard Questions in Ghana
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Traveling across Africa this week, President Bush has been a little like Santa Claus, a benevolent figure from another land handing out gifts  American foreign aid  and generating smiles wherever he goes.

title: A Change to Believe In
description: Fidel Castro has quit after a half-century in power. An African-American has become a serious contender for the U.S. presidency, winning a 10th consecutive victory over his rival for the Democratic nomination. A new European state, Kosovo, has been born.

title: Shuttle Lands, Clearing Skies for Pentagon
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  After a challenging 13-day mission that delivered a major new section to the International Space Station, the space shuttle Atlantis glided home Wednesday for a landing at the Kennedy Space Center, announcing its arrival with twin sonic booms.

title: Firms Fund Holds Off Repayment of a Debt
description: KKR Financial Holdings, the publicly traded fixed-income fund of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, has delayed repaying debt issued by two units after failing to find investors willing to refinance the commercial paper.

title: Machetes and Elections
description: KISUMU, Kenya

title: Directors Guild Ratifies Contract
description: Members of the Directors Guild of America overwhelmingly voted to ratify a new three-year contract with movie and television production companies, the unions president, Michael Apted, said in a statement on Wednesday.

title: Pakistans Victors May Lack Strength to Oust Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  This weeks election will leave President Pervez Musharraf weakened in his post, but continuing returns and haggling over the new government on Wednesday showed his opponents likely to fall short of the numbers needed to impeach him.

title: Clinton Aides Split on How to Take On Obama
description: WASHINGTON  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton meets Senator Barack Obama at a one-on-one debate in Austin on Thursday night, one of her final opportunities to change the course of the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, she will again face the challenge that has repeatedly stymied her: how to discredit her popular opponent without hurting herself.

title: Google Plans Push to Sell Ads to Appear Inside Videos
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hoping to earn more from its vast advertising network, Google said it planned to begin selling ads to appear inside videos on sites across the Web.

title: Suitor Wanted
description: Barry Bonds is still looking for a team, most likely one in the American League, to offer him a contract for the 2008 season. Would you want your favorite team signing him up to play?

title: Deadly Bomb in Mexico Was Meant for the Police
description: MEXICO CITY  Investigators have determined that a man linked to drug traffickers was trying to plant a bomb in a police officials car when it blew up and killed him on a busy avenue here last week, the citys attorney general said.

title: A Private Matter in the Backyard
description: I WANTED to build a cottage in our backyard. The problem was my wife. I had to do it before she noticed.

title: Opposition in Kenya Threatens More Protests
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyas leading opposition party on Wednesday accused the government of stonewalling in negotiations to resolve the countrys festering political crisis and threatened to resume protests if a power-sharing agreement was not reached within a week.

title: Mammals Misbehaving, and Agonized Farewells
description: Cynics and conspiracy theorists might have suspected a hidden agenda in a concert presented by the Da Capo Chamber Players at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night. The group, an accomplished instrumental quintet, augmented by many guests, offered four vocal pieces. Three featured poems by Dana Gioia, who also happens to be the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Court Rules Former A.I.G. Chief Can See Documents
description: The former chief executive of the American International Group, Maurice R. Greenberg, has won a victory in his fight against the insurance company that he ran for nearly four decades.

title: The Peoples Questions
description: Tonight, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama will debate in Texas. What should the professional questioners ask the Democratic candidates? Well, here are a few suggestions, culled from the hundreds sent in by readers of Campaign Stops, the editorial departments election blog. Many, many more terrific (and funny and pointed) suggestions can be found at nytimes.com/campaignstops.

title: The Biggest Beef Recall Ever
description: A nauseating video of cows stumbling on their way to a California slaughterhouse has finally prompted action: the largest recall of meat in American history. Westland/Hallmark Meat Company has issued a full recall of more than 143 million pounds of beef produced over the last two years, including 37 million pounds that went to school-lunch programs.

title: Man in 1986 Police Gunfight Is Killed
description: Larry Davis, the Bronx man who became a hero to some and pariah to others after waging a shootout with a group of police officers who sought to arrest him for murdering rival drug dealers, was killed in a prison-yard fight on Wednesday, the State Department of Corrections said.

title: For McCain, Self-Confidence on Ethics Poses Its Own Risk
description: Correction AppendedNote to Readers Appended

title: How to Drop a Goliath: First, You Hire Two Trainers
description: JESSICA GARCIA sat in a corner of the Crunch gym on West 38th Street, scooping up cinnamon oatmeal as she checked a long list of text messages. Make them remember u a long time, her father, Michael Garcia, wrote. Give them hell, baby.

title: Spirits That Fly High While Rooted in Tradition
description: There is a photograph in the program for the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble, which opened at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, that says a great deal about this unusual Indian dance troupe.

title: Web Legal Scholar Considers Run for House
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Lawrence Lessig, the Web legal scholar, said Wednesday that he was mulling a campaign for the House of Representatives, a move that could pit the Internet icon in a race against a Democratic loyalist.

title: Top Court Allows Suit Over 401(k)
description: WASHINGTON  Participants in 401(k) retirement plans can sue to recover losses when their investment instructions are ignored or the account is otherwise mishandled, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

title: German Bank Bails Out SIV
description: FRANKFURT  Dresdner Bank said on Thursday that it would bail out its vehicle for investing in complex financial products, the latest bank to take the step to avoid a forced sale of assets into turbulent financial markets.

title: Work to Begin on Platform Over Tracks on the West Side
description: Despite a flagging economy, Brookfield Properties says it will start work in June on a $600 million platform over railroad tracks near Ninth Avenue, where it plans to build two towering office buildings.

title: Tip of the Week: Getting Rid of That Nagging Balloon
description: If youre tired of Windows XP nagging you to clean up unused icons from your desktop, you can pop that little yellow balloon for good. Right-click on the desktop and select Properties. Click the Desktop tab and then the Customize Desktop button. In the resulting Desktop Items box, remove the check next to Run Desktop Cleanup Wizard every 60 days and click the O.K. button.

title: Files for Suicide Bombers Show No Down Syndrome
description: BAGHDAD  Psychiatric case files of two female suicide bombers who killed nearly 100 people in Baghdad this month show that they suffered from depression and schizophrenia but do not contain information indicating they had Down syndrome, American officials said Wednesday.

title: Valentn Wants Chance to Make a Difference
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The way Jerry Manuel remembers it, Jos Valentn had been a member of the Chicago White Sox for a little more than a month when, during a spring training meeting in February 2000, he got up from his chair and shared a few thoughts.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Tuesday about the opening concert in the Meredith Monk/Multi-Musics series, at Symphony Space, gave the wrong date for the next performance. It is today, not next Thursday. The phone number for information is (212) 864-5400.

title: For the Record
description: A letter on Tuesday by Doug Hostetter about Iran carried an incorrect dateline. It is Valley Cottage, N.Y., not Cottage.

title: A Big-Screen TV Thats Not Even 2 Inches Thick
description: L.C.D. televisions are all alike, right? A bright screen, some input ports and a power button are all you need. In an effort to mix things up, LG decided to make their latest sets superslim and designer-friendly.

title: Dont Step on My Steel-Toed Shoes
description: IF you think presidential candidates mix their messages as they move between blue-collar and white-collar worlds, look at mens fashion. Many mass-market clothes try to convey class, even as some designer clothes work hard to suggest that the men wearing them do the same. Ponder, for example, that Ralph Laurens Polo line, reeking of upper-class British life, is less expensive and more available than RRL, his vintage-ranch-hand line.

title: Paying Patients Test British Health Care System
description: LONDON  Created 60 years ago as a cornerstone of the British welfare state, the National Health Service is devoted to the principle of free medical care for everyone. But recently it has been wrestling with a problem its founders never anticipated: how to handle patients with complex illnesses who want to pay for parts of their treatment while receiving the rest free from the health service.

title: Britain: Bank Drops Rescue of Fund
description: The British bank Standard Chartered said it had abandoned a plan to rescue its $7 billion structured investment vehicle, Whistlejacket, which was placed into receivership last week and failed to make a debt payment due on Friday. Standard Chartered said it had withdrawn conditional proposals to rescue Whistlejacket because of a number of factors, including the pace of continuing deterioration in the market for certain asset classes and the impracticality of completing any proposal within the confines of the receivership as it has evolved. .

title: The Amber Room at Last?
description: Could it be that more than 60 years after the end of World War II, the Amber Room has been found? Long-lost amber panels backed with gold leaf were stolen by the Nazis from the Soviet Union during the war. Now it appears they may lie in a man-made cavern 60 feet underground near the village of Deutschneudorf on the German border with the Czech Republic, Spiegel Online International reported. The Amber Room, below, created by German and Russian craftsmen, was a gift from King Friedrich Wilhelm I of Prussia to his ally Czar Peter the Great of Russia in 1716. The possible discovery of an estimated two tons of gold was made over the weekend when electromagnetic pulse measurements found the cavern near a long-abandoned railway station. Heinz-Peter Haustein, the mayor of Deutschneudorf and a member of Parliament who led the search, said, Im well over 90 percent sure we have found the Amber Room.

title: In All Corners, the Sons of Drago
description: Wladimir Klitschko of Ukraine fights Sultan Ibragimov of Russia on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden to unify the heavyweight championship, or at least the shares that arent held by Oleg Maskaev, another Russian, and Ruslan Chagaev of Uzbekistan.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a design flaw in the Ares I, the rocket NASA plans to use to replace the space shuttle, misstated the process by which a solid-fuel rocket burns its fuel. It burns outward from the center of its cylindrical core, not from bottom to top.

title: The Bride Wore Very Little
description: THE gown was almost wanton  fluid but curvy with a neckline that plummeted dangerously. It makes me feel sexy and beautiful, said Natasha DaSilva, who slipped it on for a fitting last week.

title: Missile Strikes a Spy Satellite Falling From Its Orbit
description: WASHINGTON  A missile interceptor launched from a Navy warship has struck a dying American spy satellite orbiting 130 miles over the Pacific Ocean, the Pentagon announced late Wednesday.

title: Unpopular Findings
description: "Baseball Prospectus," the annual handbook of major league statistics, prides itself on including a heavy dose of counterintuitive thinking. Steven Goldman, an editor of this year's edition, which comes out Monday, described it as "the antidote to Joe Morgan" -- the Hall of Fame player whose game analysis supplies regular fodder for those following new statistical measurements.

title: Distorted Photos on a Wide Screen
description: Q. Since switching to a widescreen computer monitor, all my photos are horizontally distorted, making people look wider and shorter. Is there a way I can adjust the screen image to properly display the pictures?

title: French Bank Says Its Controls Failed for 2 Years
description: PARIS  A rogue trader at Socit Gnrale, Jrme Kerviel, began making unauthorized transactions beginning in 2005, and lapses in the banks internal controls allowed the trades to go undiscovered until January, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday.

title: Rising Inflation Limits the Fed as Growth Lags
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, for all its power, faces tough new limits on its ability to keep the economy out of a recession.

title: Bronx Landlord Fined and Sentenced to 9 Days in Jail for Code Violations
description: A Bronx landlord, Hamid Khan, was sentenced to nine days in jail and fined $156,000 for failing to correct more than a thousand housing code violations in the 94-unit, 6-story building he owns at 1055 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, the citys Department of Housing Preservation and Development said on Wednesday.

title: Obama, Drawing Criticism on Two Fronts, Fires Back
description: DALLAS  Coming off a decisive string of victories, Senator Barack Obama pushed back against attacks by his political rivals Wednesday as the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination entered a combative and critical two-week period.

title: Guilty Plea in Refco Fraud Case
description: Robert C. Trosten, the former finance chief at the futures trader Refco Inc., pleaded guilty on Wednesday to helping hide hundreds of millions of dollars in debt.

title: You Could Look It Up
description: MY bible for rejuvenating plants is Making More Plants: The Science, Art and Joy of Propagation by Ken Druse (Clarkson Potter, 2000). I also use Google and have turned up countless Web sites with helpful articles and photographs (for close-ups of rare plants, insects and diseases, you might try images.google.com).

title: At a Knockout Teams Event, a Master-Point Milestone
description: Last weekend in Hilton Head, S.C., Michael Passell of Las Vegas became the second player to accumulate 60,000 master points. (The first was Paul Soloway, who died three months ago with 65,511.92 points.) Passell, 60, reached the milestone while winning the Friday-Saturday Knockout Teams at the Low Country Classic Regional with Carolyn Lynch of Scottsdale, Ariz.; David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla.; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.

title: Columbia Cites Plagiarism by a Professor
description: A professor at Columbia Universitys Teachers College who was propelled into the national spotlight when a noose was found on her office door last fall has been found to have plagiarized the work of a former colleague and two former students, the college has announced.

title: Correction: Critical Shopper | Carrots
description: The Critical Shopper column on Dec. 27, about Carrots, a boutique in San Francisco, misspelled part of the name of a brand of dresses sold there. It is Helmut Lang, not Helmet. A reader pointed out the error in e-mail message last week.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Orchid Extravaganza

title: Footnotes
description: Viacoms BET Networks will make their debut in Britain on Feb. 28, carrying American series like 106 & Park, College Hill and American Gangster to more than 8.8 million digital satellite homes, Reuters reported. In time the network, intended for African-American viewers, seeks to develop shows for a British audience. ... The 10-time Grammy winner Beyonc, above,  will be an executive producer and star as Etta James in Cadillac Records, a Sony BMG film about the Chicago label Chess Records, Billboard reported. She joins a cast that includes Adrien Brody as Leonard Chess, the labels founder; Jeffrey Wright as Muddy Waters; Cedric the Entertainer as Willie Dixon; and Columbus Short as Little Walter. Darnell Martin, who wrote the screenplay, will direct. ... Owen Wilson is to return to work next month for the first time since his reported suicide attempt last summer, The Associated Press reported. On March 10, Mr. Wilson and Jennifer Aniston are to begin starring with Alan Arkin in Marley & Me for 20th Century Fox. The film, directed by David Frankel, tells of a couple who adopt a dog as preparation for parenthood, only to find the mischievous animal more than they bargained for. ... Hasbro Inc. and Universal Pictures have entered a six-year partnership to produce at least four films based on Hasbro games, including Monopoly, Battleship, Candy Land and Ouija. An announcement said the first film would be released in 2010 or 2011.

title: Snow, Fly a Kite
description: As Newton knew, gravity is great. But for snow lovers searching for an alternate force to help them cruise, carve, and catapult into the air, wind power is the way to go. Over the past 10 years, the sport of snowkiting, in which skiers and snowboarders strap themselves to lightweight foil kites and ride the wind, has started to blossom in the United States -- and not just in mountain regions. Minnesota and North Dakota are some of the current snowkiting hotspots where beginners, using their own skis, boots and snowboards along with the specialized kites, can figure out how to harness the breezes in just a few hours. (Though snowkiting is, of course, colder than its liquid counterpart, called kiteboarding, it's also safer and easier to learn.)

title: Sales Bumps for Grammy Winners
description: Jack Johnsons Sleep Through the Static (Brushfire/Universal) is the No. 1 album for a second week, with sales of 180,000 copies, but the big winners on the Billboard chart are Amy Winehouse and Herbie Hancock, who had big post-Grammy Awards sales bumps. Ms. Winehouse, who won five Grammys, jumped 22 spots to No. 2 with Back to Black (Universal), selling 115,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. And Mr. Hancock, whose River: The Joni Letters (Verve), above, was named album of the year, leaped to No. 5 from No. 159 with 54,000 sales, a 967 percent increase from its sales the week before. Alicia Keys, who performed at the ceremony and took home two prizes, holds at No. 3 with 109,000 sales of As I Am (J), and the compilation 2008 Grammy Nominees (Hip-O/Universal) is No. 4 with 72,000. ... A new 25th-anniversary edition of Michael Jacksons Thriller (Epic), with several new tracks, was the second-best-selling album in the country last week, moving 166,000 copies, but Billboards rules prevent Thriller from appearing on its main album chart; instead, it is No. 1 on the catalog chart, for albums more than 18 months old.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Thursday about favored projects, known as earmarks, that lawmakers sponsor in spending bills misstated the approach that Representative Bill Sali, Republican of Idaho, uses in dealing with people seeking such funds. Mr. Sali provides earmark application forms to those who ask; he does not solicit applications for earmarks.

title: Restaurants Must Rehire Deliverymen, Judge Rules
description: For nearly a year, devotees of Vietnamese food have encountered deliverymen picketing in front of two of Manhattans most highly rated Asian restaurants: the Saigon Grills on the Upper West Side and in Greenwich Village.

title: A Call for Volunteer Runners
description: New York Road Runners, the club that organizes the New York City Marathon, is asking its members to volunteer if they want to compete. About 7,000 club members gained entry to this years marathon, which will be run Nov. 2, by competing in at least 9 of 41 races of various lengths in 2007. To qualify for the 2009 marathon, members will also be required to volunteer for one of the 50 events the Road Runners organize this year.

title: Lohan Assumes the Pose: Monroes Final Sitting
description: The Feb. 25 issue of New York magazine welcomes this spring fashion season with a cover image that doesnt bother trying to promote the Op-Art prints of Miuccia Prada or the free-form gowns of Missoni or Lanvin. The marketing of fashion has had little do with clothes for a long time, after all. At play instead is a commercialism that is both creepier and more compelling: a picture of a nude Lindsay Lohan, less than a year out of her third go at rehab.

title: Look, Up in the Sky!
description: Let us pause to consider the Pentagons effort to shoot down USA-193, an intelligence-gathering satellite the size of a bus that went out of commission shortly after its launch in 2006 and then began hurtling toward Earth. A window of opportunity opened Wednesday night and soon the world will know whether it has been saved from peril.

title: Wladimir Klitschko Hopes to Reduce Ranks of Heavyweight Champs
description: Quiz:

title: Note on Wall Shuts College in Jersey City
description: Hundreds of students and faculty members were evacuated from classrooms and buildings on the campus of St. Peters College in Jersey City for about two hours on Wednesday after officials at the Jesuit institution discovered a handwritten note taped to a hallway wall. A college spokeswoman said the note referred to the massacre of more than 30 students and teachers at Virginia Tech in April.

title: Home in Box Had Its Problems; Alternative Does, Too
description: The box is as long and low as a frontier coffin, and answers soundly a knock of the knuckles. It has four small wheels and a heavy chain that snakes through a hole on the side and wraps around a No Standing sign. Hundreds of neighbors and Little Italy tourists pass it every day, just off a strip of busy lighting stores on the Bowery at Broome Street. They pass the box with barely a glance.

title: Web Movies Show Why DVDs Sell
description: Ten days ago, Netflix announced that it would abandon HD DVD, Toshiba's entry in the high-definition DVD format war. Six days ago, Wal-Mart dropped HD DVD, too. Then two days ago, Toshiba surrendered, marking the end of the most pointless format war since Betamax-VHS.

title: A Gaping Divide: Straddling Capitalisms Fault Line
description: Jamie Johnson, an heir to the pharmaceutical fortune that bears his familys name, has made a career out of retailing his wealth guilt, and so far the results have been anything but shameful. In Born Rich, shown on HBO in 2003, young people living on ancestral largess spoke  insightfully, candidly, obnoxiously  about the joys and agonies of their circumstances. The film garnered Mr. Johnson two Emmy nominations, and he deserved them. It also won him a chance to try his hand again, this time with The One Percent, another documentary, which arrives with the goal of examining the great, gaping disparity in wealth that severs the American soul.

title: ONeal Shows He Could Be the Suns Missing Piece
description: PHOENIX  The nifty over-the-shoulder pass for an easy basket brought Suns fans out of their seats Wednesday night at U.S. Airways Center. This was not the Suns superlative playmaking guard, Steve Nash, summoning his usual wizardry. It was Shaquille ONeal recording his second assist as a Sun with a blind pass inside to Leandro Barbosa for a first-quarter layup against the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Permission to Use iTunes
description: Q. When I try to add new music to my iTunes library, I keep getting an error message that says I dont have enough access privileges for this operation. This is my own computer, so what does this mean and how can I fix the problem?

title: A Korean Village Torn Apart From Within Mends Itself
description: KURIM, South Korea  This village was once drenched with blood. Bodies of villagers shot or stabbed to death lined its lanes, and the stench of people burned alive saturated its air.

title: An Eco-Friendly Pianist Wears Her Heart on Her Sleeveless Dress
description: Bowing to the protocols of classical music, most female performers give a great deal of attention to selecting a recital dress. But the one the gifted young Korean pianist Soyeon Lee wore during the second half of her recital on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall was almost the center of attention.

title: Walter J. Burghardt, Social Justice Advocate, Dies at 93
description: The Rev. Walter J. Burghardt, a Jesuit priest widely known for emphasizing social justice in the many books he wrote and the seminars he gave on the history and art of preaching, died Saturday in Merion Station, Pa. He was 93.

title: Citys Sweeping Rezoning Plan for 125th Street Has Many in Harlem Concerned
description: The street may not be much to look at now, say people who grew up in Harlem during the 1950s and 1960s, but back then, 125th Street seemed like the bustling center of the world.

title: Puttin on Razzle-Dazzle, One Bead at a Time
description: CRANFORD, N.J.  Glitz doesnt just happen.

title: Microsoft to Share More Technical Secrets
description: Seeking to satisfy European antitrust officials, Microsoft said Thursday that it would open up and share many more of its technical secrets with the rest of the software industry and competitors.

title: Hearing Is Delayed on Contract for Ashcroft
description: A Congressional hearing into lucrative no-bid contracts awarded by federal prosecutors has been postponed because the Justice Department has not indicated whether a leading witness, the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, will testify, Representative Frank Pallone Jr. said on Wednesday.

title: Work to Begin on Platform Over Tracks on the West Side
description: Despite a flagging economy, Brookfield Properties says it will start work in June on a $600 million platform over railroad tracks near Ninth Avenue, where it plans to build two towering office buildings.

title: 2 Superdelegates Declare for Obama in New Jersey
description: Senator Barack Obama won the backing of two additional superdelegates from New Jersey on Wednesday, including one who had declared for his opponent in the Democratic presidential race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Embracing Womens Inner Goddess
description: AS fierce as competition can get in the marketplace, the fight is seldom fought with blades  except, of course, when it comes to the battle between razor companies.

title: Justices Rule on Retroactivity of Decisions
description: WASHINGTON  In a new pro-defendant twist on federalism, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that state courts are free to give criminal defendants the benefit of new constitutional developments, even when federal courts would be foreclosed from doing so.

title: For Ruby, Tall, Thin and Young
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Bob Howsam, 89, Sports Executive, Dies
description: Bob Howsam, who founded the Denver Broncos as an original franchise in the American Football League and later built the Cincinnati Reds championship teams known as the Big Red Machine, died Tuesday at his home in Sun City, Ariz. He was 89.

title: That 70s Look: Stagflation
description: Lately, many people are hearing an echo  faintly perhaps but distinctly audible  of the stagflation of the 1970s.

title: Sometimes Woods Is Down, Although Never on Himself
description: MARANA, Ariz.  With the sun sinking slowly over the desert moonscape, it was time to cue the theme from The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. Tiger Woods had one foot in the desert waste and another down the road in Tombstone. Three down with five holes to play Wednesday in his match against J. B. Holmes, he was on the verge of a most untimely departure in the first round of the Accenture Match Play Championship.

title: More Americans Are Giving Up Golf
description: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y.  The men gathered in a new golf clubhouse here a couple of weeks ago circled the problem from every angle, like caddies lining up a shot out of the rough.

title: Justices Shield Medical Devices From Lawsuits
description: WASHINGTON  Makers of medical devices like implantable defibrillators or breast implants are immune from liability for personal injuries as long as the Food and Drug Administration approved the device before it was marketed and it meets the agencys specifications, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

title: CBS Shows Slump
description: One week after registering relatively mediocre ratings in their debuts, CBSs Big Brother and the second season of Jericho each lost more than a million viewers on Tuesday. According to Nielsens estimates, Big Brother drew just 5.4 million viewers at 9 p.m., compared with 6.9 million a week ago, while Jericho attracted 5.9 million at 10 p.m., down from 7.1 million. CBS ranked third for the night over all, faring best at 8 p.m. with a rerun of NCIS (10.8 million). Fox dominated the night with a two-hour edition of American Idol (28.8 million). NBC finished second over all, winning the 10 p.m. hour following Idol with Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (9.3 million). NBCs Biggest Loser (8.2 million) was also the runner-up from 8 to 10 p.m. among adults 18 to 49. ABC was a distant fourth for the night.

title: As Fire Inquiry at Ground Zero Grows, So Do the Legal Bills
description: The Bloomberg administration and the state-run Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, both under scrutiny in the criminal investigation into the fatal Deutsche Bank fire, have incurred more than $2.2 million in fees for outside lawyers to defend their roles in the events that led up to the blaze, officials said this week.

title: U.S. Security Concerns Block Chinas 3Com Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Does the America for Sale sign require a warning label?

title: Samuel Karlin, Versatile Mathematician, Dies at 83
description: Samuel Karlin, a mathematician who applied his theoretical brilliance to such far-flung areas as economics and population studies, before helping to find ways to analyze DNA swiftly and comprehensively, died on Dec. 18, in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83.

title: Business Schools Break Tradition in Global Education
description: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA universities have long led the nation in the number of students enrolled from other countries. Now the universities business programs are taking the globalization of education to a different level, offering courses that go beyond dry corporate case studies and broadening their collaboration with universities and businesses abroad, particularly in Asia.

title: Sorry, Boys, This Is Our Domain
description: THE prototypical computer whiz of popular imagination  pasty, geeky, male  has failed to live up to his reputation.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jazz World Confronting Health Care Concerns
description: Not quite a month ago the alto saxophonist Andrew DAngelo had a major seizure while driving his elderly landlady to a store in Brooklyn. I was convulsing all over the place, he later wrote on his blog, grabbing onto the steering wheel violently, biting my tongue and basically acting crazy.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,956 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: Reality-Based Rate Cuts
description: Since last summer, when the financial markets began to crack, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke has taken his share of criticism. When he didnt immediately cut interest rates, he was accused of being too timid. When he cut aggressively last month, critics said he had panicked.

title: Hate Mail Sent to Blacks at Prep School Is Investigated
description: CONCORD, N.H.  A police investigation is under way at an elite prep school here after many black students received anonymous letters that the head of the school described as threatening hate mail.

title: Treating Diabetes
description: To the Editor:

title: Enlisting a Laptop Docking Station to Tame the Motley Tethers of the Modern Workspace
description: A cluttered desk may be a sign of genius, but even Einstein might have found himself hopelessly tangled up in the cords and cables of a modern office. By keeping things simple, the Bluelounge SpaceStation, a laptop docking port, might help bring order out of chaos.

title: Do You Get Where Hes Coming From?
description: WHEN I first visited Adam, the picture windows displayed a female mannequin that was trapped inside a bell-shaped bird cage, wearing a fur-lined silver vest. A male mannequin in the opposite window was paradoxically free: seated on a wooden bench in a comfortable Mr. Rogers zip cardigan, reading a book about architecture, surrounded by a nifty collection of ornamental bird cages.

title: A Camera That Shows That Simplicity Can Be Costly
description: For a camera priced at $1,000, there is a lot missing from the Sigma DP-1. For starters, it is not a single-lens reflex camera. Indeed, the DP-1s optical viewfinder is an optional $150 accessory. Nor does its lens zoom.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. Ive heard about public buildings with green walls, but can they be used in a house, like green roofs?

title: Journalist Sentenced to Death in Iran, Accused of Terrorism
description: TEHRAN  Iran has sentenced a journalist to death, accusing him of being a member of a terrorist group in the countrys southeast, the judiciary said Tuesday.

title: 3 Coins Might Short Out This Fountain
description: As a massive crane stacked units of curved steel embedded with thousands of light bulbs on a vast circular base on Sunday, passers-by couldnt help but wonder what was rising on the exact spot where the fabled tree stands every Christmas in Rockefeller Center.

title: Of Course I Washed My Hair Last Year (Im Almost Certain)
description: CLEANLINESS may be a virtue, but when it comes to hair? Apparently, not so much.

title: Facing Questions, Rodriguez Raises More
description: During his first interview with reporters at the Yankees spring training complex on Wednesday, third baseman Alex Rodriguez was peppered with questions about Roger Clemens, Andy Pettitte and the scrutiny he expects as he pursues baseballs career home run record.

title: Canadian TV Network Seeks Release of Afghan
description: OTTAWA  Canadas largest commercial television network is asking for the immediate release of an Afghan employee who it has been told is being detained by the United States military.

title: The Head That Wears the Crown
description: BOY-SHORT, peroxide-blond heads of hair are appearing all over fashionable London, replacing the long and shaggy locks that were the dominant look of the last few years.

title: Health Insurance Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Stem Cell Therapy Controls Diabetes in Mice
description: Scientists reported on Wednesday that they were able to control diabetes in mice by harnessing human embryonic stem cells. The work raised the prospect that the embryonic cells might one day be used to provide insulin-producing replacement cells to treat the disease in people.

title: Cuba and the World Wonder: Now What?
description: MEXICO CITY  When Fidel Castro promised to step down this week as Cubas head of state, he left the Cuban people and the rest of the world wondering not only what role he will play in retirement, but what changes will follow in the country he has run for nearly 50 years.

title: New Nets Arrive, but Harriss Debut Is Delayed
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The last vestiges of the Jason Kidd era had been peeled away, quite literally, from the Izod Center by the time the Nets resumed their season Wednesday night.

title: Put Another File in the Jukebox, Baby
description: ITS only a mild case of audiophilia, according to the professionals, but its causing me significant discomfort.

title: Clemens Pulls Out of ESPN Event
description: Roger Clemens withdrew Wednesday from a scheduled appearance at an ESPN event at Disney World in Florida because, he said in a statement, I believe my current participation could be a distraction.

title: Mercury Taint Divides a Japanese Whaling Town
description: TAIJI, Japan  For years, Western activists have traveled to this remote port to protest the annual dolphin drive. And for years, local fishermen have ignored them, herding the animals into a small cove and slashing them until the tide flows red.

title: Moving Soon to an Apartment Near You
description: BROOKE BERMAN is living in Seventh Heaven this week. Thats the name of the three dorm rooms that New Dramatists, a nonprofit center for playwrights housed in an old church on West 44th Street, offers its 49 artists-in-residence for short stays.

title: Union Says Immigration Policy Doesnt Go Far Enough in Phoenix
description: The union representing 2,500 rank-and-file Phoenix police officers said Tuesday that a new policy requiring the police to ask the immigration status only of people under arrest does not go far enough and could allow illegal immigrants to commit more crimes. The policy announced Friday by Mayor Phil Gordon and an advisory panel applies to misdemeanor and felony arrests but not civil traffic stops. The police would have the option to send written notification to Immigration and Customs Enforcement on people detained but not arrested. Mark Spencer, president of the union, the Phoenix Law Enforcement Association, said a suspects immigration status was already checked at the county jail under a sheriffs department policy, making the Phoenix policy moot.

title: Britain: Diana Claims Ridiculous, Ex-Spy Chief Tells Inquest
description: Sir Richard Dearlove, the retired chief of MI6, the Secret Intelligence Service, told the inquest into the 1997 car death of Diana, Princess of Wales, that allegations that the agency plotted the crash were without substance, utterly ridiculous and completely off the map. The claim that MI6 worked with French intelligence agents and the C.I.A. to kill Diana and her lover, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, known as Dodi, and that the plot was directed by Prince Philip and Prince Charles was made at the inquest this week by Mr. Fayeds father, Mohamed al-Fayed. Sir Richard, below, who led MI6 from 1999 to 2004, was its operations director at the time of the crash. Breaking with the agencys longstanding policy of never commenting on allegations about its activities, he said he could state with complete confidence that MI6 had no operations involving Diana in the summer of 1997 and that allegations of complicity between the agency and Philip and Charles were absurd. Sir Richard said he knew of no occasion during his 38 years with MI6 when it had assassinated anyone.

title: Girardi Ushers in a New Generation
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For the last dozen seasons as Yankees manager, Joe Torre was a father figure to many players, or at least an Uncle Joe. Born in 1940, Torre was at least two decades older than most of his players and more than 40 years older than some of them.

title: Pentagon Is Confident Missile Hit Satellite Tank
description: WASHINGTON  Just hours after a Navy missile interceptor struck a dying spy satellite orbiting 130 miles over the Pacific Ocean, a senior military officer expressed high confidence early Thursday that a tank filled with toxic rocket fuel had been breached.

title: Thousands in Armenia Protest Results of Presidential Election
description: ISTANBUL  Thousands gathered Wednesday in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, to protest Tuesdays presidential election, which they said had been rigged, although international observers evaluated it as relatively free and fair.

title: Jewelry of Mets Reliever Is Stolen From His Hotel
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets reliever Ambiorix Burgos said he had more than $270,000 worth of jewelry stolen from his hotel room earlier this week, but by Wednesday afternoon he had recovered all but five pieces. Burgos said through an interpreter that he reported to the police Tuesday that a black leather bag containing the jewelry had disappeared and that hours later an unidentified man dropped it off at Burgoss hotel, the SpringHill Suites, before speeding away.

title: Russia Denies Visa to Rights Group Leader in Days Before Report
description: MOSCOW  Human Rights Watch released a report here on Wednesday accusing the Kremlin of using a host of bureaucratic rules to hinder the work of nonprofit organizations. The group did not have to look far to find what it said was a fresh example of the problem: Its own executive director was denied a visa to come to Moscow to present the report.

title: Scores With a Youth Movement
description: Youthful exuberance is a marketable commodity everywhere, and in the classical music world it commands a premium. Still, Mannes College the New School for Music offered a generous sampling of it free on Tuesday evening, when the Mannes Orchestra performed at Carnegie Hall.

title: The Sharper Image Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: The Sharper Image, the 31-year-old purveyor of futuristic adult gadgetry like $5,000 massage chairs and $300 robotic vacuum cleaners, has filed for bankruptcy protection after years of slipping sales, stiffening competition and image problems over its Ionic Breeze air purifiers.

title: Cellphone Carriers Test All-You-Can-Talk Menus
description: A PRICE war among cellphone carriers is giving users a chance to stop counting their minutes.

title: Turkey: Parliament Backs Return of Minorities Properties
description: Parliament passed a law that would return properties confiscated by the state, including hospitals and churches, to non-Muslim minorities. The law, championed by the party of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan but opposed by nationalists, was sought by the European Union. Liberals have criticized the law, saying it does not go far enough because it does not apply to property sold to third parties.

title: Launching from Both Ends
description: Twin-tips, skis rounded and curved up at the tail like the front of a traditional ski, simplify jumping and landing backward. And as The Times reports, sales of twin-tips have increased 32 percent in specialty stores and 167 percent in online sales over last season, adding up to 46,429 pairs sold this season -- making them the second most popular kind of ski. "The answer to their sudden popularity is as old-fashioned as it is modern," The Times reports. "Twin-tips are new, cool and make people feel young. So middle-aged men and women are buying them, and not just for their sons and daughters."

title: Letting the Inner Angst Out, Loudly
description: Dave Grohl was a smiling, gum-chewing, hair-flopping, guitar-thrusting rock star when his band, Foo Fighters, headlined Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night. He was also the guy who wrote and sang lyrics like Hearts gone cold and hands are tied/Whyd you have to go and let it die? in a voice that was both mournful and enraged, while the music moved from melancholy fingerpicking to a hard-rock stomp. His songs grow troubled, but Mr. Grohl himself never comes across as tortured.

title: Kidds Debut for Mavericks Ends With a Hornets Victory
description: Jason Kidd made his Dallas Mavericks debut against the host New Orleans Hornets on Wednesday night, so invigorated by the prospect of playing for a contender again that he dismissed concerns of travel fatigue or his immediate insertion into the starting lineup of a team he has practiced with twice.

title: A Traditional Therapy Finds Modern Uses
description: QUITTING cigarettes had always been agony for Michele Fenzl, a 55-year-old computer operator from Denver. Pregnancy got her to stop for a while. But in 35 years of smoking a pack a day, nothing else gave her a reprieve.

title: SNL Is Ready to Make Up for Lost Time
description: Lorne Michaels has been running NBCs Saturday Night Live for so long that when he is asked about the impact the writers strike had on his show, he can legitimately ask: Which one?

title: McCain Answers Questions About Lobbyist
description: The following is a transcript from John McCains news conference, as provided by Federal News Service.

title: Ousted Publisher Joins Nan A. Talese
description: Janet Silver, recently ousted as publisher of Houghton Mifflins adult trade division in the wake of the companys merger with Harcourt, has been appointed editor at large at Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, an imprint of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group. Last month Ms. Silver, 53, was edged out of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Adult Trade Books when Becky Saletan, publisher of the trade division of Harcourt, was appointed publisher of the combined unit. At Nan A. Talese Ms. Silver, who spent 24 years at Houghton, will focus on editing while working out of her home in Concord, Mass.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the strategy that winners of Pakistans election hope to use to deal with Islamic militancy misstated, in some editions, the government experience of Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of Benazir Bhutto and the leader of the Pakistan Peoples Party. He has indeed held office, having been elected to the National Assembly twice and to the Senate once.

title: Justices Add Legal Complications to Debate on F.D.A.s Competence
description: WASHINGTON

title: For Muslim Students, a Debate on Inclusion
description: SAN JOSE  Amir Mertaban vividly recalls sitting at his universitys recruitment table for the Muslim Students Association a few years ago when an attractive undergraduate flounced up in a decidedly un-Islamic miniskirt, saying Salamu aleykum, or Peace be upon you, a standard Arabic greeting, and asked to sign up.

title: Research Explains Formation of Unique Martian Fans
description: To figure out an odd landscape feature on Mars, play in a big sandbox.

title: Oscar Nomination Caps Columbia Film Professors Long Journey
description: Dozens of people have been nominated for Oscars this year, but none of them got there quite the way that Jamal Joseph did.

title: Fans Asked, and They Have Received
description: It was with considerable amusement that I, an inevitable University of Illinois alumnus from birth, watched as Indiana Hoosiers fans openly speculated that the only way their troubled basketball program could possibly be salvaged would be the return of Bloomington's prodigal son, Bob Knight. (Though it's sometimes difficult to imagine Knight as anyone's "son.")

title: Im Ill, but Who Really Needs to Know?
description: ONE of the first decisions you make in the emotional hours after a scary diagnosis is whether to tell others. Most of us share the news with our loved ones, but what of the circles beyond, particularly those at work? Your boss?

title: Germany Prods Liechtenstein on Fighting Fraud
description: FRANKFURT  Having turned a spotlight on what it calls Liechtensteins brisk business in abetting tax evasion, Germany has raised the prospect of retaliation in other areas unless the principality cooperates more on tax policy.

title: Broken Borders and Dover Sole: My Lunch With Lou Dobbs
description: So I was having lunch at the Four Seasons with Lou Dobbs the other day, locked in disagreement over who cared more about working people, him or me.

title: Prep Stars Rise Aided by His Brothers Best Intentions
description: ASTON, Pa.  Tyreke Evans has been rehearsing for this moment since he was 6 years old, when his brothers used an old boxing trick and duct-taped his right arm to his body, forcing him to dribble with his left hand. He learned a game of basketball Twister to improve his first step and played in the rain and the snow, even carried his basketball to bed.

title: New South Korean Leader Cleared in Fraud Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A special prosecutor on Thursday cleared President-elect Lee Myung-bak of South Korea of fraud accusations, four days before his inauguration.

title: Stanford Set to Raise Aid for Students in Middle
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Stanford University on Wednesday became the latest prominent university to expand financial aid well into the middle class. It announced that students from families earning less than $100,000 a year would not be charged tuition.

title: Teamsters Endorse Obama, Offering a Blue-Collar Lift
description: In a surprising boost for Senator Barack Obama, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters endorsed him on Wednesday, giving him new momentum among a group where he is eager to shore up support: blue-collar men.

title: 3 Hit by Trains, 2 Fatally
description: In three separate subway track accidents on Wednesday, trains struck and killed two men and injured a third, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said.

title: A Primer for Viewing the Democratic Debate
description: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have not met face to face in a debate since their love-fest in Hollywood on Jan. 31.

title: Most Children Still Live in Two-Parent Homes, Census Bureau Reports
description: The American family may be under stress, but most children still live in two-parent households, the Census Bureau reported Wednesday.

title: The Long and Winding Political Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Parents Influence in the Fight Against Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Newly Released
description: Its a clich by now to note the rise of the Scottish thriller, and ripped from the headlines plots punctuate that ka-chung sound on Law & Order so often youd think thered be none left to fuel fiction writing. Still, among this months new releases are books from both those categories; whether theyll transcend their genres remains to be seen. Also new this month: unnerving short stories and a book about a C.I.A. agent who just cant stay out of trouble.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 9 about the fading possibility of Michael R. Bloombergs becoming a candidate for president misidentified the person with whom Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, discussed the possibility of running on a ticket with the New York City mayor. Senator Hagel said there had been talks about it, but one of his aides said later that the talks had been with Deputy Mayor Kevin Sheekey, not with Mr. Bloomberg.

title: These Are Their Stories, but Some Police Officers Say, Not This Time
description: The gritty characters on Law & Order are forever linked with their real-world muses in criminal justice: What helps one helps the other.

title: Obama and Clinton Spending Furiously
description: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton both spent at the furious clip of nearly a million dollars a day in January as they battled to win the initial contests for the Democratic nomination, according to filings on Wednesday with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Picture, Picture on the Wall ...
description: THERE has always been a certain status attached to owning a home that is featured in a magazine. And a certain pleasure, for a homeowner, in leaving the evidence lying casually on the coffee table.

title: Serbs Continue to Push for Control of Northern Kosovo

Bloombergs becoming a candidate for president misidentified the person with whom Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, discussed the possibility of running on a ticket with the New York City mayor. Senator Hagel said there had been talks about it, but one of his aides said later that the talks had been with Deputy Mayor Kevin Sheekey, not with Mr. Bloomberg. (Go to Article)

title: When Addicted Son Hurts, Father Feels His Own Pain
description: Addiction is a compulsion to do the same thing over and over, despite knowing that the outcome will almost certainly be the same. Addiction memoirs often illustrate this same definition of insanity. They follow the same arc, voice the same helplessness and arrive at the same set of conclusions. Yet the genre itself remains so addictive that readers keep hoping to discover something new.

title: Richard Westenburg, Choral Conductor, Dies at 75
description: Richard Westenburg, a choral conductor who founded the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra in 1964 and made it one of the most renowned choruses in New York by the end of the 1970s, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Norwalk, Conn. He was 75 and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: Correction: For the Record

It is Ballad of Arrivals & Departures  not BlueprintViolation: Ballad of Arrivals & Departures, which is the name of Ms. McArdles company.

title: Stifling Online Speech
description: The rise of Internet journalism has opened a new front in the battle to protect free speech. A federal judge last week ordered the disabling of Wikileaks.org, a muckraking Web site. That stifles important speech and violates the First Amendment. It should be reversed, and Wikileaks should be allowed to resume operations.

title: From China, Cellphone  la Carte
description: The Zzzphone, a made-to-order cellphone, recently captured the imagination of the gadget crowd. But it remains to be seen whether it can live up to its promise.

title: The McCain Article
description: A recent New York Times article examined a number of decisions by Senator John McCain that raised questions about his judgment over potential conflicts of interest. The article included reporting on Mr. McCains relationship with a female lobbyist whose clients often had business before the Senate committee led by Mr. McCain. Since publication of the article, The Times has received more than 2,000 comments, many of them criticizing the handling of the article. More than 4,000 questions were sent via e-mail to The Times on Thursday night and Friday. Editors and reporters who worked on the article answered some of the questions on Friday. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 5 about Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC business reporter, misspelled the surname of the dean of the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University, who commented on her promotional appearance on behalf of Citigroup, a frequent subject of CNBC coverage. He is John Lavine, not Levine. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message last Thursday.

title: McCain Denies Aides Statements About Lobbyist
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  Senator John McCain said Thursday that an article in The New York Times about his close ties to a woman lobbyist was untrue, that he had no romantic relationship with the lobbyist and that he had no confrontations in 1999 with worried staff members who told him to stay away from her.

title: Antiquities Trial Continues in Rome
description: More than six months after the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles agreed to hand over 40 artifacts to Italy, the criminal trial of its former curator of antiquities lumbers on in Rome. A prosecution witness painstakingly presented the court with photographs and documents on Wednesday in an effort to establish that more than a dozen looted artifacts had made their way into the Gettys collection. Marion True, the former Getty curator, is charged with conspiring to acquire illicitly excavated antiquities for the museum. Several of the pieces discussed on Wednesday by the prosecution witness, Daniela Rizzo, are now on view at the presidential palace in Rome as part of an exhibition of objects recovered from American museums in the last two years. Ms. Rizzo repeatedly projected an image of an artifact onto a screen next to a photograph of the same piece in a dirt-encrusted, unrestored state. For most of the pieces, she said, acquisition documents provided by the Getty did not cite the objects provenance. If it came from an authorized dig, it would say so and give a date, she said. The fact that it doesnt makes you think, doesnt it? Ms. True and the American dealer Robert Hecht, who is on trial with her on similar charges, have both proclaimed their innocence. The next trial hearing is scheduled for mid-March.

title: Gesink Wins 3rd Stage of Tour of California
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. (AP)  Robert Gesink of the Netherlands claimed the days honors and Levi Leipheimer became the third overall race leader Wednesday in the mountainous third stage of the Tour of California.

title: Rio Tinto May Break With Other Producers on Iron Ore Price

title: Gucci: A Ticket to Ride
description: First of all, thanks to everyone for the terrific comments and funny asides on the blog, and to georgianna8 for the lace history (new stuff to learn!), RC (glad you couldnt resist), Marko for mentioning Raf Simons the big romantic (lets not talk austere anymore), and, Brooksie, couldnt agree with you more that its Miuccias responsibility to show racial diversity on her runway. It DOES matter, its not a trend, and it astounds me that designers in Europe and the U.S. are blankishly ignorant about why this matters. One or two black or Asian or Latina models on their runways is not enough. In general ways, in skin color, body shape, and physical expressiveness, the runways need to be far more diverse and surprising than they are. And a designer should lead the way.

title: Why Americans Are Giving Up Golf

More troubling to golf boosters, the number of people who play 25 times a year or more fell to 4.6 million in 2005 from 6.9 million in 2000, a loss of about a third.

title: Playing by Party Rules
description: When Bill Clinton ran for president in 1992, he talked, memorably and incessantly, about protecting those families who worked hard and played by the rules. Sixteen years later, it appears ever more likely that the outcome of this years Democratic nomination fight will rest, in the end, on how party leaders interpret the rules. As Ive written here before, there is no real ideological divide in the party; most Democrats would seem to be satisfied with either Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama, so theres no reason to think either candidates followers will automatically revolt if they lose. But no matter who wins, if the process itself ends up confirming the growing suspicion among voters that the rules are only there to be rigged, then the outcome could devastate a party whose central argument is all about fairness. Much has been written about the possible permutations in the Democratic race from here on out, but at this point its fairly simple. After his victories Tuesday, Mr. Obama now has a slim but hard-to-surmount lead in pledged delegates  those awarded in state contests. If Mrs. Clinton were to win the trio of Texas, Ohio and Pennsylvania by huge margins, then she might be able to overtake him, but that doesnt seem terribly likely, given the dynamic of the race right now. Even so, neither candidate has much chance of emerging from the primaries with the 2,025 delegates needed to lock up the nomination, which means that even if Mr. Obama maintains his lead, Mrs. Clinton canand probably willfight on.

title: Fans Asked, and They Have Received

title: Johnna Above it All

description: The Indy Racing League and Champ Car World Series sure hope so  as do open-wheel racing fans in America.

title: Excursions Around Florence in March
description: We are going to Italy in March and will stay just outside Florence for four days. What itinerary do you recommend in Tuscany for someone who has never been before?

title: Make That 11 for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama won his 11th straight nominating contest on Thursday, carrying the Democrats Abroad global primary by a 2-to-1 margin over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and prevailing among American expatriates in every region of the world.

title: Surprises in dry F1 testing in Spain
description: Yes, I know, we say it every year: You cannot really see through winter testing who is going to win the championship. And thank goodness for that! On the other hand, in the first day of dry testing this week at Barcelona, there were some interesting surprises. Or maybe not. Can we still be surprised by Nakajimas rocket? It seems to have lifted off several times this winter  and in Brazil  and this time Kuzuki outdid the two McLarens as well as his teammate, Nico Rosberg.

title: T Magazine | Preview the Spring Issue
description: It may be 32 degrees outside, but at T, were ready to peel off our boiled-wool swing coats and bare our shoulders to the to the 20-mph winds. Its spring! Today on T Online, you will find the best of our Spring 2008 Womens Fashion issue, packed with sun-friendly solutions to the slate-colored winter sky. The actress Charlize Theron warms our cover and talks about her new movie, Sleepwalking, in an interview with Lynn Hirschberg. The Italian supermodel Mariacarla Boscono takes center stage in a Jean-Baptiste Mondino shoot (and a web-exclusive video), while Cathy Horyn gets inside the growing Comme des Garons empire. Be sure to check out the actress Chlo Sevignys Sassy duds in Profile In Style and the skin-tingling portraits of the performance artist Orlan in My Life in Pictures. You can also take shelter in the colorful home of Warhol-muse Jane Holzer. Spring is a just click away.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Salvatore Ferragamo
description: (AFP/Getty Images)

title: The Chumby Is Open, but Not for Business
description: I find Chumby fascinating for a lot of reasons. Meant to replace a clock radio, it is a $179 device with a Wi-Fi connection, a 3.5-inch touch screen and a squishy leather case. It displays various widgets with information pulled off the Internet, and it plays podcasts, Internet radio and some Web video. I suspect over the next decade we will be deluged by various connected devices offering various views of information and entertainment. (Here is John Markoffs experience with one last fall.)

title: Chuck Norris Just Sends His Stunt Double
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Welcome to The Tonight Show. Happy Black History Month. Did you know this is Black History Month? If Barack Obama keeps winning, it looks like Hillary could be history.

title: Accounting for Emerils $20 Million Kicker
description: Theres a meaty accounting lesson in the details of Martha Stewarts recent deal with Emeril Lagasse, the celebrity chef.

title: Change to Win Gets Behind Obama
description: Its member unions represent 175,000 workers in Ohio alone. Nationwide, the group represents more than five million workers. And now Change to Win, a coalition of seven unions, is jumping on board the Barack Obama bandwagon.

title: Should All of 125th Street Be Declared Historic?
description: Adam Leitman Bailey, a lawyer who was born in Queens and grew up in New Jersey, has devised a novel way to halt gentrification in Harlem. Mr. Bailey, 37, has proposed having 125th Street, from river to river, declared the Harlem Historic Zone, which he believes would make it more difficult to tear down the neighborhoods old buildings and replace them with new ones.

title: True Lies
description: Yesterdays Times had an article on Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., the C.I.A. official who authorized destroying the tapes of C.I.A. agents questioning terrorism suspects.

title: Ratings: Idol Soars; Top Model Looks Thin
description: As the top twelve female contestants competed on American Idol on Wednesday, Fox once again easily dominated the nights ratings as 28.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for a two-hour edition of the show, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Thursday, Feb. 21:

title: Brian Schneider: Throwback
description: Brian Schneider has been called a throwback for the way he plays. Its fitting, too, considering hes a fan of Mitchell and Ness, the amazing throwback jersey store in Center City Philadelphia, whose T-shirt he was sporting this afternoon. Schneider said he has a huge collection, ranging from Hall of Famers to current All-Stars  all baseball  that he will store in the house he is building in Pennsylvania.

title: Stopping One Avalanche but Missing Another
description: NOTES ON THE NEWS Spam filters mistakenly hold back important e-mails all the time, but this particular instance reported by The Denver Post stopped an electronic avalanche while leaving Coloradans in the dark about a real one:

title: Josh Horowitz Drinks the Milkshake
description: Some hussy from MTV makes a late grab for best Oscar-related video of 2008 and triumphs. The Bagger was left with a frozen smile on his face and a wan wave from the cheap seats.

title: Of Cell Phones and Land Lines
description: NOTES ON THE NEWS A cell phone company is offering an unlikely product to customers in Dallas and Seattle: landlines.

title: A Symphony of Confusion
description: In the best song category, chaos reigns. Once was in, then it was out, then it was in again. The song from August Rush made it in, but no one saw the movie. And then three, count em, three songs from Enchanted made it in, but given the demographics of the Academy, its likely that not many voters actually saw that movie either.

title: Bushs Popularity: A (Really) New Low?
description: The American Research Group, a well-known polling organization, released a pretty surprising poll yesterday putting President Bushs approval rating at a new low: just 19 percent.

title: Not Very Brainy
description: From Yahoo:

title: Re-Starting Saturday Night Live
description: Bill Carter interviews Lorne Michaels, the executive producer of Saturday Night Live, ahead of the shows Feb. 23 return:

title: The Oscars Movie
description: Its an award-winning formula, from The Soup on E! Entertainment:

title: Saarinen Terminal to Reopen at Kennedy Airport
description: After a long darkness, the Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport  that abandoned embodiment of the Come Fly With Me era of jet-setting  would reopen this year, under a plan advanced Thursday by the Port Authority.The authoritys board approved a $19 million project to perform the essential repairs needed to allow travelers to pass through the 46-year-old terminal on their way to the enormous new JetBlue Airways terminal that wraps around the T.W.A. building in a crescent shape.

title: Movie Minutes: 'The Counterfeiters'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "The Counterfeiters," directed by Stefan Ruzowitzky.

title: Boone Pickens on Wind Energy
description: CNBC interviews Boone Pickens, chairman of BP Capital Management, on the prospects for various types of alternative energy.

title: Serbs Protest Kosovo Independence
description: Rioters set fire to buildings and attacked the United States Embassy in Belgrade, the Serbian capital, on Thursday after tens of thousands of people rallied to protest Kosovo's declaration of independence four days ago.

title: Calls for a New Park on the East River
description: Federal, state and city officials joined several civic organizations today to express support for a new four-acre waterfront park that would be built in the shadow of the United Nations and cost as much as $100 million, but the project faces considerable logistical and financial hurdles. The park would be at the northern end of Glick Park, at 36th Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan, where decaying concrete is blocked off by a gate and a fence with barbed wire. The area, which houses a now-defunct Consolidated Edison, is one of the largest parcels in Manhattan facing redevelopment in the next few years.

title: The View From Paris, Part One
description: I cant say that my first impressions of Paris, this time around, were all that encouraging. There was the sad Vietnamese restaurant where I had dinner my first night. There were the crepe-makers, working in advance, stacking their crepes twenty high in anticipation of customers. (Isnt half the reason for getting a crepe watching the process?) I cant remember when the pre-made sandwich thing took over completely. (Oh, and now there are paninis.) Why would anyone spend 15 euros for pre-shredded cabbage?

title: John McCain Press Conference
description: CNBC coverage of a press conference by John McCain as he discussed a Times article dealing with allegations of ethics breaches with a lobbyist.

title: The Hangtown Fry
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes scrambled eggs with bacon and oysters.

title: Strike News: Criminal Minds First Back On Set
description: The CBS drama Criminal Minds will become the first television drama to resume production today, only eight days after the writers strike ended, the network confirmed today.

title: S.F. Zoo Reopens Tiger Exhibit
description: The San Francisco Zoo reopened the tiger and lion exhibits today almost two months after a deadly incident proved improvements were needed. The cats are now surrounded by 19-feet high walls made of glass and concrete, high enough to satisfy the requirements of the Association of Zoos & Aquariums. The previous walls were almost 4 feet short of the standard.

title: News Or Nancy Grace? Headline News Viewers Have Voted With Their Remotes
description: Three years after the attorney-turned-television-personality Nancy Grace helped Headline News reinvent its prime time line-up, the verdict is in: viewers prefer views to news, at least at night.

title: City Warns of Fraud in Tax Preparers Loans
description: A city investigation into fraudulent and illegal practices by the income-tax preparation industry has, in its first six weeks, identified more than 500 violations, including misleading or illegal advertisements in newspapers and misrepresentations concerning so-called refund anticipation loans. The number of violations so far rose by 75 percent from the same period a year ago, officials said.

title: Soccer Fever Fails to Grip Hawaii
description: I would love to be able to tell you that the state of Hawaii is gripped by soccer fever this week. Unfortunately, the first two games of the Pan-Pacific Championship Wednesday night drew few fans to Aloha Stadium.

title: What Will the Season Bring for Duke and Indiana?
description: Indiana and Duke have long been two of the preeminent programs in mens college basketball. The past week or so, however, will not be looked upon fondly by the fans of either team.

title: Rethinking Priorities
description: Saturn wants its image to reflect a new approach to building cars.

title: A Different Kind of Woman
description: Cadillac promotes the virtues of cupholders and the women who like them.

title: Veteran Returns to Oversee Risk at Morgan Stanley
description: As banks try to rebuild themselves amid the subprime mortgage meltdown, one of the mantras on everyones lips is risk management. Battered by $7.8 billion in trading losses incurred last year, Morgan Stanley is bolstering its own internal controls by appointing a former executive as a new overseer of risk.

title: Macho Guys Soften Up for Oscar
description: After the writers strike, ABC ramps up its Oscar promotion.

title: Desperately Seeking Fauxbama
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Podcast: Tipsy Tallying at the Ballot Box
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: Fish Wrapped in Romaine Leaves
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, poaches fish in lettuce for a simple and sophisticated entree.

title: A Beatles Haunt, Cafe La Fortuna, to Close Its Doors
description: Two deaths brought about the decision to close Cafe La Fortuna, the three-decade-old cafe that attracted John Lennon, Yoko Ono and many other Upper West Side neighborhood residents with its outdoor garden, opera music and Italian desserts.The first death, which took place a few years ago, was of the longtime landlord, who had generously kept the rent for the space at 69 West 71st Street at a reasonable rate despite the escalating real estate costs in the neighborhood.

title: The New York Philharmonic in Asia: Scenes From the Shanghai Grand Theater
description: Slide Show

title: Is the End Near for El Duque?
description: Orlando Hernandez revealed something interesting this afternoon: that bunion surgery he had last October? Never happened (thatll have to be fixed in the media guide). Instead, he had a tendon fixed in the second toe of his right foot. The toe, he said, was shortened, and hes still trying to adjust and work on his balance when he pitches.

title: A Curious Notice from a SPAC Under the Gun
description: When last we left Michael S. Gross, the former private equity executive was staring down a barrel at his special-purpose acquisition company. Marathon Acquisition had to make a deal by Feb. 25, or he would have to return the $300 million he has raised from investors.

title: City Workers Object to Palming the Clock
description: A group of city Parks Department workers said today that the agencys intention to use palm scanners in place of time sheets is a violation of their privacy. The Parks Department is one of more than two dozen city agencies that is preparing to use  or has already began using - the Bloomberg administrations CityTime payroll plan, which includes the use of biometric devices such as palm scanners to collect workers start and end times.According to the citys Office of Payroll Administration Web site, supervisors may choose to place the scanners near the entrance of an office, allowing an agency to record when employee arrive at work and leave for the day.

title: Microsoft Open to Sharing
description: CNBC interviews Tom Robertson of Microsoft, who discusses his company's decision to open its vault of software secrets to outside developers.

title: Simon Set to Return
description: Islanders Coach Ted Nolan just said that left wing Chris Simon, who has finished his N.H.L. record 30-game suspension, will be in the lineup Thursday against the Tampa Bay Lightning, the first game in which he is eligible to play.

title: City Announces 52 New Schools
description: The New York City schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein today, announced that 52 new schools will open in September. But the average parent or student would not necessarily see all 52 schools as new. Of the total, 25 will replace schools that are being phased out, 12 will open in new school buildings constructed to alleviate crowding and the remaining 15 will open in underused school buildings or school buildings where schools are being permanently reduced in size.

title: Soft Serve | Chanels Chocolate Phone, Ikea Chic, Diamonds For Slashers
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Roots of the Embassy Attack
description: No, the photos are not of John McCain supporters outside my door here but rather Serbian demonstrators who have attacked the United States Embassy and set part of it ablaze on Thursday as tens of thousands of angry Serbs took to the streets of Belgrade to protest Kosovos declaration of independence.

title: Bill Clinton: Texas and Ohio or Bust
description: While Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign has been signaling how critical the Texas and Ohio primaries are, Bill Clinton took that a step further, suggesting during a campaign stop in Texas that the two states are must wins.

title: U.S. Table Tennis, Beijing Style
description: For years, Wang Chen was one of the best table tennis players in China, but never competed in the Olympics. Now, as a U.S. citizen, she will.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Versace
description: (Alessandro Garofalo/Reuters)

title: Remains of a Satellite: Pentagons One-Hit Wonder
description: The questions began shortly after the Pentagon announced its intention to shoot down a falling satellite, and they continued afterward, sometimes in circles: the threat of the 1,000 pounds of hydrazine, the heavy diplomatic costs, the video released today, and more.

title: Buying Votes
description: There is another election campaign going on, other than the one that is getting all the publicity. And in a perfectly legal way, it looks as if somebody was buying votes in that election today.

title: Submit Questions for Oliver Sacks
description: To follow  last weeks post, Patterns, and the comments it generated, Dr. Sacks has offered to take questions from readers. (Readers should submit their questions as comments to this post, not to Patterns.) Please note that Dr. Sacks will select the questions he will answer.

title: The Week Ahead
description: Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses events in the world this week.

title: Weekend in New York
description: Seth Kugel explores three of New York's ethnic grocery stores.

title: Madonna Ends Apartment Dispute
