description: Madonna has reportedly settled her lawsuit with a New York co-op board, which refused to allow her to buy her neighbors apartment. I bought the apartment upstairs, so now everythings A-OK, she told New York magazine.

title: McCain Told He Must Take Public Money
description: A bank loan that Senator John McCain took out late last year to keep his campaign for the Republican nomination afloat financially is now complicating his desire to withdraw from the public financing program for his primary bid.

title: Bourbon Apple Cake
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, lets a sweet, buttery apple cake have a drink.

title: Screen Test: George Clooney
description: Exclusive interview with George Clooney.

title: Great paper titles
description: Unfortunately, I missed the seminar. But from Princetons Office of Population Research:

title: Now Screening | George Clooney
Early Voting in Texas
description: Early voting in Texas is on track to break records, especially among Democrats. After only two days of early voting, according to data from the Texas Secretary of State, early voting totals after only two days are two-thirds the total after two weeks of early voting in 2004.

title: Live Blogging the Texas Showdown
description: Wrapup:  Maybe we were expecting too much  an intergalactic showdown. Instead, it was more of a chess game, with each side moving forward and occasionally knocking off the others pieces. Instead of ending in checkmate, they ended with a hands-across-the-water moment.

title: Names from the Combine: Shane Longest
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Of all the players paraded through the media room today at the N.F.L. scouting combine, Shane Longest was my favorite.Puns? Way too easy. Longest is  surprise, surprise  a punter and kicker from St. Xavier in Illinois. He told reporters Thursday his longest made field goal in a game was from 55 yards. He also said that during practice he once hit a 75-yard field goal  the, um, longest I have ever heard of.

title: Roasted Tomato Soup
description: Mark Bittman and a guest celebrity chef make an off-season tomato soup.

title: The Med Scare
description: At the end of my last column, I wondered about the purpose served by the narrative of the disastrously overmedicated American. Ive been pondering this question as it relates to children for the better part of the past four years.

title: Vows: Courtney & Michael
description: Courtney Wisotsky and Michael Weinstein are avid runners who were  once told "those who run together, stay together."

title: An Eco-Chat With Ed Begley Jr.
description: Times environment reporter Andrew C. Revkin talks with actor Ed Begley Jr. about living green.

title: Some Suspect Meat Used in School Lunches, U.S. Says
description: Days after the largest beef recall, the Agriculture Department said Thursday that more than a third of the meat had been used in federal nutrition programs, including school lunches.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Security Council Weighs New Sanctions on Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council on Thursday began formal consideration of a new resolution on Irans nuclear program that imposes restrictions on cargo to and from Iran, travel bans, the freezing of assets for people involved in the program and tightened monitoring of Iranian financial institutions.

title: Kenyas Glimmer of Hope
description: After weeks of horrific tribal violence, Kenyas rival leaders appear to be closing in on a political deal. That is the only hope for stopping the killing and the only chance for salvaging a country that until recently was one of Africas most stable and prosperous.

title: Georgia Claims a Sliver of the Tennessee River
description: ATLANTA  WHEREAS, in 1818 when the border between Georgia and Tennessee was marked by surveyors, mistakes were made that deprived Georgia of a sliver of the Tennessee River.

title: Acropolis Museum to Open in September
description: The new Acropolis museum in Athens will open in September, the Greek culture minister announced on Wednesday. In one month, we are to finish moving all the pieces from the old museum, the minister, Michalis Liapis, said during a visit to the site, Agence France-Presse reported. The new museum, above, designed by the Franco-Swiss architect Bernard Tschumi, is a three-level, 270,000-square-foot structure, including a room on the top floor with an area reserved for the Elgin Marbles, now in the British Museum in London. Greece has long sought the return of the friezes. The new Acropolis museum was to have been completed for the 2004 Olympics in Greece but encountered bureaucratic and technical setbacks.

title: A Window That Reflected a Golden Age Comes Down at Kennedy Airport
description: Back when Kennedy International Airport was called Idlewild and the jet age was just blooming, airports were considered elegant, even majestic destinations.

title: Rev. James E. Orange, 65, Aide to Dr. King, Dies
description: The Rev. James E. Orange, an aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. whose arrest in Alabama in 1965 is considered one of the catalysts for the historic Selma-to-Montgomery march, died on Saturday in Atlanta, his hometown. He was 65.

title: Qualms Over Clean Energy That Would Come From 12 Stories Up
description: WAYNE, N.J.  Hamburg Turnpike, a six-mile stretch dotted with strip malls and low-rise office buildings, does not seem like the place for innovation, and many people who live here seem just fine with that.

title: Putting Civility and Sportsmanship Back in Game, if Not in the Stands
description: The bench area at college basketball games had become a maelstrom, with coaches ranting along the sidelines, assistant coaches jumping up and down exhorting players, and officiating crews engaging in heated exchanges with coaches after disputed calls on the floor. The fans rode along with the same passion.

title: Former Concentration Camp Guard Dies
description: Erna Wallisch, a former concentration camp guard who was under investigation for war crimes, died in a Vienna hospital last week, Austrian prosecutors said. Investigators had reopened the case against the 86-year-old woman earlier this year after new evidence from Polish witnesses suggested that she was involved in the murder of inmates in the Majdanek concentration camp near the city of Lublin, Poland. Mrs. Wallisch, who ranked seventh on the Simon Wiesenthal Centers list of most-wanted Nazi war criminals, evaded prosecution in the 1970s due to a lack of evidence linking her directly to Nazi genocide.

title: Knee-Jerk Calls to Act Follow a Brutal Crime
description: Every once in a while something happens that is so awful, it leads immediately to cries of there ought to be a law, because everyone knows that passing laws is how to cure all of societys ills. We have such a situation now after last weeks shocking murder of Kathryn Faughey, the psychologist who was stabbed repeatedly in her office on the Upper East Side.

title: Rescues for Homeowners in Debt Weighed
description: WASHINGTON  Prodded in part by some of the nations biggest banks, the Bush administration and Congress are considering costly new proposals for the government to rescue hundreds of thousands of homeowners whose mortgages are higher than the value of their houses.

title: Magazines Up for Sale, Including Variety
description: Variety, Publishers Weekly and dozens of other trade publications are going up for sale as the publishing company Reed Elsevier looks to get out of the uncertain advertising market.

title: Lineup Confirmed for All Points West
description: Radiohead and Jack Johnson will perform as headliners at the inaugural All Points West music festival in New Jersey this summer, organizers confirmed on Thursday. The three-day event, representing the first major East Coast venture by the concert promoter behind Californias taste-making Coachella festival, will take place Aug. 8 to 10 at Liberty State Park in Jersey City. Radiohead will play the first two nights, Mr. Johnson the third. The lineup, announced yesterday by the promoter, Goldenvoice, also includes Underworld, Kings of Leon, Cat Power, the Roots, Animal Collective and Black Kids. The promoters attempt to establish a beachhead near Manhattan, which has lacked for major festivals with multiple acts, highlights the influence such events are gaining with live-music fans across the country. Tickets for All Points West go on sale Feb. 29 through Ticketmaster.com; one-day passes are $89, three-day passes $258.

title: When Bankers Fear to Act
description: Where is the next J. P. Morgan?

title: Dont Rerun That 70s Show
description: Will the next president be the second coming of Jimmy Carter? Given Thursdays economic headlines, full of dire warnings about the return of 1970s-style stagflation, you might think so.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Enduring Image Leads to Enduring Dispute
description: Tommie Smith and John Carlos were at the Black National Theatre in Harlem on Wednesday. The event was sponsored by Nike as part of its Olympic year celebration of Black History Month. Nike chose six key Olympic moments to celebrate; Smiths and Carloss moment on the victory stand at the 1968 Mexico City Games was one of the six.

title: Outdated Prices Blamed in Credit Suisse Error
description: LONDON  The surprise $2.85 billion write-down at Credit Suisse this week underscored the difficulty banks face in valuing complex investments. But the cause of the blunder may be simple: traders at the bank used old prices.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the sale of some parts of the chef Emeril Lagasses franchise to Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia misstated which of his two Food Network television programs was older. Essence of Emeril, which had its debut in 1994, was Mr. Lagasses first program on the cable network  not Emeril Live, which ran from 1997 to 2007. (Essence of Emeril went off the air in 1996 and returned in 2000 in a new form. It continues to be produced.)

title: Fraud Unit Seeks Europe Report
description: BRUSSELS  Europes antifraud investigators on Thursday demanded a copy of a confidential European Parliament report that one lawmaker says reveals such abuses in the way members are paid that some of his colleagues could be prosecuted.

title: Knicks in 60: Too Much Failure to Edit It All Out
description: With its Knicks in 60 replay vehicle, MSG has a tool with which it can alter history. A loss doesnt have to look so awful, a win can look a smidgen better through deft editing from two and a half hours to 60 minutes.

title: Teo Macero, 82, Record Producer, Dies
description: Teo Macero, a record producer, composer and saxophonist most famous for his role in producing a series of albums by Miles Davis in the late 1960s and early 1970s, including editing that almost amounted to creating compositions after the recordings, died on Tuesday in Riverhead, N.Y. He was 82 and lived in Quogue, N.Y.

title: New Claim of Taping Emerges Against Patriots
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Patriots pattern of illicitly videotaping the signals of opposing N.F.L. coaches began in Coach Bill Belichicks first preseason with the team in 2000, a former Patriots player said. The information was put to use in that years regular-season opener against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Belichicks debut as New Englands coach.

title: Agency Confronts Iran With Evidence on Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  The International Atomic Energy Agency said Friday that it had confronted Iran for the first time with evidence supplied by the United States and other countries that strongly suggested the country had experimented with technology to make a nuclear weapon, but that Iranian officials dismissed the documents obtained from an Iranian scientist as baseless and fabricated.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 12 about a lawsuit challenging a new campaign finance law in New York City, filed by a lawyer who successfully challenged Vermonts campaign finance restrictions before the United States Supreme Court, misstated, in some copies, the limit per donor for each election in statewide races in Vermont, which the justices said would prevent some candidates from getting their message out. It was $400, not $200.

title: Northeast Hit by Major Winter Storm
description: A major winter storm struck the northeast Friday, with snowfall causing massive delays at airports, closing schools and snarling traffic on streets and highways in the region.

title: Think Summer (a Warning)
description: LETS start with the bad news. Thanks to the weakness of the dollar, staying close to home this summer is probably going to be more popular than jetting off to Europe  which means everyone you can think of will be competing for nearby rentals. The good news, however, is that during the past few years, the number of rentals on the market has shot up, so theres more to go around. The even better news? If youre just starting to think about securing a spot for the season, its not too late.

title: French Banks Troubles Now Include Record Loss
description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale said Thursday that the rogue trading uncovered last month, combined with significant write-offs of United States subprime mortgage investments, had pushed it to a record loss in the quarter.

title: A Journey Shaped by a Guitar
description: EVEN though Nazareth, Pa., isnt quite the holy city its namesake is, pilgrims with a musical bent still go there every weekday in search of a potentially spiritual experience. They head to a quaint brick building, lured by the promise of taking a tour at the C. F. Martin & Company guitar factory.

title: Retired Priest Sentenced for Bilking Two Churches
description: RICHMOND, Va.  A retired Roman Catholic priest was sentenced Thursday to more than five years in prison for bilking two churches out of hundreds of thousands of dollars while he led a double life as a husband and father.

title: Art in Review
description: NAYLAND BLAKE

title: Renovated T.W.A. Terminal to Reopen as JetBlue Portal
description: The Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport  that abandoned embodiment of the Come Fly With Me era of jet-setting  would reopen this year under a plan advanced on Thursday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Bank Chief Says Japans Economy Resilient
description: TOKYO (Reuters)  The governor of the Bank of Japan, Toshihiko Fukui, said on Friday that the global economy continued to expand but that a slowdown in the United States, if it deepens, could affect growth in other parts of the world.

title: A Google Competition, With a Robotic Moon Landing as a Goal
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  More than three decades after the last Apollo astronauts roamed the lunar surface, disparate universities, open-source engineers and quixotic aerospace start-ups are planning to start their own robotic missions to the Earths barren cousin.

title: Classic Beach, but Much More
description: WITH its classic amusement pier, glittering bay and surfers bobbing on swells, Santa Monica was a perfect setting for Baywatch. But take a short walk inland, and this city on the edge of Los Angeles reveals itself as more than a stereotypical beach town.

title: A Table Tennis Star in China Now Uses Her Paddle for the U.S.
description: Wang Chen is one of two American table tennis players ranked high enough in the world to automatically qualify for the Olympics this summer in Beijing. Yet she has no coach and she receives no direct financing from the sports national governing body.

title: Time Appeals Libel Ruling Over Suharto in Indonesia
description: Time magazine filed an appeal Thursday of an Indonesian court ruling that awarded former President Suharto more than $100 million in damages over an article about what the United Nations calls one of the most gargantuan thefts of our time.

title: Triple Threat
description: This three-part horror movie directed by a trio of Atlanta filmmakers is set during the collapse of Terminus, a fictional city whose citizens are being driven to rage by a mysterious signal that jams televisions and phones.

title: Two Brit Awards for Arctic Monkeys
description: For the second consecutive year, the Arctic Monkeys won honors for best British group and best British album (Favourite Worst Nightmare) when the Brits, Britains annual pop music awards, were handed out on Wednesday night in London, Agence France-Press reported. Other winners of two accolades were the re-formed pop group Take That (best live act and best British single, for Shine) and the American rockers Foo Fighters (best international group and best international album, Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace). Paul McCartney received an award for outstanding contribution to music.

title: The Parks, He Knows. But the Trees? Dont Ask.
description: ANY doubts whether Julius Spiegel, Brooklyns commissioner of parks since 1981 and ostensibly forever, is capable of overt bossiness are dispelled the instant one squeezes into the passenger seat of his city-issued Prius. Buckle your seat belt, he orders, unfurling the suave Canadian accent hes retained since moving here from Montreal four decades ago to earn a masters degree in sociology from the New School for Social Research.

title: Donors Worried by Clinton Campaign Spending
description: This article was reported by Michael Luo, Jo Becker and Patrick Healy and was written by Mr. Healy.

title: High Schools the Same; the Drugs Have Changed
description: Ever since he played a forlorn 11-year-old boy in the insufferable 2001 tear-jerker Hearts in Atlantis, the Russian-born actor Anton Yelchin has seemed destined to step into the shoes of Hollywoods favorite quiz kid, Matthew Broderick. And in the precociously articulate title character of Charlie Bartlett, he may have found a contemporary equivalent of Mr. Brodericks beloved hooky-playing high school trickster, Ferris Bueller.

title: For Founders Grandson, On-the-Job Education
description: TOYOTA CITY, Japan   A verdigris-coated bust of the company founder Kiichiro Toyoda greets visitors to Toyotas headquarters building here.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: JAZZ

title: At Toyota, a Global Giant Reaches for Agility
description: TOYOTA CITY, Japan  At Toyotas training center inside its Motomachi assembly complex here, workers use golf balls to limber up their fingers before they learn new tasks on the factory floor.

title: Slain in Prison, but Once Celebrated as a Fugitive
description: The chronicle of Larry Davis was over on Thursday. Stabbed repeatedly in his arms, head, back, legs and chest by another inmate wielding a nine-inch shank, he fell in the yard of an upstate prison, and thereupon hangs the strange tale of a notorious killer, the antihero of another era of New York City.

title: Mangini Assesses State of the Jets
description: After his first season in 2006, Jets Coach Eric Mangini arrived at the N.F.L. scouting combine with a 10-6 record, a playoff appearance and status as the coaching Mangenius. He named quarterback Chad Pennington his starter during a news conference. He also repeatedly noted that each season was different than the next.

title: McCain Loan Complicates Financing of Campaign
description: A bank loan that Senator John McCain took out late in 2007 to keep his presidential campaign afloat is complicating his desire to withdraw from public financing for his primary effort.

title: Waterboarding Approval Focus of Justice Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department revealed on Friday that its internal ethics office is investigating the departments legal approval of waterboarding of Al Qaeda suspects by the Central Intelligence Agency and is likely to make public an unclassified version of its report.

title: A Monet Is Back on the Market
description: A MONET IS BACK

title: Pakistanis Strike Political Accord
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The two main opposition parties that won Pakistans elections this week announced Thursday that they had set aside their differences and would form a government, further isolating President Pervez Musharraf, Americas favored ally here.

title: Italy Follows Trail of Secret South American Abductions
description: BUENOS AIRES  In an unusually sweeping investigation, Italian authorities are seeking to prosecute former top officials in seven South American countries for their roles in a secret operation in the 1970s and 1980s by the regions security forces to crush left-wing political dissent.

title: Magazine Appeals Ruling That It Libeled Suharto
description: BANGKOK  Time Magazine filed an appeal Thursday in Indonesia of a court ruling awarding former President Suharto more than $100 million in damages over an article about what the United Nations calls one of the most gargantuan thefts of our time.

title: Joe Louis and Harlem, Connecting Again in a Police Athletic League Gym
description: It was the evening of June 22, 1938, and nearly everyone in Harlem was doing the same thing. Huddled around radios on their fire escapes and roofs, in their kitchens and living rooms, people were listening to the heavyweight boxing match between Joe Louis and Max Schmeling.

title: Earnings Up Across the Board at Nestl
description: VEVEY, Switzerland (AP)  Nestl, the food and drink company, reported a 16 percent rise in full-year profit Thursday on growth across all segments.

title: 5-Year-Old Boy Dies in Queens Apartment Fire
description: A 5-year-old Queens boy died Thursday in a fire that broke out after he had apparently been left alone in his familys locked apartment, the authorities said.

title: One Assassination Attempt, a Multitude of Perspectives
description: Vantage Point, a gimmick in search of a point, is nothing if not, er, timely. Set in the picturesque Spanish city of Salamanca (otherwise known as Mexico City), this jigsaw puzzle exploits a repellent conceit  the shooting of an American president (William Hurt, effectively insincere)  in a vague attempt to explore questions of narrative and subjectivity (like Rashomon) through the box-office-friendly form of a thriller (like the "Bourne flicks). Instead of pushing the story forward, the filmmakers instead repeatedly return to the crime, or rather to a handful of witnesses, all of whom saw the same exact event from critically different angles.

title: Protesters Attack U.S. Embassy in Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  Demonstrators attacked the United States Embassy and set part of it ablaze on Thursday as tens of thousands of angry Serbs took to the streets of Belgrade to protest Kosovos declaration of independence.

title: A Plan for a New Riverfront Park Faces a Struggle
description: Federal, state and city officials, as well as several civic organizations, expressed support on Thursday for plans for a waterfront park to be built in the shadow of the United Nations.

title: China Criticizes U.S. Missile Strike
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government objected Thursday to the American missile strike against a dying United States spy satellite over the Pacific Ocean, warning that the United States Navys action could threaten security in outer space

title: An Oscars Crystal Ball
description: YOU could be forgiven for arriving poolside for the Oscars in tardy fashion this year. With the brutal writers strike and the most interesting primary political season in a half-century, perhaps the most frequent answer to the question What will win best picture this year? is Who cares?

title: The Cost of Collusion, Paid in Phony Currency
description: The Italian writer Primo Levi, looking back on his time in Auschwitz, observed that in the Nazi death camps the worst, that is, the fittest, survived. The Counterfeiters, a brisk, tough new movie from the Austrian director Stefan Ruzowitzky, is in some ways an illustration of this axiom. Like most films about the Holocaust it is a survivors tale, and its protagonist, at least at first, seems long on guile and short on scruple. He is Salomon Sorowitsch, a master forger and a fixture of the Berlin underworld, and his yellow star is overlaid with a green triangle marking his status as a habitual criminal.

title: Spare Times
description: Museums and Sites

title: Sun Valley
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Rustic Retreats
description: Cabins in off-the-grid settings are available at several locations in the Northeast.

title: Hockey Fan, and Investor, Buys Bauer From Nike
description: OTTAWA  As a child in Montreal, W. Graeme Roustan regularly received hand-me-down Bauer hockey skates from his older brother, and he has continued to buy Bauer Supreme skates ever since.

title: With Strikes End, Oscars Regain Marketing Allure
description: A TELEVISION show on Sunday will bring into millions of homes subjects like war, betrayal, corporate malfeasance, murder, greed, illegal drugs and unwed motherhood.

title: Simon Ends His 30-Game Ban and Rejoins the Surging Isles
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Islanders fans did not shower Chris Simon with love when he took his first shift in more than two months on Thursday night. A thin round of applause was peppered with catcalls, and he was booed when he first touched the puck.

title: Deal to Share Power in Kenya Appears in Reach
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyas rival political parties have nearly completed a deal to end the crisis that has kept this country on edge for almost two months, with the government agreeing to create a prime minister position, one of the oppositions chief demands, a high-ranking government official said Thursday.

title: Roster Change at 'Law & Order'
description: Detective Ed Green of the New York Police Department is turning in his shield. What that means is that Jesse L. Martin, above, is leaving the role he has played since 1999 on the NBC drama Law & Order, The Associated Press reported. An episode to be filmed in the spring will account for Greens departure. Mr. Martin, who took a break from Law & Order to star in the 2005 film version of the Broadway musical Rent, is to portray the singer Marvin Gaye in the film Sexual Healing, scheduled to begin production in the spring, with James Gandolfini among his co-stars. Anthony Anderson, whose credits include the Fox television series K-Ville, FXs Shield and the films The Departed and Transformers, was reported to be concluding negotiations with Law & Order to join the cast as the new partner for Detective Cyrus Lupo, played by Jeremy Sisto.

title: Bankers Sentenced in Enron Fraud
description: Three British bankers were sentenced on Friday to 37 months in prison each for their role in an Enron-related fraud.

title: Doctor Says Exam of Girl Revealed Single Injury
description: An emergency room doctor who treated 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown for a cut on her forehead in November 2005, six weeks before she died, testified on Thursday at the murder trial of Nixzmarys stepfather that no other injuries or signs of abuse were found at the time on the girls body.

title: Covers and Classical Moves From a Bluegrass Virtuoso
description: To call the 27-year-old mandolin virtuoso Chris Thile the Les Paul of his instrument describes only one aspect of a musician who could just as rightly be compared to a great classical guitarist. Although Mr. Thile, an alumnus of Nickel Creek, can toss off witty, jazz-flavored bluegrass solos with breathtaking velocity, his technique is merely the starting point for serious experiments in genre bending that incorporate music ranging from Bach to Radiohead.

title: A Pianist Bids Farewell With Schubertian Grace
description: The audience at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, which spilled over into stage seats, would have been happy to let the ovations for Alfred Brendel go on and on. But after a substantive program devoted to the Classical masters he has championed and three encores, Mr. Brendel crossed his arms over his chest in gratitude and signaled that that was it. The time had come. With one more bow, he left the stage and ended the New York chapter of his towering 60-year career.

title: Professor at Columbia to Keep Job
description: Columbia Universitys Teachers College will not dismiss Madonna G. Constantine, the professor it charged with plagiarizing numerous works by another professor and two former students.

title: High School Star Lacking in Height, Not in Range
description: The last 3-point shot, his coach insisted, came from about 35 feet. Erving Walker was so far behind the arc that his high school coach, Bob Oliva, later said his star guards backside was inches from the teams bench.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A film review last Friday about this years Oscar-nominated shorts misidentified the animation technique used in Aleksandr Petrovs My Love. It was hand-drawn using oil paint on glass, not pastels.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about the big legal bills being run up by New York City and a state authority over a criminal investigation into the fatal fire at the former Deutsche Bank building last August referred incorrectly to the two law firms hired by the city and the authority, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The law firms  Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel, and Dechert L.L.P.  are full-service firms; their practices are not limited to criminal defense.

title: If OTB Goes, So Would a Relic of a Grittier City
description: The Off-Track Betting parlor on Seventh Avenue at 38th Street is a two-story affair, psychically as well as architecturally.

title: Trading the World for a Cabin in the Woods
description: ITS my first night in the cabin, and I cant sleep. The quiet is too loud, as if I were holding a conch shell tight over each ear, and any sounds that do seep through  a wet bulge of snow sliding off a fir tree, the pop of a log in our blazing wood stove  send me tossing and turning, a skittish city mouse in the country.

title: The Furor Over the McCain Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review last Friday about the musical The Blue Flower, at the West End Theater in Manhattan, misquoted part of a lyric that served as a response to a series of deaths and dislocations in the show. It should have been All ships that are sailing/Will come again to port, not And ships that are sailing.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Children in Poverty: There Is No Excuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing MoMAs Sculptures With a Distinctive Tool: Fingers
description: In their baseball caps and Timberlands, the five Tibetan young people giggling in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday might have been members of some kind of teen tour or youth group from abroad, chatting their way through yet another art museum, half-oblivious to its contents.

title: Cheeky Hipsters in the Halls of Victorian Brigadiers
description: The Park Avenue Armory has been undergoing a striking makeover overseen by a dedicated conservancy. Last fall it was the backdrop for a performance involving a fleet of motorcycles by the emerging artist Aaron Young; next month it will serve as a satellite location for the Whitney Biennial. This weekend old and new coexist happily there at the Art Show, the annual fair held by the Art Dealers Association of America.

title: More Down to Earth in the High Country
description: AT first sight, Edwards, high in the mountains of central Colorado, comes across as a jigsaw puzzle whose pieces dont quite fit.

title: No Recourse for the Injured
description: Consumers are already at the mercy of the all-too-fallible Food and Drug Administration. So it is especially disturbing that the Supreme Court ruled this week that patients injured by defective medical devices cannot sue for damages in state courts if the device was approved for marketing by the F.D.A. and made to the agencys specifications.

title: C.I.A. Used a British Island to Transport Terrorism Suspects
description: LONDON  In tones freighted with frustration, Britains foreign secretary, David Miliband, on Thursday told the House of Commons that contrary to earlier explicit assurances the Central Intelligence Agency had confirmed using an American-operated airfield on the British island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean for refuelling two American rendition flights carrying terrorism suspects in 2002.

title: Hills Behind Gates
description: My wife, Julie, and my son and I live in Florida, but I was raised in the western mountains of New England, and that left me with a longing for the four seasons and a desire to introduce my son, Zachery, who is 12, to nature and hunting and fishing. So I set out to determine what the closest geographical location might be to build a second home at a high elevation. We chose South Carolina.

title: Clinton and Obama Debate Once More, and Does It Matter?
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton saved what her campaign views as her personal best for last.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about plans to move and restore the Grange, Alexander Hamiltons country home in Upper Manhattan, attributed an erroneous distinction to that home. At least one other house associated with Hamilton survives: the Schuyler Mansion in Albany (also known as the Pastures), where he was married. The Grange is not the only one associated with him that still exists.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Washington States presidential primary attributed an erroneous distinction to the states nominating system. Washington is one of several states that have both primaries and caucuses; it is not the only one. (Go to Article)

title: Scientists Measure What It Takes to Push a Single Atom
description: I.B.M. scientists have measured the force needed to nudge one atom.

title: McCain Denies Aides Statements About Lobbyist
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  Senator John McCain on Thursday disputed an account in The New York Times that top advisers confronted him during his first presidential run with concerns about his ties to a female lobbyist.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Jan. 12 about jury selection in the murder trial of Cesar Rodriguez, a Brooklyn man accused of fatally beating his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, referred incorrectly to Mr. Rodriguezs courtroom attire. He wore handcuffs as he was led into and out of the courtroom while prospective jurors were absent; he was not wearing handcuffs, hidden beneath his leather jacket, in the presence of prospective jurors. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Washington States presidential primary attributed an erroneous distinction to the states nominating system. Washington is one of several states that have both primaries and caucuses; it is not the only one.

title: Rodriguez Says He Wasnt Specific About Drug Tests
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A day after raising questions about himself by saying he had been tested for performance-enhancing drugs up to 10 times last season, Alex Rodriguez tried clarifying Thursday. While he declined to be specific, he did say that he had been tested more than once, but probably fewer than 10 times, the highest number he had cited Wednesday.

title: In Chicago, the Elusive Genius of Tudor Revisited
description: CHICAGO  What are the two greatest ballets by Antony Tudor, often still credited with having invented the psychological ballet? Most dancegoers who know his work would vote for the two oldest to survive in performance: Jardin aux Lilas (1936)  or Lilac Garden, as the Joffrey Ballet and some other American companies call it  and Dark Elegies (1937). Its fascinating, therefore, to see these together on a triple bill that the Joffrey has mounted to commemorate Tudor, who was born in England 100 years ago but lived and worked in the United States from 1939 on.

title: Inspiration Lives on Where Writers Dwelled
description: I WAS wandering down an unassuming street in London, where I lived in the early 1990s, when I came upon an otherwise-ordinary Georgian house that proclaimed itself to be the home of Charles Dickens. The front door was propped open, and a small sign advertised the visiting hours and entry fee. I was trying to write my own first novel then, and had been reading the great British novelists  from Jane Austen to P. D. James, from Martin Amis to, yes, Charles Dickens  for both inspiration and insight into my adopted country. But it had never occurred to me that Dickens might be my virtual neighbor.

title: She Floats Through the Air, Trailed by Angst and Unease
description: Probably youre familiar with the phrase meet cute. The couple in Carla Cantrelles Looking Up dont, but the play does end cute, as it were.

title: Idol Tops Its Rivals
description: As the top 12 female contestants competed on American Idol on Wednesday, Fox once again easily dominated the nights ratings as 28.7 million viewers tuned in to a two-hour edition of the show, Nielsen estimated. Also on Wednesday, the 10th season of CWs Americas Next Top Model made its debut at 8 p.m., drawing an underwhelming 3.8 million viewers. Although the modeling competition was the runner-up to American Idol with the nights second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 34, it also became the third-lowest-rated premiere of the series ever among adults 18 to 49. CW finished fifth for the night but not far behind ABC and CBS, which broadcast repeats following Big Brother at 8 (5.2 million). ABC edged past CBS for third place in the 18-to-49 set, faring best at 9 p.m. with Supernanny (6 million). NBC ranked second, leading the 10 p.m. hour with Law & Order (10.8 million).

title: Another Casualty of High Rents on the Upper West Side
description: Two deaths brought about the decision to close Cafe La Fortuna, a beloved three-decade-old cafe that drew John Lennon, Yoko Ono and other Upper West Side residents with its garden, opera music and Italian desserts.

title: A New Direction With Twin-Tip Skis
description: O.K., raise your hand if you have used your skis to fly off a jump backward this winter.

title: With Sinker in Tow, a Journey Begins
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Once in a while, Eddie Kunz will insert into his DVD player a disc of a baseball game played June 13, 2005. He fast forwards to the juicy part, the sixth inning, and he watches himself, a 19-year-old freshman at the time, throw the biggest pitch in the history of Oregon States baseball program.

title: Will He Stay or Will He Go?
description: The last time a senior Republican senator secured his partys presidential nomination it wasnt long before he concluded it would be better to become an ex-senator for the White House stretch run.

title: Arizona: A Run Reconsidered
description: Less than two weeks after announcing plans to retire, Representative John Shadegg said he would run for re-election in November after all. Mr. Shadegg, 58, Republican of Arizona, said he changed his mind after 146 House Republicans signed a letter last week asking him to reconsider. He said in a statement that he also received a similar letter from 33 conservative groups urging him to stay.

title: Down by the Blue Purple Yellow Red Water
description: Look! says the man for whom seeing is everything, in a voice that both commands and beseeches. Look!

title: Correction: All Nothing, All the Time
description: A credit for an illustration with an article last Friday about visiting a B&B for a do-nothing getaway misspelled the given name of the artist. He is Christoph Niemann not Christophe.

title: German Bank Offering Aid for Its Troubled Investments
description: FRANKFURT  Dresdner Bank said on Thursday that it would bail out its investment vehicle for complex financial products, the latest bank to take the step to avoid a forced sale of assets into turbulent markets.

title: Cars and Gunpowder and Plenty of Noise
description: The Guggenheim Museums retrospective of the work of the Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang is nothing if not action packed. The galleries are so rife with the sound of explosions and the sight of suspended objects and wildlife (stuffed) that it might almost be a movie set for some new martial-arts spy thriller. Perhaps The Air-Bourne Aesthetic: Writhing Tigers, Hurtling Wolves.

title: Detainees at Guantnamo Fight Further Appeal Delay
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for a group of Guantnamo detainees who are appealing their classification as enemy combatants have told the Supreme Court that it would be unconscionable to grant the Bush administrations request for further delay in producing the records necessary for the appeals to move forward.

title: Fairness on the Farm
description: Against all odds, there is still hope that Congress will produce a halfway decent farm bill, one that increases spending for underfunded programs like food stamps and conservation while decreasing subsidies to rich farmers who have never had it so good. The reason for hope is President Bush, who has been on the right side of the farm issue from the beginning and is threatening to veto any measure that resembles the stinkers produced by the House and Senate last year.

title: Renzo Piano to Design Greek Opera House
description: Renzo Piano has been chosen as the architect for a new national opera house and cultural park in Athens, Agence France-Presse reported. The Niarchos Foundation, financing the project, said on Thursday that Mr. Piano, co-designer of the Pompidou Center in Paris and designer of The New York Times building, will also create a cultural complex, including a new national library, surrounding the opera house on the site of a former racetrack that was leveled and used as a bus depot for the 2004 Olympics. The estimated cost of the project is $441 million.

title: Violence Against Women in War Zones
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Birdies Not Enough to Save Mickelson
description: MARANA, Ariz.  After two rounds of the Accenture Match Play Championship, the fundamental truths about match play in golf remain intact. A golfer can play very well and lose  ask Phil Mickelson, whose seven birdies Thursday were not enough to defeat Stuart Appleby; a golfer can play not so well and win  ask K. J. Choi, who beat Ian Poulter in 19 holes despite shooting one over par in his last 16 holes.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Omar Sharif Ordered to Pay Damages
description: A $318,190 damage judgment was entered against Omar Sharif, below, after he failed to appear on Tuesday for a deposition in Los Angeles County Superior Court in a suit brought by a parking lot attendant, Juan Luis Ochoa Anderson, who claimed Mr. Sharif had punched him, The Associated Press reported. According to the lawsuit, Mr. Sharif, 75, who played leading roles in the films Doctor Zhivago and Lawrence of Arabia, was belligerent and intoxicated, calling Mr. Anderson, a Guatemalan immigrant, a stupid Mexican and punching him for refusing a 20-euro note in the 2005 episode outside a steak house in Beverly Hills. Last year Mr. Sharif pleaded no contest to misdemeanor battery and was ordered to take an anger management course. Calls to his press agent and lawyer were not immediately returned.

title: Behind the Mask of Civility, the Battles Rage On
description: Jacques Rivettes Duchess of Langeais seems to me a nearly impeccable work of art  beautiful, true, profound. Based on Balzacs 1834 short novel and set against the French Restoration  Napoleon is in exile and a Bourbon king again sits on the throne  it traces how a passionate affair of the heart curdles into cruelty and obsession. Originally titled Dont Touch the Ax (a threat guaranteed to make noble necks twitch), it is a story about manners, language, power and society and the bodies caught in their grip. Life, one character observes, is simply a complication of interests and feelings. Art too.

title: One of the Biggest Sinners to Play in Sin City
description: Jose Manuel Vigoa Perez, one of thousands of refugees who fled Cuba on the Mariel boatlift, arrived in Las Vegas on a blistering hot afternoon in July 1980. The bright lights and the hectic atmosphere came as a shock. I felt like I had walked through a time tunnel and was in another world and dimension, he later recalled.

title: Go on a Savings Spree
description: CONGRESS has passed and President Bush has signed legislation to rescue the economy from the jaws of recession. The $168 billion package, which includes an effort to increase consumer spending by distributing $600 rebates to individuals, can be faulted in many ways: with two wars and a budget deficit the nation cant really afford it; it will probably arrive too late in the business cycle to actually make a difference; and the near-universal aspect of the rebates doesnt make much sense. But the most fundamentally troubling thing is the premise that while consumer overspending got us into this mess, more will get us out of it. This is akin to the old saw about curing a hangover with the hair of the dog that bit you.

title: Arab Leaders Say the Two-State Proposal Is in Peril
description: CAIRO  Arab leaders will threaten to rescind their offer of full relations with Israel in exchange for a complete Israeli withdrawal from occupied lands unless Israel gives a positive response to their initiative, indicating the Arab states growing disillusionment with the prospects of a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: La Punta Papagayo and the Kootenai
description: La Punta Papagayo

title: Arizona Congressman Indicted in Land Swap Scam
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Rick Renzi, a Republican who represents a vast region of Arizona, has been indicted on charges of using his office to enrich himself through a complex land swap scam, federal prosecutors announced on Friday in Phoenix.

title: Now a Reminder From Mr. Cunningham
description: Another shoe dropped this week in a major Congressional corruption scandal. Defense contractor Brent Wilkes was sentenced to 12 years in prison for bribing former Representative Randy Cunningham, a California Republican who was once a high-flying appropriator. Mr. Cunningham had already been sent to prison for eight years for accepting millions in cash, antiques and luxury vacations from Mr. Wilkes.

title: Struggling but Grateful, Liberia Welcomes Bush
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  It has been 30 years since a sitting president of the United States has visited this West African nation, and in the decades since, rebel generals with nicknames like Butt Naked laid waste to this seaside country, raping and plundering, and a brutal warlord named Charles G. Taylor campaigned for the presidency under the slogan, He killed my ma, he killed my pa, but I will vote for him anyway.

title: Pakistan Shift Could Curtail Drone Strikes
description: WASHINGTON  American officials reached a quiet understanding with Pakistans leader last month to intensify secret strikes against suspected terrorists by pilotless aircraft launched in Pakistan, senior officials in both governments say. But the prospect of changes in Pakistans government has the Bush administration worried that the new operations could be curtailed.

title: A Final Hurrah for a Pioneering Dealer in Qing Textile Art
description: A FINAL HURRAH

title: The Soul in the New Machines
description: Bioengineered crossbreeds. Temperamental robots. Spermatozoa imprinted with secret texts. Although the fascination with organic form has been around since the Renaissance, we have now entered an age in which designers and architects are drawing their inspiration from hidden patterns in nature rather than from pretty leaves or snowflakes. The results can be scary, but they may also hold the key to paradise.

title: Clinton Says Debate Remark Not Meant as Farewell
description: DALLAS  With the mood of her campaign darkened by the death of a motorcycle officer escorting her motorcade Friday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton vowed to carry on her campaign despite reflective remarks in a debate Thursday night that some people took as a valedictory to her long effort to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: An Errant Satellite Is Gone, but Questions Linger
description: WASHINGTON  Videotape of the Navy mission to shoot down a dying spy satellite made available Thursday shows an interceptor missile ascending atop a bright trail of burning fuel, and then a flash, a fireball, a plume of vapor. A cloud of debris left little doubt that the missile had squarely hit its mark as the satellite spent its final days orbiting more than 130 miles above the Pacific Ocean.

title: Off-Track Betting
description: A horseplayer with an itch to bet has two options in New York City. Drive out to the racetrackAqueduct in the winter, Belmont or Saratoga in the summeror step into one of the 60 or so Off-Track Betting parlors scattered over the five boroughs. Option two is not an inviting prospect. Most of the city's OTBs are cramped, featureless storefronts packed with angry men screaming at the overhead television monitors as their selection of the day limps across the finish line in last place. Losing tickets litter the floor. Sullen clerks take bets. Marginal characters drift in and out. It's not a pretty sight.

title: Sites for Maharishi Effect (Welcome to Parma) Spread Across U.S.
description: PARMA, Ohio  Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the giggling guru who founded the Transcendental Meditation movement, proclaimed throughout his 50-year career that he knew the secret to worldwide peace. And now, this Cleveland suburb is poised to play a role.

title: Microsoft to Share More Technical Secrets
description: Seeking to satisfy European antitrust officials, Microsoft said on Thursday that it would open up and share many more of its technical secrets with the rest of the software industry and competitors.

title: On Health Care, Affordability and Comprehensiveness
description: Health care was the flash point of one of the most contentious exchanges between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday night, with Mrs. Clinton again taking the offensive.

title: Illinois: Gunman Took Anti-Anxiety Drug
description: The gunman who killed five students and then himself at Northern Illinois University took an anti-anxiety drug and a sleeping aid in addition to the antidepressant Prozac, his girlfriend told CNN. Earlier the woman, Jessica Baty, told the news network that the gunman, Steven P. Kazmierczak, stopped taking Prozac three weeks before he entered a university lecture hall and opened fire. On Wednesday, CNN reported that in a follow-up conversation, Ms. Baty said he also took Xanax and Ambien, at least occasionally. Mr. Kazmierczak was under the care of a psychiatrist, she said, who had prescribed the drugs. Mental health specialists say the combination is not uncommon. The university observed five minutes of silence on Thursday, one minute for each of the students killed.

title: Medical Device Ruling Redraws Lines on Lawsuits
description: The Supreme Courts decision Wednesday protecting many types of medical device makers from personal injury lawsuits began rippling through the courts and law offices almost immediately.

title: U.S. Sues 2 Over Gold-Mine Tax Promotion
description: The Justice Department filed two lawsuits on Thursday in a move against what it said was a fraudulent gold-mining scheme sold to dozens of wealthy investors, including seven current or former National Football League players.

title: New Role for Edie Falco
description: The former Carmela Soprano has a new role in life. Edie Falco, below, winner of three Emmy Awards for her portrayal of the mob boss Tony Sopranos wife on the HBO series The Sopranos, has agreed to star in the pilot for an untitled half-hour series for Showtime and Lionsgate Television. Described in an announcement as a dark comedy, the show calls on Ms. Falco to portray a strong-willed iconoclastic New York City nurse juggling the frenzied grind of an urban hospital and an equally challenging personal life. Filming will take place in New York.

title: Sentence in Volkswagen Scandal
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagens long-running corruption scandal has blackened its name and tainted some of Germanys most influential businessmen. On Friday, a court handed down the first jail time in the affair, sentencing Volkswagens former top labor leader to nearly three years in prison.

title: In Trial Over Police Killing in Queens, Focus May Be on First 2 of 50 Bullets
description: It has become widely known as the 50-shot case, but as the trial of the detectives accused in the killing of Sean Bell approaches on Monday, the defense is expected to concentrate in particular on 2 of those 50 bullets: the first one fired by each of the two detectives who are charged with manslaughter.

title: City Offering Hepatitis Vaccinations for Patrons at Restaurant Where Bartender Was Infected
description: The citys health department is offering hepatitis A vaccinations as a precautionary measure to patrons who may have been exposed at Socialista, a West Village lounge and restaurant where a bartender was found to have the disease.

title: Squaw Valley USA
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Suit Says Spinal Disk Maker Falsely Won F.D.A. Approval
description: A patient suing the maker of an artificial spinal disk now says the original maker of the device, Spine Solutions, and the investment firm that financed its development misled patients and federal regulators about the disks safety and effectiveness.

title: Eden Corrupted
description: The flesh is weak but the spirit is indestructible in Cover, a ham-fisted morality tale eager to prove that infidelity may be bad but playing with a member of ones own team is infinitely worse.

title: Another Round of Explosions, but This Time Its Fake
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanon is a country on edge, with every side warning about foreign interference and the spark that could lead to factional war.

title: Tough Quarter for J.C. Penney, and More Expected
description: PLANO, Tex. (AP)  Fourth-quarter profit at the J. C. Penney Company, the department store retailer, declined 10 percent as customers struggled with a weakening economy, the company said Thursday.

title: Researchers Find Way to Steal Encrypted Data
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A group led by a Princeton University computer security researcher has developed a simple method to steal encrypted information stored on computer hard disks.

title: Oil! and the History of Southern California
description: Eric Schlosser, the author of "Fast Food Nation" and "Reefer Madness," owned the film rights to "Oil!" the 1927 Upton Sinclair novel that was the inspiration for "There Will Be Blood," the movie made by Paul Thomas Anderson. In this interview Mr. Schlosser explains how and why he became entranced by the book, and discusses the tumultuous era in Southern California that Sinclair wrote about.

title: Profit Surges at MGM Mirage
description: LAS VEGAS (AP)  The casino giant MGM Mirage reported soaring fourth-quarter profit Thursday, including a hefty gain related to a foreign investment in its CityCenter project, which is under construction on the Las Vegas Strip.

title: Looking at You Looking at Her
description: Exhibitions dont come any smaller than Parmigianinos Antea: A Beautiful Artifice at the Frick Collection. A painting, a wall text, a nugget of a scholarly catalog, and thats it.

title: Bill Clinton Raises the Stakes of Two Contests Next Month
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign has been signaling the importance of the Ohio and Texas primaries next month, but former President Bill Clinton is taking that a step further and suggesting the two contests are ones she must win.

title: Not Your Ordinary Swap Meet
description: An obscure pressure point in the credit squeeze popped up this week when a boutique investment bank in Houston held a public auction for dozens of the most arcane products in the financial world.

title: Debate Takes On Contentious Air
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama veered from collegial to clenched and combative in a debate on Thursday, with Mrs. Clinton turning especially aggressive as she all but accused Mr. Obama of plagiarism and derided his political message as change you can Xerox.

title: Generations Shake and Shift as Time Maintains Its March
description: Countless plays have used earthquakes as metaphors for emotional disturbances and ruptures. Not to be outdone by its predecessors, Imminence features a set, designed by Nic Ularu, that actually rumbles and splits down the middle, the jagged chasm between its two hemispheres periodically widening as the action unfolds. Feelings: theyre strong stuff.

title: Theater Listings
description: THE COLOR PURPLE For anyone who has walked by The Color Purple and not noticed it, time is running out. The Broadway musical based on Alice Walkers Pulitzer Prize-winning novel and produced for the stage by Oprah Winfrey, among others, will close on Sunday after 30 previews and 910 regular performances.

title: Tit for Tat on a Night Where Spin Is Master
description: Mark Penn, pollster and chief strategist to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, how special were your candidates last comments in this Texas debate? Were you touched?

title: U.S. Ends Protections for Wolves in 3 States
description: DENVER  The Bush administration on Thursday announced an end to federal protection for gray wolves in Montana, Wyoming and Idaho, concluding that the wolves were reproductively robust enough to survive.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about movie downloading, referred incorrectly in some editions to a feature of the TiVo digital recording device that lets users rent or buy movies from Amazon. The movies can be ordered and downloaded through TiVo; it is not necessary to order the movies from Amazon.com using a personal computer.

title: Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Co. to 15.6%
description: The hedge funds that hope to elect dissident directors to The New York Times Company board said Thursday that they had increased their holdings to at least 15.61 percent of the companys common stock.

title: Step Dancing to the Lively Rhythms of a French Canadian Poet
description: There was the seed of a good show in Rapaill, performed by [Zogma] on Wednesday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater. Founded in 1999 and based in Quebec, the company describes itself as an urban folk collective devoted to the old French Canadian tradition of step dancing.

title: Across the Bay, on a School Bus Wearing Skis
description: LA POINTE, Wis.  From a distance, the large red aluminum contraption parked on the frozen shore of Lake Superior here looks like a small houseboat perched on skis. Up closer, as schoolchildren pile in with their backpacks and iPods, it becomes clear that the mystery vehicle, with two large fans on the back, is something else entirely.

title: On a Tour of China, Some Musicians Feel Overlooked
description: SHANGHAI  The New York Philharmonics recently appointed principal oboist is a native of China. Its fast-rising associate conductor is too. And they collaborated in a well-received concerto performance in Hong Kong during the orchestras current tour in Asia.

title: The McCain World Rift
description: The staff of the McCain campaign had a rude awakening last Jan. 25th. They opened The Washington Post and found a front-page story linking McCains campaign manager, Rick Davis, to the Russian aluminum magnate Oleg Deripaska. Who, some wondered, was feeding damaging information about Davis to the press?

title: Lottery Numbers
Time Runs Short to Decide Albany Health Care Cuts
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has not called anyone in the health care lobby a crybaby this year. At least not yet.

title: Cavaliers Trade to Get James Some Company
description: LeBron James pined for Jason Kidd, watched a blur of stars crisscross the country and impatiently tapped his fingers, wondering when a crimson-and-gold cavalry would appear on the horizon.

title: Paco: Argentina's Cheap Drug Scourge
description: Paco, a highly addictive form of crack cocaine that sells for less than $2, has destroyed thousands of lives in Argentina.

title: Hockey East Showdown
description: Theres no question Hockey East is having a down year. But its two best teams will be going head-to-head this weekend and the outcome will decide if the run for the regular-season title is a thrill or a snoozer.

title: EMC Acquisition Shows It Wants to be a Cloudmaster
description: EMC, the big computer storage company, bought a little Seattle start-up on Thursday for an undisclosed price. Still, the deal and the forces behind it are intriguing indeed.

title: Anand Leads Morelia-Linares, as Topolav Falters
Lessons in Shanghai
description: The New York Philharmonic coaches students at Shanghai Datong High School in Shanghai.

title: Beauty In Motion
description: Images from the  ballerina Diana Vishneva's engagement at New York City Center.

title: Giants 2008: The Year Ahead
description: The Fifth Downs guest blogger of the week, Andrew Furman, peppered the Comments section with insight during the Giants playoff run. He has his own blog, ultimatenyg.blogspot.com. Last in a series:

title: Impressionistinnen: Women Do Impressionism
description: Unless you know that the suffix -innen denotes the feminine plural in German, you might miss the meaning conveyed by the title of this exhibit. Youve probably heard of Manet, Monet, Renoir and Degas. This is all about the women who belonged to the same movement in late 19th century Paris, but have been unjustly filtered out of most historical accounts.

title: Shakespeare marathon & 15 liters of blood
description: Do you love Shakespeare, fancy English history and have 1,389 minutes plus to spare? If so, a unique opportunity is available, thanks to a mammoth project by the Royal Shakespeare Company, in what has been described in The Guardian newspaper as One of the greatest events of modern theatre.

title: The Scene at the Debate in Austin
description: Supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama gathered for the debate at the University of Texas.

title: Red-Faced Canadians Missing Pants
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Sovereign Bancorp Fires Chief Financial Officer
description: Sovereign Bancorp, the second-largest savings and loan in the United States, said on Thursday it had fired its chief financial officer, Mark McCollom, and named Kirk Walters to succeed him.

title: Transoma Medical Pulls the Plug on I.P.O.
description: Transoma Medical withdrew its registration for an initial public offering on Thursday, citing unfavorable market conditions.

title: China Everbright Names Underwriters for I.P.O.
description: China Everbright Bank appointed China International Capital, China Jianyin Investment Securities and Shenyin & Wanguo Securities to underwrite its planned Shanghai initial public share offering.

title: Calling the School SMOO
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Todays New York Times is claiming that John McCain, who is 71 years old, had an inappropriate relationship with a woman who is a Washington lobbyist. The good news is theres no footage.

title: DB Zwirn to Wind Down Principal Funds, Report Says
description: A New York hedge fund, DB Zwirn, is winding down its principal funds after investors  rattled by lapses in internal controls, including the expense of a private jet used by the firms founder  said they would withdraw more than $2 billion, The Financial Times reported.

title: Russias Binbank Sold
description: Mikhail Shishkhanov, a nephew of a Russian billionaire, Mikhail Gutseriyev, has agreed to sell a Russian lender, Binbank, to a businessman and senator, Vadim Moshkovich, the bank said on Friday.

title: Dakim Snags $10.6 Million From V.C.s
description: Dakim, a developer of software and systems that help seniors retain brainpower, raised $10.6 million in Series C funding led by Galen Partners to market its products to care facilities and to launch new ones for home use.

title: Miles Electric Moves into High Gear With $15 Million Injection
description: Miles Electric Vehicle, a maker of low-speed electric vehicles, plans on releasing a model that can reach highway speeds in late 2009 after raising $15 million in a new round of funding.

title: Tough Sledding for Hedge Funds
description: The year has begun on a brutal note for many hedge funds, judging from recent fund data and new reports of losses and liquidations at some major funds. It appears that pointed comments from Hillary Clinton are the least of the worries facing hedge-fund managers in these choppy markets.

title: More Alike Than the Olsen Twins
description: Aired Thursday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: There was a big story in The New York Times today about Senator John McCain, whos running for president. It questioned his ties to a lobbyist named Vicki Iseman. The story hinted that McCain may have had an extramarital affair with her, but the weird thing is she looks almost exactly like John McCains wife, Cindy. So he might have just got confused and grabbed the wrong woman. These two look more alike than the Olson twins.

title: Terra Firma and Suez Said to Be in Talks About Biffa Bid
description: Terra Firma, the private equity firm run by the British financier Guy Hands, is in talks with the French industrial group Suez about a 1.5 billion pound ($3 billion) counter-offer for Biffa, the waste management company, according to The Telegraph.

title: Google Shoots for the Moon
description: More than three decades after the last Apollo astronauts roamed the lunar surface, disparate universities, open-source engineers and quixotic aerospace start-ups are planning to start their own robotic missions to the Earths barren cousin.

title: A Very Tough Day for John McCain
description: Aired Thursday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Its been a very tough day for John McCain with the New York Times allegation that he had an affair. The paper is saying McCain had an affair, years ago, with Joan of Arc or something.

title: Hedge Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Co.
description: The hedge funds that hope to elect dissident directors to the The New York Times Company said Thursday that they had increased their holdings to at least 15.61 percent of the companys common stock.

title: Operation Bore Them to Death
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Hillary Clinton still doing very well in one state  the state of denial, ladies and gentlemen. Well, after winning 10 in a row, political experts say theres a very good chance that Barack Obama could end up as our next president. See, that shows you the progress weve made in this country. We can have a black man in the White House. I remember when we couldnt get a black man in the cast of Friends.

title: After Rio Move, Chinalco Mulls More Acquisitions
description: The Chinese aluminum company Chinalco, which this year led a $14 billion acquisition of 12 percent of Rio Tinto, said in remarks in an influential magazine that it will continue to seek acquisitions abroad.

title: Bridgepoint Close to Buying Pret a Manger, Report Says
description: Bridgepoint Capital, a London private equity firm, is close to an agreement to buy Pret A Manger (Europe), a sandwich chain, in a deal that would also give Goldman Sachs a minority stake in the company, The Telegraph reported. Bridgepoint reportedly fended off rival bidders Advent International and Morgan Stanley.

title: HLTHs WebMD Merger Creates Attractive Deal Target
description: The merger of HLTH Corporation and WebMD Health could make the combined company a takeover target for larger Internet companies such as Google, industry observers said Thursday.

title: Magazines Up for Sale, Including Variety
description: Variety, Publishers Weekly and dozens of other trade publications are going up for sale as the publishing company Reed Elsevier looks to get out of the advertising market.

title: News Corp. Raises Stake in Premiere
description: News Corporation has raised its stake in Premiere, Germanys largest pay-television operator, raising speculation that it could push for a full takeover of the company.

title: Out of Force of Habit, Hillary Is Standing by Him
description: Aired Thursday night on CBS: Big weekend planned for the Academy Awards Sunday night? Are you folks excited about the Academy Awards? I mean, my gosh, how can you not be? Listen to this: this year, the movies were unbelievable. We had one about a serial killer; one about Alzheimers; one about a kidnapping; one about a guy with a stroke - by God, thats entertainment, isnt it, ladies and gentlemen?

title: Lehman Brothers to Cut 200 Jobs, Report Says
description: Lehman Brothers is cutting 200 jobs, equivalent to 10 percent of its investment banking staff, CNBC television reported on Thursday.

title: Outdated Prices Blamed in Credit Suisse Error
description: The surprise $2.85 billion write-down at Credit Suisse this week underscored the difficulty banks face in valuing complex investments. But the cause of the blunder may be simple: traders at the bank used old prices.

title: Turkey Says It Has Sent Ground Troops Into Iraq
description: SAMSUN, Turkey - Turkey's military said it had sent ground troops into northern Iraq Thursday night in an operation aimed at weakening Kurdish militants there, the first confirmed ground incursion since the United States invaded Iraq in 2003.

title: Not Your Ordinary Swap Meet
description: An obscure pressure point in the credit squeeze popped up this week when a boutique investment bank in Houston held a public auction for dozens of the most arcane products in the financial world.

title: A Harsh Winter for Hedge Funds
description: Hedge funds around the world had the worst month in at least eight years in January as equities worldwide tumbled amid concerns that the U.S. economy was headed for a recession, according to Eurekahedge.

title: Bond Insurer MBIA Pulls Out of Trade Group
description: MBIA, the worlds largest bond insurer, said Thursday that it was withdrawing from the Association of Financial Guaranty Insurers, citing disagreement on the future direction of the bond insurance industry.

title: A Post-Mortem of Dead Deals
description: From PHH to SLM, plenty of leveraged buyout transactions have failed to make it to the finish line in recent months. Private equity firms have taken a lot of heat for walking away from these deals, but Investment Dealers Digest suggests that despite the criticism, buyout firms deserve credit for being disciplined investors.

title: UBS Said to Search for New Chairman
description: UBS has quietly sounded out some of Europes top bankers to join its board of directors and eventually replace the troubled Swiss banks long-serving chairman, Marcel Ospel, according to The Financial Times.

title: Parliament Approves Legislation to Nationalize British Bank
description: The British Parliament passed legislation on Thursday allowing the government to nationalize the struggling lender Northern Rock, five months after the bank became a high-profile casualty of the global credit squeeze.

title: When Bankers Fail to Act
description: Where is the next J. P. Morgan?

title: Fridays Links: How to Talk (or Not Talk) About Salary, and Other Interviewing Pointers
description: Todays links all relate to improving our interviewing skills, whichever side of the table were sitting on:

title: Nascar Riddles Solved
description: We have a winner in the stock-car science quiz, plus answers to some of the other questions about Nascar that Lab readers asked Diandra Leslie-Pelecky, the University of Nebraska physicst and subject of my Findings column.

title: Chow Fun
description: The Bagger is a little long on material and a little short on space (and he thought the Interweb was infinite), so forgive him if he sounds like Liz Smith with a modem. O.K., here goes: The dinner after the opening at the Gagosian was thick with luminaries. Russell Simmons was there, as were Colin Callendar of HBO Films, his wife Elizabeth and Chris DeWolfe, the founder of MySpace. And that was just at the Baggers table.

title: Which of These Things?
description: The Gagosian Gallery on North Camden Drive in Beverly Hills hosted the opening of a massive array of skeletons on Thursday night by an artist who also makes the occasional movie. The work was by Julian Schnabel, and was inspired by some X-rays, made early in the 20th century, that he came across in an uninhabited house in Berck-sur-Mer on the Normandy coast while making The Diving Bell and the Butterfly. The paintings, like the film, explore the human condition from the inside out. And they were also virtually cinematic in size, towering over the gallery full of filmies, arties and wannabees.

title: Demon ethanol
description: Im almost never censored at the Times. However, I was told that I couldnt use the lede I originally wrote for my column following the 2007 State of the Union address, in which Bush made ethanol the centerpiece of his energy strategy: Before the State of the Union address, there had been hints and hopes that President Bush would offer a serious plan to reduce our dependence on imported oil. Instead, however, he took refuge in alcohol.

title: A Critics Critic
description: Paul Thomas Anderson, apart from being the holy vessel of hope and aspiration for critics and cinastes, is known in the industry as both a straight shooter and a barrel of monkeys, someone who takes the work, but not himself, seriously. He did not disappoint.

title: Pickery
description: The eagle may not have landed it was actually shot out of the sky on Wednesday  but the Bagger has. His picks are in the can, beyond the pale and in the paper.

title: The Early Word: Onward From the Debate
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, fresh off a strong closing set of lines at an otherwise fairly tame debate with her rival Senator Barack Obama, hit the morning news shows today.

title: Funkytown
description: The calendar year doesnt get much traction in many parts of Los Angeles. The Oscars is New Years Eve and New Years Day rolled into one, a single day of reckoning when accounts are tallied, blessings are counted and resolutions are forged anew.

title: Tower of Obabble
description: Whats next? Were wondering when someones going to Obamify the lyrics to Little Richards Tutti Frutti (A-womp-bomp-Obama, a-womp-bam-boom!), if that hasnt already been done. (Or maybe readers would like to give it a try? Go for it!) Meantime, help yourself to Slates Encyclopedia Baracktannia, compiled from fans and detractors alike. Heres a sampler (culled by About.com Political Humor):

title: Panic, Deja Vu
description: My column today quotes from one of the most insightful books I have ever read, The Panic of 1907. When I read it last year, I thought it had lessons for today, but I did not realize just how quickly those lessons would become crucial.

title: Ratings Forecast For The Academy Awards
description: If advertisers had it their way, the five best picture nominees for Sundays Academy Awards would be blockbusters. In recent years, the ratings for the show have improved when the nominated films were widely popular and have fallen when they were not, Stuart Elliott writes in todays New York Times.

title: What to Look For in the Sean Bell Trial
description: It has become widely known as the 50-shot case, but as the trial of the detectives accused in the killing of Sean Bell approaches on Monday, Michael Wilson reports, the defense is expected to concentrate in particular on 2 of those 50 bullets: the first one fired by each of the two detectives who are charged with manslaughter. If the two detectives can prove that they were not acting recklessly or with criminal intent in firing their first shots at Mr. Bell and his friends in Queens on Nov. 25, 2006, then the shots that followed  40 more rounds between them  could be determined to be justified as well, said lawyers who have represented police officers in the past and people who have been briefed on the case. A third detective faces two misdemeanor charges.

title: Parsing Clintons Praise
description: Has Hillary caught Obama fever, or is she just throwing in the towel? asks Stephen Spruiell at National Review Online. Near the end of Democratic debate at the University of Texas Thursday night, Hillary Clinton praised her opponent, Barack Obama, in terms so glowing, she seemed like one of those people who have been fainting in his presence lately.

title: Cai Guo-Qiang: I Want to Believe
description: Images from the show at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Design and the Elastic Mind
description: Images from the show at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: We Love This Dirty Town (on Film)
description: Arguably, no one can outdo Martin Scorsese as a New York filmmaker. Taxi Driver. Mean Streets. Whos That Knocking at My Door? Not only was he born in New York, but he also went to New York Universitys film school. He even had a film called New York, New York (though admittedly a box-office and critical failure).So it was rather disappointing that, after being shut out numerous times, the movie that won him an Academy Award for best director was The Departed, which (gasp!) is set in Boston. That would be like Joe Torre taking over the Red Sox and managing them to a World Series title.

title: Riding With Ed: An Actor Devoted to the Green Life
description: I often hear people asking whether its worth trying to limit your personal greenhouse effect by driving less, buying less, eating local, and the like. Personally, I choose to limit my energy use as much as I can for both economic and environmental reasons. I try to telecommute whenever possible not just to save the planet, but to relish a break taken walking in the woods instead of to an elevator.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: A Lot of Night Music
description: While most of the New York Philharmonic remained back in Shanghai on a free day on Friday, three members had duties in Beijing, the orchestras next stop. Sheryl Staples, the principal associate concertmaster; Cynthia Phelps, the principal violist; and Carter Brey, the principal cellist, joined for a trio performance at the residence of the American ambassador, Clark T. Randt Jr. Mr. Randt held a reception for patrons, orchestra staff, corporate sponsors and Chinese guests.

title: A Moment of Silence, Then Back to the Rancor
description: Municipal politics can get heated and personal in almost any city or town in America, and Kirkwood, Mo., was no exception even before Charles Lee Thornton, a 52-year-old contractor, walked into a city council meeting on Feb. 7 and opened fire, killing two council members, the city public works chief and two police officers and wounding the mayor and a reporter before he was shot dead by police.
