Mr. Thornton, in fact, was said to have been a frequent, angry presence at earlier meetings, waging a war of shouts with city officials that led to him being banned from speaking.

title: Courts Weigh in on Valuation Debate
description: That was fast.

title: Giants Set to Reward Coughlin With Multiyear Deal
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Giants are closing in on a multiyear contract for Tom Coughlin, who deftly recast himself as a willing ally of his players and steered the team to a surprising Super Bowl victory.

title: Stray Questions for: Sean Wilsey
description: Sean Wilsey is the author of Oh the Glory of It All, a memoir.

title: And The Emmy For Best Promo Goes To
description: The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences is introducing two new Emmy Awards categories for the producers and editors who create commercials: one for an episodic message (encouraging viewers to tune in for a specific show) and one for an institutional message (publicizing the network).

title: CBS Will BeamUh, That is, Stream Star Trek And Other Classics
description: Do you miss the original Star Trek, Melrose Place or, god help us, MacGyver?

title: This Kitchens Soup Is Just Starting to Simmer
description: The people at the Greenpoint Reformed Church, whose new soup kitchen and food pantry I wrote about for the Dispatches feature in this weeks City Section, say they got the whole endeavor off the ground, in seat-of-the-pants fashion, without a lot of instruction or training. Asked if, four months in, it was living up to what they had envisioned, the Rev. Jennifer Aull, one of the Brooklyn churchs pastors, said: I dont know if we really had much envisioning. You know, you kind of dont know how to do things until youve done them already.

title: Recipe of the Day: Roasted Winter Squash With Seared Cod
description: (Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times)

title: First Big Snowfall of the Season
description: A snowstorm blanketed New York City early Friday, causing headaches for commuters and delaying flights at the region's major airports.

title: For China, One Indignity in Space After Another
description: Hours after China voiced discontent over the United Statess satellite shootdown, Scientific American doubted that their national treasure could be viewed from space:

title: Chatting With Violet
description: A quick announcement: Deanna Dunagan, who plays Violet in the current production of August, will be on a panel of Broadway actors in a TimesTalks event this coming Monday, Feb. 25, at 6:30 at the Times Center in Midtown Manhattan. Campbell Robertson, the Times theater reporter, is interviewing her along with Ian McShane and Brian Cox.

title: Poor Gazza?
description: Just when you thought it couldnt get any weirder, any sadder, for former England international and midfield magician Paul Gascoigne, the 40-year-old was detained under Britains Mental Health Act yesterday after he was identified as a potential menace to hotel guests in Tyneside.

title: Rodriguez Calls Fit-and-Trim Jeter an M.V.P.
description: Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees has won the American Leagues Most Valuable Player award three times, including last season, and teammate Derek Jeter has never won it. But Rodriguez predicted on Thursday that Jeter would have an M.V.P. season in 2008. Rodriguez based this on a conversation he had at lunch with Jeter on Thursday about Jeters conditioning during the off-season.

title: Audi Quattro, New Cop Show Resurrect the 80s
description: I never watched Life on Mars, a high-concept cop show on BBC America, but I recall reading that the detective drove a Ford Cortina. Maybe thats why I never watched the show.

title: Fantasy Football Draft 08, Part I
description: (Mark St. Amant is the author of Committed: Confessions of a Fantasy Football Junkie and Just Kick It: Tales of an Underdog, Over-Age, Out-of-Place Semi-Pro Football Player.)

title: Candidates Quietly Shore Up R.I., Vermont Support
description: Small states Rhode Island and Vermont may be suffering from a slight case of middle-child syndrome, as their March 4 primaries are being largely overlooked as the candidates spend all of their time (and most of their money) in the upcoming big states Ohio and Texas, which vote the same day.

title: Making America Safe for Nonfiction
description: The documentary nominees held a round-up of truth-tellers on Wednesday at the Samuel Golden Theater and indieWire reports that Michael Moore, who is among the annointed with Sicko, has a plan to open up some real estate for docs.

title: From Where Im Standing
description: Over a year ago at Sundance, the Bagger saw Josh Radin playing at a small party and there was a woman behind him hitting all his notes and some of her own. Upon inquiry, the Bagger found out her name was Schulyer Fisk, who was then dating Mr. Radin. It turned out that she also had her own musical career, along with film and television work, including a role in Im Reed Fish.

title: Golden Guy Prefers White Guys
description: The University of Southern California released a study yesterday about the preferences of the Academy and found that in almost in any given year of best picture nominations, the roles for people who are neither white nor male are few and far between.

title: Tearing the Roof Off the Kodak
description: Trust the Bagger when he says that one of the show-stoppers of Sunday night will come when Impact Repertory sings Raise It Up, one of the nominees for best song, from the movie August Rush. The kids from Harlem who give voice to the song are in rehearsals today at the Kodak and the word is that they will rock the place.

title: Eurostar Chief Touts Green Advantage of Trains vs. Planes
description: It seems that concern about global warming means that selling seats has never been easier for Richard Brown, the chief executive of Eurostar, the high-speed train service linking London with Brussels and Paris.

title: Will He Stay or Will He Go?
description: In his column today, Carl Hulse writes that there are some suggestions that Senator John McCain might do the same and give up his Senate seat to devote full-time to his presidential bid, avoiding the political potholes Senate Democrats are certain to place in his way in the coming months, as Bob Dole did in 1996.

title: What Was Clinton Saying? Caucus Readers Interpret
description: Last nights debate ended with a riveting moment that left many Caucus Readers suspecting that Senator Hillary Clinton was conceding the race.

title: For the Moment | Tales of Manhattan
description: (Matt Ross)

title: Buying Movies on Flash Drives: Nice Idea That Doesnt Work
description: Over the last few months, weve had quite a debate in the comments here about the relative merits of Blu-ray, HD DVD and standard DVD discs. Some argue we dont need discs at all because well all be able to download movies. And others have suggested that the price of memory chips is falling so fast that we might still buy movies in stores, but they may come loaded on U.S.B. memory sticks or the sort of SD memory cards that go in digital cameras.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Fendi
description: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment. This week, the Telex comes from Milans womens fashion week.

title: The Week in Comments: Dont Cover It in Glass!
description: Starting today, the print edition of The Times will publish weekly highlights from City Room each Friday, including selected reader comments (the first was by Adriane Fresh, below). If you would like to have your comments considered for publication, please use your real name or initials and include a valid e-mail address so we may contact you. Thanks.

title: Officer Traveling with Clinton Killed in Crash
description: Updated A Dallas police officer traveling with Hillary Rodham Clintons motorcade en route from the airport to a campaign rally was killed Friday morning in a motorcycle accident. Upon learning of the fatality either during or after her first event, Senator Clinton briefly addressed the crowd gathered at a second rally in Fort Worth but then canceled it.

title: Castro Reviews the Candidates, Who Make Him Feel Like Wolf Blitzer
description: Just days after White House hopefuls rushed out statements reacting to Fidel Castros decision to step down, Castro himself took notice.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Rene Caovilla and Zoraide
description: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment. This week, the Telex comes from Milans womens fashion week.

title: More Signals of a Motorola Split?
description: Sometimes a finance chief is more than just a finance chief.

title: GMAC Ratings Slide, Raising Concern at Cerberus
description: For Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm, things at GMAC always seem to be going from bad to worse.

title: The Envelope, Please
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: NatWest Three Sentenced in Enron Fraud
description: Three British bankers were sentenced on Friday to 37 months in prison each for their role in an Enron-related fraud.

title: Perez Wins Arbitration
description: The mets have confirmed that Oliver Perez has won his arbitration hearing in the teams first case since 1992. Perez will make $6.5 million this year; the team offered $4.725 million.

title: The Browser Choices We Make
description: TechCrunch noted Thursday that Mozilla was about to celebrate its 500 millionth download of Firefox, the open source browser that has made inroads into Microsofts dominant market share. By this morning, the official Spread Firefox site was claiming an additional 340,000 downloads, putting it over the half billion mark.

title: Valencia circuit news
description: The gpeuropa site has published a lot more details about the new Valencia circuit, including some grandstand information, and its looking interesting.

title: A Pastors Mission to Destroy Harlem
description: James David Manning says he wants to save Harlem. First though, he says he must destroy it - rather, Harlem must destroy itself.

title: The Company They Keep
description: In 1995, State Senator Alice Palmer introduced her chosen successor, Barack Obama, to a few of the districts influential liberals at the home of two well known figures on the local left: William Ayers and Bernardine Dohrn, reports Politicos Ben Smith:

title: Domaine du Jaugaret
description: Ive had Bordeaux  on the mind recently, and it reminded me of a talk I had last summer with the importer Neal Rosenthal. Most of our conversation had to do with honey, as Neal not only imports some beautiful, distinctive European honeys, he is now a dedicated beekeeper and produces his own buckwheat honeys from his farm in upstate New York.

title: The Art of Waste
description: Chris Jordans photography isnt really about food  its about consumption  but it isnt a coincidence that nearly half the images on his stunning website are of disposable packaging related to food or drink. Check it out.

title: Now Showing | Design and the Elastic Mind
description: Face Object from the BEEs project, adiagnostic tool using bees and humanbreath. Susana Soares, Design InteractionsDepartment, Royal College of Art.

title: Burger Upset in Miami
description: Guest Blogger Allen Salkin files this update on the South Beach Burger Bash:

title: All Alone By the Telephone
description: The Bagger likes to keep things on the down-low out here  the paparazzi, the bill collectors, the federales all pose significant threats  so he never mentions that he is staying at Le Parc a secret, undisclosed location in West Hollywood. Which may explain why he never got the invite to Bryan Lourds party for CAA clients and friends tonight. And the gang at Endeavor, where Ari Emmanuel is getting funky with Tilda, Javier and Viggo, must be having trouble finding him as well. The Bagger does have one e-mail invite to small studio gig tonight and Miramax might let him in tomorrow, but he often has trouble at the door, so who knows?

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Feb. 22:

title: McCain Hits Obama on Cuba
description: With an eye on the general election and presumably those Cuban-American voters in Florida and their supporters around the country, the Republican party and Senator John McCain quickly seized on remarks made during last nights Democratic debate by Senator Barack Obama.

title: New York and the Vanguard of Digital Design
description: Several works in Design and the Elastic Mind, an exhibition that opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday, offer intriguing and unexpected perspectives on New York. A team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has mapped the international phone calls and Internet traffic that connect the city with countries around the world, showing, for example, just how often Queens immigrants are on the phone back home with India. A design lab at Columbia University has traced the costs of incarceration in poor minority neighborhoods, demonstrating that taxpayers in some cases pay $1 million a year to imprison inmates from a single Brooklyn block.

title: Is Nasdaq Starting a Race to the Bottom for SPACs?
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market announced Thursday that it would propose new rules permitting special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, to list on its market.

title: Not Drinking  More Like Hitting the Sauce
description: A new way to deny you have a drinking problem: edible Cointreau! (Theres also the wine glass that holds a full bottle.)

title: Man Is Injured in Midtown Robbery
description: Updated, 4:52 p.m. | A man in his 50s was injured in an apparent robbery at 2:05 p.m. today near West 56th Street and Sixth Avenue in Midtown, according to the police. The victim was taken with a head injury to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, and his condition was not immediately known.

title: A new Moscow music sensation: Peter Nalitch plays Gitar
description: By Sophia Kishkovsky

title: Clinton Plans to Press for Florida and Michigan Delegates
description: So much for a valedictory speech.

title: Undefeated and Under Pressure
description: Sports can be startlingly simple. Two teams play; one emerges the winner. And this season every time Memphis has stepped on the court it has left victorious. That is the kind of perfection that garners attention.

title: M.T.A. Puts Off Weekend Subway Work
description: If there is a silver lining to the wet storm that blanketed the Northeast with snow this morning, this is it: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has just postponed all construction activity that had been planned this weekend, meaning that most subways will run on their normal weekend schedules. Typically on weekends, subway service is limited or rerouted to accommodate track and signal work.

title: Let There Be Light
description: One of the things Paul and I did while we were in Florida a couple of weeks ago was select lighting fixtures  all of them  for the house.

title: EMC Acquisition Shows It Wants to Be a Cloudmaster
description: From our colleague Steve Lohr at Bits:

title: Santanas First Showdown
description: The first showdown: Johan Santana pitched live batting practice Friday for the first time as a Met on field No. 6 here in Port St. Lucie.

title: Coca-Cola Says It Wont Rely on Deals for Growth
description: Coca-Cola said on Friday it would continue to make acquisitions, but they were not necessary for the company to meet its long-term growth objectives, Reuters reported.

title: Ratings: On Fox, Idol Wins And Gives A Long Echo To Lyrics
description: The results edition of American Idol lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday while giving a considerable boost to the networks other singing competition, Dont Forget the Lyrics.

title: A Playwrights Choice
description: I have to confess that as far as Johnna goes, I feel shes the one discordant note in the play because, as Eliza says, she is a sort of weak character and also because she seems too manifestly a device and, ultimately perhaps, a symbol. If, as Blake persuasively argues, shes a political device or symbol, that only compounds the problem because that meaning seems superimposed on a character too thin to carry the weight of so heavy a slice of the American gestalt.

title: Breaking Up in Five Rhyming Lines
description: You wont hear many limericks in Limerick, but evidently you will hear Its all over between us pretty often. The Independent reports today that Limerick city, the third-biggest in the Republic of Ireland after Dublin and Cork, leads the nation in divorces.

title: Lather Up: The Hand-Wringing Over Hand-Washing
description: Youve seen the signs. So have we: Employees Must Wash Hands Before Returning to Work, required by the city health code in all bathrooms in restaurants and bars. In fact, weve even seen the signs in Spanish and Chinese, as well as English.

title: CHC Agrees to $1.5 Billion Buyout in Big Oil Services Deal
description: CHC Helicopter, which provides transportation to oil rigs, agreed to be acquired by a private equity company for $1.5 billion, the largest-ever oil-field services buyout.

title: Argentina's Cocaine Problem
description: A highly addictive smokable cocaine residue, known as paco, has emerged in Argentina over the past five years and destroyed thousands of lives.

title: Report on Potential Ambac Bailout Reverses Stock Slide
description: Update: The New York Times reported Friday afternoon that Ambac will split itself into two parts and raise $3 billion. The plan, drafted by a consortium of eight banks including Citigroup and UBS, still needs approval by the credit ratings agencies but could be formally unveiled as soon as Monday.

title: Soft Serve | How To Stalk in Paris, A Gadget for Boozers, Versace Vanity
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: The Nader Question
description: Ralph Nader is scheduled to appear on NBCs Meet the Press on Sunday, sparking speculation that he is planning another third-party run for the White House.

title: Ask About Nature in New York
description: Leslie Day, the author of Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), took questions from readers over the past week. Dr. Day, who has a doctorate in science education from Teachers College at Columbia University and developed the City Naturalists Summer Institute at the Central Park Conservancy, is an environmental and life science educator at the Elisabeth Morrow School in Englewood, N.J. She is also an adjunct faculty member at Bank Street College of Education. Dr. Day and her husband live on a houseboat on the Hudson River in Manhattan.

title: This Should Clear Things Up
description: Several readers have asked about the math work involved in a chart this week that explained the probability for a player to be chosen for a random drug test under the Major League Baseball policy. As the chart explained, there are 1,200 players and baseball conducts 660 random tests over the course of a year.

title: Finding a Bomb Factory
description: U.S. troops come upon a suspected bomb factory in Diyala. In another village a house bomb, with deadly results.

title: Bush Picks S.M.U. for Presidential Library
description: Correction appended

title: Popcorn for the Red Carpet Ride
description: (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

title: Taking on Local Fighters
description: Violence has fallen drastically in Arab Jabour, a former stronghold of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

title: Google Says I.P. Addresses Arent Personal
description: UPDATE: Two Google officials, Matt Cutts, a top search engineer, and Peter Fleischer, Googles global privacy counsel, wrote comments below reacting to this post. I wrote some thoughts responding to their comments in another post here.

title: On the Road: Along the Rio Grande, Students Struggle to Surmount Poverty
description: EDINBURG, Tex.  A salutary aspect of life on the campaign trail, even in the bubble that is a candidates lot, is that one is reminded from time to time of the prosaic, not to mention heart-breaking, struggle of so many to escape povertys grasp.

title: Virgin Chairman Changes Opinion on Ethanol Investments
description: Tom Philpott of Grist.org reports that Richard Branson, chairman of the Virgin Group, seems to have changed his mind about corn ethanol:

title: What Didnt Happen at the Debate
description: Thursday nights debate was a reminder that the Democrats have narrowed their field to two very strong, intelligent and effective candidates. When juxtaposed against the mess that the likely Republican candidate found himself in this week, it was difficult not to be giddy while watching the debate in Austin, Tex.

title: Microsofts Internal Yahoo Memo to Its Troops
description: As both Microsoft and Yahoo gird themselves for a potentially drawn-out fight, Microsoft is giving a pep talk to its foot soldiers.

title: Outside Groups Advertising in Ohio, Texas
description: Voters in Ohio and Texas should be fastening their seat belts these days for an onslaught of robo-calls and direct mail solicitations from outside groups supporting  and, in some cases attacking - Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.

title: Clinton Goes Up With New Ads
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has not one, not two, but three new TV ads out today. One takes a definitive Texas angle, the others play to Ohios emphasis on jobs, jobs, jobs.

title: An Old Face Rejuvenated
description: New York's General Post Office recently completed an extensive exterior renovation.

title: Euros Not Accepted Here
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: A Family Pastime Turns Addictive Online
description: Celebrity journalist Martha Frankel has interviewed Johnny Depp, Elizabeth Taylor and Robert DeNiro. But perhaps the most interesting story of her journalistic career is the one she has written about herself.

title: A Third Time for the Third Wheel?
description: Ralph Nader could be poised for another third party presidential campaign, reports the Associated Press. The consumer advocate will appear on NBCs Meet the Press on Sunday to announce whether he will launch another White House bid. Nader kicked off his 2004 presidential run on the show.

title: Bloggingheads: Black 'Sellouts'
description:
Randall Kennedy of Harvard Law School, left, debates John McWhorter of the Manhattan Institute over whether anyone should be labeled a traitor to his or her race.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: There Will Be Oscars
description: The odds for the Best Adapted Screenplay Oscar seem to be on the Coen brothers straight-shooting adaptation of Cormac McCarthys No Country For Old Men. But Paul Thomas Anderson could still walk away on Sunday night with the statuette for There Will Be Blood, his freewheeling and darkly poetic reimagining of Upton Sinclairs 1927 novel Oil! (Pop quiz: Does anyone know any novelists besides Sinclair and Dave Eggers who have used exclamation points in their titles?)

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the old American Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport, living on a houseboat in the boat basin and the citys Off-Track Betting parlors.

title: Microsoft President on Micro-Hoo: We Can Do It
description: We can do it. We can mesh our technologies and our cultures. And well keep the Yahoo name alive.

title: Octopus, Galician Style
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes octopus accessible to those who might be squeamish.

title: Warner to Obama: Bring Me Your Captain
description: One of the dramatic moments in Thursdays Democratic debate came when Senator Barack Obama  in making the case that Iraq was the wrong place to launch a war  cited an Army captain in Afghanistan who told him of a rifle platoon that lacked manpower, ammunition and Humvees. As Mr. Obama recounted, the soldiers looked for captured Taliban weapons as it was easier to be armed that way than to get properly equipped by our current commander in chief.

title: Bobby and You
description: Thank you very much.

title: Stir-Fried Shrimp With Black Beans
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a stir-fry with shrimp and bok choy.

description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, goes south of the border for St. Patrick's Day.

description: In Texas, wind power is remaking the West Texas landscape and helping the state become a leader in another form of energy besides crude oil.

description: Paco, a cheap and highly addictive smokable cocaine residue, has destroyed thousands of lives in Argentina. But Bilma Acuna is fighting back.

description: BUTTERKNIFE 4: Bongo BoardAdd to My Profile | More Videos

title: Argentina's Cheap Drug Scourge
description: Paco, a highly addictive smokable cocaine,  has destroyed thousands of lives in Argentina. But Bilma Acuna is fighting  back.

title: New Harmonies
description: Young Chinese composers collaborate with the New York Philharmonic in Shanghai, China.

title: Nepomniachtchi Captures Aeroflot Open
F.D.A. Extends Avastins Use to Breast Cancer
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved Genentechs best-selling drug, Avastin, as a treatment for breast cancer, in a decision that appeared to lower the threshold somewhat for approval of certain cancer drugs.

title: China and the Philharmonic, in Harmony
description: SHANGHAI  In a chilly classroom at Shanghai Datong High School, the New York Philharmonic musician counted out, One, two, one, two in Taiwanese-accented Mandarin. A dozen student violinists sawed out a theme from Bizets Carmen, laughing nervously when asked if they would like to go a bit slower.

title: A Bad Year to Be a Mallard
description: I shot a banded duck, said Hillary Clinton.

title: Shuttle Director Transferred
description: N. Wayne Hale Jr., a 30-year veteran of NASA who helped lead the space agencys recovery from the 2003 Columbia disaster, was transferred from his job as manager of the shuttle program. Neither NASA nor Mr. Hale gave a reason for the shift, to a new position in space operations at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. Mr. Hale, who championed making safety the paramount factor in deciding when shuttles are to fly, said in a memorandum to colleagues that he had expected to stay with the shuttle program until it ended in 2010 with completion of the International Space Station, but that he had recently been asked to assume the new job. He will be succeeded by John Shannon, a former flight director who is chairman of NASAs Mission Management Team.

title: A Pragmatist and a Lobbyist on Atheism
description: ALBANY

title: Plunder Goes on Tour
description: Washington

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Jan. 16 about Katherine Gamble, a woman who got help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to declutter her Manhattan apartment after depression and ill health made it difficult for her to throw things out, misstated her age. She is 60, not 50. A social services agency that worked with Ms. Gamble pointed out the error recently; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Connecting the Dots on Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Considers Subpoenaing Ashcroft in Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The House Judiciary Committee disclosed Friday that it was considering subpoenaing former Attorney General John Ashcroft to testify about a contract worth at least $28 million that was steered to his consulting firm by the Justice Department.

title: A Neanderthal, Club in Hand, Finds a Thrill on the Greens
description: I STRODE onto the tee box of the 18th hole at Emerald Dunes Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla., with a 25-mile-an-hour wind blistering my cheeks and an existential quandary befuddling my brain. My industrialist friend David Koch and I were embroiled in a best-ball match against two veteran professionals. After losing three straight holes on the front nine, we had battled back to tie the match with one hole to go. But all I could think about was a vintage B.C. comic strip.

title: The Invisible Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: Battling Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Sides of a Prima Ballerina, Made to Order
description: Audiences who came of age in the Iron Curtain era still find it astonishing to contemplate a career like Diana Vishnevas. Ms. Vishneva is the prima ballerina of the Maryinsky (Kirov) Ballet in St. Petersburg, Russia, and appears on its foreign tours, dancing not just its old ballets but also its newly acquired Balanchine repertory. She is a leading guest artist with American Ballet Theater in its New York seasons at the Metropolitan Opera House, dancing both ballet classics and mid-20th-century gems by Frederick Ashton and Kenneth MacMillan. Now she is presenting a season of her own at City Center, dancing in a triple bill of ballets created for and around her by more or less eminent choreographers.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Feb. 15 about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens paraphrased incorrectly from a transcript of a conversation between Mr. McNamee and investigators for Mr. Clemens on the day before the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball was released. Mr. McNamee said he told Jim Murray, a New York-based representative for Mr. Clemenss agent, that steroids had come from the former Mets bat boy Kirk Radomski. He did not say he had purchased steroids and growth hormone from Mr. Radomski.

title: 4 Decades After Shooting, Effort to Make Punishment Fit the Crime
description: CHICAGO  What punishment should be imposed on a man who shot a police officer almost 40 years ago and fled to Canada, but went on to live an upstanding life as a husband and father who worked in a library?

title: Troubled Firm to Close 2 Funds Worth $4 Billion
description: D.B. Zwirn, a New York hedge fund that has been plagued by accounting irregularities, is closing two of its largest funds after investors demanded the firm return $2 billion.

title: Files and McCain Letter Show Effort to Keep Loophole
description: WASHINGTON  In late 1998, Senator John McCain sent an unusually blunt letter to the head of the Federal Communications Commission, warning that he would try to overhaul the agency if it closed a broadcast ownership loophole.

title: Insurer Works to Prevent Ex-Chief From Seeing Files
description: The American International Group, the insurance company, is pulling out the stops to try to prevent its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, from seeing confidential internal documents.

title: Some Nifty Declarer Play From South Carolina
description: The winners of the Friday-Saturday Knockout Teams at the Low Country Classic Regional in Hilton Head, S.C., last weekend were Carolyn Lynch of Scottsdale, Ariz.; David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla.; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; Mike Passell of Las Vegas; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.

title: An Odd Couple, in Character and in Harmony
description: There are no casting directors in jazz, but sometimes you see a pair of musicians who could have been brought together by one: for example, Enrico Rava and Stefano Bollani, the Italian trumpeter and pianist.

title: With Housing in a Downturn, a Company Renovates
description: AS the post-holiday blues drag on for retailers, even high-end brands are feeling the pinch. Hunter Douglas, in Upper Saddle River, N.J., is the leader in the custom window coverings industry, but even it is not immune from the housing slowdown and the current economy. While waiting for the housing industry and consumer confidence to improve, Hunter Douglas is focusing on its internal operations and strengthening its dealer and distributor alliances.

title: Final Birdie by Woods Proves to Be Biggest
description: MARANA, Ariz.  Under leaden skies as gray as his sweater, Tiger Woods again stood on the edge of elimination Friday. He stood with face set and arms crossed, first on the 18th green, then on the first hole of sudden death, watching Aaron Baddeley twice line up putts to send him home early from the Accenture Match Play Championship.

title: New Tactics to Control Immigration Are Unveiled
description: Bush administration officials said Friday that they would begin using new technology to create a virtual fence along sections of the border with Mexico, and that construction had been completed on 302 miles of physical fence.

title: Rotating Yankee Veterans to Find the Right Balance
description: TAMPA, Fla.  For his first five seasons as a Yankee, Hideki Matsui was a fixture in left field, a steady and heady veteran who was rarely injured, hit with power and for average, and enjoyed the trust of Joe Torre. But much has changed.

title: Politics and Needle Exchanges
description: Needle exchange programs save lives. They slow the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and they help get addicts into treatment. Yet when it comes to supporting these programs, it seems that the political cowardice never ends.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart on Friday comparing fund-raising and spending for presidential candidates misstated the amount of money raised by two of them between Jan. 1, 2007, and Jan. 31, 2008. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton raised $133 million in contributions, loans and transfers, not $118 million. Senator John McCain raised $52 million, not $48 million.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the higher risks involved in multiple births referred incorrectly at one point to the procedure by which embryos enter the womb in in vitro fertilization. They are transferred, not implanted.

title: Barnum on Each Bench in Most Unlikely Rivalry
description: MEMPHIS  Walking to class Friday morning, Memphis point guard Derrick Rose and a few of his teammates were greeted with an unusual sight. Eight people, including one with a bullhorn and a speaker, were following them around campus.

title: Nuclear Agency Says Iran Has Used New Technology
description: WASHINGTON  The International Atomic Energy Agency described for the first time on Friday the evidence it has shown to Iran that strongly suggests the country had experimented with technologies to manufacture a nuclear weapon, but reported that Iranian officials had dismissed the documents as baseless and fabricated.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the building of a Transcendental Meditation palace in Parma, Ohio, referred imprecisely in some editions to the percentage of the population practicing TM that Maharishi Mahesh Yogi believed would be necessary to achieve increased coherence in the collective unconscious. It is the square root of one percent of the population (for example, about 1,700 people in the United States)  not merely the square root of one percent, which is 10 percent.

title: Rambo Loses a Battle
description: Odeon, Britains largest chain of moviehouses, will not show Rambo at its theaters this weekend, citing commercial reasons, Variety reported. This is the films opening weekend in Britain. The news has enraged fans of Sylvester Stallone, right, especially those who live in rural areas where their only local cinema is an Odeon. The company said the decision not to screen Rambo will free up screens to show alternative popular new films such as Jumper, Be Kind Rewind and Juno, but there was speculation among British movie exhibitors that the cause of the abrupt move was a disagreement over terms between Odeon and Sony, the films distributor. I cant remember the last time this happened in the multiplex era, one film booker said. Sony Pictures Releasing U.K. declined to comment.

title: Is He Insane? No, Hes Larry
description: Witless Protection, the third feature film starring Larry the Cable Guy, finds this comedians recurring character, Larry, here a small-town deputy, fantasizing about becoming an F.B.I. agent. He plays out his hero fantasies by rescuing a sultry trial witness named Madeleine (Ivana Milicevic, her arrival heralded by hubba-hubba sax music) from the custody of F.B.I. agents who Larry believes are working for the rich crook Madeleine is supposed to testify against in a tax fraud case.

title: Sardonic Tales of Disillusionment Banged Out Quietly on the Bouzouki
description: Verbally meticulous, restrained and constitutionally glum, the songwriter Stephin Merritt is no ones idea of a rocker  apparently not even his own. His band the Magnetic Fields usually performs in a quiet acoustic lineup. So Distortion (Nonesuch), their latest album, was a surprise, since its songs are awash in guitar discord over a big beat. Would the Magnetic Fields plug in and rock out for their four-night stand at Town Hall?

title: Cheap Cocaine Floods Argentina, Devouring Lives
description: BUENOS AIRES  Bilma Acua has two drug-addicted sons and roams the streets of the Ciudad Oculta slum here with a purpose: to save others from the same fate.

title: Man Attacked and Robbed of $150,000 in Midtown
description: A man carrying a bag filled with nearly $150,000 in cash that he had just withdrawn from a bank in Midtown Manhattan was assaulted and robbed by an armed man on Friday afternoon, officials said.

title: Open-Wheel Series Unite in Effort to Halt Decline
description: The rift that has divided open-wheel racing in the United States since 1996 and helped lead to the decline of the sport is finally over. Officials from the Indy Racing League announced Friday that they reached an agreement with leaders of the opposing Champ Car World Series to unify the two into one open-wheel racing series.

title: A Moral Hazard for a Housing Bailout: Sorting the Victims From Those Who Volunteered
description: WASHINGTON  Over the last two decades, few industries have lobbied more ferociously or effectively than banks to get the government out of its business and to obtain freer rein for financial innovation.

title: Before Another Bridge Falls
description: Nearly seven months after a highway bridge collapsed in Minneapolis, a federal commission put a jaw-dropping price tag on starting to attend to Americas crumbling foundations: $225 billion a year for the next 50 years just to maintain and upgrade surface transportation.

title: Sidney Watters Jr., 90, Trainer of Champion Racehorses, Is Dead
description: Sidney Watters Jr., the Racing Hall of Fame racehorse trainer who saddled the champion colts Hoist the Flag and Slew o Gold, died Feb. 14 in Towson, Md. He was 90.

title: In Germany, Boxing Finds Appreciation and a Hub
description: HAMBURG, Germany  When Wladimir Klitschko steps into the ring at Madison Square Garden against Sultan Ibragimov on Saturday night, New York City will once again be the focus of the heavyweight boxing world. But once the fight is over, the center of gravity for heavyweights will swing back to its new and unexpected home, Germany.

title: Lottery Numbers
Rescuers Find Wreckage of Plane Carrying 46 in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Capping a frenzied search by helicopter high in the Andean mountains of western Venezuela, rescue teams said Friday that they had found the debris of a plane carrying 46 people that had crashed shortly after taking off on Thursday from the provincial city of Mrida.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about August Wilsons 20th Century, a series of staged readings of the playwrights 10-play cycle, at the Kennedy Center, misstated the history of the plays. Jitney was written first, not Ma Raineys Black Bottom.

title: Footnotes
description: The 92nd Street Y named Deborah Grace Winer, a playwright and author of several books on American song, the artistic director of Lyrics & Lyricists, the Ys long-running American Songbook series. She replaces Kristin Lancino, who will leave at the end of the 2008 season. ... Jennifer Lopez, who is married to Marc Anthony, gave birth to twins, a boy and a girl, on Friday morning, The Associated Press reported. The girl arrived first. ... Stacy Keach will star as Richard M. Nixon in the national tour of Frost/Nixon, Playbill reported. The role was created on Broadway by Frank Langella, who won a Tony Award for it. The tour is scheduled to start on Sept. 26 in Owensboro, Ky.

title: 3 Are Shot, 1 Fatally, in Brooklyn
description: One man was killed and two others were injured in a shooting at a popular Mexican restaurant in Brooklyn on Friday night, the police said.

title: Paris Puts Up the Stats as Her Sister Plays the Foil
description: NORMAN, Okla.  It was a tight fit for the twins Courtney and Ashley Paris as they sat on the piano bench Thursday night, jockeying for position. With their hands poised over the instrument, they shot each other a look and then started plunking on the keys.

title: The Conflict of Spending and Candor
description: WHEN I told my husband recently how much I had spent on a birthday gift for a relative, he had a bit of an Exorcist moment.

title: More Sharp Words Traded Over Lapsed Wiretap Law
description: WASHINGTON  A new round of political sparring erupted Friday over the governments wiretapping powers, as the Bush administration asserted that the lapsing of a surveillance law a week ago has already led to the loss of important intelligence information and made private phone carriers less willing to cooperate.

title: Fallacy in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Thursday about the choral conductor Richard Westenburg misidentified the resident choir at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church while he was music director there. It was the churchs own choir of paid professionals and church members  not the Musica Sacra Chorus, though Musica Sacra sometimes performed at the church. The obituary also misstated Mr. Westenburgs title at the Collegiate Chorale from 1973 to 1980. He was music director, not conductor.

title: 2 Ex-Marsh Officials Convicted on Antitrust Charge
description: Two former executives of Marsh Inc., the insurance broker, were convicted Friday on an antitrust charge involving a bid-rigging case brought by New York State prosecutors.

title: E-Mail Threats Lead to Arrest of a Woman
description: JERSEY CITY  Two days after the police canceled all classes at Saint Peters College and searched 20 campus buildings with bomb-sniffing dogs, an 18-year-old woman was arrested in Corpus Christi, Tex., on Friday and charged in connection with threatening e-mail messages that were sent to a 19-year-old male student at the college.

title: On Clothing Racks, Inflation Is the Hot Trend
description: THE great clothing price deflation  brought on in part by Chinas entry into the world economy  may be over.

title: Much to Applaud, With Footnotes
description: Milan

title: In California, Coastal Commission Wields Vast Power
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.  The battle here over a proposed toll road near a state park has entangled powerful interests from across California: Labor is pitted against surfers, American Indians against developers, commuters against campers and coastal people against inland dwellers.

title: Sentence in Volkswagen Scandal
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagens long-running corruption scandal has blackened its name and tainted some of Germanys most influential businessmen. On Friday, a court handed down the first jail time in the affair, sentencing Volkswagens former top labor leader to nearly three years in prison.

title: An Introspective Shade of Virtuosity
description: We tend to think of virtuosity as the musical equivalent of an extreme sport: lots of fast, loud, bravura passages that show off finger power and agility, ideally with enough originality in the phrasing to make the performance seem more than just whiz-bang display. But in his recital at the Rose Theater on Wednesday evening, the pianist Christian Zacharias argued that virtuosity comes in other forms as well, most notably as an expression of patient introspection.

title: Rocker Joins Entourage in Africa
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  The contingent of reporters accompanying President Bush on his trip to Africa was small, a reflection of how the press is turning its attention away from the current president and toward the race to succeed him. But in Rwanda this week, Mr. Bush had a celebrity journalist in his entourage: Bob Geldof, the Irish rock star.

title: Small Vendors Feel Pinch of Clintons Money Troubles
description: It was just $2,492.63, a pittance, really, alongside million-dollar television buys and direct mail drops.

title: Man Departs a Life Lived on the Fringes of Fame
description: He died away from the noisy, glittery, late-night places where he was a regular among regulars, where he was, by turns, a promoter and a would-be gossip columnist who once asked Arthur Miller about sex with Marilyn Monroe.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Saturday about competition at the Berlin Film Festival misstated the day awards were to be handed out. The ceremony took place last Saturday, not Sunday.

title: Raymond Kennedy, Novelist, Dies at 73
description: Raymond Kennedy, a writer known for his dark, absurdist novels set largely in his native New England, died on Monday in Brooklyn. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Memo to the EcoMoms: Really Go Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Rebuild Penn Station Area May Be Close to Failure
description: The sweeping $14 billion proposal to transform Pennsylvania Station and the district around it is in danger of collapse because of the softening economy, shortfalls in government financing, political inertia and daunting logistical problems, government officials and real estate executives involved in the project said this week.

title: With Oscar Show Salvaged, a Planned Film Museum Is Back in Play
description: LOS ANGELES  Until a settlement was reached two weeks ago, officials at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences were worrying that a bitter Hollywood strike might take the polish off more than Oscar night. They were concerned that it would force them to shelve an institutional transition that had suddenly become tangled in a mess of writers, ratings and real estate.

title: Israel Rejects Arab League Criticism on Palestinian Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli officials on Friday rejected Arab complaints that they were not committed to a two-state solution for Israel and the Palestinians and said Prime Minister Ehud Olmert had responded positively to the Arab League initiative as a basis for negotiations.

title: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Extends Cease-Fire by His Militia
description: BAGHDAD  The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr ordered his Mahdi Army militia on Friday to extend its cease-fire for six more months, bolstering hopes that a recent trend toward sharply lower Iraqi civilian and American military deaths in Baghdad would continue.

title: The Magnificent Jet Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Smith Wins a Libel Suit
description: Will Smith has received an apology and damages from a news agency after it falsely accused him of saying Hitler was a good person, the BBC reported. World Entertainment News Network published the article Smith: Hitler Was A Good Person in December, after which Mr. Smith sued for libel in a London court. The defendant accepts that the allegations concerning the claimant were misleading and published in error, the agencys solicitor said.

title: Photograph Could Put Clemens at 1998 Party
description: One day before Roger Clemens testified to a Congressional committee, a man told Clemenss lawyer that he had a photograph placing Clemens at a party held by Jos Canseco, according to lawyers for Clemens and Brian McNamee, his former personal trainer.

title: The Double Standard in Crisis Resolution
description: As the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by almost a third last month while the White House and Congress scrambled to concoct a $150 billion-plus fiscal stimulus package to loosen up the credit crunch, economic policy makers in developing countries couldnt help but raise an eyebrow.

title: Unfair Fixes for the Medicare Drug Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about campaign spending by Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama misstated, in some copies, the amount of money Mrs. Clinton had at the end of January. For the nominating contests, she had $8.9 million, not $10 million. For the general election, she has $20.3 million set aside, not $19 million.

title: Hollywood Gets Ready for Hoopla as Usual
description: LOS ANGELES  The calendar year doesnt get much traction in many parts of Los Angeles, where the Carpetbagger has been since Wednesday, trolling for tidbits to feed his blog about all things Oscar. The Academy Awards are New Years Eve and New Years Day rolled into one, a day of reckoning when accounts are tallied, blessings are counted and resolutions are forged anew.

title: Waterboarding Focus of Inquiry by Justice Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department revealed Friday that its internal ethics office was investigating the departments legal approval for waterboarding of Qaeda suspects by the Central Intelligence Agency and was likely to make public an unclassified version of its report.

title: Turkish Troops Enter Iraq in Pursuit of Kurdish Militants
description: BAGHDAD  Turkeys military said Friday that it had sent troops into northern Iraq on Thursday night, in what Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey called a limited operation to weaken Kurdish militants there.

title: Defending Champion Holds On to Lead
description: SOLVANG, Calif.  On paper, Levi Leipheimer looked to be facing one of his toughest days ever on the bike Friday at the fifth stage of the Tour of California.

title: For Engineer, a Cloud of Litigation After 9/11
description: To hear Ramon Gilsanz speak  voice calm and measured, even on a day when travel plans are tied in a knot by a snowstorm  you would never guess that he is being sued by thousands of people. And that does not count the man who is suing him on behalf of everyone in the United States.

title: All Those Foul Words Are Tennessee Williamss
description: Was Big Daddy always such a potty mouth?

title: Gates Calls Australia Alliance Strong
description: CANBERRA, Australia  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and top Australian officials insisted Saturday that the security alliance between the United States and Australia had not frayed despite Australias recent pledge to remove all combat forces from Iraq.

title: Cardozo Wins Girls Team Title
description: Dalilah Muhammad led Cardozo High School of Queens to the girls team title with 78 points in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor championships at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Muhammad won the high jump, finished second in the 55-meter hurdles and was third leg on Cardozos 4x800 winning relay (9:27.11). Midwood of Brooklyn captured the boys team crown with 51 points. Donald Williams paced Midwood with a victory in the 55-meter dash and ran second on Midwoods winning 4x400 relay (3:28.60). Nadonna Rodrigues of Brooklyns Boys & Girls, who recently posted the fastest 400-meter time in the country at 52.83 seconds, took the 300 in 38.39 seconds and anchored her schools winning 4x400 foursome (3:56.83).

title: Liechtenstein Looks to Move Beyond Tax Feud
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein  Do not mention the war  the tax war with Germany, that is.

title: Clear Channel and Balky Suitor Talk
description: Clear Channel Communications is in negotiations with Providence Equity Partners to strike a new agreement for its television unit, people briefed on the situation said Friday.

title: Powerful Union May Be Hedging Its Bets in Albany
description: ALBANY  No group has been more loyal or financially helpful to state Republicans than the powerful hospital workers union, 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East.

title: Move Over, Oil, Theres Money in Texas Wind
description: SWEETWATER, Tex.  The wind turbines that recently went up on Louis Brookss ranch are twice as high as the Statue of Liberty, with blades that span as wide as the wingspan of a jumbo jet. More important from his point of view, he is paid $500 a month apiece to permit 78 of them on his land, with 76 more on the way.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards on Sunday, misidentified the American Express executive who discussed his companys sponsorship of the broadcast. He is Diego Scotti, not Aldo Papone.

title: Ruling to Come on Art Collection
description: A county judge in Nashville is to issue a ruling within 30 days on whether Fisk University can keep a 101-piece art collection that includes Radiator Building  Night, New York (1927), below, given to it by the artist Georgia OKeeffe, The Associated Press reported. In a three-day trial that ended on Thursday, lawyers for the Georgia OKeeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., argued that Fisk lost the right to the prized collection and violated the terms of the 1949 gift when it took the works off display and tried to sell some. Fisk countered that it had never tried to sell the whole collection and that it now had the money to display the works according to the artists wishes. Seeking to shore up its finances, Fisk agreed in principle last fall to sell a 50 percent stake in the collection to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., for $30 million. But on Feb. 8 Ellen Hobbs Lyle, a Davidson County Chancery Court judge, struck down that proposal, saying it went against the donors wishes. Now the judge will rule on whether Fisk has forfeited its right to the art and whether it should go to the OKeeffe Museum, which represents the artists estate.

title: Judge Hints He May Reject 9/11 Families Plea to Sift Fresh Kills for Remains
description: At an inconclusive yet uncomfortably emotional hearing on Friday, a federal judge strongly suggested that he would turn down the request of several families of people who died at the World Trade Center to sift through a million tons of debris at the Fresh Kills landfill in a search for human remains left from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: 2 Plans and Many Questions on the Uninsured
description: ATLANTA  Brandy Coons is what health economists call a free rider.

title: Viewpoints Vary on Videotape Scandal
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Three N.F.L. coaches whose teams might have been targets of the illicit videotaping by the Patriots each view the controversy differently, highlighting the conflicting emotions that it has created within the leagues coaching fraternity.

title: Boys Killing, Labeled a Hate Crime, Stuns a Town
description: OXNARD, Calif.  Hundreds of mourners gathered at a church here on Friday to remember an eighth-grade boy who was shot to death inside a junior high school computer lab by a fellow student in what prosecutors are calling a hate crime.

title: Landmark Massachusetts Building Where Wharton Wrote Faces Foreclosure
description: The Mount, Edith Whartons estate in Lenox, Mass., is in danger of being put in foreclosure, says Stephanie Copeland, president of Edith Wharton Restoration, the organization that owns and maintains this stately residence and its surrounding gardens.

title: Morocco: Prison for Facebook Prince
description: Fouad Mourtada, a 26-year-old engineer, was sentenced by a Casablanca court to three years in prison for creating a fake profile of the kings brother on Facebook, the Internet social networking site, the official news agency MAP reported. He was accused of villainous practices and of stealing the identity of the crown prince, Moulay Rachid. The case has ignited the Moroccan blogosphere, which used it as a prime example of deteriorating freedom of expression in the North African kingdom. Hundreds of prank profiles exist on Facebook, for everyone from President Bush to Osama bin Laden. At least four fake Moulay Rachid Facebook pages have now been set up, apparently from the safety of overseas. The defense said it would appeal the sentence, MAP reported. MAP announced at the time of Mr. Mourtadas arrest that no Moroccan royals maintained Web sites or blogs.

title: Fraud Case Tied to Enron Ends in Prison for 3 Men
description: HOUSTON  Three former British bankers were sentenced on Friday to 37 months each in prison for their role in a fraud related to Enron.

title: A Fathers Law
description: He saw the dim image of the traffic cop make a right-face turn and fling out a white-gloved arm, signaling that the flow of cars from the east should stop and that those toward the south now had the right of way, and at the same instant he heard the cop's shrill whistle: Wrrrriiiiiieee ...

title: A Visit That Crosses Two Centuries and an Ocean
description: Given talent and the right connections, opera composers have at least an outside chance of a premiere performance by a reputable opera company. Revivals are the problem. The odds against them are long, but Conrad Susas Dangerous Liaisons has done better than most of its contemporaries.

title: New CUNY Center to Focus on the Art of the Biography
description: Hoping to elevate the art and scholarship of biography, the Graduate Center of the City University of New York is setting up a center where its practitioners can meet, trade ideas and work.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Arizona Congressman
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, was indicted this week by a federal grand jury on 35 counts of corruption, including fraud, money laundering, extortion and other crimes, federal prosecutors said Friday.

title: 'Idol' Beats Competition
description: The results edition of American Idol lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday while giving a considerable boost to that networks other singing competition, Dont Forget the Lyrics. According to Nielsens estimates, 23.2 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for American Idol, the nights top-rated show. At 9, Dont Forget the Lyrics drew 12.5 million viewers, more than 5 million above its average this season. Among adults 18 to 49, this karaoke-themed game show ranked third for the night, trailing only American Idol and ABCs Lost, which led at 9 with 13.5 million viewers. ABC finished second for the night in the 18-to-49 set but third in total viewers behind both Fox and CBS, whose reruns of CSI at 9 (11.9 million) and Without a Trace at 10 (12.1 million) buoyed the network after a solid showing for Big Brother at 8 (12.5 million). NBC was a distant fourth over all, as both The Celebrity Apprentice at 9 (8 million) and Lipstick Jungle at 10 (5.8 million) struggled in their respective time slots.

title: The Lost Treasure of Machu Picchu
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Debate Close Wasnt a Farewell, Clinton Says
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  With the mood of her campaign shadowed by the death of a police officer escorting her motorcade Friday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton vowed to carry on despite remarks in a debate Thursday night that some people took as a valedictory to her long effort to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: S.M.U. Makes It Official: Bush Library Is Coming
description: DALLAS  A center devoted to the life, works, papers and policies of President George W. Bush will be built at Southern Methodist University, officials announced Friday, despite faculty members lingering concerns and opposition from some Methodists.

title: Being Fast Is Only the Start to Racing Success
description: BOSTON  Many people work out at home. Some run on treadmills. Some stretch or do yoga. Carmelita Jeter leans.

title: F.D.A.s Rule on Off-Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: Coughlins Success Changes Opinions
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Tom Coughlin is suddenly brilliant and wildly popular. On Friday, he walked through the wide concourse of the convention center that serves as the nexus of the N.F.L. scouting combine. Fans reached for autographs and peers sought a handshake. Coughlin seemed to be in no hurry to go wherever it is that he goes from here.

title: No Trades for Knicks, but Something to Cheer
description: The fast-moving gears on the N.B.A.s trading season grinded to a halt Thursday, after two-thirds of the league made attempts to improve their prospects with moves large and small. The Knicks were shut out of the proceedings, leaving Coach Isiah Thomas with nothing to sell Friday but well-worn rhetoric.

title: A Choreographers Life, Depicted in, Well ...
description: Dancers scattered throughout St. Marks Church read books in a murmured cacophony in Juliette Mapps new Anna, Ikea and I on Thursday night. This 90-minute piece is in a way a book itself: a sweet-tempered, witty and eloquent autobiography written by a wryly self-deprecatory dancer, choreographer and teacher about her years in dance.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about the Art Show fair, at the Park Avenue Armory, contained an outdated reference to the Armory Show, an annual fair that opens on March 27 this year. It is held solely at Pier 94  not at two piers, as was the case from 2001 to 2006.

title: Castro, Nearly Retired, Keeps Busy With a Few Pokes at U.S.
description: HAVANA  If anyone thought Fidel Castro was going to slip into quiet retirement, he dispelled that notion on Friday when he published a broadside against American politicians who have called for democracy in Cuba.

title: Hillary on the High Road?
description: A referee would stop the fight. Hillary Clinton is exhausted, and her supporters are becoming increasingly demoralized. The candidate who tried to present herself as inevitable has been out-maneuvered nearly every step of the way by a prodigy with a warm and brilliant smile who still seems as energetic as an athlete doing calisthenics before a big game.

title: Trapped in the Past
description: Kosovos declaration of independence was never going to be easy. Still, it is alarming to see the Serbian government so unwilling to peacefully channel its citizens anger and disappointment. Its failure to control rampaging crowds that set fire Thursday to part of the United States Embassy compound in Belgrade  and attacked several other embassies  is a shocking and unacceptable abdication of responsibility.

title: Suspect Found Fit to Stand Trial in Therapists Killing
description: A man with a history of schizophrenia who was charged with killing an Upper East Side therapist with a meat cleaver and knives has been found mentally competent to stand trial.

title: An Arsenal Against Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Orin Lehman, 88, Parks Steward, Dies
description: Orin Lehman, who turned to public service rather than a career in his familys investment company and eventually became New York States longest-serving commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,960 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: Stimulus Plan Aids Buyers of High-Priced Homes
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Elizabeth and Ben Kilgore are back in the real estate market. All it took was a little-publicized section of the economic stimulus package President Bush signed into law last week that lowered the borrowing cost of buying a more expensive home.

title: Bond Insurer Plans a Split to Protect Ratings
description: Ambac Financial Group, the embattled bond insurance company, plans to split itself in two in a bid to safeguard its top credit ratings and avert losses on securities that it guarantees for big banks.

title: Health Coverage Often Stops at the Campus Gate
description: PARENTS often do not think twice about health coverage when their children head to college, but it might be to their advantage to take a second look before doing a double-take when they see their bills.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Feb. 15 about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens paraphrased incorrectly from a transcript of a conversation between Mr. McNamee and investigators for Mr. Clemens on the day before the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball was released. Mr. McNamee said he told Jim Murray, a New York-based representative for Mr. Clemenss agent, that steroids had come from the former Mets bat boy Kirk Radomski. He did not say he had purchased steroids and growth hormone from Mr. Radomski.

title: Ahhh, the Seductive Fragrance of Molecules Under Patent
description: Its scent is reminiscent of a mixture of a just-picked apple and a rose in its prime. But to the Takasago International Corporation, which manufactures this synthetic material, it smells even sweeter.

title: No Longer in Race, Richardson Is a Man Pursued
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  Lots of people are calling Gov. Bill Richardson these days, just to check in.

title: Ominous Signs Remain in City Run by Iraqis
description: BASRA, Iraq  This southern port city has been, in effect, on its own since September, when British forces here moved to the outskirts, yielding authority to local leaders. British and American officials say Basras experiment in self-rule could serve as a model for Iraqs future, but if so  many locals and outside advisers say  that future remains dark.

title: And Now, Back to the Democrats ...
description: To the Editor:

title: A Global Journey, Relying on Kindness and a Donkey
description: TINACO, Venezuela

title: Serbia Is Warned by Europe to Deter Embassy Attacks
description: BRUSSELS  European diplomats demanded Friday that Serbia provide better protection for Western embassies, warning that further talks on ties between Belgrade and the European Union could not take place unless violence subsided.

title: Desegregation Order Lifted From a School in Brooklyn
description: A federal judge on Friday lifted a 1974 desegregation order for a Brooklyn middle school, effectively eliminating racial quotas that had been in place at Mark Twain Intermediate School for more than three decades.

title: Big Raise for Prez After Rare Arbitration
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Oliver Prez had barely entered the Mets clubhouse Friday morning when Joe Smith asked the question.

title: Suburbias March to Oblivion
description: THE mortgage crisis has put for sale signs in front of houses across the country  including so-called McMansions  the large, expensive, often tasteless homes that have taken up so much suburban space over the last couple of decades.

title: In Aftermath of Article, McCain Gathers Donations
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Senator John McCain declared the battle over on Friday morning, but by then his lieutenants believed he had already won the war.

title: Japan: Navy Chief Fired
description: Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda ordered a review of the Defense Ministrys structure amid mounting criticism of its handling of a collision between its most advanced naval destroyer and a small fishing boat. Shigeru Ishiba, the defense minister, also fired the head of the Maritime Self-Defense Force, which took 90 minutes to inform Mr. Ishiba of the accident on Tuesday morning. The Atago, a new destroyer equipped with the advanced Aegis system, rammed into the two-man fishing boat near Tokyo Bay even though it had spotted the small vessel 12 minutes before the collision. The fishermen have yet to be found.

title: A Black Boxer Whose Opponents Included Segregation
description: Maya Angelou still retains the girlish ecstasy she felt as a 9-year-old in Stamps, Ark., listening to her grandmothers radio as Joe Louis defeated James J. Braddock to win the heavyweight championship in 1937.

title: China, in New Role, Presses Sudan on Darfur
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Amid the international outrage over the bloodshed in Darfur, frustration has increasingly turned toward China, Sudans biggest trading partner and international protector, culminating in Steven Spielbergs decision last week to withdraw as artistic adviser to the Beijing Olympics.

title: Fantasy Football Draft 08, Part II
description: (Mark St. Amant is the author of Committed: Confessions of a Fantasy Football Junkie and Just Kick It: Tales of an Underdog, Over-Age, Out-of-Place Semi-Pro Football Player.)

title: Respond to Todays Column: A Bad Year to Be a Mallard
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Feb. 23 column.

title: Four Seasons, One Silly
description: The bar at the Four Seasons hotel in Beverly Hills is a good place to take a seat in the peanut gallery. In the early evening, Harvey Weinstein motored through, Leslee Dart and Allan Mayer, the reps to the stars, were sharing a drink. Mr. Mayer said that the Oscar weekends quieter affect had less to do with some mutual agreement to keep a lid on than a kind of opportunity.

title: Fetal Monitor
description: Diablo Cody has been motoring through the season without much of a hitch, but Saturday was tough.

title: A Duet of Nerves
description: Glen Hansard, front man of The Frames and a best song nominee for Falling Slowly from Once, thought for a quick second when the Bagger asked whether he was more intimidated by the prospect of performing for the Oscar hordes or sitting in his seat while the best song winner is announced.

title: A Tiny Bit of Perspective
description: Industry types have taken a few gentle whacks at the diminutive 20-year-old, Ellen Page, suggesting that the star of Juno and a best actress nominee has not paid respect to all the glamour and gravitas of the Oscar season as she should. Page is not unaware of the blandishments of the process, she just prefers to treat it as a buffet table, taking some of it and leaving the rest, rather than just diving in. The Bagger interviewed her at the beginning of the season and now at its end, and she has not lost any of her gee-whiz or her innate skepticism of the trappings of stardom.

title: The White Hot Center and the Hole in the Middle of the Donut
description: Oscar weekend, for a blogger who has been mostly typing in his basement, is disconcerting in that suddenly this world he has been flicking at from a distance comes to life before his very eyes.

title: Pick. Your. Poison.
description: The Baggers picks for the podium tomorrow. All caveats apply  lets just say that Anton Chigurh is not the only one who flipped a coin on the way to the Oscars. (For more details on the nominees and the picks, go here.) Now, what say you?

title: Dude, Guess What I Just Heard
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama had another debate last night. Clinton accused Obama of plagiarism. Obama denied that what he did was plagiarism. I dont want to comment on that, but you have to admit that it would be great to one day have a president who can pronounce words like plagiarism.

title: Look! The Piata Is Singing!
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Last night, Senator Hillary Clinton once again accused Barack Obama of plagiarizing a speech from another politician. Hillary said, Plagiarizing is the second worst kind of cheating.

title: El Ted Sings
description: Perhaps not since the Taco Bell chihuahua have we seen such an homage to Mexican culture. Senator Kennedy at an Obama rally in Laredo, Texas (also see the Conan OBrien monologue below):

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: In Beijing, Attention Shifts to Pyongyang
description: The morning of the New York Philharmonics debut at the Egg, otherwise known as the National Center for the Performing Arts, in Beijing on Saturday yielded a news conference with orchestra officials and Lorin Maazel, the music director. The main entranceway to the new center, a vast domed structure (hence the Egg) surrounded by a moat, passes under the moat water, which reflects down on a red carpet. Large posters of Mr. Maazel lined each side of the carpet.

title: Economics in movies
description: A cute entry on the WSJ economics blog. But somehow they missed The Internecine Project, with James Coburn as a suave, murderous chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers who gets all his enemies to kill each other, or something like that.

title: Paris, Saturday
description: I arrived in Paris from Milan last evening, on a flight with perhaps 20 models, including Lily D and Coco Rocha, and nearly half of them carried stuffed animals in their arms. Its a strange sight to be standing at baggage claim watching ordinary travelers stare at giraffes with teddy bears and blue stuffed dogs, and I was surprised how many pieces of luggage a model could have, considering she spends her day wearing other peoples clothes. Girls are girls, I guess.

title: Snow Swoops In
description: Planes and Buses Go Way Off Schedule

title: Hockey Fan Buys Bauer From Nike
description: Ian Austen, who wrote in the Times business section earlier this month about Nikes de-Canadianization of Bauer as part of its failed effort to break into hockey, reported in yesterdays paper about the $200 million purchase of the Bauer division by a native Montrealer. The hockey and inline-skating businesses being what they are these days, that figure is about half what Nike paid for Bauer in 1994.

title: The Early Word: Hard Times for Hillary Clinton
description: Friday was a rough day for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as she sought to dispel speculation that her closing debate remarks amounted to a concession amid the death of a police officer escorting her campaign  all while Senator Barack Obama was stumping around South Texas, one of her strongholds in the state.

title: The Hazards of Politically Correct Research
description: The debate on female initiation rites continues. An earlier post by World Health Organization researchers discussed the hazards of the practice they call FGM (female genital mutiliation). Heres a response from two Swedish scholars who have studied the topic over the past 10 years, Sara Johnsdotter, a senior lecturer in medical anthropology at Malm University, and Birgitta Essen, a senior lecturer in international maternal health and associate professor in obstetrics and gynocology at Uppsala University:

title: The Moment, Interrupted
description: Many thought that Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons answer to a debate question about a moment that tested her sounded like a concession. So many, in fact, that she had to formally deny it on Friday. And now her campaign wants to use that moment, or a selected 60 seconds of it, in a new campaign spot.

title: Tidbits From Port St. Lucie
description: After spending the morning posing with assorted plastic vegetables, pots and pans for their second annual Gourmets cookbook, the Mets moved on to more important things. You know, like Jose Reyess flitting around the clubhouse and morphing into Mike Wallace, interviewing Pedro Martinez for a Spanish-language TV station. Yes, its business as usual in the clubhouse, which always tends to be a little more raucous earlier in camp for the simple reason that there are about twice as many people here now.

title: A Police Chase From Newark to Brooklyn
description: A man who was stopped by the police in Newark on Friday for driving a stolen car struggled with an officer, whose gun fell into the car, the police said. The man drove off, and was hit in the hand when another officer fired at him. The man then drove east and made it to Brooklyn before the car smashed into another vehicle at Smith and Pacific Streets, where the driver was arrested, the police said.

title: Will Clooney Take a Walk?
description: Tom ONeil tiptoes out on a limb  and says the geezer demo might, could, may, push George Clooney past Daniel Day-Lewis in best actor. Cool call, a swing for the fences.

title: Germanys Cabaret Culture
description: Dinner at the Palazzo. Photos by Joyce Hor-Chung Lau

title: Clinton Slams Obama Tactics
description: CINCINNATI  Accusing the Obama campaign of using tactics that are right out of Karl Roves playbook, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton angrily denounced Senator Barack Obama on Saturday for sending fliers to Ohio voters that she called misleading and false.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Feb. 23:

title: New Lawsuit Against Chess Federation
description: Gordon Roy Parker has filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania accusing several current and former chess officials of conspiring to destroy the United States Chess Federation to profit from its demise.

title: Your Examples of Obama and Clinton Courage
description: Ive had a ton of indignant emails about last Sundays column about John McCain, in which I said I disagreed with his positions but admired his willingness to disagree so often with the voters whose support he needed. I argued that he pandered when necessary  witness his recent tack to the right  but with evident discomfort and incompetence, and that it wasnt instinctive as with many candidates. Most of the criticism was from people who think its wrong to give McCain any credit, given his recent moves to the right.

title: Election Prediction Contest
description: Were going to close entries to my election prediction contest in the next couple of days. So if you want to enter, and win eternal glory, then hurry up

title: Your Comments on my Obama Roots Column
description: My Sunday column is about Barack Obamas ancestral village of Kogelo, Kenya, where I met his grandmother  actually its his step-grandma, but shes the one who raised his Dad and whom he calls his grandmother. Post your comments about the column and the video here.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Putting the Egg to the Test
description: Slide Show: Performing at The Egg

title: Devils Snatch Mediocrity From the Jaws of Disaster
description: The Devils beat the Islanders, 4-2, on Saturday afternoon, concluding their five-week-long homestand in which they played 15 out of 18 games at the Prudential Center. Going into the homestand, it seemed as if New Jersey would rack up the points and zoom to the top of the East  but thats not what happened.

title: Koufax Visits and Pedro Talks
description: It isnt every day  or ever, really  that Sandy Koufax decides to speak with reporters but that day came today (you can read all about him online later tonight) Koufax, a childhood friend of Fred Wilpon, usually drops by spring training to speak with a left-hander  Tom Glavine or Al Leiter, in the past  and he did so today at the request of Billy Wagner, who is learning to throw a curveball.
