description: THE subtitle at Finalmente Trattoria, one of Westports newer restaurants, is regional Italian cuisine. This proves apt, for the menu has dishes that range all over the map of Italy, including a wild king salmon entree from Elba of all places.

title: Blood and Oil!
description: The best moments in Paul Thomas Andersons film There Will Be Blood and in Oil!, the 1927 novel by Upton Sinclair on which it is loosely based, are identical. They depict the fiery immolation of an oil rig. There was a tower of flame, Sinclair writes, and the most amazing spectacle  the burning oil would hit the ground, and bounce up, and explode, and leap again and fall again, and great red masses of flame would unfold, and burst, and yield black masses of smoke, and these in turn red. Mountains of smoke rose to the sky, and mountains of flame came seething down to the earth; every jet that struck the ground turned into a volcano, and rose again, higher than before; the whole mass, boiling and bursting, became a river of fire, a lava flood that went streaming down the valley, turning everything it touched into flame, then swallowing it up and hiding the flames in a cloud of smoke.

title: Texas Women, With a Strong Legacy, Size Up the Democratic Field
description: HOUSTON  She served as first lady through her husbands two terms, suffered the indignities of his impeachment and then made history running for his office on her own.

title: Traditional Visit With an Untraditional Twist
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It happens every spring, or close to it. The slender, silver-haired maestro drives from his home in Vero Beach, spends a few hours reconnecting with old friends and pupils, then ducks out a side door or back exit. His departure is as stealthy as his arrival, leaving others to reflect on their audience with one of the greatest left-handed pitchers ever.

title: He Was Nouveau When It Was New
description: THESE days, the name Robbe-Grillet doesnt ring many bells. A new chateau perhaps, whose grand cru goes well with meat? A deputy minister in Sarkozys government? An up-and-coming couturier?

title: Dangerous Laughter
description: Cat 'n' mouse

title: He Shoots! He Scores! He Makes Movies!
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: The Flapper Doesnt Change Her Spots
description: As a Baby Star of 1927, Sally Phipps seemed destined for silent film immortality. The organization that bestowed the award  the Western Association of Motion Picture Advertisers, or Wampas  had a genius for spotting talent. Joan Crawford and Clara Bow had been Baby Stars, and in 1927, the 16-year-old Phipps shared the accolade with future fan-dance sensation Sally Rand.

title: Patient Is a Virtue
description: 1. Symptoms

title: Honored Ancestors on the Skyline Family Tree
description: IT is quite possible that the enthusiasts who know the most about the Nissan GT-R are those still a few years away from getting their driving licenses. Such is the downside of a car best known as a video game icon. Even so, the GT-Rs exterior styling is not so extreme that drivers old enough to vote would reject it as overtly adolescent.

title: Deep-Fried Mars Bars
description: These restaurants on Greenwich Avenue are eclectic and cozy, like the surrounding neighborhood.

title: Kosovo and the States Responsibility to Protect
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Exclusive Enclaves, Subject to Change
description: IN the case of tiny Agate Court in Brooklyn, perhaps the sincerest form of flattery is not imitation, but annexation. The little cul-de-sac of 18 row houses off chaotic Atlantic Avenue in southern Bedford-Stuyvesant was built in the late 1880s along with the flanking Alice Court, and the two have slumbered for more than a century with little change.

title: Charlize Angel
description: In your new film, Sleepwalking, you not only star but you also produce. Was that difficult?People forget that I produced Monster [the 2003 film for which Theron won the Oscar for her portrayal of the prostitute and gay serial killer Aileen Wuornos]. And, before that, we worked on Sweet Home Alabama for two years, which ended up starring Reese Witherspoon. I produce films that I feel deserve the light of day. Monster was a great learning experience for a producer. Initially, having my name attached to the project helped with getting the financing. People are more likely to say yes to tricky material when a star is interested. But then, with Monster, theyd say, Itll be a hot lesbian movie, right? That was one of the selling points until they figured out what we were actually doing.

title: Starship Kimchi: A Bold Taste Goes Where It Has Never Gone Before
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After South Korea began sending soldiers to fight beside American forces in Vietnam, President Park Chung-hee made an unusual plea. He wrote to President Lyndon Johnson to say that his troops were miserable, desperate for kimchi, the fermented cabbage dish that Koreans savor with almost every meal.

title: Early Bloomers
description: There were a few blousy moments during the spring collections when you could be forgiven for thinking you were attending an 1850s suffragist rally or a gym class at Vassar in the 1920s. Bloomers  sometimes diaperish, usually subversive and most womens idea of fashion hell  produced smirks and double-takes in New York and Europe. Gaultiers iteration had a Pirates of Penzance picturesqueness. In an unusually insane show, Comme des Garons advanced the possibility of bloomers that were not just frilly but also falling apart. Pradas take, short-short and sewn in shiny fabrics, was straight from the stroller. Betsey Johnson, well, you can guess. While todays bloomers can be traced in a straight line to the pumpkin breeches that Renaissance men wore at the top of their hose, they are but fuzzy cousins to the garment favored by the early womens libber who lent them her name, Amelia Bloomer. She rebelled against the petticoats and floor-grazing skirts of the mid-19th century in favor of knee-skimming designs layered over ballooning trousers gathered at the ankles. The bifurcated look had something weirdly haremlike about it and, however liberating, was light only in relation to what had come before. Bloomer was ridiculed but of course vindicated with the hindsight of history. Designers have fallen in and out of love with bloomers at least since 1976. Bonnie Cashin, the sportswear pioneer, celebrated the bicentennial with a collection of Amelias. Bonnie loved bloomers because they could be completely customized by the wearer, says Stephanie Lake of the Bonnie Cashin Foundation. Is there any designer who hasnt dabbled in bloomers? You can wear out your search engine trying to find one. Saint Laurents fling was in 1987. Vivienne Westwood cast her vote in velvet in 1998. Armani has shown bloomers off and on for several years. Spinning positive, one buyer called them a skirt replacement. That or gym clothes.[?][?][?]CHRISTOPHER PETKANAS

title: Driven to Save a Vista From LIPA Lines
description: Water Mill

title: Room for Eating, and Improvement
description: AFTER emigrating from Portugal in 1986, Carlos Lopes worked in construction, cooked in a succession of middling restaurants around northern New Jersey, even ran a lunch cart in downtown Newark. But all the while, he must have been thinking big. How else to explain his five-month-old restaurant, Solar do Minho in Roselle Park?

title: Cascya Charlot and Thomas Ludwig
description: Dr. Cascya Charlot and Thomas Robert Ludwig were married on Saturday at the St. Peter Great House and Botanical Gardens, a former plantation on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. William L. Arnet, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Correction: The Other Iran
description: An article on Feb. 10 about an Americans trip to Esfahan, the old Persian capital of Iran, mistranslated a word the writer used when he sought directions by asking Madrasa kojast? Madrasa means school in Farsi; the writer did not ask, Where is the religious school?

title: Tag Sale
description: Krink

title: 1876: New Jersey Blanc Mange
description: People in the 19th century had a more robust appetite for food with unusual textures. Pickled oysters were a common snack, and you could find the occasional brain fritter and kidney omelet. But nothing seems to have got cooks more excited than a chance to entomb a favorite food in jelly. Into a preserve went perfectly innocent ham, pineapple, calfs foot, sole, even a chicken or two. And then there was milk. Sweetened with sugar, lemon, almond, cinnamon and sometimes even chocolate, milk was ideal for pouring into molds and serving for dessert as a beloved dish called blancmange, which means white food. Tapped out of its form, blancmange is gorgeous and subdued, like a piece of carved ivory.

title: I Have Just the Client for You
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Pounding the Pavement to Buy a Car
description: Some products lend themselves to online sales  books, computers and toys come to mind. But cars are a tougher sell. Most consumers still head to the lot to seal the deal.

title: Correction: Hemingway, Your Letter Has Arrived
description: An article on Feb. 10 about a letter that Ernest Hemingway sent to The New York Times about writing his play The Fifth Column while covering the Spanish Civil War misidentified the person whose reference to an attack on Madrid became the plays title. It was General Emilio Mola  not Francisco Franco  who said that he had four columns advancing on Madrid and a fifth column of loyalists inside the city ready to attack from the rear.

title: Paris Passes Milestone as Oklahoma Prevails
description: NORMAN, Okla.  Fans began lining up outside the arena hours before Saturdays tipoff between the highly ranked in-state college basketball teams. Once inside, the fans seemed to flip the calendar with their collective breath, creating an atmosphere more like March Madness.

title: Woods Continues His March to the Final
description: MARANA, Ariz.  Tiger Woods started his day at 3:45 a.m. Saturday, an hour ahead of his alarm clock, four hours ahead of his tee time and about 12 hours before he mowed down his second opponent of the day in the Accenture Match Play Championship.

title: Seeking to Give Power to the People, at Least Symbolically
description: PAUL SOKOLOFF, a 51-year-old bartender with a small earring and a smokers rusty chuckle, is a blunt-spoken man, not the sort one expects to talk like a civics textbook. But that is how he sounded a few days ago when he described the vote he had cast in his local schoolhouse on the day of the New York primary.

title: Phelps Summons His Inner Early Riser
description: Before Michael Phelps even knew there was such a concept as early person/late person, he was the embodiment of a night owl.

title: In City Waters, Beds (and a Job) for Oysters
description: Hendrix Creek, flowing for just over a mile in Brooklyn through East New York, passes under the Belt Parkway and between two dormant landfills before it empties into Jamaica Bay. The creek, once fed by a natural stream, now starts at the output pipe of a wastewater treatment plant.

title: Reese Enjoys the Fruits of His Role in Scouting
description: INDIANAPOLIS  At least one of the text messages that buzzed Jerry Reeses phone as he stood atop the champions podium after the Super Bowl came from a peer. The Giants surprising playoff run and their 17-14 victory over the Patriots was fueled, in large part, by an infusion of young players.

title: Ethanol by the Numbers
description: Even those who regard ethanol as the holy grail of energy policy concede that there is a right way and a wrong way to produce it. Done right, ethanol could help wean the country from its dependence on foreign oil while reducing the emissions that contribute to climate change. Done wrong, ethanol could wreak havoc on the environment while increasing greenhouse gases.

title: Rachel Butler, David Campbell
description: Rachel Butler, a daughter of Deanna L. Butler and Mark E. Butler of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to David John Thomas Campbell, a son of Kim L. Campbell and Stewart T. Campbell of Calgary, Alberta. Frank W. Miller Sr., an elder serving in the Manhattan New York Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, performed the ceremony.

title: On the Mets Bench, More Bats Than Seats
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  After missing the 2003 season recovering from Achilles tendon surgery, Olmedo Senz chose to resume his career with the Dodgers for one simple reason.

title: Choosing Which War to Fight
description: WASHINGTON

title: No. 1 No More: Memphis Falls to Tennessee
description: MEMPHIS  In the week leading up to No. 2 Tennessees game at No. 1 Memphis, Volunteers Coach Bruce Pearl did everything he could to play down the matchup. He insisted that Tennessees coming games with Vanderbilt and Kentucky were more important and said that the Volunteers could still earn a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament if they lost.

title: Radical, Chic
description: Outrageous!, for example, is a work of talent, originality and vision. It smells deeply artificial in the best sense, intentionally bearing the same relationship to the natural world that Tang does to orange juice. Outrageous! is not a synthetic version of nature but a free-standing creation that refers to the natural world ironically and revels in its own artifice. It is, in fact, the smell of Tang sprinkled on a plate of polyurethane on which sit grapes, apples and pears made of polyvinyl chloride. The scent of kerosene ingeniously adds alarm to the soft, dystopian glow. Frowning, I once said to Sophia Grojsman, who created it for Barneys New York Co-Op, It makes me think of a Mondrian: rigid, unnatural rectangles of artificially bright colors. She put her hands on my shoulders and squeezed with delight.

title: Come Back, Little 50s, Even With the Clouds
description: THIS spring at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center a young, radiant and unmistakably American woman will proclaim proudly in song that she is as normal as blueberry pie. And when audiences listen to Kelli OHara deliver this assertion as Nellie Forbush in the musical South Pacific, they will most likely believe, at least for that moment, that all-American normalcy is a wonderful state of being.

title: He Said, He Said
description: Addiction is repetitious. The fact that alcoholics and drug abusers often tread the path of use, rehab, sobriety and relapse presents a challenge to authors of addiction memoirs, who must squeeze this dispiritingly cyclical behavior into a straight-ahead narrative or risk telling the same story over and over. Beautiful Boy is an addiction memoir once removed, depicting the collateral damage that a drug-abusing child inflicts, yet it underscores how the heartbreaking circle game of addiction can fetter a writers sense of what to include and, more important, when to stop.

title: Letters: The Other Iran
description: THE OTHER IRAN

title: Yes, Screw Caps on the North Fork
description: Screw caps have come to the North Fork. Using a bottling line installed in September, Paumanok has been putting screw caps on 2007 whites; the apparatus handles corks, too. The Premium Wine Group, a for-hire winery, hopes to install a screw cap bottler this year. Martha Clara wants to start using the caps, and Pellegrini is considering them.

title: Grandmasters, a 5-Year-Old And a Question of Eligibility
description: Is a team of three grandmasters and a young boy an amateur team?

title: Reader, He Married Her
description: This is a deeply strange book. In fact, it is, to the best of my knowledge, a nonesuch: a 400-plus-page first novel by a 49-year-old American male, dedicated to the highly dubious proposition that such a thing as perfect romantic love is possible in these doomy, gloomy, over-psychologized, terminally ironic, post-humanist, post-postmodern times. Part comedy of manners, part chick lit in male drag, James Collinss Beginners Greek is a great big sunny lemon chiffon pie of a novel, set, for good measure and our sociological titillation, among the WASP ruling classes, people who work at white-shoe investment firms and own villas in southwestern France and can instantly tell the difference between fine Bordeaux and plonk.

title: GT-R Waiting Game About to End
description: HARDLY a model year goes by without the debut of at least one new car that sets off a frenzied run on dealers showrooms. In the last decade, introductions for vehicles as disparate as the Volkswagen New Beetle, Chrysler PT Cruiser, Mini Cooper and Ford GT each resulted in months-long waiting lists, accompanied by gigabytes of Internet speculation.

title: A Capitalist Jolt for Charity
description: IN the summer of 2005, Miles Gilburne and Nina Zolt had long talks over dinner in their Washington home about what to do next. For more than six years, Mr. Gilburne, a former AOL executive, and his wife, Ms. Zolt, a former lawyer, had supported a philanthropy that used books and online tools to enhance skills of inner-city students.

title: New on the Job, Quick to Act
description: Bill Smith and Andy MacPhail made the most traumatic moves. Neal Huntington made virtually no moves at all. Is this any way to improve the team that has been the worst in the major leagues the past 15 years?

title: Recapturing the 60s, in DayGlo Colors
description: MORE than a year after the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago transformed the culture wars from metaphor to mayhem, Norman Mailer was still trying to make sense of what had happened.

title: Jamie Rosen and Russell Greenberg
description: Jamie Rosen, a daughter of Amy Rosen of Penn Valley, Pa., and Howard Rosen of Blue Bell, Pa., was married on Saturday evening to Russell Jon Greenberg, the son of Flora Greenberg of Manhasset, N.Y., and the late Kenneth Greenberg. Rabbi Gerald I. Wolpe officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

description: HAVANA

title: Problem Solving | Under Where?
description: [?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE AND COURTNEY A. WEINBLATT

description: To the Editor:

title: Students Help Track Black Squirrels
description: EVERY few weeks, two fifth-grade classes from Eugene Auer elementary school in Lake Grove take a field trip to the nearby Robert J. Henke Memorial Nature Preserve. Their mission: to find black squirrels.

title: Puerto Ricos Political Melodrama Plays On, With Its Governor in the Lead Role
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  The rumors wash up against the gray walls of La Fortaleza, the governors palace in this citys colonial quarter, with the regularity of the oceans waves. Every few weeks they seem to gather momentum, like a tidal surge, and threaten to overwhelm the place and its occupant, Gov. Anbal S. Acevedo Vil.

title: Stuck Inside of Memphis With the Oscar Blues Again
description: Memphis

title: A Wandering Kazakh, Before Borat
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan

title: The Big Commute, in Reverse
description: ON most days, Matthew Davis, a 28-year-old portfolio manager, can count on spending about two hours getting to work and another two hours getting home. Thats going against the tide of commuters going into New York City for work. Mr. Davis, who rented an apartment in Park Slope in Brooklyn when he landed a job in the securities industry in New York, found himself not on Wall Street, but in Ronkonkoma, working for a financial services management company.

title: The New Collectibles
description: FLORAL MAJORITY

title: Its the Mileage That Moves You
description: TESTED 2008 Ford Escape Hybrid

title: Vivacious and Versatile
description: White Moscato dAsti, a popular, fizzy sweet wine from Piedmont, has a little-known red sibling, Brachetto dAcqui.

title: Kusama Dot Com
description: We hope you will understand. With typically fervent Japanese politeness, Yayoi Kusamas staff warned me that the resurgent queen of the Japanese art world, now approaching 80, no longer permits herself to be photographed. But when she learned that the photographer in question was Nobuyoshi Araki, the celebrated master of nude bondage pictures, it turned out that Kusama was only too happy to oblige. And so, on a quiet Thursday afternoon, after an hour or so of failed efforts to interview Kusama, I waited with the artist and her staff around a conference table for Arakis arrival. Wearing a bright red wig, matching lipstick and her signature polka-dot motif  a red kimono-like dress adorned with circles of black and white felt  Kusama looked like a small grave clown, in the lull before a birthday party begins.

title: Baby-Talk Show
description: The early days of parenthood are filled with anxiety. Parents fret over whether their babies are eating enough, growing enough and sleeping enough. As the children get a little older, parents also worry if they are talking enough.

title: A Little Taste of France
description: The Little Grocery is a tiny, tucked-away cafe in Hoboken serving French-inspired food par excellence. Buttery brioche French toast, quiche and cassoulet are among the comforting dishes that the owner, Neamet Elsayed, prepares for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

title: Off The Dribble
description: On Your Face

title: Daring to Think Differently About Schizophrenia
description: NORTH WALES, Pa.  SCIENTISTS who develop drugs are familiar with disappointment  brilliant theories that dont pan out or promising compounds derailed by unexpected side effects. They are accustomed to small steps and wrong turns, to failure after failure  until, in a moment, with hard work, brainpower and a lot of luck, all those little failures turn into one big success.

title: Palm Springs, Calif.: Colony Palms Hotel
description: THE BASICS

title: Rising Above Racism
description: You may have heard of Charles Ethan Porter, but very few people can recall seeing one of his paintings. Mr. Porter was an African-American artist from Rockville, Conn., who, after the Civil War, created humble, poetic paintings  mostly of flowers, insects and fruit, along with occasional landscapes and portraits. He was a dedicated painter who attracted the patronage of Mark Twain and Frederic Edwin Church.

title: Upstate Race Transformed by Interest From Albany
description: FULTON, N.Y.  The chill in the air was biting, snarling across the snow-swept farming towns and old shuttered factories in the north country.

title: Klitschko Wins Fight Marked by Inaction
description: There were no jaw-breaking Mike Tyson shots. There was no Muhammad Ali tap dancing or Lennox Lewis precision. The world title fight between Wladimir Klitschko and Sultan Ibragimov at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night lacked the aura of the glory days of heavyweight boxing.

title: Catching the Imagination in Language and Imagery
description: If you can overlook the limitations of the Molloy College Art Gallery, a hallway in an administrative building where paintings are occasionally hung, there is a terrific selection of works in Words Become Pictures. It is a group show looking at the use of words in contemporary art, especially painting, sometimes to enhance the viewers understanding and sometimes as purely abstract visual symbols.

title: Jonathan Maslow, 59, a Journalist and Naturalist, Dies
description: Jonathan Maslow, a journalist and naturalist whose travels took him from the rain forests of Central America to the steppes of Central Asia, died on Tuesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 59 and lived in Dennisville and Passaic Park, N.J.

title: The Magnificent Seven
description: 1. Christophe Decarnin is revamping Balmain with Native American, Indian and animal prints, as well as a surfeit of beads, fringe and studs. Whos afraid of a little boho? At Jeffrey New York and Intermix.

title: One for the Price of One
description: Do we really want a rerun of that soap opera? Among friends and acquaintances talking through their presidential choices, it often comes down to this: excited to have two such inspiring candidates as Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton, they all roll their eyes at the melodramatic baggage that comes along with the former first couple. Not merely for the undecided voters among us, but for everyone involved, I think the situation calls for a deus ex machina solution drawn straight from the soaps themselves. Whisking a star offstage  often to some dire fate or unspecified location  is the tried-and-true secret to rescuing a flagging story line. For a campaign badly in need of an upswing, the moment has come for Hillary to declare plans to dispatch Bill to Africa once she takes office.

title: Ral Castro Named Cubas New President
description: HAVANA  Ral Castro, who has labored in the shadow of his brother Fidel since the days of the Cuban revolution, became the new president of the Communist island on Sunday, ending his brothers 49-year rule, as well as speculation that a younger generation would take power.

title: Sydneys Beachside Cuisine
description: ON an oppressively hot day in mid-January, at the peak of the Australian summer, tiny Shelly Beach, in the Sydney suburb of Manly, is crowded with sun-worshipers, body-surfers, teenagers on school break and young families gathered around blankets and picnic baskets. As the midday sun beats down, beachgoers take a dip in the cool waters of the protected cove, seek shelter in the shade of some nearby trees or just slather on another layer of lotion and contentedly bake away.

title: Correction: The Charisma Mandate
description: An article last Sunday on the role of charisma in politics referred incorrectly to Republicans who were important to President Johnsons push for the Civil Rights Act. They were Senate Republicans, not Southern Republicans. The article also referred imprecisely to Johnsons well-known We shall overcome speech before Congress. He made it in 1965 as part of his push to get the Voting Rights Act passed; he did not give the speech before the Civil Rights Act, which had passed the previous year.

title: Where Mortgage Isnt a Scary Word
description: INVEST in a mortgage REIT? For some people, that might seem as foolhardy as buying swampland in Florida.

title: At Old Racetracks Site, a Sure Thing
description: CITY CELLAR, in the section of Westbury that once was home to Roosevelt Raceway, is a surprise. From the outside it might be taken for one of the chain restaurants nearby, but the interior is dazzling, and so is the food. Actually, City Cellar is partly owned by the Big Time Restaurant Group, which has two other City Cellars in Florida.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: After the War, a New Battle to Become Citizens
description: Despite a 2002 promise from President Bush to put citizenship applications for immigrant members of the military on a fast track, some are finding themselves waiting months, or even years, because of bureaucratic backlogs. One, Sgt. Kendell K. Frederick of the Army, who had tried three times to file for citizenship, was killed by a roadside bomb in Iraq as he returned from submitting fingerprints for his application.

title: Clinton Criticizes Obama Over Fliers on Trade Pacts Distributed to Voters in Ohio
description: CINCINNATI  Accusing the Obama campaign of using tactics that are right out of Karl Roves playbook, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton angrily denounced Senator Barack Obama on Saturday for sending fliers to Ohio voters that she said falsely characterized her position on trade agreements.

title: Trying to Put New Zip Into Moores Law
description: IF innovation has a heart, its probably a semiconductor, beating to the pace of Moores Law. Under this principle, named for the Intel co-founder Gordon Moore, the chip industry in the last four decades has doubled the number of transistors it crams onto a chip about every 18 months.

title: The Road to Vegas: $55 and 70 Years
description: Before she retires as chief executive on March 1, Marilyn Carlson Nelson will preside over a 70th anniversary celebration in Las Vegas this week for Carlson, the travel, lodging, restaurant and marketing business that began as the Gold Bond Stamp Company in 1938.

title: Sea, Sex and Sunscreen
description: Dont wait for an island getaway. You can werar these exotic florals any time you have the desire.

title: Serb Grief Over Kosovo Runs Deep
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  Nationalist hooligans may have been behind the torching of the United States Embassy here, but the feelings of anger, sorrow and betrayal over the loss of Kosovo cut across all segments of Serbian society.

title: Red Fox
description: I was about 20 years old and determined to wear a red Valentino dress to my friends debutante ball. I had a crush on a boy who was going to be there, and had seen how when my mother wore Valentino couture she immediately became the center of attention. Without fail, a moment of silence would occur as she stepped into a room, much like a pause in a music score. I wanted to experience this intense feeling for myself. When I asked to borrow Moms dress, she flatly refused, saying that red at a coming-out party went against all codes of etiquette. So I did what any savvy New York girl would do: I called Valentino himself, who was thrilled at the idea of making me the social scandal of the season. He gave me my own gown, and since then, I have worn many more  recently to his anniversary in Rome and to Elton Johns birthday party. The effect is always the same: his shade of red is so rich and beautiful that it makes you want to slightly misbehave. Oh, and about that guy I liked way back then  it worked.

title: Phantoms of Broadway: The Season That Wasnt
description: IN a parallel universe you could be deciding tonight whether to try to score a hard-to-get ticket to Annette Benings play or Spike Lees Broadway directorial debut, or to grovel for a spare ticket to Jake Gyllenhaals Off Broadway play. Or, in a season heavy with musical revivals, whether to take in Pal Joey or Guys and Dolls.

title: Making Their Case for Raw Milk
description: SIMSBURY

title: Film of Gay Partners Rights in the Running for an Oscar
description: POINT PLEASANT

title: Its Law & Order
description: Confession: I have probably seen more episodes of Law & Order than can be considered healthy, even for a New Yorker. This small obsession is easily fed, of course. There are about 700 episodes of the various Law & Order programs running and rerunning on at least four television outlets in New York City.

title: Miami Beach, Fla.: Base
description: Miami beach has its own aroma, a fragrant cocktail of citrus, caramel and sun-warmed flesh. Its an essence Ive wanted to bottle for years, if only to extend the high that for me accompanies any stay in South Beach.

title: Trunk Show
description: Be Sheena, Queen of the jungle, in this seasons posh version of the loincloth.

title: Were Big, Were Back, Were Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: True Grit? Not So Much, Anymore
description: The Living In column on Feb. 10, about the East Village, misstated the number of city-recognized historic districts in the area. The East Village does indeed have one district: St. Marks Historic District, designated in 1969. It is not totally without such districts.

title: Jazz Man
description: Nearly a century after jazz emerged as a musical form with profound cultural resonance, the jazz novel, like the theater of the absurd and radio drama, seems an archaism, a good subject for a third-year undergraduate elective or a Bravo documentary. When we think of jazz fiction, we think not only of books centered on the music but of work steeped in the jazz aesthetic  an implacably rigorous and cosmopolitan tradition rooted in the blues and the African-American experience, in which obedience to the moment has primacy. We also call to mind writers dating back to the Harlem Renaissance. We think of Langston Hughes and Jean Toomer; and of F. Scott Fitzgerald, whose legend is inextricable from the age named for jazz; we think perhaps of Kenneth Rexroth; of Ralph Ellison and James Baldwin and Amiri Baraka; and of Jack Kerouac and his fellow Beats, among many others. We think of past eras in a montage of changing modes of headwear: top hats ... fedoras ... kufis ... berets. But we are unlikely to think immediately of jazz when we think of contemporary literature, and we may well conceive of the act of writing a jazz novel in the 21st century as akin to wearing a hat today  as an affectation, a mark of a retro obsession or a hint that one is trying to hide a certain lack of something up top.

title: The Innocence Project
description: Born as common as nondairy creamer, the daughter of a stableman and a domestic servant, Jane Burden rose to the crme de la crme of fin de sicle English society. The tousled-haired Pre-Raphaelite beauty not only became the wife and muse of William Morris, the founder of the British Arts and Crafts movement, but she is also believed to have been an inspiration for George Bernard Shaws Pygmalion.

title: Flight Risk
description: We members of an online pilots forum often discuss a book about an airplane model flown by many of us. The book is out of print and, despite our many requests, likely to remain so. One of us posted an electronic copy of the book and invited others to download it and (at another members suggestion) send a check to the author. Ethical?  JOHN FELLEMAN, PALO ALTO, CALIF.

title: McCains Age May Figure in Choice of a Running Mate
description: When it comes to senators hoping to make history with their presidential bids, Hillary Rodham Clinton (who would be the first woman to be president) and Barack Obama (who would be the first black president) are not the only ones. John McCain, 71, is hoping to become the oldest candidate ever elected to a first term in the White House.

title: The Dirt Devil | SLINGING MUD HAS ITS ADVANTAGES - AT LEAST FOR SKIN AND HAIR
description: Were entering the Just-spring portion of the year, according to E. E. Cummings, when the world turns mud-luscious. The Samurai Shopper has already sprung from the hibernal freeze to roll around cheek by jowl, a prehistoric swamp thing adrift in mud-luscious eddies. Theres mud on my scalp, mud on my face. Ripples of viscous silt voluptuously coat my nutrient-starved skin, nestling in nooks where the sun dont shine.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: COMEDY

title: Getting Out a Yes Vote on Budgets
description: IN Glen Ridge, the schools superintendent and other school board members laid out coffee and doughnuts at the train station in the center of town one recent morning to talk to residents about the need for more school financing and the coming school budget election.

title: Up Front
description: D. T. Max, whose review of Steven Millhausers story collection, Dangerous Laughter, begins on the cover of this issue, majored in comparative literature at Harvard but decided against graduate school after coming across John Updikes dismissal of Roland Barthess S/Z as an almost unreadable book about reading  and deciding that Updike was right. Max worked in book and magazine publishing for some years, then took up writing himself.

title: Offering Financial Calm Amid the Storm of Divorce
description: WHEN I started practicing as a certified divorce financial analyst in 2004, I knew that I would use the skills I had acquired over 16 years in the financial services industry. But what I didnt realize was that I would often feel like a therapist.

title: Israel Increases Its Gaza Forces
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Army increased its forces on the Israeli side of the border fence with the Gaza Strip on Sunday after Palestinian advocates there had called on residents to form a human chain on Monday along the Gaza side, from Rafah in the south to the Erez crossing in the north.

title: Lili Monowitz, John Lampasona
description: Lili Dowd Monowitz and John Francis Lampasona were married on Saturday at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. David J. Robb, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Ernst Jaff, 83, Expert on Red Blood Cells, Dies
description: Dr. Ernst R. Jaff, a groundbreaking hematologist who helped reveal the workings of a hereditary disorder that impairs red blood cells ability to transport oxygen, died on Feb. 16 in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Smithsonian Arts Director Takes Top Job at Wadsworth Museum
description: VALENTINES DAY brought something even sweeter than candy hearts or chocolate for the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, said Coleman Casey, the museums acting director and president of its board of trustees. The Wadsworth got the absolute best person on the face of this planet to lead the way, and that is Susan Lubowsky Talbott.

title: Without Cable Its Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: From Dancehall Rapper to Nursery Rhymer
description: An article last Sunday about the musician Father Goose misstated the name of the Grammy Award-winning Dan Zanes and Friends album on which he appeared. It was Catch That Train! not Stop That Train!

title: Jennifer Starobin, Thomas Davidson
description: Jennifer Starobin and Thomas Adam Davidson were married on Saturday at the Metropolitan Club in New York. The Rev. Mel Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated.

title: The Heart and Soul of Suburbia
description: THE bustling family- and singles-friendly neighborhood known as Huntington Village is neither incorporated nor an official government entity. But this restaurant-laden, shopper-happy 36-square-block cosmopolitan oasis is popular with residents and tourists as the downtown hub and the unofficial capital of the town of Huntington.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 7: The Cleaver

title: Contributors
description: NOBUYOSHI ARAKI : The legendary Japanese photographer Nobuyoshi Araki shot the artist Yayoi Kusama (center) for Kusama Dot Com (Page 266), but it wasnt the first time the icons crossed paths. She and I go back a long time, he says, adding that he first photographed her for a 1980s Japanese porn magazine for which he wrapped her in toilet paper. Despite their history, Araki admits there are still some unfinished chapters in their relationship: Ive never slept with her, so well never come to know everything about each other. After more than 40 years snapping everything from painted flowers (above) to scenes of fellatio, Araki is one of the most prolific and passionate artists working today. Photography is my nutrition, and the sound of the shutter is my heart-beating pulse. A show of his work at the Kestnergesellschaft in Hannover, Germany, runs through May 12.

title: Universities Make Plans to Expand
description: EXPANSION plans are in the air for some state and private universities on Long Island, as Hofstra University is near an agreement for a new medical school and Stony Brook University is talking to a state official about starting a law school, which would be only the second at a state university in New York.

title: Serbia Seeks Rioters Who Set Fire to the U.S. Embassy
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Serbias top state prosecutor said Saturday that the authorities were hunting for the rioters who attacked the United States Embassy and other diplomatic missions last week.

title: Did You Hear the One About the Christian Comedian?
description: If you are a mother with children between the ages of, say, 5 and 55, you have probably been the recipient  once, twice, maybe even more times  of an e-mail message directing you to a particular YouTube clip. The grainy film features a somewhat ordinary looking woman of indeterminate age with longish red hair who is wearing glasses, slacks and a leather jacket. She stands on a stage next to a piano and grasps a microphone and, like a magician introducing her next trick, explains that she will condense into 2 minutes and 55 seconds what a mom would say in a 24-hour period. Then she looks down, clasps her hands, looks up and, as the familiar horns of the William Tell Overture sound, declares: Strap on your seatbelt. Here we go. Then she starts to sing, with a slight Southern accent, at breakneck speed:

title: Sydneys Rock Pools
description: NEARLY every day for 14 years, Denise Leith, a writer and university lecturer, has risen before dawn and headed to the beach at Newport, a pleasant, residential suburb 19 miles north of downtown Sydney, with fruit stands, pharmacies and small shops along the main road, within the sound and smell of the sea. She walks to the south end of the long beach and after donning her cap and goggles plunges into a 50-meter pool.

title: Your Publicist Should Call My Publicist
description: LOS ANGELES  AT the annual Oscar nominees luncheon a few weeks ago, Frank Pierson  the writer of Dog Day Afternoon, the director of A Star Is Born and a former president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences  expressed wonderment as he sized up the room. And he wasnt marveling at George Clooneys smile.

title: Jill Pflieger and William Wachter III
description: Jill Marie Pflieger and William Herbert Wachter III were married Friday evening at the Frenchmans Reserve Country Club in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The Rev. Phillip Grant, a Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Harlem Pas de Deux
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about gentrification in Harlem referred imprecisely to an increase in apartment prices there. While prices for some apartments have indeed doubled in the past year, the prices of other apartments did not increase that much. (As the article noted, the average sale price in Harlem in the last quarter of 2007 was 93 percent higher than in the last quarter of 2006.)

title: Transit Villages Come to Life
description: NINE years after it was officially created, the states Transit Village program has been extended to 19 communities eligible for grants and aid to revitalize the deteriorated neighborhoods around train and bus stations.

title: Better Days for the Knicks? Dream On
description: I had a dream the other night, a dream that was too good to be true.

title: Day Glow
description: Head into spring in the kinds of revved-up colors that would look great on an old 56 Chevy.

title: With Eye on Future, Petty Team Packs Up
description: The roots of Petty Enterprises run deep through Level Cross, N.C., a small community 90 miles northeast of Charlotte that has been home to the most successful Nascar team in stock-car-racing history. The Petty family won 10 Cup championships and 268 races out of that unassuming one-story race shop that helped shape the sport.

title: Why Big Bird Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretty Ugly
description: Any aficionado of early Mad comics published during the first half of the 1950s, when Mad was still a riotous comic book and not yet a formatted magazine, will recognize the brilliantly perverse parody of a Life magazine cover featuring a portrait of a hideous girl next to the headline Beautiful Girl of the Month Reads Mad. The artist who concocted this misshapen, bug-eyed, fang-toothed, pimply-faced, spaghetti-haired, pig-nosed monstrosity was Basil Wolverton (1909-78), a Mad mainstay who specialized in things ugly. He created Lena the Hyena, a character who appeared in Al Capps Lil Abner and was known as the ugliest woman in Lower Slobbovia. And he was the mastermind behind Powerhouse Pepper, a mock-heroic melodrama, as well as covers for GJDRKZLXCBWQ Comics: A Gallery of Gooney Gags and DC Comics Mad-like Plop! Always recognizable for unbridled grotesquerie, his art ran the gamut from political satire (Candid Close-Ups: Hitler) to goofy science fiction (Rocket Rider) to biblical illustrations (for a decade he wrote and illustrated the Bible story, serialized in The Plain Truth magazine, for the Worldwide Church of God). His epic in this last genre was a gory interpretation of Armageddon, complete with horrific atomic aftermaths. He did, however, also produce posters for Topps, the trading card company. While his penchant for extreme physical exaggeration may not have been to everyones taste, through Mad he exercised incalculable influence on the history of comics and the perceptions of impressionable preteens, like me. Gross was and remains a generational code.

title: You Better Werkstatte
description: At the Wiener Werksttte, artists believed that a piece of jewelry should serve as something more personal than an advertisement for wealth. Josef Hoffmann, one of the workshops founders, used semiprecious stones including coral and moonstone to create brooches that resembled stained glass (left). His pieces also referred to Gustav Klimt, who happened to be an important patron. The artist Dagobert Peche went a more organic route with nature-inspired bracelets and pendants. They were thinking in more abstract ways, says Janis Staggs, who curated the show Wiener Werksttte Jewelry, which opens at the Neue Galerie in New York on March 27. It was about experimentation of color and pattern. But not necessarily about perfection. As Staggs explains, No two pieces were alike. There were always inconsistencies, which add to the charm. [?][?][?]MAURA EGAN

title: Letters: In Vino Veritas
description: So those grotesque drunk videos posted online arent pornography, and its perfectly fine to enjoy watching drunken people debase themselves (The Medium, Virginia Heffernan, Feb. 10). But why does it still seem so skeevy? Because it is, in fact, thoroughly pornographic in its most basic nature. Even if it isnt specifically sexual (which I believe it may well be in some perverse sublimated form), this still involves objectification and dehumanization.

title: Amid Weeds and Rust, a Ruin Seeks a Second Act
description: FOR as long as most people living in Farragut Houses can remember, the 10 weed-choked town houses around the corner have lain in ruins, partly hidden behind a high fence and ignored by all who pass.

title: Reluctant Landlords Settle Into a Rental
description: BERNIE DeCHANT owns a two-family house in a nice San Francisco neighborhood. His buddy Pascal Balthrop owns a three-story town house in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But the two choose to live together as roommates on nearby Union Street in a two-bedroom rental that Mr. DeChant describes as more of a hovel than a palace.

title: Trying to Understand Midlife Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Nells Reject Pile
description: Dear A.P.: Here are six pitches for the spring T. Personally, I think theyre all solid. Just let me know which ones (all?) you want me to do. A big mwah two inches from your cheek.

title: Bird-Dog Minute
description: Responding to a cockamamie question a few weeks ago about whether there is a secret agreement to merge the U.S., Mexico and Canada into a single continental nation (MexiCanUs?), Senator Hillary Clinton gently replied, Ive heard that story, and theres not a lot of truth to it. Not to put down her somewhat vituperative Missouri questioner, the senator added, If I am president, if I discover there is such an agreement, itll be gone in a bird-dog minute.

title: Bright Yarn Thing
description: Just as her muse Jean-Michel Basquiat used to say, Believe it or not, I can actually draw, the British knitwear sensation Clare Tough says she can actually knit. Still, grandmothers everywhere may grumble that some of her graffiti-inspired creations (like her Brooklyn Bridge bra, a skimpy creation in wool and balsa wood) break every rule of the purl-one-knit-two set. Ditto for the zippered cardigan with an overload of ribbed patchwork and vibrant embroideries, which she says has about 50 types of yarn. Tough first got noticed in 2004 with her Central Saint Martins graduation show: the string outfits of Jamaican dancehall queens re-envisioned as cobwebby knit dresses. But her real obsession is 80s New York, having grown up in the picture-postcard spa town Malvern listening to Fab 5 Freddie and old hip-hop compilations. Tough, 27, is bent on expanding the definition of knitwear. I didnt invent crochet, obviously, but I really think the way I patchwork garments together hasnt been done before, she says in her East London studio. Knitting has got a frumpy image, and it really shouldnt. [?][?][?]SUSIE RUSHTON THE REMIX

title: Drugs and Rock n Roll
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pollution Scorecard for New Cars
description: A LIST released last week of what are said to be the 12 greenest vehicles sold in the United States includes nine made by Japanese automakers, two by Europeans and only one from the Detroit companies.

title: The Stages of Bart Sher
description: The young man opened his mouth to sing, and the sound was so rich, so beautiful that when he finished there was only stunned silence. He left the audition room, and the appreciative murmuring began  with one exception. He sings great, but he has no pearly mist, Bartlett Sher said flatly. Theres something not appealing about him. The other men at the table, including the musical director, were dumbstruck. But Sher was resolute. The big perfect voice is not always the point, he said. Lets go on.

title: Made in the Shade
description: When I turned 10, my family moved from a solidly middle-class suburb of Los Angeles, where time seemed to have stopped in a kind of sleepy Norman Rockwell fashion, to Brentwood, which is nestled in the much posher, much faster west side of the city. There had been a divorce and nearly instant remarriages, and my mother, who is relentless and clever about forward motion, realized that where we were living was not where we should be living. This was a shock for many reasons, most of which had to do with the girls in my new sixth-grade class. I had come from the land of saddle shoes, bobby socks and plaid jumpers, and suddenly I was confronted with a world of snobby 11-year-old sophisticates in nylons, heels and miniature versions of their mothers 70s sheaths. I was still a child  I wanted to go trick-or-treating on Halloween, they wanted to play truth or dare with the boys; I was proud of my Girl Scout merit badges, they wanted to wear their green uniforms to entice older boys. But most of all, and most shocking to me, was that they all wore black. Not every day, but for special occasions  class photo, assembly, sixth-grade graduation  and I had never known anyone of any age who wore black for anything other than a funeral.

title: Four or Five Things You Dont Know About Me
description: THE other day I was walking down the street and I realized that everyone was wearing earmuffs. I myself was wearing earmuffs at the time, but that wasnt the reason I noticed all the other earmuffs  I noticed them because I happen to know that I personally started the trend of earmuffs. I began wearing them at the age of 21, when you could barely find a pair in a store, which doubtless was one reason no one wore them but me. The only ones for sale were made of felt, came in two separate bits and hooked over your upper ear and then snapped against your head. They were inadequate thermal protection compared to my current pair, which are made of fake fur; but they were far superior to being outdoors in winter without anything at all over your ears. I had serious fantasies that by wearing them, I would start something, fashion-wise, and now it seems I have. Its true its taken a while, 45 years to be exact, but earmuffs are definitely catching on, and its because of me.

title: Courtney Wisotsky, Michael Weinstein
description: Courtney Mia Wisotsky, a daughter of Amy Wisotsky and Peter Wisotsky of East Northport, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Michael Harris Weinstein, a son of Gail Weingstein and Dr. Melvin Weinstein of East Rockaway, N.Y. Rabbi Ian J. Silverman officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York, with Cantor Ralph Nussbaum taking part.

title: Toga Land
description: The grecian formula updated.

title: The Empty Belly, a Common Denominator
description: THE REV. JENNIFER AULL has been doing a lot of food shopping lately, for a while at a supermarket and then at a wholesale distributor where she buys peanut butter, crackers, canned vegetables and macaroni and cheese in bulk. To the people doing the billing, she must look like the owner of a small grocery.

title: A Web Portal for Shopaholics
description: If youre tired of shopping at the same old chain stores, then check out www.storeadore.com. The new Web site aims to personalize the travelers shopping experience by using local writers to provide information on their citys most estimable boutiques. Started by a former editor at Lucky Magazine and a former management consultant, the site, which also publishes exclusive shopping deals, currently covers New York, Boston, Los Angeles and Washington, as well as online stores. In June, it will expand its coverage to include San Francisco, Chicago, Philadelphia, Dallas and Miami. Users may create their own profiles with shopping bios and customize a favorite stores map, as well as keep current by reading the sites blog, which is constantly getting updated with new trends and ideas.

title: My Muse? | Myself
description: Donatella Versace

title: On the Road With the Two Jon Corzines
description: TRENTON

title: Some Kids, Some Stars, Some Season
description: A preview of some of the themes youll be noticing in theaters this season.

title: Adding Risk (Carefully) to Your Bond Portfolio
description: FIXED-INCOME investors are starting to find that the relative safety of Treasury bonds is coming at a hefty cost. Aggressive rate cuts by the Federal Reserve have driven up the prices of Treasury bonds, leaving them with razor-thin yields.

title: Feed Your Face
description: l1 Its not easy to get face time with Tracie Martyn. The beauty gurus appointment book is crammed with names like Kate Winslet, Sandra Bullock, Madonna and Rene Zellweger, all of whom get their glow on with Martyns Red Carpet and Resculpting Facials. My treatments are like having mini-lifts without the down time, Martyn says. In addition to cleaning the skin, she aims to firm and contour the jaw, cheekbones and eye area. Mere mortals can join the wait list. Go to traciemartyn.com.

title: Attacks Show Easygoing Jamaica Is Dire Place for Gays
description: MANDEVILLE, Jamaica  One night last month, Andre and some friends were finishing dinner when a mob showed up at the front gate. Yelling antigay slurs and waving machetes, sticks and knives, 15 to 20 men kicked in the front door of the home he and his friends had rented and set upon them.

title: Letters: The First Ache
description: Interesting that one of the justifications for ignoring the possibility of fetal pain in an abortion is that the identified objective of preventing possible long-term damage is irrelevant, since, in an abortion, there is no long term (Annie Murphy Paul, Feb. 10).

title: Pay and Perks Vary Widely for County Legislators
description: IN the suburbs, real estate, trusted help and income matter, even for the county legislators.

title: A Sign of Hope for Stocks
description: FROM at least one perspective, the stock market peak of last October was not accompanied by the speculative excesses found at the height of previous bull markets. This raises hope that the market decline that began in the fall may not turn out to be severe  and that it may have already run its course.

title: Michelin Gives Stars, but Tokyo Turns Up Nose
description: TOKYO  The Michelin guide recently ventured into Asia for the first time in its 108-year history to research and publish a Japanese-language guide to Tokyo restaurants. To gain credibility, it hired Japanese restaurant judges to work with its European experts and adapted its standards to the nations special culinary culture.

title: A Rocky Week Ends With Gains
description: Hints of stagflation and continuing worries about slumping growth weighed on investors as the major stock indexes ended an erratic week of ups and downs.

title: Breaking the Mold of the Musical
description: THE spring seasons small crop of new musicals is intriguingly diverse, signifying how the definition of the Broadway musical continues to expand. Artists grope their way forward, trying to invigorate the old forms, even as they search out new ones. Each represents one or another of the assorted impulses behind the making of the 21st-century American musical.

title: It Must Be Ohio
description: The Ohio Democratic primary is still nine days away and Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton are already accusing each other of being soft on trade. Criticisms of trade agreements in Ohio are as predictable as praise for ethanol in Iowa. But they do the voters no favor.

title: Correction: Review of Brooklyn Was Mine
description: A review on Feb. 3 about the essay collection Brooklyn Was Mine misspelled the given names of two contributing writers. They are Darcey Steinke, not Darcy, and Lara Vapnyar, not Laura.

title: The April Fools Joke I Played on Myself
description: MY girlfriend and I were descending into the Eighth Avenue L train subway station when I remembered it was April Fools Day. I am not a big fan of this day; Im not an office jokester, always ready with a back slap and witticism. But the realization gave me the urge to contact my little brother.

title: Fantasy Casting Calls, Imagined by Insiders
description: KERRY BUTLER in On a Clear Day You Can See Forever. Angela Lansbury in A Little Night Music. Jane Fonda in Applause. These are just three recent examples of dream-team revival casting suggested by talkinbroadway.com readers whose desires for the perfect show frequently turn that popular theater fan site into the Broadway equivalent of fantasy football.

title: If a Nonmember Sits In on a Co-op Board
description: Q I live in a New York City co-op. I recently learned that the board presidents wife was present when a prospective buyer had her board interview. Is this legal?

title: Diesel-Sipping Motorcycle for the Marines
description: THE United States Marine Corps, legendary for doing more with less, has used dual-purpose motorcycles for scouting, messenger service, convoy control and military police work.

title: Maintenance Fees: Up, Up, Up
description: NEW YORK CITY apartment owners can hardly be blamed for feeling nostalgic, and a little depressed, as they receive their increases in condominium common charges and co-op maintenance fees this year, for many, the fifth or sixth in a row.

title: ID Check
description: MEMPHIS  One of the great things about the bluster and boisterousness of Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl and Memphis Coach John Calipari is that their players take after them.

title: List of Academy Award Nominees and Winners
Anand Leads Morelia-Linares at Halfway Mark
The Week Ahead: Feb. 24-Mar. 1
description: Film

title: This Is Baghdad
description: Stephen Farrell welcomes readers to the Baghdad Bureau blog.

title: Different Venue, Same Result as England Tops France
description: PARIS  French Coach Marc Livremont spent the week before France's Six Nations rugby union match with England dismissing talk of revenge. It was wise he did so.

title: Visiting Granny Obama
description: Nicholas D. Kristof travels to Kenya to visit with the Obama family.

title: Theater Listings
description: Dates are subject to change.

title: Radio Interview: Paula Kamen on On Point
description: Listen to the author in a discussion on migraines on Bostons WBUR-FMs show, On Point.

title: Op-Classic: Castro Looks to the Future  Nervously
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: SNL: Back and In the Tank for Politics
description: Saturday Night Live plunged into presidential politics last night, mocking the media as a tool of Senator Barack Obama as the show returned to the air for the first time since Nov. 3.

title: Corrections
description: Arts & Leisure

title: The PATH Turns 100
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is celebrating the centenary of the H&M, known since 1962 as PATH (Port Authority Trans-Hudson).

title: Bad, Multiplied
description: Before the so-called best of Hollywood tonight comes the worst:

title: News Roundup: Search in Milan; Spain Eurotrash; Boom in Canada
description: Stories from the world of property:

title: Nader to Run Again
description: Dissent is the mother of ascent, Ralph Nader said on Meet the Press this morning. And in that context, I have decided to run for president.

title: Not Maxed Out
description: Last nights Miramax party had all the trappings of a major Oscar bacchanal. Tight door, movie stars, even an appearance by the elusive Cormac McCarthy (the author of No Country for Old Men). The Soho club here offered a great space and amazing views and even a smoking cage, a place where the muse often hunts the Bagger down, but no one wants to put both pom poms in the air  not the night before, and maybe not the night after. Strike, rain, macro-business problems, the death of Heath Ledger, blame it on whatever you want, but no one is doing the backstroke in Oscar froth this year.

title: The Man Who Wouldnt Die
description: Just saying: You might want to be wary of a book in which the author reveals the exact size of his erect sex organ on Page 48. Those boys!

title: Crowded High Wire
description: Yesteday, Tom ONeil took a seat on the high wire, suggesting that George Clooney could sneak past Daniel Day-Lewis in the best actor category. He got some company yesterday. The Bagger bumped into Tom Bernard, the co-chief honcho at Sony Pictures Classics, at the Spirit Awards. Bernard has a pretty good record in Oscar matters and has good sources among old members of the Academy, although he was wearing sunglasses that play MP3s, so there is that. (Dog the Bounty Hunter, who is staying at the Baggers hotel, has a similar pair.) And Bernard said that Day-Lewis may not be the lock we have all said he was. Youre probably right about Daniel Day-Lewis, but I wouldnt be surprised to see Clooney sneak in.

title: Funny Girl
description: At yesterdays rehearsals, according to The Associated Press, Cameron Diaz, in a gray sweater, skinny black jeans and towering high heels, opened a prop winners envelope and said, The Oscar goes to  your mama. No, Im just kidding.

title: Calling an Audible
description: This years Oscars would have seemed to be a great time to innovate, to put together a show on the fly that perhaps attacks some of the creakiness and convention that is part of Oscar gospel. Aint. Gonna. Happen. In spite of the fact that organizers had little more than a week to put together the show, this will be no ad-hoc Oscars. Look for the same glorious goo to be poured into the extant template. People who have seen the auditions say that there is a palpable desire for normalcy, for business as usual, but that means the same brutal copy will show up on the teleprompter and be beamed straight at you.

title: Breaking the Rules
description: When he learned I wanted to write a play, Jon Jory, who was then Artistic Director of Actors Theatre of Louisville, took me out to lunch and said, OK, here are the three mistakes you dont have to make. And thats pretty much the way I teach to this day  telling writers the traps they dont have to fall into, not saying how it has to be done, just trying to save them some of their precious time. Over the years people have yelled at me for teaching the rules, or even for suggesting that there are rules. But I never expect these rules to be followed absolutely. They serve the same purpose as the boundary flags in ski resorts. You can ski in the ungroomed powder if you want, but youd better know what youre doing, and be willing to take the risk. Still, we do not turn on the television to watch average skiers take safe trips down the green trails. We turn on the X Games to see heli-skiers land on the top of glaciers and shoot off the edges of the cliffs, or watch the great Shaun White shred some gnarly terrain, as my son says. And that brings us to August: Osage County, a play that only seems traditional, but actually creates its excitement by breaking the rules.

title: Stuffing the Ballot Box with Electrons
description: Dan, the Baggers digital peer, has been crunching some data: For the third straight year, our readers have weighed in on the race. The first year  well, we let people vote more than once, so the results were just a tad skewed. But this year, the numbers look right, and in more ways than one. NYTimes.comers votes align nicely with the general zeitgeist (though not necessarily with the Baggers picks), though there are a few surprises. No Country gets picture, director, supporting actor and screenplay. But Daniel Day-Lewis is neck and neck with Johnny Depp for Best Actor. Cate Blanchett would win both actress awards if the readers were in charge.

title: British Hegemony
description: Every year, the Oscars pay a visit to that mid-Atlantic place where British and American culture mash up into something that combines Yankee rigor with English refinement. This year, that phenomenon shows up in the form of Atonement, with a young British director, Joe Wright, and ingnue Keira Knightley defining Anglophilian upper crust lust. And in the acting categories, youve also got your Tilda Swintons  who could win this year, btw  and Julie Christies, who is favored to win. Cate Blanchett is nominated, twice in fact, a sorta Brit from Australia.

title: The Oscars: A Love/Hate Story
description: The Baggers more carefully considered doppelganger has a point-counter point about the cultural value of the Oscars in the newspaper today with A. O. Scott, a real, actual movie critic. The package includes an audio file of the throw-down, but the overlords at the House of Many Doors edited out the part where Scott called the Bagger an ignorant slut, but it is still a lively and blessedly brief  the Baggers voice has been compared to the sound cows emit when they get a batch of bad feed  podcast about the worthiness of the national bonfire of glitter and gamesmanship.

title: Kodak Moment: Intermittent Rain, a Stalled High Pressure System
description: Over the past few days, unseasonable cold and rain in Los Angeles has occasionally given way to some moments when the sun breaks through, bathing the city in welcome light and flicking at the dampness. People will scan the sky, turning their face toward sun that is generally a prerogative of living here. (Update: 11:30 PST. Sunny but chill.)

title: Open Mind, Open Thread
description: Crunch time. The Bagger picked the following in the biggies.

title: Regional Theater: Spring 2008
description: Dates are subject to change.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, Feb. 24:

title: The Sights of Spring
description: A few quick observations after my first visit to the clubhouse this spring

title: I.P. Address: Partially Personal Information
description: My post about whether Googles records of the Internet Protocol address should be considered personal information under privacy law, brought two comments from Googlers: Matt Cutts, an engineer, and from Peter Fleischer, Googles global privacy counsel.

title: Living in Huntington Village, Long Island
description: Huntington Village is popular with residents and tourists as a restaurant-laden, shopper-happy cosmopolitan oasis.

title: The Roitfelds | Family de la Mode
description: Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of Vogue Paris, bequeathed her children her soign style as if it were their birthright. Her daughter, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, is a freelance art director for the likes of Jean Paul Gaultier and was the face of Tom Fords latest fragrance; her son, Vladimir Restoin-Roitfeld, is a film school graduate and a sometime model. Going to a fashion shoot when they were young, says Mom, was as normal as tarte Tatin. (The photographer Mario Testino is their godfather.) Many consider Roitfeld the stilettoed embodiment of modern dressing: she describes her style as tacky chic. Never afraid to take a risk, she has put a bearded drag queen on a cover and printed a fashion story with a model dressed as an Anna Wintour clone. After 20-plus years in the business, certain things have changed: I dont go too much to the parties now, but my kids do. Like their mom, theyre always on the list.

title: Clinton Turns From Anger to Sarcasm
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  On Saturday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton showed her angry side, admonishing Senator Barack Obama for a campaign mailing that she called misleading.

title: The Candidates on Nader
description: The Democratic and Republican candidates have begun weighing in on Ralph Naders announcement this morning on NBCs Meet the Press that yes, he has decided to run for the presidency, again. While he has been derided by Democrats for taking away votes from Al Gore in the 2000 presidential race, his impact in 2004 was minimal.

title: Post-Strike Saturday Night Live Gets Ratings Bounce
description: The first post-strike episode of Saturday Night Live drew at least 6 million households, its highest number in twelve months, according to preliminary figures from Nielsen Media Research.

title: Electronic Arts Offers $2 Billion for Take-Two
description: Electronic Arts, the video gaming giant, made an unsolicited $2 billion bid on Sunday for a rival, Take-Two Interactive, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise. The deal would reshape the rapidly growing video game industry, which has begun a wave of consolidation.

title: Have Your Guy Talk to My Guy So We Can Talk About This Guy
description: The Bagger has assumed the position, behind one of the hedges on the red carpet at the Kodak Theater. And who will he talk to while he is there? Fabulous movies stars, perhaps? Perhaps, But first, even here, he will spend time talking publicists. In the business section of The New York Times, Michael Cieply writes a quiet, but savagely hilarious piece about the publicity apparatus that comes to a head today.

title: That Scary Movie Sound
description: The crowd across the way on the carpet is making that freaky, scary happy noise and boy are they ready. There was just a huge roar and the Bagger is pretty sure it was somebody bringing a tray of sandwiches inside.

title: Together Again
description: The Bagger is stationed next to Robert Osborne, the television host who has been introducing the talent on the carpet to the adoring hoardes for the past three years. He loves the gig.

title: The $136.5 Million Pitcher Hits the $119 Million Center Fielder
description: Johan Santana threw an inside fastball to Carlos Beltran, but it sailed too far inside and drilled Beltran in the left triceps. The sound of the ball hitting Beltrans flesh was unmistakable and even sounded like it hurt.

title: Stand-Up Accounting
description: Rick Rosas and Brad Oltmanns, those two guys from PricewaterhouseCoopers, who know all and tell nothing, came in with their briefcases that contained all the results. The Bagger took a picture and said it was an X-ray camera. Rosas said, We use lead envelopes. The briefcases looked new. We use the same ones every year, said Oltmanns. What if someone were to cheat or misspoke? We would correct them immediately, they both said in unison.

title: Sunshine & Pillow-snatchers
description: (Photo: A look from the Rick Owens fall 2008 collection in Paris. (Jean-Luce Hur for The New York Times))   I had plans--plans I tell you!--to be up early and roaming the town but my pillow snatched me back and it was past noon before I set off to the Place de la Concorde, already crowded with people. It was a stunning day, cloudless and mild. The first show for most of the editors and buyers was Balmain (the tightest, smallest pants and club tops in leather and metal mesh, nothing surprising) and a number of the guests had brought their young children. In the course of the day I heard a lot of things. Will Robert Rimondi and Tommaso Aquilano of 6267 take over Ferre? Is Hedi Slimane in negotiations for his own men's and women's label? Time will tell. I thought Slimane's pictures (in New York Magazine) of Carine Roitfeld were terrific, and evocative of her. And take a look at the spreads with Lara Stone in the current Paris Vogue, particularly Neo Classiques, by Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott.   (Photo: Another look from the Rick Owens fall 2008 collection in Paris. (Jean-Luce Hur for The New York Times))   Rick Owens was this afternoon: great show. The collection is more voluptuous than last season, with the familiar darkness and Owens grit. Owens gives a kind of hour-glass shape to jackets, sometimes using two or three fabrics in combination, and creating sculptural effects. The thought process seemed very top to toe, with small, square-ish caps, fins and cube-like volumes on some of the jackets, and wedge-heel boots with flaps that spill around the calf and drag on the ground. In the midst of all this shape and texture were simple tank dresses and skimmy biker shorts in cashmere. Thom Browne happened to be at the show.   The New York Times Magazine and the International Herald Tribune had a party tonight at the Mini Palais. I stopped by for a few minutes. Well, that was the plan... I saw Stefano Pilati, Sidney Toledano of Dior, Kris Van Assche, Maria Cornejo, and Manuel Puig, whose company owns Nina Ricci. Puig is an interesting guy to talk to--about business, U.S. politics, Europe, Formula 1 racing. On my way out, I ran into Karl Lagerfeld and Amanda Harlech. Lagerfeld told me his suit was a Jil Sander by Raf Simons. I jumped in Mr. Alloux's waiting taxi, thinking I'd better save my strength for the rest of the week.   More photos from Paris Fashion Week here.

title: Sunshine & Pillow-snatchers
description: I had plansplans I tell you!to be up early and roaming the town but my pillow snatched me back and it was past noon before I set off to the Place de la Concorde, already crowded with people. It was a stunning day, cloudless and mild. The first show for most of the editors and buyers was Balmain (the tightest, smallest pants and club tops in leather and metal mesh, nothing surprising) and a number of the guests had brought their young children. In the course of the day I heard a lot of things. Will Robert Rimondi and Tommaso Aquilano of 6267 take over Ferre? Is Hedi Slimane in negotiations for his own mens and womens label? Time will tell. I thought Slimanes pictures (in New York Magazine) of Carine Roitfeld were terrific, and evocative of her. And take a look at the spreads with Lara Stone in the current Paris Vogue, particularly Neo Classiques, by Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott.

title: Wanted: Someone Who Knows Nothing About the Job
description: In one of those ironies that make life interesting, the University of Colorado, which dismissed controversial professor Ward Churchill because of doubts about his academic qualifications, has appointed a president who doesnt have any. (The final vote was taken on Feb. 20.)

title: For Some Top Players, Invitations to Elite Tournaments Are Scarce
description: Sergey Karjakin of the Ukraine is ranked No. 14 in the world and has been ranked in the top 30 for a year. Last December, he made it to the semifinals of the World Cup before narrowly losing to Alexei Shirov Spain. Because of that performance, he is seeded into the Grand Prix, the series of tournaments that will help select a challenger for the world championship. He holds the record as the youngest grandmaster in history (12 years 7 months). And he turned 18 a little more than a month ago.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia:  New Harmonies
description: Young Chinese musicians introduced their original compositions to veteran professionals from the New York Philharmonic during the orchestras visit to Shanghai.

title: In November, Will Age Matter?
description: As John McCain comes ever closer to securing the Republican nomination, his age has remained notably absent as a campaign issue. So far it has attracted so little attention that the network exit pollsters have not included even one question on the subject in 23 state surveys  an extraordinary occurrence given that Senator McCain would be the oldest man ever to take office, if he were to win the presidency.

title: Lets Roll
description: The good news is they were able to right this overturned vehicle. The bad news is they were able to right this overturned vehicle:

title: Turned Out To Be False
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Spoof Dogg
Generational Exchange
description: Julie Christie, in the midst of a long career that this year includes a best actress not, looked down the carpet a few feet at Ellen Page, her fellow nominee.

title: Close Contests Ahead
description: The Texas and Ohio Democratic primaries on March 4 are critical to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has lost the last 11 contests. The latest polls show that the races are close. In Texas, Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama are neck and neck. In Ohio, Mrs. Clinton has a slight lead.

title: In Calm Before the Storm, an Opportunity to Regroup
description: Video

title: Learning to Speak Oscar
description: Marion Cotillard has been on the circuit for a month, going hither and yon in Los Angeles in support of La Vie en Rose and her nomination for best actress. Her English has improved rapidly  Why thank you! as has her understanding of the business. I had no idea that a little French movie would go this far, but this is what you do once it does.

title: Criss-cross
description: Ellen Page, the tiniest presence on the circuit, at least in terms of body mass, was standing in front of the Bagger when Michael Moore, one of the largest, came by. They squeezed by each other, a waif walking around a mountain, award circuit familiars.

title: Complain, Who Me?
description: Philip Seymour Hoffman is under very little pressure this year, having been nominated for best supporting actor for his role in Charlie Wilsons War  and it shows. Why such little pressure? Javier Bardem is the prohibitive favorite (He just won, btw.) Hoffman is known as somebody with very little taste for the pomp and silliness of the awards campaign.

title: Hemmed In
description: Miley Cyrus (a k a Hannah Montana), one of the evenings presenters, was told by her publicist that it was time to quit an interview and step up to be interviewed by Robert Osborne, the red carpet host of the Oscars.

title: Homers
description: The press room generally likes a surprise as much as the next person  Golden Compass for effects!????  because it makes for a story that has a few twists and turns. But the newsies like a front-runner because it makes them feel smug and knowing. Which is why they yelled like 8-year-olds when the Javier Bardem won for best supporting male.

title: Cheese Curdles
description: The press room may be the worst place in the world to watch the Oscars, but the Bagger is beginning to notice a trend. Even though the strike lifted and the whole show is back on, Jon Stewart and the producers continue to insist on showing filmed segments that would have been broadcast, as if to menace the crowd with what might have been. Maybe it would have been worse, but for the time being, there seems to be an odd juxtaposition of hackery  a filmed riff on telescopes and binoculars  sentiment  Jon Stewart going so sweet on the kids from August Rush  and vamping  pregger jokes about Cate Blanchett and Jessica Alba.

title: Curiouser and Curiouser
