description: Who in the world am I? Ah, thats the great puzzle! says Lewis Carrolls Alice after experiencing a sudden, disorienting growth spurt.

title: Secure in Their Beliefs
description: The Bagger showed up on time this year  he got clobbered last year for trying to slip in late and caused a red alert. This year, he was far more obedient and the staff was enormously helpful. But what could have been a gracious ingress and egress was marred earlier when he busted a move down the carpet to leave a little early. Two guys came up on either side and walked him to a gate. They told him he could go in through the adjacent hotel. The Bagger knew better. He was ejected. The guys with the headpieces can smell fear, and the Bagger knew what was coming. He has finally hacked his way back in.

title: What Is This, a Surprise Party?
description: The show may be short on surprises, but the actual awards have provided plenty. Tilda Swinton walked by Amy Ryan and Ruby Dee, winning best supporting for her turn as a sweaty, grasping corporate executive in Michael Clayton who drowns in her own venality. Golden Compass was on no ones radar, but walked past the artful machines of Transformers to win effects. And art direction, which many thought would be the Academys way of recognizing the achievement of There Will be Blood or perhaps giving a bon-bon to Atonement, went to Sweeney Todd instead, a movie that dropped off the radar some time ago.

title: SNL: Back and In the Tank for Politics
description: Saturday Night Live plunged into presidential politics as the show returned to the air over the weekend for the first time since Nov. 3. In a faux debate, it mocked the media as a tool of Senator Barack Obama:

title: The Euros Are Up
description: Three acting awards handed out and three go to actors whose professional homes lie outside Hollywood.

title: Let the Games Begin  The Market Will Speak on Proposed Game Merger
description: Electronic Arts made its offer for rival Take-Two Interactive. Take-Two declined.

title: Tilda Exclaimed
description: Tilda Swinton could not be any more different that the doughy, sweaty character she plays in Michael Clayton. With a shock of red, short hair and a very thin draped in black velvet, she looked like a human exclamation point.

title: Not a Suspense Director
description: Jason Reitman, the director of Juno, is oddly one of the people in the room who will not be on pins and needles waiting for the best picture announcement.

title: The Political Climate in Ohio
description: Senators Clinton and Obama are facing a electorate that has been promised many things by many presidential candidates over the years.

title: Fighting Fires With Fans
description: On Governors Island, the New York Fire Department intentionally sets fires in order to analyze the movement of air, fire and smoke.

title: A Message From God
description: Glen Hansard showed up on the red carpet with his beat-up guitar on one arm and his professional and personal partner Marketa Irglova on the other.

title: Bonbon Dispenser
description: Remember in first grade when everybody won a little something? If not first honors, then some kind of very special person award. This Oscars is feeling like that. Little Atonement, we have original score award for you. And There Will Be Blood? We have a cinematography award for you. Juno, we see you, you little dickens back there. Heres a screenplay win for you.

title: Average Joe
description: Back in Sundance, the Bagger was doing videos and talked to a quiet nice man who chatted amiably on camera about the movies at Sundance. Somebody finally interrupted the Bagger and said, Hey, that guy makes movies too. His name is Alex Gibney. He makes documentaries. As of a few minutes ago, he makes Academy Award-winning documentaries, in this case, Taxi to The Dark Side.

title: Four-Star Euro Hotel
description: Each year, four acting slots come up for grabs. European actors frequently are part of the mix, but they never have walked away with four. (Wrong, as a reader points out. It happened in 1964.) Taking cultural hegemony to a new tier, Hollywood mostly stood by.

title: Dubai Powerhouse Makes First Move into Latin America Market
description: Nakheel, the state-controlled Dubai developer, has purchased a half interest in a Mexican resort, its first foray into Latin America. Nakheel paid $315 million (213 million) for the 50 percent share of Palmilla, a high-end resort and condo development outside Cabo San Lucas, on the southern tip of Baja California.

title: Israel Adds Border Forces Ahead of Protest in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Army bolstered its forces on the Israeli side of the border fence with the Gaza Strip on Sunday after Palestinian advocates there called on residents to form a human chain on Monday along the Gaza side, from Rafah in the south to Beit Hanun in the north.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: He Stomps Like Godzilla, Stings Like a... Dont Ask
description: In Monster, 1959 David Maine invites readers into the pea-sized brain of a 40-foot monstrous smorgasbord known as K. Described as something to cause Darwin to burn his notebooks and run shrieking to the nearest monastery, K. lacks lips but is a kissing cousin to Godzilla. He is a hapless, guileless, rampaging creature straight out of B-movie science fiction. In light of Mr. Maines flair for domesticating larger-than-life subject matter, his new books premise seems hard to resist.

title: Pentagon Calls Satellite Hit a Success
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon announced Monday that the mission to launch a Navy missile-interceptor at a dead spy satellite appears to have succeeded in destroying a tank filled with toxic rocket fuel.

title: In the Drama of Britney Spears, a Show Business Fortune Is at Risk
description: LOS ANGELES  Britney Spearss klieg-lighted meltdown sent her to the psychiatric ward twice, and left her long-divorced parents, her brother, and a SWAT team of lawyers and accountants grappling with how to protect her from predatory hangers-on, from the paparazzi who dog her every move and from her own erratic behavior.

title: A Momentary Pause, in Praise of Punctuation
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Carpet, Starry Sights, Sounds and Even Smells
description: HOLLYWOOD  In his seasonal quest to sate his blog with all things Oscar, the Bagger returned Sunday evening to the red carpet  breaking a vow, but keeping his job. Both he and Hollywood were trying hard not to get too frantic in what has been a subdued, strike-affected year, but when you have George Clooney walking by Javier Bardem while Amy Adams looks on, its hard not to get your freak on.

title: Toasting an Oscar Win, Hoping for Greater Rights
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  It was part Oscar party and part civil rights rally.

title: Studios Are Trying to Stop DVDs From Fading to Black
description: A winner has finally been declared in Hollywoods high-definition DVD war. So why isnt there more cheering?

title: Its All About Him
description: Last October, a reporter asked Barack Obama why he had stopped wearing the American flag lapel pin that he, like many other public officials, had been sporting since soon after Sept. 11. Obama could have responded that his new-found fashion minimalism was no big deal. What matters, obviously, is what you believe and do, not what you wear.

title: Fire Officials Tackle Challenges of High-Rise Blazes
description: In the smoky caldron of a high-rise fire, it is the firefighters worst nightmare: a door left ajar, a window that suddenly breaks under intense heat and a blast of wind.

title: Network of TVs Talks to Cellphones and Trades Clips for Advertising
description: A LITTLE-KNOWN private company, Akoo International, is setting up a network of digital screens that can send and receive messages from cellphones. The company aims to transform mobile devices into universal remote controls that can select on-demand content from big-screen TVs in airports, bars and restaurants.

title: Mother Is Held in L.I. Slaying of 3 Children
description: A Long Island woman described as emotionally disturbed and afraid of losing custody of her children called the police on Sunday and led officers into a blood-spattered bedroom where her young daughter and two small sons lay slain on a bed, investigators said.

title: Deliveryman Shot Dead in Argument on the East Side
description: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot on a Midtown street Sunday morning, the police said. The killing occurred just two blocks from his workplace, a company that copies and prints legal documents.

title: Locking in Viewers to Watch the Commercials
description: Looking to strike a blow against the proliferation of digital video recorders, the ABC network, its affiliated broadcast stations, and Cox Communications cable systems are establishing an on-demand video service that would allow viewers to watch ABC shows like Lost and Desperate Housewives any time they choose.

title: A Beef Scandal of Our Own Making
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex in the Cities
description: WASHINGTON

title: F.C.C. to Act on Delaying of Broadband Traffic
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The head of the Federal Communications Commission and other senior officials said on Monday that they were considering taking steps to discourage cable and telephone companies from discriminating against content providers as the broadband companies go about managing heavy Internet traffic that they say is clogging their networks.

title: Fewer Youths Jump Behind the Wheel at 16
description: DETROIT  For generations, drivers licenses have been tickets to freedom for Americas 16-year-olds, prompting many to line up at motor vehicle offices the day they were eligible to apply.

title: Respite for Alicia Keys
description: The Grammy Award-winning singer Alicia Keys, below, ordered by doctors to give her voice a rest, postponed concerts on Monday in Glasgow and Tuesday in Manchester, England, The Associated Press reported. Her publicity representative, Patti Webster, said Ms. Keys had laryngitis. The dates are to be rescheduled.

title: Slow Day Cant Keep Angler From Title
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  The spectator and media boats were starting to gather behind Alton Jones just after noon here Sunday as he started to build a seemingly insurmountable lead in the Bassmasters Classic. He was tucked in at a spot on Lake Hartwell the locals call Party Island, and camera shutters clicked and an ESPN broadcast crew bobbed in the water 75 yards away from where he was throwing his bait.

title: A Battle of Legal Briefs Rages Over 07 Nigerian Vote
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Just as Kenyas electoral crisis eases, a battle is brewing over a deeply flawed and highly contested election in another fractious, ethnically and religiously divided African nation, Nigeria.

title: Poles Apart on Online-Video Habits
description: The gulf between casual and heavy consumers of online video is startlingly wide, according to figures released in mid-February. Among people who watch at least some online video each month  from short clips on YouTube to full-length programs on NBC.com and the like  the highest-consuming fifth watches more than 140 times as much as the lower half.

title: On the Internet, Everyone Can Hear You Complain
description: A San Francisco start-up called Get Satisfaction is the latest online ombudsman to try to mediate customer service complaints.

title: Actress Playing Piaf Wins French Prize
description: For her portrayal of dith Piaf in La Vie en Rose, Marion Cotillard won the Csar for best actress when the French equivalent of the Academy Awards were announced on Friday in Paris, Reuters reported. The prize for best actor went to Mathieu Amalric for his performance as a man crippled by a stroke and able to communicate only by blinking an eyelid in The Diving Bell and the Butterfly. (Mr. Amalric was in Panama, playing the villain in the next James Bond film.) The directing award went to Abdellatif Kechiche, whose film La Graine et le Mulet (The Secret of the Grain), about an elderly shipyard worker who dreams of establishing a couscous restaurant, took best film.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Iraq Troop Level to Remain Elevated
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Defense Department is projecting that when the U.S. troop buildup in Iraq ends in July, there will be about 8,000 more troops on the ground than when it began in January 2007, a senior general said Monday.

title: Distrust of McCain Lingers Over 05 Deal on Judges
description: WASHINGTON  Back in 2005, Senator John McCain of Arizona and fellow members of the so-called Gang of 14 were hailed as heroes in some quarters when they fashioned an unusual pact that averted a Senate vote on banning filibusters against judicial nominees.

title: Spitzer and Aide Differ on Presidential Race, but Its a Free Country
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has endorsed Hillary Clinton, but one of his closest aides and friends, Lloyd Constantine, is solidly in Barack Obamas corner.

title: Pfizer to End Lipitor Campaign by Jarvik
description: Under criticism that its ads are misleading, Pfizer said Monday it would cancel a long-running advertising campaign using the artificial heart pioneer Dr. Robert Jarvik as a spokesman for its cholesterol drug Lipitor.

title: Holocaust Classes Are Seldom Easy on Children
description: When President Nicolas Sarkozy mandated recently that every French fifth grader would learn the life story of a French child who died at the hands of the Nazis, the proposal didnt exactly generate the overwhelming gratitude he might have expected from Holocaust educators in his country.

title: Justices Take Vehicle-Search Case
description: WASHINGTON  A seemingly routine drug arrest in Tucson, Ariz., will be reviewed by the Supreme Court to clarify the circumstances in which police officers who do not have a warrant can search the vehicle of a person who is under arrest.

title: Book Title Search Yields Weird Works
description: The polls are open in the annual balloting for the Diagram Prize, honoring the worlds oddest book title, Agence France-Presse reported. Conducted by The Bookseller, a British trade magazine, the vote at www.thebookseller.com asks participants to choose from six mostly nonfiction titles on the shortlist, culled from titles submitted by publishers, bookstore workers and librarians around the world. The nominees are I Was Tortured by the Pygmy Love Queen by Jasper McCutcheon; How to Write a How to Write Book by Brian Paddock; Are Women Human? And Other International Dialogues by Catharine A. MacKinnon; Cheese Problems Solved edited by P. L. H. McSweeney; If You Want Closure in Your Relationship, Start With Your Legs by Big Boom; and People Who Mattered in Southend and Beyond: From King Canute to Doctor Feelgood by Dee Gordon. The winner is to be announced on March 28. The prize has been offered since 1978, when the winner was Proceedings of the Second International Workshop on Nude Mice.

title: For Rangers, Five Goals and a Little Levity
description: When the Rangers captain, Jaromir Jagr, skated in for a picturesque goal Sunday night, drawing Florida goalie Tomas Vokoun out of his net and calmly sliding a backhand shot behind him, it was a snapshot of Jagr at his best, spectacular because it has happened so rarely this season.

title: Blogger, Sans Pajamas, Rakes Muck and a Prize
description: Of the many landmarks along a journalists career, two are among those that stand out: winning an award and making the government back down. Last week, Joshua Micah Marshall achieved both.

title: A Night With Stars of Phone and Rap
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  T-Pain! Seventeen million ring tones later!

title: Nader to Run, Citing Events of 2004 Race
description: When Ralph Nader ran as a third-party candidate in 2000 and drew 96,837 votes in Florida, he was widely derided by Democrats, who saw him as a spoiler who siphoned crucial votes from Al Gore and tipped the election to George W. Bush. When he ran again in 2004, Democrats in many states tried to keep him off their ballots.

title: Biofuel, Partly From Nuts, Is Tested on an Airline Flight
description: Virgin Atlantic Airways, the British carrier controlled by Richard Branson, tested a jumbo jet on Sunday that was partly powered by a biofuel made from babassu nuts and coconut oil, a first for a commercial aircraft.

title: Faulting UBS for Losses in Bad Debt, Bank Is to Sue
description: LONDON  HSH Nordbank, a state-controlled German bank, said Sunday that it planned to sue the Swiss bank UBS over a portfolio of complex debt products, which it contends that UBS improperly sold and mismanaged.

title: Got a Problem? Ask the Super
description: AS the race for the Democratic presidential nomination nears its end and attention turns to the role of so-called superdelegates in choosing the nominee, it is instructive to look at why my party created this class of delegates.

title: Countrywide Puts an End to Ski Junket
description: The weather forecast may call for snow and good skiing conditions in Avon, Colo., on Monday. But no one at the luxury resort, near Vail, will be hitting the slopes  or eating $105 Kobe steaks  on Countrywides dime this week.

title: The Sound of the 70s From a Singer in Her 20s
description: It may seem paradoxical to describe the driving hard-rock sound of Grace Potter and the Nocturnals as comfort music. But a sense of familiarity, of a time-honored ritual expertly and reverently re-enacted, is one of the attractions of this Vermont quartet, which played a 100-minute set at the Allen Room on Thursday evening as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series.

title: In Argentina, No Assistance From Region on Gas Needs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazil has declined to cede any natural gas shipments from Bolivia to Argentina, which is struggling to find more energy sources to help it avoid supply shortages that could derail its fast-growing economy.

title: At Governors Meeting, a Vice Presidential Buzz
description: WASHINGTON  Energy policy, health care and highways were the top issues on the agenda of the National Governors Association here Sunday, but many governors were consumed with presidential politics, buzzing about the possibility that the next vice president would come from their ranks.

title: Visa Plans $17 Billion Public Offering
description: Undaunted by recent turbulence in the financial markets, Visa Inc., the nations biggest credit-card network, said Monday that it would forge ahead with what would be the largest initial public stock offering in United States history.

title: Leipheimer Wins Title, but Uphill Climb Awaits
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Levi Leipheimer and his Astana cycling team came to the Tour of California with multiple goals, including successfully defending Leipheimers title and trying to convince the organizers of the Tour de France and the Giro dItalia that they made a mistake in excluding them from this years events.

title: In Calm Before the Storm, an Opportunity to Regroup
description: Heres a change that Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign really can believe in: There is no chance whatsoever that she will lose to Barack Obama this week.

title: A Hazardous Afterlife
description: Americans have a voracious appetite for new technology, but it comes with a cost not included on the price tag: electronic waste is the fastest-growing part of the garbage stream. Much of the equipment contains toxic substances, like mercury, lead and cadmium. And once in landfills and incinerators, the poisons are on their way into soil, water tables and the air. The problem can be controlled, but only if everyone commits to recycling.

title: In Painful Past, Hushed Worry About Obama
description: DALLAS  There is a hushed worry on the minds of many supporters of Senator Barack Obama, echoing in conversations from state to state, rally to rally: Will he be safe?

title: Home Resales and Prices Decline
description: The backlog of unsold homes continued to pile up in January, a sign that home prices will continue to drop as would-be buyers hold out for better deals.

title: A Clash of Titans, With Little Panache
description: Wladimir Klitschko has managed to bring some control to boxings heavyweight division, and set it back at the same time.

title: Living With Danger, and Wondering How to Live Without It
description: NEWPORT, Ind.

title: Liechtensteins Friendly Bankers
description: History records that the Liechtenstein family began purchasing the lands that now make up the tiny European principality in 1699 to secure a seat on the council of the Holy Roman Empire. It was several decades before any prince of Liechtenstein actually set foot in his fiefdom. That was the first use of the Alpine hideaway as an address of convenience for powerful Europeans.

title: Pressure on Young Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Douglas A. Fraser, 91, Union Chief Who Helped Chrysler, Is Dead
description: DETROIT  Douglas A. Fraser, who as president of the United Automobile Workers union agreed to concessions that helped the Chrysler Corporation avoid bankruptcy in the late 1970s, died late Saturday. He was 91.

title: When Puppet and Puppeteer Switch Places
description: Its not often that a piece makes you sit up straighter, wondering what it is exactly you are seeing, but these are the moments that lovers of the arts live for. And it happened on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam, which presented the first program of Gene Pool, a selection of offerings from 10 choreographers who all teach there.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The organizers of Advertising Week, which takes place in New York each September, formed a sister city partnership with Moscow, where the first Advertising Jubilee is scheduled for Sept. 22-28, 2008. That week is also when the Advertising Week events in New York are planned to take place.

title: Virginia and Vita, Still Linked After All These Years
description: Versatile though she is as an actor, Eileen Atkins might have built an entire career around her sideline: writing and performing pieces inspired by Virginia Woolf, like the one-woman show A Room of Ones Own. Her perceptive play Vita & Virginia deftly weaves the letters and diaries of Virginia Woolf and Vita Sackville-West into the story of the friendship  improbable, briefly physical and emotionally enduring  between the aloof literary genius Virginia and the aristocratic yet middle-brow novelist and poet Vita.

title: Vantage Point Looks at Substantial Income
description: Vantage Point, the gimmicky thriller that examines and re-examines the shooting of an American president from witnesses differing angles, took over the No. 1 ranking at North American box offices in its debut weekend. Starring Dennis Quaid, Forest Whitaker, Matthew Fox and Sigourney Weaver, the Columbia Pictures release drew an estimated $24 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers. Each of the previous weekends top films slipped a notch. Jumper (Fox) dropped to second place on a gross of $12.65 million, just ahead of The Spiderwick Chronicles (Fox and Nickelodeon) with $12.6 million. Fourth place went to Step Up 2 the Streets (Buena Vista), which took in $9.7 million. The No. 5 film was Fools Gold (Warner Brothers), with $6.2 million. Juno (Fox Searchlight) passed the $130 million mark in its 12th week in release, and The Counterfeiters (Sony Pictures Classics) led the competition in its debut by taking in an average of $12,559 on each of the eight screens where it played. Vantage Point, by comparison, averaged $7,621 a screen.

title: Banks Suit May Hurt Deal for Clear Channel Unit
description: Another buyout is in danger of collapsing  but this time because one of the banks involved is suing its own client, the private equity firm trying to do the deal.

title: Cink Is No Match for Woods. Right Now, Nobody Is.
description: MARANA, Ariz.  Tiger Woods scorched the high desert Sunday, roaring like a wildfire across the Gallery Club at Dove Mountain with a phenomenal display of golf, incinerating Stewart Cink, winning the Accenture Match Play Championship and setting his sights on higher ground.

title: New CDs
description: JANET JACKSON Discipline (Island Def Jam)

title: Game Maker in $2 Billion Bid for Rival
description: Electronic Arts, the video gaming giant, made an unsolicited $2 billion bid on Sunday for rival Take-Two Interactive, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, a deal that would further a wave of consolidation in the rapidly growing industry.

title: Raptors Dominate Knicks From Every Angle
description: TORONTO  The Knicks had big-man problems again Sunday night  at both ends of the court, on both benches, in the lane and 24 feet from the basket. They also had problems with small- and medium-size men, and just about everyone wearing a white Toronto Raptors jersey.

title: The Red (Cant Go Wrong) and the Black (Sober Is So 2008)
description: HOLLYWOOD  The movie industry must have woken up from the writers strike with a rotten hangover, unable to even think about frivolous things like parties and frocks. It was such a buzz kill that quite a few of the actors on the red carpet at the Academy Awards looked as if they either couldnt be bothered with fashion this year  so not superficial were they  or had dressed in the dark on a rainy Sunday afternoon.

title: Americans Change Faiths at Rising Rate, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  More than a quarter of adult Americans have left the faith of their childhood to join another religion or no religion, according to a new survey of religious affiliation by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

title: A Tale of Race and Family and a $10,000 Question
description: A Raisin in the Sun, which plays Monday night on ABC, is a cleanser for selves soiled by a thousand Millionaire Matchmakers. It is a noble enterprise never dulled by its good intentions. Starring core members of the cast of the 2004 Broadway revival of Lorraine Hansberrys 1959 play, the television adaptation offers polish and feeling, grievance and gut. It moves and it sings, even if the gifted Broadway musical star Audra McDonald, who appears as Ruth Younger, doesnt ever actually get to hit a note.

title: Golden Raspberries for Murphy and Lohan
description: Question: When are the winners losers? Answer: When the prize is the Golden Raspberry Awards, or Razzies. Eddie Murphy, top left and right, and Lindsay Lohan, above, were the big winner-losers when the Razzies founder, John Wilson,  presided over the annual awards ceremony on Saturday at a magic shop in Santa Monica, Calif., The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, who played a double role in I Know Who Killed Me, won two worst-actress trophies for that film, which received a record eight Razzies, including worst picture. Mr. Murphy amassed three Razzies as worst actor, supporting actor and supporting actress for the comedy Norbit.

title: The Skinny on the Mets New Reliever? Great Changeup, Bad Luck
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  His name is Matt Wise. Some people know him as Wiser, but that is a little boring. In Milwaukee, his former teammates dubbed him Woody because of his spooky resemblance to that character from the movie Toy Story. A few years ago, when he played with the Angels, a few of his friends started calling him Skeletor.

title: N.C.A.A. Isnt Allowing Athletes to Be Regular Students
description: Los Angeles

title: Huskers New Coach Promises to Heed Programs Old Ways
description: GRAND ISLAND, Neb.  It did not matter that it was 10 degrees outside, that they were missing work, that the Cornhuskers season opener was still six months away. The people of central Nebraska had come to see two of the most important men in the state. They already knew  and loved  Tom Osborne, the iconic former football coach, a three-term United States representative and the current athletic director.

title: Academy Award for Will Smith
description: Will Smith has won an academy award  the first Cadet Choice Movie Award, bestowed by the cadets of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. The accolade honors a fictional screen character who best personifies West Point leadership qualities. Mr. Smith, who received 27 percent of 2,200 online votes, was chosen for his portrayal of the Army virologist Robert Neville in I Am Legend, about a zombie-making virus that devastates Manhattan.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 40 at Iraq Highway Rest Stop
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber on Sunday attacked a crowd of Shiite pilgrims heading toward the city of Karbala to visit the Shrine of Imam Hussein, killing at least 40 people and wounding at least 100, Iraqi officials said. The American military said that at least 60 people had been wounded.

title: Chinese Submarine Fleet Is Growing, Analysts Say
description: BEIJING  Several recent events, from an eagle-eyed spotting of an image on Google Earth to an overt military delivery from Russia, suggest that China is continuing its rapid expansion of a submarine fleet that would be particularly useful in a conflict with the United States over Taiwan, analysts and military officials said.

title: Ray Wu, 79, a Genetic Transformer of Crops, Is Dead
description: Ray Wu, a biochemist and genetic engineer who helped lead research at Cornell University on genetically modifying rice and other crops to better withstand environmental stresses, died on Feb. 10 in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Lottery Numbers
Headed for Korea, Orchestra Gets Tips
description: BEIJING  Anti-American posters have become hard to find on the streets of Pyongyang, North Korea. The news media there have been presenting instructional pieces on Western orchestras. Officials in that isolated and poor nation are ready to play good hosts.

title: No Country for Old Men Wins Oscar Tug of War
description: HOLLYWOOD  No Country for Old Men, Joel and Ethan Coens chilling confrontation of a desperate man with a relentless killer, won the Academy Award for best picture on Sunday night, providing a more-than-satisfying ending for the makers of a film that many believed lacked one.

title: Serbian Rage in Kosovo: Last Gasp or First Breath?
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  Nationalist hooligans may have been behind the burning of the United States Embassy here, but the feelings of anger, sorrow and betrayal over the loss of Kosovo cut across all segments of Serbian society.

title: Rising Inflation Creates Unease in Middle East
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Even as it enriches Arab rulers, the recent oil-price boom is helping to fuel an extraordinary rise in the cost of food and other basic goods that is squeezing this regions middle class and setting off strikes, demonstrations and occasional riots from Morocco to the Persian Gulf.

title: Premieres Range in Palette From Balkans to Argentina
description: When writing ... hold me, neighbor, in this storm..., Aleksandra Vrebalov, a Serbian composer living in New York City, was inspired by the musical fusion of diverse cultures in the Balkans, artistic marriages that thrive in a region long troubled by ethnic intolerance.

title: Eclectic Public-Radio Show Has Found Its Voice
description: Riding the C train this month just after his move to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, from Atlanta, Terrance McKnight found himself in a car with a testifying Christian. Some New Yorkers would have retreated to a newspaper or an iPod; he whipped out his cellphone to record her mesmerizing lyrical cadences. He heard music there.

title: An Article Brings Sharp Responses From Russians
description: MOSCOW  Some readers called it blatant propaganda from the West. Others viewed it as a depressing expos that rang true. A third group said the facts did not matter, outsiders simply had no right to train a critical eye on their country.

title: Big Weekend Gives Zito Hope for the Derby
description: The last Sunday in February was good to the trainer Nick Zito. His best 3-year-old made a successful return to the races and a second stringer won the years first major Kentucky Derby prep race. With less than seven weeks to go to the Derby, it appears that the Zito stable is ready to play a strong hand on the first Saturday in May.

title: Economic Reports Scheduled for the Week
description: ECONOMIC SIGNALS Housing will lead off this weeks economic data, with existing-home sales for January (Monday) and new-home sales for January (Wednesday).

title: Taking Blows From All Sides and Weighing When to Punch Back
description: LORAIN, Ohio  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois is getting the customary greeting that the political tribe accords to apparent front-runners: He has taken rhetorical mortar shots from all sides.

title: New Jersey College Taking Div. III Play to a Higher Level
description: UNION, N.J.  On another frenzied night at Harwood Arena, the Kean University womens basketball team looked again like a Division I opponent in Division III clothing.

title: Yanks Quiet Bullpen Acquisition Impresses
description: TAMPA, Fla.  LaTroy Hawkins found a seat next to the veteran Bob Tewksbury on the Minnesota Twins bench in the top of the seventh inning on May 17, 1998.

title: Shhhhh! Emotions at Work
description: Some pianists, when performing Schumanns Kinderszenen, offer bold emotional contrasts, loudly evoking what seems like a disturbed childhood. But when Stephen Kovacevich played the work on Thursday, it felt as if he were whispering a bedtime story, inviting the audience to share memories almost too private to reveal.

title: At Cuba Helm, Castro Brother Stays the Course
description: HAVANA  Ral Castro, who has labored in the shadow of his brother Fidel since the days of their revolution, became Cubas new president on Sunday, ending his brothers 49-year rule and washing away hopes on this Communist island that a younger generation might take power.

title: A Byline Strike in Honolulu Extends to Newspapers Blogs
description: Writers sometimes take breaks from the daily demands of posting to a blog, but they rarely, if ever, stop posting in the name of a protest.

title: So Far, Time Has Been on Obamas Side
description: WASHINGTON  They are certainly premature, but the postmortems are beginning to roll in on Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign. Mrs. Clinton, looking ahead to Ohio and Texas next Tuesday, is clearly not yet out of the running. But should her candidacy ultimately fail, there will be a lot of blame to spread around.

title: A Sparkling Bit of Defense From a Man on a Hot Streak
description: The most successful player at the Winter Sectional in Woodbridge, N.J., two weeks ago was Richard Ross of Highland Park, N.J. In five events he had three firsts and two seconds with six different partners. (In the Swiss Teams he played with three of his four teammates.)

title: Footnotes
description: On Thursday the Metropolitan Museum of Art welcomed the millionth visitor to its New Greek and Roman Galleries, 10 months after their opening. The museum said the galleries, displaying Hellenistic, Etruscan, South Italian and Roman art, have attracted an average of 3,700 people a day, about 27 percent of the museums total attendance in that time. ... Off Broadway tickets costing $20 will be offered at box offices 20 minutes before the curtain rises at more than 20 shows from Monday through March 9 in the return of the 20at20 celebration. Information: www.offbroadway.com. ... Michel Legrand, above, winner of three Oscars and five Grammys and the composer of more than 200 film and television scores, as well as a pianist, vocalist, arranger and conductor, is to perform with the bassist Ron Carter and the drummer Lewis Nash at Birdland from Tuesday through Sunday. ... Barbara Cook will present Love Is Good for Anything That Ails You, a new program featuring songs by Irving Berlin, Rodgers & Hart, Burton Lane and Stephen Sondheim, among others, at the Caf Carlyle from March 4 through April 12.

title: Patriotism on the Sleeve, or in Disguise
description: Civility versus incivility might have been the subheading for a concert at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on Friday evening. For the latest in its American Voices series, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered four specimens of homegrown art.

title: Money and the Peoples Choices
description: A mind-boggling amount of money has already been spent on this years presidential election, and we havent even gotten to the conventions. The raising and doling out of lavish sums has been dispiriting to watch, a muddle of incompetence, avarice and special pleading, only vaguely restrained by the nations campaign finance laws. We sincerely hope that things improve before the general election onslaught.

title: Constraining the Medicare Debate
description: The Bush administration has just made several proposals  some sensible, some not  to reform Medicare financing and spending. Unfortunately, the exercise is seriously hobbled by an ill-advised 2003 law that prevents consideration of some of the best and fairest ways to begin fixing Medicare.

title: Moments to Savor After Battle for No. 1
description: MEMPHIS  Few people have a better perspective of the impact that Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl has had in Knoxville, Tenn., than Chris Lofton.

title: Prizes for Juno
description: Juno, the oh-so-popular little comedy about a pregnant 16-year-old, added to its accolades when it was named the best independent film of 2007 on Saturday at the Spirit Awards in Santa Monica, Calif., The Associated Press reported. Its star, Ellen Page, was chosen as best actress, and Diablo Cody, its writer, won for best first screenplay. Honors for best actor went to Philip Seymour Hoffman for his work in the sibling drama The Savages. The directing award went to Julian Schnabel for The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, based on the memoir of the French Elle magazine editor Jean-Dominique Bauby, who suffered a paralyzing stroke. The Spirit Awards, presented by the Film Independent organization, honors movies that cost less than $20 million and derive a significant part of their budget from outside the Hollywood studio system.

title: Brown Ends Tuition for Lower-Income Students
description: Brown University is eliminating tuition for students whose parents earn less than $60,000, after decisions by fellow Ivy League universities to bolster financial aid as their endowments grow.

title: In Mosaics, an Artists Lasting Impression
description: There is life in the hands of Manny Vega. With nothing more than a pair of pliers, thick fingers and boundless patience, he transforms thousands of stubby tiles of stone and glass into glimmering mosaic portraits of poets, drummers, mothers and sons. By the end of the workday, he has to plunge his numb, dust-covered hands into hot water to revive them.

title: German Vote Confirms Shift of Political Center to the Left
description: FRANKFURT  The successor to the East German Communist Party won representation in the legislature of the northern city of Hamburg on Sunday, confirming a leftward political shift across Germany.

title: A Falsetto for All Seasons
description: John Lloyd Young may have the role of a lifetime playing in the smash-hit Broadway musical Jersey Boys. But his New York concert debut at the Allen Room on Saturday evening as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series suggested that his career milestone could turn into a millstone.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,961 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

title: Adobe Blurs Line Between PC and Web
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On sabbatical in 2001 from Macromedia, Kevin Lynch, a software developer, was frustrated that he could not get to his Web data when he was off the Internet and annoyed that he could not get to his PC data when he was traveling.

title: Small Coffee Roaster Gets Ugly to Gain Recognition
description: Move over, Maria from West Side Story. A campaign for a coffee marketer is proclaiming that feeling pretty is overrated when it comes to your morning cup of joe.

title: Leap Year Day Is Special, and Marketers Know It
description: According to folklore, leap year day is the choice moment for women who have no interest in waiting for the guy to pop the question.

title: L.I. Duck Farms Struggle With Water Regulation
description: MORICHES, N.Y.  Long coops, each housing ducks of a different age, hug the ground and form a courtyard at the entrance to the Jurgielewicz family property  believed to be the only major free-range duck farm in the United States.

title: Montages, Wistful Flashbacks and a Few Lingering Clouds
description: Were they ready or rusty?

title: Taking the Long Way, Cantwell Reaches the Top
description: BOSTON  Christian Cantwell won the highly anticipated mens shot-put Sunday at the national indoor track and field championships. But his biggest victory was just getting here.

title: Grandfather Is Accused in Babys Injury
description: A 6-month-old infant in the Bronx suffered critical injuries on Saturday when she was accidentally struck by the head of a golf club that snapped off while her grandfather was swinging the club during an argument, the police said.

title: Texas Hispanics Face a Tough Choice in Primary
description: SAN ANTONIO  As recently as two weeks ago, Rudy Davila III, a pharmacist, was part of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons political firewall, the bloc of Hispanic voters from here to the border with Mexico whom she counted on to keep her presidential campaign from collapse. But the firewall is showing signs of cracking.

title: Born Irish, but With Illegal Parents
description: DUBLIN  Cork-born and proud of it, George-Jordan Dimbo is top to toe the Irish lad. He studies Gaelic, eats rashers, plays hurling, prays to the saints, papers his walls with parochial school awards, and spends Saturdays at the telly watching Dustin the Turkey, a wisecracking puppet, mock the powerful.

title: E-Newsletter Tracks Job Changes of Business Journalists
description: Late in 2006, a free e-mail newsletter sent by a company with an unusual name began to reach the overstuffed in-boxes of business reporters and editors, many of whom either skimmed it  or just deleted it.

title: Electronic Arts Offers $2 Billion for Take-Two
description: Electronic Arts, the video gaming giant, made an unsolicited $2 billion bid on Sunday for rival Take-Two Interactive, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, a deal that would further a wave of consolidation in the rapidly growing industry.

title: Go Vegetarian
description: To the Editor:

title: The Minefield of Health Insurance
description: A little over a week ago, I asked Shifting Careers readers to tell me about their experiences with health insurance. Ive been reading comments and e-mail about the sorry state of our health insurance system ever since.

title: See You at the Hoedown
description: The Bagger is switching 10/20s to the Governors Ball and will check in later with party blather. Thanks for all of you for checking in. Now go to bed.

title: This Land: A Protector, Enemy and Provider
description: For Newport, Ind., the removal of chemical weapons agents is a blessing and a curse.

title: Back in Business With the Combine
description: Our guest blogger of the week:

title: The 2008 Academy Award Winners
description: This year's Oscars celebrated an international selection of talent.

title: A Taste of Colombia, on Wheels
description: Rustic Colombian party buses called chivas are rolling through the streets of New York. Riders enjoy live music, drinks, and food while dancing the night away, on board.

title: What's Happening with My Favorite Shows?
And the Winner Isnt
description: Our review of the hastily prepared, strike-challenged Oscars broadcast says its host, Jon Stewart, had a few amusing lines but clearly didnt have time to put together a polished and cogent monologue. The main coverage notes that he riffed on the three-month walkout by writers:

title: China Railway Cuts I.P.O. Amid Weakening Demand
description: China Railway Construction has cut the size of its initial public offering in Shanghai amid signs a slew of new shares entering the market is overwhelming investor demand.

title: Aon Picks Up Arthur J. Gallagher Units
description: Aon said Friday that it has agreed to acquire Arthur J. Gallaghers reinsurance brokerage operations in the United States and Britain for $30 million, plus an additional sum based on the performance of the businesses in the coming year.

title: UBS Denies Report on Chairmans Term
description: UBS, Switzerlands largest bank, on Sunday denied a newspaper report that its chairman, Marcel Ospel, would definitely leave after another year at the helm, but reiterated that his future after that period was undecided.

title: 2 Ex-Marsh Officials Convicted on Antitrust Charge
description: Two former executives of Marsh, the insurance broker, were convicted Friday on an antitrust charge involving a bid-rigging case brought by New York State prosecutors.

title: Rval Bidders Drop Pursuit of Biffa
description: Shares in Biffa , a British waste management company, fell more than 6 percent Monday after the company disclosed that all but one bidder for the business had dropped out.

title: China Fund to Spend $10 Billion in Japan, Report Says
description: Chinas increasingly aggressive sovereign wealth fund is poised to unleash a $10 billion investment spree in Japan and is initially expected to set its sights on the energy sector, The Times of London reported.

title: Faulting UBS for Losses in Bad Debt, Bank Is to Sue
description: HSH Nordbank, a state-controlled German bank, said Sunday that it planned to sue the Swiss bank UBS over a portfolio of complex debt products it contends were mismanaged and improperly sold by UBS.

title: Offers for Morgan Stanleys Stake in China Capital Said to Be Cut
description: Three suitors vying for Morgan Stanleys stake in China International Capital Corporation have cut the value of their offers, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Unexpected Retirement at the Top of Vanguard
description: The Vanguard Group, a fund manager known for its low-cost portfolios, surprised the industry on Friday when it announced that its chief executive, John J. Brennan, would step down.

title: Microsoft Announces $3 Million Fund for Health Care Applications
description: Got a good idea for a health care application? If so, you could get as much as $500,000 in funding from Microsoft.

title: T Magazines Oscars Wins
description: Congratulations to Tilda Swinton and Marion Cotillard, who won top honors at last nights Academy Awards. Both ladies played leading roles on the cover of T Magazine and we couldnt be more proud of them. Ms. Cotillard won best actress for La Vie en Rose and Ms. Swintons role as a corporate climber in Michael Clayton paid off. Get caught up on Hollywoods new royalty: read Ts profiles of this years  best actress and best supporting actress.

title: A Capitalist Jolt for Charity
description: Philanthropies, discovering that for-profit status and financing can be a useful tool, are changing their spots and making use of some of capitalisms virtues, The New York Times reports.

title: Royal Bank of Canada Scoops Up Phillips Hager for $1.35 Billion
description: Royal Bank of Canada has won one of Canadas last remaining independent money managers with a 1.36 billion Canadian dollar ($1.35 billion) takeover bid for Phillips Hager & North Investment Management.

title: United Said to Mull Options as Delta-Northwest Talks Drag On
description: United Airlines is pondering its strategic options as stalled talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines threaten other linkups, including a potential tie-up between United and Continental Airlines, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Temasek: The Rise of Singapore Inc.
description: Temasek Holdings, a decades-old Singaporean sovereign wealth fund, has its roots as a financial backer of domestic companies. In recent years, however, Temasek has moved aggressively, first within Southeast Asia, then Asia as a whole and finally to the West. It has acquired stakes in critical industries such as telecommunications and in companies that are household names, most recently Merrill Lynch.

title: Countrywide Puts an End to Bankers Ski Junket
description: The weather forecast may call for snow and good skiing conditions in Avon, Colo., on Monday. But no one at the luxury resort, near Aspen, will be hitting the slopes  or eating $105 Kobe steaks  on Countrywides dime this week.

title: Maybe Microsoft Should Stalk Different Prey
description: Having exhausted its best ideas on how to deal with Google, Microsoft is now working its way down the list to dubious ones  like pursuing a hostile bid for Yahoo, says Randall Stross, writing in The New York Times.

title: New Threat to Clear Channel Unit Sale
description: Another buyout is in danger of collapsing  but this time because one of the banks involved is suing its own client, the private equity firm trying to do the deal.

title: Prince, ONeal, Mozilo to Testify Before Congress on Pay
description: Two former Wall Street chieftains and the head of the nations largest home lender will testify next week before a congressional committee examining the link between executive pay and the mortgage crisis.

title: Nymex-CME Deal May Be Announced in March, Report Says
description: A deal between the CME Group and The New York Mercantile Exchange to create a $40 billion futures trading powerhouse could be formally announced by early March, The New York Post reported.

title: Cablevision Said to Hire Bear Stearns as Adviser
description: Cablevision has been quietly working with Bear Stearns on ways to enhance shareholder value, including putting a value on its Rainbow Media unit ahead of a possible sale and drawing up a list of targets for potential acquisitions, according to The New York Post.

title: Messengers of Sound
description: The New York Philharmonic readies to make its historic journey to Pyongyang, North Korea.

title: Citi Hedge Funds Get Credit Line
description: Citigroup said on Friday that it had provided a $500 million line of credit to its Falcon multistrategy fixed-income hedge funds, and as a result will move the funds $10 billion of assets and liabilities onto its balance sheet.

title: T Party | Last Nights Fete In Paris
description: (Stephane Feugere for The New York Times)

title: Internal E-Mails
description: To: Mouth@Body.comFrom: Stomach@Body.com

title: Sorting the Mortgage Victims From Those Who Volunteered
description: Over the last two decades, few industries have lobbied more ferociously or effectively than banks to get the government out of its business and to obtain freer rein for financial innovation.

title: DN Capital Connects With iFamily
description: Londons DN Capital has provided $1.5 million in Series A funding to iFamily, a New York start-up whose Familybuilder application seeks to update the Web genealogy market by tapping into the power of social networks.

title: Whack Museum
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: RBS Shares Rise on Report of Potential Qatar Stake Purchase
description: Shares in the Royal Bank of Scotland jumped more than 5 percent on Monday on hope that Qatars sovereign wealth fund could take a stake and the expectation it will lift its dividend and post strong results this week.

title: Glam Raises $85 Million in Funding
description: Glam Media, a network of fashion, style and entertainment Web sites, said Monday it had raised $65 million in new venture funding and $20 million in revenue-based debt financing. The latest financing round was led by Hubert Burda Media, a German publishing group, and includes GLG Partners, a publicly traded hedge-fund firm.

title: Iraq Returns to the Stage in Congress
description: Congress returns from a week-long break today as senators anticipate the reappearance of an issue that has been relegated to the background so far in 2008  the war in Iraq.

title: Visa Offering Could Set U.S. Record
description: Behold the power of plastic: Visa said Monday that its highly anticipated stock sale could raise nearly $18.8 billion, which would make it the largest initial public offering in United States history. In an updated regulatory filing, the credit-card giant said it would sell as many as 446.6 million shares for an expected $37 to $42 per share.

title: Not Too Shabby
description: The Bagger went 16-8 (a correction from PriceWaterhouseCoopers to the Baggers original report of 18-6) on his picks, not magnificent, but good enough in a complicated year. (You can see the winners here.)

title: How Virtuous is Ed Begley Jr.?
description: My colleague Andy Revkin recently had a good chat with Ed Begley Jr. during a pedicab ride in New York, which you can watch at DotEarth. It was the perfect vehicle for discussing Mr. Begleys famed green lifestyle, and it got me wondering: Is a pedicab really more virtuous environmentally than a taxi?

title: Bonjour From Colette!
description: This week, The Moment is coming to you live from our new Paris headquarters, Colette. T Magazine has invaded Pariss chicest boutique, where were showing off our films, flaunting our Web site, giving away our new womens fashion issue and making friends with the cool crowd. If youve never been, Colette is more than a hip shop  its ground zero for Pariss fashion-week scene. Imagine the coolest product-design store with well-curated fashion, books, the best in beauty products, and a subterranean bar that specializes in premium water. Cant wrap your head around it? Stay tuned this week for more news from the shop and its owner, Sarah, who is our guest blogger.More On Colette:

title: Brinks Plans Home-Security Spinoff
description: The Brinks Company, which has been under pressure from activist investors, said Monday it would spin off its home security unit into a separately traded company, Reuters reported.

title: Covering Its Bets
description: What is an outfit to do when it is confronted by all manner of movies with no runaway hit? Why not spread the hardware around? When the Bagger went to the Governors Ball following the awards, he noticed that the Oscars were very evenly distributed about the room, as were the smiles.

title: Studying the Blowtorch Effect on Governors Island
description: The fearsome blowtorch effect, which has killed 11 people in New York City fires since 1980, has drawn firefighters and engineers to Governors Island in an expanding search across the nation for better ways to prevent or contain high-rise infernos, Thomas J. Lueck reports.

title: Getty Images to Sell Itself for $2.4 Billion
description: Getty Images, the worlds biggest pictures and video distributor, agreed Monday to sell itself to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman for $2.4 billion including debt.

title: Where Do You Find Peace in New York?
description: Allan Ishacs New Yorks 50 Best Places to Find Peace and Quiet, a guidebook he started in 1991, offers a rich trove of suggestions for any New Yorker who wants to get away from  but perhaps not too far away from  the busy bustle of the city. But keeping the list fresh has required Mr. Ishac to make some editorial choices over the years. Earlier editions recommended the Russian and Turkish Baths, but then Mr. Ishac heard from readers who felt an uncomfortable vibe from other clients. Mr. Ishac also removed the Carapan Day Spa after a reader told him she had been yelled by the staff for complaining about construction noise. (The spas staff confirmed the customers account. The spa has since closed and is now a boutique health club called Clay.)

title: Jerry Yang Calls on Sue Decker to Bolster Pitch
description: CORRECTION: See end.

title: The Early Word: Nice No More
description: Democrats Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama exchanged niceties at a debate last week in Austin, Texas. Over the weekend, however, Mrs. Clinton took a decidedly different tone against Mr. Obama (calling his message one of magic wands and celestial choirs) and said she couldnt wait to debate him in Ohio.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: Positive Signs For Spanish-Language Mas Vale Tarde
description: In December TV Decoder noted that Telemundo introduced a new late-night talk show, Mas Vale Tarde con Alex Cambert. In Sundays New York Times, Marc Weingarten notes that it is a radical experiment for Spanish-language television, and finds some encouraging signs for the show:

title: Red Carpet at the Oscars
description: Despite the rain, the stars looked stunning at the 80th Academy Awards.

title: Locking in Viewers to Watch the Commercials
description: Bill Carter reports in Mondays Times:

title: Pakistan Blamed for Worldwide YouTube Break
description: If all had gone according to plan, Pakistan would have been the latest government taking part in an unsettling trend from Brazil to Thailand: YouTube blocking. Unlike its predecessors, though, Pakistan also affected thousands of people beyond its borders.

title: They Dont Call Him Angler for Nothing
description: Hes still only one man, but hes also still two branches of government: Vice President Cheney is still clinging to the notion that his duties as president of the Senate make him part of the legislative branch as well as the executive branch, a Washington Post editorial notes.

title: Take-Two Rejects Takeover Bid
description: CNBC's David Faber looks at Electronic Arts' unsolicited offer for the maker of Grand Theft Auto and what the game giant's options are.

title: The Answer Man: Ordering As You Go
description: A reader recently wrote to ask me what is going on with restaurants that insist on diners ordering everything from beginning to end at once?

title: ABC Promotes Dancing and Oprahs Big Give During Oscars
description: To get a sense of which television shows are priorities for ABC, look no further than the house ads during the Academy Awards.

title: The Return of the Mega-Offering
description: Consumers arent the only ones with a weakness for credit cards. Wall Street appears to have a nearly insatiable appetite for them, judging from the proposed size of Visas initial public offering, which it described in a regulatory filing on Monday.

title: Trial Starts for Detectives in Bell Shooting
description: Updated, 1:08 p.m. | Prosecutors and defense lawyers offered sharply differing accounts this morning of the November 2006 shooting that killed Sean Bell, as the trial of three New York City police detectives charged with killing Mr. Bell began in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: Why PATH Rides Are Free Today
description: One hundred years ago, a nickel bought admission to what President Theodore Roosevelt called the greatest subaqueous tunnel in the world and a bigger undertaking than any Alpine tunnel which has yet been constructed. He meant the Hudson & Manhattan Railroad, which linked New Jersey and New York for the first time on Feb. 25, 1908.Today, admission is free.

title: New Obstacle to Clear Channel Deal
description: As a deal to sell Clear Channel's TV stations looked near, Wachovia now seeks to back out. CNBC's David Faber explains.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Graphics Director Steve Duenes
description: Steve Duenes, graphics director for The Times, is answering reader questions Feb. 25-29, 2008.

title: At HBO, a Touch of Clairvoyance
description: HBO looked awfully smart on Sunday night. The premium cable channel bought the rights to the film Taxi to the Dark Side last week, just days before it received the Academy Award for best documentary feature.

title: CNBC Video: Faber on Take-Two and EA
description: The unsolicited  and possibly hostile  deals keep on coming. The latest example hit Sunday when Electronic Arts, the video game giant, made a $2 billion offer for a rival, Take-Two Interactive Software. Take-Two, the maker of the wildly popular Grand Theft Auto series, quickly rebuffed the bid.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: IndyCar: Its official. As reported last week, the Champ Car World Series will fold into the Indy Racing League this season. The I.R.L. schedule will expand from 16 races to 19, and it will include the Long Beach Grand Prix, which had been on the Champ Car calendar.

title: Burgled in the Burg
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Securing Santanas Signature
description: Collecting autographs is one of the essential parts of spring training. Fans carry baseballs, caps, pictures and jerseys and hope that their favorite players stop and sign them.

title: Take-Two Rejects EA Bid
description: CNBC interviess Andrew Ross Sorkin of The Times about why Take-Two rejected Electronic Arts' unsolicited $2 billion offer.

title: Recipe of the Day: Sauted Scallops Stuffed With Basil
description: The sea scallop is one of the most perfect of natures convenience foods  because almost nothing cooks faster. Theyre also in season through most of the year. Make sure you buy dry scallops  they should not be sitting in liquid (and they should smell like the sea).

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Saturday Night Live Takes On Drug Ads
description: At a time when the drug industry is facing increasing scrutiny from Congress and the public, the cast of Saturday Night Live has weighed in with a hilarious spoof of television drug ads.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Messengers of Sound
description: The New York Philharmonic readies to make its historic journey to Pyongyang, North Korea.

title: Obama Photo Becomes an Issue
description: The Clinton campaign struck back today at suggestions that it was behind the release of a photo of Senator Barack Obama in African garb. In an intriguing response to the Obama campaigns charges, the Clinton campaign manager, Maggie Williams, turned the matter on its head: it essentially suggested the Obama campaign was deriding ethnic dress by making an issue of the photo. At the same time, it did not deny any role in distributing the photo. Heres her statement:Enough.

title: Lessons From Hawaii
description: A larger and more spirited crowd of 23,000 turned out in Hawaii for the final two games of the Pan-Pacific Championship.

title: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Atlantic Edition
description: Today, with the NHL stretch run heating up, we start a new feature here on Slap Shot at The Times: Hockey Night in Blogdom. Why? Because a newspaper or TV network has never been able to capture the passions of fans who avidly follow a professional sport and, after all, make the whole thing happen. And besides, whos more passionate than hockey fans? So well be asking specific questions of 30 independent bloggers, one for each league club, and through their fevered rantings theyll tell us about the team they support and express their, ahem, core beliefs.

title: So Far, Time Has Been on Obamas Side
description: In his column today, Adam Nagourney writes, that political analysts and journalists, in judging a candidacy gone bad, invariably focus on a campaigns bad moves and wrong turns, with a dash of the requisite infighting among powerful staff aides and complaints by contributors. And the Clinton campaign, after starting off smoothly and with such self-assurance, provided a wealth of that: Wasted money, bad strategic calls on what states to contest, a message that failed to grasp how the mood of Democrats had changed and the questionable deployment of a certain former president.But could even the best-operated campaign have done better against Mr. Obama?

title: The Northeast Joins America
description: There is plenty of bad news in the existing home sales report, even if there was a slight uptick in the seasonally adjusted annual rate of single family sales. Actual sales  the monthly number before the seasonal adjustment  are the lowest in a decade for single family homes. For condos, where they have been keeping the data only since 1999, the figure is a record low.

title: Video-Game Deals: Whos Next?
description: In December, when Activision and Vivendi Games announced they were joining forces, Brent Thill, an analyst at Citigroup, said we expect further industry consolidation. He named Take-Two Interactive, which makes the popular video-game series Grand Theft Auto, as a potential takeover target.

title: Doggy Gastronomy in Paris
description: Since I first smelled ginger and peanut butter pupcakes baking at Mon Bon Chien, Ive been following the ongoing adventures of Hat Sternstein, an indefatiguable American baker whose grand ambition is to secure an exalted place for canine gastronomy in Paris.>By Richard Harbus

title: Scandalous?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Yang: Microsoft Bid Was a Galvanizing Event for Yahoo
description: If Jerry Yang is upset that Microsoft bid to buy the company he co-founded 13 years ago, it didnt prompt any angry words as he spoke Monday morning at the Interactive Advertising Bureaus annual meeting in Phoenix. Rather, he talked about how the bid for Yahoo and the companys frenzied search for a way to fend it off has been an exciting journey of self discovery.

title: Did an Offense Turn Fireable on YouTube?
description: Did Ian Wilkinson, described in news accounts as a respected pilot nearing retirement, get fired for the attention drawn by the following video clip, and not the Top Gun-style stunt captured therein?

title: Harry Dodge and Stanya Kahn
description: An excerpt from "Can't Swallow It, Can't Spit It Out."

title: Sanchez Returns to the Mound
description: UPDATE: Duaner Sanchez, pitching in his first competitive situation since July 28, 2006, allowed two hits and struck out one while pitching the second inning of the Mets intrasquad game Monday. He threw 26 pitches.

title: Calm Before the Storm
description: John Harwood talks about Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton's strategies for this week.

title: Reviewing Jon Stewarts Starring Role
description: Political satirist Jon Stewart returned as Oscar host on Sunday with a slew of jokes about the bitter Hollywood writers strike that had threatened the show and the grim, violent themes of many of the films, Reuters reports.

title: Media Blackout Update: Pakistan and Alabama?
description: Governments that try to keep a firm grip on information flow in their countries, like the Kremlin, have used technical problems as an excuse to shut out unwelcome content on the Web and television. But could it have happened in the United States?

title: Oscar Ratings Are Way Down
description: Early ratings for the 80th annual Academy Awards suggest the program may have attracted a significantly smaller audience than in previous years.

title: For the Moment | Sarah from Colette
description: (Jessica Antola)

title: The View From Paris, Part Two
description: For many years, the feeling among my friends was that you couldnt get a bad meal in Paris, or even in France. Thats changed, of course. Chalk it up to globalization or anything else you like. But the feeling remained that the serious restaurants were still serious, and that, music and odd clothing aside, the French, especially Parisians, really understood good taste.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Feb. 25:

title: Putting 2-and-20 to the Auction Test
description: Two and 20 is a time-honored formula in high finance, and the 20 refers to the percentage of a venture capital or private equity funds profit that usually flows to the managers of that fund.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: A Reception in Sounds
description: Related Article: North Korea Welcomes New York Philharmonic

title: Guzan Disappointed but Not Distraught
description: It was a long, long plane trip back to California from England for Brad Guzan late in January. The Chivas USA goalkeeper was oh-so-close to being up and gone to Aston Villa of the Premier League. Enter the bureaucrats.

title: Visa: Bailing Out The Banks
description: Visa plans to go publc this spring, and the prospectus filed today indicates that it will get $15.6 billion (after deducting about $481 million in underwriting fees) from the offering if it is sold at $39.50 a share, the mid-point of its offering range.

title: Analysts See More Pain for Citi
description: Analysts at Goldman Sachs said they expect additional write-downs of about $1 billion to $12 billion each for several major United States brokers in the first quarter, with Citigroup forecast to record the highest write-down of about $12 billion.

title: Missing 60 Minutes In Alabama
description: A controversy has been brewing on the Web since a 60 Minutes segment failed to appear on a CBS affiliated TV station in Alabama last night, sister blog The Lede reports. The report covered a bitter flashpoint between Democrats and the Bush administration: the case of Don Siegelman, a former Democratic governor of Alabama who was jailed for corruption last June. Read more

title: Waiting for the First Shoes to Drop
description: With the N.H.L. trading deadline lurking Tuesday, it seems odd that some teams would not have gotten started early making some of these moves. I know Trading Day is an unofficial holiday in Canada, but some people do opt to open presents on Christmas Eve too.

title: The Bunker Goes Paperless
description: My wife is usually right about things. It just takes the bunker a little time to make his way around the block before reaching this conclusion. Mrs. Bunker has often asked me, once she has pushed her way around a stack of newspapers waiting to be read, Couldnt you read all this on the Web.

title: Net Neutrality Hearing: When Is an Internet Traffic Delay O.K.?
description: UPDATED

title: You Decode: The 80th Annual Academy Awards
description: The 80th annual Academy Awards were produced under a palpable sense of pressure. The host, Jon Stewart, had little time to prepare material due to the writers strike, and the executive producer, Gil Cates, had lengthy clip reels ready in case the actors didnt show up.

title: Veterans Group Takes On McCain
description: VoteVets, a group of veterans from the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, plans to broadcast a cable television advertisement attacking Senator John McCain, the only veteran in the presidential race.

title: Previous Forays Into Paris
description: The numerous comments on my first Paris post made me look back to a couple of my more recent pieces about Paris, both of which appeared in the Travel section of The Times. The first was a little foray into the world of steak frites. And the second, my favorite falafel.

title: Poll: Obama Rises in Voter Popularity
description: Voters opinions of the top three presidential candidates have shifted significantly over the past two months, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: New Jerseys Dilemma: Raise More Revenue or Cut Spending?
description: Governor Jon Corzine was once chief executive officer of Wall Street uberfirm Goldman, Sachs, but he seems to be having trouble working fiscal magic on New Jerseys troubled finances. He also seems to be about to change his approach  under pressure from legislators and the public  from raising more revenue to cutting spending.

title: Bright Lights at Night, Perhaps Not Such a Delight
description: A new study that shows women who live in areas with brighter nighttime illumination have an increased chance of developing breast cancer drew attention from the folks at City Room.

title: Odd Man Out of Oscar Tribute
description: The Oscars ceremony last night included a feature honoring people who died in the past year, but one of the most prominent deaths in the past year was not included. But the Academy told TMZ.com said that the decision had nothing to do with the way Brad Renfro, 25, died (heroin overdose) or the quality of his work (The Client, Apt Pupil).

title: Clinton Stresses Foreign Policy Credentials
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sought to portray herself as the strongest candidate on foreign policy in a speech Monday afternoon, telling an audience that she was tested and ready to be commander in chief.

title: Wondrous Cesspools
description: If you miss the old Times Square but dont feel like sitting through Taxi Driver again, check out the expanded edition of Tales of Times Square, published this month by Feral House.

title: Girardi Will Be Watching Closely
description: Sometimes, you can learn a lot about a manager or player from what might first seem like a throw-away line. After practice today we were talking with Joe Girardi, and he was asked how much he was looking forward to games.

title: Cross-Culturalisms
description: The Bagger was very busy stuffing crab claws and shrimp into his baggie-lined pockets at the Governors Ball last night, but did actually have a notebook in there as well. He discovered that the growing cosmopolitanism of a traditionally ingrown industry is good for the business, filmgoers and the movies themselves.

title: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Southeast Edition
description: Continuing with our roll call of independent bloggers, here are five representing the hot and humid Southeast Division. The teams appear in the order of their standing at the time we post this.

title: A Vaccine for Boys to Help Girls?
description: As a parent of a school-age daughter, I havent decided what to think about the new cervical cancer vaccine. Thats why I was interested to learn the shot may soon be given to boys primarily to benefit girls.

title: The Little Things
description: I had the chance to see Villanovas 67-65 victory over UConn on Saturday. It was everything a Big East conference game should be. It featured two talented squads in a great atmosphere and the refs let the players play. Once a player got inside the paint he had to fend for himself.The refs werent bailing anyone out.

title: An Alternate Theory of Nixzmary Browns Death
description: A veteran medical examiner testified in the Nixzmary Brown case today that Nixzmary was killed only by a blow to the head, and not by a combination of a blow, long-term child abuse and malnutrition that prosecutors have cited as the cause of her death.The testimony was elicited by the lawyer for Nixzmarys stepfather, Cesar Rodriguez, in an effort to persuade the jury to focus only on one blow, rather than on the history of beatings to which Mr. Rodriguez has admitted.

title: Charges Against TV Anchor Are Reduced
description: Alycia Lane, the former Philadelphia television news anchor who was arrested last December for punching a police officer in Manhattan, walked out of Criminal Court in Manhattan a free woman today. Prosecutors promised to drop the charges, Judge Dena E. Douglas told her, if she stayed out of trouble for six months and performed one day of community service.

title: Altidore Skips Austria
description: The Red Bulls left Monday for an 11-day training camp in Salzburg, Austria, home of the teams corporate parent, without one of their rising young stars.

title: Bruno Says Hes Confident of Unions Support
description: Brimming with confidence, the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, declared today that he still had the solid backing of one of the states most powerful labor unions  no matter what campaign finance reports might show.

title: To Pave or Not to Pave?
description: John had warned us that the City of Anna Maria would require that our new driveway allow for sufficient rainwater drainage. But until last week, we hadnt realized that the drainage solution would cost us $3,395 above the cost of building the driveway. That was the estimate from Adkins Contracting, a city-approved firm that installs drainage pipe.

title: Paul Frres death
description: He was 91 years old, he lived an incredibly full life. He drove for Ferrari, raced in 11 Grand Prixs in the 1950s. He won the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1960. He was cultivated, wrote much (in English and French) and continued testing cars and writing until he was in his 80s  in fact, he was still wickedly fast at 87, setting respectably fast laptimes in an Audi that would later win Le Mans.

title: Rangers Pre-Deadline News on Mara: Ouch
description: The Rangers quest for help on defense just got a little more urgent with the news that defenseman Paul Mara will undergo surgery to repair facial fractures sustained in Saturdays game against Buffalo.

title: Satellite Shootdown Deemed A Successful Mission
description: The morning after the Pentagon slammed a missile into a dying satellite  an act deemed unprecedented at the outset  the face of the mission refrained from a full-on celebration, even though all signs pointed to one being in store.

title: Soft Serve | Bubbly Vodka, Stripping for a New Scent, Dress a Clock in Neon
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.And the Oscar goes to Soft Serve! We may be jealous of last nights winners and their golden statuettes, but the Oscar swag is decidedly lackluster since going green: toe pillows, doggie GPS, and mini-kegs Sparkling Vodka? Now theres a cutting-edge beverage that should have made the cut Wed like to be nominated for an opening night drink at The Standard New York. Andre Balazs to-be-completed hotel will have a bar on the 18th floor Speaking of killer views, Agent Provocateur recently staged a scantily clad model in the windows at Selfridges for the launch of its new fragrance, aptly named Strip Looking to draw the blinds? Magnetic curtains will chicly shield you from prying eyes JFK was not the poster boy for discretion, but his Omega timepiece certainly had an understated elegance. Snatch up a limited edition commemorative replica for $8,250 New York Magazines Best Bets has some unconventional options for keeping time. Go for the old-school glam of a wood block LED or turn up the heat on an old clock and bedeck it with glowing color Keep the colder elements and dirt off your car with wiperless windshields If youre a fan of getting dirty, Detergent T-shirts will only reveal their true intentions after youve thrown them in the wash Soft Serve is throwing in the towel. Check out our fluffy goodness again tomorrow.

title: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Pacific Edition
description: Next we call on the bloggers of the deserts and the freeways, where, as Easterners drift off to slumber, the third period is just getting under way.
