title: Forsberg Headed Back to Avalanche
description: After his agent threw cold water on the idea of a comeback just last week, Peter Forsberg has decided to return to the Colorado Avalanche for the rest of the season.

title: Answers About Nature in New York
description: Following is a first set of answers from Leslie Day, the author of Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), who is taking questions from readers through Feb. 29.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Scenes from Pyongyang
description: Slide Show

title: 80th Oscars Officially Lowest-Rated Ever
description: Ratings for Sunday nights Oscar presentations were the lowest ever, according to preliminary Nielsen figures, and down nearly 20 percent from last years broadcast of the event.

title: Is the New York Accent Disappearing?
description: Writing in amNewYork today, Rolando Pujol takes a fascinating look at the New York accent and concludes that the accent, while subject to the forces of homogenization, is alive and, if not well, then at least evolving. (And most experts do not think it varies by borough or neighborhood.)

title: About That Raise Youre Not Getting . . .
description: For most Americans, paychecks are shrinking, as the graph below shows.

title: Taking Down the Fourth Wall
description: I urge anyone following this discussion to give some close attention to our readers comments. Were incredibly lucky to have attracted an accomplished crew of actors, directors, screenwriters and playwrights  on top of all the other dedicated, careful readers who keep us in business. Im highlighting some of the comments that struck me below. But all of them are worth reading.

title: Weiner Expands Middle-Class Themes
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner continued hammering away today at his theme of making New York City a more hospitable place for the middle class, emphasizing the theme that is likely to guide his run for the Democratic nomination for mayor next year.

title: Rescuing the Dogs of War
description: Operation Baghdad Pups brought two dogs who were rescued in Baghdad by American soldiers to Kennedy International Airport this past weekend. The two dogs, Liberty and K-Pot, were escorted from Iraq by Terri Crisp, a program manager with Operation Baghdad Pups, who had gone over to retrieve them.

title: Dior: Can We Tease More?
description: You cant smoke in the cafes anymore, the French president is married to a former model, and if the models at Dior had worn bigger wigs and hair pieces, they would have tipped over and broken a nail. Franceor, anyway, French fashionseems confused. Coco Rocha motored down the runway at Dior today like a little tractor cutting through a snow drift. Her teased hair and painted eye lids looked that heavy. She had to manage the whole thing, along with her gown. The press notes to John Gallianos show, taking a line from a Dior press statement in 1961, said, Never forget the woman.

title: Times Election Fight
description: The hedge funds seeking to elect directors at The New York Times Company were buying shares until the last minute, as I speculated a few days ago. They now have 19 percent of the publicly traded Class A shares, according to their latest S.E.C. filing.

title: Lessig Decides Against Run for Congress at Internet Speed
description: Just like any good Web story, this one took just five days to go from tantalizing to nothing more than that. Silicon Valley will not be represented by an Internet icon in the House of Representatives, not for a couple of years anyway.

title: Some Big Love
description: I love to see a big man creating shots for his teammates. Its the ultimate unselfish play. When guards make a fancy pass they get an assist, but if a big man sets a monstrous screen the only satisfaction he gets is the crunch of a guard crumbling to the floor.

title: New Times/CBS Poll: Obama More Likely to Beat McCain
description: The latest survey of voters nationwide by The Times and CBS News has just been released.

title: Live From New York, an Endorsement for Clinton
J.C. Penney Launches American Living
description: Scenes from an idealized America in J.C. Penney's new line  of products.

title: Barack Obama's No J.F.K.
description: David Frum of the American Enterprise Institute and John Judis of The New Republic debate the Obama-Kennedy analogy.

title: Another Day, Another Ditch
description: Every once in a while, the Democratic primary campaign pitches into the most curious ditches. So much of Monday was spent talking, behind the scenes and through surrogates, about a sort of costume party.

title: Rocco DiSpirito for Bertolli
description: A TV chef plugs a contest on what it takes to assemble a  romantic night in.

title: Ford Promotes 'New Beginnings'
description: Ford's videos aim to highlight work opportunities after Ford and dispel workers' potential fears of venturing out again in search of a new career.

title: Last-Minute Ballot Ruling in Upstate Senate Race
description: The Republican candidate in a closely contested special election for an open State Senate seat will also be listed on the ballot as a candidate for the Independence Party, following a state Court of Appeals ruling on Monday. In such a tight race, having an affiliation with the Independence Party  the states third-largest  could be one of several factors that helps tip the balance.

title: Diane Von Furstenberg on Fashion
description: Von Furstenberg discusses her life and fashion in a spot  for American Express.

title: Renzi Says He Wont Resign
description: Representative Rick Renzi, the Arizona Republican who was indicted last week by a federal grand jury on 35 corruption charges, issued a statement on Monday saying that he would not resign despite signals from Republican leaders in Congress that they would welcome his swift departure.

title: John Kerry Smacking His Forehead
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link bleow):

title: How to Pick the Ideal Reference
description: A few weeks ago, a friend and colleague whose company is looking for investors e-mailed me to ask if Id be willing to be a reference for her. I didnt hesitate to say yes. I have complete respect for the woman and even if we didnt have any time to chat beforehand, I knew what I would say when the reference checker called. A few days ago, I got another request to be a reference  this one from a professional contact I barely know. I declined, trying to be as polite as possible.

title: Google and the Undersea Cable
description: Google said Monday that it was part of a six-company consortium that would build a new $300 million high-capacity underwater fiber-optic cable linking the United States and Japan.

title: Time to Count the Doughnuts
description: If your eyes glazed over at revelations that Hillary Rodham Clinton used $1,200 from her campaign war chest to splurge on Dunkin Donuts, that expense turns out to be just the icing on the cake.

title: The Final Frontier
description: Normally, Jon Stewart noted Sunday night at the Oscars, when you see a black man or a woman president, an asteroid is about to hit the Statue of Liberty.

title: Our Exhausted Oceans
description: Heaps of abalone shells in Santa Barbara, Calif., from a 1920 postcard. (Census of Marine Life)

title: Before They Vanish
description: Population and fishing are taking their toll on coral reefs.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Let Us Now Praise Minders  and Great Men
description: Its Tuesday morning in the D.P.R.K., and this will be brief, because one of my minders, whom Ill call Kim 1, is pressing me to leave for the bus. Supposed to be 9:30 a.m. The program has changed, he said. So it must be at 9. Things have been highly regimented here, with an emphasis on sticking to the schedule. It may be an effort at maintaining control. A diplomat with long experience in Pyongyang said officialdom here hates surprises, because they can be unpleasant.

title: Lightning Trades Prospal, Agrees to Deal With Boyle
description: Versus is reporting that the Philadelphia Flyers have acquired forward Vaclav Prospal from the Tampa Bay Lightning for defenseman Alexandre Picard and a conditional pick in the 2009 draft.

title: Dear Irrational Reader: Close the Door!
description: Dear Reader, dont take this personally, but the data are in and youre not looking very rational, at least not when it comes to closing doors.

title: Spain Must Sell Market Booming
description: With the market floundering, the foreclosure rate in Spain has more than doubled in recent years, according to industry estimates.

title: Security Details
description: On the trail with Barack Obama and the Secret Service.

title: Poll Shows Obama Is Seen as More Likely to Beat McCain
description: WASHINGTON  In the past two months, Senator Barack Obama has built a commanding coalition among Democratic voters, with especially strong support among men, and is now viewed by most Democrats as the candidate best able to defeat Senator John McCain, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Human Shadows on the Seas
description: In 1980, after college, I joined the crew of a sailboat partway through a circumnavigation of the globe. Becalmed and roasting one day during a 21-day crossing of the western Indian Ocean, several of us dived over the side. Within a few swimming strokes, the bobbing hull seemed a toy over my shoulder as I glanced back through my diving mask. Below me, my shadow and the boats dwindled to the vanishing point in the two-mile-deep water. Human activity seemed nothing when set against the sea itself.

title: Patterns: If You Keep Your Cool, You May Heal Faster
description: People who have trouble controlling their temper may take longer to heal from an injury, a new study finds.

title: Counting the Homeless to Help End Their Plight
description: NEW HAVEN  Looming over a shuttered nightclub by Interstate 91 is a billboard featuring fistfuls of cash and a brassy promise that Connecticut Lottery players could win $100,000 a year in perpetuity and be Set for Life.

title: New York City to Help Doctors Track Patients Records Electronically
description: After two years of planning and a public investment of more than $60 million, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Monday that New York City was ready to equip doctors with computer software that can track patients medical records in order to provide better preventive care.

title: Stephen Marlowe, 79, Detective Novelist, Dies
description: Stephen Marlowe, a prolific writer of popular fiction best known for his crime novels featuring the globe-trotting private eye Chester Drum, died on Friday in Williamsburg, Va. He was 79 and lived in Williamsburg.

title: Where Science and Design Collide, a Few Weird Sights to Behold
description: In the drawing, a nude man and woman stand on either side of a wall. Each wears a plastic breathing mask that covers the nose and mouth; the masks are connected to air hoses that pass through the wall. The hoses attach to pouches at each others underarms and crotches.

title: Dodd Endorses Obama for President
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a leading Democrat and an early candidate for the partys presidential nomination, announced Tuesday that he was endorsing Senator Barack Obama.

title: Lottery Numbers
As Inflation Rises, Home Values Slump, Data Show
description: Two worrisome trends for the economy  falling house prices and the rising cost of everything else  picked up speed in data reported on Tuesday, putting policy makers in an increasingly tough position.

title: Pfizer to End Lipitor Ads by Jarvik
description: Under criticism that its ads are misleading, Pfizer said Monday that it would cancel a long-running advertising campaign using the artificial heart pioneer Robert Jarvik as a spokesman for its cholesterol drug Lipitor.

title: Taliban Threatens Afghan Cellphone Companies
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The Taliban have demanded that all four cellphone companies in Afghanistan cease operating at night or face attacks on their offices and communication towers, according to a statement released to journalists on Monday.

title: A Twice-Told Tale of Addiction: By Father, by Son
description: David Sheff and his 25-year-old son, Nic, are so close these days, so much on the same wavelength, that they sometimes finish each others sentences. There was a time when they werent even speaking.

title: The Advantages of Closing a Few Doors
description: The next time youre juggling options  which friend to see, which house to buy, which career to pursue  try asking yourself this question: What would Xiang Yu do?

title: Opening a Hornets Nest (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf in Retreat: Why the Bunker Mentality?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pieces of Texas Turn Primary Into a Puzzle
description: CRAWFORD, Tex.  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton issued her gunslingers invitation to Senator Barack Obama recently, challenging him to meet me in Texas, the question many people here asked was, Which one?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about Cai Guo-Qiang: I Want to Believe, at the Guggenheim Museum, misidentified the southern Chinese city where Mr. Cai was born and raised. It is Quanzhou, not Guangzhou.

title: New Grand Jury Is Impaneled in L.I. Murders From 1988
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Almost 19 years after the murders of Seymour and Arlene Tankleff in their Belle Terre home, a new grand jury has been impaneled to determine who might have killed the Long Island couple, a prosecutor said.

title: Court Considers Protecting Drug Makers From Lawsuits
description: WASHINGTON  Less than a week after issuing a sweeping ruling that bars most lawsuits against medical device makers, the Supreme Court heard arguments Monday in the first of two cases that could determine whether drug makers receive similar protection.

title: Attention on Evidence Shifts to Testing for Fingerprints
description: One of the more intriguing elements in the confrontation between Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee has been whether the needles, syringes, gauze pads and vials that McNamee turned over to federal authorities contain Clemenss DNA or traces of steroids or human growth hormone.

title: Bush Cool to States Call for Public Works Projects
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush rebuffed appeals from the nations governors on Monday to increase spending on roads, bridges and other public works as a way to revive the economy.

title: Yankees Open to Extension for Cashman
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Hank Steinbrenner, the Yankees senior vice president, said Monday that he was open to discussing a contract extension for General Manager Brian Cashman.

title: Police Said to Have Assaulted Rights Lawyer in China
description: SHANGHAI  One of Chinas best-known human rights lawyers has been repeatedly beaten by police officers outside his home here in recent days, according to his wife and associates.

title: Mergers in a Time of Bears
description: Most mergers fail.

title: Two Men Stabbed at Jewelry Outlet
description: Two men were stabbed on Monday at their Manhattan jewelry business by a business associate who claimed they owed him money, the police said.

title: Students Return to an Altered Campus After Shootings
description: DeKALB, Ill.  Under a hard, gray sleet, students at Northern Illinois University trudged back to class on Monday for the first time since a gunman burst into a lecture hall on Feb. 14 and killed five students and himself.

title: It Went By in a Blur: PATHs 100th
description: You couldnt miss the 100th anniversary of the New York City subway in 2004. There were speeches, banners, slogans, displays, events and a shelf full of books to mark the milestone for posterity: Subways, A Century of Subways, Subwayland, Subway Memoirs, The Subway Pictures, Subway Style, The Subway and the City.

title: A Driving Force
description: Maybe he cant help himself. If William Manchester is to be believed, Ralph Nader got a fair amount of his exasperating, nonstop, take-no-prisoners-style of proselytizing from his father, Nathra, who owned a restaurant and bakery in the factory town of Winsted, Conn.

title: Station Says 60 Minutes Blackout Was Just Technical
description: A television station in Huntsville, Ala., offered viewers nothing but a black screen for 12 minutes Sunday night  at the exact time that the CBS News program 60 Minutes was broadcasting a report about potential political skulduggery involving the former Bush administration official Karl Rove in the conviction of a former Democratic governor of the state.

title: Democrats Mount New Attack on War Policies
description: WASHINGTON  Undeterred by President Bush and Senator John McCains proud talk of progress in Iraq, Congressional Democrats have begun mounting new lines of attack against the administrations war policies.

title: Body Discovered in Queens Blaze
description: A firefighters union official accused the Fire Department of a three-minute delay in sending enough trucks to a burning house where a Queens woman was found dead on Monday.

title: Republican Gets Second Line in a Special Election Upstate
description: ALBANY  The Republican candidate in Tuesdays hotly contested special election for a vacant State Senate seat will also be listed on the ballot as the candidate of the Independence Party, the states highest court ruled on Monday.

title: A Little Help for His Friends
description: Congress is looking into the decision by the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher Christie, to hand former Attorney General John Ashcroft a hugely lucrative job monitoring a wayward company.

title: F.C.C. Fines Fox
description: Putting pixels on body parts didnt save Fox from the wrath of the Federal Communications Commission. The agency has rejected the networks contention that an episode of the defunct reality program Married to America did not violate decency standards because female breasts and buttocks were pixelized during a raunchy bachelor party scene in 2003, Reuters reported. The commission said: To be sure, the pixelation of the female strippers naked breasts and buttocks does render the material less explicit and graphic than it would have been in the absence of pixilation. However, the material is still sufficiently graphic and explicit to support an indecency ruling. Fox disagreed. The commission, acting against only those stations subjected to complaints, fined 13 stations and affiliates $7,000 each. Last week it fined ABC stations and affiliates a total of $1.2 million for showing a womans bare buttock during an episode of N.Y.P.D. Blue in 2003. ABC paid but will appeal. The Supreme Court is expected to consider on Friday if it will hear the F.C.C.s appeal of an appeals court decision that declared its rulings against fleeting profanities to be arbitrary and capricious.

title: Ralph Nader: Going, Going, Not Gone
description: The real question about Ralph Naders political nadir is this: are we there yet? Once he was the hero of Americans who wanted safer automobiles, drugs, toys and food. Since then, Mr. Nader has been known for running and running and running  and now running again for president.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page picture caption on Saturday with the This Weekend summary carried an erroneous credit in some editions. The photograph of a wounded soldier in Afghanistan was by Lynsey Addario for The New York Times, not by Joshua Lott.

title: Beginning With the Unfamiliar, Then Concluding With the Ever-Present
description: To conservative ears, recitals like Markus Grohs at the Frick Collection on Sunday can be said to taketh away, then giveth back. This young German pianist held the attention of the curious and the jaded for the first half of his program with 20th-century music by Erwin Schulhoff, Gyorgy Kurtag, Ligeti and Alberto Ginastera. The ubiquitous B minor Sonata of Liszt arrived after intermission almost as an apology for any inconvenience suffered earlier.

title: Oscar Hangs His Head as Commercials Disappoint
description: FANS of advertising who watched the Academy Awards could be excused for wishing that Javier Bardem had come onstage to accept his Oscar for best supporting actor toting the stun gun his character wielded in No Country for Old Men.

title: Now Boarding Business Class
description: For a long time, low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways have had a reputation for catering to leisure travelers  in fact, half of Southwests passengers and 75 percent of JetBlues customers fit in that category.

title: Yazoo Pumps, R.I.P.?
description: Stephen Johnson, the embattled career scientist who runs the Environmental Protection Agency, seems ready to defy Congress on an issue that his more politically connected predecessors ducked. Mr. Johnson has all but decided to cancel the Yazoo Pumps, a flood control scheme in the Mississippi Delta that is potentially the most environmentally destructive project undertaken by the Army Corps of Engineers at Congresss request.

title: In Boston, Mayor and Librarian Clash Over Control
description: BOSTON  If this city is known for both intellectual heft and political blood sport, the Boston Public Library, one of its proudest institutions, aligns itself strictly with the former. But in recent months, the august library has been at the center of some nasty political tussles.

title: Justices Send Age Case to Lower Court
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court declined on Tuesday to hand down a definitive ruling in an age-discrimination case from Kansas, declaring instead that the case must go back to federal district court for clarification.

title: In Visit, Cellists Quest for Lost Chord to His Youth
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea  For much of his 60 years, Valentin Hirsu has thought of those three Korean boys in his class.

title: Tracking the Rise and Decline of Dust in the Western U.S.
description: The world is a dusty place. If you dont believe that, just look under your bed. But its dusty on regional and global scales, too, largely because of soil erosion caused by winds.

title: Nyc Marathon Registration Begins
description: Officials of the New York City Marathon started accepting lottery applications Monday for the Nov. 2 race on their Web site. Applications will be accepted until June 1 for those with a United States address and until May 1 for nonresidents and runners eligible for a guaranteed entry. The applications are being accepted online at ingnycmarathon.org. The entry fee for runners chosen in the lottery and those with guaranteed entries are $125 for New York Road Runners members, $155 for nonmembers and $210 for international entries.

title: Getty Images Agrees to Be Acquired by a Private Equity Firm
description: Getty Images, the worlds biggest distributor of pictures and video, agreed on Monday to sell itself to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman for $2.4 billion including debt.

title: Max Raab, Maker of Fashion and Film, Dies at 81
description: Max L. Raab, whose apparel company helped extend the button-down preppy look of the early 1960s to womens clothing and who then moved into the film industry as an executive producer of several mind-bending movies, including A Clockwork Orange, died Feb. 21 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 81.

title: Perez Hilton Could Play New Role: A&R Man
description: LOS ANGELES  Mario Lavandeira, known to millions of fans as the gossip blogger Perez Hilton, has a habit of humiliating celebrities he dislikes by doodling explicit images across their photos on his Web site. But he has also long used perezhilton.com to rave about his favorite new music. And now the results of his effusive postings  you will be foaming at the mouth!  have attracted the notice of a major record label.

title: Defense Casts Girls Injury as Sole Cause of Her Death
description: A veteran medical examiner testified on Monday that 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown died solely from a blow to the head  not from the blow combined with chronic abuse and malnutrition, as the prosecution contends.

title: Knicks Curry Playing Less, Questioning More
description: Eddy Curry is not obsolete. He is sure of that much. Yes, the N.B.A. has changed in strange and wondrous ways, downsizing its centers and moving them away from the basket. Yes, Curry now looks like a throwback, with his mammoth frame and short-range skills.

title: In Los Angeles, Oscar Statues Become a Popular Export
description: LOS ANGELES  The morning after the Academy Awards dawned here with a realization: There will be a lot of gold leaving Los Angeles in the next few days.

title: Airline Says Crew Acted Appropriately Before Death
description: American Airlines officials on Monday disputed accounts by relatives of a woman who died aboard a flight from Haiti to New York on Friday. The airline said that oxygen canisters on the plane were full and that oxygen had been administered in a timely manner to the passenger after she had trouble breathing.

title: Therapists and Therapy (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tortuous Path That Led to Those Central Park Gates
description: How long did it take Christo and Jeanne-Claude to realize The Gates? Heres a reminder: One of the four directors of The Gates, an HBO documentary about that saffron-hued extravaganza in Central Park, has been dead since 1987.

title: Screening: Dialysis Can Lower Blood Sugar Readings
description: A common test to see how well diabetics control blood-sugar levels tends to give misleadingly good news when the patients are on hemodialysis, researchers say.

title: Guilty Verdict for 5 in A.I.G. Case
description: Five former insurance executives were found guilty Monday of fraud and conspiracy in a scheme to manipulate the financial statements of the insurance company American International Group.

title: Is That Your Final Question?
description: Tonight, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama will debate in Ohio. It will be the 20th debate, and possibly the last, of the Democratic presidential campaign. Is there anything left to ask? The Opinion section asked five experts to pose the questions that they feel have not been answered over the course of more than a year of campaigning. Heres what they would ask the candidates if they were moderating tonights debate.

title: Goalkeeper Stays in M.L.S., for Now
description: It was a long, long airborne trek back to California for Brad Guzan in late January. Guzan, an up-and-coming goalkeeper for Chivas USA and the United States national team, was oh-so-close to moving to Aston Villa of the English Premier League. Enter the bureaucrats.

title: Thank You for the Coffee, Maam. Your Tip Is at the Stable.
description: WALLER, Tex.  As a widowed waitress struggling to make ends meet, A. D. Carrol has received some good tips over the years. Once in an airport V.I.P. club in San Francisco, stranded businessmen tipped her $600. In a Texas steak house, a happy patron left $500 on the table.

title: The Right to Counsel, in the Right Situations
description: Zacarias Moussaoui would seem to have little to complain about. He is an admitted member of Al Qaeda. He has pleaded guilty to plotting to commit mass murder. He was tried in a federal court in Virginia before a judge who generally seemed attentive to his constitutional rights. And he was spared the death penalty.

title: Midwest Hit by Winter Storm
description: A winter storm moved across the upper Midwest early Tuesday dropping snow, sleet and rain on the region and is expected to cause travel delays in the Northeast later in the day, particularly at airports.

title: New Jersey Schools Told to Discard Suspect Beef
description: Nearly a quarter of New Jerseys 615 school districts may have received beef unfit for human food from a California slaughterhouse through a federal school lunch assistance program, state agriculture officials said on Monday.

title: New DVDs: Jean-Luc Godard
description: JEAN-LUC GODARD

title: Justices Weigh if Cash Hidden Is Cash Laundered
description: WASHINGTON  In colloquial terms, money laundering means cleaning dirty money  the proceeds of a drug transaction, for example  by using it in a way that hides its origins and gives it the appearance of legitimate wealth.

title: In Precise Movements, a Russian Sense of Drama
description: The Russian National Orchestra, with its young and energetic players, seemed like an upstart band when Mikhail Pletnev founded it in 1990, but he quickly established it as an important ensemble in the post-Soviet music world. The orchestra has also had a fruitful relationship with Vladimir Jurowski, the 35-year-old Russian firebrand who became its principal guest conductor in 2005.

title: Mature Artist Celebrates Her Roots (and Flowering)
description: When you perform music, something gets in your psyche, the composer and pianist Joan Tower said before a concert at the Chelsea Art Museum on Saturday honoring her 70th birthday. It was the first of three events in the St. Lukes Chamber Ensembles Second Helpings contemporary-music series exploring the influences of Ms. Tower, who concludes her 10th and last season as St. Lukes composer in residence this year.

title: For Crowds at Courthouse, Just Being There Is the Point
description: Monty Street was not a friend or relative of Sean Bell. He never even met Mr. Bell.

title: Death Risk Found From Anemia Drugs
description: Widely used anemia drugs sold by Amgen and Johnson & Johnson raise the risk of death among cancer patients by about 10 percent, according to a new analysis of previous clinical trials that was published Wednesday.

title: Bid for Game Maker Seen as Effort to Buy Innovation
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Creating a video game costs around $20 million. So for $2 billion, Electronic Arts could develop 100 new titles.

title: Selling Gold at I.M.F. to Rebuild Its Finances
description: WASHINGTON  For decades, the International Monetary Fund has played a pivotal role in rescuing insolvent countries and stabilizing the world economy. But after years of budget problems, the fund received approval on Monday from the Bush administration to sell gold bullion to stabilize its own shaky finances.

title: Talking With Children About Sex and AIDS: At What Age to Start?
description: What age is the right age to have the talk, not just about where babies come from, but also about sex and AIDS?

title: F.C.C. Weighing Limits on Slowing Web Traffic
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The head of the Federal Communications Commission and other senior officials said on Monday that they were considering taking steps to discourage cable and telephone companies from delaying the downloads and uploads of heavy Internet users.

title: Green Fuel (Literally) (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Power Restored After Blackout
description: The power was restored to all but a few areas of South Florida on Tuesday afternoon, the utility company that supplies electricity to the region, Florida Power & Light said.

title: Azerbaijans Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Blog Helps a Yankee Connect With Fans
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It was a month or so before the start of spring training, and Phil Hughes had no weekend plans. Hughes is 21 and single, a Californian living in Tampa, and he needed some advice.

title: Russian Candidate Denounces Kosovo
description: MOSCOW  Dmitri A. Medvedev, Russias first deputy prime minister and the presumptive successor to President Vladimir V. Putin, on Monday committed the Kremlin to long-term support for Serbia against an independent Kosovo.

title: California: No Candidacy for Internet Scholar
description: The Internet scholar Lawrence Lessig decided not to run for a vacant seat in the House of Representatives. Mr. Lessig, the founder of the Center for Internet and Society at Stanford University, had posted a Web video last week hinting of a run for Californias 12th Congressional District, which was held by Representative Tom Lantos, who died on Feb. 11. Mr. Lessig used the same medium to convey a different message Monday, saying that despite seeing an outpouring of support, he had also seen a poll showing him losing in a big way to the favored candidate, former State Senator Jackie Speier. Mr. Lessig said he would instead to try to change Congress from the outside. Losing big in the first important battle is not an effective strategy, Mr. Lessig said. My running and losing big would do more harm than good. The special election to replace Mr. Lantos is scheduled for April 8.

title: Catching Up on Family Values
description: Members of Congress and state legislatures talk about family values. But unlike those in other developed countries, they have not done much to help workers with new babies or sick family members. The New Jersey Legislature is in position to become just the third state to address this problem.

title: After Facing Accusations, News Anchor Walks Free
description: Alycia Lane, the former Philadelphia television news anchor who was arrested in December for punching a police officer in Manhattan, walked out of Criminal Court in Manhattan a free woman on Monday. Prosecutors promised to drop the charges, Judge Dena E. Douglas told her, if she stayed out of trouble for six months and performed one day of community service.

title: Blast Kills Surgeon General of Pakistani Army
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A top Pakistani Army general was killed Monday when a suicide attacker approached his car at a traffic light in Rawalpindi and blew himself up, military officials said.

title: California Creates Cabinet Post to Manage Volunteers
description: LOS ANGELES  California is a state with frequent natural disasters and vast numbers of people who want to help. But Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger says a recent oil spill in San Francisco Bay helped demonstrate that volunteerism can be moved a notch.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Countrywide Financials decision to cancel a gathering of bankers at the Ritz-Carlton Bachelor Gulch ski resort in Avon, Colo., referred incorrectly to the resorts location. It is near Vail, Colo., not Aspen.

title: Savoring a Moment in the Sun, Despite a Court Date
description: NEWARK  Lil Wayne had three things to explain. No. 1, a religious confession: I believe in God and his son, Jesus. Do you? He interpreted the roar as an affirmative response. No. 2, a professional confession: He said he was nothing without the fans, adding, Make some noise for what you created! Noise was made. No. 3: Same as No. 2. More noise.

title: Congress May Single Out Clemens
description: A Congressional committee has taken the first steps toward asking the Department of Justice to start a criminal investigation into whether Roger Clemens committed perjury during testimony about performance-enhancing drugs, according to three lawyers with knowledge of the matter.

title: Peking Opera Plays Chinas Schools
description: China plans to promote its traditional culture by adding Peking Opera to the music curriculum in 200 schools in 10 provinces, Reuters reported. The aim of this program is to help the children develop an interest in the nations unique cultural treasures, said Wang Jun, a cultural official in the Beijing Education Bureau. But hot on the heels of the announcement, reported on Monday in The Beijing News, came critics who complained on the Internet that untrained teachers and forced instruction might discourage students from this 200-year-old art, characterized by complex gestures and trilling vocals. An Internet user who called himself Little Monkey, said, If the students are forced to learn, it might backfire and make them totally lose interest.

title: Yahoo Plans to Let Users Help Mold New Feature
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Even as it struggles to find alternatives to being acquired by Microsoft, Yahoo continues to push elements of a turnaround plan devised by Jerry Yang, the companys co-founder and chief executive.

title: Union Theological Gets New President
description: Union Theological Seminary in New York City named the Rev. Dr. Serene Jones, 48, as its new president, making her the first woman to hold the post in the institutions 172-year history. Currently a professor of theology at Yale Divinity School and chairwoman of its department of Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies, Dr. Jones is only the fourth woman to run an independent, mainline school of theology in the country. In the case of Union, Dr. Jones is taking on an institution emerging from serious financial problems.

title: The Wharton House: A Window Into a Writers Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Robotic Championship Bout Raises Questions for Boxing
description: Boxing will survive Wladimir Klitschkos spiritless defeat of Sultan Ibragimov on Saturday night. And the heavyweights will stumble on without stardom or charisma.

title: A Review of Prostate Cancer Leaves Men in a Muddle
description: A diagnosis of prostate cancer is scary enough. But just as scary is that nobody can tell a man the best way to treat it.

title: I.B.M. to Introduce a Notably Improved Mainframe
description: The mainframe, the aged yet surprisingly resilient survivor of computing, is getting a face-lift. A model called the I.B.M. z10, which is being introduced Tuesday, is far faster and has three times the data-juggling memory of its three-year-old predecessor, the z9.

title: Researchers Develop a Type of Rubber That Can Repair Itself
description: Flubber was pretty good stuff. The super-rubber of a 1961 Disney film starring Fred MacMurray (and of a 1997 remake starring Robin Williams) could literally make people jump through basketball hoops.

title: Siemens Plans to Cut Up to 7,000 Jobs
description: Siemens plans on Tuesday to announce that it intends to eliminate up to 7,000 jobs, or 40 percent of the workers in its troubled business telecommunications unit in Germany and Brazil, as it seeks a buyer for the business, a person with direct knowledge of the situation said.

title: McCain Says Prospects May Hinge on Iraq
description: ROCKY RIVER, Ohio  Senator John McCain said Monday that he needed to convince the American people that the troop escalation in Iraq was working and that American casualties there would continue to decline. If he did not, he said, I lose the election.

title: Other Countries Join Tax Inquiry
description: FRANKFURT  Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes at home.

title: In Merger Matters, Little Talk About Travelers
description: MARCH MADNESS may soon be upon us. No, you havent stumbled by mistake onto the sports pages. When I talk about March Madness and the makeup of the Final Four, Im talking about the airline industry in the United States and the prospect that it is on the verge of fundamental consolidation.

title: Tempelsman Sculptures Return to Italy
description: After a long battle two rare sixth-century B.C. marble sculptures that once belonged to the New York businessman Maurice Tempelsman go on view Tuesday at Italys presidential palace. For nearly 30 years rumors circulated that tomb robbers had dug up the statues on a hillside in the ancient Greek settlement of Morgantina in Sicily. After amassing evidence that they were looted, Italian investigators began seeking a handover of the acroliths  statues usually made with wooden torsos but with stone heads and extremities  in the late 1980s. Mr. Tempelsman, a diamond importer perhaps best known for having been the companion of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, remained unswayed until the Italian government threatened to sue him, an official said Monday. He hadnt wanted to give them up because hed paid for them; thats what he told me, said Mario Bondioli Osio, who formerly headed of an Italian commission that sought to recover the countrys lost cultural patrimony. Mr. Tempelsman, who was said to be traveling and unavailable for comment, bought the acroliths from the London dealer Robin Symes in 1980 for a reported $1 million. In 2002 Mr. Bondioli Osio, Mr. Tempelsman and the University of Virginia worked out a deal under which Mr. Tempelsman would give the university partial ownership of the statues for five years and then cede them entirely. On Jan. 1 the acroliths  their wooden bodies long ago lost, leaving two heads, three hands and three feet  became the property of the university, which promptly returned them to Italy. The statues, one of which is shown above, arrived in Rome on Friday along with nine classical antiquities from the private collection of the New York philanthropist Shelby White that were ceded to Italy in January under a separate pact. Italy says Ms. Whites artifacts were also looted from Italian soil.

title: North Korea Welcomes New York Philharmonic
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea  Projected on a scrim, the gently falling snow speckled the precisely twirling figures at the Mansudae Art Theater in a dance depiction of Korean Communists guerrilla action against the Japanese. At the climax, a nighttime scene of downtown Pyongyang materialized, with warm lights glowing in the high-rise buildings.

title: Tigers Off-Season Moves Forge a Lineup Without a Weak Link
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Ivn Rodrguez will be paid $13 million this season to play catcher for the Detroit Tigers and bat eighth. This is not a glamorous lineup spot for a veteran power hitter who could reach the Hall of Fame.

title: Cochlear Implant Supports an Authors Active Life
description: Josh Swiller was 22 and profoundly deaf when he applied to the Peace Corps in search of adventure. And indeed, adventure he found. His experiences in Zambia are eloquently recounted in his hard-to-put-down memoir of deafness and Africa, The Unheard (Holt, 2007).

title: Union Spends Heavily for Obama in Primaries
description: The powerful Service Employees International Union  whose local chapters helped John Edwards in the Iowa caucus  is now pouring cash and manpower into helping Senator Barack Obama in the Texas and Ohio primaries.

title: Snchez Is Back In the Game
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The fans who packed the stands surrounding Field No. 7 for Mondays intrasquad game screamed Jos Reyess name and clapped for Jon Niese and roared for David Wright. But they fell silent, eerily so, when Duaner Snchez jogged toward the mound and picked up a ball.

title: California: Study of Immigrants and Crime
description: Immigrants in the state, about 35 percent of adults, are far less likely than native-born Americans to commit crimes, according to a study by the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group. Among men ages 18 to 40, the group most likely to commit crimes, native-born Americans were 10 times more likely than immigrants to be incarcerated for crimes in California prisons and jails. The study included both legal and illegal immigrants, without focusing separately on illegal immigrants. But it found that native-born American men ages 18 to 40 were at least eight times more likely to be imprisoned for crimes than Mexican immigrants in that age range who were not naturalized citizens  a group likely to have a high percentage of illegal immigrants.

title: Is It Time for Clemens to Dial Nanny 911?
description: The nanny, it turns out, speaks English and speaks it well, idioms and all.

title: Mental Abilities: Dementia Percentages Decline for Elderly
description: Were not growing older. Were growing sharper.

title: Investing in Our Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: The Encyclopedia of Life, No Bookshelf Required
description: Imagine the Book of All Species: a single volume made up of one-page descriptions of every species known to science. On one page is the blue-footed booby. On another, the Douglas fir. Another, the oyster mushroom. If you owned the Book of All Species, you would need quite a bookshelf to hold it. Just to cover the 1.8 million known species, the book would have to be more than 300 feet long. And youd have to be ready to expand the bookshelf strikingly, because scientists estimate there are 10 times more species waiting to be discovered.

title: British Museums Told to Clean House
description: The Museums Association, founded in 1889 to represent Britains museums and galleries, reversed a 30-year ban on selling art and urged its 1,500 members on Monday to get rid of objects that are gathering dust, the BBC reported. Museums typically collect a thousand times as many things as they get rid of, Mark Taylor, the associations director, said in a posting on its Web site (museumsassociation.org.). Wonderful collections can become a burden unless they are cleared of unused objects. The association told its members to give unused art to other museums or public institutions or, in exceptional circumstances, to sell it. The organization expressed hope that its new policy would encourage museums to put some pieces on display, and said it expected only a few sales each year. Vanessa Trevelyan, convener of the associations ethics committee and head of Norfolk Museum and Archaeology Service, said, Although disposal of items is not without risk, it is preferable to transfer items to an alternative home where they will be treasured, rather than retain material that is not supporting a museums research, display or interpretation functions.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about suggestions that the economy may be entering a period of stagflation misspelled the surname of an investment strategist who commented on moves to bolster the economy. He is David Darst, not Durst.

title: Belarus: Opposition Prisoner Vows to Starve Himself
description: Aleksandr V. Kazulin, a former presidential candidate who has been serving a five-and-a-half-year prison sentence since leading anti-government demonstrations in 2006, said that he would refuse all food and fluids beginning Tuesday unless the authorities allowed him to attend the funeral of his wife, Iryna, who died of cancer on Feb. 23. He said he would then die swiftly in prison  a person on a dry hunger strike can usually live no more than a week  forcing the authorities to bury him and his wife together. The West has been pressing the Belarussian government for his release. Javier Solana, the European Unions foreign policy chief, urged Belarus to release Mr. Kazulin immediately and unconditionally, so that he can be reunited with his family and attend his wifes funeral.

title: A Place in the Sun (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Turkey Carries Ireland's Hopes
description: Ireland has chosen Dustin the Turkey, above, a glove puppet known for belching and a thick Dublin accent, to restore the countrys glory at the Eurovision Song Contest in May, Agence France-Presse reported. The bird, a star of television programs for nearly two decades, defeated five finalists late Saturday, when judges chose his song Irelande Douze Pointe (Ireland 12 Points), a parody of voting procedures at the Europe-wide competition that also pokes fun of Riverdance, the international hit Irish dance show. Composed by Darren Smith and Simon Fine, the song includes the lyrics: Shake your feathers and pop your beak, shake it to the west and to the east, wave Euro-hands and Euro-feet, wave them in the air to the turkey beat, The Times of London reported. Ireland has won the contest a record seven times, including three straight in the 1990s, but finished last in 2007 in Helsinki. Dustin has previously run (unsuccessfully) for president of Ireland and recorded with the Irish rock star Bob Geldof.

title: Annan Has Sharp Words for Kenyans as Talks Stall
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kofi Annan has had just about enough  or so it seems.

title: Multiple Hazards (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Says Satellites Tank Was Destroyed
description: The Pentagon said the mission to launch a Navy missile-interceptor at a dead spy satellite appears to have succeeded in destroying a tank filled with toxic rocket fuel. The Pentagon said it had reached the conclusion based on studying remnants from the missile strike on Wednesday. The statement said a joint space operations headquarters based at Vandenberg Air Force Base, in California, was tracking less than 3,000 pieces of debris, all smaller than a football. Most of the debris, the statement said, had already re-entered the atmosphere or would within coming weeks. There had been no reports of debris hitting Earth, the statement said, adding that it is unlikely any will remain intact to impact the ground.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 21 about Senator John McCains record on lobbying and ethics, including his role in the Keating Five case, described incorrectly the reprimand delivered to three other members of the Senate in 1991 for intervening with government regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. The Senate Ethics Committee rebuked the three senators for improper behavior, but under a parliamentary agreement the full Senate did not censure them or take any other vote on the matter.

title: Foreclosure Aid Rising Locally, as Is Dissent
description: SEATTLE  As the Bush administration and Congress consider proposals to ease the home foreclosure crisis, local governments across the country have been lending money to imperiled homeowners and confronting some opposition.

title: A Comedian Goes Green but Wont Go Off Color
description: BEFORE becoming a comedian, I was a senior engineer with Intel, presenting technical demonstrations at events throughout the world. In six years, I visited every continent but Antarctica.

title: Iraqi Pilgrims Endure Another Attack
description: BAGHDAD  Another attack on Shiite pilgrims marching to the holy city of Karbala killed at least four people on Monday, just a day after a suicide bombing left 52 dead.

title: Coral Reefs and What Ruins Them
description: Researchers who studied a string of Pacific Ocean atolls are painting the first detailed picture of pristine coral reefs and how they can be disrupted by people  particularly, they said, by fishing.

title: Selanne Was Clearly Not Ready to Retire
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  His Anaheim Ducks were preparing to play Game No. 65 on Friday, but for Teemu Selanne, it was Game No. 9 since his un-retirement.

title: Midnight Meals
description: Q. Is there any truth to the idea that if you eat heavily late in the evening, you will gain weight?

title: South Korean President Pledges Pragmatism
description: SEOUL, South Korea  After he was sworn in Monday, President Lee Myung-bak pledged to revive South Koreas economy, improve relations with the United States and draw North Korea out of its isolation.

title: History Survey Stumps U.S. Teens
description: Fewer than half of American teenagers who were asked basic questions about history and literature during a recent telephone survey knew when the Civil War was fought, and one-quarter thought that Christopher Columbus sailed to the New World sometime after 1750, not in 1492.

title: Drug-Resistant TB at Record Levels
description: Multiple-drug-resistant tuberculosis cases in parts of the former Soviet Union have reached the highest rates ever recorded and could soar even higher, spreading the bacterial disease elsewhere, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday in releasing findings from the largest global survey of the problem.

title: The Real McCain
description: You wouldnt know it to look at them, but political consultants are as faddish as anyone else. And the current vogueish advice among the backroom set is: Go after your opponents strengths. So in the first volley of what feels like the general election campaign, Barack Obama has attacked John McCain for being too close to lobbyists. His assault is part of this weeks Democratic chorus: McCain isnt really the anti-special interest reformer he pretends to be. Hes more tainted than his reputation suggests.

title: In Freshman Season, Moore Shows UConn What May Come
description: STORRS, Conn.  Since 1995, the Connecticut womens basketball team has produced five national championships, five Associated Press national players of the year (Rebecca Lobo, Jen Rizzotti, Kara Wolters, Sue Bird and Diana Taurasi), nine all-Americans and two three-time all-Americans (Svetlana Abrosimova and Taurasi). The talent pool has been so deep that renowned players like Nykesha Sales, Abrosimova and Taurasi did not start until later in their freshman seasons.

title: Councilwomans Strategy for Open Government: Sue and Sue Again
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Another Fare Increase
description: ANOTHER FARE INCREASE Major airlines have again raised domestic fares, adding $10 to round-trip prices on most routes. The latest fare increase, the third this year, was initiated by United Airlines on Friday and matched the next day by the five other network carriers, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Mr. Seaney said that there would probably be some competitive price jockeying as airlines roll back the increase on various highly competitive routes, but that over all the higher fare should stick.

title: Pakistan Cuts Access to YouTube Worldwide
description: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube was back up two hours after Pakistan, in an act of information provincialism, inadvertently made the video-sharing site inaccessible to users around the world Sunday afternoon.

title: Gates Promises Help for Indonesian Military
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pledged arms upgrades and other Pentagon support for Indonesia on Monday, as the Bush administration forged closer ties to the military of a country still viewed skeptically by some in Congress for past human rights abuses.

title: Hazards: Enlisting Hospitals in Fight Against Carbon Monoxide
description: Carbon monoxide is odorless and colorless. And it can do its work quietly, sickening and even killing people without their knowing they are being poisoned.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,962 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday :

title: Fighting for Votes in a Blue-Collar Stronghold
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  For as long as anyone here can remember, presidential hopefuls have made this scrappy, blue-collar stronghold an obligatory pit stop on the Democratic stump. Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy breezed through when the steel plants still turned the night sky orange; decades later, after the smelters had gone cold, Bill Clinton and John Kerry came by promising jobs to those left idle by the mill closings.

title: Body Discovered in Hotel Bathtub
description: The body of a 52-year-old man, his mouth covered by duct tape, was found in a hotel bathtub in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, the police said.

title: New Outlook on Bond Firms Ignites Rally
description: Signs that two embattled bond insurance companies are getting close to restoring their reputations and credit ratings bolstered stocks on Monday.

title: Clinton Campaign Starts 5-Point Attack on Obama
description: After struggling for months to dent Senator Barack Obamas candidacy, the campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is now unleashing what one Clinton aide called a kitchen sink fusillade against Mr. Obama, pursuing five lines of attack since Saturday in hopes of stopping his political momentum.

title: A Bond Born of Grief, and Hope
description: Kadiatou Diallo stayed far from the Queens courthouse where, 15 months after the 50 shots heard round the city, three police detectives went on trial Monday in the killing of Sean Bell. On Wednesday, she plans to be in New York to meet with Valerie Bell, the dead mans mother. But she has chosen to keep her distance from the courthouse.

title: Home Resales and Prices Decline
description: The backlog of unsold homes continued to pile up in January, a sign that home prices will continue to drop as would-be buyers hold out for better deals.

title: Ford Is Pushing Buyouts to Workers
description: WOODHAVEN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company is applying the hard sell these days  piling on incentives, doling out marketing DVDs and brochures, and making offers it hopes are too good to pass up.

title: Shifts in Pregnancy and Work
description: As women have children later than ever and more work outside the home, they are also working longer into pregnancy and returning to work faster than they did four decades ago, the Census Bureau said Monday.

title: Photovoltaic Cells Are Still Very Green, Comparative Test Shows
description: Solar power generated by photovoltaic cells is among the greenest of energy options. The cells just sit there, basking in the sun and emitting nothing but electrons.

title: Out of Chekhovs Orchard, Into Historys Frying Pan
description: The title of the new play at La MaMa E.T.C., The Cherry Orchard Sequel, may set off the cringe reflex: isnt that the kind of thing theater types think up during boozy cast parties? But the work, written and directed by Nic Ularu, is a sparkling surprise, helped along by fine performances all around.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline in some editions of The Arts on Monday with an article about the Academy Awards ceremony misstated, in some copies, the title of the film that won best picture. It is, of course, No Country for Old Men, not Old Country for Old Men.

title: When the Body Decides to Stop Following the Rules
description: Every day over breakfast, I fill three pillboxes. Fifteen pills in the morning, 3 at lunch and 8 before bed, for a total of 26. To my surprise, I find pleasure in the sorting, as it is one of the few moments when I can pretend I have some control over the bizarre war raging in my colon.

title: The Luckless Office Drones Life, and Afterlife, of Benumbed Desperation
description: Do those sunny Broadway songfests make you want to gag? Would you rather go to the dentist than come to the cabaret, old chum? Maybe you secretly think that Spring Awakening is too treacly, despite the teenage sex-and-suicide angle?

title: Oil Hits a High; Some See $4 Gas by Spring
description: Gasoline prices, which for months lagged the big run-up in the price of oil, are suddenly rising quickly, with some experts fearing they could hit $4 a gallon by spring. Diesel is hitting new records daily and oil closed at an all-time high on Tuesday of $100.88 a barrel.

title: Trial of Police Begins in 50-Shot Case
description: The three police detectives entered with lawyers at their sides and the stares of a crowded courtroom at their backs. The men, who once worked undercover in the shadows, were now center stage, sitting not among their fellow officers, but at the defense table.

title: Europe Warns Against Too-Restrictive Laws on Sovereign Investors
description: BRUSSELS  A top official of the European Union has warned the blocs member countries not to pass broad laws to restrict investment from sovereign wealth funds, despite fears about state-controlled foreign predators gobbling up major European companies.

title: Rolling Stone Donates Art for Arts Sake
description: A painting by the Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood will be auctioned this week to raise money for the Royal Academy of Arts, the BBC reported. The sketch of the Royal Ballet stars Carlos Acosta and Darcey Bussell will join works by Tracy Emin, Mary Fedden and Ken Howard that have been donated for the sale. Mr. Wood, who has been exhibiting his art around the world since the 1980s, will be the guest speaker at the auction to support artists through the Royal Academy Schools so people like me can continue to be inspired by new talent.

title: Knee Injuries in Children
description: To the Editor:

title: However Mean the Streets, Have an Exit Strategy
description: In the South-Central neighborhood of Los Angeles, where Margaret B. Jones grew up in the 1980s, gangs recruited with the same intensity as the N.F.L. did, she says, and shootouts and hits were so ubiquitous that the odds were stacked against a male child living to see 25. Peddlers went door to door selling life insurance policies, reminding parents of these deadly stats, and even teenage girls and elderly church ladies carried pistols to protect themselves. As the crack epidemic metastasized, and turf wars escalated, the hood became a combat zone, with police raids and deadly face-offs between Bloods and Crips becoming routine parts of daily life.

title: Obamas Support Grows Broader, New Poll Finds
description: WASHINGTON  In the past two months, Senator Barack Obama has built a commanding coalition among Democratic voters, with especially strong support among men, and is now viewed by most Democrats as the candidate best able to beat Senator John McCain in the general election, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: True North
description: To the Editor:

title: Transplant Surgeon Charged in Patients Death
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif.  On a winter night in 2006, a disabled and brain damaged man named Ruben Navarro was wheeled into an operating room at a hospital here. By most accounts, Mr. Navarro, 25, was very near death, and doctors hoped that he might sustain other lives by donating his kidneys and liver.

title: Europeans Plan Incentives, as Iran Says Sanctions Wont Halt Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  European countries are planning to offer new incentives to Iran if it agrees to halt its uranium enrichment program, European diplomats said Monday.

title: Visa Plans $17 Billion Public Offer
description: Undaunted by recent turbulence in the financial markets, Visa Inc., the nations biggest credit card network, said Monday that it would forge ahead with what would be the largest initial public stock offering in United States history.

title: The Claim: Stretching Can Prevent Soreness and Injury
description: THE FACTS

title: Mexicans Barely Increased Remittances in 07
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexicans working in the United States sent back almost $24 billion to their families at home last year, almost the same amount as the year before, the Mexican central bank reported on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 21 about Senator John McCains record on lobbying and ethics, including his role in the Keating Five case, described incorrectly the reprimand delivered to three other members of the Senate in 1991 for intervening with government regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. The Senate Ethics Committee rebuked the three senators for improper behavior, but under a parliamentary agreement the full Senate did not censure them or take any other vote on the matter. (Go to Article)

title: A Comic Who Acts Like an Ad Man
description: When Tom Brokaw turned up onstage at Radio City Music Hall on Sunday to be interviewed by Ron Burgundy  Will Ferrell, in character from the movie Anchorman  he might have been a visitor from another planet, and he knew it. Offering a tidbit of analysis, he said, By my presence on this stage, the average age of this audience has gone up by 103. True. Stuffy old Radio City felt like a college gym, which was the point of a show whose goofy, long title explains it all: Will Ferrells Funny or Die Comedy Tour Presented by Semi-Pro.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 20 through Feb. 24 with 1,266 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,115 said they were registered to vote, including 427 self-described Democratic primary voters and 327 self-described Republican primary voters.

title: On Mets Grand Stage, Opera Singers of Tomorrow
description: The Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions is a cumbersome name for one of the most high-visibility voice competition in America. Every year, typically, 1,500 young singers perform in regional auditions around the country. The field is winnowed in stages until roughly 25 semifinalists are sent to compete in New York. The finalists are then chosen to perform in a special afternoon concert with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.

title: After 3 Die, Questions on Why Erratic Mother Kept Custody
description: They could have been sleeping. The three children, all in pajamas, lay neatly arranged in a bed in their Long Island apartment  Michael Demesyeux, 5, on one side; his half-sister, Jewell Ward, 6, on the other; and Innocent Demesyeux, 18 months old, in the middle.

title: Gazans Demonstrate at Border Against Israeli Blockade
description: EREZ CROSSING, Israel  Several thousand Palestinians, many of them schoolchildren bused in from their classes, joined peaceful protests in the Gaza Strip along sections of the border with Israel for several hours on Monday, forming human chains in some locations as part of a public campaign against the Israeli blockade.

title: Two Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Company to 19%
description: Two hedge funds trying to elect a dissident slate to the board of The New York Times Company amassed 19.03 percent of the companys common stock before last weeks deadline for gaining voting power at the annual meeting, according to a report filed Monday.

title: Bush Fails to Attend Deposition
description: A lawyer for Reggie Bush has asked a court to prevent a man who is suing Bush from turning over a deposition of Bush to the N.C.A.A.

title: Poll Finds a Fluid Religious Life in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  More than a quarter of adult Americans have left the faith of their childhood to join another religion or no religion, according to a survey of religious affiliation by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

title: Motion Would Take Aim at Clemenss Top Lawyer
description: Lawyers for Roger Clemenss former personal trainer Brian McNamee said Monday that they would file a motion next Tuesday to disqualify Roger Clemenss lead lawyer.

title: For the Very Old, a Dose of Slow Medicine
description: It was two decades ago that a group of culinary mavericks took a giant step backward down the evolutionary trail with the slow food movement. Instead of fast food produced by the assembly lines of giant consortiums, they championed products of small-scale agriculture  time-consuming to prepare, beautiful to behold, very good for you.

title: Been There... Done That... Heres How
description: Terry Corbell, a management consultant, does not work for start-ups. People who are starting businesses arent good at what they do yet, he says.

title: Nielsen Looks Beyond TV, and Hits Roadblocks
description: Being part of a Nielsen household has long been a point of pride for people whose television habits are monitored by the Nielsen Company. In exchange for token compensation, these viewers know that their personal taste influences Hollywood and Madison Avenue.

title: Free Eye Care From Chvez, All the Better to See Him
description: PORLAMAR, Venezuela  Few places capture the disarray of this countrys public health system like the Hospital Luis Ortega. Unconscious patients lie on cots strewn near the reception desk. Paint peels from walls neglected for years. Soldiers stand guard to prevent worried relatives gathered on the curb from bursting inside.

title: The Clinton-Obama Tug of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Electric Shadows: Hong Kongs World Class Film Festival
description: Hong Kong gets a bad rap for not being much of a culture citythe old cliche is that were all too busy counting our money to think about Art. Meanwhile, the HK government, along with various cultural promoters and poobahs, are tripping over each other trying to promote schemes to Culture-ize the city. For without Art, how can Hong Kong ever hold its head up as a Great World City?

title: A Parting Shot at the S.E.C.
description: Kayla Gillan, a founding member of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, had to leave the board because her term was up. Now she has sent out a blast at the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the way it handled the efforts to make Section 404 of the Sarbanes Oxley Act more friendly to companies.

title: Sum Songs
description: Photos from the musical "Adding Machine."

title: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Northeast Edition
description: Now to the independent bloggers of the Adams Division, which the league has taken to calling the Northeast Division so the new fans wont be confused.

description: Properties on the market in California, Colorado and Massachusetts.

description: The Democratic presidential candidates face the challenges of campaigning in Texas.

title: The Performance in Pyongyang
description: Images from the New York Philharmonic's performance at East Pyongyang Grand Theater.

description: A look at a home in a hidden valley of the Luberon Regional Nature Park in France.

description: From The Onion:

description: More of your late night humor (send via the comment link below):

title: Paris Fashion Week | Christian Dior
description: (AFP/Getty Images)

title: Guilty Verdict for 5 in A.I.G. Case
description: Five former insurance executives were found guilty Monday of fraud and conspiracy in a scheme to manipulate the financial statements of the insurance company American International Group.

title: Virgin to Appeal Ruling on BSkyBs ITV Stake
description: The British cable operator Virgin Media said Monday that it would appeal the British Competition Commissions ruling that BSkyB must cut its stake in the rival broadcaster ITV, arguing that the regulator was not requiring a big enough divestment.

title: Indias HDFC Bank Offers $2.4 Billion for Rival
description: HDFC Bank on Monday offered $2.4 billion in shares for its smaller rival, the Centurion Bank of Punjab, in an attempt to bulk up before the banking sector is opened to foreign competitors.

title: Radar Networks Reels in $13 Million
description: Radar Networks, which is preparing a public beta launch of Twine, a Web application that organizes and manages information, has raised $13 million in Series B funding from Velocity Interactive, Draper Fisher Jurvetson, and Vulcan Capital.

title: Novell Buys Virtualization Firm PlateSpin
description: Novell said Monday it plans to acquire PlateSpin, a provider of virtualization services, for $205 million, a move that could bolster Novells software for helping customers manage their computing operations.

title: Live From Colette| Be Scene
description: Come to Colette in Paris where T is putting the stores hyper-cool clientele (like you) on film all week long. You can take your photo at T Onlines photo-booth computer or, if youre worthy, our paparazzo will hunt you down. If youre not in Paris, you can still have fun by telling us which photos you like the most. Just leave us a comment. Dont forget to smile!

title: Motorola Picks Up Chinese Set-Top Assets
description: Motorola said Monday it had acquired the assets related to the digital cable set-top products of Zhejiang Dahua Digital Technology and Hangzhou Image Silicon.

title: Hillarys Go Negative Flow Chart
Ontario Pension Says BCE Buyout Will Meet Ownership Restrictions
description: Ontario Teachers Pension Plans $48.5 billion proposed takeover of the Canadian telephone company BCE, the largest buyout in history, will comply with foreign ownership restrictions and broadcasting rules, the pension plans chief executive officer said Monday as the federal communications regulator grilled him about who will control the company.

title: Brinks to Spin Off Home Security Business
description: Brinks has decided to make its home security unit a separate, publicly traded company, following pressure from activist investors to spin off one of its two business segments.

title: Skilling Prepares for Appeal
description: Lawyers for Jeffrey Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, and the government will soon face off once again as his side argues to erase his convictions while prosecutors seek to maintain them.

title: Justice Dept. Signs Off on $2.4 Billion UnitedHealth Deal
description: The Justice Department approved UnitedHealth Groups $2.4 billion acquisition of Sierra Health Services on Monday, but required UnitedHealth to sell its Medicare Advantage business in Las Vegas to Humana as a condition.

title: The Balenciaga Line
description: The first three dresses at the Balenciaga show this morning were modern takes on the black cocktail sheathI should say, extremely modern takes. Nicolas Ghesquiere cut everything close, in fabrics that might typically be stifflike patent leather and thick wool crepesbut the effect was very light. You could see that his aim was to make everything light: the fabric, the cutting, the mentality. If you think of the couture structure from the 50s and 60s, and from his own recent collections, Ghesquiere still had subtle volumes in his opening dresses but it was as though he had stripped it down.

title: Lampert Hits Road Blocks in Search for Sears New C.E.O.
description: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge-fund investor mired in turning around Sears Holdings, has been looking for a chief executive to run the retail giant since last fall, a longer time period than publicly acknowledged, according to The Chicago Tribune.

title: Two Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Company to 19%
description: Two hedge funds trying to elect a dissident slate to the board of The New York Times Company have raised the ante in their bid to push through changes at the media company.

title: FriendFeed Hooks Up With V.C.s
description: FriendFeed, the social, shared feed reader similar to Facebooks news feed, has announced a $5 million round of funding from Benchmark Capital as well as FriendFeeds co-founders and former employees of Google, Paul Buchheit and Sanjeev Singh.

title: Sarkozy Lashes Out at SocGen Chairman
description: French President Nicolas Sarkozy stepped up pressure on the head of Socit Gnrale to quit over the banks record trading scandal on Tuesday, but Frances top business lobby warned him not to interfere.

title: Regulator Approves Libertys DirecTV Deal
description: The media mogul John C. Malone could soon be back in the business of delivering TV signals to consumers-this time via satellite.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Undercover
description: (Getty)

title: Goldman Predicts More Write-Downs for Brokers
description: Goldman Sachs said it expects additional write-downs of about $1 billion to $12 billion each for several major brokers in the first quarter, with Citigroup estimated to record the highest amount of about $12 billion.

title: Investors Jittery Over Delta-Northwest Talks
description: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines shares fell on Monday partly on concerns their merger talks may fail on the inability of pilots to agree on how to combine their ranks.

title: Buried Seed Vault Opens in Arctic
description: [UPDATED, 8:30 a.m.] After several years of planning and digging, the world has its first secure, deep-frozen repository for backup supplies of seeds from hundreds of thousands of plant varieties that underpin agriculture. The Svalbard Global Seed Vault was built into a frigid mountainside in Norways northernmost archipelago, deep in the Arctic. It had its ceremonial opening Tuesday morning in the frigid gloom of the Arctic winter. [UPDATE: Many readers wondered about whether it was too close to sea level. But, as I learned in my three Arctic trips, things up there are way more spread out than they appear. The tunnel entrance is 130 meters, or about 400 feet, above sea level. So all can rest easy on that front.]

title: Bid for Game Maker Seen as Effort to Buy Innovation
description: Creating a video game costs around $20 million. So for $2 billion, Electronic Arts could develop 100 new titles. Instead, it wants to pay $2 billion for Take-Two Interactive, known primarily for one particular game, Grand Theft Auto.

title: Visa I.P.O. Could Be Boon for Banks
description: Amid the dark days of multibillion dollar write-downs, trading scandals and congressional inquiries, one group of banks have a $17 billion bright spot on their horizon.

title: Science and Art
description: Images from the exhibition "Design and the Elastic Mind."

title: Morgan Stanley: Friend to the Bear-Huggers
description: Morgan Stanley, it seems, is the darling of the mulitbillion dollar bear hug these days.

title: Hedge Funds Still Pose Risk to Financial System, Report Says
description: Despite closer monitoring by regulators, hedge funds still pose significant risks to the financial system, a government report said Monday.

title: Catching Up With | Michel Gaubert
description: As creator of Colettes legendary mix CDs, designer of a line of deejay-specific bags for Longchamp and his endless list of fashion clients for whom he creates runway soundtracks, the deejay/sound designer extraordinaire Michel Gaubert is a veritable fashion-music powerhouse. The Moment caught up with him in the midst of fashion weeks.

title: Live from Germany: Super Return 2008
description: What a difference a year makes.

title: Wachovias Inscrutable Lawsuit
description: The New York Times reported Monday that Wachovia had sued its client, Providence Equity Partners, in a North Carolina court. Wachovia is seeking to have the court declare that it is no longer required to finance Providences $1.2 billion acquisition of Clear Channel Communications television unit.

description: This years Super Return conference seemed smaller and more subdued than the one last year in Frankfurt.

title: Tips for Weathering the Storm
description: The buyout crowd here in Munich got a welcome speech from Jon Moulton, managing partner of Alchemy Partners, a London-based private equity advisory firm. And what was his counsel in these challenging times?

title: Potshots at the Zeppelin
description: Over at the Film Experience, it is especially and wonderfully clear that somebody moved blogger Nathaniels milkshake. In particular, hes sick and tired of hearing that the awards honored obscure movies.

title: The Early Word: Fight Night
description: Oh, Ohio. Tonights Democratic debate (9 p.m. E.T., MSNBC) will be the last face off between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama before the states bellwether primary one week from today  and with none scheduled for the future, it could be the last one, period.

title: Och-Ziff Posts Loss on I.P.O. Costs
description: Och-Ziff Capital Management posted a net loss in its first quarterly earnings report as a public company, mostly because of the costs of listing its shares in November. But the hedge-fund group reported higher-than-expected distributable earnings, the number that analysts look at most closely, Reuters said.

title: Missing Link
description: The Bagger was really busy backstage and his headset was working only intermittently. He heard a number of touching speeches  Diablo Cody fell apart when she thanked her family for loving her as she is  but it all went by too fast.

description: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.
