title: Sam Zell on Selling Chicago Cubs
description: CNBC interviews Sam Zell, real estate tycoon and Tribune chief executive, about trying to sell the Chicago Cubs and Wrigley Field by opening day.

title: Oscar Nation Shrinks
description: Throughout his personal and professional life, the Bagger has made a habit of showing up right when a particular cultural phenomenon was about to crash. He went to a Yippie camp-in in 1974. Do the math: the war was over and Nixon was on his way out. And he didnt get punk until it was more about fashion than music.

title: In Trial Over Police Killing, Clashing Perspectives
description: The opening of the trial of three New York City police detectives in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell is the top local news story of the day, and every news outlet seemed to have its own take. In a front-page article in The Times, Michael Wilson describes the sharply diverging perspectives of the prosecution and the defense. The lead prosecutor called the detectives as a careless and incompetent group who ran on amok the morning of Nov. 25, 2006, unorganized and desperate for an arrest as their nightclub detail was coming to a close.

title: Update: Edwards Wins Auto Club 500 on Monday
description: On Sunday, rain stopped the Sprint Cup race on lap 87 with Jimmie Johnson in the lead. The race resumed on Monday.

title: A Nation Briefly Without Starbucks
description: At 5:30 p.m. Eastern time today, all 7,100 Starbucks locations in the United States will close their doors for three hours.

title: One Thing Everyone Can Agree On
description: In a panel discussion that pitted industry competitors against each other  it was called Head-to-Head With the Industry Experts  there was a hotbed of consensus on at least one issue: the lousy state of the market for private equity deals.

title: The Democratic Debate in Cleveland
description: The following is a transcript of the Democratic presidential debate on MSNBC in Cleveland, Ohio, as provided by the Federal News Service and CQ Transcriptions via The Associated Press.

title: Yahoo Reveals (Some) Details About Its Ad Plans
description: The meat of the presentation by Jerry Yang, chief executive, and Sue Decker, president, of Yahoo at the Interactive Advertising Bureaus convention Monday was a new advertising system called Apex (for Advertiser Publisher Exchange).

title: A Guarded Tone
description: Jonathan Nelson of Providence Equity Partners is a big-time media investor. But the title of his talk on Tuesday  Off the Record with Jonathan Nelson  suggested he might be a bit media-shy himself. As a courtesy, this blogger asked Mr. Nelson afterwards if his speech was on the record. After a bit of confusion, he said, What if I say no? Our answer: Id say, Youve got to be kidding with this room full of people.'

description: If you have to go to work today, take the trade deadline update machine with you.

title: Mets vs. Wolverines
description: Its T-minus 2.5 hours until the showdown of the spring. Well, at least for the University of Michigan baseball team. Fred Wilpons alma mater, ranked No. 8 in the Collegiate Baseball poll, is fresh off a three-game weekend sweep of Villanova.

description: This week, as The Moment blogs from the Colette boutique in Paris, were stalking the fashion faithful as they pass through the chic boutique.

description: If youve missed the blogorrhea over Jonah Goldbergs New York Times bestseller Liberal Fascism, Michael Tomaskys review in The New Republic can get you up to speed. Tomasky, the editor of Guardian America, calls the book one of the most tedious and inane  and ultimately self-negating  books that I have ever read. He writes:

description: The Associated Press reports: Media company CBS Corp. reported a 14.6 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings Tuesday as revenue slipped, but adjusted earnings still beat analysts expectations.

title: YouTube Returns to Pakistan: Calm on the Internet, for Now
description: News agencies are reporting that the Pakistani government lifted its restrictions on its citizens access to YouTube after a video that it deemed blasphemous was removed. And the nation confirmed that its decision to impose those restrictions accidentally led to a global disruption of YouTube for two hours on Sunday.

description: Rogers Sportsnet is reporting that the Devils have traded Cam Janssen to St. Louis for Bryce Salvador. Sportsnet received confirmation of the deal from the Blues.

description: Rick Peterson, the deep-thinking, ultra-prepared Mets pitching coach, studies every nuance of his pitchers. Peterson is so conditioned to studying habits that he sometimes studies reporters, too.

title: Sean Bells Father Recalls Fatal Night at Club
description: Updated, 5:43 p.m. | William Bell, the father of Sean Bell, testified this morning about the final night he spent with his son. The testimony, on the second day of the trial of three New York City police detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell, was striking because of the short amount of time that passed  about an hour  between the last time the father saw his son alive and the sons death.

title: Belak to Florida
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs have sent defenseman Wade Belak to the Florida Panthers for a fifth-round pick in this summers draft.

title: A Policy Change at Freemans
description: In response to yesterdays post about restaurants that wont let you order as you go, I received an e-mail from William Tigertt, one of the owners of Freemans. He wanted it known that the current policy at Freemans  the policy for quite a while now, actually  is to let diners order appetizers or snacks before the rest of their meal if they want to.

title: Avalanche Grabs Salei
description: The Florida Panthers have sent defenseman Ruslan Salei to the Colorado Avalanche. In return, defenseman Karlis Skrastins and a third-round pick in this summers draft is the package that the Panthers have accepted.

title: From ABC, a Candid Camera-Style Twist on Reality
description: When network newsmagazines use hidden cameras, they are usually pursuing child predators, as the To Catch A Predator series on Dateline NBC has demonstrated. But for the next several weeks, ABC is introducing a new twist on the genre  a social psychology experiment called What Would You Do?

title: Told Him To Shut Up
description: Aired Monday night on NBC: Last night, Javier Bardem won the best supporting actor Oscar for No Country for Old Men, and he delivered part of his acceptance speech in Spanish. Afterwards, Bardem said he did this because he wanted everyone who lives in California to understand him.

title: Leon Black on Doubling Down
description: If you cant buy em, buy their debt.

title: Chicago Trades Ruutu and Lapointe
description: Tuomo Ruutu is now a Carolina Hurricane. The Blackhawks have traded the young forward to the Hurricanes for left wing Andrew Ladd.

title: Now Screening | Charlize Theron
description: Last weekend, T rolled out its latest issue with our cover girl Charlize Theron. Wed like to call your attention to the Francesco Carrozzini-directed T: Online video with Ms. Theron  we think its pretty cool. Watch the Monster talent as she muses about South African drive-ins, homemade outfits, her affection for fried things and falling in love with Tom Hanks. You can see the video and read the accompanying article here.Click the still, below, to view the video.

title: Its Off to Ohio for Corzine
description: With New Jersey confronted by staggering debt and shrinking revenue, Gov. Jon S. Corzine unveiled a grim budget today that calls for eliminating thousands of state jobs, $3.2 billion in program cuts, the trimming of every state department and reduced hours at motor vehicle offices and state parks.

title: Arson Suspected at Fire Chiefs Mansion
description: Somebody trashed a San Francisco landmark that doubled as temporary housing for local officials, resulting in as much as $25,000 in damage, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. The boyfriend of the citys recently installed planning director is under arrest in connection with the vandalism, which included tossing furniture around and painting the place red with a can of crushed tomatoes. (In San Francisco, even the graffiti is organic.)

title: Insider | Julia Restoin-Roitfeld
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, the graphic designer, sometime muse, and daughter of Carine, shares with The Moment a few of her stylish essentials. Roitfeld Jr. currently freelances for clients such as Peter Som, V Magazine, and Jean Paul Gaultier. No word yet on if shell be hitting up Paris fashion week.Name: Julia Restoin-RoitfeldAge: 27Occupation: Art directorRetail Standbys: Kiki de Montparnasse, Marc By Marc, Fantasy World (for the latex clothes), and Darys, a vintage jewelry store in Paris.Book Shop: Le Comptoire de Limage in Paris and Strand Bookstore in New York.Provisions: Sunrise Mart on 3rd Avenue, WholefoodsGifts: Kiki de MontparnasseRestaurant: Omen, Indochine, Caviar KaspiaCocktail: Vodka tonic or a lychie martiniParty Central: Matisse in Paris, The Beatrice Inn in NYMomentary style obsessions: Miu Mius Spring 08 collection, Repetto, and the new turban cashmere hat I got for winter!Reading Material: Paris Vogue!Art Pick: Cocteau drawings; GauguinMuseums: Muse dOrsay (more for its architecture than its content)Vacation: Anywhere where I can disconnect a bit from NY!Winter Survival Tip: Tons of Moisturizer!

title: Private Cooking Classes in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Beijing and Kobe, Japan
description: I am going on a cruise to Asia in March and I want to learn how to make local specialties in Hong Kong, Kobe, Shanghai and Beijing. Do you have any information on how to book private cooking classes in these cities?

title: These People Are Called Republicans
description: Aired Monday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Ralph Nader announced he is running for president again. His announcement has filled millions of people with excitement and hope. And these people are called Republicans.

title: Rangers Loose After Practice, Awaiting Trade News
description: The roll call at Rangers practice was complete, save for their two injured players, forward Colton Orr and defenseman Paul Mara. Rangers management was absent, preferring to work the trading deadline business from their Manhattan offices. That left everyone else to pretend it was a normal day.

title: Ral Nader Will Then Take Over
description: Aired Monday night on NBC: How many watched the Academy Awards? You know, the Oscars are broadcast in over 100 different countries, three of which actually like us. Did you know that?

title: Some Sad News
description: Dennis Letts  who was Tracy Lettss father, and whom many of us saw on Broadway playing Beverly Weston  died last week. The cause was cancer.

title: Foote Returning to Colorado
description: The Columbus Blue Jackets have traded defenseman Adam Foote to the Colorado Avalanche, according to Rogers Sportsnet. In return, the Blue Jackets will receive a fourth-round pick this summer and a conditional first-round pick in either this summers draft or in 2009, depending on whether the Avalanche re-signs Foote, who is eligible to be an unrestricted free agent after this season. Foote, who began his career in the Nordiques/Avalanche organization, waived his no trade clause to return to Denver.

title: Home Price Plunge Accelerates
description: The S.&P./Case-Shiller indexes for December, out this morning, show the following price changes for the fourth quarter of 2007, annualized:

title: Fedorov to Washington
description: The Columbus Blue Jackets continue to shed veterans, trading forward Sergei Fedorov to the Washington Capitals. In return, the Blue Jackets will get Ted Ruth, a freshman defenseman at Notre Dame. Ruth, according to TSN and Sportsnet, prefers to be called Theo rather than Ted. But Notre Dame and CollegeHockeyNews.com list him as Ted or Teddy, in case you were wondering.

title: Dodd Explains Why He Chose Obama
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio  Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut became the first of the vanquished Democratic presidential hopefuls to endorse a rival, putting his hand on Barack Obamas back and declaring him the best choice for the 21st Century.

title: Wake Us When Its Over
description: Twelve to 18 months seems to be the magic range.

title: City Settles Parks Bias Suit for $21 Million
description: Updated, 4:14 p.m. | After 14 months of negotiation, New York City has agreed to pay more than $21 million to settle a federal class-action discrimination lawsuit filed against the Department of Parks and Recreation and will make major changes in certain of its personnel practices as part of the settlement, the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund announced today. The settlement, which is expected to be ratified by Judge Denny Chin in United States District Court in Manhattan, includes $11.9 million in back pay and compensatory damages to a group of about 3,500 former and current workers.

title: Isles Deal for a Defenseman
description: The Islanders have sent a seventh-round draft pick to the San Jose Sharks for defenseman Rob Davison.

title: Two Matts Make a Deal
description: The Vancouver Canucks have traded forward Matt Cooke to the Washington Capitals, according to TSN. In return, forward Matt Pettinger will be headed to the Northwest Division.

title: Serious Cash for a Cortina
description: Did I slight the Ford Cortina last week? Quizs. But the Cortina wasnt much to look at, especially in the 1970s. It was a simple econocar built by Ford in England:

title: McCain Repudiates Hussein Obama Remarks
description: CINCINNATI, OhioA conservative radio talk show host who helped introduce Senator John McCain before a rally here Tuesday used Senator Barack Obamas middle name, Hussein, three times, while disparaging him, prompting Mr. McCain to apologize and repudiate the comments afterward.

title: Its Not the Heat, Its the Cupidity
description: Earlier this month the wine industry held a conference in Barcelona on the effects of climate change on winemaking. I just followed from afar, but I was especially intrigued by the slant in one article, Bordeaux Big Guns Bullish About Climate Change, posted on the Decanter web site.

title: Dodd Explains Why He Chose Obama
description: CLEVELAND  Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut became the first of the vanquished Democratic presidential hopefuls to endorse a rival, putting his hand on Barack Obamas back and declaring him the best choice for the 21st century.

title: A Second Life for Quarterlife
description: Tonight, Quarterlife becomes the first program to be rejected by a television network (ABC), produced for the Internet, then purchased by another television network (NBC).

title: This Is Not a Commuting Tip
description: Watch the car in the far right lane (location unknown).

title: Trash-Talking From the D.C. Metro?
description: This City Room reporter was riding on the Metrorail system in Washington this week when she spotted a poster with a large rat glaring down on her, with the ominous headline, You gonna eat that?

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Feb. 26:

title: The Failure of Using Corn as Fuel
description: Still think corn is better as fuel than food? Heres my quote of the day, from David Pimentel, a professor at Cornell:

title: The World According to Calpers
description: Private equity firms are hardly the only ones adjusting to a brave new world these days. Investors in private equity funds are also facing a reality check as it becomes more clear that the days of wine, roses and 30 percent returns may be over, at least for a while.

title: Toronto Trades Gill to Pittsburgh
description: The veteran defenseman Hal Gill has been traded from the Toronto Maple Leafs to the Pittsburgh Penguins for picks in the second and fifth rounds.

title: Golden Boy Eyes Dynamo Opportunity
description: Boxer, gold medalist, pop singer, fight promoter Oscar De La Hoya is negotiating to become a part owner of the M.L.S. champion Houston Dynamo. That would make quite a resume for the 34-year-old super welterweight.

title: Report: Marian Hossa to Pittsburgh
description: Pierre LeBrun of the Canadian Press, who is appearing on Rogers Sportsnet, is reporting that the Pittsburgh Penguins have acquired Marian Hossa from the Atlanta Thrashers. The rest of this deal is still being worked out with two minutes to go to the trade deadline.

title: Rangers Get Backman from St. Louis
description: TSN reporting that the Rangers get defenseman Christian Backman from St. Louis for a fourth-round draft pick.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: A Rare Outsiders Glimpse of North Korea
description: Slide Show

title: Gerontocracy Alerts Issued for U.S. and Cuba
description: Two nations long at odds seem to have something in common, if two thoughts published today are any guide. While Cuba and the United States select their leaders quite differently, of course, the results can leave both open to the same characterization:

title: Detroit Adds Stuart
description: The Detroit Red Wings have sent a second- and a fourth-round pick to the Los Angeles Kings for defenseman Brad Stuart.

title: Remembering 2/26
description: Had 9/11 not happened, 2/26 would have been the worst day of terrorism in New Yorks modern history.

title: Rangers Trade the Other Hossa
description: TSN reporting that the Rangers have sent forward Marcel Hossa and minor-league goalie Al Montoya to Phoenix for forward Fredrik Sjostrom, goalie David Leneveu and forward Josh Gratton.

title: The Bunker Is Signing Off
description: Well, the bunker had a productive day. But I want to read your thoughts on who did the right thing and who just missed the boat by a mile.

title: Sorting It All Out
description: Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin? Pretty good. Add Marian Hossa to the mix and suddenly you have an absurdly nuclear offensive array. Can this put them over the top for the Stanley Cup this year? (Will Ty Conklin turn into a pumpkin at midnight?) Can they re-sign Hossa at the end of the season? Both good questions. But for now, a power play with Gonchar-Whitney-Crosby-Malkin-Hossa will be feared in the East.

title: A Banner Month for CNN
description: CNN, which normally comes in second to Fox News Channel in cable news ratings, is celebrating its first prime-time victory over its top rival since 2001.

title: More Images of Leaders All Dressed Up
description: After Mondays dust-up on the campaign trail between supporters of Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Clinton, The Financial Times stepped forward today to show that dressing up in turbans and other traditional attire is old hat for world leaders on goodwill visits.

title: The Power of Words for Cancer Patients
description: When my mother was first diagnosed with cancer, she did something she had never done before. She started to write down her feelings.

title: Mos Def, Recycling, Breakfast Places, Barack Obama
description: From a site on things that white people cant do to one with stuff they love to do.

title: Randy Falcos Napoleonic Strategy at AOL
description: Nobody could get off the stage at the Interactive Advertising Bureau convention here in Phoenix without being asked about the prospect of Microsofts acquisition of Yahoo.

title: Readers and Delia Smith
description: I love the comments on the little piece I wrote about Delia Smith and food for poor people, Frozen Potatoes for the Masses.

title: Bullpen Battles Are Under Way in Yankees Camp
description: The Yankees have three open spots in their bullpen, and all of the candidates have their own reasons to be motivated.

title: Tuesday: Paris Fashion Week
description: Selections from the Tuesday runway shows during Paris Fashion Week.

title: Bruno Gets Makeup Cash From 1199
description: Over the weekend, The Times reported that 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East, the powerful hospital workers union, might be hedging its bets in state political circles by throwing huge amounts of money at the Working Families Party, which is leading the charge for the Democratic candidate in a hotly contested special election for the State Senate being held today.The move was curious because in recent years, 1199 has been the most important financial backer of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the states top Republican. In recent weeks, though, 1199 has donated $257,000 to the Working Families Party. And in the last six months? Nothing to the Senate Republicans.

title: A Very Popular Raisin
description: Video

title: Mr. Naders Unforgivable Wrong
description: With Ralph Naders announcement of a fourth (or maybe fifth) run for president, it is worth taking a minute to recall his most infamous previous campaign: his 2000 presidential bid. The rosy and imprecise glow of memory might lead one to remember it as a well-intentioned effort to make a point that simply went awry. But such a view is far, far more benign than the reality of the Nader 2000 campaign, and therefore a review of that effort is in order to put his current campaign in context.

title: Roger Clemens: Its Baseball Time
description: Roger Clemens was 50 feet in front of me, walking fast and talking into a cell phone. He was headed to an off-limits area at the Houston Astros minor league complex here in Kissimmee, Fla., so I rushed forward and asked him if he had a few minutes. He put the cell phone down and agreed to answer some questions.

title: Of Superdelegates and the Black-Brown Divide
description: Democratic House members and university professors of color held two events in Washington within the past 24 hours where they spoke frankly about the issues facing their communities.

title: Starbucks Retrains, Rivals Discount
description: CNBC reports on how rivals like Dunkin' Donuts are responding to Starbucks closing most of its outlets for three hours to retrain its baristas.

title: City Raids Counterfeit Triangle, Shutting 32 Storefronts
description: City investigators raided dozens of storefronts on a triangular block in Chinatown this morning in what officials described as a major seizing of counterfeit goods  including fake Rolex, Coach, Prada and Gucci products  with an estimated street value of more than $1 million. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, who announced the raids, also said that the city had obtained a temporary restraining order to shut the storefronts.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Random Observations
description: North Korea has been trying hard to counter issues often reported about the country: famine, malnourishment, lack of heat, isolation. As mentioned, the heat is blasting in places where the contingent following the New York Philharmonic congregates and in hotel rooms. Photographing has been unfettered. And food at the banquet on Monday night was abundant. The breakfast buffet on Tuesday, too, was vast. A colleague who came late reported a poignant moment: the waiters and waitresses were taking pictures of the food.

title: Soft Serve | Tunes by Perez Hilton, Coconut Jet Fuel, Doggie Vitamin Water
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.Wanna enjoy the daily dish while listening to iTunes? Gossip gangster Perez Hilton is in talks to get his own music imprint from Warner Brothers If your house isnt getting the paparazzi attention it deserves, hire an (expensive) photographer to do it for you For those with an unfurnished abode, opt for a quick fix with a Room In a Box Need a houseplant for your pad? Botanicals Twitter will alert you on your Blackberry when your green friend needs some H20 If youre sick of vacationing on land, soon youll be able to check out a number of exotic underwater hotels Jet fuel may soon be just as tropical as your destination. Virgin Atlantic recently pureed 150,000 coconuts to help fuel a 747 If you are worried that your canine companion is getting parched, theres now vitamin water for fido For many, a morning cup of coffee is crucial, but in Texas a man tipped a waitress a thoroughbred racehorse after his cup of joe Caffeine addicts should be wary of tomorrows nationwide Starbucks closure from 5:30-8:30pm. Well be on the lookout for rabid Olsens Thats all for todays fluffy fix. Come back tomorrow for another dose.

title: Answers to Reader Questions
description: Thank you for all your responses to my first post and the questions you submitted last week. Ill do my best to answer a few here.

title: Unroll Your Own
description: Do you live like there is no tomorrow? Are you gone? Real gone? If so, you may bea beatnik! To find out, take this hilarious quiz, posted by the University of Texass amazing Harry S. Ransom Center for its exhibit On the Road with the Beats.

title: Richardsons Balance Sheet
description: When it comes to the home-state advantage, Gov. Bill Richardson was helped by New Mexico citizens  particularly some state employees  in last-minute fund raising.

title: Hawaii Senator Apologizes to Obama
description: We all know aloha, how about kaumaha?

title: Moroccan Bloggers Protest Jailing for Facebook Prank
description: The week after Fouad Mourtada, a Moroccan engineer, was sentenced to three years in prison for creating a fake profile of the kings brother on Facebook, Reporters Without Borders protested on the grounds that this disproportionate sentence has shocked the Moroccan blogger community.

title: Thoughts on the Rangers Moves
description: After a conference call with Rangers general manager Glen Sather and a few minutes to digest the Rangers trading deadline moves, here are some early thoughts:

title: The Bunker Cleans Up After Himself
description: It appears I left just as a few final deals were coming across the high-speed trade wire.

title: Submarines: New Plaything for Rich
description: CNBC reports on personal submarines, which are fast becomming the must-have object of desire for the ultrarich.

title: More On That Military Survey
description: Last week, The Board wrote about a survey of American military officers views on the state of the military. The sponsors of that survey have now issued a clarification about their work after criticism about the way the poll was conducted and represented.

title: Exploiting the Troops, Part 2
description: In an editorial and a blog post this month, we told you about Roger Chapin and his fishy charities for veterans.

title: Picking Olympians
description: Updated: United States Olympic team Coach Peter Nowak announced his training camp roster Monday ahead of the under-23 teams qualifying schedule to begin March 11. The 24-player list is available on the U.S. Soccer site and below.

title: Cliff Diving for Pacifico Beer
description: A new ad campaign by Pacifico Beer combines a variety of  online methods.

title: Swimming for Pacifico Beer
description: A new ad campaign by Pacifico Beer combines a variety of  online methods.

title: Radio silence
description: I havent died, or lost my will to be annoying. The shameful truth is that  dare I tell you this?  Ive been doing algebra. Deadlines to meet (actually to avoid missing by more than I already have), and Im not even looking at the news until this stuff is out the door.

title: Writers Ratify New Contract
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: The Last Waltz? The Democratic Debate in Cleveland
description: Wrapup: This was a debate of several strong, sharp moments that may not have added up to a game-changer for Mrs. Clinton but it gave her a chance to get back to basics  health care, fighter, woman  and to express regret (again) for her vote for the war in Iraq.

title: What We Learned Today
description: Its that time of year again: spring training games. The Mets open their season Wednesday against the Tigers in Lakeland, Fla., where Ryan Church will be your only regular position player making the trip. In that spirit, this is as good a point as any to remind you, dear fans, that the outcomes of these games arent as important as what transpires in them  theres a difference.

title: The Akhdam of Yemen
description: In Yemen, the Akhdam, a word meaning "servants," live in extreme poverty and at the absolute margins of Yemeni society.

title: Evolving Mistakes
description: Being the second part of an occasional series looking at mutations.

title: Democrats Debate in Cleveland
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama set aside their cordiality Tuesday evening in their final debate before the pivotal March 4 primaries.

title: G.M. Voices Confidence in Lending Business
description: DETROIT  Despite big losses at the auto and mortgage lender GMAC, General Motors is confident that its partner, the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, can fix the troubled financing business.

title: Democrats Raise Legal Point Over McCain and Ohio as He Opts Out of Public Money
description: CINCINNATI  Did Senator John McCain of Arizona benefit unfairly from rules that automatically placed him on the ballot in Ohio once he qualified for public campaign financing?

title: Raymond Smith, Founder and Editor of Literary Journal, Dies at 77
description: Raymond J. Smith, a founder and the longtime editor of The Ontario Review, a noted literary journal, died on Feb. 18 in Princeton, N.J. He was 77 and lived in Princeton.

title: Ivy Leagues Director to Step Down After an Era of Change
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  In the mid-1980s, the Ivy League was going nowhere fast. The days of leather helmets and Rose Bowl glory were long gone, and the league, which began formal play only in 1956, seemed headed for irrelevance.

title: Pondering Public Uses for a Hall Named Great
description: What if you had a majestic skylighted, columned hall in a Beaux-Arts ferry building at the tip of Manhattan and were required to use it as a public space? What would you do with it?

title: Huck and Jim Rewrite Story, Sing and Add Their 2 Cents
description: In a Notice to his novel The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Mark Twain advised: Persons attempting to find a motive in this narrative will be prosecuted; persons attempting to find a moral in it will be banished; persons attempting to find a plot in it will be shot. The author didnt say what he had in mind for persons wanting to rewrite it, but it couldnt have been very pleasant.

title: Now on the Campaign Trail, a Reined-In Bill Clinton
description: LANCASTER, Ohio  The long campaign has taken some of the fight out of the Big Dog.

title: Child Welfare Supervisor Suspended in L.I. Case of 3 Dead Children
description: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Acknowledging a series of mistakes by child welfare officials, the Nassau County executive announced on Tuesday that he had suspended a supervisor who he said had not adequately followed up a complaint against a Long Island woman who is now accused of drowning her three young children.

title: New-Home Sales and Prices Continue to Drop
description: Sharply lower prices failed to perk up sales of new homes in January, a government report showed on Wednesday, as a closely watched index fell to its lowest point in 13 years.

title: Starbucks Takes a 3-Hour Coffee Break
description: At Starbucks stores across the country on Tuesday night, it was time for the corporate version of re-education camp.

title: A Disaster Relegated to Second Place by the Events of 9/11
description: Had 9/11 not happened, 2/26 would have been the worst day of terrorism in New Yorks modern history.

title: Islanders Trade Simon Before Losing to Penguins
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders finally gave up on Chris Simon. By late Tuesday afternoon, his blue equipment bag had been packed and it sat in the hallway outside the teams locker room at Nassau Coliseum, ready to be hauled to Minnesota.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the death of an eighth-grade boy in Oxnard, Calif., whose killing is being called a hate crime by prosecutors, misidentified the group that is pushing for a legislative review of anti-bias policies in California schools. It is the Gay-Straight Alliance Network, not the Gay-Straight Alliance. (The network coordinates clubs in California schools that operate under the name Gay-Straight Alliance.)

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: South Egremont, Mass.

title: The Legions of Frozen Yogurt Push East
description: ACCORDING to Herodotus, even the mighty armies of the Greek and Persian empires took the winter off from warfare.

title: Racket in the Kitchen, Ruckus in the Crib
description: I AM the silent chef.

title: Upset Sends Democrat to Albany
description: ALBANY  In a major victory for Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his party, a Democratic assemblyman won a stunning upset in a State Senate election on Tuesday in a district that has been in Republican hands for a century.

title: F.D.A. and Disk Maker Questioned
description: A ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked the Food and Drug Administration and the maker of an artificial spinal disk about potential financial conflicts of many of the doctors involved in the clinical research that led to F.D.A. approval of the device.

title: Gazprom Moves Into Coal as a Way to Increase Gas Exports
description: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the worlds largest natural gas producer, acquired control of a leading Russian coal company in an asset merger announced Tuesday that extends its sprawling business empire into electricity.

title: Not Everyone Spins Their Wheels
description: Paris

title: Wildfires Burn in Texas
description: ROBERT LEE, Tex. (AP)  Officials kept watch Tuesday on a wildfire threatening this town of 1,500 people, but evacuated residents were allowed to return.

title: Binding Emissions Treaty Still a Possibility, U.S. Says
description: PARIS  A senior White House official on Tuesday outlined a new tactic aimed at convincing a skeptical Europe that the Bush administration would support a meaningful agreement to limit global warming.

title: Surgeon Accused of Speeding a Death to Get Organs
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif.  On a winter night in 2006, a disabled and brain damaged man named Ruben Navarro was wheeled into an operating room at a hospital here. By most accounts, Mr. Navarro, 25, was near death, and doctors hoped that he might sustain other lives by donating his kidneys and liver.

title: Witness Gives House Committee More Information About Clemens
description: C. J. Nitkowski, who gave a telephone interview under oath as part of the Congressional investigation into Roger Clemenss suspected use of performance-enhancing drugs, said Tuesday that he had provided more information to the committee since a public hearing on the matter Feb. 13.

title: Unfurling a Musical Thank You
description: Among Ralph Shapeys last pieces were two quintets for the Juilliard String Quartet and specific soloists, the clarinetist Charles Neidich and the pianist Gilbert Kalish. The scores were not commissioned, and the musicians didnt know about them until after Shapeys death in 2002. Shapey composed them as gestures of friendship, in gratitude to players who had championed his music over many years.

title: Lottery Numbers
One Nation, Indivisible
description: Belgrade, Serbia

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 18 about the cancellation of some campaign events in Wisconsin because of a snowstorm misspelled the name of a town there. It is Menomonee Falls, not Menominee Falls.

title: City Agrees to Settlement in Parks Dept. Bias Case
description: Moving to close the books on a long and ugly chapter in New Yorks employment history, the city has agreed to pay more than $20 million to settle a federal class-action lawsuit charging that the Department of Parks and Recreation systematically discriminated against black and Hispanic employees in awarding jobs and setting salaries, lawyers for the plaintiffs said Tuesday.

title: Competing on Calls That Arent Just Elk to Elk
description: RENO, Nev.  Maddie Smith took a deep breath, the better to get in touch with her inner elk. Nine and nervous, she turned her back on the denim-and-camouflage-clad audience below her. Slowly she bent over, put a piece of soft corrugated plastic pipe to her lips, and began to recreate the soprano bugle of a bull elk.

title: Study Finds Death Risk From Anemia Drugs
description: Widely used anemia drugs sold by Amgen and Johnson & Johnson raise the risk of death among cancer patients by about 10 percent, according to a new analysis of previous clinical trials that is to be published Wednesday.

title: Democrats Clash on Trade, Health and Tactics
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton confronted Senator Barack Obama on health care, Nafta, Iraq and his political tactics on Tuesday night in one of her most pugnacious debate performances of the campaign, as she fought for fresh momentum before four potentially decisive nominating contests next Tuesday.

title: Warrantless Searches Removed From Legislation in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexican lawmakers on Tuesday stripped a controversial provision from their plan to overhaul the countrys judiciary that would have given police officers, who are widely mistrusted here, the ability to enter homes without obtaining warrants beforehand.

title: A Watercolorist Who Turned His Hand to Oils of Heroic Vision
description: Search the history of American art, and you will discover few watercolors more beautiful than those of Charles Demuth. Combining exacting botanical observation and loosely Cubist abstraction, his watercolors of flowers, fruit and vegetables have a magical liveliness and an almost shocking sensuousness.

title: Gas Prices Soar, Posing a Threat to Family Budget
description: Gasoline prices, which for months lagged behind the big run-up in the price of oil, are suddenly rising quickly, with some experts saying they could approach $4 a gallon by spring. Diesel is hitting new records daily, and crude oil rose above $102 in trading Wednesday after settling at a record high of $100.88 a barrel on Tuesday.

title: Small and Midsize U.S. Banks Beginning to Struggle in Credit Crisis
description: The credit crisis is tightening the screws on thousands of small to midsize banks across the United States, squeezing local builders and businesses that depend on those lenders for financing.

title: Dan Shomron, Leader of Entebbe Airport Rescue, Is Dead at 70
description: Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, a former chief of Israels general staff and the paratroop commander who planned and led the storied 1976 raid in which Israeli troops freed 103 hijacked hostages at Entebbe Airport in Uganda, died yesterday in Israel. He was 70.

title: In Wiretap Laws Stead, Uncertainty
description: WASHINGTON  All last week, intelligence officials fielded calls from nervous lawyers for the countrys phone companies. With a wiretapping law allowed to lapse in Congress, they were no longer certain what they were supposed to do when the government came to them with a wiretapping order, administration officials said.

title: Magic Proves Too Tough for Nets Late in Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Even if the Izod Center had been full Tuesday night, instead of half-empty, the giant Turkish flag would have been easy to spot.

title: Not Ready to Pay for TV Time, a Mexican Beer Goes Online
description: DECADES ago, brewers determined that television commercials were just about the best way to sell beer, as anyone can attest who has listened to consumers still able to sing jingles like This Buds for you, Tonight, let it be Lwenbru or A beer is a beer is a beer is a beer until youve tasted Hamms.

title: A Stew With a Past and a Future
description: IT is hard for me to cook for people I dont like. I dont have to do it often, but when I do, I find it a torment because cooking is so personal, so revealing. Even more than sex, I think.

title: New Twist Keeps Dickeys Career Afloat
description: PEORIA, Ariz.  By all rights, R. A. Dickey should be working a day job somewhere, cursing twisted fate. Or he should be coaching at some Tennessee high school, telling kids what he once was and lamenting what might have been.

title: No Laughs, No Thrills, and Villains All Too Real
description: BERLIN  The other morning Jens Augner, slight and owlish, a schoolteacher in his 40s, quizzed his eighth-grade class of 13- and 14-year-olds at the Humboldt Gymnasium, a local school. As part of a trial program, he has just introduced a new history textbook into the curriculum: to be exact, a comic book about the Holocaust, called The Search.

title: Go Back to Black
description: London

title: Two Siblings Stuck in a Junkyard World, Struggling to Survive and Dream
description: Because the last shot of Ramin Bahranis Chop Shop is as quiet and matter-of-fact as most of the rest of the film, it takes a moment to register as a metaphor. For nearly an hour and a half we have been immersed in the rhythms of daily life in the battered Willets Point section of Queens, and Mr. Bahranis hand-held camera has remained studiously fixed at street level. Now, all of a sudden, it pitches upward to follow a flock of pigeons breaking toward the sky, a shift in perspective that also changes, subtly but unmistakably, our understanding of the movie.

title: There Will Be Floods
description: LAST month, a 30-foot section of levee ruptured in Fernley, Nev. While the cause of the breach, which swamped 450 homes and forced dozens of people to evacuate, is unknown, anyone familiar with the drowning of New Orleans by Hurricane Katrina will tell you this: Levees fail.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a court ruling allowing Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, to review documents on certain questionable transactions that led to his ouster, misidentified the founder of A.I.G. It was Cornelius Vander Starr, not Mr. Greenberg.

title: Studies on Depression and Teenagers
description: Depressed teenagers who are not helped by antidepressants like Celexa or Prozac may improve if they switch drugs and receive a certain type of behavioral therapy, a review of studies found. A separate analysis of 35 clinical trials of antidepressants in adults submitted to regulators found that the drugs were no more effective than placebos, other than a small minority with the most severe levels of depression. The study of adolescents, published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, gives mental health professionals guidance about how to treat teenagers who do not improve using antidepressants, said David Brent, a psychiatrist at the Western Psychiatric Institute at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Late-Night TV Satires Become Online Hits
description: LOS ANGELES  The worst-kept secret in Hollywood on Oscar night was whom Jimmy Kimmel was sleeping with.

title: A Loss in Los Angeles
description: An independent Los Angeles bookstore with a national following and local client base of writers and movie stars will close on April 30 after 23 years as a neighborhood meeting spot for dog walkers and a refuge for readers. Duttons Brentwood Books, in the Brentwood neighborhood, is known for its thorough stock of classic, new and esoteric literature and a staff of bibliophiles far more familiar with their wares than most employees at corporate chains. More than $500,000 of debt and competition from chain stores and online vendors led Doug Dutton, the owner, to announce his plans to close in a statement on the stores Web site (duttonsbrentwood.com) on Tuesday. The property owners, Nancy and Charles T. Munger, said in a statement to The Los Angeles Times that they would allow Duttons to remain open rent-free through its liquidation.

title: UConn and Adrien Dominate Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Connecticut does not need Jeff Adrien to dominate a game, but he did so anyway Tuesday night. Adrien, a junior forward, had a career-high 27 points and pulled down 11 rebounds as No. 15 Connecticut defeated slumping Rutgers, 79-61.

title: North Korea Seeks a Clapton Concert
description: LOS ANGELES  On Tuesday, as the New York Philharmonic was on the second day of its visit to North Korea, word emerged that North Korean officials have invited the guitarist Eric Clapton to perform there, according to a representative for the North Korean Embassy in London.

title: One Pot
description: THIS is a soulful dish: handmade meatball sausages subtly seasoned with onion, garlic, cumin, cinnamon, allspice and nutmeg and baked in a bubbling tomato sauce.

title: Jury Selection Starts in Corruption Trial of Mayor Who Ran Newark for 20 Years
description: NEWARK  Reviewing the questionnaires filled out on Tuesday by 135 potential jurors in the corruption trial of former Mayor Sharpe James, Judge William J. Martini of United States District Court said he was struck by the unusual number who had checked the box for Question 36. Many, it seemed, thought they might be swayed by racial, religious or ethnic bias, or by personal sympathy or personal dislike for Mr. James, his co-defendant or the lawyers and witnesses in the case.

title: Writers Ratify Contract
description: Members of two writers unions ratified a three-year contract with Hollywoods movie and television production companies on Monday, ending the entertainment industrys most difficult labor negotiation in 20 years.

title: Reborn After 3 Years Frantic Effort, Georgias Ballet Troupe Tours the U.S.
description: Nina Ananiashvili was having a busy season dancing fragile swans and hot-blooded flirts with American Ballet Theater when she received the phone call in May 2004. Would she meet with Mikheil Saakashvili, the new president of Georgia, in Tbilisi at her first opportunity?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Feb. 15 of The Middle-Class Millionaire, about a new demographic group that can afford expensive new personal services, overstated the cost of concierge-type medicine. Patients pay a retainer of as much as $20,000 a year, not a month.

title: William F. Buckley Jr. Is Dead at 82
description: William F. Buckley Jr., who marshaled polysyllabic exuberance, famously arched eyebrows and a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse, died Wednesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82.

title: Superdelegates, or Ordinary Voters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nortel Posts Loss and Plans More Job Cuts
description: OTTAWA  Nortel Networks, the telecommunications company long plagued by bookkeeping troubles, reported a $957 million loss for 2007, largely because of a huge accounting adjustment. The company also said it would cut 2,100 jobs and move 1,000 othersto lower-wage countries.

title: Lipitors Pitchman Gets the Boot
description: Pfizer has been relying on the reputation of Dr. Robert Jarvik, one of the pioneers in designing artificial hearts, to bolster sales of Lipitor, its cholesterol-lowering drug. Now that a Congressional committee is investigating the credibility of those ads, the company has dropped Dr. Jarvik as its pitchman. It was a telling reminder that consumers, besieged by drug promotion ads on television and in print media, need to take what they see, hear and read with a very large grain of skepticism.

title: Catching a Streamed-In Philharmonic Live From North Korea
description: It would of course have been fascinating to attend the New York Philharmonics concert on Tuesday night at the East Pyongyang Grand Theater in North Korea. Daniel J. Wakin, a reporter for The New York Times, was there to cover this breakthrough event, the first performance by an American orchestra in that totalitarian country.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and an article in Business Day on Friday about a recall of 143 million pounds of beef, some of which was used in federal nutrition programs, misstated the reason for the recall. The federal Food Safety and Inspection Service, an agency of the Agriculture Department, labeled the beef unfit for human food because of violations of food safety regulations. It did not deem it tainted or contaminated. (An article on Tuesday about some of the beef that was sent to New Jersey schools repeated the error.) (Go to Article)

title: WHNTs Technical Glitches
description: In 1955, when WLBT-TV, the NBC affiliate in Jackson, Miss., did not want to run a network report about racial desegregation, it famously hung up the sign: Sorry, Cable Trouble. Audiences in northern Alabama might have suspected the same tactics when WHNT-TV, the CBS affiliate, went dark Sunday evening during a 60 minutes segment that strongly suggested that Don Siegelman, Alabamas former Democratic governor, was wrongly convicted of corruption last year.

title: 9. Tilth
description: 1411 North 45th Street, Seattle; (206) 633-0801; tilthrestaurant.com.

title: Suitors Are Set to Say to Leno, Long Live King
description: LOS ANGELES  The Jay Leno chase is on.

title: Britain Convicts 7 of Terrorist Training
description: LONDON  A London court on Tuesday convicted seven men of involvement in a terrorist training plot that included camping weekends in remote English parkland. During the sessions, dozens of young Muslims were trained to throw imaginary grenades, to stage mock ambushes with rifles fashioned from branches and to chop watermelons in simulated beheadings.

title: Struggling to Squelch an Internet Rumor
description: Prof. Jeremy D. Popkin returned to his office at the University of Kentucky on Feb. 19 after teaching a lesson about Vichy France in his course on the Holocaust. During its 30 years on the curriculum, the class has grown perpetually popular, with 60 applicants vying for half as many seats. The university has even created a Judaic Studies program.

title: South Africa: Power Crisis Puts Jobs at Risk
description: The economic fallout from South Africas electricity crisis continued to reverberate as Gold Fields, the second largest gold producer, announced that it might cut up to 6,900 jobs, 13 percent of its work force, because of a 10 percent power reduction by the state utility, Eskom. It said its production would decline by 20 to 25 percent this quarter because of the power cuts. The National Union of Mineworkers, which represents 320,000 workers, said its members would take to the streets if there were major job cuts.

title: For the Press, a Closely Guided Tour of Pyongyang
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea  Journalists in town for the New York Philharmonics historic concert on Tuesday received a grand tour of this capitals sites by North Korean officials eager to show off the glories of the revolution.

title: Regulator to Lift Caps on Fannie and Freddie
description: Federal regulators for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the biggest buyers of American home mortgages, will remove limits on the amount of loans and securities the companies can own, a step that could help bolster the weakening housing market.

title: Sony Gamesman Quits
description: After 15 years of helping to build Sonys globe-spanning video game empire, Phil Harrison, below,  is leaving the company. Now president of Sonys worldwide game development studios, Mr. Harrison announced on Monday that he would resign Friday. Mr. Harrison joined Sony in 1992 and has become perhaps the most public face of the companys game business. After dominating the last generation of gaming with its PlayStation 2, the company has failed to maintain its leadership more recently with the PlayStation 3 amid new challenges from its rivals Microsoft and Nintendo. The company said that Kazuo Hirai, Mr. Harrisons boss as chief executive of Sonys overall game unit, would assume Mr. Harrisons duties. Mr. Harrison raised eyebrows in the game industry last week when he criticized Sonys failure to recognize the growth of casual, social gaming. Nintendo has embraced that trend while Sony has largely focused on complicated, sometimes violent fare directed at young men.

title: When Is a Bar Not a Bar?
description: IN an era of casual dressing, piecemeal supping and food as the adjunct to wine, is a restaurants best bet to pretend its less than it is? Should it persuade diners that it doesnt harbor big ambitions or demand close attention, even if the opposite is true?

title: A Reluctant Partygoer, a Grieving Father, Now a Witness
description: William Bell did not want to go to the party. It felt awkward, going to his sons bachelor bash at a strip club. It just was not his kind of place. Be with your friends, he told his son, Sean.

title: Ousted Premier Is Set to Return to Thailand, Officials Say
description: BANGKOK  Seventeen months after being ousted in a military coup, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra was set to return to Thailand on Thursday, officials close to him said Tuesday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,963 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: The Scottish Play Steps In
description: Witch: All hail, Macbeth, thou shalt be on Broadway hereafter! Macbeth: Tell me more. I know I am a hit at BAM, but to be on Broadway stands not within the prospect of belief. Say from whence you owe this strange intelligence? Well, it just so happens that the Broadway production of Mark Twains new-old play, Is He Dead?, is closing on March 9, when it will have played 13 previews and 105 regular performances at the Lyceum theater. The show, an adaptation by David Ives of a recently discovered Twain manuscript, was generally well reviewed, and its star, Norbert Leo Butz, drew raves. But the stagehands strike, a traffic jam of plays  some of which received stellar reviews  and the traditionally bad winter months helped do it in. If I thought I could stay open through May, I would, but financially it just doesnt make sense, Bob Boyett, the lead producer, said.And it also just so happens that Macbeth, like its title character, is duly poised to fill the vacancy. The production, starring Patrick Stewart, is to begin performances at the Lyceum at the end of March for an eight-week run.

title: A Husbands Personal Tale of Life on the Home Front
description: Never mind that warning about cellphones; theres a moment midway through James Bralys Life in a Marital Institution that may prompt you to pull yours out and report Mr. Braly to the child-welfare authorities.

title: Florida Blackouts Affect One Million Across State
description: MIAMI  A wide-ranging blackout swept across Florida on Tuesday, affecting nearly one million households and businesses, knocking out traffic signals and trapping scores of people in elevators. It also forced two nuclear reactors to shut down.

title: Russia Quietly Starts to Shift Its Oil Trade Into Rubles
description: MOSCOW  Americans surely found little to celebrate when the price of oil settled above $100 a barrel last week.

title: City Agents Shut Down 32 Vendors of Fake Items
description: It is a vibrant fixture of Lower Manhattan commerce. Tourists jostle for space at Canal Streets stores and sidewalk kiosks, bargaining with vendors over sparkly watches, handbags and perfumes with fake designer labels that are sold at a fraction of the cost of the genuine item.

title: U.S. Among Countries Investigating Tax Evasion
description: FRANKFURT  Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

title: Argentina: Dirty War Suspect Found Dead
description: A military officer linked to crimes during Argentinas dictatorship was found dead, the second in three months. The body of Lt. Col. Paul Alberto Navone, who was suspected of kidnapping babies during the dirty war from 1976 to 1983, was found with a gunshot to the head at a hotel in Asochinga, in Crdoba, according to a lawyer involved in the case. He was to testify next week as part of an investigation into the kidnapping of babies of political prisoners. While the police said that a gun found next to him suggested suicide, rights advocates suggested murder. They are eliminating the military officers being investigated for the dictatorships crimes, Estela de Carlotto, president of the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, said in a radio interview. Marina Barbagelata, a lawyer involved in prosecuting the Navone case, said on television that it was highly probable that there were people that could have seen themselves threatened by what he would say. During the dictatorship, about 500 babies were kidnapped from their parents, of whom 88 have been identified through the efforts of rights advocates, Agence France-Presse reported. On Dec. 10, Hctor Febres, a former coast guard officer, was found dead in his prison cell, poisoned by cyanide. The authorities said they believed that he was ready to disclose details about the kidnapped babies.

title: North Korea Invites Clapton, Too
description: LOS ANGELES  On Tuesday, as the New York Philharmonic was on the second day of its visit to North Korea, North Korean officials invited the superstar rock guitarist Eric Clapton to perform there, according to a representative for the North Korean Embassy in London.

title: North Koreans Welcome Symphonic Diplomacy
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea  As the New York Philharmonic played the opening notes of Arirang, a beloved Korean folk song, a murmur rippled through the audience. Many in the audience perched forward in their seats.

title: A Case-by-Case Ruling on Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled Tuesday in a closely watched job discrimination case that allegations that a plaintiffs co-workers had also suffered discrimination, offered as evidence of a biased corporate culture, may be admissible in court  some of the time.

title: Candles and Bagpipes Honor Officer Killed 20 Years Ago
description: He was a stranger to most of the men and women with whom he worked, and he died a stranger. And early Tuesday, exactly 20 years after he was gunned down in the line of duty, Officer Edward Byrne was honored by strangers.

title: Fantasyland With Eyes Wide Open
description: PARIS

title: Begrudging His Bedazzling
description: CLEVELAND

title: Finding Their Way Home, or at Least to the Garden
description: Back in the 1960s some of the most promising British musicians aspired only to sound as good as their collections of American blues and R & B records, or perhaps some Saturday-night gig along the old chitlin circuit.

title: Dining Briefs
description: CHECKING IN

title: Flooded Village Files Suit, Citing Corporate Link to Climate Change
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Lawyers for the Alaska Native coastal village of Kivalina, which is being forced to relocate because of flooding caused by the changing Arctic climate, filed suit in federal court here Tuesday arguing that 5 oil companies, 14 electric utilities and the countrys largest coal company were responsible for the villages woes.

title: 10. Central Michel Richard
description: 1001 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington; (202) 626-0015; centralmichelrichard.com.

title: Ohioans Hear Populist Pleas by Democrats
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  For as long as anyone here can remember, presidential hopefuls have made this scrappy, blue-collar stronghold an obligatory pit stop on the Democratic stump.

title: A Highflier Loses Altitude as Googles Clicks Go Flat
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Are Internet users clicking on fewer Google ads and putting the companys growth prospects at risk?

title: Bush Vows to Veto a Mortgage Relief Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush sided with banks and mortgage lenders on Tuesday, threatening to veto a bill being offered by Senate Democrats that would give more bargaining power to homeowners who face foreclosure.

title: One of 5 Bidders Backs Off on Building Over Railyards
description: One of the five bidders for the development rights over the West Side railyards failed to submit a revised offer on Tuesday for the tract, the largest development site in Manhattan.

title: Quill Awards Are Ended
description: Reed Business Information said it had suspended support of the Quill Awards program, Publishers Weekly reported. Winners of the 19 awards for books, established in 2005 in an attempt to infuse the publishing industry with some pizazz, were selected by the public in online voting. A spokeswoman for Reed Business Information, a founder of the awards and a parent of Publishers Weekly and Variety, declined to give further details, the Canadian Press news agency reported. The company went up for sale last week. The Reed announcement said that as part of the dissolution of Quills, the remaining money of the Quills Literacy Foundation, a philanthropy associated with the awards, would be distributed to First Book and to Literacy Partners, nonprofit organizations. NBC televised the annual black-tie awards ceremony.

title: Fire Department Defends New Tactic Blamed in Blaze
description: The Fire Department on Tuesday defended an experiment with new dispatching rules in Queens, saying that it had sharply lowered response times.

title: Humane Society Criticized in Meat Quality Scandal
description: WASHINGTON  As the meat industry scrambles to recover from a public-relations disaster over an undercover video of abused cattle, the secretary of agriculture and at least one congressman have picked an unlikely target to share in the blame: the Humane Society of the United States.

title: Expressing National Pride, Without a Flag Pin
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Brink of Destruction, Singing to the Beat of a New Religion
description: Given Americas latest war, its not surprising that Kurt Vonneguts absurdist satirical takedowns of mans destructive impulses are showing up in the theater. In January there was Joe Tantalos staging Off Broadway of Vonneguts masterpiece, Slaughterhouse-Five, and now Edward Einhorn and Henry Akona have created a musical adaptation of an earlier, even more apocalyptic novel, the 1963 Cats Cradle, for the Untitled Theater Company No. 61.

title: Martnez Would Be Open to Mets Extension
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Pedro Martnez knows he has a lot to prove with the Mets this season, knows that the one solid month he had last September has not answered all the questions about whether he can successfully return from rotator cuff surgery almost 17 months ago.

title: Senate Democrats Focus on Economic Cost of War
description: WASHINGTON  Undeterred by President Bush and Senator John McCain proudly pointing to progress in Iraq, Congressional Democrats are trying to mount new lines of attack against the administrations war policies.

title: U.S. and Czechs Close on Radar Plan
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush and the leader of the Czech Republic said on Wednesday that they are close to agreement on a plan for the United States to install an early warning radar system in the Czech Republic, a key component of a missile defense system that has drawn stiff opposition from Russia.

title: Gas Prices Soar, Posing a Threat to Family Budget
description: Gasoline prices, which for months lagged behind the big run-up in the price of oil, are suddenly rising quickly, with some experts saying they could approach $4 a gallon by spring. Diesel is hitting new records daily, and oil settled at a record high of $100.88 a barrel on Tuesday.

title: 'Raisin' Nourishes ABC
description: Averaging 12.7 million viewers, ABCs Monday broadcast of A Raisin in the Sun, with Sean Combs and Phylicia Rashad, lifted the network to No. 1 in that nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. A made-for-television movie, it won every hour of prime time except the 8 p.m. slot, when it trailed NBCs Deal or No Deal (15.3 million). After a six-week streak of leading on Monday nights among adults 18 to 49, NBC finished in second place over all as its new game show, My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad, at 9 (7.8 million), suffered a decline of 2 million viewers from its debut a week ago. CBS and Fox were third and fourth for the night, with CBS drawing more total viewers and Fox, buoyed by The Moment of Truth at 8 (8.6 million), faring better with the 18-to-49 set. Foxs Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles drew lower ratings at 9 (7.1 million). On Friday the cable series Monk ended its sixth season on USA Network, delivering the shows largest audience on record, 6.9 million viewers.

title: China Says It Will Resume Human Rights Talks
description: BEIJING  China said Tuesday that it would resume a human rights dialogue with the United States, in a move that appeared to be aimed at countering criticism from activists ahead of the Olympic Games here in August.

title: Anne Frank's True Love
description: Anne Frank called Peter Schiff her one true love. Now his photograph, below, is to be displayed in the Anne Frank House museum in Amsterdam, which is dedicated to her memory, Agence France-Presse reported. The photograph was given to the museum by Peters childhood friend Ernest Michaelis, now 81, who visited the museum last month with his children and grandchildren. The Observer Magazine reported in London on Sunday that Mr. Michaelis came to realize that the childhood friend in a photograph given him as he left Germany for Britain was the 13-year-old boy that the 11-year-old Anne Frank later wrote about in her diary. Im such an idiot, she wrote on Jan. 7, 1944. I forgot that I havent yet told you the story of my one true love. I can still see us walking hand in hand through our neighborhood. Anne Frank died in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp the next year. Peter Schiff, whose family, like Franks, fled Germany for the Netherlands, died in Auschwitz or Bergen-Belsen.

title: Corzine Seeks to Cut N.J. Budget and Work Force
description: TRENTON  Declaring that New Jersey had reached an irrevocable turning point because of years of bad fiscal habits, Gov. Jon S. Corzine proposed a budget on Tuesday that would reduce the states work force by 3,000 people, close three departments and prune expenses for services including colleges and hospitals.

title: Fed Chief Signals Hes Open to More Rate Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  Having already slashed short-term interest rates by almost half since August, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, signaled on Wednesday that more rate cuts  which is to say more cheap money  may lie ahead.

title: Bus Accident Snarls Traffic Near Port Authority
description: The morning commute into midtown Manhattan was snarled for thousands of travelers Wednesday morning when an accident cut off road access to the Port Authority Bus Terminal for about an hour.

title: Presidents Cup Captains Are Couples and Norman
description: Fred Couples and Greg Norman, two of golfs most popular figures and dominant players in the 1980s and 90s, have been named captains for the 2009 Presidents Cup.

title: A Rule Just Waiting to Be Broken
description: RED wine with oysters? Are you mad?

title: 43 Days Without a Homicide, and Then a Newark Man Is Shot
description: A 43-day stretch without a homicide in Newark  the citys longest such period in decades  came to an end Tuesday night in front of a bodega in the violence-prone South Ward, where the police said a young man was fatally shot in the head.

title: 2 Charged With Demanding Payoffs From Contractors
description: Armed with little more than hard hats and a fancy name, two men posing as building inspectors carried out an extortion scheme that gave a sinister new twist to the idea of civic virtue, prosecutors said Tuesday.

title: Aetna to Still Pay for Colonoscopy Drug
description: Bowing to critics who contended it was putting profits before patients, Aetna said Wednesday that it has suspended  at least temporarily  a plan to stop paying for routine use of a powerful anesthetic in a procedure to screen for colon cancer.

title: Prosecution Plays Defense on How Girl Was Killed
description: Prosecutors in the trial of a man charged in the killing of Nixzmary Brown went on the defensive for the first time on Tuesday, aggressively cross-examining a medical expert called by the defense who had disputed the prosecutions theory that long-term abuse helped cause the girls death.

title: E.P.A. Staff Lobbied Boss on Decision on Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  Senior nonpolitical staff members at the Environmental Protection Agency wrote an impassioned plea for a former agency chief to deliver to the current E.P.A. administrator about an important decision on greenhouse gas emissions from cars, according to documents released Tuesday by a Senate committee.

title: Providence Begins to See Its Future Around the Corner
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  This is a city of 25 diverse neighborhoods, many with distinctive New England character, but it is Downcity that is the urban core and the citys historical heart.

title: Annan Tries to Spur Kenya Talks
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kofi Annan suspended day-to-day mediation talks in Kenya on Tuesday and said he would now take up the remaining divisive issues with Kenyas leaders directly.

title: Judges Uphold Nigerias Presidential Election
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  A panel of judges has upheld the election of President Umaru YarAdua of Nigeria, ruling that the evidence of ballot-box stuffing and phantom voting booths presented by two challengers in the race was not enough to overturn the outcome.

title: Suit Against Predator Show Advances
description: A federal judge in New York ruled on Tuesday that a lawsuit contending that an NBC television series on pedophiles had played a role in the suicide of a Texas prosecutor two years ago could move forward.

title: Dutch Bank Restricts Accounts of Americans
description: LONDON  ABN Amro, the Dutch bank bought by three European rivals last year, said Tuesday that it was closing any portfolio investment accounts held by customers with a United States passport within 30 days, citing strategic reasons.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Cook Like a Ligurian

title: Pilots Battles Over Seniority Play Havoc With Airline Mergers
description: Merger talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines have been held up for a couple of weeks while pilots at each carrier discuss how to combine their union seniority lists.

title: Yanks Aim for Giambi to Return to First
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The winter meetings will be in Las Vegas in December. That is where Jason Giambi lives. So what are the chances Giambi hits the town with a general manager and winds up with a rich new contract?

title: Belarus Opposition Leader Freed for Wifes Funeral
description: MOSCOW  Authorities in Belarus temporarily freed Aleksandr V. Kazulin, an imprisoned opposition politician who threatened to starve himself if not permitted to attend his wifes funeral.

title: Outrageously Transgressing Boundaries
description: Pick an artist, any artist, and imagine him announcing that he has excised from his production a magical flight of fancy involving Joan Didion, ruby slippers, time travel and Anne Frank. Now exhale: theatrical horror averted.

title: Getting Real About the Rescue
description: Some big banks are supporting new proposals to rescue homeowners who owe more on their mortgages than their houses are worth, but lets get one thing straight: the banks havent been struck by a sudden urge to help the needy. Rather, by advocating bailouts, the lending industry is trying to head off a possible change in the law that would let troubled borrowers modify their mortgages in bankruptcy court  where lenders, not taxpayers, would be stuck with the losses.

title: Coast to Coast, Restaurants That Count
description: I HAD called once to make my reservation, and then again to confirm it, but it wasnt until I telephoned to say I was running late that I really heard the greeting.

title: Losing Credibility, Piece by Piece
description: Call this the crumbling case of Roger Clemens.

title: Hoops Hybrid Being Molded Into a League
description: SlamBall redux? The hybrid basketball-gymnastics extreme sport that had a short life on Spike in 2002 and 2003 is being resurrected for a showcase season to be taped in June with expectations of selling eight franchises before 2009.

title: Cubans Wary of Ral Castros Hints at Change
description: HAVANA  In his first state reception as Cubas president, Ral Castro met Tuesday not with leftist Latin American leaders like Hugo Chvez and Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, nor with Chinese officials, but with the secretary of state of the Vatican, a traditional enemy of Communism and a critic of Cubas record on human rights.

title: Bloomberg Ends Presidential Speculation
description: Bringing an end to a long flirtation with a bid for the White House, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has officially closed the door on a presidential candidacy.

title: $60 Million Gift for Stony Brook
description: James H. Simons, a math professor-turned-hedge fund manager, is giving Stony Brook University $60 million, its largest gift ever and the largest gift to any public university in the state.

title: Drug-Resistant TB Rates Soar in Former Soviet Regions
description: Drug-resistant tuberculosis cases in parts of the former Soviet Union have reached the highest rates ever recorded globally, the World Health Organization said Tuesday. The rates could soar even higher, spreading the potentially fatal disease elsewhere, a top W.H.O. official said, releasing findings from the largest global survey of the problem.

title: 20th Debate: Reality Show or a Spinoff?
description: Everybody wanted to know which Hillary Rodham Clinton would show up to the Cleveland debate on Tuesday night. It turned out to be the Amy Poehler version.

title: Dollar Weakens to $1.51 to the Euro
description: The dollar breached the level of $1.50 to the euro on Wednesday for the first time as fears of weakness in the United States economy mixed with evidence of resilience in Europe.

title: A Downtown Impresarios New Uptown Canvas
description: Between sets backstage at Joes Pub one evening recently, the crew was busy carrying out a menagerie of African drums for one act and carefully loading in a piano for the comedy-cabaret group coming up next. Inches away, fans crowded the merchandise table while the artists squeezed through to their dressing rooms, and patrons from a play down the hall rushed to the restrooms at intermission.

title: Filings Show Take-Two Raised Management Payout in Takeover
description: Just days after Take-Two Interactive, the troubled video game maker, received a buyout offer from a rival, Electronic Arts, the board of Take-Two approved a measure that significantly increased the compensation that management would receive in a merger or takeover, according to regulatory filings.

title: Languishing at the Bottom of Yemens Ladder
description: SANA, Yemen  By day, they sweep the streets of the Old City, ragged, dark-skinned men in orange jump suits. By night, they retreat to fetid slums on the edge of town.

title: Moving On, Clemens Turns to Baseball
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Roger Clemens offered hugs, handshakes and advice to members of the Houston Astros on Tuesday, doing everything he could to become immersed in baseball again. He was under a canopied batting cage, not inside a Congressional hearing room, trying hard to behave like the tough-guy pitcher known as the Rocket.

title: Footnote
description: It will be father-daughter night in Nashville on April 14 when Billy Ray Cyrus and Miley Cyrus, above, will be the hosts and perform at the seventh annual CMT Music Awards, The Associated Press reported. Other performers on the country music awards show, to be broadcast live on CMT, include Alan Jackson, Brad Paisley, Carrie Underwood, Sugarland, Taylor Swift and Toby Keith.

title: Iraq Cabinet Demands Turks Leave Kurdish Area in North
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government on Tuesday condemned Turkeys raids into northern Iraq and demanded that Turkey withdraw its troops, as fighting continued for a sixth day between Turkish forces and Kurdish rebels.

title: Union Strikes Parts Maker for G.M.
description: DETROIT  The United Automobile Workers union called its third strike in five months Tuesday, sending some 3,650 workers at parts factories in Michigan and New York off the job in opposition to proposed pay and benefits cuts, and to what it called unfair labor practices.

title: Profit Rises at Macys and Falls at Target
description: The department store company Macys said Tuesday that lower costs sent fourth-quarter profit up more than analysts had expected, while Target reported that its sales declined.

title: 2 Teenagers Are Accused of Torturing Ohio Woman
description: CINCINNATI  Two teenagers with long criminal records have been charged with torturing a young woman for at least six hours inside her home in rural southwestern Ohio.

title: Israel: Court Backs Deal for Ex-President
description: The High Court upheld the plea bargain last year by which possible rape charges against former President Moshe Katsav, left, were dropped in exchange for his stepping down and pleading guilty to lesser charges. There has been fierce public criticism of the deal, and the courts five-judge panel split 3 to 2 in its opinion. Chief Justice Dorit Beinisch was in the minority. The judges unanimously agreed that there was not sufficient evidence to charge Mr. Katsav with rape. Although Mr. Katsav has protested his innocence, he is to plead guilty to committing indecent acts without consent, sexual harassment of two women and harassing a witness. He faces a suspended sentence and payment of compensation, but no prison time.

title: Gaza: Israeli Army Clears Itself in 21 Deaths
description: The army said no legal action would be taken against military officials over an artillery strike in Beit Hanun in 2006 in which an errant shell hit residential buildings and killed 21 Palestinian civilians. An army investigation concluded that the shell was fired based on information that militants were intending to fire rockets from the area, an army statement said. The civilian deaths, it said, were directly due to a rare and severe failure in the artillery control system. The armys military advocate general concluded that there was no need for further investigation.

title: Ashcroft to Testify in Congress on No-Bid Contract for His Firm
description: WASHINGTON  Former Attorney General John Ashcroft has agreed to testify to Congress about a multimillion-dollar no-bid contract steered to his consulting firm by the Justice Department under an out-of-court settlement between federal prosecutors and a medical-supply company, Congressional officials said Tuesday.

title: Vladimir Putins Russia
description: The eight years of Vladimir Putins presidency have faithfully reflected his formative years in the Soviet secret police. Mr. Putins term ends this spring, but he is nearly certain to become prime minister. That means, we fear, that little will change. The next American president will have to deal with a Russia that is not only nuclear-armed but increasingly wealthy and increasingly authoritarian.
