title: Doctored Up in the Oven
description: MY desperation for good tomato flavor in the winter (documented here a few weeks ago in a column about sun-dried tomatoes) led me a year or two ago to try roasting canned tomatoes.

title: British Government Ordered to Release Notes on Iraq
description: LONDON  Britains information commissioner has ordered the government to release the minutes of two cabinet meetings held in March 2003 under Tony Blair, then the prime minister, to discuss the legality of the allied invasion of Iraq that began later that month.

title: Near Avignon, a Peaceful Retreat
description: OPPDE, France

title: McCain Criticizes Obama on Al Qaeda
description: Senator John McCain, looking ahead to a possible general-election matchup with Senator Barack Obama, attacked Mr. Obama on Wednesday for what he called a weak and nave approach to the conflict in Iraq and the effort to combat international terrorism.

title: Europe Fines Microsoft $1.35 Billion
description: BRUSSELS  The European antitrust regulator levied a record $1.35 billion fine against Microsoft on Wednesday in a ruling designed to send a clear message to the worlds biggest software maker  and to any other company  of the dangers of flouting its competition rulings.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about Toyotas global expansion misidentified the location of its European headquarters. It is outside Brussels, not outside Belgium. An accompanying article about Akio Toyoda, the grandson of the companys founder and its probable next president, also misstated the location of Babson College, where he earned his M.B.A. It is in Wellesley, Mass., a suburb of Boston  not in Boston itself.

title: The Politics of Trade in Ohio
description: Watching Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton compete with each other to say the nastiest possible thing about the Nafta trade deal has made me think about the politics of abortion.

title: New Worries on Inflation and Homes
description: Houses are getting cheaper by the month. Everything else is becoming more expensive.

title: For St. Anthony, a State Title Would Be the Perfect Ending
description: St. Anthony High School of Jersey City has the No. 1-ranked boys basketball team in the country, according to two polls. Six of its nine seniors have already signed to play for Division I teams, and two juniors are likely to follow. Their season is the focus of a documentary.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and an article in Business Day on Friday about a recall of 143 million pounds of beef, some of which was used in federal nutrition programs, misstated the reason for the recall. The federal Food Safety and Inspection Service, an agency of the Agriculture Department, labeled the beef unfit for human food because of violations of food safety regulations. It did not deem it tainted or contaminated. (An article on Tuesday about some of the beef that was sent to New Jersey schools repeated the error.)

title: Run Wasnt Cheap; Heilman Gets Off for a Song
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Aaron Heilman is a proud graduate of Notre Dame. Decal-on-the-car, donates-money proud, which made Tuesdays exhibition against one of his alma maters biggest rivals, Michigan, a matter of great personal interest.

title: A Complicated Challenge on One Side; a Single Task on the Other
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the final debate before Tuesdays critical primaries with two imperative goals: Challenge Senator Barack Obamas qualifications to lead the country and raise doubts about his ability to defeat a Republican opponent as experienced as Senator John McCain.

title: A Host Disparages Obama, and McCain Quickly Apologizes
description: CINCINNATI  Senator John McCain apologized Tuesday after a conservative radio host who helped introduce him before a rally used Senator Barack Obamas middle name, Hussein, three times, while disparaging him.

title: Going First Most of the Time
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sounded almost put upon.

title: Dallas and Pittsburgh Trade for Offense
description: On a frenetic day that included 25 trades, the Pittsburgh Penguins snatched the biggest prize, Atlanta forward Marian Hossa, less than two hours before the deadline Tuesday afternoon, adding one of the N.H.L.s best snipers to a lineup that already features the high-scoring Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin.

title: Great Lakes Officials Seek Aid From U.S. and Canada
description: CHICAGO  Regional government agencies around the Great Lakes spend some $15 billion a year to protect the lakes from invasive species, contaminated sediment and sewage overflows, a new study shows. But local officials say that still more protection is needed and that the United States and Canadian governments should pay for it.

title: Corporate Welfare Lives, Especially for Baseball
description: More than four years ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg claimed victory over one of the citys longest-running three-card-monte operations: big companies demanding, and getting, tax breaks to remain in New York when they really werent going anywhere.

title: Delays at Rijksmuseum
description: Renovation of the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam is unlikely to be finished until late 2012 or 2013, Reuters reported. The Dutch culture ministry said that the renovations were to have been completed this year, but a dispute with the building contractor over costs led to new delays at the museum, a major tourist attraction and home to some of the greatest works of the Dutch masters. In a face-lift reminiscent of the modernization of the Louvre in Paris, the Rijksmuseum, designed by Pierre Cuypers (1827-1921) and opened in 1885, is to have a huge new underground entrance hall. Since the main building closed, in 2003, paintings by Rembrandt, Frans Hals and Vermeer have remained on view in a wing.

title: Steinbrenner, a Legend, Deserves a Field
description: One of the nicest things I have heard from baseball in a long time is taking place in Florida this spring training: the name of the Yankees ballpark in Tampa is being changed from Legends Field to Steinbrenner Field.

title: Fancy Some Soldiers for Your Eggs, Mate?
description: Wartime rationing in Britain ended in 1954, just in time for the birth of John Haney. A good thing, too, because the boy had an appetite, gluttonously documented in Fair Shares for All. The greasy curtain in this food-and-family memoir rises on the 4-year-old John stuffing his face with soldiers  toast strips for dipping in soft-boiled egg  as if in training for the strenuous regime of sausages, mince pies, custard, beans on toast and bacon sandwiches to come.

title: Survey Finds Teenagers Ignorant on Basic History and Literature Questions
description: Fewer than half of American teenagers who were asked basic history and literature questions in a phone survey knew when the Civil War was fought, and one in four said Columbus sailed to the New World some time after 1750, not in 1492.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: From Witness in Police Killing, Tearful Recall of a Party Gone Bad
description: A riveted courtroom in Queens listened on Tuesday to the first witness testimony describing the 50 police gunshots that killed Sean Bell outside a strip club, delivered by an exotic dancer who saw part of the shooting before running around a corner and hiding in some bushes.

title: In Las Vegas, Dubai Worlds New Investment Sets Sales Record
description: Recent penthouse sales at the massive MGM CityCenter, which is now half-owned by Dubai World, set new records for price-per-square-foot in Las Vegas, according to the agent who made the sales.

title: Whos Who in the Baghdad Bureau
description: Update | May 21, 2009

title: Love and Consequences
description: Lost

title: The Sporting Life in Dubai
description: In their quest to bring us the biggest and best of everything, the Emirati billionaires are leaving no game unplayed.

title: Did Your Team Get Jobbed, or Did It Prosper?
description: Thats the question we asked each member of our Hockey Night in Blogdom crew in 27 cities across North America in the shell-shocked aftermath of Tuesdays trade deadline frenzy. Below are their thumbnail analyses for each deal, but there were so many trades that we have to split them into three separate posts. Heres the first:

title: Wrinkled but Formidable
description: The amazing career of Gil Miranda, the greatest senior softballer of all time.

title: How to Get on the Baghdad Bureau Blogroll
description: Send your suggested links to baghdadbureau@nytimes.com and put Baghdad Bureau blogroll in the subject line.

title: Taking Questions: Life Inside the Red Zone
description: Its been too long since we last answered your questions on life in Iraq. The Baghdad Bureau blog will be answering as many questions as we can on a wide number of issues about the country, its people, the U.S. military, the private contractors and the media attempting to cover it all.

title: Food Stuff
description: Fruit to Keep, for a Bit of Sweetness Out of Season

title: Welcome: Dateline Baghdad
description: The Baghdad bureau of The New York Times serves as both home and office for 7 to 10 Western reporters, photographers and videographers, who work with a large Iraqi staff of reporters based in Baghdad and other cities across Iraq.

title: Did Your Team Get Jobbed, or Did It Prosper? Part 2
description: Tampa Bay traded C Brad Richards and G Johan Holmqvist to Dallas for G Mike Smith, LW Jussi Jokinen, C Jeff Halpern and a fourth-round pick in the 2009 draft.

title: How Accurate Were They in 2007?
description: Our guest blogger of the week:

title: Super Return: The Big Buyout Questions
description: As a founder and managing director of The Carlyle Group, one of the worlds biggest private equity firms, David Rubenstein gets asked a lot of questions these days about the fate of the buyout business.

title: Revenge, a Comic Dish Served Virally
description: A satiric video in which Jimmy Kimmel touts his sexual relationship with Ben Affleck is a huge hit online, todays Times reports. It all began when Kimmels girlfriend, the comedian Sarah Silverman, revealed in a video that she was hooking up with Matt Damon:

title: Not Again': Fleeing My Home
description: Hurry up, Mom, we dont want to be late, I called my mother after I heard the sound of an I.E.D., an improvised explosive device, blowing up. They would seal off the area and we would be trapped, that was my concern. My mother was running here and there in the house trying to pack as much stuff as she could. It was our last day. We had decided earlier that we couldnt stay in our house anymore; the area was getting more and more dangerous and deserted.

title: A Revamping for the Financial Accounting Standards Board
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets American accounting rules, will have two fewer members and the power of its chairman will be increased, the boards oversight body said on Tuesday.

title: Gazprom Moves Into Coal
description: Gazprom, the worlds largest natural gas producer, acquired control of a leading Russian coal company in an asset merger announced Tuesday that extends its sprawling business empire into electricity.

title: I.B.M. Plans $15 Billion Share Buyback
description: I.B.M. said on Tuesday that its board had authorized a $15 billion share buyback program that could increase 2008 earnings by up to 5 cents a share, sending its stock up 4.2 percent.

title: ABN Amro Restricts Accounts of Americans
description: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank bought by three European rivals last year, said Tuesday that it was closing any portfolio investment accounts held by customers with a United States passport within 30 days, citing strategic reasons.

title: Lucky Pai Rolls the Dice for Second Round
description: Lucky Pai, a Shanghai-based home-shopping network that hawks jewelry and electronics to millions of Chinese households, is showcasing-itself.

title: FusionOne Picks Up $6 Million from V.C.s
description: FusionOne, which creates applications and services for mobile devices, has raised $6 million in a Series A-1 preferred stock round for its mobile content backup services.

title: Podcast: Examining Sadrs Cease-Fire
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: U.S. Joins Countries Investigating Tax Evasion in Lichtenstein
description: Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

title: G.M. Voices Confidence in Lending Business
description: Despite big losses at the auto and mortgage lender GMAC, General Motors is confident that its partner, the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, can fix the troubled financing business.

title: China Railway Seeks to Raise $5.4 Billion in I.P.O.
description: China Railway Construction announced a larger-than-expected $5.4 billion initial public offering that would be the worlds biggest so far this year, despite a cut in the number of shares to be listed in Shanghai amid market weakness.

title: Loss Narrows at Sirius as It Awaits Ruling on Merger
description: Sirius Satellite Radio reported a narrower loss on Tuesday as it awaits regulatory action on its plans to combine with a rival, XM Satellite Radio Holdings.

title: Chinalco Said to Weigh Options in Rio Tinto Stake
description: The Chinese aluminum giant Chinalco, which led a $14-billion investment in the global miner Rio Tinto, has not increased its Rio Tinto holding, despite an agreement that allows them to buy more, according to Reuters.

title: Goldman Sachs Names 2 Vice Chairmen
description: Goldman Sachs said on Wednesday that it had appointed J. Michael Evans and Michael S. Sherwood as vice chairmen of the firm effective immediately.

title: Morgan Stanley, Starwood Sell Tokyo Westin to Singapore Fund
description: The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation bought the Westin Tokyo hotel from Morgan Stanley and the Starwood Capital Group as Morgan Stanley shuffles its Japan portfolio.

title: Novells Big Virtualization Bet
description: Novells $205 million acquisition of PlateSpin, a Canadian provider of virtualization services, represent its biggest bet yet on the server-virtualization business and its largest transaction since 2003.

title: Sun Sews Up MySQL Deal
description: Sun Microsystems on Tuesday announced that it had completed its $1 billion acquisition of MySQL, the open-source database company, and is now on the prowl for similar prey.

title: Och-Ziff Dips Toe into Troubled Mortgage Market
description: The Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, a hedge fund, has tentatively begun buying troubled home loans and will likely expand more aggressively in residential mortgage markets this year, its chief executive, Daniel Och, said on Tuesday.

title: Petroplus Teams Up With Blackstone for Oil Deals
description: Petroplus Holdings has signed a $2 billion deal with private equity firms the Blackstone Group and First Reserve to acquire crude oil refineries in the United States.

title: Suit Against Predator Show Advances
description: Alan Feuer reports:

title: Genesco Adds Charge Against UBS in Fight With Finish Line
description: The legal battle over the $700 million merger of the shoe retailers Genesco and Finish Line is coming to a head.

title: Two Years Before Contract Ends, Suitors Circle Jay Leno
description: Four years ago, NBC made Jay Leno the lame-duck host of The Tonight Show, announcing with fanfare that he would be succeeded by Conan OBrien in 2009, Bill Carter reports in todays New York Times.

title: Pilots Battles Play Havoc With Airline Mergers
description: Merger talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines have been held up for a couple of weeks while pilots at each carrier discuss how to combine their union seniority lists.

title: Smackdown Moving To MyNetworkTV
description: Cherry, Domino, Edge, Hornswoggle, Jimmy Wang Yang and their friends will soon have a new home.

title: Showdown Expected at UBS Shareholders Meeting
description: Switzerlands troubled flagship bank, UBS, was expected to face a disturbed bunch of shareholders at its annual meeting on Wednesday.

title: Activist Investor Raises Stake in Reddy Ice
description: Reddy Ice, the packaged ice maker whose $1.1 billion buyout collapsed in January, may be in for further turmoil as a group of investors, including the Shamrock Activist Value Fund, has increased its stake in the company to 15.6 percent.

title: Small and Midsize Banks Start Struggling in Credit Crisis
description: The credit crisis is tightening the screws on thousands of small to midsize banks across the United States, squeezing local builders and businesses that depend on those lenders for financing.

title: Canada: The Country That Couldnt Say No
description: Canadas takeover-friendly securities laws have helped make the country the easiest in the world for foreign acquirers, according to a new study that shows Canadians are the worlds biggest net sellers of corporate assets in terms of the nations market size.

title: Egypts Citadel Mulls I.P.O. for Venture Fund
description: Citadel Capital, an Egyptian buyout shop with $7 billion under management, is in talks with four international banks to help it sell shares to the public to raise funds for new energy, food and manufacturing ventures.

title: Elliott Hits Cedar Hill With Espionage Suit
description: A hedge fund, Elliott Management, accused Cedar Hill Capital Partners in a lawsuit on Tuesday of corporate espionage by misappropriating Elliott Managements proprietary trading software.

title: Live From Colette | Smile for the T Cam!
description: Here are some more photos from Colette in Paris. T is there putting the stores hyper-cool clientele (like you) on film all week long. Stay tuned for shop shots from our paparazzo. Join the fun by telling us which photos you like the most. Just leave us a comment but be nice!

title: Rubenstein and the Big Buyout Questions
description: As the founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group, one of the worlds biggest private equity firms, David Rubenstein gets asked a lot of questions these days about the fate of the buyout business.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Viktor & Rolf
description: (AFP/Getty Images)

title: Sign of the Times
description: More bad news on the economy today  although Wal-Mart still seems to be doing just fine. But this is not one of its ads:

title: This Is Baghdad
description: Video

title: What New Yorkers Are Missing
description: Heres what you notice when you leave New York and do an intensive stretch of dining elsewhere in the country:

title: Paris Fashion Week | Comme des Garons
description: (Comme des Garcons collection; Ganzalo Fuentes/Reuters)

title: Posers
description: The Bagger has always felt that the Film Experience is a pretty hip blog and this certainly proves it. Lots of pretty hips, lots of hands on them.

title: Neck and Neck
description: The Bagger saw Gary Busey on the carpet last Sunday, but did not ask him a question, in part because he could not think of one besides, What makes your teeth seem so threatening? Is it their size? Their shape? The Crazy Guggenheim stare that floats over them?

title: Take-Two Raised Management Pay Amid Takeover Bid
description: Just days after Take-Two Interactive, the troubled video game maker, received a buyout offer from a rival, Electronic Arts, the board of Take-Two approved a measure that significantly increased the compensation that management would receive in a merger or takeover, according to regulatory filings.

title: Great Taste, Less Coffer-Filling
description: Have the Oscars and the industry it celebrates become a microcosm of the American economy? Think about it. High costs to market something the consumer doesnt seem to want; a reliance on imports, as well as on selling a traditional product at a time when consumers have all manner of new options. Then theres the stubborn unwillingness to meet those consumers on the platform and device of their choosing.

title: L.A. to N.J.
description: The Bagger is outside LAX at Terminal 6, a phrase that pretty much brackets his last six days. Normally, before he hits the red-eye to Newark, he hits the smoking cage to be among his fellow cellmates, they of the off-brand ciggies chain smoked through tattooed fingers. But the smoking cage is closed, with stickers all over it. This was one of the last airports in the country that accommodated smoking  in a town where correctness and prevailing vibe of well-being-whether-you-like-it-or-not persists. It was too good to last.

title: Ad Agencies Are Starting to Bet for the House
description: Wall Street ideas are creeping into the world of online advertising. One of the most controversial topics at the Interactive Advertising Bureaus conference in Phoenix has been the rise of advertising exchanges, that are mean to trade impressions on Web sites the way Nasdaq trades stock.

title: Ranking Corporate America on Identity Theft
description: This is a chart that lots of well-paid corporate executives probably do not want you to see. Based on consumer complaints to the Federal Trade Commission, it purports to rank the overall vulnerability of the worlds largest financial institutions, phone companies and retailers - and their customers - to identity theft.

title: Democrats One Seat Away From Control of State Senate
description: In a major victory for Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his party, a Democratic assemblyman scored an upset victory in a State Senate election on Tuesday in a district that has been in Republican hands for a century, Trymaine Lee reports.

title: Live From Colette | Laetitia Crahay
description: This week, as The Moment blogs from the Colette boutique in Paris, were stalking the fashion faithful as they pass through the chic boutique.

title: Danger: Curves Ahead
description: What is a private equity professional to do when all the talk about credit crunches and distressed debt becomes too much? Shake it off with a spin in a virtual race car.

title: The Early Word: Strong, But Strong Enough?
description: The debate between the Democratic presidential candidates Tuesday night in Cleveland  possibly the last time Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama will meet head-to-head in this campaign  brought up the issues that have become standard, health care mandates, foreign policy and trade deals.

title: The Family Dinner
description: I never thought Id see the day when The Times could offer a first-rate course in playwriting gratis online, but thats what Marsha Norman has provided in her last post. So if any of you havent read it, take a step back and enjoy.

title: White House to World: Well Sign a Binding Climate Pact (Theres a Catch)
description: James Kanter and I have a story in todays paper about a new tack by the Bush administration aimed at clarifying, for Europe particularly, that the United States is not opposed to any new climate treaty  just all of the formulations that have bubbled up since 1992, when the first global pact was accepted by nearly all countries (it was signed by the first President Bush).

title: Auction Set for Michael Jacksons Neverland
description: Statistics released on Tuesday showed that more than 233,000 properties in the United States were foreclosed in January alone, so the addition of just one more person this year would hardly be cause for news coverage. Except, of course, that the person is Michael Jackson, and the property is his Neverland ranch.

title: Worried Sick
description: After last nights debate, the folks at The Corner, National Reviews staff blog, have come down with a case of Obama Fever  meaning, the prospect of Barack Obama as the Democratic presidential nominee is making them feel a little sick to the stomach.

title: Faith in the Operating Room
description: Patients often rely on religious faith to help them cope with illness. But for Milwaukee surgeon Dr. Bruce H. Campbell, operating on a Jehovahs Witness rattled his own faith in himself.

title: An Old Face Rejuvenated
description: New York's General Post Office recently completed an extensive exterior renovation.

title: The View from the Trenches
description: A lot of people talk about the wisdom of crowds. Today, we give you the wisdom of the private equity crowd, straight from Munich.

title: An Old Face Rejuvenated
description: Video

title: Parents Speak Out on 8th-Grade Promotion
description: Educators typically refer to middle school as the critical years, the time when students either hunker down and succeed or get distracted and begin to fail. In January, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his State of the City address to propose ending so-called social promotion for eighth-grade students, just as he has done in earlier grades.

title: Some Morning Joe Before the Yanks Intrasquad Game
description: The Yankees will hold an intrasquad game in about two hours, but the only thing darting around the field now is a cat. Cant say for sure if its black or brown, so I dont know what kind of omen that is. But I bet the Yankees lose today. (And win. Ha, ha.)

title: The Kings of Europe
description: As if there were some other way to determine which is the best soccer team, other than playing the game, a German consulting firm reports that, win-or-lose, Spanish clubs are more popular in Europe than English teams.

title: Good Morning, Pyongyang
description: Musicians from the New York Philharmonic receive a tour of the North Korean capital, including a visit to the Grand People's Study Hall, before performing at the East Grand Theatre.

title: Selig Back on the Hill to Talk Steroids
description: Congress cant get enough of sports and performance-enhancing drugs, so the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Trade and Consumer Protection will hold a hearing Wednesday in which the commissioners and union chiefs of Major League Baseball, the N.F.L., N.B.A. and N.H.L. are testifying.

title: Open Caucus: Ohio Debate Discussion
description: Several of our Open Caucus voters  including one from Ohio  tuned into Tuesdays debate between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, held in Cleveland. A few also watched last weeks debate between the two Democrats in Texas, as well.

title: Recipe of the Day: Fast Roast Chicken
description: There are a couple of very real challenges when you roast a chicken: You need high heat to brown the skin, but superhigh heat may burn it. You need to cook the thighs and legs through before the breast dries out. You want to do the whole chicken as quickly as possible. And if you are interested in minimalist cooking, you must accomplish all this without a lot of fuss.

title: America Closed for Three Hours Today
description: Aired Tuesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Barack Obama said if they make a movie about his life, he would like Will Smith to play him. And Hillary said she would want an older woman who looks good in a pantsuit, so obviously shes picked John Travolta.

title: The No-Chance-in-Hell Vote
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Tonight in Cleveland, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton are debating one another for the 20th time. Experts are calling it redundant, unnecessary, and the most exciting thing that ever happened inCleveland.

title: More on Tomatoes . . .
description: After I made such a fuss about sun-dried tomatoes a few weeks ago, you might have thought Id let the subject of off-season tomatoes die. But no: Im back with some comments about the benefits of oven-roasting canned tomatoes. See todays Minimalist column and accompanying video for more.

title: Stevens to Face Democratic Challenge in Alaska
description: It looks like Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the most senior Republican in the Senate, may have a serious challenger in November.

title: Clemens to Reporters: Get a Life
description: Roger Clemens wheeled his black Hummer into the Houston Astros spring training facility in Kissimmee, Fla., at about 10:40 a.m. on Tuesday. There were roughly two dozen reporters, photographers and camera operators waiting for him. The Rocket is expected to throw batting practice to minor leaguers for the next three days.

title: A Clinton Victory, Certified
description: Its official. Hillary Rodham Clinton carried New York City in the Feb. 5 presidential primary with about 56 percent of the vote, compared to Barack Obamas 43 percent, according to the returns certified on Tuesday by the citys Board of Elections. But Mrs. Clinton won Brooklyn by a mere 1,225 of the more than 273,000 votes cast. The borough has more enrolled Democrats than nearly any other county in the country, and the New York senator had been endorsed by the Democratic county leader and all of Brooklyns members of Congress. Mrs. Clinton carried the 15th Congressional District, represented by one of her earliest supporters, Representative Charles B. Rangel, by 60,573 to 53,165. But within that northern Manhattan district, in the 71st Assembly District, where she was endorsed by Herman D. Farrell Jr., the former Democratic county and state chairman, she narrowly won by only 11,843 to 10,178.

title: Will Publishers Lose Their Bacon if Ads Are Traded Like Pork Bellies?
description: Aside from the Microsoft bid for Yahoo, the biggest topic of conversation at the Interactive Advertising Bureaus convention this week was pork bellies.

title: Gary Busey, Philosopher
description: Sure, Gary Busey may have behaved a little oddly at the Oscars. (Theyre calling it When Busey Attacks  see second video below). Anyway, hes apologized. But did you know the mans a sage? Check it out:

title: Obama and Israel
description: I posted recently about the relative lack of courage on the part of both Senator Clinton and Senator Obama to disagree with primary voters, and I asked readers to cite example of political courage on the part of either of them. Im sure that both senators are far more sympathetic to gay marriage, gun control and free trade, for example, than they let on, and I wish they would show some leadership on issues like those.

title: Bernanke Speaks to Congress
description: CNBC coverage of Ben Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, addressing the House Financial Services Committee.

title: Spitzer Has Options for Turning Things Around
description: Updated, 7 p.m. | The story of Gov. Eliot Spitzers rough-and-tumble first year in office is, by now, well documented: his fight with fellow Democrats over the selection of a state comptroller; his staff members handling of the seemingly interminable scandal known as Troopergate; and his abandonment of a plan to issue drivers licenses to illegal immigrants. Can the governor recover, and if so, how?

title: Campaign Conversations
description: John Harwood of The Times and CNBC talks to Gov. Ted Strickland of Ohio.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Maazel Conducts the State Symphony
description: Lorin Maazel led the State Symphony Orchestra of the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea (the Norths official name) in a brief rehearsal and run-through of the prelude to Die Meistersinger and the fantasy-overture Romeo and Juliet.

title: From Chilly Lakeland, Pelfreys Spring Audition
description: Yes, chilly. I know its all relative. But 53 degrees with 17 mile an hour winds is more like opening day weather in Detroit. Not here.

title: YSL Sell
description: YSL has gotten its revolution on. This week, the Rive Gauche womens boutique reopened to show off its new design concept (read: store design) to Fashion Week editors. Dubbed The Opium Experience (very soixante-huitard!), the persimmon lacquer and pale stone space also features a hint of green: namely CO2-emission-busting ductal concrete that will also reduce water waste.

title: Populist Ads for Democrats
description: Barack Obama, once vocally opposed to outside groups involvement in campaigning, quietly has been letting pro-Obama ads from the Service Employees International Union run in Ohio without much comment.

title: Tributes to William F. Buckley, Conservative Icon
description: Some tributes and other ephemera surfacing across the Web as news spreads of the death of William F. Buckley. The New York Timess obituary, written by Douglas Martin, is here.

title: A Tale of Two Hostiles
description: Electronic Artss unsolicited takeover offer for Take-Two Interactive is unfolding fast: Take-Two, which makes the popular Grand Theft Auto video-game series, has responded to Sundays public bid by Electronic Arts with the flurry of activity that usually follows these kinds of things: golden parachutes, rapid strategic maneuvers of questionable shareholder value and general hostility.

title: German Mistaken for Whitey Bulger, F.B.I. Says
description: Whitey Bulger has found himself at the center of another mandatory kill, though this one was ordered by a photo agency seeking to delete an image from their archives. The alert was prompted by the F.B.I.s admission that they misidentified a German couple vacationing in Sicily as the reputed Boston crime boss and his girlfriend, Catherine Greig.

title: For the Moment | Sarah from Colette, Day Trois
description: (Jessica Antola)

title: Remembering Buckleys 1965 Run for Mayor
description: Updated, 3:55 p.m. | William F. Buckley Jr., who died today at 82, ran for mayor of New York City in 1965, in a bizarre but memorable chapter of the citys political history. Asked what he would do if he won, he famously replied, Demand a recount. He injected a rare degree of lofty oratory into city politics  has any other mayoral candidate ever promised a vision of a new order and the beginning of a new dawn?

title: Q&A on William F. Buckley
description: Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of The Times Book Review and Week in Review, is writing a biography of William F. Buckley Jr., who died Wednesday. Mr. Buckley was for decades the intellectual standard bearer for American conservatism, and he was also one of the 20th centurys truest men of letters: a magazine editor, newspaper columnist, novelist and essayist  the author of 55 books.

title: Obama Reaches 1 Million Donor Mark
description: One million and counting. Thats how many people Barack Obama says have invested in him.

title: Ill Take Rugelach Recipes for $500
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Moonves Unfazed by the 100 Days That Shook Hollywood
description: The good news is the network business is back, proclaimed Les Moonves, the president of CBS Corporation, on Tuesday, hours before the Writers Guild of America formally ratified a new contract with Hollywood studios.

title: Soft Serve | Stolen Bling, Neverland Ranch Sale, Canal St. Raids
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.Tilda Swinton may have picked up a red carpet win for Damiani by wearing their diamond cuff, but the jewelers Milan showroom wasnt quite so lucky. Seven men dug a tunnel through a neighboring building and stole $20 million worth of jewels Next years male Oscar nominees wanting to sport a little bling should check out the diamond cufflinks that Thom Browne has designed for Harry Winston If real estate is your expense of choice, why not throw down for Michael Jacksons Neverland ranch when it hits the auction block on March 19th They may not have a theme park, but Curbeds got a list of the top 10 private pools in the city that may make you spring for a new condo Having trouble waking up in your new pad? Check out this aromatherapy alarm clock that will wake you to favorite scentAmy Winehouse may not be the freshest fashion icon in music, but her style is unmistakable. Now you can buy a piece of the action when she launches her new clothing and make-up line A sad day for fans of felonious fashion. Mayor Bloomberg and the NYPD raided and seized $1 million in goods from Canal St. counterfeiters In Shanghai, the trend is not towards knock-offs, but the rebirth of individualism Youll be hardly alone wearing Marc Jacobs re-launched Hillary tee, but as least it one-ups Senator Clintons boxy pantsuits Soft Serve is sick of todays politics. Check us out tomorrow for more of the spin.

title: Did Your Team Get Jobbed, or Did It Prosper? Part 3
description: Islanders traded LW Chris Simon to Minnesota for a sixth-round selection in 2008.

title: No Backing From Bloomberg in 09 Democratic Primary
description: All those probable Democratic mayoral candidates who may have been hoping for the Midas-touch endorsement of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg next year should stop holding their breath. At a news conference this morning about the greening of the citys black car fleet, the billionaire said that he would not be making any endorsements in that 2009 primary.

title: The Wild, the Innocent and the Chris Simon Shuffle
description: Our colleague Dave Caldwell has a great account of the deal here.

title: Leaving Lenders Behind
description: Cant get funding from a bank? Forget the bank.

title: Oscar Nerds Express Digital Fealty
description: Believe it or not, 5.6 million of you checked into Movieville and Baggertown on the day after the Oscars, enough traffic so that the entire site of the New York Times drew 37.6 million, a big number that suggests that the dotcom at the House of Many Doors outdrew  the Oscars.

title: New York Philharmonic in Asia: After the Big Event, Off to Seoul
description: The Philharmonic left Pyongyang this afternoon for Seoul, where there are no minders, cars fill the roads (boy, do they), shopping is abundant, and a new president was just inaugurated on Monday. The scene at the Pyongyang airport was warm. Many of the musicians and their minders exchanged embraces and warm farewells. There were no exchanges of e-mail addresses, because there is no commonly accessible Internet in North Korea.

title: Obama and McCain Spar Over Iraq
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Senator Barack Obama tangled from afar with Senator John McCain on Wednesday, delivering a spirited retort to Mr. McCains mocking suggestion that Mr. Obama was not familiar with the presence of Al Qaeda in Iraq.

title: Wage Loss a Costly Side Effect of Breast Cancer
description: Among the many challenges women with breast cancer face, heres one most people dont pay attention to: a smaller paycheck.

title: Now Screening | Suzy Menkes with Nicolas Ghesquire
Live From Colette | Maryse and Charlotte Gaspard
description: This week, as The Moment blogs from the Colette boutique in Paris, were stalking the fashion faithful as they pass through the chic boutique.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Dries Van Noten
description: (AFP/Getty)

title: Quarterlife Is a Ratings Flop
description: NBCs new drama Quarterlife, which made its debut on Web sites like MySpace and YouTube, got off to a sluggish start in the network television ratings on Tuesday, drawing just 3.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Bondermans Bright Side
description: Heres one way to sum up the feeling at this weeks Super Return conference: A leading figure in the private equity business predicted a 40 percent drop in deals in 2008  and went on to suggest it could be a lot worse.

title: Mayor Rules Out Run (and a Texas Petition Drive)
description: This time, no may really mean no. On the heels of a WNBC-Marist College poll [pdf] showing that two-thirds of New Yorkers think Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should not run for president, he suggested that an independent campaign is not in his immediate future.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, Feb. 27:

title: The View From Paris, Part Three
description: As usual, I left Paris thinking it was not as good an eating city as New York. Though the variety and creativity are getting there, theres still no comparison.

title: Guess Whos Educating Your Doctor?
description: Its no secret that drug companies sponsor medical conferences and seminars. But a new report by Australian broadcasters shows how drug companies also help select the speakers at those events.

title: Fly Over the Moon
description: This animation depicts a flyover of the moon's south poleregion ending in the vicinity of Shackleton Crater. (Credit: NASA)

title: Hey, Easy, Lady  Were Not Married
description: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: By the way, youre here on a good night: everybody in the balcony in the Ed Sullivan Theater is full of Academy Award-winning strippers.

title: Violence in Serbia Could Spread To Suburbia
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Well, heres a shocking story. You see this on the news last night? Politics, people get so worked up. A man in Pennsylvania stabbed his brother-in-law in the stomach with a knife after they got into a fight over who was a better candidate, Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton. Dont confuse that with Hillary and Barack. They keep stabbing each other in the back.

title: The Private Equity Lawsuit of the Year
description: On Tuesday, in dueling letters by their attorneys to Leo Strine of Delawares Court of Chancery, the full positions of Clear Channel Communications and Providence Equity Partners were finally laid clear.

title: The Tea Bag Basks in Its Moment to Simmer
description: Beverage-centered artsy recycling seems to be all the rage these days. We have bottle caps transformed into coffee cups reborn as coasters, beer bottles recycled as Okinawan glassware, purses, aluminum can tabs woven into handbags, and water bottles refashioned as pet jellyfish (note the Volvic and San Pelligrino versions).

title: Mussina Trying to Hold His Place
description: Spring training pitching rotations have a way of changing with a tweak or a twinge. But starting on Saturday against the Phillies in Clearwater, the Yankees will go with this alignment: Chien-Ming Wang, Andy Pettitte, Mike Mussina, Phil Hughes and Ian Kennedy/Joba Chamberlain. (Kennedy and Chamberlain will pitch on the same day.)

title: An Air-Powered Car by 2009? Dont Hold Your Breath
description: A small French company recently announced that it has produced an air-powered car that will be ready for sale within the year.

title: Wishing for the Old Yodel From Yahoo
description: They wanted more from Jerry Yang.

title: Is Our Children Learning?* Maybe Not.
description: A new report (pdf) is out on what 17-year-olds know, and the news is not good. The study  by a new group with no particular ideological ax to grind, called Common Core  painted a grim portrait of what teenagers know and dont know.

title: Jon Stewart: The Oscars Post-Mortem
description: The Academy Awards, almost as good as The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants:

title: Planning the Office
description: One of the reasons I am more than happy to have just a 13-by-9-foot office is that I dont work the way most people do.

title: In M.L.S., Philadelphia Is Sweet 16
description: Major League Soccer always wanted to be in Philadelphia, and on Thursday the league will make it official: The leagues 16 team will call the City of Brotherly Love (make that the city of Chester, a few miles south of Philly) home.

title: Firing One-Liners
description: William F. Buckley Jr., who died on Wednesday at 82, engaged in some amusing, almost Marxian (as in Groucho) repartee on Hannity & Colmes on May 10, 2005. On the show, everyone is true to form  the conservative icon Buckley, the liberal Alan Colmes and the lunch-bucket, next-generation conservative Sean Hannity. And its all so Fox News Channel. Heres a transcript, from Nexis:

title: A Makeover for Guiding Light
description: Actors from the CBS soap opera Guiding Light rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday morning, capping a month of promotions ahead of the Friday introduction of a new visual style for the show.

title: On Fox, a Moment of Cashing In
description: Fox televised the first truly uncomfortable episode of the lie-detector test show The Moment of Truth on Monday, and the contestant who admitted to adultery now says she only did it for the prize money.

title: Answers About Nature in New York, Part 2
description: Following is a second set of answers from Leslie Day, the author of Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), who is taking questions from readers through Feb. 29. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment box below.

title: Safe House
description: Margaret B. Jones, who grew up in South Central Los Angeles, has now made a home in Eugene, Ore.

title: Ottawa Dumps Paddock
description: The part of Lou Lamoriello will be played this playoff season by Ottawa Senators GM Bryan Murray.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Costume National
description: (Wire Image)

title: Paris Fashion Week | Ann Demeulemeester
description: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment. This week, the Telex comes from Paris womens fashion week.

title: Schools Give Out Free Cellphones
description: A Harvard economists idea  giving free cellphone air time to high-performing students as an incentive to continue doing well  is now in effect. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein today started the Million Motivation Campaign, an experimental program involving about 2,500 students in seven middle schools. The students will each receive a free cellphone, called the Million, with opportunities to earn minutes and other rewards if they achieve academic goals set by their principals.

title: Live From Colette | Portrait of the Shopper
description: Voila, another fresh batch of pictures from Ts photo booth in Colette in Paris. T is there putting the stores hyper-cool clientele (like these folks) on film all week long.

title: Buckleys Way
description: Our revered founder, William F. Buckley Jr., died in his study this morning, begins National Reviews editorial, published at 1 p.m. Eastern. The editorial adds:

title: Live From Colette | The Video Feed
description: Tomorrow is a big day for you and your favorite style blog  The Moment has set up a video camera inside Colette and well be bringing you all the sights and sounds of high-level Paris shopping. If youre swinging by the store, dress to impress your friends at home. See you soon

title: Paris Fashion Week | Emanuel Ungaro
description: (Getty)

title: Blogtalk: A Texas Family Feud
description: A mini tempest, as one Texas blogger calls it, is brewing after two sons of former governor Ann Richards have come out against their sisters assumption that their mom would have been a Hillary Rodham Clinton supporter.

title: Lifting Loan Caps on Fannie, Freddie
description: CNBC interviews James Lockhart, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, on removing caps on the amount of loans owned by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

title: Mega-Church Pastor in Texas Backs McCain
description: SAN ANTONIO  Senator John McCain got support on Wednesday from an important corner of evangelical Texas when the pastor of a San Antonio mega-church, Rev. John C. Hagee, endorsed Mr. McCain for president. Mr. Hagee, who argues that the United States must join Israel in a preemptive, biblically prophesized military strike against Iran that will lead to the second coming of Christ, praised Mr. McCain for his pro-Israel views.

title: Save the American Time Use Survey?
description: Should we save the American Time Use Survey? A coalition of social scientists hope the Bureau of Labor Statistics changes plans to ditch the annual report on budgetary grounds, saying that the trove of data is unlikely to be duplicated elsewhere.

title: Bruno on Election Defeat: The Season Is Not Over
description: This morning, after a humbling defeat in a heated and expensive State Senate race in a heavily Republican district upstate  a seat that Republicans had held for a century  the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, rallied his troops in Albany on Wednesday in an attempt to bolster spirits.

title: Bloggingheads: McCain and Iraq
description:
David Corn of Mother Jones, left, and Matthew Continetti of The Weekly Standard debate how the Iraq war will affect John McCain's campaign.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Boyd Coddington, Hot Rod Hero, Dies at 63
description: Your king is dead, hot-rodders. Long live the king.

title: The Farmer and the Cranes
description: Endangered whooping cranes have found a haven on George West's Tennessee farm -- itself in danger of being swallowed up by development.

title: Like Listening to Golf on the Radio in Mandarin
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Good Country for Old Men (And Women)
description: Oscar is 80 years old this year, Jon Stewart said during the Academy Awards show, which makes him now automatically the front-runner for the Republican nomination.

title: Ask Russians About Their Presidential Election
description: Last week, The New York Times created a Russian-language Live Journal community to give Russian readers a chance to read and discuss articles written by the Moscow bureau. So far, Russian readers have posted more than 4,000 comments.

title: Bloomberg Writes That He Wont Run
description: After teasing us for months and months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York is letting us down easy in an Op-Ed in Thursdays New York Times.

title: Your Comments on my Sudan Column
description: My Thursday column is from Juba, Sudan, and argues that the Sudanese government in Khartoum is moving to restart the brutal war between north and south Sudan. Im afraid that the genocide in Darfur is going to be remembered simply as the prologue to an even more bloodier slaughter that stretches across the entire south of the country as well.

title: Debate Breaks Record For MSNBC
description: Tuesdays duel between Democratic candidates Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama earned MSNBC the highest ratings in its 11-year history.

title: Russias Next President
description: Dmitri A. Medvedev is set to become the new president of Russia, having been personally chosen for the job by President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: An Eco Blogs List and Thoughts on Blogging
description: The other Times, over in Britain, put out a list of its 50 favorite eco blogs on Wednesday and I finally had time to explore it just a bit. There are some fascinating sites that I wasnt aware of. More on those below. Id be interested to hear about your favorites, and any criticisms of their list (or my blogroll at right, for that matter).

title: Respond to Todays Column: Hillary, Buckeye Girl
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Feb. 28 column.

title: Google Goes After Another Microsoft Cash Cow
description: Google is adding a new front to its assault on Microsofts software applications business.

title: Neverland Under Siege
description: Michael Jackson could lose his Neverland Valley Ranch in California, above, unless he pays nearly $25 million before March 19. A five-page filing at the Santa Barbara County Recorders Office said, You are in default of a deed of trust, Reuters reported, citing FoxNews.com. Unless you take action to protect your property, it may be sold at a public sale. Mr. Jacksons representative, Raymone Bain, did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Mr. Jackson has owned the 2,800-acre ranch in the foothills above the California coast since 1988. He has mainly lived abroad since he was acquitted of child molestation charges in 2005.

title: Jack Abramoff, Jack Abramoff ...
description: Anxiety is palpable in the House as lawmakers try to wriggle out of a vote on whether to create an independent Office of Congressional Ethics. Despite last-minute cries of alarm and resistance from both sides of the aisle, the public is counting on Speaker Nancy Pelosi to stand fast and steer this overdue dose of ethics reform to passage.

title: A Revision Makes a Photo Management Software Amenable to Amateurs and Pros
description: Aperture, Apples photo management and editing software, was originally intended as a professional alternative to iPhoto. But since it was released about 18 months ago, a large number of Aperture buyers have been amateur photographers with digital single-lens reflex cameras who want more sophisticated controls.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Feb. 18 about two concerts by the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the age of the twin children of the orchestras music director, David Robertson, who mentioned them in remarks before one concert. They are 5 months old, not 5 years.

title: A Calm Stretch Ends in Newark, but Officials Claim Progress on Crime
description: NEWARK  The day shift almost always stretches into night for this citys homicide detectives, but on Tuesday at a little after 5 p.m., Sgt. Miguel Arroyo threw on his coat, picked up his umbrella, bid the boss good night and headed for the door.

title: Campus Shooting Site to Be Torn Down
description: CHICAGO  The classroom building at Northern Illinois University where a gunman killed five students and himself this month will be demolished and replaced, state officials said Wednesday.

title: An Office Space of Ones Own for Entrepreneurs
description: WITHIN a few months of starting In Good Company Consulting, a business to advise female entrepreneurs, Amy Abrams and Adelaide Fives discovered that they shared something with many of their clients. They, too, needed office space that was well located and professional with a place for private meetings. And they wanted to be near like-minded entrepreneurs.

title: With a Tough Win, Stringer Joins Elite Group
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  There were just a few minutes left in the game, and a milestone was approaching, but C. Vivian Stringer had not had time to think about the possibility of winning for the 800th time. With DePaul, a team that was supposed to be in over its head, refusing to go away, it was a matter of first things first for No. 4 Rutgers.

title: New Jerseys Warning
description: It is hard to remember when any governor used the sort of desperate language that New Jersey Gov. Jon Corzine chose this week to describe his states fiscal crisis. His words should be a sober warning to other states to get their fiscal houses in order before they face a crisis of Trentons magnitude.

title: Putins Chosen Successor Whatzisname
description: Near the end of Tuesday nights Democratic debate between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, one of the moderators, Tim Russert of NBC News, tossed up a jump ball. What can you tell me about the man whos going to be Mr. Putins successor?

title: M.T.A. Plan Shows Less Help From Congestion Pricing
description: Supporters of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to charge people who drive into the busiest parts of Manhattan have promoted it as a way to provide a steady flow of money to pay for improvements to public transportation for decades to come.

title: Microsoft Gets Record Fine and a Rebuke From Europe
description: BRUSSELS  The European antitrust regulator imposed a record $1.35 billion fine against Microsoft on Wednesday in a ruling intended to send a clear message to the worlds largest software maker  and to any other company  of the dangers of flouting Europes competition rulings.

title: Now Windows Users Have Their Own Skinny Contender in the Battle of the Lightweight Laptops
description: Its hard to be the Lenovo ThinkPad X300. While the rest of the world was fawning over Apples ultraslim MacBook Air, Lenovos laptop entered the world with little fanfare, even though it is 0.1 of a pound lighter and runs Windows Vista.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 12 about efforts by hospitals in New York City to expand their emergency rooms misidentified the hospital system with the busiest emergency department, according to the New York State Department of Health, which verifies figures provided by hospitals. It is NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, not Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: Hopping Over to Taiwan for Another Title Shot
description: First, look at only the West hand. What would you lead against four spades? You know that South has a minimum opening bid with 6-3-3-1 shape (six spades and a singleton club). North has asked only meaningless questions, then signed off in four spades. Ignore the given auction, which happened at the second table in the match.

title: A Serious Building, Tailor Made for Fun
description: The butter-hued building with porthole windows rises from the weathered brownstones of Crown Heights like a yellow submarine surfacing from a slate-gray sea. The Brooklyn Childrens Museum, after a six-year, $46 million expansion complicated by financial challenges, is readying itself to open in May.

title: Republicans in Albany Say, Its Not Over
description: ALBANY  In his sprawling suite in the Capitol, a humbled Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, gathered an aging coterie of fellow Senate Republicans on Wednesday morning to commiserate over a fresh defeat and plot a last stand for their beleaguered party.

title: New Louisiana Governor Pierces Brazen Style of Business as Usual
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Downstairs, legislators gnashed their teeth, while upstairs at the Capitol here this week, the new governor claimed victory against the old customs down below.

title: School Board to Pay in Jesus Prayer Suit
description: A Delaware school district has agreed to revise its policies on religion as part of a settlement with two Jewish families who had sued over the pervasiveness of Christian prayer and other religious activities in the schools.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Argentinas struggle to avoid energy shortages attributed an erroneous distinction to Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, the countrys president. She is the first woman to have been elected president  not the first woman to serve in that office. (Mara Estela Pern, known as Isabelita, became president in July 1974 after her husband, Gen. Juan Domingo Pern, died.)

title: Sign Augurs Fordhams 28th Loss
description: Even an electronic sign outside Fordhams Rose Hill Gym on Wednesday night appeared to be pleading for mercy. It advertised, among other things, an interfaith discussion on the subject of Why Do Bad Things Happen to Good People? Inside, for the 28th time in 28 games, in front of another sparse crowd, the universitys womens basketball team trailed its opponent.

title: The Moons Craggiest Stretch Comes Into Focus
description: In the craggy terrain around the Moons south pole, the deepest craters dip 2.5 miles beneath the surface while the peaks reach as high as the highest mountain in North America  a 37,000-foot change of elevation.

title: Bloomberg Says He Will Not Endorse Anyone for Mayor in the 2009 Democratic Primary
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in a move that could darken the friendly relations he has enjoyed with the other branches of city government and change the dynamic of the nascent contest for mayor next year, said on Wednesday that he would not make any endorsements in that races Democratic primary.

title: Cash-Rich, Publicity-Shy, Abu Dhabi Fund Draws Scrutiny
description: Abu Dhabi has about 9 percent of the worlds oil and 0.02 percent of its population. The result is a surfeit of petrodollars, much of which is funneled into a secretive, government-controlled investment fund that is helping to shift the balance of power in the financial world.

title: Dmitri Medvedev, in His Own Words
description: The following are excerpts of speeches by and interviews with Dmitri A. Medvedev, President Vladimir V. Putins hand-picked successor, as posted in English on his campaign Web site.

title: The Long Haul in Afghanistan
description: BRUSSELS

title: McCain and Obama Trade Jabs on Iraq
description: Senator John McCain opened a new line of attack against Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday, accusing him of being willing to surrender Iraq to Al Qaeda.

title: A Touch of Blues-Rock From a Son of the South
description: Strange things appear in Jim Whites songs. There are revelations and tall tales, absurdities and tragedies, Southern roots and existential disorientation. A man sits on a railroad track howling at the moon. Jesus returns driving a motor home, alongside Buddha on a motorcycle and Muhammad in a train. The singer finds himself handcuffed to a fence in Mississippi, where things is always better than they seem.

title: Contract Awarded for Newark Heliport
description: A $10 million contract for the construction of a heliport in Newark has been awarded to Air Pegasus Helicopters, a company that operates heliports in Manhattan and Washington.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,966 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Softball Is Losing a Chance to Celebrate
description: They are the odd couple of Olympic sports, bonded by three bases and home plate. Womens softball and mens baseball have been voted off the Olympic island after this Augusts Summer Games in Beijing.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart with a sports article on Tuesday about the anticipated strength of the Detroit Tigers lineup misstated, in some copies, the year of the statistics for three players who are out of the lineup and for three additions to the team. The totals were from 2007, not 2006.

title: Hamas and Israelis Trade Attacks, Killing Several
description: JERUSALEM  In a sudden surge of violence, an Israeli civilian was killed Wednesday in a rocket attack by Hamas militants from Gaza, the first such fatality in nine months, and at least eight Palestinians, militants and civilians, were killed in Israeli airstrikes before and after the rocket attack.

title: Im Not Running for President, but ...
description: WATCHING the 2008 presidential campaign, you sometimes get the feeling that the candidates  smart, all of them  must know better. They must know we cant fix our economy and create jobs by isolating America from global trade. They must know that we cant fix our immigration problems with border security alone. They must know that we cant fix our schools without holding teachers, principals and parents accountable for results. They must know that fighting global warming is not a costless challenge. And they must know that we cant keep illegal guns out of the hands of criminals unless we crack down on the black market for them.

title: Delay in House Vote on New Ethics Panel
description: WASHINGTON  Facing a bipartisan backlash from lawmakers, the House leadership postponed on Wednesday consideration of a plan for an independent ethics panel to review House members conduct.

title: Editors Note
description: A front-page article on Saturday described a cocaine epidemic in Argentina fed by the consumption of paco, an addictive smokable cocaine residue. The article included an explanatory paragraph about pacos addictive power and toxicity that repeated material from a 2006 article published in The Miami Herald, without attributing it to the newspaper. The correspondent, who had done his own research with Argentine and Brazilian officials on the drug and its effects, should have summarized it in his own words, or credited The Herald.

title: Does Weight Lifting Make a Better Athlete?
description: MIKE PERRY, a 31-year-old rower, trained by himself in Ann Arbor, Mich., for six years while his wife attended medical school. Now he is a member of the United States rowing team and hopes to be selected in a couple of months to compete in the Summer Olympic Games.

title: American Missing in Afghanistan Is Feared Dead
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  An American woman and her Afghan driver who were abducted at gunpoint on Jan. 26 are feared dead, the administrator of her aid organization said Wednesday.

title: William F. Buckley Jr.
description: When William F. Buckley Jr.s God and Man at Yale appeared in 1951, the critic and conservative sage Peter Viereck dismissed it as jejune, a word much favored by Mr. Buckley in his later years to describe views he regarded as uninformed by experience. Mr. Buckleys fierce denunciation of collectivism and atheism on the Yale faculty was all to the good, Mr. Viereck said, but it fell far short of the profound conservative manifesto that needed to be written.

title: Italy: Men Cant Grope...Themselves
description: Whatever their reason might be, a passing hearse or simple discomfort, Italys highest court ruled that men may not touch their genitals in public. The ruling settled an appeal by a 42-year-old worker from Como, north of Milan, who was convicted in May 2006 of ostentatiously touching his genitals through his clothing, though his lawyer argued it was a problem with his overalls. But the court struck against a broader practice: a tradition among some Italian men of warding off bad luck by grabbing the crotch. The court ruled that this has to be regarded as an act contrary to public decency, a concept including that nexus of socio-ethical behavioral rules requiring everyone to abstain from conduct potentially offensive to collectively held feelings of decorum. The judges suggested that if they need to, men can wait and do it at home.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Orchid Extravaganza

title: Outlook Versus Outlook Express?
description: Q. What does Outlook do that Outlook Express doesnt do? Is there any reason to buy Outlook?

title: Saluting Ella Fitzgerald With Scatting and Swinging
description: When one singer pays tribute to another, you often learn as much about the object of veneration as about the performer carrying the torch. So it is with Freda Paynes celebration of Ella Fitzgerald at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. In the show, which runs through Sunday, Ms. Payne, fondly remembered for her 1970 hit Band of Gold, sings Fitzgeralds signature songs, concentrating on the numbers that lean more toward jazz than toward the standards on her songbook albums.

title: McCain Steps Up Criticism of Obama
description: Senator John McCain stepped up his critique of Senator Barack Obama on Thursday by accusing him for the second consecutive day of a willingness to hand over Iraq to Al Qaeda, as the Democratic contenders released record-breaking fund-raising figures.

title: Putting Bad Luck Behind Them, 2 Yankees Focus on Standing Out
description: TAMPA, Fla.  They are right-handers with less than a year of major league service time. Neither has overpowering stuff, and for the Yankees, they are best suited to make occasional starts or pitch in long relief. A rash of injuries to the Yankees rotation last spring was supposed to be their big chance.

title: Aetna Backs Off a Colonoscopy Change
description: Bowing to critics who contended it was putting profits before patients, Aetna said Wednesday that it had suspended  at least temporarily  a plan to stop paying for routine use of a powerful anesthetic in a procedure to screen for colon cancer.

title: Britain Acquires Major Modern Art Collection
description: A collection of 725 works of modern art valued at $250 million has been bought for Britain for $52 million and will tour the country under the ownership and management of the Tate and the National Galleries of Scotland, the museums said on Wednesday. Described as one of the most important holdings of postwar and contemporary international art in private hands, the collection, featuring names like Diane Arbus, Damien Hirst, Jeff Koons, Sol LeWitt, Robert Mapplethorpe (whose portrait of Patti Smith is shown above), Gerhard Richter and Andy Warhol, was assembled over three decades by the art dealer Anthony dOffay. Under the name Artist Rooms, reflecting the concept of devoting individual rooms to particular artists, the works will be seen at museums and galleries across Britain starting in spring 2009. The cost of acquisition, for a price described as Mr. dOffays original cost, was met by the Scottish and British governments, the National Heritage Memorial Fund and the Art Fund. Prime Minister Gordon Brown reacted to Mr. dOffays contribution by saying, Individual acts of generosity like this impact on the lives of millions, and reinforce the U.K.s richly deserved reputation as having a range of world-leading museums and galleries.

title: Technique That Glitters, Music That Hurtles Through
description: One of the improvisational trademarks of the guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel is a high, pinging long tone followed by a briskly descending glissando. Its a dazzling gesture, the sort of thing that elicits whoops and envious murmurs from the musicians in the room. But he makes it seem no more difficult than trailing a finger across a row of percussive bar chimes. The feeling of effortlessness is a big component of his technique.

title: Partisan Split Grows Over Housing Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Just one month after President Bush and Democratic leaders hailed their bipartisan agreement on an economic stimulus plan, the two sides went back to war on Thursday over how to deal with widening damage from the housing and mortgage crises.

title: Buddy Miles, Hendrix Drummer, Dies
description: Buddy Miles, the drummer in Jimi Hendrixs Band of Gypsys and a hitmaker under his own name with the song Them Changes, died on at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 60.

title: Colombia: Rebels Free 4 Politicians
description: Latin Americas largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, freed three men and a woman, all former members of Congress, held in captivity for more than six years after negotiations led by President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela. The release follows Mr. Chvezs success in January in winning the freedom of two other politicians held by the group, known as the FARC. But hopes that it might imminently free more captives, including three Americans and the former presidential candidate Ingrid Betancourt, were dashed by a statement from the guerrillas requesting that Colombias president, lvaro Uribe, demilitarize two areas in the southwest as a venue for a broader prisoner exchange. The hostages released Wednesday said Ms. Betancourt was seriously ill.

title: To G.E., a Chinese Olympics Is Just Made for a Global Message
description: SO, how do you say Imagination at Work in Chinese?

title: U.S. Commander Wants Brief Pause in Troop Cuts
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The commander of American forces in the Middle East says he will endorse a brief pause in troop reductions from Iraq this summer, but then will seek a resumption of withdrawals to ease stress on the overall military and allow him to balance deployments across the volatile region.

title: A Refugee From Gangland
description: Eugene, Ore.

title: Juilliard and Met Meld Opera Training
description: The Metropolitan Opera and the Juilliard School have agreed to pool their resources in a program for young opera singers, as well as pianists who hope to work as vocal accompanists or opera conductors, the two institutions announced Wednesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about the three-part movie The Signal reversed the identities of two directors. Part 2 was directed by Jacob Gentry and Part 3 was directed by Dan Bush. The review also misidentified a character at one point. It is Lewis who is now raging in Part 2, not Ben.

title: An Intriguing Adventure, Too Bad About the Dull Heroine and the Misspellings
description: There is an inherent artificiality in video games. You pretend to be wielding a sword or building a skyscraper when in fact you are just playing with a mouse or controller.

title: Border Patrol Agents Trial in Killing of Illegal Immigrant Starts in Arizona
description: TUCSON  In a patch of desert just north of Mexico, what began as a relatively routine interception a year ago ended when a Border Patrol agent shot and killed an illegal immigrant at close range.

title: William F. Buckley Jr., 82, Dies; Sesquipedalian Spark of Right
description: William F. Buckley Jr., who marshaled polysyllabic exuberance, arched eyebrows and a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse, died on Wednesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82.

title: A Lender Halts U.S.-Backed Student Loans
description: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency, one of the nations largest student loan operations, announced Wednesday that it would suspend making federal-guaranteed loans starting early next month.

title: Boulez Visits With Selections That Sound Like Tomorrow
description: The Chicago Symphony came to Carnegie Hall on Monday and Tuesday. Pierre Boulez, who happily leaves the three Bs and most of the Ms and Ss of the standard repertory to other conductors, offered pieces from the 20th and 21st centuries. On Tuesday there was also music by Berlioz, a 19th-century composer whose beautiful strangeness will assuredly make him sound original in the 22nd.

title: Gannett Picks Head for Newspaper Unit
description: The Gannett Company, owner of USA Today, named Robert J. Dickey president of its newspaper division on Wednesday, succeeding Susan Clark-Johnson, who is retiring in May.

title: 1890s Outside, Loftlike Inside
description: WHEN Ellen Weiman and Dubi Silverstein began dating, they often went for rambles through Lower Manhattan, killing time before a movie or just meandering for the fun of it.

title: House Passes Renewable Energy Credits
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Wednesday approved a bill to extend more than $17 billion in tax credits and other incentives to encourage the production of energy from solar, wind and other renewable sources, and to promote energy conservation. The bill would be financed by ending tax incentives for oil and natural gas producers.

title: When Training Becomes Overtraining
description: "Though it seems innocuous, overtraining isn't just a matter of having overdone things in a workout or two," Gretchen Reynolds writes in her column, "Crash and Burnout." Overtraining is a recognized illness, she writes, one that's similar in some respects to chronic-fatigue syndrome and major depression, with symptoms that might include mood changes, insomnia and fatigue. The conundrum for elite athletes, then, is maximizing training without crossing the line into overtraining. While science doesn't agree on how best to avoid crossing that line, there is consensus on how to treat it: "Rest, rest and more rest," says Robert Schoene, a professor of medicine at the University of California, San Diego.

title: Senator Queries F.D.A. and Spinal Disk Maker
description: A ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked the Food and Drug Administration and the maker of an artificial spinal disk about potential financial conflicts of many doctors involved in the clinical research that led to F.D.A. approval of the device.

title: France: Holocaust Study Plan Tweaked
description: President Nicolas Sarkozys intensely criticized plan for each fifth grader to study the life of one of the 11,000 French children killed in the Holocaust was abandoned at the first meeting of the education ministers advisory group, officials said. Instead, they said, an entire classroom might be paired with a young victim, a proposal the advisers said would be less traumatizing for students and more acceptable to their parents.

title: King and Mellencamp Team Up for Musical
description: Ghost Brothers of Darkland County, a new Southern Gothic musical by Stephen King, the horror writer, and John Mellencamp, the musician, is to open in April 2009 at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta. In a recent interview in Rolling Stone Mr. Mellencamp said that if the musical, about the reverberations of a tragedy in small-town Mississippi, did well in Atlanta, it would head to Broadway.

title: Mendelssohn for Two Parts (of the World)
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea  With international attention focused on the New York Philharmonics music making here, it was time on Wednesday for the North Koreans to show what they could do with Mendelssohn, Wagner and Tchaikovsky.

title: Senate Panel Seeks to Alter Whistle-Blower Law
description: WASHINGTON  Complaining that recent court rulings were thwarting efforts by citizens to report fraud against the government, members of a Senate committee said on Wednesday that they wanted to work with the Justice Department to undo some of the harm they thought the courts had caused.

title: W. C. Heinz, 93, Writing Craftsman, Dies
description: W. C. Heinz, the sports columnist, war correspondent, magazine writer and novelist who was considered one of the finest journalistic stylists of his era, died Wednesday in Bennington, Vt. He was 93.

title: Flu Shots Recommended for Children Through 18
description: All children aged six months to 18 years in this country should receive an influenza shot every year, a federal advisory panel said on Wednesday.

title: Ralph Nader: A Spoiler, or a Welcome Voice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Calls Surveillance Bill an Urgent Priority
description: WASHINGTON  Using some of his toughest language in weeks, President Bush prodded Congress on Thursday to pass his preferred version of surveillance legislation, asserting that every day of delay could put the country in danger.

title: New Pitch for Mickelson, Just for Laughs
description: SAN DIEGO  The commercial shoot seemed to be going along just fine Tuesday. The star was delivering his ad-libbed lines with aplomb, nicely timed one-liners, and his arch eyebrows were raised just so, displaying facial expressions that stretched into a winsome, nonplussed look. But there was a slight problem.

title: Never Too Young for That First Pedicure
description: ONE recent rainy afternoon, Eleanor LaFauci, 7, sat with her feet in open-toed foam slippers, admiring her toenails, freshly painted watermelon pink.

title: Congress Requests Clemens Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  A Congressional committee asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to investigate whether Roger Clemens made false statements under oath about his suspected use of steroids and human growth hormone, strengthening the possibility that he could be charged with perjury.

title: A Genocide Foretold
description: JUBA, Sudan

title: Reporters Seeking Reaction From Clemens Receive Brushback
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Roger Clemens did a lot of throwing, but very little talking, in his first day as an intensely scrutinized batting-practice pitcher for the Houston Astros. Clemens essentially ignored questions from reporters during his three-and-a-half-hour visit to the teams spring training complex Wednesday.

title: Also in this Issue ...
description: -- In "Daddy's Little Phenoms," Pat Jordan writes about Ginger and Robbi Howard, two junior golfers in Florida whose father has an ambitious master plan -- to create the Williams sisters of golf.

title: Pelfrey Hopes First Outing Becomes a Lasting Impression
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  The Mets ride here was timed at a cool 2 hours 30 minutes. And when they shook the sleep out of their eyes and tottered off the bus, they encountered a frightening possibility: Were they still in Florida, or had the driver misread the directions and zoomed past Tigertown, all the way to Detroit?
