title: Undercurrents of Hope in a Region of Turbulence
description: Few American journalists are as familiar with the Middle East as Robin Wright. Having first visited Iran in 1973, lived in Beirut in the 1980s and chronicled the region on repeated trips since then, she has a deep mix of on-the-ground knowledge, awareness of the historical background and step-back policy perspective. She wrote one of the first books on militant Islam (Sacred Rage) and two others on Iran.

title: Winehouse Seeks Delay in Drug Case
description: A lawyer for Amy Winehouse has asked a court in Norway to postpone a hearing on Friday related to her arrest in October on a charge of drug possession in Bergen, The Associated Press reported. She and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were held overnight at the time and released after paying fines of $715 each. She later appealed, contending that the police made mistakes in handling the case, involving a quarter-ounce of marijuana. ... A lawyer for the singer Bobby Brown said a Brockton County District Court clerk magistrate in Massachusetts had found no probable cause to issue a criminal complaint against Mr. Brown, whom the police found in possession of a small amount of cocaine in December. Mr. Brown, formerly married to Whitney Houston, agreed to a years community service, and the lawyer said the matter would be struck from the docket if no problems involving Mr. Brown arise in the next year.

title: Where to Find Help (and Self-Help)
description: FOR those paralyzed by the fear of galleries and large expenditures, below are a few tips from art consultants and other experts.

title: Twists in Chain of Supplies for Blood Drug
description: RUGAO, China  With reports of more than 400 patients in the United States suffering serious complications after receiving the blood-thinner heparin, American investigators are trying to determine whether the raw material for the drug, made from pig intestines, became contaminated on the journey that begins in the slaughterhouses of China.

title: Hot, Hotter, Hottiest
description: PUNXSUTAWNEY PHIL knows nothing. If there was any sign earlier this month that spring was around the corner, it was the sight of the stylist Tina Chai standing at the summit of the Bryant Park steps in shoes the color of daffodils. She had purloined the lace-up stilettos from Thakoons fall 2008 collection (as the show stylist, Ms. Chai is allowed such indiscretions) and paired them with dark tights and a leopard print coat. Amid the sea of fashion-editor black, she looked like a ray of sunshine.

title: Guggenheims Provocative Director Steps Down
description: After nearly 20 years, Thomas Krens, the provocative director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, is stepping down, its board announced on Wednesday.

title: Chief Is Leaving the About.com Unit of The Times
description: The chief executive of About.com, The New York Times Companys lucrative information and advice site, said Wednesday that he would leave the company next week.

title: Clocking Your Internet Speed
description: Q. My broadband Internet connection seems to be slower than advertised and is noticeably pokey at certain times. What might be causing this slowness, and how I can find out how fast my connection really is?

title: Humane Society Sues U.S. in Cattle Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Humane Society of the United States sued the Agriculture Department on Wednesday for creating a loophole that it said is permitting potentially sick cows into the food supply.

title: Iraqs Legal System
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying Times for the Remaining Nader Faithful
description: Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Orchids Without Tears
description: Orchids Without Tears

title: Qaeda Suspect Escapes
description: A Singaporean man who was once one of the most hunted terrorist suspects in Southeast Asia escaped from a detention center in Singapore on Wednesday, the government announced.

title: Footnotes
description: Jim Shepard has won the $20,000 Story Prize. This four-year-old award for short-story collections honors his 2007 volume, Like Youd Understand Anyway (Alfred A. Knopf). ... A federal judge in Los Angeles has postponed the wiretapping trial of the Hollywood private investigator Anthony Pellicano and co-defendants until March 5 to give lawyers more time to prepare. ... The modest East Hollywood bungalow that was once the rented residence of the hard-drinking poet and novelist Charles Bukowski (1920-1994) has been designated a civic landmark by the Los Angeles City Council, The Associated Press reported.

title: Early Obama Promise on Money Becomes Target
description: Just 12 months ago, Senator Barack Obama presented himself as an idealistic upstart taking on the Democratic fund-raising juggernaut behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Pictures From a Democratic Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about commercials that ran during the Academy Awards show on Sunday, referred incorrectly to Killing the Blues, a song featured in a commercial for J. C. Penney. Although the recording heard is from a new album by Alison Krauss and Robert Plant, the song itself is not new. (It is by John Prine and has been recorded by many artists.)

title: The Terrible Toll of Art Anxiety
description: TEDDY GREENSPAN is a longtime art collector who does not suffer doubt. He is a bond salesman at Libertas Partners, in Greenwich, Conn., and he and his wife, Emily, recently created an art consulting company in Bedford, N.Y., called tag-arts. The pieces he sells average about $20,000, with a few selling for as much as $90,000; his clients, many of whom work in the financial fields, can well afford them. So you can imagine his frustration when dealing recently with a friend and potential client he calls Mr. No-Name Hedge Fund Manager.

title: Former Prosecutor to Testify for Detainee
description: Until four months ago, Col. Morris D. Davis was the chief prosecutor at Guantnamo Bay and the most colorful champion of the Bush administrations military commission system. He once said sympathy for detainees was nauseating and compared putting them on trial to dragging Dracula out into the sunlight.

title: Tyree Talks the Talk, and Also Wears the Helmet
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  The helmet that Giants wide receiver David Tyree wore and used to help secure Eli Mannings pass in the waning minutes of the Super Bowl glistened under the lights at the Yogi Berra Museum on Wednesday, proving that it was not covered in bubble gum or Velcro.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday by The Associated Press about the crash of a B-2 stealth bomber misspelled the name of the Air Force base in Guam from which the plane took off. It is Andersen Air Force Base, not Anderson.

title: He Listens. He Cares. He Isnt Real.
description: COMPASSION is an aphrodisiac. It is a potent elixir for sure to those who tune in to HBO five nights a week to watch Gabriel Byrne play Dr. Paul Weston, the rumpled, world-weary shrink of In Treatment.

title: Rice Offers Regret After Marine Is Accused of Rape on Okinawa
description: TOKYO  Hoping to prevent outrage here from harming ties between the United States and Japan, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice expressed deep regret on Wednesday over a case in which an American marine is accused of raping a 14-year-old Japanese girl on Okinawa.

title: A Plan to Keep the C.W.S. in Omaha
description: In an effort to keep the College World Series in Omaha, city officials on Wednesday announced plans to replace Rosenblatt Stadium with a $140 million downtown ballpark that would open in 2011.

title: Celtics' Bench Mantra: 'Pinch Me'
description: Fortunes have changed dramatically for the Boston Celtics this season. But as Chuck Klosterman writes in "What a Difference a Man Makes," a number of players from the luckless 2007 team still play for the successful 2008 version, including several bench players. "These are the same people, living in the same city, holding the exact same jobs - yet so much about their lives has changed," he writes. Credit Kevin Garnett, the superstar acquired in the offseason. Brian Scalabrine, a seven-year veteran in the league and one of team's returning role players, tells Klosterman: "Look, I can keep saying a million clichs, but those clichs are going to be true... He demands a different level of focus from everybody." Still, the question remains: Can the Celtics, built around aging veterans with little playoff success, have more than a good regular season?

title: BMW Plans to Eliminate 8,100 Jobs
description: FRANKFURT  BMW announced Wednesday that it was eliminating 8,100 jobs, as the rising euro pushed the company into the kind of tough cost-cutting it had resisted.

title: At Fiery Meeting, UBS Shareholders Back Bid to Raise Cash
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Managers of the troubled Swiss bank UBS won shareholder backing Wednesday for a plan to raise capital, but only after facing fierce criticism over the huge write-downs on subprime investments that led to the banks first annual loss.

title: Moving Forward Quickly After the Unification of Open-Wheel Racing
description: Tony George described the merger of his Indy Racing League and the Champ Car World Series as a unification at a news conference Wednesday in Homestead, Fla., but it sounded as if Georges open-wheel series would be virtually swallowing up its rival.

title: $60 Million Gift Is a Record, for Stony Brook
description: James H. Simons, a mathematician turned investor, may be one of the worlds most successful  and wealthy  hedge fund managers, but he can remember how Stony Brook University gave him a berth after he lost his job as a Defense Department code-breaker for protesting the Vietnam War.

title: The Modern Nursery, Batteries Required
description: MODERN technology aids in many of lifes experiences, with one noticeable oversight: raising infants.

title: McCains Canal Zone Birth Prompts Queries About Whether That Rules Him Out
description: WASHINGTON  The question has nagged at the parents of Americans born outside the continental United States for generations: Dare their children aspire to grow up and become president? In the case of Senator John McCain of Arizona, the issue is becoming more than a matter of parental daydreaming.

title: Justices Take Up Battle Over Exxon Valdez
description: WASHINGTON  The Exxon Valdez oil spill, which caused a 3,000-square-mile oil slick and still affects Alaskas fisheries after nearly 19 years, was a tragedy, Exxons lawyer told the Supreme Court on Wednesday.

title: U.S. and India to Strengthen Security Ties
description: NEW DELHI  With a landmark nuclear energy pact between the United States and India stalled, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that the nations would nonetheless strengthen their security ties as India looked to embark on a closer  and still contentious  level of military cooperation with the United States.

title: Council Vote for Good Health May Weaken Business at Groceries in Poor Neighborhoods
description: They are fixtures of New York City life: sidewalk peddlers and the grocers who try to shoo them away from their storefronts. The City Council grudgingly added to that time-honored clash on Wednesday, approving a bill that will increase the number of fruit and vegetable carts in the citys poor neighborhoods.

title: Sprint Nextel Posts $29.5 Billion Loss
description: Daniel R. Hesse, Sprint Nextels new chief executive, tells it like it is  but on Thursday, investors didnt like what they heard.

title: Europe to Review Rules After Bailouts of 2 Banks
description: FRANKFURT  European Union regulators on Wednesday said they would investigate whether bailouts of two German banks hit by the subprime lending crisis had violated rules on state aid for ailing enterprises.

title: Dell Misses Forecast as Profit Falls
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A year after it began a fundamental transformation of its basic formula, Dell missed analysts forecasts on Thursday for quarterly net income and revenue.

title: Tip of the Week: Adding Songs to an iTunes Playlist
description: Want to quickly add a song in iTunes to a playlist without dragging it? Right-click (or control-click) on the songs title in the iTunes window. Choose the Add to Playlist option from the menu and select a playlist; you can also select multiple songs and add them this way. And if you want to see how many playlists contain a certain song, click the song title and choose the Show in Playlist option to see a list.

title: Catholic Principal Was Fired Over Photos, Official Says
description: The principal at a prominent Catholic boys high school in the Bronx was ousted late last week after photos of nude men were discovered on his computer, a law enforcement official confirmed on Wednesday.

title: Ranking Officer Expected to Testify About Sean Bells Killing
description: Prosecutors in the trial of three detectives accused in the shooting death of Sean Bell plan to call the detectives commanding officer to testify on Thursday about the club enforcement detail that he supervised, and to be questioned about supposed blunders it made, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

title: Paparazzo Loses Case
description: A celebrity photographer who sued an Australian newspaper for defamation after it accused him of hounding Nicole Kidman has lost his case, The Associated Press reported. Not only did Justice Carolyn Simpson of the New South Wales Supreme Court find against the photographer, Jamie Fawcett, below, she also called his conduct intrusive and threatening and ordered him to pay the legal costs of Fairfax Media, the publisher of the newspaper he sued, The Sun-Herald. Ms. Kidman was a star witness in the case. Mr. Fawcett, who, the judge found, tried to bug the Kidman house in Sydney and engaged in a dangerous car chase, said he would probably appeal the courts decision.

title: Black Leader Changes Endorsement to Obama
description: DALLAS  Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday accepted the endorsement of Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat and longtime African-American political leader, who switched his support from the presidential candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Private Medicare Plans Cost Questioned
description: WASHINGTON  Private Medicare plans often cost beneficiaries more than the traditional government-run Medicare program, Congressional investigators say.

title: Beanie Babies Updated With a Web Connection
description: Toy collectors and cultural anthropologists, take note. The Beanie Babies 2.0 Collection has arrived in stores, with a Web-ready scratch-off code on every heart-shaped tag.

title: The Boss's Legacy
description: Jonathan Mahler writes in this weekend's PLAY about the succession strategy within the Yankees, with George Steinbrenner firmly in the background and his two sons taking over control of the team. Though the original Boss hasn't left the scene entirely, this seems like a good time to take stock of his 24-year stewardship: When all is accounted for -- his six championships, his free spending, his blunders, his bluster, his impact on baseball overall -- how do you think we should view the elder Steinbrenner?

title: Personality Plus: A Twin Takes Over
description: IT was hard to tell just who was talking over a plate of scrambled eggs at a cafe in the West Village on Tuesday: was it Elisa DeCarlo, a playwright and part-time vintage dealer, or her online alter ego, the Mad Fashionista? But neither one of her personalities was very pleased with the red carpet parade at Sunday nights Oscars.

title: Panel Advises Flu Shots for Children Up to Age 18
description: All children ages 6 months to 18 years in this country should receive an influenza shot every year, a federal advisory panel said on Wednesday.

title: Federal Regulators to Ease Rules on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: Federal regulators for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the biggest buyers of American home mortgages, will remove limits on the amount of loans and securities the companies can own, a step that could help bolster the weakening housing market.

title: Lottery Numbers
Heralded New Law Is Vetoed by Iraqs Presidency Council
description: BAGHDAD  Political momentum in Iraq hit a sudden roadblock on Wednesday when a feud between the largest Shiite factions led to the veto of a law that had been passed with great fanfare two weeks ago. The law had been heralded by the Bush administration as a breakthrough for national reconciliation.

title: David Watkin, 82, Cinematographer, Dies
description: David Watkin, a British cinematographer best known for the scenic splendor he framed for Out of Africa and for capturing the loping strides of runners on the beach in Chariots of Fire, set to the symphonic score by Vangelis, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Brighton, England. He was 82.

title: Family Saga, Steinbrenner Style
description: From the moment Hank Steinbrenner commandeered Jonathan Mahler's rental car, navigated it through Tampa then swerved onto a walkway at Legends Field and pulled to stop a few feet from his offices, Mahler could sense something "very Steinbrennarian" about the older son who was taking command of the New York Yankees, along with his brother Hal. "Hank was in exile for so many years," Mahler said the other day, "but he's clearly quite comfortable stepping into this role."

title: 1 in 100 U.S. Adults Behind Bars, New Study Says
description: For the first time in the nations history, more than one in 100 American adults is behind bars, according to a new report.

title: Ousted Thai Premier Returns to Face Charges
description: BANGKOK  Saying I miss my motherland, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra returned to Thailand on Thursday, 17 months after being ousted in a coup, and said he was ready to face corruption charges that have been brought against him.

title: Ill Have What Shes Having
description: COMPARED with an array of beverages, sports drinks are wildly skewed to men, said David Lockwood, a director of research at Mintel International, a market research group. Part of the reason, he said, is that women tend to avoid the high calories and salty taste. Manufacturers are coming out now with lower-calorie, lighter-flavored drinks aimed at fit women.

title: Cheruiyot Seeks 4th Boston Title
description: No Kenyan man has won four Boston Marathons, but three Kenyans have won three each. One of them is Robert Kipkoech Cheruiyot, and race officials announced that he would return April 21 for the 112th running of the race. His main challengers will include Patrick Ivuti and James Kwambai, also from Kenya. In the Chicago Marathon last October, Ivuti outleaned Jaouad Gharib of Morocco, the world champion. Kwambai finished second in Boston last year.

title: Clintons Efforts on Ethanol Overlap Her Husbands Interests
description: To big rounds of applause, three of the worlds richest men  Richard Branson, Ronald W. Burkle and Vinod Khosla  trooped onto a New York ballroom stage with former President Bill Clinton to pledge support for renewable energy projects to combat global warming and create jobs.

title: New Jersey Braces for Cuts Sought by the Governor
description: TRENTON  From the emergency rooms of city hospitals to hayfields in horse country, from motor vehicle offices to small towns and state parks, New Jersey residents began bracing on Wednesday for the upheaval that Gov. Jon S. Corzines plan to reduce the state work force by 3,000 people and eliminate three government departments is expected to cause.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about homeowners who hire professional photographers to take pictures of their houses misidentified Juergen Nogai, who was shown with two such homeowners. He is a photographer and the business partner of another photographer, Julius Shulman, who was also pictured. Mr. Nogai is not Mr. Shulmans assistant.

title: For A Students in Some Brooklyn Schools, a Cellphone and 130 Free Minutes
description: Whats the cheapest way to text message your friends? For thousands of the citys middle school students, the answer now is to earn an A.

title: They Come Bearing Mystique
description: Paris

title: Winning Parties, Urging Unity, Press Pakistans Leader to Convene Parliament
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Nawaz Sharif, a former prime minister and an opposition leader, on Wednesday increased the pressure on President Pervez Musharraf by urging him to call a session of Parliament and contending that the three opposition parties discussing a coalition had won two-thirds of the seats.

title: Europe Fines Microsoft $1.3 Billion
description: BRUSSELS European antitrust regulators on Wednesday fined Microsoft $1.3 billion for failing to comply with a 2004 judgment that the company had abused its market dominance. The new fine by the European Commission was the largest it has ever imposed on an individual company, and brings the total in fines imposed on Microsoft to about $2.5 billion, in current exchange rates.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A listing of American military deaths on Tuesday misstated the number of confirmed dead in the Iraq war as of then. It was 3,962, not 3,961. An updated Names of the Dead appears on Page A10 today.

title: Think of Adidas, by Way of Porsche
description: AT least twice a year, a fashion reporter will write an article about The New Modesty, declaring that clothes are finally returning to well-constructed tailoring of subtlety and restraint. Then, in the same publication, you will see a fashion spread of an impossibly chiseled man in a python codpiece straddling a Russian supermodel wearing a bikini made of pink dental floss, and you wonder (1) what that writer was on; and (2) if humanity will ever be sophisticated again.

title: Supreme Court Alters Tone in Discrimination Case
description: WASHINGTON  The failure to file the proper form to complain about job-related age discrimination does not deprive an employee of the ability to go into court later with a discrimination lawsuit, the Supreme Court ruled Wednesday.

title: Robust Moves, Exuberant Yet Distinguished
description: Ballet de Monterrey traveled many miles from its home in northeastern Mexico to land at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. For the occasion the company laid out quite a spread: eight short dances featuring pageboy wigs, broken hearts, tango encounters, a stage that resembled a scene out of the 1982 film Tron, spooky masks, a Day of the Dead celebration and star-crossed lovers. But what really stood out in every work, no matter the tone, was exuberant dancing, occasionally blurred by exhaustion yet distinguished by willful, effervescent classicism.

title: Mine Water Poses Danger of a Toxic Gusher
description: LEADVILLE, Colo.  In a snowswept trailer park, Emily Medina wakes each morning wondering whether she will be washed away by toxic water that local officials fear could burst from a decaying mine tunnel near her home.

title: Freedom for Cubans
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands Are Warned of Clinics Dirty Syringes
description: LAS VEGAS  Thousands of patients may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus because of an inappropriate medical practice at an outpatient clinic here over the past four years, state health officials said Wednesday.

title: If You Build It ...
description: The goal of Dubai Sports City is both grand and simple: to be the ultimate destination for athletes and fans. And no expense is spared in the process.

title: Pop Sales Resume Slide
description: Last weeks Billboard chart had some rare good news for the music industry, with sales bumps for Amy Winehouse and Herbie Hancock in the wake of their Grammy victories. But now its mostly back to the doldrums. Jack Johnsons Sleep Through the Static (Brushfire/Universal) is No. 1 for a third week with a respectable 105,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. From there the numbers plunge. Alicia Keyss As I Am (J) is No. 2 with 53,000, and Ms. Winehouses Back to Black (Universal Republic) is right behind it with 52,000; the new Kidz Bop 13 (Razor & Tie) sold 49,000 copies to reach No. 4, and the soundtrack for Step Up 2 the Streets (Atlantic) rose five spots to No. 5, though its 43,000 sales were slightly less than the week before. Chris Cagles My Lifes Been a Country Song (Capitol Nashville) opened at No. 9 with 37,000.

title: Businesses, Worried About Economy, Invest Less
description: Hesitant about the shaky economy, American businesses are cutting back on investments and equipment. And the housing industry, in its worst crisis since the early 1990s, is poised for several months of anemic sales.

title: Poor Start for Quarterlife
description: NBCs new drama Quarterlife, which made its debut on the Internet, got off to a sluggish start in the network television ratings on Tuesday, drawing just 3.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The new series, from the creators of My So-Called Life and Thirtysomething, Marshall Herskovitz and Edward Zwick, finished third in the 10 p.m. time slot behind CBSs Jericho (6.9 million) and ABCs Primetime (7.6 million). NBC ranked third for the night over all in total viewers but second among adults 18 to 49, thanks to a solid showing for The Biggest Loser from 8 to 10 (8.1 million). Fox dominated the nights ratings with American Idol at 8 (28.5 million), followed by Back to You, which earned a series-high 12.3 million viewers at 9:30. CBS was runner-up in total viewers for the night but third in the 18-to-49 set. ABC finished fourth.

title: Black Ohioans Backing Clinton Feel the Pressure to Switch
description: CLEVELAND  The way Eugene R. Miller was hemming and hawing about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, you would have thought he was trying to sell igloos in the Sahara.

title: Despite Nafta Attacks, Clinton and Obama Havent Been Free Trade Foes
description: As they have tussled for votes in economically beleaguered Ohio, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both excoriated the North American Free Trade Agreement while lobbing accusations against their opponent on the issue.

title: Some Fear the Scope of Nortel Is a Liability
description: OTTAWA  For investors in Nortel Networks, Wednesdays news release fit a familiar pattern.

title: Bloomberg Says He Wont Run but Will Be Active
description: Bringing an end to a long flirtation with a bid for the White House, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has officially closed the door on a presidential candidacy this year.

title: Gates Urges Limits on Turkish Raids
description: BAGHDAD  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates urged Turkish leaders on Wednesday to abandon their invasion of guerrilla-controlled lands in the northernmost reaches of Iraq by mid-March.

title: A PC That Imagines Itself on the Move Between Home Office and Living Room
description: If desktop computers are ever going to get out of the home office, they need to be smaller, prettier and quieter. The Asus Nova P22, priced at $749 to $899 depending on options, is a step forward in all three directions, weighing just under 4 pounds and measuring 9 by 7.2 by 2 inches.

title: Its Not a Cellphone, but Itll Get Your Words Across
description: The Sony Mylo Personal Communicator COM-2, or Mylo 2, is a device situated firmly in the netherworld between laptops and cellphones. It has Wi-Fi and a touch screen, but it can make only Skype phone calls. It has a keyboard, but you wouldnt want to type your novel into it. Its not a media player, but it can handle audio, photos and video.

title: Black Cars Are Destined to Turn Green
description: Those long lines of sleek black cars that idle outside corporate headquarters, belching exhaust as they wait to shuttle executives from meeting to meeting, will become more environmentally friendly under a plan announced on Wednesday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Wines Global Reach Brings New Buyers to Bordeaux
description: ST.-MARTIN-DU-PUY, France  The chateaus walled courtyard under the gracefully decaying 15th-century tower and the irregular pond, stone-lined and shaped roughly like a kidney, caught Haiyan Chengs eye.

title: 18 Finalists for Hall Announced
description: Brian Boitano, Joan Benoit Samuelson, Oscar De La Hoya and David Robinson head a list of 18 finalists announced Wednesday for the United States Olympic Hall of Fame. The public will select six inductees.Boitano won the gold medal in mens figure skating in 1988. In 1984, Samuelson won the first Olympic marathon for women. De La Hoya won boxings lightweight gold medal in 1992 and Robinson basketball gold medals in 1992 and 1996.The other individual finalists are Greg Barton (kayak), Bruce Baumgartner (wrestling), Jeff Blatnick (wrestling), Valerie Brisco (track and field), Teresa Edwards (basketball), Karch Kiraly (volleyball), Mary T. Meagher (swimming), Sheila Young Ochowicz (speed skating), Darrell Pace (archery), Michael Plumb (equestrian), John Smith (wrestling), Amy Van Dyken (swimming), Peter Westbrook (fencing) and Lones Wigger (shooting).

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article in some editions last Thursday about concerns that New York Citys plans to rezone 125th Street in Harlem would force out many black residents and small businesses referred incompletely to a street scene along East 125th Street, shown in the picture at left. It was taken in 1975. (The picture at right showed a current scene of nighttime commerce between Fifth Avenue and Malcolm X Boulevard.)

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How can I create a faux brick wall in my home?

title: Chile: 11 Die as Plane Crashes Into Ball Field
description: A small police plane crashed into a soccer field in Santiago, the capital, where dozens of women and children were enjoying their first day of aerobics classes, and burst into flames. The planes six occupants and three women and a child on the field were killed immediately. Another woman, seriously burned, died later. Seven other women were said to have suffered critical burns. The cause of the crash was unknown. The plane, a Cessna, crashed minutes after taking off from the nearby Tobalaba airport, which residents have been demanding be relocated from the populous residential area.

title: George Mason Calmer 2 Years After Final Four Run
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  After George Masons unimaginable Final Four run in 2006, Patriots forward Will Thomas found that visits to the dining hall inevitably regressed into eat-and-greets.

title: Bush and Czech Leader Close to Deal on Radar
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush and the Czech leader said Wednesday that they were close to an agreement on a plan for the United States to install an early warning radar system in the Czech Republic, a key component of a missile defense system that has drawn stiff opposition from Russia.

title: Hillary, Buckeye Girl
description: ZANESVILLE, Ohio

title: A Little Nuke Music
description: The New York Philharmonics concert in Pyongyang was a tantalizing taste of what might be in Americas relationship with North Korea. It was also a reminder of the missteps and dangerously wrongheaded judgments that have kept the two countries apart and at saber-point for more than a half century.

title: In a Season of Lows, a High Point Is Reached
description: When Jamal Crawford inexplicably threw himself an alley-oop off the backboard and missed the dunk attempt, and when Coach Isiah Thomas did not budge from his seat on the bench, the Madison Square Garden crowd knew it was the Knicks night.

title: China Says Poisoning Was Isolated
description: BEIJING (Bloomberg News)  The Chinese government reported Thursday that the pesticide-laced dumplings that sickened at least 10 people in Japan might have been deliberately poisoned, but that its investigators found no evidence that the contamination had occurred in China.

title: A Surrealistic Journey to Mexico With Paul Taylor
description: The rehearsal studio is narrow and a little battered, with uncompromising sunlight pouring in from windows overlooking Broadway. Paul Taylor watches his dancers, his big, lean, denim-clad body hunching into his chair, a cigarette constantly in hand and a cup of coffee never far. An invisible curtain rises on a flesh-and-blood dancer, a smiling Mexican flower seller who seems to have stepped out of a travel poster just as the music begins for De Sueos (Of Dreams) and De Sueos Que Se Repiten (Of Recurring Dreams), new works that are centerpieces of the Paul Taylor Dance Companys City Center season, which opens on Thursday.

title: Top F.T.C. Official Expected to Resign
description: The chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission is expected to resign her post next month to take a senior position at Procter & Gamble, according to people briefed on her plans.

title: Easing the Pain of Collecting
description: JEN BEKMANS apartment is hardly what you would expect from a woman who has made herself a force in the art world in the last five years, building a photography and fine arts Web site that draws international collectors and earning an innovator-of-the-year title from American Photo magazine.

title: Detroit Mayor Loses Fight Over Secret Papers
description: DETROIT  The Michigan Supreme Court on Wednesday ordered the release of a trove of documents that revealed how Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit and city lawyers tried to cover up Mr. Kilpatricks extramarital affair with his chief of staff, as well as text messages that could expose the mayor to perjury charges.

title: Building a Web of Influence
description: IVE always thought Id make a great chief executive of a Fortune 500 company. I have strong organizational skills, for instance, and I would be happy to slash redundant divisions to raise the stock price.

title: Bernanke Says Sagging Growth Is Chief Concern
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, signaled his readiness on Wednesday to bolster the economy with cheaper money even though inflation is picking up speed.

title: As Gaming Turns Social, Industry Shifts Strategies
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Even before Electronic Arts roiled the video game world on Sunday with its $2 billion hostile takeover bid for Take-Two Interactive, even before Phil Harrison, president of Sonys worldwide game studios, announced his resignation on Monday, one could plainly see the creative and financial disruptions underlying the industrys explosive growth.

title: Longtime Clinton Aide Returns to the Fray
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Harold M. Ickes may be Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons last hope for winning the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Nonprofit Diabetes Group Is Subject of Investigation
description: The Manhattan district attorney is investigating the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International after an internal audit showed that hundreds of thousands of dollars was missing. The audit led to the dismissal of two foundation employees.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a lawsuit filed against energy companies by an Alaska Native coastal village that is being forced to relocate because of flooding caused by the changing Arctic climate misstated the estimated cost of moving the village. It could cost up to $400 million, not up to $400,000.

title: Putins Anointed Heir Shows Hints of Less Icy Style
description: ALABINO, Russia  Dmitri A. Medvedev, the man chosen to be the next Russian president, sat surrounded by soldiers. It was Feb. 23, Defenders of the Motherland Day, and Mr. Medvedev had traveled to the parade grounds of the Tamanskaya Motorized Rifle Division outside Moscow.

title: Bill Gates and Other Happenings at LinkedIn
description: Bill Gates has changed his social networking allegiance.

title: More Dubai: Fund makes bid for troubled Spanish property firm
description: Not to get off on a Dubai tangent here, but a Dubai-based investment fund made a 3 billion ($4.5 billion) bid Wednesday for a majority stake in Colonial, the struggling Spanish property giant.

title: Paris: Just Clothes
description: Im sitting in my hotel room, its 7 in the morning, and Carlos, the waiter in my hotel, has gratefully arrived with the black coffee and the boiled egg. A light rain is falling; my kind of day in Paris. Yesterday was a barn-burner: long, with deadlines and many shows, and not very good shows at that. Givenchy was the march of the toothpicks. Super-skinny pants with feminine blouses and jackets with Spanish or Sud de France embroidery. Either way, you felt the influence, from way, way back, of Ghesquiere (the Jules Verne collection, among others) and, much closer, Christian Lacroix, especially in the last black and white coat.

title: Audio & Photos: At Night, the Band of Brothers Splits Up to Reflect
description: Listen to Specialist Michael Martinez

title: Mispronounced the Word Filibuster
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Last night was the final Democratic debate, and one of the big stories was that Barack Obama mispronounced the word Massachusetts twice and then mispronounced the word filibuster. Yeah. Yeah, which explains why this morning, Obama was endorsed by President Bush.

title: Unpacking the Debate
description: Hillary Clinton continues to fare poorly with the mockitariat:

title: Survival of the Fittest M&M
description: A post from a Best of Craigslist compilation:

title: Yelp Takes $15 Million in Fresh Funding
description: Yelp, a business reviews site that has gained a loyal following of opinionated young urbanites, as well as a couple of critics, announced on Wednesday that it has raked in a fresh $15 million in venture dough.

title: Oracle Gets Regulatory Nod for BEA Deal
description: Oracle announced Wednesday it had received a green light from regulators to move forward on its merger plans with BEA Systems.

title: Rubbermaid Taps Technical Concepts in $445 Million Deal
description: The consumer products maker Newell Rubbermaid said Wednesday it had agreed to buy an Illinois maker of touch-free washroom dispensers and other devices for $445 million, its second acquisition announced this week.

title: Galderma Buys CollaGenex for $420 Million
description: CollaGenex Pharmaceuticals, a maker of oral care and skin care products, said Wednesday that it would be bought for about $420 million by Galderma Laboratories.

title: Proofpoint Raises $28 Million
description: Proofpoint, a company that provides e-mail and data security to large corporate and government customers, announced Wednesday that it has closed a new $28 million round of financing to accelerate its global expansion.

title: Europe to Review Rules After Bailouts of 2 Banks
description: European Union regulators on Wednesday said they would investigate whether bailouts of two German banks hit by the subprime lending crisis had violated rules on state aid for ailing enterprises.

title: Unsolicited Bid for Yahoo Follows a Trend in the Acquisition Market
description: Microsofts $44.6 billion offer to buy the Internet company Yahoo is not an aberration but part of a broader trend in which suitors make bold unsolicited bids during a time of weak stock prices and tight credit markets.

title: A Joint Performance
description: Lorin Maazel, the New York Philharmonic's music director, led the State Symphony Orchestra of the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea.

title: 2 Plead Guilty to Insider Trading
description: A former executive at UBS who sold nonpublic information about the banks stock recommendations and a former trader who used those tips pleaded guilty Wednesday to insider trading.

title: Rocking the Stocks of Your Favorite Bands
description: A lot of people have talked about selling stock in bands as a means to help finance promising musicians. In Britain, a company called Slicethepie.com is enabling fans to trade shares of music acts the way they would a publicly traded company.

title: LinkedIns Newest Member: Bill Gates
description: Microsofts big bet on Facebooks online social network isnt stopping its chairman, Bill Gates, from promoting other popular Internet hangouts.

title: Yahoo Faces 7 Lawsuits Over Response to Microsoft Bid
description: Yahoo is facing seven shareholder lawsuits alleging the copmany bungled its response to Microsofts unsolicited takeover bid.

title: Simons $60 Million Gift to Stony Brook
description: James H. Simons, a mathematician turned investor, may be one of the worlds most successful  and wealthy  hedge fund managers, but he can remember how Stony Brook University gave him a berth after he lost his job as a Defense Department code-breaker for protesting the Vietnam War.

title: Lessons From the Family Bathroom
description: Every morning, my daughter and I share a single, cramped bathroom. We take turns brushing teeth, and she lectures me about leaving the water running too long. I tie her hair into a ponytail while one of our two cats or two dogs usually shows up to drink from the sink, the toilet or both.

title: At Fiery Meeting, UBS Shareholders Back Bid to Raise Cash
description: Managers of the troubled Swiss bank UBS won shareholder backing Wednesday for a plan to raise capital, but only after facing fierce criticism over the huge write-downs on subprime investments that led to the banks first annual loss.

title: EU Seeks More Transparency from Sovereign Wealth Funds
description: State-owned sovereign wealth funds, armed with billions of dollars, are welcome to invest in the European Union, but they should be more open about their motives and methods, the blocs executive body said Wednesday.

title: Cerberus Said to Mull Ambac Investment
description: Cerberus Capital Management is among the firms in talks with banks and regulators about potentially investing in the bond insurer Ambac Financial Group, according to Reuters.

title: Top F.T.C. Official Expected to Resign
description: The chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission is expected to resign her post next month to take a senior position at Procter & Gamble, according to press reports.

title: Could Egypts Citadel Make a Tasty Target?
description: The announcement Wednesday that a Cairo-based private equity firm, Citadel Capital, is preparing to go public had Breakingviews wondering if an even-bigger private equity shop looking for a regional presence might swoop in and pre-empt an I.P.O.

title: Electronic Arts Said to Consider Going Hostile
description: Electronic Arts is dialing up the pressure on Take-Two Interactive Software.

title: Zale to Close Stores and Cut Jobs
description: The jewelry retailer Zale, which has searched in vain for a winning formula even in better economic times, announced Wednesday that it would close more stores and cut 20 percent of its headquarters staff to save more than $65 million a year.

title: China Railway Raises $3.1 Billion in Shanghai I.P.O.
description: China Railway Construction, which built part of the controversial train line to Tibet, said Thursday it raised 22.25 billion yuan ($3.1 billion) from a domestic initial public offering.

title: European Hedge Fund Openings Declined Last Year
description: Investors cooled toward new hedge funds last year, with cash put into European openings falling for the first time since the 2001 bear market.

title: Step Away From the Cow
description: Texas, which holds its primary next Tuesday, is hard for politicos to fathom, as The Times notes. And the state is hard for Texans themselves to fathom, to judge from this lawyers ad:

title: Following Up on the Debate
description: At an event in Ohio, Hillary Clinton followed up on a criticism she had first launched at Barack Obama the night before in a debate.

title: I.B.M.s Follow-Through on Cognos
description: I.B.M. spent $5 billion last November to acquire Cognos to expand its so-called information-on-demand strategy. The 451 Group, an analyst firm, looks at what has happened since the transaction closed in late January.

title: Deutsche Banks C.E.O. Sees More Subprime Pain for Banks
description: Deutsche Bank managed to steer mostly clear of the subprime mess that has swamped its rivals. Now its chief executive says that he expects further writedowns at other banks as they continue to calculate unrealized losses from assets tied to risky mortgages and loans made to finance private equity deals.

title: Xstrata Investor Said to Threaten Vale Bid
description: A dispute over marketing rights held by the biggest shareholder of the mining group Xstrata is threatening a possible $90 billion takeover by Brazils Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.

title: Even Solo Workers Want Company
description: There is a lot of buzz these days about coworking (without the hyphen), a new movement  well chronicled in this recent New York Times article  in which people share a workspace to combat loneliness, forge a community and enjoy the creative sparks generated by like-minded people. But coworking is about much more than sharing a workspace. It is a global movement whose adherents follow certain principles (check out the terrific video at the bottom of this page), including environmental responsibility and a free exchange of ideas. Interestingly, these spaces are not usually run for a profit; they tend to be more mission-focused.

title: Technology Investment Specialist at Citigroup Joining Buyout Firm
description: Citigroups co-global head of technology, media and telecommunications investment banking is planning on leaving to join a fledgling private equity firm, The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.

title: Quarterlife Belonged on Cable TV, Not NBC, Co-Creator Says
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Quarterlife, the Internet series whose debut on NBC Tuesday night got poor ratings, does not belong on a broadcast network, a co-creator of the show said Wednesday.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Hussein Chalayan
description: (Francois Guillot/AFP/Getty Images )

title: ABN Amro Posts $2.36 Billion Write-Down
description: The Dutch bank ABN Amro said on Thursday it had made a 1.56 billion euro ($2.36 billion) writedown in its global markets business in its last results before being split between three buyers.

title: Rich and Media-Shy, Abu Dhabi Fund Draws Scrutiny
description: Abu Dhabi has about 9 percent of the worlds oil and 0.02 percent of its population. The result is a surfeit of petrodollars, much of which is funneled into a secretive, government-controlled investment fund that is helping to shift the balance of power in the financial world.

title: The Early Word: Foreign Credentials Tested
description: John McCain and Barack Obama offered the public Wednesday a preview of what a general election between them would be like: A back-and-forth over Iraq.

title: Clinton Asked About Veep Role
description: BELPRE, Ohio  She didnt say yes, but she didnt say no, either.

title: Foreign Policy Pop Quizzes: Fair Game?
description: George W. Bush, then the governor of Texas, was seeking to be the leader of the free world, not a Jeopardy! contestant, Karen P Hughes, his spokeswoman at the time, told a reporter who sprung a pop quiz about world leaders on Mr. Bush in 1999. (He scored 25 percent and failed to remember the name of the new leader of Pakistan  now hes unlikely ever to forget it.)

title: Live From Colette | Saro and Hanna Patz
description: This week, as The Moment blogs from the Colette boutique in Paris, were stalking the fashion faithful as they pass through the chic boutique.

title: Its Really, Finally Official: Bloomberg Wont Run
description: After a long flirtation with the idea of running for the White House, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today  in the form of an Op-Ed article in The New York Times  that he would not seek the presidency. But he left open the possibility of endorsing and supporting a candidate in the general election, writing, If a candidate takes an independent, nonpartisan approach  and embraces practical solutions that challenge party orthodoxy  Ill join others in helping that candidate win the White House.

title: MF Global Takes Hit From Unauthorized Trades
description: MF Global said Thursday that it had taken a $141.5 million bad debt provision after one of its traders substantially exceeded his authorized trading limit and lost that amount in the wheat futures market.

title: Illegal Guns on Decline in New York
description: The number of illegal guns recovered in New York City declined last year, compared with 2006, according to an analysis by the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

title: Medvedev Hits Trail After Hillary Clintons Flub
description: Perhaps you can forgive Hillary Clinton for stumbling over the name of Russias likely next president in Tuesdays debate with Barack Obama. Dmitry Medvedev, the man billed to replace President Vladimir Putin after elections this Sunday, only began officially campaigning yesterday.

title: This Anti-Drug Message Is Brought to You By
description: This anti-drug message is brought to you by  Keith Richards, former Rolling Stone and recanter of the claim, I snorted my Dads ashes. He was interviewed by the British Magazine Uncut this month:

title: At Sprint, Calls for Change May Get Louder
description: Sprint Nextel should be prepared for some serious static from shareholders.

title: Revisiting the Other Half of Jacob Riis
description: Mention Jacob A. Riis, and what usually comes to mind are spectral black-and-white images of New Yorkers in the squalor of tenements on the Lower East Side. The commonly held view of Riis is that of the muckraking police reporter, whose seminal 1890 work, How the Other Half Lives, prompted legislative reforms, focused attention on the desperate lives of poor urban immigrants and left an enduring mark on the history of documentary photography.

title: The Treasurers Report
description: Is Stephen Colbert the Democrats secret weapon for Congressional money-raising? James H. Fowler, a political scientist at the University of California, San Diego, crunched the numbers, and in an op-ed in The Los Angeles Times, Fowler says the answer is yes. He writes:

title: So a Writer Walks Into a Bar
description: Since when did all the story writers turn into comedians?

title: Final Scenes From the 80th Academy Awards
description: [EDITORS NOTE: This concludes the Baggers coverage of the 2007-2008 awards season.]

title: On CBS, Saturday Nights Alright for Fighting
description: CBS is looking to the organizers of a popular competition called mixed martial arts (MMA) to supply some programming for the often-overlooked Saturday night time slot.

title: The Names Behind the Diamonds
description: Our trip to Joker Marchant Stadium yesterday got me wondering: Just who is Joker Marchant anyway? Apparently, he was the director of Lakelands Parks and Recreational Department in the 1930s and 40s, and the stadium was named in his honor on March 12, 1966.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Revillion
description: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment. This week, the Telex comes from Paris womens fashion week.

description: Are people with autism trapped in their own world? Or are the rest of us just trapped in ours?

description: Motorcycle news and blog items were reading around the Web

title: Recipe of the Day: Naked Ravioli (Ravioli Nudi)
description: For the most part, the history of stuffed pasta is a history of labor-intensive work by servants, housewives and even children, but convincing people today that this is a good use of their time is not an easy task.

title: You Know What?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Clemens Sticking With His Silent Routine
description: Roger Clemenss stint as a highly-scrutinized batting practice pitcher for the Houston Astros continued on Thursday. So did Clemenss refusal to discuss his precarious legal situation.

title: Explaining the Shoe-Store Wars
description: Next Monday starts the long-awaited New York trial of UBSs suit against Finish Line  its own client  and Genesco. UBS is suing both of these footwear companies in an attempt to terminate its obligation to finance their $1.5 billion merger, which is also subject to litigation in Tennessee.

title: Scent Notes | Angel Men Pure Coffee by Thierry Mugler
description: In the only conversation Ive ever had with the movie critic David Denby, in a kitchen on New Years Day, I mentioned some terribly obvious movie that had done extremely well despite Denbys (and everyone elses) having ripped it apart. He shrugged. Its critic-proof, he said, and made a round motion with his hands. No point of critical entry. I think the most interesting thing about Thierry Muglers Angel Men Pure Coffee, a limited edition scent landing this April and hanging around for a scant four months or so, is that it feels critic-proof as well. It is jarringly direct, like the person blithely unflustered by your eye contact. It is, in its friendly self-assurance, impossible to approach with any kind of critical knife; irritatingly disarming, it is as effortlessly pleasing as it is exasperatingly obvious. The one difference between Pure Coffee and the movie is that this scent is excellent.

title: Moving Tax Breaks From Oil to Sun and Wind?
description: If oil lost its subsidies, and solar power and similar options got them, would the world be better off? The political debate continues.

title: State Wont Sell Block Owned by Javits Center
description: The Spitzer administration said today that it is suspending its plan to sell an entire city block owned by the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a move that critics, including the Bloomberg administration, said would foreclose any possibility of expanding the complex in the future and doom the trade show industry. Instead, state officials will establish a task force made up of city officials, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, state legislative leaders, hotel and tourism executives to address the future of the convention and trade show industry in New York.

title: The Night Manager of a Creepy Motel
description: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: How about the Democratic debate last night - how many folks saw the debate in Ohio? Well, you know, Hillary Clinton now is trailing Barack Obama and shes very desperate. Have you noticed this? Shes starting to get desperate. Today, she accused Barack Obama of attending a party at Jose Cansecos house.

description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton had another Democratic debate last night. This time it was in Ohio. The big winner, of course, Foxs American Idol.

description: A few years ago, a parenting magazine asked me to write an article about the dangers that children face when they go online. As it turns out, I was the wrong author for the article they had in mind.

title: The Bosss Legacy
description: Jonathan Mahler writes in this weekends PLAY about the succession strategy within the Yankees, with George Steinbrenner firmly in the background and his two sons taking over control of the team. Though the original Boss hasnt left the scene entirely, this seems like a good time to take stock of his 35-year stewardship: When all is accounted for  his six championships, his free spending, his blunders, his bluster, his impact on baseball overall  how do you think we should view the elder Steinbrenner?

title: Scenes from a National Sweep: Comme a
description: In Manhattan it can be madness to show up at a hot new restaurant during a prime time on a weekend night.

title: Saturn Imitates Louis XIV
description: Sometimes science imitates art. The Greeks myths told how Enceladus, a Giant who was buried beneath Mount Etna, caused earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. At Versailles, Louis XIV built a fountain in his honor. When the Giants name was given to one of Saturns moons in the 19th century, no one had any idea what was on that faint dot in the sky, but it turns that Enceladus really does have underground rumblings and a mysterious fountain.

title: Pettitte Weary of Clemens Story
description: You know how the media is portrayed in many movies, as a rabid pack of hounds barking questions at people? Its not like that in a baseball clubhouse. People might think that Andy Pettitte gets no peace with reporters after him 24/7 asking about the Roger Clemens mess. Not so. Pettitte usually floats in and out of the clubhouse just like the rest of his teammates. He is not a pressing topic every moment.

title: Exploring Brazil With Children
description: We are a family with three children, ages 9, 3 and 1. We are going to be in Brazil this month. Where and how should we enjoy this country with a growing family?

title: Where Does Stringer Rank?
description: On Wednesday night, C. Vivian Stringer became the third womens basketball coach in Division I history to win 800 games. Rutgerss 60-46 victory over DePaul put Stringer into the same rarified air as Tennessees Pat Summitt and the former Texas coach Jody Conradt (not to mention mens coaches like Bob Knight and Dean Smith).

title: Spelling Errors, Breakfast Cereal and 10 Rings
description: Joe Girardi showed some mercy on his players Thursday and gave them a short practice. With 30 consecutive days of games coming up, all the work was done by 11 a.m. Here are a few loose ends:

description: A few years ago, a parenting magazine asked me to write an article about the dangers that children face when they go online. As it turns out, I was the wrong author for the article they had in mind.

description: Until recently, two people presided over Goldman Sachss giant securities business; now, the unit will be run by four  or more, depending on how you parse the recent promotions at the investment bank.

title: An eBay Surprise: Lost Diskful of Data on Britons
description: In announcement after embarrassing announcement in recent months, the British government has revealed that it had lost control of a huge cache of personal information about many of its citizens.

title: Tonight: New Teams for Hossa and Richards
description: Fans of the Pittsburgh Penguins and Dallas Stars will get their first look at their new stars tonight. Marian Hossa will suit up for the Penguins in Boston and Brad Richards will don the Star at home against the Blackhawks.

title: Chess and Culture
description: A couple of unrelated items, just as a reminder of how much the game can and does permeate the world around us.

title: A Tall Sign, Worth Saving, Tells the Towers Tales
description: Updated Feb. 29, 3:50 p.m. | On one street corner in Lower Manhattan, the World Trade Center is still spoken of in the present tense; confusing some passers-by, enlightening many others.

description: (Art Production Fund)

title: How Do You Write a Sustainable Recipe?
description: Okay, my friends, Ive thought long and hard about your criticisms about using only sustainable fish in recipes and I dont disagree. (Ironically, 30 years ago, when I first started writing about fish, we talked about underutilized species  one by one, each of them has become endangered.)

title: EBay Settles Its Patent Dispute
description: Every big high-tech company, it seems, has at least one intellectual property adversary whose job is to harass the firm to the ends of the legal system, if not the earth itself.

title: Perelman on Dealmaking
description: CNBC interviews Ron Perelman, Revlon chairman and billionaire financier, about the dealmaking climate amid the current economy.

title: Obama Camp Says It Will Outraise Clinton
description: Updated Senator Barack Obamas campaign did not release an estimate of its February fund raising totals Thursday, but the amount is believed to be more than $50 million, according to several major donors.

title: $6.50 to Enter a Taxi?
description: Updated, 4:21 p.m. | A state assemblyman who opposes Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing proposal held a 2 p.m. news conference to propose an alternative plan that would aim to reduce traffic by charging a $4 surcharge on all taxi and limousine rides. The drop charge  the flat fee imposed once a passenger enters a cab  would rise to $6.50 from $2.50, but the subsequent charge would be reduced to 35 cents per one-fifth of a mile, down from the current charge of 40 cents per one-fifth of a mile.

title: And for Our Next Act
description: Were not quite done with August  weve got another couple days of posts left  but I wanted to announce our next Reading Room selection now: Starting March 24, the Timess Katy Roberts will be leading a discussion of Tom Wolfes blockbuster New York novel, The Bonfire of the Vanities. Equal parts social realism, legal thriller and novel of manners, Bonfire tackles money, sex, politics, journalism, race relations  you name it. And its an incredibly entertaining read. Were putting together a great panel, which we will announce soon. Until then, start reading: the book is a page-turner, but its long!

title: With Your Cloned Meat, a Side Dish of Safety
description: City Room was intrigued when a city councilwoman introduced a bill that would require the labeling of all retail and wholesale meat produced from cloned animals sold within a city as a result of the recent Food and Drug Administration decision not to require labeling for cloned meat.The issue of labeling for cloned meat has been a contentious issue. While the F.D.A. concluded that labeling would be unnecessary because meat and dairy from cloned animals were not different from non-cloned animals, others argue that cloning is also a matter of principle or ethics.

title: M.L.S. Welcomes Newest Team
description: Its official: Philadelphias Major League Soccer franchise will begin playing in 2010 in Chester, Pa. Plans are in the work for a new 20,000-seat soccer specific stadium. As Jack Bell reported here yesterday, it will be part of a $500 million revitalization project on the banks of the Deleware River that is expected to include housing, retail, a convention center and a riverfront promenade.

title: Gustave Courbet at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
description: At a time when seemingly old-fashioned representational painting is thriving, the works of Gustave Courbet has a striking pertinence, Roberta Smith writes.

description: More campaign-related opinion for Thursday, Feb. 28:

title: Friends of Bell Describe Argument Outside Club
description: Two of Sean Bells friends took the witness stand in the shooting trial of three detectives this morning to recount the argument outside a strip club moments before Mr. Bell was shot to death by police, driving home the prosecutions argument that even though no gun was ever found, it was widely believed that the man arguing with Mr. Bell was armed.

title: Nader Announces Pick for Vice President

The networks wide lead over its competitors eroded considerably at 9:30 p.m., however, as viewership of Fox dwindled to 12.3 million for the half-hour comedy Back to You.

description: Holland Cotter writes: The show is modest and compact, but like Kahlos work, it offers both an unnerving and pleasurable effect.

title: A Serviceberry Sprouts in Brooklyn
description: On hearing that the Brooklyn Public Library was going to plant a tree in honor of Betty Smith, the author of the famed A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, we assumed, of course, that the selected tree would belong to the species of the namesake tree: Ailanthus altissima.

title: Riverside Park Nest Draws Hawk Watchers
description: Bird lovers have been congregating near the intersection of 81st Street and the West Side Highway for what several urban nature experts say is a rare event: the construction of a nest by red-tailed hawks on the Far West Side of Manhattan. Leslie Day, a naturalist who lives on a houseboat on the Hudson River and is author of Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City, said that bird watchers first noticed the nest around nine days ago, in a honey locust tree.

title: Podcast: The State of Conservatism

title: The Relevance of Ralph
description: Eight years ago, I traveled the country with Ralph Nader. He was sardonic and surprisingly funny. As we drove through post-industrial landscapes of depressing sameness, Mr. Nader kept up a constant monologue about the spiritual costs of box stores and fast food. I recall standing at an airport counter  it was Sioux Falls, or maybe Fargo  where the agent cheerfully informed Mr. Nader that he had been upgraded to first class; he protested vigorously and smoldered the entire flight home. After Mr. Nader was tossed out of the presidential debate site in Boston, he and I watched the next debate in front of the TV at the brownstone that was his Washington headquarters. I ate pizza as Mr. Nader paced the room trying out phantom debate lines and railing against the two corporate supremacists on stage, who, he pointed out, refused to mention the plight of the working poor, the tilt of the political system toward special interests, the human toll of free trade.Mr. Naders candidacy took a dark turn in the closing weeks of the 2000 campaign. Until then, he had been running primarily to get the 5 percent of the vote he needed to qualify the Green Party for matching funds. But then Mr. Naders consuming resentment  at the way leading Democrats pressured his friends to denounce him, at the way Al Gore refused to speak his name  seemed to possess him, and at some point he seemed to make it his mission to deny Mr. Gore the presidency, attacking his Democratic rival in swing states over the protests of his own aides. Ive always thought that Mr. Gore probably could have avoided what came next simply by picking up the phone in those final weeks and making some small gesture of respect toward the man. But he didnt, and Mr. Nader got his wish.

title: From Pentagon, a More Obvious Show of Force
description: Fresh off muscle-flexing charges during the satellite shootdown operation, the Pentagon has ordered a more obvious show of force. The U.S.S. Cole, the destroyer attacked by Al Qaeda in 2000, has been sent towards Lebanon to warn Syria, according to an official quoted by Reuters:

title: Wild Wheat
description: There was a time when commodities markets were viewed with deep suspicion by farmers, who saw speculators and gamblers manipulating the prices of crops to benefit themselves and steal from farmers. In 1874, one house of the Illinois legislature approved a bill to make it a crime to trade a futures contract unless the seller actually had possession of the crop. The Chicago Board of Trade managed to water down the law to bar the trading of options, but not futures, and thus stayed in business.

Bloomberg said today that he planned to rely mostly on the bully pulpit that being mayor of New York gives him, one he said he did not believe had been diminished by the end of his own presidential aspirations.

Theyre very good at what they do, and when theyre about to be written off for dead, thats when theyre at their very best.

title: YSL: The Chic is Real
description: Nicolas Ghesquiere finally has someone to set his shoulder against. Tonight, Stefano Pilati hammered out his best Saint Laurent collection since he became creative director. This is the first group of clothes that has captured the energy of the Rive Gauche era and at the same time feels contemporary. You are no longer looking at any trace of the old Saint Laurent, except perhaps a jewel color, and yet it is Saint Laurent. Pilati carries forward the simplified lines of the spring collection and now adds more sex appeal, more flare to the geometry. The collection has a lot of versaility, but your eye goes immediately to the straight shoulders of unlined, cutaway coats in Donegal tweeds and then to the succinct volumes at the hem. Sharpness at the top, movement and freedom at the bottom, an effect repeated in wool felt coats and skirts.

The news spooked investors, fanning worries that Googles growth might be stalling, and that the company would not be immune to the broader economic slowdown. The companys shares, which have been falling since their early November peak, dropped 4.6 percent on Tuesday. They regained some ground in the last two days.

Turns out hes in the room right across the hall. Theres just something neat about that. The greatest living Yankee is sleeping just a few feet away. Sounds like the start of a novel.

He also ended a career in the National Hockey League, turning his back on a dream shared by nearly every young Russian with a stick and skates for the last 15 years.

title: 'Idol' Still Glitters
description: Fox dominated Wednesday nights ratings with a 90-minute edition of American Idol, which drew 27.4 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The networks wide lead over its competitors eroded considerably at 9:30 p.m., as Foxs Back to You earned a more modest 12.3 million viewers during the half-hour following the singing competition. NBC ranked a distant second over all, getting a boost at 10 p.m. from Law & Order, which led its time slot with 11.4 million viewers, outpacing both CBSs CSI: NY repeat (8 million) and the return of ABCs Men in Trees (5.7 million). CBS and ABC ranked third and fourth respectively. On Tuesday MSNBCs broadcast of the Democratic presidential primary debate in Ohio delivered 7.8 million viewers, making it the third-highest-rated debate of this season and the most-watched program in MSNBCs 11-year history.

title: China to Reconsider One-Child Limit
description: BEIJING  China is studying how to move away from the countrys one-child-per-couple restriction, but any changes would come gradually and would not mean an elimination of family planning policies, a senior official said Thursday.

title: Senate Kin and the Campaign Kitty
description: A worthy House measure to clamp down on members of Congress who employ relatives using campaign donations has disappeared into the maw of the Senate. A nonprofit watchdog group, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, may have come up with a reason why. It has uncovered at least 20 senators who have paid out more than $500,000 in campaign funds to family members since 2000.

title: Fathers and Sons in Gloom Above Rios Sunny Beaches
description: The most disquieting moment in City of Men, a rootin-tootin gangster movie shot in the notoriously lawless shantytowns overlooking the beaches of Rio de Janeiro, is also the most subdued. Acerola, a k a Ace (Douglas Silva), an 18-year-old still carrying baby fat, admits that he is frightened and unprepared to care for his infant son as his wife, Cris (Camila Monteiro), leaves to find work in So Paulo. Although Ace loves his little boy, he is only a child in a mans body himself, and he begs her not to go. For him to assume full parental responsibility is almost unimaginable.

title: On a Treasure Hunt, Uncovering Modern Wonders
description: Works on Paper, a gathering of 78 purveyors of drawings, prints, posters and photographs at the Park Avenue Armory, is not one of those jaw-dropping fairs that confront you at every turn with shockingly expensive brand-name wonders. And though it features mostly modern and contemporary material, there is little in it to challenge conservative tastes. Yet once you adjust to its low-key visual register, perusing the exhibition becomes enthralling and often revelatory.

title: Obama Cutting Into Clintons Edge Among Superdelegates
description: Senator Barack Obama has made significant inroads over the last month among the Democratic elected officials and party leaders known as superdelegates who will cast a fifth of the votes at the partys convention, cutting into Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons long-held advantage with the group.

title: Bipartisan Spirit Falters in Fights on Debt Relief
description: WASHINGTON  Just a month after President Bush and Democratic leaders hailed their bipartisan agreement on an economic stimulus plan, the two sides went to war on Thursday over how to prevent widening damage from the housing crisis.

title: Forgiveness in Doubt for Detroit Mayor
description: DETROIT  This city has forgiven Kwame M. Kilpatrick, its towering, charismatic, next generation mayor, before.

title: A Haunting Enigma of Violence and Chaos
description: The picture of Iceland that emerges in Baltasar Kormkurs Jar City is vivid and powerful but not something the countrys tourist board would be likely to endorse. The landscape has its austere poetry to be sure  mountains framing the apartment blocks of Reykjavik, spits of volcanic rock jutting into a churning sea  but a fog of damp unhappiness seems to pervade every face and conversation.

description: Cinderella meets The Ugly Duckling in Penelope, a muddled, charm-free fairy tale whose title character, played by Christina Ricci, is a rich girl born with the snout of a pig.

description: Congress and the White House are preparing to ramp up spending on programs to combat AIDS and related diseases around the world while removing some of the ideological blinders that have long undermined the effort to slow the spread of the AIDS virus. It will be a welcome strengthening of a foreign aid program that was already one of the shining accomplishments of the Bush administration.

title: Iraq Clears Execution of Chemical Ali
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi leaders say they have found a way to execute Ali Hassan al-Majid, known as Chemical Ali and one of Saddam Husseins most notorious henchmen.

title: Latest Legal News for Two Pop Singers
description: Amy Winehouse, above left, doesnt have to worry about a hearing on drug-possession charges in Norway as long as her husband stays in a British jail. That was the essence of a court ruling on Thursday in Bergen, Norway, where the Grammy-winning Ms. Winehouse was scheduled to appear on Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. One of the people involved in the case, Blake Fielder-Civil, Amy Winehouses husband, is currently in jail in Britain and cant make the trip, said Anne Vedvik of the Bergen court. The hearing has therefore been postponed to an undetermined date. Ms. Winehouse, 24, her husband and her hairdresser were arrested in Bergen in October and charged with possessing a quarter-ounce of marijuana. Ms. Winehouse was released after paying a $756 fine, which she later contested. Agreeing to a fine in Norway is equivalent to admitting the charges, which could make it difficult for Ms. Winehouse to obtain visas. Mr. Fielder-Civil has been in custody since November, awaiting trial on charges of assault and conspiracy to pervert the cause of justice. He is accused of trying to bribe a barman not to testify against him in an assault case. ... Boy George, above right, denied on Thursday that he imprisoned a 28-year-old Norwegian man at his London home last year, The Associated Press reported. Appearing in a London court under his real name, George ODowd, he pleaded not guilty to a charge of false imprisonment lodged by Audun Carlsen, who claimed that he was handcuffed to a wall after he went to Boy Georges apartment in April as a photo model. Boy George, 46, is free on bail and is to stand trial in November.

title: The Peoples Artist, Herself a Work of Art
description: PHILADELPHIA  You really should come down, a friend e-mailed me this summer from Mexico City. She meant, come down for the Frida Kahlo centennial, with a retrospective at the Palacio de Bellas Artes and displays of memorabilia at Casa Azul, the Blue House, Kahlos home. You should come, she wrote, not just for the art, which looks fabulous, but for the place, the people.

title: Festival Highlights
description: The New York International Childrens Film Festival runs Friday through Sunday, March 8 and 9, and March 15 and 16 at four theaters in Manhattan. Prices run from $10 to $25 for the opening gala and the awards ceremony. Information and tickets: (212) 349-0330, gkids.com.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 13 about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, misstated the circumstances of his offices prosecution in 2002 of James Treffinger, then the Essex County executive. Mr. Treffinger was seized by armed F.B.I. agents, but not at gunpoint. The article also misspelled the surname of a former prosecutor in Mr. Christies office who said partisan politics did not play a role in whom the office investigated. He is Scott Resnik, not Resnick.

description: GOSHEN, Ohio  The scream that Dustin Carter let loose in a gym here last weekend conveyed equal parts pain and elation. It was the sound of glory for a high school senior who wrestles unlike any of his opponents.

He is Jeff Lonsinger, not Ken. (Ken is his brother, who was with him at the time.)

description: LAS VEGAS  A man who stayed in a Las Vegas hotel room where ricin was discovered on Thursday has been hospitalized in critical condition since Feb. 14 with symptoms consistent with exposure to the deadly toxin, Las Vegas police said Friday.

title: Shoot It Yourself
description: Michel Gondrys current exhibition at Deitch Projects in SoHo is more than an extravagant promotion for the new movie he wrote and directed, Be Kind Rewind. This project, also called Be Kind Rewind, is a serious but flawed effort to carry over into the real world the films idealistic, anti-commercial fantasy of do-it-yourself creativity.

title: Prosecutors Build Case Against Pellicano
description: LOS ANGELES  The manager of a billion-dollar hedge fund, the billionaire head of a buyout firm, and the ex-wives of a television actor and a major real estate developer all will be crucial witnesses at the racketeering trial beginning next week for Anthony Pellicano, the infamous Hollywood private eye.

title: A Tiny, Beloved Home That Was Built for Spite
description: COLLEEN SAMMIS recalls that it came out at a restaurant in early 2006. She, the man she later married and friends were having dinner, and they were talking about a house Jack owned, Jack being Jack Sammis.
