title: Israel Sees Escalation in Gazans Longer-Range Strikes
description: JERUSALEM  Palestinian militants in Gaza fired at least eight imported, Katyusha-style rockets on Thursday at Ashkelon, on the Israeli coast, in what Israeli officials said was a serious broadening of the conflict.

title: A Glide Along Minnesotas Gunflint Trail
description: IN Minnesota, a state known for its relentless winters, theres a spot in the pointy northeastern corner known as the Arrowhead, where snow falls earlier, drifts deeper and hangs on longer. That spot is centered on a 57-mile-long road called the Gunflint Trail.

title: Mets Unveil Their Own Health Plan: Keep Alou on the Field
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The oldest position player in baseball enters the clubhouse with only a few minutes to spare, removes his sunglasses and puts on his favorite blue Smarty Jones T-shirt. He makes a brief call on his cellphone, gets his ankles taped and wolfs down a quick breakfast.

title: Report to Senators Says Many States Are Lax in Funding Their Pension Plans
description: Congressional auditors said Thursday that many states have been failing to set aside enough money for the pensions they owe public workers, and are likely to face fiscal distress, particularly those states that have also promised to help cover retiree health costs.

title: Stocks Dive on New Signs of Economic Chill
description: In a painful year for Wall Street, even the shortest month couldnt end soon enough.

title: Semi-Animated History of an Animated Time
description: The 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago  to say nothing of the violent confrontations between police and antiwar protesters that simultaneously seethed in the citys parks and streets  can hardly be called an obscure historical event. Demonstrators chanted, The whole world is watching, and so it was. Images of blue-helmeted officers and their long-haired antagonists have been part of the collective memory ever since.

title: Learning Some Lessons About How the Pecking Order Works
description: PARIS

title: A Relaxed Mountain Retreat That Offers More Than Snow
description: ONE HUNDRED miles east of the smog, gridlock and vanity of Los Angeles, cupped high in the pine forests of the San Bernardino Mountains, sits Big Bear Lake, a glistening splash of fresh alpine water ringed by 22 miles of shoreline. A resort town of the same name hugs the lakes south shore and offers a multiseason retreat.

title: Modern Pool for Public Is Opening in Flushing
description: In an era of private grandeur, New York City has built a temple for the public in Queens: the Flushing Meadows-Corona Park Natatorium and Ice Rink  it does not even have a corporate name  which is to open on Friday.

title: Asian Tour Ends on a High Note
description: After two encores at the Seoul Arts Center, the New York Philharmonic gave the audience of 2,500 what it had been waiting for, The Associated Press reported: Arirang, the wistful folk song that is an unofficial anthem for reunification of the two Koreas. Thunderous applause and cries of Bravo! erupted from audience members, who rose from their seats after the music ended on Thursday. Theres no sides; theres no North and South in Arirang, Lorin Maazel, the orchestras music director, said afterward. Its a melody for everybody. All these artificially created barriers fade away. Backstage, Park Sam-koo, chairman of the Kumho-Asiana Culture Foundation, referred to the combined population of the Koreas when he told Mr. Maazel, Seventy million Koreans love you. Besides Arirang, which the orchestra also played in Pyongyang, the Seoul program included Beethovens Piano Concerto No. 2, featuring the South Korean pianist Son Yeol-eum, and Beethovens Symphony No. 5.

title: U.S. Imprisons One in 100 Adults, Report Finds
description: For the first time in the nations history, more than one in 100 American adults are behind bars, according to a new report.

title: A Great Leap Forward
description: Exeter, England

title: Hyundai Joins List of 10 Top Car Picks
description: DETROIT  Two vehicles made by Hyundai cracked this years Consumer Reports list of 10 top picks, the first time that the influential publication has given such recognition to a South Korean automaker.

title: Edgemont and Allure Waikiki
description: Edgemont

title: Law Firms Follow Banks to the Persian Gulf
description: At Latham & Watkins, the international law firm, William H. Voge is the resident whiz on Dubai. And Abu Dhabi. And Qatar.

title: Sweden and Norway Hold 6 on Terror-Related Charges
description: OSLO,  In coordinated raids, the Swedish and Norwegian security services on Thursday arrested six people on suspicion of financing or otherwise taking part in terrorist activity.

title: On TV, Buckley Led Urbane Debating Club
description: The relationship of William F. Buckley Jr.s Firing Line to the partisan shoutfests that pass for evening political exchange on television nowadays?

title: In the Heart of Texas, a Greenbelts Inconvenient Truth
description: In October 2002 a Texas developer named Gary Bradley e-mailed The Austin Chronicle that all he ever really wanted to do was to make movies. Its doubtful that the politely muck-raking documentary The Unforeseen, in which the developer persuasively plays one of the films villains, is what he had in mind.

title: Bush Criticizes Democrats Running for President on Trade, Iraq and Cuba, but Not by Name
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush waded into presidential politics on Thursday, criticizing the Democratic contenders for their positions on free trade and taking particular aim at Senator Barack Obama for his comments about the threat of terrorism in Iraq and the wisdom of meeting the new leader of Cuba.

title: Muscular Dystrophy: Three Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Univisions Music Assets Are Sold
description: The Universal Music Group, the worlds biggest music conglomerate reached a deal to acquire the recorded music and music publishing assets of Univision, the Spanish-language media giant, the companies said on Thursday.

title: The G.O.P. and Lobbyists
description: To the Editor:

title: A Goofballs Quest: Slam Dunk for Survival
description: A throwaway scene in Semi-Pro, a comedy starring Will Ferrell as Jackie Moon, the owner, coach, promoter and star of a struggling 1970s-era basketball team, boils Mr. Ferrells macho man-child persona down to a sentence.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Friday about a proposal for a waterfront park near the United Nations building in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the status of a request to Sheldon Solow, the owner of an adjacent site, for an easement allowing access to the park property. Although a member of a local community board said Mr. Solow hadnt said anything yet about granting the easement, Mr. Solows company, East River Realty, said it had in fact responded to the request. In an e-mail statement issued the day that officials announced the proposal at a news conference, the company said, We will certainly consider creating an easement.

title: NBC Pulls the Plug on 'Quarterlife'
description: NBC pulled Quarterlife, the made-for-Internet series, on Thursday, after broadcasting only one low-rated episode. The network had intended to run the series on the next five Sunday nights; Dateline NBC and reruns of Law & Order will replace it. On Wednesday Marshall Herskovitz, a co-creator of the series, said it did not belong on broadcast television because its subject matter, the lives of blog-savvy men and women in their 20s, was too narrow for a network audience. If it was going to go on TV, it probably should have been on a cable network, and thats probably where its going to end up, Mr. Herskovitz said at a conference at Harvard. An NBC spokeswoman confirmed that the show would run its course on the Bravo cable channel. Quarterlife stirred considerable interest as the first network show born on the Internet. It originally consisted of eight-minute Web episodes, which were then strung together into one-hour episodes for television.

title: Texas on Pace for Record Voter Turnout
description: SPRING, Tex.  Anita Dawkins has never voted early. But there she was Wednesday, a 48-year old homemaker, or domestic engineer, as Ms. Dawkins called herself, lining up outside the Barbara Bush Branch Library in this fast-growing northern Houston suburb to beat the crowds and cast her primary ballot for Senator Barack Obama.

title: Yes, Theres the Trial, but There Are Also Broader Statistics
description: Inevitably, emotions ran high this week with the start of the trial in the 50-shot police killing of Sean Bell. That much was obvious in protests outside the courthouse in Queens. It was obvious in angry comments posted on blogs.

title: Buddy Miles, 60, Hendrix Drummer, Dies
description: Buddy Miles, the drummer in Jimi Hendrixs Band of Gypsys and a hitmaker under his own name with the song Them Changes, died on Tuesday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 60.

title: Goyas Get a New Look
description: Two celebrated Goya paintings damaged during the Spanish Civil War are being restored by the Prado in Madrid for Goya and the War Years, an exhibition scheduled to run at the museum from April 14 through July 13, Agence France-Presse reported. Though the paintings, Charge of the Mamelukes and The Shootings of May 3rd, have been on view at the Prado, Manuela Mena, who is in charge of conserving Goyas works, said this was the first restoration to repair damage to parts of the paintings that show buildings and heads. Both works depict a popular uprising in Madrid that led to Spains war against France from 1808 to 1814. They were damaged when transported to the Mediterranean port of Valencia to safeguard them from bombings in Madrid.

title: Reduce the Risk
description: Here are recommendations to minimize your risk if your vacation home is in a region with wild animals:

title: Strike at Auto Parts Supplier Stops Work at a G.M. Plant
description: DETROIT  General Motors halted production at one of its pickup truck plants Thursday afternoon when it ran out of some parts because the workers who make them are on strike.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sharp Rebuke for Developer in Big Project at Landfills
description: The inspector general of New Jersey sharply criticized a developer and a politically powerful law firm, accusing them of bungling a billion-dollar project to clean up landfills in the Meadowlands and replace them with golf courses and houses. The official asked the state attorney general to determine whether a criminal investigation was warranted.

title: Judith Jamison to Retire in 2011
description: Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, announced on Thursday that she would retire in 2011. She plans to maintain her connection to the company, which she joined as a dancer in 1965, as artistic director emerita.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: A Series and Its Sponsor Capture a Shared Link With History
description: ALTHOUGH television is a visual medium, sound is also important. And there are few sweeter sounds for viewers than the words brought to you with limited commercial interruption by. ...

title: Prince Harry Withdrawn From Afghanistan
description: LONDON  The Defense Ministry announced Friday that Prince Harry, the third in line to the British throne, would have to come home from Afghanistan because it was too risky for him to stay there.

title: More Radio for Seacrest
description: Ryan Seacrest, a familiar face on American Idol, also wants to be a familiar voice on pop radio. This spring Mr. Seacrest, who is already the host of American Top 40, a four-hour national weekend radio show, will also become the host of a nationally syndicated three-hour show, Premiere Radio Networks announced on Thursday. The show, to run Monday through Friday, will borrow from Mr. Seacrests successful morning program on KIIS-FM in Los Angeles, with custom insertions for local stations. Mr. Seacrest, 33, will control some of the advertising time on the new show.

title: Open Country for Women of a Certain Age
description: The synopsis of Bonneville makes it sound like Thelma and Louise in first gear: A recent widow named Arvilla Holden (Jessica Lange) and her two best friends, Carol and Margene (Joan Allen and Kathy Bates), hit the road in Idaho in a 1966 Pontiac convertible to deliver an urn full of ashes to a funeral in Santa Barbara, Calif., bickering, bonding and facing hard truths along the way.

title: The Week in Twang, Day by Day
description: Acoustic music, especially bluegrass, has found new momentum and a new generation of pickers, and can be found every night of the week these days in clubs around New York. (The number preceding each item corresponds to a location on the map at right.)

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Stringers Crowded Rsum Has a Spot Left
description: C. Vivian Stringer has to win the national championship. Thats all there is to it. No coming close, no near miss, no rainbow at the end of a tunnel.

title: California: Bringing Home Babies
description: Two American families have been notified that they can bring home their adopted Vietnamese babies, who initially had been denied United States entry visas over concerns they were not actually orphaned. One of the mothers, Julie Carroll, who adopted an 11-month-old girl in September, said by phone from Camarillo, Calif., that she was overjoyed and that her husband, Steve Carroll, was flying to Hanoi. Mr. Carroll and another adoptive father, Claude McRoberts, of Seaside, Calif., planned to retrieve their girls from foster care. The State Department, which has urged families to beware of possible baby buying and other irregularities in Vietnamese adoptions, confirmed that the families had been given visa notifications.

title: Retooled State Ballet of Georgia Shows Its Wares
description: I wonder what the State Ballet of Georgia looked like in 2004. According to a program note for its current engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the dancer and choreographer Vakhtang Chabukiani had transformed it into one of the leading dance ensembles of the former Soviet Union and choreographed ballets which became Soviet classics during his 30-year tenure as artistic director starting in 1941; then, from 1973 on, George Aleksidze brought the SBG to another level.

title: New York City Education Department Proposes Changes in School Grades
description: The New York City school system has released a list of proposed changes to its system of grading schools, intended to soften some of the sting of the blunt A through F grades, as well as to measure school quality more accurately.

title: William Buckleys Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Backcountry Trip Across British Columbias Glaciers
description: THE Spearhead Traverse is a two- to four-day backcountry ski trip into the unpopulated alpine realm that awaits just beyond the boundary ropes of Whistler Blackcomb, in British Columbia. The epitome of high (and cold) lonesome, its a journey of glacier crossings, impossibly fresh snow and winter camping in tents and huts.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Man Abandons Infant Girl in a Car for Hire in Queens
description: A man carrying a 6-month-old girl flagged down a black car for hire in Queens on Thursday and left the baby behind after asking the driver to stop, the police said.

title: In His Nets Debut, Harris Leads the Way
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As far as stopgap solutions go, Marcus Williams had been doing his part. Starting each of the four games since the Nets traded Jason Kidd to the Dallas Mavericks, he had averaged 12 points, 6.2 rebounds, and 7.3 assists.

title: World Group Tells Banks to Beware Deals With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  In a move that strengthens the American-backed effort to isolate Iran, a leading international organization responsible for combating financial crimes called Thursday for all countries to be wary of Irans banking system because of concerns over money-laundering and aid to terrorists.

title: Letting His Racing Colors Show
description: CONSIDERING that C. Steven Duncker is a master-of-the-universe type who is arguably addicted to action  be it at the track, on the trading floor, or across a poker table like the 2004 Main Event of the World Series of Poker  a monumental stillness emanates from his Upper East Side apartment. There is no sound of pounding hooves, though he has an oft-enjoyed home library of audio replays of his racehorses finer finishes.

title: Art in Review
description: BARBARA T. SMITH

title: The Word Is Out: Harry Is in Afghanistan
description: LONDON  For 10 weeks he has been in Afghanistan, deployed with the British Army in Helmand Province with the full knowledge of the rapacious British news media, and no one said a word.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about the growing use of wind power in Texas referred imprecisely to the amount of money that Louis Brooks is paid for allowing 78 wind turbines on his ranch on the outskirts of Sweetwater, Tex. It is $500 a month for each, not $500 for all of them. The article also misstated the length of blades for new wind turbines that stand as high as 20-story buildings. The blades span about 200 feet; they are not longer than a football field, which is 300 feet. (Go to Article)

title: Seductive Rebel Who Kept It Real
description: At the moment the Metropolitan Museum of Art, always a paradise of painting, is more edenic than ever. In less than four weeks it has opened three large exhibitions, each devoted to a master of sublime strangeness. First Jasper Johns, then Nicolas Poussin and now Gustave Courbet.

title: Myron Cope, 79, Writer and Steelers Broadcaster, Is Dead
description: Myron Cope, the longtime broadcaster for the N.F.Ls Steelers who became a sports treasure in Pittsburgh with his distinctive vocabulary and his creation of the fans Terrible Towel, died Wednesday in Mount Lebanon, Pa. He was 79.

title: Turkey Resists Gatess Call to End Its Iraq Offensive
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Turkish leaders on Thursday resisted calls by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates for a swift end to Turkeys offensive against Kurdish guerrillas, offering no timetable for withdrawing their troops from northern Iraq.

title: For Young Filmgoers, a Chance to Venture Far Beyond the Multiplex
description: On any recent weekend adult filmgoers could see big, commercial movies like Vantage Point and Fools Gold, or art-house foreign works like The Bands Visit and 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days. Children could choose big, commercial movies like The Spiderwick Chronicles and the Miley Cyrus 3-D extravaganza, or art-house foreign works like ... like ...

title: Groups Urge a Moratorium on City Use of Artificial Turf
description: Several environmental and civic groups are calling for a moratorium on the use of artificial turf in new sports fields in the city, and question the seriousness with which the Bloomberg administration is investigating the turfs potential hazards.

title: Romanticism, Aborning and in Full Flower
description: Romanticism was the engine that drove the recital by David Finckel and Wu Han at the Morgan Library & Museum on Tuesday evening, and if there was a message to be found in their program, it was that Romanticism covers a vast range of musical styles.

title: The Sound Is Rural, the Setting Urban
description: HOWDY, folks, Chris Thile said one recent Tuesday night, as he twisted a peg on his mandolin. His audience, packed into the cozy Rockwood Music Hall on the Lower East Side, seemed to appreciate the salutation. Somebody voiced a request: Over the Waterfall, a bluegrass standard. Second tune I ever learned, he shot back, after Woodys Rag.

title: Energy Loss
description: David Novacks documentary Burning the Future: Coal in America is as upsetting as it is informative. The movie concentrates on the Appalachian states  particularly West Virginia, the epicenter of an industry that mines enough coal to provide electricity for half the nation. In recent years increasing amounts of coal have been obtained through mountaintop mining, in which mountain ridges are scraped away by heavy machinery to get at the coal seams below.

title: Naders No. 2
description: The 2008 campaign has its first official vice-presidential candidate, and it is not Mike Huckabee.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Ralph Naders announcement that he is again running for president misstated the percentage of votes Mr. Nader received nationwide in the 2004 presidential election. He won 0.38 percent of the vote, not 0.3 percent. The article also misstated the reason that Mr. Nader was not on the ballot in California in 2004. It was because he did not gather enough signatures, not because of lawsuits and challenges filed by the Democratic Party.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Wiretapping Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush May Take Foreign Money for Presidential Library
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush said Thursday that he would probably accept foreign donations to build his presidential library in Dallas and would consider keeping the donors names confidential if they do not want to be identified.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a television station in Huntsville, Ala., that showed a black screen for 12 minutes on Sunday night during a 60 Minutes report about possible political deception involving the former Bush administration official Karl Rove in the conviction of a former Democratic governor of Alabama referred incorrectly to one of the owners of the station. Robert M. Bass, manager of an investment company that bought the station, WHNT, last year, has been a contributor to Democratic Party candidates, but unlike his brothers in Texas, he has not been a contributor to President Bush. An editorial on Wednesday about WHNT going dark repeated the error. An article about an internal review of the incident by the Huntsville station is on Page C4 today.

title: Rethinking Help for Children
description: The federal nutrition program known as WIC  for Women, Infants and Children  has enormous reach. It helps feed about 8 million people every day and, at one time or another during the course of a year, it helps provide nourishing meals for half of all Americas infants and one-quarter of its children.

title: An Iconic Look in High Demand
description: Often, people refuse to look at anything else, said Terry Horrocks, owner of Prudential Terry Horrocks Real Estate in Lake Placid, N.Y., referring to Adirondack-style homes. Whether on a historic home or on new construction, the styles twig-filigree detailing, stone appointments and bark-sheathed surfaces appeal to buyers who want to own a part of, or pay tribute to, the regions rustic history.

title: Exploring Small Stories of the Great War
description: With her new novel, Life Class, Pat Barker returns to the subject of World War I  a subject that earned her immense acclaim in the 1990s with her Regeneration trilogy (Regeneration, The Eye in the Door and The Ghost Road), an artful improvisation on the lives of the poets Siegfried Sassoon, Wilfred Owen, Robert Graves and their compatriots, which unfurled into a fierce meditation on the horrors of war and its psychological aftermath.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Sports Briefing column on Thursday about the announcement that Robert Kipkoech Cheruiyot will race in the Boston Marathon in April misstated the number of times the event has been held. This will be the 112th running, not the 111th.

title: Yankee Joba Chamberlain, a Big Kid at Heart
description: TAMPA, Fla.  If everything works out for Joba Chamberlain  and life has been a dream lately  he will start and finish this season with a trip to Disney World. That is where athletes go after winning a championship, and it is where Chamberlain is going this weekend, with a family from Nebraska in tow.

title: Creature Discomforts
description: EVERYONE knows that unpleasant neighbors can take some of the fun out of a vacation house. They might be noisy. They might have junked cars in their front yards. They might bite.

title: Wyeth Antidepressant Is Approved
description: Faced with the looming loss of patent protection for its top-selling drug, the antidepressant Effexor XR, Wyeth on Friday received federal approval for a follow-on drug, Pristiq, that the company hopes will also become a blockbuster.

title: Minnesota Transportation Chief Is Out
description: Minnesotas transportation commissioner was removed from her post on Thursday by the State Senate after several years of concern about the departments performance, the low point of which was last summers deadly collapse of a highway bridge over the Mississippi River in Minneapolis and its aftermath.

title: Theater Listings
description: WINTER REP 2008 While a season of plays presented in rotating repertory is common practice in summer stock, it is not the norm in the Off Off Broadway world. But the Oberon Theater Ensemble, now in its 11th season, has been presenting shows this way for a few years, and its current offerings include Macbeth, with James Holloway, above left, and William Laney, and Michael Wellers Ghost on Fire.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: A Sign That Has Served Its Time
description: On one street corner in Lower Manhattan, the World Trade Center is still spoken of in the present tense, confusing some passers-by, enlightening many others.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday erred in saying that the medication Lipitor was losing market share to Zocor. It is losing market share to the generic version of Zocor.

title: Revlon Swings to Quarterly Profit
description: Revlon, the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, posted its first quarterly profit in two years, bolstered by sales outside the United States and by savings from ending its Vital Radiance line.

title: Rival Sisters Duke It Out for the Passion of a King
description: More slog than romp, The Other Boleyn Girl tells the salacious story of two hot blue bloods who ran amok and partly unclothed in the court of Henry VIII. Best known for losing her head to the king, first metaphorically, then literally, Anne Boleyn (Natalie Portman, saucy), along with her sister, Mary (Scarlett Johansson, sedate), entered the court of the king (Eric Bana, brooding and glowering) when he was still wed to Catherine of Aragon (Ana Torrent). A man of considerable and changeable appetites, the king yearned for a male heir and anything in a frock who wasnt the queen. His sexual wish was their command.

title: U.S. Embrace of Musharraf Irks Pakistanis
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Bush administrations continued backing of President Pervez Musharraf, despite the overwhelming rejection of his party by voters this month, is fueling a new level of frustration in Pakistan with the United States.

title: Remembering the Mentor
description: When I was in college, William F. Buckley Jr. wrote a book called Overdrive in which he described his glamorous lifestyle. Since I was young and a smart-aleck, I wrote a parody of it for the school paper.

title: Supplier Strikes Idle 16,000 Auto Workers
description: DETROIT  More than 16,000 workers at General Motors and Chrysler have been temporarily laid off because strikes at two suppliers have created a shortage of parts at some of the carmakers factories.

title: Bill Would Remove Doubt on Presidential Eligibility
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain said Thursday that he had no concerns about his meeting the constitutional qualifications for the presidency because of his birth in the Panama Canal Zone. A Democratic colleague said she wanted to remove even a trace of doubt.

title: Brooding on the Bayou
description: Men are men, and women are no end of sorry in Little Chenier, a steamy saga of jealousy and revenge set on a waterlogged spit of Louisiana land  the kind of place where strangers are greeted with Who your daddy?, and the sheriff is up in everybodys business.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Tuesday about Brad Guzan, a promising goalkeeper for the United States national team who was close to joining an English Premier League club, referred imprecisely to a requirement for a British work permit that Guzan failed to meet. He needed to have played in at least 75 percent of his national teams official matches in the previous two years, not one year.

title: Trader Accused of Betting Money He Didnt Have
description: For nearly two decades Evan Dooley quietly made a living trading commodities like wheat in his home state, Tennessee, far from the hurly-burly of Wall Street.

title: Sprint Nextel Posts $29.5 Billion Loss
description: Daniel R. Hesse, Sprint Nextels new chief executive, tells it like it is  but on Thursday, investors did not like what they heard.

title: Declining to Enter Field, Mayor Eyes Sideline Role
description: For more than two years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had the ultimate presidential campaign that wasnt. Aides spent hundreds of hours and untold dollars plotting out a route to the White House. But the prospects for his maybe-I-will, maybe-I-wont campaign were never tested in the quiet of a voting booth.

title: Mike Smith, Lead Singer of Dave Clark 5, Is Dead
description: Mike Smith, the lead singer of The Dave Clark Five, died Thursday outside London, less than two weeks before the band is to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. He was 64.

title: N.F.L. Free Agency Begins With Lack of Big Names
description: Maybe the surest sign of how quiet free agency is expected to be for anyone not named Asante Samuel comes from the flight plans for the plane owned by the Washington Redskins owner, Daniel Snyder.

title: Boutique Bank Thats Riding Out the Storm
description: It was over sushi in Midtown Manhattan that Blair W. Effron and Robert A. Pruzan, two longtime Wall Street deal makers, began devising plans for a new investment bank.

title: Its a Hard Rock Life
description: At this point in the play, we were planning a show tune, says the roly-poly guy with the guitar and the funny eyeglasses. An upbeat gotta-leave-this-town kinda show tune.

title: Germany: Gallery Shut After Muslim Threats
description: The authorities in Berlin closed a gallery whose exhibition included satirical works by Danish artists that caricatured the Kaaba shrine in Mecca after Muslims protested, the German news agency Deutsche Presse Agentur reported, citing the local arts council. The protesters had threatened to use violence if the posters of the Danish art group Surrend were not removed from the gallery, Galerie Nord, the report said.

title: Hoping to Become the Next Hot Baseball Export From Japan
description: NAGO, Japan  No. 81 is the eighth uniform number of Masato Yoshiis professional career.

title: Families Help Care for Half of U.S. Preschoolers, Census Says
description: Grandparents serve as the primary caregivers for about 20 percent of the 11.3 million preschool children with employed mothers, according to data released Thursday by the Census Bureau.

title: Knight Joins ESPN as a Commentator
description: Bob Knight, who recently resigned as the basketball coach at Texas Tech, will join ESPN next month as a television, radio and online commentator for the networks championship week and the N.C.A.A. mens tournament.

title: Northrop and EADS Win Refueling Tanker Deal
description: In a surprising reversal for the Boeing Company, the Pentagon on Friday awarded a multibillion-dollar contract for refueling tankers to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and EADS, the European parent of Airbus.

title: Painting Natures Grandeur With Music
description: The second week of December 1908 was a happy time for modern music. On Dec. 10 Olivier Messiaen was born in Paris. The next day Elliott Carter was born in New York. Miraculously, Mr. Carter remains alive and active. And though Messiaen died in 1992, his visionary work is being commemorated in concerts around the world.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about the growing use of wind power in Texas referred imprecisely to the amount of money that Louis Brooks is paid for allowing 78 wind turbines on his ranch on the outskirts of Sweetwater, Tex. It is $500 a month for each, not $500 for all of them. The article also misstated the length of blades for new wind turbines that stand as high as 20-story buildings. The blades span about 200 feet; they are not longer than a football field, which is 300 feet.

title: New Heathrow Runway Would Erase a Village
description: SIPSON, England  The fortunes of this little village have long depended on the fortunes of Heathrow Airport, just a couple of miles away. But just as it has lived for Heathrow, Sipson might have to die for Heathrow.

title: Union Grows, but Leader Faces Criticism
description: Andy Stern has been hailed in some quarters as the nations top labor leader largely because his union, the Service Employees International Union, has added members faster than any other, 800,000 over the last decade.

title: Panel Is Set to Examine Security at U.N. Sites
description: UNITED NATIONS  The director of a new panel that will look into attacks on United Nations offices said Thursday that the organization had to accept the fact that in many parts of the world it was no longer viewed as impartial and was therefore increasingly vulnerable.

title: Missile Attack, Possibly by NATO, Kills 8 in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Eight suspected Islamic militants, including four men of Middle Eastern origin and two from Central Asia, were killed early Thursday in a triple missile attack on a house used as a training facility in Pakistans tribal areas, a security official and residents said.

title: Kenya Rivals Reach Peace Agreement
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyas rival leaders broke their tense standoff on Thursday, agreeing to share power in a deal that may end the violence that has engulfed this nation but could be the beginning of a long and difficult political relationship.

title: A Vermeer Painting Is Heading West
description: West Coast art lovers will be offered a rare opportunity to see a Vermeer when the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, Calif., exhibits A Lady Writing, above, from Nov. 7 through Feb. 2, 2009. On loan from the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the painting, one of about 35 known works by Vermeer, will come to Pasadena as part of a series of exchanges between the Norton Simon foundations and the National Gallery. The program began last summer when the Norton Simon lent Rembrandts Portrait of a Boy, Presumed to Be the Artists Son, Titus to the National Gallery. A Lady Writing depicts a young woman poised to write with a quill pen as she sits at a desk, wearing an ermine-trimmed yellow morning jacket, pearl earrings and golden ribbons in her hair, with a strand of pearls and a ribbon on the desk. It is the first loan from the National Gallery to the Norton Simon.

title: Pettitte Says He Hates Having a Role in a Legal Drama
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte was not surprised to learn that his friend and former teammate Roger Clemens was being investigated by the Department of Justice for possibly making false statements to Congress earlier this month.

title: Latest Troubles Put Detroit Mayors Job at Risk
description: DETROIT  This city has forgiven Kwame M. Kilpatrick, its towering, charismatic, next-generation mayor, before.

title: Blood Thinner Might Be Tied to More Deaths
description: Amid indications that more people may have died or been harmed after being given a brand of the blood thinner heparin, federal drug regulators said Thursday that they had found potential deficiencies at a Chinese plant that supplied much of the active ingredient for the drug.

title: A Life Spent Between Colored Strands and Colorful Strays
description: Mitzis future in West New York, N.J., where she lived in a down-and-out pocket of town, didnt look particularly bright. She might have ended up on the street, like so many of her peers, if she hadnt caught the eye of a beloved New York hair colorist named Grato Longoria. Within a year of that chance encounter, she was living on upper Madison Avenue, rolling around in 330-thread-count Matouk sheets and maintaining a meticulous grooming regimen.

title: Leaving Las Vegas, for the Suburbs
description: WHEN Bob Carson set out last year to find a second home in the Las Vegas area, his list of must-haves was short but sweet.

title: Logging in Congo River Basin Imperils Sea Turtles Very Far Downstream
description: The growth of logging in the rain forests of central Africa appears to be posing a long-distance threat to one of the worlds most important nesting grounds for several species of rare sea turtles  the coast of Gabon.

title: A Hardy Cowgirl Endures the Pain and Longing on the Trail to Love
description: A prairie wind swept through the Allen Room on Wednesday night as the singer K. D. Lang and a five-member band conjured big-sky country where romantic dreamers infused the wide-open spaces with swooning desire. Listening to Ms. Langs languid interpretations of songs from her new album, Watershed (Nonesuch), as well as selections from her older records, an image surfaced of the singer as a hardy cowgirl, lost in reflection as she leans on a fence post and gazes toward the horizon.

title: Profit Falls as Dell Tries to Grow and Limit Costs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The midterm grades are in, and Dell says it has a lot more work to do.

title: Rikers Island Counselor Is Charged With Selling Cocaine to an Officer

This being a Loach film, its also a cruel world, populated by capitalist tools and fools, schemers and dreamers of every stripe, accent and ethnicity. In Its a Free World ... its the war of all against all yet again, this time with fistfuls of filthy pound notes and mouths crammed with speeches and broken promises.

title: Time and Time Again
description: The Bush administration has tried repeatedly to kill or shortchange government surveys. Motivated in part by pound foolishness, but also by a disdain for information that might upset partisan or ideological agendas, the attempts have had mixed results. Taken together, however, they amount to an assault on reliable data thats necessary to judge the effectiveness of existing government programs and the need for new ones.

description: XM Satellite Radio Holdings, awaiting regulatory approval for its merger with Sirius Satellite Radio, said on Thursday that it narrowed its fourth-quarter loss, helped by a 20 percent increase in revenue and a favorable comparison to last year, when the company took a significant write-down.

title: Top Officer at Bell Shooting Testifies

Gary Napoli, the commanding officer who was supervising several New York City police detectives when they fatally shot Sean Bell in November 2006, gave a first-hand account today of the shooting  the most detailed account so far in the trial of three of the detectives.Lieutenant Napoli, who took the stand on Thursday afternoon in State Supreme Court in Queens, continued his testimony today. He recalled being in a car with two colleagues  Detectives Paul Headley and Marc Cooper  not far from Club Kalua, early on the morning of Nov. 25, 2006, when he got a frantic call on his cellphone from one of his detectives, Gescard F. Isnora.

title: All About the M.T.A. Fare Increase
description: Updated, 9:40 p.m. | Even the most seasoned subway and bus riders might be a bit confused by some aspects of the fare increases that take effect at 12:01 a.m. Sunday. Passengers who buy regular pay-per-ride MetroCards will start to see odd amounts left over on their cards. Those who buy MetroCards at supermarkets and newsstands will find themselves paying amounts like $17.39 and $52.17. And New Yorkers who want to hoard unlimited-ride MetroCards at the present cost should beware: the M.T.A. wont say how long the cards will be honored.

title: Fatal Stabbing at Key Food on Lower East Side
description: Updated, March 1 | Two female workers, ages 24 and 27, were stabbed  one fatally  inside a Key Food grocery store on the Lower East Side this afternoon, by a man who then fled and is still at large, the police said. The suspect, later identified as James Gonzalez, 42, ran from the store after the attack and apparently dropped the knife outside, near Avenue A and East Fourth Street, the police said. The 24-year-old, later identified as Tina Negron, was stabbed in the torso. At 5:45 p.m. she was confirmed to have died from her injuries at Beth Israel Hospital, where both women were taken for treatment.

title: American to its Core
description: I love to think of this play as super-American, and that American is, as Jeff put it, a big stew of meat and potatoes confrontations, and a brainy one at that. But August is not brainy to the degree of preachiness or wrought with heavy literary earnestness. It is not at all condescending, and  though I know America is so often perceived as haughty and arrogant  it is this America, this mix of high and low, as Frank points out, and this humor thats loaded with so much humanity, that I like to think of as ours. That the play is breaking rules that I havent even considered, as Marsha so fascinatingly explained, is all the more reason to call it American to its core.

description: I had lunch last week with Olivier Krug, the managing director of Krug Champagne or Champagne Krug, as they like to say it. It was an opportunity for me to taste Krugs new single-vineyard Champagne, the 1995 Clos dAmbonnay.

title: Clintons Blistering Obama Attack
description: WACO, Tex.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just delivered a blistering indictment of Senator Barack Obamas qualifications to serve as commander in chief, saying he had been missing in action at several important moments.

title: Beer Soup for the Overcaffeinated Soul
description: A certain national coffee chains well-publicized shutdown earlier this week got me thinking, in a jittery way, about the origins of our collective craving for caffeine.

title: A French Rendez-Vous
description: Images from the films playing in the 2008 Rendez-Vous With French Cinema.

title: Up Close With North Koreas Nuclear Reactor
description: Few Americans have ever visited North Korea and many fewer still have been to Yongbyon, the isolated countrys nuclear complex.

title: Sears Tries an Ad Makeover
description: Sears aims to ramp up its moribund marketing efforts before it loses more sales.

title: A Spitzer Tale Is Not Oll Korrect
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer told a story Thursday morning about the role of President Martin Van Buren  one of his predecessors as governors of New York  in the origins of the phrase O.K. But in venturing into the world of etymology, Mr. Spitzer offered an account that is a matter of some dispute.

title: Naders Running Mate Was Not Such a Fan in 04
description: Back in June 2004, Matt Gonzalez, the young president of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, spoke candidly to a group of the nations top college journalists as part of a prestigious writing competition.

title: Settling Very Old Scores in South Korea
description: To what extent should people be made to pay today for what their parents or grandparents did more than 60 years ago?

title: Remembering That Theres a War Going On
description: Whether its due to election year politics, conviction, or a combination of the two, were encouraged to see Senate Democrats planning an energetic re-examination of Americas Iraq policy over the next couple of months.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 29
description: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the 15th anniversary of the first World Trade Center bombing, a new swimming pool in Flushing and a mural by Tattfoo Tan in Dumbo.

title: Graffiti in Berlin
description: Graffiti artists show off what may be the world's most colorful city.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Speak, Tootsie
description: Tootsie came out in 1982, when most Americans assumed that if you didnt catch a movie while it was playing in theaters, you might never see it. Moviegoers were largely ignoring the climactic developments in home-entertainment technology  including the so-called format war between Betamax and VHS  that would, in the coming decades, transform not just movie watching but also home design and romantic relationships. The best format for audiovisual data storage was still considered to be the human memory.

title: CNBC Video: Bayh on Sovereign Wealth Funds
description: Sovereign wealth funds have gained a harsh spotlight from Washington over the past year, as one American firm after another has taken billions of dollars from these overseas investors. Politicians in Congress have bemoaned the coming of another selling of America to foreigners, this time wealthy funds run by governments in the Middle East and eastern Asia.

title: Graffiti in Berlin
description: Graffiti artists show off what may be the world's most colorful city.

title: Kenya's Tourism Industry in Shambles
description: Months of violence have taken their toll on Kenya's tourism industry. Jeffrey Gettleman reports from the Masai Mara game reserve.

title: An Italian Designers Sleek Interpretation of Green
description: The Geneva auto show is right around the corner (press days start on Monday). Over the past couple of weeks, Italdesign Giugiaro, the Italian design firm founded by Giorgetto Giugiaro (of DeLorean fame) has been leaking sneak peeks of its latest show car. On Friday, Italdesign released final images ahead of its press conference at the show next week.

title: Getting to Know Them
description: If they turn out to be their partys nominees, both Barack Obama and John McCain need to educate voters about themselves in some pretty basic, and challenging, ways. The Democratic candidate has to give voters a better sense of what he stands for, and the Republican candidate has to assure members of his own party that he is conservative enough.

title: UrbanEye: 'Passing Strange'
description: The new musical (or perhaps opera, or perhaps rock show) 'Passing Strange' opens at the Belasco Theater on Broadway.  Melena Ryzik reports.
